headline: 2 Names Familiar in Malibu Battle Over Anti-Development Measure
abstract: The director Rob Reiner is pushing an initiative that requires any big commercial proposals be approved by voters, pitting him against the Los Angeles police commissioner.
lead_paragraph: MALIBU, Calif. — Steve Soboroff is a police commissioner in Los Angeles, a former candidate for mayor and a developer whose latest venture is a supermarket complex on an open field off the Pacific Coast Highway here. Rob Reiner is an actor and a director who has a history of political advocacy in California going back 20 years.

headline: Tim Cook’s Coming Out: Reporter’s Notebook
abstract: James B. Stewart provides insight into his column about the Apple chief executive’s announcement that he is proud to be gay.
lead_paragraph: James B. Stewart provides insight into “The Coming Out of Apple’s Tim Cook: ‘This Will Resonate’,” his column in Friday’s New York Times. Mr. Stewart’s piece explored the impact Mr. Cook’s announcement is likely to have.

headline: Five Football Players Charged in a Beating in Pennsylvania
abstract: California University of Pennsylvania canceled and forfeited its next game after five members of its football team were charged in an assault case.
lead_paragraph: Five football players from California University of Pennsylvania, who reportedly chanted “Football strong” as they left after brutally beating a 30-year-old man outside a popular off-campus restaurant, were arrested Thursday.

headline: Opposing Gun Measures in Washington State Draw Cash and Sow Confusion
abstract: One proposal would impose background checks that go beyond federal law, while the other would expressly forbid an expansion.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — The nation’s only major gun-control ballot initiative this year, here in Washington State, is drawing big money and star-power names like Bill Gates and former Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York as backers. But the defining aspect is confusion, many residents say, because there are in fact two gun measures on the ballot, side by side, and they are diametrically opposed.

headline: Friday Night Music: Amason
abstract: From Sweden, with jet lag.
lead_paragraph: Actually Saturday morning music where I am, but anyway. I don’t have anything Japanese themed ready to go, so here’s what I tried to post last week only to have the system eat it. Amason is a Swedish group, record not yet out, who did a live performance on Seattle’s KEXP — but they actually did the performance at the Cutting Room in NYC, and the nice people at KEXP invited me to sit in the control room and watch:

headline: Bill Simmons Discusses Suspension From ESPN, Until He Doesn’t
abstract: Simmons was suspended for three weeks after calling N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell a “liar” concerning when he became aware of the Ray Rice video.
lead_paragraph: When Bill Simmons was suspended by ESPN in September for three weeks, it was for saying on his popular podcast that N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell was a “liar” for his remarks about when he saw the elevator video of Ray Rice punching his fiancée. He also effectively challenged ESPN to punish him for the comments.

headline: Democrats Count on Edge With Women to Limit Election Losses
abstract: Getting more women to the polls was bound to be good for Democrats, operatives believed. But some are now questioning whether pulling focus away from such issues as jobs and the economy was a good idea.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Democrats are nervously counting on an enduring edge among female voters in most states to prevent a Republican rout in Tuesday’s elections. Yet so great is the uncertainty that even before the returns are in, some are second-guessing the party’s strategy of focusing more on issues like abortion and birth control than on jobs and the economy.

headline: Roderick M. Hills, Counsel to Gerald Ford and S.E.C. Chairman, Dies at 83
abstract: Mr. Hills was a deputy counsel to President Gerald R. Ford and former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission.
lead_paragraph: Roderick M. Hills, who marshaled political acumen and legal agility to become an influential counsel to President Gerald R. Ford and was later appointed chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, died on Wednesday in Baltimore. He was 83 and lived in Washington.

headline: Underwriting the Next Housing Crisis
abstract: Regulators are wrong to water down tough mortgage standards.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — SEVEN years after the housing bubble burst, federal regulators backed away this month from the tougher mortgage-underwriting standards that the Dodd-Frank Act of 2010 had directed them to develop. New standards were supposed to raise the quality of the “prime” mortgages that get packaged and sold to investors; instead, they will have the opposite effect.

headline: At First Look Media, Personalities Prove Tough to Manage
abstract: After the departure of the journalist Matt Taibbi, people inside the company described a power struggle between journalists and management at the digital start-up.
lead_paragraph: When First Look Media, the journalism enterprise backed by the billionaire founder of eBay, Pierre M. Omidyar, started about a year ago, its mission was clear.

headline: Fluid, Plucky and Injury-Free, a Gelding Faces a New Test
abstract: The undefeated Shared Belief is a 9-5 favorite in Saturday’s Breeders’ Cup Classic, and it could be a defining race for the three-year-old gelding.
lead_paragraph: ARCADIA, Calif. — Jerry Hollendorfer began learning about thoroughbreds when he worked as a groom at Bay Meadows Racetrack in San Mateo, Calif., in the late 1960s. He cleaned stalls and began to understand the qualities of good horses as he tended to their needs.

headline: David Armstrong, Photographer of Subcultures, Dies at 60
abstract: Mr. Armstrong photographed the often overlapping worlds of gay men, drug addicts, transvestites, fashion models and creative artists.
lead_paragraph: David Armstrong, a photographer who gained prominence exploring the often overlapping worlds of gay men, drug addicts, transvestites, fashion models and artists, died on Sunday in Los Angeles. He was 60.

headline: How to Mend the Conservation Divide
abstract: As the planet changes, saving nature is not so simple anymore.
lead_paragraph: A SCHISM has recently divided those who love nature.

headline: Transcript of New York Times Interview With President Ma Ying-jeou of Taiwan
abstract: An official transcript from the office of President Ma Ying-jeou of Taiwan of an interview with The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Following is a transcript, provided by the Taiwanese government, of an interview with President Ma Ying-jeou conducted by The New York Times in Taipei on Friday. Mr. Ma mainly spoke in Chinese, but briefly answered a question in English.

headline: Home and Campaigning Lure Bill Clinton to Arkansas
abstract: The former president, campaigning for fellow Democrats, is returning to Arkansas this weekend for the sixth time since April.
lead_paragraph: During a recent visit to Arkansas, former President Bill Clinton took issue with a news story that implied he has been returning to his home state lately only because of the midterm elections.

headline: When to Shut Down Failing Schools
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio needs to flesh out his vague policies on how and when the city should intervene.
lead_paragraph: During his mayoral campaign, Bill de Blasio did not give high priority to the crucial issue of how and when the city should intervene to abolish or remake failing schools.

headline: On Visit, Obama to Face a Backsliding Myanmar
abstract: President Obama has pressed the Burmese leader on the pace of constitutional reforms and on the treatment of religious minorities.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Obama made his historic visit to Myanmar two years ago, he answered critics who charged that he was prematurely rewarding the country’s military-dominated rulers by saying, “If we waited to engage until they achieved a perfect democracy, my suspicion is we’d be waiting an awful long time.”

headline: Cuomo, Backed by Working Families Party, May Chip Away at Its Clout at the Polls
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo wants to win as many votes as possible in the election on Tuesday, but some liberals suspect he also wants to weaken a political party.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo wants to win as many votes as possible in the election on Tuesday. Some liberals suspect he has a second goal: to weaken the Working Families Party.

headline: Street-Level Views of the Protests in Burkina Faso
abstract: Video posted on YouTube offered vivid glimpses of the demonstrators who forced Burkina Faso’s longtime president, Blaise Compaoré, from office.
lead_paragraph: As my colleagues Hervé Taoko and Alan Cowell report, protesters in Burkina Faso forced President Blaise Compaoré from office on Friday, one day after they ransacked Parliament to prevent a vote that could have allowed him to extend his rule.

headline: Better Staffing Seen as Crucial to Ebola Treatment in Africa
abstract: Doctors say that better systems for treating fluid loss, routine in the United States, could also help patients in West Africa.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Rick Sacra, a missionary who contracted Ebola in Liberia this August, was first treated there. Each nurse on the ward cared for 15 or 20 patients, and none could work for more than an hour at a time because the protective gear was so suffocatingly hot. They never drew his blood for lab tests. There was no lab.

headline: Deceptions of the F.B.I.
abstract: Tactics used in two cases risk opening the door to constitutional abuses on a wide scale if they are not halted.
lead_paragraph: If your Internet service goes down and you call a technician, can you be certain that the person who arrives at your door is actually there to restore service? What if he is a law enforcement agent in disguise who has disabled the service so he can enter your home to look around for evidence of a crime?

headline: The People’s Choice on Gun Safety
abstract: Approval of a Washington State initiative requiring deeper background checks would be significant evidence of large-scale popular desire for tougher controls.
lead_paragraph: When Congress displayed its timidity about gun safety legislation last year after the school massacre in Connecticut, it became clear that only direct political action from voters could force the tough new controls that most Americans wanted.

headline: The 41st Annual Halloween Parade in Greenwich Village
abstract: The parade, along Avenue of the Americas from Spring Street to 16th Street, brought out ghouls, zombies and Daft Punk.
lead_paragraph: The parade, along Avenue of the Americas from Spring Street to 16th Street, brought out ghouls, zombies and Daft Punk.

headline: With Political Rift Still Deep, Russia-Ukraine Gas Deal Is Widely Seen as a Patch
abstract: The agreement was reached after both sides accepted the financial realities, in the face of an approaching winter.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — A deal struck on Thursday to restart Russian natural gas supplies to Ukraine will keep homes heated this winter, but it does not fully settle a fierce, long-running fight over energy prices that is likely to resume early next year if not sooner, analysts said Friday.

headline: Spy Allegations in a Presidential Race Conjure Romania’s Authoritarian Past
abstract: A spying allegation tapped into a rich vein of Romanian political culture clogged with accusations and counter-accusations of undercover skulduggery.
lead_paragraph: BUCHAREST, Romania — The front-runner in a presidential election here on Sunday disappointed his 10-year-old son recently by informing him that, contrary to feverish talk on the campaign trail, he was not a Romanian James Bond.

headline: Subdued Chris Christie Still Finds Center Stage
abstract: As Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey conducts a 19-state campaign swing for Republican candidates, he is still the focus of attention.
lead_paragraph: SCHOFIELD, Wisc. — Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey on Friday played a rare second fiddle at a campaign rally here for Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, dialing back his intensity after a week in which he dominated headlines for his handling of Ebola procedures and a heckler back home.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Oct. 31, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Alarmed by Ebola, Public Isn’t Calmed by ‘Experts Say’
abstract: Shifting guidelines on how to handle Ebola, combined with a mistrust of elites, have fed the public’s mistrust of assurances by government officials and scientists.
lead_paragraph: When public health leaders and government officials make the case against isolating more people returning from the Ebola hot zones in West Africa, or against imposing more travel restrictions from that region, time and again they cite science and experts. It isn’t working very well.

headline: Inspiration Outside the Bun
abstract: At 14 & Hudson in Piermont, burgers may rule, but other dishes showcase the chef’s talents.
lead_paragraph: I couldn’t remember the last time I’d voluntarily gone out for brunch, but after two mixed experiences at 14 & Hudson in Piermont, I decided to cross the Tappan Zee Bridge one last time to see the place in the daylight, and take a chance on the French toast. A fall tableau of gourds and chrysanthemums met us at the door, and the hostess smiled broadly as we stepped inside.

headline: The Guantánamo Tapes
abstract: Still asking: Does force-feeding detainees amount to torture?
lead_paragraph: Jihad Ahmed Mujstafa Diyab is a Syrian man who has been a detainee at the prison in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, since 2002. In 2009, the Guantánamo Review Task Force ruled that he was not a threat to national security and could be released. Yet here we are five years later, and Diyab is still imprisoned at Guantánamo, having never been tried, or even accused of a crime, and with no idea when — or if — he’ll ever get out. Last year, to protest their continued confinement, he and many other detainees began a hunger strike. Most of the detainees have since given up their hunger strikes. Diyab, however, has never completely stopped his.

headline: G.O.P. Ads Chase Voters at Home and on the Go
abstract: After lagging behind Democrats technologically in previous campaigns, the G.O.P. has begun using sophisticated techniques to target voters.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Commuters on the sea-hugging Montauk line of the Long Island Rail Road had a shared experience while browsing the Internet on their smartphones recently: A half-screen ad popped up attacking Representative Timothy H. Bishop as “one of Congress’s most corrupt” members.

headline: Italian Food That Won’t Drag You Down
abstract: The owners of Rustica Ristorante insist on making each dish to order, offering light cuisine that doesn’t sacrifice flavor.
lead_paragraph: In these carbophobic times, when every third person seems to have self-diagnosed a gluten intolerance or embraced a “paleo” diet, it can be easy to forget the simple, uncomplicated love affair many of us once had with Italian food. These days, a rendezvous with a hunk of lasagna or dish of pappardelle can feel more like an illicit tryst — delicious, but fraught with guilt, and often concluding with a resolution to avoid further temptation.

headline: In Nigeria, Fragile Hopes of Boko Haram Freeing Schoolgirls Are Dashed
abstract: After the Nigeria Army reported reaching a cease-fire with the militant Islamist group Boko Haram two weeks ago, its leader Friday denied any truce had been reached.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — The news from Nigeria sounded almost too good to be true — and so it appears to have been.

headline: U.N. Says Iran Is Silent on Efforts for a Bomb
abstract: Remarks by the head of the International Atomic Energy Agency come as Secretary of State John Kerry prepares for further negotiations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At a moment when American negotiators say they see some signs of movement on the part of Iran toward a broad nuclear deal with the United States, the head of the United Nations nuclear inspection organization declared Friday that Iran had stopped answering the agency’s questions about suspected past efforts to design the components of a bomb.

headline: A Kennedy’s Campaign Is Sharply Questioned on Finances
abstract: Ted Kennedy Jr.'s Republican opponent in a Connecticut Senate district, Bruce Wilson Jr., has complained about $207,000 spent on the race by the state’s Democratic Party.
lead_paragraph: BRANFORD, Conn. — Getting a scion of the Kennedy family elected to an open seat in the State Senate in this heavily Democratic state must have seemed as though it would be a cinch.

headline: Stopping Street Harassment
abstract: Should current laws dealing with harassment be strengthened to include catcalling, or will that go too far in controlling speech and behavior?

headline: Former U.S. Envoy to Moscow Says Russians Are Still Spying on Him
abstract: Michael McFaul said that Russian agents were tapping his telephone as well as that of his wife.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — During two years as ambassador to Russia, Michael McFaul was constantly followed, harassed and demonized on state television. But though Mr. McFaul has left government service and returned home, the spying on him doesn’t seem to have stopped.

headline: Not at All Creaky
abstract: Math symbols. It had to be math symbols. Thanks a whole lot, Trip Payne.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — It was the mathematical symbols that got me. They got me good.

headline: Favored Untapable Rallies to Win Breeders’ Cup Distaff
abstract: The three-year-old Untapable completed an undefeated season against fillies and mares when she took the Breeders’ Cup Distaff by a length and a quarter at Santa Anita Park.
lead_paragraph: ARCADIA, Calif. — As long as the 3-year-old filly Untapable stays away from the boys, she appears to be unstoppable.

headline: Election Day Pop Quiz
abstract: Are you ready for the midterms? It’s time to test your political smarts.
lead_paragraph: Are you ready for the midterms? It’s time to test your political smarts.

headline: Mets’ Juan Lagares Soars, Attaining New Heights
abstract: Lagares, who was named the best center fielder in baseball by winning the annual Fielding Bible award, is emerging as a key figure on the Mets as they try to become a contender again.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes Juan Lagares plays so shallow in center field for the Mets that he looks as if he is hoping to bait the batter into swinging too hard in an effort to hit the ball over his head. But as opponents have learned over the past two seasons, Lagares has the speed and instincts to get to almost any ball hit in the air. If you do hit the ball deep, he will probably catch up to it. And if you try to tag up and advance a base after he runs the ball down, he might just throw you out.

headline: Iran Hints at Possible Release of Washington Post Correspondent Soon
abstract: Iran’s emissary to a United Nations human rights meeting said he hoped the case against Jason Rezaian would soon be dropped.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — A senior Iranian emissary hinted on Friday that Iranian authorities might be prepared to free a Washington Post correspondent who has been inexplicably imprisoned and kept virtually incommunicado since July 22.

headline: Wheelies: The ‘Technology and Stuff’ Edition
abstract: Chevrolet incorporates a World Series gaffe into its new ad campaign; Ram’s chief says technology is to blame for reliability problems.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Schumer Hits the Trail for a Goal in Albany: A Democratic New York Senate
abstract: Over the last few weeks, Senator Charles E. Schumer has endorsed in person five Democrats in races from the Hudson Valley to Buffalo.
lead_paragraph: With control of the New York Senate hanging in the balance, one of the state’s most prominent Democrats was once again on the campaign trail on Friday, appearing with an upstate candidate and trying to tip the upper chamber into friendly hands.

headline: What Is on the Line in the Midterm Elections
abstract: Republicans are seeking to gain control of the Senate, but some of the most compelling races have been for governor.
lead_paragraph: Things to look for in Tuesday’s midterm elections:

headline: Herb Schapiro, Playwright Behind ‘The Me Nobody Knows,’ Dies at 85
abstract: Inspired by essays by urban children, Mr. Schapiro had the idea for what became a “dark and lovely” Broadway musical.
lead_paragraph: Herb Schapiro, a writer and teacher whose idea to create a stage play from the collected essays of poor city kids resulted in a hit musical, “The Me Nobody Knows,” died on Oct. 17 at his home in Brooklyn. He was 85.

headline: Saturday’s College Football Games to Watch
abstract: Auburn will play Mississippi in what looks like an elimination game in the College Football Playoff.
lead_paragraph: 4 AUBURN at 7 MISSISSIPPI

headline: Mets Deny Bias in Ticket Official’s Firing
abstract: The Mets and their chief operating officer, in court papers filed Friday, denied accusations made in a lawsuit by a former senior ticket-sales executive who said that she had been discriminated against for being pregnant out of wedlock.
lead_paragraph: The Mets and their chief operating officer, Jeff Wilpon, in court papers filed Friday, denied all the accusations made in a lawsuit by a former senior ticket-sales executive who said that she had been discriminated against for being pregnant out of wedlock.

headline: Ukrainians in the Battered East Scramble in Darkness as Winter Nears
abstract: They are picking up the war-torn pieces in the rebel-held region, hoping someone — whether from Kiev or Moscow — can get essential services running again.
lead_paragraph: NOVOSVITLIVKA, Ukraine — On one of the last warm days of autumn, Father Vladimir shed his priest’s robes and scaled a rickety wooden ladder to replace the shattered windows on the once-golden cupola of his village church.

headline: Brook Lopez Stays on Sideline as the Nets Say Little
abstract: The Nets’ Brook Lopez has not played full-contact basketball since he sprained his right foot in China on Oct. 15.
lead_paragraph: Fans and reporters hoping to understand the extent of an injury to an N.B.A. player are often reduced to guesswork.

headline: With Gadgetry, New York Marathon May Be Watched Like No Other
abstract: New York City Marathon officials are aiming to make the event the most advanced in the world, as far as gee-whiz gadgetry goes.
lead_paragraph: This year’s New York City Marathon on Sunday could be the largest road race ever staged, with about 50,000 runners registered.

headline: The Grove: Ole Miss’s Living Room
abstract: The Grove at the University of Mississippi is a place of refuge. But on football game days the 10-acre space turns into one of the most raucous and distinctive tailgating parties in the country.
lead_paragraph: The Grove at the University of Mississippi is a place of refuge. But on football game days the 10-acre space turns into one of the most raucous and distinctive tailgating parties in the country.

headline: Tailgating Goes Above and Beyond at the University of Mississippi
abstract: A tour of the Grove in Oxford, Miss., which comes alive each football weekend with one of the most elaborate pregame gatherings in the country.
lead_paragraph: OXFORD, Miss. — Perhaps there isn’t a word for the ritualized pregame revelry on the University of Mississippi campus. “Tailgating” certainly does not do it justice. It might be a gathering of football fans before a game, but it hardly resembles those celebrated scenes in Green Bay and Kansas City, which are modest by comparison.

headline: Girl, 14, Dies of Wounds in Washington School Shooting
abstract: Shaylee Chuckulnaskit, who was shot in the head last week when a classmate fired on five classmates in Marysville, Wash., died at a hospital in Everett.
lead_paragraph: A 14-year-old girl who was shot in the head last week when a classmate opened fired in a high school cafeteria in Washington State has died, hospital officials said Friday.

headline: What’s On TV Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) WINTER’S TALE (2014) The high-spirited consumptive daughter (Jessica Brown Findlay) of an early-20th-century mogul (William Hurt, above) is confronted by a thief (Colin Farrell) who breaks into her mansion to steal the silver — and absconds with her heart, aided by a flying white horse — in Akiva Goldsman’s adaptation of Mark Helprin’s 1983 best seller. Russell Crowe, rejoining Mr. Goldsman, the writer for “A Beautiful Mind,” is the gangster intent on putting their love asunder. “Mr. Goldsman, making his directing debut, suppresses the morbid and even the merely sad implications of the story in favor of wide-eyed, mystical wonder,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. But “a thin line separates the magical from the preposterous, and by insisting so strenuously on its own magic, ‘Winter’s Tale’ pitches helplessly into earnest ridiculousness.”

headline: 3 Girls Killed in Hit-and-Run While Trick-or-Treating in Santa Ana
abstract: The girls, two of whom were twin sisters, were in a marked crosswalk when they were struck by a sport utility vehicle Friday evening, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: Three 13-year-old girls dressed in Halloween costumes and carrying bags of candy were killed by a hit-and-run driver while trick-or-treating in Santa Ana, Calif., on Friday evening, the authorities said.

headline: Corrections: November 1, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, November 1, 2014.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, November 1, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “We never lose a party here at Ole Miss.”

headline: Timeline: Manny Being Manny
abstract: The Dodgers’ Manny Ramirez has been one of the most feared hitters and controversial personalities in baseball.
lead_paragraph: The Dodgers’ Manny Ramirez has been one of the most feared hitters and controversial personalities in baseball.

headline: Grading Your School
abstract: The performance history for more than 3,500 schools and 700 districts since 1999.
lead_paragraph: The performance history for more than 3,500 schools and 700 districts since 1999.

headline: For Everything There Is a Season
abstract: November is a busy month, but leave some time for solving our crossword puzzles.
lead_paragraph: TIMES INSIDER — November is a busy month. Nature prepares for its winter rest, going to sleep after one last blaze of glory. Elections are held, so we can start the new year with a fresh slate of public officials. It feels like we cook all month long for our Thanksgiving feasts. There’s the unbelievable amount of gift shopping to be done. And before you know it, the month is over and we are lighting candles and untangling strings of light bulbs in preparation for the winter holidays.

headline: Deborah Harmon, on Playing to Your Team’s Strengths
abstract: The chief executive of Artemis Real Estate Partners says that by playing to people’s strengths, “you create a team of complementary skill sets.”
lead_paragraph: This interview with  Deborah Harmon, chief executive of Artemis Real Estate Partners, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Their Steps Make Her Dance
abstract: “Knowing that they’re walking because of something I made for them hits me in the heart,” says Julianne Gupta, 28, who works at a prosthetics company.

headline: In the Office of the Hard Rock C.E.O., Riffs on a Theme
abstract: The office of Hamish Dodds, chief executive of Hard Rock International, reflects the restaurant chain’s eclectic, rock ‘n’ roll aesthetic.
lead_paragraph: The office of Hamish Dodds, chief executive of Hard Rock International, reflects the restaurant chain’s eclectic, rock ‘n’ roll aesthetic.

headline: Cracks in the Stress Tests of European Banks
abstract: All but a relative few European banks passed a recent exam regarding their soundness. But some findings in the European Central Bank’s report point to shortcomings.
lead_paragraph: The sigh of relief was almost audible last week when the European Central Bank published its long-awaited safety and soundness report on 130 banks in 19 countries in the region. Many investors seemed comforted that just 13 banks had failed the comprehensive exam.

headline: Paying for Smoke Detectors
abstract: Questions about who pays for smoke detectors; buying a rental building; and responsibility for roof repairs.
lead_paragraph: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: What Goes Up Must at Least Slow Down
abstract: After a five-year surge for stocks, a market forecaster says it’s time for investors to temper expectations.
lead_paragraph: Good news sometimes causes its own problems. That is, arguably, what’s happened with the American stock market.

headline: That Devil on Your Shoulder Likes to Sleep In
abstract: Research shows that people are more likely to lie or cheat in the afternoon and evening, when their brains are worn out.
lead_paragraph: It is often asked why good people do bad things. Perhaps the question should be when.

headline: Polls Show Tight Senate Races in Iowa and North Carolina
abstract: Two new polls show tight Senate races in Iowa and North Carolina just days before the midterm election.
lead_paragraph: Many polling outfits will be releasing their final surveys over the next few days, polls on which bragging rights for “most accurate” for the next election cycle could rely.

headline: Macy’s Opens on 34th Street
abstract: The original article on Macy’s 34 Street location in the New York Times.
lead_paragraph: The original article on Macy’s 34 Street location in the New York Times.

headline: Variety: An Acrostic Discovery
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon offer us a delightfully educational acrostic puzzle and, for extra credit, a sonnet.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — I don’t know about you, but I solved this more inside the grid than in the clues.

headline: The Vital Role of the Occasional Voter
abstract: People who sit out some elections, but jump in to vote at crucial times, may help keep a democracy on track, behavioral research suggests.
lead_paragraph: Low voter turnout is a bad thing. Let’s get that out of the way immediately.

headline: With Turbulent Season Looming for Lakers, Kobe Bryant Demonstrates an Early Calm
abstract: Bryant, once notorious for his hair-trigger impatience, has seemed to display more collegiality and tactful communication this season with teammates despite the Lakers’ dim prospects.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It was an unusual scene. Here was Kobe Bryant, casually comfortable in his hooded sweatshirt, calmly reflective late Friday after the Los Angeles Lakers lost their third consecutive game to start the season.

headline: Military Backs an Interim President, but Burkina Faso Remains Unsettled
abstract: The military threw its weight behind one of two high-ranking military officers who had been competing to take over the presidency after President Blaise Compaoré quit.
lead_paragraph: OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso — A day after President Blaise Compaoré fled the country, ending 27 years in power in the face of revolt on the streets, military commanders on Saturday appeared to have resolved an internal power struggle by endorsing a colonel from the presidential guard to oversee a transition to elections.

headline: Which President Cut the Most Nukes?
abstract: Hint: It’s not the one who just won the Nobel Peace Prize.
lead_paragraph: DOVES who once cheered President Obama for his antinuclear crusades and later fell silent as he backpedaled are now lining up to denounce him. A recent skewering by the Federation of American Scientists details how Mr. Obama, despite calling repeatedly for “a world without nuclear weapons,” has reduced the size of the nation’s atomic stockpile far less than did any of his three immediate predecessors, including both Presidents Bush.

headline: Putin’s Friend Profits in Purge of Schoolbooks
abstract: When the number of approved textbooks for Russia’s 14 million schoolchildren was slashed by more than half, one publisher with close ties to President Vladimir V. Putin profited handsomely.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The purge began in late winter. One by one, hundreds of textbooks that Russian schoolchildren had relied upon for years were deemed unsuitable for use in the country’s 43,000 schools. The reasons varied, but they shared a certain bureaucratic obstinacy.

headline: Coach Trains 900 Runners, Never Meeting Many of Them
abstract: As an online coach for New York Road Runners, which organizes the New York City Marathon, John Honerkamp makes marathoners out of strangers.
lead_paragraph: Of the 900 marathoners John Honerkamp coaches, most skip workouts for the usual reasons: a sore knee, a looming work deadline, a toddler who screams through the night. Others are more particular, like the soldier in Afghanistan who could not fit in a run until he had helped move his base. Afterward he measured an 800-meter loop in the sand and made up the missed miles.

headline: New York Ebola Patient’s Condition Improves, Officials Say
abstract: Dr. Craig Spencer’s condition has been upgraded to stable at Bellevue Hospital Center, where he remains in isolation, health officials said.
lead_paragraph: Doctors have upgraded the condition of New York City’s first Ebola patient, health officials said on Saturday.

headline: Change of Scenery in N.H.L.: Crackdown on Theatrical Falls
abstract: The N.H.L. has directed referees to be stricter about violations of Rule 64, which penalizes blatant diving or embellishment after an infraction.
lead_paragraph: Anaheim Ducks defenseman Sami Vatanen felt a stick blade jab him in the face during a game last week against the San Jose Sharks. Vatanen fell and lifted his hand to his mouth, either to draw attention to the foul or simply as a reaction to being stabbed by a stick.

headline: Pouring One for the Muse
abstract: Pairing alcohol and creativity, painting studios offer an alternative to another dinner and a movie with group classes for students to create works of their own.
lead_paragraph: Believe it or not, people are still getting together in the flesh, and blood, to express themselves and socialize, leaving Facebook and Instagram behind, at least temporarily. Take painting parties, combined art classes and cocktail hours, which are becoming more prevalent on Long Island. Pamela Paredes just opened a Wine and Design franchise in Syosset in August and said business was already booming. “Last weekend was absolutely fabulous,” she said of the team-building event she had organized at Fox Hollow in Woodbury.

headline: Wistful but Having Fun, Obama Gives Last Push
abstract: The energy is different for Mr. Obama now than it has been in campaigns past, as he travels the country on a final get-out-the-vote push for the midterm elections.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The giant white letters spelling V-O-T-E were already hoisted and the audience was on its feet in the gold-and-green-painted gymnasium as Gary Peters, the Democratic candidate for Senate, roused the room for President Obama.

headline: Cricket Contract Dispute in India Forces Schedule Change
abstract: India will play Sri Lanka in a one-day international in Cuttack in eastern India on Sunday, a day when it should have been engaged in a five-day test match against the West Indies.
lead_paragraph: India’s millions of television-watching cricket fans will get their fix of top-class action this weekend, just not the match that was originally scheduled.

headline: Mother Who Provides Round-the-Clock Care Finds Solace in Her Home
abstract: Geraldine Kentish supports two children with disabilities, but had little money left over after paying rent on their Harlem apartment.
lead_paragraph: Whenever Geraldine Kentish and her daughter Ena return home — from whatever errand or doctor appointment lured them out — Ms. Kentish gently takes away Ena’s walker so that she can climb the stairs to their second-floor apartment on her own.

headline: Wild Messengers
abstract: Did my mother send those eagles to comfort me?
lead_paragraph: About a decade ago, a brain tumor came to steal my mother away. It was diagnosed after she’d exhibited a series of strange behaviors (stranger than usual, I should say, as she was a quirky lady to begin with), and she very quickly went to a dark, quiet place that none of us could reach. Still, for a number of weeks, as she curled into an ever tightening ball under a growing mound of blankets, she continued caressing her three cats as they snuggled against her. When her hands finally went still, a week or so before her death, I knew we were nearing the end.

headline: The New War’s Rising Cost
abstract: Congress has a duty to to take a hard look at goals and expenses of the military campaign in Iraq and Syria.
lead_paragraph: The Pentagon disclosed last week that America’s ever-shifting new war in the Middle East has cost taxpayers more than half a billion dollars since it began in August. Yet Congress has not bothered to hold a vote to authorize the Obama administration’s decision to get into another war.

headline: A Catholic Debate
abstract: Readers discuss a column by Ross Douthat about the recent synod on the family.
lead_paragraph: Readers discuss a column by Ross Douthat about the recent synod on the family.

headline: How Obama Lost America
abstract: There are four explanations for the Democrats’ biggest problem heading into the midterms.
lead_paragraph: THE 2014 midterms have featured many variables and one constant. Whether they’re running as incumbents or challengers, campaigning in blue or red or purple states, Democratic candidates have all been dragging an anchor: a president from their party whose approval ratings haven’t been north of 45 percent since last October.

headline: They Call Me Doctor Berry
abstract: As a black female engineer, I have to insist on using my title.
lead_paragraph: TERRE HAUTE, Ind. — I HAVE never been big on titles. Many people I interact with outside my job don’t even know that I am a professor, or that I have a doctoral degree. When I introduce myself in public, I’m Carlotta Berry.

headline: Debra Granik
abstract: The filmmaker on depending on motel bathtub coffee and apologizing for involuntary swearing.
lead_paragraph: Debra Granik is an independent filmmaker whose credits include “Down to the Bone,” “Winter’s Bone” and, most recently, the documentary “Stray Dog.”

headline: Why 2014 Isn’t as Good as It Seems for the Republicans
abstract: The party is favored to win the Senate and expand its House majority. But there are few signs that it is making progress toward a national majority.
lead_paragraph: The Republicans are looking forward to having a good week. They are favored to win the Senate, and they could pick up enough House seats to finish with their largest margin since 1928.

headline: The ‘Kind of, Sort of’ Era
abstract: Our language reflects the uncertainties of modern life.
lead_paragraph: I’VE sort of noticed something about the way we speak, and I wonder if you’ve sort of noticed it, too. Let me kind of explain. It’s about sort of, and its twin, kind of, and how these adverbial downtoners, as the British grammarian Sir Randolph Quirk calls them, have totally, completely, 100 percent taken over casual speech.

headline: Flying Blind in Iraq and Syria
abstract: With no reporters inside ISIS territory to document the war, how do we know what’s happnening on the ground?
lead_paragraph: THE Islamic State, also known as ISIS and ISIL, has accompanied its brutal takeover of large swaths of Iraq and Syria with the kidnapping and beheading of journalists. Any Western journalists who would dare to venture into ISIS territory today would be risking their lives every second. So the United States is now involved in the first prolonged war in the modern Middle East that American reporters and photographers can’t cover firsthand on a daily basis, with the freedom to observe and write what they please and with the sustained presence to offer perspective on how the story is evolving. That is not good.

headline: The Missing Campus Climate Debate
abstract: Universities must consider divesting from fossil fuels.
lead_paragraph: CLIMATE CHANGE is our era’s defining challenge, but most of America’s universities are planning to sit this one out. Though students and faculty members at more than 400 colleges have called for administrators to divest from fossil-fuel energy companies, fewer than 20 have committed to doing so. Stanford recently divested from coal, but none of the other schools had endowments within the 150 largest in 2013.

headline: New Buildings for Older People
abstract: “Silver” design should ensure accessibility and safety.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — I HEARD about the new building for months before I saw it. Part of a leading medical center, its green architecture and design were getting a lot of attention, as was its integration of top-notch modern medicine with health and wellness spaces inspired by cultures from around the world. My father’s doctor had moved there, and driving to his appointment we looked forward to experiencing the cutting-edge new building firsthand.

headline: There Is No ‘Healthy’ Microbiome
abstract: The same microbes can be helpful allies or dangerous threats.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — IN the late 17th century, the Dutch naturalist Anton van Leeuwenhoek looked at his own dental plaque through a microscope and saw a world of tiny cells “very prettily a-moving.” He could not have predicted that a few centuries later, the trillions of microbes that share our lives — collectively known as the microbiome — would rank among the hottest areas of biology.

headline: The Terrible 32s
abstract: A guide for parenting the challenging youngish adult.
lead_paragraph: WHAT ARE THE TERRIBLE 32S?

headline: Teenagers Stand Up to Backpage
abstract: Some brave girls who say they were sold for sex on Backpage.com are fighting back in lawsuits that could have far-reaching implications for sex trafficking in America.
lead_paragraph: IF prostitution of children is illegal, why is it that we allow an estimated 100,000 underage girls and boys to be sold for sex in America each year — many on a single American website, Backpage.com?

headline: A Cup of G.I. Joe
abstract: Howard Schultz of Starbucks says America is good at sending people to war but bad at bringing them home. He has a plan to help.
lead_paragraph: WHEN I close my eyes, I can easily flash back to a time when it was cool to call people in uniform “pigs” and “baby killers.”

headline: American Partisanship, From Sports to Disease
abstract: This week was a good one for baseball spectators; some politicians burnished their images by embracing the spreading fear of Ebola.
lead_paragraph: This is the time of year when this expatriate most acutely misses the American homeland, where nature is staging one of the most spectacular color shows on earth and the greatest of sports follow in exhilarating succession.

headline: The Pitiful Whimper of 2014
abstract: Voters abhor the status quo. When will someone present them with anything truly different?
lead_paragraph: IMAGINE a house ablaze. Now picture a team of firefighters pulling up to it. They behold the flames shooting through its roof. They feel its heat on their faces. And they get in position to fight it.

headline: Tax Cuts on Trial in Governors’ Races
abstract: Many voters seem ready to demand a change from ruinous Republican policies.
lead_paragraph: There is only so long a governor can do great damage to a state before voters start to demand a change. In Kansas, Gov. Sam Brownback, a Republican who has driven down his state’s credit rating and cratered its budget with ill-advised tax cuts, is paying a huge price in popularity for his actions.

headline: The Knicks’ Way Starts to Change
abstract: The Knicks have only played two games, but the approach of Coach Derek Fisher indicates that he may not settle for the status quo.
lead_paragraph: Only hours removed from expressing even more uncertainty about his new role in a new offense under a new coach, J. R. Smith was in a good mood. It was late Thursday in the visitors’ locker room at Quicken Loans Arena, and Smith had played a major role in the Knicks’ unexpected victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers.

headline: What We’re Watching: Sunday Shows
abstract: With the midterm elections around the corner, lawmakers make their final arguments for their parties’ candidates on the Sunday shows.
lead_paragraph: Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky, is not running for re-election this fall, but he’s certainly kept busy  this fall stumping for candidates in North Carolina, Georgia and Iowa. On Sunday, Mr. Paul will continue to promote his party, which many forecasters say will retake Congress, on several network shows, including CNN’s “State of the Union,” CBS’s “Face the Nation” and NBC’s “Meet the Press.”

headline: Week 9 N.F.L. Matchups
abstract: This week’s games include a matchup between the Broncos and the Patriots, with the rivalry between Peyton Manning and Tom Brady taking center stage.
lead_paragraph: Broncos (6-1) at Patriots (6-2)

headline: In North Carolina, Campaigns for Senate Play to Dislikes in an Effort to Stoke Interest
abstract: Thom Tillis is partial to Exhibit A from his party’s national playbook this year: mentioning his Democratic opponent, Senator Kay Hagan, in the same breath as President Obama, and doing so as often as possible.
lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N.C. — Thom Tillis, North Carolina’s Republican candidate for the United States Senate, is partial to the first page from his party’s national playbook this year. It involves mentioning his Democratic opponent, Senator Kay Hagan, in the same breath as President Obama, and doing so as often as possible.

headline: Endurance Test of a Race, for Candidates and Voters in Iowa
abstract: Bruce Braley and Joni Ernst have visited all 99 of Iowa’s counties in their Senate race, and voters have been subjected to a litany of negative campaign advertisements.
lead_paragraph: NEWTON, Iowa — A small crowd of the faithful had gathered at the county Democratic headquarters here to listen to Representative Bruce Braley make his closing case, giving little hint of the blunder-pocked road he has traveled during his campaign for the United States Senate.

headline: Republicans Setting the Early Pace in Colorado With 104,000 More Ballots
abstract: Early voter returns tracking Colorado’s first major election run entirely through mail-in ballots showed that Republicans had turned in 104,000 more ballots than Democrats.
lead_paragraph: MANITOU SPRINGS, Colo. — It was warm and sunny and smelled of cinnamon-orange tea inside a roadside cafe here in the mountains, but as a dozen Democrats waited for Senator Mark Udall’s campaign bus to arrive for a last-minute pep rally, the air was laced with dread.

headline: To Rebuild, Jets Can Use Chiefs’ Blueprint
abstract: A new general manager, coach and quarterback helped Kansas City transform from a 2-14 team in 2012 to a squad that went 11-5 and secured a playoff spot in 2013.
lead_paragraph: Once there was a 1-7 team. It had the worst turnover margin in the N.F.L. and the worst quarterback situation, too. It gave up a lot of points, despite Pro Bowl talent on defense, and scored not nearly enough. Its fan base fumed and frothed, shamed by the on-field product and disenchanted with the leadership and direction.

headline: In France, Dam Is the Catalyst for a Flood of Young People’s Anger
abstract: What had been a local protest has turned into a national drama, spawning vigils and front-page news coverage, while prompting criticism of the government of President François Hollande.
lead_paragraph: LISLE-SUR-TARN, France — The protests began a year ago in this quiet corner of southwestern France, as a small and peaceful gathering of hippies, environmental activists and utopians of all types set up tents to oppose the construction of a nearby dam.

headline: In Torrent of Rapes in Britain, an Uncomfortable Focus on Race and Ethnicity
abstract: Widespread abuses involving so-called grooming gangs put an uncomfortable spotlight on issues of race, religion and ethnicity — and the slow response of law-enforcement authorities.
lead_paragraph: ROCHDALE, England — Shabir Ahmed, a delivery driver for two takeout places, did not have to go looking for young girls. Runaways and rebellious teenagers would show up at the restaurants, often hungry and cold. He slipped them free drinks and chicken tikka masala. “Call me Daddy,” he would say.

headline: Handling of Sexual Harassment Case Poses Larger Questions at Yale
abstract: Concerns grew about the climate for women at the Yale School of Medicine after a sexual misconduct committee’s ruling to remove the cardiology chief went unheeded.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN — A sexual harassment case that has been unfolding without public notice for nearly five years within the Yale School of Medicine has roiled the institution and led to new allegations that the university is insensitive to instances of harassment against women.

headline: Both Parties See Campaign Tilting to Republicans
abstract: Republicans entered the final weekend before the midterm elections clearly holding the better hand, but a sour electorate and a large number of undecided voters added a measure of suspense.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republicans entered the final weekend before the midterm elections clearly holding the better hand to control the Senate and poised to add to their House majority. But a decidedly sour electorate and a sizable number of undecided voters added a measure of suspense.

headline: Sunday’s Matchup: Jets (1-7) at Chiefs (4-3)
abstract: The Jets are on a pace for six takeaways, which would shatter the record for fewest in a 16-game season, set by the 2013 Texans, who had 11.
lead_paragraph: 1 p.m., CBS

headline: Electricity Returns to Bangladesh After Power Failure
abstract: The whole country lost power for an hour on Saturday after a transmission line in the grid failed.
lead_paragraph: DHAKA, Bangladesh — A power failure swept through Bangladesh on Saturday after a transmission line in the electrical grid failed, causing a nationwide blackout.

headline: Clashes on Syrian Border Split Lebanese Town
abstract: The village of Ras Baalbek, Lebanon, is determined to stay out of the Syrian conflict, even as it is pushed toward deeper reliance on one of the combatants, Hezbollah.
lead_paragraph: RAS BAALBEK, Lebanon — Waleed Fayyad coaxed his sport utility vehicle through a chilly rain, peering down dark streets in search of suspicious vehicles. Later that night, a few miles down the road, Lebanese soldiers and Hezbollah fighters would rush to thwart insurgents trying to descend the mountains from the Syrian border, but on Mr. Fayyad’s patrol through this remote Christian village, nothing moved.

headline: Scott Walker Leaves His Mark on Vikings’ New Stadium
abstract: Touring a steel plant in his state, Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin wrote “Go Packers” a steel beam that will be used in the rival Minnesota Vikings’ new football stadium.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, locked in a tight race for re-election, may have just scored a few points with voters by ratcheting up the rivalry between his state’s Green Bay Packers and their arch rivals, the Minnesota Vikings.

headline: Marriage Built on Miles Finds Hope in Marathon
abstract: Running a marathon is about putting in the work, then letting the force of your will and the power of your heart take over. Marriage isn’t much different.
lead_paragraph: John and I had been married for 16 years, and lately it felt as if we couldn’t get through a day without bickering. It didn’t matter if we were discussing the best way to get our 10-year-old to sleep in his own bed or our health insurance plan; the result was the same — another fight. Even a simple dinner was a minefield: He couldn’t call when he was running late, I couldn’t cook chicken that tasted edible, and we both wavered on whether our 12-year-old should have to finish his broccoli before starting his hours of homework. Was this what marriage was all about?

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers respond to recent articles in the Sports section of The Times.
lead_paragraph: Golf Gives Short Shrift to Women

headline: Regional Classics, Many Moods
abstract: True American Kitchen in Mineola can present a divided dining experience: Truly lovely or downright disappointing.
lead_paragraph: In August, pasta gave way to grits when the business at 348 East Jericho Turnpike in Mineola, known as a home for Italian restaurants like Lula Trattoria and Circa Ristorante Enoteca, reopened with a classic American menu. True American Kitchen offers popular dishes like New England lobster rolls, Georgia peach barbecue baby back ribs and Louisiana shrimp and grits.

headline: Escaping Civilization, but Not His Former Family
abstract: In ‘Annapurna,’ by Sharr White, a middle-aged American named Ulysses is frying sausages in his trailer and sounding like a cowboy, not a former English professor.
lead_paragraph: Ulysses is one major oddball. Not the hero of “The Odyssey,” in this case, or James Joyce’s novel, but the wreck of a middle-aged American man portrayed in Sharr White’s “Annapurna,” which is the strong and poignant opening production of Theaterworks Hartford’s 2014-15 season.

headline: Even Brutes Can Learn to Cry
abstract: Hafthor Julius Bjornsson, an Icelandic strongman best known for lifting cars or tugging trucks or throwing barrels, has parlayed his imposing size into a role on “Game of Thrones.”
lead_paragraph: REYKJAVIK, Iceland — The Mountain is crying and it looks like a thunderstorm, a shaking of colossal shoulders and a soaking of crocodile tears. Hafthor Julius Bjornsson, known to most as Thor and to anyone who watches “Game of Thrones” as the Mountain, is acting, or at least trying to show that he resembles a skilled thespian as much as he does a refrigerator.

headline: For Man in Ebola Virus Cleanup, a History of Fraud
abstract: Sal Pane, the chief safety officer of Bio-Recovery Corporation, which cleaned Dr. Craig Spencer’s home, was accused of mortgage fraud in 2009 by the attorney general at the time, Andrew M. Cuomo.
lead_paragraph: The chief safety officer of the hazardous-materials company that cleaned the apartment of New York City’s first Ebola patient was, in a past career as a mortgage negotiator, accused of fraud in 2009 by the attorney general at the time, Andrew M. Cuomo.

headline: Proud. Elegant. Feathered.
abstract: An exhibition of about 150 objects at the Hudson River Museum explores the multiple personalities of a gorgeous bird.
lead_paragraph: Eagles were made to soar, canaries to sing and peacocks, obviously, to dazzle the eye. But in “Strut: The Peacock and Beauty in Art,” the gorgeous creature with the magnificent plumage is dissected and found to have hidden depths and multiple personalities. Through some 150 objects created in the 19th, 20th and 21st centuries, this fascinating exhibition from the Hudson River Museum recounts the many ways artists, designers and the rest of us have made use of this astonishing bird.

headline: Pitchers, Hitters and a Panda
abstract: Monday is the deadline when teams will have to decide whether to offer their eligible free agents a $15.2 million qualifying offer that protects them if the player decides to sign elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, more than 100 players became free agents, and a few dozen more could be granted free agency depending on the status of their contract options. Though the 2015 season is five months away, Monday represents a huge deadline: Teams will have to decide whether they want to offer their eligible free agents a $15.2 million qualifying offer that will protect them from receiving no compensation if a player decides to sign elsewhere.

headline: Diageo Is Said to Be in Talks on Exchange of Brands With Jose Cuervo
abstract: Under the proposed terms, Diageo would acquire control of the Don Julio tequila brand and Cuervo would gain Bushmills brand of Irish whiskey.
lead_paragraph: Diageo and the family that manufactures Jose Cuervo tequila are in advanced talks to swap two of their best-known brands, a person briefed on the matter told DealBook on Saturday.

headline: BP Station
abstract: Fill up on this Brendan Emmett Quigley puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — You know what I like? I like a nice, relatively easy puzzle with a nice, relatively easy theme after a puzzle like yesterday’s Trip Payne tour de force. No math symbols. No tricks. No rebuses. Like today’s puzzle: a nice, well put-together letter-swap theme. And by Brendan Emmett Quigley, yet. That means lots of good pop culture. Just what the doctor ordered.

headline: A Few Election Answers That Will Define the State of Political Power in Texas
abstract: The questions behind the question of who will win on Tuesday will reveal plenty about where the state is headed.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN — Republicans appear poised to maintain their grip on every statewide office in Texas for a 16th straight year, yet Tuesday’s election results will yield information beyond winners and losers. Political observers will be looking closely at voter turnout and exit poll data, seeking insights into where Texas is politically, and where it may be headed. Here are the questions most drawing their attention:

headline: A Broad Consensus Emerges on Senate Races
abstract: In conversations Saturday with officials in both parties a consensus emerged about the Senate landscape.
lead_paragraph: Republicans were growing increasingly confident on Saturday that they would win the Iowa Senate race, picking up a Democratic-held seat that could ensure that they gain the majority.

headline: A Band That Couldn’t Wait to Quit Now Lingers a Bit
abstract: In the 1990s, Mineral burned out after less than four years and only two albums, never comfortable with its emo label. They’re enjoying a second chance, no matter what their music is called.
lead_paragraph: In 2007, on the message boards at Absolutepunk.net, a fan posted a picture of a tattoo he had commissioned featuring a lyric from the long-defunct Austin band Mineral: “How blessed we are.”

headline: Senior Senator Waits Quietly in the Wings
abstract: John Cornyn is in the No. 2 spot in the Senate’s Republican leadership; if his party takes control of the Senate on Tuesday, he could find himself in a leadership role.
lead_paragraph: While the junior United States senator from Texas hogs the limelight, the senior senator could soon move into management of that chamber.

headline: Fleeing a Mexican Border Town Amid a Yearslong Drug War
abstract: The emptying of Guadalupe comes at a time when officials in Ciudad Juárez, about 30 miles away, are promoting tourism and celebrating a decrease in bloodshed.
lead_paragraph: GUADALUPE DISTRITO BRAVO, Mexico — Remnants of small-town charm were still visible last week from the outskirts of this Mexican border city as bolls of damp cotton weighed down branches and a rancher slowly chased a stray cow headed for the highway.

headline: In Thailand, Tracking the Dog Trade
abstract: Thai police are ramping up efforts to slow the trafficking of dogs who are being captured and killed for their meat and skin.
lead_paragraph: Thai police are ramping up efforts to slow the trafficking of dogs who are being captured and killed for their meat and skin.

headline: Dog Meat Trade in Thailand Is Under Pressure and May Be Banned
abstract: The police have arrested what they describe as the country’s dog meat kingpins, and the military government is considering banning the trade.
lead_paragraph: BAAN KLANG, Thailand — The dog-eating community here, a small minority of rice farmers and day laborers, has long understood that its culinary habits do not sit well with people from other parts of Thailand, especially the pet-loving urban middle and upper classes.

headline: Virgin Galactic Is Rattled, but Undeterred, by Deadly Space Plane Crash
abstract: The company and federal investigators began their investigations into what caused a space plane to crash Friday in the Mojave Desert, while the pilot killed was identified as Michael Alsbury.
lead_paragraph: A team of about 15 investigators from the National Transportation Safety Board began its inquiry on Saturday into the crash of a Virgin Galactic space plane on Friday in the Mojave Desert that killed the co-pilot and severely injured the pilot.

headline: Alagappa Alagappan, 88, Dies; Founded Hindu Temples Across U.S.
abstract: Mr. Alagappan, a native of India, began a movement in 1970 to build Hindu temples in the United States.
lead_paragraph: In 1968, on a trip to his native India, Alagappa Alagappan dreamed that an ancient Hindu god told him to visit a medium. So he did, and on his first visit the medium read palm leaves to tell him that the Lord Ganesha — another deity, this one beloved for his laugh and his elephant head — wanted to settle in a city beginning with the letter N.

headline: Bernard Mayes, 85, Dies; Started First U.S. Suicide Hotline
abstract: Mr. Mayes, a multifaceted Anglican priest, started the first suicide hotline in the United States and a decade later became the founding chairman of National Public Radio.
lead_paragraph: Bernard Mayes, a multifaceted Anglican priest who started the first suicide hotline in the United States and a decade later became the founding chairman of National Public Radio, died on Oct. 23 in San Francisco. He was 85.

headline: Braced for a Shift in Congress, Obama Is Setting a New Agenda
abstract: Expecting a less friendly Congress after the election, aides are mapping out possible compromises with Republicans to expand trade, overhaul taxes and build roads and bridges.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Whipsawed by events and facing another midterm electoral defeat, President Obama has directed his team to forge a policy agenda to regain momentum for his final two years in office even as some advisers urge that he rethink the way he governs.

headline: Labour Party Leader Backs Replacing House of Lords
abstract: Ed Miliband, the Labour leader, proposed replacing the House of Lords, which traces its roots to the 14th century, with an American-style elected Senate.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The House of Lords traces its roots to the 14th century. Now the Labour Party is proposing to consign it to history.

headline: Breeders’ Cup 2014: In Classic, Bayern Bumps the Favorite, Shared Belief, Then Wins in a Wild Finish
abstract: After a contentious start, Bayern turned back California Chrome and held off Toast of New York down the stretch to give the Hall of Fame trainer Bob Baffert his first Classic victory.
lead_paragraph: ARCADIA, Calif. — When the gates swung open for the start of the $5 million Breeders’ Cup Classic late Saturday afternoon at Santa Anita Park, it did not so much resemble a high-stakes horse race as it did Nascar on hooves.

headline: Defects Found Before Debut of Health Insurance Site for Small Businesses
abstract: The Obama administration has discovered a number of defects in the online marketplace that will offer health insurance to small-business employees, but said they would be fixed before Nov. 15.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration has discovered a number of defects in the online marketplace that will offer health insurance to millions of small-business employees, but federal officials said the problems could probably be fixed before the website goes live on Nov. 15.

headline: Michigan’s Win Is Easy; Questions on Future Are Anything But
abstract: The news on Friday of Dave Brandon’s resignation as athletic director was an uneasy undercurrent in the Wolverines’ 34-10 victory over Indiana on homecoming weekend.
lead_paragraph: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — The day after Dave Brandon resigned as the University of Michigan’s athletic director resembled most other football Saturdays in this college town.

headline: Fire Kills 5 in Building Near College in Maine
abstract: A three-alarm fire swept through a duplex building in Portland early Saturday morning, killing five people and critically injuring one.
lead_paragraph: A three-alarm fire swept through an apartment house in Portland, Me., early Saturday morning, killing five people and critically injuring one, in what the authorities said was the deadliest fire in the state in 30 years.

headline: Army’s Rough Week Gets Worse as Air Force Secures Commander-in-Chief’s Trophy
abstract: A drubbing by Air Force followed a report that Army had incurred multiple N.C.A.A. violations last winter on a recruiting outing.
lead_paragraph: WEST POINT, N.Y. — Wind and rain did not diminish the line of cars that stretched for miles before Thayer Gate, one of two main entrances to Army’s hilly campus. For all intentions, Saturday afternoon was the last meaningful home game of the Black Knights’ season, and a sellout crowd crammed into Michie Stadium to see it.

headline: In Rhode Island Governor’s Race, Pension Issue Could Hurt Raimondo
abstract: As the state treasurer, Gina M. Raimondo has made painful changes in the pension system. Now running for governor, she is encountering some resentment.
lead_paragraph: CRANSTON, R.I. — Serena Mancini, who has worked at Rhode Island’s Department of Transportation for 25 years, had planned to retire in four years, at 54. But when Gina M. Raimondo, the state treasurer, restructured the state’s failing pension system, Ms. Mancini had to recalculate. She has had to put off retirement until 59, and will be receiving fewer benefits.

headline: Netanyahu Urges Restraint in Row Over Sacred Site
abstract: Several lawmakers from Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s Likud Party have been among a small but vocal group advocating increased Jewish access and prayer at the site, known to Jews as the Temple Mount.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel called Saturday night for “responsibility and restraint” regarding this city’s most sensitive sacred site, urging members of Parliament “to work to calm the situation” after days of mounting tension.

headline: Argentine Judge Orders Arrest of Spanish Ex-Officials
abstract: The judge invoked universal jurisdiction in the case of 20 Franco-era officials accused of torturing dissidents.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — A judge in Argentina has ordered the arrest of 20 former Spanish officials accused of torturing dissidents during the dictatorship of Francisco Franco, from 1939 to 1975, renewing efforts to pursue cases of human rights abuses beyond the country’s borders.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 1, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Inside the Guts of Macy’s Herald Square
abstract: Macy’s Herald Square has been undergoing a luxury makeover. But with a building that is more than a century old, everything from the loading bays to the stockrooms also needs to be overhauled.
lead_paragraph: Macy’s Herald Square has been undergoing a luxury makeover. But with a building that is more than a century old, everything from the loading bays to the stockrooms also needs to be overhauled.

headline: For Macy’s, a Makeover on 34th Street
abstract: Macy’s flagship has long tried to be everything to everyone. But in a $400 million renovation, it’s taking sharper aim at millennials and free-spending tourists.
lead_paragraph: Terry J. Lundgren, the chief executive of Macy’s, strode through the women’s shoe department of the company’s flagship store in Manhattan’s Herald Square, determined to find a bargain.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, November 2, 2014
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, November 2, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “I have never seen such a level of cynicism and chaos before.”

headline: Patterns on Repeat
abstract: Geometric graphics made strong statements this season, with designers taking their cues from art and architecture to play tricks on the eye.

headline: Deadly Halloween Across the Nation
abstract: At least 15 people were killed and nine others injured in accidents and a fire connected to the festivities from California to New York.
lead_paragraph: Halloween took a deadly turn for trick-or-treaters, paradegoers and party guests across the country, on a holiday that federal safety regulators say is one of the deadliest on America’s roadways.

headline: Corrections: November 2, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Sunday, November 2, 2014.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK

headline: Eclectic and on Point, Prince Hijacks 8 Minutes on ‘S.N.L.’
abstract: In a metallic jacket and three-eyed sunglasses, the performer took the stage with the power trio 3rdEyeGirl, playing a medley that included a mid-tempo funk tune, a power-riff number, a catchy roadhouse punk song and a barbed slow jam.
lead_paragraph: “It’s America; we commercialize everything,” said Chris Rock in his opening monologue for “Saturday Night Live.” That would be the cynical take on the episode’s carefully hyped musical performance: a mid-show appearance by Prince. Booked for the show at Mr. Rock’s request, Prince departed from longstanding “S.N.L.” custom for musical guests; instead of two brief, single-song performances, he played an eight-minute mini-set.

headline: ‘Off Color’ and on Target About Race in America
abstract: “Off Color,” a New York Times video series, looks at how artists of color are making sharp social commentary about race in America through comedy and performance.
lead_paragraph: In his comedy album “Waiting for 2042,” Hari Kondabolu pokes fun at the shifting demographics in the United States, where minorities are expected to outnumber whites by 2042. But there’s no need to “freak out,” the Indian-American comic advises whites. “You were the minority when you came to this country,” he said. “Things seem to have worked out for you.”

headline: China Approves Security Law Emphasizing Counterespionage
abstract: The change, made official on Saturday, targets foreign spies and their domestic collaborators, reflecting top-level concerns about growing political threats from abroad, analysts said.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — President Xi Jinping of China has signed a new Counterespionage Law, replacing the 1993 National Security Law with an updated set of rules that will more closely target foreign spies and Chinese individuals and organizations who collaborate with them.

headline: Heartache for New York’s Catholics as Church Closings Are Announced
abstract: Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan announced the names of 55 parishes that will merge with neighboring parishes from Staten Island to the Catskills.
lead_paragraph: There were gasps and tears at Holy Rosary Church in East Harlem. At Sacred Heart in Mount Vernon, congregants shared mournful embraces. And at Our Lady of Peace on the East Side, parishioners pledged a fight.

headline: U.N. Panel Issues Its Starkest Warning Yet on Global Warming
abstract: Failure to reduce emissions could threaten society with food shortages, refugee crises, major flooding and mass extinctions, the group of scientists and other experts found.
lead_paragraph: COPENHAGEN — The gathering risks of climate change are so profound that they could stall or even reverse generations of progress against poverty and hunger if greenhouse emissions continue at a runaway pace, according to a major new United Nations report.

headline: Monster Moves to Restore a Faded Job Search Brand
abstract: Monster, which revolutionized online job hunting in the 1990s, is trying to reinvent itself for the era of Twitter and Facebook with new products that capitalize on social media.
lead_paragraph: Remember Monster.com?

headline: Republicans Hold Edge in Early Voting in Colorado
abstract: Democrats are starting to see positive trends with early ballots but still have far to go to give Senator Mark Udall a shot at victory.
lead_paragraph: It would be a galling symbol of Democratic misfortune this cycle if Colorado turned out to be where the Democratic turnout machine most obviously fell short of its lofty goals.

headline: When a Teacher Is Arrested for Child Pornography, Students Will Talk
abstract: When a teacher at my children’s elementary school was arrested, the school sent an email asking parents to have older children keep quiet to protect the younger kids. But it’s impossible to put a stop to playground talk.
lead_paragraph: “Can I ask a question about Mr. W?” 10-year-old Brennan asks, and my stomach takes a roller-coaster dip. We have just left the school potluck, where he spent hours playing a game of tag on the playground. But when I went to retrieve him, I was surprised to discover that he had dropped out of the action and sat alone atop the playground’s chain-link fence, kicking his feet. I asked him what was up but he avoided my eyes and shrugged, saying only that he was ready to go home. Now that we are buckled in and on the road, he is ready to talk.

headline: Bracing for the Falls of an Aging Nation
abstract: Across the nation, places like The Sequoias are trying to reduce the number of falls among their increasingly elderly residents while satisfying people’s desire to live life as they choose.
lead_paragraph: Across the nation, places like The Sequoias are trying to reduce the number of falls among their increasingly elderly residents while satisfying people’s desire to live life as they choose.

headline: 1914: Parisians Flock to Cemeteries on All Souls’ Day to Honor Dead Soldiers
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: The French mourn their dead in 1914.
lead_paragraph: All Souls’ Day, when French custom decrees one shall make a pilgrimage to the tombs of the dead, is always an impressive occasion in Paris, but yesterday was especially so, owing to the bereavements of the war, and the great outpouring of the public to the cemeteries at Pantin, Ivry and Bagneux, where soldiers fallen in the conflict have been buried. It was a throng typically Parisian, typically proletariat, which filed through the massive stone gates of the cemetery at Bagneux to the section where most of the soldiers who have died in the great military hospital of Val-de-Grâce lie buried. Perhaps half of the women were hatless. Many carried children in their arms. By half-past two o’clock in the afternoon the street in front of the cemetery was an unbroken phalanx moving toward the gates. At half-past four, when the autumn sun was disappearing behind the trees, the stream was still coming from Paris. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Nov. 3, 1914

headline: The Economy Elects Presidents. Presidents Elect Congress.
abstract: While presidential elections are shaped largely by economic performance, the largest factor in midterm elections is the president.
lead_paragraph: In 1992, Bill Clinton’s strategist, James Carville, made famous a presidential campaign mantra: It’s "the economy, stupid.” He meant that presidential election outcomes are tied to the nation’s economic conditions, something that should not surprise many people. The same, however, is not true for midterm elections. Those are much more tied to the president himself.

headline: Hong Kong Police Arrest British Banker After 2 Women’s Bodies Are Found
abstract: One woman had her throat slashed and the body of the other was discovered decomposing in a suitcase on a balcony.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A 29-year-old British man has been arrested after the bodies of two women were found in his upscale apartment, the Hong Kong police said over the weekend. One woman’s throat had been slashed, and the body of the other was found decomposing, stuffed in a suitcase on a balcony.

headline: List of Merging Churches and Those That Will Cease Regular Services

lead_paragraph: A list of churches in the region that will merge. The parish listed on the left and the parish on the right will merge. Masses and other sacraments will cease to be celebrated on a regular basis at the church in the right column. The merger is expected to take effect by August 2015.
