abstract: A list of churches in the region that will merge. The parish listed on the left and the parish on the right will merge. Both churches will remain open for the regular celebration of Masses and other events. The merger is expected to take effect by August 2015.
lead_paragraph: A list of churches in the region that will merge. The parish listed on the left and the parish on the right will merge. Both churches will remain open for the regular celebration of Masses and other events. The merger is expected to take effect by August 2015.

headline: 1939: American Ships Hasten to Sail Before New Bill Takes Effect
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: American ships rush to sail before a neutrality bill goes into effect, prohibiting travel to states designated as belligerent.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — United States liners and freighters scheduled to sail for belligerent ports tonight [Nov. 2 ] speeded preparations to get away within the next day or two before the Administration’s neutrality bill, passed by the House of Representatives today, would become effective. The United States liner Washington, scheduled to sail for Europe next Wednesday, will leave New York tomorrow morning, and the President Roosevelt is sailing tomorrow noon instead of Saturday. The American Farmer will make a special trip without passengers, sailing today or tomorrow. Under the terms of the existing neutrality legislation American vessels are permitted to carry merchandise of a non-military nature to belligerent ports, but when the new law goes into effect, all American ships will be forbidden to enter the waters of states designated as belligerents by the President. Although ships of the United States merchant marine may not call at French, British or German ports in the actual war zone, they may carry cargo and passengers to ports belonging to the belligerents definitely outside the zone of combat, such as Australia, New Zealand, India, Indo-China and the West Indies. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Nov. 3, 1939

headline: A Rise in Falls
abstract: The number of falls is expected to rise among the elderly, The Times reports.
lead_paragraph: As the population ages, hospitals and retirement communities are bracing for an increase in the number of falls among the elderly, The Times reports. Read the full story. Update: A second story on falls was published in Science Times.

headline: Bomber Kills at Least 50 in Wagah, Town on India-Pakistan Border
abstract: The attack, which also wounded at least 120 people, occurred near the border with India where a flag-lowering ceremony takes place daily at sunset.
lead_paragraph: LAHORE, Pakistan — At least 55 people were killed and at least 120 more were wounded Sunday evening when a suicide bomber set off explosives at a border post in eastern Pakistan, police officials said.

headline: Kenyans Duel in Close Women’s Race
abstract: Mary Keitany, from Kenya, edged her countrywoman Jemima Sumgong after the two pulled away from the lead pack and dueled for the final four miles.
lead_paragraph: Another show of Kenyan dominance in distance running came down to a two-woman race Sunday at the New York City Marathon.

headline: Arm Bump Precedes Late Burst in Men’s Race
abstract: Wilson Kipsang kept a one-stride lead over Lelisa Desisa of Ethiopia as they entered Central Park. When Desisa tried to make a move, he pushed Kipsang’s arm away, which seemed to motivate Kipsang.
lead_paragraph: As Wilson Kipsang of Kenya and Lelisa Desisa of Ethiopia ran stride for stride into the last stretch of the New York City Marathon on Sunday morning, a long run turned into an unusually personal sprint. As Desisa, the younger challenger, tried to surge ahead, his left arm pushed Kipsang’s arm away.

headline: Panel’s Latest Warming Warning Misses Global Slumber Party on Energy Research
abstract: The latest global warming report from the U.N. climate panel helpfully clarifies risks but largely misses a key factor in driving an energy transformation — research.
lead_paragraph: The year-long rollout of the latest assessment of climate change science and solutions by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change ended today in Copenhagen with the release of a final synthesis report offering an overview of the world’s climate trajectories and choices.

headline: ‘Nightcrawler’ Leads Halloween Weekend Box Office
abstract: This crime drama starring Jake Gyllenhaal took in an estimated $10.91 million to rank No. 1 at North American movie theaters.
lead_paragraph: “Nightcrawler” (Open Road Films), an $8.5 million crime drama starring Jake Gyllenhaal, took in an estimated $10.91 million over the weekend, enough to rank atop the North American box office.

headline: The Guts of a Neighborhood Center, Tossed Out in the Trash
abstract: The clearing out of the Highbridge Community Life Center in the Bronx was the latest sad twist in the drawn-out demise of what was a vital resource.
lead_paragraph: Brother Bill Fecteau banged on the padlocked door of the Highbridge Community Life Center in the Bronx. No answer. Inside, beyond the vestibule where scraps of paper littered the floor like confetti, he spied dark figures moving about. They ignored him. He went around to the back and peered through a window, only to see classrooms with no books, furniture or computers.

headline: Rebel-Backed Elections to Cement Status Quo in Ukraine
abstract: Separatist leaders portrayed the voting in Donetsk and Luhansk as a capstone to their six-month struggle for independence, and voters said the elections would compel Kiev to end the war.
lead_paragraph: DONETSK, Ukraine — The campaign billboards in this city suggested a tight race between Aleksandr Zakharchenko and Aleksandr Zakharchenko.

headline: It May Be Too Late, but Colorado Early Ballots Are Shifting Toward Democrats
abstract: It’s far from clear if this improvement in Democratic prospects will be enough to whittle away the Republican advantage.
lead_paragraph: In an article published this morning, I wrote that the trend lines for early ballots weren’t moving fast enough for Democrats in Colorado. The ballots received over the last week leaned Republican by about six percentage points — no better for Democrats than in 2010.

headline: U.N. Employee Under Treatment for Ebola in France
abstract: The health ministry said in a statement on its website that the patient had contracted the virus in Sierra Leone and was being treated in a military hospital near Paris.
lead_paragraph: France was treating a United Nations employee who contracted the Ebola virus in Sierra Leone, the health ministry said in a statement posted Sunday on its website.

headline: Reaction to the Merging of Catholic Churches
abstract: Tell us your thoughts about the merging of 55 area parishes with neighboring churches in New York.
lead_paragraph: As part of the largest reorganization in the history of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, 55 area parishes will merge into neighboring churches by August 2015.

headline: What’s On TV Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (HBO) OLIVE KITTERIDGE Frances McDormand, above, aging 25 years on screen, portrays Olive, a dowdy, gruff math teacher who witnesses the affairs, crimes and tragedies in an unremarkable Maine town alongside her husband, Henry (Richard Jenkins), a kindly pharmacist, in Lisa Cholodenko’s adaptation of Elizabeth Strout’s Pulitzer Prize-winning collection of stories. John Gallagher Jr. plays the couple’s son, Christopher, who resents his mother’s ways; and Bill Murray is Jack Kennison, a lonely widower who shares Olive’s inner sadness. This mini-series, shown on Sunday and Monday, “is a rare treasure, a measured, understated portrait of a marriage that finds poetry in the most prosaic of settings and circumstances: flinty, stolid citizens of a small, insular town in coastal Maine,” Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. “There is no glamour and little romance, yet there is a fine-grained mystery to the most ordinary, blunted lives.”

headline: In Iowa Senate Race, Joni Ernst Increases Her Edge
abstract: Joni Ernst has taken a bigger lead in her bid to become the next senator from Iowa, according to a new Des Moines Register poll.
lead_paragraph: Joni Ernst has taken a bigger lead in her bid to become the next senator from Iowa, according to a new poll, but her advantage remains within the poll’s margin of sampling error.

headline: N.B.A. Pounds Pavement for Fitness Effort
abstract: More than 20 league executives and former players ran a relay along the marathon route, in part to connect with the city in preparation for the All-Star Game in February.
lead_paragraph: N.B.A. Commissioner Adam Silver had just finished an icy three-mile run over the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge. His lips, ears and nose were red from the blistering gusts of wind.

headline: Israeli Lawmaker’s Tour Stokes Tension Over Holy Site
abstract: The visit by the lawmaker, Moshe Feiglin, passed without violence, eliciting only chants of “God is great!” and taunts from Muslim protesters.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — A hard-line Israeli lawmaker from Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s Likud Party toured this city’s most contested holy site with a police escort on Sunday, and a far-right minister reiterated a contentious call for Jews to be allowed to pray there, despite Mr. Netanyahu’s plea for politicians to show responsibility and restraint.

headline: A Verdi Test Where Nuance Is Just One of the Many Demands
abstract: In a season that has already featured productions of “La Bohème and “Carmen,” the Met completes the ABC’s with “Aida.”
lead_paragraph: Six weeks into its season, the Metropolitan Opera has presented all three pinnacles of the standard repertory, the so-called ABC’s of opera: Verdi’s “Aida,” Puccini’s “La Bohème” and Bizet’s “Carmen.” While none of these revivals has been thrilling, most dismaying is the listless “Aida” that opened Thursday. It begins in a chill and barely thaws.

headline: Microsoft Band Is a Welcome Surprise in the Wearable Market
abstract: The company’s new wearable device may be the most flexible of its kind available now.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft surprised the tech world last week by introducing a new fitness tracking wristband, along with an app and cloud-computing technology for tracking health and fitness data.

headline: Contortions, Clowning and Confetti
abstract: A clown, contortionists, jugglers and one sheepadoodle are among the attractions in “Metamorphosis,” the latest edition of the Big Apple Circus.
lead_paragraph: “Metamorphosis” is the theme of the latest edition of the Big Apple Circus, now nested at Lincoln Center for the holidays. And considering the scale of this troupe — more intimate, in the European tradition, than the Ringling Brothers behemoth — you could say this impressive production starts modestly, only to spread its wings and soar.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
abstract: Account assignments, miscellaneous news from advertising agencies and more.
lead_paragraph: Accounts

headline: After Eighth Loss in a Row, the Jets Sound a Lowly Refrain
abstract: The losing streak matches the Jets’ longest since 1996, when the team lost eight straight and finished 1-15.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — As always, the Jets had a terrific week of practice. They always do. Always, always, always. Then comes game day, when they are required to line up opposite people wearing different-colored uniforms.

headline: Elite Runners Serve as Muses for Shoe Design
abstract: At a laboratory near Boston, top athletes are tested and observed as part of the shoe design process.
lead_paragraph: LEXINGTON, Mass. — On a $100,000 two-lane treadmill surrounded by cameras in a studio near Boston, the elite runner Michelle Lilienthal easily pounded out seven-minute miles, her stride widening as she approached her marathon race speed and dipped below a six-minute pace.

headline: Like One-Word Answers
abstract: The return of Janet R. Bender.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Janet R. Bender has been contributing puzzles to The New York Times since 1992, and if you look at her track record, she seems to have a real thing for themes where the beginning letters of multiple-word phrases are the same.

headline: With Magazine, CNET Tech Site Makes Jump From Screen to Page
abstract: CNET is starting a quarterly magazine, joining other media organizations that are capitalizing on their digital success with physical publications or outlets.
lead_paragraph: A LEADING technology website, CNET, is expanding into a platform that its users praise as portable, accessible and affordable. And unlike tablets, smartphones or laptops, it is also good for squishing bugs.

headline: An Eclectic Evening to Start a Season
abstract: The Riverside Symphony, conducted by George Rothman, opened its new season at Alice Tully Hall on Saturday night with the pianist Hélène Tysman.
lead_paragraph: In the musical world, we still have work to do to broaden and update our canon, perhaps to go beyond the very idea of a canon at all. But even beyond the major orchestras and star soloists, plenty of performers have been engaged in such an effort for years.

headline: First Draft Focus: Common Ground
abstract: Michelle Nunn, the Democratic candidate for the open Senate seat in Georgia, helped out at a community garden in Atlanta on Sunday.

headline: Naughty in Spite of Himself
abstract: The Gilbert and Sullivan Players present the operetta “Ruddigore” at the Skirball Center.
lead_paragraph: The issue of street harassment has received wide attention recently, with men and women often disagreeing on what constitutes harassment versus harmless flattery in a public space. This longstanding (and serious) issue surfaces in lighthearted form in Gilbert and Sullivan’s “Ruddigore (The Witch’s Curse),” when the virtuous maiden Rose Maybud consults her etiquette manual about the appropriateness of a stranger’s complimenting her appearance.

headline: Legions of Faiths, Girded for Battle
abstract: The latest Norton anthology takes on major world religions, in 4,000-plus pages.
lead_paragraph: Jack Miles has undertaken no less ambitious a project than writing a “biography” of God, winning a Pulitzer Prize in the bargain.

headline: Quarantine, North Korea Style
abstract: Pyongyang tackles human rights.
lead_paragraph: Pyongyang tackles human rights.

headline: Chilling Story of Friendship and Death, Served Chilled
abstract: The French choreographer Gisèle Vienne’s “Kindertotenlieder” explores a youthful murder.
lead_paragraph: The French choreographer Gisèle Vienne has said that she doesn’t think of “Kindertotenlieder,” her staggeringly dark work of dance-theater, as “scary.” It’s more “uncanny,” as she sees it. I saw things differently during the production’s United States premiere on Wednesday at New York Live Arts. “Scary” definitely applied.

headline: Michelle Nunn’s Hopes in Georgia Are Fading in Final Stretch
abstract: The Republican in the Senate race, David Perdue, has taken a narrow but consistent lead in the polls.
lead_paragraph: One of the few bits of bad news for Republicans over the last couple of months was the Georgia Senate race, where the Democrat, Michelle Nunn, pulled into a tie with the Republican, David Perdue, after a 2005 deposition was revealed in which Mr. Perdue said that he was proud of his record of outsourcing.

headline: The Guys Who Just Watch
abstract: In Richard Ford’s fourth Frank Bascombe book, “Let Me Be Frank With You,” his Everyman hero is 68, retired and living in Default Mode.
lead_paragraph: It’s been almost three decades since we first met Frank Bascombe in Richard Ford’s milestone 1986 novel “The Sportswriter.” In the years since, Frank has become his creator’s Everyman, as much a representative of middle-class American life and its discontents as John Updike’s Harry Angstrom was for another generation in the “Rabbit” novels.

headline: Medal for American Pair at World Championships
abstract: The only American medalists in the three concluding pair events at the world championships in China last month were Reese Milner of Los Angeles and Hemant Lall of Dallas.
lead_paragraph: The only American medalists in the three concluding pair events at the world championships in China last month were Reese Milner of Los Angeles and Hemant Lall of Dallas. They won the silver medals in the Senior Pairs, which followed on their victory in the Rand Senior Teams.

headline: When Deal Wobbles, a Double Steps In
abstract: In “The Lookalike,” a noir with many characters, a woman and her double become involved with drug dealing.
lead_paragraph: “Sordid” seems too mild a word for “The Lookalike,” an arch, clotted new noir. A convoluted plot begins when Sadie (Gillian Jacobs) agrees to sleep with her father’s former business associate for $500,000. The assignation will leverage a drug connection for a gangster, Bobby (John Corbett, sounding like Jeff Bridges). Then Sadie dies in a freak accident: Bobby’s criminal partner (Steven Bauer) shakes a desk, causing a chandelier to fall on her. Hey, it happens. But it leaves the men scrambling to find a double.

headline: Man Behind Operation Needs One Himself
abstract: John Spinello, inventor of what became the board game Operation in 1965, is able to afford a $25,000 dental procedure because of a crowdfunding campaign.
lead_paragraph: Cavity Sam of the classic board game Operation recently got a makeover, and the man who helped create him will, too. John Spinello, above, inventor of what became Operation in 1965, is able to afford a $25,000 dental procedure because of a crowdfunding campaign begun by his fellow game inventors Tim Walsh and Peggy Brown. The campaign, which began Oct. 22 at crowdrise.com, raised over $31,000 by early Sunday. The experience, Mr. Spinello said by phone from Bloomington, Ill., has been “mind boggling.” “It’s really rewarding to have people calling me right now from all over the world,” he said. “You can’t put a price tag on it.” Mr. Spinello, 77, invented the buzzer game while studying industrial design at the University of Illinois. He sold his idea to a toy invention firm for $500, and it was then licensed to Milton Bradley. Through the years there have been various riffs on the character, including Homer Simpson, SpongeBob SquarePants and a version with 21st-century ailments like headphone headache and gamer’s thumb. Though Mr. Spinello still owns the patent for the game, he said he receives no royalties. In recent years, the recession hurt his trucking warehouse company, and he and his wife have filed for bankruptcy. In addition to the donations at Crowdrise, money has also been raised through the sale of signed copies of the game and $3 “Dear John” thank-you letters at iloveoperation.com. Hasbro, which owns Milton Bradley, has pitched in by agreeing to buy the original prototype from Mr. Spinello. Calls requesting comment from Hasbro were not returned. Mr. Spinello said he hoped any leftover money would go to saving his home. But, he added, he would be grateful for “a decent smile and the ability to chew.”

headline: $10 Million Gift for Madison Estate
abstract: The Virginia estate of President James Madison may soon look more like the home he knew, through a $10 million gift from the businessman and philanthropist David Rubenstein.
lead_paragraph: The Virginia estate of President James Madison may soon look more like the home he knew, complete with 19th-century furnishings and slave quarters, through a $10 million gift from the businessman and philanthropist David Rubenstein. The Montpelier Foundation announced on Saturday that the money would be used to further restore the mansion to its original 1817 appearance and provide more context about the lives of Madison’s slaves. Part of the gift, $3.5 million, will support reconstruction of the mansion’s south yard, where the family’s domestic servants lived and worked. The plans include three slave quarters, two smokehouses and a detached kitchen. The rest of the money will go toward restoring, researching and refurnishing the home, including purchasing items authentic to the time period or the home; much of what was there has been dispersed over the years through family members or sales. Dolley Madison sold the property in 1844 after her husband’s death, and Montpelier had various owners until it was purchased in 1901 by William duPont. In 1984, it was bestowed to the National Trust for Historic Preservation by Marion duPont Scott, following her death in 1983. This is Mr. Rubenstein’s third major recent gift to presidential estates in Virginia.

headline: In a World of Whimsy, a Perilous Journey Home
abstract: In “Over the Garden Wall,” a comic horror odyssey by Patrick McHale, two brothers stray into a realm called the Unknown and must find their way home.
lead_paragraph: Cartoon Network’s new 10-episode series, “Over the Garden Wall,” isn’t quite like anything else on television, but it’s a little bit like a lot of things you’ve seen. Guessing at what has influenced its creator, Patrick McHale, is one of the pleasures of watching it.

headline: Amazement Befitting a Miracle, Translated to Sound
abstract: Yannick Nézet-Séguin conducted the Philadelphia Orchestra in Mahler’s Symphony No. 2 (“Resurrection”) on Friday night at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: “Why did you live? Why did you suffer? Is it all nothing but a huge, frightful joke?” As Gustav Mahler explained to an admirer, Max Marschalk, his Second Symphony tries to answer the loftiest of questions. Lasting 90 minutes and requiring two female vocalists, full chorus, organ and what the musicologist Deryck Cooke described as “much percussion,” one would hope so.

headline: Angry About War and Liars All Over Again
abstract: Barb Jungr interprets the work of Bob Dylan and Leonard Cohen in “Hard Rain” at 59E59 Theaters.
lead_paragraph: Bob Dylan and Leonard Cohen: As much as you may think you know the songs of these two musical patriarchs, the British singer Barb Jungr interprets their work with a ferocity and truthfulness that demolishes every cover version you’ve ever heard. Her show, “Hard Rain,” at 59E59 Theaters, interweaves classics old and new, and emphasizes their contemporaneity, even though some of the Dylan selections were written half a century ago in a spirit of boiling rage.

headline: Lone Star Candidate
abstract: This short documentary profiles Mike Minter, an underfunded Democrat who seeks election against a Republican incumbent in one of the most conservative districts of Texas.
lead_paragraph: This short documentary profiles Mike Minter, an underfunded Democrat who seeks election against a Republican incumbent in one of the most conservative districts of Texas.

headline: ‘Lone Star Candidate’
abstract: Mike Minter, a Democratic candidate for Congress, has little chance of winning in one of the most conservative districts in Texas. So why run?
lead_paragraph: Mike Minter, a Democrat, is under no illusion that he will be elected as the next congressman from the 13th Congressional District of Texas. He freely admits to anyone who will listen that he is there to “get his butt whipped.” And based on his opponent’s war chest, the slammed doors, and recent elections — a butt whipping is exactly what Mr. Minter is going to get on Tuesday.

headline: Lighting a Flamenco Fire Under an Ancient Heroine
abstract: In Noche Flamenca’s latest adventure, “Antigona,” at the Joyce Theater, the company travels to ancient Greece.
lead_paragraph: There are dancers, and there are spellbinding creatures for whom movement emanates from deep within the body and erupts like a volcano. Soledad Barrio is such a force. Beating out rhythms with rattling heels and swirling her arms overhead with emphatic bearing, she leaves one world for another. In her latest adventure, seen Wednesday at the Joyce Theater, her company, Noche Flamenca, travels to ancient Greece.

headline: A Flood of Late Spending on Midterm Elections, From Murky Sources
abstract: Outside groups are pouring tens of millions of dollars into campaign attack ads and automated calls, timing their efforts to avoid identifying donors until after the election.
lead_paragraph: A stealthy coterie of difficult-to-trace outside groups is slipping tens of millions of dollars of attacks ads and negative automated telephone calls into the final days of the midterm campaign, helping fuel an unprecedented surge of last-minute spending on Senate races.

headline: We Are Not the Only Political Animals
abstract: To define other species as “nonpolitical” excludes them from consideration as beings with interests of their own. What’s wrong with that?
lead_paragraph: Homo sapiens has long sought to set itself apart from animals — that is, apart from every other living species. One of the most enduring attempts to define humanity in a way that distances us from the rest of animal life was Aristotle’s description of the human being as a “political animal.” By this he meant that human beings are the only species that live in the “polis” or city-state, though the term has often been understood to include villages, communes, and other organized social units. Implicit in this definition is the idea that all other animals are not political, that they live altogether outside of internally governed social units.

headline: A Comedy Moment in New York
abstract: The New York Comedy Festival starts Wednesday with controversy surrounding a headliner, Bill Cosby, and a profusion of Los Angeles acts rarely in New York.
lead_paragraph: With scores of funny people plying their trade at bars, clubs and theaters, the city feels like a comedy festival every night. So why get excited about the annual New York Comedy Festival? Simple: Size matters. From Wednesday through Sunday, more than 200 comics will play more than 60 shows, including more major headliners in big rooms than at any other time of the year. The quantity of performances, large and small across the city, means a dizzyingly array of talent, and some fascinating story lines. Here are a few to keep an eye on.

headline: An Artifact Once Was Just Home
abstract: The Tenement Museum on the Lower East receives a visit from the last living resident who remembers the building as it was in the 1930s.
lead_paragraph: Rita Ascione made her way slowly up the steep, narrow staircase at 97 Orchard Street, on the Lower East Side, one recent morning, letting out a few moans and groans along the way. Her daughter Valerie Carmody tried to jolly her along. “Come on, Ma, you’re always telling me that you used to fly up these stairs.”

headline: Punch Line With Real Political Punch
abstract: The results of Bill Maher’s bid to influence a House race in Minnesota will be seen with Tuesday’s election returns.
lead_paragraph: Bill Maher has wrung the most comedy — and attention — he can out of his campaign to unseat a little known Republican congressman from Minnesota. But on Tuesday, things get serious for Mr. Maher, the host of HBO’s “Real Time”: He wants to win.

headline: Italian Bank Monte dei Paschi to Sell Shares to Meet Capital Demands
abstract: Monte dei Paschi has until Nov. 10 to satisfy European regulators.
lead_paragraph: The Italian bank Monte dei Paschi di Siena said on Sunday that it would ask investors to help it raise the money it needed to satisfy demands from the European Central Bank that it bolster its ability to survive an economic downturn or other crisis.

headline: Finding a Job After Serving Time
abstract: Readers discuss how to open up more work opportunities for former inmates.

headline: Personal and Political: Judging People by Their Party
abstract: Readers take issue with a column by David Brooks.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Treating Acid Reflux, With Drugs and Lifestyle Changes
abstract: Doctors from Mount Sinai and the Cleveland Clinic respond to a Sunday Review article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Effects of Optimism
abstract: Two readers discuss an essay about the drawbacks of positive thinking.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Invest in Poor Children
abstract: Lucy Friedman of TASC, The After-School Corporation, responds to a column by Nicholas Kristof.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Hudson Yards Tax Breaks
abstract: James A. Parrott of the Fiscal Policy Institute writes that former Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s “giveaways” will cost New York City billions.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: An Encore Vote on Hunting in Alabama
abstract: A measure on Tuesday’s ballot would create an amendment to the State Constitution that is similar to one that was approved in 1996.
lead_paragraph: PARRISH, Ala. — It is easy to stop in a back room of Brady Johnson’s home and miss the bowls of individually wrapped peppermints and oatmeal cream pies.

headline: Cancel the Midterms
abstract: Elections every two years make actual governing impossible.
lead_paragraph: DURHAM, N.C. — By Tuesday night about 90 million Americans will have cast ballots in an election that’s almost certain to create greater partisan divisions, increase gridlock and render governance of our complex nation even more difficult. Ninety million sounds like a lot, but that means that less than 40 percent of the electorate will bother to vote, even though candidates, advocacy groups and shadowy “super PACs” will have spent more than $1 billion to air more than two million ads to influence the election.

headline: Wheelchair Racer’s Tumble Doesn’t Keep Her From Win
abstract: Tatyana McFadden fell late in the race, but regained her seat and her pace to win the women’s wheelchair title in the New York City Marathon and complete a second straight grand slam in her discipline.
lead_paragraph: Late in her final push through Central Park in the women’s wheelchair race at the New York City Marathon on Sunday, Tatyana McFadden felt her herself begin to tip. She was falling, literally, and the hopeless sensation of imbalance gave way to waves of panic.

headline: Treasury Auctions for the Week of Nov. 3
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: European Union Economic Data, and October’s U.S. Job Figures
abstract: The European Union will publish growth and job forecasts for the fall, and the Labor Department will report on United States unemployment for October.
lead_paragraph: EUROPEAN UNION TO PUBLISH GROWTH AND JOBS FORECASTS

headline: ‘Masterpiece’ Franchise on PBS Is Adding Broadcasts
abstract: “Masterpiece,” the 43-year-old English drama franchise, is capitalizing on the runaway success of “Downton Abbey” by adding new shows and more airtime early next year.
lead_paragraph: PBS’s “Masterpiece,” the enduring Sunday night British drama and mystery franchise, will expand by at least 20 hours next year, an approximate 50 percent increase, with the new hours being broadcast either before or after the program’s traditional time slot of 9 p.m. Eastern time.

headline: A Brother Runs Past His Sorrow
abstract: Stephan Shay’s run on Sunday in the New York City Marathon carried him past the place in Central Park where his brother Ryan had a fatal heart attack in 2007 during the Olympic trials.
lead_paragraph: For Stephan Shay, the downhills were the worst.

headline: In Korean Baseball, Louder Cheers and More Squid
abstract: Professional baseball is thriving in South Korea, with the festivities in the stands both raucous and organized to a degree that American fans might find startling.
lead_paragraph: BUSAN, South Korea — It was the bottom of the ninth and the home team was behind, 10-6. In an American ballpark, fans might have started glumly filing out of the stands to beat the traffic.

headline: Bouquet, Used Only Once
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: Two friends watch and reinvent an attempt at peacemaking in Washington Square Park.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: De Blasio’s Plan to Eliminate Workfare Lifts Hopes for Job Seekers
abstract: The de Blasio administration is revamping the city’s welfare system, with plans to dismantle the largest workfare program in the nation.
lead_paragraph: Every workday morning, Phedra Schliefer-Tobias mops floors, cleans toilets and scrubs sinks just like the rest of the members of the custodial staff in a nine-story office building in Lower Manhattan. But her city-issued identification card — her badge of shame — makes it clear that she stands apart.

headline: Women in New York City Marathon Lead a Glorious Cross-City Sprint
abstract: There are few finer two-hours-and-change tours to be had of this city than the glorious cross-city sprint that is the marathon.
lead_paragraph: The lithe women ran back and forth in high-stepping sprints, their pink and yellow sneakers a blur. Then they stopped to bounce, and to shake their arms, as if to banish the cold.

headline: E-Book Mingles Love and Product Placement
abstract: Product placement in a novel might strike some as unseemly, but “Find Me I’m Yours” — an e-book that also makes room for sponsored content from companies — is not like most novels.
lead_paragraph: The heroine of “Find Me I’m Yours,” a new novel by Hillary Carlip, is a quirky young woman named Mags who works at an online bridal magazine and is searching for love in Los Angeles.

headline: Wolves at the Door
abstract: In the 1990s, the federal government reintroduced the gray wolf to Yellowstone National Park. It was considered a big success. And that’s when the real fight began.
lead_paragraph: In the 1990s, the federal government reintroduced the gray wolf to Yellowstone National Park. It was considered a big success. And that’s when the real fight began.

headline: For Gray Wolves, a Success Story Not Without Detractors
abstract: The restoration of the gray wolf population in several Western states has put various factions at odds, each claiming to carry the banner of equity.
lead_paragraph: Few mammals are as unloved as the wolf. Not that the feeling is universal. Some North American Indian tribes traditionally honored the predator as a worthy fellow hunter. Other societies have shown comparable reverence. How can anyone bear a grudge against the she-wolf that suckled Romulus and Remus, mythological founders of Rome? Without her, would we have had all that glorious architecture, those inspiring Michelangelo frescoes, Sophia Loren? Still, in popular culture and many a metaphor this animal is far from adored. There it is at the door in hard times, disguising itself in sheep’s clothing, tormenting the likes of Little Red Riding Hood and the Three Little Pigs.

headline: Over the Hill, and Beyond It
abstract: Slower but lighter at age 60, a writer who had lost all enthusiasm for running marathons decided to test his body in New York one more time.
lead_paragraph: Wilson Kipsang of Kenya won the New York City Marathon in 2 hours 10 minutes 59 seconds — or as I like to call it at my age, a good night’s sleep.

headline: House Democrats Dig Deep for Cash, From Their Colleagues’ Campaigns
abstract: Democratic members who appear to be winning re-election are being asked to funnel money to weaker candidates.
lead_paragraph: Democrats in the House of Representatives have poured more than a half a million dollars from their own campaigns into their colleagues’ tight races during the final weeks leading to Tuesday, more than twice the amount their Republican counterparts have given.

headline: In a Partisan Atmosphere, It Can Even Be Hard to Find Numbers That Agree
abstract: Fundamental conditions drive election outcomes. But in this odd campaign, the fundamentals conflict. Once familiar political signals are muffled. That makes predictions hazy — still.
lead_paragraph: Since his second term began, President Obama has had a solid answer to Republicans’ “Where are the jobs?” complaint. The jobless rate has fallen two full percentage points.

headline: Journalism, Independent and Not
abstract: SugarString, a Verizon-run website, highlights problems with the blurring of news and advertising, while The Texas Tribune, a nonpartisan news organization, is thriving.
lead_paragraph: Last week, I read an interesting article about how smart hardware can allow users to browse anonymously and thus foil snooping from governments. I found it on what looked like a nifty new technology site called SugarString.

headline: Seeing a New Future for French Nuclear Site, After the Toxic Dust Has Settled
abstract: Scientists blew up more than half a ton of uranium in 2,000 explosions at a fort only 14 miles from the Eiffel Tower. Now there is disagreement over whether the site should be redeveloped.
lead_paragraph: VAUJOURS, France — On a walk through her garden on a recent afternoon, Lisa Leclerc ran a Geiger counter over her mushrooms.

headline: Blacks, Obama and the Election
abstract: Race has been the great immeasurable in this presidency, and the midterms are no exception.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s name won’t be on any ballots Tuesday, but he will most certainly be on them in spirit — a fact that many Republicans are trumpeting and some Democrats are hoping to downplay.

headline: Money and Judges, a Bad Mix
abstract: There’s growing evidence that donations to judicial campaigns may be influencing rulings.
lead_paragraph: Follow the money: It’s a truism of the mechanics of political influence, and no less so when that money is spent on judicial campaigns.

headline: As Tours Evolve, Indoor Tennis Tournaments Are Increasingly Being Left Out
abstract: While there used to be a month or more of indoor tournaments leading into the year-end finals, the tours’ detours into Asia after the U.S. Open have created a more abbreviated season.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Professional tennis is increasingly finding sunshine preferable to having a roof overhead. In 1994, 25 men’s and 16 women’s tour events were held indoors. Two decades later, those numbers are 15 and 8.

headline: Dell’s Life After Wall Street
abstract: A year after a grueling fight with the investor Carl C. Icahn, Michael S. Dell says he is very happy to have the computer company that bears his name back to himself.
lead_paragraph: A year after spending $24.9 billion taking his computer company private, Michael S. Dell is gleeful to have his namesake firm to himself. And to be done with Wall Street.

headline: Business vs. Economics
abstract: Why corporate chieftains and money managers give such bad advice about the economy.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The Bank of Japan, this country’s equivalent of the Federal Reserve, has lately been making a big effort to end deflation, which has afflicted Japan’s economy for almost two decades. At first its efforts — which involve printing a lot of money and, even more important, trying to assure investors that it will keep printing money until inflation reaches 2 percent — seemed to be going well. But more recently the economy has lost momentum, and last week the bank announced new, even more aggressive monetary measures.

headline: One Day in an Elevator With Obama, Then Out of a Job
abstract: An armed security guard at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, held out as an example of a failing Secret Service, wonders why he was fired after operating an elevator for President Obama.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Kenneth Tate toiled for years as a construction worker and corrections officer, and he has no doubt that his last job — working as a $42,000-a-year private security guard at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention — was the best he ever had.

headline: Woman in Iran Sent to Prison After Going to Sports Event
abstract: An Iranian-British woman was arrested and later detained after attending a men’s volleyball match. Now she has received a one-year prison sentence.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — An Iranian-British woman who was arrested in June when she tried to attend a men’s volleyball match in Iran has been sentenced to a year in prison, her lawyer said Sunday.

headline: Europe Shifts on Priorities for Telecoms
abstract: The new European Commission is prioritizing more investment and costlier Internet and cellphone services rather than affordability and antitrust concerns.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Poor cellphone and Internet service is a fact of life in many parts of Europe.

headline: Previewing the N.B.A.’s Game of the Week: Spurs at Rockets
abstract: After beginning the season 3-0, Houston will face its first real test on Thursday when it hosts the league’s defending champion, San Antonio.
lead_paragraph: Houston is 3-0, but the record and attendant statistics are largely meaningless. The Rockets have beaten the Lakers, the Celtics and the Jazz, the worst team in the Western Conference last season. It still feels blasphemous to say, but the traditional powers are nearly automatic wins for any contender. The Rockets’ first real test comes at home Thursday (8 p.m. Eastern on TNT), when they face the defending champion San Antonio Spurs.

headline: Bernard Spitzer, New York Developer and Philanthropist, Dies at 90
abstract: He long supported his son Eliot’s political career and at times became entangled in it, as well as built a real estate empire over more than five decades.
lead_paragraph: Bernard Spitzer, a prominent New York City real estate developer and philanthropist who supported his son Eliot’s political career and at times became entangled in it, died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 90.

headline: Independent Journal Review Website Becomes a Draw for Conservatives
abstract: With a mix of entertaining topics and politics, the two-year-old Independent Journal Review has web traffic that exceeds more seasoned right-wing sites.
lead_paragraph: ALEXANDRIA, Va. — Last week, with the midterm elections fast approaching, the conservative website Independent Journal Review was not focused on the control of the Senate or crucial statehouse races. Instead, it led its home page with a gruesome beheading on Long Island and a video of a belligerent drunk being arrested at a Dallas airport.

headline: Falling Short on Concussion Warnings
abstract: Most N.C.A.A. member schools have a plan in place, as required, but serious gaps remain.
lead_paragraph: More than four years after the National Collegiate Athletic Association held its first concussion conference, some universities are still not doing enough to protect athletes from the lasting effects of head injuries.

headline: A Prisoner Swap With Cuba
abstract: Trading three spies for Alan Gross, the American subcontractor jailed in Cuba, is the best way to clear a path to a new bilateral relationship.
lead_paragraph: Nearly five years ago, authorities in Cuba arrested an American government subcontractor, Alan Gross, who was working on a secretive program to expand Internet access on the island. At a time when a growing number of officials in Washington and Havana are eager to start normalizing relations, Mr. Gross’s continued imprisonment has become the chief obstacle to a diplomatic breakthrough.

headline: Un canje de presos con Cuba
abstract: Canjear tres espías por Alan Gross, el subcontratista estadounidense detenido en Cuba, podría despejar el camino hacia una nueva relación bilateral.
lead_paragraph: Hace casi cinco años, las autoridades en Cuba detuvieron a Alan Gross, un subcontratista del gobierno estadounidense que estaba trabajando en un sigiloso proyecto para expandir el acceso a Internet en la isla. Aunque un creciente número de líderes en Washington y La Habana parecen estar ansiosos por comenzar a normalizar la relación entre los países, el caso de Gross se ha convertido en el principal obstáculo para lograr un avance diplomático.

headline: Alan Gross and the Cuban Five: A Timeline
abstract: To understand why The Times’s editorial board is calling for a prisoner swap with Cuba, it is instructive to revisit the history of both cases.
lead_paragraph: To understand why The Times’s editorial board is calling for a prisoner swap with Cuba, it is instructive to revisit the history of both cases. The spies Cuba wants back were detained long before Alan Gross, an American contractor, was arrested in Havana in 2009. But soon after, officials on the island came to see him as the the best pawn to get their prisoners back.

headline: Arriving Where He’s Supposed to Be
abstract: Until he was 14, Giants defensive end Damontre Moore had lived most of his life in a  rough-edged Dallas neighborhood. Then his mother boldly moved the family to a leafy suburb.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Until he was 14, Damontre Moore lived most of his life in a hardscrabble, rough-edged Dallas neighborhood. Then his mother boldly moved the family to a leafy suburb 35 miles to the northeast.

headline: Keeping Mexico’s Revolutionary Fires Alive
abstract: A small teacher training college has been at the center of a national crisis in Mexico since 43 of its students disappeared after a violent confrontation with the police.
lead_paragraph: AYOTZINAPA, Mexico — In their first week of school, the new students eat and drink nothing but beans and cold coffee, and spend sleepless days cleaning up the buildings and planting crops.

headline: Colts (5-3) at Giants (3-4)
abstract: Matchups to watch in Monday’s game between the Giants and the Colts.
lead_paragraph: 8:30 p.m., ESPN

headline: Washington Redskins Draw Protesters in Minnesota Before Losing in Griffin’s Return
abstract: Thousands gathered at a rally before Sunday’s game, which was the first that Robert Griffin III has played in since he was sidelined with a dislocated left ankle.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — The protesters arrived from as far as Oklahoma, Montana and New Mexico. They marched across the University of Minnesota campus on a cold, sunny morning to a grassy patch outside TCF Bank Stadium, near the Minnesota Tribal Nations Plaza, which honors the state’s 11 federally recognized Native American tribes.

headline: Egyptian Journalists Protest Editors’ Pledge Not to Criticize State
abstract: Hundreds objected to a statement from top newspaper editors that they would refrain from publishing articles critical of the government during a time of fierce fighting with militant extremists.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Hundreds of Egyptian journalists objected on Sunday to a pledge by newspaper editors to refrain from publishing reports critical of the government, calling the curb on freedom of expression “a victory for terrorism.”

headline: Obama Lending Support, but Only in Democratic Bulwarks
abstract: With both parties seeing an edge for Republicans going into Tuesday’s balloting, President Obama made a final push through Democratic strongholds.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — President Obama implored voters to cast aside cynicism and turn out to elect Democrats who are “fighting for you,” making his closing argument before midterm congressional elections that will shape the contours of his final two years in office.

headline: Winning Powerball and Lottery Numbers for Nov. 2, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Showdown of Rivals and Passers Ends in Rout
abstract: New England’s fifth straight victory was a surprisingly easy one, with the Patriots scoring 24 straight points to help Tom Brady improve to 9-3 in regular-season matchups with Peyton Manning.
lead_paragraph: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — The marquee games on New England’s schedule are getting to be like pretty much every other game at Gillette Stadium: unending torment for whichever unfortunate team happens to be playing the Patriots.

headline: Montana Judicial Race Joins Big-Money Fray
abstract: Judicial races have been evolving into another political battleground for big money, as seen in Montana, where a sitting State Supreme Court justice is running in the most expensive race on state record.
lead_paragraph: HELENA, Mont. — In a coffee shop on Last Chance Gulch, a woman approached Mike Wheat to say she was planning to knock on doors for him. “It’s getting pretty brutal out there,” she said.

headline: The Mind of the Undecided Voter
abstract: From Louisiana to Kansas, voters are still struggling to make up their minds about which candidates to vote for in the midterm elections Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: From Louisiana to Kansas, voters are still struggling to make up their minds about which candidates to vote for in the midterm elections Tuesday.

headline: Popular Demand
abstract: HuffingtonPost.com is the most visited political website according to eBizMBA. eBizMBA derives its visitor numbers based on data from Alexa, Compete and Quantcast.
lead_paragraph: HuffingtonPost.com is the most visited political website according to eBizMBA. eBizMBA derives its visitor numbers based on data from Alexa, Compete and Quantcast.

headline: Condé Nast Moves Into the World Trade Center as Lower Manhattan Is Remade
abstract: The media company will occupy floors 20 through 44 in 1 World Trade Center, confirming a shift in the culture downtown.
lead_paragraph: For two days last weekend, moving trucks shuttled a total of 2,800 orange crates crammed with files, photographs and books from a Times Square office tower downtown to the tallest skyscraper in North America, 1 World Trade Center.

headline: Iraqis Prepare ISIS Offensive, With U.S. Help
abstract: The goal is to break the Islamic State’s hold over northern and western Iraq, and establish the Iraqi government’s control over Mosul and other population centers by the end of 2015.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Iraqi security forces, backed by American-led air power and hundreds of advisers, are planning to mount a major spring offensive against Islamic State fighters who have poured into the country from Syria, a campaign that is likely to face an array of logistical and political challenges.

headline: Rubber-Legged Red Bulls Make a Charge
abstract: Downing D.C. United, 2-0, the Red Bulls gained the upper hand in the conference semifinals series.
lead_paragraph: HARRISON, N.J. — Since 1996, the first year of Major League Soccer, D.C. United has been the guys in the black hats — actually the all-black uniforms — first against the MetroStars and now against the Red Bulls.

lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio called the New York Police Department “the best it’s ever been.” “Extraordinary things are happening,” he said.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It’s the first Tuesday of the month, and the book club is in session. Between bites of their lunch buffet, two dozen members leaf through classics, best sellers and the latest nonfiction.

lead_paragraph: HARTFORD — At the It’s a Gee Thang barbershop in the neglected North End, the clippers have gone quiet and the only hair being sculpted sits on a plastic mannequin’s head.

lead_paragraph: Jeffrey Vanchiro has been a conspicuous fixture at Barclays Center since the Nets began playing there two years ago, but his signature game-day outfit did not come together until a few games into the inaugural season.

abstract: Ryan McDonagh, the Rangers’ captain, on Saturday separated his left shoulder, the same one he injured last April and missed five games.

lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo gets strong marks for his aggressive response to the Ebola virus. But some voters are unsettled by what they view as his back-room, bullying style and by a federal investigation into an anti-corruption commission he established.

headline: In New York and Connecticut, a Last Big Push for Votes
abstract: Candidates worked hard on the trail as Tuesday’s election loomed.
lead_paragraph: As Tuesday’s election loomed, candidates worked hard over the weekend. Below are some snapshots from the campaign trail.

headline: Senate Control May Be Decided by Runoff Votes in Louisiana and Georgia
abstract: If control of the Senate is not settled on Tuesday, strategists foresee a frenzy that would make a runoff look like Iowa during a presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — As the 2014 midterm elections barrel toward a close and Democrats brace for losses around the country, operatives in both parties are already preparing for likely runoff elections here and in Georgia — and the chance that control of the Senate will not be determined until next year.

headline: Stung Last Year, Retailers and Shippers Retool for the Holiday Season
abstract: Americans are expected to buy a record $89 billion worth of gifts online, a 13 percent jump over the 2013 season.
lead_paragraph: This year, Santa’s reindeer will be huffing and puffing their way from the North Pole, carrying more than they usually do.

headline: Parishioners Mourn as Mergers are Announced
abstract: Throughout the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, many parishes will be merged and their churches effectively shut down in the largest reorganization in the history of the archdiocese.
lead_paragraph: Throughout the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, many parishes will be merged and their churches effectively shut down in the largest reorganization in the history of the archdiocese.

abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Monday, November 3, 2014.
lead_paragraph: NATIONAL

headline: What’s On TV Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (CMT) WINTER’S BONE (2010) Jennifer Lawrence, above, received her first Oscar nomination for her role as Ree Dolly, a teenager living in the Ozarks of southwestern Missouri who goes in search of her meth-cooking father after he puts up the family home to cover his bail and disappears. But her efforts to find him place her in a terrible dilemma: either betray the code of silence that keeps her clan proudly on the wrong side of the law or face destitution. The harshness in Debra Granik’s “regional-realist morality tale,” based on the novel by Daniel Woodrell, “is not there to illuminate a sociological condition,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “Something more primal, almost Greek in its archaic power, is at stake in ‘Winter’s Bone,’ and its visual and emotional starkness do not feel like simple badges of authenticity.”

headline: Who Would Have Health Insurance if Medicaid Expansion Weren't Optional
abstract: A new data set suggests that more than three million people would have gained health insurance across 24 states if the Supreme Court had ruled differently.
lead_paragraph: A new data set suggests that more than three million people would have gained health insurance across 24 states if the Supreme Court had ruled differently.

headline: Investigators in Virgin Galactic Crash Focus on Tail Booms
abstract: The Virgin Galactic space plane that broke apart on Friday shifted early into a high-drag configuration that is designed to slow it down.
lead_paragraph: The Virgin Galactic space plane that broke apart over the Mojave Desert on Friday shifted early into a high-drag configuration that was designed to slow it down, federal accident investigators have said.

headline: Portraits of Those Braving Ebola
abstract: Daniel Berehulak’s “Braving Ebola” is a result of inspiration, improvisation and a determination to offer viewers a new way to see, and feel, an urgent story.
lead_paragraph: Hours from the nearest city, in a clearing in the Liberian jungle, a small army of doctors, nurses, sprayers and gravediggers is battling the Ebola virus at a clinic run by an American medical charity. Weeks of sustained, hard-hitting coverage by the photographer Daniel Berehulak chronicled in detail the urgent, grim and unrelenting work. But after more than two months, how could he find a new way to tell the story?

headline: Diageo and Cuervo Swap Brands: Bushmills Whiskey for Don Julio Tequila
abstract: Diageo will gain full control of the fast-growing tequila brand from Casa Cuervo, which in turn will take on the Irish whiskey.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Diageo and the family that makes Jose Cuervo tequila have agreed to swap two of their best-known brands, giving the global spirits maker a bigger presence in the tequila market.

headline: Programmers Deploy Cellphone Game to Support Hong Kong Protests
abstract: A Hong Kong-based mobile software company has created an app that allows people to indulge in both gaming and an interest in all things Occupy, featuring protesters facing off against thugs, police officers with tear gas and pepper spray, anti-Occupy demonstrators wearing blue ribbons and a character who resembles the city’s chief executive, Leung Chun-ying.
lead_paragraph: Hong Kong residents love their mobile phone games. Look around in any subway car and you’ll see passengers launching birds, constructing imaginary cities or battling zombies.

lead_paragraph: Below are the first six paragraphs of the Oct. 31 article “10 Minutes, and They’re Gone.”

headline: Hong Kong Court Charges British Banker With Murder of 2 Women in Apartment
abstract: The victims were found in Rurik George Caton Jutting’s high-rise apartment in the city’s Wan Chai district.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A 29-year-old British banker was charged with two counts of murder on Monday in the killings of two women at his high-rise apartment.

headline: For French Giant Publicis, a Deal for Sapient to Expand in Digital Ads
abstract: Publicis Groupe says it believes its cash deal with Sapient, a consulting firm based in Boston, will help it compete with Facebook and Google.
lead_paragraph: The French advertising giant Publicis Groupe said on Monday that it had agreed to pay $3.7 billion in cash for Sapient, a marketing and consulting company based in Boston, as it seeks to become a stronger digital competitor against Internet powerhouses like Google and Facebook.

headline: What Work Went Into Reaching Your Most Difficult Goals?
abstract: What sacrifices did you make to achieve something meaningful?
lead_paragraph: There is an old adage, “good things come to those who wait.” But good things also come to people who work hard and stay focused on their goals.

headline: The Right to Say ‘God’ Divides a Diverse Nation
abstract: According to government orders and rulings by the country’s Islamic councils, the word for God in the Malay language cannot be used by people of other faiths.
lead_paragraph: KOTA KINABALU, Malaysia — As the students knelt in a circle at a Christian kindergarten near the shores of the South China Sea, a 6-year-old girl in pigtails read out a chapter from a children’s Bible: “Sepuluh hukum dari Allah” — God’s Ten Commandments.

headline: HSBC Hurt by $1.69 Billion in Legal and Other Costs
abstract: The British bank said that its third-quarter profit rose 7 percent, but it took a charge to cover potential legal costs associated with regulatory investigations.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British bank HSBC said on Monday that its third-quarter profit rose 7 percent, but its results, like those of many of its European investment banking rivals, were dragged down by $1.69 billion in legal and restructuring costs.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: The Counties to Watch on Election Night
abstract: With the country so polarized, many once-bellwether counties no longer deserve that name. Here are the ones to follow this year.
lead_paragraph: It used to be that you could turn to a key bellwether county and get a sense of where a state might go on Election Night. For decades, the bellwethers were a host of fairly conservative but traditionally Democratic rural counties. For much of the last decade, historically Republican suburban areas in Franklin, Ohio, or Orange, Fla., fit the bill.

headline: Here’s How to Avoid Getting Fooled on Election Night
abstract: Rumors and misinformation run rampant in the absence of real news. Be especially wary of exit polls, fraud claims and biased experts.
lead_paragraph: Election Day creates a vast information vacuum — millions of Americans (and hundreds of reporters) are trying to figure out the outcome of an event before it has been decided. With few useful indicators of what is actually happening at the polls, rumors and misinformation can run rampant. Here’s how to avoid getting fooled.

headline: New York Today: A Hint of Winter
abstract: Monday: A chilly morning, the last day before elections, and vanishing billboard poetry.
lead_paragraph: Good chilly Monday morning to you.

headline: Why Do We Still Care About the Confederate Flag?
abstract: Is the Confederate flag a symbol of the South’s oppressive past, a celebration of fallen ancestors or a badge of honor for rural America?
lead_paragraph: In the run-up to the midterm elections, with deep divides between conservatives and liberals, observers say political debates are losing substance. It’s an increasingly “us-versus-them” kind of scene, the “Divided States of America,” as NBC’s Mark Murray put it in a recent article.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Nov. 3, 2014
abstract: On Mondays, we publish a Times photo without a caption, headline or other information about its origins. Join the conversation by posting about what you see, and why. A live discussion is offered from 9 a.m. to 2 p.m. Eastern time.
lead_paragraph: Updated: Nov. 4, 2014

headline: Preparing for ‘APEC War’ in China
abstract: A bevy of government orders are kicking in to prepare Beijing for the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation meeting beginning on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: What price a successful international meeting? Smoggy skies, upended work routines, an abruptly weaned baby — everything, it seems, is worth it, as a bevy of government orders kicks in to prepare the Chinese capital for the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation meeting beginning on Wednesday. “Prepare for the APEC war,” said an item on the website of the Committee of China Energy Conservation Association.

headline: Following Up on the Job Candidate Who Was ‘Checking Out the Waitress’
abstract: Almost every commenter who responded to the post advised that the candidate should not be hired.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, I wrote a post that asked whether a female boss can manage a chauvinist. I’ve struggled with this issue for many years, and from your replies it’s clear that other women have endured similar experiences.

lead_paragraph: LabCorp agreed on Monday to buy Covance for about $6.1 billion in cash and stock, taking control of one of the biggest providers of contract medical research.

headline: Russia Continues to Train and Equip Ukraine Rebels, NATO Official Says
abstract: After Sunday’s elections in breakaway regions of Ukraine, Western officials are increasingly concerned that the Kremlin may be trying to establish an enclave outside Kiev’s control.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hundreds of Russian troops are still training and equipping separatists in Ukraine, NATO’s top military commander said Monday, activities that are heightening tensions with the West and Ukraine’s government that were aggravated by Sunday’s elections in the breakaway regions of eastern Ukraine.

headline: Altice Offers to Buy Telecom Assets in Portugal for $8.7 Billion

lead_paragraph: LONDON — Altice, the European cable and mobile service provider, has set its sights on Portugal.​

headline: Manual on How to Spot a Spy Circulates in an Increasingly  Wary China
abstract: A guide to counterespionage aimed at the average Chinese citizen is undergoing a surge in popularity online, just as Beijing passes a stricter national security code, with an emphasis on countering threats from abroad.
lead_paragraph: “On the Internet, nobody knows you’re a dog.” Or an American spy. Or a “hostile foreign force.” So says the “China Folk Counterespionage Manual,” a “how to spot a spy” guide circulating on the Internet.

headline: Tom Ford Explains Those Pasties, and More
abstract: The designer’s blog post acknowledges his fallibility, and it works to his advantage.
lead_paragraph: There’s something a little surprising on Tom Ford’s website, and it reads kind of like… honesty.

headline: Daily Report: The New Dell
abstract: On Tuesday, Michael S. Dell will try to persuade people that his company is about far more than the personal computers and computer servers it has been known for, with products intended for things as varied as the cloud computing networks of global enterprises and handy personal devices.
lead_paragraph: A year after spending $24.9 billion taking his computer company private, Michael S. Dell is gleeful to have his namesake firm to himself. And to be done with Wall Street, Quentin Hardy reports.

headline: Morning Agenda: A Book Club That Pays
abstract: A Republican book club draws Wall Street lobbyists. | Diageo and Cuervo announce a brand swap. | A British banker is charged in Hong Kong with two murders. | Behind the discovery of a security breach at JPMorgan Chase.
lead_paragraph: On the first Tuesday of the month, a book club gathers at a Republican social parlor in the Capitol’s shadow. But unlike a local library’s book club, this event doubles as a political fund-raiser, Ben Protess and Eric Lipton write in DealBook. For the book club’s members ‒ an A-list of lobbyists from banks and insurance companies ‒ the main attraction is access to the House Financial Services Committee. The cost of admission is a campaign donation to whichever committee member is playing host that month.

headline: 99 Counties, 24 Hours, 2 Candidates, 1 State (Iowa)
abstract: Joni Ernst and Bruce Braley start the campaigning early on Tuesday and will end it late.
lead_paragraph: Joni Ernst is one-upping “the full Grassley,” the 99-county tour of Iowa named after the state’s Republican senator, Charles E. Grassley, by taking a 24-hour, round-the-clock final campaign push. It will end with the casting of her ballot in her hometown of Red Oak, Iowa, on Tuesday.

headline: Drawing Food in London
abstract: Menus at a beloved restaurant that are as mouthwatering as the meals.
lead_paragraph: Menus at a beloved restaurant that are as mouthwatering as the meals.

headline: Little Opposition Seen in Some Votes to Raise State Minimum Wages
abstract: As voters in red states like Alaska and Arkansas decide at the polls whether to raise their minimum wage, those against an increase concede that the measures are likely to pass.
lead_paragraph: In state after state, labor unions and community groups have pushed lawmakers to raise the minimum wage, but those efforts have faltered in many places where Republicans control the legislature.

headline: Romanian Premier Faces Runoff in Presidential Race
abstract: Prime Minister Victor Ponta will face Klaus Iohannis, the ethnic German mayor of Sibiu, on Nov. 16.
lead_paragraph: BUCHAREST, Romania — Prime Minister Victor Ponta of Romania, the favorite to replace Traian Basescu as president, has been forced into a runoff after failing to capture the majority of votes in an election over the weekend that was closer than expected.

headline: Daily Clip Report
abstract: Daily Clip Report is a collection of articles about the media and The Times that is emailed each day to senior executives and newsroom managers here.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

headline: Migrants Die After Boat Capsizes North of Bosporus Off Turkey
abstract: At least 24 migrants were said to have died from a boat carrying 43 to the European Union from the Middle East, the Turkish Coast Guard said.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — A boat carrying 43 migrants to the European Union from the Middle East capsized north of the Bosporus in the Black Sea on Monday, killing at least 24 people, the Turkish Coast Guard said.

headline: 1 World Trade Center, a Pillar of Resilience, Is Open for Business
abstract: Condé Nast workers began moving into the new building, built on the lot where the twin towers once stood, and signs of a resurgence were everywhere.
lead_paragraph: More than 13 years after a terrorist attack destroyed the twin towers — soaring symbols of New York City’s might, financially and structurally — the first employees of the first tenant in the building erected to take their place arrived on Monday for their first workday.

headline: At Autumn Festival in Paris, William Forsythe Is Everywhere
abstract: A program brought to the Théâtre de la Ville by Dresden’s Semperoper Ballett highlighted some of the American choreographer’s important early works.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The choreographer William Forsythe is ubiquitous here this fall. He is the focus of this year’s Festival d’Automne, with five companies presenting his work around the city over three months, and the Paris Opera Ballet offered a Forsythe program over three weeks in September and October. The appetite for Mr. Forsythe’s work in Paris, and the crowds that have flocked to the shows, point to the anomaly in his reputation. In Europe, where he has spent his whole professional career, he is an artistic giant; in his native United States, he is regarded with far less reverence.

headline: Election Day Information for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut
abstract: Details about polling hours and other election information for the three states.
lead_paragraph: Polls in New York State are open on Tuesday from 6 a.m. to 9 p.m. Voters will elect the governor, lieutenant governor, attorney general and comptroller and decide three ballot questions. There are also races for Congress, the State Legislature and local offices. Voter information is available from the State Board of Elections at vote-ny.com or by calling 1-800-FOR-VOTE (1-800-367-8683); from the New York City Board of Elections at vote.nyc.ny.us or by calling 1-866-VOTE-NYC (1-866-868-3692), or from the New York Public Interest Research Group at 212-822-0282. Voters who have problems can visit Election Protection at 866ourvote.org or call 1-866-OUR-VOTE (1-866-687-8683).

headline: The Trials and Tribulations of Being ‘That Child’
abstract: Every family seems to have one caregiver who has to look out for parents as they age; some also have out-of-state siblings who do not.
lead_paragraph: A friend of mine, Sarah, recently put her mother, who has early-stage dementia, into a nursing home in the town where she lives. Moving her mother out of the family home after 40 years was anything but easy, but neither was driving an hour each way to check on her well-being several times a week.

headline: Four States Vote to Raise Minimum Wage
abstract: Minimum wage measures passed in Arkansas, Nebraska, South Dakota and Alaska.
lead_paragraph: This story has been updated to reflect election results.

headline: Tenement Memories
abstract: Rita Ascione is one of the last living residents of the Lower East Side building that is now the Tenement Museum. She recently returned with her daughter, Valerie Carmody, to see her old apartment.
lead_paragraph: Rita Ascione is one of the last living residents of the Lower East Side building that is now the Tenement Museum. She recently returned with her daughter, Valerie Carmody, to see her old apartment.

headline: The Economy, and Voters’ Perception of It, Are Two Very Different Things
abstract: The actual state of the economy has a bigger effect on presidential elections than on congressional ones. But perceptions are important in both cases.
lead_paragraph: We learned on Thursday that the United States economy expanded at a healthy rate this summer, growing 3.5 percent from July through September. This growth — as robust as it is — is unlikely, however, to influence how the president’s party fares this week at the polls. Midterm election results are not as directly related to objective economic conditions as presidential election outcomes are, something we discussed yesterday at The Upshot.

headline: Emotion Is Not the Best Medicine, Ebola Case Further Shows
abstract: People ideally would base medical decisions on an unbiased evaluation of evidence. But people are often irrational and don’t rely on facts.
lead_paragraph: Breast cancer, tick bites, gluten, G.M.O.s, artificial sweeteners, shark attacks — and now Ebola.

headline: Virgin America Aims to Raise $300 Million in I.P.O.
abstract: The low-cost airline, which is partially owned by Richard Branson’s Virgin Group, set a price range of $21 to $24.
lead_paragraph: Virgin America has moved a step closer to a Wall Street debut, filing a price range on Monday for its planned initial public offering.

headline: D.C., Oregon and Alaska Vote to Legalize Marijuana
abstract: Legalization got strong support in D.C. and won by lesser margins in two other states. A medical marijuana proposal in Florida did not get the required 60 percent.
lead_paragraph: This article has been updated with election results.

headline: Softcore Logos
abstract: Fashion’s most explicit calling card submits to some subtlety.
lead_paragraph: Fashion’s most explicit calling card submits to some subtlety.

abstract: Four states are voting to lift the minimum wage on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The future of the Senate is not the only thing at stake in Tuesday’s midterm election.

headline: 1889: A Visit to Constantinople
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The German emperor and empress visited Turkey in 1889.
lead_paragraph: CONSTANTINOPLE — The Emperor and Empress this morning [Nov. 3] attended divine service in the German church at Pera. They were escorted by a regiment of lancers. The people lining the route manifested much enthusiasm, particularly the Germans. It is estimated that nearly two hundred thousand people were in the streets to see their Majesties pass. The Sultan and his Ministers have spared no trouble or expense to combine a gorgeous ceremonial with the comfort of the Emperor and Empress, and these in turn have evinced an almost juvenile pleasure in what they have seen, whilst the attitude of the general public has been all that could be desired. On Tuesday the Emperor and Empress will take their departure, their intention being to return to Berlin by way of Venice. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Nov. 4, 1889

headline: 1939: Allies Seize Contraband
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The Allies seized contraband in 1939.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — More than a half-million tons of contraband suspected of being destined for Germany has been intercepted and detained by the Allied contraband control organizations, the Ministry of Economic Warfare announced today [Nov. 3]. Up to October 12, seizures by the French amounted to 150,000 tons, it was stated. The British figures for October 14 to October 28 show 63,000 tons intercepted, raising the British total for the first eight weeks of the war to more than 400,000 tons. Petroleum products detained since the war began amount to 87,540 tons, including 12,000,000 gallons of gasoline. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Nov. 4, 1939

headline: Warner Music to Offer $100,000 Classical Prize
abstract: The Warner Music Prize will recognize a musician between 18 and 35 who demonstrates exceptional promise.
lead_paragraph: The Warner Music Group is establishing the Warner Music Prize, a new classical music award, to be given annually to a musician between 18 and 35 who demonstrates exceptional promise during a season in which his or her performances are seen by a jury of classical musicians and music industry executives. The award includes a $100,000 cash prize, and a recording offer from Warner Classics.

headline: U.S. Fines Automakers Hyundai and Kia for Misstating Mileage
abstract: Hyundai and Kia, owned by the Hyundai Motor Group, will pay a combined $300 million for overstating their fuel-economy standards.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the largest-ever penalty for a violation of the Clean Air Act, the Korean automakers Hyundai Motor and Kia Motors will pay the federal government a combined $300 million as part of a settlement for overstating vehicle fuel-economy standards on 1.2 million cars, Justice Department and Environmental Protection Agency officials said on Monday.

headline: Yildiz of Turkey to Buy British Cookie Maker United Biscuits
abstract: Yildiz, the owner of the cookie and chocolate maker Ulker Biskuvi Sanayi and Godiva chocolate, beat out the Kellogg Company and Burtons Biscuits. The deal is said to be valued at about $3.2 billion.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The private equity owners of United Biscuits said on Monday that they had agreed to sell the British cookie maker to Yildiz Holding of Turkey.

headline: What to Wear This Week: Nov. 3
abstract: Explore keeping time with a device other than your smartphone.
lead_paragraph: Daylight savings, the final confirmation that summer’s longer days and warmer weather are again behind us, has ended. We’ll spend more time in darkness with no less to do. Explore keeping time with a device other than your smartphone.

headline: Shaky Times, Strong Journalism
abstract: The Times is beset with business challenges but despite the turbulence, some recent investigative stories have been hard-hitting.

headline: Verbatim: Joni Ernst on Being Compared to Taylor Swift
abstract: Joni Ernst responds to Senator Tom Harkin, who compared her to Taylor Swift.
lead_paragraph: — Joni Ernst, the Republican candidate for United States Senate, responding to incumbent Senator Tom Harkin, a Democrat who is retiring from the Senate this year, who said of Ms. Ernst: “I don’t care if she’s as good-looking as Taylor Swift or as nice as Mr. Rogers, but if she votes like Michele Bachmann, she’s wrong for the state of Iowa.”

headline: Taylor Swift Announces World Tour and Pulls Her Music From Spotify
abstract: The tour will run from May through October, in North America and Europe.
lead_paragraph: For Taylor Swift fans, Monday morning brought a whiplash-inducing pair of announcements: news of a world tour, and a defensive statement from Spotify saying that Ms. Swift had removed all of her music from the service.

headline: A Holiday Shop for Art Connoisseurs, Rare Sigmar Polke Works and More From the Art Calendar
abstract: Plus, the screenwriter Paul Schrader curates a show, Henri Samuel’s furniture and more events in the week ahead.
lead_paragraph: T’s list of happenings worth visiting in the week ahead.

headline: The Plot to Burn Chicago
abstract: In the fall of 1864, Union officers foiled a series of Confederate conspiracies to attack the Second City.
lead_paragraph: At the beginning of November 1864, Col. Benjamin J. Sweet, the commandant of the Camp Douglas prisoner-of-war camp near Chicago and commander of the Army post of Chicago, began to hear reports of large numbers of men arriving on trains from Southern Illinois and now milling around the streets and saloons. Detectives also noted that men known to be officers in the Confederate States Army lodged in Chicago hotels. Army detectives working for other commands likewise confirmed the presence of rebel officers in the city.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
abstract: Del Monte picks MRY’s San Francisco office as its digital and social agency of record.
lead_paragraph: Adaptly, New York, hired four employees. They are Logan Moore, director for strategic accounts; Bryn Sanders, vice president for revenue, East; Miles Rutter, account executive; and Charles Timko, director for strategic accounts.
