headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
abstract: A violin piece backing a Splenda commercial gets some recognition.
lead_paragraph: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: R.B.S. to Aid British Police in Unraveling Financial Crimes
abstract: The Royal Bank of Scotland will provide the expertise of bankers in areas like stocks and markets, financial instruments, cybertechnology and foreign languages.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The Royal Bank of Scotland, which is 81 percent owned by the British government, has negotiated a new deal, though not one that is likely to help the bank in the league tables. The bank signed a “landmark agreement” to help the City of London police tackle complex financial crime.

headline: Dvorak’s ‘New World’ Manuscript to Revisit New York
abstract: The composer’s manuscript for the “New World” Symphony is to be displayed in New York, more than 120 years after the Philharmonic played its premiere.
lead_paragraph: Antonin Dvorak’s “New World” Symphony holds an important place in American music, not only because Dvorak composed it during his residency in this country, but also because he meant it to show that great symphonic music could be built on themes from various American folk traditions. The New York Philharmonic gave the work its premiere in 1893, but when Dvorak returned to Prague in 1895, he took the manuscript of the symphony with him. It has remained in Prague ever since, and is currently in the collection of the Czech National Museum. But it is returning to New York, briefly, for the first time.

headline: Today in Small Business: ‘The Yelp of Business Software’
abstract: The rush is on for a new breed of marijuana capitalist in New York. How even a profitable company can run out of cash. Binding referendums in several red states Tuesday would raise the state minimum wage above the $7.25 an hour mandated by the federal government.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: More Voters Track Candidates by Smartphone
abstract: New research suggests that you are probably reading this piece of political news on your smartphone, by way of Facebook or Twitter.
lead_paragraph: New research suggests that you are probably reading this piece of political news on your smartphone, by way of Facebook or Twitter.

headline: With One Band Left Behind, Gregg Allman to Tour
abstract: Mr. Allman announced a solo tour, just a week after what was billed as the last-ever Allman Brothers Band concert.
lead_paragraph: The Allman Brothers Band played the final show of its 45-year career barely a week ago, but Gregg Allman is apparently not planning to sit back and reflect on the band’s accomplishments.

headline: Daniel Finkel’s Circle-Toss Game
abstract: By math educator Daniel Finkel, a puzzle that’s child’s play. Can you figure it out?
lead_paragraph: Our puzzle this week was suggested by Daniel Finkel, a regular Numberplay contributor who also runs, along with Katherine Cook, Math for Love — the Seattle-based team committed to revitalizing math education. Let’s check out —

headline: Prudential Center Ads Declare, ‘There’s No Place Like Home ... and Watch for Flying Pucks’
abstract: A campaign focuses on the comfortable living-room atmosphere of an arena.
lead_paragraph: In introducing its first brand campaign, the Prudential Center is inviting the estimated two million people who attend events each year at the arena in downtown Newark — and the millions of others who have yet to buy tickets — to feel right at home there.

headline: The Carter Family: “The Storms Are on the Ocean” (1927)
abstract: This song is used with permission from Bear Family Records. Visit bear-family.com to learn more about their re-releases of the Victor and Bluebird recordings.
lead_paragraph: This song is used with permission from Bear Family Records. Visit bear-family.com to learn more about their re-releases of the Victor and Bluebird recordings.

headline: Sonya Yoncheva to Star as Mimi in Met ‘Bohème’
abstract: The season is shaping up to be a big one for Ms. Yoncheva, who stepped in as a replacement in last season’s “Rigoletto” and will do the same in “La Traviata” in January.
lead_paragraph: It was an operatic domino effect, or prima donna-mo effect. Anna Netrebko’s decision to withdraw from a series of performances in Munich means that New York will be getting a new Mimi in “La Bohème” later this month: Sonya Yoncheva.

headline: When Bruce Met Ruhs
abstract: The latest edition of Bruce Weber’s annual anthology series includes a standout piece on the sculptor Kris Ruhs.
lead_paragraph: For 14 years, the famed photographer Bruce Weber has published an annual anthology of essays, poetry and images that celebrates, with his trademark patriotism, everything from canines to cops to mountain climbers. The book’s latest edition, “Affairs of the Heart,” includes stories about the late novelist and C.I.A. agent Peter Matthiessen as well as one on a boarding school for equestrians, and features contributions by art-world heavyweights like Francesco Clemente. Most notable, however, is a piece on Kris Ruhs, the New York City-born sculptor responsible for the amazing three-story chandelier at the Azzedine Alaïa store in Paris and the silver jewelry sold by Carla Sozzani (his companion and frequent collaborator) at her Milan boutique-bookstore-gallery-cafe 10 Corso Como. Weber had previously encountered Ruhs’s workspace when he shot the actress Marion Cotillard in the sculptor’s Paris studio four years ago. “The day just flew by,” Weber recalls, “because we were so enchanted by the things that Kris had made.”

headline: Tracking House Elections and the G.O.P. Majority
abstract: Political analysts expect the G.O.P. to add 5 to 12 seats, with the likeliest outcome, estimated by YouGov, being six.
lead_paragraph: This article has been updated with election results.

headline: On Election’s Eve, G.O.P. Is Confident, but Voters Are Sour
abstract: Republicans entered the end of the most expensive midterm campaign in American history confident they will take control of the Senate, but voter interest is low.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The most expensive midterm campaign in American history stumbled into Election Day on Tuesday with voters’ interest at record lows and their divisions deep over what they want their government to do in President Obama’s final two years.

headline: Gate Bearing Notorious Slogan Is Stolen From Dachau Site
abstract: The police said at least two adults must have been involved, noting that they not only had to cut the heavy object loose, but also had to heave it over an outer gate.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — A heavy metal gate bearing the Nazis’ infamous concentration camp slogan, “Arbeit Macht Frei” (Work Sets You Free), was stolen under cover of darkness on the weekend from the memorial site at the old Nazi camp of Dachau, just north of Munich, in what looked like a carefully planned crime, the authorities in Bavaria said on Monday.

headline: Foraging for a Pastry Chef in the Bronx
abstract: Malcolm Livingston II prepares to make the jump from WD-50 to being Noma’s pastry chef.
lead_paragraph: Hanging out on the corner of Fordham Road and the Grand Concourse in the Bronx will not yield a lot of clues about how Malcolm Livingston II first got fired up about food.

headline: Last Missing Body Is Found in Costa Concordia Wreck
abstract: The remains of Russel Rebello, a waiter, were found by workers dismantling the hulk of the ship that struck rocks off an island near Tuscany in 2012.
lead_paragraph: ROME — The last missing person from the wreck of the cruise ship Costa Concordia was finally accounted for on Monday when workers dismantling the hulk found the remains of Russel Rebello, a waiter on the ship.

headline: A Builder Swears He’ll Stay at 49 Employees to Avoid the Mandate. Unless He Grows.
abstract: The comment, an owner says, was an expression of his frustration with just how complex the Affordable Care Act is and how the resulting confusion has paralyzed his company.
lead_paragraph: Todd Hawkins is a Virginia home builder who insists that the big plans he has for his business are not so big that they will put him in the path of the Affordable Care Act. That, anyway, is what he told You’re the Boss readers when he commented on a recent post about determining whether a company is subject to the law’s employer mandate. “I can promise we won’t go over 49 employees, so A.C.A. will affect employment, at least by one company,” he wrote. “Mine.”

headline: Malpractice Reform Won’t Do Much to Reduce Health Spending
abstract: Evidence shows that “defensive medicine” practiced by doctors fearing lawsuits is only a tiny bit of overall care.
lead_paragraph: Among the many ideas that have been tossed around for decades on how to bring down health care spending, none may be as well known as malpractice reform. Many people believe that it’s the key to removing waste from the health care system and making the practice of medicine better. But a growing body of evidence shows that belief is most likely mistaken.

headline: Robust Sales of Jeeps and Rams Lead Big Increase for Chrysler
abstract: Chrysler posted an October sales increase of 22 percent, while Ford was down 1.7 percent and General Motors was essentially flat.
lead_paragraph: Falling gas prices accelerated American car buyers’ increasing love affair with trucks and sport utility vehicles last month. And a big beneficiary was Chrysler, whose Jeep and Ram pickup brands continued their surge, leading the automaker to double-digit sales gains even as its crosstown rivals General Motors and Ford Motor fell flat.

headline: In Bill Gross’s Latest Investment Letter, a Sly Reference to ‘Adaptation’
abstract: Now at Janus Capital, the famous money manager takes his usually eccentric prose style to a head-scratching new level .
lead_paragraph: Analyzing an investment essay by Bill Gross usually requires a background in finance.

headline: A Family’s Truth About Marijuana Depends on the Family
abstract: Reporting on five families with wildly divergent ideas about what to teach their kids about marijuana, from no tolerance to offering to roll the joints and make nachos.
lead_paragraph: What is the truth about marijuana? As long as I’ve been an adult I’ve known people who smoke marijuana, and they certainly don’t fit the stereotype of skater dude or hippie holdover.

headline: Banks’ Cycle of Misbehavior
abstract: The government has imposed billions of dollars in penalties on the big banks for wrongdoing. But, Peter J. Henning writes in the White Collar Watch column, that may not be enough to change banks’ behavior.
lead_paragraph: The latest round of global banks’ taking reserves for investigations into manipulation of foreign exchange rates calls to mind Ronald Reagan’s famous retort in a debate: “There you go again.” It seems to be a never-ending refrain: Misconduct by traders and bankers is uncovered, multiple regulators mount investigations, and then millions, or even billions, of dollars in penalties are paid, all to little apparent effect.

headline: When the Message on Marijuana Is Still ‘Just Say No’
abstract: While some families may approach it differently, there remain excellent reasons for taking a ‘Just Say No’ stance on marijuana use and teens — without expecting that to end the conversation.
lead_paragraph: As I wrote last month, marijuana and its use has changed. The laws around it are in flux. As of now, marijuana for medical usage is legal in 23 states and the District of Columbia; two of those states, Colorado and Washington, have legalized recreational use as well (for people 21 and over). The stuff itself, usually green, leafy and intended for smoking, is increasingly available in a form that I have also written about before: It may be a drug, but it can look like candy.

headline: When Celebrities Get Political, What’s a Reporter to Do?
abstract: Adam Nagourney, The Times’s Los Angeles bureau chief and its former chief national political correspondent, weighs what happens to a story when celebrities get involved.
lead_paragraph: When Rob Reiner decides he wants to campaign to prevent commercial development in an affluent Southern California city, should he be subjected to the same scrutiny that a reporter might give a professional politician? Adam Nagourney, The Times’s Los Angeles bureau chief and its former chief national political correspondent, weighs what happens to a story when celebrities get involved.

headline: Abortion, Marijuana and the Minimum Wage: Ballot Measures Around the Country
abstract: Red states may vote to raise the minimum wage, and the marijuana experiment continues.
lead_paragraph: Tuesday’s voting will not only determine control of the Senate, but the fate of important ballot initiatives in several states. Among them:

headline: In a Lisbon Band, Echoes From Afar
abstract: The Portuguese ensemble Buraka Som Sistema shows the melting-pot side of this former colonial power.
lead_paragraph: LISBON — On a warm, moonlit fall night, the band Buraka Som Sistema took the stage at an outdoor festival here. Andro Carvalho, known as Conductor, shouted out lyrics while Blaya, the band’s high-octane frontwoman, leapt around in sparkly short shorts. “From Portugal to the world!” Kalaf Angelo, another vocalist, called out to the crowd, which ranged from pre-teenagers to retirees, all dancing to the intense beat.

headline: Inside a Jumping Spider’s Brain
abstract: Inside the poppy-seed brain of a stalk-and-pounce predator.
lead_paragraph: Inside the poppy-seed brain of a stalk-and-pounce predator.

headline: Unexpected Complexity in a Spider’s Tiny Brain
abstract: A group of researchers has found a way to study the delicate and complex brain of a jumping spider.
lead_paragraph: Here is something to keep arachnophobes up at night.

headline: Outside the Spring/Summer 2015 Shows in Kiev
abstract: A glimpse at what some of the guys and gals were wearing in and around the city’s just-concluded fashion shows.
lead_paragraph: A glimpse at what some of the guys and gals were wearing in and around the city’s just-concluded fashion shows.

headline: Big Law Firms Win 47% of Corporate Legal Spending, Analysis Finds
abstract: But adjusted for inflation, gross revenue per lawyer fell in 2013 to its lowest level since 1998, a new analysis by the American Lawyer found.
lead_paragraph: The nation’s top-grossing 200 law firms have garnered about half of the country’s business spending on legal services since 2010, according to a new analysis by the American Lawyer, which tracks data at the biggest law firms.

headline: W.H.O. Assails Delay in Ebola Vaccine
abstract: Dr. Margaret Chan, the director general of the health organization, said the drug industry’s drive for profit was one reason no vaccine had yet been found for Ebola.
lead_paragraph: The leader of the World Health Organization criticized the drug industry on Monday, saying that the drive for profit was one reason no vaccine had yet been found for Ebola.

headline: Jonathan P. Hicks, Former Reporter for The New York Times, Dies at 58
abstract: Mr. Hicks covered big business and all levels of New York politics for over 24 years as a reporter for The Times.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan P. Hicks, who covered big business and all levels of New York politics, including the campaigns of three New York City mayors, over 24 years as a reporter for The New York Times, died on Monday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 58.

headline: A Bach Organ Marathon Set for St. Peter’s in Manhattan
abstract: Paul Jacobs will be joined by 19 of his current and former students to play all of Bach’s organ works — more than 200 — over two days this month.
lead_paragraph: The organist Paul Jacobs once played all of Bach’s organ works – more than 200 pieces – in an 18-hour marathon. That was 14 years ago, in Pittsburgh, and no, enough time has not elapsed that Mr. Jacobs is ready to do it again. But when he began discussing a Bach marathon with WQXR, as part of the station’s monthlong “Bachstock: 30 Days of Peace and Music,” he came up with an alternative plan: he would play some works himself, and would invite 19 of his current and former students to play the rest.

headline: Papers That Are Most Cited Aren’t Most Famous
abstract: The top three of the 100 most highly cited scientific papers are biochemical techniques for quantifying the amount of protein in a solution.
lead_paragraph: It may never win a Nobel Prize, but a 1951 paper describing a way to detect protein levels in a solution tops a new list of the 100 most cited research papers.

headline: What Determines the Sex of a Persimmon
abstract: Most plants have both male and female organs, but not the permission tree. Now researchers have figured out what causes an individual to be either male or female.
lead_paragraph: Most plants are hermaphroditic: Each individual has male and female organs. An exception is the persimmon tree, which belongs to a small group of plants that are dioecious — that is, one sex or the other. Females need pollen from male trees to produce fruit.

headline: A Gene by Any Other Name
abstract: All human genes get three-to-five-letter symbols for easier reference, though they may seem abstract.
lead_paragraph: Q. WHAT IS THE LOGIC IN NAMING HUMAN GENES? THE NUMBER-LETTER COMBINATIONS SEEM ABSTRACT AND HARD TO REMEMBER.

headline: LabCorp’s $6.1 Billion Deal Doesn’t Pass the Test
abstract: The strategic logic behind the acquisition of the clinical trial outsourcing company Covance is hazy, Robert Cyran of Reuters Breakingviews writes.
lead_paragraph: Laboratory Corp of America’s $6.1 billion deal for Covance tests positive for value destruction.

headline: Type(writer) Casting: A Book of Short Stories From Tom Hanks
abstract: Tom Hanks, who loves typewriters, has sold a short story collection inspired by them.
lead_paragraph: Tom Hanks has a thing for typewriters. He’s been collecting them — “for no particular reason,” he says — since 1978. A few months ago he released a writing app called the Hanx Writer, which mimics the sounds and motions of an old-school typewriter on an iPad. Last summer he wrote an essay for The New York Times about his favorite models, riffing on the relative merits of a Hermes 2000, a 1930s Remington or a mid-century Royal.

headline: Immigration and Obama’s Swoon
abstract: Where the immigration issue fits into the weakening of the president.
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column considered various possible and partial explanations for President Obama’s long year of low approval ratings, which seem likely to help cost his party control of the Senate tomorrow. The big four I considered were structural forces (the idea that polarization and gridlock alone suffice to send most second-term presidents regressing to the low 40s), the essential mediocrity of our “recovered” economy, the continued unpopularity of Obamacare, and foreign policy (where the president’s approval ratings have fallen hard) as a kind of synecdoche for larger doubts about the administration’s basic competence. Obviously there are many more factors one could consider, but since I write about the issue frequently I thought I should explain why I didn’t include immigration, another area where the president’s approval numbers have plummeted as his administration has stumbled in various ways over the last year.

headline: Walkabout: Investigation of Virgin Galactic Crash Continues
abstract: A weekly capsule of travel news curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: Questions Arise An investigation into the crash of a Virgin Galactic space plane that killed one pilot continues, focusing on the failure of a technical configuration. (The New York Times)

headline: Eurozone Bank Regulator to Follow Up on Stress Tests
abstract: The tests’ shortcomings will be addressed as the Single Supervisory Mechanism legally assumes overall authority in the eurozone on Tuesday, Danièle Nouy said.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The eurozone’s new chief bank overseer insisted on Monday that a review of lenders completed by the European Central Bank last month was rigorous and credible. But she conceded that there were shortcomings that would have to be corrected later.

headline: Unidentified Drones Are Seen Above French Nuclear Plants
abstract: Security officials are investigating drone flights that have buzzed illegally over more than a dozen nuclear facilities across France.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Security officials are investigating a mysterious wave of drone flights that have illegally buzzed over more than a dozen nuclear plants across France, raising security concerns around the country’s primary energy source.

headline: Ways to Increase Your Wealth When Your Income Is Flat
abstract: Lowering debt, adding to savings or learning more about investing are strategies that can help combat stagnant income.
lead_paragraph: Income inequality can arise from a number of things, like gender, race, social class and education. We know it’s an issue. But the most recent recession revealed what may be an even bigger problem: wealth inequality.

headline: A Beloved Downtown Men’s Wear Boutique Launches Its Own Label
abstract: C.H.C.M., the influential Bond Street shop, is debuting an in-house range of refined wardrobe essentials.
lead_paragraph: “I’m quite aware of what’s out there, and I never wanted to be like other stores,” Sweetu Patel says about C.H.C.M., his celebrated New York men’s wear boutique which has just launched its debut collection. The Indian-born, British-raised Patel — a former furniture designer and one-time founder of the high-end contemporary-furniture gallery Citizen: Citizen — started C.H.C.M. out of his Brooklyn apartment in August 2008, went online seven months later and opened his Bond Street location four years ago. Despite the nod to tradition in its name (which originally stood for “Clinton Hill Classic Menswear”), the store has offered ahead-of-the-curve clothing from the beginning. Its stock, which included brands like Ovadia & Sons, Arpenteur and Sunspel when they were virtually unknown, often blurred the lines between sportswear, workwear and suiting.

headline: As New York Election Looms, Cuomo and Astorino Rally Voters
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, widely expected to win a second term, addressed supporters in Times Square as his challenger, Rob Astorino, campaigned at numerous events.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo rallied supporters in the heart of Manhattan and across upstate New York on Monday, while his Republican challenger, Rob Astorino, hunted for votes across New York City and its northern suburbs, as time waned on a campaign with little suspense anywhere but in the State Senate.

headline: De Niro, in Tax Fight, Wins Little Sympathy From His Neighbors
abstract: Robert De Niro’s long challenge to his $6 million property assessment in Gardiner, Ulster County, deepened when his lawyers appealed a court ruling against him.
lead_paragraph: GARDINER, N.Y. — Even after he bought his 78-acre property here, expanded it and turned it into a veritable Bobbywood, Robert De Niro never made much of an impression on this town of 5,800 farmers, climbers, laborers and second-home owners.

headline: Democrats Try Scaring Voters to the Polls
abstract: A report cards sent to Democrats evaluates their voting records.
lead_paragraph: Much of this year’s election has been defined by Republicans trying to scare people into voting their fears, but Democrats are also capable of frightening voters to the polls. Their most visible attempt arrived in mailboxes in New York and elsewhere over the last few weeks in the form of a “report card” grading voters on their participation in past elections.

headline: Donmar Warehouse to Broadcast a Politics Play on British Election Night
abstract: As part of the spring season of the Donmar Warehouse in London, “The Vote” will be broadcast on May 7, the day of the general election in Britain.
lead_paragraph: The Donmar Warehouse in London will broadcast a live performance of “The Vote,” a new collaboration between Josie Rourke and James Graham, on May 7, the day of the British general election. “The Vote” will be part of the Donmar’s 2015 spring season, announced Monday, which includes a revival of Patrick Marber’s “Closer,” directed by David Leveaux and starring Nancy Carroll, Oliver Chris, Rufus Sewell and Rachel Redford.

headline: Google Search Data Suggests Voter Turnout Will Not Surge
abstract: In 2012, web searches on “vote” and “voting” helped predict turnout. This year, search volumes are roughly at the same level as four years ago.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, a graduate student in economics named Seth Stephens-Davidowitz discovered that Google searches including the word “vote” or “voting” could help predict turnout. In places where searches for those terms were more common, turnout was higher, even after controlling for other factors, like voter-registration rates and early-vote volume.

headline: Sting and Renée Fleming Among Thanksgiving Day Parade Performers
abstract: Macy’s announced that the giant character balloons and floats will be joined by the opera star Renée Fleming, the Broadway singer Idina Menzel and Sting.
lead_paragraph: You’ve seen them on stage and on television, singing and dancing. Now you can see them ride in slow-moving vehicles, waving, in the vicinity of giant Spider-Man and Thomas the Tank Engine balloons. Macy’s has announced the celebrity roster for the 88th annual Thanksgiving Day Parade, on Nov. 27, and it’s an eclectic bunch. Along with the opera star Renée Fleming, the Broadway singer Idina Menzel, Muppets from Sesame Street, acrobats from Cirque du Soleil and the television chef Sandra Lee, there will be a contingent of rock stars of various stripes, including Sting, Nick Jonas, Kiss and the Vamps.

headline: A Cookbook That Veers From the Usual Recipe
abstract: From the chef Gabrielle Hamilton, a 576-page cookbook as idiosyncratic as her restaurant, Prune.
lead_paragraph: Since 1999, when the chef Gabrielle Hamilton put Triscuits and canned sardines on the first menu of her East Village bistro, Prune, she has nonchalantly broken countless rules of the food world. The rule that a successful restaurant must breed an empire. The rule that chefs who happen to be women should unconditionally support one another. The rule that great chefs don’t make great writers (with her memoir, “Blood, Bones and Butter”).

headline: Tavern on the Green Hires Jeremiah Tower as Head Chef
abstract: Jeremiah Tower, a star of California cuisine, will helm the kitchen of the troubled legend.
lead_paragraph: Jeremiah Tower, one of the originators of California cuisine, is best known for creating the restaurant Stars, a big, bright celebrity magnet in San Francisco that pulsed with energy and grossed millions from the mid-1980s to the late ’90s.

headline: Recalled G.M. Cars Remain Unrepaired
abstract: Owners of vehicles recalled over a faulty, and deadly, ignition switch problem say they are still waiting for repairs and sometimes get the runaround at dealerships.
lead_paragraph: YONKERS — Nearly nine months after General Motors began recalling millions of its cars for a dangerously defective ignition switch, almost half of the vehicles still have not been fixed.

headline: Marie-Chantal’s Lifestyle Site, Online Gifting Resources and More
abstract: All the places you should be hanging out online this week.
lead_paragraph: Every week, T rounds up five captivating online destinations you should be visiting often.

headline: A Debatable Fix for Young Eyes
abstract: Eye specialists are offering young patients a contentious remedy to nearsightedness: contact lenses that temporarily flatten the cornea overnight and correct vision for the next day.
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, CALIF. — Lilith Sadil, 12, climbs into an examination chair here at the Myopia Control Center at the University of California. “Do you know why you are here?” asks Dr. Maria Liu, an optometrist.

headline: An Exhibition of French Fries, Ramen for the Dining Room and More Food News
abstract: White truffles abound, special black bread to buy and good news about ramen and French fries.
lead_paragraph: To Visit: Yes, We’ll Have Fries With That

headline: Monday Motorsports: Lady’s Night in Vegas
abstract: Erica Enders-Stevens wins an N.H.R.A. event, improving her chances of becoming the first female Pro Stock car champion; Hamilton extends his Formula One lead.
lead_paragraph: Erica Enders-Stevens, aiming to become the first female Pro Stock champion in the car class took a giant step toward that goal Sunday evening by winning the National Hot Rod Association nationals event in Las Vegas. Enders-Stevens, who had set a new track speed record in qualifying, beat the defending series champion Jeg Coughlin in the final round and regained the series points lead. It was her fifth nationals victory of the season.

headline: Southwest Airlines Offers Free Streaming of Apple’s Beats Music Service
abstract: Airplanes are becoming more like electronics retail stores, where you can try things out before you buy them. The latest example is Southwest Airlines, which will allow passengers to test-drive Apple’s Beats Music free on its aircraft equipped with an Internet connection.
lead_paragraph: Airplanes are becoming more like electronics retail stores, where you can try things out before you buy them. The latest example is Southwest Airlines, which will allow passengers to test-drive Apple’s Beats Music for free on its aircraft equipped with an Internet connection.

headline: Strays Leading the Soviets Into Space
abstract: Throughout the 1950s and into the ’60s, canine cosmonauts were plucked from the streets and alleys of Moscow, trained at the Institute of Aviation Medicine, then vaulted toward the heavens in satellites.
lead_paragraph: There are two reasons I couldn’t resist this book. First, I was born on Oct. 5, 1957, one day after the Soviet Union slingshotted the first satellite, Sputnik, into space. So I’m a true space age baby who grew up obsessed with the Cold War grudge match to reach the moon.

headline: What If You Had a Hypothetical Question That Needed Answering?
abstract: Randall Munroe, a former NASA roboticist who achieved viral fame with his website xkcd.com, has a new book called “What If? Serious Scientific Answers to Absurd Hypothetical Questions.”
lead_paragraph: Randall Munroe, a former NASA roboticist who achieved viral fame with his website xkcd.com, has a new book called “What If? Serious Scientific Answers to Absurd Hypothetical Questions.”

headline: Supreme Court Weighs Status of Jerusalem for Passports
abstract: The Supreme Court heard arguments on whether Congress may order that American children born in Jerusalem may be listed as born in Israel.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday considered the status of Jerusalem, which Solicitor General Donald B. Verrilli Jr. told the justices was “the most vexing and volatile and difficult diplomatic issue that this nation has faced for decades.”

headline: Pictures of the Day: Turkey and Elsewhere
abstract: Photographs from Turkey, the United States, India, Italy and Indonesia.
lead_paragraph: Photographs from Turkey, the United States, India, Italy and Indonesia.

headline: Stacey Snider Named Co-Chairwoman of 20th Century Fox
abstract: Formally confirming what has long been known in Hollywood, Fox said that Stacey Snider was joining it after a bumpy tenure as chief executive of DreamWorks Studios.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — On Monday, 20th Century Fox announced what Hollywood has long known: Stacey Snider, after a bumpy tenure as chief executive of Steven Spielberg’s DreamWorks Studios, will join Fox as co-chairwoman.

headline: He’s Glad You Asked
abstract: How much power can one Yoda output? What happens if you tried to hit a baseball pitched at 90 percent the speed of light? There’s a book with the answers.
lead_paragraph: While giving a physics talk for high school students five years ago at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Randall Munroe could tell that his audience was, in his words, “not totally with me.”

headline: Loss of SpaceShipTwo, Withholding Judgment on Latrines, ‘Black Holes’ of Yore
abstract: Letters to the editor and online comments.
lead_paragraph: Spaceflight

headline: Why I’m Not Voting in the Midterms
abstract: Voters share the reasons that they will not show up at the polls Tuesday for the midterm elections. Are you voting? Tweet using the hashtag #whyvotemidterms and tell us why.
lead_paragraph: Voters share the reasons that they will not show up at the polls Tuesday for the midterm elections. Are you voting? Tweet using the hashtag #whyvotemidterms and tell us why.

headline: Albums by Neil Young, Bette Midler and Miguel Zenón
abstract: Neil Young, Bette Midler and Miguel Zenón have all released new music.
lead_paragraph: NEIL YOUNG

headline: New York Parking Alert: Alternate-Side Rules Suspended Tuesday
abstract: The regulations will not be in effect because of the election.
lead_paragraph: Because of Election Day, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Tuesday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: Placebo May Aid Baby’s Cough
abstract: Need help for a baby’s cough? In some cases the best treatment may be a placebo.
lead_paragraph: Need help for a baby’s cough? In some cases the best treatment may be a placebo.

headline: The Fortepiano, Shy and Playful by Turns
abstract: The fortepianist Kristian Bezuidenhout led Juilliard students in a concert of orchestral works by Mozart and J. C. and W. F. Bach.
lead_paragraph: Musicians tune their instruments before the start of each concert. But audience members sometimes need to tweak their mode of listening, too, as they settle in for a performance. This is especially true of programs featuring the fortepiano, an instrument that speaks so much more softly than the modern piano our ears are accustomed to.

headline: How the Speed of Response Defined the Ebola Crisis
abstract: How did the timing of the large-scale intervention in the Ebola outbreak affect the number of reported cases today?
lead_paragraph: How did the timing of the large-scale intervention in the Ebola outbreak affect the number of reported cases today?

headline: Liturgy and a Tale, Revived and Sprawling as Ever
abstract: The production of “Mass: A Theatre Piece for Singers, Players and Dancers,” at Queens College on Sunday, encapsulated its composer, Leonard Bernstein.
lead_paragraph: Leonard Bernstein’s “Mass: A Theatre Piece for Singers, Players and Dancers” begins with a 12-tone Kyrie played from the four corners of the theater. A guitar-strumming Celebrant enters in street clothes, then there’s a jazzy “Alleluia,” like a 1950s radio jingle. A marching band enters, flanked by a chorus, dancers, a children’s choir and another choir, backed by a full symphony orchestra — and that’s just in the first 15 minutes, before the rock band, the blues band and, near the two-hour mark, a climactic mad scene.

headline: Political Feeding Frenzy as a Turning Point
abstract: “All the Truth Is Out,” by Matt Bai, makes the case that the Gary Hart scandal of 1987 left a lasting scar on America’s political life.
lead_paragraph: In his thoughtful new book, “All the Truth Is Out,” the journalist Matt Bai says he can pinpoint the exact moment when the rules of politics changed, and “the nation and its media took a hard turn toward abject triviality.”

headline: A Quiet Week at the Box Office for Broadway
abstract: Ticket sales were sluggish for many of the 34 shows running on Broadway.
lead_paragraph: Most holiday weekends are a boon for Broadway shows, given the spike in tourists and families buying tickets, but Halloween isn’t a night made for sitting inside theaters. Last weekend’s combination of Halloween, the New York City marathon and the change in daylight savings time (which can throw off routines) hurt box-office business for most Broadway musicals and plays, which earn the bulk of their weekly grosses during performances between Fridays and Sundays. Broadway grossed $23.5 million for a total of 34 shows last week, or about 10 percent less than the previous week (when 32 shows were running), according to box office data released on Monday.

headline: A Midterm Election Quiz: Testing Our Political Assumptions
abstract: Do you know who’s a Republican — or a liberal?
lead_paragraph: Is President Obama a Republican? Was Richard M. Nixon our last liberal president? Claims like these (from Bruce Bartlett, in a cover story for The American Conservative, and Noam Chomsky, in a discussion at The Huffington Post, respectively) challenge what we think we know about political labels and about our presidents and their records in office.

headline: Scene City: Fashion, Film and Art Collide at Lacma Gala
abstract: Leonardo DiCaprio, Quentin Tarantino, Kanye West, Kim Kardashian and Culture Club are among the guests at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: Leonardo DiCaprio, Quentin Tarantino, Kanye West, Kim Kardashian and Culture Club are among the guests at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art.

headline: The Marijuana Industry Comes to New York and Everyone Wants In
abstract: The medical marijuana industry is coming to New York. John Leland and Mosi Secret, reporters for Metro, wrote an article on Sunday about the people who are eager to get involved in what will become a multimillion-dollar business. Here, John describes the experience.
lead_paragraph: The medical marijuana industry is coming to New York. John Leland and Mosi Secret, reporters for Metro, wrote an article on Sunday about the industry after attending the East Coast Cannabis Business Expo, Educational Conference and Regulatory Summit, their first glimpse of the people who are eager to get involved in what will become a multimillion-dollar business. Here, John describes the experience.

headline: Inquiry Faults Liberia Force That Fired on Protesters
abstract: An independent human rights panel found that Liberian security forces fired directly into a crowd of civilians who were protesting a quarantine this summer.
lead_paragraph: MONROVIA, Liberia — Liberian security forces fired with “complete disregard for human life” into crowds of civilians protesting a blanket Ebola quarantine over the summer, killing one teenager and seriously wounding another young man, according to the first independent investigation of the deadly clashes.

headline: In Performance | Danner and Lange
abstract: Blythe Danner and Eric Lange play mother and son at odds in a scene from Donald Margulies’s play “The Country House.” The show is on Broadway at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater through Nov. 23.
lead_paragraph: Blythe Danner and Eric Lange play mother and son at odds in a scene from Donald Margulies’s play “The Country House.” The show is on Broadway at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater through Nov. 23.

headline: Nov. 3, 2014 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Turkey, Syria, India and the United States.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Turkey, Syria, India and the United States.

headline: Pests in the Apartment, but No Ants in the Pants
abstract: Benjamin Kunkel’s “Buzz” follows a playwright and his girlfriend in their South Brooklyn apartment.
lead_paragraph: The devastation of the climate, the ravages of capitalism, the marginal status of theater — that’s a lot to cram into a single South Brooklyn apartment. “Buzz,” the debut play by the novelist and critic Benjamin Kunkel, takes place in the loft where Tom (Trevor Kluckman) struggles to write a play, while his girlfriend, Sasha (Jeri Silverman), awaits the birth of their baby.

headline: Writer, Rejected for a Retail Job, Is Embraced and Vilified on Facebook
abstract: A story of a failed marriage and financial implosion provokes equal and opposite reactions on Facebook. Why?
lead_paragraph: It was the usual Sunday night Facebook scroll. To be honest, what really caught my eye on Deborah Copaken’s “How I Got Rejected From a Job at The Container Store” was the image, which was of containers. I like containers; clearly, many of us do, thus The Container Store.

headline: Treating Disease, and Spreading It?
abstract: In the case of Ebola, caretaking is a job of the highest risk, and doctors and nurses are innately terrible at even the basics of infection control.
lead_paragraph: Most infectious diseases reinforce that appealing “them and us” schism that so often deludes health care professionals. They, our patients, have it, their contacts out in the world are at risk for getting it, and we, their caregivers, are safely removed from the whole thing. Not Ebola: We have met the patients, and they are us.

headline: The Indestructible Beat of Tamino
abstract: The Isango Ensemble has adapted “The Magic Flute” for South African accents, rhythms and interpretations at the New Victory Theater.
lead_paragraph: Less glockenspiel, more drumming! A very different sort of “The Magic Flute” took the stage at the New Victory Theater on Sunday afternoon in front of an attentive and appreciative family audience. This two-hour adaptation of Mozart’s fairy tale opera was presented under the Xhosa title “Impempe Yomlingo” by the South African Isango Ensemble, a company that recruits performers from townships in the Cape Town area and presents classics from the Western canon in an updated, African context.

headline: Ideas to Improve Financial Lives, From the Treasurer’s Office
abstract: State and local treasurers have introduced innovative programs and policies aimed at lifting the fortunes of low- and moderate-income people.
lead_paragraph: Known primarily as number crunchers and tax collectors, treasurers for state and local governments traditionally were limited to activities like processing payrolls, managing budgets, safeguarding pensions and being the target of accountant jokes.

headline: How to Watch the Elections Like an Expert
abstract: Many people follow vote counts that ignore the geographic mix of those votes. It doesn’t have to be that way, and The Upshot can help.
lead_paragraph: On election night, knowing who is ahead isn’t enough.

headline: Fighting an Epidemic With Hands Tied
abstract: Hundreds of care personnel have braved the terrifying prospect of infection to respond to the Ebola emergency in West Africa. Thousands more will be needed in the future, but will they go?
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hundreds of government and civilian workers of all stripes, and thousands of military personnel, have braved the terrifying prospect of infection to respond to the Ebola emergency in West Africa. And thousands more will be needed for an effort that is expected to go well into 2015.

headline: On the Infield or Onstage, a Diva Is but a Click Away
abstract: The mezzo-soprano Joyce DiDonato is a leader in using digital media to change the worlds of opera and classical music.
lead_paragraph: No, Maria Callas did not tweet. But if there were any question about how digital media are changing the worlds of opera and classical music, consider the last few weeks in the life of the great American mezzo-soprano Joyce DiDonato.

headline: How Do You Measure the Mood of the Electorate?
abstract: A correspondent covering the midterm elections says gauging the mood of the electorate is largely a matter of gut feeling.
lead_paragraph: The congressional reporter Jonathan Weisman is covering the midterm elections. We asked him how he gauges voters’ moods.

headline: Sprint’s Tough Quarter Highlights Lost Promise of T-Mobile Deal
abstract: Even before Sprint abandoned its pursuit of T-Mobile, analysts said the embattled wireless carrier needed a huge shot in the arm — like that attempted merger — to reverse its fortunes.
lead_paragraph: Even before Sprint ended its long pursuit of T-Mobile US, analysts and investors had come to believe that the embattled wireless carrier needed a huge shot in the arm — like that attempted merger — to reverse its fortunes.

headline: The Day in Pictures
abstract: Get caught up on Monday’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Get caught up on Monday’s top stories.

headline: For Viewers Who Set Their Sights High and Low
abstract: Shows like “Hair Jacked” and “How to Be a Grown Up” offer viewers alternatives to major network programming.
lead_paragraph: The World Series is over, and the first cancellations of the new TV season have been recorded, so that must mean it’s time for the mid-autumn television malaise: After weeks of being pummeled with a lot of new shows, suddenly everything seems drab. But that’s why we have 300 channels now instead of just three.

headline: A Tiny Stumble, a Life Upended
abstract: After a fall, life is upended in an instant — a sudden loss of independence, an awkward reliance on family and friends, and a new level of fear for those who fall, and their contemporaries.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Joan Rees, 79, had hardly been ill a day in her life. Her biggest problem was arthritis, mostly in her knees, but at home in San Francisco she walked every day and she traveled frequently.

headline: Steps to Avoid an Accident
abstract: Experts who have studied falls wish that people would take measures to protect themselves much as they do against heart disease or viral infections.
lead_paragraph: Preventing a fall, and the resulting injuries, isn’t simply a matter of being more careful. Indeed, experts who have studied falls wish that people would take measures to protect themselves much as they do against heart disease or viral infections.

headline: Intersection | Carnegie Hill, Manhattan
abstract: Agostino Magni, an Italian businessman, says he follows a family tradition of wearing custom-made shirts, monogrammed with his initials, and he chooses pocket squares to match.
lead_paragraph: Agostino Magni, an Italian businessman, says he follows a family tradition of wearing custom-made shirts, monogrammed with his initials, and he chooses pocket squares to match.

headline: At a Napa Festival, Taking the Appellation Trail
abstract: The Flavor! Napa Valley festival includes workshops, tastings and dinners at local wineries.
lead_paragraph: If a food festival features food from celebrity alumni of the Culinary Institute of America and is hosted in California’s Napa Valley, there’s a good chance it’s going to appeal to travelers.

headline: Election Day: The Mood of America
abstract: Readers discuss coverage of the midterm elections and President Obama’s popularity.

headline: Skipping the Front Desk, and Checking In With a Click
abstract: In a bid to help harried travelers save time at check-in, a number of major brands are experimenting with letting guests use their phones to unlock their rooms.
lead_paragraph: People use smartphones today to do everything from pay for coffee to board a plane. Now, a growing number of hotels want guests to be able to unlock their guest rooms with their phones.

headline: Judicial Confirmations
abstract: Nan Aron, president of the Alliance for Justice, says a Republican-controlled Senate won’t necessarily stymie confirmation of judges.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Humans Raise Penguins as Well as Penguins Do
abstract: Penguin chicks hand-raised by researchers and released back into the wild survived at about the same rate as wild penguins, says a new study from the University of Cape Town.
lead_paragraph: Penguin chicks hand-raised by researchers and released back into the wild survived at about the same rate as wild penguins, says a new study from the University of Cape Town. With the endangered African penguin population dropping rapidly since 2001, conservationists have been rescuing and raising abandoned chicks that would otherwise have starved. Writing in the journal PLOS One, the researchers said that of the 1,320 chicks adopted by conservationists, more than 1,100 were rereleased in 2006 and 2007, and thrived similarly to wild penguins.

headline: Luring Private Investors
abstract: Steve Dreyer of Standard & Poor’s suggests ways to attract private funding for infrastructure projects.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: How Citi Bike Succeeds
abstract: Susi Wunsch, a reader, writes that it has helped legitimize bicycling as a public transportation option.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: H.I.V. Patients in Yemen Face Hospital Evictions
abstract: Patients infected with H.I.V. are being ordered out of hospitals in Yemen, even when they are in dire need of care, a human rights group says.
lead_paragraph: Patients infected with H.I.V. are being ordered out of hospitals in Yemen, even when they are in dire need of care, a human rights group says.

headline: Remember Chocolate
abstract: A reader calls it “decadent,” but asks why not.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Value of Older Workers
abstract: Ruth Finkelstein of the Columbia University Mailman School of Public Health responds to a Working Life column.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Bill Nye on the Science of Creation
abstract: In his new book, “Undeniable,” the veteran television science showman Bill Nye talks about chicken knees, the importance of understanding evolution in an increasingly technologically based society and why he thinks creationists are preoccupied with death.
lead_paragraph: In his new book, “Undeniable,” the veteran television science showman Bill Nye talks about chicken knees, the importance of understanding evolution in an increasingly technologically based society and why he thinks creationists are preoccupied with death.

headline: A Fight for the Young Creationist Mind
abstract: Bill Nye, well known as a televised educator and sometimes firebrand for science, follows a very public debate for evolution against creationism with a new book on the divide.
lead_paragraph: In February, William Sanford Nye, better known as Bill Nye the science guy, stepped onto a stage in Kentucky and faced down a hostile crowd in a debate that pitted evolution against creationism. It wasn’t his first time in the ring in science’s corner. In recent years, Mr. Nye has transitioned from the zany, on-screen face of an educational show on PBS, which ran from 1993 to 1998, to a hardened warrior for science on cable news programs and speaking tours of colleges and universities around the United States.

headline: Video: How to Watch Election Night
abstract: David Leonhardt, editor of The Upshot, offers an animated look at the six states to watch as Democrats try to beat the odds and maintain control of the Senate.
lead_paragraph: A guide to following the races on Election Day.

headline: How to Watch Election Night
abstract: David Leonhardt, editor of The Upshot, offers an animated look at the six states to watch as Democrats try to beat the odds and maintain control of the Senate.
lead_paragraph: David Leonhardt, editor of The Upshot, offers an animated look at the six states to watch as Democrats try to beat the odds and maintain control of the Senate.

headline: Under Investigation, JPMorgan Increases Its Potential Legal Costs
abstract: The bank added $1.3 billion to its estimate of the amount of legal costs it might face for current investigations.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase recently added $2.4 billion to its estimate of the amount of legal costs it may face, the latest sign that investigations into the possible manipulation of the currency market are gaining momentum.

headline: Scenes From the Hello Kitty Convention in Los Angeles
abstract: The Sanrio character, who turns 40 this year, was the star of a suite of events that began on Wednesday at MOCA’s Geffen Contemporary. The photographer Jacqueline DiMilia captured the style scene in and around the show.
lead_paragraph: Red carpets and celebrities are a dime a dozen in L.A., but this past weekend the city feted an icon unlike any other. Hello Kitty, who turns 40 this year, was the star of a suite of events that began on Wednesday with the opening of the first annual Hello Kitty Convention. The carnival-meets-trade fair drew more than 26,000 Sanrio disciples dressed to the nines, plus several stars from the Nickelodeon set and the superfan Katy Perry, to MOCA’s Geffen Contemporary in Little Tokyo. Highlights included musical performances, scholarly panels on licensing and globalization, live appearances and, last but not least, shopping, while some of the strangest sights included watching Kitty christen the Friendship Village pop-up shop as she bought a cartload of merchandise featuring herself, and the tattoo parlor that offered attendees a spectrum of free, permanent body art (Perry partook). The photographer Jacqueline DiMilia captured the style scene in and around the show; for those craving a closer look, the companion exhibition at the Japanese American National Museum next door, “Hello! Exploring the Supercute World of Hello Kitty,” is on view through April 26 of next year.

headline: U.S. Oil Prices Fall Below $80 a Barrel
abstract: Saudi Arabia reduced its price for oil to America, causing oil prices to decline.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The benchmark American oil price fell below the symbolic $80-a-barrel threshold on Monday, swooning to two-year lows, after Saudi Arabia aimed to shore up its dwindling exports to the United States by cutting its selling price for the American market.

headline: Broadway Sailors’ New Leading Lady
abstract: The three lead actors of the musical “On the Town” bond around New York even when they’re not in their roles.
lead_paragraph: Three sailors on a 24-hour furlough in New York City have one thing on their mind, and it isn’t seeing the Statue of Liberty. Or at least so goes the story line in “On the Town,” the 1944 musical currently enjoying a much-lauded Broadway revival.

headline: Business Aircraft Industry Climbing Back, Slowly
abstract: After a steep plunge from the peak year, 2008, demand for midsize and smaller jets is picking up again.
lead_paragraph: AT the convention of the National Business Aviation Association in Orlando, Fla., last month, it seemed that happy days were not quite here again, but at least the miserable days that hit the business aircraft industry in 2009 appeared to be waning.

headline: Under Pressure, Burkina Faso’s Military Promises to Cede Power
abstract: The military officer who took charge of Burkina Faso on Saturday denied on Monday that he had any intention of holding on to power.
lead_paragraph: One day after street protests against the military ended in violence, Burkina Faso’s interim leader, Lt. Col. Isaac Zida, insisted on Monday that the army planned to give way to a civilian-led transitional body soon.

headline: Wallenda Tightrope Walk Is No Match for ‘Walking Dead’
abstract: The Discovery Channel special, which featured Nik Wallenda’s walk across the Chicago skyline, drew fewer than half the viewers of the hit AMC show.
lead_paragraph: Maybe it’s getting too easy for Nik Wallenda — or maybe walking on a tightrope across the Chicago skyline isn’t as scary as walking zombies.

headline: Stand-Up Routine
abstract: Joel Fagliano finds both the positive and the negative in his puzzle.
lead_paragraph: Administrivial Chance To Back Something Great Alert! Our friend Patrick Merrell — artist, author, former Wordplay blogger and general man-about-town — has launched a Kickstarter campaign to crowdfund his newest venture, a puzzle adventure story book called “Zep in the Curse of the Evil Dr. Sumac Who Lives Next Door”! This would make a great gift for young puzzlers, but, as Mr. Merrell says, it’s “An amusing book for young and old alike. It’s a kid’s book, but with a very sophisticated, multi-step puzzle hidden within its pages.” Let’s see what we can do to make this a reality. Click here for more information about the book and rewards for contributing to Patrick’s campaign.

headline: Cubs, After Clearing Air Over Joe Maddon Hiring, Turn Attention to a Drought
abstract: Maddon called his new job as Chicago’s manager “a one-in-107-year opportunity,” referring to the time that has passed since the team last won a title.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — A Bears cap on his head, Chicago Cubs President Theo Epstein hopped two planes to Pensacola, Fla., last week. There, he drove to an R.V. park on the beach to find Joe Maddon.

headline: A Photographer’s Promise to an Indian Child
abstract: Alex Masi vows to help an Indian child he photographed in Bhopal continue her schooling while he presses on with a long term project about her.
lead_paragraph: Alex Masi vows to help an Indian child he photographed in Bhopal continue her schooling while he presses on with a long term project about her.

headline: Mustn’t Keep the Client Waiting
abstract: Scott Lee of SB Architects says that business once took him from San Francisco to meetings in San Diego to a dinner in Beijing, without a day’s rest.
lead_paragraph: I’VE spent a lot of time in planes. I’m an architect, and president and principal of SB Architects. My passport reads like an atlas, with stamps from Europe, Asia, the Middle East, North Africa, the Caribbean, Central America, South America and China. We have offices in San Francisco, Miami and Shenzhen, so those are frequent stops, too. We’re contemplating offices in Istanbul and São Paulo, so those may join my list of most-visited airports.

headline: Not a Flight of Fancy
abstract: Private space travel isn’t frivolous or impossible. It’s an epic enterprise.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — ONE clear winter day in 1909, in Hampshire, England, a young man named Geoffrey de Havilland took off in a twin-propeller motorized flying machine of his own design, built of wood, piano wire and stiff linen hand-stitched by his wife. The launch was flawless, and soon he had an exhilarating sensation of climbing almost straight upward toward the brilliant blue sky. But he soon realized he was in terrible trouble.

headline: Stryker Settles Suits by Hip Implant Patients for $1 Billion
abstract: The Stryker deal resolves claims by patients who said they were injured by metal debris from a hip replacement.
lead_paragraph: Stryker, the major producer of artificial hip implants, said on Monday that it had reached a settlement of thousands of patient lawsuits involving now-recalled devices that is expected to cost the company about $1 billion.

headline: Flattening Flattens
abstract: It’s a no smaller world, after all.
lead_paragraph: Justin Fox notes that the world is still not flat, and in fact doesn’t seem to be getting flatter; global “connectedness”, by various measures, seems to have leveled off. In particular, north-north trade doesn’t seem to be going much of anywhere.

headline: ‘Pippin’ to Close on Broadway
abstract: The Tony Award-winning musical revival will close in January.
lead_paragraph: The Tony Award-winning Broadway revival of the musical “Pippin” will close at the Music Box Theater on Jan. 4, 2015, the show’s producers announced on Monday evening.

headline: Her Anorexia, My Fear
abstract: What happens when a patient triggers a doctor’s phobia?
lead_paragraph: For some people, the psychiatrist’s couch is a metal examining table.

headline: Where Riding and Wrangling Beat Virtual Adventures
abstract: In Utah and nearby states, rodeo children — weaned on mutton-busting and goat-tying — grow up in a culture that prizes riding sheep over Facebook updates.
lead_paragraph: OGDEN, Utah — There were 5-year-olds riding woolly white sheep and fourth graders astride 600-pound bulls, all trying very hard not to fall off. Girls in pink tops took their turn at the goat tie, riding their horses toward a tethered goat, wrestling it to the ground and tying its hooves together with a rope.

headline: Falling Tape Measure Kills Man at Jersey City Construction Site
abstract: The device slipped off the belt of a worker 50 stories above and fell about 400 feet before striking and killing Gary Anderson, 58.
lead_paragraph: A tower rising 50 stories. A one-pound tape measure attached to the waist of a construction worker. An unsuspecting man stepping from a vehicle at the foot of the building.

headline: Maine: Nurse Reaches Agreement on Travel
abstract: A nurse who fought efforts by Maine to quarantine her at home after she returned from treating Ebola patients in West Africa reached an agreement on Monday with the state that largely leaves her free to travel.
lead_paragraph: A nurse who fought efforts by Maine to quarantine her at home after she returned from treating Ebola patients in West Africa reached an agreement on Monday with the state that largely leaves her free to travel. The agreement requires the nurse, Kaci Hickox, 33, to be monitored daily for Ebola symptoms and to coordinate travel with public health officials until next Monday, the end of the 21-day incubation period after her last possible exposure to Ebola. The agreement extends a temporary order issued Friday by Judge Charles C. LaVerdiere, the chief judge for Maine District Courts, who had rejected a request by Gov. Paul LePage’s administration that Ms. Hickox stay off public transportation, avoid public gatherings and stay three feet away from other people.

headline: Returns on College Endowments Average 15.8 Percent
abstract: A study found that colleges were allocating more than half their investments — and almost two-thirds of the largest endowments — to alternative strategies such as hedge funds and private equity.
lead_paragraph: The average return, after fees, on college and university endowments was 15.8 percent in the fiscal year that ended in June, up from 11.7 percent the previous year, according to the preliminary data collected for the annual Nacubo-Commonfund Study of Endowments, which will be released in January. The largest endowments — those over $1 billion — had the highest average return, 16.8 percent. The study, based on data from 426 colleges, found that colleges were allocating more than half their investments — and almost two-thirds of the largest endowments — to alternative strategies such as hedge funds and private equity.

headline: Burkina Faso: A Regional Warning
abstract: The African Union on Monday gave Burkina Faso’s military leaders two weeks to return power to a civilian-led government or face severe sanctions.
lead_paragraph: The African Union on Monday gave Burkina Faso’s military leaders two weeks to return power to a civilian-led government or face severe sanctions. The warning by the Peace and Security Council of the 54-nation organization, posted on its Twitter account after an emergency meeting in Ethiopia, came as the country’s interim president, Lt. Col. Isaac Zida, sought to assure diplomats and residents that the military takeover of the government on Friday was only temporary. The armed forces seized control after the longtime president, Blaise Compaoré, fled amid mass protests over his efforts to engineer a vote that would have allowed him to stay in office indefinitely. The United States government, which is legally obliged to suspend aid to countries where power is usurped by the military, did not immediately take a position on whether the events in Burkina Faso had amounted to a coup. “We’re still gathering facts,” said Jen Psaki, a State Department spokeswoman. “We’re not going to make a policy or legal determination at this point in time.”

headline: An Emotional Response to Charlotte Hornets’ Name Change
abstract: Nothing resembles a bouncing ball so much as the 26-year history of professional basketball in Charlotte, N.C.
lead_paragraph: MANY residents of Charlotte, N.C., have answered their doorbells in recent days to find a giant hornet standing before them, holding a purple basketball net. It was not, it turns out, a fever dream; rather, it was Hugo, the teal-and-purple mascot for the Charlotte Hornets, and he was handing out the nets to help create, as hornets are apt to, buzz.

headline: Bells Tolling for Miles, Boston Offers a Goodbye to Former Mayor
abstract: Thousands of Bostonians lined the 10-mile route to view the procession for Thomas M. Menino, who died Thursday at the age of 71, just 10 months after he left office — too young and too soon, many said.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Church bells tolled across Boston on Monday as a hearse bearing the body of Thomas M. Menino, this city’s longest-serving mayor, rolled through the streets, from historic Faneuil Hall, where he lay in state, to the church in the Hyde Park neighborhood where he had been baptized and where mourners bid their final farewell.

headline: Beverly Blossom, Solo Dancer With a ‘Voice,’ Dies at 88
abstract: Ms. Blossom was influenced by the work of Bertolt Brecht and studied in Germany with a dance teacher of the expressionist tradition.
lead_paragraph: Beverly Blossom, a modern-dance choreographer and teacher and a daring, vividly imaginative solo performer, died on Saturday in Chicago. She was 88.

headline: Egyptian Cleric Defends Forced Evacuation of Families From Sinai
abstract: The government-appointed mufti, or chief interpreter of Islamic law, defended the clearing out of more than 1,100 families from the peninsula to root out extremists.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — A government-appointed Muslim clerical leader on Monday provided a religious defense of the forced evacuation of more than 1,100 families from the Sinai Peninsula in an attempt to root out militant extremists.

headline: Election Day Choices
abstract: A reminder of some of the recommendations made by The Times’s editorial board.
lead_paragraph: Poll hours: 6 a.m. to 9 p.m.

headline: Brittany Maynard, ‘Death With Dignity’ Ally, Dies at 29
abstract: Ms. Maynard became a public face for the “death with dignity” movement after she was found to have terminal brain cancer. She ended her life on Saturday at her home in Portland, Ore.
lead_paragraph: Brittany Maynard, who became a public face for the “death with dignity” movement in the United States after she was found to have terminal brain cancer, ended her life on Saturday at her home in Portland, Ore. She was 29.

headline: After 26 Miles, Thousands of Paths
abstract: After the completion of the New York City Marathon on Sunday, signs of the field dispersing lingered across the city.
lead_paragraph: After the completion of the New York City Marathon on Sunday, signs of the field dispersing lingered across the city. Clockwise from top left, workers on East 62nd Street collected paper cups discarded by the participants. After the race, some runners took the C train. Sunny Kang and Jason Choi, who both completed the race, walked through Central Park on the 65th Street transverse. Others just sat on the ground in the park.

headline: De Blasio Unveils New Plans for Troubled Schools in New York
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio said his tactics of offering more help to failing schools, and providing social services to students and families there, differed sharply from his predecessor’s.
lead_paragraph: In the packed auditorium of an East Harlem high school, Mayor Bill de Blasio announced a new approach to fixing New York City’s most troubled public schools on Monday, offering them more money and staffing, extending the length of their day, and arranging for social services to be delivered to students and families on site.

headline: Election 2014: Your Very Predictable Vote
abstract: Self-interest, not ideology, explains most people’s political views.

headline: David M. Abshire, Who Helped Reagan Through Iran-Contra Scandal, Dies at 88
abstract: Mr. Abshire also served as United States ambassador to NATO, held other high-level government posts and led respected research groups.
lead_paragraph: David M. Abshire, who led respected research groups and held high government posts but made his most visible mark by helping President Ronald Reagan navigate the political storms of the Iran-contra scandal, died on Friday in Alexandria, Va. He was 88.

headline: Investigation of Honda Centers on Failure to Report Deaths From Takata Airbags
abstract: Regulators are studying whether the automaker failed to report deaths and injuries from a defective airbag that can rupture violently.
lead_paragraph: Federal safety regulators said on Monday that they were investigating whether Honda Motor failed to report deaths and injuries from defective airbags that can rupture violently.

headline: So Far, Knicks Are Succeeding With Less Carmelo Anthony
abstract: At 2-1, the Knicks are over .500 for the first time in more than a year, and they have been able to keep Anthony, their top scorer, from playing too many minutes.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — For the first time in 369 days, the Knicks showed up for practice on Monday morning with a winning record. They have 79 games left to play, starting Tuesday night against the Washington Wizards, so their 2-1 record means little in the grand scheme of a season. But it means something to the players.

headline: In Traveling to the Stars, Risk and Cost
abstract: Two recent accidents, one of them fatal, involving commercial rockets have underscored the high risks and soaring costs involved in any spaceflight.
lead_paragraph: Space travel has long been the preserve of governments and sci-fi fans, but in recent years a crop of new commercial ventures, often backed by billionaire entrepreneurs, has sought to get into the race.

headline: After the Death of Her Father, She Fights Her Way Back to College
abstract: Melicia Pristell grew up estranged from her father and spent a year in a homeless shelter, but they rebuilt their relationship before his death.
lead_paragraph: On a rainy Tuesday morning, Melicia Pristell sat in the lobby of Academic Building 1 on the Medgar Evers College campus, where she often comes to study. Her face buried in a book and a messenger bag across her lap, she had safely returned to her sanctuary — one she had almost lost.

headline: Death by Data
abstract: Politicians are micro-targeting their messages at their own peril.
lead_paragraph: Over the past decade or so, political campaigns have become more scientific. Campaign consultants use sophisticated data to micro-target specific demographic slices. Consultants select their ad buys more precisely because they know which political niche is watching which TV show. Campaigns trial test messages that push psychological buttons.

headline: Long in Repose, Last Remnants of a Founding Family Will Leave Long Island City
abstract: A bulldozer will break ground in Queens next year on the site of what was once a cemetery, owned by a family that settled there 350 years ago.
lead_paragraph: More people are buried in Queens than are living there now. This is a story of some of the departed.

headline: Hotel-Room Calls: No More Quarters in the Slot
abstract: Some hotels are providing their guests the perk of unlimited free talking anywhere in the world.
lead_paragraph: Using your hotel room phone for domestic or international calls usually means getting hit with a prohibitively high bill: Properties charge a premium running up to several dollars a minute to dial direct and even tack on service fees for calling locally.

headline: Merkel Toughens Position on Britain’s E.U. Demands
abstract: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain, under mounting pressure from anti-European populists, continued to insist on new measures limiting the right of Europeans to live and work there.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany has indicated that she is prepared to contemplate a future for the European Union without Britain, if Prime Minister David Cameron insists on new measures to limit the rights of Europeans to live and work there, German news media reported on Monday.

headline: Should Voting Be a Constitutional Right?
abstract: Should a  constitutional amendment guarantee the right to vote, to fend off efforts that inhibit and restrict voting?

headline: ‘Gotham’ Recap: All Hail the Penguin
abstract: The Penguin continued his path through, and manipulation of, Gotham City’s underworld on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Season 1, Episode 7, “Penguin’s Umbrella”

headline: A $15.3 Million Pitch, With a Catch
abstract: David Robertson received a qualifying offer from the Yankees — a one-year pact that would pay him handsomely. If he signs elsewhere, his new team will be required to forfeit a draft pick.
lead_paragraph: In his long, record-breaking career as a closer, playing in a huge baseball market, Mariano Rivera ultimately made $15 million a year, the most any relief pitcher has ever been paid.

headline: Hollywood Works to Maintain Its World Dominance
abstract: At the American Film Market, some in the business will be worrying about the subtle shifts away from their products in other countries.
lead_paragraph: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — Twice in the last few months, there was a faint knock on the door of American supremacy in the global film market.

headline: Tom Magliozzi, One Half of the Jovial Brothers on ‘Car Talk,’ Dies at 77
abstract: Mr. Magliozzi hosted the popular NPR show “Car Talk” for more than 30 years with his younger brother, Ray, in which they bantered with callers through an automotive prism.
lead_paragraph: Tom Magliozzi, who with his younger brother, Ray, hosted “Car Talk,” for years the most popular entertainment show on NPR, died on Monday at his home outside Boston. He was 77.

headline: Another Battle for Eisenhower
abstract: The 34th president might have been bemused at the bureaucratic retreats and aesthetic flak it has taken to win approval of his memorial.
lead_paragraph: Dwight David Eisenhower, the 34th president and military legend who organized the Normandy invasion, might have been bemused in his grinning Kansas way at the bureaucratic retreats and aesthetic flak it has taken to win approval of an official Eisenhower memorial on a 4-acre site overlooking the Capitol. A crucial vote of approval Oct. 16 from the United States Commission of Fine Arts signaled a go-ahead for an overdue tribute first approved by Congress 15 years ago.

headline: Driving Student Borrowers Into Default
abstract: Congress should do more to help graduates mired in student loan debt find a way to make payments and meet their obligations.
lead_paragraph: People who pay for college with federal student loans can avoid default when they fall on hard times by making lower payments — or no payments at all — until they recover financially. Borrowers who take out private student loans from banks and other institutions typically have no such option. When they lose their jobs or suffer other financial setbacks, they have little choice but to default, which, in turn, damages their credit histories and ability to borrow for other purposes or even to find a job.

headline: Sex and Drug Claims at Investment Bank Jefferies Draw Risky Retort
abstract: Scandalous accusations made against a managing director at the investment bank Jefferies as part of a divorce and custody filing have become the talk of Wall Street.
lead_paragraph: “We went to our partners in health care investment banking yesterday afternoon and said, ‘The two of us are going to go take a drug test, and do you want to join us?’ ”

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 3, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Guns and Public Health
abstract: A gun dealer says the country needs a new approach to guns and gun violence, one where doctors play the same central role they did in the smoking debate.
lead_paragraph: Mike Weisser is my favorite gun dealer. The longtime proprietor of the Ware Gun Shop in Ware, Mass., Weisser, 70, estimates he has sold more than 40,000 guns in his career as a wholesaler and retailer. He also has a nice little business teaching a gun-safety course that Massachusetts requires of all new gun owners.

headline: Trying to Seal the Deal
abstract: Candidates across the country made their final appeals to voters on Monday before Tuesday’s midterm elections.
lead_paragraph: Candidates across the country made their final appeals to voters on Monday before Tuesday’s midterm elections.

headline: What to Watch For as G.O.P. Expects Big Night at Polls
abstract: The outcomes of 36 governors’ contests, the battle for control of the Senate, nearly 50 competitive House races and countless ballot questions are at stake. Here’s how to make sense of it all.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It is a recipe for sensory overload: Election returns will start flooding every device and screen Tuesday evening, capturing the outcomes of 36 governors’ contests, the battle for control of the Senate, nearly 50 competitive House races and countless ballot questions.

headline: Passion and Eloquence, Smothered in Explanation
abstract: Dialogue is loudly delivered in service of an Issue, with a capital I, in Nikkole Salter’s tale of a mother’s effort to get her daughter a better education.
lead_paragraph: There’s a poignant moment in “Lines in the Dust” when Denitra, a working-class single mother, describes how she and her daughter sometimes put on fine clothes and visit open houses held by real estate agents in wealthy neighborhoods.

headline: Heirs to the Peyton Manning-Tom Brady Rivalry? For Now, It’s Up for Grabs
abstract: The N.F.L., under siege on many fronts, is facing a potential quarterback vacuum. Who will step up to fill the void? And, perhaps more critically, how marketable will that new guard be?
lead_paragraph: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — The New England Patriots had trounced the Denver Broncos, 43-21, in a game between quarterback titans, and Darrelle Revis, a veteran cornerback for the Patriots, considered a question about Tom Brady and Peyton Manning.

headline: For a Packed Part of Jerusalem, Expansion Plans Have Built Mostly Outrage
abstract: An Israeli committee’s approval of about 500 new apartments for settlers in Ramat Shlomo on Monday brought condemnation from the Obama administration.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Residents jokingly refer to “Lower Ramat Shlomo”: In the parking area beneath apartments, instead of cars, wood-veneer doors mark homes fashioned illegally to accommodate a bursting population. Elsewhere in the ultra-Orthodox Jewish neighborhood of East Jerusalem, courtyards and porches are enclosed by wood, glass, even burlap — every available space, it seems, transformed into makeshift shacks by a community whose growth has been stymied by the fraught politics of this contested city.

headline: Role for Russia Gives Iran Talks a Possible Boost
abstract: Iran has tentatively agreed to ship much of its huge stockpile of uranium to Russia if it reaches a broader nuclear deal with the West.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Iran has tentatively agreed to ship much of its huge stockpile of uranium to Russia if it reaches a broader nuclear deal with the West, according to officials and diplomats involved in the negotiations, potentially a major breakthrough in talks that have until now been deadlocked.

headline: Sex After 50? Less Important for Women, Portuguese Court Rules
abstract: A three-judge panel reduced compensation for a widow, now 69, who had won a court battle after surgery made sex painful, saying sex was less important after 50.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — It was difficult and depressing enough for a middle-age widow in Portugal who was unable to have a normal sex life after botched surgery.

headline: A Draft Bust Playing in Vienna Pictures Life After Hockey
