abstract: Hugh Jessiman, the 12th pick of the 2003 draft, who played for eight minor league teams and in two N.H.L. games, is now in Austria and planning his next steps.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA — On the crowded cobblestone streets of Austria’s largest city, the locals largely ignore the 6-foot-6 hockey player in their midst.

headline: A Special Child: What’s a Mother to Do?
abstract: In Sarah Ruhl’s new play, “The Oldest Boy,” at Lincoln Center, Buddhist monks want to take an American child to India because they say he is the reincarnation of a revered teacher.
lead_paragraph: The nuclear family and the traditions of Tibetan Buddhism come into conflict in “The Oldest Boy,” the new play by Sarah Ruhl, about an American child who is identified by monks as the reincarnation of a revered Buddhist teacher. This revelation — if revelation it truly is — poses a painful challenge to the child’s parents, a Tibetan-born father who runs a restaurant in an unnamed American city, and his Cincinnati-born mother. Buddhist practice would require that the boy — just 3 when the play begins — be sent to India to study for his calling at a monastery, a move that naturally dismays his parents, particularly his mother.

headline: ‘Sleepy Hollow’ Recap: And the Father Has Eight Legs
abstract: On this Election eve, is Ichabod Crane a conservative Republican or a liberal Democrat?
lead_paragraph: Season 2, Episode 7, “Deliverance”

headline: N.S.A. Director Makes Another Visit to Silicon Valley
abstract: The tough encryption added to Apple’s iPhones made bad relations between tech companies and the intelligence community even worse in recent months. But Adm. Michael S. Rogers played down government concerns.
lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, Calif. — Adm. Michael S. Rogers, director of the National Security Agency, said on Monday that a secure Internet was in the best interest of the United States, following disclosures that the N.S.A. had been exploiting weaknesses in the web for foreign intelligence gathering.

headline: The Shake-Up at Rikers Island
abstract: Some high-level officers may have stepped down, but that is not enough to inspire confidence in efforts to reform the city’s jail system.
lead_paragraph: Violence and corruption became entrenched at New York City’s Rikers Island jail because officers who ignored or even condoned that culture were moved steadily up the ladder into management.

headline: Politicians Show Frustration After a Police Chief’s Exit in New York
abstract: Despite efforts to address concerns, Mayor Bill de Blasio and Police Commissioner William J. Bratton continue to draw criticism over the resignation of Philip Banks III.
lead_paragraph: Not long after Philip Banks III, the New York Police Department’s highest-ranking uniformed officer, abruptly resigned on Friday, Mayor Bill de Blasio phoned several black elected officials to convey his disappointment.

headline: Rangers’ Stand-In Lineup Comes Up Short Against Blues
abstract: The Rangers, who were missing Mats Zuccarello and dressed four replacements on defense because of injuries and a suspension, came out flying, but St. Louis still won its fifth straight.
lead_paragraph: A long list of lineup challenges, a tough Western Conference opponent and last season’s top scorer on the sideline were more than sufficient motivation for the Rangers.

headline: Word of the Day | prim
abstract: This word has appeared in 111 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: prim •\ˈprim\• adjective and verb

headline: Nets Follow a Bit of Levity With a Serious Drubbing of the Thunder
abstract: Mikhail D. Prokhorov offered up some jokes, one about the departure of the former Nets coach Jason Kidd, and then his team, with Brook Lopez back for the home opener, routed Oklahoma City.
lead_paragraph: It had been almost 10 months since Mikhail D. Prokhorov last spoke to the reporters who cover the Nets, the team he has owned since 2010, so it felt as if there was some catching up to do Monday night at the team’s first home game of the season.

headline: Much Has Happened Since the Jets Last Won
abstract: A random sampling of some of what has taken place in the world since the Jets last came out on top, on Sept. 7.
lead_paragraph: It is with the benefit of hindsight that Sept. 7 now stands out as a rare and amazing day. For that was the Sunday when the Jets, in their season opener, actually won a game. They have not won since — not in eight games, played in five stadiums and in two time zones. Their misery is in its third month, with no relief in sight.

headline: Did Someone Say ‘2016’? Presidential Contenders Circle
abstract: Ready or not, the midterm elections signal the unofficial start of the next presidential campaign. Assessing the prospects of some likely candidates.
lead_paragraph: Ready or not, the midterm elections signal the unofficial start of the next presidential campaign. Assessing the prospects of some likely candidates.

headline: Few Retired N.F.L. Players Opt Out of Proposed Concussion Settlement
abstract: By not taking part in the settlement, designed to pay those with neurological conditions, the players could have preserved the right to continue suing the league for injuries related to head hits.
lead_paragraph: Fewer than one percent of former N.F.L. players opted out of a settlement with the league that is designed to pay players with severe neurological conditions.

headline: A Design-Centric New Pizzeria From One of Mexico City’s Buzziest Chefs
abstract: Eduardo García is opening Lalo! — a new, more casual space — right across the street from his celebrated bistro Maximo.
lead_paragraph: Since 2012, Maximo, helmed by the chef Eduardo García, has been drawing the city’s food cognoscenti to the Roma neighborhood for its innovative approach that fuses Mexican ingredients with European techniques. Now, García and his wife and business partner, Gabriela López-Cruz, are introducing their newest venture, Lalo!, a pizzeria and cafe situated directly across the street. And thanks to García’s training at Michelin-starred restaurants in Mexico City and New York (Enrique Olvera’s famed Pujol and Le Bernardin, respectively), Lalo! promises more than the average grab-a-slice experience. Potato, rosemary and truffle oil pizza, inspired by a trip to Puglia, will be on the menu, along with striped sea bass served with caramelized onions and gremolata, salads using lettuce from the Mexican region of Xochimilco and suckling pig in salsa verde paired with a Mexican succulent known as verdolagas.

headline: At the Guggenheim, an Orb by Otto Piene Ascends
abstract: The artist installed “White Balloon,” which will be on display for just three days, to coincide with this year’s International Gala.
lead_paragraph: The imposing rotunda inside the Guggenheim museum in New York has just become a lot more striking thanks to Otto Piene’s “White Balloon” installation, on display for only three days. Specially installed to coincide with this year’s Guggenheim International Gala, sponsored by Christian Dior, it dovetails with a longer exhibition: the first large-scale survey in an American museum of Zero, the experimental, post-World War II group. “Zero: Countdown to Tomorrow, 1950s-60s” presents a breadth of work by more than 30 artists from 10 countries around the world, including some of the movement’s founders: Piene, Gunther Ueker, Heinz Mack and Yves Klein.

headline: Two Men Charged With Murder in Fatal Shooting Outside Bronx Club
abstract: Zaire Bansey, 19, and Peter Hajdari, 18, were arrested in the killing that occurred during a fight outside the Xtreme Lounge in October.
lead_paragraph: Two men were arrested on Monday and charged with murder in the shooting of a man during a fight outside a Bronx club last month, the police said.

headline: Woebegone Giants Fall to the Colts in a Rout
abstract: In the Giants’ third straight loss, there were dropped passes, wayward throws, an anemic running game, blown defensive assignments and three Colts fumbles that were not recovered.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — There were many things the Giants did wrong in Monday night’s 40-24 defeat to the Indianapolis Colts. There were dropped passes, wayward throws, a hopelessly anemic running game, three Colts fumbles that were not recovered and a multitude of blown assignments defensively.

headline: Football, the Newest Partisan Divide
abstract: A new poll — consistent with data on high-school participation — finds that much of liberal-leaning America has growing qualms about the sport.
lead_paragraph: To the list of issues that divide the country along partisan lines, you can add an unusual item: football.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (HBO Signature) ADMISSION (2013) Tina Fey portrays Portia Nathan, a Princeton admissions officer who seems to take a special kind of glee in controlling the fate of applicants aspiring to the university. She also has a goal of her own: to succeed the retiring dean of admissions (Wallace Shawn) and beat out her office rival (Gloria Reuben) while reclaiming Princeton’s place at the top of the U.S. News & World Report rankings. But just as her smug English-professor boyfriend (Michael Sheen) dumps her for an aggressive Virginia Woolf scholar (Sonya Walger), a fellow Dartmouth alum (Paul Rudd) comes along with an unusual student (Nat Wolff) he wants Portia to consider. “How could anyone make light of the brutal, capricious system by which our young people are judged and sorted?” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this comedy from Paul Weitz, adapted from the novel by Jean Hanff Korelitz. “I must confess that I don’t know whether to be relieved or disappointed that ‘Admission,’ which had the potential to be a sharp, satirical jab at the soft belly of middle-class anxiety, chose instead to be a warm and wacky fable of wish fulfillment.”

headline: Corrections: November 4, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Tuesday, November 4, 2014.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, November 4, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “I’m telling you, that banana pudding, really — it’s life-changing.”

headline: Enthusiasm Is Good (Personal and Trivial)
abstract: Even if it’s not my cup of tea.
lead_paragraph: In case you’re wondering about the scarcity of posts, I made a resolution: on this visit to Japan, which includes two conferences with a stretch of time in between, I would actually try to see something. I’ve been visiting some of the usual sites, like the Meiji Shrine:

headline: Why Don’t We See More Macroeconomic Populism?
abstract: Free lunches aren’t popular, but why not?
lead_paragraph: As I’ve been noting recently, there’s a lot of opposition within Japan to the Bank of Japan’s policy of printing more money; there’s also a lot of pressure on the government to raise taxes. And that’s not really very different from what has been happening in the rest of the advanced world: central banks that have pursued quantitative easing have done so despite political pressure, not because of it, and fiscal austerity has been imposed almost everywhere.

headline: Saving an Ancient Opera Form
abstract: An opera singer who once performed for Chairman Mao turned to smartphone donations in a bid to revive Sizhou Xi, a 200-year-old Chinese art form.
lead_paragraph: Last Friday in a Beijing theater, Li Baofeng and 10 of her colleagues from the Feng Yun Theatrical Company bowed to a small but enthusiastic audience after their performance of Sizhou Xi, a 200-year-old form of Chinese opera. It was the second time Ms. Li, 81, had performed in Beijing. The first time was 57 years earlier, for Mao Zedong at Zhongnanhai, the seat of the Chinese leadership.

headline: Banco Santander Profit Jumps 52% Amid Recovery in Spain
abstract: Santander said third-quarter profit rose to about $2 billion as economic conditions in Spain improved and provisions for bad loans continued to decline.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Banco Santander of Spain reported on Tuesday that its third-quarter profit rose 52 percent, posting its strongest earnings in more than two years as the Spanish economy continued to recover.

headline: Test Yourself | At Facebook, Creating Empathy Among Cyberbullying
abstract: Here are the first six paragraphs of the Oct. 22 article “Meet Facebook’s Mr. Nice.” Can you choose the best word for each blank?
lead_paragraph: Below are the first six paragraphs of the Oct. 22 article “Meet Facebook’s Mr. Nice.”

headline: Virgin Money’s I.P.O. Is Back on Track
abstract: The British financial services company Virgin Money, which delayed an offering because of volatile market conditions, intends to list its shares in London by the end of November.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British financial services company Virgin Money, partly owned by the billionaire Richard Branson, said on Tuesday that it planned to list its shares in London by the end of November, after having delayed an initial public offering last month because of volatile market conditions.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | An Artifact Once Was Just Home
abstract: What was life like living at 97 Orchard Street for Rita Ascione as a young girl?
lead_paragraph: Watch the above video and read the article “An Artifact Once Was Just Home” to answer the questions below:

headline: Will the LeBron James Stimulus Be Good for Cleveland?
abstract: Some locals are hoping King James’s return will revive the city’s economy, but experts say these predictions are wildly inflated and unlikely to last.
lead_paragraph: When LeBron James announced his return to the Cleveland Cavaliers in July, fans celebrated by hanging banners, getting drunk and digging old jerseys out of purgatory. They ran into the streets, honked horns and hugged strangers. And some of them started trying to figure out just how much money was about to rain down on Cleveland. According to one estimate, the return of the “king,” as James is known, will add $500 million a year to the city’s economy. “When people say this is just about an athlete making money, there’s more to it than that,” said Edward FitzGerald, the Cuyahoga County executive, at a news conference devoted to the anticipated windfall. “Other people will make a living.”

headline: Treating Ebola Without Fear
abstract: A doctor reflects on his history with infectious disease.
lead_paragraph: Observing my patient through the chicken wire, I saw that the front half of his scalp was shaved — and the long gray hairs behind that equator were gathered in a kudumi, or knot. He was a temple priest. All these years later I can still see that tuft and the three broad white stripes of vibhuti, or holy ash, smeared across his forehead, proclaiming his Shaivite faith, a reminder that the world was all maya — illusion. But his discomfort was real. In my recollection, he sits cross-legged on his mat in that locked room, groaning, restless, his trunk swaying, his features anxious, grimacing as if he’d tasted something bitter.

headline: A Photographer’s Promise to an Indian Child
abstract: Alex Masi vowed to help an Indian child he photographed in Bhopal continue her schooling while he pressed on with a long term project about her.
lead_paragraph: It started with $5,000.

headline: Should Students Be Barred From Taking Cellphones to School?
abstract: What is your school’s policy regarding cellphones? Do you take a phone to school? Has your cellphone helped or hurt your learning?
lead_paragraph: New York City will be ending its longstanding ban on cellphones in public schools. For years the city argued that cellphones had no place in schools, and that they disrupted student learning. Many parents countered that cellphones were a vital link to their children.

headline: European Union Lowers Growth Forecasts as Business Confidence Sags
abstract: The 28-member bloc adjusted its estimates after weak economic performance in France, Germany and Italy, and in the face of declining business confidence.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — European Union officials on Tuesday sharply lowered growth forecasts as member states like France, Germany and Italy showed weak economic performance, and as business confidence suffered from heightened geopolitical risks.

headline: As New Rules Take Effect, Voters Report Problems in Some States
abstract: Snags were reported in Texas, North Carolina and Georgia, in many cases reflecting concerns raised by civic groups that new rules would deter voters.
lead_paragraph: Some longtime voters in Texas reported on Tuesday that they were refused a ballot because they lacked newly required photo identification. In North Carolina, voters who showed up at the wrong precinct were unable to vote, reflecting a new policy. And in Georgia, hundreds of frustrated people called a hotline to say they were unsure if their voter registrations had been processed, some of the thousands of would-be new voters who reportedly faced uncertainty.

headline: Greene King Meets Deadline With $1.2 Billion Offer for Spirit Pub
abstract: The Spirit Pub Company’s board, which agreed last week to give Greene King more time to make a proposal, intends to recommend that shareholders approve the offer.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Greene King, a British brewer and operator of pubs and hotels, said on Tuesday that it had reached an agreement on a recommended offer to acquire the Spirit Pub Company of Britain.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: America’s Big Bet on Indonesia
abstract: Its new leader gives hope that Jakarta can help fight terror and be a counterweight to China.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State John Kerry’s presence last month at the inauguration of President Joko Widodo of Indonesia was another sign of the Obama administration’s greater involvement in Asia. It was also an investment in America’s relationship with Indonesia, whose importance as an emerging democracy and the largest economy in Southeast Asia is sometimes overlooked.

headline: New York Today: Elections Arrive
abstract: Tuesday: Voters head to the polls, a balmy day, and a visit from Henry Kissinger.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this fine Tuesday.

headline: Prosecutors Seek Appeal of Rulings on Pistorius
abstract: Filings by South African prosecutors question Oscar Pistorius’s acquittal on murder charges and what they call the “shockingly light” sentence on a lesser charge.
lead_paragraph: Starting a new phase in a case that captivated a global audience, South African state prosecutors began legal proceedings on Tuesday to appeal the conviction and what they called the “shockingly light” sentence handed down to the track star Oscar Pistorius last month for killing his girlfriend.

headline: Playing the Midterm Elections Game
abstract: Republicans look set to cash in on voter anger.
lead_paragraph: Republicans look set to cash in on voter anger.

headline: Daily Report: Hotels Try Smartphone Apps as Room Keys
abstract: In a bid to help harried travelers save time at check-in, a number of major brands are experimenting with letting guests use their phones to unlock their rooms.
lead_paragraph: People use smartphones today to do everything from pay for coffee to board a plane. Now, a growing number of hotels want guests to be able to unlock their guest rooms with their phones, Martha C. White reports.

headline: When Spell-Check Can’t Help
abstract: Here’s another batch of word mix-ups, both familiar and novel. Some are pure homophone errors, other examples show confusion between similar words with related, but not identical, meanings.
lead_paragraph: Here’s another batch of word mix-ups, both familiar and novel.

headline: Facebook Has Its Own Get-Out-the-Vote Message
abstract: The social network is using its vast reach into virtually every American household to urge adults to vote in Tuesday’s elections. The effort mirrors Facebook’s push in other countries’ national elections this year.
lead_paragraph: Facebook wants its users in the United States to vote this Election Day — and it plans to put a reminder Tuesday at the top of the news feed of each of its American users of voting age.

headline: Searching for a Web Design Firm That Understands Search
abstract: In the end, the owner identified six companies to contact.
lead_paragraph: This is part two of a series on commissioning a new website. You can read the first post here.

headline: Today in Politics
abstract: After all the money, attack ads, debates, rallies, missteps, surprises and that rare discussion of policy, it’s time to count votes.
lead_paragraph: On Election Day, Keeping an Eye on the Early Races

headline: Morning Agenda: Sex, Drugs and Investment Banking
abstract: Sex and drug claims at Jefferies draw a risky retort. | JPMorgan lifts its estimate for legal costs. | Tough quarter for Sprint highlights lost promise of T-Mobile US deal.
lead_paragraph: An investment bank has taken unusual steps to quell any idea that it tolerates drug use or promiscuous activity. In response to scandalous accusations made against a managing director, Sage Kelly, as part of a divorce and custody filing, Richard B. Handler, the chief executive of Jefferies, has defended Mr. Kelly, made an impassioned case that his firm was being unfairly smeared and ended up marching an army of bankers into a drug test in the middle of the day after approaching other members of Mr. Kelly’s team, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in the DealBook Column. Mr. Kelly was accused by his wife, Christina, of abusing drugs, including cocaine and ecstasy. She also contended that Mr. Kelly instigated a sexual encounter involving a client, Marc Beer, and his girlfriend.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | Oct. 28-Nov. 3, 2014
abstract: Have you been following the news? Take our quiz to see what you know and to learn more, and look for a new edition each week on Tuesday morning.
lead_paragraph: Have you been following the news?

headline: Election Night: What to Expect
abstract: A look at when the polls close in crucial states, what factors to pay attention to, and what to ignore.
lead_paragraph: Get some coffee or some Vitaminwater, because it’s going to be one of the most dramatic election nights in a long time.

headline: Top British Spy Warns of Terrorists’ Use of Social Media
abstract: Robert Hannigan, director of Britain’s electronic eavesdropping agency, said young foreign jihadists who had grown up on the Internet had benefited from leaks by Edward J. Snowden.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — One of Britain’s highest-ranking intelligence officials on Tuesday castigated the giant American companies that dominate the Internet for providing the “command-and-control networks of choice for terrorists and criminals” and challenged the companies to find a better balance between privacy and security.

headline: Beyoncé to Release a New Album, a Version of Her Old Album
abstract: The news comes after rumors of an entirely new album swept the Internet over the weekend.
lead_paragraph: So Beyoncé is releasing a new album this month, but it is not quite what the Internet guessed that it was.

headline: Alibaba, Shrugging Off Slowdown in Chinese Economy, Reports Strong First Earnings
abstract: Revenue at the Chinese e-commerce company, which went public in September, rose 54 percent, to $2.7 billion.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Alibaba, the Chinese e-commerce behemoth, reported on Tuesday a jump in profit in its first earnings announcement since its initial public offering in September.

headline: In Performance: Blythe Danner and Eric Lange of ‘The Country House’
abstract: An actress and her aspiring playwright son are at odds in this scene from the new Broadway play by Donald Margulies.
lead_paragraph: This week’s video features Blythe Danner and Eric Lange as mother and son at odds in “The Country House,” a new Broadway play by Donald Margulies. In this scene Ms. Danner plays Anna, a veteran actress who can’t hide her disappointment after learning from her son Elliot, played by Mr. Lange, that he wants to be a playwright. The show, directed by Daniel Sullivan, continues through Nov. 23 at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater.

headline: Ye Haiyan, Rights Campaigner, Is Detained Over Photo Posted Online
abstract: The prominent activist for the rights of women and sex workers was detained in the central city of Wuhan after posting a nude photo of herself on the microblogging service Weibo, her friends said.
lead_paragraph: Ye Haiyan, a prominent campaigner for the rights of women and sex workers, has been detained in the central city of Wuhan for posting a nude photo of herself on the microblogging service Weibo, her friends said.

headline: Daily Clip Report
abstract: Daily Clip Report is a collection of articles about the media and The Times that is emailed each day to senior executives and newsroom managers here.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

headline: As Power of Terror Group Declines, Once-Feared Fighters Defect
abstract: Dozens of Shabab defectors live in a halfway house in Baidoa, Somalia, where they are learning new skills but live in fear of their old comrades.
lead_paragraph: BAIDOA, Somalia — Bashir was a true believer, a foot soldier who recently quit after seeing too many innocents slaughtered.

headline: Nostalgic Odors on the No. 5 Train
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A stranger on the subway smelled of tobacco, and suddenly, a rider was flooded with memories.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: At the CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund Awards, Some Surprises and Agendas
abstract: A shoemaker won first prize, and a jeweler and a knitwear designer were selected as runners-up.
lead_paragraph: “It was the toughest decision we’ve had to make,” Anna Wintour, the editor of Vogue, said at the CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund award dinner on Monday night.

headline: Oscar de la Renta’s Island Oasis
abstract: The late fashion designer’s legacy also includes suites designed for the Tortuga Bay Hotel in Punta Cana.
lead_paragraph: Tortuga Bay Hotel in Punta Cana has luxurious plantation-style villas, access to two golf courses and a V.I.P. airport terminal. And now it boasts beachfront suites redecorated by its former part owner, the Dominican Republic native Oscar de la Renta. His use of wicker, mahogany and neutral linens graciously echoes the surroundings. As part of the revamp, the on-site Bamboo Restaurant was also refurbished by de la Renta to match the property’s colonial vibe.

headline: Investigators in Mexico Detain Mayor and His Wife Over Missing Students
abstract: President Enrique Peña Nieto of Mexico hailed the arrests and expressed hope they would lead to the whereabouts of the 43 students missing since September.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The fugitive mayor of a southern Mexican town where 43 college students were apparently abducted in September after he reportedly ordered the police to attack them was detained Tuesday along with his wife in an early-morning raid here, federal officials said.

headline: Digital Ads Lift 3rd-Quarter Revenue at Time Inc.
abstract: The magazine company’s chief executive, Joseph A. Ripp, said strong performance in digital advertising helped offset drops in print advertising and circulation.
lead_paragraph: Time Inc., America’s largest magazine publisher, reported on Tuesday that its third-quarter revenue had increased slightly as it continued to suffer from declines in print advertising and circulation.

headline: Voting in the New York Region After a Dispiriting Campaign
abstract: Even with campaigns spending millions of dollars on ads, many people said they were casting ballots out of a sense of duty rather than excitement.
lead_paragraph: With voters in a sour and surly mood after a campaign season many found dispiriting, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York appeared poised to win re-election, although probably not with the sweeping mandate he had once hoped for, and Gov. Dannel P. Malloy of Connecticut remained locked in a tight struggle with his Republican rival.

headline: Election 2014: Live Coverage
abstract: Our politics dashboard provides up-to-the-minute updates on the aftermath of the midterm races from our correspondents across the country.
lead_paragraph: Our politics dashboard provides up-to-the-minute updates on the aftermath of the midterm races from our correspondents across the country.

headline: 1889: Witchcraft in Michigan
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: A witch hunt was spreading in Michigan villages in 1889.
lead_paragraph: HOLLAND — The little village of Graafschap, in Allegan county, is known as an industrious, quiet and religious place, but the silliest superstition of ancient times troubles them much at present. Lately several cases of severe and stubborn sickness have been attributed to some unknown witch, and for that reason pillows and feather beds were opened and carefully examined. The bunches formed inside are called crowns, wreaths, chickens or any imaginable thing. A case a few days ago of this description happened. A hot fire was made, and the crowns and such put in the fire, but would not burn; even the feathers would not be scorched; but while wondering about it, they had suddenly disappeared. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Nov. 05, 1889

headline: 1964: U.S. Vote Pleases Europeans
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Europeans were happy Lyndon B. Johnson was elected in 1964.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It was no surprise in Europe today [Nov. 4] that Lyndon B. Johnson had been elected president of the United States, but there was considerable relief at the results and the fact that the election hiatus is now over. There has not, in fact, been such complete and unconcealed partisanship among Europeans in an American election since the end of the war. In 1964 Europe had been almost as totally committed to Mr. Johnson as the American voters turned out to be. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Nov. 5, 1964

headline: A 2016 Preamble: Opposition Research for Hillary Clinton
abstract: Even before the midterm election results are tallied, American Bridge, the Democratic super PAC that supports Hillary Rodham Clinton, is tracking and researching 20 Republicans who could be potential presidential or vice presidential nominees in 2016.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton hasn’t said whether she will run for president in 2016, but it’s never too early to dig up some dirt on her potential competitors.

headline: ‘What You Sign Up For’ When You Marry Into the Military
abstract: As we prepare for my husband’s deployment, the first since the birth of our two children, a not-so-sympathetic friend asks, “But you had to know what you signed up for, right?”
lead_paragraph: Through the lump in my throat, I’ve just finished telling my friend that my husband, a lieutenant in the United States Navy, is leaving again in a few days. It will be his fourth deployment since we were married, the first since the birth of our two children.

headline: Riding Wave of Discontent, G.O.P. Takes Senate
abstract: Republicans picked up seats in Arkansas, West Virginia, Montana, South Dakota, Colorado, North Carolina and Iowa, consolidating their power on Capitol Hill.
lead_paragraph: Resurgent Republicans took control of the Senate on Tuesday night, expanded their hold on the House, and defended some of the most closely contested governors’ races, in a repudiation of President Obama that will reorder the political map in his final years in office.

headline: Voters Head To the Polls
abstract: As voting for midterm elections starts around the country, some voters get an early start.
lead_paragraph: As voting for midterm elections starts around the country, some voters get an early start.

headline: Your OkCupid Self
abstract: Critics of online dating data say it doesn’t say much about people’s real-world behavior. Might it give us insight into online behavior instead?
lead_paragraph: Who are you when you’re online dating? Are you your real self, stripped of the pretenses you put on when you’re out in the world? Do you take those pretenses with you when you log on? Or do you perhaps construct new ones, unique to the medium? And what does the self you bring to a dating site say not just about you, but about the site itself?

headline: Gigya, a Social Log-In Manager, Raises $35 Million
abstract: The financing round, led by the venture capital arm of Intel, will allow the company to expand its business of linking websites to social media.
lead_paragraph: Gigya was once a creature of an earlier social media age, starting in 2006 as a way to assist people with pages on the ill-fated social network Myspace.

headline: Millstein Hires Sovereign Restructuring Adviser
abstract: Millstein & Company, the financial advisory firm founded by James E. Millstein, has hired Mark Walker, a former banker with Rothschild.
lead_paragraph: Millstein & Company, the financial advisory firm founded by James E. Millstein, has hired Mark Walker, a former banker with Rothschild.

headline: As a Writer, What Influences You Other Than Books?
abstract: Thomas Mallon and James Parker discuss what influences their work — aside from other books.
lead_paragraph: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Thomas Mallon and James Parker discuss what influences their work — aside from other books.

headline: Lessons for a Grandfather, Unexpectedly Deployed to Afghanistan
abstract: Deployed to Afghanistan at 53, as a grandfather, Lt. Col. James Gleason Bishop struggled with the training and the idea of going at all, but found purpose even in the mundane and dangerous parts of his job.
lead_paragraph: “You know you won a free round-trip ticket to Afghanistan?” a perpetually busy chief master sergeant asked me one warm winter evening. We were at the gym at Robins Air Force Base in Houston County, Ga., after a day spent serving on a panel of public affairs chiefs.

headline: ‘S.N.L.’ Memories and Getting-Some-Rest Dreams
abstract: Amy Poehler’s new book, “Yes Please,” includes backstage “Saturday Night Live” stories, lists, old photos and guest essays from both her parents.
lead_paragraph: Amy Poehler’s memoirish book is titled “Yes Please,” as in Bring it on, but its tone is more “No, Really, Make This Stop,” as in Get me out of here.

headline: All the World’s a Gallery
abstract: No longer just for pop-music hopefuls, social media has become a way for big-name artists to prop up fresh talent.
lead_paragraph: No longer just for pop-music hopefuls, social media has become a way for big-name artists to prop up fresh talent.

headline: A New App for Travel Meet-Ups
abstract: Tripr, a new digital application, helps travelers connect with others who will be at the same destination.
lead_paragraph: “People, not places, make the trip,” is the motto of Tripr, a new digital travel application that allows travelers to connect with others who plan to be in the same place at the same time.

headline: Restaurant Review: Tuome in the East Village
abstract: Thomas Chen brings a clear and fresh point of view to his cooking, particularly when he interprets Chinese flavors.
lead_paragraph: Look inside the head of a bright young chef and you’ll see a beehive of swarming ideas, a few of them just hatched and others that buzzed in from somewhere else. It can take time to sort out which are borrowed and which have the sting of the new.

headline: Challenge at Mission Peak: Finding a Place to Park
abstract: Every Saturday and Sunday, 1,500 to 2,000 people arrive to climb Mission Peak in Fremont, Calif. However, there are only 42 parking spaces.
lead_paragraph: FREMONT, Calif. — At three miles long and 2,000 feet in elevation, the hike up Mission Peak is not for the faint of heart: The trail is dry and nearly bald, and climbing it can be painfully hot. The incline near the top is rocky and preposterously steep.

headline: In London, Sadler’s Wells Teams Up With English National Ballet
abstract: The ballet company will present two seasons a year at the theater, a partnership that is a departure for both organizations.
lead_paragraph: The London theater Sadler’s Wells announced on Tuesday that the English National Ballet would become its first associate ballet company, starting in March.

headline: 3 Million ‘Frozen’ Princess Dresses Sold, Disney Says
abstract: Disney Consumer Products released sales figures for the dresses on Tuesday, an unusual step for the company and a reflection of the movie’s $1.3 billion in global box office sales.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — More than three million “Frozen” role-play dresses have been sold this year in North America, reflecting the continuing cultural and financial effect of a movie that is now 12 months old.

headline: Early Voting: It’s Not Just for Democrats
abstract: There’s really nothing inherently partisan about expanded voting opportunities.
lead_paragraph: When Democrats in Colorado passed a series of election changes in 2013, permitting mail-in balloting and same-day registration, it was over the furious objection of Republicans. This happens every time a state tries to make voting easier, or expand the electorate, because Republicans are convinced that new voters are biased against them.

headline: New-Music Festival to Focus on Young Composers
abstract: The MATA Jr. Festival in New York will spotlight pre-college composers.
lead_paragraph: Organizations that help young composers further their careers are plentiful these days, but the MATA Festival – one of those organizations, and also one of New York’s more enterprising new-music festivals – is taking its support a step further. On Nov. 17, MATA will present its first MATA Jr. Festival at the DiMenna Center for Classical Music. The spotlight will be on works by pre-college composers, performed by Face the Music, the Kaufman Center’s student new-music ensemble.

headline: Republicans Have Already Won a Governor’s Race Today, in Guam
abstract: Gov. Eddie Calvo, a Republican, has been re-elected in a landslide. The Republican incumbent also leads in the Northern Mariana Islands.
lead_paragraph: Even before noon on the East Coast, Republicans notched a governor’s race victory on Tuesday: in Guam, where Gov. Eddie Calvo was re-elected in a landslide. In the nearby Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, Gov. Eloy Inos, also a Republican incumbent, leads with most of the votes counted but is likely to face a runoff.

headline: Tracey Emin on Middle Age and the Cuteness of Andy Warhol’s Cats
abstract: The artist, who has curated an online auction launching on Paddle8 tomorrow, talks with T about the project and her newest body of work.
lead_paragraph: In July, the German collector Count Christian Duerckheim purchased Tracey Emin’s “My Bed” — the artist’s notorious Turner Prize-nominated work from the late ’90s, a bed on which she had slept and left bodily secretions and discarded junk — at auction for a record $3.7 million. Somewhat more cautious buyers will have the occasion to bid on a few of the iconic British artist’s more modest originals — several monoprints and neon installations with estimates between $10,000 and $150,000 — when Emin curates a sale for the online auction house Paddle8, which launches today. Called “From the Cute to the Powerful,” the auction will also feature an Emin-picked selection of works from artists such as Tim Noble and Sue Webster, Cindy Sherman and Jenny Holzer; 100 percent of the proceeds from two of Emin’s pieces in the show will go to support the Serpentine Trust.

headline: ‘The Fashion Fund’ and ‘House of DVF’ Reveal Fashion Truths
abstract: Two reality shows prove that before you design clothes, you need to design a personality.
lead_paragraph: A scene in Episode 1 of the Ovation series “The Fashion Fund” — the documentary that has its season premiere on Wednesday and offers a behind-the-scenes look at the selection of the winner of the 2014 CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund, a.k.a. the big kahuna prize for an emerging American designer — is as revealing of current fashion-world reality as anything I’ve seen.

headline: What We’re Watching on Election Day
abstract: Voters will be deciding on mandatory GMO labels and taxes on sugar-sweetened beverages.
lead_paragraph: In addition to seeing who will control the Senate, here are four specific votes we’ll be watching:

headline: Colts Blessed by All Kinds of Fortune
abstract: Fate has smiled on Indianapolis as it has on few other franchises in such a short time, delivering Andrew Luck to the Colts in what was as opportune a superstar transition game as possible.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Why was Reggie Wayne crying during the national anthem before his Indianapolis Colts turned MetLife Stadium into a fourth-quarter ghost town of gray empty seats Monday night in a not-as-close-as-it-sounds 40-24 demolition of the Giants?

headline: An Apple-Like Valuation for a Chinese Rival
abstract: A new funding round could give Xiaomi a valuation of as much as $50 billion, but the Chinese company lacks the market dominance and innovation that would justify such a price, Ethan Bilby of Reuters Breakingviews writes.
lead_paragraph: The Chinese smartphone maker Xiaomi is a hit with customers, but its upward valuation spiral seems hard to justify. A new funding round could value the group at as much as $50 billion, according to Bloomberg News. That suggests investors are valuing it the same way they do Apple. Xiaomi is growing fast, but it lacks its American rival’s dominance or innovation.

headline: S.E.C. Raises Barrier to Disclosure of Information
abstract: Despite efforts to improve disclosure under the Freedom of Information Act, the S.E.C. continues to resist sharing data with the public, William D. Cohan writes in the Street Scene column.
lead_paragraph: The Freedom of Information Act is supposed to make it easier for journalists and ordinary Americans to obtain documents and other information about how the federal government conducts its business. As such, it is one of the bedrocks of our democracy. “It is often described as the law that keeps citizens in the know about their government,” boasts FOIA.gov, a website dedicated to the law.

headline: Health Care at the Bagel Shop
abstract: Reaching businesses like Bagel Grove in Utica, N.Y., is a priority for the new health care law. But as the cost of coverage has climbed, companies are struggling to afford coverage for employees.
lead_paragraph: Reaching businesses like Bagel Grove in Utica, N.Y., is a priority for the new health care law. But as the cost of coverage has climbed, companies are struggling to afford coverage for employees.

headline: Today in Small Business: Minimum Wage and Marijuana
abstract: Why the economy and voter perception of the economy are two different things. A study shows that shorter email subject lines deliver higher open rates. Is it possible to go an entire week using only mobile payment?
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Voters Head To the Polls
abstract: As voting for midterm elections starts around the country, some voters get an early start.
lead_paragraph: As voting for midterm elections starts around the country, some voters get an early start.

headline: Providing Health Insurance Still a Struggle for Small Business
abstract: A year after the insurance marketplaces were introduced as part of the Affordable Care Act, provisions meant to help small businesses offer benefits to employees have yet to fulfill their promise.
lead_paragraph: Brian Adams, who sells fireplaces in Indianapolis, is like many of the nation’s small-business owners. As the cost of providing health benefits has climbed, he has struggled to afford coverage for his employees — a problem the new health care law was designed, in part, to address.

headline: A House Race to Remember That Staten Islanders Would Sooner Forget
abstract: The campaign for the 11th Congressional District of New York has been memorable, but for reasons that make residents cringe.
lead_paragraph: The nadir did not arrive in January, Staten Islanders say, when their congressman threatened to throw a reporter off a Capitol balcony — nor in April, when the 20-count federal indictment was handed up.

headline: Musical America Award Goes to Peter Sellars
abstract: Peter Sellars was named artist of the year for his inventive staging of Bach’s “St. Matthew Passion” with the Berlin Philharmonic at the Park Avenue Armory
lead_paragraph: Musical America, the venerable classical music publication, has announced its annual awards, which this year include a departure: the top award, usually musician of the year, has been renamed artist of the year. The winner, the publication announced on Tuesday, is Peter Sellars, the iconoclastic director whose biggest success this season was his inventive staging of Bach’s “St. Matthew Passion” with the Berlin Philharmonic at the Park Avenue Armory, as part of Lincoln Center’s White Light Festival. But he is also known for his productions of works by John Adams, Mozart and Handel.

headline: Election 2014: The Vote You Save May Be Your Own
abstract: The rising importance of the provisional ballot.
lead_paragraph: Millions of Americans will head to the polls today, and many of them will confront some of the most serious obstacles to voting in decades, including strict new photo ID requirements in several states. No voter, however, should be turned away without the opportunity to cast at least a provisional ballot. In an environment in which partisan legislatures aggressively curtail voting rights, the protections provisional ballots offer are especially vital.

headline: Elisa Monte to Retire From Dance Company
abstract: Ms. Monte founded Elisa Monte Dance in 1981, and will be replaced as artistic director by Tiffany Rea-Fisher.
lead_paragraph: Elisa Monte, the veteran choreographer, will retire as artistic director of Elisa Monte Dance, the noted modern dance company she started in 1981. Ms. Monte, 68, announced her retirement on Monday night, following a private tour of the Fashion Institute of Technology’s “Dance & Fashion” exhibition. Tiffany Rea-Fisher, the company’s associate artistic director, will take over from Ms. Monte in 2016.

headline: Rings Around the City
abstract: In New York, a proliferation of styles and shapes threatens to capsize the whole idea of a doughnut.
lead_paragraph: Dough, fried. It is a humble snack, fuel for late-night stakeouts, comfort after a day toiling at the nuclear power plant.

headline: He Wants His Name in Lights but Could Use an Editor
abstract: “Spacebar: A Broadway Play by Kyle Sugarman” is a coming-of-age comedy about a Colorado drama geek yearning for his father, who has fled to New York.
lead_paragraph: Hey, Broadway! Kyle Sugarman has a play called “Spacebar” that he’d like you to read. If you’ve been checking your mail, you may have noticed that he’s sent it three times — all several hundred pages of it.

headline: A Documentary Follows the Curious Career of Maurizio Cattelan
abstract: The artist, who plays the jester in public but fiercely guards his privacy, is the subject of “Maurizio Cattelan: The Movie.”
lead_paragraph: The artist Maurizio Cattelan – who famously retired at the age of 51 in 2011, after a highly unconventional retrospective in which he dangled his works in the rotunda of the Guggenheim museum in New York – seems to be having a post-career livelier than his career.

headline: Off to the Stars, With Grief, Dread and Regret
abstract: In Christopher Nolan’s science-fiction parable “Interstellar,” Earth is dying, and a team of astronauts searches the universe for a new home for the human race.
lead_paragraph: Like the great space epics of the past, Christopher Nolan’s “Interstellar” distills terrestrial anxieties and aspirations into a potent pop parable, a mirror of the mood down here on Earth. Stanley Kubrick’s “2001: A Space Odyssey” blended the technological awe of the Apollo era with the trippy hopes and terrors of the Age of Aquarius. George Lucas’s first “Star Wars” trilogy, set not in the speculative future but in the imaginary past, answered the malaise of the ’70s with swashbuckling nostalgia. “Interstellar,” full of visual dazzle, thematic ambition, geek bait and corn (including the literal kind), is a sweeping, futuristic adventure driven by grief, dread and regret.

headline: Plan for a Times Square in Mumbai Stirs Criticism
abstract: India’s government would like to boost tourism by turning a historic neighborhood into a bustling cultural hub, but many locals don’t want the noise and congestion it could bring.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI — It was a bold, if somewhat mystifying, proposal.

headline: For Republicans, What Counts as Victory?
abstract: The midterms and the expectations game.
lead_paragraph: You won’t get formal midterm predictions from me today — that’s why we have Mr. Silver’s difference engine and Mr. Leonhardt’s Skynet, surely — but I do have a couple of thoughts on the debate over what the midterm results mean for the Republican Party’s political position overall. Over the weekend, as the Republican advantage seemed to solidify, a number of writers made the point that the G.O.P. could probably win the Senate without making the kind of inroads that would bode well for their chances of winning the White House (or even keeping the Senate) two years hence. This year’s midterm map is unusually unrepresentative of the country as a whole, the Washington Post’s Patrick Egan noted, and so tonight’s outcomes don’t tell us that much about the future; the G.O.P. is winning more on second-term disillusionment than on any positive vision or agenda, two the party’s pollsters argued in the same newspaper, and isn’t showing any signs of expanding the electoral map into blue territory. The upshot (if you will) of these patterns, my colleague Nate Cohn suggested, is that Republicans are poised to retake the Senate without winning over “many voters who supported President Obama in 2012″ — an outcome that would indicate they’ve “made little progress in attracting voters they would need to take back the White House.”

headline: Cleveland Orchestra Director to Retire Next Year
abstract: Gary Hanson, the executive director of the Cleveland Orchestra, announced Tuesday that he would retire next October.
lead_paragraph: Gary Hanson, the executive director of the Cleveland Orchestra, announced Tuesday that he would retire next October — a few years shy of the orchestra’s 2017-18 centennial season.

headline: The Secret About Undecided Voters: They’re Predictable
abstract: Those who make a decision are likely to choose a candidate that most closely represents their party or positions — and more so in the battleground states.
lead_paragraph: Candidates for Congress have aired more than two million television ads this year. They will have spent more than $3.6 billion. And yet there is still a small set of registered voters who are unsure about their votes in races that could pivot control of the Senate.

headline: Letter From the Editor: A New Way to Follow Elections
abstract: Tracking election results by looking at the initial raw-vote totals can be very misleading. We have a better way.
lead_paragraph: We’re going to try a new way to follow election results tonight, and we’re excited about it.

headline: Exit Polls: Why They So Often Mislead
abstract: When the first exit polls start to circulate Tuesday afternoon, some analysts will start talking about surprises. Here’s a guide to why that’s a mistake.
lead_paragraph: Did you think John Kerry was poised to win the presidency? That Scott Walker was close to losing the 2012 governor’s recall election in Wisconsin? Do you believe that the black share of the electorate in North Carolina dropped to 23 percent in 2012, from 26 percent in 2004?

headline: Why Did I Vote That Way? Don’t Ask Me
abstract: Researchers find that asking people to explain their choices isn’t always informative.
lead_paragraph: When the returns from tonight’s election start to become clear, the debate is likely to turn, as it so often does, to why the American people voted the way they did.

headline: Election Will Leave Medicaid Policies Largely Unchanged
abstract: Victories for Republican governors in several states means those states are not likely to expand coverage under the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: This article has been updated with election results.

headline: Smartphones and Social Media Play Larger Role in This Election
abstract: A survey finds people using Facebook and Twitter to feel personally connected to candidates, to get information first or to avoid news media spin.
lead_paragraph: More Americans have been following this election cycle glued to their phones and social media than ever before, according to a new report from Pew Research Center.

headline: Republicans Hold Advantage in Run for Senate
abstract: But a weak right flank leaves the Democratic path to victory broader than it might be.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a long and chaotic election cycle, but, in the end, we’re about where we thought we would be: The Republicans have a 75 percent chance to win control of the Senate, according to the final run of Leo, The Upshot’s Senate model. But both a Republican landslide and a narrow Democratic majority remain possibilities.

headline: Absurdism, Scrubbed and Domesticated
abstract: Genet’s “The Maids” is reconceived with a little help from the professionals — professional housekeepers, that is — at Abrons Arts Center.
lead_paragraph: Isabel Sanchez takes an odd approach to housecleaning. In “The Maids’ The Maids,” at Abrons Arts Center, she bops onto the stage in a frilly apron, feather dusters and dishwashing gloves at the ready. Then she starts spilling corn chips and cheese curls all over the floor. She puts a raw egg between her teeth and crunches it. Shell and yolk and albumen drip from her lips.

headline: Are European Museum Passes Worth the Money?
abstract: The answer: It depends. That said, here are some things to consider if you’re visiting Amsterdam, Madrid, Florence or Paris.
lead_paragraph: Visit the tourism office in any major city in Europe and you’ll most likely find an offer to purchase a museum pass – a card that gives the holder entry to multiple local museums. Some passes include additional perks – priority entrance, discounts at monuments, free use of public transportation – but the high prices have always left me skeptical: These passes are marketed to tourists as a way to save money, but how many museums do you need to visit before you’ve recouped the cost of the pass? And were all of those museums already on your itinerary? To determine if the passes really are bargains, I examined the offers in four museum-dense European cities popular with travelers: Amsterdam, Madrid, Florence and Paris. So what’s the verdict on these supposed money-savers? It depends on the city – and on the traveler’s interests, allotted time and stamina.

headline: Recalling Anne Frank, as Icon and Human Being
abstract: As the anniversary of Kristallnacht, a watershed event in the Holocaust, approaches, relatives and friends of Anne Frank share memories of the girl who became a symbol of murdered innocence.
lead_paragraph: Eva Schloss, a playmate of Anne Frank’s in Amsterdam whose mother later married Anne’s father, recalls an 11-year-old who hopscotched, shot marbles, gossiped and talked so much her friends nicknamed her “Miss Quack Quack.”

headline: Watch Out for the Plaster Casts
abstract: The dancer and choreographer Jonah Bokaer was joined by Valda Setterfield and others at Lightbox.
lead_paragraph: Jonah Bokaer, the dancer and choreographer, knows how to make an entrance. When three of his pieces were performed recently at Lightbox, a small convertible space in Hell’s Kitchen, he did not appear until the second section. His head entered first. It probed into the performance area on top of a spine that was slowly arching backward toward the floor. He stayed bent for a long time.

headline: At Tijuana Picnic, Mexican Food With an Asian Touch
abstract: The partners who are involved in Indochine and Acme are trying their hands at yet another cuisine.
lead_paragraph: Headliner

headline: Why One Insurer Sees a Growing Market for Small-Business Health Insurance
abstract: Health Care Service Corporation sees an opportunity to attract small businesses that have not previously offered health insurance.
lead_paragraph: In an article The Times has just published, Reed Abelson surveys how small businesses are reacting to the Affordable Care Act. She found that some businesses are dropping coverage, and most are avoiding the government-run health insurance exchanges set up for small businesses. But Ms. Abelson encountered one insurance company that hoped to do a brisk business in the small-group market next year.

headline: Warner Bros. Begins Layoffs to Cut Costs
abstract: Hollywood’s largest movie and television studio will ultimately lose 1,000 jobs amid trims by its parent company, Time Warner.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Warner Bros. on Tuesday began layoffs that will ultimately eliminate about 1,000 jobs, or 12.5 percent of the studio’s total staff, as it tries to increase profitability in the face of weak domestic box-office sales and a challenged television business.

headline: Awash in Campaign Cash, Cuomo Benefited From Big Donors and Loopholes
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has raised more than $45 million over the past four years, according to a research group. His opponent, Rob Astorino, had raised $4.8 million as of last month.
lead_paragraph: Even as he confronted a federal investigation and sagging poll numbers, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo always possessed one source of comfort: No matter the adversity he faced, he could pay for enough television advertising to try to wash his problems away.

headline: ‘Not Rescuing’ Our Kids Shouldn’t Mean Letting Them Flounder
abstract: I understand why so many of the smartest women I know are proudly carrying the no-rescue flag. Hovering and rescuing isn’t a good way to raise kids. But do we really need to leave them to flounder alone?
lead_paragraph: Say “helicopter parenting” and then picture the buzzing drone overhead flinging string cheese and geometry answers to the helpless below. Say “no-rescue parenting” and picture the lifeguard who is watching your child wrestle an octopus before looking away.

headline: Student Crossword | Voting in the U.S.A.
abstract: Test your knowledge of voting in the United States by playing our crossword.
lead_paragraph: Test your knowledge of voting in the United States by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

headline: Election 2014: Only the Polarized Are Actually Polarized
abstract: The more ideological you are, the more ideological you think other people are.
lead_paragraph: According to the conventional wisdom, American politics and politicians are more polarized now than they have been since the Civil War, reflecting a growing chasm between Democrats and Republicans. But what if the conventional wisdom is wrong? There’s no question that politicians are more divided; just look at their voting records. But what if the polarization of politicians reflects a common mistake about Americans — a widely held but false belief that Democratic and Republican voters are more divided than they actually are?

headline: Why the Time Is Now to Predict (Loudly) a Democratic Victory
abstract: You have a chance to be the only pundit in the country to correctly predict the race, and to bask in the resulting glory.
lead_paragraph: Want to be a superstar political pundit? Here’s my advice: Predict the Democrats to hold the Senate. Do it now, do it loudly and do it confidently.

headline: Catalonia to Defy Court With Independence Straw Poll
abstract: Catalan leaders vowed to challenge the Spanish government on the grounds that it had violated the right of Catalans to decide their own future.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — The regional government of Catalonia said Tuesday that it would go ahead with a straw poll on independence, scheduled for this Sunday, in seeming defiance of an order from Spain’s Constitutional Court to suspend the ballot.

headline: French Political Scions Exchange Jabs in Twitter Feud
abstract: Louis Sarkozy, son of Nicolas Sarkozy, has been dueling with Léonard Trierweiler, whose mother was the partner of President François Hollande.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Being a teenager is seldom easy, and all the more difficult, perhaps, if you are the son of a former president or first lady in the age of Twitter, and your every impolitic outburst or adolescent angst can play out in front of thousands in a single indiscreet click.

headline: Protests Erupt in Kashmir After Army Shooting
abstract: A day after Indian soldiers shot dead two people in a car that did not stop at a checkpoint, angry crowds gathered in Kashmir, chanting slogans and throwing stones.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Protests broke out in Indian-administered Kashmir on Tuesday, a day after Indian soldiers opened fire on a car that did not stop at a checkpoint, killing two people in the car and wounding another two, all civilians.

headline: As Qaeda-Backed Group Makes Gains, Rift Grows Among Rebels in Syria
abstract: The Nusra Front has been expanding its control in the northern province of Idlib, seizing territory from two Western-supported rebel organizations.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — The Nusra Front, a Syrian rebel group affiliated with Al Qaeda, has been expanding its control in the northern province of Idlib, seizing territory from two Western-supported rebel organizations and potentially threatening a critical border crossing with Turkey, according to rebels and monitoring groups.

headline: Rising Stars of Fashion Take a Bow
abstract: Paul Andrew wins top prize at CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund dinner.
lead_paragraph: Paul Andrew wins top prize at CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund dinner.

headline: Judge Declines to Block Ackman From Voting in Board Fight at Allergan
abstract: William A. Ackman’s hedge fund could vote its stake in Allergan in support of ousting directors at a meeting scheduled for Dec. 18, bolstering his effort to force the company into a sale.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Tuesday declined to block the hedge fund billionaire William A. Ackman from voting his firm’s shares in a fight for control of the board of Allergan, the maker of Botox, potentially bolstering his effort to force the company into a sale to Valeant Pharmaceuticals International.

headline: Icahn’s Publicly Traded Arm Is Stung by Energy Investments
abstract: Icahn Enterprises, part of Carl Icahn’s investment empire, reported a third-quarter loss of $355 million, driven by lower values of energy investments like CVR Refining and CVR Energy.
lead_paragraph: Carl C. Icahn has profited from a string of recent bets on prominent companies like eBay, Netflix and Family Dollar. But the energy sector is giving the activist investor some trouble.

headline: David Leonhardt Thinks That Even Football Is Political
abstract: David Leonhardt discusses the politics of playing football on WNYC’s “The Takeaway.”
lead_paragraph: David Leonhardt, the editor of “The Upshot,” joined WNYC’s “The Takeaway” on Tuesday morning to preview the midterm elections and discuss his piece on the politics of playing football.

headline: The Fabulous Beekman Boys Pop Up in the East Village
abstract: The pair, made famous by two reality shows, have opened a branch of their gift shop for the holidays.
lead_paragraph: Brent Ridge and Josh Kilmer-Purcell, whom some may know from their television show “The Fabulous Beekman Boys” (currently in reruns on the Cooking Channel), or as winners of “The Amazing Race” two years ago, have opened a pop-up shop in the East Village. Mr. Ridge said he chose the location because it had a “sense of sustainability, grit, strife and entrepreneurship that perfectly fits where our company is at the moment.” Called The Beekman 1802 Holiday Gift Emporium, the pop-up is a mini-version of the couple’s flagship Beekman 1802 Mercantile, in their hometown of Sharon Springs, N.Y., with some of the same offerings. These include the Lump of Kohl soap ($15) made from the milk of goats on their farm, cheese cutters forged by their blacksmith ($28), linens made by their master weaver and autographed copies of their four books.

headline: Ford, Nissan and Toyota Issue Recalls
abstract: Ford issues five recalls, Nissan issues two and Toyota posts one for various defects.
lead_paragraph: Ford is recalling about 200,000 vehicles in five actions in North America for problems including airbags that might not deploy in a crash, possible fires and a steering defect that was not corrected in a previous recall, the automaker said on Tuesday. In all five recalls, Ford said it was aware of one accident, but no injuries.

headline: Island-Hopping in the Caribbean With Carrie Gibson
abstract: The British historian, who toured the region to research her new book, talks about ferries versus flying, places to stay and more.
lead_paragraph: Colonialism has left its mark on many aspects of Caribbean life. Among them: travel.

headline: Creditors Keep Troubled Law Schools on Life Support
abstract: Creditors do not move to shut down a law school because keeping a struggling school alive means there is some possibility of repayment, writes Steven Davidoff Solomon in the Deal Professor column.
lead_paragraph: A recent debt restructuring at Thomas Jefferson School of Law shows that a law school may be worth absolutely nothing.

headline: What Is the Future of ‘Alex From Target’?
abstract: A young Target employee’s picture has gone viral, but who benefits from his fame?
lead_paragraph: The rise to Internet fame of the young man known as “Alex From Target” has focused attention on Target, on teenagers, and, of course, on Alex himself. Now, those who have followed his rise are considering which of these parties will actually benefit from it.

headline: Joni Ernst Votes
abstract: Joni Ernst, the Republican candidate for Senate in Iowa, voted in Red Oak, Iowa, after a 24-hour tour of the state ended the morning of the 2014 midterm election.
lead_paragraph: Joni Ernst, the Republican candidate for Senate in Iowa, voted in Red Oak, Iowa, after a 24-hour tour of the state ended the morning of the 2014 midterm election.

headline: Numbers Tell the Story: The A.F.C. North Is the N.F.L.'s Best Division
abstract: The division’s teams — the Bengals, the Browns, the Ravens and the Steelers — are a combined 14-5-1 when not facing one another.
lead_paragraph: At the midway mark of the season, the A.F.C. North is the best division in football. By the end of the year, it may be viewed as one of the strongest divisions in N.F.L. history.

headline: Adrian Peterson Agrees to Plea Deal in Child-Abuse Case
abstract: Peterson, a Vikings running back accused of disciplining his 4-year-old son with a switch, will pay a fine and perform community service after pleading no contest to a reduced charge.
lead_paragraph: Minnesota Vikings running back Adrian Peterson agreed to a plea bargain Tuesday, reducing his felony child-abuse charges to a single charge of reckless assault, a misdemeanor that comes with a $4,000 fine and an order to perform community service.

headline: Verizon Wireless Under Fire for Ad-Targeting Program
abstract: The cellular provider uses a unique identifier inserted into its customers’ web page requests to tailor advertising to them, raising concerns by online-privacy watchdogs.
lead_paragraph: Google and Facebook are not the only companies tracking your online activities to customize ads. Verizon Wireless has recently come under fire from privacy advocates for running a similar program on its cellular network.

headline: Voters Around the Nation on Election Day
abstract: Voters in Manchester, N.H., Manhattan Beach, Calif., Overland Park, Kan., Greensboro, N.C., Arlington, Va., and Miami spoke out from polling stations on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Voters in Manchester, N.H., Manhattan Beach, Calif., Overland Park, Kan., Greensboro, N.C., Arlington, Va., and Miami spoke out from polling stations on Tuesday.

headline: Supreme Court Weighs Air Marshal’s Firing in Whistle-Blower Case
abstract: The court appeared ready to agree that the air marshal, Robert J. MacLean, was covered by federal law when he disclosed safety fears to a reporter.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A majority of the justices seemed ready to side with a fired air marshal on Tuesday in a Supreme Court argument over whether he was covered by a federal law protecting whistle-blowers.

headline: An Eclectic Evening to Start a Season
abstract: The Riverside Symphony, conducted by George Rothman, opened its new season at Alice Tully Hall on Saturday night with the pianist Hélène Tysman.
lead_paragraph: In the musical world, we still have work to do to broaden and update our canon, perhaps to go beyond the very idea of a canon at all. But even beyond the major orchestras and star soloists, plenty of performers have been engaged in such an effort for years.

headline: A California Location for Cycling House Camps
abstract: The Cycling House will offer training camps designed for endurance cyclists and triathletes in Solvang, Calif., this winter.
lead_paragraph: The Cycling House has added Solvang, Calif., to its staple of winter training camps for the 2014-15 winter season.

headline: Google Glass May Have a Blind Spot, Study Says
abstract: A research letter about a very small sample test said Google Glass may create a small blind spot on the right side.
lead_paragraph: Is that an email in your eyes, or are you about to get hit by a truck?

headline: Pixie Remorse and Remedies
abstract: Tips for ladies who regret their sharply shorn pixie cuts as they endure the slow process back to longer hair.
lead_paragraph: It turns out not everyone is Halle Berry.

headline: Voter Voice: New Hampshire
abstract: Ann Halloran of Salem, N.H., believes voters need to think about what’s happening on the national level as they cast ballots in the midterm election.
lead_paragraph: Ann Halloran of Salem, N.H., believes voters need to think about what’s happening on the national level as they cast ballots in the midterm election.

headline: An Author Mines His Niche, One Usually Filled With Song
abstract: The writer David Ritz reflects on his career of helping celebrities, often recording artists, put their lives on the page.
lead_paragraph: David Ritz was deep in his element one recent afternoon, taking the measure of a complex life and its cherished music at the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem. The occasion was a memorial service for the jazz singer Jimmy Scott, whose widow, Jeanie, sat beside Mr. Ritz’s wife, Roberta, in a curved wooden pew. Draped in a black Issey Miyake tunic — his version of somber finery — Mr. Ritz, the author of “Faith in Time: The Jazz Life of Jimmy Scott,” sat appreciatively before a succession of songs and spoken tributes, sneaking odd glances at his own prepared remarks on an iPad screen.

headline: Playing With Those Poolside Toys, Jealousy and Guilt
abstract: “Pool (no water),” Mark Ravenhill’s dark comedy, which had a brief run in 2012, has reopened off Broadway at the Barrow Street Theater.
lead_paragraph: “Pool (no water),” which had a brief run at PS122, beginning in May 2012, has reopened off Broadway at the Barrow Street Theater, 27 Barrow Street, at Seventh Avenue South, West Village; 212-868-4444, smarttix.com. Following are excerpts from Charles Isherwood’s review, which appeared in The New York Times on May 15, 2012; the full text is online at nytimes.com/theater.

headline: A Swan Song Season Begins on the Jersey Shore
abstract: As the final season of “Snooki & Jwoww” begins, the two stars of the show are pregnant.
lead_paragraph: Back in 2009 and 2010, when  Nicole Polizzi was getting flattened in a bar fight and arrested for disorderly conduct on “Jersey Shore,” she didn’t look like the future star of one of television’s most comforting depictions of middle-class domesticity. But here she is, pregnant with her second child, learning to bake, living in her prospective mother-in-law’s basement. Our little Snooki has grown up.

headline: Jacolby Satterwhite’s Kinetic Mixed-Media Creations
abstract: The artist’s work is kaleidoscopic, weird — and totally genius.
lead_paragraph: The artist’s work is kaleidoscopic, weird — and totally genius.

headline: Wheelies: The SEMA Van Edition
abstract: Mercedes-Benz to unveil midsize project van concepts at SEMA; Ford plant in Chicago sued for sexual harassment.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Pictures of the Day: the United States and Elsewhere
abstract: The United States and Elsewhere — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: The United States and Elsewhere — Pictures of the Day

headline: Seeking New Tools to Address a Wage Gap
abstract: Redistributing income with taxes and transfers is largely failing to close the income gap. Perhaps it’s time to try a corporate approach.
lead_paragraph: What can be done about income inequality?

headline: Offering Playwrights a Better Deal
abstract: Playwrights Horizons, a leading New York company, is now paying authors for meetings and helping with health insurance.
lead_paragraph: Playwrights may deliver the essential ingredient for any theater production — the script — but they are often the only people on the artistic team who go unpaid during casting auditions and rehearsals for their shows, and they usually fend for themselves with health insurance, too. But one major Off Broadway theater company is changing that, aiming to offer a model for compensation after years of national debate about ways to help often struggling playwrights.

headline: Today’s Best Pictures
abstract: As chosen by our editors. (Besides election news!)
lead_paragraph: As chosen by our editors. (Besides election news!)

headline: A Music Video From the Lagerfeld-Approved Rapper Theophilus London
abstract: The Kaiser shot the cover art for London’s new album, “Vibes,” out today.
lead_paragraph: “I got misconstrued a lot,” the rapper Theophilus London says of the reception to his 2011 debut, “Timez Are Weird These Days.” “People thought I was just some fashion kid who wanted to rap, when honestly I hadn’t even walked into a Chanel store until 2010.” London was — and still is — first and foremost a musician, as his sophomore album, “Vibes,” out today, should prove: It’s a fully manifested vision, recorded entirely in Palm Springs (his last was brought to life in a Stockholm studio). “The difference this time was I could focus. Much less hot babes and much more old ladies in the desert,” he says. “I was celibate the entire time.”

headline: Election 2014: The Campaign in North Carolina Is Not ‘About Nothing’
abstract: The left won’t talk openly about ideology, while the right pretends to ignore its own identity politics.
lead_paragraph: Chapel Hill, N.C. — Over the last few weeks it has become fashionable to ridicule this election as a jumble of debates that don’t resonate with the average American. The Washington Post deemed these midterms “kind of — with apologies to Seinfeld — an election about nothing,” and many other journalists have echoed the comparison. The joke is an old one: “as the reigning cliché had it, 2002 was the ‘Seinfeld’ election — an election about nothing,” Frank Rich wrote in these pages 12 years ago.

headline: Japan on the Brink
abstract: Fiscal credibility isn’t crucial right now, anti-deflation credibility is.
lead_paragraph: When a nation is engaged in a real policy debate — the kind we’re not having in the United States, because America’s right wing knows what it knows, and never looks at evidence or admits mistakes — certain decisions take on significance that goes beyond their substantive importance, because they are symbols of the broader direction. So it is with Japan’s current plan to hike consumption taxes a second time. Not that this is a trivial decision on the substance; it would be a fairly big deal in any case. But right now it has become more — a sort of Rubicon for policy.

headline: Nov. 4, 2014 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from the United States, Bahrain, Kashmir and France.
lead_paragraph: Photos from the United States, Bahrain, Kashmir and France.

headline: Final Upshot Senate Forecast: Republicans at 75 Percent
abstract: The G.O.P. has a good chance, about 50-50, of not needing runoffs and winning control of the Senate outright tonight.
lead_paragraph: After the odds hovered around 60 or 70 percent for the past several months, the chances that Republicans would take the Senate rose to 75 percent in this morning’s forecast from Leo, the Upshot’s Senate forecasting model.

headline: Four Centuries, One Compositional Voice
abstract: The pianist Peter Serkin presented a centuries-spanning program at a Peoples’ Symphony Concert on Oct. 25.
lead_paragraph: If you’re looking for a concert experience totally without artifice, the Peoples’ Symphony Concerts at the Washington Irving High School auditorium in Manhattan fit the bill. It’s not just the ticket price ($14) of these concerts, now in their centenary season in this airy, acoustically bright hall, that endears. The program tells you all you need to know and little more. Generic cough drops are offered in a little bowl by the door, but few are taken. On a recent night, coats were strewed just to the left of the stage, next to a floor fan pasted with a scrawled note reading “broken.”

headline: Fantasy Football: Week 10 Waiver Wire Picks
abstract: Fantasy owners will be without Tom Brady, Rob Gronkowski, Alfred Morris, Philip Rivers, Arian Foster, Andrew Luck and T.Y. Hilton this week.
lead_paragraph: So you made it through Week 9 without Aaron Rodgers, Brandon Marshall, Sammy Watkins, Jordy Nelson, Randall Cobb, Eddie Lacy and Matt Forte. Congratulations.

headline: International Mensch Fund
abstract: Facing up to austerity mistakes.
lead_paragraph: The IMF has released an audit of its own response during the aftermath of the financial crisis, which concludes that it messed up by embracing fiscal austerity in 2010. It failed to understand that you need to differentiate between economies that borrow in someone else’s currency and those that don’t; it failed to appreciate that the negative effects of fiscal contraction would be much larger in a zero-lower-bound environment than historical patterns might suggest.

headline: 2014 SEMA Show Opens in Las Vegas
abstract: Event organizers expect 2,500 automotive aftermarket equipment manufacturers to present products to 60,000 wholesale buyers.
lead_paragraph: The Specialty Equipment Market Association’s annual trade show opened here on Tuesday, spread out over more than a million square feet of space at the Las Vegas Convention Center.

headline: Families Receive Loved Ones Killed in Peru’s Dirty War
abstract: The International Red Cross recently delivered the bodies, which were exhumed last year and identified in Peru.
lead_paragraph: The International Red Cross recently delivered the bodies, which were exhumed last year and identified in Peru.
