headline: Gigi Jordan, Charged in Her Son’s Death, Wages Publicity Blitz as She Awaits Verdict
abstract: Murder defendants avoid making public statements after a trial begins, but Ms. Jordan, who is accused of poisoning her 8-year-old son in Manhattan, is not staying silent.
lead_paragraph: Most murder defendants avoid making public statements after a trial starts, and that rule goes double once a jury begins its deliberations.

headline: Sadness Amid the Laughter
abstract: The makers of the comedy “A Merry Friggin’ Christmas,” one of Robin Williams’s last movies, have found his death a delicate challenge.
lead_paragraph: When he finished shooting “A Merry Friggin’ Christmas” in spring 2013, Joel McHale was proud to have played a lead role in this holiday satire about a man who comes to terms with his estranged father, and to have acted alongside Robin Williams, one of his heroes.

headline: Sesame Workshop Bullish on Children’s Magazines
abstract: Sesame Street magazine is being reintroduced, and a digital publication called Sesame Street S’More is selling well in the Apple store.
lead_paragraph: At a time when the magazine business is struggling, Sesame Workshop is making the case that the demand for magazines for young readers is still strong.

headline: Voters at the Polls
abstract: Control of the Senate is at stake as voting in the midterm elections takes place around the country.
lead_paragraph: Control of the Senate is at stake as voting in the midterm elections takes place around the country.

headline: Joni Ernst Wins Iowa Senate Seat for Republicans
abstract: Updated election news from The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Joni Ernst, a dogged campaigner who rose from a relatively unknown one-term state senator to a household name, eked out a victory over Representative Bruce Braley Tuesday night to win a Senate seat and become the first woman elected to Congress from Iowa.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: New York Times reporters and editors highlight great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Peter Baker, Dan Saltzstein and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Morgan Stanley to Get $1.3 Billion Benefit
abstract: A change in the structure of its Morgan Stanley Smith Barney business allows the firm to release $1.3 billion it had previously set aside for taxes.
lead_paragraph: While other banks are reporting big additional legal costs, Morgan Stanley said Tuesday that it would get a one-time lift of $1.3 billion as a result of a change in the structure of its Morgan Stanley Smith Barney operation.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Peter Baker, Dan Saltzstein and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Election Spending Is Changing, as Well as Expanding
abstract: This campaign featured record expenditures, but it’s also worth paying attention to how that money was spent.
lead_paragraph: The title of Most Expensive Midterm Election can obscure the fact that campaigns raise and spend money very differently.

headline: How 10 New Yorkers Flaunted Their “I Voted” Stickers
abstract: New Yorkers who voted Tuesday proudly and creatively showed off their “I Voted” stickers. Here’s a selection of shots taken from neighborhoods around the city, worn by voters and even tolerated by a few pets.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers who voted on Tuesday proudly and creatively showed off their “I Voted” stickers. Here’s a selection of Instagram photos from various New York City neighborhoods, worn by voters and even tolerated by a few pets.

headline: Election 2014: Should Black Voters Keep Their Faith in Obama?
abstract: President Obama may be a flawed politician, but he has guided the nation through troubled waters. Black voters should resist alienation.
lead_paragraph: MY trainer, a 31-year-old black man, doesn’t vote. It doesn’t make any difference which party wins, he says. He doesn’t believe that President Obama is really in charge.

headline: Framing the Viewers, and the Viewed
abstract: “National Gallery,” a documentary, uses that London museum to expose the heart of the network of relationships connecting art, artists, institutions and the public.
lead_paragraph: The explicit subject of Frederick Wiseman’s magnificent documentary “National Gallery” is the stately museum that rises at the northern end of Trafalgar Square in London. Like most of Mr. Wiseman’s work, the movie is at once specific and general, fascinating in its pinpoint detail and transporting in its cosmic reach. It’s about art and process, money and mystery, and all the many, many people gazing and gawping and, at times, lining up to see a blockbuster show. That “National Gallery” is also about movies is surely a given.

headline: SoundCloud Signs Licensing Deal With Warner Music
abstract: The deal will guarantee that Warner artists will get paid when their music is played on SoundCloud.
lead_paragraph: SoundCloud, a streaming music service that attracts 175 million users each month, has moved one step closer to being legit in the eyes of the music industry.

headline: China Weighing More Emphasis on Traditional Culture in Textbooks
abstract: Education officials in China are considering changes to elementary and middle school textbooks that would expand the study of Chinese philosophy and literature.
lead_paragraph: Education officials in China are considering changes to elementary and middle school textbooks that would  expand the study of Chinese philosophy and literature, a shift that some education experts say is connected to recent efforts by the government to emphasize China’s cultural heritage.

headline: A Change in Sales Policy Weighs on Herbalife
abstract: Herbalife’s stock fell nearly 21 percent on Tuesday after the company reported disappointing earnings.
lead_paragraph: Herbalife, the nutritional supplements company, is feeling the pressure of being under Wall Street’s microscope.

headline: Investors Pulled $27.5 Billion From Flagship Pimco Fund
abstract: The bond giant Pimco said investors withdrew $27.5 billion from its flagship Total Return fund in October, shrinking the size of the world’s largest bond fund to $171 billion.
lead_paragraph: The asset drain at Pimco continues.

headline: Researchers Seek Crucial Tool: A Fast, Finger-Prick Ebola Test
abstract: Medical companies are looking for a technology that takes only a little blood, and gives an answer in minutes instead of hours or days.
lead_paragraph: Searching for a new way to attack Ebola, companies and academic researchers are now racing to develop faster and easier tests for determining whether someone has the disease.

headline: Nevada Could Elect First Openly Transgender State Legislator, a Republican
abstract: Lauren Scott is running in a Democratic-leaning Reno-area district, but strong Republican turnout puts her in striking distance.
lead_paragraph: Lauren Scott, the Republican nominee in Nevada’s 30th Assembly district, stands a chance of winning today and becoming the first openly transgender person elected to and seated in a state legislature.

headline: Oil Continues to Plummet to 4-Year Lows as Investors Wager on OPEC Price War
abstract: Saudi Arabia cut its oil price for America on Monday, sending the prices down.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Oil prices plunged for a second consecutive day on Tuesday as commodity traders appeared convinced that a move by Saudi Arabia to cut its oil price for the United States will presage a price war by the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries.

headline: Tribe by Theophilus London
abstract: The video premiere of “Tribe” by Theophilus London, featuring Jesse Boykins III.
lead_paragraph: The video premiere of “Tribe” by Theophilus London, featuring Jesse Boykins III.

headline: Colombians Shed International Pariah Status
abstract: Starting next year, 32 European nations will allow Colombians to visit visa-free for up to 90 days.
lead_paragraph: Traveling While Colombian is about to get significantly easier.

headline: A Whisky Campaign for Those Who Want to Drink Like Don Draper
abstract: The goal is to capitalize on renewed interest in Scotch and other brown spirits that is attributable partly to the popularity of “Mad Men.”
lead_paragraph: A BRAND of Scotch whisky that was advertised during the “Mad Men” years in the trade publication Advertising Age is reviving a product from the era. The goal is to capitalize on renewed interest in Scotch and other brown spirits that is attributable partly to — yes, the popularity of “Mad Men.”

headline: Stuart Siegel
abstract: Mr. Siegel is the president of the recently established New York City brokerage office of Engel & amp;Völkers, a real estate company based in Hamburg, Germany.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Siegel, 59, is the president of the recently established New York City brokerage office of Engel & Völkers, a real estate company based in Hamburg, Germany, with around 600 offices in 38 countries. Before starting Engel & Völkers New York in May, Mr. Siegel was a founder and principal of Ore Hill Advisors, and he served as the president and chief executive of Sotheby’s International Realty from 1991 to 2006.

headline: Judge Denies Motion to Dismiss Lawsuit Over Anti-Semitic Bullying in a New York School District
abstract: Several Jewish children had described years of anti-Semitic slurs, including Nazi salutes, swastika graffiti and “white power” chants, in the Pine Bush Central School district.
lead_paragraph: In a strongly worded ruling, a federal judge has denied a motion by an upstate New York school district to dismiss a lawsuit by the families of several Jewish children who had claimed they were victims of pervasive anti-Semitic harassment.

headline: Election 2014: Ill-Concealed Prejudice
abstract: It’s harder for black people to get concealed handgun licenses, suggesting that voter ID laws may disenfranchise minorities.
lead_paragraph: Austin, Tex. — On the face of it, requesting identification in order to vote does not seem like an impediment to democracy. But concealed handgun licenses — one of seven accepted forms of government-issued photo identification under Texas’s strict voter ID law — tell a different story.

headline: Recent Commercial Transactions
abstract: Notable properties that have been recently listed for sale, sold or leased.
lead_paragraph: RECENT SALE

headline: Time Is Running Out for a Grand Central Bookstore
abstract: Squeezed out by new construction, Posman Books, which has been at Grand Central Terminal for 15 years, will close its store there on Dec. 31.
lead_paragraph: For 15 years, employees of Posman Books in Grand Central Terminal have perfected their response to six magic words: “I have a train to catch.”

headline: Place For High Living
abstract: Gareth Bain makes no sense whatsoever.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — I don’t believe I have ever come right out and said that a theme was complete and utter gibberish, but today I get to do just that.

headline: Exit Polls
abstract: How Americans voted in the House and Senate elections, based on exit polls conducted by Edison Research.
lead_paragraph: How Americans voted in the House and Senate elections, based on exit polls conducted by Edison Research.

headline: The President’s Party Will Probably Lose Seats—That’s Often How It Goes
abstract: Even presidents now considered amazingly popular lost Senate seats in their second term.
lead_paragraph: Assuming the polls are right, tonight the Democrats will lose the Senate and lose ground in the House. Tomorrow some pundits will beat up on the president, who’s unpopular, for damaging his party’s chances; others will beat up on the Democratic candidates who failed to defend his policies, becoming almost indistinguishable from their Republican opponents. There may be something to both lines of argument, but it’s also the case that midterm elections are, historically speaking, bad for the president’s party.

headline: Ukraine: President Orders Forces Bolstered in the Separatist East
abstract: President Petro O. Poroshenko has ordered the military to send reinforcements to Ukraine’s east.
lead_paragraph: President Petro O. Poroshenko has ordered the military to send reinforcements to Ukraine’s east. The order came in response to elections held over the weekend in rebel-controlled areas, which Ukraine, the European Union and the United States say violated a peace agreement, and also after an increase in rebel military activity in recent days. Mr. Poroshenko, speaking during a meeting of his national security council, also asked Parliament to repeal a law granting special status to the separatist regions and said controls at checkpoints into and out of those areas would be stiffened.

headline: Mitch McConnell Wins 6th Term in U.S. Senate
abstract: With an easy win in Kentucky, the Republican senator moved toward his decades-long dream of becoming majority leader of the chamber.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Mitch McConnell, the taciturn leader of the Senate Republicans who overcame childhood polio and decades of political conflagrations to become the longest-serving senator in Kentucky’s history, cruised to re-election Tuesday.  With his party winning control of the Senate on the same night, he fulfilled his decades-long dream of becoming majority leader.

headline: A Recent Surge of Leveraged Loans Rattles Regulators
abstract: Regulators fear that the stampede into less conventional assets, including leveraged loans, could create bubbles that will later pop, harming banks and the wider economy.
lead_paragraph: As regulators hunt for the next financial bubble, they are homing in on an obscure corner of Wall Street: the debt market where Tom Shannon’s company, a chain of flashy bowling alleys, recently borrowed nearly half a billion dollars.

headline: G.M. Offers $25 Cards to Owners Who Get Ignition Switches Fixed
abstract: The automaker said it would give cards that could be used at one of seven retailers to owners who get the repairs before Dec.1.
lead_paragraph: With more than a million defective small cars still on the road, General Motors said on Tuesday that it was adding an incentive for owners to have them fixed: $25 gift cards to one of seven retailers, like Applebee’s and Bass Pro Shops.

headline: The Kentucky Pipe Dream, and How It Hurt Democrats
abstract: Mitch McConnell’s victory was entirely foreseeable. By focusing on Kentucky, Democrats distracted themselves from races where they had better chances.
lead_paragraph: Democrats spent much of this year pouring attention and money into Kentucky, believing that Senator Mitch McConnell was vulnerable to defeat. That decision was almost certainly a strategic mistake — and not just in hindsight.

headline: Kashmir Protests Follow Shootings
abstract: Protests broke out in Indian-administered Kashmir on Tuesday, a day after Indian soldiers fatally shot two people in a car that did not stop at a checkpoint.
lead_paragraph: Protests broke out in Indian-administered Kashmir on Tuesday, a day after Indian soldiers fatally shot two people in a car that did not stop at a checkpoint. They and two others who were wounded were all civilians. Crowds of protesters in the main city, Srinagar, chanted anti-Indian slogans and threw stones at officials, and separatist organizations called for a strike on Wednesday. The Indian soldiers were on high alert after a huge  explosion on Sunday on the Pakistan side of the border that killed 50 people. Omar Abdullah, the chief minister of Jammu and Kashmir State, described the deaths as “avoidable” and discussed the matter with India’s defense minister, Arun Jaitley.

headline: Amnesty International Says Israel Showed ‘Callous Indifference’ in Gaza
abstract: Amnesty International published a report accusing Israel of war crimes in its 50-day war with Hamas in the Gaza Strip this summer.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Amnesty International published a report early Wednesday accusing Israel of war crimes in its 50-day war with Hamas in the Gaza Strip this summer, saying its military showed “callous indifference” to civilians in airstrikes on homes that felled entire families.

headline: Voters at the Polls
abstract: Control of the Senate is at stake as voting in the midterm elections takes place around the country.
lead_paragraph: Control of the Senate is at stake as voting in the midterm elections takes place around the country.

headline: Apple Issues Bonds in Euros for First Time
abstract: When you are as rich as Apple and you want to make investors happy, you issue debt. On Tuesday, Apple issued debt in euros for the first time.
lead_paragraph: When you are as rich as Apple and you want to make investors happy, you issue debt. That is what the company has done for investors over the last year and a half. On Tuesday, Apple issued debt for the first time in euros.

headline: Appeals Court Is Urged to Strike Down Program for Collecting Phone Records
abstract: A conservative legal activist urged a federal appeals court Tuesday to strike down the National Security Agency’s program that collects Americans’ phone records in bulk.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A conservative legal activist urged a federal appeals court Tuesday to strike down the National Security Agency’s program that collects Americans’ phone records in bulk, calling it “perhaps the biggest violation of freedom and constitutional rights in history” and warning the judges that if they did not step in, Americans would take to the streets in revolt.

headline: Why Sand Is Disappearing
abstract: The demand of beaches and industries is leading to a worldwide shortage.
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — TO those of us who visit beaches only in summer, they seem as permanent a part of our natural heritage as the Rocky Mountains and the Great Lakes. But shore dwellers know differently. Beaches are the most transitory of landscapes, and sand beaches the most vulnerable of all. During big storms, especially in winter, they can simply vanish, only to magically reappear in time for the summer season.

headline: Oklahoma Supreme Court Blocks 2 Abortion Laws
abstract: The court voted to prevent enforcement of the new abortion measures pending the outcome of lawsuits challenging their constitutionality.
lead_paragraph: The Oklahoma Supreme Court on Tuesday blocked two new laws that critics say may have made it difficult for women to obtain abortions in the state.

headline: Turner Hires Kevin Reilly, Ex-Fox Executive, to Run TNT and TBS
abstract: Kevin Reilly made a reputation for hit shows at Fox, NBC and FX.
lead_paragraph: Turner Broadcasting has landed one of the most prominent names in television programming in recent years, announcing on Tuesday that Kevin Reilly will become president of the TNT and TBS cable networks and the chief creative officer of Turner Entertainment.

headline: Strong Film and Cable Profit at Fox Tempered by Network TV
abstract: The movie studio and cable networks at 21st Century Fox reported better-than-expected results for the quarter, but the broadcast group fared poorly.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Movie studio and cable network growth resulted in better-than-expected quarterly profit at 21st Century Fox. But weakness at the Fox broadcast network continued to bedevil the company.

headline: 2014 Election Coverage of New York, Connecticut and New Jersey Races
abstract: A collection of articles on Election Day spanning the New York region.
lead_paragraph: Our coverage of Election Day (so far) in the New York area:

headline: Thomas Sneddon, 73, Dies; Prosecuted Michael Jackson Case
abstract: Mr. Sneddon was a district attorney who failed twice to convict Mr. Jackson on child molestation charges and became the target of a bitter song on one of the pop star’s albums.
lead_paragraph: Thomas W. Sneddon Jr., a former district attorney who tried and failed twice to convict Michael Jackson on child molestation charges and became the target of a bitter song on one of the pop star’s albums, died on Saturday in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 73.

headline: Kentucky Election Highlights
abstract: Highlights from the election in Kentucky.
lead_paragraph: Senator Mitch McConnell, the ranking Republican member of the Senate, managed to win his sixth full term, defeating Alison Lundergan Grimes, his Democratic challenger, in one of the most closely watched races in the country.

headline: Scottish Club Hamilton Academical Combines Soccer and Sobriety
abstract: Hamilton Academical, excelling in the Scottish Premier League after an unlikely ascent, hosts regular meetings for recovering addicts and gives away tickets for the families of those affected.
lead_paragraph: HAMILTON, Scotland — Twelve miles outside of Glasgow, at the tiny New Douglas Park soccer stadium, Colin McGowan was talking about divine intervention.

headline: 1965: The War Over G.I. Joe
abstract: This feature looks at the first time famous names or terms appeared in The Times.
lead_paragraph: This feature looks at the first time famous names or terms appeared in The Times. Have an idea for someone or something you would like to read about? Send a suggestion in the comments section.

headline: Election 2014: How the Turks See Us
abstract: Republican criticism of Obama’s foreign policy finds unexpected echoes among Turkey’s public.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — ASIDE from a few thousand American service personnel at the military bases in Izmir and Incirlik, there are no votes in the midterm elections from Turkey. But standing at the edge of the Bosporus, with Russian tankers steaming past his fishing lines, Nazim Yanikdag expressed frustration with President Obama’s policies in the Middle East.

headline: Pakistani Christian Couple Are Tortured and Burned to Death by Angry Mob
abstract: The authorities planned to arrest 460 people in the killings, which began when the couple were accused of blasphemy by burning the Quran.
lead_paragraph: LAHORE, Pakistan — An enraged mob tortured a Pakistani Christian couple and incinerated their bodies in a brick kiln in eastern Pakistan on Tuesday after they were accused of burning a Quran, police officials said.

headline: Republicans, Meet Science
abstract: You two haven’t been so well acquainted. In the new, post-midterms Congress, is there hope for a more respectful relationship?
lead_paragraph: Just days before the midterm elections, we got the latest alarm: The globe is heating up like a griddle, and we’re just lolling here like eggs.

headline: Filtering Out the Jargon of Politics
abstract: The Polifiller, as in “political filler,” is a new computer tool that lets you plug in the text of any politician’s speech and, with one click, it draws red lines through jargon.
lead_paragraph: A new computer tool lets you plug in the text of any politician’s speech and, with one click, it draws red lines through jargon. It is called Polifiller, as in “political filler,” and searches for phrases in what it calls the Hall of Shame.

headline: Invesco Fund Treads Risky Path as Major Investor in Distressed Corporate Debt
abstract: Investors seeking high yields have poured billions into Invesco’s PowerShares suite of exchange-traded funds, but regulators worry that a lack of liquidity could hamper redemptions if the market softens.
lead_paragraph: When a unit of a Texas power giant filed for bankruptcy this year, investors did not go looking for bargains. Because the company was saddled with $40 billion in debt from a boom-era buyout in 2007, the virtual “buyer beware” tag on its leveraged loans kept even the most brazen risk-seekers at bay.

headline: Lorenzo Albacete, Theologian and Confidant of Popes, Dies at 73
abstract: Msgr. Albacete, a former aerospace researcher turned Roman Catholic priest, became one of the Vatican’s most articulate, unofficial defenders in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Msgr. Lorenzo Albacete, a former aerospace researcher turned Roman Catholic priest who became one of the Vatican’s most articulate, unofficial defenders in the United States, died on Oct. 24 in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. He was 73.

headline: South Carolina Election Highlights
abstract: Highlights from the election in South Carolina.
lead_paragraph: Nikki R. Haley, a Republican who at 42 is the nation’s youngest governor, won re-election in South Carolina. She defeated Vincent Sheheen, a longtime Democratic state senator, who lost narrowly to her in 2010 by just 4.5 percentage points.

headline: Ohio Election Highlights
abstract: Highlights from the election in Ohio.
lead_paragraph: Gov. John R. Kasich of Ohio won re-election easily, with the help of a series of missteps and uncomfortable revelations by the Democratic candidate, Ed FitzGerald. Mr. FitzGerald, the Cuyahoga County executive, lost staff members and donors after reports that two years before, the police had found him in a parked car at 4:30 a.m. with a woman who was not his wife. Mr. FitzGerald, a former F.B.I. agent, said that nothing untoward had occurred. His campaign was further damaged by the news that he had been driving for years without a valid license. Mr. FitzGerald’s campaign never recovered, and Mr. Kasich enjoyed a double-digit lead in the two months leading up to the election.

headline: Oregon Moves Up in College Football Playoff Rankings, With Top 3 Unchanged
abstract: The 12-member selection committee released its second set of rankings, which left Mississippi State at No. 1, Florida State at No. 2 and Auburn at No. 3. Oregon replaced Mississippi at No. 4.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday morning, the former Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice wrote on Twitter, “Today, we have the opportunity to exercise one of our most precious rights ... the right to vote. Go to your local polls and cast your ballot!”

headline: Harsher Rule in Turkey
abstract: Carol Delaney, emerita professor at Stanford, writes that what is happening in Turkey is worrisome.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Living Wage in Denmark, and in America
abstract: Readers respond to a Business Day article, “Serving Up Fries, for a Living Wage.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Telecommuting Option
abstract: Nicole Belson Goluboff, a lawyer and author, writes that interstate telecommuters should not be subject to a double tax penalty.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Steinway’s Early Days
abstract: Richard K. Lieberman, author of a book about Steinway & Sons, says the company is returning to its roots in Lower Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Pass Go, Take Pictures
abstract: Revisiting the Atlantic City streets that were immortalized in Monopoly.
lead_paragraph: Revisiting the Atlantic City streets that were immortalized in Monopoly.

headline: Climate Change: Questions for Colleges
abstract: Readers respond to a Sunday Review article, “The Missing Campus Climate Debate.”

headline: Saudi Arabia Takes Action After Shiites Are Attacked
abstract: Security officials moved on Tuesday to crush an outbreak of violence that included what the Interior Ministry called a terrorist ambush on mosque worshipers in a minority Shiite community.
lead_paragraph: Saudi Arabian security officials moved aggressively on Tuesday to crush an outbreak of anti-Shiite violence, arresting 15 people in six cities and killing two others in connection with what the Interior Ministry called a terrorist ambush on mosque worshipers in a minority Shiite community.

headline: Fire Destroys Family-Owned Cannoli Factory in Mount Vernon
abstract: The factory’s indefinite closing will put a huge dent in the business of Artuso Pastry Foods Corporation, which produces 10 million cannoli a year.
lead_paragraph: MOUNT VERNON, N.Y. — Anthony J. Artuso Sr. stood outside the burned-out ruin of his family’s cannoli factory on Tuesday and lamented his luck.

headline: Exposing the ‘Bangalore Techie’
abstract: Indians should pay attention to Tim Cook’s coming-out story.
lead_paragraph: TWO men, both in technological fields, were in the news last week because of their homosexuality. The first was Tim Cook of Apple, whose coming-out essay in Bloomberg Businessweek made headlines because it established him as the first openly gay C.E.O. of a Fortune 500 company. The announcement generated considerable optimism that with his influence and visibility he would be a force for far-reaching advocacy in years to come.

headline: Pursuing a Degree While Balancing Chronic Illness and Classes
abstract: Renny Vilorio has chronic asthma that puts him in the hospital seven or eight times a month, but he is determined to finish an associate degree in public administration.
lead_paragraph: Slung over Renny Vilorio’s shoulder is a fabric bag that rarely leaves his side; its contents keep him breathing. A second accessory complements his ensemble: a backpack, loaded with textbooks.

headline: Fight Poverty, Not Cooking
abstract: It’s not important that everyone cook, but it is important that everyone eat well — and the best way to do that now is to buy good food and cook it.
lead_paragraph: For many people, “cooking is fraught” — that’s the core message of “The Joy of Cooking?”, an article written by three academics that appeared in the latest issue of the journal “Contexts”, based on 150 interviews with families “from all walks of life.” The interviews and most of the authors’ conclusions are convincing.

headline: Tennessee Election Highlights
abstract: Highlights from the election in Tennessee.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Bill Haslam, a Republican, did not face a serious challenge in his re-election bid, easily defeating his opponent, a retired construction worker named Charles V. Brown, listed on the ballot as Charlie, who barely campaigned.

headline: To Angry Voters, Washington Comes Out the Biggest Loser
abstract: Some voters said that after watching the infighting in Washington, they did not think that anything made much of a difference.
lead_paragraph: WHEAT RIDGE, Colo. — Jane Dempsey has been out of work since 2007, but she still has faith in the Colorado economy. What she has lost heart in, she said after casting her vote at the municipal building here Tuesday morning, are the public officials representing her in the nation’s capital.

headline: Wary of Losing Rams, St. Louis Is Set to Huddle on Stadium
abstract: With the owner Stan Kroenke becoming a bogeyman to fans who fear he will move the Rams back to California, Missouri’s governor is expected to appoint a task force to work on a plan for a new stadium.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — For beleaguered Rams fans, it was the happiest of celebrations: Last month, the team that won the franchise’s only Super Bowl title gathered for a 15th-anniversary reunion. Marshall Faulk, Kurt Warner and four dozen other members of the Greatest Show on Turf were bathed in cheers from fans who have watched a lot of losing teams since that magical season.

headline: Donald Saddler, Dancer, and a Choreographer on Broadway, Dies at 96
abstract: A soloist with Ballet Theater, Mr. Saddler made his Broadway musical theater debut in 1947, and he went on to win two Tonys as a Broadway choreographer.
lead_paragraph: Donald Saddler, a dancer and choreographer whose career lasted more than 60 years and embraced opera, television, movies, ballet and Broadway, where he won two Tony Awards, died on Saturday in Englewood, N.J. He was 96.

headline: West Virginia Election Highlights
abstract: Highlights from the election in West Virginia.
lead_paragraph: Representative Shelley Moore Capito became the first woman elected to the Senate from West Virginia and will become the state’s first Republican senator since 1959.

headline: Bloody and Belittled Shiite Ritual Draws Historic Parallels
abstract: Shiite men in Baghdad commemorated the Ashura holiday by cutting themselves and bleeding, at a time when Shiites are being attacked again by ISIS extremists.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — The blood oozing from the cuts in the top of Ali Rassoul’s head on Tuesday had crusted in streaks around his eyes and ears and soaked the front of his long, white gown.

headline: Voters’ Second Thoughts on Hope and Change
abstract: A decade after President Obama made his national political debut with an appeal for Americans to put aside their divisions, the midterm elections delivered a resounding rejection of his call for consensus.
lead_paragraph: A decade after President Obama made his national political debut with an appeal for Americans to put aside their divisions, the midterm elections on Tuesday delivered a resounding rejection of his call for consensus. Mr. Obama’s poor poll numbers dragged down candidates and hastened his party’s decline in the South and the West, as Democrats watched their hold on the Senate slip away.

headline: Pennsylvania Election Highlights
abstract: Highlights from the election in Pennsylvania.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Tom Corbett, the Republican and first-time incumbent, lost his race for re-election to Tom Wolf, a Democratic businessman. Mr. Wolf, who runs a building company specializing in kitchen cabinets, had criticized Mr. Corbett for letting education funds fall — even as the governor pushed through more than $300 million in business tax cuts that were enacted in 2011 and 2012.

headline: When Red Wings Are on the Ice, Minds Are on Gordie Howe
abstract: With Howe in Texas recovering from a stroke and fighting the effects of dementia, the Red Wings have become traveling ambassadors for him.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Gordie Howe is in Texas recovering from a stroke and fighting the effects of dementia. But wherever the Detroit Red Wings go these days, he is with them.

headline: Alabama Election Highlights
abstract: Highlights from the election in Alabama.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Robert Bentley, a Republican, won a second term with ease, carried by widespread job approval and strong annual job growth that trumped concerns about that trumped concerns about rising unemployment. He fended off a nominal challenge from Parker Griffith, a former congressman who has switched from Democrat to Republican and back again. The state’s unemployment rate, which fell to 6.6 percent in September, is among the highest in the nation. But it has fallen from 9.1 percent in January 2011, when Mr. Bentley took office with a pledge not to take a salary until unemployment dropped below 5.2 percent. A majority of voters were unconvinced that they should replace Mr. Bentley with Mr. Griffith, who lacked money and name recognition.

headline: New Jersey Election Highlights
abstract: Highlights from the election in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: Senator Cory Booker, a Democrat, has won his first full term after arriving through a special election last year to fill the seat vacated by the death of Frank R. Lautenberg. His election continues the Democrats’ 38-year Senate winning streak in the state.

headline: Andrew Cuomo Is Re-elected New York Governor, but Loses Clout
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, who defeated Rob Astorino, enters his second term without the aura of invincibility that aided him among Albany lawmakers.
lead_paragraph: This was the election in which Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo had every reason to think he would outdo his father.

headline: As the Climate Changes, Voters Go for Coal
abstract: Two states with particularly long histories of poverty and hunger voted for Senate candidates who have vowed to fight limits on coal burning with everything they have.
lead_paragraph: It was just two days ago that a United Nations panel on climate change issued a frightening warning about the dangers of global warming.

headline: Conflicts in the Sharing Economy
abstract: Businesses like Airbnb should be regulated if they make it harder for people to find permanent housing, but benign forms of apartment sharing should be allowed.
lead_paragraph: It can be hard to stay grounded in reality when talking about the sharing economy. Businesses like Airbnb say they are making the world more efficient by connecting buyers and sellers of services in ways never possible before. Critics argue that these businesses can’t violate rules that apply to everyone else.

headline: Delaware Election Highlights
abstract: Highlights from the election in Delaware.
lead_paragraph: Delaware loves Democrats, so it was no surprise that Chris Coons, the incumbent senator, coasted to victory over his Republican challenger, Kevin L. Wade.

headline: Illinois Election Highlights
abstract: Highlights from the election in Illinois.
lead_paragraph: In a state where registered Democrats far outnumber Republicans and President Obama’s approval rating has stayed near the 50 percent mark, Bruce Rauner, a wealthy Republican businessman, managed to push out the Democratic governor, Pat Quinn, in a close and nasty contest.

headline: Irish Agog That Joe Kernen, CNBC Host, Missed Their Exit From U.K.
abstract: Irish viewers were puzzled to learn this week that a host of CNBC’s “Squawk Box” seemed unaware that they were not part of Britain.
lead_paragraph: The head of Ireland’s Industrial Development Agency, which is devoted to promoting foreign investment, became an unlikely viral video star after a bizarre appearance on CNBC on Monday.

headline: New York Election Highlights
abstract: Highlights from the election in New York.
lead_paragraph: The solidly blue state of New York delivered for Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, a Democrat running for a second term. Mr. Cuomo won despite an array of challenges, including the muted enthusiasm he often draws from New York voters and an explosive report earlier this year about his handling of a statewide ethics panel, which he created and then abruptly shut down.

headline: Maine Election Highlights
abstract: Highlights from the election in Maine.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Paul R. LePage, a Republican running for a second term, defeated his Democratic opponent, Representative Michael H. Michaud, who conceded the race shortly after midnight.

headline: Mitch McConnell’s Victory Speech
abstract: Senator Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky, spoke after defeating Alison Lundergan Grimes, the Democratic candidate.
lead_paragraph: Senator Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky, spoke after defeating Alison Lundergan Grimes, the Democratic candidate.

headline: Vermont Election Highlights
abstract: Highlights from the election in Vermont.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Peter Shumlin, a Democrat seeking a third two-year term, finished with a narrow lead over the Republican candidate, Scott Milne, but failed to get more than 50 percent of the vote. Under the state Constitution, the race will be decided in January by the Vermont Legislature, which is controlled by Democrats.

headline: Arkansas Election Highlights
abstract: Highlights from the election in Arkansas.
lead_paragraph: The Republicans flipped a key Senate seat in Arkansas, when Tom Cotton, a Republican congressman, defeated the Democratic incumbent, Mark Pryor. The race had been watched as one of the key competitions for control of the chamber.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 4, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: In Rapidly Changing World, Nets Strive for an Important Constant
abstract: With an owner who talks like an investor and an old-school coach who is trying to modernize, the Nets have set their sights on winning.
lead_paragraph: The Nets’ owner, Mikhail D. Prokhorov, made a rare appearance at Barclays Center on Monday, when the Nets routed the Oklahoma City Thunder in their home opener.

headline: Election 2014: What Do the Midterms Tell Us About 2016?
abstract: Perhaps the most significant development is the ability of Republican candidates to break with hard right orthodoxy, even when their own roots lie there.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 election will be a four-part test that will tell us more than who will win control of the Senate.

headline: Given Chance, Mets’ Juan Lagares Hauls In a Gold Glove
abstract: With regular playing time, Lagares, 25, blossomed into perhaps baseball’s best defensive center fielder, widely praised for his technique, his arm, his speed and his instincts.
lead_paragraph: After the Mets signed Juan Lagares out of the Dominican Republic at 17, he struggled in his first three years in their system as a shortstop. In those years, playing perhaps the most difficult position in baseball, he made 69 errors.

headline: Surveys of Voters Signal Dismay With Both Parties
abstract: In surveys of those who cast ballots in Tuesday’s elections, voters signaled that they were at least as negative about Republican legislators as about President Obama.
lead_paragraph: Politically divided Americans were in dour agreement about much as they voted in this year’s midterm elections — broadly distrustful of government, overwhelmingly disapproving of Congress, convinced that the nation’s economic system favors the wealthy and doubtful that the next generation will inherit a better economic future.

headline: In New Hampshire, Jeanne Shaheen Beats Scott Brown to Keep Senate Seat
abstract: Ms. Shaheen, 67, a former governor who was first elected to the New Hampshire State Senate in 1990, presented a stark contrast with Mr. Brown, 55, a Republican, who moved to New Hampshire last year.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Senator Jeanne Shaheen barely fended off an aggressive challenge for her United States Senate seat Tuesday from Scott Brown, a Republican and former senator from Massachusetts.

headline: South Dakota Election Highlights
abstract: Highlights from the election in South Dakota.
lead_paragraph: Mike Rounds, a former governor, picked up a critical seat for Republicans. In a surprisingly unpredictable three-way race to replace Senator Tim Johnson, a retiring Democrat, Mr. Rounds slipped ahead of Rick Weiland, a former congressional aide and regional director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, and Larry Pressler, a former Republican congressman and senator who ran as an independent.

headline: The World Is Fast
abstract: The biggest challenge of all was never discussed during the midterms: the surging of the market, Mother Nature and Moore’s Law at once.
lead_paragraph: We’ve just had a nonsense midterm election. Never has more money been spent to think so little about a future so in flux. What would we have discussed if we’d had a serious election? How about the biggest challenge we’re facing today: The resilience of our workers, environment and institutions.

headline: Republicans Extend House Control as Democratic Holdouts Fall
abstract: Republicans expanded their majority in the House of Representatives as moderate and conservative Democrats lost their states in red states.
lead_paragraph: Republicans expanded their majority in the House of Representatives, riding a wave of dissatisfaction with President Obama to victories on Tuesday that will embolden Speaker John A. Boehner as he tries to manage a rebellious Tea Party caucus.

headline: Republicans Hold the Top 2 Prizes in Governor Races
abstract: Rick Scott of Florida and Scott Walker of Wisconsin were re-elected in states that both parties are looking to as a gauge of voter sentiment in the run-up to the 2016 presidential race.
lead_paragraph: Republicans won the two most intensely followed, high-stakes governor’s races of the year as Rick Scott of Florida and Scott Walker of Wisconsin won re-election on Tuesday in states that both parties are looking to as a gauge of voter sentiment in the run-up to the 2016 presidential campaign.

headline: Texas Election Highlights
abstract: Highlights from the election in Texas.
lead_paragraph: Greg Abbott, the state’s attorney general, went into Election Day with such a powerful electoral advantage over State Senator Wendy Davis that the race was called moments after the polls closed.

headline: Coach Botched Challenge, but Red Flags Are Easy to Find
abstract: On Monday night, after an arguable call, Giants Coach Tom Coughlin delayed in throwing a challenge flag, the Colts quickly snapped the ball, and Coby Fleener ran untouched into the end zone.
lead_paragraph: There is no disputing that the Giants are in a desperate, downward spiral. The collapse has been so comprehensive that there are a multitude of places to point the finger of blame.

headline: Arkansas Votes for Higher Minimum Wage, and a Republican
abstract: Both Tom Cotton and Mark Pryor supported the state initiative but not the federal one.
lead_paragraph: Arkansas just voted to raise its minimum wage to $8.50 an hour, up from $6.25. It also voted to elect a new Republican senator, Tom Cotton, who voted in the House against raising the national minimum wage to $10.10.

headline: Alison Lundergan Grimes Concedes Race
abstract: Alison Lundergan Grimes, the Democratic Senate candidate from Kentucky, spoke after being defeated by Senator Mitch McConnell.
lead_paragraph: Alison Lundergan Grimes, the Democratic Senate candidate from Kentucky, spoke after being defeated by Senator Mitch McConnell.

headline: Mississippi Election Highlights
abstract: Highlights from the election in Mississippi.
lead_paragraph: The re-election of Senator Thad Cochran, a Republican, came as no surprise in this conservative state, but it concealed unpredictable currents in Mississippi politics.

headline: Knicks’ Offense Runs Aground Against Wizards, and a Promising Start Follows Suit
abstract: The Knicks were ready for John Wall, the Wizards’ star point guard, but an offensive dry spell in the third quarter spelled doom.
lead_paragraph: As defenders pressed them on the perimeter and passing lanes disappeared, the Knicks searched for space against the Washington Wizards on Tuesday. Space for shots. Space to breathe. They found very little of either.

headline: Keeping Informed With CNBC
abstract: Don’t forget those Irish unicorns, either.
lead_paragraph: I’ve said some harsh things about the quality of analysis on CNBC. But at least watching it keeps you informed about tough questions like which currency European nations use. Or maybe not …

headline: Indiana Election Highlights
abstract: Highlights from the election in Indiana.
lead_paragraph: Indiana displayed its strong Republican leanings as Representative Jackie Walorski, a Republican supported by Tea Party activists, easily defeated the Democrats’ best hope for capturing a House seat here, and Representative André Carson, a Democrat, had to fend off a surprisingly tough challenge.

headline: President Obama Left Fighting for His Own Relevance
abstract: The midterm elections culminated a season of discontent for President Obama — and may yet open a period of even deeper frustration in his final two years in office.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two things were clear long before the votes were counted on Tuesday night: President Obama would face a Congress with more Republicans for his final two years in office, and the results would be seen as a repudiation of his leadership.

headline: New Hampshire Election Highlights
abstract: Highlights from the election in New Hampshire.
lead_paragraph: Jeanne Shaheen, a Democrat and former governor of New Hampshire, held on to her seat in the Senate despite a spirited campaign by Scott P. Brown. Mr. Brown had served as a senator from Massachusetts, and moved to New Hampshire last year after being beaten by Elizabeth Warren in a Senate contest. Despite a talent for retail campaigning and his arguments that he had strong roots in the state, Mr. Brown suffered under the burden of a carpetbagger label. Exit polls showed the issue was important: When asked “Has Brown lived in N.H. long enough?” a majority of voters said no — and some nine out of 10 of those voters expressed support for Ms. Shaheen.

headline: North Carolina Election Highlights
abstract: Highlights from the election in North Carolina.
lead_paragraph: In one of the nation’s most closely watched races, Thom Tillis, the Republican speaker of the North Carolina House, narrowly won a Senate seat against Kay Hagan, a first-time Democratic senator. For months, Ms. Hagan, a prime Republican target, led in the polls, but Mr. Tillis closed the gap in the final days of the race.

headline: Michigan Election Highlights
abstract: Highlights from the election in Michigan.
lead_paragraph: Representative Gary Peters, a Democrat, battled through a surprisingly close race with Terri Lynn Land, a former Republican secretary of state, in a state that had gone twice for President Obama. Mr. Peters pulled ahead as Election Day approached in spite of dissatisfaction with an uneven economic recovery. Americans for Prosperity, a conservative political advocacy group supported by the Koch brothers, had backed away as the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee pumped even more money into holding the seat vacated by Carl Levin, the longtime Democratic senator.

headline: Louisiana Election Highlights
abstract: Highlights from the election in Louisiana.
lead_paragraph: Mary L. Landrieu, the Democratic incumbent, and her Republican challenger, Representative Bill Cassidy, will face off in a runoff election scheduled for Dec. 6; no candidate in the race was able to capture at least 50 percent of the vote as state law requires.

headline: Alex Rodriguez Could Be Called to Testify in His Cousin’s Case
abstract: Rodriguez’s doping ban might be over, but his legal woes could linger well into spring training of 2015 with the Yankees.
lead_paragraph: Alex Rodriguez’s unprecedented doping ban is over, but his legal woes could linger well into spring training, when he will be in the midst of a potentially awkward reunion with a Yankee team he hasn’t played for since September 2013.

headline: Wyoming Election Highlights
abstract: Highlights from the election in Wyoming.
lead_paragraph: It was expected to be a fascinating showdown: Senator Michael B. Enzi, a three-term Republican, was staring down a primary fight with Liz Cheney, the elder daughter of former Vice President Dick Cheney and one of the most well-known names in the state. But Ms. Cheney’s candidacy failed to gain traction, amid grumbling that she should not have taken on a well-liked member of her party and that she had not lived in the state for decades. When she dropped out in January, citing “serious health issues” in her family, Mr. Enzi’s outlook became rosier. His Democratic challenger, Charlie Hardy, a former Roman Catholic priest, missionary and educator, did not pose a real threat in this crimson bastion.

headline: Missouri Election Highlights
abstract: Highlights from the election in Missouri.
lead_paragraph: The fallout from the death in August of Michael Brown, an unarmed black teenager who was shot by a white police officer in Ferguson, a St. Louis suburb, made for an unexpectedly close race for St. Louis County executive. The Democratic candidate, Steve Stenger, eked out a victory over his Republican opponent, Rick Stream, with fewer than 2,000 votes.

headline: Michael Grimm Overcomes Democrats’ Campaign to Capture His Congressional Seat
abstract: Mr. Grimm, the Republican incumbent, fended off Domenic M. Recchia Jr., who focused on his rival’s legal troubles from a federal indictment related to his career before politics.
lead_paragraph: Staten Islanders have picked their poison.

headline: Rhode Island Election Highlights
abstract: Highlights from the election in Rhode Island.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic candidate for governor, Gina M. Raimondo, pulled off a difficult victory on Tuesday, becoming the state’s first female governor despite having made powerful enemies among public employees unions when she overhauled the state pension system as state treasurer.

headline: Oklahoma Election Highlights
abstract: Highlights from the election in Oklahoma.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in the state’s history, both of Oklahoma’s Senate seats were in play. One of the races was held out of the usual rotation because of the retirement of Tom Coburn, a Republican. James Lankford held that seat for the Republicans, defeating Constance N. Johnson, a Democrat, and Mark Beard, an independent.

headline: Eric Schneiderman Re-elected Attorney General of New York
abstract: Eric T. Schneiderman, a Democrat, fended off his Republican opponent, John P. Cahill.
lead_paragraph: Attorney General Eric T. Schneiderman of New York won re-election on Tuesday, according to The Associated Press, fending off his Republican challenger, John P. Cahill, in a race that attracted relatively little attention.

headline: Arizona Election Highlights
abstract: Highlights from the election in Arizona.
lead_paragraph: The Republican nominee, Doug Ducey, has won the governor’s race, filling the seat left by Gov. Jan Brewer, who is leaving office because of term limits. Mr. Ducey, the state treasurer, is a former executive for Cold Stone Creamery, the ice cream company. Despite his lack of experience in the public sector, Mr. Ducey characterized his position at the company as a valuable leadership role, and his campaign produced an advertisement that included testimonials from Cold Stone franchise holders. Mr. Ducey earned the support of high-profile Republicans, including Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, who campaigned for him in early October.

headline: Election 2014: Europe Looks Beyond Obama
abstract: The midterms have one simple message for the European chancelleries: Plan for America’s next president.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — He had to laugh. A senior official at one of the world’s leading foreign ministries was describing how he had been in a meeting with a counterpart from the Middle East, who was telling him that the United States no longer mattered the way it used to, in that region especially.

headline: Colorado Election Highlights
abstract: Highlights from the election in Colorado.
lead_paragraph: In unpredictable Colorado, the contest for an open Senate seat was a real nail-biter — one that helped determine which party controls the chamber. Cory Gardner’s unseating of Mark Udall, a Democrat, helps push Colorado back into the Republican fold.

headline: Virginia Election Highlights
abstract: Highlights from the election in Virginia.
lead_paragraph: Dave Brat, who upset the House majority leader Eric Cantor in the Republican primary, won the seat in the Seventh District. The surprising primary result left a race between two relative political neophytes, and Mr. Brat beat Jack Trammell, a Democrat. Both are members of the faculty of Randolph-Macon College, a small liberal-arts institution in Ashland.

headline: Health Care in the Hands of the Court
abstract: Four words buried deep within the 900-page law are the reason for the latest legal challenge to the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: Two and a half years ago, the Supreme Court upheld the Affordable Care Act by a single vote. This year alone, between 8 million and 11 million Americans have been able to get health insurance that they did not have before, according to a new analysis by The Times.

headline: New Mexico Election Highlights
abstract: Highlights from the election in New Mexico.
lead_paragraph: The Republican governor, Susana Martinez, is poised to play a significant role in national politics after she won re-election against her Democratic challenger, Attorney General Gary King. Ms. Martinez, who became the nation’s first Latina governor in 2010, gained prominence when the Republicans gave her a prime-time platform at their 2012 convention. New Mexico, with an electorate that is estimated to be about 35 percent Hispanic, is still suffering the effects of the Great Recession. Its unemployment rate remains well above the national average, but Democrats failed to make the case that Ms. Martinez was to blame.

headline: Mary Landrieu of Louisiana Is Pushed to Runoff in Senate Race
abstract: The runoff election between Ms. Landrieu, the incumbent, and Bill Cassidy is set for Dec. 6.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Extending an expensive and largely negative campaign for one more month, voters in Louisiana sent Mary Landrieu, a Democrat and three-term United States senator, and her Republican challenger, United States Representative Bill Cassidy, into a runoff election set for Dec. 6.

headline: Historical Lessons for a President Forced to Deal With a Hostile Congress
abstract: There are at least three possible approaches for a president facing a Congress controlled by the opposite party.
lead_paragraph: So what does President Obama do now? Modern presidential history suggests at least three plans of action for a president faced with an opposition House and Senate.

headline: Rick Scott Fends Off Charlie Crist in Testy Florida Governor’s Race
abstract: The Republican governor of Florida eked out a second term despite failing to capture a majority of votes.
lead_paragraph: BONITA SPRINGS, Fla. — Rick Scott, a Republican, was elected to a second term as the governor of Florida on Tuesday by the slimmest of margins after a heated and expensive campaign against his predecessor, Charlie Crist.

headline: Thanks to Giacometti, Sotheby’s Hits Its Highest Total Ever at Fall Opening
abstract: Sotheby’s sold $422.1 million worth of Impressionist and Modern art, just $1 million shy of its high estimate.
lead_paragraph: Sotheby’s salesroom went dead quiet on Tuesday night, the audience members visibly at the edge of their seats when Giacometti’s “Chariot,” a 1950 bronze of an elongated female, came on the block at the Impressionist and Modern evening sale, the opening to the fall season. The provenance of “Chariot” was pristine; it was being sold by Alexander Goulandris, a member of the Greek shipping family, and the sculpture was among the artist’s rarest.

headline: Election Night Winners
abstract: It was a happy night for Republican candidates for Senate, as well as for New York’s Democratic governor and a New Jersey Democratic senator.
lead_paragraph: It was a happy night for Republican candidates for Senate, as well as for New York’s Democratic governor and a New Jersey Democratic senator.

headline: Florida Election Highlights
abstract: Highlights from the election in Florida.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Rick Scott’s narrow re-election in one of the nation’s most expensive races means that state government remains firmly in Republican hands. As the nation learned in 2000, that control can influence the outcome of a presidential election.

headline: Nebraska Election Highlights
abstract: Highlights from the election in Nebraska.
lead_paragraph: Ben Sasse, a Tea Party favorite making his first run for public office, won election to the United States Senate, and another Republican, Pete Ricketts, was elected governor.

headline: Montana Election Highlights
abstract: Highlights from the election in Montana.
lead_paragraph: Democrats lost a Senate seat they had held for a century to Representative Steve Daines, the state’s only congressman. Democrats had been poised to lose after the incumbent’s unexpected retirement, a campaign-killing plagiarism scandal and the last-minute nomination of a political newcomer.

headline: David Perdue Wins Senate Seat, and Nathan Deal Is Re-Elected as Georgia Governor
abstract: Mr. Perdue won the open Senate seat, and Mr. Deal, his fellow Republican, regained his post, dealing decisive blows to moderate Democratic challengers.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — David Perdue won Georgia’s open Senate seat on Tuesday and Nathan Deal, his fellow Republican, was re-elected governor, dealing decisive blows to moderate Democratic challengers from famous political families who had hoped to force the races into runoffs.

headline: Chris Benz on Assuming the Mantle at Bill Blass
abstract: In his first interview since being named creative director of the house, the 32-year-old designer talks about modernizing an American classic.
lead_paragraph: “I was living a kind of pastoral life in Brooklyn,” says the designer Chris Benz of his whereabouts when he got the call to take the reins at Bill Blass. Benz, 32 — whose colorful eponymous line last showed at New York Fashion Week two years ago — has high hopes for the revival of the storied fashion house, which will return to the runways for spring/summer 2016. “I think that Bill Blass has had some ups and downs since Mr. Blass passed away in 2002,” Benz says. “It had a moment to breathe — and an update doesn’t feel rushed.”

headline: A Los Angeles Ladies-Only Dinner Club Migrates to New York
abstract: The artist Zoe Crosher introduced a small set of East Coast women belonging to the fields of food and art to her food series — and shares recipes from the inaugural meal.
lead_paragraph: The week before last, the Los Angeles-based artist Zoe Crosher emailed a number of her female friends in the art and food worlds: “Please join us for the inaugural New York City meeting of The Fainting Club.” She started the club — so named, she explains, after an encounter she’d had “where a group of incredibly fabulous women all came together to help one of the ladies, who fainted” — in March. The incident made her appreciate “how powerful we were as a group” and prompted her to begin throwing luncheons in her city. This latest dinner party, which took place last Thursday, was her first step to expand the organization outside of California.

headline: In Defense of Technology
abstract: As products and services advance, plenty of nostalgists believe that certain elements of humanity have been lost. One contrarian argues that being attached to one’s iPhone is a godsend.
lead_paragraph: As products and services advance, plenty of nostalgists believe that certain elements of humanity have been lost. One contrarian argues that being attached to one’s iPhone is a godsend.

headline: Negativity Wins the Senate
abstract: Republicans returned to the majority by campaigning on basically one thing: what they called the failure of President Obama.
lead_paragraph: Republicans would like the country to believe that they took control of the Senate on Tuesday by advocating a strong, appealing agenda of job creation, tax reform and spending cuts. But, in reality, they did nothing of the sort.

headline: Kansas Election Highlights
abstract: Highlights from the election in Kansas.
lead_paragraph: Longtime Republican Senator Pat Roberts was re-elected after one of the tightest, most hotly contested races in the country, which ended as yet another blow to Democrats.

headline: Word of the Day | bluff
abstract: This word has appeared in 201 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: bluff •\ˈbləf\• noun, adjective and verb

headline: Calls Grow to Broaden Search for Next U.N. Leader
abstract: With Ban Ki-moon set to step down in 2016, momentum is building to open up the secretive selection process for the next United Nations secretary general.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — There is no job description for the world’s top civil servant, except to solve its messiest problems. There are no campaign rules, nor is there any list of qualifications, except what is left unsaid: He (and it has always been a he) must be palatable to the world powers.

headline: The Bad Air in Our Gyms
abstract: Gyms showed high levels of airborne dust, formaldehyde and carbon dioxide, all of which can pose problems for energetic, heavy-breathing exercisers.
lead_paragraph: With chilly weather settling in and darkness arriving before most people’s workdays end, many of us are shifting our workouts indoors, a practice that is much better for us than abandoning exercise for the winter. But a new study of air quality in gyms raises some interesting questions about whether the places in which we work out are as healthy as they should be.

headline: De Blasio Still Faces Uphill Battle in Trying to Connect With Cuomo
abstract: The tension between Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and Mayor Bill de Blasio is not likely to change with the election results, public officials and political experts say.
lead_paragraph: For the most dysfunctional couple in New York politics, it was a chance for a feel-good moment after a feel-bad year.

headline: Mark Udall of Colorado Loses Senate Seat to Cory Gardner, a Republican
abstract: Mr. Gardner and Mr. Udall, the incumbent, each tried to persuade voters that he truly represented the state, while framing the other as someone who embodied Washington politics.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Colorado voters elected Representative Cory Gardner, the Republican challenger, as their new senator on Tuesday, rejecting the incumbent Mark Udall as a Democrat too closely tied to President Obama and as a candidate who ran a one-note campaign focused on the politics of abortion.

headline: In Rebuke to Democrats, Voters Return Control of New York Senate to G.O.P.
abstract: Voters elected Republicans to a clear majority in the State Senate, handing them a wave of victories upstate and on Long Island, and returning the party to full control of the chamber.
lead_paragraph: In a decisive rebuke to efforts by Democrats to dominate both houses of the New York State Legislature, voters elected Republicans to a clear majority in the State Senate on Tuesday, handing them a wave of victories upstate and on Long Island, and returning the party to full control in a chamber it long dominated.

headline: Georgia Election Highlights
abstract: Highlights from the election in Georgia.
lead_paragraph: David A. Perdue defied expectations by winning more than the required 50 percent of the vote to avoid a runoff with Michelle Nunn, a Democrat and the daughter of the popular former Senator Sam Nunn.

headline: Nevada Election Highlights
abstract: Highlights from the election in Nevada.
lead_paragraph: Brian Sandoval, a Republican, easily won a second term as governor in a race against Robert E. Goodman, a Democrat who is a trade expert and relative political unknown. Mr. Sandoval served as a United States District Court judge before running for governor in 2010.

headline: Republicans’ First Step Was to Handle Extremists in Party
abstract: The Republican victory was the result of methodical plotting, careful candidate vetting and an abundance of preparation to ensure the party’s candidates would avoid repeating the same mistakes.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was late spring, and Republican leaders knew that if they wanted to win the Senate, they needed to crush the enemy: not Democrats, but the rebels within their own party.

headline: Gov. Scott Walker Wins Re-election in Wisconsin, and Hope of Higher Office
abstract: Mr. Walker, a Republican who clashed with labor unions, beat Mary Burke and kept alive the possibility that he might run for president.
lead_paragraph: WEST ALLIS, Wis. — Scott Walker, the Republican who made a national name for himself by clashing with labor unions, won a second term as governor of this state on Tuesday, keeping alive the possibility that he may be among the candidates for president in 2016.

headline: Bake Sales and Inequality
abstract: Fund-raising is useful for public schools, but does is it give better-off families an advantage?

headline: Scott Walker’s Victory Speech
abstract: Gov. Scott Walker, Republican of Wisconsin, gave an impassioned defense of his policies after defeating Mary Burke, the Democratic candidate.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Scott Walker, Republican of Wisconsin, gave an impassioned defense of his policies after defeating Mary Burke, the Democratic candidate.

headline: Higher Minimum Wage Passes in 4 States; Florida Defeats Marijuana Measure
abstract: Voters approved higher minimum wages in Alaska, Arkansas, Nebraska and South Dakota. A proposal to allow medical marijuana failed in Florida.
lead_paragraph: Voters in four states on Tuesday supported measures to raise their minimum wages, bringing the number of states that have passed such laws to 29 and reflecting widespread dissatisfaction with Congress’s failure to increase the federal minimum of $7.25.

headline: Massachusetts Election Highlights
abstract: Highlights from the election in Massachusetts.
lead_paragraph: The race for governor continued a longstanding pattern: Massachusetts is among the most reliably Democratic states in other contests, but Republicans tend to do well in races to be the state’s chief executive.

headline: North Dakota Election Highlights
abstract: Highlights from the election in North Dakota.
lead_paragraph: Representative Kevin Cramer, a Republican, won a second term in North Dakota’s sole House seat. He defeated State Senator George Sinner, a Democrat whose father was the state’s governor from 1985 to 1992. They both described themselves as pragmatists, with Mr. Cramer, 53, criticizing his fellow Republicans for the government shutdown.

headline: With Same Candidates as in ’10, Race for Connecticut Governor Is Again Tight
abstract: The bitter race for governor of Connecticut was too close to call, but Gov. Dannel P. Malloy appeared to open a lead against the Republican challenger, Thomas C. Foley.
lead_paragraph: The bitter race for governor of Connecticut was too close to call early on Wednesday, but Gov. Dannel P. Malloy appeared to open a lead against the Republican challenger, Thomas C. Foley, with results still coming in from the state’s heavily Democratic cities.

headline: What’s on TV Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (BBC America) THE GAME When a defecting K.G.B. agent in 1972 London reveals a plot that could change the course of the Cold War, Daddy (Brian Cox), the head of MI5, assembles a team to investigate — prompting the Soviets to activate sleeper agents across Britain. But then Joe Lambe (Tom Hughes), Daddy’s prized operative, becomes obsessed with the reappearance of his nemesis and risks letting his quest for revenge jeopardize the operation. The cast is rounded out by Paul Ritter as the head of counterespionage; Victoria Hamilton as his deputy; Jonathan Aris as her husband; Shaun Dooley as a Special Branch detective; and Chloe Pirrie as the secretary. The show’s creator, Toby Whithouse, examines a possible traitor in each of the six episodes, part of the network’s “Dramaville” programming block.

headline: Wisconsin Election Highlights
abstract: Highlights from the election in Wisconsin.
lead_paragraph: In winning re-election, Gov. Scott Walker, a hero to conservatives and a villain to liberals for his campaign against public employee unions, keeps alive speculation that he could be a Republican contender for national office.

headline: Hubert de Montille, French Winemaker, Dies at 84
abstract: Mr. de Montille was known for his insistence that wine should speak clearly of the place and the culture that produced it.
lead_paragraph: Hubert de Montille, an influential grape grower and winemaker who revived his family’s estate to make it a leader in the Côte de Beaune in Burgundy, France, died on Saturday in Alsace. He was 84.

headline: Sam Brownback and Pat Roberts, Both Republicans, Undefeated in Kansas
abstract: The Democratic surge that was supposed to end Republican control of Kansas never happened. Governor Brownback and Senator Roberts survived unusually close races.
lead_paragraph: TOPEKA, Kan. — The Democratic surge that was supposed to end Republican control of Kansas never happened.

headline: Oregon Election Highlights
abstract: Highlights from the election in Oregon.
lead_paragraph: In challenging Senator Jeff Merkley, a Democrat, Monica Wehby, a pediatric neurosurgeon, fought to become the first Republican to win a statewide race in more than a decade, branding herself as a middle-of-the-road conservative. In the end, however, it appears she was unable to convince voters that she was the right fit for this blue state. She was also plagued by accusations that she plagiarized portions of her health care plan from other candidates.

headline: Utah Election Highlights
abstract: Highlights from the election in Utah.
lead_paragraph: Mia Love narrowly won the Fourth Congressional District for Republicans on her second try, giving the party control of the state’s entire congressional delegation. Her victory coincides with the retirement of the state’s lone Democratic congressman, Representative Jim Matheson, to whom she narrowly lost in 2012. Ms. Love, a former mayor of Saratoga Springs, Utah, and the daughter of Haitian immigrants, was declared the winner with fewer than 5,000 votes separating her from her Democratic opponent, Doug Owens, a corporate defense lawyer and the son of a former congressman.

headline: Idaho Election Highlights
abstract: Highlights from the election in Idaho.
lead_paragraph: Gov. C.L. (Butch) Otter, a Republican, won a third term, beating Anthony Joseph Balukoff, known as A.J., who was determined to become the state’s first Democratic governor in 20 years.

headline: ‘Making the President Small’
abstract: Three significant developments reflected in the outcome of Tuesday’s elections.
lead_paragraph: Democrats counting on favorable demographic trends to carry their party to victory in 2016 should consider three significant developments reflected in the outcome of Tuesday’s elections.

headline: The Evaporating Democratic Majority
abstract: The G.O.P. fought the future, and the future lost.
lead_paragraph: “For Republicans, what counts as victory?” I asked in my pre-election post, and now we have an answer: This counts. Control of the Senate with room to spare, easy victories in what were supposed to be tight purple-state races and even easier victories in red states, an unexpected nailbiter in Virginia and an upset win in North Carolina, Rick Scott and Scott Walker re-elected, gubernatorial wins all over the map in deep blue states, a historically-large House majority … it’s a wave, it’s a thumping, it’s whatever metaphor you favor to describe a major repudiation of the president and his party.

headline: Minnesota Election Highlights
abstract: Highlights from the election in Minnesota.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Mark Dayton, a Democrat, beat Jeff Johnson, a Republican, in a race that had tightened in the days leading up to the election. Governor Dayton has said it would be his last campaign.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, November 5, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “All they do is fight between each other and don’t get anything done. So we — and I — need something different in there. Everything needs to change.”

headline: Corrections: November 5, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Wednesday, November 5, 2014.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Hawaii Election Highlights
abstract: Highlights from the election in Hawaii.
lead_paragraph: The victory by David Ige, a Democratic state senator, was not surprising in this deep blue state. He pummeled the incumbent governor in the primary and garnered support from the state’s major unions, as well as elderly and Japanese-American voters. While he had to fend off criticism that he offered little in the way of new policy direction, his chances were bolstered by a split opposition: Duke Aiona, a Republican former lieutenant governor, and Mufi Hannemann, a former mayor of Honolulu, who ran as an independent.

headline: Toyota’s Quarterly Profit Jumps
abstract: The Japanese automaker, helped by rising sales and a weak yen, is forecasting a record profit for the year.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — As quarterly earnings surged, Toyota issued a rosier outlook for the year, forecasting record profit on rising sales and a weaker Japanese currency.

headline: Iowa Election Highlights
abstract: Highlights from the election in Iowa.
lead_paragraph: State Senator Joni Ernst, a Republican, defeated Representative Bruce Braley, a Democrat, and will take the seat being vacated after 30 years by Senator Tom Harkin, a liberal Democrat and longtime ally of organized labor.

headline: Mark Warner Hangs On to Slim Senate Lead in Virginia
abstract: Mr. Warner, a Democrat, claimed victory just after midnight Tuesday, but his Republican opponent, Ed Gillespie, may be able to request a recount.
lead_paragraph: A Virginia electorate angry at President Obama made its displeasure known on Tuesday, and Mark Warner, the state’s popular former governor and current Democratic senator, was holding on to a slim lead over his Republican opponent early Wednesday.

headline: W.N.B.A. Star Scratched in Knife Attack in China
abstract: Brittney Griner, the Phoenix Mercury center who is playing in China this winter, was in Shenyang boarding a bus with teammates when a man attacked them.
lead_paragraph: An American basketball star playing in China was assaulted by a man with a knife on Monday but said she was only scratched in the encounter.

headline: Cory Gardner’s Victory Speech
abstract: Representative Cory Gardner, Republican of Colorado, spoke after defeating Senator Mark Udall.
lead_paragraph: Representative Cory Gardner, Republican of Colorado, spoke after defeating Senator Mark Udall.

headline: Rick Scott’s Victory Speech
abstract: Gov. Rick Scott, Republican of Florida, spoke after defeating Charlie Crist, a former Republican governor who was running as a Democrat.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Rick Scott, Republican of Florida, spoke after defeating Charlie Crist, a former Republican governor who was running as a Democrat.

headline: David Perdue’s Election Night Speech
abstract: David Perdue, the Republican Senate candidate from Georgia, defeated the Democrat Michelle Nunn.
lead_paragraph: David Perdue, the Republican Senate candidate from Georgia, defeated the Democrat Michelle Nunn.

headline: Joni Ernst’s Victory Speech
abstract: Joni Ernst, Republican of Iowa, spoke after defeating Representative Bruce Braley, a Democrat.
lead_paragraph: Joni Ernst, Republican of Iowa, spoke after defeating Representative Bruce Braley, a Democrat.

headline: Jeanne Shaheen’s Victory Speech
abstract: Senator Jeanne Shaheen, Democrat of New Hampshire, spoke after defeating Scott Brown, the Republican candidate.
lead_paragraph: Senator Jeanne Shaheen, Democrat of New Hampshire, spoke after defeating Scott Brown, the Republican candidate.

headline: Michelle Nunn’s Concession Speech
abstract: Michelle Nunn, the Democratic Senate candidate from Georgia, spoke after being defeated by David Perdue, the Republican candidate.
lead_paragraph: Michelle Nunn, the Democratic Senate candidate from Georgia, spoke after being defeated by David Perdue, the Republican candidate.

headline: Greg Orman’s Concession Speech
abstract: Greg Orman, the Independent Senate candidate from Kansas, spoke after being defeated by Senator Pat Roberts.
lead_paragraph: Greg Orman, the Independent Senate candidate from Kansas, spoke after being defeated by Senator Pat Roberts.

headline: Maryland Election Highlights
abstract: Highlights from the election in Maryland.
lead_paragraph: Larry Hogan’s stunning upset over Lt. Gov. Anthony G. Brown, a Democrat, was the icing on the cake for the Republican Governors Association as most Republican incumbents in other states fended off strong challengers. Though the race was close, with the Democratic Governors Association making a hefty investment to try to protect the seat, Mr. Brown had been expected to win in the state President Obama carried with 62 percent of the vote in 2012.

headline: Test Yourself | Taylor Swift’s ‘1989’
