abstract: Here are the first six paragraphs of the Oct. 23 music review, “A Farewell to Twang.” Can you choose the best word for each blank?
lead_paragraph: Below are the first six paragraphs of the Oct. 23 music review, “A Farewell to Twang.”

headline: ING Group Moves Up Final Payment of Bailout Money to Dutch Government
abstract: The Dutch financial services company said it would repay the last of what it owes for a bailout during the financial crisis on Friday, six months earlier than expected.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Dutch financial services firm ING Group said on Wednesday that it would make a final repayment six months earlier than expected of the billions of euros in state aid it received during the financial crisis.

headline: Inside the Vigilante Fight Against Boko Haram
abstract: As their military struggles to combat the Islamist terrorist group, everyday Nigerians have formed citizen battalions to defend their towns. But have they gone too far?
lead_paragraph: Long before the Islamist militant group Boko Haram kidnapped nearly 300 schoolgirls from Chibok in April, Abba Aji Kalli watched his country descend into madness. Kalli lives in Maiduguri, a city of more than one million and the capital of Borno State, just 80 miles from Chibok, in Nigeria’s impoverished northeast. For months before the girls were taken, refugees flooded into Maiduguri, fleeing almost-daily Boko Haram raids on nearby villages. The militants arrived on motorcycles and Toyota Hilux trucks, sometimes in the middle of the night, sometimes in broad daylight, destroying homes and businesses and killing villagers. By May, a month after the kidnappings, the rebels were coming closer, striking surrounding villages and towns. Maiduguri could only be next.

headline: Pass Go, Take Pictures
abstract: Revisiting the Atlantic City streets that were immortalized in Monopoly.
lead_paragraph: Illinois Avenue is the place to go if you want cash for gold — though be advised that the street is now known as Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Boulevard. If your marriage is on the rocks, head over to Pacific Avenue, where A.C. Dolls, a “premier gentleman’s club,” advertises divorce parties. And on Virginia Avenue, there is yet another casino.

headline: Would You Want to Be a Space Tourist?
abstract: Is space tourism a frivolous endeavor? Is it a waste of money and human ingenuity, plus dangerous to boot? Or, is it a worthwhile venture, much like the pioneering efforts with early flying machines many decades ago?
lead_paragraph: Last week’s crash of Virgin Galactic’s SpaceShipTwo, killing one test pilot and seriously injuring the other, was a new setback for commercial spaceflight. Still, the prospect of space tourism seems quite real.

headline: Party Investigators Warn Officials in Zhejiang Province Against Religion
abstract: Officials from an antigraft body cautioned against practicing religion in the eastern province, where several Christian churches have been demolished or forced to remove prominent crosses over the past year.
lead_paragraph: Communist Party investigators have warned officials in the eastern province of Zhejiang, where several Christian churches have been demolished or forced to remove prominent crosses over the past year, against practicing religion. The brief message was included in a statement from the Central Commission for Discipline Inspection describing its recent tour of the province.

headline: For Israel, Two-State Is No Solution
abstract: The Oslo plan for a settlement of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict is finished. We need a new model.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Recent events in the Middle East are a reminder of how the old models of peace between Israel and the Palestinians are no longer relevant. The time has come to rethink the two-state solution.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: States Benefiting Most From Obama’s Health Law Elected Republicans
abstract: People who were pleased with their new health care coverage remained unhappy with the Democrats who passed it.
lead_paragraph: In places where the uninsured rate plummeted this year, Republicans still scored big electoral victories.

headline: New York Today: Political Parties
abstract: Wednesday: Election Night events, clouds roll in, and a cannoli factory burns.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this warm Wednesday.

headline: District of Columbia Election Highlights
abstract: Highlights from the election in District of Columbia
lead_paragraph: The District of Columbia has taken big steps on marijuana policy this year, decriminalizing some possession of the drug last summer before voters on Tuesday approved legalizing it by a wide margin. Adults will be allowed to have up to two ounces of marijuana and cultivate some plants for personal use, though the ballot measure would not permit sales; however, the City Council has already started looking into passing a law that would.

headline: Has the World Forgotten the Central African Republic?
abstract: World governments and the international press are ignoring another humanitarian crisis coming to a full boil in Africa.
lead_paragraph: A “forgotten crisis.” That’s how the Council on Foreign Relations defines the state of affairs in the Central African Republic — a landlocked stretch of scrubland and dry forest wedged between Chad and the Democratic Republic of Congo.

headline: Dannel Malloy, in Repeat, Wins a Close Election for Connecticut Governor
abstract: On a day when Republicans snatched up governor’s seats in traditionally Democratic states, Dannel P. Malloy’s wobbly victory took on the tone of a much larger triumph, and might have opened a narrow path to national prominence.
lead_paragraph: By the standards of Connecticut’s long-conflicted relationship with Gov. Dannel P. Malloy, the tense wait on Tuesday night for returns in his re-election effort was a cakewalk.

headline: The Most Detailed Maps You’ll See From the Midterm Senate Elections
abstract: Maps of precinct-level results from some of the closest Senate races.
lead_paragraph: Maps of precinct-level results from some of the closest Senate races.

headline: The Most Detailed Maps You’ll See From Yesterday’s Senate Elections
abstract: Maps of precinct-level results from some of the closest Senate races
lead_paragraph: Maps of precinct-level results from some of the closest Senate races

headline: Facing Up to the Reality of a Layoff
abstract: It is not “right-sizing,” it is not a “reduction in force,” it is not a “rebalancing.” It is a layoff.
lead_paragraph: Once again, we have decisions to make. I have given my latest problem a lot of thought — the problem of losing money because we don’t really have enough work for about three people.

headline: Counting the Varied Costs of China’s Dependence on Coal
abstract: A report by the Natural Resources Defense Council and Chinese partners puts a monetary price on the problems created by the energy source, like air pollution.
lead_paragraph: The Natural Resources Defense Council has presented research that attempts to take on the Herculean task of quantifying the environmental, social and economic toll of China’s reliance on coal.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Riding Wave of Discontent, G.O.P. Takes Senate
abstract: Who took control of the Senate on Tuesday night, expanded their hold on the House, and defended some of the most closely contested governors’ races?
lead_paragraph: In “Riding Wave of Discontent, G.O.P. Takes Senate,” Jonathan Weisman and Ashley Parker write about the results and implications of Tuesday’s election.

headline: 2 Drivers Plow Into Israelis, Fueling Fears of New Palestinian Uprising
abstract: The episodes, in Jerusalem and the West Bank, have added to fears that a third uprising is taking shape as the latest crisis continues to reverberate beyond Israel’s borders.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Amid soaring tensions fueled by religious fervor and Palestinian anger over control of East Jerusalem, two drivers on Wednesday plowed their cars into Israelis in separate episodes, killing one police officer and injuring three soldiers.

headline: Son of South Korea Ferry Owner Is Convicted of Stealing Millions
abstract: Yoo Dae-kyoon, the eldest son of the business mogul linked to the Sewol ferry disaster, was sentenced to three years in prison for taking nearly $6.8 million.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The eldest son of the South Korean business mogul who controlled the company that ran the Sewol ferry, which sank in April, leaving more than 300 people dead, was convicted of embezzlement on Wednesday and sentenced to three years in prison.

headline: Carlyle to Buy Dealogic for $700 Million
abstract: The Carlyle Group is teaming up with two other investors to acquire the company, which sells software to investment banks and provides data on initial public offerings, mergers and other transactions.
lead_paragraph: The Carlyle Group and other investors have agreed to buy Dealogic, a software and data company catering to investment banks, for about $700 million.

headline: Morning Agenda: Wall St. After G.O.P. Victory
abstract: Wall Street is ready for change. | Regulators are homing in on the leveraged loan market. | Alibaba reports strong earnings. | Creditors keep troubled law schools afloat.
lead_paragraph: Republicans took control of the Senate on Tuesday night and expanded their hold on the House, in a rebuke of President Obama that will reshape the political landscape for his final two years in office, The New York Times writes. Propelled by economic dissatisfaction and anger toward the president, Republicans grabbed Democratic Senate seats in North Carolina, Colorado, Iowa, West Virginia, Arkansas, Montana and South Dakota to gain their first Senate majority since 2006. With at least a nine-seat gain and most likely more, House Republicans will have close to 245 seats, the largest Republican majority since the Truman administration.

headline: The Reporter as a Hero, Not a Joke
abstract: With “Rosewater,” Jon Stewart directs a film about Maziar Bahari, a reporter imprisoned and tortured in 2009 in Iran shortly after the disputed election there.
lead_paragraph: For someone who spent 118 days imprisoned in Iran after reporting on the disputed 2009 election there, Maziar Bahari has a surprising sense of humor about the subject.

headline: Today in Politics
abstract: Republicans won the Senate, padded their majority in the House and added to their numbers among the nation’s governors.
lead_paragraph: Special Edition: Washington Wakes to a Republican Reality

headline: Daily Clip Report
abstract: Daily Clip Report is a collection of articles about the media and The Times that is emailed each day to senior executives and newsroom managers here.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

headline: James Baldwin, a Stranger and Me
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A young woman feared the worst when a subway rider asked her an odd question, but it was about her book.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: France Approves G.E. Deal for Alstom’s Energy Business
abstract: All that is needed now is the backing of Alstom’s shareholders at a Dec. 19 meeting and the agreement of the antitrust authorities in 20 countries.
lead_paragraph: PARIS – The French government gave formal approval on Wednesday to General Electric’s $13.5 billion deal for the energy business of Alstom, the French power and transportation company.

headline: Mark Udall’s Concession Speech
abstract: Senator Mark Udall, Democrat of Colorado, spoke after being defeated by Representative Cory Gardner in the race for United States Senate.
lead_paragraph: Senator Mark Udall, Democrat of Colorado, spoke after being defeated by Representative Cory Gardner in the race for United States Senate.

headline: Kay Hagan’s Concession Speech
abstract: Senator Kay Hagan, Democrat of North Carolina, spoke after being defeated by State Representative Thom Tillis. The Senate race was the most expensive in United States history.
lead_paragraph: Senator Kay Hagan, Democrat of North Carolina, spoke after being defeated by State Representative Thom Tillis. The Senate race was the most expensive in United States history.

headline: Mary Landrieu’s Election Night Speech
abstract: Incumbent Senator Mary Landrieu, Democrat of Louisiana, spoke after learning that she will face a December runoff against Representative Bill Cassidy.
lead_paragraph: Incumbent Senator Mary Landrieu, Democrat of Louisiana, spoke after learning that she will face a December runoff against Representative Bill Cassidy.

headline: Free of Ebola, Nurse’s Aide Leaves Spanish Hospital
abstract: María Teresa Romero Ramos, 44, was found to be infected with the virus after treating a Spanish missionary who had returned from West Africa with the disease.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — A nurse’s aide who was the first person known to have contracted the Ebola virus outside Africa was released from a Madrid hospital on Wednesday, almost a month after she tested positive for the disease.

headline: Thom Tillis’s Victory Speech
abstract: State Representative Thom Tillis, Republican of North Carolina, spoke after defeating Senator Kay Hagan. The Senate race was the most expensive in United States history.
lead_paragraph: State Representative Thom Tillis, Republican of North Carolina, spoke after defeating Senator Kay Hagan. The Senate race was the most expensive in United States history.

headline: The Strange Case of States’ Penchant for Casinos
abstract: Significant expansions of gambling passed in three states, but were rejected in two where in-state interests balked.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, voters in five states considered proposals to significantly expand legal gambling and approved three of them. The two defeated proposals, in California and Colorado, had something in common: They faced strong opposition bankrolled by gambling operators that would have competed with the newly authorized gambling.

headline: The Tornado Election
abstract: More than a third of people voting for a Republican House candidate said they were unhappy or even angry at the Republican leaders in Congress.
lead_paragraph: The clichéd term for what happened last night is “wave election,” but if natural phenomena are going to be evoked, the more accurate expression is “tornado election,” leading to widespread destruction in weird, jagged patterns that are often difficult to explain when it’s over.

headline: The Restaurant Dishes Come to Your Door
abstract: A group of entrepreneurs, including Momofuku’s David Chang, is starting a company that looks to deliver high-quality food in as little as 15 minutes.
lead_paragraph: The options for people who have no time to cook and don’t want to go out to eat every night can be disappointing. A group of entrepreneurs, including David Chang of the Momofuku restaurants, is starting a company that plans to make high-quality restaurant food that it expects to deliver in as little as 15 minutes.

headline: The Democrats’ Southern Problem Reaches a New Depth
abstract: The national Democratic party has been out of favor in the South for decades, and now the party has become a toxic brand for local politicians.
lead_paragraph: For decades, Southern Democrats could count on winning local and statewide offices, even though the voters in their states would often withhold support for the Democrat in presidential races. No longer.

headline: Time Warner Profit Beats Third-Quarter Estimates
abstract: The entertainment company, which rejected a takeover effort by Rupert Murdoch over the summer, also raised its growth forecast for the year.
lead_paragraph: Three months after rebuffing Rupert Murdoch’s takeover effort, Time Warner beat analysts’ expectations with its third-quarter earnings and revenue, suggesting that the company’s insistence on remaining independent may yet reward investors.

headline: 1914: Republicans Sweep Elections
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Republicans Sweep Mid Term Elections in 1914
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — The Congressional elections have resulted in what might be properly termed a sharp warning to the Administration of President Wilson. The returns show that the Democratic majority in the House of Representatives will be not more than 21. They will retain the Senate. The present House has a Democratic majority of 115 and is divided as follows: DEMOCRATS … 290; REPUBLICANS … 127; PROGRESSIVES … 18. This means that the Republicans have carried some sixty districts which returned Democratic representatives in 1912.— The New York Herald, European Edition, Nov. 6, 1914

headline: After Election, Obama Vows to Work With, and Without, Congress
abstract: President Obama shook off an electoral drubbing and said he was eager to find common ground, but he also vowed to bypass Congress to change the immigration system.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama shook off an electoral drubbing on Wednesday and said he was eager to find common ground with Republicans during the final two years of his presidency, but he swiftly defied their objections by vowing to bypass Congress and use his executive authority to change the nation’s immigration system.

headline: Christopher Bailey Makes a (Mini) Movie
abstract: One hopes that the Burberry head, who is both chief executive and chief creative officer, isn’t just bored.
lead_paragraph: Renaissance men or control freaks?

headline: Election 2014: Gun Sense
abstract: In Washington State, voters approved a ballot measure that tries to limit mass killings.
lead_paragraph: The saddest ritual cycle in modern life is a school shooting. Kids get killed. Yellow ribbons, balloons and guidance counselors appear. Everyone wonders why and how. And then, we shrug and feel helpless that nothing can be done because the all-powerful gun lobby will move mountains to ensure that crazy people can always get a firearm.

headline: Election 2014: President Obama Is Not a Happy Warrior
abstract: This administration has been afflicted almost from the start with the inability to decide just whom it is trying to appeal to.
lead_paragraph: I love voting. I love pretty much everything about it. My polling place is and has been for many years the Alfred E. Smith School, P.S. 163, an elementary school. The voting booths are arrayed around a mottled, parquet gym floor, and there are always mothers running a bake sale outside to raise money for the school.

headline: 12 Recipes for Pickles, No Canning Required
abstract: As long as they’re eaten within a week or two, there are countless pickles that you can make quickly and easily.
lead_paragraph: As long as they’re eaten within a week or two, there are countless pickles that you can make quickly and easily.

headline: A Writer Is Moved to Learn More About Anne Frank
abstract: Joseph Berger explains what drew him to report on Anne Frank, whose “spirit while she was alive resonates through the decades.”
lead_paragraph: Joseph Berger wrote a piece today about Anne Frank’s surviving relatives and friends, and how, on notable anniversary dates, they are invited to talk about the young woman they knew and about their own often harrowing stories. He explains what drew him to the story.

headline: Bryan Ferry Reflects on Some of His Album Art
abstract: On the occasion of his latest release, “Avonmore,” the music icon looks back at four classic covers.
lead_paragraph: “Music has to take you to another place, capture some particular mood, so it just seems crazy to not get involved in the visuals,” says Bryan Ferry who, as both a solo artist and the frontman of Roxy Music, has been behind some of the most influential music — and album covers — of our time. A former student of the English Pop artist Richard Hamilton and a noted aesthete (not for nothing did he name his 1978 release “The Bride Stripped Bare,” after a Marcel Duchamp masterwork), Ferry has overseen every aspect of the imagery that has defined his career. That tradition has endured all the way up to “Avonmore,” his latest solo release, which features an old portrait of the 69-year-old Brit.

headline: How an Entrepreneur Learned to Sell Quinoa in the Land of Grits
abstract: Richard Thomas opened a health food restaurant after a nutritional consultant told him that fried food was bad for his customers.
lead_paragraph: In 1985, after many years in the fast-food business, Richard Thomas took a 180-degree turn and opened a health food restaurant, R. Thomas Deluxe Grill, on Peachtree Street in Atlanta. It struggled for 10 years, and then it became a local institution.

headline: 1964: Are Big Hairdos Out of Style?
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: A columnist questioned the hairstyle hegemony of the season in 1964.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — Everybody knows that the big hairdo has been out of style for at least a year. Out, my eye. You have only to look around the restaurants at noon, or the charity halls at night to see how far in it still is. The evening hairdos are bigger and more imposing than ever. Naturally, they’re a bit different. The do happens at the back of the head, where there are all kinds of things like puffy chignons, lacquered curls, ringlets like the Empress Eugenie, feathers, flowers or what not. A girl with an un-trimmed head looks like a sparrow among the peacocks. — By Eugenia Sheppard for the New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Nov. 6, 1964

headline: Audi Recalls 102,000 Cars for Airbag Defect
abstract: A software problem could affect the airbags in some A4 and S4 sedans and Allroad wagons; N.H.T.S.A. investigates Honda motorcycles.
lead_paragraph: Audi is recalling almost 102,000 A4 and S4 sedans and Allroad station wagons from the 2013-15 model years because a software problem could cause the front airbag to malfunction, according to a report the automaker posted Wednesday on the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration website.

headline: Digging to Freedom
abstract: Twenty-five years after the Berlin Wall came down, a picture book finds hope in one family’s escape from the East.
lead_paragraph: The 25th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall would hardly seem the occasion for an entrancing picture book, but the British author-illustrator Tom Clohosy Cole’s “Wall” is just that. The narrator is a little boy stuck in East Berlin with his mother and sister, while his father has ended up in the West. Out of this wrenching scenario Cole has fashioned a tight little narrative that has all the ambient foreboding of a fairy tale, the sense of children at the mercy of enormous, irrational, half-understood forces. But with a morose, shadowy palette of midnight blues and browns and a flat, elongated look that calls to mind Cold War poster art, it’s clear that the evil lurking is a distinctly modern one: jackboots and rifles, not malevolent spells, but what’s the difference to a child whose parent has been taken away?

headline: Raising Invisible Kids: Not Everyone Needs to Be Famous
abstract: So many young people think: Why would I want to work backstage when I can vie to be the front person? But “backstage” work (literally or metaphorically) can lead to a more fulfilling and even more successful life.
lead_paragraph: From the oft-lamented explosion of reality TV to the social media platforms nearly all of us participate in, we are in the age of the over-share. The message today is that recognition equals value, attention equals success.

headline: Kuwaiti Released From Guantánamo Under New Review System
abstract: Fawzi al Odah is only the second low-level prisoner to be released this year, and is the first transfer under a new system of parole-board-like hearings to periodically review cases.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A Kuwaiti man held by the United States without trial for nearly 13 years in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, was released early Wednesday, the military said. His repatriation was the first transfer to result from a new system of parole-board-like hearings to periodically review whether it is still necessary to keep holding prisoners.

headline: Quiet Island, With Change Coming
abstract: Change is coming to Roosevelt Island, which is part of Manhattan, with several new developments and residential subsidy programs about to end.
lead_paragraph: When Yarin and Talia Katz first came to the United States from Israel, they spent a year sampling various parts of New York City and New Jersey with monthly rentals. In 2011, when they were ready to settle down, Mr. Katz said, “We pretty much knew we wanted to move to Roosevelt Island.”

headline: Artificial Intelligence as a Threat
abstract: Smarter technology requires smarter humans to keep machines under control.
lead_paragraph: Ebola sounds like the stuff of nightmares. Bird flu and SARS also send shivers down my spine. But I’ll tell you what scares me most: artificial intelligence.

headline: What Democrats Don’t Get About the Minimum Wage
abstract: While increases to the minimum wage are popular among liberal voters, it’s not an issue that fires up the middle-class electorate.
lead_paragraph: Democrats have greatly misunderstood the politics of the minimum wage in a way that hurt them in the 2014 elections.

headline: Gigi Jordan Convicted of Manslaughter, Not Murder, in Son’s Killing
abstract: A jury accepted Ms. Jordan’s claims that she had acted in the throes of an “extreme emotional disturbance” when she poisoned her son in 2010.
lead_paragraph: It was, to say the least, an unusual murder defense.

headline: Aftermath of Attack in Jerusalem
abstract: A witness and a spokesman for the Israeli police described the scene after a Palestinian man rammed his car into people near a light-rail station in Jerusalem on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: A witness and a spokesman for the Israeli police described the scene after a Palestinian man rammed his car into people near a light-rail station in Jerusalem on Wednesday.

headline: A Dive Into Darkness
abstract: Saying that he’s ready for a detour, Hugh Jackman embraces an eerily enigmatic role in “The River,” now in previews on Broadway.
lead_paragraph: Wolverine seems ageless, but Hugh Jackman is definitely aging.

headline: What You Get for ... $1,700,000
abstract: This week’s properties include a converted barn in Connecticut, a compound in Texas and a historic house in Alabama.
lead_paragraph: LITCHFIELD, CONN.

headline: Bound for Pluto, Carrying Memories of Triton
abstract: When the New Horizons probe passes the former planet next year, it may look familiar: Neptune’s moon Triton, scrutinized 25 years ago by Voyager 2, is probably a long-lost brother of Pluto.
lead_paragraph: On Aug. 25, 1989, the Voyager 2 spacecraft slipped over the north pole of Neptune, then the most distant planet in the solar system, swerved south at Neptune’s big moon Triton and left the known worlds forever.

headline: A Captured Ice Moon
abstract: Neptune’s moon Triton was the last stop on Voyager 2’s tour of the outer planets. It is one of the coldest objects in the solar system and a big brother of Pluto, which NASA will visit next year.
lead_paragraph: Neptune’s moon Triton was the last stop on Voyager 2’s tour of the outer planets. It is one of the coldest objects in the solar system and a big brother of Pluto, which NASA will visit next year.

headline: Lydie Salvayre Is Awarded Goncourt Prize
abstract: The daughter of Spanish exiles received France’s most prestigious literary award for ‘Pas Pleurer,’ a novel set in the first summer of the Spanish Civil War.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The writer Lydie Salvayre, the daughter of Spanish exiles, on Wednesday won France’s most prestigious literary award, the Goncourt Prize, for a novel set in the first summer of the Spanish Civil War.

headline: Washington Election Highlights
abstract: Highlights from the election in Washington.
lead_paragraph: With no governor to elect nor Senate seat to fill, it was a pair of conflicting ballot measures regulating background checks for firearms that drew attention and quite a bit of outside money during this campaign season.

headline: A Celebration of E. B. White at Symphony Space
abstract: Naomi Watts, David Hyde Pierce and Liev Schreiber are among those who will gather to read stories and poems by White on Nov. 16.
lead_paragraph: A starry roster of film, television and theater actors — including Naomi Watts, David Hyde Pierce, Liev Schreiber, Michael Potts and Jane Curtin — will read from E. B. White’s stories and poetry at Symphony Space on Nov. 16. The program, “Terrific Tails: A Celebration of E. B. White,” is a collaboration between Symphony Space; the Manhattan branch of First Book, an organization that provides new books to disadvantaged children; and Harper Collins.

headline: Newly Empowered, Mitch McConnell Promises an End to ‘Gridlock’
abstract: After winning full control of Congress, Republicans plan to move quickly to show they can legislate, aware that they risk a backlash if they fail to deliver.
lead_paragraph: Fresh from his own re-election victory and his party’s powerful showing nationwide, Senator Mitch McConnell on Wednesday pledged to break the stalemate in Washington as newly empowered congressional Republicans moved quickly to demonstrate that they can get things done. “We’re going to pass legislation,” Mr. McConnell said at a news conference in Louisville, Ky. “This gridlock and dysfunction can be ended.”

headline: Lessons for Obama’s Final Two Years From Reagan, Clinton and Bush
abstract: The historical record shows intriguing possibilities for pragmatic action if President Obama can put aside his policy priorities.
lead_paragraph: A president in the final two years of an eight-year run in the White House. Congress held by an opposing party that loathes the occupant of 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue. A staff that is depleted and exhausted by six-plus years of governing.

headline: House Hunting in ... New Zealand
abstract: The market in Wellington has experienced modest growth, with home prices just now returning to levels not seen since the 2008 global financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: A FOUR-BEDROOM CONTEMPORARY WITH VIEWS OF WELLINGTON HARBOR

headline: G.O.P. Leader’s New Role Could Take Strained White House Ties to Next Level
abstract: As the Senate minority leader, Mitch McConnell has been a constant foil to the president’s agenda. Now he’s expected to be the majority leader. Can two political combatants function together without driving each other crazy?
lead_paragraph: After Oval Office meetings with the four congressional leaders, President Obama has often turned to his staff and asked of the Senate minority leader, Mitch McConnell, “What angle do you think he’s playing?”

headline: Why Elections Make Us Miserable (for a Little While)
abstract: New research finds that our happiness takes a hit when our party loses, but we don’t necessarily get a bump when it wins. And this may have implications for how candidates woo us.
lead_paragraph: If Tuesday’s election didn’t go the way you hoped, you might assume that those of the opposite political persuasion are as gleeful right now as you are despondent. But that may not be the case: A new study suggests that elections bum out their losers far more than they cheer up their winners, and its findings may have implications for the ways campaigns try to win us over.

headline: Lacma Gala Honors Quentin Tarantino and Barbara Kruger
abstract: The Los Angeles County Museum of Art draws the A-listers, including Kim Kardashian and Amy Adams.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — “I’d rather go to hell than have my picture taken,” the artist Barbara Kruger said over cocktails at the annual Art & Film gala last Saturday to benefit the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, otherwise known as Lacma.

headline: A Hotel Week for Los Angeles
abstract: Los Angeles will join New York this year in a Hotel Week promotion.
lead_paragraph: As the season of mad discounts approaches, travelers can once again look to Hotel Week N.Y.C. for a chance to score a cheaper stay in one of the city’s finer establishments.

headline: In Brooklyn, Never-Before-Seen Warhol Films Meet Titans of Indie Rock
abstract: “Exposed,” a multimedia event at BAM this week, pairs recently digitized shorts from the late artist’s archive with musical performances from the likes of Dean Wareham, Eleanor Friedberger and Bradford Cox.
lead_paragraph: “A lot of people think of early Warhol films as being minimal,” says Geralyn Huxley, a film curator at the Andy Warhol Museum in Pittsburgh. Specifically, she is referring to “Exposed: Songs for Unseen Warhol Films,” a multimedia program of 15 of Andy Warhol’s never-before-screened films set to live music by Tom Verlaine, Dean Wareham, Martin Rev, Eleanor Friedberger and Bradford Cox. After stops across the country, the show is being presented at BAM this Thursday, Friday and Saturday. Huxley notes that many of Warhol’s films were actually “really personal: he’d go to downtown theater performances and film them, or he’d film dinner parties he went to,” she says. “Later on, he always carried a Polaroid camera, a tape recorder. He was interested in recording everything he could.”

headline: Formula One in Crisis Mode
abstract: With a depleted grid and uncertain finances, the racing series looks inward as it heads to the Brazilian Grand Prix near São Paulo this weekend.
lead_paragraph: Once again, Formula One, the world’s leading global auto-racing series, rescued itself from a controversial week with its performance on the track at the U.S. Grand Prix in Texas last weekend.

headline: As Other Democrats Fall, Colorado Governor Goes From Angst to Relief
abstract: Gov. John W. Hickenlooper’s narrow victory over Bob Beauprez defied a wave of Republican victories in races for governor in usual Democratic strongholds like Maryland, Massachusetts and Illinois.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — It was getting late on election night, and Gov. John W. Hickenlooper was trailing. Colorado’s senior United States senator, Mark Udall, had already conceded defeat, and other Democratic politicians were falling here and across the country. Political allies reported encouraging signs — long lines at college-town polling sites, strong support in Colorado’s suburban counties — but it was never supposed to be this close for Mr. Hickenlooper, a governor who had cast himself as a moderate, pro-energy Democrat at the helm of a growing Western economy.

headline: Ted Kennedy Jr. Wins State Senate Race in Connecticut
abstract: Mr. Kennedy, the son of the former United States senator, won his first bid for office despite questions about the way he financed his campaign.
lead_paragraph: Connecticut finally got a Kennedy of its own on Tuesday night when Ted Kennedy Jr., the 53-year-old son of the former United States senator from Massachusetts, overcame opposition over the novel way his race was financed and won his bid to become a state senator representing Branford and five other towns east of New Haven.

headline: Ebola-Free Spanish Nurse Speaks Out
abstract: María Teresa Romero Ramos, a Spanish auxiliary nurse who was the first person to be infected by Ebola outside of Africa, spoke after she was released from Carlos III hospital in Madrid.
lead_paragraph: María Teresa Romero Ramos, a Spanish auxiliary nurse who was the first person to be infected by Ebola outside of Africa, spoke after she was released from Carlos III hospital in Madrid.

headline: Timepieces That Connect With a History of Exploration
abstract: Early explorers relied on mechanical timepieces for navigation; modern-day adventurers are carrying on the tradition.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A rowboat in the middle of the Pacific Ocean is not the most festive place to celebrate a 30th birthday, but Alex Bellini made the most of it. “I enjoyed a full panettone by myself,” he said, recalling the sweet bread from his native Italy that helped distinguish Sept. 15, 2008, from the 293 other days he spent alone at sea.

headline: Boutique Brands in Japan Keep Independent Watchmaking Alive
abstract: In a market dominated by industrial-scale brands such as Seiko, Citizen and Casio, niche businesses are fighting to keep artisan trades alive.
lead_paragraph: KYOTO, Japan — In a wooden house on a narrow lane of Kyoto’s Gion district, a place of cherry blossoms and strolling geisha, artisans craft delicate, colorful designs for the watchmaker Dedegumo.

headline: Outside Groups With Deep Pockets Lift G.O.P.
abstract: The election was a pivotal moment for the “super PACs” and political nonprofit groups that helped the party defeat Democrats across the country.
lead_paragraph: Last fall, Steven Law, the president of the nation’s largest Republican “super PAC,” met with two of his party’s biggest donors in a Houston office. Both had given generously to Mr. Law’s organization, American Crossroads, and other Republican outside groups in 2012, when they spent more than $700 million but failed to defeat President Obama or flip the Senate to Republican control. The donors were polite but incredulous.

headline: Business Leaders Cautiously Expect G.O.P. Win to Open Some Doors
abstract: Issues expected to get a new look include a corporate tax overhaul, environmental and financial regulation, trade deals and the Keystone oil pipeline.
lead_paragraph: After years of gridlock in Washington, American business is gearing up for a major push on long-sought goals like an overhaul of the corporate tax system, building the Keystone XL oil pipeline, lighter environmental and financial regulation and winning congressional backing for trade deals with Asia and Europe. Business interests face a much more receptive audience now that Republicans are poised to control both the House and Senate next year.

headline: Festive Host, Fervent Fans and Historic Race in Brazil
abstract: A look at what's happening in São Paulo during the Brazilian Grand Prix this weekend at the Interlagos circuit.
lead_paragraph: The Brazilian Grand Prix, held near São Paulo, is one of the most celebrated, festive and historic races on the Formula One calendar. The Brazilian fans are enthusiastic, making for a major event every time the race comes to the Interlagos circuit, with Brazilian flags waving and spectators descending on the circuit in hordes.

headline: Can’t Afford a Giacometti Sculpture? There’s Always the C.I.A.’s bin Laden Action Figure
abstract: An action figure of Osama bin Laden created after the 9/11 attacks is up for auction.
lead_paragraph: In the years after the 9/11 attacks the Central Intelligence Agency searched for novel ways to combat the threat of international terrorism. Some were more novel than others, and none more so than the agency’s partnership with Don Levine, the retired head of research and development at the toy company Hasbro and the creator of G.I. Joe.

headline: Jay Z Acquires Luxury Champagne Brand Armand de Brignac
abstract: A gold bottle of the Champagne, nicknamed “Ace of Spades,” appeared in a music video in 2006. A spokeswoman for Sovereign Brands said Jay Z “made us an offer we simply couldn’t refuse.”
lead_paragraph: In his song, “Young Forever,” Jay Z envisions a life where “you never get old and the Champagne’s always cold.” He may not be able to do much about aging, but he may be able to help with the chilled bubbly.

headline: California Election Highlights
abstract: Highlights from the election in California.
lead_paragraph: Jerry Brown easily won re-election, defeating Neel Kashkari — the little-known and underfunded Republican who is a former Goldman Sachs banker and Treasury official. Mr. Brown, 76, was seeking his second consecutive term as governor; the state’s term limits bar him from serving a third. He also served as California’s governor in the 1970s.

headline: Paid Sick Leave: On Four Ballots, and Undefeated
abstract: Paid sick leave was on four ballots last night. All four initiatives passed, even in Massachusetts, which now has both a Republican governor and the nation’s strongest requirements for paid sick leave.
lead_paragraph: Families in one state and three municipalities were big winners in last night’s elections in one respect: paid sick leave. On the ballot in Massachusetts as well as in Trenton and Montclair, N.J., and Oakland, Calif., (where a new law will expand the existing state requirements), paid sick leave won all four times.

headline: Truck Sales Help Profit Rise 32% at Chrysler
abstract: The automaker said its United States market share was 12.3 percent in the third quarter, with strong demand for its Jeep and Ram models.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Lifted by surging demand for its trucks and sport utility vehicles, net income at Chrysler jumped 32 percent in the third quarter, the company reported on Wednesday.

headline: Workday to Put Employees Through a Big Data Analysis
abstract: The same kind of data analysis behind a Netflix movie recommendation will analyze how people are working in your office. Workday’s new personnel and financials software can spot who’s likely to quit, exceed their expenses, or make sales budgets.
lead_paragraph: Don’t be afraid (yet) but big data is coming to your job. While it is unclear whether it will make life better or worse, it is almost certain to change the way companies function.

headline: Exponential Outbreaks: The Mathematics of Epidemics
abstract: In this lesson, students explore the fundamental mathematical concepts underlying the spread of contagious disease.
lead_paragraph: Note: We have published two additional lessons about the Ebola virus in West Africa and the United States.

headline: Goldman Sachs Sells $285 Million in Hedge Fund Holdings
abstract: Goldman has sold $2.55 billion it had in hedge funds to comply with the Volcker Rule, which bars banks from several types of investing and trading with their own money.
lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs is continuing to sell off its hedge fund holdings, including $285 million during the third quarter of this year, as the start date for the Volcker Rule draws closer.

headline: Voices of Privilege, Deconstructed
abstract: Young Jean Lee’s new play, “Straight White Men,” comes to the Public Theater.
lead_paragraph: Do you really want to know what Young Jean Lee’s new play, “Straight White Men,” is about? You have a clue right there in the title, and if you are someone who is remotely theater savvy, you probably already know that Ms. Lee, who usually directs her own plays, is a formally daring and intellectually curious experimentalist with an interest in identity and the limits and uses of showmanship.

headline: Alex Rodriguez Told Federal Agents of Doping in Bosch Case, Report Says
abstract: Rodriguez, the Yankees third baseman, told federal agents in January that he had used performance-enhancing drugs supplied by Anthony Bosch’s South Florida clinic, according to a report in The Miami Herald.
lead_paragraph: Last November, Alex Rodriguez, in a bitter dispute with Major League Baseball, took to the radio to dispute allegations that he had used performance-enhancing drugs supplied by a South Florida clinic.

headline: The President In His Labyrinth
abstract: Some post-shellacking advice for the POTUS.
lead_paragraph: As we await an official presidential response to last night’s Democratic debacle, here are two quotes that seem likely to frame the political class’s discussion of how the president might respond. First, from Politico, days before the drubbing, when the White House could still hope for just a modest setback at the polls:

headline: Fossil’s Unusual Size and Location Offer Clues in Evolution of Mammals
abstract: The skull fossil is from a newly discovered extinct species, Vintana, similar to groundhogs, that lived in the time of the dinosaurs, and is only the third mammal fossil found in the Southern Hemisphere.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, while searching for fish fossils on Madagascar, paleontologists came upon what proved to be a well-preserved cranium of a mammal that lived about 66 million to 70 million years ago, in the closing epoch of the mighty dinosaurs.

headline: 36 Hours in Tulum, Mexico
abstract: Explore street view, find our points of interest and sign in to your Google account to save your map.
lead_paragraph: Explore street view, find our points of interest and sign in to your Google account to save your map.

headline: 36 Hours in Tulum, Mexico
abstract: Once a laid-back resort village with a hippie vibe, Tulum’s pace has quickened, with new shops, restaurants and nightlife options complementing the broad white beaches and yoga retreats.
lead_paragraph: Once a laid-back resort village with a hippie vibe, Tulum’s pace has quickened, with new shops, restaurants and nightlife options complementing the broad white beaches and yoga retreats.

headline: 36 Horas en Tulum
abstract: Un pueblo tranquilo con un ambiente hippie, el ritmo de Tulum se ha acelerado, con nuevas tiendas , restaurantes y retiros de yoga al lado de la playa.
lead_paragraph: Un pueblo tranquilo con un ambiente hippie, el ritmo de Tulum se ha acelerado, con nuevas tiendas , restaurantes y retiros de yoga al lado de la playa.

headline: Today in Small Business: Election Fallout
abstract: The private sector created 230,000 jobs in October. New York is becoming doughnut city. And how did Taylor Swift sell a million copies of her album in a week? It’s called #taylurking.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: 36 Hours in Tulum, Mexico
abstract: Change has come to tranquil Tulum, now with traffic and crowds, but the beach is still stunning and the water as clear as a fishbowl.
lead_paragraph: The good news is that you still can’t flush the toilet paper in Tulum. The plumbing, like the balmy weather and a tenacious iguana population, is deeply rooted in the identity of this town an hour and a half south of Cancún. But even a quasi-functional plumbing infrastructure can’t dissuade tourists. Which leads me to the less good news. If you haven’t been to Tulum in the last few years, a heads-up: It’s a whole lot bigger than you remember. Today’s Tulum has three things many never thought possible: traffic, crowds and restaurants with waiting lists. But don’t despair. In fact, the town (it’s not a village anymore) is more exciting than ever. The beach is still stunning. The ruins are still there. The food is spicy and authentic. And for those willing, there are secret gems a long, dusty way from the beaten path.

headline: Classical Playlist: Carl Nielsen, Lou Harrison, Bach and More
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: LOU HARRISON: ‘La Koro Sutro’ and Suite for Violin with American GamelanBoston Modern Orchestra Project, Gil Rose, conductor; Gabriela Diaz, violinist; Providence Singers(BMOP/sound 1037)The American maverick composer Lou Harrison (1917-2003), like his colleague John Cage, was a pioneering explorer of Asian music. He was also an innovative builder of instruments. He and his lifelong partner, Bill Colvig, built sets of tuned percussion instruments that they called the American gamelan. This rewarding new recording offers a captivating performance of a Harrison masterpiece for this instrument, the Suite for Violin with American Gamelan, with the fine violinist Gabriela Diaz as soloist. The other enticement here is Harrison’s beguiling, delicate, melodically haunting “La Koro Sutro,” a setting of an Esperanto adaptation of the traditional Buddhist text the Heart Sutra, with the Providence Singers. This piece ends in a glorious burst of musical joy. (Anthony Tommasini)

headline: Amy Chozick Looks Ahead to 2016
abstract: Amy Chozick discussed the impact of Tuesday’s midterm results on the 2016 presidential election on MSNBC’s “The Daily Rundown.”
lead_paragraph: The reporter Amy Chozick of The Times discussed the impact of Tuesday’s midterm results on the 2016 presidential election on MSNBC’s “The Daily Rundown.”

headline: A New Face on the End-of-Life Debate
abstract: The death of Brittany Maynard may reinvigorate discussions over aid-in-dying policies.
lead_paragraph: The two videos in which Brittany Maynard explained her decision to end her life under Oregon’s Death With Dignity Act put a human face — and a very young one — on a sometimes abstract debate.

headline: What Does It Take to Sell Quinoa in the Land of Grits?
abstract: For Richard Thomas, it took many years of losing money and plugging away.
lead_paragraph: Richard Thomas got the idea to open a health food restaurant after traveling around California, where he sampled the menus of the kinds of places that were not easily found in the South in the 1980s. Later, he was further motivated when he met a nutritional consultant, Donna Gates, author of “The Body Ecology Diet,” who told him that he had been poisoning people with his fried food.

headline: Connecticut Election Highlights
abstract: Highlights from the election in Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Dannel P. Malloy, a Democrat, battled through the most hotly contested race in the state to win re-election, beating back an intense challenge from Thomas C. Foley, a Republican. The race was a replay of the 2010 contest, in which Mr. Malloy beat Mr. Foley by only a few thousand votes.

headline: Behind the Election’s Stunning Visual Elements
abstract: Steve Duenes, the graphics director, shows how The Times tries to add analysis — along with giving readers “something they don’t see anywhere else” — in the charts, maps and interactive coverage of the midterm races.
lead_paragraph: The Graphics and Interactive News desks rolled out some new visual elements as part of The Times’s midterm election coverage that have been months in the planning. Steve Duenes, the graphics director, describes some of them.

headline: How to See a Full Web Address on the Safari Browser
abstract: The browser’s settings can be changed, or users can click on the address field. Also, a considering the value of a touch-screen PC.
lead_paragraph: Q. Ever since I upgraded my Mac to OS X Yosemite, the Safari browser does not display the full web address of the sites I visit. I like to know the exact page I’m on, so is there a way to extend the abbreviated addresses that are shown at the top of the window?

headline: Milan Time: A Historical Tale of Night and Day
abstract: What are great cities without people? The photographer Alessandro Grassani finds the city’s geometry after the streets start emptying.
lead_paragraph: What are great cities without people? The photographer Alessandro Grassani finds the city’s geometry after the streets start emptying.

headline: The Eczema and Broken Bone Connection
abstract: Eczema sufferers are more likely to suffer bone fractures and other joint and bone injuries.
lead_paragraph: People with eczema, a skin condition marked by itching, irritation and rashes, have another problem to add to the list: A new study suggests that they are more likely to suffer broken bones and other joint-and-bone injuries.

headline: Hermès Scarves Form Basis for Limited Edition Wristwear
abstract: Designs for the carré scarf — drawn from the company’s classic origins as a maker of saddles and other equestrian tackle — are being used for new watch models.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Princess Grace of Monaco, Audrey Hepburn and Queen Elizabeth II are known for their very different senses of style, but one fashion accessory unites them: the Hermès scarf.

headline: Patek Philippe Celebrates 175th Anniversary in Style
abstract: The Swiss watchmaker marked its 175th year with the unveiling of six new pieces, including the Grandmaster Chime, which was seven years in the making.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — If guests at Patek Philippe’s 175th anniversary gala in mid-October were expecting a sedate celebration, in keeping with the watchmaker’s reputation for maintaining a low profile, they may have been surprised to find themselves witnesses to a spectacle.

headline: How Will Apple’s ‘Smart Watch’ Affect the Industry?
abstract: Ryan Raffaelli, a Harvard Business School professor, recently argued that the Apple device could bolster the watch industry rather than threaten it.
lead_paragraph: What does Apple’s “smart watch,” to be released early next year, mean for the traditional watch industry? The Harvard Business School professor Ryan Raffaelli, who recently argued on his blog that the Apple device could be more of a boost than a threat, discussed it with Jake Cigainero.

headline: Watchmakers Turn to 3-D Printing
abstract: Atelier le Brézéguet, a small French company, is among the first in the sector to use the new technology to create unique dials for its wristwatches.
lead_paragraph: A small French watch brand has developed a way to use 3-D printing technology to make artistic watch faces for Swiss-made timepieces.

headline: Bringing Old Watch Brands Out of Obscurity
abstract: Montres L. Leroy, a watchmaker to the royal courts of Europe, and Manufacture Royale, which has ties to Voltaire, are among companies that are reviving old names.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — In the world of luxury brands, history can be a useful tool to fashion the revival of an extinct name.

headline: The Republican Party In Triumph
abstract: Brooks and Collins on the full extent of the Election Day devastation of Democrats, including some who weren’t on the ballot.
lead_paragraph: David Brooks: Well, that was pretty much a complete drubbing.

headline: At Future Cornell Campus, the First Step in Restoring Murals Is Finding Them
abstract: Restoring three pieces from the federal Work Projects Administration at a hospital on Roosevelt Island presented many challenges.
lead_paragraph: Cornell University and its conservators faced a lot of challenges rescuing three rare 7-by-50-foot murals from the Goldwater Memorial Hospital on Roosevelt Island.

headline: New House Will Be More Conservative, and More Liberal
abstract: Deeper ideological divides could make compromise even harder to reach.
lead_paragraph: Conservatives in the next House of Representatives will be more conservative and its liberals more liberal.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Sales of Taylor Swift’s ‘1989’ Intensify Streaming Debate
abstract: Ms. Swift has the best-selling new album of the year, and has taken center stage in the industry war over streaming services like Spotify.
lead_paragraph: Taylor Swift has proved herself a music phenomenon on more than one front, scoring the fastest-selling album in 12 years and adding new fire to the industry debate on streaming music.

headline: Obama Requests $6 Billion for Ebola
abstract: A White House official said most of the emergency funding would be for immediate response efforts.
lead_paragraph: President Obama is asking Congress for just over $6 billion in emergency funding to combat Ebola in West Africa and protect Americans from the virus in the United States, an administration official said Wednesday.

headline: New York City Elects a Republican Under Federal Indictment
abstract: Michael Grimm has promised to resign if convicted.
lead_paragraph: It turns out that even a 20-count federal indictment did not stop New York voters from re-electing Representative Michael Grimm of Staten Island. Mr. Grimm, a Republican, easily beat former City Councilman Domenic Recchia, a workaday Democrat who would have done the job in Congress with a lot less bluster. At least he probably wouldn’t threaten to throw a reporter off a balcony, as Mr. Grimm did earlier this year.

headline: Next Steps for Victorious Republicans
abstract: Congressional Republicans are likely to go for smaller, bipartisan measures before working on bigger goals like cutting taxes.
lead_paragraph: While the Republican victories in Tuesday’s midterm elections said a lot about the national mood and priorities, they also raised new questions about how the parties will govern and the political landscape as they enter the next election cycle. A few of those are below.

headline: Carlyle’s Purchase of Dealogic Shows It Pays to Sell Shovels in Merger Gold Rush
abstract: Dealogic is in a sweet spot as bankers depend on the company for pitch-books and analysis on transactions of all stripes, Quentin Webb writes in Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: In a gold rush, it pays to sell the shovels.

headline: Wheelies: The ‘No Thanks, Chevrolet’ Edition
abstract: Manchester United players spurn free cars offered from a team sponsor, Chevrolet; Ford lays off 90 workers with automated telephone message at a Chicago plant.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: William Bratton Names a New Deputy for the New York Police Department Amid Scrutiny
abstract: After days of controversy over the second most powerful post in the New York Police Department, Benjamin B. Tucker was sworn in as the first deputy commissioner.
lead_paragraph: After days of controversy over the No. 2 post at the New York Police Department, Commissioner William J. Bratton on Wednesday named his new pick for the job of first deputy commissioner.

headline: A Soulful Piano Ballad From New York’s New Chanteuse to Watch
abstract: Hayley Coupon, who has traded a career in fashion for one in music, offers up a dynamic track that evokes Fiona Apple and Joni Mitchell.
lead_paragraph: The official website of the Brooklyn-based singer-songwriter Hayley Coupon is a purposefully minimalist statement. On it are the musician’s name in script, a SoundCloud embed of her latest single, email listings for press inquiries and bookings, three candid photographs and four social media links, one of which leads to a private Instagram account. In an era of digital oversharing, Coupon prefers to let her work speak for itself. “I don’t tend to offer up a lot of personal information, even to close friends,” she says of her sparse online presence, which mirrors her passion for “purity” and directness in songwriting. She quotes Joni Mitchell: “Don’t muddy the waters to make them seem deep.”

headline: A Maddening Bargain With a Mexican Police Officer
abstract: How much was this “infracción” between Tulum and Cancún going to cost us?
lead_paragraph: I should have known that renting a car in Mexico was a bad idea. Before I had my keys in hand, the price had doubled.

headline: Globe Theater to Offer Streaming Shakespeare
abstract: The Globe Theater will offer full video versions of its own productions as well as others for a fee.
lead_paragraph: Some 50 productions filmed in performance at Shakespeare’s Globe Theater will be available to watch online, the theater announced on Tuesday. Homegrown productions, like an all-male “Twelfth Night” with Mark Rylance and Stephen Fry, as well as 35 foreign-language productions that were part of the “Globe to Globe’ festival during the 2012 Cultural Olympics will be offered. Each film costs about $6.50 to rent or $13 to buy.

headline: Driven | 2015 Mercedes-Benz S550 4Matic
abstract: A stately luxury sedan with silky driving dynamics that’s more than the sum of its premium parts.
lead_paragraph: A stately luxury sedan with silky driving dynamics that’s more than the sum of its premium parts.

headline: Midterm Political Ads That Worked, and Why
abstract: Successful ads are all about connecting with voters, but there is more than one way to do that, as a look at two campaigns makes clear.
lead_paragraph: Tuesday night, Joni Ernst of Iowa won her Senate race, and in her acceptance speech she said she was going to go to Washington and “make 'em squeal!” The line referred to her famous hog-castration campaign ad, “Squeal,” which introduced her as a Senate candidate to the state and the nation almost eight months ago.

headline: Video: The 2015 S550 4Matic Is Mercedes’s Sedan for the Boardroom
abstract: Though expensive, Mercedes-Benz’s flagship sedan seduces with a combination of premium craftsmanship and technology.
lead_paragraph: If you’re not collecting big paychecks, nothing says “You need to find a better-paying job” the way a Mercedes-Benz S550 does. The $95,325 starting price of an S-Class is three times the cost of an average automobile. The version I tested was even more expensive, with options that drove up the price to nearly $129,000. If that seems extravagant, its 12-cylinder big brother, the S600, starts at $167,000.

headline: Roger Goodell Testifies at Ray Rice’s Appeal Hearing
abstract: At the hearing, which was expected to last at least another day, Rice argued that the N.F.L. had acted inconsistently and unfairly.
lead_paragraph: N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell was among several people who testified Wednesday at Ray Rice’s appeal of his indefinite suspension. The hearing, held in front of an arbitrator, was expected to last at least another day.

headline: Voters Know Themselves Better Than the Pollsters Do
abstract: Asking voters whom they expect to win yields better predictions than asking whom they intend to vote for.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday’s elections provide further ammunition for the idea that we should pay less attention to polls of voters’ intentions, and more to polls asking them who they think will win.

headline: Fall of the Banner Ad: The Monster That Swallowed the Web
abstract: In the 20 years since their introduction, banner ads have ruined the appearance and usability of the web, perverted content and diminished privacy.
lead_paragraph: Twenty years ago last month, a team of well-meaning designers, coders and magazine publishers inadvertently unleashed on an unsuspecting world one of the most misguided and destructive technologies of the Internet age: the web banner ad.

headline: While Some Parents Volunteer Too Much, Others Feel Excluded
abstract: Language barriers and perceived race and class barriers can mean that when it comes to volunteering, some parents stay home—and feel unable to help their children achieve.
lead_paragraph: This past September, just as I’ve done every September for the last few years, I signed up for the PTA. But this year, I told myself things would be different. I would go to every single meeting.

headline: Anatomy of a Number | ‘Found’
abstract: Eli Bolin, who wrote the music and lyrics for the musical “Found,” talks about how boxing and calypso music inspired the song “Cats Are Cats.” The show closed on Nov. 9 at the Atlantic Theater.
lead_paragraph: Eli Bolin, who wrote the music and lyrics for the musical “Found,” talks about how boxing and calypso music inspired the song “Cats Are Cats.” The show closed on Nov. 9 at the Atlantic Theater.

headline: Drop in Democratic Turnout Was the Difference in the Maryland Governor’s Race
abstract: It’s not easy for a Republican to become governor of Democratic-leaning Maryland, but here’s how Larry Hogan did it.
lead_paragraph: How did Larry Hogan, a Republican commercial real estate broker who had never run for office, pull off such an upset in Maryland’s governor race on Tuesday? By benefiting from a huge drop-off in Democratic turnout in the state’s largest population centers and winning big where it counts for Republicans.

headline: For Steve Israel, Democrat Charged With Protecting House Seats, a Rout Hits Close to Home
abstract: With Representative Steve Israel of Long Island as chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, his party lost 14 House seats nationwide, including three in New York.
lead_paragraph: Over the last six months, Steve Israel, the Long Island congressman in charge of defending Democratic House seats from the coming Republican onslaught, used his phone to call candidates, email donors and type 40,000 words of his second novel, a sendup of National Rifle Association lobbyists titled “Big Guns.”

headline: Choosing Our Coalitions
abstract: On the making of our midterm-presidential seesaw.
lead_paragraph: Both of my two post-election posts so far have focused on the role of chance and political agency, as opposed to just grinding demographic forces, in shaping our politics, and now I’m going to go three for three by saying something about the idea that we’re stuck in what Vox’s Matt Yglesias (or at least his headline) rather vividly describes as a “meaningless, demographically driven seesaw,” pitting one coalition optimized for midterms against another optimized for presidential elections, with no end in sight.

headline: Justices Consider Whether Tossing Out Fish Destroyed Records
abstract: Some appeared critical of the decision to prosecute John L. Yates, who faced a maximum of 20 years in prison for throwing back three undersize red grouper.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Most of the justices seemed troubled by Supreme Court arguments on Wednesday about the prosecution of a Florida fisherman for throwing three undersize red grouper back into the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Hold the Phone: There’s Breaking News!
abstract: News apps like Flipboard, Circa News and BBC News help keep users updated on breaking events.
lead_paragraph: NEWS flash: The news industry is changing faster than ever nowadays. Smartphone and tablet apps have given news-hungry consumers a whole new way to discover what is going on nearby and around the world. With apps always connected to the Internet, you can also argue that news breaks faster than it ever has.

headline: App Smart | News You Can Use
abstract: The news industry is changing faster than ever. Kit Eaton reviews three apps that help you stay on top of current events.
lead_paragraph: The news industry is changing faster than ever. Kit Eaton reviews three apps that help you stay on top of current events.

headline: Style in Carnegie Hill, Manhattan
abstract: Agostino Magni brings his elegant style to Carnegie Hill in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Agostino Magni was recently perusing the Carnegie Hill neighborhood in Manhattan for an apartment, planning a move from Italy, his home country. He was wearing a custom blazer, a shirt monogrammed with his initials, and Zara pants paired with Church’s shoes and a camouflage Prada bag. Mr. Magni describes his style as formal and elegant with touches of fun in his accent accessories. “I’m not scared to wear stripes or polka dots or crazy colors,” he said. This interview has been edited and condensed.

headline: Colon Cancer Rates Rising in Young Adults
abstract: Incidences of colorectal cancer among people under 50 — the recommended screening age — have been increasing sharply since the 1980s.
lead_paragraph: Incidences of colorectal cancer have been decreasing by about 1 percent a year since the mid 1980s, but incidences among people under 50 — the recommended screening age — has been increasing sharply, and these younger patients are more likely to present with advanced disease.

headline: The Daily Gift: A One-of-a-Kind Handmade Knife
abstract: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.
lead_paragraph: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.

headline: Hundreds of Companies Seen Cutting Tax Bills by Sending Money Through Luxembourg
abstract: The businesses, including PepsiCo, Ikea and FedEx, appear to have saved billions of dollars in taxes, according to a group of investigative reporters.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The list of multinational businesses accused of using European jurisdictions to cut their tax bills grew much longer on Wednesday when a group of investigative reporters published findings accusing more than 300 companies, including PepsiCo, Ikea and FedEx, of benefiting from preferential deals with the government of Luxembourg.

headline: Carmelo Anthony Cannot Pick Up Slack With J. R. Smith Suspended
abstract: With Smith suspended for one game, the Knicks needed a big night from Anthony, but he had only 13 points against the previously winless Pistons.
lead_paragraph: AUBURN HILLS, Mich. — The early season is proving to be a time of adjustment for the Knicks — a time to try to master the triangle offense and to work with a new coach.

headline: A Touch of Brooklyn in ... Ridgewood, Queens?
abstract: Ridgewood, Queens, is the new frontier for bohemians who are either priced out of Brooklyn or fed up with it.
lead_paragraph: Old world Bavarian charm was abundant in Gottscheer Hall, a community hub in Ridgewood, Queens, that celebrated its 90th anniversary in early October. Children wore lederhosen and dirndls. A trio played trumpets and accordions. German septuagenarians in suspenders and polka dots swayed beneath tiered chandeliers.

headline: Digging Deep Into an Alter Ego
abstract: Gugu Mbatha-Raw talks about preparing for her role as a hip-hop vixen teetering on the divide between superstardom and destruction in “Beyond the Lights.”
lead_paragraph: To prepare for the role of Noni, a hip-hop vixen teetering on the divide between superstardom and destruction in the film “Beyond the Lights,” Gugu Mbatha-Raw researched Rihanna and Beyoncé, went backstage at the Grammys, recorded with the producer The-Dream and learned to grind at Greystone Manor, the Los Angeles nightclub. So when it came time to dance, sing and swagger for the big screen, that was all her alter ego. “I think in my mind I was Noni,” she said. Directed by Gina Prince-Bythewood (“The Secret Life of Bees”), the film traces Noni’s struggle — aided by a quietly debonair police officer (Nate Parker) — to escape the manipulations of her “momager” (Minnie Driver), snip out her weave and trade explicit lyrics for the aching melodies of Nina Simone.

headline: From a Billowing Sound to an Ornamental Wisp
abstract: Joyce DiDonato returned to Carnegie Hall on Tuesday for a solo recital of songs with a Venetian theme by Vivaldi, Fauré, Rossini and others.
lead_paragraph: Nine days after seizing Carnegie Hall’s stage as a formidable sorceress in the title role of Handel’s “Alcina,” and six after singing the national anthem before Game 7 of the World Series, the endearing mezzo-soprano Joyce DiDonato returned to Carnegie on Tuesday evening in a gentler vein.

headline: A Cross-Dressing Tour Guide in White Tie and Tails
abstract: Patti LuPone’s “Faraway Places Part Two,” at 54 Below, is the sequel to her show there in 2012.
lead_paragraph: To watch Patti LuPone sing “Surabaya Johnny,” the great Brecht-Weill song from the musical “Happy End,” is to watch a performer dive into the muck of one of the most desperate musical harangues by an abused woman ever written. Because an attitude of defiance seems encoded in Ms. LuPone’s DNA, the character’s confession of erotic enslavement to a contemptuous stud is all the more disturbing.

headline: One Factor Blunting Impact of Green Spending on Election: Inertia
abstract: What’s missed in debates over the impact of liberal and conservative spending on congressional campaigns.
lead_paragraph: After the Republican success in the mid-term elections, it’s no surprise that a search of Twitter for “Steyer election Koch” — meaning for discussions of the relative impact of the millions spent on campaigns by the liberal billionaire Tom Steyer and the conservative Koch brothers — turns up a lot of heated assertions.

headline: Anatomy of a Number: ‘Found’
abstract: Eli Bolin, who wrote the music and lyrics for the show “Found,” talks about how boxing and calypso music inspired the number “Cats Are Cats.”
lead_paragraph: In the Anatomy of a Number video series, musical theater makers talk about the elements that inspired a song from their show.

headline: Jalopnik Film Festival to Hold Car Show in Williamsburg
abstract: A collection of classic, exotic and quirky cars will be lined up on the street in front of Nitehawk Cinema on Thursday night.
lead_paragraph: It’s time again for the Jalopnik Film Festival, and although tickets for the screening have sold out, the online curator of automotive quirk will be holding other events in conjunction with the films Thursday night.

headline: CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund Picks Paul Andrew as Winner
abstract: At the annual CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund dinner, Paul Andrew, a shoemaker from Britain, is the big winner.
lead_paragraph: A little before 8 p.m. on Monday, Seth Meyers was holding court at the annual CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund dinner at Spring Studios. Mr. Meyers is a regular at fashion events; he hosted the CFDA awards (a different event from this one) and the FIT Couture Council luncheon. But the fashion crowd can be tricky.

headline: Karen Finley: Keeping Her Clothes on but Still Causing a Stir
abstract: Ms. Finley, whose “Written in Sand” pays tribute to those who died of AIDS, is taking a more solemn approach.
lead_paragraph: “I want to start bartending,” the performance artist Karen Finley said, and her friend Chip Duckett, an events promoter and publicist, jumped right in. “Come over to my house,” he said. “I’m tired of pouring my own drinks.”

headline: G.O.P.’s Inroads With Latinos Hint at a Path for 2016
abstract: Latinos voted two to one for Democratic candidates in the midterm elections, but Republican gains in key races showed a possible tactic for cutting that lead in 2016.
lead_paragraph: Hispanics voted nearly two to one for Democratic candidates on Tuesday just as they did in the 2010 midterm elections, a national exit poll shows. In a number of key races, however, they voted more heavily Republican, pointing to a strategy for Republicans in the presidential contest in 2016.

headline: When a Stranger Delivers Your Texts
abstract: Miranda July’s app aims to shake up your life, or at least some of your conversations. Does it deliver?
lead_paragraph: If you find texting just too simple and predictable (if you’re not, that is, spending a lot of time on text exegesis), Miranda July has an app for you.

headline: Compression Socks and Hose Are No Longer for Grandma
abstract: Compression tights are beginning to come into vogue among stylish women who sit on uncomfortably small airplane seats during long-haul travel.
lead_paragraph: Even though she wears granny tights, Jamie Rubin, 43, fits no one’s definition of dowdy.

headline: N.C.A.A. Questioned Its Authority in Penalizing Penn State
abstract: Emails released as part of a lawsuit reveal that N.C.A.A. officials were unsure of their own authority to punish Penn State in the wake of the Jerry Sandusky scandal.
lead_paragraph: Emails released as part of a lawsuit reveal that N.C.A.A. officials were unsure of their own authority to penalize Penn State in the wake of the Jerry Sandusky child sexual-abuse scandal. In one email, an official said that she told the N.C.A.A.’s president, Mark Emmert, that sanctions would be a “bluff” and that he “basically agreed.”

headline: Funding Is Restored for Storied California Observatory
abstract: A year after the University of California said it would phase out funding for its Lick Observatory, the university said it had changed its mind.
lead_paragraph: A year after the University of California announced that it would phase out all funding for its storied Lick Observatory, sparking fears that the observatory could close if it could not find outside support, the university said on Tuesday that it had changed its mind.

headline: Season of Big Book Advances Includes a Reporter
abstract: Stephanie Clifford, a New York Times reporter who covers the Brooklyn courts, sold her debut novel to St. Martin’s Press for a low seven-figure sum.
lead_paragraph: Big book advances are back. Diana Gabaldon got more than $6 million for the ninth novel in her Outlander series. On Monday, Publishers Marketplace reported that Ecco paid $3 million or more for Charles Frazier’s fourth novel. And during an acquisitions frenzy leading up to the Frankfurt Book Fair last month, Random House signed two seven-figure deals with debut novelists, including 25-year-old Emma Cline, who got a three-book deal worth $2 million.

headline: The Best Eyeliners for Smoky Eyes
abstract: Adding smoke to your gaze.
lead_paragraph: Makeup trends come and go, but darkly shadowed bedroom eyes are as evergreen as red lips. (Just be wary of wearing them together.) If your eyelids are at all like mine, however — as oily as grunge hair — shadows and liners can slip and slide into raccoon territory. Below, some indefatigable finds that will last day to night.

headline: Choreographed Anecdotes in a New York Minute
abstract: With “Story/Time #35,” at New York Live Arts, Bill T. Jones began two weeks of reading one-minute tales as his dancers perform snippets from his company’s repertory.
lead_paragraph: What does one minute feel like?

headline: W Hotels to Return to Australia
abstract: W Hotels, which has not been in Australia since its Sydney location closed in 2005, plans to open a property in Brisbane in 2018.
lead_paragraph: W Hotels is planning a return to Australia. The Starwood brand plans to open a W Brisbane in Queensland in 2018, with a full line-up of luxury amenities.

headline: A Closer Look at Sexual Dysfunction in China
abstract: Long a taboo, along with other sexual topics, the impact of male impotence on men, women and relationships is increasingly being studied.
lead_paragraph: Shortly before Men’s Health Day on Oct. 28, reports of a new study of sex in China, presented in jokey and sympathetic language, raced through the Internet.

headline: Where Might Obama and the G.O.P. Agree? Here Are Possibilities
abstract: There’s another factor at play: two sides of the G.O.P. that may work against each other.
lead_paragraph: Now that Republicans are set to control both houses of Congress, the great question is: What will they do with it?

headline: Firm Associated With Dominique Strauss-Kahn Declares Insolvency
abstract: The firm said it acted after the apparent suicide of Mr. Strauss-Kahn’s business partner last month and the discovery of previously unknown “financial commitments.” Mr. Strauss-Kahn was no longer with the firm.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Luxembourg investment firm formerly associated with Dominique Strauss-Kahn was declared insolvent on Wednesday after the apparent suicide of his business partner last month and the discovery of previously unknown “financial commitments,” according to a statement issued by the company’s board of directors.

headline: Augmenting Your Password-Protected World
abstract: While passwords aren’t likely to disappear soon, new technology that uses eyes and fingerprints as identifiers can protect data more easily.
lead_paragraph: A USERNAME and password combination has long been the standard security mechanism for online accounts. But that method just isn’t cutting it anymore.

headline: How to Create a Secure Password
abstract: Four easy tips to protect your digital accounts from the next breach.
lead_paragraph: Four easy tips to protect your digital accounts from the next breach.

headline: Fantasy Football: Week 10 Matchup Breakdown
abstract: Have you given up on Falcons receiver Julio Jones? He is among the favorable matchup picks for Week 10.
lead_paragraph: Have you given up on Falcons receiver Julio Jones?

headline: Political Feud Weakens Coalition in Georgia
abstract: After the defense minister was dismissed on Tuesday, members of his Free Democrats Party abandoned the governing coalition, potentially slowing the country’s integration with the West.
