lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The Free Democrats, a pro-Western political party, abandoned Georgia’s governing coalition on Wednesday, deepening a political crisis in the former Soviet republic that critics fear may slow the country’s path toward integration with the West.

headline: Ford Shows Off the All-Aluminum F-150
abstract: Ford says the 2015 F-150 is 700 pounds lighter than the 2014 model and is making a push for acceptance of its turbocharged 2.7-liter engine.
lead_paragraph: Ford made a big splash at the Detroit auto show in January when it introduced its redesigned, mostly aluminum F-150 pickup truck. Now, the automaker is sending the truck, which it says is 700 pounds lighter than the outgoing model, around the country to give journalists and dealers a closer look.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Israel and Elsewhere
abstract: Israel and More — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: Israel and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: E.J. Manuel’s Stock Is Sagging, but Buffalo Bills Quarterback Is ‘Fearless’
abstract: E.J. Manuel’s his stock has sagged more than 50 percent since a start-up, Fantex, sold shares linked to his future earnings in football.
lead_paragraph: It happens all the time in the corporate world: Chief executives, when their stock price is down, will try to reassure anxious shareholders by pitching them on the company’s future potential.

headline: A Tale Outsmarting Itself, à la Hitchcock
abstract: Sally Silvers invokes the mood, imagery and plots of the master of suspense in her work at Roulette.
lead_paragraph: Gesture and choreographic structures may not be the first things one notices in a Hitchcock movie. But the right choreographer can unearth a vast inventory of both. In “Actual Size,” which had its premiere on Tuesday at Roulette, Sally Silvers expertly plunders the Master of Suspense to construct her own kind of thriller: mischievous, furtive and constantly changing, exposing and exploiting the absurdities of the genre.

headline: Soviet-Era Engine Is Blamed for Antares Rocket Explosion
abstract: The Orbital Sciences Corporation said that a preliminary analysis pointed to a failure of a turbopump for the Oct. 28 fireball in Virginia.
lead_paragraph: Substantiating suspicions right after the spectacular fireball that destroyed a rocket carrying cargo to the International Space Station, the manufacturer of the rocket said Wednesday that the fault most likely lay in Soviet-era rocket engines that powered the first stage.

headline: Finding Election Day Solace in Ronan Farrow’s T-Shirt
abstract: The MSNBC host posted a photo of himself at a Connecticut polling place that quickly went viral on Twitter.
lead_paragraph: Nothing like a little unexpected eye candy to brighten up what was — for some voters, at least — an otherwise gloomy election night. As news sites like The Atlantic, CNN, FiveThirtyEight and Politico recorded the results of one Republican win after another (Joni Ernst in Iowa, Tom Cotton in Arkansas, Rick Scott in Florida), some people clearly unhappy with those results found solace in Ronan Farrow’s lithe figure. Early in the evening, Mr. Farrow, the MSNBC host, posted on Instagram a picture of himself at a Connecticut polling station dressed fetchingly in a white form-fitting V-neck T-shirt — a photo that quickly went viral on Twitter.

headline: Nov. 5, 2014 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Israel, Algeria, Russia and the United States.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Israel, Algeria, Russia and the United States.

headline: Trying to Shatter Ceiling in Online Art Auctions
abstract: Despite efforts by auction houses to reach buyers through online auctions, in terms of the highest prices, they have so far shown limitations, especially among top artworks.
lead_paragraph: As art collectors gather in New York this week for the glittering fall auctions, works of art will routinely change hands for tens of millions of dollars, a few for much more, like a Giacometti bronze “Chariot” sculpture that sold for nearly $101 million at Sotheby’s on Tuesday evening.

headline: A Mosquito-Borne Virus Sweeps the Caribbean
abstract: Chikungunya, which causes fever and muscle pain, has spread across the region this year. Here are tips for travelers.
lead_paragraph: It started with a nagging pain in his wrists.

headline: Citing Volatility, Lawmakers in Lebanon Vote to Extend Their Term
abstract: Foreign diplomats, human rights organizations and Lebanese citizens denounced the move as detrimental to the country’s democracy.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Members of Lebanon’s Parliament voted by a large margin on Wednesday to extend their own terms in office by more than two and a half years, asserting that the country’s tenuous security situation made it too difficult to hold elections.

headline: Brooklyn Principal Apologizes for Remark Deemed Offensive
abstract: Donna Taylor, the principal of the Brooklyn School of Inquiry, said she regretted telling a group of parents and children that “if you don’t speak Spanish, you’re going to clean your own house.”
lead_paragraph: The principal of an elite public school in Brooklyn who infuriated parents this week by making what some considered an insensitive remark about learning Spanish has apologized, officials said on Wednesday.

headline: Study Points to Overdiagnosis of Thyroid Cancer
abstract: Soaring diagnoses in South Korea and elsewhere could be attributable to increased screening and could lead to unnecessary treatment.
lead_paragraph: To the shock of many cancer experts, the most common cancer in South Korea is not lung or breast or colon or prostate. It is now thyroid cancer, whose incidence has increased fifteenfold in the past two decades. “A tsunami of thyroid cancer,” as one researcher puts it.

headline: The Upshot and the Midterms: Big Test, Good Grade and Lessons Learned
abstract: The data-driven enterprise had a solid run, and wants to build on it.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago – during the coverage of the 2012 presidential race – the relationship between Nate Silver’s Five Thirty Eight (then based at The Times) and the paper’s political team seemed tense. And an observant reader could sometimes pick that up in the journalism.

headline: Taylor Swift Responsible for 22% of Album Sales Last Week
abstract: Ms. Swift’s album “1989” sold more than the next 106 titles on this week’s chart combined.
lead_paragraph: Taylor Swift stunned the music industry on Wednesday with the news that her new album, “1989” (Big Machine), sold 1.287 million copies in its first week out. Defying the prevailing trends in music, it became the fastest-selling album in 12 years and is also the only title released so far this year to sell one million copies (once a very common milestone).

headline: This Week in Shopping
abstract: Jumpsuits you can wear to work; vintage corsetry finds its modern match; oh-so-comfortable, easy-to-pack shoes and aphoristic clutches.
lead_paragraph: Ready To Roll Up Its Sleeves

headline: Malicious Software Campaign Targets Apple Users in China
abstract: It would not be easy for the average Mac user to be hit by this malware, but it points to new ways in which hackers are targeting Apple products.
lead_paragraph: Researchers at a Silicon Valley security company said on Wednesday that they had found a new manner in which hackers can infect Apple products.

headline: How Big Were Tuesday’s Republican Swings?
abstract: The Republicans took control of the Senate on Tuesday, picking up at least seven seats, and expanded their majority in the House. Their victory in the Senate was significant but not the largest historically — though it could rank among the top five election year swings since 1946.
lead_paragraph: The Republicans took control of the Senate on Tuesday, picking up at least seven seats, and expanded their majority in the House. Their victory in the Senate was significant but not the largest historically — though it could rank among the top five election year swings since 1946.

headline: Princeton Mishandled Sexual Misconduct and Discrimination Cases, U.S. Inquiry Finds
abstract: The Office of Civil Rights found that the university, which is already enacting reforms, failed to respond quickly and fairly to students’ complaints.
lead_paragraph: A federal investigation into Princeton University’s sexual misconduct and discrimination policies has found that the university violated the law and failed to respond quickly and fairly to students’ complaints.

headline: Reading The Times With Joseph O’Neill
abstract: Prize winning writer Joseph O’Neill reads The New York Times post-election day.
lead_paragraph: Joseph O’Neill is an Irish born writer. His latest novel is “The Dog.”

headline: An Underdog Triumphs at the World Series
abstract: The Rosenblum Teams final at the 14th Red Bull World Series in China last month was between Monaco and Poland.
lead_paragraph: The Rosenblum Teams final at the 14th Red Bull World Series in China last month was between one of the pretournament favorites, Monaco (Pierre Zimmermann, Franck Multon, Fulvio Fantoni, Claudio Nunes, Geir Helgemo and Tor Helness), and a dark-horse team from Poland (Marcin Mazurkiewicz, Krzysztof Jassem, Piotr Gawrys, Michal Klukowski, Stanislaw Golebiowski and Wlodzimierz Starkowski).

headline: The Plot to Burn New York City
abstract: In November 1864, Confederate agents came dangerously close to setting fire to Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: In the waning days of the Civil War, as a Northern victory became both obvious and inevitable, the Confederate government of President Jefferson Davis financed what it hoped would be a drawn-out war of attrition, with the intention of driving President Abraham Lincoln to the bargaining table. A large part of that strategy involved members of the South’s Secret Services, who hatched a series of plots against Union territory that featured Canada as their operations site and relied on an impressive network of hundreds of soldiers, agents and operatives. Their most ambitious plot? To burn New York City.

headline: Conquering Big Lines in France
abstract: Learn the dangers and difficulties of skiing big mountain lines from veteran Ian McIntosh, as he travels to the peaks of La Grave, France.
lead_paragraph: Learn the dangers and difficulties of skiing big mountain lines from veteran Ian McIntosh, as he travels to the peaks of La Grave, France.

headline: They’re Trapped in an Elevator and in Life
abstract: Two African-American executives, caught in an elevator during a building crisis, discuss matters of class and sex as well their own threatened physical safety.
lead_paragraph: A play calculated to make anyone who sees it take the stairs, “Lift,” at 59E59 Theaters, is the debut full-length drama from the novelist Walter Mosley. After terrorists attack a skyscraper, two young African-American executives find themselves trapped in an elevator. The intercom won’t function, the doors won’t open, the hatch is locked, cellphones won’t work and, hey, is that the smell of smoke?

headline: For Joan Rivers’s Doctor, Fame Delivers Its Bill
abstract: Dr. Gwen Korovin was known for being close to many of her celebrity clients. In the case of Joan Rivers, perhaps too close.
lead_paragraph: The first things you notice as you walk through the small hallway leading to the Upper East Side office of Dr. Gwen Korovin, a prominent ear, nose and throat specialist, are the mounted platinum records.

headline: One Star, 2 Films and Conflict
abstract: A publicity scuffle over Jessica Chastain, who appears in both “Interstellar” and “A Most Violent Year,” exemplifies how actors and filmmakers occasionally face conflicts over overlapping films.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Take a good look when Jessica Chastain walks the red carpet at a Hollywood premiere for J. C. Chandor’s “A Most Violent Year” on Thursday night.

headline: The Midterms Were Not a Republican Revolution
abstract: They were a repudiation of a broken political system.
lead_paragraph: ON election night 1994, as Republicans recaptured the House for the first time in 40 years, I stood in the audience and watched my client Newt Gingrich, who would soon become speaker of the House, declare the beginning of the “Republican revolution.”

headline: Video: Veteran Skier Conquers Big Line in France
abstract: Learn the dangers and difficulties of skiing big mountain lines from veteran Ian McIntosh, as he travels to the peaks of La Grave, France.
lead_paragraph: Behind the Line is a video series produced by Teton Gravity Research that takes you into the minds of skiers. In each episode, the athletes will look back on a line, a jump or a session, and discuss the moment.

headline: Einhorn Ends Green Mountain Bet, but Suggests Amazon Could Decline
abstract: In a letter sent to investors in his firm, David Einhorn disclosed that he had ended his gamble that shares in Keurig Green Mountain would fall.
lead_paragraph: After wagering against the maker of Keurig single-serve coffee machines for three years, the hedge fund manager David Einhorn has settled his bet at a loss. But the investor had tough words for an even bigger potential target: Amazon.com.

headline: McConnell on the New Senate
abstract: Mitch McConnell, who will most likely become majority leader in the Senate next year, said the two sides in the Senate would work together but also warned of partisan divisions.
lead_paragraph: Mitch McConnell, who will most likely become majority leader in the Senate next year, said the two sides in the Senate would work together but also warned of partisan divisions.

headline: Markets Seem to Cheer Mario Draghi’s Off-Script Comments
abstract: Mario Draghi has sent markets soaring and raised hopes for Europe’s economic outlook after previous freewheeling comments, and Thursday could bring more of the same.
lead_paragraph: Mario Draghi, the president of the European Central Bank, is scheduled to host a regular news conference on monetary policy on Thursday. If the event progresses as it normally does, he will start by reading out a numbers-heavy statement composed by the council that sets policy.

headline: An Epidemic of Thyroid Cancer?
abstract: No. It’s an epidemic of overdiagnosis.
lead_paragraph: HISTORICALLY, the science of epidemiology was directed toward identifying and controlling epidemics of infectious disease. In a study just published in the New England Journal of Medicine, my colleagues and I highlight another important job for epidemiologists: identifying and controlling epidemics of medical care.

headline: Putting the Cart Before the Art
abstract: The overpopulation of food vendors in front of the Metropolitan Museum of Art prompted city surveillance in January to confirm whether they were disabled veterans or stand-ins.
lead_paragraph: No food carts were in sight on Sept. 9, when the Harlem Teen Choir serenaded dignitaries attending the opening of the new $65 million plaza in front of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, with its pristine granite fountains and allées of little leaf linden trees.

headline: Obama on Working With the New Congress
abstract: President Obama said he looked forward to the Republicans putting forward their governing agenda after they regained control of Congress in the midterm elections.
lead_paragraph: President Obama said he looked forward to the Republicans putting forward their governing agenda after they regained control of Congress in the midterm elections.

headline: Virgil Abloh, Kanye West’s Creative Director, Puts Street Wear in the Spotlight With His Off-White Line
abstract: Mr. Abloh’s line Off-White, a high-minded take on street wear, is gaining traction with a global collective of fans and retailers.
lead_paragraph: Sitting down to lunch at the Mercer Kitchen in New York not long ago, Virgil Abloh checked off the most recent stops on the circuitous route that had led him to where he sat: from Tokyo to Copenhagen, back to Tokyo, to San Francisco, to Los Angeles, to Chicago, and then here.

headline: Quick, Robin, to the Blu-ray Box!
abstract: The campy 1960s TV series “Batman” has been restored and released on DVD and Blu-ray in a new boxed set.
lead_paragraph: The news arrived via a celebrity tweet.

headline: Anatomy of a Presidency While It’s Still Unfolding
abstract: In ‘The Stranger,” Chuck Todd, moderator of “Meet the Press,” dissects President Obama’s record.
lead_paragraph: For his inaugural program this September as moderator of NBC’s “Meet the Press,” Chuck Todd landed a big guest: Barack Obama. If the president reads Mr. Todd’s new book “The Stranger,” it’s hard to imagine him wanting to return to the program anytime soon. The book delivers a stinging indictment of his presidency so far, one underscored by this week’s elections, which resulted in huge gains for Republicans and are widely seen as a repudiation of Mr. Obama and his policies.

headline: Texas Democrats Ponder How They Will Ever Win
abstract: After Wendy Davis’s lopsided defeat in the governor’s race, analysts agreed that the problems went beyond her campaign.
lead_paragraph: FORT WORTH — Wendy Davis was beaten not once but twice on Election Day.

headline: Wearable Gear and Apps to Make Running Healthier, and a Lot More Fun
abstract: A look at products ranging from sensor-equipped shirts that can track your workout to apps that can turn a long jog into an exercise in play.
lead_paragraph: If the New York City Marathon has inspired you to hit the pavement running, here are some noteworthy gadgets and apps to help you get on your feet.

headline: Report Cites Evidence of War Crimes in Myanmar
abstract: There is sufficient evidence to try military commanders over an offensive against ethnic Karen fighters from 2005 to 2008, Harvard researchers say.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — A report by Harvard researchers due to be released on Friday says there is sufficient evidence to prosecute high-ranking officers in Myanmar’s military for crimes against humanity and war crimes committed against an ethnic minority.

headline: Caught in Insider Trading Crackdown, Ex-Galleon Trader Turns It Around
abstract: Adam Smith, a former trader at the Galleon Group hedge fund, turned his brush with the law into a top job at American Prison Data Systems.
lead_paragraph: Adam Smith, a portfolio manager at the now-defunct hedge fund the Galleon Group, always seemed to have a Plan B.

headline: Skewering the Pretensions of Their Rarefied Milieu
abstract: Sending up the pretensions of experimental dance, Larissa Velez-Jackson presented her work “Star Crap Method” at the Chocolate Factory.
lead_paragraph: To name a performance “Star Crap Method” is to lower all expectations except the expectation of humor. And at the Chocolate Factory on Tuesday, when Larissa Velez-Jackson’s work had its debut, the disarming effect of the title was reinforced with some preshow karaoke. Audience members were also invited to decorate the theater with objects that evoked the central word in the title.

headline: Split Decision by Voters on Local Fracking Bans
abstract: The oil industry and fracking opponents split eight races, three in California, four in Ohio and one in Texas.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The small city of Denton, Tex., voted to ban hydraulic fracturing in Tuesday’s election after a hard-fought battle between environmentalists and local oil companies in the heart of natural gas country.

headline: Openings, Sales and Events in New York City
abstract: A lingerie exhibition, loungewear store opening and shopping opportunities around New York.
lead_paragraph: Openings and Events

headline: Obama Promises Action on Immigration
abstract: In his first speech after Republicans won control of Congress, President Obama pledged executive action on immigration “before the end of the year.”
lead_paragraph: In his first speech after Republicans won control of Congress, President Obama pledged executive action on immigration “before the end of the year.”

headline: Looking Back, Looking Forward
abstract: Now Republicans must demonstrate that they are capable of solutions, and not just sullenness. They have to pass actual legislation.
lead_paragraph: The Republicans proved Tuesday that the establishment still knows how to win.

headline: Election Day Entailed Casting Votes for Soda Taxes and Food Issues Too
abstract: Food and biotech companies spent $60 million battling proposals dealing with what Americans can and cannot eat and drink.
lead_paragraph: Voters delivered mixed messages on a number of measures and initiatives involving food and beverages on Tuesday.

headline: Don’t Call Clay Benskin a Street Photographer
abstract: Three years after Clay Benskin told a photographer friend he could take better pictures with a smartphone, he has produced thousands of images. But he still doesn’t see himself as a street photographer.
lead_paragraph: Three years after Clay Benskin told a photographer friend he could take better pictures with a smartphone, he has produced thousands of images. But he still doesn’t see himself as a street photographer.

headline: Alaska Election Highlights
abstract: Highlights from the election in Alaska.
lead_paragraph: Voters approved a proposal to legalize marijuana for adults and regulate it like alcohol.

headline: What ‘White Privilege’ Really Means
abstract: Is not fearing that the police will kill your child for no reason a privilege or a right?
lead_paragraph: This is the first in a series of interviews with philosophers on race that I am conducting for The Stone. This week’s conversation is with Naomi Zack, a professor of philosophy at the University of Oregon and the author of “The Ethics and Mores of Race: Equality After the History of Philosophy.”  — George Yancy

headline: Chinese President’s  Delegation Tied to Illegal Ivory Purchases  During Africa Visit
abstract: At a time when China says it is trying to root out corruption, a report accuses President Xi Jinping’s delegation of colluding with corrupt Tanzanian officials to smuggle ivory.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — When President Xi Jinping of China and his entourage of government officials and business leaders arrived in Tanzania in March 2013, it was to officially promote economic ties between the two countries.

headline: A Conservatory in the Kitchen
abstract: The writer discovered a warm, light-filled place where he could grow herbs and vegetables year-round. It’s called his condo.
lead_paragraph: ST. PAUL — Two years ago, Elizabeth Millard discovered a way to put fresh produce into car food. No, she’s not the one who smuggled shredded lettuce into the Doritos Cheesy Gordita Crunch-Fiery, a 490-calorie, zero-noun snack from Taco Bell. Rather, Ms. Millard, a sustainable farmer outside the Twin Cities, did something even more unlikely: she grew a crop of microgreens on the passenger-side floor mat of her 2005 VW Beetle convertible.

headline: Cuddle Up in This
abstract: Because the only thing cuter than a tiny house is a tiny house on wheels.
lead_paragraph: ­Sitting in a tiny room wrapped in birchwood the color of honey on a rainy afternoon last week, Kelle Arvay had a look of deep contentment. “It’s hard to describe the feeling of being inside here,” Ms. Arvay said. “It’s comfortable. It’s a real safe-feeling space.”

headline: Beds: Sleeping Beauties
abstract: A stunning bed can always be appreciated, even when you’re in the land of Nod.
lead_paragraph: Of all the furniture you’ll ever buy, “the bed, the sofa and dining table are the three biggest things,” Jeffrey Bernett said.

headline: Same Tree, New Nest
abstract: A bigger apartment required a radically new attitude about what went into it.
lead_paragraph: The plan was simple.

headline: A Pritzker Sets Out With Ideas of Empire
abstract: Adam Pritzker, a member of the family behind Hyatt hotels, has started Assembled Brands, with ambitions of building his own consumer goods and hospitality conglomerate.
lead_paragraph: Adam Pritzker strolled through a spacious SoHo loft, pausing to admire a fake narwhal tusk. Handblown glass chandeliers from the Czech Republic dangled overhead, and vintage Moroccan rugs covered expansive hardwood floors.

headline: In Japan, Moves to Stimulate Economy Reach a Critical Stage
abstract: Two years into an aggressive stimulus under Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, his campaign to reinvigorate Japan’s economy is entering a make-or-break phase.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Hiroyuki Hara has increased prices at his flower shop in recent months, part of a broad reversal of the deflation that has long plagued Japan’s economy. Getting prices rising is a national goal, but Mr. Hara isn’t sure the new landscape is any more vibrant.

headline: Warship Deal With Russia
abstract: Representative Eliot L. Engel writes that France, the maker of the Mistral-class warships, and the allies should work to annul the deal.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Bad Alternatives to Banks
abstract: Julie Menin, the consumer affairs commissioner for New York City, says poor people should not have to rely on fringe financial services.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Supporting New York City Parks
abstract: Daniel Squadron, a New York State senator, defends his proposal to have park conservancies help other parks that need improvements.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Gazing Into the Void
abstract: Ben Jensen, a British scientist, explains why his company’s new invention, Vantablack, may not work in your home. Not even on an accent wall.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this week, Donald Kaufman, an architectural color specialist, declared that the color for November is black. He may be on to something. Recently, Surrey NanoSystems, a high-tech company near Brighton, England, announced its new invention, Vantablack, which it claims is the blackest black ever seen, or, actually, not seen.

headline: Known as ‘Alex From Target,’ Teenage Clerk Rises to Star on Twitter and Talk Shows
abstract: While many people focused on the midterm elections, others became enamored of a young employee at a Target store in Texas.
lead_paragraph: While political analysts spent Wednesday interpreting the significance of the midterm elections, social media pundits obsessed over the meaning of Alex from Target.

headline: A Pressing Question
abstract: The Swiss-made iron had a steep price and a bewildering set of instructions. But what would it do for my silk shirt?
lead_paragraph: Laurastar, a Swiss company dedicated to ironing technology, now sells its portable steam iron, Lift, in the United States. At $749 to $799, depending on color, Lift is not cheap. But it is marketed as a fast and easy way to keep your clothes looking presentable, thereby reducing the need for expensive dry cleaning.

headline: Thursday’s Matchup: Browns (5-3) at Bengals (5-2-1)
abstract: A look at how Cleveland and Cincinnati match up for Thursday night’s game.
lead_paragraph: 8:25 p.m. Eastern, NFL Network

headline: Step on Him at Your Own Risk
abstract: Tibetan wool tiger carpets faithfully reproduce a rare species.
lead_paragraph: Tigers may be endangered, but wool Tibetan tiger rugs are even more so.

headline: The ‘Get Smart’ Desk
abstract: New pieces from Henrybuilt are designed to focus attention.
lead_paragraph: Henrybuilt, a Seattle company known for its kitchen systems, has introduced a writer’s desk ($3,100) and a chair ($1,450). “It was a design exercise, not a business exercise,” said Scott Hudson, the founder. “We wanted to produce something with as few parts as possible that perfectly represented the design philosophy of our brand.”

headline: The Messages of the Midterm Election
abstract: Readers debate how to interpret the huge Republican victories on Election Day, and what Democrats should have done differently.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: From a Persian Mosque, Design Inspiration
abstract: Ruby Tree produces furniture and accessories inspired by traditional Islamic craft.
lead_paragraph: The Ruby Tree, a furnishings company, was founded by Mitchell Abdul Karim Crites, the director of Saray Design, an Indian studio that specializes in the decoration of mosques, and Bethan Gray, a product designer in London. The first collection, introduced at Harrods in London, includes Petal bowls, platters and tables, which Ms. Gray and Mr. Crites designed with Saray artisans in marble inlaid with lapis lazuli or ruby or rose quartz; the pattern is inspired by the dome of the 17th-century Sheikh Lotfollah Mosque in Iran. (The lapis Petal bowl shown is $5,495.) The Striped range, in black marble and green amazonite, recalls medieval Persian ceramics.

headline: Fledgling Grief
abstract: I could save the birds, or at least try. I could do nothing for my father.
lead_paragraph: I haven’t sent my father’s watch to be fixed since his death six months ago. I am scared to let it out of my grasp. For 45 years it circled his wrist: a silver-faced Accutron with a tuning-fork movement that I could hear humming when I brought Dad’s warm arm up to my ear. Its face tells me it stopped at 4:04 on the 27th. My father stopped at 6:04 on the 30th.

headline: Discounts at Uhuru Design, Chelsea Textiles, Holland & Sherry and More
abstract: Sales on home décor, furniture and hardware.
lead_paragraph: During Uhuru Design’s sample sale on Nov. 6, furniture is up to 75 percent off (a Stitch table in turquoise, originally $7,800, is $4,600); 185 Van Dyke Street (Ferris Street), Brooklyn, 718-855-6519, uhurudesign.com.

headline: Should We Repair Our Water-Damaged Kitchen Ceiling?
abstract: Even if you’re not planning to renovate your kitchen before you list your house, you’ll want to make it look as well maintained as possible.
lead_paragraph: Q. We plan to sell a house that will need a kitchen renovation, and the kitchen ceiling has water damage. Should we fix the ceiling before selling?

headline: Landlords Say de Blasio Ignores Their Plight
abstract: Ask tenant leaders about Mayor Bill de Blasio and they say so far so good. Many landlords, though, say they are just bracing themselves for the next hit.
lead_paragraph: First he raised water and sewer rates. Then he helped engineer the skimpiest rent increases in the history of rent regulation.

headline: In Love With a Priest: Support Groups Spread
abstract: Challengers point to a shortage of Roman Catholic priests and to studies that show celibacy is a deterrent for young men wanting to enter the priesthood.
lead_paragraph: ROME — They had not planned on falling in love, but they did.

headline: Dating Website Emphasizes Like, Rather Than Love
abstract: A campaign based on the slogan “First Comes Like” highlights the moments when daters discover each other’s endearing qualities.
lead_paragraph: MATCH.COM and eHarmony have tussled over which dating website has spawned more marriages, and in August, a self-regulatory advertising panel ruled eHarmony should discontinue marketing claims including “#1 Most Marriages.”

headline: World Cup Shift Could Hurt, or Help, Networks
abstract: Moving the 2022 World Cup out of its traditional start in June could have ramifications for two of FIFA’s TV partners, Fox and Telemundo.
lead_paragraph: The reality of the summer heat in Qatar has fully dawned on FIFA. A top official of soccer’s world governing body said Monday that it was considering turning the 2022 World Cup into a late autumn or winter event that would start in January or November of that year. That change might benefit players and fans who would avoid triple-digit temperatures outside air-conditioned stadiums.

headline: New England Delegation Acquires a Tinge of Red
abstract: The region’s all-Democratic House delegation will gain two Republican members, one from New Hampshire and one from Maine.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. — New England states have not voted for a Republican for president in years, even spurning one of their own, Mitt Romney, the former Massachusetts governor, in 2012.

headline: Abortion-Rights Advocates Preparing for a New Surge of Federal and State Attacks
abstract: Republican gains are likely to add to state abortion restrictions, from two-day waiting periods to bans at 20 weeks after conception to costly building requirements.
lead_paragraph: Advocates for abortion rights were bracing Wednesday for renewed assaults on abortion access in Washington as well as in state capitols after widespread Republican electoral gains.

headline: Switzerland: Next Director Is Named for CERN Nuclear Laboratory
abstract: Fabiola Gianotti, who led one of the two teams of physicists that discovered the Higgs boson, the so-called God particle that imbues other particles with mass, has been named the next director general of CERN, the European Organization for Nuclear Research.
lead_paragraph: Fabiola Gianotti, who led one of the two teams of physicists that discovered the Higgs boson, the so-called God particle that imbues other particles with mass, has been named the next director-general of CERN, the European Organization for Nuclear Research. Dr. Gianotti, 52, will take over for a five-year run at the end of 2015, when the current director, Rolf-Dieter Heuer, steps down. She will be the first woman to direct the laboratory — which is outside Geneva and is home to the world’s most expensive science experiment, the Large Hadron Collider — where the Higgs boson was finally produced and detected in 2012, capping a half-century quest. The machine, which has been down for repairs for the past two years, is to fire up its proton beams again next March with higher energies in the hunt for better understanding of the new boson and of other mysteries, like the nature of dark matter.

headline: Publishing and Real Estate Services Push Revenue Up at News Corporation
abstract: Declines in advertising and subscriptions pushed revenue at the company’s news and information services division down 3 percent.
lead_paragraph: News Corporation, the publishing company controlled by Rupert Murdoch, which is rapidly trying to transform itself, is finding that its nonnewspaper businesses are paying the bills.

headline: The Hague: Serbian Nationalist Leader With Cancer May Be Freed Temporarily
abstract: The United Nations war crimes tribunal in The Hague has proposed a temporary release for Vojislav Seselj, a Serbian nationalist leader with cancer, whose health has seriously deteriorated during his long-running trial.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations war crimes tribunal in The Hague has proposed a temporary release for Vojislav Seselj, a Serbian nationalist leader with cancer, whose health has seriously deteriorated during his long-running trial. In a decision published on Wednesday, the judge in charge of his case suggested that “to avoid the worst-case scenario” Mr. Seselj should return to Serbia for treatment. Mr. Seselj, a firebrand politician, has been charged with inciting others to commit war crimes in Bosnia and Croatia in the 1990s by creating a militia and sending its members off with incendiary speeches. He has also been convicted of contempt of court. Mr. Seselj surrendered to the tribunal in 2003, and his enduring presence during his much-delayed trial has become an embarrassment for the Yugoslavia tribunal. He has often harangued judges and has taken pride in provoking prosecutors.

headline: Alaska Awaits Election Results for Senate and Governor
abstract: The race for Senate — between Dan Sullivan, a Republican, and the incumbent, Mark Begich, a Democrat — and the vote for governor were still undecided on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: ANCHORAGE — The top two political races in Alaska, in terms of campaign spending, public attention and, now, cliffhanger postelection drama — remained unresolved on Wednesday.

headline: Dodgers Set to Hire Farhan Zaidi, a Small-Market Executive, as G.M.
abstract: Zaidi has worked in consulting, in business development for a division of a sports magazine, and in the Oakland Athletics’ front office for the last 10 years.
lead_paragraph: Farhan Zaidi’s résumé sounds almost as eclectic as his background.

headline: Fox Election Coverage Draws Biggest Share of a Less-Than-Rapt Audience
abstract: Every network was down substantially from its view levels of four years ago, suggesting a deep lack of interest in the results.
lead_paragraph: With interest down sharply across the board in television coverage of the midterm elections, Fox News had about as big a night as the Republican Party, drawing the biggest audience not only in cable but also beating the broadcast networks’ limited coverage.

headline: Always Look on the Bright Side
abstract: There are some positive ways to interpret the midterms. You just have to look for them.
lead_paragraph: Our topic for today is: looking on the post-election bright side.

headline: Mr. Obama’s Offer to Republicans
abstract: The president said what he heard from voters Tuesday was to “get stuff done,” and he pointed out areas where he thinks agreement could be reached.
lead_paragraph: President Obama refused on Wednesday to submit to the Republican narrative that his presidency effectively ended with the midterm elections.

headline: Swamped in a Red Surge, Southern Democrats Contemplate Their Rebuilding Plans
abstract: After decades of decline from once-total control of the South, Democrats already had little left to lose before the election.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Burns Strider, a native Mississippian who has advised the Democratic Party on faith issues, spent Tuesday night watching the election returns with a couple of other Democratic consultants and a bottle of small-batch bourbon. It was that kind of night.

headline: In Red and Blue States, Good Ideas Prevail
abstract: In many states, voters approved ballot measures that were directly at odds with the positions of many Republican candidates who won.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic brand did not fare well, to put it mildly, in congressional and governors’ races on Tuesday. Most were contests of political blame, driven by ideological hatred for President Obama. But when the ballot offered a choice on an actual policy, rather than between candidates with a D or R next to their names, voters made notably liberal decisions in both red and blue states.

headline: Republican Takeover of New York Senate May Aid Cuomo’s Centrist Brand
abstract: A divided Legislature will put Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo in a powerful position, allowing him to play deal maker between Republicans and Democrats.
lead_paragraph: Liberal activists were left seething over his feeble efforts to help fellow Democrats. Republicans, even in defeat, could point to the many counties across upstate New York that he failed to win.

headline: Chief Quits as Mississippi Prisons Face Inquiry
abstract: Christopher Epps, the longtime commissioner of Mississippi’s Department of Corrections, resigned amid a federal investigation of conditions at state prisons.
lead_paragraph: Mississippi’s longtime corrections commissioner resigned Wednesday amid a federal investigation into the state’s prison system, which has been plagued by squalid conditions and violence by guards and inmates.

headline: Fostering Pheasants to Keep a Tradition Alive
abstract: Families, wildlife groups and others are raising day-old chicks that they will release into the wild as part of a Utah program to promote hunting.
lead_paragraph: BENJAMIN, Utah — The lid on the cardboard box flips open, and the birds shoot out like rockets and scatter into the gray sky, wings flapping hard to catch the strong winds that carry them off to a life in the wild.

headline: The Possibility of Post-Election Bipartisan Deals
abstract: What compromises, if any, are realistic for President Obama and the new Congress to make?

headline: A Year of Unforeseen Hits
abstract: John Moffitt abruptly retired from the N.F.L. a year ago, and the transition to life outside the sports bubble has been rocky.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — John Moffitt spent 20 years to reach the pinnacle of his profession, a day to ditch that job and a year grappling with the consequences of his decision.

headline: State Wage Initiatives Fare Better Than Democrats
abstract: If the ballot measures on Tuesday were any measure, the issue has become unmoored from partisan politics, drawing support from both sides.
lead_paragraph: In an election in which the merest hint of association with President Obama seemed radioactive to Republican voters, one of his signature issues was embraced Tuesday in some of the country’s most solidly red states: raising the minimum wage.

headline: Obama to Seek Congressional Backing for Military Campaign Against ISIS
abstract: The president opened the door to a lengthy, potentially contentious debate over the nature and extent of American engagement in Iraq and Syria.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama said on Wednesday that he would seek specific authorization from Congress for the military campaign against the Islamic State, opening the door to a lengthy, potentially contentious debate over the nature and extent of American engagement in Iraq and Syria.

headline: Perella Weinberg Said to Merge 2 Subprime Auto Lenders
abstract: The asset management arm of the firm will combine the lenders Flagship Credit Acceptance and CarFinance Capital into one company that will enable them to complete larger securitizations at a lower cost.
lead_paragraph: The asset management arm of Perella Weinberg Partners is merging two subprime auto lenders that it owns as part of an effort to streamline their operations and expand market share.

headline: Republican Voters Want to Get Things Done, but Differ on Priorities
abstract: Beyond a forceful repudiation of President Obama, there was little uniformity on just what Republican voters wanted from their party’s new Senate majority.
lead_paragraph: Republican voters got an early Christmas present on Election Day: a Senate majority and expanded control of the House when the next Congress takes its seats shortly after the actual holiday.

headline: With Statehouse Victories, Republicans Are Poised to Enact Changes
abstract: With the states acting as laboratories for legislation that cannot advance in Washington, Republican policy changes are likely on a variety of issues.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Republicans posted sweeping gains in state houses across the nation on Tuesday, taking control of the most state legislatures in nearly 100 years and approaching a record number of governors’ seats — a critical development at a time when most major policy has been coming out of states, rather than Washington.

headline: New Marijuana Initiatives Loom as 3 Win Approval
abstract: Lessons for both sides of the issue are seen in votes in Alaska, Oregon and Washington, D.C.
lead_paragraph: ANCHORAGE — Conservative candidates garnered majorities in many elections around the country on Tuesday, but so did efforts to legalize marijuana. And the lessons of that complex pattern — with voters in Oregon, Washington, D.C., and here in Alaska approving recreational marijuana, and in Florida supporting medical marijuana — are already being absorbed for the next wave of state voter referendums, and fights, already planned for 2016.

headline: America’s Broken Politics
abstract: We painlessly inherited democracy, but by allowing political dysfunction to set in, we’ve botched it.
lead_paragraph: Let’s face it: The American political system is broken.

headline: Women in Both Parties Are Disappointed by Their Modest Election Gains
abstract: While Republican women fared somewhat better than Democratic women, 2014 was hardly the year of the woman.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Senator Jeanne Shaheen, a New Hampshire Democrat, beat Scott Brown to win re-election on Tuesday, her supporters saw history being made — although not by Ms. Shaheen.

headline: With Alex Rodriguez Coming Back, Things Look Bleak in the Bronx
abstract: As Rodriguez brings his drug-laden baggage back to his team, a strange bit of fallout has occurred: Some people are feeling sorry for the Yankees.
lead_paragraph: In a million years, in a million baseball seasons, I never would have dreamed I’d ever say this: I feel sorry for the Yankees.

headline: Kansas’ Advice to Republicans: Stay to the Right
abstract: After a comfortable, across-the-board victory Tuesday, state Republican leaders proudly affirmed their conservatism and said the party should follow suit.
lead_paragraph: TOPEKA, Kan. — After a comfortable, across-the-board victory, Republican leaders here proudly affirmed their conservatism on Wednesday and sent a message to their party that Republicans can win on principles.

headline: What the Forecasts Got Right, and Wrong
abstract: The elections are over. What have we learned about the efforts to analyze and predict the outcomes of various Senate races?
lead_paragraph: The results of the midterm elections are in, leaving Republicans with at least 52 Senate seats, along with the likely addition of Alaska, where Dan Sullivan holds a four-point lead. In Louisiana, Mary Landrieu and Bill Cassidy will face off in a runoff election on Dec. 6. And without the possibility of control of the Senate being on the line, Ms. Landrieu can no longer hold out hope that a flood of Democratic support will come to her aid.

headline: ‘No Mercy’ for Killers of Couple in Pakistan
abstract: Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif ordered the authorities to “show no mercy” in bringing to justice those involved in the killing of a Christian couple who were accused of blasphemy.
lead_paragraph: LAHORE, Pakistan — Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif on Wednesday ordered the authorities to “show no mercy” in bringing to justice those involved in the murder of a Christian couple, who were tortured and then incinerated in a brick kiln after being accused of blasphemy, officials said.

headline: Protests Resume at Guggenheim Over Abu Dhabi Museum
abstract: Critics say they will take their protests to donors, not just managers of the museum.
lead_paragraph: Just after 5 p.m. on Wednesday a 40-foot banner fluttered into view inside the central rotunda of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum in Manhattan, where visitors were looking at works by a collection of painters and sculptors called the Zero Group, who had aimed to redefine art after World War II.

headline: By Lending a Hand, Christie Gains Some Clout for 2016
abstract: For Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, the wave of Republican victories in statehouses on Tuesday is helping recast his image as a team player within his wary party.
lead_paragraph: As the midterm elections neared, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey counseled the Republican candidate for governor of Massachusetts, Charlie Baker, on how to land verbal punches against a female opponent without alienating women during televised debates. (Mr. Baker won.)

headline: 2 New York City Officers Charged With Assaulting Teenager
abstract: Officers Tyrane Issac and David Afanador also face misconduct charges in the arrest of Kaheem Tribble, 16, in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: The surveillance video starts with a 16-year-old running down a sidewalk in Brooklyn, with the police in pursuit.

headline: 8 Million Rats for 8 Million New Yorkers? Data Suggest a City Legend Is Flawed
abstract: In a newly published paper, a Columbia University doctoral student argues that the city has far fewer rats than had been thought. About six million fewer.
lead_paragraph: For some years, statistics have suggested that New York City was getting safer, cleaner and more expensive. Now there are numbers that suggest the city may not be home to as many rats as New Yorkers might have thought — or liked to boast about to visitors.

headline: Ukraine to Freeze Payments in Separatist Areas
abstract: The prime minister said payments totaling $2.6 billion, mostly for public sector wages and pensions, would be withheld, putting a burden on Russia.
lead_paragraph: DONETSK, Ukraine — Ukraine’s prime minister said Wednesday that the government would freeze payments it had been sending to parts of eastern Ukraine even after the areas had fallen under the control of pro-Russian separatists.

headline: More Expensive Cars Are Leading to Longer-Term Loans
abstract: Car loans used to last three or four years, but the average length of a new-car loan is now a record five and a half years, with some loans reaching eight years.
lead_paragraph: It used to be that a car loan lasted three or four years. After 36 or 48 months of payments, you could drive debt-free for a few more years, before deciding if you wanted to get a new vehicle.

headline: Washington Denies a Role in Yemeni Unrest
abstract: Supporters of the former Yemeni president, Ali Abdullah Saleh, accused the United States ambassador to Yemen of demanding that Mr. Saleh leave the country.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The Obama administration on Wednesday denied that it was interfering in Yemen’s escalating civil conflict, after supporters of the former Yemeni president, Ali Abdullah Saleh, accused the United States ambassador to Yemen of demanding that Mr. Saleh leave the country.

headline: In States Seen to Be Tilting Left, Voters Defy Democrats’ Forecast
abstract: A powerful lesson for both parties emerged Tuesday: Demographic shifts that are gradually reshaping the American electorate cannot overcome a difficult political environment and a weak message.
lead_paragraph: Republicans working on the Senate race in Colorado sensed something was shifting even before the votes were counted.

headline: Tesla Reports Loss, but Beats Wall Street Expectations
abstract: The electric automaker lost $75 million in the third quarter, less than what analysts had predicted.
lead_paragraph: Tesla Motors, the electric vehicle maker, reported net losses of $75 million for the third quarter, nearly twice as much as the previous year, on revenue of $852 million.

headline: At Golan Heights, Israel Eyes Syria Chaos
abstract: A general said that for now neither the rebels nor President Bashar al-Assad of Syria and Hezbollah, the Lebanese Shiite militia assisting him, were interested in engaging Israel.
lead_paragraph: MOUNT AVITAL MILITARY BASE, Golan Heights — As Israel has heightened its presence in the Golan Heights with a new army division, the division’s commander said Wednesday that he had counted 15 intentional attacks from across the once-quiet Syrian frontier since March, most of them attributed to two “proxy groups,” which are supported by Hezbollah and Iran.

headline: Like Father, Like Son: Similarities in Cuomos’ Races for Governor Rankle Democrats
abstract: After landslide re-election wins, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and his father, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, were accused of failing to support other Democrats on the ballot.
lead_paragraph: A yawning victory margin for a Democratic governor. An incumbent who seemed intent to run out the clock, playing down the importance of debates. And a liberal base that felt shortchanged once the votes were counted, upbraiding the man atop the New York State ballot for not doing more.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 5, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Egypt Elevates an Official Hostile to U.S.
abstract: Fayza Abul Naga, who led a criminal case against American nonprofit groups, will be national security adviser to President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi is appointing a national security adviser who two years ago spearheaded criminal charges that nonprofit groups were acting as agents of an American conspiracy to weaken and destabilize Egypt.

headline: Mark Sanchez Is Making Return in a System That Suits Him
abstract: Sanchez, who was more or less asked to serve as a caretaker with the Jets, is now being asked to win games for the Eagles.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Jordan Matthews was drafted in May by the Philadelphia Eagles, who were eager to add him to their stable of dynamic offensive talent. Those first few days, Matthews met LeSean McCoy and Darren Sproles, Jeremy Maclin and Zach Ertz, but none of them had quite the effect on him that the team’s backup quarterback did.

headline: Hunting Down Nazis and Surviving the Holocaust, at a Cost
abstract: The one-man show “Wiesenthal,” written by and starring Tom Dugan, humanizes appalling events.
lead_paragraph: There’s a large map on the set of “Wiesenthal,” and hundreds of books line the onstage shelves. The script, too, is filled with information: dates, names, statistics. But it’s the personal moments that at times elevate this otherwise standard one-man show about the life of Simon Wiesenthal.

headline: Winter Plantings
abstract: Matt Ginsberg returns with a divisive puzzle.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — I finished Matt Ginsberg’s puzzle and had an unusual reaction to it: I thought I was losing my mind. Or that maybe there was some meta puzzle in here that I just wasn’t seeing. Because isn’t PESACH in the spring? Well, we’re not going to hold that against anybody; Happy Passover, everyone! Pass the matzo down this way, please.

headline: Effort Begins for More Say on Directors
abstract: Scott Stringer, the New York City comptroller who oversees five pension funds, is leading a drive to let shareholders nominate board directors.
lead_paragraph: Annual shareholder meetings are supposed to allow a company’s owners to change troubling governance practices such as outsize executive pay or directors who neglect their fiduciary duties.

headline: ‘No Pulse’? Not Enough Passion? Giants Shrug at a Captain’s Criticism
abstract: Safety Antrel Rolle’s comments the day after the Giants lost to the Colts did not produce much reaction from his teammates, and Coach Tom Coughlin mildly disputed Rolle’s remarks.
lead_paragraph: Antrel Rolle’s comments Tuesday that the Giants had “no pulse” during their blowout loss to the Indianapolis Colts and that the team needed to play with more passion did not produce much reaction from his teammates, and Coach Tom Coughlin mildly disputed Rolle’s remarks.

headline: De Blasio Deflects Blame for Losses in New York Senate Races
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio was depicted as a liberal boogeyman in ads by Republicans aimed at upstate voters.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio wanted to be front and center in this year’s battle for the New York State Senate.

headline: Treating Those Treating Ebola in Liberia
abstract: A dedicated Ebola field hospital for health workers is scheduled to open Friday in Monrovia, Liberia, as part of an effort to ease the worries of would-be volunteers.
lead_paragraph: HARBEL, Liberia — As the number of people sickened with Ebola soared this summer, American and Liberian officials faced a new challenge: How could they encourage international medical workers, understandably frightened about the risks, to come help fight the disease? The officials knew they would have to provide some assurances to the workers that they would be cared for if they fell ill.

headline: North Korea Chief Walks Minus Cane
abstract: State media reports indicated that Kim Jong-un had recovered enough to move about without assistance following what South Korean intelligence officials called an operation on his left foot.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea’s state-run news media on Wednesday showed the country’s leader, Kim Jong-un, walking without a cane, indicating that he had recovered enough to move about without assistance after what South Korean intelligence officials called an operation on his left foot.

headline: Jo Ann Harris, 81, Dies; Prosecuted Headline Cases
abstract: Ms. Harris investigated a confrontation between government lawyers and Monica Lewinski, and helped prosecute Imelda Marcos on corruption charges.
lead_paragraph: Jo Ann Harris, a federal prosecutor who investigated a pivotal confrontation between government lawyers and Monica Lewinsky that contributed to the impeachment of President Bill Clinton, and concluded that the interrogation had been riddled with mistakes and “poor judgment,” died on Oct. 30 in the Bronx. She was 81.

headline: The 2nd Act in His Unlikely Pursuit: A College Degree
abstract: Derrick Lawson, 21, raised in a public housing development in Queens, felt “lost” in college the first time around. But now he hopes to have an associate degree by 2016.
lead_paragraph: Born and raised in the Queensbridge Houses in Long Island City, Queens, the largest public housing development in the country, Derrick Lawson dreamed of a life outside the projects. Perhaps one day his interest in computers would earn him a respectable job, and he would make his way to TriBeCa. But college was never part of the plan.

headline: On Unity Day, Putin Divides Nationalists
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin’s inconsistent embrace of nationalist tenets may have hampered turnout at the traditional Russian March.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — It is often difficult to untangle the welter of competing agendas among Russian nationalists, a cacophony of ideas that was on display on Tuesday in the central event of their year: the Russian March, held on Unity Day, which marks the battle in 1612 when Russians united to expel the Polish Army from Moscow.

headline: Russia Plans to Boycott 2016 Nuclear Meeting Hosted by Obama
abstract: The plan to bypass the event is the latest sign of the deteriorating relationship with the United States over Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Russia plans to boycott an international nuclear security summit meeting to be hosted by President Obama, American and Russian officials said Wednesday, the latest sign of the deteriorating relationship between the two nuclear powers.

headline: Therapist and Patient Share a Theater of Hurt
abstract: A clinical psychologist and her patient will appear in a show called “Borderline,” which features the two women playing themselves and dealing with the patient’s borderline personality disorder.
lead_paragraph: It was not easily recognizable as therapy, these two women screaming at each other, their faces inches apart, during a rehearsal in a basement space in Greenwich Village.

headline: Vojislav Seselj, on Trial for War Crimes, Is Offered Temporary Release
abstract: The Serb nationalist leader, who has cancer of the liver, was offered a chance by a United Nations tribunal to leave The Hague to receive treatment.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations war crimes tribunal in The Hague has proposed a temporary release for Vojislav Seselj, a Serb nationalist leader, whose health has seriously deteriorated while awaiting the end of his long-running trial. In a decision published Wednesday, the judge in charge of his case suggested that “to avoid the worst-case scenario,” Mr. Seselj should return to Serbia “to receive treatment in the most suitable environment.”

headline: Mitch McConnell’s Path to Victory
abstract: The career of the Kentucky senator expected to become Senate majority leader and his promises to change the Senate.
lead_paragraph: The career of the Kentucky senator expected to become Senate majority leader and his promises to change the Senate.

headline: In Exclusive Club of U.S. Ebola Survivors, Kinship Is Sealed in Blood
abstract: After surviving the Ebola virus in August, Nancy Writebol, a 59-year-old missionary, donated blood plasma to Craig Spencer, the patient in New York.
lead_paragraph: On Aug. 19, Nancy Writebol, a 59-year-old missionary who had contracted Ebola in Liberia, was released from Emory University Hospital in Atlanta, free of the disease after a period in isolation. Her doctors asked whether she would be willing to donate her potentially lifesaving blood plasma to other Ebola patients. Grateful to be alive and eager to help someone else, she said yes.

headline: Coach Inspires Timberwolves by Pointing to Nets Veteran
abstract: The Timberwolves, who are rebuilding, took their work in progress to Brooklyn, where they faced the former Minnesota star Kevin Garnett.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Wiggins, the No. 1 pick of this year’s N.B.A. draft, had one of those inglorious moments last Saturday that can eat at a young player’s mind for days. With his team, the Minnesota Timberwolves, protecting a 1-point lead over the Chicago Bulls and less than three seconds to play, Wiggins, 19, bit on a pump fake, committed a foul to concede two free throws, and essentially gifted the Bulls the victory.

headline: ISIS Wave of Might Is Turning Into Ripple
abstract: The Islamic State, facing airstrikes, as well as demographics that do not favor expansion, is carrying out a less visible operation in some areas.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — The extremists of the Islamic State appeared unstoppable after their sudden blitz through Iraq this summer, with its battle-hardened fighters continually raising their black flag over newly conquered areas.

headline: China’s Uighur Unrest Is Opportunity for Afghans
abstract: With new aid and investments, Beijing seems to be coming to grips with Afghanistan’s role in its national security.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Since the British first tried and failed to subdue Afghanistan in the 19th century, stumbling into a costly Afghan war seems to have become a mandatory step for global power players. The Soviet Union did it in the 1980s, and the American battle here has passed the 13-year mark.

headline: Rising Stars in the Republican Party
abstract: The midterm election results that rolled in on Tuesday night were unremitting good news for Republicans.
lead_paragraph: Call it a wave, call it a referendum, call it a red sweep — but the midterm election results that rolled in on Tuesday night were unremitting good news for Republicans. They picked up at least seven Senate seats, wresting the majority from the Democrats, and made gains in the House that would give them their largest majority since the World War II era.

headline: Old Books, New Thoughts
abstract: On the occasion of an auction of annotated first editions to benefit PEN American Center, seven authors look back on their early books and younger selves.
lead_paragraph: In an original essay, Philip Roth considers the experience of rereading his classic novel “Portnoy’s Complaint,” first published 45 years ago, in 1969. Six other authors, including Lydia Davis, Marilynne Robinson and George Saunders, also reflect on their own earlier works. These essays were written for T in anticipation of an auction in December in which 75 first-edition books annotated by their authors will be sold through Christie’s to benefit PEN American Center.

headline: J.Crew’s Beauty Guru Launches a Line of His Own
abstract: Troi Ollivierre, the makeup and hair stylist responsible for the brand's signature effortless-chic look, will start with six lipsticks.
lead_paragraph: The ever-popular J.Crew look, à la Jenna Lyons — fresh-faced and smart, polished but approachable — is about to be as accessible in the beauty realm as it is in apparel. The brand’s longtime makeup and hair stylist Troi Ollivierre is launching his own beauty line, starting with a collection of six lip colors; four are available to preorder at his website, while the other two are being offered exclusively at J.Crew and jcrew.com. “Even when we add a pop of color to the lips, we try to keep it looking clean,” Ollivierre says of the matte lipstick he used on the models for the brand’s Fashion Week presentations and in-house shoots. “I felt like a lot of the matte colors on the market tended to be dry and heavy, so I wanted to create a highly saturated, pigmented, matte, luxe lipstick that is moisturizing and feels weightless.” It’s an easy approach to a bold makeup choice and one that matches the effortless look that J.Crew has perfected. “It’s really about the beauty of the girl coming through,” he says.

headline: Slouchy Suede Bags
abstract: A luxuriously supple carryall, just in time for fashion’s new ’70s groove.
lead_paragraph: A luxuriously supple carryall, just in time for fashion’s new ’70s groove.

headline: Great Vacation? Don’t Brag to Your Friends
abstract: When you rush to tell your friends about your amazing experience, they will crowd around you, eager for every delicious detail, right? Wrong.
lead_paragraph: Your friends don’t want to hear about your excellent adventures.

headline: Word of the Day | suavity
abstract: This word has appeared in 13 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: suavity •\ˈswä-və-te\• noun

headline: A Manet Portrait Fuels High Prices on a Competitive Night for Christie’s
abstract: The artist’s 1881 painting of the actress Jeanne Demarsy was bought by the J. Paul Getty Museum for $65.1 million.
lead_paragraph: Christie’s Rockefeller Center salesroom was the setting for a surprisingly competitive evening on Wednesday when six bidders doggedly chased “Le Printemps,” Manet’s 1881 portrait of the actress Jeanne Demarsy in a flowery dress and bonnet. The winner was Otto Naumann, the Manhattan dealer who was in the salesroom on behalf of the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles, paying $65.1 million, well above the painting’s high estimate of $35 million.

headline: Seconds From Victory in Regulation, Rangers Overtake Red Wings in Overtime
abstract: A power-play goal by Derick Brassard gave the Rangers, who were playing with a depleted roster, a victory over the resilient Red Wings.
lead_paragraph: The Rangers are inching toward normalcy, one returning player at a time.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 11:20 A.M. (Starz Cinema) THE PAST (2013) An Iranian, Ahmad (Ali Mosaffa), returns to Paris to give his estranged wife, Marie (Bérénice Bejo), the divorce she seeks — and in the process opens a Pandora’s box — in this drama by Asghar Farhadi. Tahar Rahim plays Samir, the man Marie has taken up with, whose wife is in a coma. Elyes Aguis is Samir’s son, whose presence in the house means a playmate for Marie’s younger daughter (Jeanne Jestin). And Pauline Burlet is Marie’s older daughter, who finds the situation nearly intolerable. “The narrative complications can be distracting, at times exasperating, but they’re finally irrelevant because Mr. Farhadi’s filmmaking is so fluid, and the performers, Ms. Bejo, in particular, are so attractive,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “As in ‘A Separation,’ Mr. Farhadi shows a masterly gift for moving his characters and camera through rooms that — with a raised voice, a violent exit — become stages in a ferocious domestic drama. But here, keep your eye on the littlest players, the small ones trembling in the wings.” In French and Persian, with English subtitles.

headline: Turnout, a Scapegoat, Wasn’t Always the Difference This Time
abstract: Many Democrats would have won if turnout had resembled a presidential election year. But Democrats also lost in states where turnout surpassed that of 2010.
lead_paragraph: Low Democratic voter turnout has been blamed for the decisive Republican victory in Tuesday’s midterm elections. It has quickly become the scapegoat, even though the Democrats invested millions of dollars in an expansive effort to persuade young and nonwhite voters who do not usually participate in midterm election to head to the polls.

headline: Russian Billionaire Tied to Putin Is Focus of Inquiry
abstract: Gennady Timchenko, who is known to have ties to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, has been the focus of a federal investigation into money laundering and oil trading, according to documents.
lead_paragraph: A billionaire Russian businessman known to have ties to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and a company the businessman controlled have been the focus of a federal investigation into money laundering and oil trading, according to documents and people briefed on the matter.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, November 6, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “It doesn’t make me mopey. It energizes me, because it means that this democracy’s working.”

headline: Peng Liyuan Song Accompanies China’s Latest Space Mission
abstract: The recording by the wife of the current Chinese president was one of 10 included on a microchip carried in an unmanned spacecraft during its mission.
lead_paragraph: An unmanned Chinese spacecraft that returned to Earth after orbiting the moon late last month carried with it a selection of Chinese music, including a song by Peng Liyuan, a famous singer and the wife of China’s president, Xi Jinping.

headline: Spending and Growth, 2009-13
abstract: Austerity, yet another plot.
lead_paragraph: Just for my own reference: since the IMF has concluded that it loved austerity not wisely but too well, I thought I would add another austerity/growth chart to the file. Instead of using changes in structural budget balance, I thought it might be useful to just look at spending. This one uses data from the IMF’s World Economic Outlook database to compare changes in total government spending (in national currencies — I didn’t correct for inflation, but that won’t matter) with changes in real GDP; I look at advanced countries, dropping the very small ones like San Mario. The picture looks like this:

abstract: Can you choose the best word to complete each blank?
lead_paragraph: Below are seven paragraphs of the Nov. 5 article “Rings Around the City.”

headline: African Mediators Fail to Name a Civilian to Lead Burkina Faso
abstract: There was, however, agreement on the outlines of a plan to restore the Constitution and begin a path to elections by November next year.
lead_paragraph: OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso — Despite often rancorous discussion brokered by three African presidents, political and military leaders in Burkina Faso have failed to name a civilian to lead a transition to democracy after the resignation of President Blaise Compaoré.

headline: Deutsche Telekom’s Net Profit Drops 14% Under Weight of Investments
abstract: Spending on high-speed mobile and broadband networks, coupled with continuing economic malaise in some European markets, led to the decline.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Deutsche Telekom, Europe’s largest telecommunications carrier by revenue, reported on Thursday a 14 percent decline in net profit during the third quarter, as investments in its core markets in Germany and the United States weighed on the company’s performance.

headline: Computing a Winning Formula at the Pinnacle of Racing
abstract: Eugene Kaspersky’s global computer security company, Kaspersky Lab, is a major sponsor of the Ferrari Formula One team.
lead_paragraph: Eugene Kaspersky, 49, is co-founder, chairman and chief executive of Kaspersky Lab, one of the world’s leading providers of antivirus technology for computers. Kaspersky, who was born in Novorossiysk, Russia, graduated in 1987 from the Russian Institute of Cryptography, Telecommunications and Computer Science with a degree in computer technology and mathematical engineering. In 1989, while working for the Soviet military as a cryptographer, he discovered a virus in his computer and began to study and treat it. He did the same for another colleague who had found a virus in his computer. By 1991, Kaspersky had moved to a private company, where he and his colleagues developed a program called AntiViral Toolkit Pro. That was the prototype for what became the Kaspersky Anti-Virus, now sold by Kaspersky Lab, the company that he founded in 1997. Based in Moscow, the company now has 30 regional offices and works in nearly 200 countries. The company became a sponsor in Formula One with the Ferrari team in 2010 and has expanded into one of the team’s major sponsors and technical partners. Kaspersky’s software is used in the Ferrari computer system and he plans additional projects within the series. Kaspersky is a racing fan and he occasionally drives sports cars on racetracks for fun. As part of an occasional series focusing on famous and unusual Formula One fans, Kaspersky spoke recently with Brad Spurgeon of the International New York Times.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Where Riding and Wrangling Beat Virtual Adventures
abstract: Where is youth rodeo “as much of a way of life … as it is an extracurricular activity”?
lead_paragraph: In “Where Riding and Wrangling Beat Virtual Adventures,” Julie Turkewitz writes about youth rodeo in Utah.

headline: How One Lawyer’s Crusade Could Change Football Forever
abstract: The N.F.L. is more popular — and more profitable — than ever. But its coming settlement over brain injuries could lay the groundwork that pushes the sport to the margins of American culture.
lead_paragraph: There are 1.27 million lawyers in the United States, one for about every 300 Americans — about 400,000 more of them than there are doctors. Their work is rarely glamorous, and especially for those just starting out in the profession, it can be grinding and repetitive. Jason Luckasevic, hired out of law school in 2000 by a firm in Pittsburgh, passed the bar exam on his first try and was quickly sworn in to practice. The ceremony, such as it was, took place on a Thursday in a clerk’s office, rather than in a courtroom in front of family and friends, because his bosses needed him to get started. The following Monday morning, he drove to Johnstown, about 90 minutes away, where he spent the day taking depositions from former employees of an enormous steel plant that had exposed them to asbestos. Late that afternoon, he climbed back into his Honda Civic and headed home. He repeated this routine for the next six months, five days a week, racking up some 400 depositions and about 20,000 miles on the road.

headline: Don’t Call Clay Benskin a Street Photographer
abstract: Three years after Clay Benskin told a photographer friend he could take better pictures with a smartphone, he has produced thousands of images. But he still doesn’t see himself as a street photographer.
lead_paragraph: Clay Benskin weaves his way through the crowded sidewalks of Lower Manhattan, apparently invisible to the people streaming past him. He is not a small man. Yet even as his camera gets to within inches of someone’s face, the person doesn’t flinch.

headline: Do You Consider Yourself a Republican, Democrat or Independent?
abstract: What do you think is the biggest influence on your political identity? Your family, friends, community or values? Or is there another influence? Why?
lead_paragraph: We get our political identity from all sorts of influences. Maybe from our parents, friends or communities — or perhaps from caring deeply about key issues.

headline: Siemens to Sell Its Hearing Aid Unit for About $2.69 Billion
abstract: The sale to the private equity firm EQT Partners and the Strüngmann family means the German conglomerate will not pursue a public listing for Siemens Audiology Solutions.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Siemens, the German engineering conglomerate, said on Thursday that it had agreed to sell its hearing aid unit to the European private-equity firm EQT Partners and the Strüngmann family of Germany for 2.15 billion euros, or about $2.69 billion.

headline: Despite Risks, Wealthy Chinese Still Determined to Travel to Space
abstract: The deadly crash of Virgin Galactic’s SpaceShipTwo has not affected the resolve of Chinese clients already booked to go to space, according to one Beijing sales agent.
lead_paragraph: The deadly crash of Virgin Galactic’s SpaceShipTwo in California may be raising concerns in the United States over the safety of space tourism, but so far it does not seem to have dampened the enthusiasm of would-be astronauts in China.

headline: To Quell Unrest, Beijing Moves to Scatter Uighurs Across China
abstract: As violence upends Xinjiang, officials are working to transplant and try to assimilate members of the mostly Muslim, Turkic-speaking ethnic minority.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — As a winter chill settled across China’s far northwest, 489 people boarded a chartered train in the city of Urumqi for the 50-hour ride to the country’s opposite corner, in semitropical Guangdong Province, to take up new factory jobs.

headline: Société Générale and Crédit Agricole Profits Exceed Market Expectations
abstract: Both French banks overcame weak domestic retail businesses to post higher net income, with Société Générale cutting its loan loss provisions.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Société Générale and Crédit Agricole, two of France’s largest banks, reported third-quarter profits on Thursday that exceeded market expectations despite weak domestic retail businesses.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.
