abstract: Thursday: a new speed limit. Also: rain, rats and A-Rod.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this icky Thursday.

headline: Troubled Bank Monte dei Paschi di Siena Approves Plan to Raise $3.1 Billion
abstract: The bank is seeking satisfy demands that it bolster its capital cushion after the results of a review by the European Central Bank.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Italian bank Monte dei Paschi di Siena said on Wednesday that its board had approved a plan to sell new shares to raise as much as 2.5 billion euros, or about $3.1 billion, to satisfy demands that it bolster its capital cushion.

headline: How the Fall of the Berlin Wall Really Happened
abstract: Mistakes by East German officials and rising opposition by large numbers of everyday citizens led to the opening.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — The opening of the Berlin Wall, 25 years ago this Sunday, marked a surprisingly joyous end to a conflict that could have erupted into thermonuclear combat. In the decades since, many Americans have come to believe that the wall fell thanks to President Ronald Reagan’s direct, personal intervention. In a 1987 speech in front of the Brandenburg Gate in a divided Berlin, he told Soviet leaders to “tear down this wall” — and so, we’ve been told, they did.

headline: Bank of England Holds Interest Rate Steady
abstract: Britain’s central bank said it would keep its benchmark interest rate at 0.5 percent, where it has been since March 2009.
lead_paragraph: The Bank of England on Thursday left its key interest rate unchanged at historically low levels as policy makers try to balance Britain’s economic recovery against lower-than-expected wage growth and the risk that continued weakness in the eurozone might put pressure on the country’s economy.

headline: Today in Politics
abstract: What might happen in the final months of a Democratic-led Congress.
lead_paragraph: Its Days Numbered, Senate Led by Democrats Plans Final Moves

headline: Britain to Investigate Dominance of Big Banks
abstract: Britain’s four largest banks – the Lloyds Banking Group, Barclays, the Royal Bank of Scotland and HSBC – account for more than three-quarters of all consumer and business accounts, the Competition and Markets Authority said.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The competition regulator in Britain said on Thursday that it planned to begin an inquiry into the dominant position of the country’s largest lenders in retail banking and in lending to small and midsize businesses.

headline: Morning Agenda: Seeking More Say on Directors
abstract: An effort to let shareholders hire and fire directors directly. | A Pritzker dreams of empire. | Businesses assess impact of G.O.P. victory. | Einhorn gives up on Green Mountain.
lead_paragraph: Annual shareholder meetings are supposed to allow a company’s owners to change troubling governance practices. But in reality, most of these meetings and the shareholder votes that are cast at them give outside investors little say on oversight of a company’s board, as the current director election system in the United States allows board members to win or hold their seats even if they do not receive support from a majority of shareholder votes cast, Gretchen Morgenson writes in The New York Times. Now, a band of institutional shareholders is looking to change what they see as a dysfunctional dynamic. Led by Scott M. Stringer, the New York City comptroller and a Democrat, the group is mounting the first push ever at 75 United States companies to allow investors to hire and fire directors directly.

lead_paragraph: The New York Times Archives Twitter feed has been celebrating Election Days of the past all week with tweets like this one, which take you to a Nov. 8, 1944 front-page story. It begins:

headline: A Baby Food Company Grows Up
abstract: Fran Free faced a classic start-up dilemma: She needed to ramp up production to realize economies of scale and reduce her costs, but she lacked the large contracts that would allow her to raise the capital to do so.
lead_paragraph: When I first wrote about Fran Free in 2010, she was whipping up organic baby food in a leased kitchen and trying to lower her production costs. Her products were sustainable, but her business, Oh Baby Foods, was not.

headline: The Luxury Culture Wars Heat Up: Kering Ups Its Film Ante
abstract: The luxury giant announced a five-year commitment to the Cannes Film Festival.
lead_paragraph: What is it with fashion and film this week? Two fashion TV premieres, a move behind the camera for a designer and now this: Kering, a.k.a. the parent company of Gucci, Saint Laurent, Balenciaga, Bottega Veneta, McQueen and McCartney, among others, has announced a five-year stint as an “official partner” of the Cannes Film Festival.

headline: For Draghi, Promises Are Still His Main Policy Option
abstract: Forced to coax consensus, the European Central Bank chief must rely on statements of resolve, unspooling monetary policy in monthly increments.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Mario Draghi may have invented a new kind of policy tool. Call it verbal quantitative easing.

headline: The Evolution of #Alexfromtarget
abstract: Social media pandemonium over #Alexfromtarget started with a photo of teenage Target employee named Alex Lee. Alex, who started with 144 Twitter followers, now has more than 600,000.
lead_paragraph: Social media pandemonium over #Alexfromtarget started with a photo of teenage Target employee named Alex Lee. Alex, who started with 144 Twitter followers, now has more than 600,000.

headline: Marriage Is Hard, Physics Is Easy

lead_paragraph: “The Theory of Everything,” James Marsh’s biographical film about the British theoretical physicist Stephen Hawking, tries very hard to live up to its title: It wants to show a remarkable man in full, to explore his ideas, his emotional life and his struggle with illness.

lead_paragraph: The Challenge: Can you figure out what is causing a 68-year-old woman to lose her vision over the course of several months?

headline: Victory Followed in States Where G.O.P. Groups Spent Big
abstract: Republican outside groups spent more money than their Democratic counterparts in seven of the nine top Senate races.
lead_paragraph: Republican outside groups spent more money than their Democratic counterparts in seven of the nine top Senate races, according to a final analysis of Federal Election Commission records.

abstract: After 21st Century Fox agreed to sell its 57.45 percent stake to British Sky Broadcasting earlier this year, the offer was extended to other shareholders.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – British Sky Broadcasting said on Thursday that it had agreed to acquire 87.45 percent of Sky Deutschland, including a 57.45 percent stake held by 21st Century Fox, after making a takeover offer earlier this year.

lead_paragraph: PARIS — Two men and a woman were questioned by the police on Thursday after being arrested in possession of two drones near the Belleville-sur-Loire nuclear power plant in central France, news agencies reported.

headline: Microsoft, Changing Tack, Makes Office Suite Free on Mobile
abstract: In a sign of the seismic changes underway in the tech industry, Microsoft will give away the software for iPads, iPhones and Android tablets.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Few golden geese in technology have survived as long as Office has for Microsoft.

headline: Will Democrats Rebel Against Reid? Many Hints, but No Action Plan
abstract: Could Harry Reid be deposed by his own caucus before he even has a chance to become minority leader?
lead_paragraph: Senator Harry Reid failed to keep the Senate in Democratic hands. That means that come January, he will no longer be majority leader.

abstract: The free software for iPads, iPhones and Android tablets will do most of the most essential tasks done with the computer versions of the product, whose applications include Word, Excel and PowerPoint.
lead_paragraph: Few golden geese in technology have survived as long as Office has for Microsoft, Nick Wingfield reports.

headline: The Child Who Declares ‘I Want to Be Rich’
abstract: It’s a statement that makes some parents uncomfortable — what are we teaching them, if that’s the goal? It’s still worth talking about honestly.
lead_paragraph: Kids will ask startling questions about money on a regular basis. It’s their job to be curious, and money is extra mysterious since grown-ups don’t talk about it enough and sometimes lie when they do.

headline: Myanmar Policy’s Message to Muslims: Get Out
abstract: A government plan to resettle Muslim minorities who cannot meet strict standards for naturalized citizenship has spurred a major exodus, rights groups say.
lead_paragraph: SITTWE, Myanmar — The Myanmar government has given the estimated one million Rohingya people in this coastal region of the country a dispiriting choice: Prove your family has lived here for more than 60 years and qualify for second-class citizenship, or be placed in camps and face deportation.

headline: You May Have Missed It, but There Was an Election Debate on Criminal Justice Reform
abstract: Voters did not hear much about criminal-justice reform during the midterm election, but several ballot propositions passed across the country to reform the system.
lead_paragraph: It is no secret that the United States prison population surpasses that of any other nation, that the country has very harsh sentencing laws for minor offenses, and that, as many argue, the inherent racial bias in the system is powerful and detrimental to society.

headline: Drug Maker Perrigo to Buy Omega Pharma in $4.5 Billion Deal
abstract: The acquisition is expected to expand Perrigo’s international presence and give it a larger position in the European over-the-counter health care sector.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The Irish drug maker Perrigo said on Thursday that it had agreed to acquire Omega Pharma, one of the largest providers of over-the-counter health care products in Europe, for about $4.5 billion, including the assumption of debt.

headline: California Governor on Winning 4th Term
abstract: Gov. Jerry Brown of California spoke after decisively winning an unprecedented fourth term in the state dominated by Democrats.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Jerry Brown of California spoke after decisively winning an unprecedented fourth term in the state dominated by Democrats.

headline: Brown to Start 4th California Term With Pledge for Fiscal Restraint
abstract: “Living within our means is a heroic continuing battle here,” the 76-year-old Democratic governor said in an interview.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Gov. Jerry Brown did not even make a campaign stop until nine days before the election. He did not air any commercials for his own candidacy, even as he amassed more than $20 million in campaign funds. And yet, in an election in which so many Democratic incumbents came to woe, he easily defeated his Republican opponent, a businessman named Neel Kashkari, and glided into an unprecedented fourth term as governor with 58.6 percent of the vote.

headline: Cott to Acquire Water and Coffee Provider for $1.25 Billion
abstract: The Cott Corporation has agreed to acquire the parent company of DS Services of America, a direct-to-consumer provider of bottled water, office coffee and water filtration services.
lead_paragraph: The Canadian soft-drink maker Cott Corporation has agreed to acquire the parent company of DS Services of America, a United States direct-to-consumer provider of bottled water, office coffee and water filtration services, for $1.25 billion.

headline: Report Implicates Chinese Officials in Smuggled Tanzanian Ivory
abstract: Two weeks before President Xi Jinping arrived in Tanzania, Chinese buyers purchased thousands of pounds of poached tusks, which were “later sent to China in diplomatic bags on the presidential plane,” the report said.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — When President Xi Jinping of China and his entourage of government officials and business leaders arrived in Tanzania in March 2013, it was to officially promote economic ties between the two countries.

headline: PineBridge Names Ex-Goldman Executive Thornton as Chairman
abstract: John L. Thornton, the chairman of Barrick Gold and a professor at Tsinghua University in Beijing, was designated as a possible successor to Henry M. Paulson Jr. when they were at Goldman Sachs.
lead_paragraph: John L. Thornton, a professor at Tsinghua University in Beijing and a former Goldman Sachs executive, has been named chairman of the asset management firm PineBridge Investments.

headline: Takata Warns of Larger Loss
abstract: The Japanese supplier, whose faulty airbags have been linked to several deaths, faces legal uncertainty and rising costs related to a large recall.
lead_paragraph: Takata, the Japanese supplier, whose faulty airbags have been linked to three deaths in the United States, warned of wider-than-expected losses this year as it grapples with legal uncertainties and the rising cost of recalls.

headline: Low Birth Weight Tied to Hip Replacement in Adulthood
abstract: Low birth weight and preterm birth significantly increase the risk for hip replacement in adulthood, a new study has found.
lead_paragraph: Low birth weight and preterm birth significantly increase the risk for hip replacement in adulthood, a new study has found.

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘November for Beginners’
abstract: Rita Dove’s poem “November for Beginners,” and the article “Heavy Autumn Snowstorm Barrels Across Northeast,” by Al Baker, Elizabeth A. Harris and Sarah Maslin Nir, appear in this pairing.
lead_paragraph: This Poetry Pairing features Rita Dove’s poem “November for Beginners” and the article “Heavy Autumn Snowstorm Barrels Across Northeast” by Al Baker, Elizabeth A. Harris and Sarah Maslin Nir.

headline: Sweet Potatoes: Ripe for Baking Into Seasonal, Savory Bread Puddings
abstract: Chef Jeff Schwarz visited Quail Hill Farm in Amagansett, where three varieties of tubers are being pulled from the ground.
lead_paragraph: This series by the chef Jeff Schwarz and the photographer Greg Kessler traces the trajectory of seasonal food — from its original source to a place on your table.

headline: Investigator Posing as Rikers Guard Smuggled In Contraband, Inquiry Finds
abstract: A report called on the New York City Correction Department to bolster screening at Rikers Island after an undercover investigator carried drugs and alcohol through checkpoints.
lead_paragraph: Despite repeated promises by the New York City Correction Department to tighten security at Rikers Island, an investigator posing as a guard last month was able to smuggle in heroin, pills, marijuana, vodka and a razor blade, a city inquiry found.

headline: Report on Security Failures at Rikers Island
abstract: A report released Thursday by the New York City Department of Investigation detailed how an investigator posing as a guard smuggled contraband into the correction facility.
lead_paragraph: A report released Thursday by the New York City Department of Investigation detailed how an investigator posing as a guard smuggled contraband into the correction facility.

headline: Giving Beauty a Tech Makeover
abstract: Melody McCloskey has created StyleSeat, an online booking service that connects customers with salon professionals.
lead_paragraph: Melody McCloskey has created StyleSeat, an online booking service that connects customers with salon professionals.

headline: What 2014 Elections Can Tell Us About 2016: Not Much at All
abstract: Democrats’ poor midterm performance is unlikely to help, or hurt, their next presidential candidate. The state of the economy will matter more.
lead_paragraph: America has again embraced our long history of electoral overreaction. While it’s true that Republicans won a major victory at the polls, the results tell us far less about future elections than some commentary has suggested.

headline: Los Angeles County Museum of Art Donor Identified
abstract: A. Jerrold Perenchio, the former chairman of Univision, pledged to donate about 50 artworks — including notable Impressionist paintings —
lead_paragraph: The suspense was short-lived. After announcing yesterday that an anonymous donor to the Los Angeles County Museum of Art was making “the largest gift of art to LACMA in its history” — including works by Bonnard, Manet, Monet, Pissarro and Picasso — today the museum revealed the patron to be A. Jerrold Perenchio, the former chairman and chief executive of the Spanish-language television network Univision.

headline: Well, That Conciliation Seems Short-Lived
abstract: Senator Harry Reid’s office this morning took a shot at Senator Mitch McConnell, the incoming majority leader, under the subject line: “Senator McConnell vows more of the same.”
lead_paragraph: That didn’t take long.

headline: 1939: Sir Thomas Cullinan Dies
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The man who discovered the Cullinan Diamond died in 1939.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Sir Thomas Cullinan, whose name the famous Cullinan diamond bears, has died at his home in Johannesburg, South Africa, at the age of seventy-nine. Founder and director of the first organized diamond mining company during his youth, he became known throughout the world in 1905 with the discovery of the ‘‘Cullinan’’ diamond. With its weight of 3,025.75 carats, it was by far the largest diamond ever found. The government of the Transvaal presented the great diamond to King Edward VII of Great Britain. Amsterdam cutters fashioned nine large gems and many smaller ones from it. The two most beautiful today belong to the British royal treasure, one being on the crown of King George VI and the other in his sceptre. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Nov. 7, 1939

headline: The Après-Graduation Apartment
abstract: Three roommates, Danica Ciccariello Teresa Sanacore and Sarah Pascuzzi, went hunting for an apartment.
lead_paragraph: Having graduated from the Fashion Institute of Technology and vacated her dorm room, Danica Ciccariello needed to find a new place to live last summer.

headline: Bulgaria’s Central Bank Revokes License of Troubled Lender K.T.B.
abstract: The move halts all activities at the bank and opens the way for the payment of about $2.3 billion in deposits to businesses and consumers.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Bulgaria’s central bank on Thursday revoked the license of one of the country’s biggest lenders and moved to open bankruptcy proceedings.

headline: Country Awards Keep the Party Polite
abstract: The 48th Annual Country Music Association Awards on Wednesday featured pop stars like Ariana Grande but largely failed to reflect the current state of a genre in flux.
lead_paragraph: For the last 11 weeks, a country songwriter has held the top spot on the Billboard Hot 100. Three of those weeks belonged to Taylor Swift, whose cheeky “Shake It Off” is a nail in the coffin of her relationship with Nashville, and the other eight belonged to Meghan Trainor, whose song “All About That Bass” isn’t a country number at all but a modern doo-wop tune about self-acceptance.

headline: 1964: Yale Manuscripts Scrutinized
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Yale University was accused of holding stolen manuscripts in 1964.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN, Conn. — A spokesman for Yale University expressed ‘‘great surprise and astonishment’’ last night that its eight rare Greek manuscripts were reported to have been stolen from a Spanish cathedral 20 years ago. The manuscripts were traced to Yale by a professor of Greek philology at Madrid University after four men were convicted a month ago of the 20-year-old theft. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Nov. 7, 1964

headline: Disconnecting in Hilton Head
abstract: A package at the Westin Hilton Head Island Resort & Spa in South Carolina encourages guests to unplug their laptops and phones in favor of walking and biking.
lead_paragraph: The Westin Hilton Head Island Resort & Spa wants your laptops, smart phones and tablets. Not to be pushy, but they’ll also take your car keys.

headline: First Editions, Second Thoughts
abstract: The authors Robert A. Caro, Paul Auster and Jane Smiley, whose annotated first editions will be auctioned off at Christie’s, reflect on the process of revisiting their past works.
lead_paragraph: The authors Robert A. Caro, Paul Auster and Jane Smiley, whose annotated first editions will be auctioned off at Christie’s, reflect on the process of revisiting their past works.

headline: Phil Rudd, AC/DC Drummer, Charged With Trying to Hire Hit Man
abstract: Mr. Rudd was arrested in New Zealand and charged with trying to hire someone to commit murder.
lead_paragraph: Phil Rudd, the drummer in the Australian rock band AC/DC, was arrested Thursday morning and charged with trying to hire someone to commit murder, threatening murder and possession of methamphetamine and cannabis, the New Zealand news site SunLive reported.

headline: Democratic Congressional Campaign Chairman to Step Down
abstract: Representative Steve Israel is stepping down as the chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, turning down a request from Representative Nancy Pelosi to return for a third term, but is hoping to remain within the Democratic House leadership.
lead_paragraph: Representative Steve Israel is stepping down as the chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, denying a request from Representative Nancy Pelosi to return for a third term though he is hoping to remain within the Democratic House leadership.

headline: Red Bulls Defense Raises Its Game
abstract: Red Bulls defender Richard Eckersley salvaged his season and is now part of a steady back four.
lead_paragraph: It was during the season when reporters were speaking to Red Bulls Coach Mike Petke at the team’s training center in Hanover, N.J.

headline: Diamonds in the Rough
abstract: Jagged stones, graphic settings and a touch of black give the new gems a strikingly youthful edge.
lead_paragraph: Jagged stones, graphic settings and a touch of black give the new gems a strikingly youthful edge.

headline: In a City Accustomed to Seeing the Dead, Bodies Remain Unknown and Unclaimed
abstract: In an average year, the city’s police register more than 3,000 unidentifiable bodies, most of them men who have come from distant villages to find work.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The most lost of the lost people of Delhi end up here, in a cold metal-sided room at the Sabzi Mandi mortuary. They are lying on every available surface, including the blood-smeared floor, some with body parts flung out in the position of their death, protruding from the white plastic bags that are used to store them.

headline: Discouraged in School, Melody McCloskey Thrives as a Tech Entrepreneur
abstract: “I was the only woman in the class,” she said, “All the guys either wanted to talk to me or didn’t want me to be there.”
lead_paragraph: This is the second in our video series on Women in Tech. You can see the first video here.

headline: Fannie Mae Chief Details Plan to Ease Mortgage Rules
abstract: The chief executive of Fannie Mae said that Fannie would accept more low down payment mortgages but would require private mortgage insurance as well.
lead_paragraph: Seeking to bring more people into the housing market, the government said last month that it planned to expand the availability of mortgages with low down payments.

headline: Majority in New Jersey Approve of Christie’s Response to Ebola
abstract: New Jerseyans, in a new poll, said they preferred Gov. Chris Christie’s response to that of the federal government.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey drew some national criticism for his blunt statements and aggressive handling of the Ebola crisis, but a majority in his home state preferred his response to that of the federal government, according to a new poll from Monmouth University Polling Institute.

headline: Cable Deal Wave Hits the Caribbean
abstract: Cable and Wireless’s move for Columbus International comes at a high price and with an odd structure. But the potential to cut costs and grow faster might offset concerns, Quentin Webb of Reuters Breakingviews writes.
lead_paragraph: The cable M.&A. wave has hit the Caribbean.

headline: Bob Odenkirk: By the Book
abstract: The actor and author of “A Load of Hooey” keeps a volume of “hippie philosophizing” on his shelves as a counterbalance to his “angry, skeptical, scowling mind.”
lead_paragraph: The actor and author of “A Load of Hooey” keeps a volume of “hippie philosophizing” on his shelves as a counterbalance to his “angry, skeptical, scowling mind.”

headline: Mariano Pensotti Work Among Offerings at Under the Radar Festival
abstract: The festival in January will present “Cineastas,” created by the Argentine theater director Mariano Pensotti, along with works from around the world.
lead_paragraph: Playwrights and theater artists from Argentina, Brazil, Iran and across the United States will be featured in January at the 11th annual Under the Radar festival, its producers at the Public Theater announced on Thursday. The 12-day cornucopia of experimental works will also include the start of a new performance series, Incoming!, which showcases works-in-progress by writers, comedians, poets and theater collectives.

headline: C.M.A. Awards Red Carpet
abstract: Nicole Kidman in Roberto Cavalli, Faith Hill in Naeem Khan, and more at the Country Music Association Awards on Wednesday night.
lead_paragraph: Nicole Kidman in Roberto Cavalli, Faith Hill in Naeem Khan, and more at the Country Music Association Awards on Wednesday night.

headline: Comeback Stories
abstract: Sometimes crushing political defeats are just a step on the way to bigger victories. Just ask George Bush.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes crushing political defeats are just a step on the way to bigger victories. Just ask George Bush.

headline: Joined at the Script
abstract: Emily Padgett and Erin Davie star as the performers Daisy and Violet Hilton, conjoined twins, in the Broadway revival of the musical “Side Show.”
lead_paragraph: Emily Padgett and Erin Davie stood shoulder to shoulder and hip to hip while stagehands focused lights on and around them during a recent rehearsal for the Broadway revival of “Side Show.” Ms. Padgett ran a hand through her curly wig, parted on the opposite side of Ms. Davie’s. Ms. Davie toyed with the hem of her red dress, a mirror image of Ms. Padgett’s. When they sang the final chorus to the ballad “Who Will Love Me as I Am?,” their voices melded so seamlessly you could hardly tell which bright note issued from which lipsticked mouth.

headline: Bleak Existence for Myanmar’s Rohingya Minority
abstract: More than 100,000 Rohingya have fled the country and a similar number are confined in camps amid violence by the Buddhist majority, which accuses them of being foreign interlopers.
lead_paragraph: More than 100,000 Rohingya have fled the country and a similar number are confined in camps amid violence by the Buddhist majority, which accuses them of being foreign interlopers.

headline: A Bleeding Jackman Goes On With the Show
abstract: Hugh Jackman continues his performance in “The River” after cutting his finger.
lead_paragraph: Hugh Jackman is drawing attention on Broadway this week for his current play, “The River” – and for what might come next.

headline: Chance for Tax Overhaul Is Seen in Shift of Power
abstract: Tax restructuring, international trade and budget policy may offer common ground for Democrats and Republicans in President Obama’s final two years in office.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After years of clashes and a grudging truce, fiscal and economic policy was brought back to center stage by the wave of Republican electoral victories on Tuesday, with President Obama and the new congressional leadership expressing hope that they could reach deals to simplify the tax code, promote trade and eliminate the budget deficit.

headline: Excerpt: ‘Sticks and Bones’
abstract: Bill Pullman and Holly Hunter in a scene from the revival of David Rabe’s “Sticks and Bones.”
lead_paragraph: Bill Pullman and Holly Hunter in a scene from the revival of David Rabe’s “Sticks and Bones.”

headline: The Daily Gift: An Oasis for Discerning Kitties
abstract: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.
lead_paragraph: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.

headline: Culebra, a Quiet Corner of the Caribbean
abstract: On a visit to this low-key island near Puerto Rico, you could find yourself sharing a spectacular beach with a few people, or with no one at all.
lead_paragraph: I was paddling along in my kayak, floating over a coral reef on which purple and yellow sea fans waved lazily in the current, when something broke the surface ahead of me. A snorkeler? No, it was a hawksbill turtle, which seemed as surprised to see me as I was to see it, though not as delighted. The turtle gulped some air, flexed its fin feet, as graceful in the water as the brown pelicans passing nearby were in the air, and effortlessly angled through the green water toward the sea grass 10 feet below.

headline: C.M.A. Awards Red Carpet
abstract: Nicole Kidman in Roberto Cavalli, Faith Hill in Naeem Khan, and more at the Country Music Awards on Wednesday night.
lead_paragraph: Despite the absence of the red carpet darling Taylor Swift from the Country Music Association Awards on Wednesday night in Nashville, others like Faith Hill, Nicole Kidman and Lily Aldridge dazzled on the red carpet.

headline: Hungry City: Hard Times Sundaes in Mill Basin, Brooklyn
abstract: Burgers from a food truck in a remote corner of the borough prove their greatness in the God-given talent of their maker.
lead_paragraph: It was high noon at Hard Times Sundaes, a food truck parked behind a Walgreen’s in Mill Basin, Brooklyn, and the gas wasn’t on. “Can you give me a minute?” asked Andrew Zurica, the owner, cook and lone employee. Carrying a propane tank in one hand, he sprinted to Home Depot.

headline: Not All Political Defeats Are Permanent
abstract: Some Republican losers in the 1964 elections went on to distinguished careers. One would even become president.
lead_paragraph: The Times has converted all of its 1964 issues into a digitized, searchable format. Each week, The Upshot will unearth an item from 50 years ago and put it in the light of today. “Johnson Swamps Goldwater and Kennedy Beats Keating” appeared on Nov. 3 and can be seen in its original format on TimesMachine.

headline: In a Jungle of Boxes, Terrors of a Psychic Spring Cleaning
abstract: For “The Object Lesson,” a performance space has been packed with towering cardboard boxes that the audience and the author, Geoff Sobelle, explore in a meditation on human detritus.
lead_paragraph: In their later years, my parents used to tease each other with the threat that whoever lived longer would be forced to deal with (ominous organ chords) the Attic. It was a fearsome prospect, for within the cramped upper level of their otherwise manageable house lurked the flotsam and jetsam of at least four generations of their family’s lives.

headline: Lollipop, the Latest Version of Android, Is Grown-Up and Accessible
abstract: Google’s latest version of Android is sophisticated and refined, and adds welcome security features to tablets. The Nexus 9 tablet, on the other hand, leaves some to be desired.
lead_paragraph: Google has just released its new version of Android, and the company is showing it off on a new slate of Nexus devices: A 9-inch tablet and a coming phone, the Nexus 6.

headline: Fantasy Football: Picks for Week 10
abstract: The record-setting Steelers quarterback Ben Roethlisberger is a must-start against the Jets. This and more fantasy picks for Week 10.
lead_paragraph: The record-setting Steelers quarterback Ben Roethlisberger is a must-start against the Jets. This and more fantasy picks for Week 10.

headline: Cuomo Says Obama’s Woes Hurt Democrats in New York Races
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, offering his first public comments on the election since his victory speech, said voters were motivated by “dissatisfaction with a Democratic administration in Washington.”
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Thursday blamed frustration with President Obama for the poor performance of Democratic candidates in New York, saying his victory fell short of a landslide because of discontent unrelated to the state.

headline: Today in Small Business: Veteran-Owned Businesses
abstract: More business-related election returns. After 20 years, the banner ad is finally in decline. And there’s a Bitcoin-only cafe in Prague.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Facts & Figures: Healthcare Premiums Are Not on the Rise
abstract: Only two of 17 states in an Urban Institute study will see premium increases of more than 5 percent.
lead_paragraph: Republicans warned that insurance premiums would rise dramatically in 2015, but it doesn’t look like that will happen. Only two of 17 states in an Urban Institute study will see premium increases of more than 5 percent.

headline: Jean-Claude Juncker, Top E.U. Official, Faces Rising Furor Over Luxembourg Tax Revelations
abstract: Mr. Juncker was the prime minister of Luxembourg when the tiny country was transformed into one of the world’s premier low-tax hubs.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Less than a week after taking over as head of the European Union’s executive arm, Jean-Claude Juncker, the former longtime leader of Luxembourg, was buffeted Thursday by a flood of leaked documents detailing his home country’s role as a haven for hundreds of companies seeking to drastically reduce their tax bills.

headline: A Gallery Show, Site Unseen
abstract: One participant’s experience of Marina Abramovic’s “Generator,” at the Sean Kelly Gallery, in which visitors wear blindfolds and headphones, are led into a gallery and are let go.
lead_paragraph: The artist might be present, and then again, she might not. For her last, spectacularly popular outing in New York, “The Artist Is Present” (2010), the performance diva Marina Abramovic sat in the Museum of Modern Art’s atrium and silently exchanged gazes with other people, one person at a time, for hours and days on end. “Generator,” a participatory exercise in sensory deprivation at the Sean Kelly Gallery, doesn’t depend on Ms. Abramovic’s charismatic personal presence. She will be at the gallery for much of the exhibition’s run, and she will participate in the action sometimes — but not according to any set schedule. In any case, whether she’s on site or not won’t matter for participants, because their eyes will be covered.

headline: B. J. Novak’s ‘Book With No Pictures’ and More
abstract: Five picture books directly address young readers with unconventional storytelling.
lead_paragraph: Have your kids gone meta? Do they call their neighborhood jungle gym a “play structure”? Do they mix and match their dress-up garb — a tiara here, firefighter’s boots there — with a sense of mischief that might, unnervingly, be termed “ironic”? Have they spotted the clown at the neighbor’s birthday party removing his wig and slinking out the side door? They’re probably not ready for the labyrinthine tricksterism of David Foster Wallace or Spike Jonze. But on the evidence of a recent spate of highly self-conscious picture books, it would seem that the suspended-disbelief state of early childhood is adapting to the wink-wink, nudge-nudge sensibility of our moment. It’s not surprising. There has long been a strain of subversion in picture books — think of Maurice Sendak and Tomi Ungerer, among others — alongside the dominant anodyne snuggliness of the form. Now, sophisticated cheekiness appears to have gone mainstream. These five specimens of reinvention deftly pop the bubbles of their own illusory worlds, drawing attention to the artifices of their norms and aiming to teach children to become not just book lovers but pint-size “consumers of text.” The best of these books, luckily, manage to find fresh magic in demystification, and to delight kids while spinning the heads of their grown-up companions.

headline: Jim Aylesworth’s ‘My Grandfather’s Coat,’ and More
abstract: The older generation guides the youngest and inspires creativity in these picture books.
lead_paragraph: A really good children’s book and the ideal grandparent have something in common. It’s a special kind of bonding, when you feel you just can’t wait to visit time and again. A good book about a good grandparent should double the payoff. And in some cases, it does.

headline: ‘Rain Reign,’ by Ann M. Martin
abstract: Ann M. Martin tells the story of a lonely fifth-grade girl with autism who finds a soul mate in a stray dog.
lead_paragraph: Autism has come of age, rapidly growing into a matter of common knowledge. Who doesn’t now know that this condition is framed by a wide spectrum, or that diagnosed cases continue to rise? With one in 68 children affected, tens of millions in the United States know someone, or of someone, on the spectrum. Those who don’t can watch Sheldon’s autistic-like behaviors on CBS’s “The Big Bang Theory.”

headline: Money Talks? Tax Policy Could Bring a Bipartisan Deal
abstract: Altering the tax code may be one area where Democrats and Republicans might be able break the gridlock.
lead_paragraph: The list of issues where Republicans and Democrats might be able find common ground is not long, but on fiscal matters there could be some deal-making to be done.

headline: First Draft Focus: Honoring a Civil War Hero
abstract: Civil War Hero Awarded the Medal of Honor at Last
lead_paragraph: Civil War Hero Awarded the Medal of Honor at Last

headline: John Rando in Talks to Direct ‘King Kong’ on Broadway
abstract: The Tony Award-winning director John Rando, who has earned recent acclaim for staging “On the Town,” is in negotiations to direct the musical “King Kong” that is aimed for Broadway.
lead_paragraph: The Tony Award-winning director John Rando, who earned critical acclaim last month for staging the Broadway revival of “On the Town,” is in advanced negotiations to direct the new musical “King Kong” that is aiming for Broadway, a spokesman for the “Kong” producer confirmed on Thursday. Mr. Rando is flying this weekend to Australia, where “Kong” was developed and had a tryout run last year, for several days of discussions with the producer about overhauling the show for New York.

headline: Behind the Poster: ‘Filler’
abstract: The designer Barry Hutchinson talks about how chicken feet inspired his artwork for the new play “Filler.”
lead_paragraph: Barry Hutchinson doesn’t eat chicken feet. But as an artist and designer based in Jackson, Miss., he has a history with the distinctly Southern foodstuff.

headline: Leaving the Monsters Behind
abstract: The sculptor Thomas Houseago, who made his name with towering figures, will exhibit a single large installation which he considers his “first proper New York show.”
lead_paragraph: The sculptor Thomas Houseago was practically bouncing off the walls of the Metropolitan Museum of Art late last month as he toured some of the treasures on the first floor. He unleashed a torrent of praise — “insane,” “unbelievable, “crazy,” “weird,” “wicked” — as he pinballed from an ancient Greek grave stele to a striking series of squatting Aztec and Maya figures.

headline: An Oklahoma Court’s Good Move on Abortion Rights
abstract: The Oklahoma Supreme Court blocked enforcement of two egregious new laws designed to make it more difficult than it already is for women to obtain safe and legal abortions.
lead_paragraph: This week’s focus on the abortion-related ballot measures in Colorado and North Dakota (where “personhood” initiatives were emphatically defeated), and Tennessee (where a majority of voters weakened protection of reproductive rights) has obscured a notable Election Day development in a fourth state: Oklahoma.

headline: In a Mother’s Milk, Nutrients, and a Message, Too
abstract: A new study of infant monkeys demonstrates that a hormone present in a mother’s milk can have profound effects on how her offspring develops.
lead_paragraph: Milk is not just food. The more closely scientists examine it, the more complexity they find.

headline: Lyft Sues Former Executive, Saying He Stole Trade Secrets
abstract: The ride-hailing start-up claims its former chief operating officer took a trove of sensitive documents with him to his new job at Uber, the company’s largest competitor.
lead_paragraph: The ride-hailing wars aren’t going away.

headline: Boehner Says Obama Risks ‘Burning Himself’ on Immigration
abstract: An emboldened Speaker John A. Boehner warned on Thursday that President Obama risked “burning himself” if he took unilateral action to reform the United States immigration system.
lead_paragraph: Speaker John A. Boehner, emboldened by Tuesday’s election results, warned on Thursday that President Obama risked “burning himself” if he took unilateral action to reform the United States immigration system.

headline: A Timepiece Dialed Back to the ’30s
abstract: Shinola’s new titanium Black Blizzard watch was inspired by the grit of the Dust Bowl era.
lead_paragraph: In this weekly series, the men’s fashion editors of T invite creative personalities to put their own aesthetic spin on a new watch. Here, the artist Jay Riggio captures a timepiece from Shinola.

headline: Sexual Harassment at Yale: Delicate Subject, High-Impact Investigation
abstract: Tamar Lewin talks about reporting on a sexual harassment case and the months it took to find people who would speak on the record and provide documents.
lead_paragraph: Last weekend, Tamar Lewin wrote about a sexual harassment case at Yale University that had been unfolding for nearly five years without much public notice. The case centers around a former chief of cardiology who professed love for a young Italian researcher at the Yale School of Medicine.

headline: Cafe Edison, a Broadway Haunt, Is Closing
abstract: The 34-year-old coffee shop, home of Broadway deals and Eastern European Jewish cooking, has been asked to leave by the owner of the Edison Hotel, the restaurant’s manager said.
lead_paragraph: Cafe Edison, the venerable domain of pastrami, borscht and blintzes that doubled as a downscale dining club for producers, stage managers, actors, ticket-takers, stagehands, musicians, and countless other creatures of old Broadway, will close at the end of the year, its manager said on Thursday.

headline: Civil War Hero Awarded the Medal of Honor at Last
abstract: After a long campaign, First Lt. Alonzo H. Cushing of the Union army was honored for his sacrifice at Gettysburg; at the time the medal was not given posthumously.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After more than 151 years, First Lt. Alonzo H. Cushing finally got his day at the White House, even if he could not enjoy it personally.

headline: In Jerusalem Unrest, Signs of a ‘Run-Over Intifada’ for the 21st Century
abstract: While tensions and violence appear to be rising, most commentators say the conditions are different from those of the previous Palestinian uprisings.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — One cartoon circulating on social networks on Thursday depicted a car as the barrel of an automatic weapon, captioned in Arabic, “Revolt and resist, even by your car.” Another showed an odometer with the slogan, “Oh, revolutionary, use more gasoline, so we can have Palestine back.” A third simply had a vehicle in the red, white and green of the Palestinian flag hitting two men with Jewish stars on their black hats.

headline: Readers Respond: On Election 2014
abstract: Democrats, Republicans and other Times readers shared their thoughts on the opinion pages’ midterm election coverage.
lead_paragraph: The midterm election of 2014 was a gleeful moment for many Republican readers. A lot like the World Series win by the San Francisco Giants last week, one said.

headline: Fantasy Football: Week 10 Player Tiers
abstract: With two consecutive six-touchdown games, Steelers quarterback Ben Roethlisberger is a Tier 1 option this week, playing against the Jets.
lead_paragraph: In this statistical model, I apply a clustering algorithm called the Gaussian mixture model to an aggregation of expert ranking data provided by Fantasypros.com. The algorithm finds natural tiers and clusters within the data. The charts that result visualize the tiers and help you decide your starting lineup each week.

headline: E.C.B. Threatened to End Funding Unless Ireland Took Bailout, Letters Show
abstract: Letters released by the European Central Bank show how Ireland’s government was left with little alternative but to apply for the bailout.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Newly released documents suggest that Ireland was pressured into a controversial 67.5 billion euro bailout that left taxpayers rescuing crippled banks, reigniting a fierce debate about the international aid that Dublin accepted after the financial crash.

headline: Obama Honors Civil War Soldier
abstract: President Obama awarded the nation’s highest military honor to a Union soldier who was killed more than 150 years ago during the Battle of Gettysburg.
lead_paragraph: President Obama awarded the nation’s highest military honor to a Union soldier who was killed more than 150 years ago during the Battle of Gettysburg.

headline: A Doctor-Parent Exchange Reveals a Dangerous Gap Between Fears and Facts on Ebola and Flu
abstract: A parent presses a doctor to vaccinate a child against Ebola, while rejecting a flu shot.
lead_paragraph: Via Facebook, my old friend Jeff Kluger at Time Magazine drew my attention to a sobering Twitter item by David Stukus, an allergist and pediatrics professor in Columbus, Ohio:

headline: In War Over Botox Maker Allergan, Technicalities Can Be Tricky
abstract: If you look at the fine print, a judge’s ruling this week may open up a new line of attack against the hedge fund manager William Ackman, Peter Henning and Steven Davidoff Solomon write.
lead_paragraph: For those keeping score in the hostile battle for control over the Botox maker Allergan, the latest court ruling is a mixed bag.

headline: In Faded Vacationland, Gambling’s Promise Falls Short
abstract: The Mount Airy resort in the Poconos has not hit any of the projections set in 2006. Another region desperate to reinvent itself, the Catskills, could get its own gambling center.
lead_paragraph: MOUNT POCONO, Pa. — In 2006, when plans were set to transform the crumbling Mount Airy Lodge here into a casino resort, the predictions about the onetime honeymooners’ getaway were as gaudy as its famous old heart-shaped bathtubs.

headline: Jawbone Up3 Band Takes Tracking to the Extreme
abstract: Jawbone, the activity tracker pioneer, is introducing the Up3 band and the inexpensive Up Move activity tracker. The trackers — as well as Jawbone’s focus on activity, health and data tracking — are cementing the company’s status as a whole-health juggernaut.
lead_paragraph: Jawbone, the wearable activity tracker pioneer, will not be moved by the move toward smart watches.

headline: Scratch Baths From the Recovery Regimen
abstract: In the horror movie “Jessabelle,” a woman returns to her childhood home to recover from a car accident and finds unsettling videotapes of her mother telling fortunes.
lead_paragraph: In one respect, the horror film “Jessabelle” qualifies as unexpected. The credited screenwriter is the comedian Robert Ben Garant, a creator of “Reno 911!” In other regards, “Jessabelle” is depressingly rote. How are VHS tapes, voodoo and the specter lurking in a house connected? Your impatience for answers is likely to eclipse your trepidation.

headline: David Redfern, British Photographer of Jazz and Pop, Dies at 78
abstract: Mr. Redfern’s images of greats like Miles Davis, the Beatles and Jimi Hendrix became the basis for an important picture archive.
lead_paragraph: David Redfern, whose photographs of Louis Armstrong, John Lennon, Frank Sinatra and others captured a half-century of popular music and formed the core of an extensive archive of musical images, died on Oct. 22 at his home in Uzès, France. He was 78.

headline: Behind Closed Doors in Both Berlins
abstract: Christian Schwochow’s dramas “The Tower” and “West” deal with paranoia in East and West Berlin for very different people in different decades.
lead_paragraph: “The Tower” is a condensed version of a devastating German television mini-series about life in East Germany in the 1980s as experienced by a cultured family in suburban Dresden. Directed by Christian Schwochow, who grew up in Leipzig and East Berlin, this epic-scale story spans the last seven years before the demise of East German Communism. It’s far from the first film to show how the Stasi, the East German secret police, infiltrated everyday life so thoroughly that no one could trust anyone, and how society was gripped by institutionalized paranoia.

headline: Happiness Is a Warm Robot
abstract: In the animated “Big Hero 6,” a tech-nerd protagonist rises to a challenge with the help of his friends and a doughy robot when evil threatens their metropolis.
lead_paragraph: Have the Walt Disney and Pixar animation studios become Walt Pixar, or maybe Wixar or Dixar? It’s getting hard to tell these once-distinct siblings apart. Disney’s latest animated feature, “Big Hero 6,” is a bright, visually sumptuous 3-D computer-animated feature that gives you a bit of an emotional workout. It doesn’t have some of the familiar Disney markers: There are no eardrum-busting anthems or warbling critters, and it isn’t a fairy tale, exactly, mostly because it’s about a boy. It’s a Disney superhero movie with a story from a Marvel comic book, if one rendered with the wit and texture often associated with Pixar, which I guess makes it a Walt Pixar Marvel.

headline: Modern Love | Into the Woods
abstract: Amy Butcher’s unexpected connection with Sam, a man she found living in a tent in the woods, gave her a lasting lesson in love.
lead_paragraph: Amy Butcher’s unexpected connection with Sam, a man she found living in a tent in the woods, gave her a lasting lesson in love.

headline: Text to Text | ‘Little Things Are Big’ and ‘Students See Many Slights as Racial ‘Microaggressions’ ‘
abstract: Read New York Times reporting on the concept of “microaggressions” alongside a widely-taught 1961 piece by Jesús Colón. Use the two to spark discussions about identity, difference, bias and awareness.

headline: First Editions, Second Thoughts
abstract: Next month, Christie’s will auction off 75 first editions to benefit PEN American Center. Each has been annotated by its respective author or artist.
lead_paragraph: Next month, Christie’s will auction off 75 first editions to benefit PEN American Center. Each has been annotated by its respective author or artist.

headline: On the Road to ‘the One,’ Sometimes, a Rest Stop
abstract: Love is not a product of waiting, of being patient, but is instead a rest stop, perhaps one of many, where we decide, for however long, to stay.
lead_paragraph: I saved Sam after the park ranger’s third warning. A tornado was imminent, the ranger said, and we should seek shelter immediately. The Iowa state park where Sam was camping offered only a small brick outhouse, which I joked seemed the worst possible way to die, surrounded by daddy longlegs and cinder block walls on which teenagers had scribbled “Weed Rules!” in black Sharpie.

headline: Israel Pledges to Restore Security at Religious Site
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel called King Abdullah II of Jordan, who withdrew his ambassador, to reassure him that Israel would maintain the status quo at the contested site.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel sought to reassure King Abdullah II of Jordan in a phone call on Thursday that Israel was committed to maintaining the status quo at a contested holy site in East Jerusalem, and that Israel would make every effort to restore calm there after weeks of escalating tensions, according to statements from both sides.

headline: Matt Taibbi of Rolling Stone Spotlights a JPMorgan Whistle-Blower
abstract: Matt Taibbi is back in the pages of Rolling Stone magazine with a lengthy report on Alayne Fleischmann, a former manager for JPMorgan.
lead_paragraph: Matt Taibbi, a prominent journalist who has written critically of Wall Street, is back in the pages of Rolling Stone magazine with a lengthy report on a JPMorgan Chase whistle-blower.

headline: Warburg Institute Claims Victory After Court Ruling in Dispute With University of London
abstract: The Warburg Institute in London houses a world-renowned library.
lead_paragraph: Both the Warburg Institute and the University of London, which houses it, claimed victory on Thursday after a ruling by London’s High Court that sought to clarify the university’s obligations to the institute, which has a world-renowned humanist library founded by Aby Warburg, a scion of the German banking family.

headline: Continents in Conversation
abstract: Bill Cosby’s rarely seen collection is part of an exhibit juxtaposing black Americans’ art with African works at the Smithsonian Institution’s National Museum of African Art.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On an impulse, in the early 1960s, a cultural attaché for the State Department named Warren M. Robbins started buying African art, first one piece, then many, and filled his Washington house with sculptures and textiles. In 1964, he turned his basement into a mini-museum and opened it to visitors, partly as a gesture of cross-cultural outreach at a time of high racial tension in the capital and across the land.

headline: Dear Teenagers: Come Babysit. Please.
abstract: I get it. You’re busy with iPhones and iPads and WhatApp and whatnot. But couldn’t you do all those things from the comfort of my home for $10 (or so) an hour?
lead_paragraph: Dear teenagers,

headline: Reality, or Artful Dodge?
abstract: Brandy Burre stars as herself in “Actress,” a movie about her own life raising children in the Hudson Valley and yearning to reclaim her acting career.
lead_paragraph: In the first shot of “Actress,” Robert Greene’s elusive and intriguing new film, Brandy Burre stands at her kitchen sink, wearing a red dress that matches the symmetrically placed poinsettias on the windowsill. In a voice-over, she muses that she is a “type A” personality, which she defines as someone “who breaks things.”

headline: New Loretta Lynn Project Includes New and Old Music
abstract: The 82-year-old has been recording with her daughter, Patsy L. Russell, and John Carter Cash, for a project combining new songs and old folk and gospel tunes.
lead_paragraph: Loretta Lynn has not released an album of new material since “Van Lear Rose,” the 2004 record produced by Jack White, which won the country music album of the year Grammy. But it turns out that the 82-year old singer has been recording new material with her daughter, Patsy L. Russell, and John Carter Cash, Johnny Cash’s son, for an expansive project that will include newly composed songs, and will also revisit the Appalachian folk songs and gospel tunes that Ms. Lynn heard during her childhood.

headline: Recombining Identities to Define a Self
abstract: The dancer Panaibra Gabriel Canda from Mozambique communicates expressions of political and personal identity through the body.
lead_paragraph: Panaibra Gabriel Canda begins his “Time and Spaces: The Marrabenta Solos” simply, by introducing himself. But introducing himself turns out to be not so simple. As a citizen of Mozambique, born in 1975, the year that nation achieved independence from Portugal, he is or has been, like his country, Portuguese, African, Communist, democratic. Combining and recombining these adjectives of identity, he keeps stopping and restarting — comically, affectingly — as he struggles to define himself.

headline: The Glow Coming to Madison Square
abstract: “Fata Morgana,” an installation by Teresita Fernández that features hundreds of polished reflective metal discs, will take up residence in Madison Square Park next spring.
lead_paragraph: Public art projects in Madison Square Park — the urban oasis between Madison and Fifth Avenues from 23rd to 26th Streets — have been beautiful, bemusing and sometimes even a tad creepy. One of the most outrageous took place in 2009, when 31 slightly different sculptures of a naked man dotted the park’s grounds, were perched along rooftops on neighboring buildings and scattered around the sidewalks of the Flatiron district. The figure, cast by the British sculptor  Antony Gormley from his own body, caused quite a stir. One passer-by called 911, having mistaken a sculpture perched on the ledge of the Empire State Building for a jumper.

headline: 2014 SEMA Show Tracks Industry Trends
abstract: With displays from most major automakers and thousands of aftermarket suppliers, SEMA serves as a bellwether of customization trends.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — The annual Specialty Equipment Market Association trade show is traditionally a good place to track trends and find the leading edge of new technology arriving in the automotive industry. The 2014 edition, which runs through Friday, is no exception.

headline: Timeline: Israel, the Gaza Strip and Hamas
abstract: The recent fighting between Israel and Hamas, the Palestinian group in control of the Gaza Strip, is the latest chapter in six decades of conflict.
lead_paragraph: The recent fighting between Israel and Hamas, the Palestinian group in control of the Gaza Strip, is the latest chapter in six decades of conflict.

headline: A Salem Cabinetmaker in Revolutionary Times
abstract: The mahogany wares of a prosperous Salem, Mass., cabinetmaker go on view next weekend at the Peabody-Essex Museum.
lead_paragraph: The 18th-century cabinetmaker Nathaniel Gould left inkblots in his battered gray notebooks as he recorded the luxurious mahogany output of his workshop in Salem, Mass. His listings of clients and fees, found seven years ago in forgotten boxes at the Massachusetts Historical Society in Boston, have enabled researchers to attribute his mostly unsigned antiques. Next weekend, about 20 of these pieces will go on view at the Peabody Essex Museum in Salem in the exhibition “In Plain Sight: Discovering the Furniture of Nathaniel Gould.”

headline: Flirting With Trouble
abstract: Questions about a girlfriend who keeps in touch, a deceased sibling, a father who tweaks his son, and a lent sweater that has gone missing.
lead_paragraph: My girlfriend maintains relationships with her former boyfriends. She drove 90 minutes through the pouring rain to counsel one (who dumped her last year) when he broke it off with his new girlfriend. She goes hiking and biking with them. And she tells me how other men flirt with her — though she never responds that she’s in a committed relationship. Is it possessive of me to expect her to make clear that she’s not available? Her line of demarcation seems to be she’s only sleeping with me.

headline: Chris Martin
abstract: Mr. Martin’s paintings at Anton Kern convey a sense that the artist himself is part of the medium.
lead_paragraph: Chris Martin’s first solo show at Anton Kern feels like a breakthrough, although he’s been painting for decades. Big, glittering and ethereal, the canvases were made upstate last summer, and they have the sun-drenched, baked-on look of the desert, a frequent touchstone in Mr. Martin’s work. Many include a shimmery dusting of glitter, and not just any glitter: the holographic kind used by showgirls in Las Vegas, whose living depends on transfixing their audience.

headline: Daniel Gordon: ‘Screen Selections and Still Lifes’
abstract: Mr. Gordon’s show at Wallspace comprises two groups: large-scale still lifes and photographs that are enlarged details of the still lifes.
lead_paragraph: In a new group of large-scale still lifes that may be his best works yet, the photographer-sculptor Daniel Gordon hops back and forth across the analog/digital divide with a combination of playful insouciance and dogged determination.

headline: Wheelies: The Mazda Motorsports Edition
abstract: Mazda announces a Global Cup race series for its 2016 MX-5 Miata; General Motors to kill the fleet-only Chevrolet Captiva crossover.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Tommy Hartung: ‘The Bible’
abstract: Mr. Hartung’s video “The Bible” sets out to be a contemporary interpretation of the Old Testament.
lead_paragraph: TOMMY HARTUNG

headline: American Fighter Jets Carry Out Series of Airstrikes Against Qaeda Cell in Syria
abstract: American intelligence assessments say the group could pose a more immediate threat than the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — American fighter jets carried out a series of airstrikes in northwestern Syria on Thursday that sought to kill leaders of a Qaeda militant cell that is plotting attacks on the West, American officials said.

headline: ‘Diva’? Deconstructing Pop Images of Black Women
abstract: Musicians, artists, activists and others will deconstruct images of black women in popular culture in a panel discussion at the Brooklyn Museum.
lead_paragraph: The term “diva” has come rather unmoored from its 19th-century origins invoking the divine talents of female opera singers. Now the label seemingly can apply to just about any outsize personality in any field of endeavor. It’s gotten to the point where even the poor old Miser, on certain fraught occasions, has heard the term flung in his direction by certain members of his own household.

headline: The Rap on Old Age: Not a Young Man’s Game
abstract: A veteran writer returns to the Nuyorican Poets Cafe to compete in a poetry slam against people who are mostly decades younger.
lead_paragraph: A few days past my 79th birthday, I am sitting in a packed house of poets and their followers at the Nuyorican Poets Cafe in the East Village, nervously waiting to compete in a slam against people who are mostly decades younger.

headline: In Private Equity, Individual Investors Take a Bigger Role
abstract: So far this year, individuals with more than $1 million in available assets provided 10 percent of the capital raised by private equity firms globally, according to Triago, an advisory firm.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street’s private equity firms are raising an increasing share of their capital from individual investors, according to a new report.

headline: 2000 | When Election Night Became Election Month
abstract: The arc of election night was clear this year before Election Day began. Fourteen years ago, the arc of election night wasn’t clear when Thanksgiving Day began.
lead_paragraph: David W. Dunlap is a Metro reporter and writes the Building Blocks column. He has worked at The Times for 39 years.

headline: Jana Backs Dollar Thrifty’s Former Chief to Lead Hertz
abstract: The activist hedge fund urged Hertz in a letter to pick as its new chief Scott Thompson, the former head of the Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group.
lead_paragraph: Jana Partners has already disclosed that it is one of the biggest shareholders in Hertz Global Holdings. Now, it’s urging the rental car service to pick its preferred candidate for the company’s chief executive spot.

headline: PBS to Broadcast a Sixth Season of ‘Downton Abbey’
abstract: Julian Fellowes, the series creator, will continue to write every episode of the drama, whose fifth season begins Jan. 4 and sixth will begin in 2016.
lead_paragraph: Any network would want more episodes of the most-watched show in its history, and PBS is getting that with the announcement on Thursday that it had secured a deal for a sixth season of “Downton Abbey.”

headline: Grumpy Critic’s Earliest Christmas Ever
abstract: “A Cookie Cutter Christmas” is one of several new television movies focused on the holiday.
lead_paragraph: Why don’t you just shut your mouth and not be cynical for once?

headline: What Happened in Virginia? Democrats Didn’t Show Up
abstract: The lowest turnout of any competitive Senate race was the main reason for an unexpected nail-biter.
lead_paragraph: Some weak Democratic performances in the midterm elections Tuesday are hard to explain. Virginia is not.

headline: ‘Who Needs a Beach When You’ve Got This?’
abstract: On Dominica, an island marbled with waterfalls, rivers and hiking paths, taking a more vigorous Caribbean vacation.
lead_paragraph: When I saw that the only way down the 300-foot cliff was a series of ropes and roots for handholds, I gasped. Below, a field of rocks was being battered by the Atlantic. I wistfully thought about earlier Caribbean vacations, when the main activity was sitting on a beach, lifting a pastel drink that complemented the startlingly aqua water. But after reminding myself I hadn’t come to Dominica for lolling, I grabbed a rope and began the climb down, backward, to reach a place called Wavine Cyrique, which I’d been told was one of the best sights on the island.

headline: Marquee Works Amid Buried Treasure
abstract: The Print Fair rewards visitors willing to poke around, but also has an increasing emphasis on gallerylike solo and theme exhibitions.
lead_paragraph: For a little taste of May in November, head to the Park Avenue Armory for the annual Print Fair of the International Fine Print Dealers Association. Now in its 23rd year, the fair, which opened on Wednesday night, continues to court veteran print collectors with Dürers and Goyas and lure entry-level contemporary collectors with editions from brand-name artists.

headline: New Donor Generation Stimulates U.S. Giving
abstract: Five years after the Great Recession reshaped the global economy, charitable giving is making a big comeback.
lead_paragraph: When the Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg gave the federal Centers for Disease Control foundation $25 million to help combat the Ebola crisis last month, it served as a public service announcement of sorts.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
abstract: Photographs from Syria, Belgium, Turkey and Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: Photographs from Syria, Belgium, Turkey and Afghanistan.

headline: Just Can’t Trust Those Americans
abstract: “Worricker,” starring Bill Nighy, is a disquisition on misdeeds in the war on terrorism, while “The Game” features a good old-fashioned villain.
lead_paragraph: “The island is interesting for its flora and fauna.” That line is so bland it sounds like an enunciation exercise for English-language students, or, possibly, terrorist code for an imminent attack. Actually, as pronounced by the actor Bill Nighy, the words are deliciously rich in irony and elliptical portent.

headline: Romania Hunger Strike Prompts Inquiry Into Dissident’s Death
abstract: A Romanian-born American ended his 17-day hunger strike when the government, after years of inaction, agreed to open an inquiry into the beating death of his father in a prison 30 years ago.
lead_paragraph: BUCHAREST, Romania — Andrei Ursu celebrated by eating a banana.

headline: Atul Gawande’s ‘Being Mortal’
abstract: Atul Gawande believes that the medical profession’s job is to “enable well-being,” not just strive for survival.
lead_paragraph: It began with a tingle in the surgeon’s fingers and a pain in his neck. A couple of years later, he learned he had a tumor inside his spinal cord. That was when the difficult choices began. Should he have it removed right away in a risky operation, as his doctor recommended? Or should he take time to consider this question: At what point would the expanding tumor cause debility bad enough to justify the risk of greater debility or even death in trying to fight it?

headline: Naomi Klein’s ‘This Changes Everything’
abstract: The status quo is no longer an option, Naomi Klein warns in this analysis of the climate crisis.
lead_paragraph: “Every inhabitant of this planet must contemplate the day when this planet may no longer be habitable.” Thus spoke President Kennedy in a 1961 address to the United Nations. The threat he warned of was not climate chaos — barely a blip on anybody’s radar at the time — but the hydrogen bomb. The nuclear threat had a volatile urgency and visual clarity that the sprawling, hydra-headed menace of today’s climate calamity cannot match. How can we rouse citizens and governments to act for concerted change? Will it take, as Naomi Klein insists, nothing less than a Marshall Plan for Earth?

headline: ‘Empire of Sin,’ by Gary Krist
abstract: In the early 1900s, an 18-block area of New Orleans was a battleground between moral reformers and purveyors of vice.
lead_paragraph: When Tom Anderson’s saloon opened in 1901, at the entrance to the recently designated sin district known as Storyville on the edge of New Orleans’s French Quarter, people from all over town came to marvel at its opulence. Its cherrywood bar stretched half a block and was lit by a hundred electric lights. With Anderson’s encouragement, high-class brothels were soon flourishing down Basin Street. Josie Arlington, his business partner, had a four-story Victorian mansion with a domed cupola, mirrored parlor and Oriental statues. The exotic, mixed-race Lulu White built a brick palace that specialized in interracial sex and featured the jazz pioneer Jelly Roll Morton at the piano. Another octoroon (the appellation given to people considered to be one-eighth black), Willie V. Piazza, passed herself off as a countess and sported both a monocle and a diamond choker. Anderson, whose civic spirit earned him the title “the Mayor of Storyville,” published a Blue Book that contained photos and descriptions of the area’s better prostitutes, annotated with symbols (“w” for white, “c” for colored, “J” for Jewish and “oct.” for octoroon). It was all a vivid expression of the city’s tolerance and diversity.

headline: Nov. 6, 2014 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Syria, Belgium, United Arab Emirates and Turkey.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Syria, Belgium, United Arab Emirates and Turkey.

headline: ‘At Home in Exile’ and ‘The Pious Ones’
abstract: Alan Wolfe explores the challenges facing secular American Jews, while Joseph Berger studies the Hasidim.
lead_paragraph: Jews who have made their scholarly reputations studying other peoples and communities sometimes return, in the autumn of their careers, to studying their own. Simon Schama, best known as a European historian and art critic (though he did write an early book on the Rothschilds), recently produced a high-profile BBC series that became a book entitled “The Story of the Jews.” Now Alan Wolfe, a sociologist and political scientist highly regarded for his work on American democracy and Christian evangelicals, has published “At Home in Exile: Why Diaspora Is Good for the Jews.”

headline: The Warhol Collaborator Billy Name on Andy, Photography and the Afterlife
abstract: The photographer and in-house archivist for The Factory will be celebrated with an exhibition opening next week and a book due out next month.
lead_paragraph: Starting next week, Milk Gallery will host a photography exhibition celebrating the iconic works of Billy Name, the multitalented in-house archivist at Warhol’s Factory during the better part of the ’60s. The show, titled “Billy Name: The Silver Age,” will coincide with next month’s release of a book bearing the same title and promises to feature numerous “superstars” who frequented the East 47th Street studio, which Name famously draped in tin foil and silver spray paint — much to Warhol’s delight.

headline: Living Wills Still Alive for Regulators
abstract: Living wills would explain how systemically important banks could be resolved in an orderly manner, but a number of challenges still exist, writes Mayra Rodríguez Valladares in Another View column.
lead_paragraph: Mayra Rodríguez Valladares is managing principal at MRV Associates, a New York based capital markets and financial regulatory consulting and training firm. On Twitter, she is @MRVAssociates.

headline: Netflix Acquires Rights to Lemony Snicket Books
abstract: The streaming service has been trying to expand into original programming, especially family friendly shows.
lead_paragraph: The streaming service Netflix continued its ambitious expansion into original programming with the acquisition of the rights to the popular children’s books “A Series of Unfortunate Events” by Lemony Snicket, the pen name of the American writer Daniel Handler.

headline: Midterm Turnout Lowest Since 1942
abstract: The midterm elections generated a lot of buzz, but they did not draw a lot of voters.
lead_paragraph: The midterm elections on Tuesday generated a lot of buzz, but they did not draw a lot of voters.

headline: When a Donation Steers Off Course
abstract: Dozens of times a year, something goes awry — a donor may lose interest, or the project may become more complex than a charity expected.
lead_paragraph: When he donated $500,000 in 2005, the country singer Garth Brooks never signed an agreement with Integris Canadian Valley Hospital in his hometown, Yukon, Okla.

headline: The Economist Plans Espresso, a Daily News Roundup for Mobile Readers
abstract: The service, with items no longer than 140 words, is the magazine’s first attempt in its 171 years to produce a daily news product.
lead_paragraph: The Economist has built its success by being the weekly magazine that succinctly summarizes the news of the world. Now, as it aims for mobile readers, the magazine is trimming its prose even more.

headline: Cry of Protest From MetLife Signals Right Direction for Regulators
abstract: The designation of MetLife as “systemically important” is a sign that regulators are looking ahead to the next possible crisis, Stephen J. Lubben writes in the In Debt column.
lead_paragraph: As of the middle of this year, the value of MetLife’s bond portfolio was $214 billion, according to Bloomberg.

headline: Bank of America Sets Aside $400 Million More for Currency Inquiry
abstract: Bank of America is nearing a deal with federal regulators to settle an investigation into the bank’s suspected manipulation of the currency market.
lead_paragraph: Bank of America is nearing a deal with federal regulators to settle an investigation into the bank’s suspected manipulation of the currency market, the latest sign that Wall Street is bracing for another crackdown on its misbehavior.

headline: Interviewer’s Dearest Subject
abstract: Lynn Barber recounts her life as an interviewer of celebrities in her memoir “A Curious Career.”
lead_paragraph: There are two stereotypical ways of becoming an older woman, Lynn Barber says in “A Curious Career,” her terrific new memoir.

headline: Russian Troupe Poised for a Global Stage
abstract: The Mikhailovsky Ballet of St. Petersburg, which has lately seen its fortunes rise, will begin a two-week run on Tuesday at the David H. Koch Theater at Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: When we think about Russian ballet, our minds inevitably drift to two companies, the Bolshoi and the Mariinsky. They represent a kind of yin and yang of Russian aesthetics, the cold elegance of St. Petersburg reflected in the extraordinary refinement of the Mariinsky ballerinas, the dynamism and bluster of Moscow in the large-scale dancing of the Bolshoi.

headline: Why Migraines Deserve More Attention
abstract: Migraine is a chronic neurological disease that afflicts 36 million Amerians. So why do we know so little about it?
lead_paragraph: When Susanna Styron’s daughter, Emma, was 14, she began to have migraines. Emma would retreat to a dark room and tell her mother to leave her alone. Ms. Styron didn’t know how to react, much less get her daughter the treatment she needed. “I couldn’t touch her or talk to her,” Ms. Styron recalled to Op-Talk. “I was so alone, and so in the dark. It would have made such a difference to know that people out there are in the same position, to know who to ask for help.”

headline: Rudolph Valentino in ‘The Sheik’
abstract: “The Sheik” opened at the Rivoli and the Rialto in New York the first week of November 1921 and went on to break box office records.
lead_paragraph: 93 YEARS AGO

headline: Details on Obama’s Ebola Funding Request
abstract: When President Obama meets with the congressional leadership on Friday, he will ask them to authorize $6.18 billion to fight Ebola, including upgrading a nationwide network of hospitals in the United States to treat patients with the disease.
lead_paragraph: When President Obama meets with the congressional leadership on Friday, he will ask them to authorize $6.18 billion to fight Ebola, including upgrading a nationwide network of hospitals in the United States to treat patients with the disease, officials said Thursday.

headline: Signs of the Evolutionary Step From Land to Sea
abstract: Ichthyosaurs, which loosely resembled dolphins, have long been an evolutionary mystery. Now, researchers say they have recovered an early Ichthyosaur fossil that may fill in the blanks.

headline: Tote That Barge, Snip That Book
abstract: Norm Lewis and Vanessa Williams lead the impressive singers in the New York Philharmonic’s unusually pallid staging of “Show Boat.”
lead_paragraph: Life upon the stage isn’t very wicked, or even emotionally stirring, in the New York Philharmonic’s musically solid but dramatically pallid staging of “Show Boat,” the venerated 1927 musical by Jerome Kern and Oscar Hammerstein II.

headline: Martin Short to Replace Nathan Lane in ‘It’s Only a Play’
abstract: Mr. Short will replace Nathan Lane in Terrence McNally’s hit Broadway comedy.
lead_paragraph: The hit Broadway comedy “It’s Only a Play” has a new star, a new home and a new closing date.

headline: ‘Foxcatcher’ | Anatomy of a Scene
abstract: Bennett Miller narrates a sequence from his film. featuring Steve Carell, Channing Tatum and Mark Ruffalo.
lead_paragraph: Bennett Miller narrates a sequence from his film. featuring Steve Carell, Channing Tatum and Mark Ruffalo.

headline: Assessing One Possible Change to the Affordable Care Act
abstract: The Save American Workers Act would raise the threshold for full-time work — and eligibility for employer-sponsored health insurance — from 30 hours to 40 hours a week.
lead_paragraph: In the wake of the resounding Republican victory in Tuesday’s midterm elections, there has been much talk about bipartisan changes Republicans might want to make to the Affordable Care Act. On Wednesday, The Times reported on one possibility that could affect small businesses:

headline: Court Upholds Marriage Bans in Four States
abstract: Setting up a Supreme Court case, the decision overturned lower court rulings in Kentucky, Michigan, Ohio and Tennessee that were in favor of same-sex marriage.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court in Ohio upheld on Thursday the right of four states to ban same-sex marriage, contradicting rulings by four similar courts and almost certainly sending the issue on a rapid trajectory to the Supreme Court.

headline: Bennett Miller Narrates a Scene From ‘Foxcatcher’
abstract: The director discusses a sequence from his film.
lead_paragraph: “Foxcatcher,” directed by Bennett Miller, features Steve Carell in the role of the John E. du Pont, a millionaire with an interest in wrestling. Channing Tatum and Mark Ruffalo play alongside him as the wrestling brothers Mark Schultz and David Schultz. In this video, Mr. Miller discusses one particularly tense scene between the three characters. The film opens Nov. 14.

headline: What the Doctor Ordered: Urban Farming
