abstract: New Haven Farms, in the Fair Haven section of the Connecticut city, is a combination of community garden, cooking school and weight-loss program.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN — At a dead-end street in a blighted section of this city, crumbling roofs of old factories, smokestacks and the Interstate 95 overpass loom overhead, casting long shadows on an October afternoon. Along one end of a field, children play soccer; on the other, men stand around motorcycles, sipping from beer cans.

headline: Only One Sugar Plum Fairy a Year
abstract: Serene Meshel-Dillman’s documentary “Getting to ‘The Nutcracker’ ” focuses on the Marat Daukayev School of Ballet in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: There are no trade secrets or magic formulas revealed in “Getting to ‘The Nutcracker,' ” Serene Meshel-Dillman’s documentary about a dance school preparing for a big performance. The unsurprising way you get to “The Nutcracker”? Practice and hard work.

headline: Navy SEALs Trade Secrecy for Swagger
abstract: The SEAL who says he killed Bin Laden is prepping for a Fox News interview.
lead_paragraph: A furious Navy command is asking whatever happened to the professionalism and tight secrecy of SEAL Team Six, the group of warriors who killed Osama bin Laden three years ago.

headline: A Patron Gives, of Herself and Her Art
abstract: Agnes Gund owns about 2,000 artworks, has her own philanthropic foundation and works with a host organizations that promote art.
lead_paragraph: Agnes Gund didn’t want to part with Willem de Kooning’s “The Time of the Fire” or Arshile Gorky’s “Housatonic Falls.” She especially doesn’t like to give up pieces from her collection made by artists who are her friends, which, it seems, just about every artist happens to be.

headline: Crushed by a Giant, With No White Knight in Sight
abstract: The documentary “The Invisible Front” centers on Lithuania’s quixotic postwar struggle to escape Soviet dominion.
lead_paragraph: THE INVISIBLE FRONT

headline: Marco Rios: ‘"S” Is for Sincere, Formerly Formally “F” Is for Fake’
abstract: Here is an exhibition of Marco Rios’s own childhood artwork, done between the ages of 3 and 5.
lead_paragraph: Artists have been using the work of children as source material for decades: Paul Klee and the Art Brut and Cobra movements are a few examples. Marco Rios adds a twist, using his own childhood drawings, made between the ages of 3 and 5, as fodder for a new series of paintings.

headline: Driver Who Sped Around Manhattan in 24 Minutes Is Convicted of Reckless Endangerment
abstract: Adam Tang, who was arrested after posting a video of his high-speed drive last year, did not show up to court.
lead_paragraph: A speedster who raced around Manhattan in a car and posted a video of the stunt online was convicted in absentia on Thursday of reckless endangerment.

headline: Blockbusters and Theme Parks Fuel a Strong Year for Disney
abstract: The Walt Disney Company reported $7.5 billion in profit for the 2014 fiscal year, riding strong revenue from Walt Disney Studios that helped offset rising sports-rights costs that weighed on ESPN.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Disney ended its fiscal year on Thursday with $7.5 billion in profit, a hefty 22 percent increase from 2013, as hit movies and robust theme park attendance combined to offset higher sports-rights costs at ESPN.

headline: A Director’s Gift
abstract: “21 Years: Richard Linklater,” by Michael Dunaway and Tara Wood, offers a star-studded tribute to the director of “Boyhood,” “School of Rock” and “Slacker.”
lead_paragraph: 21 YEARS

headline: Another Security Fix Is Made to JPMorgan Chase’s Race Website
abstract: The website, which had been largely inoperable since hackers broke into the bank’s network this summer, is slowly returning after another security fix.
lead_paragraph: The website for the JPMorgan Chase Corporate Challenge, which was hit by the same hackers that broke into the bank’s own network this summer, is slowly crawling back to health.

headline: Humiliations on the Road From Boy to Man
abstract: “Fugly!,” John Leguizamo’s bittersweet new comedy, mixes narrative and stand-up comedy, embellished with clever animation by Bill Plympton.
lead_paragraph: “Fugly!,” the title of John Leguizamo’s wobbly, bittersweet new comedy, is a taunt hurled at his character, Jesse Sanchez, by neighborhood girls in the Bronx when, as a boy, he lowers his pants and exposes himself in a desperate bid for attention. That ridicule is the first of many humiliations and rejections by the opposite sex that Jesse endures in the film, written by Mr. Leguizamo and Kathy DeMarco and directed by Alfredo De Villa.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: The Soul of a Business, in a Single Photograph
abstract: Can you capture the essence of your small business in one photograph? If so, we want to hear from you.
lead_paragraph: Can you capture the essence of your small business in one photograph? If so, we want to hear from you.

headline: Ex-Mayor Voted, and Now He’s on House Arrest
abstract: Patrick D. Cannon, awaiting prison on wire fraud charges, said that his only explanation for voting was “the light simply did not go off.”
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Former Mayor Patrick D. Cannon, convicted in June of federal wire fraud in a bribery sting, will be on house arrest until he reports to federal prison after illegally voting in the midterm election.

headline: Spielberg’s ‘Schindler’ Bequest
abstract: Fulfilling Steven Spielberg’s promise made after making “Schindler’s List,” his foundation has collected testimonies from more than 50,000 survivors.
lead_paragraph: With blockbusters that include “E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial,” “Raiders of the Lost Ark” and “Saving Private Ryan,” Steven Spielberg has garnered nearly every accolade Hollywood can bestow. It was 1993’s “Schindler’s List,” however, that gave the director the opportunity to create a very different legacy — “something I was put on this earth to do,” Mr. Spielberg said.

headline: Hitting the Road to Keep a Holiday Illusion Alive
abstract: “A Merry Friggin’ Christmas” stars Robin Williams in one of his last roles.
lead_paragraph: A MERRY FRIGGIN’ CHRISTMAS

headline: Mortgage Insurance Paid Upfront
abstract: An alternative to private mortgage insurance allows borrowers to make one lump-sum payment upfront.
lead_paragraph: Private mortgage insurance is the bane of home buyers who can’t put down at least 20 percent. The insurance protects the lender in the event that a borrower defaults on a property with little equity, but it also guarantees a considerably higher monthly mortgage payment.

headline: When Yakuza Meets the Movies
abstract: A starlet from a crime family, an aimless movie director and lots of violent types populate Sion Sono’s “Why Don’t You Play in Hell?”
lead_paragraph: In some filmmaking quarters, excess has turned into a short-circuiting shorthand: Make a movie nutty enough, and the eccentricity is expected to drown out considerations of quality.

headline: Election Results Endanger Innovative Arkansas Medicaid Plan
abstract: The plan called the “private option” has helped lower premiums for many Arkansans, not just the poor.
lead_paragraph: UPDATED to include the latest number of people in the plan: to 211,000 from 205,000.

headline: Democrats Pull $2 Million in Ads in Landrieu Runoff
abstract: The Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee cancels $2 million worth of ads on behalf of Senator Mary L. Landrieu of Louisiana.
lead_paragraph: Senator Mary L. Landrieu’s uphill climb to a runoff victory in Louisiana just got a little steeper.

headline: It’s a Plane! No, It’s a Bird
abstract: “Pelican Dreams” is a study of California’s brown pelicans by Judy Irving, the director of “The Wild Parrots of Telegraph Hill.”
lead_paragraph: Judy Irving injects just enough of herself into her “Pelican Dreams” to distinguish this sweet film from an episode of the PBS series “Nature.”

headline: A Politician Slips, and an Ideal Impostor Steps In
abstract: In “Viva la Libertà,” a twin impersonates his brother, a politician who has dropped out of sight.
lead_paragraph: VIVA LA LIBERTà

headline: First Draft Focus: Perry’s Day in Court
abstract: Perry Faces Texas Court on Abuse of Power Charges
lead_paragraph: Perry Faces Texas Court on Abuse of Power Charges

headline: Love, Not Young, but New and Invigorating
abstract: Circumstances bring together two seemingly mismatched characters in the romantic comedy “Elsa & Fred.”
lead_paragraph: A grumpy old man and a dotty old lady share a moment of late-life bliss in the geriatric romantic comedy “Elsa & Fred.” Because that fun couple are played by Christopher Plummer and Shirley MacLaine, the movie’s too-cute concept yields more rewards than you might reasonably expect.

headline: The Wrong Question to Ask About Same-Sex Marriage
abstract: The Sixth Circuit became the first federal appeals court to uphold a ban.
lead_paragraph: And just like that, same-sex marriage is very likely headed back to the Supreme Court’s docket.

headline: From the Lips of Desperate Poles in ’44
abstract: “Warsaw Uprising” harnesses archival film from that World War II resistance battle, even using actors to recite what on-camera subjects might have been saying.
lead_paragraph: An extraordinary but problematic effort in you-are-there archival work, “Warsaw Uprising” presents life on the ravaged ground in this Polish city in August 1944. Vivid restored wartime footage shows Poles huddled in air raid bunkers, slurping soup, flirting with soldiers, dodging sniper fire or going for a dip, all with a breathtaking sense of tangible detail.

headline: Matters of the (Young) Heart
abstract: A young man who happens to be blind begins to indulge his independence and understand his sexuality in “The Way He Looks.”
lead_paragraph: The pleasures of understatement abound in the assured drama “The Way He Looks,” a quiet, closely observed high school romance set in São Paulo, Brazil. Leonardo (Ghilherme Lobo), a shy classical music fan, is beginning to think more independently: He weighs joining an overseas transfer program, perhaps studying in the United States. His mother is skeptical; Leonardo is also blind, which the movie wisely doesn’t belabor. Leonardo’s best friend, Giovana (an effortlessly naturalistic Tess Amorim), shares gossip with him and accompanies him to school.

headline: ‘I’ll Give You the Sun,’ by Jandy Nelson
abstract: A family tragedy has left this novel’s twin narrators unrecognizable to themselves and each other.
lead_paragraph: “I’ll Give You the Sun,” the second novel by the talented Jandy Nelson, author of “The Sky Is Everywhere,” is told from the alternating perspectives of teenage fraternal twins, a boy and girl named Noah and Jude, each of them narrating from a different side of the accident that forever changed their lives. On one level, the book is about duality: As Jude and Noah wrangle over who will go to a prestigious art school and vie for attention and approbation and even, for a short time, the affections of the same boy, each narrator struggles to become whole, to become something other than merely half of one. Although Nelson portrays the relationship between the twins, their oneness, as comforting, more often it is claustrophobic — perhaps contributing to the book’s tense, almost breathless feel. One of their favorite games is to divide up the world between them, choosing and bartering the sun or the trees or the oceans. There is the sense that the world is simply not big enough for both of them.

headline: Andrea Davis Pinkney’s ‘Red Pencil,’ and More
abstract: Children (and a cat) struggle for survival in the midst of conflict in Sudan, Kenya and the West Bank.
lead_paragraph: That the world can be a harsh place is unquestionable. For those of us who live in relative comfort, far from lands coping with brutal ethnic conflict and severe deprivation, the images of suffering are heart-wrenching, all the more when children are affected. With little or no firsthand experience of these distant places, how do we make sense of it? How do we help our children do so? For three North American writers, one answer is through literature.

headline: Marie Lu’s ‘Young Elites’
abstract: A girl develops special powers after she survives a plague in this young adult novel.
lead_paragraph: It is “13 Juno, 1361,” and Adelina Amou­teru, a teenage girl from a place called Kenettra, is going to be burned at the stake for committing a murder. Several years earlier, we learn, a blood fever spread across this land. Most infected adults died. Children sometimes survived. Some of these children emerged without any sign of the infection; others, like Adelina, were marked and strangely scarred, their hair changing in color. These children, known as malfettos, are considered to have no social value and are persecuted by the government. Adelina’s own father, who regarded her as worthless, was preparing to sell her off to a business associate as a mistress to complete a deal. She decided to escape rather than accept this fate, and in the process accidentally killed her father. It is this act that has brought her to the stake, an uncompromising opening to “The Young Elites,” Marie Lu’s first novel after her hugely popular ­Legend series.

headline: Gorillas in the Midst of a Battle Over Oil
abstract: In “Virunga,” a national park in the Democratic Republic of Congo with rare mountain gorillas is a battleground over oil drilling and conservation.
lead_paragraph: Showcasing the best and the worst in human nature, Orlando von Einsiedel’s devastating documentary “Virunga” wrenches a startlingly lucid narrative from a sickening web of bribery, corruption and violence.

headline: Okapi Partners, Proxy Solicitor, Adds Executive to Focus on Corporate Clients
abstract: The firm plans to announce on Friday that it has hired Tony Vecchio from Georgeson, a rival firm, as a managing director.
lead_paragraph: Okapi Partners has gained prominence in recent years for its role in advising activist investors like Elliott Management and Starboard Value in their fights against companies like the Hess Corporation and Darden Restaurants, the parent of Olive Garden. But the firm is hiring a new senior executive to help bolster its work for corporate clients.

headline: Lincoln, the Beardless, Ethereal Youth
abstract: In “The Better Angels,” written and directed by A. J. Edwards, Abraham Lincoln spends his boyhood in a rural Indiana paradise.
lead_paragraph: The story of Abraham Lincoln’s childhood, “The Better Angels,” is also a Christ story in a strange key. It opens with black-and-white images of the Lincoln Memorial, some suggestive of the view of an awe-struck visitor. The absence of color holds your eye (black-and-white has become a palette for gimmicks and obscure auteurs), as do several arcs traced by the camera, as if that visitor were looking up and even searching. The camera movements seem familiar not only because they mirror the physical effort of what it’s like to tilt your head and stretch your neck, to gape up at a cathedral window or gathering clouds, but also because they evoke Terrence Malick.

headline: 30 Years Later, Reliving an Industrial Disaster
abstract: “Bhopal: A Prayer for Rain” dramatizes the buildup to the 1984 poisonous gas leak from a pesticide factory in India, taking historical liberties for effect.
lead_paragraph: “Bhopal: A Prayer for Rain” dramatizes the buildup to the 1984 poisonous-gas leak from a pesticide factory in Bhopal, India. The leak, sometimes called the world’s worst industrial disaster, killed 3,000 almost instantly and has left a legacy of contamination and adverse health effects.

headline: Luxembourg Minister Defends Tax Laws
abstract: Pierre Gramegna, the finance minister, says Luxembourg is abiding by international law after it was found that many companies are using subsidiaries there to lower their tax bill.
lead_paragraph: Pierre Gramegna, the finance minister, says Luxembourg is abiding by international law after it was found that many companies are using subsidiaries there to lower their tax bill.

headline: Perry Faces Texas Court on Abuse of Power Charges
abstract: Defense lawyers for Governor Rick Perry called the case, in which the governor is accused of abuse of power, a “comedy of errors.”
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — Facing abuse of power charges, Gov. Rick Perry of Texas made his first appearance before a state judge on Thursday, sitting stoically as his lawyers assailed the case against him as a “comedy of errors.”

headline: A Monograph Celebrates the Architecture of Mario Botta
abstract: “Mario Botta: Architecture and Memory” focuses on Botta’s public projects, including the iconic San Francisco Museum of Modern Art and the Church of San Giovanni Battista in his home country of Switzerland.
lead_paragraph: The Swiss architect Mario Botta once described his hometown as “madre e matrigna” — “mother and stepmother” — an apt description for the Italian-speaking Swiss province of Ticino, which possesses cultural sensibilities of both nations. And just like his nuanced patrimony, the architectural style Botta has honed over a 50-year career stems from a mixture of influences. His half-century of work is celebrated in “Mario Botta: Architecture and Memory,” a monograph just released from Silvana Editoriale ($60 at artbook.com).

headline: Making Cars Safer: A View From the Industry
abstract: Mitch Bainwol, president of the Alliance of Automobile Manufacturers, says safety is the top priority of automakers.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Animal Abuse at the Rodeo
abstract: Jennifer O’Connor of the PETA Foundation writes that “participating in the rodeo is the last thing that children should be encouraged to do.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: To Catch a Crook: The F.B.I.’s Use of Deception
abstract: James B. Comey, the F.B.I. director, takes issue with an editorial.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Grand and Central: A Bookstore’s Farewell
abstract: Readers mourn the closing of Posman Books in Grand Central Terminal at the end of the year.

headline: The Cuban and American Prisoners
abstract: Readers agree with an editorial supporting a prisoner swap.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Investment Firm Raises New $2.1 Billion Fund for Latin America
abstract: Advent International’s new private equity fund is thought to be the largest ever raised for Latin America, a sign of investor confidence in the region.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — The investment firm Advent International said on Thursday that it had completed raising a new $2.1 billion private equity fund for Latin America, a sign of investor confidence in the region.

headline: Keeping Wheelies, Kickstands and Helmets in the Family
abstract: Dana Brown — son of the director Bruce Brown, who made the 1971 motorbiking documentary “On Any Sunday” — makes a follow-up to his father’s classic.
lead_paragraph: In 1971, Bruce Brown’s sports documentary “On Any Sunday” took a down-home spin with American bikers of all stripes (including the motocross enthusiast Steve McQueen, who bankrolled it). Now Dana Brown, son of Bruce (who was also the man behind “The Endless Summer”), has tried an updated tour called “On Any Sunday, the Next Chapter.”

headline: A Study of Opposites
abstract: Gibney Dance’s DoublePlus series opened with a program featuring Audrey Hailes and the Royal Osiris Karaoke Ensemble, curated by Annie-B Parson.
lead_paragraph: Gina Gibney hasn’t so much resuscitated the site formerly occupied by Dance New Amsterdam as transformed it. At the first installment of DoublePlus, a performance series at her newly christened Gibney Dance: Agnes Varis Performing Arts Center on Wednesday, the sleek space was as much a draw as the art.

headline: Comedy Listings for Nov. 7-13
abstract: A selected guide to improv, stand-up and New York Comedy Festival shows.
lead_paragraph: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Movie Listings for Nov. 7-13
abstract: A critical guide to movies playing at theaters, as well as a selected overview of film series and festivals.
lead_paragraph: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Theater Listings for Nov. 7-13
abstract: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.
lead_paragraph: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Pop, Rock & Cabaret Listings for Nov. 7-13
abstract: A selected, critical guide to performances of rock, pop, cabaret and more in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Stars Offer Rewards and Risks to Charities
abstract: A famous face can attract donations and recognition a nonprofit group, but public figures can also behave in ways that harm a cause.
lead_paragraph: Joe Torre, the Hall of Fame baseball player and manager, was standing on a trading floor in Midtown Manhattan, surrounded by people dressed as Minnie Mouse, Gilligan, a “Top Gun” pilot, Oompa Loompas (from “Charlie and the Chocolate Factory”), John Lennon (in his protest phase), assorted pirates and the Grim Reaper, who was in charge.

headline: Family Time on Prison Buses
abstract: A little-known network of buses and vans takes people from New York City to visit relatives in prisons scattered in small towns across the state.
lead_paragraph: A little-known network of buses and vans takes people from New York City to visit relatives in prisons scattered in small towns across the state.

headline: In Army Health Surveys, Troops Report Chemical Weapons Exposure in Iraq
abstract: Post-deployment health assessments showed that more than 600 American service members since 2003 have indicated they believed they had been exposed to chemical warfare agent. Following are two such surveys, with names redacted to protect patients’ privacy.
lead_paragraph: Post-deployment health assessments showed that more than 600 American service members since 2003 have indicated they believed they had been exposed to chemical warfare agent. Following are two such surveys, with names redacted to protect patients’ privacy.

headline: Exchange Between Hagel and Congress on Chemical Weapons Exposure in Iraq
abstract: Letters between Representative Jeff Miller, who is the chairman of the House Veterans Affairs Committee, and Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel, about the secret casualties of Iraq’s abandoned chemical weapons program.
lead_paragraph: Letters between Representative Jeff Miller, who is the chairman of the House Veterans Affairs Committee, and Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel, about the secret casualties of Iraq’s abandoned chemical weapons program.

headline: Inexperienced, in More Ways Than One
abstract: In “Sex Ed,” Haley Joel Osment plays a teacher who bounces from one humiliation to another.
lead_paragraph: Purveying a strangely sweet vulgarity, the romantic comedy “Sex Ed” commiserates with Eddie (Haley Joel Osment), 23, a would-be geometry teacher who’s as much a virgin in the bedroom as in the classroom. Everyone except Eddie, it seems, is getting some love, from the customers in the bagel shop where he works to his cheerfully randy roommate (a bang-on Glen Powell). So when he’s hired to supervise middle school detention, it seems particularly cruel that the one subject his students most need to learn is the one he may be least qualified to teach.

headline: More Than 600 Reported Chemical Exposure in Iraq, Pentagon Acknowledges
abstract: Defense officials said they failed to recognize the scope of the reports from Americans who served in Iraq, or to offer them adequate care.
lead_paragraph: More than 600 American service members since 2003 have reported to military medical staff members that they believe they were exposed to chemical warfare agents in Iraq, but the Pentagon failed to recognize the scope of the reported cases or offer adequate tracking and treatment to those who may have been injured, defense officials say.

headline: Jazz Listings for Nov. 7-13
abstract: A selected, critical guide to jazz performances in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: The Psycho, the Starlet and the Voyeur
abstract: In “Open Windows,” a mistreated entertainment blogger accepts an offer to spy on his favorite actress through her computer and phone cameras.
lead_paragraph: Cleverly designed but hellish to watch, Nacho Vigalondo’s “Open Windows” unfolds entirely on a computer screen whose manipulators are sometimes visible and more often not. The result is a thriller with so many viewpoints, feints and fake-outs that it swiftly disappears up its own URL.

headline: The S.E.C. Should Copy the D.M.V.
abstract: A point system would reduce bad behavior by banks and traders.
lead_paragraph: THE S.E.C. and other federal regulators have levied over $125 billion in penalties on Wall Street since the global financial crisis of 2008. Yet few believe that these fines are enough to change behavior. For the largest financial institutions, a multibillion-dollar penalty can amount to a speeding ticket — another cost of doing business. Repeat offenders are the real problem, and financial penalties alone are no longer an effective deterrent.

headline: Opera & Classical Music Listings for Nov. 7-13
abstract: A selected, critical guide to classical music performances in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Dance Listings for Nov. 7-13
abstract: A selected guide to dance performances in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Home Depot Says Hackers Also Stole Email Addresses
abstract: Hackers took 53 million email addresses in addition to the payment card details of 56 million of its customers during this year’s data breach, the retailer disclosed.
lead_paragraph: The hackers that broke into Home Depot’s computer network this year took 53 million customer email addresses in addition to the payment card details for millions of customers, the company announced on Thursday.

headline: Museum & Gallery Listings for Nov. 7-13
abstract: A selected guide to exhibitions and installations in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Push for Fossil-Free Nonprofits
abstract: Donors are increasingly taking into account whether an institution’s investment portfolio includes petroleum or coal companies before making a contribution.
lead_paragraph: Nonprofits have been closely scrutinized for all sorts of practices, as varied as their overhead expenses or how “pink” — focused on women’s causes like breast cancer — they are.

headline: Bookshelf: Sea Creatures
abstract: New picture books include Chris Raschka’s “Clammy Clam” and Carron Brown’s “Secrets of the Seashore.”
lead_paragraph: New picture books include Chris Raschka’s “Clammy Clam” and Carron Brown’s “Secrets of the Seashore.”

headline: Bookshelf: Misbehavior
abstract: New picture books include Lisa Charrier’s “Oh My, Oh No!” and Steve Antony’s “Betty Goes Bananas.”
lead_paragraph: New picture books include Lisa Charrier’s “Oh My, Oh No!” and Steve Antony’s “Betty Goes Bananas.”

headline: Bookshelf: Lives of the Artists
abstract: New picture books include “Matisse’s Garden,” “Mr. Cornell’s Dream Boxes” and “Edward Hopper Paints His World.”
lead_paragraph: New picture books include “Matisse’s Garden,” “Mr. Cornell’s Dream Boxes” and “Edward Hopper Paints His World.”

headline: Spare Times for Children for Nov. 7-13
abstract: A selected guide to cultural events for children, teenagers and families in New York City.
lead_paragraph: ‘Somebody Come and Play’

headline: Sierra Leone Detains Journalist for Criticism of Ebola Response
abstract: David Tam-Baryoh devoted a segment of his radio program to a critical discussion of President Ernest Bai Koroma’s handling of the outbreak.
lead_paragraph: In what reporters in Sierra Leone denounced as an abuse of the government’s emergency powers to deal with the spread of Ebola, one of the country’s most prominent broadcast journalists was detained this week after he devoted a segment of his popular radio program to a critical discussion of President Ernest Bai Koroma’s handling of the outbreak.

headline: Q. and A.: Andrew Wedeman on the Fight Against Corruption in China
abstract: The professor of political science at Georgia State University explains the background and implications of the anticorruption drive led by the Communist Party leader Xi Jinping.
lead_paragraph: In November 2012, Xi Jinping became the leader of the Chinese Communist Party and soon began a drive against corruption by officials that continues two years later. The campaign has left a deep imprint on political life and the economy.

headline: Let’s Play ‘Scare the Actors’
abstract: Rendlesham Forest in England, site of a famed U.F.O. sighting, plays a leading role in Daniel Simpson’s science-fiction “Hangar 10.”
lead_paragraph: Opens on Friday

headline: Spare Times Listings for Nov. 7-13
abstract: A selected guide to readings, exhibitions, walking tours and other cultural events in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Veterans Day Parade and Events (Tuesday) Raymond W. Kelly, the former city police commissioner who was a Marine Corps officer in the Vietnam War, is grand marshal of this year’s salute to veterans. Sponsored by the United War Veterans Council, the parade pays tribute to the Marine Corps. Loree Sutton, a retired Army brigadier general, now the commissioner of the city’s Office of Veterans Affairs; Mayor Bill de Blasio; and other officials will take part.

headline: Ice Bucket Challenge: Can Lightning Strike Again?
abstract: The Ice Bucket Challenge, which helped raise over $100 million for the ALS Association, proved to be a fund-raising phenomenon, but one that would be hard to replicate, marketing experts say.
lead_paragraph: Ice in a bucket became lightning in a bottle this summer, raising awareness and a record $115 million to combat the rare disease amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.

headline: A Circle of Celebration, Forged in Africa
abstract: Angélique Kidjo’s Carnegie Hall concert commemorating Miriam Makeba on Wednesday night was respectful, yet far from solemn.
lead_paragraph: One strong African woman honored another at Angélique Kidjo’s tribute concert for Miriam Makeba on Wednesday night at Carnegie Hall, where she was joined by Vusi Mahlasela from South Africa, Laura Mvulu from England and Ezra Koenig from the African-influenced New York City band Vampire Weekend. Whoopi Goldberg started the concert with praise for both Makeba, who died in 2008, and Ms. Kidjo.

headline: Takata Internal Documents
abstract: Documents related to Takata’s handling of an airbag inflater problem and the company’s guidelines on handling airbags and other safety equipment.
lead_paragraph: Documents related to Takata’s handling of an airbag inflater problem and the company’s guidelines on handling airbags and other safety equipment.

headline: Takata’s Malfunctioning Airbags
abstract: In the course of reporting, The Times obtained video showing the potentially dangerous consequences of mishandling Takata’s airbags. Millions of vehicles with the airbags have been recalled worldwide.
lead_paragraph: In the course of reporting, The Times obtained video showing the potentially dangerous consequences of mishandling Takata’s airbags. Millions of vehicles with the airbags have been recalled worldwide.

headline: Events in Connecticut for No. 9-15, 2014
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: The Big Sleep
abstract: Can we treat the next two years as a fog of fractious do-nothingism that has already passed? Because two people are poised to complete some unfinished business.
lead_paragraph: Maybe it’s best to close your eyes and fall into a Rip Van Winkle slumber for the next two years. The party that has refused to govern for half a decade and ran a substance-free campaign will now play at governing and not take up anything of substance.

headline: Is Streaming Good for Musicians?
abstract: As listeners begin to move from CDs and downloads to streaming, is the trend good for music and musicians?

headline: Events in Westchester for Nov. 9-15, 2014
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Church Group Has a Hammer
abstract: The Mennonite Disaster Service, a religious organization, has recently been at work helping Far Rockaway and Staten Island residents recover from the 2012 hurricane.
lead_paragraph: It’s a rainy, late October day in Far Rockaway, nearly two years to the day since Hurricane Sandy devastated the area. Some of the streets are flooded, giving residents flashbacks to that awful time in their lives — not just to the flooding itself, but also to the construction swindles, insurance nightmares and disasters that followed. But for a few residents in the Broad Channel neighborhood, help has finally arrived.

headline: Semper Fi Fund’s Horsemanship Program Offers Peace to Veterans
abstract: The Jinx McCain Horsemanship Program, started by the Semper Fi Fund, is one of many efforts to help ill and injured veterans.
lead_paragraph: Eleven years after he lost his leg in a motorcycle accident that no one thought he would survive, Mike Johnston found himself on a horse last spring, a cowboy for a week, herding cattle through rolling Wyoming terrain with a dozen other former and current members of the United States military.

headline: Manhattan Preschool Teacher Who Alleged Abuse Sues Over Firing
abstract: Mariangela Kefalas was fired a week after telling her supervisor at International Preschools that she had seen Malthe Thomsen touching students inappropriately.
lead_paragraph: A teacher who reported allegations that a co-worker was touching students inappropriately, and was subsequently fired, on Thursday sued the Manhattan preschool where she had worked, saying her termination violated whistle-blower protection laws.

headline: An L.A. Story: Unions Show Signs of Life
abstract: The influence of organized labor in the United States has drastically declined, but it can still make a difference.
lead_paragraph: Gabriela Ochoa is a vivacious woman who buses tables at the Landings Restaurant at the Holiday Inn near Los Angeles International Airport, a job she has held since 2001.

headline: Doing Good in Harm’s Way
abstract: Those who go abroad to scenes of disaster or conflict already take considerable personal risks — and those who go where Ebola is prevalent can face misunderstanding at home as well.
lead_paragraph: As Dr. Rick Sacra prepared to fly to Liberia to treat patients in the Ebola zone, he prepared for the worst.

headline: Takata Saw and Hid Risk in Airbags in 2004, Former Workers Say
abstract: When secret tests a decade ago showed its airbags could crack and explode, the company tried to erase the evidence, former employees said.
lead_paragraph: Alarmed by a report a decade ago that one of its airbags had ruptured and spewed metal debris at a driver in Alabama, the Japanese manufacturer Takata secretly conducted tests on 50 airbags it retrieved from scrapyards, according to two former employees involved in the tests, one of whom was a senior member of its testing lab.

headline: Obama Action on Immigration Could Benefit Texas Economy
abstract: Analysts say that if the president takes executive action, the state’s agricultural, construction and service industries may be better off.
lead_paragraph: EL PASO — With the midterm elections behind him, President Obama said he was ready to take executive action to prevent many undocumented immigrants from being deported, which analysts said could benefit Texas’ agricultural, construction and service industries.

headline: Welcoming a Boom’s Cash, but Not Its Rowdier Side
abstract: Karnes City, a small Texas community enjoying an oil drilling bonanza, is taking a more cautious approach to growth, keeping new businesses like strip clubs at bay.
lead_paragraph: KARNES CITY, Tex. — Circling this small South Texas city in his black Cadillac, Ray Kroll surveys empty streets, faded storefronts and a century-old mercantile building with fresh blue paint and a teetering veranda.

headline: Iran: Detained Reporter Is Charged, but May Be Freed Soon, Official Says
abstract: The Iranian authorities have charged a detained Washington Post reporter, Jason Rezaian, with being “involved in activities beyond journalism,” a senior Iranian emissary said in a television interview on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The Iranian authorities have charged a detained Washington Post reporter, Jason Rezaian, with being “involved in activities beyond journalism,” a senior Iranian emissary said in a television interview on Thursday. The emissary, Mohammad Javad Larijani, said in the interview that he nonetheless anticipated that prosecutors or the court would set the charges aside and free Mr. Rezaian, above, “in less than a month.” Mr. Larijani, who spoke in English in an interview with Euronews, is secretary general of Iran’s High Council for Human Rights and a member of a politically powerful Iranian family; one of his brothers heads the nation’s judiciary system and another is speaker of the Parliament. Mr. Rezaian has been detained since July 22.

headline: U.S.D.A. to Allow Chicken From Chinese Companies
abstract: The change in policy comes after the department last year approved the export of chicken raised in the United States to be processed in China.
lead_paragraph: Genuine General Tso’s chicken may soon be on the plate.

headline: Goldman Names New Head of Enterprise Technology Investment Banking
abstract: Ryan Limaye, the head of communications technology banking for the firm, will add oversight of software investment banking to his responsibilities.
lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs has given one of its senior technology bankers the expanded title of global head of enterprise technology investment banking, according to an internal memorandum reviewed by DealBook on Thursday.

headline: Russia: Putin Defends Soviet-Nazi Pact
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin has revised his opinion of an important piece of Soviet history, calling the 1939 Molotov-Ribbentrop pact that Moscow signed with Nazi Germany to divide up Eastern Europe not so bad.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin has revised his opinion of an important piece of Soviet history, calling the 1939 Molotov-Ribbentrop pact that Moscow signed with Nazi Germany to divide up Eastern Europe not so bad. “The Soviet Union signed a nonaggression treaty with Germany,” Mr. Putin said during a meeting with historians on Wednesday, according to a Russian transcript of the meeting that the Kremlin released Thursday. “People say: ‘Ach, that’s bad.’ But what’s bad about that if the Soviet Union didn’t want to fight? What’s bad about it?” While the Soviet Union is accused of dividing Poland, he said, Poland actually seized part of Czechoslovakia when Germany attacked that country. “Serious research should show that those were the methods of foreign policy then,” Mr. Putin said. Five years ago he had called the very same pact “immoral.” The statement is likely to increase security concerns in Eastern European states, which have been jittery about Russia’s intentions ever since it seized Crimea in March. Mr. Putin signed a law in May mandating five years imprisonment for anyone convicted of trying to rehabilitate Nazism.

headline: In Brooklyn Church’s Ad, Question About Economy and Award for Answer
abstract: Bay Ridge United Methodist Church is offering $33,000 for any economist who can explain why there is more wealth inequality in America now than in the postwar era.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump has done it, calling for the return of the death penalty in New York and “a little backbone” in American foreign policy. Cindy Crawford and Richard Gere did it, proclaiming themselves, despite tabloid rumors to the contrary, “very married.” It remains the mass protest medium of choice for political organizations (gay Republicans vs. Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel), professional groups (disaffected authors vs. Amazon) and even corporations (Walmart vs. the world).

headline: Tuesday Aside, It Was All Over Back in March
abstract: The Texas election produced few competitive contests, but Tuesday’s results answered some questions about the state’s direction.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN — The election produced few competitive contests, but Tuesday’s results answered some questions about the direction of the state.

headline: Biotronik to Pay $4.9 Million to Settle Kickback Claims
abstract: The settlement followed a whistle-blower lawsuit that asserted the company had induced physicians to use its devices by paying them inflated fees.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department said on Thursday that a producer of heart implants, Biotronik, had agreed to pay $4.9 million to resolve claims that it paid kickbacks to physicians to use its devices. The settlement followed a whistle-blower lawsuit filed by a former Biotronik employee, Brian Sant, who said that the company had induced physicians to use its pacemakers and defibrillators through methods like paying them inflated fees to serve on a company advisory board. The company did not acknowledge wrongdoing. In 2011, The New York Times published an article documenting an unusual pattern in the growth of Biotronik devices in some Western states. In Las Vegas, for example, the article reported that surgeons at a major hospital switched to using almost exclusively the company’s devices soon after being put on its payroll as consultants. The Justice Department said its settlement with Biotronik covered the company’s activities in Nevada and Arizona.

headline: GTT ★
abstract: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.
lead_paragraph: Our quirky, discerning picks for

headline: War in the Field and in Cyberspace
abstract: “Level Five” examines the Battle of Okinawa in the Computer Age; “Verdun, Looking at History” recreated a battle with some of its survivors.
lead_paragraph: Every fact-based war movie is a virtual monument, a cenotaph — or “empty tomb” — memorializing the dead who lie elsewhere. Some, like Chris Marker’s “Level Five” (1996) or Léon Poirier’s “Verdun, Looking at History” (1928) are even self-aware cenotaphs.

headline: A.C.L.U. in $50 Million Push to Reduce Jail Sentences
abstract: The funding from George Soros’s Open Society Foundations aims to slash an incarceration rate in the United States that has tripled since 1980.
lead_paragraph: With a $50 million foundation grant, the largest in its history, the American Civil Liberties Union plans to mount an eight-year political campaign across the country to make a change of criminal justice policies a key issue in local, state and national elections.

headline: Stoic Souls, Gliding as One
abstract: “Red Army” traces the rise and fall of the Soviet hockey team of the 1970s and ’80s, whose grace and skill were unmatched, even as the players chafed at restrictions.
lead_paragraph: Gabe Polsky, the director of the documentary “Red Army,” likes to say that his film is a hockey movie for people who don’t care about hockey, and its reception so far has proved him right. That the movie was well liked at the Toronto International Film Festival in September is perhaps no surprise. Hockey is, after all, the national sport there. But it was also a hit recently at Telluride and in May at Cannes, where hockey is surely the last thing on most people’s minds. The movie was originally scheduled for commercial release next year, but enthusiasm for it has grown such that it will get a brief run starting Nov. 14 so that it can qualify for an Oscar.

headline: New York Judge Dismisses Murder Indictment Against Man Accused of Vigilantism
abstract: A judge in Orange County said the prosecution had prejudiced its case against David Carlson by not allowing a grand jury to hear statements regarding aggressive movements by a rape suspect.
lead_paragraph: The case drew attention because law enforcement authorities accused a man, who shot and killed a rape suspect he had been trying to take to the police, of engaging in vigilante justice.

headline: A Window Beyond the Western
abstract: Tommy Lee Jones discusses his new film, “The Homesman,” and five films that have personal significance for him.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — “I think that the genre of western in film is defined by having horses and men in big hats,” Tommy Lee Jones said recently. He was talking about his new film, “The Homesman,” which has horses and a big hat or two, but that’s the closest Mr. Jones would come to any categorization of the movie, which had its premiere at the Cannes Film Festival in May to generally approving reviews and will be released Nov. 14.

headline: Secret Cameras Rekindle Privacy Debate at Harvard
abstract: Harvard acknowledged this week that it had used hidden cameras to photograph classes, poking a sore spot created by the news last year that it had searched faculty members’ email accounts.
lead_paragraph: Privacy has been a prickly topic at Harvard ever since it was revealed last year that the university had searched the email accounts of some junior faculty members, prompting a major self-examination and promises by the administration to do better.

headline: Ray Rice Awaits Ruling After Appeal Hearing Ends
abstract: Testimony in Rice’s appeal of his suspension by the N.F.L. ended in New York on Thursday, and the case is now in the hands of a former federal judge.
lead_paragraph: After two days of testimony in New York, Ray Rice’s football fate is now in the hands of a former federal judge.

headline: F.T.C. Settles First Case Targeting ‘Patent Troll’
abstract: The Federal Trade Commission said MPHJ Technology Investment used “deceptive sales claims and phony legal threats” to get unsuspecting companies to license patents.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Trade Commission said on Thursday that it had settled its first consumer-protection lawsuit against a company for using “deceptive sales claims and phony legal threats” to try to get unsuspecting companies to license patents.

headline: The Uses of Ridicule
abstract: Snark serves a purpose.
lead_paragraph: What I’ve been doing; en route home. Yes, I know there was a midterm election; thoughts in tomorrow’s paper.

headline: This Week’s Movies | Nov. 7, 2014
abstract: The New York Times film critics review “Interstellar,” “Big Hero 6” and “National Gallery.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “Interstellar,” “Big Hero 6” and “National Gallery.”

headline: Already, Marketers Look Past Christmas to the Super Bowl
abstract: Super Bowl XLIX is 86 days away, but reports about who is buying ads for it are already emerging.
lead_paragraph: WHEN Madison Avenue starts Halloween advertising before Labor Day and Christmas advertising before Halloween, it ought to come as no surprise that marketers are already talking about advertising during Super Bowl XLIX although it is still 86 days away.

headline: Trial on G.M. Safety Defects Set for 2016
abstract: More than 100 lawsuits against the car company will be consolidated. The trial is meant to test how similar cases might play before a jury and to help predict the prospect for a settlement.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge has scheduled early 2016 for a trial related to safety defects in General Motors cars, including an ignition switch flaw linked to more than 30 deaths and the recall of millions of vehicles.

headline: A New Bounty of Oysters in Maryland, but There Is a Snag
abstract: Recent changes to state policy and a growing national affection for the shellfish have led to an oyster farming boom that is hampering the traditional fishing ways of the watermen.
lead_paragraph: RIDGE, Md. — A diver pulled a large, porous bag of oysters from Calvert Bay and heaved it onto the motorboat, and the sucker fish and baby crabs began to scurry and skid in a vain search for escape along the slippery floor. Another bounty of bivalves, almost ready for market. But not everyone is excited.

headline: Christopher Epps, Former Chief of Prisons in Mississippi, Is Arraigned
abstract: Mr. Epps was arraigned on federal charges of receiving nearly a million dollars in mortgage payments in exchange for arranging contracts for prison services.
lead_paragraph: Christopher B. Epps, a former state corrections commissioner in Mississippi, was arraigned in federal court on Thursday on charges of participating in a corruption scheme in which he received nearly a million dollars from a contractor who paid off Mr. Epps’s home mortgage and helped him buy a beach condominium.

headline: Libyan Supreme Court Rules Parliament Invalid
abstract: Libya’s Supreme Court ruled that the country’s Parliament had been seated unconstitutionally. The governing coalition said the court had been influenced by a rival faction.
lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI, Libya — Libya’s Supreme Court ruled on Thursday that the country’s recently elected Parliament was seated unconstitutionally, throwing fresh fuel on the country’s increasingly violent and divisive civil conflict.

headline: Meager Returns for the Democrats’ Biggest Donor
abstract: Tom Steyer, the billionaire environmentalist who spent at least $57 million of his own money to influence Tuesday’s outcome, appears to have largely wasted his time and money.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the last days before the midterm elections, Tom Steyer, the billionaire environmentalist who spent at least $57 million of his own money to influence Tuesday’s outcome — more than any other single donor — set off on a frenetic get-out-the-vote tour to Colorado, Iowa and finally New Hampshire. There, he told business owners in Portsmouth that climate change is an economic issue, thanked college students in Durham for knocking on doors, and gave a pep talk to canvassers in Dover before they fanned out to collect voter data on their smartphones.

headline: In Town Hall, Zuckerberg Discusses T-Shirts, Telephones and That Facebook Movie
abstract: Mark Zuckerberg, the chief executive of Facebook, fielded questions from users of the social network on Thursday in a live town hall format, addressing things as diverse as the company’s mobile ambitions to his personal dress code.
lead_paragraph: Well, we finally know the secret to Mark Zuckerberg’s success: He wears an identical gray T-shirt every day. “I want to clear my life so I have to make as few decisions as possible beyond serving this community,” Mr. Zuckerberg, Facebook’s co-founder and chief executive, said on Thursday.

headline: In Ukraine Crisis, U.S. Businesses Face Tit-for-Tat Response to Sanctions
abstract: American brands doing business in Russia have become political targets since the European Union and United States enacted sanctions.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The scene was straight out of “C.S.I.,” food safety edition.

headline: Hague Prosecutor Cites Possible Israeli War Crimes in Gaza Flotilla Raid
abstract: The court says that Israeli forces may have committed war crimes in 2010 when they stormed a civilian flotilla delivering aid but that the consequences did not warrant a criminal investigation.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Israeli military forces may have committed war crimes when they stormed a flotilla of civilian ships delivering aid to the Gaza  Strip four years ago, but the consequences were insufficiently grave to warrant a criminal investigation by the International Criminal Court in The Hague, the court’s chief prosecutor said Thursday.

headline: Terminal at J.F.K. Could Soon Offer Travelers a Bit of the High Line
abstract: Atop the extension it just added for international arrivals at Kennedy Airport, JetBlue plans to build an open-air park based on the High Line in Manhattan that would be open to all passengers.
lead_paragraph: Travelers passing through Kennedy International Airport may soon be able to get a taste of the High Line without leaving JetBlue’s expanded terminal.

headline: A Post-Election Day Certainty: New Scrutiny for the Affordable Care Act
abstract: Tuesday’s Republican victory ensures a new round of attention over the Affordable Care Act as people on both sides of the partisan divide would like to repair provisions of the law.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — This week’s elections ensure a new round of political attacks on the Affordable Care Act, but they also create potential opportunities to repair provisions of the law that people on both sides of the partisan divide would like to fix.

headline: Veterans Affairs Chief Calls Culture Change Key to Improving System’s Health Care
abstract: Robert A. McDonald says that wait times for patients at a Phoenix veterans’ hospital have dropped by 37 percent.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Robert A. McDonald, the secretary of Veterans Affairs, spoke with reporters on Thursday about changing the culture of an agency that is still trying to recover from the scandal over delays in care at V.A. hospitals that was uncovered in May. Since then, he said, wait times for doctor visits at the hospitals across the country have gone down.

headline: Chicago Archdiocese Offers Sex Abuse Data
abstract: There are complaints against 36 priests, many of whom are now dead and none of whom remain in active ministry. Most of the alleged abuses occurred decades ago.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The Roman Catholic archdiocese here released thousands of internal documents on Thursday that detailed decades of sexual abuse by its priests, a disclosure timed just days before the retirement of the current archbishop.

headline: Secret FIFA Report Stirs Dispute Between Investigators
abstract: A report on the circumstances surrounding the winning World Cup bids by Russia and Qatar has not been released, and the men at the center of the investigation disagree about whether it should ever be made public.
lead_paragraph: For several days in September in a conference room at a Munich law office, two men discussed an investigation into potential corruption at the highest level of soccer.

headline: The Governing Party
abstract: Republicans detoxify the brand with deep roots in the business community, the military, the church and civic organizations.
lead_paragraph: Every party in opposition goes a little crazy. For Republicans in the early Obama era, insanity took the form of the Sarah Palin spasm. Veteran politicos took the former Alaska governor seriously as a national figure. Republican primary voters nominated the likes of Todd Akin, Christine O’Donnell and Sharron Angle. Glenn Beck seemed important enough to hold a big rally at the Lincoln Memorial.

headline: Doubting the Economic Data? Consider the Source
abstract: If government economic statistics prove to be wrong, it may have more to do with how they are compiled than with deliberate manipulation.
lead_paragraph: The economic statistics are fake. There is no real economic recovery.

headline: Triumph of the Wrong
abstract: It’s not often that a party that is so wrong about so much does as well as Republicans did on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The race is not to the swift, nor the battle to the strong, neither yet bread to the wise, nor yet midterms to men of understanding. Or as I put it on the eve of another Republican Party sweep, politics determines who has the power, not who has the truth. Still, it’s not often that a party that is so wrong about so much does as well as Republicans did on Tuesday.

headline: Q. and A. With Sheri Fink on Covering Ebola in Liberia
abstract: Sheri Fink, a New York Times reporter and a physician, answers readers’ questions about the Ebola crisis in rural Liberia.
lead_paragraph: Sheri Fink, a New York Times reporter and a physician, has been chronicling the Ebola crisis from an American-run clinic in rural Liberia. The Times invited readers on Twitter and Facebook to ask questions of Ms. Fink about what she has seen during her reporting trip. Readers asked about a variety of topics, including the characteristics of survivors and the risk of contracting the disease. Ms. Fink answered a selection of the questions.

headline: Boehner Urges Against Executive Action
abstract: John A. Boehner, the House speaker, cautioned President Obama not to take executive action on immigration and called for the repeal of the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: John A. Boehner, the House speaker, cautioned President Obama not to take executive action on immigration and called for the repeal of the Affordable Care Act.

headline: A Soul Steadied by Pigeons Stays True as Feathers Fly
abstract: Rene LeClerc keeps pigeons in a loft outside the window of his Hamilton Heights apartment, a hobby he considers therapeutic, but the birds were threatened recently by the arrival of a red-tailed hawk.
lead_paragraph: From his corner of the earth at 138th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, Rene LeClerc could see the red-tailed hawk around one of the two air-conditioner shells that jut from his living room windows. Mr. LeClerc had modified the boxes into tiny lofts for pigeons, birds he has fancied and flown in the Hamilton Heights neighborhood of Manhattan since he was a boy of 10 or 11, not quite 50 years ago.

headline: Broad Shield Requested Against Deportations
abstract: Activists asked President Obama to protect from deportation seven million of the 11.7 million people in the country illegally.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Immigrant and Latino advocacy groups and labor unions called on President Obama on Thursday to include more than seven million people in executive measures he says he will take this year to shield immigrants here illegally from deportation.

headline: New York Needs a Stronger School Plan
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s initiative adds support services, but the help may be too little and too slow for the most dysfunctional schools.
lead_paragraph: The rescue plan for struggling schools that Mayor Bill de Blasio unveiled on Monday needs to be fleshed out in greater detail before it can be fully appraised. But it is already clear that the plan — which involves giving failing schools support services and seeing how that turns out — might not be sufficient to remake the city’s lowest-achieving, most-dysfunctional schools. The plan could easily delay action on schools that are in desperate straits and should be reorganized or closed in fairly short order.

headline: Problems With Antidoping System Cast a Shadow on Kenyan Runners
abstract: The Kenyan marathon runner Rita Jeptoo failed an initial doping screening, raising questions about doping enforcement in that African nation.
lead_paragraph: Frank Shorter, the American marathoner who won an Olympic gold medal in 1972 and made running cool, isn’t the kind of guy to say, “I told you so.”

headline: In Egypt, Business as Usual
abstract: The Egyptian government moves to silence pro-democracy groups, and what does the State Department do? It holds an investment conference in Cairo.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration’s Egypt policy — to the extent that one can be discerned — has been characterized by a combination of mixed messages, wishful thinking and a willful disregard of inconvenient truths.

headline: Mr. Obama’s Moment on Immigration
abstract: Waiting for Congress to help fix immigration is delusional. President Obama should take executive action now and make it big.
lead_paragraph: President Obama said on Wednesday that he would act on his own by the end of the year to “improve” the immigration system, presumably by giving many — perhaps millions — of the country’s unauthorized immigrants temporary protection from deportation and permission to work. He has said this before, only to back off in deference to election-year politics.

headline: Midterms, for Clinton Team, Aren’t All Gloom
abstract: The Democratic debacle in Tuesday’s midterm elections has put fresh urgency on Hillary Rodham Clinton’s efforts to create a blueprint for a 2016 presidential candidacy.
lead_paragraph: In the coming weeks, Hillary Rodham Clinton will stop delivering paid speeches. She will embark on an unofficial listening tour to gather ideas from the business community, union leaders and others. And she will seek advice from such far-flung advisers as an ad man in Austin, Tex., behind the iconic “Don’t Mess With Texas” campaign and a leading strategist at a Boston-based public affairs consulting firm with ties to the Kennedys.

headline: Voters Defeat Measure to Prevent Santa Monica, Calif., From Altering Airport
abstract: The City Council will retain the right to make decisions about the 227-acre airport, which has been the object of complaints about noise and pollution.
lead_paragraph: The Santa Monica City Council in California will retain the right to make decisions about the city’s airport now that voters have defeated a proposal backed by national aviation interests.

headline: Manitas de Plata, Superstar of the Flamenco Guitar, Is Dead at 93
abstract: Mr. de Plata, considered a crowd pleaser rather than an observer of the music’s formal ritual traditions, picked up his distinct style of play as a young boy.
lead_paragraph: Manitas de Plata, a celebrity of flamenco guitar who sold millions of records, befriended Salvador Dalí and Brigitte Bardot, performed for raucous crowds at Carnegie Hall, made and spent fortunes and generally lived a life of fulfilled appetites, all after growing up poor and illiterate, died on Thursday in Montpellier, France. He was 93.

headline: Arizona: Woman Accused of Abuse Misses Deadline
abstract: A Phoenix mother who was charged with felony child abuse after leaving her children in a hot car while she went to a job interview, missed a deadline to establish trust funds for the children.
lead_paragraph: Shanesha Taylor, a Phoenix mother who was charged with felony child abuse after leaving her children in a hot car while she went to a job interview, missed a deadline on Thursday to establish trust funds for the children. The prosecutor had agreed to dismiss the charges if she set aside $60,000 of the $115,000 she received in donations; he later lowered the amount to $40,000. Ms. Taylor said she had disagreements with her lawyer over the details of the trusts but still planned to finance them. A trial has been set for Dec. 10.

headline: Arizona: Court Hears Arguments Over Medicaid
abstract: A rift between Gov. Jan Brewer and state legislators in her own party over her support of Medicaid expansion played out before the State Supreme Court on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: A rift between Gov. Jan Brewer and state legislators in her own party over her support of Medicaid expansion played out before the State Supreme Court on Thursday. Lawyers for Governor Brewer, a Republican, asked justices to uphold a lower court’s ruling, which stopped a lawsuit by a group of Republican legislators who say the Brewer administration unconstitutionally found a way to pass the expansion with a simple majority rather than the two-thirds support they say is required. The maneuver was “a devaluation of their voting rights,” said Christina Sandefur, a lawyer for the lawmakers. “Their injury is political,” the governor’s lawyer, Timothy Berg, countered. “Their vote hasn’t been diluted.”

headline: Georgia: Lawsuit Over Taser Death Is Settled
abstract: The family of a man who died after being stunned up to 13 times with Taser devices during his arrest settled a lawsuit against East Point, an Atlanta suburb, and two police officers.
lead_paragraph: The family of a man who died after being stunned up to 13 times with Taser devices during his arrest settled a lawsuit against East Point, an Atlanta suburb, and two police officers.  Gregory L. Towns Jr., 24, fled officers who tried to stop him for questioning. The police said Mr. Towns resisted instructions after his capture, but family members said officers had “acted with malice.” The family’s lawyer did not disclose details of the settlement on Thursday except to say that it was for the maximum amount permitted under the city’s insurance policy. One officer resigned after the episode, and another was fired.

headline: A League Grins as a Star Grimaces
abstract: Given the culture of the National Football League, which grooves on manliness, Cowboys quarterback Tony Romo is an odds-on bet to trot out onto the field this Sunday against the Jacksonville Jaguars, who are 1-8.
lead_paragraph: The Circus Maximus known as the National Football League alighted in London for a game between the Dallas Cowboys and the Jacksonville Jaguars. The league’s many fascinations will be on display: its wonderful athleticism, its stupendous television ratings, and its blithe disregard for the safety of its most valuable commodities, the players.

headline: Another Ex-Commando Says He Shot Bin Laden
abstract: Robert O’Neill, a former member of the Navy SEALs, has come forward claiming to have shot the Qaeda leader during the daring operation in Pakistan in 2011.
lead_paragraph: Who killed Osama bin Laden?

headline: A Mother Confesses Her Mistakes as a Lesson for Her Daughter
abstract: Bettie Robinson is forthright about her struggles with drug addiction in the hopes that it will teach her 13-year-old, Shantasia Mason, about actions and consequences.
lead_paragraph: Candor is a hallmark of Bettie Robinson’s home. Especially where her 13-year-old daughter, Shantasia Mason, is concerned. Ms. Robinson makes no secret of her long drug addiction.

headline: In Britain, Guidelines for Spying on Lawyers and Clients
abstract: British spies have the authority to intercept privileged communications — and may have illegally exploited that access — according to confidential documents that were released Thursday.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — British spies have the authority to intercept privileged communications between lawyers and their clients — and may have illegally exploited that access in some sensitive security cases — according to confidential documents that were released Thursday.

headline: Bad News, Ozzie: David’s Home From ’Nam
abstract: Bill Pullman, Holly Hunter and Ben Schnetzer star in a revival of “Sticks and Bones,” David Rabe’s 1971 drama about a soldier just home from Vietnam.
lead_paragraph: A pestilence has entered the house of Ozzie and Harriet. It is a disease of unease that creeps into their walls, their furniture, their bloodstreams, like a fast-mutating mold. The contagion was spawned on the battlefields of Vietnam; their son, newly home from the fighting, is a carrier. And their best and trustiest defense, all-American denial, isn’t working at all.

headline: Lines of Reasoning
abstract: Friday fun with Patrick Berry.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE— A Patrick Berry puzzle! What a great way to cruise into the weekend. Thanks, Will Shortz.

headline: Beneath a Pile of Losses, the Philadelphia 76ers Seek a Formula for Victory
abstract: The 76ers, who are winless and have a mostly anonymous roster, could take a step toward success by getting a high draft pick next year.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — For as long as there has been professional basketball in Philadelphia, Harvey Pollack has promoted it or kept statistical track of it. His 68-year career, begun in 1946, has spanned two local franchises; two comings of Wilt Chamberlain; one each of Julius Erving and Allen Iverson; a slew of colorful owners, executives, coaches and players; and four championships.

headline: Putin Ally Denies Knowledge of U.S. Money Laundering Investigation
abstract: Federal prosecutors and the F.B.I. are investigating a Russian firm once controlled by Gennady N. Timchenko, an ally of President Vladimir V. Putin.
lead_paragraph: A commodities firm under investigation by federal prosectors on suspicion of money laundering and improper oil trading said on Thursday that it had no knowledge of the inquiry and called allegations of wrongdoing “baseless and false.”

headline: Richard Schaal, TV Actor and Second City Veteran, Dies at 86
abstract: Best known for his recurring appearances on hit shows like “The Dick Van Dyke Show” and “The Mary Tyler Moore Show,” Mr. Schaal was also a writer and an early member of Second City in Chicago.
lead_paragraph: Richard Schaal, an actor, writer and first-generation member of Second City, the Chicago improvisational theater company that sparked a new comedy movement in America, died on Tuesday in Woodland Hills, Calif. He was 86.

headline: Charge of Trying to Hire Hit Man Dropped Against AC/DC Drummer
abstract: Phil Rudd still faces charges of threatening to kill a person and drug possession in New Zealand, a newspaper reported.
lead_paragraph: The most serious of the charges facing Phil Rudd, the drummer for the Australian rock band AC/DC – that of attempting to hire someone to murder two others – has been dropped, The New Zealand Herald reported on Friday. But the other charges, which include threatening to kill a third person and possession of methamphetamine and cannabis, remain.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 6, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Nets and Knicks Resuming Rivalry Amid Cooperation
abstract: The Knicks visit the Nets on Friday for their first face-off of a season in which they will serve as joint hosts of the N.B.A. All-Star Game.
lead_paragraph: The intracity turf war between the Knicks and the Nets, still lukewarm after two years, will resume Friday night with a curious new wrinkle.

headline: At Guggenheim, Protesters Renew Criticism of Abu Dhabi Expansion Plan
abstract: The museum plans a new branch on Saadiyat Island, where there is already a New York University campus built by migrant laborers who worked under harsh conditions.
lead_paragraph: Town Cars carried patrons on Thursday to a black-tie benefit for the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, one of the institution’s biggest fund-raising nights, where tables cost up to $75,000 apiece. As the museum’s supporters arrived, they were greeted by about 20 uninvited guests who stood in front of the building, at Fifth Avenue and 89th Street in Manhattan, clanging pots and pans as they paraded back and forth on the sidewalk.

headline: Cappelen Grabs a Two-Stroke Lead
abstract: Cappelen had five birdies on the front nine on the way to a seven-under-par 65 that gave him a two-shot lead at the Sanderson Farms Championship in Jackson, Miss.
lead_paragraph: Sebastian Cappelen of Denmark had five birdies on the front nine on the way to a seven-under-par 65 that gave him a two-shot lead at the Sanderson Farms Championship in Jackson, Miss.

headline: New York City’s Week in Pictures: Nov. 7
abstract: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include scenes from the midterm elections and Halloween night.
lead_paragraph: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include scenes from the midterm elections and Halloween night.

headline: S. Donald Stookey, Scientist, Dies at 99; Among His Inventions Was CorningWare
abstract: By accident, Dr. Stookey discovered a highly versatile material that could be used in everything from guided missiles to cookware.
lead_paragraph: S. Donald Stookey, a scientist with Corning Glass Works who in the 1950s accidentally discovered a remarkably strong material that could be used not just to make the nose cone of a missile but also to contain a casserole in both a refrigerator and hot oven — its durable culinary incarnation was called CorningWare — died on Tuesday in Rochester. He was 99.

headline: Man Charged With Operating Silk Road 2.0, a Black Market Website
abstract: A criminal complaint said the website was created to replace the original Silk Road, used for drug sales and other illegal activities, which had been seized by the government.
lead_paragraph: A California man has been arrested and charged with operating an online marketplace created to be a successor to the original Silk Road website, a black market for drug sales and other illegal activity that used Bitcoins.

headline: The Elegance of Time
abstract: While smart watches are grabbing headlines, there's something thoroughly modern in bucking the trend in favor of a handsome gold timepiece with no complications.
lead_paragraph: While smart watches are grabbing headlines, there’s something thoroughly modern in bucking the trend in favor of a handsome gold timepiece with no complications.

headline: A Hangout Grows in Brooklyn
abstract: Sisters, a design-centric new restaurant and bar, brings modern design, local produce and live music to low-key Clinton Hill.
lead_paragraph: The leisurely, largely residential Brooklyn neighborhood of Clinton Hill will become a bit livelier this weekend when the former site of a storied hardware store reopens as a design-centric restaurant, bar and live-music lounge of the same name: Sisters. Damon Gorton, the proprietor of the nearby Park Slope favorite Flatbush Farm, is the mastermind behind the new venture, which looks set to become a social and dining hub for the neighborhood and beyond. “I’ve lived here for 15 years and simply wanted to create a place I would really enjoy,” Gorton says. “I’ve had my eye on a few locations, but this one came with a 30-foot high skylight.”

headline: Word of the Day | amorally
abstract: This word has appeared in one New York Times article in the past three years.
lead_paragraph: amorally •\ˌa-ˈmȯr-ə-le, (ˌ)a-, -ˈmär-\• adverb

headline: What’s On TV Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 7:45 P.M. (HBO) THIS IS 40 (2012) In this film written and directed by Judd Apatow, Pete (Paul Rudd) and Debbie (Leslie Mann) and their daughters (Maude and Iris Apatow, above from left, with Mr. Rudd and Ms. Mann; both are the real-life daughters of Ms. Mann and Mr. Apatow) inhabit a big white house in a nice Los Angeles ZIP code. There, in the course of a hectic week, they undergo a series of crises as the parents’ milestone birthdays approach: financial woes at Pete’s record label; an embezzling employee at Debbie’s boutique; mother-and-daughter hormones; and, not least, the state of their marriage. “Do you still even like me?” Debbie asks Pete in a moment of vulnerability. “ ‘This Is 40’ is an intensely, at times embarrassingly, personal film, by a man who has worked hard, lucked out and wants to share some of his happiness and its attendant worries with the rest of us,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. In other words, it “should not be mistaken for satire.”

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, November 7, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “I’ve got a handful of hawk in my apartment.”

headline: Corrections: November 7, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Friday, November 7, 2014.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Chinese Officials Issue Rules for Employing Uighurs in the South
abstract: Nearly 500 workers from the restive Xinjiang region, mostly ethnic Uighurs, will start factory jobs in Guangzhou under a government labor export program that is part of President Xi Jinping’s agenda of ethnic integration.
lead_paragraph: Last week, 489 people from the far western region of Xinjiang got off a government-chartered train in the city of Guangzhou to start factory jobs in southeastern China. Mostly members of ethnic minorities, and in particular the Uighur minority, they are part of a labor export program that has been in place for years but is being stepped up as a result of orders from the top levels of the Communist Party.

headline: Test Yourself | Designing a Robotics Lab for ‘Big Hero Six’
abstract: Can you choose the best word to complete each blank?
lead_paragraph: Below are six paragraphs from the Nov. 2 article “Higher Learning in a Hybrid City.”

headline: ArcelorMittal Posts Slim Profit of $22 Million
abstract: The world’s largest steel maker has been shrugging off deteriorating economic conditions in Europe and around the world.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The world’s largest steel maker, ArcelorMittal, said on Friday that it earned $22 million in its third quarter, shrugging off deteriorating economic conditions in Europe and around the world.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | As Myanmar Advances Resettlement Plan, Rohingya Flee
abstract: How should the United States and the rest of the world respond to the treatment of the Rohingya in Myanmar?
lead_paragraph: In “As Myanmar Advances Resettlement Plan, Rohingya Flee,” Jane Perlez writes about a long-persecuted Muslim minority in Southeast Asia.

headline: Canary Wharf Owner Spurns Takeover Bid From Qatar and Brookfield
abstract: Songbird Estates said that the $3.47 billion offer from the Qatar Investment Authority and Brookfield Property Partners undervalued the company.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Another high-profile piece of London real estate could end up in the hands of Qatar’s sovereign wealth fund.

headline: Family Time on Prison Buses
abstract: A little-known network of buses and vans takes people from New York City to visit relatives in prisons scattered in small towns across the state.
lead_paragraph: The United States prison system puzzled the German photographer Jacobia Dahm. It seemed that every week she read something that didn’t make sense: punishments outweighing crimes; racial disparities; prisoners revealed innocent decades after convictions. But how do you photograph that?

headline: Would You Want Your Photo or Video to Go Viral?
abstract: What do you think will happen with “Alex from Target”? Will his viral photo lead to more opportunities than just 15 minutes of fame? Or, do you think Mr. Laboeuf will go back to his normal life, just with a lot more Twitter followers?
lead_paragraph: Before this weekend, Alex Laboeuf was a 16-year-old from North Texas with Justin Bieber-ish looks who worked at a Target store. Then, in almost a mere instant, he became an Internet sensation and was being interviewed on TV by Ellen DeGeneres.

headline: The Wall Cycle
abstract: A quarter-century later, another divide in Europe.
lead_paragraph: A quarter-century later, another divide in Europe.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
