lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: New York Today: What a Week
abstract: Friday: The week in pictures, gusty but clearing, and a very big tree comes to town.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this pleasant Friday. Cars are driving slower, or at least are supposed to.

headline: Regional Politicians Approve Restart of Nuclear Plant in South of Japan
abstract: The reactors at the Sendai plant would be the first brought back online under new safety standards introduced in the wake of the Fukushima disaster.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japan moved closer to reviving part of its moribund nuclear power industry on Friday, as a regional government agreed to restart two reactors at a plant that is among a dozen nationwide waiting to be switched back on following the Fukushima disaster three and a half years ago.

headline: Week 10 N.F.L. Matchups
abstract: This week’s games include a matchup between the Buffalo Bills, whose play has caught the attention of opposing coaches, and the Kansas City Chiefs, who have an unconventional offense.
lead_paragraph: Chiefs (5-3) at Bills (5-3)

headline: Chastened Republicans Beat Democrats at Their Own Ground Game
abstract: The Republican Party took hard lessons from 2012 and built a formidable turnout and digital strategy for the midterm elections — one it hopes will serve it well in 2016.
lead_paragraph: The Republicans’ ground game and digital strategy in 2012 were disasters, bad enough to become a political punch line. The party was determined not to repeat those mistakes, and operatives were well on their way to overhauling its systems this election cycle when the Democrats announced their “Bannock Street project,” an ambitious voter-mobilization program.

headline: In Beijing, Clearer Views Hide Real Life
abstract: Determined to show a cleaner version of Beijing, the Chinese authorities have ordered dozens of temporary changes that are upending daily life.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — As she does every year on the same day, Ms. Zhu hauled a large wreath of multihued paper chrysanthemums to Babaoshan Revolutionary Cemetery in western Beijing. Ms. Zhu, who declined to give her full name, planned to burn it, as Chinese tradition dictates, to honor her husband and parents, who are buried here.

headline: South Korea Sets Independent Inquiry Into Ferry Disaster
abstract: South Korean legislators passed a bill initiating the inquiry into the sinking of the ferry Sewol in April, which killed 304 people.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The South Korean National Assembly passed a bill on Friday initiating an independent investigation into the sinking of the ferry Sewol in April, which killed 304 people in a tragedy that traumatized and polarized the country.

headline: Daily Report: Hidden Cameras at Harvard Raise New Privacy Concerns
abstract: The university acknowledged this week that it had used hidden cameras to photograph classes, poking a sore spot created by the news last year that it had searched faculty members’ email accounts.
lead_paragraph: Privacy has been a prickly topic at Harvard ever since it was revealed last year that the university had searched the email accounts of some junior faculty members, prompting a major self-examination and promises by the administration to do better.

headline: Indian Navy Ship Sinks, Killing at Least One Crew Member
abstract: The vessel, used to collect torpedoes from practice firings, developed a leak off the coast of the southern Indian port of Visakhapatnam.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — A ship collecting torpedoes from practice firings sank on Thursday off the coast of the southern Indian port of Visakhapatnam, killing at least one crew member and leaving four missing, the Indian Navy said.

headline: Marin Cilic Is on the Upswing
abstract: The U.S. Open champion, the first man to win a Grand Slam title after serving a doping suspension, is one of three newcomers at the ATP World Tour Finals in London.
lead_paragraph: There will be three newcomers at this year’s ATP World Tour Finals in London: Marin Cilic, Milos Raonic and Kei Nishikori. But the only rookie with a Grand Slam title is Cilic. It came all in a rush in September at the United States Open, where Cilic swept over the final three hurdles — Tomas Berdych, Roger Federer and Nishikori — without so much as a stumble or a lost set.

headline: Roger Federer Is Still Game at 33
abstract: After a humbling 2013, the Swiss star put himself front and center again in 2014, showing few signs of age as he is set to finish the season at No. 2.
lead_paragraph: It has been quite a tennis year for 33-year-olds, with Serena Williams finishing No. 1 and Roger Federer set to finish No. 2 with an option to go one spot better depending on Novak Djokovic’s form and mood at the ATP World Tour Finals starting Sunday in London.

headline: Roger Federer and Novak Djokovic Battle for No. 1 Ranking
abstract: Federer and Djokovic head to the ATP World Tour Finals, which start Sunday in London, with a chance to secure the year-end top world ranking.
lead_paragraph: The odds of Roger Federer catching Novak Djokovic for the No.1 ranking this year are now objectively long. But heading into the ATP World Tour Finals that begin Sunday in London, Federer still has a chance, and sometimes a chance is all that is required.

headline: China to Punish Those Responsible for Pollution Levels in Beijing
abstract: More than 20 officials in the province that encircles Beijing are to be disciplined, as well as five heads of the most-polluting companies in the city, who will face administrative detention and fines.
lead_paragraph: With Asia-Pacific leaders gathering for a summit meeting in Beijing, forecasts that smog would envelop the capital this weekend were bad news not just for China’s leaders, who hoped to present the city in its best light for the occasion, but for officials charged with ensuring clean air.

headline: Today in Politics
abstract: President Obama having lunch with congressional leaders even as the post-election truce appears to have already broken down.
lead_paragraph: Hide the Knives: The G.O.P. Meets Obama for Lunch

headline: China and Japan, in Sign of a Thaw, Agree to Disagree on a Disputed Island Group
abstract: The countries’ leaders gave the first public declaration they are trying to roll back a long standoff that has inflamed nationalist sentiments and damaged economic ties.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Signaling a potential thaw in their long-frozen relations, China and Japan announced Friday that they would talk to each other about their competing positions on islands in the East China Sea and would gradually resume diplomatic and security discussions.

headline: The Trouble With Campaign Volunteers
abstract: A mismatch between volunteers and the voters they are trying to persuade could prove damaging to a candidate, a study finds.
lead_paragraph: For decades, idealistic and young college-educated volunteers joined political campaigns and were promptly sent off to canvass voters in factory towns and inner cities who were nothing like them.

headline: Why It Took Us So Long to Finish Our New Website
abstract: In April, we finally had enough photographs ready to load into the development site to get a sense of how it looked. It looked horrible.
lead_paragraph: This is part three of a series on commissioning a new website. You can read the first part here and the second part here.

headline: Paternity Leave: The Rewards and the Remaining Stigma
abstract: When a new father takes time off from work, his whole family can benefit. But maybe his career won’t.
lead_paragraph: Five months after Todd Bedrick’s daughter was born, he took some time off from his job as an accountant. The company he works for, Ernst & Young, offered paid paternity leave, and he decided to take six weeks — the maximum amount — when his wife, Sarah, went back to teaching. He learned how to lull the fitful baby to sleep on his chest and then to sit very still for an hour to avoid waking her. He developed an elaborate system for freezing and thawing his wife’s pumped breast milk. And each day at lunchtime, he drove his daughter to the elementary school where Sarah teaches so she could nurse. When she came home at the end of the day, he handed over the baby and collapsed on the couch.

headline: Helping Homeless Veterans Locally, and Thinking Bigger
abstract: VetConnect, a Bronx-based organization devised to combat homelessness among veterans, is also helping them find jobs and health care.
lead_paragraph: Under the tracks of a northbound 5 train, Joseph Gotesman pulled a sandwich from a plastic bag and approached a man sitting near a jumble of boxes. His query was crisp and succinct: “Excuse me, sir. Are you a veteran?”

headline: Ed Miliband, British Labour Party Leader, Denies Rumblings of Discontent
abstract: Publicly, at least, no lawmakers have called on him to quit, but several days of poor newspaper headlines reflect disappointment in his performance, opinion surveys show.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Ed Miliband, the leader of Britain’s center-left opposition, should be looking forward to the general elections six months from now: His Labour Party holds a narrow lead in most opinion polls over the Conservatives, led by Prime Minister David Cameron, who have lost two lawmakers in defections to a populist right-wing party.

headline: Teenagers in The Times | October 2014
abstract: A collection of everything published in The Times about young people in October 2014.
lead_paragraph: In this monthly feature we try to collect everything published in The Times about young people so you can find it all in one handy spot.

headline: Ex-Trader, Arrested in 2010, Pleads Guilty in Insider Trading Case in Britain
abstract: Julian Rifat, a former trader at Moore Capital Management, was among those arrested in a widespread crackdown that was called Operation Tabernula.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Julian Rifat, a former trader arrested more than four years ago in what was then described as the largest crackdown on insider trading here, pleaded guilty on Friday.

headline: Plan to Exit Bankruptcy Is Approved for Detroit
abstract: The decision allows the city to shed $7 billion in debt and to invest about $1.7 billion into long-neglected services after deals were struck with creditors.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Less than 16 months after Detroit became the largest city in the United States to file for bankruptcy, a federal judge on Friday approved a plan intended to help it escape years of financial ruin and begin the hard work of becoming viable again.

headline: Former Trader Ensnared in Libor Case Faces Another Inquiry
abstract: The British brokerage firm Tullett Prebon Group said it was being investigated over trades made by two former employees, including Noel Cryan, who had also been charged with manipulating interest rates.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The British brokerage firm Tullett Prebon Group said on Friday that it was facing a regulatory investigation over trades made by two former employees.

headline: International Arts Events Happening in the Week Ahead
abstract: A slideshow of arts events taking place across the world this coming week.

headline: Morning Agenda: Bank of America’s Legal Hit
abstract: Bank of America takes a $400 million legal charge. | Details emerge on low-down-payment mortgage plan. | More twists in battle for Allergan.
lead_paragraph: BANK OF AMERICA RAISES LEGAL COSTS | Bank of America said in a news release on Thursday that it was nearing a deal with federal regulators to settle an investigation into the bank’s suspected manipulation of the currency market, saying it had increased its legal costs to deal with the inquiry, Michael Corkery and Ben Protess write in DealBook. The increased legal bill resulted in a $400 million charge that cut into the earnings that Bank of America reported for the third quarter a few weeks ago. The charge resulted in the bank’s reporting a loss of $232 million, or 4 cents a share, in the quarter.

headline: 1889: Nice Is Too Alluring
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: A writer traveled to Nice in 1889.
lead_paragraph: Nice has awakened from its summer slumbers and the general brush up which always precedes the winter season has almost been completed. The shops on the quais are stocked with fine things and there are all the signs around that the natives are expecting a very busy season. There can be no doubt that the old popularity of Nice is fast returning. But now that the people are coming again a very difficult problem presents itself: Where shall we put them?

headline: Australia Nears Deal to Sell Cattle to China
abstract: Exports of live animals could reach a million a year and benefit the domestic market by raising beef prices.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Australia is close to signing an agreement to ship live cattle to China, opening up a significant market for producers, who said exports could grow to one million animals a year, driven by demand there for fresh beef.

headline: The Hand That Rules the Chorus
abstract: Donald Palumbo transformed the Metropolitan Opera’s chorus from an inconsistent ensemble to an equal partner currently excelling in the most challenging fall season in years.
lead_paragraph: Once the rehearsal process for a production at the Metropolitan Opera moves from basement rooms to the main auditorium, Donald Palumbo, the company’s chorus master since 2007, gets uncomfortable sitting down. He walks restlessly up and down the aisles, score in hand, watching the stage, conferring with the conductor, making notes in his head.

headline: Cornyn Thinks He’s Found the Key to Winning Hispanic Votes
abstract: Senator John Cornyn of Texas won a greater share of the Hispanic vote than his Democratic opponent, and he thinks his methods are a model of success for Republicans nationwide.
lead_paragraph: As he sailed to re-election in Texas on Tuesday, Senator John Cornyn, a Republican, won 48 percent of the Hispanic vote, besting his Democratic opponent, David Alameel, by one point among a group of voters who favored Democrats by two to one nationwide.

headline: Does India Need a Times Square?
abstract: Max Bearak, a Times contributing writer, wrote this week about the backlash from locals in Mumbai to a plan to model a new commercial center after New York City’s Times Square, and he writes here about the notion of false equivalencies between cities.
lead_paragraph: Add Mumbai to the list of cities hoping to model a new commercial center after New York City’s Times Square. Max Bearak, a Times contributing writer, wrote this week about the backlash from locals, who want to preserve the Kala Ghoda district’s heritage, and he writes here about the notion of false equivalencies between cities.

headline: Daily Clip Report
abstract: Daily Clip Report is a collection of articles about the media and The Times that is emailed each day to senior executives and newsroom managers here.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

headline: Focusing on the Human Element of Estate Planning
abstract: A lawyer’s institute takes a more personal approach to trusts, encouraging clients to craft them in a way that is not destructive to beneficiaries.
lead_paragraph: JOHN A. WARNICK remembers exactly when he realized trust and estate lawyers like him were doing a disservice to their clients.

headline: House Tour | Osanna Visconti
abstract: The jewelry and furniture designer shows T her Milan home and studio.
lead_paragraph: The jewelry and furniture designer shows T her Milan home and studio.

headline: Alexander Wang for H&M: Calm Your Frenzy
abstract: Like the film world’s dependence on opening weekends, limited collections now seem to be all about the debut.
lead_paragraph: The world went a bit nuts on Thursday over the debut of the Alexander Wang x H&M collection. The website crashed. On Twitter, the hashtag #alexanderwangxhm was trending. Consumers waiting to buy Mr. Wang’s funky sports bras and leggings were handed color-coded tags with time slots. Desperate buyers were advised to go on eBay, where merchandise was already for sale, albeit at reportedly crazy prices. It was a case study in creating anticipation.

headline: French President Says He Won’t Seek a 2nd Term if Unemployment Persists
abstract: “If I don’t succeed by the end of my term, do you think I will present myself to the French people in 2017?” the French president said.
lead_paragraph: President François Hollande of France, facing dismal approval ratings at the midpoint of his five-year term, has strongly hinted in a television interview that he would not seek a second term if he could not reduce the nation’s stubbornly high unemployment rate.

headline: Jobs Data Show Steady Gains, but Stagnant Wages Temper Optimism
abstract: While the report was upbeat, with a survey finding a big increase in the number of people who found a job last month, wage growth continued to drag.
lead_paragraph: Only days after many voters complained of worsening economic prospects, the new employment report from the government on Friday provided fresh evidence that the economy was actually getting better, with a sizable jump in the number of people saying they found a job last month.

headline: The Halls of TV Justice
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A lawyer in an elevator at Surrogate’s Court in Manhattan suddenly realized that she was surrounded not by court clerks, but by a cast of familiar faces.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: A Low-Carb Switch for Mashed Potatoes
abstract: The comfort of mashed potatoes — without the carbs of potatoes, inspired by Irish colcannon.
lead_paragraph: Thanksgiving is problematic for dieters and anyone who wants to avoid carbohydrates. But what are we supposed to do about our beloved mashed potatoes? We look forward to their place on the Thanksgiving menu, especially now that we know that enriching them with butter and whole milk is not as bad for us as we once thought it was. If you’ve been following recent studies you’re aware of the fact that fats have gained a lot of ground over simple carbohydrates in the nutritional world.

headline: Khaki for Days
abstract: A great-looking trench makes all the sartorial difference.
lead_paragraph: A great-looking trench makes all the sartorial difference.

headline: Attacks on Fatah Sites Sharpen Tensions in Gaza
abstract: The series of explosions, which caused property damage but no casualties, sharpened mistrust between Fatah and its longtime rival, Hamas. No group has taken responsibility for the blasts.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — A series of small explosions rocked the homes and headquarters of several leaders of Fatah in Gaza early Friday, causing no casualties but sharpening tensions with the group’s longtime rival, Hamas, months after they joined forces to form a new government.

headline: Sears Weighs a New Unit to Hold Some of Its Real Estate
abstract: In its campaign to raise much-needed cash, Sears Holdings seems willing to explore different and complicated financial engineering methods.
lead_paragraph: Over the last year, Sears Holdings has moved to sell a variety of assets to help raise money, including the Lands’ End business and some of its ownership in its Canadian enterprise.

headline: Rallying Catalans to the Separatist Cause
abstract: Carme Forcadell, head of the Catalan National Assembly, has helped make Catalonia’s secessionist drive the biggest issue facing the Spanish government.
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain — THE speech, before hundreds of thousands of pro-independence Catalans, was as straightforward as the seven-mile-long V for vote that the crowd formed along two of the main avenues of Barcelona, Catalonia’s regional capital.

headline: 8 Distinctive Caribbean Inns for a Range of Budgets
abstract: A survey of new and improved lodging options from Mexico to Puerto Rico, Saba to St. Kitts.
lead_paragraph: The diminutive size, steep topography or far-flung nature of many Caribbean locales tend to limit resort sprawl. Whether by circumstance or by design, the following new and improved inns — ranging from budget-friendly bunks to guest-spoiling splurges — are the sort of distinctive properties that promise a memorable stay. ­

headline: 1914: Armored Train Surprise
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: German troops were ambushed by an armored train in 1914.
lead_paragraph: NORTHERN FRANCE — Exasperated by the defeat of their fresh army corps, the Germans this week resorted to a purposeless plan of laying Ypres in ruins and ashes. From guns concealed by a haystack they inflicted enormous damage on the town, but late in the afternoon the Germans met with summary punishment in a way for which they were completely unprepared. The puffing of a steam-engine warned them as they thought of the approach of a troop train. They waited their opportunity, expecting it to pass a section of the railway which was visible to them nearly two miles away. Their opportunity never came. They simply heard the terrific crash of the heavy guns, and within a few seconds they and their guns ceased to exist. The enemy had been surprised by an armored train — the first which the British had sent to the firing line. The armored train has now supported our artillery for several days. Its casualties up to date consist of one man wounded. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Nov. 8, 1914

headline: Job Growth Continues Apace, Offering Solace to Democrats
abstract: Job growth in October kept pace with the gains for the year, adding 214,000 jobs and giving the Democrats a small victory.
lead_paragraph: The employment picture continued to improve in October. The gains may not be drastic enough to change the electorate’s negative views of President Obama, but they could at least help Democrats pull themselves off the mat after a bruising Election Day.

headline: A Journey Of Jubilation, 38 Years Later
abstract: Stevie Wonder and a huge band played his 1976 album, “Songs in the Key of Life,” from start to finish, 38 years later and every bit as vibrant.
lead_paragraph: “Yes! We did it!” Stevie Wonder exulted, and rightly so, about three hours into his concert at Madison Square Garden on Thursday night. He and a huge band, directed by the keyboardist Greg Phillinganes, had played his 1976 album, “Songs in the Key of Life,” from start to finish, 38 years later and every bit as vibrant.

headline: Spanish Court Upholds Tax Fraud Charges Against Princess Cristina
abstract: The court agreed to drop the more serious money-laundering charges that were also filed against her.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — A Spanish court on Friday upheld tax fraud charges against Princess Cristina, who has been entangled in a corruption case centered on whether her husband and his business associates embezzled millions of euros in public funds earmarked for sports events.

headline: Finding, and Battling, Hidden Costs of 401(k) Plans
abstract: Despite federal requirements on disclosure, few workers and retirees realize how fees could be eating into their savings.
lead_paragraph: LIKE millions of retirees who assumed their companies had taken care of them, Ronald Tussey never thought that his retirement plan might be flawed. He trusted his company so much he kept his money in his 401(k) long after he left.

headline: The October Jobs Report Is Boring, in a (Mostly) Good Way
abstract: The numbers point to a continuing trend of steady, if slow, expansion.
lead_paragraph: There was nothing surprising about Friday morning’s report on the state of the American job market. And that’s (mostly) good news.

headline: ‘Hunger Games’ Coming to the Stage in London
abstract: The film studio Lionsgate said that a stage adaptation of the hugely successful book and movie franchise is to open in summer 2016.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Katniss Everdeen, having conquered books and movies, will next bring her survival skills to the stage.

headline: Rock Star on a Quest for Heroes
abstract: Dave Grohl plays a fan and an accidental historian in “Sonic Highways,” a new HBO series he directed and that became the basis of a new Foo Fighters album.
lead_paragraph: Dave Grohl, the great drummer, inspirational songwriter, former member of Nirvana and current leader of the Foo Fighters, recently discovered the extent to which he is an American musician. He found out by visiting recording studios in eight cities during the production of “Sonic Highways,” an eight-part HBO series that he directed, about the common threads of popular music in this country.

headline: Verbatim: Miss Hathaway Goes to Washington
abstract: Anne Hathaway talked about movies and politics while in Washington for a screening of “Interstellar.”
lead_paragraph: — Anne Hathaway, in the capital for a screening of “Interstellar,” musing about how to merge science fiction and Washington drama for the movies.

headline: Video Reviews of ‘Interstellar,’ ‘Big Hero 6’ and ‘National Gallery’
abstract: Times critics on “Interstellar,” “Big Hero 6″ and “National Gallery.”
lead_paragraph: In this week’s video, Times critics share their thoughts on “Interstellar,” “Big Hero 6″ and “National Gallery.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: The Daily Gift: a Simple, Elegant Ear Cuff
abstract: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.
lead_paragraph: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.

headline: Marco Zanini Is Leaving Schiaparelli
abstract: The house said that “a new creative director would be named soon.” So for the next few weeks, the fashion world will engage in a frenzy of guessing about candidates for the post.
lead_paragraph: There’s another job opening in the fashion world.

headline: Australia’s Little Guantánamos
abstract: The international community has been critical of Canberra’s decision to close its borders to travelers from Ebola-affected nations — but it’s only the most recent debacle in a series of anti-immigration policy moves.
lead_paragraph: “Australia has temporarily closed its border to people from Ebola-affected West African nations,” reports Dan Harrison for The Sydney Morning Herald — an effort he says is meant to bolster the nation’s “defenses against the virus.”

headline: Dallas Closes the Door on Its Ebola Scare
abstract: The last person in the region being monitored for symptoms of the disease was cleared on Friday.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — If there was a physical landmark of this city’s five-week Ebola scare it was Apartment 614.

headline: Events in New Jersey for Nov. 9-15, 2014
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Events on Long Island for Nov. 9-15, 2014
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Hollande on Taxes and Re-election Bid
abstract: In a television interview on Thursday, President François Hollande of France suggested he wouldn’t run for re-election in 2017 if he was unable to lower unemployment rates in the country.
lead_paragraph: In a television interview on Thursday, President François Hollande of France suggested he wouldn’t run for re-election in 2017 if he was unable to lower unemployment rates in the country.

headline: The Jobs Report Is Even Better Than It Looks
abstract: A close look at the details, including the household survey, reveals a labor market that is improving rapidly and a recovery that is gaining steam.
lead_paragraph: The topline of this morning’s jobs report shows nonfarm payrolls expanding by 214,000 jobs in October. It’s the sort of number that suggests a narrative of a continuing, albeit disappointing, economic recovery.

headline: Loretta Lynch, Federal Prosecutor, Will Be Nominated for Attorney General
abstract: Ms. Lynch, the top federal prosecutor in Brooklyn, is the leading contender to succeed Eric H. Holder Jr., who is stepping down.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama will nominate Loretta E. Lynch, the top federal prosecutor in Brooklyn, to be the next attorney general, reaching outside his inner circle to fill a key post, the White House said Friday.

headline: The Wendy Davis Experiment
abstract: Notes on an entirely-foreseeable debacle.
lead_paragraph: I mentioned the Texas Democrats’ gubernatorial nominee in passing in my immediate post-election post, but I can’t let the week disappear without saying a bit more about the Davis candidacy’s epic failure … one that’s been featured prominently in discussions of how the Democrats’ entire roadmap for the future failed them in this cycle, as the demographically-shifting states they had targeted conspicuously failed to turn even slightly purple. Here is Bloomberg’s Dave Weigel on some of the Texas-specific elements of that failure; here is my colleague Jonathan Martin on the broader pattern:

headline: The Disillusionist
abstract: In this excerpt from the forthcoming documentary film “An Honest Liar,” James Randi explains how Harry Houdini inspired him to also become a famed magician and escape artist.
lead_paragraph: In this excerpt from the forthcoming documentary film “An Honest Liar,” James Randi explains how Harry Houdini inspired him to also become a famed magician and escape artist.

headline: Reply All: The 10.26.14 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: WHAT IF AGE IS NOTHING BUT A MIND-SET?

headline: Garry Trudeau on Bringing His Political Satire to TV
abstract: In the second season of his show, “Alpha House,” the longtime editorial cartoonist continues his exploration of the Republican narrative.
lead_paragraph: The creator of Doonesbury and “Alpha House” talks with Jim Rutenberg about his change of heart on Reagan and what’s inside Obama’s brain.

headline: When Your Childhood Home Isn’t How You Remember It
abstract: I went back to the house I grew up in. But I didn’t like what they’d done with the place.
lead_paragraph: Ever since my parents split up when I was 27, I fantasized about walking back into my childhood home, which they moved out of six years before they parted ways. The divorce seemed to invalidate my entire childhood. All the carefully saved bits and pieces that documented my existence before my 20s — concert T-shirts decorated with safety pins, a white jean skirt bought with babysitting money — were gone without explanation, tossed out by movers, lost in the chaos of a hasty real estate transaction or appropriated by new people passing through my parents’ now-separate lives.

headline: Teddy Thompson’s Folk-Rock Family Reunion
abstract: Three decades after his famous parents broke up, Thompson brings them together again on a new album, “Family.”
lead_paragraph: One evening last fall, Teddy Thompson stepped onto the stage at the Purple Crayon, a cultural center in Hastings-on-Hudson, not far from New York City. The venue regularly attracts established pop-folk singers, the kind embraced by the public-radio-listening, Subaru-driving locals; Thompson loosely falls into that category, although he has the louche glamour of a heartbreaker, as well as the reputation (“I haven’t been invited on the Lilith tour,” he once dryly pointed out in an interview). Tall, fair, lean and British, he sang that night, with what one admiring critic has called his “keening tenor,” a series of songs about failed relationships in which Thompson, single at 38, was usually the bad actor: “I was born with a love disease/It’s known as chronic hard-to-please.”

headline: The Unbelievable Skepticism of the Amazing Randi
abstract: An expert magician, avid debunker and scourge of spiritualists and con men prepares for the final curtain.
lead_paragraph: A few minutes before 8 o’clock one Sunday evening last July, around 600 people crowded into the main conference hall of the South Point casino in Las Vegas. After taking their seats on red-velvet upholstered chairs, they chattered noisily as they awaited the start of the Million Dollar Challenge. When Fei Wang, a 32-year-old Chinese salesman, stepped onto the stage, they fell silent. Wang had a shaved head and steel-framed glasses. He wore a polo shirt, denim shorts and socks. He claimed to have a peculiar talent: from his right hand, he could transmit a mysterious force a distance of three feet, unhindered by wood, metal, plastic or cardboard. The energy, he said, could be felt by others as heat, pressure, magnetism or simply “an indescribable change.” Tonight, if he could demonstrate the existence of his ability under scientific test conditions, he stood to win $1 million.

headline: Why Can’t I Clean My Boyfriend’s House for Pay?
abstract: An offer to tidy up in exchange for a discount in rent; paranoia over a gardener’s Breathalyzer.
lead_paragraph: About a year ago, I moved into my boyfriend’s house in a new city. I’m renting out my old house for income as I look for work. I pay my partner $100 each month to cover my utility expenses. He pays his cleaning person $160 a month to clean the house twice a month. I am not convinced that the house gets cleaned well, and I have plenty of free time anyway. I offered to clean the house in lieu of the money I pay him, which would save him $60 and me $100. He refuses, claiming that it would be as if he were paying me to clean the house. Would that be so wrong? NAME WITHHELD, SANTA FE

headline: After Work, Bypass the Wine and Reach for a Highball
abstract: Upgrade your 5 o’clock drink, and wash the stress away.
lead_paragraph: The lamentations of people like me who work mostly from home don’t tend to inspire much sympathy from 9-to-5ers. I can sleep in if I’ve had a late night. I can go to movie matinees and spare myself the most crushing crowds at museums. But there are things I miss. Benefits. A routine. That built-in reading time during a subway commute. And most of all, the distinct pleasure of packing it in after a day at the office and heading straight to the bar to wash the stress away, even if it’s only for an hour or two.

headline: Ferguson Waits Uneasily for Grand Jury’s Decision
abstract: Few in Ferguson, Mo., expect peace when, sometime in the next few weeks, a grand jury decides whether to indict the police officer who shot an unarmed black teenager in August.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — Walk down West Florissant Avenue, and the scars of the summer are still there. The door and display window of a beauty supply store remain covered with plywood; a glued-up poster, “Beauty Town Is Back,” is the one hopeful sign of the life inside. A cellphone store, too, still has the plywood up from when riots and confrontations with the police shook this neighborhood. And the Family of Faith Baptist Church uses its billboard to proclaim, “Join us as we pray for peace.”

headline: Rudolph, the Red-Nosed Forever Stamp
abstract: At the risk of being accused of holiday creep, I have to share these Rudolph, Santa, Hermey and Bumble stamps.
lead_paragraph: At the risk of being accused of holiday creep, I have to share these Rudolph, Santa, Hermey and Bumble stamps. I haven’t ordered my holiday cards yet, but I ordered these. Happy it’s-not-even-Thanksgiving-yet Friday!

headline: Carrie Mathison of ‘Homeland’, My Former BFF
abstract: You think the “Homeland” character might be high maintenance? You have no idea.
lead_paragraph: I was watching Carrie Mathison on “Homeland” last Sunday, and when it got to the part where she insists they bomb the terrorist Haissam Haqqani even though it would have killed her mentor and friend Saul Berenson, who was standing, like, six feet away, it made me glad that we were no longer close.

headline: Building Human Pyramids for Catalonia
abstract: Castell competitions in Catalonia feature human pyramids that build community and celebrate culture as the region debates independence from Spain.
lead_paragraph: Castell competitions in Catalonia feature human pyramids that build community and celebrate culture as the region debates independence from Spain.

headline: The Who of the Matter
abstract: To some prospective renters and buyers, who the neighbors will be is as important as the building itself.
lead_paragraph: The apartment checked off every box on the buyers’ wish list: airy, gracious, great views of the park. It was in a terrific building, one of the most prestigious on the Upper East Side. The couple moved in, unpacked and tried without success over the next few months to get settled.

headline: Solvency, Lost in the Fog at the Fed
abstract: The Federal Reserve is bound by tradition and law to make emergency loans only to solvent institutions. So why did its top officials save Bear Stearns and A.I.G., but not Lehman Brothers?
lead_paragraph: When it comes to the Federal Reserve’s emergency lending powers, the crucial word is “solvent.” That’s because both by tradition and, since the passage of the Dodd-Frank Act, by law, the Fed can use its emergency powers to make loans only to a solvent institution.

headline: Catalonia’s Human Towers as a Metaphor for Independence
abstract: The tradition of castell building has become a rallying point of national pride as the region goes into a straw vote on independence from Spain.
lead_paragraph: VALLS, Spain — It took the child about a minute to scramble up the wobbly human tower, more than three stories tall. He paused for a few precarious seconds, to steady himself, before raising his hand to thunderous applause from the crowds packed into this town’s main square.

headline: Reince Priebus, R.N.C. Chairman, Would Relish Hillary Clinton Campaign
abstract: The head of the Republican National Committee said Friday he is hoping that Hillary Rodham Clinton runs for president in 2016.
lead_paragraph: Add one more name to the list of those hoping for a Hillary Rodham Clinton presidential run in 2016: Reince Priebus, chairman of the Republican National Committee.

headline: On the Corner of Main Street, a Rare Institution
abstract: World Pie offers a variety of menu items, but the pizza is its bread and butter, and can be paired with homemade sangria,
lead_paragraph: Looking for a place to impress a client, be wowed by the architecture of food, or rekindle the culinary magic from last summer’s trip to Tuscany? It’s probably not World Pie, the self-described “Italian saloon” on Main Street in Bridgehampton.

headline: U.N. Rights Chief Says Sri Lanka Is Obstructing War Crimes Inquiry
abstract: A strongly worded statement by Zeid Ra’ad al-Hussein is the latest twist in a diplomatic struggle to conduct a credible investigation of events in the country’s brutal civil war.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The United Nations human rights chief, Zeid Ra’ad al-Hussein, sharply rebuked the Sri Lankan government on Friday for “unacceptable conduct” for what he said were efforts to obstruct an investigation into possible war crimes in Sri Lanka.

headline: China, Japan to ‘Overcome’ Difficulties
abstract: Ken Okaniwa, the Japanese Foreign Ministry spokesman, said Japan and China agreed on Friday to work on improving ties and to set aside tensions over disputed islands in the East China Sea.
lead_paragraph: Ken Okaniwa, the Japanese Foreign Ministry spokesman, said Japan and China agreed on Friday to work on improving ties and to set aside tensions over disputed islands in the East China Sea.

headline: Near the Waterfront, and Nearly Hidden
abstract: Tucked along the waterfront and offering great views all around, Forty North has a menu that is ambitious without being complicated.
lead_paragraph: Unless you are familiar with Hastings-on-Hudson, it isn’t that easy to find Forty North, which officially opened near the waterfront in mid-June. To get there, you must navigate onto the train-track overpass and search between the Hasting Tennis Club’s two big courts. The restaurant’s signs still look temporary, and are hard to read.

headline: In Search of Townhouse Deals
abstract: As more families stay in the city, and condominium prices surge ever higher, renewed attention is being lavished on the niche townhouse market.
lead_paragraph: In 1998, Leslie Feder and her husband, Dr. Garrick Leonard, paid $1.7 million for a townhouse on the Upper West Side, just half a block from Central Park. The 25-foot-wide property, at 60 West 83rd Street, was built as a single-family mansion in 1885, but had since been carved into 16 separate units, with some apartments sharing bathrooms and kitchens.

headline: Exhibition Will Feature Recreation of William Blake’s Studio
abstract: A recreation of William Blake’s London studio will be the centerpiece of an exhibition at the Ashmolean Museum in Oxford.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A recreation of William Blake’s London studio, based on a discovery of the original building plans, will be the centerpiece of the exhibition “Apprentice & Master” at the Ashmolean Museum of the University of Oxford, the museum announced Friday. The studio will be reconstructed to the exact dimensions detailed in the plans of No.13 Hercules Building, Hercules Road in the suburb of Lambeth, where Blake lived and worked from 1791 to 1800, creating most of his illuminated books and developing his own method of color printing. It will show the artist’s workbench and printing equipment, including a marble slab, inking stone, boards, papers and a star-wheel rolling press as well as three original prints representing his work and interests at the time.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘Empire of Sin’
abstract: This week, Gary Krist discusses “Empire of Sin”; Alexandra Alter has news from the literary world; Maria Russo discusses this week’s Children’s Books section; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Gary Krist discusses “Empire of Sin”; Alexandra Alter has news from the literary world; Maria Russo discusses this week’s Children’s Books section; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘Empire of Sin’
abstract: This week, Gary Krist and Maria Russo.
lead_paragraph: This week, Gary Krist and Maria Russo.

headline: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
abstract: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

headline: New York Fed Legal Memo
abstract: Legal memo from 1999, introduced at the A.I.G. trial, written by a lawyer at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, Joseph H. Sommer.
lead_paragraph: Legal memo from 1999, introduced at the A.I.G. trial, written by a lawyer at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, Joseph H. Sommer.

headline: International Raids Target Sites Selling Contraband on the ‘Dark Web’
abstract: A joint European and American operation targeted sites that typically operated on the Tor network, which conceals the I.P. addresses of computers.
lead_paragraph: In the digital marketplace, they operated as a secret underground with names like Blue Sky and Silk Road 2.0 where anonymous buyers could purchase drugs, stolen credit cards and weapons, or even hire a hit man.

headline: Obama and Congressional Leaders Discuss How to Move on Immigration
abstract: Speaker John A. Boehner issued a warning to the president, then accepted a gift of a six-pack of White House beer.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Speaker John A. Boehner warned President Obama in person Friday that taking unilateral action to ease deportation of undocumented immigrants would rupture relations with the new Republican majority and would kill efforts to overhaul immigration policy as congressional leaders gathered at the White House for the first time since Tuesday’s elections.

headline: Trailer Home Trend: Reporter’s Notebook
abstract: Steven Kurutz describes how he came to write about people who buy and transform vintage travel trailers.
lead_paragraph: Steven Kurutz identifies a new trend in the Home section on Thursday: People are investing in vintage travel trailers and transforming them in all kinds of ways.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
abstract: In the news: Asthma, children’s coughs and colon cancer rates. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: In the news: Asthma, children’s coughs and colon cancer rates. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: ‘Man v. Nature,’ by Diane Cook
abstract: In Diane Cook’s apocalypse-tinged tales, human connection is a perishable and often scarce commodity.
lead_paragraph: In the title story of Diane Cook’s debut collection, three men, childhood friends, are stranded in a great lake on a lifeboat. They’re in the middle of a shipping route, and yet no one has passed them, no rescue is in sight. “I want you to write me a world in which that happens,” one of the friends asks the television writer on the boat. It’s a grim scene. They’re running out of food, they can’t sleep or stretch out, and old tensions between the men have started to renew. The television writer creates an origin story for their predicament: a “coup d’état” in Canada, hostages, armed gunmen. He names the imaginary show “Man v. Nature.” “Everything is man versus this and man versus that,” he says. “It’s so simple. . . . It’s man versus everything. It’s me. It’s you. It’s us. It’s in us.”

headline: Mike Curato’s ‘Little Elliot, Big City,’ and More
abstract: Amid the hustle and bustle of the big city, or the vast stillness of the desert, life is better when there’s someone to share it with.
lead_paragraph: We’ve all been there at some point. Feeling a little out of place, unnoticed. If we were lucky, perhaps we met someone who, though very different, complemented us. Maybe we met a Jim and, like Huck Finn, left our familiar though confining small town; maybe we were Maude seeking companionship in a boy named Harold; maybe we were Joe Buck, the midnight cowboy in a city that never sleeps, who befriended the lowliest of the low, Ratso Rizzo.

headline: Memoirs
abstract: New books by Caitlin Doughty, Diogo Mainardi, Anne Sinclair and Marcos Giralt Torrente.
lead_paragraph: SMOKE GETS IN YOUR EYES

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE BOOK OF STRANGE NEW THINGS,  by Michel Faber. (Hogarth, $28.) Faber is a master of the weird; in his defiantly unclassifiable novel, a pastor from Earth is picked to satisfy an alien planet’s mysterious yen for religious instruction.

headline: Peter Stamm’s ‘All Days Are Night’
abstract: Horribly disfigured, Peter Stamm’s heroine reassesses her life.
lead_paragraph: “All literary characters are inventions, even if they are based on real people,” the Swiss writer Peter Stamm has said. “But we don’t really like to be reminded of this fact. We have to forget it to be able to enjoy reading at all.” Yet sometimes writers — including Stamm — can’t resist spotlighting the authorial hands pulling the strings. The first line of Stamm’s first novel, “Agnes,” for example, reads: “Agnes is dead. Killed by a story.”

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Jill Lepore, whose “Secret History of Wonder Woman” is No. 12 on the hardcover nonfiction list, says “Wonder Woman’s origin story borrows from all the conventions of feminist utopian fiction.”
lead_paragraph: Missing Link: The high-low appeal of cultural studies, in which academics devote serious attention to the meanings and implications of pop phenomena, is nothing new. But it may have reached its happy apotheosis with “The Secret History of Wonder Woman,” new at No. 12 on the hardcover nonfiction list, by the Harvard historian and New Yorker staff writer Jill Lepore. “It struck me that Wonder Woman’s origin story borrows from all the conventions of feminist utopian fiction,” Lepore said in a recent interview with Comic Book Resource (“the premier online comics magazine”). “I had never noticed that tie before, and I don’t think comics fans or comics historians necessarily noticed it, either — mainly because there’s not a great deal of overlap between comics historians and readers of feminist utopian fiction.” Among other things, Lepore’s book traces the pervasive bondage scenes in “Wonder Woman” to suffragist politics, and locates the comic at an important point on the timeline of feminism. “People often think of the women’s rights movement as having taken place in waves,” she told Comic Book Resource. “There’s a first wave that ends with the passage of the 19th Amendment in 1920, and a second wave that begins in the ’60s, and in between those two waves, it’s as if there’s nothing going on. But once you lift the veil on the secret history of Wonder Woman, right there in the middle in the 1940s, there’s Wonder Woman, inspired by the feminism of the first half of the century, and an inspiration for the feminism in the second half.”

headline: ‘Pennyroyal Academy’ and ‘The Princess in Black’
abstract: These feisty heroines are measured by their ability to fight threatening witches and monsters.
lead_paragraph: Over the past decade or so, storybook princesses have gotten a worse rep than even the Koch brothers.

headline: ‘Gabriel,’ by Edward Hirsch
abstract: Edward Hirsch’s book-length elegy on the death of his 22-year-old son.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 2011, when Edward Hirsch’s 22-year-old son, Gabriel, died of cardiac arrest after taking a club drug at a party in Jersey City, I was writing about my 1-year-old son, Ronan, who would eventually die of Tay-Sachs disease before his third birthday. During the course of Ronan’s life, I wrote constantly, often through the night, gripped by a need to understand a world in which such suffering was possible; and also to try to mitigate my helplessness and despair by giving myself something to do. “Gabriel: A Poem” — part tribute; part existential howl; part intellectual investigation of our most primal emotions; part novella-like, buoyant, unsentimental romp through the life of Hirsch’s “wild spirit beloved son” — is the kind of wrenching, meticulous study of grief I craved at that time.

headline: ‘Taking Flight,’ by Michaela DePrince with Elaine DePrince
abstract: In this memoir, a girl adopted from war-torn Sierra Leone achieves her dream of becoming a ballerina.
lead_paragraph: “It’s a miracle I’m even here,” says Michaela DePrince in “First Position,” the 2011 documentary about aspiring ballet dancers. “Everywhere you looked, you saw someone die.” She wears a tutu and pointe shoes, about to go onstage, a picture of straight-backed ballerina calm. But the story she tells — now in greater detail in her inspiring Y.A. memoir, “Taking Flight” — is one of almost unimaginable turmoil and out-of-the-blue good fortune, much like the fairy-tale dances she now performs.

headline: ‘The Glass Cage,’ by Nicholas Carr
abstract: Nicholas Carr argues that becoming dependent on our technologies turns us into their slaves.
lead_paragraph: In his previous book, “The Shallows” — essential reading about our Internet Age — Nicholas Carr, former executive editor of the Harvard Business Review and author of several books about technology, discussed the detrimental effects the Web has on our reading, thinking and capacity for reflection. In this new book, “The Glass Cage: Automation and Us,” similarly essential if slightly repetitive, Carr explains how certain aspects of automative technology can separate us from, well, Reality. How, for all its ­miraculous-seeming benefits, automation also can and often does impair our mental and physical skills, cause dreadful mistakes and accidents, particularly in medicine and aviation, and threaten to turn the algorithms we create as servants into our mindless masters — what sci-fi movies have been warning us about for at least two or three decades now. (As Carr puts it near the end of “The Glass Cage,” when “we become dependent on our technological slaves . . . we turn into slaves ourselves.”)

headline: Ali Berman’s ‘Misdirected,’ and More
abstract: These teenagers risk alienation, and worse, when they diverge from the religious beliefs of those around them.
lead_paragraph: Atheists are a despised minority. According to a recent Pew survey, voters are warier of an atheist candidate than of a lesbian, an adulterer or an erstwhile marijuana user. At the same time, atheist pride is waxing in the United States. Atheist tracts share prominent space at airport bookstores with memoirs about dogs and inspirational volumes for aspiring C.E.O.s. Atheist campus groups are multiplying, and polls show growing numbers of Americans identifying with the label.

headline: The Big Easy
abstract: Walker Percy once said, “New Orleans may be too seductive for a writer.”
lead_paragraph: This week, Walter Isaacson reviews Gary Krist’s “Empire of Sin,” about New Orleans in the early 20th century. In the years since Hurricane Katrina, New Orleans and its fate have been the subject of many books of serious nonfiction, including Sheri Fink’s “Five Days at Memorial” and Douglas Brinkley’s “The Great Deluge,” but the city will always attract artists as much as journalists.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: LITTLE FAILURE: A Memoir,  by Gary Shteyngart. (Random House, $16.) Shteyngart’s first novel, “The Russian Debutante’s Handbook” (2002), followed the bumbling efforts of a Russian émigré grasping for a share of the American dream. Now Shteyngart recounts his own family’s move from Leningrad to Queens in 1979, and his emergence as a writer, in a memoir that our reviewer, Andy Borowitz, called “hilarious and moving.”

headline: ‘A Map of Betrayal,’ by Ha Jin
abstract: In Ha Jin’s new novel, a man drifts into the world of espionage and becomes a long-term Chinese Communist mole within the C.I.A.
lead_paragraph: Many years ago, the F.B.I. coined an acronym, MICE, to describe the motivations of the spy. This stands for Money, Ideology, Compromise and Ego. All spies, it is argued, are drawn into espionage by some combination of these factors.

headline: ‘Losing Our Way,’ by Bob Herbert
abstract: Bob Herbert documents the struggles of ordinary Americans and issues a political call to action.
lead_paragraph: My father taught me to see what was missing from neglected public spaces — the opportunities rooted in overgrown woods, trash-strewn highways and busted public parks. “You could give young people work cleaning that land, and they’d be a part of something, and learn useful skills,” he would say. During the Depression, the Civilian Conservation Corps had been his school, where he had learned how to drive a truck, build lean-tos and benches, and helped support his parents.

headline: ‘The Right Word: Roget and His Thesaurus,’ and More
abstract: The subjects of four picture-book biographies make their marks: a linguist, an engineer, an astrophysicist . . . and a movie dog.
lead_paragraph: Children, like nations, need heroes to call their own. Parson Mason Weems’s “Life of Washington” rolled off the presses in Philadelphia in 1800, mere months after the death of the father of our country, with Weems’s stated goal to inspire young Americans to emulate the great man’s shining example. We have that book to thank for the compelling image of the rambunctious 6-year-old George chopping down his father’s best cherry tree, then fessing up to his misdeed with the immortal words: “I cannot tell a lie.” The irrepressible parson, we now know, invented the scene out of whole cloth, which is certainly a tad ironic. Yet less cavalier authors than Weems have wrestled with the question of whether, or to what extent in the seemingly special case of a biography for young readers, a touch-up job might be in order. The 1940 Caldecott Medal winner, “Abraham Lincoln,” by Ingri and Edgar Parin d’Aulaire, ends with an illustration of the weary president resting contentedly in a favorite rocker, the Civil War having just come to a successful conclusion. You would never guess Lincoln had those theater tickets.

headline: Letters: ‘In Security’
abstract: Readers respond to recent reviews of James Risen’s “Pay Any Price,” Nell Zink’s “The Wallcreeper” and more.
lead_paragraph: ‘In Security’

headline: ‘Wildlife’ and ‘Even in Paradise’
abstract: These coming-of-age novels find the heady days of high school filled with friendships, secrets, romance and treachery.
lead_paragraph: Fiona Wood’s enchanting “Wildlife” has two narrators: Sibylla, former wallflower and newly minted billboard model, and Lou, a loner bereft after the death of her boyfriend. When their 10th-grade class is thrust into the Australian equivalent of an Outward Bound program, neither realizes that her new survival skills will extend way beyond campfire-building and reptile identification. Bad friends, it turns out, are more treacherous than snakes.

headline: John Darnielle’s ‘Wolf in White Van’
abstract: A fantasy role-playing game ends in death.
lead_paragraph: “I don’t believe in happy endings or even in endings at all, but I am as susceptible to moments of indulgent fantasy as anybody else,” says Sean Phillips, the traumatized narrator of John Darnielle’s arresting, enigmatic debut novel, “Wolf in White Van.” As a kid, he was especially receptive to “dark dreams” of the pulpy, “Conan the Barbarian,” blood-oath and death-wish variety. “It had a soundtrack. All screams.”

headline: ‘A World Elsewhere,’ by Sigrid MacRae
abstract: The author’s mother remained in Germany through World War II.
lead_paragraph: Aimée Ellis met Baron Heinrich Alexis Nikolai von Hoyningen-Huene in 1927, within the moment between two European catastrophes. To the casual observer, they seemed to have little in common. He was a tall, darkly handsome, high-minded Baltic-German aristocrat whose large family had served the czar loyally for generations and were then evicted from their ancestral lands by the Bolsheviks. She was an orphaned heiress from bourgeois Hartford, Conn. — shy, overconscious of her long nose (her “proboscis,” as her older brother called it), as gauche as she was eager to seize the world.

headline: ‘Censors at Work,’ by Robert Darnton
abstract: Robert Darnton probes the history of censorship and finds it isn’t always what we think it is.
lead_paragraph: The impulse to censor is as old as the impulse to create. Plato, not the most liberal of men, suggested that the work of storytellers should be carefully examined “and what they do well we must pass and what not, reject.” His purpose was to moralize literature; others, over the centuries, have offered equally noble motives. Ibn Khaldun, the great Arab historian, reported that in the seventh century, when Muslim soldiers invaded Persia, they discovered an extraordinary number of books; wishing to carry them off as loot, they asked Omar bin al-Khattab, second caliph of the Muslims, for permission. Omar’s answer became legendary and was applied to other book destructions: “Throw them in the river! If they hold a guide to the Truth, God has given us a better guide in the Holy Quran. And if they hold nothing but lies, may God rid us of them.” In our own time, the president of Turkey, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, forced Google and Twitter to remove content objected to by his government or risk blackouts, arguing that “these regulations do not impose any censorship at all on the Internet. . . . On the contrary, they make it safer and freer.” Morality, truth, civilized society, freedom: All these have been invoked to defend what most people would understand as censorship.

headline: ‘100 Sideways Miles,’ by Andrew Smith
abstract: A boy injured in a bizarre accident yearns to break free of his overprotective novelist father in this young adult novel.
lead_paragraph: In his ninth young adult book, Andrew Smith returns to the big-hearted realism of his prep school/rugby novel, “Winger,” then adds the hectic pace and catchy rhythms of his recent science fiction romp, “Grasshopper Jungle.” The result is a coming-of-age story packed with teenage angst, teenage sex (that is, thinking about sex), about 10 million arcane facts, deep metaphysical musing and great lashings of rank humor. That said, “100 Sideways Miles,” which was a semifinalist for a National Book Award, is more interior and profound than its predecessors, and possibly more beguiling.

headline: ‘Arcady’s Goal,’ by Eugene Yelchin
abstract: For Eugene Yelchin’s young hero, athletic prowess becomes a means of surviving Stalinist oppression.
lead_paragraph: Any historical event, examined from the right perspective, can resemble a children’s story. In “Arcady’s Goal,” an immensely rewarding novel by Eugene Yelchin, the protagonist’s parents are devoured in much the way the parents are devoured in “James and the Giant Peach.” Only instead of a rhino, it’s Stalin. And instead of the boy being made to live in the house of his mean aunts, he’s sent to a home for the offspring of “enemies of the state.” At the risk of seeming to equate the evils of the 20th century with the fiction of Roald Dahl: If you were born, say, in the early 2000s, the fate of a boy like Arcady might seem just as strange and unreal as anything cooked up by a fabulist from the middle of the last century.

headline: A Manual for Life
abstract: The author credits the official guide of the Boy Scouts of America for his secondary education.
lead_paragraph: I read only two books cover to cover during high school. The first was Owen Wister’s “The Virginian,” which I found gathering dust in the parlor of the old Wilson house on Charleston Street in Mobile, Ala. Wister, along with issues of Collier’s, Life magazine, Reader’s Digest and the yellow-tinted Mobile Press-Register, made up the household literature. There was a public library a few blocks north of us on Government Street, but I never thought of going there. Libraries were not part of the culture in which I was raised.

headline: Jane Smiley’s ‘Some Luck’
abstract: Jane Smiley’s novel, the first in a planned trilogy, follows an Iowa family over three transformative decades in America.
lead_paragraph: Before Marilynne Robinson’s Iowa, there was Jane Smiley’s. While Robinson, already revered as the author of “Housekeeping,” was taking a long pause from publishing to teach at the Iowa Writers’ Workshop, Smiley wrote “A Thousand Acres,” a story of an Iowa farm family in extremis that won the Pulitzer Prize. While Robinson was writing “Gilead,” her own Pulitzer winner, and two subsequent novels about Iowa church people and their descendants, Smiley was shaking off the Heartland-Author tag with novels about real estate and tax evasion (“Good Faith”), Hollywood (“Ten Days in the Hills”) and a military wife transplanted from Missouri to San Francisco (“Private Life”). With a short biography of Dickens, she invited us to see her, like him, as a writer whose work is defined by its energy and range rather than its settings and subject matter. With a whistle-stop tour of 100 novels (“Thirteen Ways of Looking at the Novel”), she lined up with Henry James and John Updike as a writer who offsets her own fiction with spot-on commentary about other people’s work. So it’s appropriate to turn to “Some Luck” — the first novel in a projected trilogy about Iowa farm people and their descendants — by way of Smiley’s critical insights.

headline: ‘As an Oak Tree Grows,’ and More
abstract: Three picture books appeal to children’s fascination with trees, providing information and flights of imagination.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, we had a young neighbor who, walking to school, would stop by her favorite trees and ask what kind of morning they were having, maybe chat for a bit. She was a regular second grader and she talked to trees. I don’t think she’s the only one. Trees have always played a central role in the lives and minds of our species. Researchers tell us that surgical patients heal faster when their windows look out on trees and children do better in school when they can see green spaces. When the famous Treaty Oak in Austin, Tex., was poisoned in 1989, kids made hundreds of cards and placed them under the tree. Not all kids live near historic oaks, but most care about trees, and wonder about them. Books about trees speak to that wondering.

headline: Johanna Skibsrud’s ‘Quartet for the End of Time’
abstract: From Washington to Paris, four interwoven characters grapple with guilt and injustice.
lead_paragraph: Incarcerated in the German prisoner-of-war camp Stalag VIII-A in 1940, the French composer Olivier Messiaen set down what he called “Quatuor Pour la Fin du Temps,” the “Quartet for the End of Time.” It was first performed in January 1941 before a freezing audience of prisoners and German guards. The reception was said to have been respectful if bemused. As the critic Alex Ross later explained: “By 1941, this composer no longer wanted to hear time being beaten out by a drum — one, two, three, four; he had had enough of that in the war. Instead, he devised rhythms that expanded, contracted, stopped in their tracks and rolled back in symmetrical patterns.” The quartet, Ross observed, is “the most ethereally beautiful music of the 20th century.”

headline: ‘The Laughing Monsters,’ by Denis Johnson
abstract: In Denis Johnson’s new novel, set in Africa, a spy and his ne’er-do-well friend plan to become rich by exploiting post-9/11 politics.
lead_paragraph: On the plane I was reading this book.

headline: Christopher Paul Curtis’s ‘Madman of Piney Woods’
abstract: In a small Canadian town in 1901, boys from very different backgrounds meet, bond and solve a mystery together.
lead_paragraph: Rarely have I read a children’s book so suspenseful that it’s made me worry about being stranded in the weeds with the bleak, hateful aspects of human nature. But Christopher Paul Curtis’s “The Madman of Piney Woods” did just that. Again and again, I doubted that what would happen next would be O.K. for young and old readers alike. Yet at every turn of this middle-grade novel, a “companion book” to the Newbery Honor-winning “Elijah of Buxton,” Curtis deftly makes what might have been simply heart-rending hopeful and redeeming instead.

headline: ‘Ambassador’ and ‘Lowriders in Space’
abstract: Latino characters take readers on a journey into the cosmos in these middle-grade books.
lead_paragraph: Like a bad haircut, the word “alien” has affixed itself to the popular perception of what it means to be Latino in the United States. To the unworldly, the average working person of Latin American descent looks like an “illegal alien.” For decades Latino comedians have been making satirical commentary on the absurdity (and cruelty) of using the same word to describe people with Spanish surnames and slimy creatures from other worlds, and now William Alexander has given us a middle-grade novel that stretches out the joke for an entire book. Alexander, who won a National Book Award for his 2012 novel “Goblin Secrets,” merges the fantastic with the ­everyday to create an engaging and smart allegory about the hurt and strangeness of the modern immigrant condition.

headline: ‘How Google Works,’ by Eric Schmidt and Jonathan Rosenberg
abstract: Two technology executives explain the business methods behind Google’s groundbreaking success.
lead_paragraph: There is a footnote on Page 3 of the new book by Google’s executive chairman, Eric Schmidt, and its former vice president of products, Jonathan Rosenberg, that should set readers’ expectations suitably low. The authors are describing Schmidt’s first years as C.E.O., when the board of directors was consumed with worry about its most formidable competitor, Microsoft. Back then Google employees, the authors write, referred to their archrival by a secret code name: “Finland.” It seems like a fresh if somewhat inexplicable detail, until the eye wanders down to the bottom of the page and this disclaimer: “In fact, ‘Finland’ is a code name for the code name we actually used. If we used the actual code name in this book, it wouldn’t be much of a code name, would it?”

headline: ‘Afterworlds,’ by Scott Westerfeld
abstract: This young adult novel’s 18-year-old protagonist is the author of her own young adult novel about life after death.
lead_paragraph: Scott Westerfeld’s semi-supernatural novel “Afterworlds” beckons us into a universe where dutiful drones, pale from sun deprivation, spend long, lonely days toiling at an irksome task in order to prove their worth. The challenges they face are many, and their chances of survival, let alone success, are low. Though these worker bees occasionally bond with others of their ilk, they’re really on their own, forever outrunning the authority figures who regularly swoop down to assess their accomplishments and mete out punishment accordingly. The stakes are high: If the denizens of this universe fail, they’ll be dropped into the black hole of obscurity where, unless they can claw their way out, they’ll languish forever.

headline: ‘The Doubt Factory’ and ‘Love Is the Drug’
abstract: Two young adult thrillers exploit the conventions of genre to offer head-on critiques of today’s political landscape.
lead_paragraph: To be a teenager is to be acutely aware of power, in all its forms — by virtue of having so frustratingly little of it. Which means adolescent protagonists impose a limiting factor on political fiction. Young adult authors looking to vent their political spleen commonly circumvent this with one of two routes: They embrace George Eliot’s reminder that “there is no private life which has not been determined by a wider public life,” filtering political exigencies through the lens of personal experience and mapping out the Machiavellian power plays of home and high school. Or they turn to science fiction and fantasy and play politics to their heart’s content: There’s no believability ceiling to how teenagers in futuristic societies can change their worlds.

headline: ‘In Real Life,’ by Cory Doctorow and Jen Wang
abstract: A teenager joins an all-female online group and is given a troubling assignment with real-world repercussions.
lead_paragraph: Games have unintended consequences, good and bad. Their mini-marketplaces and ersatz economies are just as hard to predict as their real-world counterparts. Anyone who has suffered family fallout over an evening of Monopoly, or lost sleep over a Fantasy Football roster, knows this all too well.

headline: From Adolescent Mysticism to Hardheaded Experiments
abstract: A look at new sounds from Willow Smith, Grouper, 2:54 and Ashley Paul.
lead_paragraph: Willow Smith

headline: In Texas, Preserving a Neighborhood for Bats
abstract: A $20.5 million land purchase near San Antonio will keep the runway for 20 million Mexican free-tail bats clear of human neighbors.
lead_paragraph: At dusk, 20 million Mexican free-tail bats would pour from the darkness inside Bracken Cave on the outskirts of San Antonio, Tex., in a skillfully crafted black tornado against the dimming orange sunset. But a few thousand feet away, directly in their flight path, a community of 3,500 homes would soon stand.

headline: Dependent Care Accounts, Hamstrung by Limits, Are Still Worth Exploring
abstract: The $5,000 set-aside can be used for some babysitting, after-school programs and even summer day camp. The cap hasn’t increased since 1986, however.
lead_paragraph: If you work for an employer with a standard slate of benefits, perhaps you got the note last week. In 2015, you can put an extra $50 away in your health care flexible spending account on top of the $2,500 you could deposit this year. Every bit of tax savings counts, right?

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: This week’s properties include a co-op in Yorkville, a Condop in Kips Bay, and a two family house in Kensington.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties in New York City:

headline: On the Market in the New York Region
abstract: This week’s properties include a horse farm in North Branch, N.J., and a six-bedroom house in Glen Cove, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties in the New York region:

headline: F.B.I. Is Investigating Retired U.S. Diplomat, a Pakistan Expert, Officials Say
abstract: F.B.I. counterintelligence agents have searched the home and office of Robin L. Raphel, a veteran American diplomat, but have not said whether she was a target of their investigation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — F.B.I. counterintelligence agents are investigating a veteran American diplomat suspected of taking classified information home from the State Department, and have searched her house and office for evidence, government officials said Friday.

headline: Bellying Up to a Different Bar
abstract: The bar at Trattoria Bolu doesn’t have a bartender, or bottles of liquor, but it has antipasti, made fresh, where the beer taps would be.
lead_paragraph: Every time I walk into Trattoria Bolu, the first thing I notice is the bar. It’s striking, though it doesn’t have a bartender, or even bottles of liquor. What it does have is antipasti, made fresh, right there where the beer taps would be.

headline: Weekend Auto Calendar: Tractor Time in the Hawkeye State
abstract: Mecum Auctions plans to sell 250 vintage tractors at its sale in Davenport, Iowa; Brazil hosts the penultimate Formula One race of the 2014 season.
lead_paragraph: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend:

headline: Nissan Recalls 6,600 Infiniti Hybrids for Unintended Acceleration Problem
abstract: The automaker says a software problem is affecting some Infiniti M35, Q50 and Q70 hybrids from the 2013-15 model years.
lead_paragraph: Nissan is recalling almost 6,600 Infiniti hybrid vehicles for an unintended acceleration problem that the company says is caused by a software problem, according to a report posted Friday on the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration website.

headline: When Library Time Means Screen Time
abstract: I was hoping my 4-year-old would see the library as I once did, as a hushed building full of endless promise. Instead, it’s become an arcade.
lead_paragraph: Lately, my 4-year-old and I have been having a conflict about the library. One of us wants to go. This is not a debate that is playing out according to plan.

headline: Going Topless, Tig Notaro Takes Over Town Hall
abstract: Comedians often show their scars, but never so literally as when Ms. Notaro revealed her double-mastectomy scars to a New York audience.
lead_paragraph: Tig Notaro couldn’t possibly deliver a stand-up act as bold as her last one, right?

headline: Today in Small Business: Paternity Leave
abstract: The economy is producing steady gains on jobs. Oyster farming is booming. And here’s why the new soda tax in Berkeley, Calif., may not reduce obesity.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: New York Plants Curbside Gardens to Soak Up Storm-Water Runoff
abstract: The city, as part of a $2.4 billion project to protect waterways, will add thousands of street-side plots in the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens in the coming months.
lead_paragraph: The gardens appeared suddenly along an industrial corridor of Brownsville, Brooklyn — one, two, a half-dozen — as if airlifted from a cul-de-sac upstate.

headline: Maisonette on the River
abstract: At 1 Sutton Place South, one of two maisonettes at the 1927 riverside co-op is for sale for $10.25 million.
lead_paragraph: An apartment at 1 Sutton Place South is poised to enter the market at $10.25 million. It is one of two maisonettes at the 1927 riverside co-op, which was designed by Rosario Candela with Cross & Cross as the architect/builder. The maintenance fee, paid four times a year, as per the building’s somewhat unusual tradition — cash-only sales are another — is $26,838.63 a quarter.

headline: Latest Hotel Amenity: A Magazine
abstract: The Standard hotel group is publishing Standard Culture, a print version of its cultural website.
lead_paragraph: The Standard, a chain of five boutique hotels with properties in Los Angeles, New York City and Miami, has introduced a print edition of its cultural website, standardculture.com.

headline: The Rubber Meets the Mud: Trying Out a New BFGoodrich Off-Road Tire
abstract: The company says that its new All-Terrain T/A KO2 will work as well on the highway as on the trail.
lead_paragraph: HUNTER, N.Y. — A vehicle — any vehicle — is only as good as its tires. That maxim is especially true for the generally poor driving conditions encountered when the wheels leave a paved surface. Mud, rocks and wet leaves reduce traction, and forward progress bogs down when the wheels begin spinning.

headline: Supreme Court to Hear New Health Law Challenge
abstract: The Supreme Court on Friday agreed to hear a new challenge to the Affordable Care Act, imperiling President Obama’s signature legislative achievement two years after it survived a separate Supreme Court challenge by a single vote.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court on Friday agreed to hear a new challenge to the Affordable Care Act, imperiling President Obama’s signature legislative achievement two years after it survived a separate Supreme Court challenge by a single vote.

headline: Government Shows Growth, After Years of Shrinking
abstract: The end of the early Obama administration’s stimulus program brought years of shrinking spending by governments, which is just now beginning to grow again, slowly.
lead_paragraph: THE government is growing. Finally.

headline: Book Review Podcast: ‘Empire of Sin’
abstract: Gary Krist discusses “Empire of Sin” and Maria Russo talks about this week’s Children’s Books section.
lead_paragraph: In The New York Times Book Review, Walter Isaacson reviews Gary Krist’s “Empire of Sin,” about Storyville, a district on the edge of New Orleans’s French Quarter, in the early 20th century. Mr. Isaacson writes:

headline: Justices to Hear New Challenge to Health Law
abstract: The Supreme Court will consider whether the Affordable Care Act allows tax subsidies in those states that did not set up exchanges for people to select their health insurance.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Friday agreed to hear a new challenge to the Affordable Care Act, potentially imperiling President Obama’s signature legislative achievement two years after it survived a different Supreme Court challenge by a single vote.

headline: Home Sales Around the New York Region
abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: First Draft Focus: Leaders Who Lunch
abstract: President Obama has lunch with Speaker John Boehner, Senator Mitch McConnell and other members.
lead_paragraph: On the Menu:

headline: Bank Audit in Europe Cuts Doubt, Yellen Says
