abstract: The Federal Reserve chairwoman, speaking in Paris, appeared to disagree with critics who have questioned the rigor of a recent eurozone audit.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Janet L. Yellen, chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, on Friday praised a recent review of eurozone banks, saying it would help remove doubts about the integrity of the financial system.

headline: Bank Regulators Warn Again on Leveraged Loans
abstract: As part of an annual review of bank lending, three federal agencies sharply criticize a type of loan that Wall Street firms have been making to companies with low credit ratings.
lead_paragraph: Bank regulators continue to sound the alarm about a type of debt that has become a hot product on Wall Street in recent years.

headline: Facebook Makes Its News Feed a Little Less Frustrating
abstract: The social network rolled out new tools Friday to give users more control over what they see on its main screen. Facebook has made improving its news feed a top priority, and more changes are coming soon.
lead_paragraph: Facebook’s news feed, the main screen that shows you what your friends are doing, is the heart of the service. Yet the mysteries of why things do and don’t show up in each person’s news feed have confounded users of the social network ever since the feature was introduced in 2006.

headline: Joan Jett for Hot Topic, Zanini No More and Lea T’s Tresses
abstract: Plus, Galliano pays up, at home with Kate Moss and more from the week in style.
lead_paragraph: All the week’s fashion news that’s fit to reprint.

headline: The Raging Bulls on Wall Street, Charity Division
abstract: Wall Street executives have no doubt used the language of the sweet science, but several of them got a taste of the real thing on Thursday, entering the ring to raise money for cancer research.
lead_paragraph: Leon D. Black, the billionaire financier, watched silently as his son administered a flurry of punches.

headline: U.S.D.A. Approves Modified Potato. Next Up: French Fry Fans.
abstract: The so-called Innate potato, which produces less of a cancer-causing chemical when it is fried, was developed by a major McDonald’s supplier.
lead_paragraph: A potato genetically engineered to reduce the amounts of a potentially harmful ingredient in French fries and potato chips has been approved for commercial planting, the Department of Agriculture announced on Friday.

headline: Seeing the Whole of Antigua
abstract: Thousands of visitors are drawn to this island for its beaches and resorts, but a more complicated story awaits those willing to dig a little deeper.
lead_paragraph: Antigua lets you in slowly. It reveals itself cautiously, at its own unhurried pace. You’ll miss it if you turn away too quickly.

headline: Independent Projects Unveils New Art Fair Concept: A Show
abstract: Independent Projects features work by Yves Klein among its 40 solo shows, which go from art fair to exhibition over the next week.
lead_paragraph: The art fair has become a primary vehicle for viewing and selling art, but this doesn’t mean it’s a static form. Independent Projects, a hybrid art fair and exhibition installed in the former Dia Art Foundation space on West 22nd Street in Chelsea, is a welcome mutation. With 40 solo shows, it’s a fair this weekend, but on Monday, the gallerists’ tables will disappear, and docents (just as in museums) will arrive. Best of all for artists and students, the Independent is free.

headline: A Seafood Spot Is Reopened, but Not Remade
abstract: A reopened seafood restaurant has new owners and a new chef, but stays true to its past.
lead_paragraph: When a popular restaurant is sold, it is natural to wonder what changes, if any, to expect. Will the new owners close the place indefinitely for extensive remodeling? How much of the previous menu will be retained? What kind of turnover will there be in the staff?

headline: Hello, Green Man
abstract: Some older people with impaired vision begin to see people and objects that aren’t there. It’s not dementia, but a condition called Charles Bonnet Syndrome.
lead_paragraph: A few days after I wrote about conditions that can mimic dementia, reader Sue Murray emailed me from Westchester County. Her subject line: “Have you heard of Charles Bonnet Syndrome?”

headline: Low-Level Employee at Dewey & LeBoeuf to Get Separate Criminal Trial
abstract: Zachary Warren, a client relations manager at Dewey & LeBoeuf, will now be tried after the main defendants, three top executives at the law firm.
lead_paragraph: A former low-level employee at the law firm Dewey & LeBoeuf will be tried separately on criminal charges arising from the collapse of  the once-mighty New York firm and not stand trial with three of its former top executives.

headline: A Drink as Red as Congress
abstract: Toasting an election full of surprises with a Chicago Fizz, from a state that’s traditionally Democratic — but just elected a Republican governor.
lead_paragraph: There’s only one color appropriate for this week’s cocktail: red — as in, Republican red. The G.O.P. had an even better week than almost any forecaster expected, taking the Senate by a comfortable margin, gaining seats in the House and winning governorships even in blue states like Massachusetts, Maryland and Illinois.

headline: Election Stuff We Liked: From the Great to the Ingrates
abstract: Sticking with an election theme, The Upshot staff found several thought-provoking and visually appealing items on the web this week.
lead_paragraph: Sticking with this newsletter’s election theme, The Upshot staff found several thought-provoking and visually appealing items on the web this week.

headline: Letter From the Editor: The Story of Culpeper
abstract: We appreciate all of the reader reaction to our new election-night vote tracker. We also want to tell you about Culpeper County, Va.
lead_paragraph: Watching raw-vote counts has long been the only way for most people to follow election night. And it’s deeply unsatisfying. In some states, like Iowa, Democratic areas report their votes first, making the Democrat seem ahead even when he’s not. In other states, like Virginia, the opposite is true. That’s why we introduced a new way to watch election returns this year — with vote counts adjusted for geography — and we’re deeply gratified by the response from readers and other analysts.

headline: A Once-Skeptical Colorado Town Embraces Marijuana Legalization
abstract: Gunnison, Colo., will allow recreational and medical sales.
lead_paragraph: Gunnison, Colo. (pop. 5,800), profiled this summer in The Times’s series on legalizing marijuana, was the little town that wasn’t sure about weed.

headline: Gorillas in the Crossfire
abstract: A national park ranger in the Democratic Republic of Congo struggles to protect gorillas from a brutal civil war.
lead_paragraph: A national park ranger in the Democratic Republic of Congo struggles to protect gorillas from a brutal civil war.

headline: ‘Gorillas in the Crossfire’
abstract: A national park ranger in the Democratic Republic of Congo struggles to protect gorillas from a brutal civil war.
lead_paragraph: In a national park in the Democratic Republic of Congo, a caretaker struggles to save gorillas from the violence of a brutal civil war.

headline: ‘Grand Bargain’ Saves the Detroit Institute of Arts
abstract: A “grand bargain” to help save pensions also ends a threat to the Detroit Institute of Arts, a danger with roots going back nearly a century.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — With his decision on Friday approving this city’s federal bankruptcy plan, Judge Steven W. Rhodes — aided by nearly a billion dollars in private and state rescue money — ended an unprecedented threat to the Detroit Institute of Arts, whose world-class paintings and sculpture could have been parceled off at auction to help pay city debt.

headline: Ed Gillespie, Republican Challenger for Senate in Virginia, Concedes
abstract: Ed Gillespie, the Republican candidate for Senate in Virginia, said the the gap of 16,700 votes was too great to make up in a recount.
lead_paragraph: Ed Gillespie, the Republican candidate in Virginia who surprised nearly everyone by running a photo-finish race with Senator Mark R. Warner, conceded on Friday, saying the gap of 16,700 votes was too great to make up in a recount.

headline: Clinton Accuser Returns as N.C.A.A. Defender
abstract: College sports have given Kenneth W. Starr, now president of Baylor, a second act in public life, as a major player in the debate over the compensation of athletes.
lead_paragraph: WACO, Tex. — Kenneth W. Starr stepped onto Baylor’s football field before a game last month wearing a track suit. He looked in better shape — less paunchy, less stressed — than he did more than 15 years ago, when he became famous for investigating a sitting president.

headline: Senators Seek Inquiry of Takata Airbag Accusations
abstract: The senators were responding to a New York Times article quoting former employees of the company who said Takata discounted airbag safety issues.
lead_paragraph: Three senators are calling for a criminal investigation of the airbag maker Takata after two former employees reported that it had carried out tests on airbags over a decade ago and found signs of defects, yet erased computer files containing data and threw away tested airbags.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Interstellar’
abstract: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Interstellar.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Interstellar.”

headline: Book Offers a New  Overview of Nick Drake
abstract: “Remembered for a While” is a compilation of essays and memorabilia edited by Gabrielle Drake, the singer’s sister, and Cally Callomon, the manager of his musical estate.
lead_paragraph: The singer and songwriter Nick Drake had scant success in his lifetime, despite enthusiastic reviews and a following among English folksingers in the late 1960s and early 1970s. After three albums that sold only modestly, he was dropped by his label, and he died in 1974, at 26, of an overdose of antidepressant drugs. Since his death, however, Drake’s music has won a large and still growing following, not least among young listeners tuned to the emotional fragility of his songs, and attracted by the romantic image of a darkly mysterious, sensitive songwriter who died too young.

headline: Movie Review: ‘National Gallery’
abstract: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “National Gallery.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “National Gallery.”

headline: Movie Review: ‘Big Hero 6’
abstract: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Big Hero 6.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Big Hero 6.”

headline: A Glutton for Ridicule Returns
abstract: Lisa Kudrow returns as a self-absorbed actress in a revived version of “The Comeback,” on HBO.
lead_paragraph: “The Comeback” has come back.

headline: Slower Cabs, and Safer Children: New York City Reduces Speed Limit to 25
abstract: The families of young victims of traffic violence advocated for a slower speed limit in New York City, and won. Not everyone is happy about it.
lead_paragraph: On Nov. 2, 2013, one year and five days ago, my son’s friend Lucian was killed by a reckless driver in Brooklyn.

headline: Unraveling, in Slow Motion
abstract: After nearly 20 years of marriage, David Grah and Mary Daniel, college sweethearts, divorced and have begun making new lives for themselves.
lead_paragraph: After nearly two decades of marriage, David Grah and Mary Daniel, college sweethearts, divorced and have begun new lives. They agree that they are now better matched to others.

headline: Where a Talker Sleeps
abstract: Leonard Lopate, the talk show host, and his wife, Melanie Baker, an artist, live in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Leonard Lopate, the eponymous host of a long-running talk show on the public radio station WNYC, was born and bred in Brooklyn, even staying put there for college. Though he eventually decamped, living briefly in Rockland County, then for 30 years in Manhattan, he returned to the borough of his birth in 2000 after his first marriage ended.

headline: Indian Army Takes Responsibility for Killing 2 Civilians in Kashmir
abstract: The army called the shooting at a checkpoint a case of mistaken identity.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The Indian Army on Friday took responsibility for the killing of two teenagers in the Indian-administered portion of Kashmir this week, calling it a case of mistaken identity.

headline: Cornbread That Gets the Most Out of Butter
abstract: For a more tender, flavorful, crisp-edged cornbread, brown your butter and bake in a hot skillet. (Article plus video.)
lead_paragraph: Some cornbread falls on the light and fluffy side of the spectrum, sweet enough to pass for dessert. Then there is crisp, lean and salty cornbread, nearly as savory as the fried chicken that often goes with it.

headline: Brown Butter Skillet Cornbread
abstract: Melissa Clark bakes tender, flavorful cornbread in a cast-iron pan.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Clark bakes tender, flavorful cornbread in a cast-iron pan.

headline: Obama Seeks to Work With New Congress
abstract: Before a lunch meeting with Republican congressional leaders, President Obama said he was interested in setting aside partisanship to work on areas of common interest.
lead_paragraph: Before a lunch meeting with Republican congressional leaders, President Obama said he was interested in setting aside partisanship to work on areas of common interest.

headline: Dave Grohl’s ‘Sonic Highways’
abstract: Ben Ratliff and Jon Caramanica discuss “Sonic Highways,” the new album and HBO mini-series by Dave Grohl and the Foo Fighters.
lead_paragraph: Ben Ratliff and Jon Caramanica discuss “Sonic Highways,” the new album and HBO mini-series by Dave Grohl and the Foo Fighters.

headline: Ukraine Accuses Russia of Sending Tanks Across Border
abstract: A Ukrainian military spokesman said a Russian convoy had crossed into the Luhansk region to bolster separatists, but offered no clear evidence to support the claim.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Ukraine accused Russia on Friday of dispatching tanks, troops and other weaponry across the border to bolster separatists who control a small eastern portion of Ukraine, the latest in a series of charges and countercharges that are gradually undermining a tenuous peace plan signed two months ago.

headline: All Not Right in Sears REIT Plan
abstract: A REIT sale and lease-back would raise much-needed cash. But the prospects for the rump retailer remain pretty dim, Kevin Allison of Reuters Breakingviews writes.
lead_paragraph: Sears Holdings investors are too giddy about the money-losing retailer’s slow-motion breakup. Shares of Edward S. Lampert’s struggling store chain jumped 35 percent by early Friday afternoon on the news that it may create a real estate investment trust for many of its stores and lease them back. The move would raise significant cash, but shareholders, Mr. Lampert included, would finance the deal. And the prospects for the rump retailer remain pretty dim.

headline: Defying Soviets, Then Pulling Hungary to Putin
abstract: After helping topple communism in Eastern Europe in 1989, Prime Minister Victor Orban of Hungary has come to question Western values.
lead_paragraph: BUDAPEST — A quarter-century ago, as Hungary helped ignite the events that would lead to the collapse of communism, the ferment produced a new political star.

headline: Tackling Cavities in India’s Slums with Xylitol Gum
abstract: Can a gum reduce tooth decay in urban slums? Sweet Bites, formed by five friends from the University of Pennsylvania, is trying to do just that.
lead_paragraph: During Morgan Snyder’s year of volunteering at an education charity in Bangalore, she noticed that many of the children complained of toothaches. Teachers told her that kids were missing sessions because of dental health problems, and that many did not brush more than once a day, and poorly at that. Her well-educated local friends didn’t like going to the dentist, and she observed that a culture of regular dental check ups did not exist in India.

headline: How Many Soldiers Were Exposed to Chemical Weapons in Iraq?
abstract: More than 600 American service members have come forward.
lead_paragraph: One of the more scandalous secrets from America’s decade in Iraq is coming to light.

headline: Obama Praises Latest Jobs Figures
abstract: Speaking before a cabinet meeting, President Obama said that the economy had experienced the strongest job growth since the 1990s, and that the unemployment rate was at a six-year low.
lead_paragraph: Speaking before a cabinet meeting, President Obama said that the economy had experienced the strongest job growth since the 1990s, and that the unemployment rate was at a six-year low.

headline: With Deal, Staff at 2 Struggling Schools in Brooklyn Must Reapply for Jobs
abstract: The agreement between the de Blasio administration and the teachers’ and principals’ unions came just before a deadline for the city to submit plans to the state for turning around the institutions.
lead_paragraph: The de Blasio administration said on Friday that it would require the entire staff at two of New York City’s lowest performing schools to reapply for their jobs next year, the result of a deal with the teachers’ and principals’ union that came just before a state deadline.

headline: Fate: The Family Matchmaker
abstract: Kelly Aronowitz Katz and Andrew Swartz were married Oct. 26, at Tarrytown House Estate in Tarrytown, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: Kelly Aronowitz Katz and Andrew Swartz were married Oct. 26, at Tarrytown House Estate in Tarrytown, N.Y.

headline: Popcast: Dave Grohl’s ‘Sonic Highways’
abstract: Ben Ratliff and Jon Caramanica discuss the new album and HBO series by Dave Grohl and the Foo Fighters.
lead_paragraph: HBO is currently in the middle of showing an eight-part series about American music called “Sonic Highways.” Its host and director is Dave Grohl, leader of the Foo Fighters, whose new album of the same name comes out next Monday.

headline: George Condo Creates Portraits in Action
abstract: The artist’s newest work, partially inspired by Willem de Kooning, emphasizes complex layering techniques that obscure the paintings’ subjects.
lead_paragraph: Last June, the Metropolitan Museum of Art asked the artist George Condo to participate in a discussion on Willem de Kooning. In the course of his research on de Kooning, Condo read several texts by the art critic Harold Rosenberg and became inspired by the concept of “action painting” — the term Rosenberg coined to describe the intense, almost performative energy the Abstract Expressionists used to paint their canvases. Condo experimented with that idea while creating his newest body of work earlier this year in his East Hampton studio. “They coalesced into the form of a portrait, rather than just a sort of abstract painting,” Condo says. That series, which he calls “action portraits,” is on view from Nov. 8 to Dec. 20, in a 12-piece exhibition titled “Double Heads / Black Paintings / Abstractions” at Skarstedt’s Chelsea location.

headline: Called by Destiny, Like Generations Before Them
abstract: Ten days, four dates and dozens of phone calls later, the couple was engaged after a first date through a matchmaker operating in New York’s subways.
lead_paragraph: From childhood, Kelly Aronowitz Katz had heard the story of how her maternal grandparents met. It was 1939 and her grandmother’s family was visiting Poland from Palestine, then under British Mandate, when war broke out. They left for home and landed temporarily in Istanbul, where they stayed in a hotel packed with refugees.

headline: Nascar’s Kurt Busch Is Focus of Domestic Assault Inquiry
abstract: Busch’s former companion Patricia Driscoll said the accusations involved an episode in his motor home at a race in Dover, Del., in September.
lead_paragraph: Add Nascar to the list of sports organizations now having to manage domestic violence accusations against one of their stars. The police in Dover, Del., released a statement Friday saying that Kurt Busch, the 2004 Cup champion and the driver of the No. 41 Chevrolet for the high-profile Stewart-Haas Racing team, was under investigation on suspicion of domestic assault.

headline: Do You Have Questions About Thanksgiving?
abstract: Join Sam Sifton and Melissa Clark for a Q. and A. on Monday, Nov. 10, at 1 p.m. Eastern time, on The New York Times Facebook page.
lead_paragraph: What kind of turkey are you roasting this year? Or are you braising? Or frying? Are you set on how to do that? What about dressing, side dishes, gravy, wine, how to say grace (whether to say grace!), the timing, the desserts, the fact that you said you’d make delicata squash and now you’re looking at the things and realize you have no idea how to make delicata squash?

headline: Obama to Send 1,500 More Troops to Assist Iraq
abstract: The deployment will double the number of Americans meant to train and advise Iraqi and Kurdish forces as they plan a major offensive against Islamic State fighters who have poured into Iraq from Syria.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama has authorized the deployment of an additional 1,500 American troops to Iraq in the coming months, doubling the number of Americans meant to train and advise Iraqi and Kurdish forces.

headline: What’s at Stake in Supreme Court’s Latest Health Care Case
abstract: King v. Burwell could have big implications for middle-income people in 36 states, but it is not a threat to the entire law.
lead_paragraph: Unlike the Obamacare case the Supreme Court decided in 2012, the one it took Friday, King v. Burwell, isn’t a threat to the entire Affordable Care Act. But it could be a threat to health insurance that the law has provided to millions of Americans in 36 states.

headline: For Black 47, the Pipes Are Calling
abstract: Black 47, a band known for its Irish roots, New York City grit and political activism, is calling it quits after 25 years, 14 albums and 2,300 performances.
lead_paragraph: Larry Kirwan stood at the microphone in his well-traveled green suede shoes. Fighting bronchitis, he sipped his Jameson’s whiskey with honey and surveyed the crowd. His band, Black 47, has had 2,300 performances over the years. It moved from humble origins playing in Irish pubs in the Bronx to appearing on David Letterman’s show and playing in stadiums.

headline: What Our Kindle Reading Says About Us
abstract: Data on the most-highlighted passages in Kindle books reveals a penchant for advice. Are we all reading fiction as self-help?
lead_paragraph: “The wide world is all about you: you can fence yourselves in, but you cannot for ever fence it out.”

headline: You ‘Can’t Imagine Life Without Kids’? I Can.
abstract: If I want to grocery shop, there is the Leo Factor — will a bagel appease him, or will this require juice? I fantasize about not needing to consider that, and that doesn’t make me unworthy of being a parent.
lead_paragraph: “How was your sister’s baby shower?” I asked my friend Steph. She was gathering muddy clothes off the floor and wiping dried yogurt from the table while our 4-year-old sons hammered a plank of wood to bits in the front yard.

headline: A Week of the Tried-and-True
abstract: In today’s episode of “The Triumph of the Well-Stocked Kitchen,” our heroine runs out of bread and chicken broth, but is able to save the day on both occasions. The exciting weekly cooking routine of this mother of four.
lead_paragraph: In today’s episode of “The Triumph of the Well-Stocked Kitchen,” our heroine runs out of bread and chicken broth, but is able to save the day on both occasions! Thank you, loaf-of-sandwich-bread-from-the-freezer, for this morning’s toast and lunch PBJs, and thank you, “Better Than Bouillon” for the butternut squash soup that we will be eating tonight. Also, a gold star for me (and I had better buy another loaf of bread to throw in the freezer, that was a great save).

headline: Cigna Agrees to Reduce H.I.V. Drug Costs for Some Florida Patients
abstract: Under the settlement with Florida regulators, the insurer will limit to $200 a month what patients have to pay for some commonly prescribed drugs..
lead_paragraph: The health insurer Cigna has agreed to reduce the out-of-pocket costs that patients in Florida must pay for H.I.V. drugs, settling a complaint filed by advocacy groups, who said the drug pricing system in the state’s health care plans was discriminatory.

headline: Jon Stewart Sells TriBeCa Penthouse for $17.5 Million
abstract: Jon Stewart’s sale of his TriBeCa penthouse was the top residential real estate transaction of the week.
lead_paragraph: A sophisticated penthouse at 161 Hudson Street, configured as a duplex loft with 2,000 square feet of outdoor options and nearly 6,000 square feet of interior space, sold for $17.5 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records. The voluminous unit, No. 9A/8B, with more than 40 windows providing exposures in three directions, had been owned since 2005 by the television pundit Jon Stewart, the host of “The Daily Show.”

headline: Democrats Say Economic Message Was Lacking
abstract: The focus on issues such as those affecting women provided no broader vision to inspire voters to turn out.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For all the finger-pointing among Democrats over Tuesday’s election calamity, the White House, Congress and party establishment all share responsibility for weaknesses that the defeats laid bare, critics say, and should confront them as the 2016 contest takes shape.

headline: Doorknob to Doorknob With the Coupon Crew
abstract: Each week, small crews of workers fan out across New York to deliver advertising circulars full of coupons known as mailers.
lead_paragraph: The battered white van came to a stop outside Knickerbocker Village, a middle-income housing complex on the Lower East Side, carrying five workers who sat knee-deep in the printed advertising circulars known as mailers. On the ride from a warehouse in East New York, Brooklyn, they had folded hundreds of mailers and stuffed them into individual plastic delivery bags.

headline: Leelee Sobieski, Zoë Kravitz and Other A-List Patrons at the Dior Sponsored Guggenheim Gala
abstract: Dior sponsored the Guggenheim’s big fall gala, held in the museum’s landmark rotunda.
lead_paragraph: Dior sponsored the Guggenheim’s big fall gala, held in the museum’s landmark rotunda.

headline: Pampered Baby Knows How to Crawl
abstract: The GLA, which shares much of its innards with the least expensive Mercedes automobile, the CLA-Class, enters a growing segment of small luxury S.U.V.s from other automakers.
lead_paragraph: STEWARTSTOWN, N.H. — When Robert Reed and his family turned their all-terrain vehicles onto a dirt trail in far northern New Hampshire, he was surprised to see tracks from a bigger machine. The rough trail is typically used only by riders of all-terrain vehicles frolicking on a new 1,000-mile regional network of A.T.V. trails called Ride the Wilds.

headline: 2015 Mercedes-Benz GLA250 and GLA45 AMG
abstract: The smallest Mercedes S.U.V. is based on the CLA sedan, but it can scamper in the wild.
lead_paragraph: The smallest Mercedes S.U.V. is based on the CLA sedan, but it can scamper in the wild.

headline: ‘Hell on Wheels,’ Below-the-Radar Hit for AMC, Is Renewed for Final Season
abstract: The drama, which is set during the construction of the transcontinental railroad, has found an audience despite airing on Saturday nights.
lead_paragraph: The Western drama “Hell on Wheels” is being renewed by AMC for a fifth and final season, the network announced on Friday, while at the same time declaring its decision to move the series to Saturday nights a success story.

headline: Stand Up Right Now.  Notes From a Health and Fitness Reporter.
abstract: Gretchen Reynolds, the Phys Ed columnist for the Well blog and Science Times, talks about fitness and her own workout routine.
lead_paragraph: Gretchen Reynolds is the Phys Ed columnist for the Well blog and Science Times.

headline: But How Much to Tip an Automatic Garage?
abstract: Milton A. Kent’s solution to a car-clogged city has been revisited by today’s developers.
lead_paragraph: Someone must have been the first to realize that it’s not the heat, it’s the humidity. Likewise, in New York in the late 1920s, Milton A. Kent had a flash: It wasn’t the moving cars, it was the parked ones hogging two-thirds of the roadways and clogging traffic.

headline: A New Road for Women in India
abstract: G Adventures is offering travelers in Delhi ground transportation from Women on Wheels, a program that trains female drivers.
lead_paragraph: Travelers headed to Delhi on select G Adventures’ trips will receive ground transportation from Women on Wheels, a team of commercially trained female drivers.

headline: Founder of Anti-Money ‘Super PAC’ Defends Its Poor Showing
abstract: Mayday PAC, started this spring as the “super PAC to end all super PACs,” wasn’t the biggest group of its kind to have a disappointing Election Day, but it might be the one that gets the most attention for its failures.
lead_paragraph: Mayday PAC, started this spring as the “super PAC to end all super PACs,” wasn’t the biggest group of its kind to have a disappointing Election Day, but it might be the one that gets the most attention for its failures.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: Going Blind Solved!
abstract: Readers solve the case of a 68-year-old woman who lost her vision over the course of several months.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, we challenged Well readers to solve the mystery of a 68-year-old woman who lost her vision over the course of a few months. More than 250 readers wrote in with their take on this terrifying case. A couple of you nailed it, but frankly this case was a super-zebra – at least to me.

headline: W.H.O. Issues New Guidelines on Safely Burying Ebola Victims
abstract: Victims are at their most infectious when they die, so the agency has tried to balance safety with the cultural sensitivities that surround traditional burial rites.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The World Health Organization released a new protocol Friday for the burial of Ebola victims in an effort to slow transmission of the disease and reinforce signs of progress in curbing the spread of the epidemic in West Africa.

headline: Obama Makes His Choice for No. 2 Post at State Department
abstract: President Obama will appoint Antony J. Blinken as the deputy secretary of state, in what may be the first step in a reordering of his top foreign policy staff.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama will appoint Antony J. Blinken as the deputy secretary of state, the White House announced Friday, placing one of his closest advisers in the State Department’s No. 2 post.

headline: Florida Leads the Pack – in Felon Disenfranchisement
abstract: More than one in ten Floridians are shut out of the polls because of felony convictions.
lead_paragraph: Many nations around the world value voting rights so much that their citizens can vote from prison. These countries include Denmark, Finland, Ireland and Sweden. The United States, by contrast, strips felons of the right to vote, not just while they are imprisoned, but often after they have done their time and returned to their communities. This shameful practice deadens engagement in the political process, particularly in minority communities where imprisonment rates are highest and children grow up in the company of adults who cannot cast a ballot.

headline: Bunny Mellon’s Collection, On the Block
abstract: The late heiress’s rarefied objects go to market, emphasizing the elegance of the understated.
lead_paragraph: The late heiress’s rarefied objects go to market, emphasizing the elegance of the understated.

headline: Beaten on the Boston Bombing, Then Landing a Snowden-esque Scoop
abstract: As “The Newsroom” begins its final season, its journalistic warriors grapple with real-world events and a takeover threat.
lead_paragraph: “The Newsroom” begins its truncated, six-episode final season on HBO on Sunday, and its pilgrim’s progress through 21st-century American journalism has brought it to the Boston Marathon bombings. This gives Aaron Sorkin, the writer of record on every episode, plenty of opportunities for finger-wagging as his fictional ACN cable news crew watches less meticulous or fortunate outlets falsely naming suspects and bannering photos of innocent people.

headline: AT&T to Buy Mexican Wireless Provider Iusacell for $2.5 Billion
abstract: For AT&T, the move fit into a strategy that it has articulated for more than two years: diversifying its revenue by moving into foreign markets.
lead_paragraph: AT&T agreed on Friday to buy Iusacell, one of Mexico’s biggest cellphone service providers, for $2.5 billion including debt, as it seeks to expand its international presence by moving southward.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
abstract: Photographs from Ukraine, Syria, the United States and Germany.
lead_paragraph: Photographs from Ukraine, Syria, the United States and Germany.

headline: The Stock Market Doesn’t Care About Elections
abstract: Well, sometimes it does. But mostly it doesn’t.
lead_paragraph: HOW much do investors care about election outcomes?

headline: Nov. 7, 2014 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Ukraine, Syria, Scotland and the United States.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Ukraine, Syria, Scotland and the United States.

headline: Passion Threaded With Silken Whispers
abstract: The Orchestra of St. Luke’s performed works by Tchaikovsky, Mendelssohn and others — all of them pieces inspired by poetry and drama — at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: A thrilling performance of Mendelssohn’s “Die erste Walpurgisnacht” capped the Orchestra of St. Luke’s season-opening concert at Carnegie Hall on Thursday, proving that, under the leadership of its firebrand music director, Pablo Heras-Casado, this is an ensemble to watch. While it feels as though it has yet to achieve its full potential, the orchestra is brimming with enthusiasm and clearly hungry to nip at the heels of its more established colleagues at Lincoln Center.

headline: Malaysian Court Overturns Islamic Law Banning Cross-Dressing
abstract: The decision struck down a law in the state of Negeri Sembilan that prohibited men from engaging in transgender practices, including posing as women.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — A Malaysian appeals court on Friday struck down an Islamic law that banned men from dressing as women in what lawyers described as a landmark case in the stormy battle for primacy between secular and religious laws.

headline: For a Student of the City, It’s Always New
abstract: Andrew S. Dolkart, director of Columbia’s Historic Preservation program and a chronicler of New York old and new, spends many Sundays wandering its neighborhoods.
lead_paragraph: If you’re curious about a particular building in New York, odds are that Andrew S. Dolkart knows something about it. Mr. Dolkart, the 62-year-old director of Columbia University’s Historic Preservation program, spends many Sundays wandering the city with his husband, Paris R. Baldacci, 70, a law professor at the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law. Mr. Dolkart, in recognition of his tireless study of New York old and new — he has written dozens of books and essays, and is working on a book about the garment district — will receive the Historic Districts Council’s Landmarks Lion award on Nov. 19.

headline: The ‘Super El Niño’ Forecast Fadeout
abstract: Early-year warnings of a “super El Nino” are history.
lead_paragraph: On time scales from decades to months, fluctuations in ocean conditions present persistent challenges to climate scientists (see the “pause” in warming) and weather forecasters. The latest example is the fadeout of portentous predictions of a “super” or “monster” El Niño warming of the tropical Pacific. It’s hard for me to avoid thinking of the departed comedian Chris Farley when exploring this weather phenomenon:

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Berlin Welcomes Back the Trabant, if Only for a Day
abstract: The Trabant, the flyweight car produced by East Germany, remains a beloved artifact in Germany.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The two-door, 2-cylinder Trabant was — and almost certainly remains — the most familiar commodity to come out of the former East Germany. The flyweight car with plastic body panels and an engine barely more powerful than a garden tractor was best known for its dull tones and cramped, bumpy ride.

headline: Accepting With Joy, and Barbs
abstract: Harry Belafonte, who will receive the Jean Hersholt award from the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences on Saturday, will have another chance to speak his mind.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — On Saturday night, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences here will give Harry Belafonte an Oscar for his long fight against injustice, racial and otherwise, at its annual Governors Awards banquet. And one thing is sure: Mr. Belafonte, true to form, will speak his mind.

headline: Free Service, for One Owner Only
abstract: BMW has announced that its complimentary maintenance plan can be transferred to subsequent buyers only if they are members of the owner’s family.
lead_paragraph: For some buyers, a new vehicle’s allure goes beyond handling, styling and prestige: They parse the terms of the warranty and even whether maintenance is covered. Some BMW enthusiasts were surprised this summer when the automaker announced limitations on the transfer of its four-year or 50,000-mile complimentary maintenance plan when a car goes to a subsequent buyer.

headline: An Outbreak of Fluid Leaks
abstract: Harsh-shifting Jaguar transmissions and Volkswagens with balky door handles are among the maladies covered in the latest technical service bulletins.
lead_paragraph: Harsh-shifting Jaguar transmissions and Volkswagens with balky door handles are among the maladies covered in the latest technical service bulletins.

headline: In Self-Driving Cars, a Potential Lifeline for the Disabled
abstract: The cars could prove to be a life-changing breakthrough for many people with disabilities, granting them a new measure of independence.
lead_paragraph: The self-driving car, embraced as a stress-reducing convenience for harried drivers and a potential advance in road safety, could also prove to be a life-changing breakthrough for many people with disabilities, granting them a new measure of independence.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Jenna Wortham, Alan Flippen and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Thinking Big. Then Thinking Bigger.
abstract: Jim Venturi’s big idea, still in its drawing phase, involves the radical transformation of La Guardia Airport.
lead_paragraph: Jim Venturi has a big idea, and it led him, on a recent afternoon, to a lush strip of overgrown vegetation in the South Bronx, through a gap in the wire fence, past a sign saying to keep out, past abandoned furniture and an empty homeless encampment.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Jenna Wortham, Alan Flippen and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Bright Specks of Dust From Comet Siding Spring Light Up Martian Sky
abstract: The comet Siding Spring dropped tons of dust into the planet’s atmosphere as it passed the planet in October.
lead_paragraph: A comet that zipped past Mars last month dumped tons of dust into the planet’s atmosphere, providing a spectacular light show, scientists said Friday in presenting initial scientific findings from the flyby.

headline: Jesus and the Modern Man
abstract: Retrieving the centrality of Jesus can restore the simplicity of faith.
lead_paragraph: SOMETIMES, when I kneel alone in a pew in the far back shadows of a church, face buried in my hands, a forbidden thought intrudes: You should have left all this behind a long time ago. The joyful new pope has quickened the affection even of the disaffected, including me, but, oddly, I sense the coming of a strange reversal in the Francis effect. The more universal the appeal of his spacious witness, the more cramped and afraid most of his colleagues in the hierarchy of the Roman Catholic Church have come to seem.

headline: A Harlem Throwback to the Era of Billie Holiday
abstract: Bill’s Place in Harlem, the sort of underground jazz club once frequented by Billie Holiday and Duke Ellington, features jazz by Bill Saxton, a bebop saxophonist.
lead_paragraph: Around 8 p.m. on a recent Saturday, a few dozen people were gathered in a narrow, dimly lit Harlem brownstone. Couples smoked in the backyard beneath Christmas lights; a group of Chilean expats sought a corkscrew; a man and his young son searched for seats.

headline: Keep Warm and Carry On
abstract: With Heatseek NYC and Tug, two noteworthy apps that recently won competitions, developers turned their attention to the public need.
lead_paragraph: It is not hard to find apps catering to the whims of those with disposable incomes — witness the race to help diners score reservations at the hottest restaurants or provide homeowners with a rental butler. But as two noteworthy apps that recently won competitions in New York prove, good things can happen when developers are asked to turn their attention to the public need.

headline: Joe on WNYC’s Money Talking
abstract: Joe discusses what comes next for the energy sector and tax reform after Tuesday’s GOP takeover.
lead_paragraph: Whether the Democrats received a shellacking or merely a temporary bruise on Tuesday, one thing is certain: Republicans are in control of Congress and determined to prove they know how to say “yes” as effectively as they say “no.” While that might not mean passing a comprehensive immigration bill, it could be a good thing for business.

headline: Sharp Words on Israel and Palestine
abstract: Readers disagree with an Op-Ed essay by Israel’s economy minister, Naftali Bennett, that argues against a two-state solution.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Linzer Torte Fit for Thanksgiving
abstract: Pairing the European classic with cranberry filling hits the right note for the season.
lead_paragraph: At one point in my meandering cooking career, I found myself working in a French pastry shop in California. Though the owner was Swiss, nearly everything we produced was classical French: croissants, brioches, éclairs, that sort of thing. There were fresh fruit tarts, chocolate gateaux and all kinds of puff-pastry delights, everything a self-respecting Francophile could dream of.

headline: For Old Trauma, Fresh Sensitivity
abstract: Programming related to Tuesday’s observance of Veterans Day is plentiful, and a lot of it seems determined to throw off the stodginess sometimes associated with the holiday.
lead_paragraph: There was a stretch not long ago when it seemed as if Veterans Day had been largely forgotten, but not this year, at least not on television. Programming related to Tuesday’s observance is plentiful, and a lot of it seems determined to throw off the stodginess sometimes associated with the holiday, whose roots are in World War I.

headline: Meet the Nation’s First Marijuana Critic
abstract: A day in the life of Jake Browne of The Denver Post.
lead_paragraph: A day in the life of Jake Browne of The Denver Post.

headline: Of Mops and Mad Bulls
abstract: Since learning how to make kites as a child in Grenada, Shawn Thomas has continued making them, sometimes selling them, tweaking the design and even acquiring a patent.
lead_paragraph: Like many children growing up in Grenada, Shawn Thomas learned at an early age how to make a kite using a traditional Caribbean folk design.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Marathon Medley
abstract: It seemed as if a kaleidoscope of colors had exploded on the runners participating in the five-borough New York City Marathon last Sunday.
lead_paragraph: It seemed as if a kaleidoscope of colors had exploded on the runners participating in the five-borough New York City Marathon last Sunday.

headline: The First One Home to Care for Dad Gets to Unpack the Most Baggage
abstract: In “You Got Older,” a daughter returns home to tend to her ailing father while sorting through her own issues of love and desire.
lead_paragraph: Among the pithier observations from that eloquent philosopher Blanche DuBois was the idea that death is the opposite of desire. Those opposites attract, after a fashion, in “You Got Older,” a new play by Clare Barron about a young woman returning home to care for her father, who’s learned he has a rare and aggressive cancer. Sleeping in the room next to him, Mae (Brooke Bloom) finds her fearful imaginings for his future shoved aside by wild sexual fantasies involving a mysterious cowboy.

headline: The End Is Near
abstract: At the end of the month, after 11 years of challenging New York’s palate, WD-50, a Lower East Side landmark, is closing shop.
lead_paragraph: At the end of the month, after 11 years of challenging — some might say confounding — New York’s palate, WD-50, Wylie Dufresne’s world-famous culinary skunk works on the Lower East Side, is closing shop. Oldest story in the book: A developer is tearing down the building and putting up — what else? — condominiums. To celebrate (or rather, mourn) the end of his temple to molecular gastronomy, Mr. Dufresne has devised a pair of menus for his last few weeks, and on Wednesday night they drew a crowd of curious first timers, former employees back for a last repast and a man who is widely acknowledged as the restaurant’s best customer: Stewart Waltzer, an art dealer who has dined at WD-50 more than 300 times and has booked a table for each remaining Wednesday of the month.

headline: With Eloquent Arms, Movement Gives Voice to Visceral Images
abstract: On Thursday, Ronald K. Brown and his company, Evidence, began a run at BRIC House in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: There are certain givens in a dance by Ronald K. Brown. Deep, spiritual seriousness. A sophisticated mastery of stage space. Music that makes you want to move. A vocabulary, drawn from many parts of the African diaspora, that Mr. Brown has developed into a personal language that’s flexible, richly expressive and irresistibly kinetic.

headline: A Bridge Deal From the Final of the Rosenblum Teams
abstract: This diagramed deal featured what was probably the most exuberant bid and one of the best defenses at the world championships in China last month.
lead_paragraph: This diagramed deal occurred during the final of the Rosenblum Teams at the world championships in China last month. It featured what was probably the most exuberant bid and one of the best defenses of the two weeks.

headline: Beyoncé and Cara Delevingne Celebrate a Topshop Opening
abstract: Topshop’s second-largest store settles in Manhattan after a stop at Grand Central Terminal.
lead_paragraph: Topshop’s second-largest store settles in Manhattan after a stop at Grand Central Terminal.

headline: Just Because a Policy Causes a Death Spiral Doesn’t Mean It’s Unsustainable
abstract: A ruling against the government in King v. Burwell could make a mess of many states’ insurance markets. That mess could persist for years.
lead_paragraph: As my colleague Margot Sanger-Katz notes, a Supreme Court ruling against the Obama administration in King v. Burwell would cause significant disarray in health insurance markets, by denying subsidies to anyone buying health insurance on the individual market in states that rely on the federal health insurance exchange.

headline: Topshop’s Next Stop Is Fifth Avenue
abstract: The brand’s second-largest store arrives on Fifth Avenue after a stop at Grand Central Terminal.
lead_paragraph: “Can I do it like pushing a big red button?” the ropy supermodel Cara Delevingne drawled on Tuesday afternoon. She was pondering the ways in which she might officially open the new Fifth Avenue Topshop store the next day, several of whose walls are covered in larger-than-life-size photographs of her beetle-browed visage. (She appears in the current ad campaign.)

headline: Magnum’s Archive of Once-Orphaned Photos
abstract: Most pictures don’t make the final edit. But Magnum photographers went back through their files and found delightful images that had gone unseen. Until now.
lead_paragraph: Most pictures don’t make the final edit. But Magnum photographers went back through their files and found delightful images that had gone unseen. Until now.

headline: Corporate Disclosure of Political Donations
abstract: Daniel M. Gallagher, an S.E.C. commissioner, and Raymond C. Offenheiser of Oxfam America discuss whether more transparency in corporate spending is needed.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Dior Gives the Guggenheim a Twirl
abstract: Dior sponsored the Guggenheim’s big fall gala, held in the museum’s landmark rotunda.
lead_paragraph: For the second year in a row, Dior sponsored the Guggenheim’s big fall gala, held Thursday in the museum’s landmark rotunda. And after a rocky journey that found the Dior brass grounded after extreme turbulence in Paris, a full caravan arrived to toast the occasion: Raf Simons, Dior’s creative director; Sidney Toledano, the company’s chief executive; and many others.

headline: Educating for Democracy
abstract: Harry Boyte of Augsburg College writes that higher education needs to undergo a “pedagogical shift” to the “cultivation of civic skills.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Cuts to Weather Forecasts
abstract: A reader says our crumbling weather infrastructure reflects our unwillingness to properly fund important government services.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Signs of Secular Stagnation
abstract: Check out our low, low rates.
lead_paragraph: And they aren’t even being ironic …

headline: Q and A: For Supreme Court, a Case of Economics and Politics
abstract: The latest challenge to the Affordable Care Act could affect the ability of many people to pay for health insurance.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the Supreme Court on Friday agreed to hear a new challenge to the Affordable Care Act, it caused concern for many people who support the law, which has provided health insurance to more than 10 million. The challenge poses a threat to the law, according to defenders of President Obama’s policies.

headline: F.B.I. Chief Backs Agent Who Posed as Reporter
abstract: James B. Comey said in a letter to the editor in The New York Times that the agency was justified in having an agent pose as a reporter to catch the sender of bomb threats.
lead_paragraph: In spring 2007, Timberline High School in Lacey, Wash., received bomb threats by email, on paper and on a bathroom wall, causing the school to be evacuated. A few days later, according to a local news report, a 10th-grade student was arrested.

headline: The Life of a Pot Critic: Clean, With Citrus Notes
abstract: Jake Browne, the first pot critic for The Denver Post, is paid to smoke marijuana and then write about the high.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Jake Browne was seated in a yellow suede chair, carefully rotating a marijuana bud between his fingers. “I’m looking for bugs, mildew, things I wouldn’t want to ingest,” he said, leaning forward to hold the nickel-size flower up to the light. He paused, then took a sip of water from a cup with a Miley Cyrus hologram down its side. “This looks clean,” he concluded.

headline: Prominent Editor’s Exit Is Setback for Amazon Publishing Unit
abstract: Ed Park, a novelist who shaped Amazon’s sole literary fiction imprint with his taste and connections, is leaving, raising questions about the program’s future.
lead_paragraph: When Amazon hired the novelist Ed Park as a senior editor in its New York publishing office in 2011, it seemed an unlikely match. Mr. Park — a member of New York’s literary elite who had worked for the Poetry Foundation, co-founded a literary magazine and edited The Village Voice’s literary supplement — seemed ill suited to Amazon’s algorithm-driven business.

headline: Friday Night Music: Suzanne Vega, Jacob and the Angel
abstract: Wrestling through the night.
lead_paragraph: Back from Japan, jet-lagged into oblivion, and not exactly wildly happy about some things. But music remains! I did an interview, which some people might find interesting.

headline: Stricken by Grief, Finding Solace in a Robin
abstract: A reader tells of an encounter with a robin that left him feeling as if the spirit of his late daughter were reaching out to him.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Bill Cunningham | New York City Marathon Medley
abstract: It seemed as if a kaleidoscope of colors had exploded on the runners participating in the five-borough New York City Marathon last Sunday.
lead_paragraph: It seemed as if a kaleidoscope of colors had exploded on the runners participating in the five-borough New York City Marathon last Sunday. Ending in Central Park, the run was set against a backdrop of autumn leaves. Some of the international runners sported traditional garb from their home countries. Curiously, a number of runners wore tutus.

headline: Evening Hours | A Busy Autumn
abstract: A funeral mass for Oscar de la Renta, honors and costumes.
lead_paragraph: A funeral mass for Oscar de la Renta, honors and costumes.

headline: Atlanta Symphony Musicians and Management Reach Tentative Labor Deal
abstract: The two-month lockout of the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra, which has delayed the start of the ensemble’s 70th anniversary season, could be nearing its end: federal mediators announced on Friday that the musicians and management had reached a tentative labor deal.
lead_paragraph: The two-month lockout of the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra, which has delayed the start of the ensemble’s 70th anniversary season, could be nearing its end: federal mediators announced on Friday that the musicians and management had reached a tentative labor deal.

headline: On Twitter and Instagram, Hiding in Plain E-Sight
abstract: Almost any action we take on social media is a time-stamped signpost that we were paying attention to at least some of our smartphone communication.
lead_paragraph: My older sister hates Twitter. Absolutely hates it, and avoids it at all costs. Her feelings do not come from some slavish devotion to fully formed thoughts and sentences. No, Lizzie can speak in text pidgin with the best of ’em.

headline: The Soviet Style
abstract: The director of “Red Army,” a documentary about Soviet era hockey, discusses the essence of the Russian style of play.
lead_paragraph: The director of “Red Army,” a documentary about Soviet era hockey, discusses the essence of the Russian style of play.

headline: Want to Make a Movie, Jason Schwartzman?
abstract: On a night off, the actor Mr. Schwartzman finds himself in a familiar role.
lead_paragraph: Hanging out with Jason Schwartzman feels a bit like living inside one of his movies. The banter is ironic. The course of events is without obvious purpose. And in the end, something kind of spectacular happens.

headline: With Some Dating Apps: Less Casual Sex Than Casual Text
abstract: More and more millennials are shying away from physical encounters and supplanting them with virtual quasi relationships.
lead_paragraph: Jason Sprung, a 26-year-old comedian in Brooklyn, connected last year on the location-based dating app Tinder with a Tennessee woman who was visiting New York. The two didn’t get a chance to meet up while she was in town, but that didn’t deter them.

headline: Federal Form for Voting Is Ruled Valid
abstract: An appeals court rejected bids by Arizona and Kansas to force the federal government to require proof of citizenship for voter registration.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court on Friday rejected the demands by Arizona and Kansas that federal forms for voter registration used in their states require documentary proof of citizenship.

headline: Larry Agenbroad, Paleontologist at Mammoths’ Graveyard, Dies at 81
abstract: Dr. Agenbroad presided over a decades-long excavation in South Dakota that gave rise to the Mammoth Site museum and continues to yield fossils.
lead_paragraph: Larry Agenbroad, a paleontologist who presided over the unearthing of scores of fossilized mammoths from a scrape of southwest South Dakota, helping it become an international research destination, died on Oct. 31 in Hot Springs, S.D. He was 81.

headline: For Millennials, the End of the TV Viewing Party
abstract: In the era of laptops and Hulu, millennials’ viewing habits may signal the end of the communal living-room screen.
lead_paragraph: The television has always been more than just an appliance. For decades, going back to the days when a single family on a block might have a color TV that the neighbors were invited in to watch, it has been a portal to a dreamscape, a status symbol, a trusted late-night companion.

headline: Erased iPhone Gets a Mother in Trouble
abstract: Eileen Lagala’s son said the last he saw of his phone, the police were putting it in a plastic bag. “I asked him for the password,” she said. “That was a mistake.”
lead_paragraph: Eileen Lagala, a Staten Island resident for 55 of her 60 years, and a mother of three sons and four daughters, added two new titles in the past year — one when she became a grandmother and the other when she began serving a year’s probation following her guilty plea in criminal court last month.

headline: Weekly Wrap
abstract: A quick list of highlights from this week’s Times Insider.
lead_paragraph: Hello Insiders.

headline: Montefiore’s New Bronx Medical Center Emphasizes Outpatient Care
abstract: The $152 million Hutchinson campus, operated by Montefiore Medical Center, will send patients home the same day as part of the hospital system’s shift toward outpatient operations.
lead_paragraph: The newest medical complex in the Bronx offers valet parking, views of Long Island Sound, and operating rooms equipped with overhead lamps that do not throw shadows and nonporous, plastic-lined walls to reduce the spread of infection.

headline: Republican Beats Expectations but Concedes Virginia Senate Race
abstract: Ed Gillespie, the Republican candidate in Virginia who surprised nearly everyone by running a photo-finish race with Senator Mark R. Warner, conceded on Friday, saying the gap of 16,700 votes was too great to make up in a recount.
lead_paragraph: Ed Gillespie, the Republican candidate in Virginia who surprised nearly everyone by running a photo-finish race with Senator Mark R. Warner, conceded defeat on Friday, saying the gap of 16,700 votes was too great to make up in a recount.

headline: 25 M.P.H. Speed Limit Takes Effect in New York
abstract: On the first day of the dawn of a new speed limit in New York City, some drivers seemed oblivious as they sped along, though fear of enforcement was palpable among others.
lead_paragraph: The 25-mile-per-hour speed limit that went into effect in New York City on Friday did not slow a black Mercedes that blazed a path down the middle lane of Madison Avenue at a brisk 34 miles per hour around 1 p.m. Nor did it deter the drivers of a tow truck going 32 m.p.h. or a city bus lumbering along at 28 m.p.h. Even a police car was spotted darting through traffic, though no emergency was apparent.

headline: The Labor Picture in October
abstract: October Jobs data show solid employment growth.
lead_paragraph: October Jobs data show solid employment growth.

headline: Finding $816 Million, and Fast, to Save Detroit
abstract: At the center of Detroit’s swift exit from the nation’s largest-ever municipal bankruptcy is an improbable arrangement hashed out in many months of behind-the-scenes negotiations.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Late one afternoon last November, leaders of some of the nation’s top foundations were invited into a private meeting in a courthouse conference room here as Judge Gerald E. Rosen, the appointed mediator in this city’s federal bankruptcy case, made an unheard-of request.

headline: U.S. Embassy in Bahamas Issues Crime Warning
abstract: Water scooter operators are reported to have sexually assaulted at least three Americans since July, the embassy said in a security alert, the latest in a series of advisories about crime.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Water scooter operators on Paradise Island in the Bahamas are reported to have sexually assaulted at least three American tourists since July, the United States Embassy announced in a security advisory this week that warned of increasingly brazen crimes sweeping the country.

headline: A Muckraking Magazine Creates a Stir Among Evangelical Christians
abstract: The magazine World serves born-again Christians with its investigative reporting, which recently helped topple the leader of a megachurch.
lead_paragraph: In October, Mark Driscoll, the evangelical pastor and best-selling author,  resigned from Mars Hill, his Seattle megachurch. This month, Mars Hill announced that it was dissolving its network of 13 satellite churches.

headline: Health Care Reform Imperiled
abstract: The Supreme Court agreed to hear a legal challenge to the health care law that deals with the subsidies that many use to buy insurance.
lead_paragraph: Will five Supreme Court justices eliminate essential health care subsidies for more than four million lower-income Americans, based on a contorted reading of four words?

headline: Job Growth, but No Raises
abstract: There is little evidence that a fair share of prosperity is flowing to workers, or will do so anytime soon.
lead_paragraph: The employment report for October, released on Friday, reflects a steady-as-she-goes economy. And that is a problem, because for most Americans, more of the same is not good enough. Since the recovery began in mid-2009, inflation-adjusted figures show that the economy has grown by 12 percent; corporate profits, by 46 percent; and the broad stock market, by 92 percent. Median household income has contracted by 3 percent.

headline: Detroit Leaders Praise Judge’s Decision
abstract: Officials in Detroit celebrated “a new day” after a federal judge approved a plan to bring the city out of bankruptcy.
lead_paragraph: Officials in Detroit celebrated “a new day” after a federal judge approved a plan to bring the city out of bankruptcy.

headline: Waiting for the European Central Bank
abstract: The steps the E.C.B. seems to have in mind will not sufficiently bolster the eurozone economy.
lead_paragraph: The European Central Bank said this week that it was prepared to take additional steps to revive the struggling economies of the 18 countries that use the euro. The trouble is that the E.C.B. is already way behind the curve, and the steps it seems to have in mind will not be sufficient to help the millions of unemployed people.

headline: Making the Rent
abstract: A couple staves off the threat of eviction with help from The Neediest Cases Fund.
lead_paragraph: In 1981, Aleksander Ptselintsev, an Estonian Jew of Russian descent and a soldier in the Soviet army, was deployed in Afghanistan. He fought the mujahedeen for over a year, until his unit was ambushed and an explosion sent him to the hospital for eight months, leaving him with post-traumatic stress disorder.

headline: Former Navy SEAL, Author of Bin Laden Best Seller, May Face Costly Penalties, Lawyer Says
abstract: Matt Bissonnette, a former SEAL member, will probably forfeit $4.5 million in royalties for failing to let the Pentagon vet his book on the Osama bin Laden raid, his lawyer contends.
lead_paragraph: Matt Bissonnette, a former member of Navy SEAL Team 6, will probably have to forfeit at least $4.5 million in book royalties over his failure to allow the Pentagon to review his best seller on the Osama bin Laden raid for possible security breaches, according to court documents filed by his lawyer.

headline: SEMA Show Closes with a Peek for the Public
abstract: SEMA wrapped up its annual convention by parading customized and one-of-a-kind vehicles from the trade-only show around Las Vegas.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — The annual Specialty Equipment Market Association trade show closed on Friday with an official public event — a first in the show’s 47 years of existence.

headline: Pregnant Lawyer Requests Delay in New York Corruption Retrial
abstract: Deborah N. Misir, who represents Vincent Tabone, a former leader of the Queens Republican Committee, told Judge Kenneth M. Karas of Federal District Court that she must avoid stress.
lead_paragraph: Deborah N. Misir is in the sixth month of a high-risk pregnancy. So Ms. Misir, a Long Island lawyer, has asked that an upcoming trial for one of her clients — set for about two months before her due date — be postponed.

headline: How Lincoln Won the Soldier Vote
abstract: An overwhelming majority of Union soldiers voted for Lincoln. But how much was the result of Republican Party manipulation?
lead_paragraph: Francis Lieber, the famed German-born Columbia University professor, was amazed that America would hold a presidential election during the Civil War. “If we come triumphantly out of this war, with a presidential election in the midst of it,” he wrote in August 1864, “I shall call it the greatest miracle in all the historic course of events.”

headline: No Need to Hype Clash Between Kansas State and T.C.U.
abstract: When Kansas State meets Texas Christian, there will be no need for fiery speeches, as the players are well aware of what is riding on the outcome: a possible berth in the College Football Playoff.
lead_paragraph: The magnitude of the game speaks for itself, so much so that Kansas State Coach Bill Snyder did not bother fretting about the Wildcats’ focus for Saturday night’s Big 12 Conference showdown with Texas Christian.

headline: To China, Shift in Obama’s Political Fortunes Eclipses U.S. Economic Gains
abstract: When President Obama visits China on Monday, authorities there are likely to dwell more on his electoral reversals than on the robust American economy, analysts say.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The last time President Obama went to China, five years ago, he was a political supernova from a nation with a depleted, debt-ridden economy. When he returns to Beijing on Monday, he will be a political casualty from a country with a resurgent economy.

headline: Drug Gang Killed Students, Mexican Law Official Says
abstract: Members of a drug gang arrested in connection with the disappearance of 43 college students told investigators that they had killed the students and burned their bodies, the Mexican attorney general said.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Members of a drug gang arrested in the investigation into the disappearance of 43 college students in September told investigators that they had killed the students and burned their bodies in a pyre of tires and branches, the attorney general announced Friday.

headline: Transocean Challenged by Plummeting Oil Prices
abstract: The company announced it would take charges of more than $2.7 billion because of weakening demand for its rigs.
lead_paragraph: In a sign that lower prices are starting to exact a toll on the oil industry, the offshore-rig owner Transocean announced it would take charges of more than $2.7 billion because of weakening demand for its rigs. Transocean said the charges forced it to delay its third-quarter earnings report, which was scheduled for Friday. Companies that explore for and produce oil are cutting back on investment because of sharp declines in the price of oil, which is reducing demand for rigs and lowering rates for Transocean’s equipment. Brent crude, the most common benchmark for global oil, has fallen 28 percent since late June.

headline: Obama Urged Iranian Leader to See Common Interests
abstract: The president, in an October letter to Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, said that a nuclear agreement and supporting the fight against the Islamic State would help Iran.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a letter last month to Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, President Obama urged Iran’s supreme leader to seize the opportunity of the Nov. 24 deadline for negotiating a nuclear agreement with the West, arguing that Iran’s interests in the Middle East would be served by proving its interest in nuclear technology was solely for the production of electricity, according to senior administration officials.

headline: A Team Player to the Very End
abstract: Thierry Henry’s illustrious career may be nearing an end, but he is keeping his mind on the task at hand: winning an M.L.S. title.
lead_paragraph: HARRISON, N.J. — If retirement is near for Thierry Henry — and he is not yet saying it is — he will follow Derek Jeter as the next great athlete to leave New York, minus the season-long goodbyes and parting gifts.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 7 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Pregnant, and No Civil Rights
abstract: Anti-abortion measures are used to control childbirth decisions.
lead_paragraph: WITH the success of Republicans in the midterm elections and the passage of Tennessee’s anti-abortion amendment, we can expect ongoing efforts to ban abortion and advance the “personhood” rights of fertilized eggs, embryos and fetuses.

headline: Big Money Wins Again in a Romp
abstract: The $4 billion spent to influence the outcome of the midterms isn’t as big a problem as the post-election purpose of that spending.
lead_paragraph: Two days after the midterm elections, I met up with a man named Ira Glasser, the former longtime head of the American Civil Liberties Union. For days, the media had been full of news about the enormous sums of money likely to be spent by special-interest groups and others to influence the outcome of Senate races, House races, gubernatorial races — even judicial races. According to the Center for Responsive Politics, which issued a report just days before the midterms, nearly $4 billion was expected to be spent, in toto, on the midterms. Glasser had no problem with any of this.

headline: A Resolve to Stay Young, Undimmed by Illness
abstract: Irina Finkel of Brooklyn, who made films as a young woman in Ukraine, has been disabled by a brain tumor and was helped by a beneficiary agency of UJA-Federation.
lead_paragraph: At age 28, Irina Finkel, a gregarious film student in what was then Soviet-ruled Ukraine, came to a conclusion.

headline: Latvian Minister Declares He’s Gay, Exposing Fault Lines of New Culture War in Europe
abstract: Differing reactions to Foreign Minister Edgars Rinkevics’s declaration seemed to reveal the contours of a cultural fault line between East and West.
lead_paragraph: When Latvia’s foreign minister, Edgars Rinkevics, declared on Twitter on Thursday that he was “proud to be gay,” the announcement was welcomed there by lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender rights activists, who have faced open hostility from social conservatives in the former Soviet republic.

headline: Republicans ♥ Pipeline
abstract: For the next Congress, the Keystone pipeline gets voted most likely to succeed.
lead_paragraph: The Keystone XL oil pipeline is so popular! Ever since the Republicans won control of the Senate, it’s become the Taylor Swift of political issues.

headline: Derek Stepan Set to Return as Rangers Try to Stabilize Lines
abstract: Stepan, who is set to make his season debut Saturday, reached career highs with 40 assists and 57 points last season.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Happy faces were everywhere after the Rangers’ practice Friday ahead of a trip to Toronto.

headline: Cardinals’ Bruce Arians Took Long Route to Top N.F.L. Job
abstract: Arians became the head coach at Temple in 1983. In 2013, after a circuitous career, he finally got a head coaching position in the N.F.L.
lead_paragraph: TEMPE, Ariz. — In 1983, Bruce Arians’s future stretched before him like a desert highway. He was given the keys to Temple’s program at age 30, becoming the youngest head coach in major college football.

headline: General Theological Seminary Bringing Back Professors It Dismissed
abstract: Seven of the eight faculty members who were dismissed in late September from the Episcopal institution in Manhattan will return to their classrooms on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Seven of the eight professors who were dismissed in late September from the General Theological Seminary, the nation’s oldest Episcopal seminary, will return to their classrooms on Monday.

headline: A Tiny Bit Strange
abstract: Barry C. Silk writes puzzles for grown-ups, but once in a while you can find stuff for less mature adults like me.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Barry C. Silk writes puzzles for grown-ups — tough yet elegant grids filled with lots of scientific and political entries — but if you look carefully, there are always a few entries that remind us that, no matter how old you are, the kid in us remains.

headline: Labor Board Says Cablevision Chief Tied Raises to Vote Against a Union
abstract: In its latest complaint against the company, the National Labor Relations Board charged Cablevision’s chief executive officer, James L. Dolan, with illegally threatening to deny technicians a pay increase.
lead_paragraph: The National Labor Relations Board has charged Cablevision’s chief executive officer, James L. Dolan, with illegally threatening to deny company technicians in Brooklyn a pay increase unless they voted to quit their union.

headline: Saturday’s College Football Games to Watch
abstract: Alabama will play Louisiana State under the lights in Baton Rouge, with plenty on the line. In college football, it rarely gets better than this.
lead_paragraph: 4 ALABAMA at 14 L.S.U.

headline: New York Police Officer Found After Vanishing With Money
abstract: A veteran New York City police officer disappeared for two days with tens of thousands of dollars intended for him and colleagues to travel for a Giants football game, the police and a person familiar with the matter said.
lead_paragraph: A veteran New York City police officer disappeared for two days with tens of thousands of dollars intended for him and a group of his colleagues to travel to Seattle this weekend for a Giants football game, the police and a person familiar with the matter said.

headline: Nets Make Knicks Look Like a Long-Term Project
abstract: Amid the Knicks’ public struggles adapting to the triangle offense, they reinforced how much work they have ahead of them as they dropped their third straight game.
lead_paragraph: The Knicks and the Nets share a city, three bridges and deep pockets. About $180 million in player payroll was on display Friday night at Barclays Center, which was treated to the renewal of an embryonic rivalry — if it can be considered that — between two teams that were merely hoping to take a step toward respectability.

headline: Britain Is Granted Delay in Payment to European Union
abstract: British officials said the delay amounted to the halving of a payment of 2.1 billion euros, but ministers of other European countries said Britain would end up paying the full amount.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Britain was given the leeway on Friday to defer a payment of 2.1 billion euros, or about $2.6 billion, to the European Union, whose demand had given ammunition to a populist party pressing the country to leave the bloc.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (Showtime) AUGUST: OSAGE COUNTY A dysfunctional clan unfurls its secrets as it gathers to mourn the loss of its patriarch in this dark comedy, directed by John Wells and adapted by Tracy Letts from his Pulitzer Prize-winning play. Sam Shepard portrays Beverly Weston, an alcoholic poet living in a rambling farmhouse in northeastern Oklahoma who hires a Native American caretaker (Misty Upham) for his shrill, pill-addicted wife, Violet (Meryl Streep) — and then disappears. Julia Roberts, Ms. Nicholson and Ms. Lewis and play Beverly and Violet’s daughters; Ewan McGregor, Dermot Mulroney and Benedict Cumberbatch are the men in their lives. And Margo Martindale and Chris Cooper are Violet’s sister and brother-in-law, who are there to lend support. But the story of the Weston family “is secondary to the spectacle the actors make of themselves,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times, calling the film “a thespian cage match” in which “a bunch of unquestionably talented performers is assembled with no instructions other than to top one another.” He added, “It goes without saying that nobody can beat Ms. Streep at this game.” (She received an Oscar nomination, as did Ms. Roberts.) “But everyone joins in.”

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, November 8, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “I said if you do $100 million, we should give $20 million.”

headline: Corrections: November 8, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, November 8, 2014.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: The Daily Gift: a Gadget That Trains the Brain
abstract: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.
lead_paragraph: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.

headline: The Company Is Still Tight-Lipped, but Shareholders Aren’t
abstract: A lawsuit by retirement funds against Conn’s — the appliance store chain that isn’t talking to the Haggler — followed a sharp decline in the company’s stock price.
lead_paragraph: Email haggler@nytimes.com. Keep it brief and family-friendly, include your hometown and go easy on the caps-lock key. Letters may be edited for clarity and length.

headline: The Stock Market Is on Edge About a Cable Merger
abstract: As regulatory issues swirl, investors are fretting over a Comcast deal with Time Warner Cable.
lead_paragraph: The debate over net neutrality and cable company concentration has been rattling Wall Street.

headline: A Strategy for Rich Countries: Absorb More Immigrants
abstract: If developed economies are to keep thriving, they’ll need more people. Two paths to that goal are immigration reform and family-friendly working conditions.
lead_paragraph: Economic debate since the financial crisis and Great Recession has often focused on issues like monetary policy, fiscal stimulus, unemployment and financial regulation. Yes, these are all important, but in the future we will need to pay much more attention to a relatively neglected field: population economics. It’s an area that will prove central to understanding whether nations will grow richer — or will stagnate and lose global importance.

headline: No Burden Too Heavy
abstract: A longtime forklift driver has not let kidney disease alter his career path. The job, he says, “gives me a sense of purpose.”
lead_paragraph: Marcus Rede, 50, is a forklift driver for an Ikea distribution center in Bakersfield, Calif.

headline: Reinventing Themselves, Without a Net
