abstract: Would you quit one job before finding the next? Amid upheaval in many industries, many millennials are saying yes.
lead_paragraph: My husband, who is 34, recently quit his federal government job, where he worked on climate-change issues for four years. He left because we decided to move to New York for my work and because he was itching to explore other options.

headline: Wearing Your Failures on Your Sleeve
abstract: In entrepreneurial circles, a start-up flop is now something to analyze and proclaim, not hide.
lead_paragraph: Five years ago, Cassandra Phillipps founded FailCon, a one-day conference in San Francisco celebrating failure. Discouraged by a growing chorus of start-up founders promoting their triumphs throughout Silicon Valley, and nervous about her own prospects as an entrepreneur, she craved the stories of people who had flopped.

headline: On LinkedIn, a Reference List You Didn’t Write
abstract: A lawsuit is challenging how a feature on LinkedIn, the professional-networking site, uses a job candidate’s work history.
lead_paragraph: LinkedIn is the industry leader in helping people make work connections. Log on, and this professional-networking site displays a sampling of “people you may know” — often including colleagues at a user’s own workplace — with whom to start hobnobbing.

headline: Janet Elkin, on Not Letting the Process Defeat the Purpose
abstract: Named to her post in the recession, a chief executive didn’t dwell on reporting poor results. “Let’s talk about how we’re going to get better,” she told the staff. “Let’s get started.”
lead_paragraph: This interview with  Janet Elkin, chief executive of Supplemental Health Care, a health care staffing firm, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Kenneth Bae and Matthew Todd Miller, Released by North Korea, Are Back on U.S. Soil
abstract: Mr. Bae and Mr. Miller arrived Saturday night at a base near Tacoma, Wash., after a secret negotiation by the director of national intelligence, James R. Clapper Jr.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — North Korea released two Americans who had been accused of trying to subvert the secretive state, after the director of national intelligence for the United States flew to the country on a secret mission and left on Saturday with the men aboard his aircraft.

headline: 1989: Checkpoint Charlie as a Gateway for Shoppers
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Checkpoint Charlie the weekend the Berlin Wall fell.
lead_paragraph: Berlin — A statement painted on the Berlin Wall at Stresemannstrasse summed up an extraordinary weekend in West Berlin:

headline: Montserrat Seeks a Comeback After a Volcano
abstract: Since 1995, when a volcano buried its capital, Plymouth, the Caribbean island has sought a comeback. Now it thinks it has one.
lead_paragraph: Since 1995, when the Soufrière Hills volcano began erupting and eventually buried its capital, Plymouth, in pyroclastic flows, the Caribbean island of Montserrat has sought a comeback. Now it thinks it has one, and Plymouth is again part of the plan.

headline: A Blank Page in the S.E.C. Rule Book, Four Years Later
abstract: The order in the Dodd-Frank law sounded simple: Write a rule governing clawbacks of executive pay. Yet that rule is still unwritten.
lead_paragraph: It’s something that almost everyone can agree on: Executives should return compensation earned improperly as a result of accounting shenanigans at their companies.

headline: Mom, the Guarantor, Steps In
abstract: Subjects include renting during building renovation; apartment access to repair a co-op’s common elements; and union dues.
lead_paragraph: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: The Many Genres of a Salsa Giant
abstract: Rubén Blades will perform a set of his own famous songs with the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra.
lead_paragraph: Working with Willie Colón in 1978, the great singer Rubén Blades made possibly the best-selling record in the history of salsa, “Siembra.” His songs were stories about class divisions, crime, love and history. With parallel careers as an actor and statesman — he was Panama’s minister of tourism from 2005 to 2009 — he connected with audiences across Latin America and continued to push beyond whatever he felt the constraints of Latin pop might be. (On records from the 1980s onward, he used elements of doo-wop, bagpipes, Cuban folklore and tango; many of them felt like theoretical demonstrations.)

headline: Rising Quartets, Hip and Passionate
abstract: Is ours the new golden age of string quartets? If certainly feels that way.
lead_paragraph: Is ours the new golden age of string quartets? If certainly feels that way, with a growing number of fiercely individualistic and accomplished ensembles made up of passionate young players. Two stellar groups from the European scene come to town this week: the Danish String Quartet and the Paris-based Quatuor Ebène. Catch the Danes underground at their CD release party at SubCulture or at one of two sets on Thursday at the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center. Joined by the pianist Gilles Vonsattle, they present music by Debussy and Vierne at the Rose Studio Concert and Late Night Rose Program. (8 p.m., Wednesday, 45 Bleecker Street, near Lafayette Street, East Village, subculturenewyork.com; 6:30 and 9 p.m. Thursday, Lincoln Center, chambermusicsociety.org.)

headline: Sledders Training for a Smackdown
abstract: You might prefer being tackled by a lineman to absorbing some of the hits seen in “Ice Warriors: USA Sled Hockey.”
lead_paragraph: Football has been taking a lot of heat lately over the roughness of the sport, but you might prefer being tackled by a lineman to absorbing some of the hits seen in “Ice Warriors: USA Sled Hockey,” a documentary about that Paralympic sport Monday night on PBS.

headline: Reliving the Shock of a Pas de Nude
abstract: A dance troupe is dedicated to preserving and performing musical-theater choreography.
lead_paragraph: Many Broadway musicals have great dance numbers. But when the shows close, those dances often fade from memory. That realization led the dancer Lee Theodore to establish the American Dance Machine, which preserves and performs musical-theater choreography, in 1976.

headline: A Nazi-Era Diva as Victimized Relic
abstract: “Light and shadow, the two secrets of motion pictures,” the faded film star tells her companion in “Veronika Voss.”
lead_paragraph: “Light and shadow, the two secrets of motion pictures,” the faded film star tells her companion in “Veronika Voss.” Part of a generous Fassbinder retrospective running through Nov. 26 at the Film Society of Lincoln Center, “Veronika Voss” uses a light-and-shadow palette (and all sorts of wipes and iris effects) to tell the story of Veronika, a star during the Nazi years, who now finds herself addicted to morphine and captive to the doctor who provides it. (Remarkably, it’s based on a true story.)

headline: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
abstract: Why you need more cryptic crosswords in your life.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — When I have solved all of the crossword puzzles I need to solve for the blog and I need a bit of a break, I turn to cryptic crosswords for a breath of fresh air.

headline: Creators Inspired by Ebony and Jet
abstract: Magazines and their images are part of everyone’s childhood experience, but that’s especially the case with artists.
lead_paragraph: Magazines and their images are part of everyone’s childhood experience, but that’s especially the case with artists, who often mine them for motifs, materials and memories. This is the premise behind “Speaking of People: Ebony, Jet and Contemporary Art,” opening Thursday at the Studio Museum in Harlem. It examines the aesthetic uses that artists of African descent have made of Ebony and Jet, mainstays of black life in the United States since their founding in Chicago after World War II. (The show is titled after a column in Jet.)

headline: Pope Demotes U.S. Cardinal Critical of His Reform Agenda
abstract: Pope Francis removed Cardinal Raymond L. Burke, who has questioned the pontiff’s leadership, from his post as head of the Vatican’s highest judicial authority.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Pope Francis on Saturday sidelined a powerful American cardinal who has emerged as an unabashed conservative critic of the reform agenda and the leadership style that the Argentine pontiff has brought to the Roman Catholic Church.

headline: It’s Elementary: Knicks’ Problem Is Chemistry, Not Geometry
abstract: A handful of games in, most of them unsightly, discussion of the Knicks’ triangle offense is deflecting attention from a roster that is ill-suited for it.
lead_paragraph: It is too early to argue that the Knicks cannot get a better grasp of the triangle offense. But it may be too late to acknowledge that the narrative of Phil Jackson’s first full season as the Knicks’ president and Derek Fisher’s as coach should not have been so much about the installation of a system not ideally suited for the habits and skills of too many players, several of whom will not be around beyond this season.

headline: The Places in America Where College Football Means the Most
abstract: Data from Facebook provides insight into where the sport’s biggest fans live.
lead_paragraph: It is hard to explain to someone who grew up in a big city in the Northeast just how big a deal college football is in the Southeast.

headline: Loretta Lynch, a Nominee for Attorney General, Is Praised for Substance, Not Flash
abstract: Ms. Lynch, the federal prosecutor in Brooklyn nominated to be the nation’s attorney general, is a calm, under-the-radar lawyer who is not afraid to fight hard for her cause, associates say.
lead_paragraph: When Kenneth P. Thompson was a young federal prosecutor in Brooklyn in the late 1990s, he was assigned to one of the biggest cases the office had ever handled, that of the police officers accused of beating and sodomizing Abner Louima, a Haitian immigrant.

headline: McCain Poised to Press Obama, and Pentagon, at Armed Services Helm
abstract: With the chairmanship of the Senate Armed Services Committee almost certain to go to him, Senator John McCain will have a bully pulpit for his foreign-policy disputes with the White House.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Of all the areas where Barack Obama and John McCain clashed during the 2008 presidential campaign, none was more combustible than defense, with their starkly different views on the deployment of American men and women to wage war overseas.

headline: Lynch Portrayed as Tough, Fair and Apolitical
abstract: President Obama, announcing the nomination of Ms. Lynch at a White House ceremony, described her as a highly qualified prosecutor with a reputation as a “people person.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama announced on Saturday that he would nominate Loretta E. Lynch, the top federal prosecutor in Brooklyn, to be the next attorney general, paving the way for the first African-American woman to hold the job.

headline: On Berlin Wall Anniversary, Somber Notes Amid Revelry
abstract: Most Germans are celebrating the 25th anniversary of the wall’s opening, but for relatives of those killed trying to cross the barrier it is a time of sadness.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — It was the morning after the best party ever, the tumult and joy that marked the fall of the Berlin Wall on Nov. 9, 1989. After 28 years, East Berliners were giddy with marvel that they could now visit the West.

headline: Brazil Military Drills to Defend Amazon
abstract: Half of Brazilians believe the resource-rich rain forest will become the target of a foreign power. Military exercises this month simulate warding off such plunderers.
lead_paragraph: MANAUS, Brazil — Brazil’s army is deploying troops this month to the far reaches of the Amazon in a military exercise simulating a foreign invasion of the rain forest, focusing attention on sensitivity over sovereignty in a region rising in importance as a strategic pillar of Latin America’s largest economy.

headline: The Ethics of Infection
abstract: Bowling with Ebola raises the question: What is everyone’s duty to prevent transmission of infectious diseases?
lead_paragraph: “PRIMUM NON NOCERE” or “First, do no harm” is supposed to be the guiding principle of health care workers. And within civil societies, at least, not harming others is considered every person’s moral, ethical and even legal responsibility.

headline: Democracy’s Circuses, Triumphs and Shams
abstract: Elections were just held in the United States and Ukraine, and the world reflected on the anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall.
lead_paragraph: The main event of the past week was, of course, the midterm elections. It was a Republican romp, far greater than any poll predicted, but for those watching it from abroad it was also a striking lesson in the enormous complexity, expense, passion and mystery of the democratic process as practiced in the world’s premier republic.

headline: Medical Records: Top Secret
abstract: Patients face a tortuous process to obtain their own information.
lead_paragraph: MANY readers were shocked by my recent article about Peter Drier, who received a surprise bill of $117,000 from an out-of-network assistant surgeon who helped out during his back operation. But almost as surprising was how difficult it was during my reporting for Mr. Drier to extract his own records from the hospital.

headline: Private Manning’s Missing Medical Care
abstract: The military’s backward policy has left Chelsea Manning without essential treatment for more than a year.
lead_paragraph: As a matter of constitutional rights and basic decency, prisoners — including military prisoners — are entitled to proper care for their serious medical conditions. Yet, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel and other officials continue to deny medically necessary care to Chelsea Manning, the military prisoner formerly known as Pfc. Bradley Manning, who was convicted in August 2013 of leaking a vast cache of classified government documents.

headline: Republicans Are Only Sometimes the Party of Uber
abstract: The national party champions ride sharing, but officials at the state and local level often defend anticompetitive restrictions on businesses.
lead_paragraph: Republicans have hailed Uber, the smartphone-based car service, as a symbol of entrepreneurial innovation that could be strangled by misplaced government regulation. In August, the Republican National Committee urged supporters to sign a petition in support of the company, warning that “government officials are trying to block Uber from providing services simply because it’s cutting into the taxi unions’ profits.”

headline: Pricey Doughnuts, Pricier Homes, Priced-Out Readers
abstract: An affluent audience helps the paper pay the bills, but at what cost?
lead_paragraph: DAVID Gonzalez approached the South Bronx street-corner preacher and said he was from The New York Times.

headline: How We View A.D.H.D.
abstract: Readers discuss the reasons behind the increased diagnosis and treatment.
lead_paragraph: Readers discuss the reasons behind the increased diagnosis and treatment.

headline: Our ‘Mommy’ Problem
abstract: The current culture demands that every mother be all in, all the time.
lead_paragraph: WHEN I hear someone telling an expectant mother that having a baby will turn her into a new person, I can’t help but imagine a pathologically optimistic weather forecaster brightly warning that an oncoming tornado is about to give a town “an extreme makeover.” Becoming a mother doesn’t change you so much as violently refurbish you, even though you’re still the same underneath it all.

headline: The Fight Republicans Need Now
abstract: The G.O.P. needs to flesh out its agenda, and a Rand Paul-Marco Rubio rivalry could be the best way to do that.
lead_paragraph: FOR the second time in four years, the Republican Party has won a sweeping midterm victory without having a policy agenda to match. The party has a more-than-comfortable House majority, a solid Senate edge, and it faces a lame-duck president sealed in a bubble of sour self-regard. But if you look for consensus on the ends to which this new power should be turned, you’ll find ... well ... um ... repeal of the medical-device tax?

headline: Living Life Secondhand
abstract: Without electricity, I revel in the phases of the moon, the owls and loons.
lead_paragraph: “LIFE is an ecstasy,” Ralph Waldo Emerson wrote in an essay called “The Method of Nature,” a founding document of American transcendentalism. Life is also electricity, as our minds’ synapses and heart muscles would testify if they could.

headline: Eric Betzig
abstract: The Nobel Prize-winning physicist on how every child is a scientist and how each scientific paper is like making a record.
lead_paragraph: Eric Betzig is a physicist at the Howard Hughes Medical Institute’s Janelia Research Campus in Ashburn, Va. He won this year’s Nobel Prize in physical chemistry for his role in the development of super-resolved fluorescence microscopy, which allows visualization of minute biological processes such as DNA transfer and neural activity.

headline: Vibrant, Timid Berlin
abstract: Most of what the city is praised for stems from the big changes of 25 years ago and not the efforts of city administrations since then.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — A QUARTER-CENTURY ago today, the Berlin Wall fell, and since then this city has been on a roll. It’s one of the party capitals of the world and an affordable center for young artists and musicians, with enough layers of history to inspire a novelist for a few lifetimes. And its economy has benefited greatly from a growing start-up scene. In a country dominated by pleasant but boring cities, Berlin is Germany’s one truly cosmopolitan metropolis.

headline: Makers and Breakers
abstract: The other great geopolitical struggle in the world today is happening on the Internet.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — FLIP through any newspaper and go from the foreign news to the business pages and what you’ll see is the “other” great geopolitical struggle in the world today. It’s not the traditional one between nation states on land. It’s the struggle between “makers” and “breakers” on the Internet.

headline: Gray Hair and Silver Linings
abstract: I’m starting to see the worst of aging. But I’m more struck by the best of it.
lead_paragraph: I TURNED 50 just the other day, but I got the gift that I most needed nearly two years earlier, from a couple of strangers whom I never saw again.

headline: A Changed China Awaits Mr. Obama
abstract: President Xi Jinping of China is tugging his country in a hard-line direction. President Obama should stand up to him.
lead_paragraph: PRESIDENT OBAMA hasn’t even begun his state visit to China and he has already been mocked.

headline: A Promising Approach to Internet Rules
abstract: To ensure a fair hybrid system for Web traffic, the F.C.C. must be willing to limit the power of broadband giants.
lead_paragraph: This spring, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission  proposed a plan  that would have allowed broadband companies to divide the Internet into fast and slow lanes. That idea that was roundly attacked by advocacy groups like Public Knowledge and the American Civil Liberties Union, and now the chairman is reportedly considering a new approach.

headline: Prehistory’s Brilliant Future
abstract: Spectacular dinosaur finds represent just a fraction of what the fossil record has to tell us.
lead_paragraph: ONE morning last spring, I opened my email to see a photograph of the paleontologist Diego Pol. There he was, stretched out, feigning sleep, on a dinosaur’s femur roughly the size of a living room couch.

headline: Making My Therapist Laugh
abstract: I thought that a good patient should entertain.
lead_paragraph: My career in therapy has been a long and varied one, spanning four decades and calling on different aspects of my presented self. One of the odder things about therapy, I’ve discovered, is that it comes with little in the way of a code of conduct as opposed to other situations you find yourself in — little, that is, beyond showing up, paying your bill in a timely fashion, leaving when the session comes to an end and not upending any of the shards or vessels that might be lying around the office in homage to Freud’s passion for collecting antiquities.

headline: Dark Money Helped Win the Senate
abstract: Now the chances for limiting secret, special-interest donations seem more distant than ever.
lead_paragraph: The next Senate was just elected on the greatest wave of secret, special-interest money ever raised in a congressional election. What are the chances that it will take action to reduce the influence of money in politics?

headline: What We’re Watching: Sunday Shows
abstract: Republicans swept in the midterm elections and the Sunday shows will showcase several newcomers to Congress.
lead_paragraph: Republicans swept the midterm elections this week, retaking control of both houses of Congress, several governors’ mansions and statehouses. President Obama, who stayed home on Election Day, will appear on CBS’s “Face the Nation” to discuss his plans for the final two years of his presidency with a Republican-controlled Congress.

headline: Deft Footwork Updates a Classic
abstract: “Irving Berlin’s Holiday Inn” is a reworking of the 1942 movie musical for the stage by Gordon Greenberg and Chad Hodge, who have woven in additional tunes by Berlin.
lead_paragraph: Times do change, so turning a corny, conventional 1942 movie musical like “Holiday Inn” into a 2014 stage offering does entail risk. But the final production of the Goodspeed Opera House season — and of Michael P. Price’s 46-year tenure as executive director — manages to step nimbly around the pitfalls. It avoids both desecrating the movie that gave the world “White Christmas” and distressing a contemporary audience with “Abraham,” the film’s appalling blackface number (sometimes omitted from TV broadcasts, as it is here).

headline: Personal Ways of Untangling the Political
abstract: “The Women’s Room: Female Perspectives on Men, Women, Family and Nation” is on view at the Hudson Valley Center for Contemporary Art in Peekskill, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: Hair pervades “The Women’s Room: Female Perspectives on Men, Women, Family and Nation,” an exhibition of short videos at the Hudson Valley Center for Contemporary Art. It is brushed, braided, snipped and shaved. It falls in golden curls from the head of a toddler, lies thinning and gray on the scalp of an old woman, blows seductively across the faces of flawless models who twirl in the wind.

headline: For LeBron James and the Cavaliers, a Passing Cloud
abstract: Sluggish ball movement kept Cleveland’s record at 1-3, but on Twitter, LeBron James told everyone to “relax,” and the team posted 25 assists in winning its next game.
lead_paragraph: LeBron James, for one, does not think it is time to panic.

headline: Seeking Her Own Stove, With Hopes of Teaching Others How to Use One
abstract: Despite homelessness and an injury, Amina Gilmore, 24, a full-time culinary student and the mother of a 2-year-old, has kept her eyes on the goal of opening a cooking school.
lead_paragraph: Amina Gilmore spent one of her first nights of homelessness on the No. 1 train, guarding her 1-year-old son as he slept. The next day she went to class. Even as her life shifted and balances wavered in a few short years, Ms. Gilmore kept her eyes fixed on her goal.

headline: A Musical Education Full of Sweat and Sequins
abstract: “Celebrating the Music of Marvin Hamlisch,” at Molloy College in Rockville Centre, N.Y., will star several students from the college’s joint program with CAP21, a conservatory in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Peggy Sue Johnson, a theater arts student at Molloy College in Rockville Centre, didn’t sing her best at the audition for “Celebrating the Music of Marvin Hamlisch,” a musical theater event set to take place Saturday at the Madison Theater on the Molloy campus.

headline: Indian Muslims Lose Hope in National Secular Party
abstract: With a stridently right-wing Hindu nationalist group sweeping elections across India, Muslims have lost faith in the Indian National Congress and are turning to a sectarian party signaling changes.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — When he set out on a muggy morning in mid-October to vote in the Maharashtra State legislative elections, Zubair Azmi intended to cast his ballot, as usual, for the Indian National Congress, the party that has promised for years to protect Muslims like him.

headline: Ottawa Senators Are Welcoming an N.H.L. Crowd in Soccer’s Image
abstract: In an attempt to enliven the mood and build attendance in one of the N.H.L.'s smallest markets, the Senators are trying to foster the atmosphere of an avid soccer crowd for home games.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — The Ottawa Senators’ home arena was a bit too quiet, as it often is for regular-season games not involving the Toronto Maple Leafs or the Montreal Canadiens. The opponents last Tuesday night were the Detroit Red Wings, and most of the phlegmatic Senators crowd at Canadian Tire Centre sat and watched in hushed contemplation.

headline: Steelers Nation Swoops In to Annex Jets’ Territory
abstract: Jets fans, whose team is a dreadful 1-8, can expect a big turnout of Steelers fans on Sunday when Pittsburgh visits MetLife Stadium.
lead_paragraph: The Dallas Cowboys might be America’s Team, but when it comes to a national following, few teams rival the Pittsburgh Steelers.

headline: As Russia Draws Closer to China, U.S. Faces a New Challenge
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, faced with a West angry over his actions in Ukraine, has been strengthening ties to the East and will be in Beijing this coming week, as will President Obama.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama flies to Beijing on Sunday to renew efforts to refocus American foreign policy toward Asia. But when he lands, he will find the man who has done so much to frustrate him lately, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia. “You are pivoting to Asia,” Russia’s ambassador to Washington said last week, “but we’re already there.”

headline: U.S. Airstrikes in Iraq Target ISIS Leaders
abstract: Fighter jets from a United States-led coalition hit a gathering of leaders of the Islamic State group in northwestern Iraq on Saturday, and Iraqi officials said they believed a number of top militants had been killed.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — An airstrike by a United States-led coalition hit a gathering of leaders of the Islamic State jihadist group in northwestern Iraq on Saturday, and Iraqi officials said they believed that a number of top militants had been killed.

headline: Berlin’s Wall of Light
abstract: To commemorate the 25th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall, the artists Christopher and Marc Bauder created a border of lights called the “Lichtgrenze.”
lead_paragraph: To commemorate the 25th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall, the artists Christopher and Marc Bauder created a border of lights called the “Lichtgrenze.”

headline: Lights and Celebration Where a Wall Divided Berlin
abstract: An art installation with 8,000 illuminated balloons retraces the path of the Berlin Wall to celebrate the 25th anniversary of its fall.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Frank Ebert, a human-rights activist from East Berlin, was so sure the breach in the Berlin Wall was temporary that he spent part of his first day in the West stocking up on ink, paper, books and other materials that would be impossible to get once he returned to the Communist side.

headline: Arizona Law on Immigrant Smuggling Is Struck Down
abstract: A federal district county judge ruled that the law, which allowed a sheriff to target immigrants, was trumped by federal statutes.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — A federal judge here has struck down a state law against smuggling immigrants into the United States, the latest state-enacted measure against illegal immigration in Arizona to be thwarted in court.

headline: A Passionate N.F.L. City, if in Absentia
abstract: Los Angeles has rabid fans of the league, but no franchise, which does not seem to bother people much.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — When running back Ben Tate burst into the end zone Thursday night, giving the Cleveland Browns an early lead, the St. Felix bar in the heart of Hollywood erupted. Andy Lytle, in his Bernie Kosar No. 19 jersey, shouted, “Here we go Brownies, here we go.” And the other 40 or so Browns fans answered, “Woof, woof, woof.”

headline: Giants Focus on Starting Fast, and Get Nowhere
abstract: The Giants have not scored on their opening drive for 19 consecutive games and have been outscored this season in the first quarter by 51-14.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — It is customary for an N.F.L. team to script the first 10 to 15 plays it plans to run to start each game. The offensive coordinator, after spending days and nights studying the defense of the next opponent, usually designs a sequence of plays he thinks have a high chance of success based on his team’s strengths and the other team’s weaknesses. The starting quarterback offers opinions, too.

headline: U.S. Citizens Released from North Korea
abstract: Kenneth Bae and Matthew Todd Miller are released after months of detention in North Korea.
lead_paragraph: Kenneth Bae and Matthew Todd Miller are released after months of detention in North Korea.

headline: New York Prosecutor Accused of Attacking Woman at a Bar
abstract: Eli Cherkasky, a Manhattan assistant district attorney, has been arrested on charges that he berated and then choked a woman.
lead_paragraph: A New York City prosecutor has been arrested on charges that he berated and then choked a woman at an Irish bar on the East Side of Manhattan.

headline: Fans Unload (and Upload) Ire, Urging Firings of Coaches and Executives
abstract: A group of Jets fans seeking the firing of General Manager John Idzik have joined the increasing number of sports devotees conducting electronic campaigns to pursue such goals.
lead_paragraph: The online pleas for sideline and front-office changes simmer on Twitter and Facebook. The demands persist on blogs and petition sites like MoveOn.org.

headline: Manhattan Speeder Says He Has Fled to Canada
abstract: Adam Tang was convicted in absentia of reckless endangerment after posting on YouTube a video of himself racing around Manhattan in 24 minutes.
lead_paragraph: A driver convicted in absentia of reckless endangerment for racing around Manhattan in 24 minutes said in a telephone interview that he had fled to Canada and did not intend to return to face a sentence of up to a year in jail.

headline: Sunday’s Matchup: Giants (3-5) at Seahawks (5-3)
abstract: Russell Wilson could have a field day taking advantage of whatever combination of young and inexperienced cornerbacks the Giants put on the field.
lead_paragraph: 4:25 p.m., Fox

headline: Sunday’s Matchup: Steelers (6-3) at Jets (1-8)
abstract: Ben Roethlisberger will be facing an ineffective Jets secondary depleted by injuries.
lead_paragraph: 1 p.m., CBS

headline: Colorful Characters
abstract: Tom McCoy makes our Sunday a bit more colorful.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — I don’t give out awards for puzzles, because I think that if they’ve made it into The New York Times, they already have something special going for them. If I did, however, I would give Tom McCoy’s puzzle a gold star, just for all of the thematic theatrics that he has piled into today’s grid. It took me a while to fully appreciate the depth of the theme, but when I got it, as Will Shortz says below, it was definitely a wow.

headline: Needing to Hire, Chief of V.A. Tries to Sell Doctors on Change
abstract: Robert A. McDonald, secretary of the Department of Veterans Affairs, has been courting medical students, young doctors and nurses as he seeks to add 28,000 workers to the department.
lead_paragraph: BURLINGTON, Vt. — The longtime corporate executive entered the college lecture hall to make a pitch the medical students had probably heard before: He was offering good starting salaries, well-financed research opportunities and rewarding work with patients in great need.

headline: With Fear of Being Sidelined, Tea Party Sees the Republican Rise as New Threat
abstract: As Republicans on Capitol Hill move from being the opposition party to being one that has to show it can govern, a powerful tension is emerging between its establishment and its activist wing.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As most Republicans were taking a victory lap the morning after the elections, a group of conservatives huddled anxiously in a conference room not far from Capitol Hill and agreed that now is the time for confrontation, not compromise and conciliation.

headline: Survival English
abstract: At Oakland International High School, about a quarter of the students are unaccompanied minors and face possible deportation back to Central American countries.
lead_paragraph: At Oakland International High School, about a quarter of the students are unaccompanied minors and face possible deportation back to Central American countries.

headline: Honduran Youth Finds Welcome Mat at Oakland School Designed for Immigrants
abstract: Oakland International High School in California is one of a few schools in the country helping child migrants build better lives than the ones they left behind.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Above the bunk bed Lester Valladaras sleeps on each night, a collection of photos of his three younger sisters and his mother, Maribel Irias, is tacked to the wall. Ms. Irias made the collage during an English class a couple of years ago, before Lester came to America, writing this explanation next to the images: “I have three daughters here with me and two sons still in Honduras. I miss them very much. I hope they come here one day.”

headline: Powerful Afghan Police Chief Puts Fear in Taliban and Their Enemies
abstract: Lt. Gen. Abdul Raziq has effectively checked the insurgents while being accused of human rights abuses, presenting Afghanistan’s new president with a dilemma.
lead_paragraph: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — With his boyish looks and hesitant smile, Lt. Gen. Abdul Raziq cuts a modest figure that belies his reputation as a man of both courage and cruelty: the tough-guy sheriff who kept the Taliban out of Kandahar.

headline: Recreating Adam, From Hundreds of Fragments, After the Fall
abstract: A dozen years after a 500-year-old marble Adam by the Renaissance sculptor Tullio Lombardo broke into hundreds of pieces, the Metropolitan Museum of Art is poised to reintroduce it to the public.
lead_paragraph: It happened at 6 on a Sunday night. Adam — a strapping, 6-foot-3-inch marble sculpture by the Venetian Renaissance master Tullio Lombardo — fell to the ground on a patio at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, smashing into hundreds of pieces. “Nobody knew what had happened — it could have been foul play,” said Jack Soultanian, a conservator who was called to the museum that night in 2002.

headline: Clement A. Price, a Cheerleader for Newark, Dies at 69
abstract: Professor Price was a Rutgers scholar with a deep affection for Newark, a city he wrote about, taught about, promoted and defended.
lead_paragraph: Clement Alexander Price, a distinguished history professor who fell in love with Newark, a city some thought unlovable, and went on to write books and articles about it, as well as to lead tours, brief journalists and shamelessly promote it, died on Wednesday in New Brunswick, N.J. He was 69.

headline: Britain Plans for Future of Shale Oil and Gas Industry
abstract: The government of Prime Minister David Cameron said it would create a sovereign wealth fund to invest future proceeds from oil and gas extracted from shale deposits.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British government said on Saturday that it would establish a sovereign wealth fund with the proceeds from extracting natural gas from shale.

headline: Atlanta Symphony Orchestra Agrees to a New Labor Deal
abstract: The agreement, which resolves a two-month lockout, will give the musicians small raises but require them to pay higher health insurance rates.
lead_paragraph: The Atlanta Symphony Orchestra announced on Saturday that it would end its two-month lockout after reaching a deal that would give its musicians small raises but require them to pay more for their health insurance, while also allowing the orchestra to leave positions vacant longer.

headline: Well-Trod Victims of the Oil Fields: Roads Used to Get There
abstract: A rush to the Eagle Ford Shale — the oil-rich fields that have brought prosperity to many in South Texas — is clogging and crumbling the roads taken to get there.
lead_paragraph: CRYSTAL CITY, Tex. — With much of the town sleeping, Tino Mendoza walked across a moonlit bus yard on a recent morning, preparing for his first trip of the day. While inspecting bus No. 32, he surveyed the latest casualty of this region’s newfound oil and gas economy: a small but growing crack in the windshield.

headline: Getting Close to Terror, but Not to Stop It
abstract: Despite the C.I.A.'s concerns, a Port Authority officer working with the F.B.I. kept ties to sources inside the Sunni terrorist group Jundallah.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After a car bombing in southeastern Iran killed 11 Revolutionary Guard members in 2007, a C.I.A. officer noticed something surprising in the agency’s files: an intelligence report, filed ahead of the bombing, that had warned that something big was about to happen in Iran.

headline: On Endangered Species List in Austin: White Democrats
abstract: After Tuesday’s election, 63 of 181 seats in the Texas House will be held by Democrats. Of those 63, 37 are Hispanic, and 17 are African-American.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — When Donna Howard of Austin won a seat in the Texas House in 2006, she was the only white woman among Democrats in the state Legislature.

headline: Army Returns Interception 99 Yards to Repel UConn’s Rally in the Bronx
abstract: Chris Carnegie of Army returned the ball 99 yards for a touchdown with 28 seconds left that secured the victory at Yankee Stadium.
lead_paragraph: It is not easy being a Connecticut football player in November. The calendar flips to college basketball season, and you are battling for attention on your own campus with not just one national championship team, but two: the men’s and the women’s programs.

headline: Other Instruments, Beware; the Pipe Organs Cometh
abstract: Over six days, world-famous organists will perform 20 concerts, mostly on Aeolian-Skinner organs, and scholars, teachers and organ builders will host several talks at the East Texas Pipe Organ Festival.
lead_paragraph: KILGORE, Tex. — East Texas is about to be booming. Not from the fracking that is waking the small cities outside of Dallas, but from an arts revival that is tapping into another local resource — one of the country’s highest concentrations of mid-20th century Aeolian-Skinner organs.

headline: Turnout Down in Texas, and Democrats Claim a Reason: Voter ID Law
abstract: The overall number of votes cast in this year’s election was less than in 2010 — by about 271,000.
lead_paragraph: Say this for the state’s new voter ID law — it gave Texas Democrats a patsy for the thumping they got on election night.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 8, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, November 9, 2014
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, November 9, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “She really is the soul of grace under pressure.”

headline: The Mascot Will Sit This One Out, Thanks
abstract: For all seven of L.S.U.'s home games this season, Mike the Tiger has refused to leave his well-appointed residence for the mobile cage that would take him into the stadium.
lead_paragraph: BATON ROUGE, La. — Few universities venerate their sports mascots as much as Louisiana State cherishes Mike the Tiger — or Mike VI, as he is formally known here. He resides in a 15,000-square-foot habitat across the street from Tiger Stadium, replete with a waterfall, a pool and an Italianate tower, and professionals at L.S.U.'s veterinary school look after his teeth, claws and paws each day.

headline: Ying Wang and Patrick Dooley
abstract: The bride works in video advertising and technology and the groom is a management consultant.
lead_paragraph: Ying Wang, a daughter of Xiaojun Wu and Dunrui Wang of Chantilly, Va., was married Saturday to Patrick Joseph Dooley, the son of Maureen A. Dooley and Joseph P. Dooley of Durham, Conn. The Rev. John Unni, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Cecilia Church in Boston.

headline: Julie Wechsler, Erik Scott
abstract: The bride works in marketing; the groom teaches math.
lead_paragraph: Julie Alyse Wechsler and Erik Jordon Scott were married Saturday by Rabbi Elliot N. Perlstein at the Atrium at Curtis Center, an event space in Philadelphia.

headline: Laura Laughlin, Stirling Cox
abstract: The bride runs a matchmaking business; the groom oversees a network consulting company.
lead_paragraph: Laura Ashton Laughlin and Stirling Alexandre Cox were married Saturday evening at the Ritz-Carlton, Naples, in Naples, Fla. The Rev. Richard S. Riccardi, a priest of the Old Catholic Church of New Utrecht, officiated.

headline: Swept Away in a Single-Prop Plane
abstract: Mr. Weiss and Ms. Osofsky were both fed up with dating, then suddenly they met and their relationship took flight.
lead_paragraph: Cynthia Greenberger Osofsky and Dr. Fredric K. Weiss are to be married Sunday at the Washington Crossing Inn in Washington Crossing, Pa. Rabbi Yair D. Robinson will officiate.

headline: Mary McConnell, Daniel Cocoziello
abstract: The couple were married at the Church of the Resurrection in Rye, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: Mary Elizabeth McConnell, a daughter of Helen C. McConnell and Mathew J. McConnell of Rye, N.Y., was married Saturday to Daniel Federico Cocoziello, a son of Sharon L. Cocoziello and Peter J. Cocoziello of Oldwick, N.J. Msgr. Donald M. Dwyer performed the ceremony at the Church of the Resurrection in Rye.

headline: Lisa Applebaum, Michael Eskenazi
abstract: The bride is a special-education teacher and the groom is a lawyer.
lead_paragraph: Lisa Applebaum and Michael Evan Eskenazi are to be married Sunday at Liberty Warehouse in Brooklyn. Rabbi Stuart L. Berman is to officiate.

headline: Joui Hessel and James Hexter
abstract: The bride is a rabbi; the groom is a senior partner in an investment firm.
lead_paragraph: Rabbi Joui Marlo Hessel and James Robert Hexter were married Saturday evening at the Mandarin Oriental hotel in Miami. Rabbi M. Bruce Lustig led the ceremony, with Rabbi Susan N. Shankman participating.

headline: Julie Weiswasser, Andrew Hyman
abstract: The couple, both corporate lawyers, were married at the Longboat Key Club in Florida.
lead_paragraph: Julie Miriam Weiswasser and Andrew Steven Hyman were married Saturday in Longboat Key, Fla. David Leeb, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated at the Resort at Longboat Key Club.

headline: Adele Lewis and Jay Gleacher
abstract: The bride is pursuing an M.B.A. in London, where the groom is a partner in a commodities trading firm.
lead_paragraph: Frances Adele Lewis and Jay Stevens Gleacher were married Saturday at the Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York. The Rev. Matthew F. Heyd, an Episcopal priest and the rector of the church, performed the ceremony.

headline: Warm Words With a Frequent Visitor
abstract: The couple are graduates of the University of Virginia.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Mitchell Yates, the daughter of Mary M. Yates and Charles R. Yates Jr. of Atlanta, was married Saturday evening to Brian John Umana, the son of Victoria J. Doran of Alexandria, Va., and John Umana of Washington. The Rev. Paul N. Walker, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Charlottesville, Va.

headline: Megan Romigh, Sidney Jackler
abstract: The bride is a Navy lieutenant; the groom is a physician assistant.
lead_paragraph: Lt. Megan Elizabeth Romigh and Sidney Michael Jackler were married Saturday at the Naval Station Norfolk Chapel in Norfolk, Va. Dr. Richard Zweifler, a friend of the couple, received permission from Virginia to officiate.

headline: Marcy Richardson, Scott Murphy
abstract: An operatic soprano marries a content producer for an ad agency.
lead_paragraph: Marcy Richardson and Scott Frederick Murphy were married Saturday evening at Landmark on the Park, an event space in New York. Jean Richardson, a Presbyterian minister and an aunt of the bride, officiated.

headline: Kristen Lukiewski, Michael Szczerban
abstract: The couple met as editors of rival literary journals at Carnegie Mellon.
lead_paragraph: Kristen Lukiewski and Andrew Michael Szczerban were married Saturday under Pennsylvania’s self-uniting marriage statute at the Landis Valley Village and Farm Museum in Lancaster, Pa.

headline: Lauren Barnett, Michael Medvin
abstract: The bride is a fashion executive and the groom is an associate director with the YES Network.
lead_paragraph: Lauren Lee Barnett and Michael Jay Medvin were married Saturday evening at the Glen Island Harbour Club in New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbi Joshua Goldstein officiated.

headline: Mary Monahan, Michael Kaufman
abstract: An assistant district attorney and an investment analyst wed in New Haven.
lead_paragraph: Mary Elizabeth Monahan and Michael David Kaufman were married Saturday at Battell Chapel on the Yale campus in New Haven. The Rev. Robert L. Beloin, a Roman Catholic chaplain, officiated, with Rabbi Richard S. Winer assisting.

headline: Marlena Reese and Reginald McKnight
abstract: The couple were married in the Lawless Memorial Chapel on the campus of Dillard University in New Orleans.
lead_paragraph: Marlena Elizabeth Reese and Reginald Brantley McKnight were married Saturday evening at Lawless Memorial Chapel on the campus of Dillard University in New Orleans. The Rev. Dr. Henry Masters Sr., a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony, with the Rev. Wallace J. McKnight Sr., an African Methodist Episcopal priest and an uncle of the groom, taking part.

headline: Rachel Denny, Laurence Jackson
abstract: A fund-raiser for Jazz at Lincoln Center weds an N.Y.U. administrator.
lead_paragraph: Rachel Eliza Denny and Laurence Arthur Jackson were married Saturday at Linden Terrace in Fort Tryon Park in New York. Kristopher Marx, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

headline: Leigh Jones and Christina Shaffer
abstract: The two women were joined under Pennsylvania’s self-uniting marriage statute.
lead_paragraph: Leigh Alexandra Jones and Christina Beth Shaffer were married Friday at their home in Philadelphia under Pennsylvania’s self-uniting marriage statute.

headline: Lindsey Goldstein, David Ross
abstract: The couple met at the University of Michigan, from which they both graduated.
lead_paragraph: Lindsey Beth Goldstein, a daughter of Eileen R. Goldstein and Paul D. Goldstein of Highland Park, Ill., was married Saturday evening to David Lawrence Ross, the son of Jodie L. Ross of Roslyn, N.Y., and Robert M. Ross of Long Beach, N.Y. Rabbi Vernon Kurtz officiated, with Cantor Larry Goller assisting, at the Standard Club, a private social club in Chicago.

headline: Amari Coombs, Daniel Kopelow
abstract: The couple were married at the Chop Shop in Chicago.
lead_paragraph: Amari Joia Coombs and Daniel Avi Kopelow were married Saturday at the Chop Shop, an events space in Chicago. The officiant was Teresa Payne, a grandmother of the bride who became a minister of American Marriage Ministries for the event.

headline: Dana Cohen, Adam Wolf
abstract: A structural engineer and a software development manager wed at the Stone House at Stirling Ridge.
lead_paragraph: Dana Michelle Cohen, the daughter of Lisa D. Cohen and Don Cohen of East Brunswick, N.J., is to be married Sunday to Adam Paul Wolf, a son of Meryl J. Wolf of River Vale, N.J., and the late William Wolf. Rabbi Beth Kalisch is to officiate, with Cantor David Frommer taking part at the Stone House at Stirling Ridge, an event space in Warren, N.J.

headline: Lauren Elinsky and Robert Meek
abstract: The bride works in the Office of the Director of National Intelligence; the groom is a director at KPMG, the accounting firm.
lead_paragraph: Lauren Beth Elinsky and Robert Keith Meek were married Saturday evening at Trummer’s on Main, a restaurant in Clifton, Va. Rabbi Laszlo Berkowits officiated.

headline: Karina Conlin, Jonathan Chang
abstract: The couple married at Monona Terrace in Madison, Wis.
lead_paragraph: Karina Anne Conlin, the daughter of Victoria L. Conlin of McFarland, Wis., was married Saturday to Dr. Jonathan Stanley Chang, a son of Jean W. Chang and Dr. Stanley Chang of New York. The Rev. Connie Engmann, who was ordained at Circle Sanctuary and Pathways of Light Spiritual College, officiated at Monona Terrace, the Frank Lloyd Wright-designed convention center in Madison, Wis.

headline: Libra LaGrone, Casius Pealer III
abstract: The couple married in a park in New Orleans.
lead_paragraph: Libra Marie LaGrone and Casius Henry Pealer III were married Saturday at the Capital One Pavilion in Woldenberg Riverfront Park in New Orleans. Lloyd Shields, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

headline: Stevie Sharpe-Jones, Hakim Surmon
abstract: The bride works for the TV Guide Network and the groom is a banker at JPMorgan Chase.
lead_paragraph: Stephanie Marial Sharpe-Jones and Hakim Jamal Surmon were married Saturday at the W Hoboken Hotel in Hoboken, N.J. Sola Winley, a friend of the groom who is a Universal Life minister, officiated at a ceremony that was led by Timothy H. Marshall, a deacon in the Baptist church.

headline: Ohio State Rolls Past Michigan State to Bolster Playoff Hopes
abstract: The Buckeyes displayed offensive variety and precision off the poised passing performance of the freshman quarterback J. T. Barrett on the way to a dominating victory over the Spartans.
lead_paragraph: EAST LANSING, Mich. — The players and the coaches of No. 8 Michigan State and No. 14 Ohio State, speaking before Saturday’s game, described their teams as mirror images.

headline: Challenger Sergey Kovalev Wins Two Titles From Bernard Hopkins
abstract: The 49-year-old Hopkins lasted 12 rounds, but he could not match the relentlessness of Sergey Kovalev, who won a unanimous victory in the Atlantic City bout.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTIC CITY — Until facing Bernard Hopkins on Saturday night, Sergey Kovalev had never fought beyond the eighth round. He had dominated each of his previous opponents. Hopkins, two months short of his 50th birthday, put up a valiant effort and lasted the full 12 rounds, but he could not match the relentlessness of Kovalev.

headline: Corrections: November 9, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on November 9, 2014.
lead_paragraph: SPORTS

headline: Explosions Rock Afghan Capital After Months of Calm
abstract: In one attack, an explosive detonated near a bus carrying soldiers; in another, a suicide bomber infiltrated Police Headquarters. Casualties appeared to be limited.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Three blasts on Sunday morning punctured months of relative calm in Kabul, with the Taliban carrying out at least two attacks, including a suicide bombing inside the city’s heavily fortified Police Headquarters that reportedly targeted senior officials there.

headline: Afghan Women, Imprisoned
abstract: After covering the fall of the Taliban, Zohreh Soleimani returned to Afghanistan to examine the lives of women in prison.
lead_paragraph: Zohreh Soleimani first visited Afghanistan in 2001, when she was among the first journalists to reach the city of Herat after the fall of the Taliban. Some of her co-workers wondered why she got so close to the refugees she photographed, many of whom were sick. But she wanted a more intimate view of a country that had been cut off from the world.

headline: Ireland Vies to Remain Silicon Valley’s Low-Tax Home Away From Home
abstract: Though Ireland has been under international pressure to close loopholes that have drawn companies like Google and Microsoft, the country is still touting its low-tax appeal.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — In a sprawling conference center on the outskirts of the Irish capital, more than 20,000 people from the global tech industry gathered last week to sign deals and swap contacts.

headline: The Daily Gift: Self-Inking Stamps for Custom Correspondence
abstract: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.
lead_paragraph: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.

headline: Jeb Bush May Run for President, George W. Bush Says
abstract: Former President George W. Bush puts the odds at “50-50” that his brother, Jeb, will become the third member of their immediate family to look to call the White House home.
lead_paragraph: Will Jeb Bush, a former Florida governor, try to become the third member of his immediate family to run for president? His brother calls it “a tossup.”

headline: Keynes Derangement Syndrome
abstract: The vindication that must not be acknowledged.
lead_paragraph: One of my favorite quotes in economics comes from Frank Graham, who wrote that disorder is the sole substitute in social science for the controlled experiments of the natural sciences. What he meant was that drastic events, outside the normal run of experience, offer a much better way to test competing theories than day-to-day events, which aren’t too hard to shoehorn into various dogmas.

headline: Economics as a Science, Not
abstract: Evidence? Never mind.
lead_paragraph: From Chris Sims’s Nobel lecture (pdf):

headline: On a Memory-Filled Date, the Fall of the Berlin Wall Stands Front and Center
abstract: Chancellor Angela Merkel led Germany in celebrations flavored with a mix of triumph and tragedy to commemorate the fall of the wall on Nov. 9, 1989.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — If memory needs places, Berlin was the place this weekend to remember the horror of the Berlin Wall, and the joy of unexpected liberation that accompanied its fall 25 years ago Sunday.

headline: 1889: London Celebrates Lord Mayor’s Day
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Sir Henry Isaacs celebrates his election as Lord Mayor with a parade in London in 1889.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The double anniversary of Lord Mayor’s Day and the Prince of Wales’s birthday was kept up with more than usual éclat to-day [Nov.9]. Indeed, old stagers who have seen the show for twenty years past say nothing has ever been seen to equal the pageant of to-day.

headline: Post-Election, Obama Says the Blame Is on Him
abstract: In an interview, President Obama called the Democratic election losses on Tuesday a “failure of politics” that he must change in the final two years of his presidency.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Just days after his party was routed in the midterm elections, President Obama said that he and his White House team had not succeeded in effectively selling the benefits of his policies to the American people, calling it a “failure of politics” that he must change in the final two years of his presidency.

headline: Oscars 2015: A Scrum for Votes at the Governors Awards
abstract: Ostensibly held to honor Hollywood veterans like Maureen O’Hara and Harry Belafonte, the evening turned into a rush for contender status.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The movie academy’s Governors Awards, typically one of the classier prizefests, teetered on the brink Saturday of becoming the Golden Globes, one of the gabbier — and grabbier — galas on Hollywood’s annual pre-Oscar circuit.

headline: Catalonia Overwhelmingly Votes for Independence From Spain in Straw Poll
abstract: Defying objections from the Spanish government in Madrid, about two million people took part in a symbolic vote presented as a prelude to secession.
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA — Defying legal and political objections from Madrid, more than two million Catalans took part on Sunday in a straw poll on independence that the region’s governing politicians have presented as a prelude to breaking away from the rest of Spain.

headline: Tensions Mount as Israeli Arabs Protest Police Shooting
abstract: An Arab man wielding a knife was killed by the police after he attacked a police vehicle, but a video appeared to show him retreating when he was shot.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israel’s Arab minority observed a one-day general strike on Sunday to protest the fatal police shooting of a young Arab man over the weekend, an event that raised tensions here and prompted charges that the Israeli police resort to force rashly when dealing with Arab citizens.

headline: What’s On TV Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (13, 49) WORRICKER: TURKS AND CAICOS Bill Nighy reprises his role as the British spy Johnny Worricker, now on the lam from his former employees on a Caribbean island overrun with New Jersey businessmen investing in a clandestine project. Winona Ryder (above, with Mr. Nighy) plays the group’s vampy publicist, and Christopher Walken is an eccentric C.I.A. operative; both befriend Johnny. Then a British philanthropist (Rupert Graves) arrives with an associate (Helena Bonham Carter) whom Johnny knows well — prompting him to revive his cloak-and-dagger lifestyle in this follow-up to “Page Eight,” Part 1 in a trilogy of thrillers written and directed by the playwright David Hare. “Mr. Hare doesn’t want to puzzle and intrigue viewers, but to hammer home his outrage over Britain’s contribution to the invasion of Iraq and the United States’ secret prisoner rendition program,” Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times about this “Masterpiece Contemporary” production. Still, she added, “viewers can trust that Mr. Nighy will deliver the most subtle, colorful performance that can be squeezed out of a sermon.”

headline: ‘Big Hero 6’ Leads the Box Office; ‘Interstellar’ Takes Second
abstract: The animated Disney film earned a little over $56.2 million domestically; the space drama drew $50 million.
lead_paragraph: It was by no means a crash landing, but Christopher Nolan’s aggressively promoted “Interstellar” had some engine trouble nonetheless, losing the weekend box office race to the animated “Big Hero 6.”

headline: With Signature Moves, R&B Romeo Takes a Turn as Casanova
abstract: Usher’s latest tour stopped by Madison Square Garden, where he mixed beloved oldies with singles from his delayed album “UR.”
lead_paragraph: Video close-ups showed the sweat pouring down Usher’s face just a few songs after he started his set at Madison Square Garden on Friday. And no wonder. From the moment he hit the stage, he had been dancing nonstop: up on his toes, doing tight little twirls, strutting, pointing, making quick stop-start hand gestures, snaking his body from head to foot and matching the angled poses of his dancers, much of it while singing or rapping. It was a show of superhuman precision, control and stamina, of hitting his marks on a heavily trafficked stage, and he was just getting started.

headline: Commemorating the Fall of the Berlin Wall
abstract: On Nov. 9, Germany marked the 25th anniversary of the fall of the wall. Here is a look back at scenes of the wall in decades past.
lead_paragraph: On Nov. 9, Germany marked the 25th anniversary of the fall of the wall. Here is a look back at scenes of the wall in decades past.

headline: 1939: France Aims for ‘Total Peace’, Says Finance Minister
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: France Aims for ‘Total Peace’, Says Finance Minister, Paul Reynaud 1939.
lead_paragraph: France is determined to fight Hitler’s ‘‘totalitarian war” until it obtains a ‘‘totalitarian peace,’’ Paul Reynaud, French Minister of Finance, told a record gathering of members and guests of the American Club of Paris at its weekly luncheon at the Cercle Interallié yesterday.

headline: In India, Modi Expands His Council of Ministers
abstract: Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s government announced the appointment of 26 new ministers, a long-expected move to reward his political allies and spread out some of the work needed to fulfill his agenda.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Prime Minister Narendra Modi expanded his council of ministers on Sunday in a long-expected move to reward his political allies and spread out some of the work needed to fulfill his agenda.

headline: Ina Ginsburg, Arts Patron and Washington Hostess, Dies at 98
abstract: Ms. Ginsburg, who fled to the United States from Austria during World War II, went on to champion the works of modern artists and actors, including Andy Warhol and Arnold Schwarzenegger.
lead_paragraph: Ina Ginsburg, who for more than half a century elevated the arts and the art of socializing in the nation’s capital as a prominent hostess, a fund-raiser and a well-dressed decoder of Washington ways for unelected outsiders, including Andy Warhol and Arnold Schwarzenegger, died on Sunday at her home there. She was 98.

headline: St. Francis Manuscripts Headed to U.S., in First Trip Out of Italy in 700 Years
abstract: Thirteen artifacts from the Sacred Convent of St. Francis in Assisi underwent meticulous last-minute restoration before beginning their journey on Monday.
lead_paragraph: TEOLO, Italy — Scattered around the steel table of a monastery in the Veneto region of Northern Italy are manuscripts, one with green, red and intensely blue medieval miniatures of dragons, another adorned with ornate leaves culminating in golden flowers.

headline: Dawn of Nuclear Arms, Declassified
abstract: Waves of declassified photographs and movies from the nation’s push to make Little Boy and Fat Man — the world’s first atom bombs — are exciting to a generation less familiar with the United States’ atomic past.
lead_paragraph: It was near midnight when John Coster-Mullen, the author of “Atom Bombs: The Top Secret Inside Story of Little Boy and Fat Man,” was scrutinizing one image among hundreds newly released by Los Alamos, the birthplace of the bomb.

headline: Rosberg Edges Out Hamilton in Brazil Grand Prix
abstract: With only one race left in the season, the Mercedes teammates are battling it out for the drivers' title.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — With two races left in the Formula One season before the Brazilian Grand Prix on Sunday, all Lewis Hamilton needed to do to take his second drivers’ title in the final race in Abu Dhabi in two weeks was to finish in second place in both races — even if his Mercedes teammate, Nico Rosberg, won both.

headline: Philip M. Crane, Former Illinois Congressman and Conservative Leader, Dies at 84
abstract: Mr. Crane, a Republican, was best known as leader of the American Conservative Union, leading its unsuccessful fight against the treaties turning the Panama Canal over to Panama.
lead_paragraph: Former Representative Philip M. Crane of Illinois, who fought for conservative causes in 35 years in the House and who made a failed run for president in 1980, died on Saturday in Jefferson, Md. He was 84.

headline: Sun, Fun And Trouble In Brazil
abstract: In Nikkole Salter’s “Carnaval,” three men travel to Rio de Janeiro, in an exploration of black masculinity and friendship.
lead_paragraph: Tourists of the world: Stay home.

headline: Excerpt: ‘The Band Wagon’
abstract: Brian Stokes Mitchell and Tony Sheldon sing “I Guess I’ll Have to Change My Plan” from the Encores! production of “The Band Wagon,” at City Center.
lead_paragraph: Brian Stokes Mitchell and Tony Sheldon sing “I Guess I’ll Have to Change My Plan” from the Encores! production of “The Band Wagon,” at City Center.

headline: New HealthCare.gov Opens Early to Allow for Review of Plans
abstract: The Obama administration said that people would be able to compare their options beginning Monday and that the site was now easier to use.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration said Sunday that consumers could shop for health insurance and compare their options on HealthCare.gov starting Monday, even before the open enrollment period formally begins five days later.

headline: Finally, Against Steelers, Jets Look Unlike Themselves
abstract: The Jets ended an eight-game skid, scoring the game’s first 17 points and holding Ben Roethlisberger, who had thrown for 862 yards in his last two games, to 54 in the first half.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Imagine being sequestered for the last nine weeks, with no access to television or smartphones or the news media, and imagine that the first act of re-entry involved attending the Jets’ game Sunday at MetLife Stadium.

headline: Michael Barker Elected Co-Chairman of Museum of the Moving Image
abstract: The Sony Pictures Classics co-president will take over from Herbert S. Schlosser, who will be chairman emeritus.
lead_paragraph: Michael Barker, who has been a cinematic tastemaker as a founder and co-president of Sony Pictures Classics, will join the Museum of the Moving Image as co-chairman of its board of trustees, the museum plans to announce on Monday. He succeeds Herbert S. Schlosser, the former NBC president and chief executive, who served as the chairman beginning in 1985, and became co-chairman, in 2013, with Ivan L. Lustig.

headline: Men in Towels on the Prowl and Other Steamy Scenes From the Sauna
abstract: “John,” by the choreographer Lloyd Newson and based on multiple interviews, is about a gay sauna as a transformative experience.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It is astonishing to note how the range of British dance theater has changed and grown over recent decades. In 1980, there were virtually no one-choreographer troupes or seasons other than Lindsay Kemp’s; almost every dance ensemble, small or large, was a repertory company. Now, the names Richard Alston, Matthew Bourne, Russell Maliphant, Wayne McGregor and Lloyd Newson are just the most internationally known of a larger number of British or British-based choreographers with their own dance collectives; and some of these have won as much recognition in the world of theater as that of dance.

headline: Frick’s Plan for Expansion Faces Fight Over Loss of Garden
abstract: Preservation groups opposed to the Frick Collection’s plans for a six-story addition say the museum is going back on a 1973 promise to make a garden permanent.
lead_paragraph: Officials at the Frick Collection knew their plan to build a six-story addition to a beloved, landmark, jewel-box museum would draw detractors. But leaders of that Fifth Avenue museum say they didn’t expect it to get so intense so fast.

headline: Country Star Strides Back Onto the Stage
abstract: Garth Brooks is back after more than a decade with “Man Against Machine,” a new album of originals.
lead_paragraph: More than a decade ago, Garth Brooks did the most admirable thing any successful performer can do: He walked away.

headline: From Eerie Shards to Vivid Emotion
abstract: The Pacifica Quartet performed the New York premiere of a work by Shulamit Ran in a program that also included works by Mendelssohn, Puccini and Haydn.
lead_paragraph: Encores in opera houses are different than they are in concert halls, where artists usually respond to ovations by showing off something new. In opera, though, excited audiences will demand a “bis” — a repeat of an aria that’s gone particularly well.

headline: Giving Factory Faces Their Own Score
abstract: The musicians Dean Wareham, Tom Verlaine Martin Rev, Eleanor Friedberger and Bradford Cox offered accompaniment to 15 Warhol shorts at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: Echoes of the Velvet Underground filled “Exposed: Songs for Unseen Warhol Films” on Friday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music: 15 silent short films by Andy Warhol from 1963 to ’66, rediscovered by the Andy Warhol Museum in Pittsburgh and set to live new music. The films offered a gallery of Warhol strategies — including the unadorned encounters with a camera that he called screen tests — and 1960s faces, many of them famous.

headline: Tig Notaro Faces ‘Medical Emergency’
abstract: The comedian canceled shows over the weekend because of an unspecified “medical emergency,” according to promoters of the performances.
lead_paragraph: The comedian Tig Notaro canceled shows in Boston and Denver over the weekend because of an unspecified “medical emergency,” according to promoters of the performances. Notes on the Facebook accounts of the Wilbur Theater in Boston, where Ms. Notaro was scheduled to perform on Saturday, and AEG Live Rocky Mountains, which promoted Sunday’s event in Denver, said that tickets would be refunded and the shows rescheduled. “Tig is dealing with a medical emergency and is being hospitalized,” a post on the AEG Live Rocky Mountain account said. “She will be all right but has to cancel the show tonight.” Calls and emails to Ms. Notaro’s manager were not returned on Sunday. Ms. Notaro has publicly battled breast cancer, working her diagnosis into her 2012 comedy routine; she received a 2013 Grammy nomination for her comedy album “Live.” She performed at the New York Comedy Festival on Thursday, and received critical praise for her act. Ms. Notaro performed most of the show topless, revealing scars from a double mastectomy with no reconstruction. The next stop on her “Boyish Girl Interrupted” tour is Portland, Ore. As of Sunday afternoon, that sold-out performance was still scheduled for Wednesday night.

headline: Globe-Trotter Dashes Into a Challenge
abstract: The Semperoper Ballett was part of a Richard Strauss evening commemorating the 150th anniversary of his birth.
lead_paragraph: DRESDEN, Germany — Alexei Ratmansky’s new “Tanzsuite,” created in June for the Semperoper Ballett here, is breathtakingly inventive, formally rigorous and gorgeously dancey. From the opening moments, as a bank of lights ascends to form a modernist chandelier above the neat lines of dancers, to the final heart-in-mouth swirled lift, the ballet captivates. As you watch, you feel slightly desperate about continually losing sight of the elusive felicities onstage.

headline: A Midcentury Agitator, Boxing Left and Right
abstract: “A Voice Still Heard,” a collection of essays by Irving Howe, seems to make the case that he was an insightful literary critic, but its content suggests that he was more of a sociologist.
lead_paragraph: “He was suspicious of characters like me,” Irving Howe recalled of a genteel Princeton literary scholar he knew in the late 1940s. “New York street fighters likely to cause trouble and, in any case, too political.”

headline: Depicting a Man’s World With One Key Absence
abstract: Sebastian Junger’s documentary “The Last Patrol,” on HBO, is about manhood, male camaraderie and how fathers can unknowingly push their sons toward war.
lead_paragraph: “You know what I think happens?” Sebastian Junger says in his new documentary, “The Last Patrol” (Monday night on HBO). “I think men protect women, and women protect children.” Expanding on his idea, he says of the 2012 theater shooting in Aurora, Colo. — where several men died shielding their girlfriends — “not one woman stepped in front of a man, because that’s not their job.”

headline: Oral History Project at Primary Stages
abstract: The theater company announced that it would move forward with a project which seeks to create a video archive of interviews.
lead_paragraph: The theater company Primary Stages announced on Sunday that it would move forward with its Off Broadway Oral History Project, which seeks to create a video archive of interviews with the actors, directors, designers, producers, playwrights and theater founders who have participated in Off and Off Off Broadway since World War II. The project is the brainchild of Casey Childs, the Primary Stages founder, who said he considered the idea for years after noticing a lack of firsthand information about this part of the theater world. Since July, Mr. Childs, the director Sally Plass and a team of interns have recorded about 50 hours of interviews with 20 Off Broadway leaders, including the actors Fyvush Finkel and Arthur French, the Chelsea Theater Center founder Robert Kalfin, the Playwrights Horizons founder Robert Moss and the Pan Asian Repertory Theater founder Tisa Chang. Mr. Childs said the goal was to record at least 100 interviews to be made available to the public online in the next six to 12 months. “It’s important to do because these people are dying every day,” Mr. Childs said in a phone interview. “It’s a race against the clock, but we’re getting them.” He said that he was in talks with several universities and foundations to host the videos but that it was too early to name the candidates.

headline: Obstacles Limit Targets and Pace of Strikes on ISIS
abstract: Commanders of the American-led air campaign in Iraq and Syria are challenged by spotty intelligence, poor weather and an Iraqi Army that has only begun an offensive against the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — More than three months into the American-led air campaign in Iraq and Syria, commanders are challenged by spotty intelligence, poor weather and an Iraqi Army that is only now starting to go on the offensive against the Islamic State, meaning that warplanes are mostly limited to hitting pop-up targets of opportunity.

headline: Pooh Illustrations to Be Auctioned
abstract: How many honey pots could a silly old bear fill if he had 100,000 British pounds, or roughly $159,000?
lead_paragraph: How many honey pots could a silly old bear fill if he had 100,000 British pounds, or roughly $159,000? That’s the low estimate for an original illustration from A. A. Milne’s 1928 book “The House at Pooh Corner” to be sold at Sotheby’s London next month. The drawing, signed by the artist E. H. Shepard, depicts Winnie-the-Pooh playing a game of “Poohsticks” on a bridge with Christopher Robin and Piglet. It has been part of a private collection since 1975, according to the Sotheby’s London sale catalog. The illustration is expected to fetch £100,000 to £150,000, or about $159,000 to $238,000, and is one of several drawings by Shepard that the auction house will feature at its “English Literature, History, Children’s Books and Illustration” sale on Dec. 9. Other items include drawings by Beatrix Potter and Edmund Dulac, a copy of “Peter Pan” signed by J. M. Barrie, and presentation copies of uncorrected “Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets” proofs signed by J. K. Rowling. Pooh has proved to be a lucrative draw at previous auctions. In November 2008, an original Shepard sketch of Pooh and friends sold for about $50,100 at a Bonham’s auction. A month later, the Stanley J. Seeger and Christopher Cone collection of Shepard’s original drawings for the Winnie-the-Pooh books brought in about $1.97 million at a Sotheby’s London auction.

headline: Imaginative Auction at the Rosenblum Teams
abstract: In bridge, which is the larger, the number of possible deals or the number of possible auctions? (Answer at the end.)
lead_paragraph: In bridge, which is the larger, the number of possible deals or the number of possible auctions? (Answer at the end.)

headline: Archipelago Component
abstract: An exclamation of disbelief from Bruce Haight.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — This week’s Monday through Thursday puzzles were part of the fourth annual Arlington (Va.) Puzzle Tournament. Will Shortz explains more about this and the worthy causes he donates puzzles to farther below.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Wednesday.

headline: Communities Fight State Laws That Can Divide Broadband Access
abstract: Small cities are asking the F.C.C. to use its power to override laws in 19 states that forbid municipalities to build or expand broadband networks.
lead_paragraph: WILSON, N.C. — Jason Bissette could throw a sweet potato from his office here in eastern North Carolina, where he and his family oversee nearly 3,000 acres, to their newest barn.

headline: Ebola’s Mystery: One Boy Lives, Another Dies
abstract: Over and over, doctors have been confounded by the divergent paths of Ebola patients whose cases appeared similar at first.
lead_paragraph: SUAKOKO, Liberia — Soon after he lost his parents to Ebola, Junior Samuel, 8, slumped in a plastic chair inside a treatment center here, listless, feverish and racked with aches. Within a day, he began bleeding from his gums, a particularly ominous sign.

headline: With All-Star Benched for Lax Defense, the Nets Hang On
abstract: The Nets won with a tenacious defensive performance in the fourth quarter, but they stuck with an effective Kevin Garnett as Brook Lopez watched from the sidelines.
lead_paragraph: Orlando’s Nikola Vucevic was picking and popping and draining jump shots with aplomb Sunday afternoon, so Nets Coach Lionel Hollins had a decision to make.

headline: Modern Beer Culture Through a 19th-Century Lens
abstract: Documenting Denver’s resurgent craft brewing culture using an appropriately old-fashioned technology: wet plate collodion, or tintype photography.
lead_paragraph: Documenting Denver’s resurgent craft brewing culture using an appropriately old-fashioned technology: wet plate collodion, or tintype photography.

headline: The Crazy Puppy and the Flying Boy
abstract: We arrived at the home of a single father to rescue his neglected dog. But what would become of his son?

headline: The Soul of Cowardice
abstract: In the annals of history, courage is common, but a cowardly man is hard to find.

headline: A Veteran Actor’s Backstage Fight for Affordable Health Care
abstract: The union that represents theater performers plans to drop insurance for about 200 members, leaving a Harlem man to wonder how he will manage the higher costs of a new plan.
lead_paragraph: Richard E. Waits was lying in bed hours before his audition, envisioning his metamorphosis. He closed his eyes and imagined his easy stride transformed into a jaunty strut, his smooth baritone sinking into a gravely rasp.

headline: N.B.A. Game of the Week: Kings vs. Mavericks
abstract: On Tuesday, the Kings, who went 28-54 last season but are off to a fast start, will face the Mavericks, a playoff team last season that is scoring a lot of points but giving up a lot, too.
lead_paragraph: Every week, The New York Times will choose one essential game to watch, highlighting hot teams, winning and losing streaks and statistical intrigue in the N.B.A.

headline: Making Chemistry Green
abstract: Synthetic chemicals are vital to our society. Let’s fix how we produce and regulate them.
lead_paragraph: FOR nearly 40 years, the Food and Drug Administration has wrestled with regulating the chemicals triclosan and triclocarban as they have become among the world’s most ubiquitous environmental contaminants. Designed to kill bacteria, they have been added to antibacterial soaps, cosmetics and other consumer products despite longstanding concerns about their impacts on humans and the environment.
