lead_paragraph: Five months after staging one of the most promoted initial public offerings of the year, GoPro is heading back to the stock market to sell more shares. And so is the video camera maker’s founder, Nicholas Woodman.

headline: Frauds That Prey on the Vulnerable
abstract: Thieves lure older victims with charity solicitations or promises of merchandise and prizes, resulting in huge losses of money, trust and confidence.
lead_paragraph: Barely a week passes in this house without one of us picking up the phone to an automated call offering my parents a free medical alert system. Of course, it is not free, but rather a well-known fraud trying to get their credit card information either for a donation, shipping or some additional emergency service.

headline: Gazprom Makes a New Gas Deal With China
abstract: Should tensions with the West over Ukraine persist, the pipeline could be used to divert energy supplies, currently headed to Europe, to Asia.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Gazprom, the Russian gas giant, is adding substance to the Kremlin’s plan to shift its economic focus to Asia, as the company signs its second major gas deal with China this year.

headline: Truth-Tellers and Liars
abstract: A conga line of truth-tellers and liars. Can you tell who’s lying and who’s telling the truth?
lead_paragraph: Our puzzle this week was suggested by Marco Moriconi, a regular Numberplay contributor and professor of physics at the Universidade Federal Fluminense, in Niteroi, Rio de Janeiro. (He also writes a monthly math column for the Brazilian national science magazine, Ciência Hoje (Science Today), called Qual o Problema, or “What’s the Problem?”). Dr. Moriconi found this week’s puzzle in a blog by its creator, Roy Cook, a professor of philosophy at the University of Minnesota who tells how he momentarily stumped the famous paradox master Raymond Smullyan with the challenge. (Check out Dr. Cook’s recently-published Paradoxes and Dr. Smullyan’s Beginner’s Guide to Mathematical Logic, selected by Amazon as a favorite book of 2014.)

headline: Today in Small Business: Start-Ups Founded by Women
abstract: Seven-day postal service. Republicans don’t always hate business regulations. Is maple syrup good for anything besides pancakes and French toast?
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: No Comment Necessary: The Wrong Loretta Lynch
abstract: The conservative site Breitbart claimed that President Obama’s attorney general nominee represented President Clinton during the Whitewater investigation.
lead_paragraph: The conservative website Breitbart claimed that President Obama’s attorney general nominee, Loretta Lynch, represented President Clinton during the Whitewater investigation. Actually, that was a different Loretta Lynch. The appended correction didn’t really do justice to the scope of the misidentification.

headline: A Tricky Transition From Fossil Fuel
abstract: Denmark is pursuing the world’s most ambitious policy against climate change, but conventional electricity remains a problematic part of the mix.
lead_paragraph: COPENHAGEN — Denmark, a tiny country on the northern fringe of Europe, is pursuing the world’s most ambitious policy against climate change. It aims to end the burning of fossil fuels in any form by 2050 — not just in electricity production, as some other countries hope to do, but in transportation as well.

headline: SHV Holdings Raises Bid for Nutreco, Dutch Supplier of Animal Food
abstract: The Netherlands conglomerate SHV Holdings increased its offer to $3.71 billion in cash after Cargill made a counteroffer in which it would break up Nutreco.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The conglomerate SHV Holdings of the Netherlands said Monday that it had sweetened its offer for Nutreco, the Dutch supplier of animal food, to 2.98 billion euros or about $3.71 billion, in cash.

headline: Please. Don’t ‘Decry’ the ‘Divorcée.’ Or Give Us Your ‘CV.’ The Times Guide to Modern Usage
abstract: For language students and plain speakers, The New York Times Manual of Style and Usage offers an inside look at the changing world of language.
lead_paragraph: We investigate subjects here. We do not “probe” them. And no, none of the bodies here are buried in “caskets”; The New York Times Manual of Style prefers the term “coffin.”

headline: Geldof’s New Charity Disc Aimed at Ebola
abstract: Bob Geldof is commemorating the 30th anniversary of the first Band Aid single, “Do They Know It’s Christmas,” with a new version intended to raise money to fight Ebola in West Africa.
lead_paragraph: The Irish rocker Bob Geldof has become better known for assembling starry charity projects – the Live Aid and Live 8 concerts, the Band Aid singles – than for the music he recorded with his own band, the Boomtown Rats. He has another charity disc in the works: on Monday, Mr. Geldof announced that he is commemorating the 30th anniversary of the first Band Aid single, “Do They Know It’s Christmas,” with a remake that will raise money to help combat Ebola in West Africa. It is scheduled to be released Nov. 17.

headline: Limiting Ebola’s Spread in Mali
abstract: Mali’s Ebola scare is not yet over. But with a quick diagnosis, extensive communication, and no shortage of luck, authorities and partners may be able to limit the number of cases to one.
lead_paragraph: Mali’s Ebola scare is not yet over. But with a quick diagnosis, extensive communication, and no shortage of luck, authorities and partners may be able to limit the number of cases to one.

headline: In a Topsy-Turvy World, China Warms to Sci-Fi
abstract: Liu Cixin’s “The Three-Body Problem,” a science-fiction trilogy whose first book comes out Tuesday in the United States, has attracted a diverse Chinese audience.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — With a state-owned power plant in nearby Shanxi Province temporarily shut down to reduce air pollution, one of its engineers, Liu Cixin, is using the free time to work on his hobby: reigning as China’s best-selling science-fiction author.

headline: Verbatim: Nothing Can Come Between Them
abstract: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. spoke quickly on his relationship with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel during remarks to the Jewish Federation.
lead_paragraph: — Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. to Ron Dermer, the ambassador to Israel, regarding the vice president’s relationship with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, in remarks at the Jewish Federations of North America General Assembly. The statement followed a report last month of a slur against Mr. Netanyahu by an unnamed senior American official.

headline: Postal Service Discloses Major Theft of Its Employees’ Personal Data
abstract: The agency told employees that an attack “potentially compromised” databases containing names, addresses, birth dates and Social Security numbers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Postal Service on Monday became the latest government agency to announce a major theft of data from its computer systems, telling its roughly 800,000 employees and retirees that an attack “potentially compromised” databases containing postal employees’ names, birth dates, addresses and Social Security numbers.

headline: A Super-Simple Way to Understand the Net Neutrality Debate
abstract: President Obama has thrown his support behind the idea that Internet access is more like access to electricity than to cable TV.
lead_paragraph: It’s one of the most important policy disputes that will determine the future of the Internet, and now President Obama has formally weighed in in favor of so-called net neutrality. What has been a long-simmering battle between telecommunications and tech lobbyists is now likely to step to the front of public debate.

headline: Where Audubon Found Repose, Sprayed-On Specimens Alight
abstract: The Manhattan murals, a modern twist on John James Audubon’s prints, have helped the Audubon Society raise awareness about birds threatened by climate change.
lead_paragraph: Among the beloved prints in John James Audubon’s “The Birds of North America” is plate No. 411, a Tundra Swan, Cygnus columbianus.

headline: Klinsmann Calls Up 25 Players for Next Two U.S. Soccer Friendlies
abstract: Coach Jurgen Klinsmann cast a wide net while retooling the national men’s soccer team roster after the World Cup over the summer.
lead_paragraph: Jurgen Klinsmann, the coach of the United States national men’s soccer team, continued his effort to phase in new faces to his roster by calling in 25 players for the next two friendly matches, against Colombia in London on Friday and against Ireland in Dublin next Tuesday.

headline: In This Future War, Soldiers Are Part Superhero
abstract: The new video game Call of Duty: Advanced Warfare stars Kevin Spacey and finds players on a battlefield far in the future.
lead_paragraph: Even before the newest version of Call of Duty went on sale last week, these games about real and imagined wars made up the best-selling first-person shooter series in history, with close to 190 million copies sold, according to Guinness World Records. But despite annual sales in excess of $1 billion for five years running, there have been signs that the juggernaut is in decline. So the latest entry, Call of Duty: Advanced Warfare, is an acknowledgment that after 11 years and 11 games, it’s time to start over.

headline: A Big Night for Bruckner Boosters
abstract: Members of the Bruckner Society of America presented the conductor Riccardo Chailly with the group’s Kilenyi Medal of Honor on Sunday night.
lead_paragraph: Fan clubs are not only for pop stars, or even for the living.

headline: Democrats’ Own Demographic Problem: Few Younger Leaders
abstract: Not only did Democrats lose seats in the House, the Senate and several governor’s mansions last week, but they also aren’t getting any younger.
lead_paragraph: Not only did Democrats lose seats in the House, the Senate and several governor’s mansions last week, but they also aren’t getting any younger.

headline: Obama for Net Neutrality
abstract: Ted Cruz tried to link his proposal to health care reform.
lead_paragraph: President Obama wrote on Monday that the Federal Communications Commission should issue strong regulations to prevent cable and phone companies from dividing the Internet into fast and slow lanes.

headline: Matthew Morrison to Star in Weinstein’s ‘Finding Neverland’ on Broadway
abstract: Mr. Morrison will play J.M. Barrie in the show about the creation of “Peter Pan”; he and Jeremy Jordan have both played the role in earlier productions.
lead_paragraph: Harvey Weinstein is going back to Plan A for his leading man in this spring’s Broadway musical “Finding Neverland.” He announced on Monday that Matthew Morrison, best known from the Fox series “Glee,” will star as the playwright J.M. Barrie in the show about the creation of “Peter Pan.”

headline: Estimate of Health Coverage Enrollment Leaves Room to Grow
abstract: The Department of Health and Human Services said fewer than 10 million people would have coverage purchased through insurance exchanges by the end of 2015.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Monday offered a surprisingly modest estimate of the number of people who would sign up for health insurance in the second round of open enrollment, which begins on Saturday.

headline: A Rare Delacroix, Chickens in a Crypt and More from the Art Calendar
abstract: Plus, New York heavyweights in Greenwich, a real-life treasure hunt and more happenings to see in the week ahead.
lead_paragraph: T’s list of happenings worth visiting in the week ahead.

headline: A Bat Signal Is Jammed
abstract: To gain an advantage when hunting, Mexican free-tailed bats emit a special call that interferes with the calls of other bats in search of food, researchers say.
lead_paragraph: To gain an advantage when hunting, Mexican free-tailed bats emit a special call that interferes with the calls of other bats in search of food, researchers say. Bats navigate by making calls and sensing where the sound echoes off objects. But researchers from Wake Forest University who studied recordings of hunting bats in two outdoor sites found that bats can jam competitors’ frequencies by producing a special signal, making it difficult for them to locate their prey’s position. Writing in the journal Science, the researchers noted that the bats being targeted by a jamming signal can emit their own special signal in retaliation.

headline: In Performance | Joely Richardson
abstract: A scene from the new production of William Luce’s biographical play “The Belle of Amherst,” about the 19th-century poet Emily Dickinson. The show runs through Nov. 23 at the Westside Theater.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the new production of William Luce’s biographical play “The Belle of Amherst,” about the 19th-century poet Emily Dickinson. The show runs through Nov. 23 at the Westside Theater.

headline: Syrian Leader Says U.N. Cease-Fire Proposal Is Worth Considering
abstract: President Bashar al-Assad said it was worth studying a proposal by the United Nations envoy to Syria, Staffan de Mistura, to freeze the conflict in Aleppo, Syria’s largest city.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — President Bashar al-Assad of Syria said Monday that a United Nations proposal for a local cease-fire in Syria’s largest city, Aleppo, was worth considering. It was Mr. Assad’s first response to the idea floated recently by the new United Nations envoy to Syria.

headline: The Benefits of Being Politically Correct
abstract: The term “political correctness” is perhaps most often used by its detractors — but new research has found that thinking about being P.C. can actually improve creativity.
lead_paragraph: When people bring up political correctness, they’re often talking about how much they hate it. Unlike, say, “diversity” or “inclusion,” the term is perhaps most frequently used by those who object to what it stands for, who feel that calls to change the way they speak harm them or society in some way.

headline: In Tampa, the World of Poseidon
abstract: The Tampa Museum of Art exhibit “Poseidon and the Sea: Myth, Cult and Daily Life” includes more than 100 objects.
lead_paragraph: Poseidon played an impressive number of roles in the world of the ancient gods: he was not only the lord of the sea, but also of horses and earthquakes. How those roles were recorded in ancient art is the subject of a notable exhibit at the Tampa Museum of Art.

headline: Leahy Sees Easy Road for Attorney General Pick, Now or Later
abstract: Senator Patrick J. Leahy said he believes Loretta E. Lynch, President Obama’s choice for attorney general, should be confirmed easily no matter when the Senate votes.
lead_paragraph: Senator Patrick J. Leahy, the chairman of the Judiciary Committee, didn’t give away much during a television appearance this morning about whether he would proceed posthaste to take up the nomination of Loretta E. Lynch, President Obama’s choice for attorney general. But he made it pretty clear that he believes she should be confirmed easily no matter when the Senate votes.

headline: A Young New Hampshireman and His Old British Roadster
abstract: Chris Seely, 16, inherited his father’s British car bug, buying and restoring a 1967 MGB roadster.
lead_paragraph: BETHLEHEM, N.H. — The fascination and affection Chris Seely, 16, feels for the 1967 MGB he rebuilt and drives daily were hand-me-downs.

headline: Apple Releases Web Tool for iPhone Switchers
abstract: A new web tool allows former iPhone users to deregister their phone numbers from Apple’s proprietary messaging service, iMessage.
lead_paragraph: Breaking up is never easy, not even with an iPhone. But Apple has released a tool to make that process cleaner.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
abstract: A leader is chosen to head a new effort by the industry to combat digital fraud, malware and piracy.
lead_paragraph: ACH Food Companies, Cordova, Tenn., the American division of Associated British Foods, chose Doner, Southfield, Mich., part of MDC Partners, as digital agency of record, handling all the company’s digital work and part of its social media work. Billings were not disclosed. The assignment had been handled by Digitas, part of the Publicis Groupe. ACH brands include Argo, Fleischmanns, Durkee, Karo and Mazola.

headline: Rothko and O’Keeffe Works Among Highlights of Mellon Auction
abstract: Paintings by Rothko, Diebenkorn, O’Keeffe and Fontana will be auctioned at Sotheby’s on Monday, along with other artworks from the collection of Rachel Lambert Mellon, known as Bunny.
lead_paragraph: The week of back-to-back important postwar and contemporary art auctions kicks off at Sotheby’s on Monday night with masterworks from the estate of Rachel Lambert Mellon, known as Bunny. Mrs. Mellon, who died in March at 103, spent her final years at Oak Spring Farms in Upperville, Va., surrounded by the art and objects she lovingly collected her entire life. Among them are paintings by Rothko, Diebenkorn, O’Keeffe and Fontana, which will be sold at Sotheby’s on Monday along with an illustrated letter Manet wrote in 1880 and white bronze painted fireplace irons decorated with birds that she commissioned from Diego Giacometti in 1972.

headline: Lower Projections for Health Law
abstract: Enrollment for health insurance purchased through the Affordable Care Act’s exchanges is not expected to be as robust next year as previously projected.
lead_paragraph: Enrollment for health insurance purchased through the Affordable Care Act’s exchanges is not expected to be as robust next year as previously projected.

headline: Microsoft Hopes This Video Game Collection Wings Its Way to Success
abstract: A campaign that rivals the promotion of a major movie is underway for Halo: The Master Chief Collection, a set of four Xbox video games.
lead_paragraph: Although the expression “halo effect” was coined long before video games or video game systems were invented, Microsoft is hoping for a Halo effect during this frenetic, competitive Christmas shopping season.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
abstract: Some background on the background in Dodge truck commercials.
lead_paragraph: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: A Rare Form of Malaria Is Spreading in Malaysia
abstract: In part of Borneo, a parasite called Plasmodium knowlesi causes severe malaria three times as often as Plasmodium falciparum, which has long been considered the deadliest form of the disease, new research suggests.
lead_paragraph: A rare and sometimes lethal form of malaria usually found only in monkeys is becoming so common in Malaysia that it accounts for most malaria hospitalizations there, scientists have found.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Harvick Needed to Win, and Did
abstract: Kevin Harvick joined three other drivers in the final round of the series championship playoff; Nico Rosberg could still win the Formula One championship.
lead_paragraph: Kevin Harvick, in a must-win situation, beat Jeff Gordon to the finish Sunday at Phoenix International Raceway, in the penultimate Nascar Sprint Cup event of the season. The victory earned Harvick one of four berths in the season finale next weekend in Homestead, Fla.

headline: Italian Appeals Court Overturns Guilty Verdicts in Earthquake Trial
abstract: Seven earthquake experts had been convicted of manslaughter for failing to adequately warn residents before a 2009 quake that killed more than 300 people.
lead_paragraph: ROME — An appeals court on Monday cleared seven prominent Italian earthquake experts who were accused of failing to adequately warn the residents of a seismically active area in the months before a 2009 earthquake that killed more than 300 people.

headline: U.S. Imposes Sanctions on Yemen’s Ex-President and 2 Rebel Leaders
abstract: The Obama administration accused former President Ali Abdullah Saleh of undermining “stability” in Yemen by backing a rebel group that recently took control of its capital.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The United States on Monday imposed sanctions on the former president of Yemen, Ali Abdullah Saleh, a onetime American counterterrorism ally whom the Obama administration accused of undermining “stability” in Yemen.

headline: The Enduring Republican Grip on the House
abstract: With a large majority and structural advantages, Republicans could keep the House for a generation, frustrating every major Democratic policy priority.
lead_paragraph: Whatever doubts existed about the Republican grip on the House should now be gone.

headline: Wines for Thanksgiving That Refresh the Palate
abstract: A versatile wine will go with all dishes; a nimble one will keep the palate awake.
lead_paragraph: Thanksgiving, like any holiday, is an act of repetition, only more so. Not just because it rolls around every year on the fourth Thursday of November, but because we ritually prepare the same meal.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Best-Selling Science Books
abstract: Titles, fundamentally based on the sciences, as selected by the science editors from all adult nonfiction books reported to The New York Times for the month.
lead_paragraph: 1 BEING MORTAL by Atul Gawande. Metropolitan/ Holt. The surgeon and New Yorker writer considers how doctors fail patients at the end of life, and how they can do better.

headline: U.N. to Investigate Strikes on Its Facilities in Gaza
abstract: A panel will investigate the attacks on more than 100 United Nations facilities and the death of 11 staff members during the Gaza conflict during the summer.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The United Nations secretary general announced on Monday that a five-member panel would investigate the attacks on more than 100 United Nations facilities and the death of 11 of its staff members during the Gaza conflict during the summer, defying Israeli demands to wait until the conclusion of its own government inquiry.

headline: G.O.P. Faces Tougher Job Finding Democrats to Repeal Health Law
abstract: Of the 10 House Democrats who have joined the G.O.P. most often in attempts to change or repeal the health care law, two will remain in the new Congress.
lead_paragraph: The “Democrats Against Obamacare” caucus in the House of Representatives has been decimated through retirements and election defeats. But Republicans seeking a bipartisan veneer for their efforts to dismantle the health care law could ally with a few lawmakers.

headline: Sewage Science
abstract: A group of researchers at New York University is using sewage water to track diseases and monitor health.
lead_paragraph: A group of researchers at New York University is using sewage water to track diseases and monitor health.

headline: In a New Show, Takashi Murakami Visits the Dark Side
abstract: The artist’s larger-than-life new works at Gagosian in Chelsea explore themes of life, death and spirituality, a shift prompted by the the 2011 earthquake and tsunami in Japan.
lead_paragraph: On March 11, 2011, the day the the Tohoku earthquake and tsunami devastated Japan, Takashi Murakami was in his studio near Tokyo. Though his family, who live in the south, were unharmed, the artist’s studio assistant lost his grandmother and grandfather. The magnitude of the tragedy got Murakami thinking. “I used to think of religion as something kind of false and hypocritical, but after the earthquake disaster, I realized in a time like that, religion and fairy tales and things like that are actually a necessity,” he said through a translator.

headline: Takata Faces Inevitable U.S. Inquiry Into Airbags
abstract: The Japanese manufacturer Takata will need to decide on its approach to handling an investigation into defective airbags, Peter J. Henning writes in the White Collar Watch column.
lead_paragraph: The Japanese manufacturer Takata is the latest company to be caught in a firestorm of controversy over how it allowed a faulty automobile part to be used for years. A report in The New York Times that the company secretly conducted tests on defective airbags four years before the first recall of vehicles that used them can be expected to touch off a wide-ranging criminal investigation.

headline: Narendra Modi’s Cabinet Is a Rogue’s Gallery
abstract: At least five of his new appointees have been charged with such serious offenses as rape and rioting.
lead_paragraph: On the campaign trail earlier this year, India’s prime minister, Narendra Modi, appealed to voters by promising to combat corruption and clean up politics. He was rewarded with a huge national electoral victory as well as success in state elections last month.

headline: Jerry Tallmer, Critic Who Created the Obies, Dies at 93
abstract: Mr. Tallmer, the first theater critic for The Village Voice, also conceived its award for Off Broadway theater, the Obie.
lead_paragraph: Jerry Tallmer, who brought professionalism and a personalized approach to arts coverage to The Village Voice in its earliest days, and who dreamed up its award for Off Broadway theater, the Obie, died on Sunday in Manhattan. He was 93.

headline: Our Real ‘Mommy’ (and ‘Daddy’) Problem: Your Children Are Your Problem
abstract: What happens when children are considered the adorable lifestyle choice of a nation of “mommies?” No one else needs to worry about the needs of those children—or of any children.
lead_paragraph: We do have a “Mommy” problem. And a “Daddy” problem. It’s a “Baby” problem and a “Kiddie” problem. It’s even a “Grammy” and “Grampy” problem, and if you can think of any other cutesy monikers we can attach to parents and families, it’s that kind of problem, too.

headline: Fat Man and Little Boy Revisited
abstract: Newly available photographs and movies have made the dawn of the nuclear weapons era go viral, providing a history lesson to a new generation.
lead_paragraph: Newly available photographs and movies have made the dawn of the nuclear weapons era go viral, providing a history lesson to a new generation.

headline: New York City Parking Alert: Alternate-Side Rules Suspended Tuesday
abstract: The regulations will not be in effect because of Veterans Day.
lead_paragraph: Because of Veterans Day, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Tuesday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: China Action Against Multinational Firms
abstract: Legal and regulatory action against some companies doing business in China.
lead_paragraph: Legal and regulatory action against some companies doing business in China.

headline: Blue Note Owners Opening a New Club in Meatpacking District
abstract: A new club, Subrosa, will emphasize Latin and world music.
lead_paragraph: The owners of the Blue Note, the legendary jazz club, are opening a new club in the meatpacking district of Manhattan that will be devoted to Latin music and world music, the Blue Note Entertainment Group announced Monday. The club, Subrosa, at 63 Gansevoort Street, will present a preview concert Wednesday night by the Pedrito Martínez Group, which will become a resident ensemble at the club with several shows every month.

headline: Museum Sues Sendak Estate Over Rare Books
abstract: The Rosenbach Museum and Library in Philadelphia has sued the estate of Maurice Sendak, claiming that the estate is withholding rare books that Sendak promised to the library.
lead_paragraph: The Rosenbach Museum and Library in Philadelphia has sued the estate of Maurice Sendak, who died in 2012, claiming that the estate is withholding a collection of rare books that Sendak promised to the library in his will.

headline: Players in Sayreville Football Hazing and Abuse Case Will Be Tried as Juveniles, Lawyers Say
abstract: Punishments meted out in family court are typically far less harsh than those in criminal court, and defendants are not named.
lead_paragraph: The seven football players accused of hazing and sexual abuse at Sayreville War Memorial High School in New Jersey in a scandal that has led to cancellation of the season and drawn national attention will be tried as juveniles, according to lawyers representing them.

headline: Marines Remember Falluja, 10 Years Later
abstract: On Nov. 6, 2004, NATO forces launched an assault on Falluja, a city north of Baghdad that had become a magnet for Sunni insurgent forces, and the resulting battle was one of the bloodiest for American forces since Vietnam. Thomas James Brennan fought there with the 1st Battalion, 8th Marine Regiment; he and other veterans of the assault say that their memories of Falluja will never leave them.
lead_paragraph: On Nov. 6, 2004, NATO forces launched an assault on Falluja, a city north of Baghdad that had become a magnet for Sunni insurgent forces. Thomas Brennan, then a 19-year-old Marine Corps lance corporal, was one of the infantrymen with First Battalion, Eighth Marine Regiment who would participate in the attack. The battalion suffered numerous casualties in the battle, one of the bloodiest for American forces since Vietnam. Now a journalism student, Mr. Brennan recalls the battle with the help of some of the Marines and sailors he fought beside.

headline: ‘Interstellar’ Opening Tops Out Under $50 Million
abstract: Opening-weekend sales for Christopher Nolan’s space epic were weaker than Paramount had hoped, coming in at $47.5 million, short of the $50 million figure projected on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – More air came out of “Interstellar” on Monday.

headline: What Our Sewage Can Teach Us
abstract: By analyzing samples from each of the five New York City boroughs, Jane M. Carlton hopes to detect viruses before an outbreak.
lead_paragraph: Beneath Visionaire, a breathtaking high-rise overlooking the southern tip of Manhattan, sewage gushes through a network of pipes and then drools into a stone tank, which is draped in quivering cockroaches. They scatter as Dennis Keefe, a contractor for Natural Systems Utilities, dips a metal ladle into the putrid stew and gently stirs.

headline: Groupon, Too, Turns to Multiple Apps
abstract: The daily deals company released Getaways, an app focused on travel and hotel deals.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes offering one mobile app just isn’t enough.

headline: Atlanta School Cheating Was ‘Conspiratorial,’ Ex-Governor Testifies
abstract: Former Gov. Sonny Perdue testified during the trial of 12 Atlanta educators whom prosecutors have accused of participating in cheating.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The former Georgia governor who ordered a state inquiry amid suspicions of widespread cheating in Atlanta’s public schools testified Monday that he felt the wrongdoing was pervasive and that academic officials had tried to impede a public accounting of it.

headline: Making Friends With Free Racing Tickets
abstract: A Nascar executive tries to be as civil as possible on flights, happily changing seats and hoisting luggage — but giving away tickets makes him most popular.
lead_paragraph: I WASN’T a big traveler growing up and when I started my career as an investment banker, I didn’t travel much for work then, either. Now I’m Nascar’s chief sales officer, and business travel is a big part of my job.

headline: Is It Too Late for a Democratic ALEC?
abstract: Conservatives have enacted their agenda with impunity at the state level.
lead_paragraph: After years of slumber, Democrats are finally waking up and realizing that one of the most powerful prizes in American politics — the control of state governments — has slipped from their grasp. It is likely to be many years before they have a chance of getting it back.

headline: A Seductive Track from Rising Soul-Pop Songstress George Maple
abstract: “Vacant Space,” premiering here, is the lead single from the singer’s upcoming EP of the same name.
lead_paragraph: “I wanted to have a space where I could be creatively unlimited,” says the 24-year-old Australian soul-pop songstress George Maple, née Jess Higgs, of her musical alter ego. Though the pseudonym is still a relatively new one — she adopted it in late 2012, when she appeared on Flume’s down-tempo electro track “Bring You Down” — it has already served as a vehicle for growth. “Between building that character and now, I feel like there’s been a fast progression of development as an artist,” Maple says. “I’m saying what I want to say now, as opposed to when I was a little bit more timid at the beginning.”

headline: What to Wear This Week: Nov. 10
abstract: Play peekaboo with camisoles and bodysuits chic enough to want to show off.
lead_paragraph: With all the talk of winter coats, sweaters and boots, it’s easy to forget the importance of undergarments. This week, play peekaboo with camisoles and bodysuits chic enough to want to show off.

headline: How ‘Solution Aversion’ and Global Warming Prescriptions Polarize the Climate Debate
abstract: A tendency of climate campaigners to bundle science and preferred solutions runs up against “solution aversion,” a study finds
lead_paragraph: Anyone eager to understand, and move past, the deep political polarization around global warming would do well to explore the findings in “Solution aversion: On the relation between ideology and motivated disbelief,” published in the November issue of the Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. The paper is behind a subscription wall, but a Duke University news release does a fine job laying out the basic findings, as does Chris Mooney, getting into gear in his new blogging position at the Washington Post. Here’s an excerpt from the Duke release, followed by more from Mooney and some thoughts from me on how this work echoes points explored here for many years:

headline: Supreme Court Weighs Case Over Cuts to Retirees’ Health Benefits
abstract: The case involves a union contract at a plant in West Virginia and whether health benefits for retirees would vest.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court seemed puzzled on Monday about why it was being asked to decide whether a chemical company could cut the health benefits of its retired workers.

headline: ‘Evil Dead’ to Rise Again as Starz Series
abstract: “Ash vs. Evil Dead” will star Bruce Campbell, who originated the role in the Sam Raimi movies. Mr. Raimi will direct the first episode.
lead_paragraph: Grab your boom stick and prepare to hail to the king, baby: Ash Williams, the super-suave opponent of demons, doppelgangers and assorted reincarnated pests — a k a the character played by Bruce Campbell in Sam Raimi’s “Evil Dead” movies — is moving to the small screen in a new cable series.

headline: Verbatim: Will Rick Perry Run?
abstract: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, at an event in New Hampshire. For more: A look at 2016 likely presidential contenders.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, at an event in New Hampshire. For more: A look at 2016 likely presidential contenders.

headline: Overseas, Lost in Transition
abstract: Women’s basketball players say the money is overseas, but the adjustment can be tough, especially if you’re not in a metropolis, say the first-timers Bria Hartley and Kayla McBride.
lead_paragraph: SOPRON, Hungary — Bria Hartley and Kayla McBride’s preparation for their first season of professional basketball abroad was not unlike how they prepared for college. Skype accounts were set up. Xboxes were packed. Slingboxes were installed at their parents’ houses, ready to stream American television shows 4,250 miles away.

headline: ‘Elephant Man’ and ‘The River’ Showcase Stars’ Box-Office Power on Broadway
abstract: Bradley Cooper’s turn in “The Elephant Man” and Hugh Jackman’s role in “The River” helped both shows to strong sales for early performances.
lead_paragraph: The last time Bradley Cooper was on Broadway, in the 2006 play “Three Days of Rain,” the show’s main attraction was Julia Roberts and the packed audiences were thanks to her. But Mr. Cooper is now a movie star too, and his fans were out in force last weekend for his return to Broadway in “The Elephant Man,” which sold out its first four preview performances, according to box-office data released on Monday. Demand for seats was so high that the average ticket price hit $163.45 – the highest of any play last week, and second only to the average price for the blockbuster musical “The Book of Mormon.” The show, which stars Mr. Cooper as John Merrick, the title character in the 1979 play, grossed $520,087 for the four previews.

headline: It’s Just a (Thanksgiving Dinner) Fantasy
abstract: There are two Thanksgivings, for some of us. The rigid one that unfolds in the real world and the one in fantasy land replete with nontraditional food and fun.
lead_paragraph: There are two Thanksgivings, for some of us. There is the one that will unfold in the real world, the Thanksgiving that involves transportation snarls, hours of televised football, family members stunned into a comatose state by rivers of gravy and lagoons of mashed potatoes, testy spats over the thermostat and, over all, a rigid adherence to the Way Things Are Supposed to Be Done.

headline: Steven A. Cohen Was Buyer of Giacometti’s ‘Chariot,’ for $101 Million
abstract: Mr. Cohen, the hedge fund billionaire, was the sole bidder for the sculpture, among the artist’s finest.
lead_paragraph: The lone bidder who spent $101 million at Sotheby’s last Tuesday night for Giacometti’s “Chariot,’’ a 1950 sculpture of a spindly woman riding atop a chariot, was the hedge fund billionaire Steven A. Cohen, experts with knowledge of the sale said Monday. The sculpture, which came from the collection of Alexander Goulandris, a member of the Greek shipping family, is considered among the artist’s finest.

headline: Mets Make Statement, Signing Rockies’ Cuddyer
abstract: By adding the bat and veteran presence of outfielder Michael Cuddyer to their lineup, the Mets made a move in free agency that signaled they plan to contend.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Ever since Sandy Alderson took over as general manager of the Mets in 2010, the team has clung to its draft picks as if they were pure gold, always in the hope that they would lead to a glittering future. The Mets think that future begins in 2015.

headline: Major League Teams Look to Cuba, Land of Bargains
abstract: With the White Sox’ Jose Abreu named the American League rookie of the year, the word is out: Cuban players are better than good and come at a reasonable price.
lead_paragraph: The leading slugger in the major leagues last season was Jose Abreu, a rookie first baseman from Cuba whose six-year, $68 million contract was thought to be a reach for the owner of the Chicago White Sox.

headline: How One Presidency Jump-Started Another
abstract: In “Landslide,” Jonathan Darman recounts the midterm elections in 1966 as not only signaling the fall of Lyndon B. Johnson, but also the emergence of Ronald Reagan as a national political figure.
lead_paragraph: On the morning of Nov. 22, 1963, Lyndon B. Johnson and Ronald Reagan both had reason to feel they were sliding into obscurity.

headline: Assessing Space on a Computer’s Hard Drive
abstract: Plus, comparing HDTV with ultrahigh-definition.
lead_paragraph: Assessing Space

headline: How to Erase Personal Information From an iPad
abstract: Plus, tracking an Amazon package by text.
lead_paragraph: Q. I recently bought a new iPad Air and transferred all my content to it from my older iPad. I’d like to pass the old model along to a friend. But how do I fully erase it so that my personal information, apps and iTunes password are permanently removed?

headline: French Brandy Gains a Foothold on American Cocktail Menus
abstract: American mixologists find ways to slip Cognac, Armagnac and Calvados into cocktails at affordable prices.
lead_paragraph: France has done well by the American cocktail revival. French liqueurs, bitters and aperitifs that were gathering dust on the shelf (like Lillet and Benedictine) or weren’t available in the United States (like Suze) now enjoy a renewed relevance.

headline: Comfortable Inducing a Laugh or a Squirm
abstract: “Odd Birdz,” from the ensemble Tziporela, features sketches with a wide range of characters and situations.
lead_paragraph: Oddball characters materialize fully formed in “Odd Birdz,” a sketch comedy show by the clever young Israeli ensemble Tziporela, which is making its American debut at the Players Theater in Greenwich Village.

headline: Craig Spencer, New York Doctor With Ebola, Will Leave Bellevue Hospital
abstract: Dr. Spencer, who had contracted the virus while treating patients with the disease in Guinea, is now free of the virus, hospital officials said.
lead_paragraph: Craig Spencer, the New York City doctor who became the first person in the city to test positive for Ebola, is free of the virus and is set to be released from Bellevue Hospital Center on Tuesday, hospital officials said on Monday.

headline: Preserving an Accident, the Salton Sea in California, for the Good of Nature
abstract: The Salton Sea, a briny lake created by a mismanaged effort to divert a river, has become a key habitat for migrating birds and is now in danger of drying out.
lead_paragraph: MECCA, Calif. — The area around this town of date palms attracts two kinds of migrants — hundreds of humans who work the land, and millions of birds that stop to rest and gorge at the nearby Salton Sea. The sea is a 110-year-old, increasingly briny, shallow lake that covers 350 square miles but is dwindling fast.

headline: Transported to Paradise, but Needing More
abstract: Edward O. Wilson thinks we should set aside half the planet as wilderness, and he believes we can do it. In a new book, he tells the story of a nature preserve in Mozambique to make his case.
lead_paragraph: Edward O. Wilson is a great biologist, a great conservationist and a great optimist. He thinks we should set aside half the planet as wilderness, and he believes we can do it. In this new book, he tells the story of a nature preserve in Mozambique to make his case.

headline: Order for Summons, in Lieu of Arrest, for Possession of Marijuana
abstract: The procedure for the issuance of a criminal court summons for a person found with 25 grams or less of marijuana in a public place and open to public view.
lead_paragraph: The procedure for the issuance of a criminal court summons for a person found with 25 grams or less of marijuana in a public place and open to public view.

headline: Walkabout: U.S. and China Lift Visa Restrictions; Space Tourists Cancel Reservations
abstract: A weekly capsule of travel news curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: Open Door News out of the APEC summit in Beijing included a surprise announcement that the United States and China will lift visa restrictions for visitors from both countries. Chinese and American tourists will now be eligible for 10-year visas, up from one year. (Quartz)

headline: Q. and A.: Dennis M. Gormley on China’s Military Capabilities
abstract: Dennis M. Gormley, a senior lecturer in military affairs at the University of Pittsburgh’s Graduate School of Public and International Affairs, discusses China’s air defenses.
lead_paragraph: Every two years since 1996, the China International Aviation and Aerospace Exhibition, the largest air show in China, has been held in Zhuhai, Guangdong Province, attracting thousands of commercial traders and military enthusiasts. This year its opening was set for Tuesday, the 65th anniversary of the founding of the People’s Liberation Army Air Force, or Plaaf, adding to the buzz around the six-day event. For those in commercial aviation, it is an opportunity to show off their wares to a fast-growing aviation market, including an increased appetite for private jets. Nearly 150 military and trade delegations attended the previous exhibition in 2012, which saw $11.8 billion in sales, according to the organizers.

headline: White Rodent Finds Fame on the Great White Way
abstract: Toby, the rat kept by the teenager with autism in “The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time,” is so popular her role has been expanded.
lead_paragraph: The Broadway cast was less than thrilled when it found out who one of their fellow performers would be. It made them squeamish — not because of who it was but because of what it was.

headline: Kalettes, a Pilgrim Dinner and More Food News
abstract: What happens when you cross kale and brussels sprouts, and Chapter One offers a colonial dinner.
lead_paragraph: To Serve: Two Vegetables Combine for a Taste of Their Own

headline: Quandary: When the Tests Are Overwhelming, What’s Next?
abstract: Most schools conduct some form of standardized testing. What helps a child who finds the tests stressful, and when is the testing too much?
lead_paragraph: In the Weekly Quandary, we pull from the comments, the weekly open thread or email a question that we know (or at least suspect) plagues more than one parent. You — the readers — provide the advice: How have you made this work better in your family? This week’s quandary comes from a much-commented-upon article in the National section. What can parents do if school testing is overwhelming their students, or their school?

headline: A New Home for a Secretive Songbird
abstract: Swainson’s warbler — a secretive, rarely seen songbird that nests in the swamplands of the southeastern United States — may no longer be so hard to find. Researchers report that the bird has found a new safe haven.
lead_paragraph: Swainson’s warbler — a secretive, rarely seen songbird that nests in the swamplands of the southeastern United States — may no longer be so hard to find.

headline: Showtime Renews ‘Homeland’ and ‘The Affair’
abstract: The two series draw millions of viewer for the cable channel, through multiple broadcasts.
lead_paragraph: Showtime shrugged off the occasional critical barb about the last season of “Homeland” and announced on Monday that it had renewed the Emmy-winning espionage drama for a fifth season.

headline: U.S. to Focus on Equity in Assigning of Teachers
abstract: Federal officials want states to ensure that poor and minority students will not be disproportionately taught by inexperienced educators.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration is directing states to show how they will ensure that all students have equal access to high-quality teachers, with a sharp focus on schools with a high proportion of the poor and racial minorities.

headline: Epidemics of Confusion
abstract: Two different epidemics have prompted eerily similar reactions from health officials and the public, raising crucial questions about why the world remains persistently unprepared to react to the emergence of viral threats.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A mysterious virus emerges in Africa and makes its way to our shores. An anxious and skeptical public rejects scientific evidence that the lethal virus is transmitted only through body fluids. There are no drugs to effectively treat infected patients, nor a vaccine to prevent new cases.

headline: Hungry as a Bear
abstract: Which animals are most and least efficient at digesting food?
lead_paragraph: Q. WHICH ANIMALS ARE MOST AND LEAST EFFICIENT AT DIGESTING FOOD?

headline: The Opera in Rome Is a Hotbed of Chaos
abstract: The Rome Opera is buckling under both a traditional patronage system and attempts to reform it.
lead_paragraph: ROME — After the maestro Riccardo Muti signed on with the Rome Opera, in 2008, with the honorary title of conductor for life, he lifted the orchestra to new levels. Houses were packed, and audiences moved to tears. But the news in September that he had decided to pull out of productions at the house, citing a lack of “serenity” at this financially troubled and strike-prone theater, has plunged the opera back into uncertainty.

headline: Bucket List for Tweens With Fears
abstract: In “100 Things to Do Before High School,” three seventh-grade friends are expecting life as they know it to end at the conclusion of middle school in this new offering from Nickelodeon.
lead_paragraph: Is there a minimum age requirement for having a bucket list? Apparently not, because on a cute new offering from Nickelodeon, three seventh-grade friends have one.

headline: A Man Whose Music Animated Looney Tunes
abstract: “Powerhouse,” on the life of the composer Raymond Scott, sustains the controlled mad dash of the Warner Bros. Looney Tunes cartoons that used his music.
lead_paragraph: “Powerhouse,” an electrifying account of the life of the composer Raymond Scott at the New Ohio Theater, kicks off in 1936 with the cast executing a jitterbug while Scott (Erik Lochtefeld) conducts his Quintette on radio’s “Your Hit Parade.” From there, the show hurtles forward, sustaining the controlled mad dash of the Warner Bros. Looney Tunes cartoons that adapted Scott’s music.

headline: The Amazing Adventures of Ronson & Chabon
abstract: The novelist Michael Chabon has written lyrics for half the songs on Mark Ronson’s album “Uptown Special,” due in January.
lead_paragraph: Michael Chabon’s last novel, “Telegraph Avenue,” was set mostly in a California record shop and was packed with the kind of detail that told record collectors that Mr. Chabon was one of them. And that gave one of his readers, the British musician and producer Mark Ronson, an idea for a project: why not write to Mr. Chabon, whose earlier novel, “The Amazing Adventures of Kavalier & Clay” was a favorite, and invite him to write lyrics for Mr. Ronson’s next album?

headline: Decoding the Brain’s Math
abstract: Larry Abbott started his career working with particle colliders, but he realized that the complex mathematics of physics came in quite handy for trying to understand the brain.
lead_paragraph: Larry Abbott started his career working with particle colliders, but he realized that the complex mathematics of physics came in quite handy for trying to understand the brain.

headline: Hear Those Tapping Shoes? That’s the Sound of Empowerment
abstract: Two tap-dancing troupes, Syncopated Ladies and Beauteez’n the Beat, performed in separate shows in New York.
lead_paragraph: “Syncopated Ladies: Live in NYC” is a lot like a Beyoncé concert without Beyoncé. For the show’s premiere at the Gerald W. Lynch Theater on Friday, a nine-piece band played a handful of that singer’s hits, but the star wasn’t a vocalist. It was seven young women mimicking the sexualized moves of Beyoncé backup dancers and dressed for the part, except for the metal on the soles of their shoes. The Syncopated Ladies are tap dancers.

headline: Tracking the Events in the Wake of Michael Brown’s Shooting
abstract: Updates on the events in Ferguson, Mo., following the shooting of Michael Brown, an unarmed teenager, by a police officer on Aug. 9.
lead_paragraph: Updates on the events in Ferguson, Mo., following the shooting of Michael Brown, an unarmed teenager, by a police officer on Aug. 9.

headline: Nov. 10, 2014 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Mexico, China, Israel and Turkey.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Mexico, China, Israel and Turkey.

headline: Explaining Boko Haram, Nigeria’s Islamist Insurgency
abstract: Boko Haram is largely known for its kidnapping of schoolgirls in Nigeria, but it is suspected of having committed atrocities before and after those abductions.
lead_paragraph: Boko Haram is an Islamist extremist group responsible for dozens of massacres of civilians and the abduction of more than 500 women and girls in its five-year insurgency in Nigeria.

headline: Artists on How Pink Floyd Influenced Them
abstract: As the band prepares to release its first new material in two decades, four contemporary talents weigh in on the group’s impact on their own work.
lead_paragraph: Not long after they first emerged in the underground music scene in mid-1960s London, Pink Floyd earned a reputation, as Rolling Stone put it in 2007, as the city’s “farthest-out group.” And as art students at the time they got together, the band members — the bassist Roger Waters, the singer Syd Barrett, the drummer Nick Mason and the pianist Rick Wright; Barrett was later replaced by David Gilmour — firmly believed their aesthetic was as important as the notes they played. The Floyd, as they were known, provided audiences with a complete sensory experience, pairing visceral, operatic lyrics with elaborate light projections that seemed to move in turn to the music. And even as they achieved global popularity in the 1970s with a string of landmark albums including 1973’s “The Dark Side of the Moon,” 1975’s “Wish You Were Here” and 1979’s “The Wall,” the band remained focused on bringing visual ideas to the forefront through their live shows and iconic album art.

headline: The Burning of Atlanta
abstract: Why the Union destroyed the Georgia city, through the eyes of one Union officer.
lead_paragraph: On the evening of Nov. 15, 1864, Union Lt. Col. Charles Fessenden Morse sat on the roof of a house and watched Atlanta burn. It was a “magnificent and awful spectacle,” he wrote later to his brother Robert. “For miles around the country was as light as day, … the flames shooting up for hundreds of feet into the air.” Earlier, over the roar and crackle of the flames, Morse had heard the 33rd Massachusetts band serenade Gen. William Tecumseh Sherman, who ordered the city torched. “It was like fiddling over the burning of Rome.” The next morning, nothing was left of the city “except its churches the city hall and the private dwellings. You could hardly find a vestige of the once splendid R.R. depots, warehouses, &c. It was melancholy,” Morse lamented, “but it was war, prosecuted in deadly earnest.”

headline: Casting a Magnetic Field That He Happily Shares
abstract: Spooky Black and his Minnesota-based band, thestand4rd, played their first New York club date on Sunday at S.O.B.’s.
lead_paragraph: The bonus track on “Leaving,” the most recent EP by the angelic ghost-soul singer Spooky Black, is called “DJ Khaled Is My Father.” It’s typical of this young singer’s output — mournful and woozy and glancingly erotic. Needless to say, there’s no apparent connection between the song and DJ Khaled, mainstream hip-hop’s exulter-in-chief. The title’s not a joke, per se, but sort of an absurdist wink.

headline: Some Benefits for Veterans From the World of Travel
abstract: Some airport donations help provide care packages to troops overseas, while United Airlines offers an airfare discount — for a price.
lead_paragraph: I AM an occasionally cranky Vietnam veteran who regrets having been a little churlish recently when a cashier in an airport shop asked me if I cared to make a donation to “support our troops.”

headline: On Veterans Day, Tales of Heroism and Loss
abstract: Descendants of veterans of World War I share their families’ stories, and describe their efforts, 100 years after the start of the Great War, to verify tales of bravery and tragedy.
lead_paragraph: Descendants of veterans of World War I share their families’ stories, and describe their efforts, 100 years after the start of the Great War, to verify tales of bravery and tragedy.

headline: Ask Well: Immune to Ebola?
abstract: If a person is infected with Ebola and recovers, are they then immune to the disease or can they still contract it again?
lead_paragraph: Question:

headline: Albums by Nick Jonas, Bobby Shmurda and New Basement Tapes
abstract: New albums include ones by Nick Jonas and Bobby Shmurda and “Lost on the River: The Basement Tapes,” a collection based on Bob Dylan lyrics from 1967.
lead_paragraph: THE NEW BASEMENT TAPES

headline: After the Fall: Preventing Catastrophe
abstract: Letters to the editor and online comments.
lead_paragraph: After the Fall: Preventing Catastrophe

headline: Learning How Little We Know About the Brain
abstract: The body of knowledge about how the brain works is growing, but so is the list of gaps in our understanding. Larry Abbott, a former theoretical physicist, is looking for models to fill them in.
lead_paragraph: Research on the brain is surging. The United States and the European Union have launched new programs to better understand the brain. Scientists are mapping parts of mouse, fly and human brains at different levels of magnification. Technology for recording brain activity has been improving at a revolutionary pace.

headline: Survivor Who Hated the Spotlight
abstract: Mary Berg wrote a diary about her life in the Warsaw Ghetto that was published in English long before Anne Frank’s diary. Then she disappeared.
lead_paragraph: Mary Berg, a Polish Jewish teenager who wrote one of the earliest firsthand accounts of the Nazi genocide to be published in English, has long been something of a mystery in the annals of Holocaust literature.

headline: Sarkozy Tries Quick Comeback, but France May Not Go Along
abstract: The former French president is campaigning for the leadership of his center-right party, but there is little doubt that his sights are on a return to the Élysée Palace.
lead_paragraph: ST.-CYR-SUR-LOIRE, France — On a recent evening, Nicolas Sarkozy, who since being voted out of office more than two years ago has done nothing to temper his reputation as the bad boy of French politics, was on stage in a gymnasium trying to generate enthusiasm for his latest campaign.

headline: Philae Lander Nears a Cosmic Touchdown
abstract: Even if it fails in its comet landing, the Rosetta mission will offer scientists a slew of new data.
lead_paragraph: In its 10-year chase of a comet, the European Space Agency’s ambitious Rosetta mission has pushed the edges of engineering ingenuity.

headline: With a Stealth Fighter, China Tries to Gain Attention
abstract: By exhibiting a stealth aircraft at an air show this week, China wants to show just how far its arms industry has come, experts say.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Amid the whine of high-performance jet engines at the start of an air show in Zhuhai, the Chinese government is hoping to generate a different sort of buzz: admiration, and perhaps purchases, of its shadowy J-31 stealth fighter, which is expected to make its first public appearance.

headline: Pursuing a Shipping Revolution as Big as His Airship
abstract: Igor Pasternak is developing an airship called the Aeroscraft that could travel much faster than a cargo ship and carry much more than a cargo plane, but obstacles remain.
lead_paragraph: MONTEBELLO, Calif. — Somewhere beneath the graying shock of mad-professor hair, the dark circles under his eyes and the Russian-strained, cigarette-stained baritone, there remains in Igor Pasternak a boy with a dream.

headline: Brokaw, Sondheim, Streep, Wonder: All Stars of Freedom
abstract: The White House announced the 19 recipients of this year’s Presidential Medal of Freedom.
lead_paragraph: Tom Brokaw, Stephen Sondheim, Meryl Streep and Stevie Wonder are among the 19 recipients of this year’s Presidential Medal of Freedom, the White House announced Monday.

headline: The Midterm Election: New Reflections
abstract: A sampling of responses to news and opinion articles about the election.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Juniper Networks Changes Its Chief, Again
abstract: Juniper said on Monday afternoon that Shaygan Kheradpir resigned as chief executive following a review by the company’s board into his handling of negotiations with an unnamed customer, as well as his general leadership.
lead_paragraph: It was roughly a year ago that Juniper Networks named Shaygan Kheradpir as its chief executive, whose predecessor had resigned as the networking company was being investigated under the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act.

headline: The Eisenhower Memorial
abstract: Sam Roche of Right by Ike: Project for a New Eisenhower Memorial responds to an editorial.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Big Pharma and Ebola
abstract: John J. Castellani of the Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America writes that the industry is “the second largest funder in the world for research into tropical diseases.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: DeGrom Goes From Class AAA to the Class of the N.L. Rookie Field
abstract: Jacob deGrom’s career took off this year as he became the Mets’ best pitcher, an emerging star who started pitching in serious competition only four years ago.
lead_paragraph: Before Tammy deGrom’s youngest child and only son, Jacob, was married over the weekend, she imparted a few bits of advice. She told him to always keep his faith first. She told him to continue doing what he was doing in his profession.

headline: Joan Rivers’s Treatment Had Numerous Violations, U.S. Inquiry Finds
abstract: Doctors treating Ms. Rivers did not notice her deteriorating vital signs for about 15 minutes before she went into cardiac arrest, a report said.
lead_paragraph: A Manhattan clinic treating Joan Rivers in August did not notice that her vital signs were deteriorating for at least 15 minutes before she went into cardiac arrest, leading to her death several days later, a federal investigation has found.

headline: The Police and the Community
abstract: Tobias Winright, a former reserve police officer, writes about improving relations after the events in Ferguson, Mo.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Sierra Leone Defends Jailing Critic of Ebola Response
abstract: The attorney general in Sierra Leone said a prominent radio journalist had undermined the government’s effort to stop the disease’s spread.
lead_paragraph: Sierra Leone’s attorney general defended the arrest last week of a prominent radio journalist who criticized the government’s handling of the Ebola crisis as lawful and justified, in a news release distributed over the weekend.

headline: Oops! Health Insurer Exposes Member Data
abstract: Anthem Blue Cross, one of the largest health insurers in California, inadvertently sent emails to some members with demographic and health information in the subject lines.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, OfficeMax became a little too personal with one customer, sending a mailing to a man in Chicago with a street address that, after his own name, inadvertently included information about a family tragedy: “daughter killed in car crash or Current Business.” (An OfficeMax spokesman later blamed a third-party data broker the company had hired for exposure of the intimate information.)

headline: High Hopes for Lo-Fi Photos
abstract: Every day is “Throwback Thursday” for Daniel Akselrad and Erik Goyenechea, who have perfected the lo-fi ’90s look of Game Boy photos.
lead_paragraph: Every day is “Throwback Thursday” for Daniel Akselrad and Erik Goyenechea, who have perfected the lo-fi ’90s look of Game Boy photos.

headline: Who Really Tore Down This Wall?
abstract: Readers offer varying causes for the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989.

headline: Work-for-Welfare Gains a Foothold in Hungary
abstract: Under the right-wing rule of Prime Minister Viktor Orban, the unemployed in Halmaj — a poor, rural village of 1,800 — must work to get more public assistance.
lead_paragraph: HALMAJ, Hungary — The big sow nearest the barn door looked especially frisky this chilly morning. About the size of a Dumpster, and nearly as fragrant, she poked her speckled snout through the bars of her pen and snorted happily as Jeno Baba, 27, stroked her bristled head.

headline: V.A. Creates Plans to Consolidate Services
abstract: The agency intends to initiate a bureau to focus on customer service training, and have facilities forge tighter bonds with local groups and lawmakers.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Veterans Affairs announced plans Monday for a new customer service bureau to help train employees to focus on customer satisfaction and make the department more accountable to the millions of veterans it serves. The plans also include a structural overhaul that over time could lead to consolidating a wide range of functions under a handful of regional offices.

headline: The Truth About the Wars
abstract: We need to stop telling ourselves stories about Iraq and Afghanistan, and face what went wrong.
lead_paragraph: AS a senior commander in Iraq and Afghanistan, I lost 80 soldiers. Despite their sacrifices, and those of thousands more, all we have to show for it are two failed wars. This fact eats at me every day, and Veterans Day is tougher than most.

headline: Where Hell Is Other Patients
abstract: There is an epidemic of violence in hospitals for the criminally insane.
lead_paragraph: NAPA, Calif. — IN the public imagination, forensic mental hospitals — where states place the criminally insane — are hellish scenes of cages and restraints, the better to keep us safe from the Hannibal Lecters of the world.

headline: Medicare Proposes Paying for Lung Cancer Screenings for Older Longtime Smokers
abstract: A draft decision by the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services would extend coverage for CT scans to Medicare beneficiaries who smoked at least a pack a day for 30 years or the equivalent.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Medicare will cover annual screenings for lung cancer for older Americans with long histories of heavy smoking, the federal government said Monday in a proposal that would cover an estimated four million people, many of whom are at greatest risk for the disease.

headline: How to Be French
abstract: My otherness has become an identity. Can I abandon it?
lead_paragraph: PARIS — I HAVE an unusual item on my to-do list, wedged between home repairs and unwritten thank-you notes: Become French. I’ve begun the long process of gathering documents to apply for French citizenship.

headline: Fix the New G.I. Bill
abstract: Veterans should be protected from exploitation by for-profit schools that get government grants.
lead_paragraph: THIS Veterans Day there will be over a million students on college campuses in the United States who are using their G.I. Bill benefits. The Department of Veterans Affairs forecasts that the number of student veterans will increase by 20 percent in the next few years.

headline: Czechs Celebrate Commitment to Team Success
abstract: The Czech Republic won its third Fed Cup final in four years Sunday. But it is not just the Czech women who have become juggernauts: The men won Davis Cup titles in 2012 and 2013.
lead_paragraph: PRAGUE — The choreography comes automatically by now: When the Czechs win a set in a team tennis competition, the home fans behind the team bench immediately unfurl a giant Czech flag that covers the section.

headline: Banks Are Laughable, Except for Ours
abstract: A new campaign for a Midwestern bank takes a popular approach in its industry: poking fun at banks, which Americans generally do not like.
lead_paragraph: AMERICANS of a certain age may have fond recollections of banks, like getting lollipops from kindly tellers and being issued their first passbooks to deposit earnings from babysitting and paper routes, but affection for banks is decidedly scarce in the aftermath of the financial crisis. Only 32 percent of Americans rate the reputation of banks as positive, ranking it 13th among 15 sectors, with just the tobacco industry and the government held in lower esteem, according to a recent Harris Poll.

headline: Re-enacting the Vietnam War
abstract: Each year in Oregon, a group of men gather to re-create a war that so many Americans have tried to forget.
lead_paragraph: Each year in Oregon, a group of men gather to re-create a war that so many Americans have tried to forget.

headline: ‘Re-enacting the Vietnam War’
abstract: Each year in Oregon, a group of men gather to re-create a war that so many Americans have tried to forget.
lead_paragraph: Growing up in the 1980s and ’90s, we were familiar with the idea of war re-enactments: masses of men in woolen uniforms dutifully recreating Pickett’s Charge at Gettysburg or trading puffs of white smoke across the Lexington Battle Green while families and schoolchildren look on. Although they were recreating gruesome battles, it all seemed rather quaint.

headline: H. Gary Morse, Who Built Mecca for Retirees, Is Dead at 77
abstract: Mr. Morse turned a small mobile home park in Central Florida into large and politically influential development that drew retirees from around the country.
lead_paragraph: H. Gary Morse, who became a billionaire by turning a Florida mobile home park into a sprawling retirement destination, the Villages, with nearly 600 holes of golf, more than 80,000 residents and outsize political influence, died on Oct. 29. He was 77.

headline: Supreme Court Stays Gay Marriage in Kansas
abstract: The Supreme Court temporarily blocked a federal court’s order that would have allowed same-sex marriages in Kansas to start on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court on Monday temporarily blocked a federal court’s order that would have allowed same-sex marriages in Kansas to start on Tuesday. In urging the Supreme Court to intercede, state officials said their case involved a novel conflict between state and federal courts in Kansas. They also relied on Thursday’s ruling from the federal appeals court in Cincinnati that upheld several state bans on same-sex marriage. Justice Sonia Sotomayor, the member of the court responsible for overseeing federal courts in Kansas, issued the stay. She ordered the plaintiffs to file a response to the state’s emergency application by Tuesday evening.

headline: Massachusetts: New Limits Are Placed on Cod Fishing in the Atlantic
abstract: Federal regulators on Monday restricted commercial fishing for Atlantic cod in the Gulf of Maine.
lead_paragraph: Federal regulators on Monday restricted commercial fishing for Atlantic cod in the Gulf of Maine. Officials with the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration announced a temporary emergency action that establishes rolling restrictions to commercial boats with gear capable of catching cod in areas of the gulf. It also limited catches to 200 pounds per trip in areas that remain open. Earlier this year, the administration released a study showing stocks of the species to be at historically low levels. The action will be in effect through the spring, but similar terms could be extended for the 2015 fishing season. Some fishermen said the cuts could put them out of business. Also Monday, the regulators increased the amount of haddock that fishermen are allowed to catch.

headline: Jack Nelson, Olympic Swimmer and Gold Medal Coach, Dies at 82
abstract: A competitor in the 1956 Olympics, he coached the United States women’s team to gold in the 400-meter freestyle relay at the 1976 Games against powerhouse East Germany.
lead_paragraph: Jack Nelson, an Olympic swimmer and coach who directed a quartet of American women to a surprising gold medal in the 400-meter freestyle relay at the 1976 Games in Montreal, died on Wednesday in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 82.

headline: Russian News Agency Expands Global Reach
abstract: The major expansion of Russia’s state news agency into the West, including capitals like Washington and Berlin, is intended to counter what Russia describes as Western propaganda.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — When Dmitry K. Kiselyov, the firebrand Russian television pundit, announced on Monday that the state news agency he leads was planning a major foreign expansion, he did not deny that the goal was to spread a type of propaganda.

headline: As Federal Reserve Selects New Top Officials, Coalition Calls for Public Input
abstract: Community groups and labor unions criticized the Fed’s selection process as secretive, undemocratic and dominated by banks and corporations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A coalition of community groups and labor unions wants the Federal Reserve to change the way some Fed officials are appointed, criticizing the existing process as secretive, undemocratic and dominated by banks and other large corporations.

headline: For Guccifer, Hacking Was Easy. Prison Is Hard.
abstract: Marcel-Lehel Lazar, whose pseudonym celebrated “the style of Gucci and the light of Lucifer,” rampaged through the email of rich Americans, showing the ease of going rogue online.
lead_paragraph: ARAD, Romania — He reveled in tormenting members of the Bush family, Colin L. Powell and a host of other prominent Americans, and also in outfoxing the F.B.I. and the Secret Service, foiling their efforts to discover even his nationality, never mind his identity. Early this year, however, the elusive online outlaw known as Guccifer lost his cocky composure and began to panic.

headline: Suit Accuses Banks of Role in Financing Terror Attacks
abstract: More than 200 people filed the lawsuit in federal court, accusing the banks of helping to finance the violent activities through their ties to Iran, painting Wall Street as a sort of middleman of terror.
lead_paragraph: A five-car convoy opened fire on a compound 30 miles south of Baghdad, a sneak attack that killed four American soldiers in one of the deadliest days in the Iraq war. A roadside bomb struck a United States military vehicle, severing part of a soldier’s head. And a militant group kidnapped and killed an American journalist, dumping him in the street after firing three shots into his chest.

headline: Don’t Delay on the Attorney General
abstract: Waiting for the next Congress to begin the confirmation process could open the door for political mischief and leave the Justice Department in limbo.
lead_paragraph: By selecting Loretta Lynch as his nominee for attorney general, President Obama wisely hopes to avoid the drawn-out confirmation battle that a more controversial nominee, like Labor Secretary Thomas Perez, would have faced.

headline: Danbury Laborers Fight Unjust Arrests
abstract: Eleven men from Ecuador say the Connecticut town singled them out because they look Hispanic. A full circuit court should hear their appeal.
lead_paragraph: One September day in 2006, the police in Danbury, Conn., and agents of Immigration and Customs Enforcement did a deplorable thing. An undercover officer, posing as a contractor, picked up some day laborers at a local park, drove them to a nearby parking lot and handed them over to waiting ICE agents. The laborers, 11 men from Ecuador, have been fighting deportation ever since.

headline: New York Changes Marijuana Arrest Policy
abstract: The police commissioner, William J. Bratton, and Mayor Bill de Blasio announced that people arrested in possession of 25 grams or less of marijuana may be issued a summons instead of being arrested.
lead_paragraph: The police commissioner, William J. Bratton, and Mayor Bill de Blasio announced that people arrested in possession of 25 grams or less of marijuana may be issued a summons instead of being arrested.

headline: Classroom Breakfasts: a Good Idea, Overdue
abstract: Everyone starting the school day with a nutritious meal would remove any stigma of a free breakfast and would ensure that no child is learning on an empty stomach.
lead_paragraph: When he was running for mayor, Bill de Blasio had a plan to improve the health and learning of tens of thousands of schoolchildren. It was to require all public schools to serve free breakfast in the classroom, instead of in the cafeteria before school started. The change was needed, he said, because so few eligible children take advantage of free cafeteria breakfasts — either because it is too hard to get to school that early or because participating in the program stigmatizes recipients as needy. Low participation squanders millions of unused dollars in federal aid and leaves too many children hungry.

headline: Concerns in Criminal Justice System as New York City Eases Marijuana Policy
abstract: Under the change, people found with small amounts of marijuana will typically be given a ticket and cited for a violation instead of being arrested and charged with a crime.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio, who took office promising to reform the Police Department and repair relations with black and Latino communities, on Monday unveiled his plan to change the way the police enforce the law on marijuana possession.

headline: Memorandum Order in Hamm Case
abstract: Harold Hamm is paying one of the biggest divorce settlements in history.
lead_paragraph: Harold Hamm is paying one of the biggest divorce settlements in history.

headline: An Oklahoma Oilman’s Billion-Dollar Divorce
abstract: After a secretive trial, Harold Hamm, the chief executive of Continental Resources, is paying one of the biggest divorce settlements in history.
lead_paragraph: During his nearly 50 years as an Oklahoma oil man, Harold Hamm has done everything on a huge scale. The chief executive and majority shareholder of Continental Resources, he owns the largest piece of the greatest oil discovery of our age, in the shale-rich plains of North Dakota. His net worth has been pegged at more than $18 billion by Forbes, making him the 24th richest man in the country.

headline: NBC Executive Says He Is ‘Very Satisfied’ With Pace of Super Bowl Ad Sales
abstract: Sales of commercial time in Super Bowl XLIX by NBC, which will broadcast the game Feb. 1, is approaching 90 percent.
lead_paragraph: NBC, which will broadcast Super Bowl XLIX on Feb. 1, is “very satisfied” with the pace of sales of commercial time during the game, according to a top sales executive.

headline: More Bank Settlements Coming in Widening Currency Case
abstract: Banks face tougher settlement language than expected and larger fines in a currency-manipulation case as multiple United States and British regulators act in concert.
lead_paragraph: As authorities in the United States and Britain ready actions this week against giant banks suspected of manipulating the foreign currency market, both the number of government agencies involved and the cost of settling the cases continues to grow.

headline: It’s Official: Mormon Founder Had Up to 40 Wives
abstract: The church made the disclosure about Joseph Smith to show transparency about its history at a time when some members have been feeling doubtful.
lead_paragraph: Mormon leaders have acknowledged for the first time that the church’s founder and prophet, Joseph Smith, portrayed in church materials as a loyal partner to his loving spouse Emma, took as many as 40 wives, some already married and one only 14 years old.

headline: ‘Gotham’ Recap:  The Cheap Thrill of Smacking a  Rich Kid
abstract: Gordon and Bullock investigate office supply murders and the Penguin and Fish Mooney face off.
lead_paragraph: Season 1, Episode 8: “The Mask”
