headline: 11 Years Later, Woman’s Death Is Tied to G.M. Ignition Defect
abstract: The family of a woman who died when her General Motors car crashed in 2003 was never told her death was linked to a flaw that has killed at least 12 others.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Conn. — Jean P. Averill warranted only a footnote.

headline: Malala Yousafzai, Nobel Laureate, Is Assailed by Schools Group in Pakistan
abstract: A network of private schools on Monday called for a day of protest against Ms. Yousafzai, 17, and her memoir about being shot by a Taliban gunman after pressing for girls’ rights and education.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A network of private schools on Monday unleashed a scathing public attack on Malala Yousafzai, the teenage Nobel laureate, in the most concerted assault yet on her reputation in her home country.

headline: Republicans Vow to Fight E.P.A. and Approve Keystone Pipeline
abstract: Republicans aim to use their new powers to subvert regulations aimed at curbing carbon pollution. They also see greater leverage in pushing President Obama to approve the Keystone XL pipeline.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The new Republican Congress is headed for a clash with the White House over two ambitious Environmental Protection Agency regulations that are the heart of President Obama’s climate change agenda.

headline: Jets’ Jaiquawn Jarrett Steps In, Then Stands Out
abstract: No player influenced the outcome of the Jets’ win Sunday more than Jarrett, a Jets reserve safety, who had a sack, a fumble recovery and two interceptions.
lead_paragraph: Rex Ryan began his teleconference Monday by praising the Jets’ pass protection and their defense and their special teams and T. J. Graham and Calvin Pryor, and all of that came from a coach who a minute earlier had said he did not have much in the way of opening remarks.

headline: Mr. Obama’s Message to Myanmar
abstract: President Obama should press forcefully for meaningful democratic reforms and an end to the persecution of the Rohingya Muslims during this week’s visit.
lead_paragraph: President Obama was ebullient during his historic visit to Myanmar in November 2012, the first by an American president to a nation that appeared on the cusp of a democratic transformation after five decades of authoritarian rule. But, in the two years since, the military-dominated, quasi-civilian government in Yangon has moved far too slowly on the commitments to reforms it made to the United States when the two nations pledged to begin a new relationship.

headline: The Legacy of Fear
abstract: The post-communist states have not flourished as expected. It is much harder to change a culture and a mind than an economic system.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-five years after the fall of the Berlin Wall, the biggest surprise is how badly most of the post-communist nations have done since. There was a general expectation back then that most of these countries would step out from tyranny and rejoin the European club of prosperous nations. Most of us did not appreciate the corrosive power of distrust, and how long it would take to heal the mental scars caused by it.

headline: Day After Being Run Over, the Giants Look to Recover
abstract: Coach Tom Coughlin searched hard for something positive to say Monday, the day after his team allowed 350 rushing yards and endured a fourth-quarter meltdown against Seattle.
lead_paragraph: The hopeful voices heard during Giants training camp, the ones that spoke of winning the N.F.C. East or of wild-card prospects, are no longer heard. Coaches and players now talk the talk of a losing team, speaking of the need to stay professional and not allow a poor season to spiral into an abysmal one.

headline: More Transparency, More Pay for C.E.O.s
abstract: As compensation consultants have become more popular in determining pay, chief executives’ paychecks have actually grown.
lead_paragraph: “It’s very seldom that publishing compensation accomplishes much for the shareholders. No C.E.O. looks at a proxy statement and comes away saying, ‘I should be paid less.’ ”

headline: After One Bashing, Bears Are Battered by News Media, Too
abstract: Newspaper columnists and radio hosts up and down the dial called for an organizational reboot of the Bears after their 55-14 loss at Green Bay on Sunday night.
lead_paragraph: LAKE FOREST, Ill. — The Chicago Bears are a source of civic pride with a tradition of playing hard-nosed, blue-collar football. Though they have won only a single Super Bowl — after the 1985 season — and have missed the playoffs six of the last seven seasons, they are still the Monsters of the Midway, the proud franchise of George Halas, Mike Ditka, Dick Butkus, Mike Singletary and Brian Urlacher.

headline: What Makes 'Natural' Natural?
abstract: Is the food label "natural" misleading to consumers? Should the F.D.A. enforce a definition of the term?

headline: Share a Single Bed
abstract: We get cozy with James Mulhern.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — If you read James Mulhern’s notes below, he believes that his theme is not necessarily “overly thrilling,” but that in forming this theme set, he offers us some lively entries. I would have to agree. Is it the world’s most thrilling theme? No. Maybe this is a result of having solved thousands of crossword puzzles and, in doing so, inadvertently set the bar too high in my mind for themes. But is it a perfectly fine Tuesday puzzle that is a pleasure to solve? Yes, of course it is.

abstract: A sameness has settled over the series.
lead_paragraph: Season 2, Episode 8: “Heartless”

headline: 2 Killed in Elevator at Bronx Housing Project; Police Consider Retaliation as Motive
abstract: The victims were shot once in the head on Monday at the Morrisania Air Rights complex, said the police, who are questioning a person of interest.
lead_paragraph: Two men were fatally shot on Monday in an elevator at a public housing building in the Bronx, and the police said they were questioning a person of interest.

headline: A Final Tribute for a Daughter Who Died From a Secret Illness
abstract: Vilyam and Mayya Gil left Ukraine 22 years ago to follow one of their twins, Larisa, to New York. When she died last year, the Gils struggled to afford a gravestone.
lead_paragraph: The phone rang in the middle of the night.

headline: Brooklyn Landlord Pleads Guilty to Negligent Homicide in 2010 Fire
abstract: Vasilios Gerazounis, the landlord of an illegally subdivided apartment building in the Bensonhurst neighborhood, faces one to three years in prison.
lead_paragraph: Late one January night in 2010, someone doused a roll of toilet paper in paint thinner in a building in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, and lit it, and five immigrants from Guatemala were killed.

headline: Investigation of Charney Adds to Loss at American Apparel
abstract: The beleaguered retailer said sales fell 5 percent in the third quarter and losses grew as it reeled from the firing of its chief executive, Dov Charney, in June.
lead_paragraph: American Apparel, a beleaguered retailer still wincing from a boardroom struggle over the summer, said sales fell 5 percent in the third quarter and losses grew — dragged down in no small part by its own investigation of the behavior of Dov Charney, who was fired as chief executive in June. The company, which has been without a permanent chief executive ever since, reported a net loss of $19.2 million, or 11 cents a share, most of which was nonrecurring costs, including $5.3 million in legal and other costs connected to Mr. Charney’s departure. A year ago, the net loss was $1.5 million. Net sales in the third quarter slipped to $155.9 million, compared with $164.5 million last year. Highlighting the company’s adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, which jumped 38 percent to $13.5 million, Scott Brubaker, the interim chief, said in a statement, “I am encouraged by these results, and am optimistic about the future prospects of the business.”

headline: Jackson Offers Advice, but Knicks Fail to Follow It All
abstract: The team’s president, Phil Jackson, who has tried to stay in the background, told his players to protect the ball and shed defenders, but that didn’t happen against the Hawks.
lead_paragraph: In his continuing effort to maintain a healthy distance between himself and the team he runs, Phil Jackson acknowledged Monday night that it was a “fine balance.” On one hand, he wants it to be clear to the players that Coach Derek Fisher is really in charge. But on the other, Jackson sometimes feels the urge to get involved.

headline: Videos Add Details in Fatal Arizona Wildfire, but Big Question Remains
abstract: Newly released videos document the search for 19 wilderness firefighters killed in the Yarnell Hill fire last year, but do not explain why the men left a relatively safe spot before their deaths.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — A DC-10 airplane roars overhead. Wind chimes toll. Tree branches rustle as the wind gusts, carrying embers of fire that ignite clusters of parched grass on the sides of a dirt road.

headline: Real Sociedad Hires New Manager
abstract: The Spanish club named David Moyes as their manager, giving him a chance to revive his career after a failed stint at Manchester United.
lead_paragraph: Jurgen Klinsmann, the coach of the United States men, continued his effort to phase in new faces by calling up a dozen promising players under 24 for the next two friendly matches, against Colombia in London on Friday and Ireland in Dublin next Tuesday. They include midfielders Alfredo Morales and Julian Green, and forwards Miguel Ibarra, Bobby Wood and Rubio Rubin, who, at 18, will be the youngest player in camp.

headline: A Sparkling Synth-Pop Debut
abstract: “Heaven,” the first offering from the Birmingham-raised, Los Angeles-based 24-year-old T.O.L.D., premieres here.
lead_paragraph: “Heaven,” the debut EP from T.O.L.D., runs a bit like a three-act play. It opens with “Lucifer’s Eyes,” a deceptively upbeat electro-pop tune that lays bright steel-drum sounds over pulsing synth lines and warm, dreamy backing vocals — elements that carry into “In Low Light,” which leads with a guitar intro that wouldn’t be out of place in a song by the XX. Like that band’s music, and others to which the project will draw comparison (Tanlines or Discovery, perhaps), the EP, which will be released Nov. 18 and premieres here, finds unexpected balances between lightness and darkness. “You focus on the beauty, but you use the sadness as a skeleton,” says Dan Smith, the 24-year-old Birmingham-born artist behind the project.

headline: Industrial Elegance
abstract: The interior architect Vincenzo de Cotiis — sought after in his native Italy for the dynamic monastery-meets-laboratory approach he brings to designing furniture, homes and hotels — deserves our attention.
lead_paragraph: The interior architect Vincenzo de Cotiis — sought after in his native Italy for the dynamic monastery-meets-laboratory approach he brings to designing furniture, homes and hotels — deserves our attention.

headline: Chloe Collaborates With a London Art Collective
abstract: To commemorate the 20th anniversary of Studio Voltaire, the fashion brand has produced a capsule collection including pieces designed by the artists Karen Kilimnik, Cao Fei and Jenny Saville.
lead_paragraph: Since its inception in 1994, the London-based collective Studio Voltaire has cultivated some of the brightest under-the-radar talent in the art world. To mark the organization’s 20th anniversary this month, however, its director Joe Scotland is teaming up with a much more recognizable name. Beginning tomorrow and running through December, the studio will open the third installation of its biennial pop-up shop, taking place this year in partnership with Chloé and its creative director Clare Waight Keller. The temporary store, House of Voltaire, which opens tomorrow in Mayfair, will sell a curated selection of commissioned home décor, limited edition prints and artworks as well as clothing and accessories by a variety of artists and designers. Chloé has also created a special four-piece capsule collection — a bag by Waight Keller, a top and shorts by the painter Karen Kilimnik, a dress by the multimedia artist Cao Fei and a scarf by the painter Jenny Saville — all of which will also be available on Net-a-Porter starting Friday, Nov. 14.

headline: Sirius XM Adds Show Based on Popular Dance Songs on YouTube
abstract: “The YouTube EDM 15” will highlight trending electronic dance music and will be the second show by the satellite radio service based on YouTube data.
lead_paragraph: By sharing data, Sirius XM and YouTube are hoping for another George Ezra.

headline: All 43 Works From Bunny Mellon’s Collection Sell at Sotheby’s Auction
abstract: The philanthropist’s collection included “masterworks” spanning 400 years. It brought $158.7 million at Sotheby’s on Monday, topping a high estimate of $121 million.
lead_paragraph: Rachel Lambert Mellon, better known as Bunny, spent her lifetime collecting whatever caught her eye, from antique porcelains and shaker baskets to abstract paintings by Rothko and Diebenkorn. Her legendary taste and style, from an era long gone, proved irresistible for scores of collectors who descended on Sotheby’s York Avenue salesroom on Monday night to see 43 “masterworks,” as the auction house called them, bringing prices that were well past anyone’s expectations.

headline: Captain Gets 36 Years for Deserting Korean Ferry
abstract: Lee Jun-seok was convicted of deserting the Sewol as it sank in April, killing 304 people, but the judge rejected the death penalty sought by prosecutors.
lead_paragraph: GWANGJU, South Korea — The captain of the South Korean ferry that sank in April, killing more than 300 people, was sentenced on Tuesday to 36 years in prison for deserting his ship and its passengers in a fatal crisis. But he was acquitted of murder, infuriating family members of some of the victims in the country’s worst disaster in decades.

headline: What an Uncensored Letter to M.L.K. Reveals
abstract: Would the F.B.I.’s smear campaign against Martin Luther King Jr. work today?
lead_paragraph: The note is just a single sheet gone yellow with age, typewritten and tightly spaced. It’s rife with typos and misspellings and sprinkled with attempts at emending them. Clearly, some effort went into perfecting the tone, that of a disappointed admirer, appalled by the discovery of “hidious [sic] abnormalities” in someone he once viewed as “a man of character.”

headline: How Well Do You Think Standardized Tests Measure Your Abilities?
abstract: How much time do you spend taking and preparing for standardized tests in school? Do you think it’s too much?
lead_paragraph: Over the past decade students have faced an increasing number of standardized tests as the government — at federal, state and local levels — introduced new academic standards and increased accountability for schools and teachers. Have you noticed an increase in standardized tests in your school or district? Do you think these exams do a good job in measuring your intelligence, abilities and what you have learned in school?

lead_paragraph: Americans studying and working in China have welcomed the announcement that, starting Wednesday, both China and the United States will begin offering each other’s citizens multiple-entry visas of up to 10 years.

headline: In Defense of ‘Exhibit B’
abstract: The managing director of the Barbican, London, responds to a column by T. O. Molefe.
lead_paragraph: Re “Racism and the Barbican’s ‘Exhibit B'” (Opinion, Oct. 28): T.O. Molefe’s column on the cancellation of Brett Bailey’s “Exhibit B” in London was thoughtful, but his description of the protests against the exhibit as “loud but peaceful” ignores the fact that barriers were pushed over by some of the protesters, the only entrance was blocked and the audience was prevented from entering. The cancellation occurred because of clear dangers to the safety of the cast, staff and audience.

headline: Hungarians Made Their Choice
abstract: Just this year Viktor Orban’s Fidesz party was re-elected by the overwhelming majority of Hungarian voters.
lead_paragraph: Re “Hungary’s authoritarian descent” (Opinion, Nov. 4): Kati Marton’s discontent with the policies of the current, right-center Hungarian government conveniently ignores the fact that just this year Viktor Orban’s Fidesz party was re-elected by the overwhelming majority of Hungarian voters. Sixty percent of the electorate voted. For a second straight time, Fidesz achieved a two-thirds majority in Parliament.

headline: Fighting the Stigma of Ebola
abstract: People are focusing on making sure they do not catch the disease, not on what needs to be done so people in Africa have what they need to survive.
lead_paragraph: Re “Don’t let Ebola dehumanize Africa” (Opinion, Oct. 31): I agree with Angélique Kidjo — it does seem that Ebola is becoming a bad stigma in Africa. People are focusing on making sure that they do not catch the disease, but not on what needs to be done so people in Africa have what they need to survive. In Liberia, Sierra Leone and Guinea, the infrastructure is primitive. This contributes to the spread of the disease — and is something that should have been addressed a long time ago.

headline: 1914: King Opens ‘Khaki’ Parliament
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The king opened his war-time parliament in London in 1914.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — History was made to-day [Nov. 11] when King George opened the ‘‘Khaki Parliament.’’ Although shorn of some of its wonted splendor on account of the war and the fact that so many members of the Royal household are serving with the colors, the scene to-day in the House of Lords was an impressive one, the pomp and circumstance of the State procession tinged with melancholy by the half-mourning which was worn as a sign of the nation’s bereavement for those who have fallen fighting. The Royal progress through the streets, lined with khaki-clad troops, was made to the accompaniment of the cheers of crowds. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Nov. 12, 1914

headline: Welsh Carson Leads $100 Million Investment in Revel Systems
abstract: The private equity firm Welsh, Carson, Anderson & Stowe is taking a small equity stake in Revel Systems, a start-up that makes point-of-sale payment software for retailers, restaurants and grocery stores.
lead_paragraph: The private equity firm Welsh, Carson, Anderson & Stowe, though known for its leveraged buyouts, is straying from its traditional playbook by making a minority investment in a young software company.

headline: 12 Women Die After Botched Government Sterilizations in India
abstract: Dozens more were ill after surgical sterilizations at a government-run camp, where some women are paid in an effort to control population growth.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Twelve women have died and dozens more were sickened after surgical sterilizations at a government-run camp in India, where women are often paid to undergo the procedures in an effort to control population growth, health officials said on Tuesday.

headline: Morning Agenda: Settlements Near in Currency Case
abstract: Bank settlements near in widening currency case. | Transparency and higher C.E.O. pay. | Banks accused of role in financing terror attacks. | Obama’s call for open Internet.
lead_paragraph: As authorities in the United States and Britain ready actions this week against giant banks suspected of manipulating the foreign currency market, banks are facing tougher settlement language and bigger fines than expected, Ben Protess and Jenny Anderson write in DealBook. The banks learned on Monday that the Commodity Futures Trading Commission in Washington was planning to announce its own settlements in the case, ending weeks of suspense over whether the agency would act in coordination with British authorities and United States banking regulators. The agency is expected to level around $300 million in fines against each of the banks, with the worst offenders paying slightly more and marginal players somewhat less.

headline: The Advantages of World Leaders Looking Silly
abstract: Local dress for political leaders at the APEC summit meetings? Think of it as a bonding exercise.
lead_paragraph: Global leaders attending an economic summit meeting in Beijing on Tuesday wore their usual uniforms — dark suits, white shirts, subdued ties — for meetings and trade announcements, but the opening photos of the event that went around the world showed them in more unconventional garb: amethyst tunics with Mandarin collars.

headline: Bright Passages
abstract: Another small sampling of sparkling prose in recent editions, from serious to silly to Kenny G.
lead_paragraph: Here’s another small sampling of sparkling prose in recent editions, from serious to silly to Kenny G.

headline: Race: If You Can’t Laugh About It …
abstract: Channon Hodges, a video journalist, describes the background of “Off Color,” a video series on comedians taking on race.
lead_paragraph: “Asian women complain to me that they’re preyed on by white guys with yellow fever. But I say I haven’t paid for a meal in three years,” said Kristina Wong, joking on Myx TV about men who only date Asian women. This is the type of humor that The Times’s “Off Color” videos highlight in an effort to start a more relaxed dialogue about race. The series was created by Tanzina Vega, whose national beat is focused on America’s changing demographics, and Channon Hodge, a video journalist.

headline: In Performance: Joely Richardson of ‘The Belle of Amherst’
abstract: The actress plays Emily Dickinson in the new production of William Luce’s biographical play.
lead_paragraph: There’s a touch of the poet in this week’s video, which features Joely Richardson in a scene from the revival of “The Belle of Amherst,” William Luce’s biographical play about Emily Dickinson. Charles Isherwood, in his review of the solo show, said Ms. Richardson “meets the challenge of shaping the verse capably, setting the shimmering phrases apart from Dickinson’s chattering monologue with a nice delicacy, and a welcome absence of ostentatious bravura.” The play, directed by Steve Cosson, continues through Nov. 23 at the Westside Theater.

headline: Daily Clip Report
abstract: Daily Clip Report is a collection of articles about the media and The Times that is emailed each day to senior executives and newsroom managers here.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

headline: First Draft Focus: Look Who’s Talking
abstract: President Obama and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia discussed Iran, Syria and Ukraine during three brief conversations at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit meeting.

headline: Israeli Forces Kill Palestinian Man in West Bank Clash
abstract: A spokeswoman for the Israeli military said that troops opened fire at the man, who was aiming a homemade gun at them from a crowd of about 200 people.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israeli forces fatally shot a Palestinian man during a demonstration in the occupied West Bank on Tuesday, a day after a pair of knife attacks by Palestinians left an Israeli soldier and a female settler dead.

headline: When Ebola Fears Hit the Neighborhood
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A day after Dr. Craig Spencer became New York City’s first Ebola patient, a Harlem neighbor chronicled the change in atmosphere.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: The Daily Gift: Gourmet Holiday Baskets for the Indie Inclined
abstract: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.
lead_paragraph: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.

headline: 22 Imprisoned in Crackdown on Extremism in Xinjiang
abstract: The court ordered terms ranging from five to 16 years, continuing an aggressive, high-profile campaign against what it calls extremism that began in May.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The authorities in Xinjiang, an ethnically divided region in northwest China, have imprisoned 22 people in a mass sentencing that included charges of rape, disturbing public order and “illegal preaching,” a state news media outlet reported on Tuesday.

headline: Excluded From the Silicon Valley Dream
abstract: Many have argued that tech’s lack of diversity leads to discrimination in hiring and promotion. Now one woman reveals how it can affect employees’ very sense of self.
lead_paragraph: “I feel alone every day I come to work,” writes Erica Joy, “despite being surrounded by people.” In a widely read Medium essay, she chronicles her experiences as a black woman in a tech industry dominated by white men. And in so doing, she shows how deep the effects of exclusion can go.

headline: Putin Gives Shawl to China’s First Lady
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia caused a minor stir Monday after offering a shawl to the wife of President Xi Jinping of China at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia caused a minor stir Monday after offering a shawl to the wife of President Xi Jinping of China at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum.

headline: On Veterans Day, Offering Gratitude and Accepting It
abstract: When I told the man at the baggage counter that my husband was deployed, he immediately replied, “Thank you for your service.” I didn’t quite know how to respond.
lead_paragraph: When I told the man at the baggage counter that my husband was deployed, he immediately replied, “Thank you for your service.” I didn’t quite know how to respond, so I smiled uncomfortably and nodded, graciously trying to clarify that my husband was the one serving. When I think of the phrase “service to our country,” I can hear the bayonets and see the tattered flag waving valiantly in the breeze.

headline: Japanese Leader Cites Improved Ties With Beijing
abstract: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan said that he believed his country and China had taken a major step forward in repairing relations, although the official Chinese reaction after the meeting was less optimistic.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Striking an upbeat note, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan said Tuesday that he believed his country and China had taken a major step forward in repairing relations, and that from now on there should be frequent dialogue between them.

headline: On This Day: An Armistice Is Signed
abstract: On this day in 1918 an armistice was signed ending World War I hostilities.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of people will flock to the National Mall today to commemorate Veterans Day with live music from the likes of Bruce Springsteen and Eminem.

headline: Should the United States Declare Books an ‘Essential Good’?
abstract: Daniel Mendelsohn and Mohsin Hamid debate whether the United States should follow the French government’s lead.
lead_paragraph: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. The French government has declared books an “essential good.” This week, Daniel Mendelsohn and Mohsin Hamid debate whether the United States should do the same.

headline: The Third Way: Tricycles
abstract: Long a favorite of toddlers, three-wheelers have also attracted the attention of British lords, Indian maharajahs — and now, one writer hopes, a bold new generation.
lead_paragraph: Long a favorite of toddlers, three-wheelers have also attracted the attention of British lords, Indian maharajahs — and now, one writer hopes, a bold new generation.

headline: GitHub Hits the Cloud
abstract: The popular method of creating software says its business version will be available for direct use on the most popular public cloud. GitHub also said it now has 17 million repositories, or projects, on file. At the start of the year it had 10 million.
lead_paragraph: Software is eating the world, as venture capitalist Marc Andreessen noted three years ago. Now it may not even be taking the time to chew carefully.

headline: Court Lets E.U. Nations Curb Immigrant Welfare
abstract: The European Court of Justice, hearing the case of a Romanian migrant in Germany, ruled that member nations may withhold benefits to immigrants from other, usually poorer, member nations.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The European Union’s top court put its thumb on the scale of one of the bloc’s most divisive issues Tuesday, ruling in effect that richer countries can limit access to welfare benefits for citizens from poorer ones.

headline: Sotomayor’s Notable Court Opinions and Articles
Dozens Die in Bus Crash on Pakistan Highway
abstract: The deaths occurred, the police said, when the driver lost control of the bus, crossed over into oncoming traffic and collided with a truck.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — At least 57 people were killed and 18 were injured on Tuesday when a passenger bus rammed into a truck in southern Pakistan, officials and rescue workers said.

headline: Africa Cup Disrupted by Ebola Concerns
abstract: Because it sought to delay the championship, fearing a spread of Ebola, Morocco was barred from the 2015 Cup, another disruption to soccer related to the outbreak.
lead_paragraph: Fear of the spread of Ebola has now thrown Africa’s most important soccer tournament into disarray.

headline: UniCredit Profit Jumps as Loan Losses Fall
abstract: UniCredit’s earnings report offers more evidence that it is healthy enough to provide badly needed loans to Italian businesses and individuals.
lead_paragraph: UniCredit said on Tuesday that net profit more than tripled in the third quarter as the Italian bank booked lower losses related to doubtful loans.

headline: Plenty of Hugs as Craig Spencer, Recovered New York Ebola Patient, Goes Home
abstract: Dr. Craig Spencer, who tested positive for Ebola after treating patients in Guinea, was released from Bellevue Hospital Center, and doctors said he posed no danger to the public.
lead_paragraph: For recovered Ebola patients, the new rules of etiquette demand hugs.

headline: 1964: Monnet Meets With de Gaulle
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Two antagonists of the European community met in Paris in 1964.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Jean Monnet, chief proponent of a ‘‘United States of Europe,’’ met today with its chief opponent, President Charles de Gaulle, to discuss the current crisis in the Common Market. Coming during a confrontation between France and West Germany over agriculture, stirred much speculation. Upon leaving the Elysée Palace, Mr. Monnet told reporters: ‘‘I don’t think the Franco- German difficulties are insoluble. A solution could be found in Brussels.’’ Then he added with a laugh: ‘‘I repeat that what I’m saying does not reflect the conversation I’ve just had with Gen. de Gaulle.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Nov. 12, 1964

headline: 100 Years After World War I Began, Europe Remembers Its End
abstract: This year, the remembrance was particularly poignant, culminating in months of preparation, exhibits and re-examination of a murderous conflict.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In Britain, there were commemorative poppies by the hundreds of thousands, bright red ceramics that filled the moat of the Tower of London.

headline: Shinzo Abe on Meeting China’s President
abstract: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan said meeting with President Xi Jinping of China was a “big step” for improving relations.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan said meeting with President Xi Jinping of China was a “big step” for improving relations.

headline: Indian Officials on Sterilization Deaths
abstract: Officials and activists discussed the deaths of the women who underwent sterilization surgery at a government-run “health camp” in the central Indian state of Chhattisgarh.
lead_paragraph: Officials and activists discussed the deaths of the women who underwent sterilization surgery at a government-run “health camp” in the central Indian state of Chhattisgarh.

headline: How an iPhone Can Lead to Broken Bones for Young Children
abstract: A new paper argues that the wide adoption of smartphones, along with the distractions caused by them, has led to more playground injuries.
lead_paragraph: The iPhone may cause broken bones and concussions. Yes, I’m leaving out a few in-between steps there.

headline: Restaurant Review: Dumpling Galaxy in Queens
abstract: At Helen You’s dumpling emporium in Flushing, you can watch the stars on TV and then eat them.
lead_paragraph: When I am on my way to a big dinner at a restaurant in Flushing, Queens, I like to limber up by eating a dozen of Helen You’s dumplings.

headline: Alibaba and Others Push to Improve Delivery, on Singles’ Day in China
abstract: The country’s largest Internet merchants are working to improve logistics in China, a country plagued by delivery inefficiency.
lead_paragraph: HANGZHOU, China — It’s the biggest shopping day of the year in China, and the discounts are steep. But Jiang Shan waited to buy some of what she wants.

headline: Google Chromecast Adds Games
abstract: Google’s Chromecast streaming device now has the ability to let people play video games in tandem.
lead_paragraph: Technology companies have taken over your stereo, television and home movies. Now they’re coming for your board games.

headline: From The Upshot: Why Democrats Should Cut Taxes
abstract: The lack of income growth has become a defining national issue and is hurting Democrats.
lead_paragraph: The Great Wage Slowdown, Looming Over Politics

headline: Spouses Denied Social Security Survivors’ Benefits
abstract: Social Security will not pay benefits to same-sex spouses in states where their marriage is not recognized.
lead_paragraph: In July, Kathy Murphy received a letter from the Social Security Administration. “We are writing to tell you that you do not qualify for widow’s benefits,” it said. “You do not qualify for the lump-sum death benefit because you are not Sara Elizabeth Barker’s widow or child.”

headline: With Persistence and Phone Calls, Defending Against Ebola in New York
abstract: The health department is monitoring almost 300 people, including those involved in Dr. Craig Spencer’s care and recent arrivals to New York City from African countries hit hardest by the virus.
lead_paragraph: On the 12th floor of a glass tower at the city health department’s headquarters in Long Island City, Queens, workers huddle like telemarketers at banks of 30 computers, doggedly calling one telephone number after another.

headline: Why the Voters of 2016 Are Likely to Be Younger and More Diverse
abstract: Enthusiasm for President Obama brought out younger and nonwhite voters in 2008 and 2012, but demographic changes are set to have the same effect.
lead_paragraph: A midterm election has come and gone, and now begins a new round of speculation about whether the Democrats can remobilize young and nonwhite voters in 2016.

headline: A Dual Review of What’s New, Starring Lisa Kudrow and Jarvis Cocker
abstract: The actress and the Britpop icon slather on snail slime while considering rose gold sneakers and a knitter’s sex guide.
lead_paragraph: Lisa Kudrow, alleged Post-it note inventor and everyone’s favorite Friend who currently stars in a pair of cable series: Showtime’s “Web Therapy” and HBO’s “The Comeback,” which just came back after a nine-year hiatus, takes on Jarvis Cocker, Britpop icon and the droll subject of a new documentary on his band, “Pulp: A Film About Life, Death & Supermarkets.” His radio show — “a nocturnal exploration of the human condition” — is available on iTunes.

headline: States Race to Improve Health Insurance Exchanges
abstract: Many states will have more workers in call centers this year and more enrollment events to help people through the insurance sign-up process.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Massachusetts and Minnesota have sharply increased the number of call center workers who will help people enroll in health plans through the states’ insurance exchanges. Colorado has created an online avatar named Kyla to guide consumers through the sign-up process. And Maryland has replaced its exchange, which floundered last year, with Connecticut’s successful model.

headline: Gillian Flynn’s Comic-Book Story
abstract: “Masks,” by Gillian Flynn, will be published by Dark Horse Comics in February.
lead_paragraph: Fans of Gillian Flynn’s dark view of a marriage in “Gone Girl” may want to read “Masks,” her first comic-book story, to be published by Dark Horse Comics in February.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Choosing When to Die
abstract: A writer says assisted suicide should be legal for the elderly even if they don’t face a terminal illness. Readers are invited to respond.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Song From the Forest’ Charts a Musicologist’s Love Affair With Pygmy Music and Culture
abstract: A mesmerizing film explores how pygmy music lured an American to the Congo and pygmy culture held him there.
lead_paragraph: Back in March, while at the South by Southwest festival to discuss data visualization with a NASA team, I had a chance to watch “Song from the Forest,” a deeply captivating visual and sonic exploration of the strange, music-driven life of Louis Sarno, an American ethnomusicologist who was lured to the Congo River basin in the 1980s by recordings of pygmy songs and, in many ways, never came back.

headline: Today in Small Business: An S.E.O. Challenge
abstract: Military-friendly companies. Could a drop in lending be good news for small businesses? Is Igor Pasternak on the verge of revolutionizing shipping?
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: With Faith of Investors, Downtown Tulsa Reawakens
abstract: Anchored by the redevelopment of an old hotel, and a rejuvenated oil and gas industry, the central business district in the Oklahoma city is beginning to thrive again.
lead_paragraph: For decades, the Mayo Hotel had been the societal symbol of Tulsa’s reign as the Oil Capital of the World, catering to oil barons with names like Getty, Skelly, Phillips and Sinclair. But its closing in 1981 underscored the city’s faded status as Houston became the focal point of the energy industry.

headline: Celebrating Diane von Furstenberg’s Memoir, ‘The Woman I Wanted to Be’
abstract: Ms. von Furstenberg had an early fan in Chelsea Clinton.
lead_paragraph: “Oh gosh, the first dress I ever bought with my own money was a wrap dress,” Chelsea Clinton said. “About 10 years ago — at the Stanford shopping mall, probably. I still have it.”

headline: Nonclassical, a London New-Music Franchise, Expanding to New York
abstract: The Nonclassical recording label and concert series run by the composer Gabriel Prokofiev will present concerts in Brooklyn for the first time.
lead_paragraph: Nonclassical, the London-based indie-classical new-music label and club series run by the composer and producer Gabriel Prokofiev, is celebrating its 10th anniversary with an expansion to New York. In a collaboration with the like-minded New Amsterdam label, Nonclassical will present the first New York installment of the Classical Club-Nights series it presents monthly in London.

headline: Working Parents Who Cook, or Don’t Cook, Family Meals
abstract: Has the emphasis on the importance of home cooking inspired you or frustrated you? Tell us.
lead_paragraph: These days, the advice on healthy eating seems to come from many corners. But the consensus is there.

headline: Vegetarian Thanksgiving: Brussels Sprouts Sliders
abstract: Every year at Well, we take the turkey off the table and celebrate the delicious non-meat side dishes, appetizers and main courses that make Thanksgiving the best meal of the year.
lead_paragraph: This year for Well’s Vegetarian Thanksgiving we’re highlighting some of our favorite — and your favorite — recipes from Vegetarian Thanksgivings past. Here’s one from 2014, when we asked readers to submit their own favorites. See more of Well’s Vegetarian Thanksgiving selections at NYT Cooking.

headline: De Blasio Hugs Recovered Ebola Patient
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York was present as Dr. Craig Spencer, who contracted Ebola while working in West Africa, was released from Bellevue Hospital Center upon being declared cured.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York was present as Dr. Craig Spencer, who contracted Ebola while working in West Africa, was released from Bellevue Hospital Center upon being declared cured.

headline: On a Mexican Island, Murals With a Conservation Message
abstract: The nonprofit PangeaSeed has organized a collection of murals in Isla Mujeres, Mexico, to raise awareness of ocean conservation.
lead_paragraph: The small island of Isla Mujeres, off the coast of Cancún, Mexico, is getting big dose of art with the recent inauguration of “Sea Walls: Murals for Oceans,” a display of 15 large-scale murals by some of the top names in contemporary street art.

headline: 9 Wallpaper Studies
abstract: The artist Leanne Shapton painted wallpaper from museums, stately homes and National Trust houses in England.
lead_paragraph: The artist Leanne Shapton painted wallpaper from museums, stately homes and National Trust houses in England.

headline: A Well-Timed Book Tour for Rubio
abstract: Senator Marco Rubio is not sure if he will run for president, but he is planning a national book tour that just happens to coincide with the start of the presidential election cycle.
lead_paragraph: Senator Marco Rubio says he is not sure whether he will run for president, but he is planning a national book tour that just happens to coincide with the start of the presidential election cycle.

headline: This Veterans Day, Read (and Listen to) Family Stories
abstract: Military experience was once common. Many of us grew up surrounded by parents and family who had served. Now, military life seems removed from the everyday for many of us. Here, for Veteran’s Day, stories of military family.
lead_paragraph: When I was growing up, it felt like everyone had family in the military. My father served, as did his father. We lived close to a variety of military bases; I went to college near Fort Riley, in Kansas. My roommate married a military man; my cousin and her husband both serve.

headline: John Doar, Federal Lawyer on Front Lines Against Segregation, Dies at 92
abstract: A Republican, Mr. Doar prosecuted some of the most notorious cases of murder in the South in the ’60s and was chief counsel to the House panel investigating Watergate.
lead_paragraph: John Doar, a country lawyer from northern Wisconsin who led the federal government’s on-the-ground efforts to dismantle segregation in the South, and who later headed the team that made the case for impeaching President Richard M. Nixon in the wake of the Watergate scandal, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 92. The cause was congestive heart failure, his son Robert said.

headline: New York Jazz Clubs Double as Record Labels
abstract: In the current music-industry climate, a lane has opened for small but serious labels with low overhead and ready-made recording space.
lead_paragraph: The saxophonist Ian Hendrickson-Smith has caught his share of deflected stardust: as a former foot soldier with Sharon Jones and the Dap-Kings, as a hired gun for the likes of Al Green and as a member of “The Tonight Show” band (which is to say, the Roots). For the rest of this year, as part of the Loston Harris Trio, he’ll appear Thursday through Saturday nights at Bemelmans Bar, the hobnobby lounge in the Carlyle Hotel in Manhattan.

headline: Higher Counterbid Made for Club Med, With Help From K.K.R.
abstract: Andrea C. Bonomi, the Italian businessman battling a Chinese-French bid for Club Méditerranée, announces a sweetened offer for the resort company.
lead_paragraph: PARIS – Andrea C. Bonomi, the Italian businessman battling a Chinese-French bid for Club Méditerranée, on Tuesday announced another sweetened offer for the resort company, this time with backing from Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Company.

headline: The Dining Section Is Now Food
abstract: We have renamed this section, in print and online, to reflect its increasingly broad focus.
lead_paragraph: We have renamed this section, in print and online, to reflect its increasingly broad focus on food and drink, restaurants and home cooking, gastronomic trends and innovation. The new name looks forward, to coverage that extends beyond the dining room. But it looks back as well: “Food” was the name of the report Craig Claiborne edited when he joined The New York Times in 1957. It provides the foundation upon which we build today.

headline: Tig Notaro Says She’s Healing After Surgery
abstract: The comedian had canceled performances in Boston and Denver because of a medical emergency.
lead_paragraph: The comedian Tig Notaro said on Tuesday that she was recovering from a burst cyst that had required her to undergo emergency surgery and cancel several planned performances.

headline: Reporters Barred From Alito Speech? Just ‘a Small Mix-Up’
abstract: Reporters were surprised on Tuesday morning when the Federalist Society, a conservative legal group, announced that the news media would be barred from an appearance by Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. at its annual gala black-tie dinner.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court is famously secretive, and its justices do not always make it easy for the press to cover their public appearances. Still, reporters were surprised on Tuesday morning when the Federalist Society, a conservative legal group, announced that the news media would be barred from an appearance by Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. at its annual gala black-tie dinner.

headline: In Tokyo, Following Elders to Bargains
abstract: Budget-conscious travelers can shop, snack and sip in the old-school Sugamo neighborhood for a song.
lead_paragraph: One of Tokyo’s mainstay tourist attractions is Harajuku, a labyrinthine shopping district jammed with trend-obsessed teenagers parading famously outlandish fashions. But in spite of Harajuku’s youthful flash and flair, to walk around the city is to realize that Japan is a country of old people. Gray-haired grandpas zip past on bicycles, impressing with their cavalier attitude toward traffic. Immaculately coifed senior women do the same, their faces freshly powdered and lipsticked, their flowered shirts neatly pressed.

headline: Officials Discuss Violence in West Bank
abstract: The Israeli defense minister and the president of the Palestinian Authority discussed the escalating violence in the West Bank after Israeli forces fatally shot a Palestinian man on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli defense minister and the president of the Palestinian Authority discussed the escalating violence in the West Bank after Israeli forces fatally shot a Palestinian man on Tuesday.

headline: BNP Paribas Could Make a Merger With Monte dei Paschi Work
abstract: BNP Paribas could find worthwhile synergies if it acquires Monte dei Paschi, even though buying the bank carries risks, Neil Unmack writes in Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: BNP Paribas should be thinking seriously about Monte dei Paschi di Siena. After this year’s $8.9 billion fine from American regulators, BNP’s shareholders probably feel they’ve had enough excitement. But looking past the risks, there would be logic to swooping on the Italian lender.

headline: Chris Christie: Selling Out Local Pigs for Iowa Pig Farmers
abstract: The governor doesn’t like a bi-partisan bill that would ban gestation crates for pregnant sows.
lead_paragraph: The National Review has brought renewed attention to an animal-welfare bill awaiting New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie’s signature. Somewhat unusually for a conservative publication not associated with environmental causes or animal rights, the piece argues that the Republican governor should go ahead and sign the bill, which would ban the use of gestation crates for pregnant sows.

headline: Chief Defends Spotify After Snub by Taylor Swift
abstract: The decision by Ms. Swift to remove her entire catalog from Spotify has intensified a debate over royalties paid by streaming music services.
lead_paragraph: Spotify is the future. Spotify is the enemy. Spotify doesn’t pay enough. Spotify is music’s best bet for revenue growth.

headline: A Thanksgiving Checklist
abstract: From Regina Charboneau, tips for making a successful holiday meal easier.
lead_paragraph: Regina Charboneau knows how to make Thanksgiving easier. Here are some of her timesaving tips.

headline: Chiefs Play It Safe, and Haven’t Been Sorry Since Week 1
abstract: Since losing their first two games, including their opener against the Titans, the Chiefs have used a slow, methodical offense to go 6-1 and outscore opponents by 89 points.
lead_paragraph: It was the most surprising result of the season. We just didn’t know it at the time.

headline: How to Dazzle Without the Frazzle
abstract: From the Southern chef Regina Charboneau, tricks and tips for an elaborate and elegant Thanksgiving dinner without endless hours in the kitchen.
lead_paragraph: NATCHEZ, Miss. — Regina Charboneau, who is much more organized than you are, will host 145 people at her house this Thanksgiving.

headline: Families of Victims After Sentencing
abstract: Victims’ family members reacted to what they saw as lenient sentences for the captain and crew of a South Korean ferry that capsized in April, killing more than 300 passengers.
lead_paragraph: Victims’ family members reacted to what they saw as lenient sentences for the captain and crew of a South Korean ferry that capsized in April, killing more than 300 passengers.

headline: First Draft Focus: Veterans Day
abstract: Wilma Burris visited the grave of her husband, David Graham Burris, at Arlington National Cemetery on Tuesday, which was Veterans Day. Mr. Burris served in the Army in the Persian Gulf and died on Aug. 3, 2010.

headline: Nicholas Kristof on Obama’s Tour of Asia
abstract: The New York Times columnist Nicholas Kristof discussed the complicated agenda of President Obama’s weeklong tour of Asia on MSNBC’s “Now with Alex Wagner.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times columnist Nicholas Kristof discussed the complicated agenda of President Obama’s weeklong tour of Asia on MSNBC’s “Now With Alex Wagner.”

headline: Big Business ‘Strongly Opposed’ to Net Neutrality Rules
abstract: The biggest business lobby group in the United States is not happy that President Obama is pressuring the Federal Communications Commission to impose stricter rules on broadband providers.
lead_paragraph: The biggest business lobby group in the United States is not happy that President Obama is pressuring the Federal Communications Commission to impose stricter rules on broadband providers.

headline: Net Neutrality Debate: Internet Access and Costs Are Top Issues
abstract: After President Obama urged the F.C.C. to set tougher net neutrality rules, questions loom about decreased competition and the cost of monitoring.
lead_paragraph: What is the problem with the Internet in the United States?

headline: At Afghan Border, Graft Is Part of the Bargain
abstract: Afghan and foreign officials say that corruption can no longer be described as a cancer on the system: It is the system.
lead_paragraph: TORKHAM, Afghanistan — Some call them “the men who sit on golden chairs” — Afghan customs officials who preside over a vast ecosystem of bribery that stretches from dusty border crossings to the capital.

headline: U.S. and China Reach Climate Accord After Months of Talks
abstract: The deal, the signature achievement of President Obama’s state visit to China, could galvanize efforts to negotiate a new global agreement.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China and the United States made common cause on Wednesday against the threat of climate change, staking out an ambitious joint plan to curb carbon emissions as a way to spur nations around the world to make their own cuts in greenhouse gases.

headline: Can America and Russia Get Along?
abstract: To hear some Russians tell it, the United States has a “master plan” to demonize their president, Vladimir Putin.
lead_paragraph: Dayton, Ohio – To hear some Russians tell it, the United States has a “master plan” to demonize their president, Vladimir Putin, and use sanctions, imposed because of the crisis in Ukraine, to bring down his government. They also accuse Washington of backing pro-Nazi factions in Ukraine.

headline: Shelly Fireman Is Opening Florian Downtown
abstract: The restaurateur is looking to attract a different clientele for his brand of jazzy Italian food, including a lavish antipasto array.
lead_paragraph: Headliner

headline: Wheelies: The Duality of Honda Edition
abstract: Honda releases an interactive ad for the sporty Civic R; Ford begins production of the new F-150 pickup truck.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Custody Agreement Reached in Investment Banker’s Messy Divorce
abstract: In a statement, the wife of a Jefferies managing director said the two had reached an “amicable custody arrangement.” She also seemed to take back some of the lurid details reported in the media.
lead_paragraph: An ugly divorce battle that briefly riveted Wall Street has ended with a whimper.

headline: Restaurant Report: BackYard Bia Hoi in Hanoi
abstract: Opened in March, this spot offers an elegant spin on the “bia hoi,” a roadside restaurant where locals drink beer and eat snacks on plastic stools.
lead_paragraph: In Vietnamese, “bia hoi” refers to both fresh-brewed beer and the roadside restaurants where locals, perched on plastic stools, gather to consume it. The light brew is typically enjoyed with snacks like roasted peanuts and fermented sausage and simple stir-fries of whatever ingredients happen to be on hand.

headline: Hotel Review: Amoy Hotel in Singapore
abstract: This year-old boutique property offers a charming — and calming — experience in the center of the financial district.
lead_paragraph: ­Standard rooms start at 238 Singapore dollars, about $190, at 1.25 Singapore dollars to the U.S. dollar.

headline: It Wasn’t Just the Shoes
abstract: In “Livin’ la Vida Imelda,” Carlos Celdran delves into many corners of Imelda Marcos’s life.
lead_paragraph: There are tour guides, and there are tour guides. Should you visit the Philippines, see if you can still get Carlos Celdran, who is also a performance artist and has brought his very entertaining solo show, “Livin’ la Vida Imelda,” to the Clurman Theater.

headline: Fearing Bombs That Can Pick Whom to Kill
abstract: Weapons that rely on artificial intelligence to decide what to target could become increasingly difficult to control, critics warn.
lead_paragraph: On a bright fall day last year off the coast of Southern California, an Air Force B-1 bomber launched an experimental missile that may herald the future of warfare.

headline: Two Sides, One Ensemble
abstract: The play of the Leipzig Gewandhaus Orchestra’s string section contrasted sharply with its winds and brasses on Sunday and Monday at Avery Fisher Hall.
lead_paragraph: Two ensembles showed up onstage when the storied Leipzig Gewandhaus Orchestra played at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday and Monday, led by its music director, Riccardo Chailly.

headline: The Plight of Gay Veterans
abstract: They don’t have access to the full array of benefits available to their colleagues.
lead_paragraph: As we celebrate Veteran’s Day, let’s pause to consider the men and women who have served in the armed forces, but who don’t have access to the full array of benefits available to their colleagues because they’re gay.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: In Net Neutrality Push, Internet Giants on the Sidelines
abstract: Companies like Facebook and Google have stayed away from mobilizing their users to support an issue that primarily affects smaller Internet upstarts.
lead_paragraph: Silicon Valley’s giant companies have been quiet lately on the question of whether the government should protect an open Internet, which they’ve previously argued is vital to innovation. Don’t count on them staking out a stronger position even though President Obama has stepped into the fray, and Washington looks to be gearing up for an epic battle over the rules that govern the Internet.

headline: Even the Stars Are Fans
abstract: “This is my first night out as a mother,” Ms. Clinton said while accepting her award on Monday night.
lead_paragraph: “This is my first night out as a mother,” Ms. Clinton said while accepting her award on Monday night.

headline: Should Your Child Play Football?
abstract: Football is either an outdated activity that endangers players and promotes violence or a character-building pastime that helps mold American youth.
lead_paragraph: To the partisan battles of red and blue America, we can apparently add another culture clash: football.

headline: WNYC’s ‘Soundcheck’ to Go Online-Only
abstract: The show, which has been on New York public radio since 2002, will go off the air, but will continue digitally in a modified form.
lead_paragraph: “Soundcheck,” the weekday music program on WNYC that has been a staple of the New York music scene since 2002, will be going off the air at the end of this week.

headline: U.S. Bishops Struggle to Follow Lead of Francis
abstract: American bishops say they can feel change rattling the church hierarchy even if they do not yet understand where the pope is leading them.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — It was a hail and farewell moment at a tumultuous time for the Roman Catholic Church. More than 200 bishops rose to their feet Monday and gave a protracted standing ovation to Cardinal Francis George, a former president of the bishops’ conference, who will step down next week as the archbishop of Chicago.

headline: From The Upshot: A Look at the Next Big Election
abstract: Enthusiasm for President Obama brought out younger and nonwhite voters in 2008 and 2012, but demographic changes are set to have the same effect.
lead_paragraph: Why the Voters of 2016 Are Likely to Be Younger and More Diverse

headline: Missouri Governor Says National Guard Is Still Option in Ferguson
abstract: Gov. Jay Nixon said he was obligated to prevent potential violence as the St. Louis area braced for a grand jury decision on whether to indict a police officer in the fatal shooting of Michael Brown.
lead_paragraph: WELDON SPRING, Mo. — Gov. Jay Nixon said Tuesday that the Missouri National Guard was part of a multiforce contingency plan by law enforcement authorities to avert violence as the region around St. Louis awaited a grand jury’s return in the death of Michael Brown three months ago.

headline: Detroit Emerges From Bankruptcy, Yet Pension Risks Linger
abstract: A deal to keep Detroit’s pension system funded leaves the bankrupt city vulnerable to future fiscal crises.
lead_paragraph: When the judge in Detroit’s historic bankruptcy case approved the city’s exit plan on Friday, he said the deal Detroit cut with its retirees bordered on “miraculous.”

headline: Grim Horrors of Modernity, via Auden
abstract: The Royal Ballet presented the premiere of Liam Scarlett’s “The Age of Anxiety,” based on the Auden poem, and works by Kim Brandstrup and Christopher Wheeldon.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain is awash in World War I centenary commemorations and poppy mania. Ballet companies here haven’t lagged behind. Both English National Ballet and the Birmingham Royal Ballet have offered war-themed programs; on Friday came the Royal Ballet’s contribution, with a triple bill that uses music by Britten and Leonard Bernstein from the 1930s and ’40s and poetry by W. H. Auden to evoke a period in which another great war changed the world.

headline: Hollywood on the Tiber
abstract: What could be more melancholic, extravagant, alienated, operatic and deeply strange than Italian film? Try turning Italian film into a theme park.
lead_paragraph: What could be more melancholic, extravagant, alienated, operatic and deeply strange than Italian film? Try turning Italian film into a theme park.

headline: A Hot Coffee Culture in Salt Lake City
abstract: Small-batch roasters, siphon-brewed coffees and nitro-poured cups in the shadow of the Wasatch Mountains.
lead_paragraph: In a place known more for proximity to powdery ski slopes than perfect espresso pulls, it’s easy to assume Salt Lake City couldn’t breed advanced coffee geek culture. Yet the high-desert city has become the kind of town where some cafes sell 12 ounces of roasted coffee beans for $50 and teach customers about the benefits of drinking coffee without cream or sugar.

headline: Russia Reaches Deal With Iran to Construct Nuclear Plants
abstract: The agreement to supply civilian power technology shows that Russia is pressing ahead with its own vision for ensuring that Iran does not build nuclear weapons.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia agreed on Tuesday to build two new nuclear power reactors in Iran, with a possibility of six more after that, in a deal that greatly expands nuclear cooperation between the two countries.

headline: Argentina’s Feeder System Drains Talent From Nation’s Top Division
abstract: A result of exporting so many players — more than 2,700 Argentines now play in foreign leagues — is that club soccer in the South American nation is blighted by a lack of continuity.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — Casual fans might think Argentine soccer is enjoying a golden age. The country’s national team finished second at the World Cup last summer, led by Lionel Messi, a player many consider one of the best to play the game, and Argentine players and coaches are key figures at many of the world’s top clubs.

headline: A Tribute to Veterans at Attack Site in Ottawa
abstract: The killing of two Canadian soldiers last month, including one at the National War Memorial, brought out crowds not seen in decades at Canada’s annual Remembrance Day service.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Tens of thousands of Canadians streamed toward the National War Memorial on Tuesday, just three weeks after a gunman shot a soldier guarding it and rampaged through the Parliament building, plunging the capital into panic and fear.

headline: Love Flows, President to President
abstract: In “41,” former President George W. Bush draws an affectionate portrait of his father, George H. W. Bush.
lead_paragraph: The relationship between George W. Bush and his father, George H. W. Bush, might just be the most dissected filial relationship in modern history — compared, variously, to Shakespearean history, Greek tragedy and opéra bouffe. In his new book, the 43rd president draws an affectionate portrait of the 41st president that’s short on factual revelations and long on emotion.

headline: Fantasy Football: Week 11 Waiver Wire Picks
abstract: With the Dallas Cowboys on a bye week, fantasy owners have several holes to fill in Week 11.
lead_paragraph: We are one week away from not having to worry about bye weeks and the fantasy playoffs are just around the corner. And we are finally done with being inundated by political ads. All is right with the world, right?

headline: Xi Jinping’s Rapid Rise in China Presents Challenges to the U.S.
abstract: President Xi Jinping has bold ambitions at home and abroad and sees China as a peer of the United States.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — President Obama will sit down Wednesday with the kind of Chinese leader no American president has ever encountered: a strongman with bold ambitions at home and abroad who sees China as a great power peer of the United States.

headline: ‘What Exit?’ For Some in New Jersey, the Answer Has Changed
abstract: Residents of Lakewood have lost Exit 88 on the Garden State Parkway as part of a plan to improve connections with local roads.
lead_paragraph: In New Jersey, divining where someone is from can be done with a simple question or two — enough to learn a region, a county or a municipality.

headline: Why the Theater Next Door Isn’t Fit for a Queen
abstract: The Broadway producers of “The Audience,” with Helen Mirren as Queen Elizabeth II, have turned down $400,000 to let “It’s Only a Play” continue in the Schoenfeld Theater.
lead_paragraph: How badly did the Broadway producers of “The Audience,” a coming play starring Helen Mirren, want their first-choice theater, the Schoenfeld? Enough to brush off rival producers who were prepared to pay them $400,000 for dibs on the house.

headline: The Look of the APEC Summit
abstract: World leaders at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum have shown off traditional apparel of the host country every year.
lead_paragraph: World leaders at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum have shown off traditional apparel of the host country every year.

headline: On Fifth Avenue, With Flags and Pride on Veterans Day
abstract: The Annual Veterans Day Parade in Manhattan began at 11:11 a.m. and proceeded from 26th Street to 52nd Street.
lead_paragraph: The Annual Veterans Day Parade in Manhattan began at 11:11 a.m. and proceeded from 26th Street to 52nd Street.

headline: Photos From Veterans Day
abstract: A look at Veterans Day gatherings from around the country.
lead_paragraph: A look at Veterans Day gatherings from around the country.

headline: Police Seek Suspects in Manhattan Jewelry Store Robbery
abstract: Officers conducted a floor-by-floor search of the building on West 47th Street after the crime, which occurred near the route of the annual Veterans Day parade.
lead_paragraph: An armed robber posing as a delivery man stole a bag of jewelry on Tuesday afternoon from a store in Manhattan’s diamond district, the authorities said, prompting a search and unsettling the usually bustling block.

headline: Pictures of the Day: France and Elsewhere
abstract: France and More — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: France and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Missouri May Use National Guard Again
abstract: As Ferguson awaits a decision on whether a police officer will face charges in the shooting death of Michael Brown, Gov. Jay Nixon said the National Guard could be deployed to protect against violence.
lead_paragraph: As Ferguson awaits a decision on whether a police officer will face charges in the shooting death of Michael Brown, Gov. Jay Nixon said the National Guard could be deployed to protect against violence.

headline: Zoetis, an Animal Health Company, Says Ackman Has Taken a Stake
abstract: The activist investor William A. Ackman has acquired an 8.5 percent economic interest in the former animal health arm of Pfizer.
lead_paragraph: The activist investor William A. Ackman appears to have found yet another target for his hedge fund in the health care industry: Zoetis, the former animal health arm of Pfizer that is now a $21.8 billion publicly traded company.

headline: Will Bill Clinton Be First Husband? Ellen’s Turn to Ask
abstract: Interviewers of all kinds have been prodding the Clintons with questions from every angle in hopes of gathering a clue about Hillary Rodham Clinton’s presidential intentions.
lead_paragraph: Interviewers of all kinds have been prodding the Clintons with questions from every angle in hopes of gathering a clue about Hillary Rodham Clinton’s presidential intentions.

headline: European Antitrust Regulators to Hold Discussions With Google’s Rivals
abstract: The new competition commissioner for the European Union says she wants to hear what companies most concerned about Google’s practices have to say before resolving the union’s longstanding antitrust case.
lead_paragraph: European antitrust regulators will hold discussions with the companies most concerned by Google’s business practices before deepening existing investigations or resolving them, the new competition commissioner for the European Union said Tuesday.

headline: Nov. 11, 2014 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from France, China, Poland and the United States.
lead_paragraph: Photos from France, China, Poland and the United States.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Kevin McKenna, Stacy Cowley and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Kevin McKenna, Stacy Cowley and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Landing on a Comet: Inside Rosetta Orbiter’s Philae Landing Mission
abstract: Joel W. Parker, a planetary scientist at the Southwest Research Institute, answers questions about putting a 220-pound lander on a comet.
lead_paragraph: Joel W. Parker, a planetary scientist at the Southwest Research Institute in Boulder, Colo., is the deputy principal investigator for an ultraviolet spectrograph instrument on the European Space Agency’s Rosetta spacecraft, which is orbiting Comet 67P/Churyumov–Gerasimenko. Dr. Parker was not working on the Rosetta project at the very beginning, more than two decades ago, but he has been working on it for a long time, since 1998.

headline: Playing at DOC NYC
abstract: Images of some of the films appearing in the festival.
lead_paragraph: Images of some of the films appearing in the festival.

headline: A Murder Mystery Thaws After 5 Decades in the Freezer
abstract: LMN’s “Footsteps in the Snow” is a movie-length treatment of what has been called the coldest cold case ever solved, the 1957 murder of a 7-year-old girl.
lead_paragraph: Television is full of true-crime stories, many of them trashily told, but the genre is well served by the one offered on Wednesday night on LMN, “Footsteps in the Snow.” It’s a movie-length treatment of what is often described as the coldest cold case ever solved, the 1957 murder of a 7-year-old girl in Sycamore, Ill. A man named Jack McCullough was finally convicted of the crime in 2012.

headline: Images That Dare You to Turn Away
abstract: In the DOC NYC nonfiction film festival, honesty and truthfulness are often in conflict with painful images on which people would rather not dwell.
lead_paragraph: To hell and back describes the psychological journey of the great Brazilian photographer Sebastião Salgado in the magnificent documentary “The Salt of the Earth.” Directed by Wim Wenders and Juliano Ribeiro Salgado, Mr. Salgado’s son, the film is a crowning moment in DOC NYC, the nonfiction film festival starting on Thursday. Some of Mr. Salgado’s black-and-white photos are grisly, Boschian tableaus of the world’s horrors with the formal beauty and grand composition of paintings by the Renaissance masters.

headline: How to Cure the Housewife Blues
abstract: Eva-Maria Westbroek stars as a poignantly restless housewife in the Metropolitan Opera’s production of Shostakovich’s earthy “Lady Macbeth of Mtsensk.”
lead_paragraph: The libretto of Shostakovich’s bitterly satirical 1934 opera, “Lady Macbeth of Mtsensk,” sets the first scene in the bedroom of Katerina, the restless wife of a dull merchant who has taken over the prosperous family business from his oafish father. Katerina’s husband has left for work, and she has gone back to bed. But she is too bored and depressed to sleep.

headline: Soccer Player Convicted of Rape Will Train With Old Club
abstract: Ched Evans of Wales, who spent two years in prison for rape, will resume training at his former club in England, Sheffield United.
lead_paragraph: A Welsh soccer player who spent two years in prison for rape will resume training at his former club in England, Sheffield United, the club said in a statement.

headline: As Sears Gasps, Lampert Turns to Financial Engineering to Revive It
abstract: Edward Lampert is employing a method he is familiar with: breaking up Sears and monetizing it, Steven Davidoff Solomon writes in the Deal Professor column.
lead_paragraph: Sears Holdings is dying a slow, sad death led by its chief executive, Edward S. Lampert, and his hedge fund, ESL Investments, yet Wall Street is going mad over its stock.

headline: Yahoo Buys BrightRoll, a Video Ad Platform, for $640 Million
abstract: The purchase, which had been rumored for weeks, was the Internet company’s largest acquisition since it bolstered its coffers with $6.3 billion from the Alibaba initial public offering.
lead_paragraph: Yahoo’s chief executive, Marissa Mayer, is starting to spend the $6.3 billion that the Internet company netted from selling shares in Alibaba’s initial public offering.

headline: As Currency Settlement Draws Near, Barclays Gets Cold Feet
abstract: The next phase of the case will most likely present a greater test to the banks, as the focus shifts to criminal investigations and individual liability.
lead_paragraph: On the eve of a multibillion-dollar settlement with six giant banks suspected of manipulating the foreign currency market, regulators in Washington and Britain encountered a last-second complication: One of the banks was dropping out of the deal.

headline: Recent Commercial Transactions
abstract: Notable properties that have been recently listed for sale, sold or leased.
lead_paragraph: RECENT SALE

headline: Animation of How New Missiles May Work
abstract: In an artistic rendering from Lockheed Martin, tactical missiles that operate using artificial intelligence are shown selecting and destroying their targets.
lead_paragraph: In an artistic rendering from Lockheed Martin, tactical missiles that operate using artificial intelligence are shown selecting and destroying their targets.

headline: Lawyers for the Homeless
abstract: Jane Gross, a retired Times reporter, writes that “providing lawyers to these victims would be far cheaper and much kinder.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Replacing Workfare
abstract: Arnold S. Cohen, an advocate for the homeless, praises an initiative by Mayor Bill de Blasio.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Sports Boycott of Iran?
abstract: J. Patrice Marandel, a reader, suggests a response to the imprisonment of a woman in Iran who tried to attend a men’s volleyball match.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Ways to Improve New York’s Schools
abstract: Responses to an editorial and a news article about Mayor Bill de Blasio’s education plan.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Taking Pictures, Raising Children
abstract: A generation of female photographers is looking to one another for advice and support as they raise children while still going on assignment overseas.
lead_paragraph: A generation of female photographers is looking to one another for advice and support as they raise children while still going on assignment overseas.

headline: Lame-Duck Session Is First Crucial Test of Breaking Gridlock
abstract: If members of Congress cannot make deals now, they might never be able to, because all sides have real incentives to act.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Fresh from an election that emphatically punctuated voter dissatisfaction with a gridlocked Washington, lawmakers return Wednesday for a lame-duck session that will provide the first crucial test of whether Democrats and Republicans can cooperate or if the next Congress will be another study in dysfunction.

headline: First Aluminum-Body Ford F-Series Pickup Trucks Come Off Assembly Line
abstract: The automaker hopes that the truck will be a hit with consumers and be a step toward reaching new government fuel standards.
lead_paragraph: DEARBORN, Mich. — It was hardly planned this way, but Ford Motor on Tuesday began building its most fuel-efficient pickup ever, just as gas prices kept dropping to their lowest level in years.

headline: U.N. Seeks a More Nimble Response to Ebola in Africa
abstract: The organization has struggled to keep up with the spread and decline of the disease in specific localities.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — A shortage of international health workers and delays in building Ebola treatment clinics in West Africa are forcing the United Nations to change course in fighting the virus, and to call for smaller and more mobile treatment units that make greater use of local staff — and in turn require more money.

headline: Should Hermès, LVMH and Kering Keep Their Fights Private?
abstract: Kering, LVMH and Hermès have been in and out of court in recent years. It’s time for this fashion trend to end.
lead_paragraph: When a French labor court finally ruled last week against the designer John Galliano in his wrongful-dismissal case against the house of Dior and Galliano (which is owned by Dior) — a case that dates back more than three years — the symbolic, almost-comical amount of one euro that he was ordered to pay suggested that a certain message was being sent to both sides: Enough is enough.

headline: Are Democrats Losing the Youth Vote?
abstract: The G.O.P. is gaining young voters, because it lost the culture war.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — ONCE again, the youth vote went firmly Democratic in last week’s election — but the actual numbers, combined with some telling survey results, indicate that the party’s grip on the young may be loosening.

headline: Mexico: Protesters Burn Party Office
abstract: Teachers and students protesting the abduction and apparent murder of 43 college students in September set fire Tuesday to the headquarters of President Enrique Peña Nieto’s party in Guerrero State.
lead_paragraph: Teachers and students protesting the abduction and apparent murder of 43 college students in September set fire Tuesday to the headquarters of President Enrique Peña Nieto’s party in Guerrero State. The protesters, who clashed with the police over several hours, at one point detained the state security chief but later released him. A number of demonstrations have erupted since Friday, when federal officials said they had found burned remains that may be those of the missing students. Witnesses have told the authorities that the students were abducted by the police and turned over to a drug gang that killed them.

headline: Oregon Passes Florida State in College Football Playoff Rankings
abstract: Mississippi State remained at the top, and Texas Christian rounded out the selection committee’s top four. Ohio State jumped to No. 8, and Auburn, which had been ranked third, dropped to No. 9.
lead_paragraph: Under the Bowl Championship Series and its two-team championship, a late-season game like Saturday night’s between Michigan State and Ohio State — ranked No. 8 and No. 14 at the time in the Associated Press poll — would have had few playoff implications.

headline: Wobbling on Climate Change
abstract: The science of global warming is too important to trivialize.
lead_paragraph: GREENBELT, Md. — I’M a climate scientist and a former astronaut. Not surprisingly, I have a deep respect for well-tested theories and facts. In the climate debate, these things have a way of getting blurred in political discussions.

headline: Guyana: Legislature Is Suspended
