abstract: President Donald Ramotar of Guyana used a constitutional mechanism that gives him the right to disband the legislature for up to six months.
lead_paragraph: The president of Guyana has suspended the National Assembly in an escalating conflict with the political opposition. President Donald Ramotar used a constitutional mechanism that gives him the right to disband the legislature for up to six months. He said he had taken the step on Monday to keep the legislature from holding a no-confidence vote. In a speech to the nation, Mr. Ramotar criticized opposition politicians for “an atmosphere of confrontation” and pledged to seek an agreement with them that would allow the legislature to return to work. David Granger, a retired general who leads the opposition, called the president’s action a “denial of democracy,” according to The Associated Press, which said legislators had staged a protest outside the Parliament building.

headline: Volkswagen to Sponsor a CNN Series
abstract: The sponsorship opportunity includes automotive category exclusivity during each CNN Films presentation.
lead_paragraph: DECADES after television offered sponsored newscasts like the “Camel News Caravan,” CNN has signed Volkswagen of America as a presenting sponsor of CNN Films, the series of documentary movies that CNN added to its schedule last year to help stimulate viewership and ratings.

headline: Don’t Ask How to Feed the 9 Billion
abstract: The solution isn’t to produce more food, it’s to eliminate poverty.
lead_paragraph: At dinner with a friend the other night, I mentioned that I was giving a talk this week debunking the idea that we need to grow more food on a large scale so we can “feed the nine billion” — the anticipated global population by 2050.

headline: Mali: New Ebola Case Is Confirmed as Response to First Was Wrapping Up
abstract: Mali, which was just coming to the end of 21-day quarantines for 108 people linked to its first Ebola case, now has a second, the government announced Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Mali, which was just coming to the end of 21-day quarantines for 108 people linked to its first Ebola case, now has a second, the government announced Tuesday. The new case, in the capital, Bamako, was not linked to the first case, a 2-year-old girl from Guinea who died in the northwestern town of Kayes on Oct. 24, a spokeswoman for the World Health Organization said. The W.H.O. and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention have known for at least 24 hours that a new cluster of possible Ebola cases existed in Mali, but did not announce it because they were waiting for laboratory confirmation of at least one case. Information Minister Mahamadou Camara said Tuesday evening on Twitter that a case had been confirmed and that a clinic in Bamako had been quarantined.

headline: Landing on a Comet, 317 Million Miles From Home
abstract: The Rosetta spacecraft’s Philae lander is attempting to land on Comet 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko.
lead_paragraph: The Rosetta spacecraft’s Philae lander is attempting to land on Comet 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko.

headline: Injured Player Withdraws to Save a Year at Columbia
abstract: Because Ivy League eligibility is intended to expire after four years, the senior Alex Rosenberg withdrew from classes so he could return to the basketball court for Columbia a year from now.
lead_paragraph: After fracturing his foot during a routine drill in practice several weeks ago, Alex Rosenberg, a forward on Columbia’s men’s basketball team, learned that he might not return to play for as long as four months. That was a tough blow for the Lions, who were counting on him to lead them in scoring for a second season in a row.

headline: 2 Navy Veterans Set Sail for a Day at the Casino
abstract: On Veterans Day, Dominick Morea and Al Dembro, friends and Manhattan neighbors who served in World War II, made one of their occasional visits to Yonkers slot machines.
lead_paragraph: It’s not exactly “On the Town” when these two sailors get together for some gambling.

headline: Freud and the Middle East
abstract: Dreams, nightmares and the war against ISIS.
lead_paragraph: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates — When trying to make sense of the Middle East, one of the most important rules to keep in mind is this: What politicians here tell you in private is usually irrelevant. What matters most, and what explains their behavior more times than not, is what they say in public in their own language to their own people. As President Obama dispatches more U.S. advisers to help Iraqis defeat the Islamic State, or ISIS, it is vital that we listen carefully to what the key players are saying in public in their own language about each other and their own aspirations.

headline: Politics Mingles With Art at a Palestinian Cultural Festival
abstract: The festival, Qalandiya International, faced special challenges in catering to a fragmented Palestinian society struggling against Israel and recovering from the 50-day Gaza war.
lead_paragraph: RAMALLAH, West Bank — Jugglers and stilt walkers led the procession one recent evening from Manara Square to City Hall here in street theater meant to recall the first Palestinian intifada.

headline: Karim Rashid
abstract: Mr. Rashid is a designer whose real estate projects include work for HAP Investments in East Harlem and Chelsea.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Rashid, 54, is a designer whose real estate projects include work for HAP Investments in East Harlem and Chelsea.

headline: Manhattan’s Second-Tier Office Buildings Make Energy Efficiency a Goal
abstract: In recent years, several of Manhattan’s Class B buildings, typically known for being old and out of the way, have acted to improve their carbon footprints.
lead_paragraph: Class B office buildings are known for being old, no-frills and off the beaten path. What they are usually not associated with is energy efficiency.

headline: Law and Order in Mexico
abstract: Outrage over the presumed grisly slaying of 43 college students is the latest example of a breakdown of law and order in the country.
lead_paragraph: The disappearance, and presumed murder, of 43 college students six weeks ago has brought parts of Mexico to a tense point. On Monday, thousands of protesters blocked access to the airport in Acapulco, and last week tens of thousands more filled the streets of Mexico City.

headline: The Worst Voter Turnout in 72 Years
abstract: Apathy, anger and frustration at the negative tone of the campaigns resulted in the lowest percentage of voter participation since 1942.
lead_paragraph: The abysmally low turnout in last week’s midterm elections — the lowest in more than seven decades — was bad for Democrats, but it was even worse for democracy. In 43 states, less than half the eligible population bothered to vote, and no state broke 60 percent.

headline: A Leaderless Palestinian Revolt Proves More Difficult to Curb
abstract: With no peace process to speak of and a political leadership that lacks the public’s confidence, Palestinians described the emergence of a smoldering, improvised intifada.
lead_paragraph: ASKAR REFUGEE CAMP, West Bank — Sawsan Abu Hashieh said she packed a bag of clothing on Sunday for her 18-year-old son, Nur al-Din, who told her he planned to sneak into Israel to work for two weeks. Instead, he was arrested in Monday’s fatal stabbing of a soldier near a crowded Tel Aviv train station.

headline: SheRides, a New York Taxi Service Aimed at Women, Finds a Loyal Following
abstract: A new app for a livery car company in New York is offering rides for women by women, but critics say the business reeks of gender discrimination.
lead_paragraph: Minutes after calling a livery car on a phone app, Lorena Cantillo easily picked out her ride in the crowd of black sedans on West 42nd Street. It was the only car with a pink sign in the window, and pink stickers all over the rear bumper.

headline: Obama’s Call for Net Neutrality Sets Up Fight Over Rules
abstract: Virtually everyone agrees that some rules written to regulate telephone service should not apply to the Internet but there are disagreements about what rules should survive.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Obama argued on Monday for rules to protect an open Internet, he said the regulations should be strong.

headline: Rehab for Corporations
abstract: Should the government reconsider its use of deferred prosecution agreements?

headline: Attack’s Aftermath Imperils Man’s Efforts to Care for His Family
abstract: Arafan Koita, an immigrant from Guinea, had to give up his cabdriving job after a beating by a passenger left him legally blind.
lead_paragraph: K. Arafan Koita, 48, remembers distinctly the day he arrived at Kennedy International Airport, having fled ethnic discrimination in his homeland of Guinea in West Africa. It was April 28, 1992, a Tuesday, and he headed straight to the Bronx to stay in a building inhabited by many other Guinean immigrants.

headline: Colorado Ousts Pro-Gun Republicans, Showing Effect of Turnout
abstract: The two pro-gun Republicans elected during recall elections last year were handily beaten this month by Democrats, which analysts called a lesson in the impact of turnout.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — After two Colorado lawmakers who supported strict new gun-control laws were voted out of office in a special recall election last year, the National Rifle Association and its allies celebrated their huge win in the battle over gun laws in state capitols. But that particular victory did not last.

headline: The Problem With New York’s Marijuana Policy
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio may have tried to address the disproportionate impact of marijuana arrests on blacks and Hispanics, but his plan is still flawed.
lead_paragraph: While running for office, Bill de Blasio promised that as mayor he would amend the practice of singling out young black and Latino men for unfair and, in some cases, illegal arrests for possessing minuscule amounts of marijuana. Though the charges are often dismissed, the arrests can cost people their jobs and access to housing or the prospect of joining the armed forces.

headline: Alex Rodriguez May Be Out at Third as Yankees Pursue Other Options
abstract: The team has continued talks to bring back the free agent Chase Headley and has been exploring the trade market for an infielder who could take over the position Rodriguez has held for a decade.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — The Yankees are engaged in talks with Chase Headley to return as their third baseman, and General Manager Brian Cashman is also exploring the trade market for the same position. If one of those options pans out, Alex Rodriguez will lose his job as the Yankees’ starter at third, which he held from 2004 through 2013.

headline: Bush (43) Shares Spotlight With Bush (41) as Tribute Book Is Published
abstract: Former President George W. Bush’s book “41: A Portrait of My Father” could inspire historical reassessments of two former presidents.
lead_paragraph: COLLEGE STATION, Tex. — While hosting guests at his Texas ranch shortly after leaving office, former President George W. Bush got into a discussion with the daughter of the historian David McCullough.

headline: St. Francis’ Papers, in Brooklyn, a Borough He’d Appreciate
abstract: Brooklyn Borough Hall is the only place in the United States where the public will be able to see the oldest documents that tell the story of St. Francis of Assisi.
lead_paragraph: Ever since monks and conservationists were known to be nearly finished restoring medieval manuscripts from the Sacred Convent of St. Francis in Assisi, some of the mightiest museums in the world have clamored to display them. After all, they are the oldest documents that tell the story of St. Francis. Born Francesco di Bernardone, a soldier and son of a merchant, he renounced wealth and war, then founded orders of friars and sisters organized on principles of simplicity. His embrace of the poor inspired the current pope to take the name Francis.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 11, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Walmart Memo Orders Stores to Improve Grocery Performance
abstract: The company issued an “urgent agenda” memo to managers, pushing them to improve performance on fresh items, reflecting customer complaints about food quality.
lead_paragraph: VALLEY STREAM, N.Y. — The dairy section in the Walmart supercenter here, just across the border from Queens, was sparsely stocked. Some gallon jugs of milk were dented, others soiled with what looked like dirt. The meat aisle had run out of ground beef patties and strip steak, and residue streaked some shelves.

headline: Small Labels and YouTube Enter Deal on Licensing
abstract: YouTube has been developing features that would preserve its free model, but also give paying subscribers more extensive access to music.
lead_paragraph: Ending a monthslong dispute, YouTube has signed a licensing deal with independent record companies, a move that clears the way for YouTube to introduce a long-planned subscription feature to compete with online music outlets like Spotify and Rhapsody.

headline: Pitching Website Aims to Protect Young Elbows
abstract: Alarmed by the surge in Tommy John surgery, Major League Baseball and USA Baseball have set up a website that offers guidelines on pitching usage and injury prevention.
lead_paragraph: The last baseball season started with a flurry of injured elbows and ended with Madison Bumgarner firing 68 pitches on two days’ rest to clinch the World Series for the San Francisco Giants. For people who specialize in repairing damaged arms — and preventing future problems — it was a mixed message.

headline: George W. Bush on His Father and 9/11
abstract: Former President George W. Bush talked to his former chief of staff, Andrew H. Card Jr., about his book on his father, former President George H.W. Bush, and mentioned talking to his parents on 9/11.
lead_paragraph: Former President George W. Bush talked to his former chief of staff, Andrew H. Card Jr., about his book on his father, former President George H.W. Bush, and mentioned talking to his parents on 9/11.

headline: Big Bank Hank, an Early Star of Rap, Dies at 58
abstract: Big Bank Hank was one of the three members of the Sugarhill Gang, whose “Rapper’s Delight” put rap on the commercial map.
lead_paragraph: Big Bank Hank, one-third of the Sugarhill Gang, the unlikely ambassadors who took hip-hop out of Bronx parks and onto the pop charts, died on Tuesday in Englewood, N.J. He was 58.

headline: Hitting at Heart of Hollywood, the Palm Takes Down Its Stars
abstract: The restaurant, known for featuring celebrity caricatures, is opening at a new location in Beverly Hills, and leaving its famous portraits behind.
lead_paragraph: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — Power in Hollywood is still signaled by who sits where at a handful of watering holes, but restaurant real estate as status symbol is fleeting: Lose that studio chairmanship on Monday, say hello to Siberia on Tuesday.

headline: For Veterans Day, Stars Give a Return Salute
abstract: The “Concert for Valor” on the National Mall in Washington drew thousands of veterans and active-duty service members.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For days, people here had been bracing for Tuesday’s first-ever “Concert for Valor,” a tribute to veterans. Inauguration-style barriers took over the National Mall, a subway line and several streets shut down, and people whispered a number that made many of them shudder: 800,000.

headline: A Cabin in the Woods, but Hardly a Getaway
abstract: A man and a woman, both facing crises, keep slightly uncomfortable company in David Auburn’s small-scale and sleepy new play, “Lost Lake.”
lead_paragraph: A man and a woman, both facing crises, keep slightly uncomfortable company in David Auburn’s small-scale and sleepy new play, “Lost Lake,” which opened on Tuesday night at City Center in a Manhattan Theater Club production.

headline: Repeat Offender
abstract: Daniel Landman rampages through his own puzzle.
lead_paragraph: Administrivial Deb-Amlen-In-N.Y.C. Fun Times Alert! Pencils up, New York! If you plan to be in New York City on Sunday, Nov. 16, come hang out with me at the Ace Hotel, located at 20 West 29th Street, as I show people that they can solve the Sunday crossword puzzle with a minimum of tears and bloodshed. The fun starts at 11:00 a.m. E.T. and it’s open to the public. Hope to see you there, and if you are a Wordplayer, please be sure to come up and say hi. Click here for more information.

headline: Taunting Nets? Family Makes That Its Domain
abstract: Along with her son, the owner of a New Mexico company that holds the Nets.com domain name is behind pranks on the site that are intended to push the Nets to buy the domain.
lead_paragraph: SANTA FE, N.M. — Mark Cuban, the owner of the Dallas Mavericks, and his counterpart with the Knicks, James L. Dolan, were early suspects, as were any other N.B.A. executives who had ever squabbled with Mikhail D. Prokhorov, the Russian billionaire owner of the Nets. Or perhaps the culprit was an old rival of Prokhorov’s from back home in Russia, where oligarchs have been known to make enemies.

headline: Excerpts From Walmart Memo
abstract: These pages from a Walmart memo urge managers to improve performance on “Chilled and Fresh” items in their dairy, meat and produce departments as part of an effort to stem long-sluggish sales.
lead_paragraph: These pages from a Walmart memo urge managers to improve performance on “Chilled and Fresh” items in their dairy, meat and produce departments as part of an effort to stem long-sluggish sales.

headline: The Demise of the White Democratic Voter
abstract: In the midterm elections, three out of five whites voted for a Republican House candidate. Why does this keep happening?
lead_paragraph: It has not escaped the notice of political analysts that 72 percent of whites without college degrees — a rough proxy for what we used to call the white working class — believe that “the U.S. economic system generally favors the wealthy.” Or that on Nov. 4, these same men and women voted for Republican House candidates 64-34.

headline: Spurs, Picture of Continuity, Are Set for Another Run
abstract: With the same players, save for a rookie, the Spurs are trying to recapture the form they displayed in June when they eviscerated the Heat to win their fifth N.B.A. championship.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The San Antonio Spurs, the ever-evolving Darwinian darlings of the N.B.A., were not about to stand pat after winning their first championship in seven years. So they made changes — big ones.

headline: Pondering the Change Pope Francis Envisions
abstract: The United States Conference of Catholic Bishops is gathered in Baltimore only weeks after a contentious Vatican meeting on marriage and family ended in Rome.
lead_paragraph: The United States Conference of Catholic Bishops is gathered in Baltimore only weeks after a contentious Vatican meeting on marriage and family ended in Rome.

headline: China, America and Our Warming Planet
abstract: The U.S. will reduce emissions by 26 to 28 percent by 2025. China will try to reach peak emissions before 2030.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The United States and China are the world’s two largest economies, two largest consumers of energy, and two largest emitters of greenhouse gases. Together we account for about 40 percent of the world’s emissions.

headline: In Joint Steps on Emissions, China and U.S. Set Aside ‘You First’ Approach on Global Warming
abstract: China and the United States pledge simultaneous steps to curb emissions of greenhouse gases.
lead_paragraph: After years of “you first” rhetoric on addressing the unrelenting buildup of climate-warming greenhouse gases in the atmosphere, China and the United States, the world’s biggest emitters, agreed in Beijing on Wednesday to intensify domestic steps and international partnerships to rein in their contributions to global warming. Click here for the news coverage in The Times.

headline: Looking Like Champions, Rangers Rout a Top Team
abstract: The Rangers scored three goals in the first period at the Garden and ended Pittsburgh’s seven-game winning streak.
lead_paragraph: The Rangers knew what they were getting themselves into Tuesday when the high-flying Pittsburgh Penguins came to town.

headline: Pakistan: U.S. Drone Strike Is Reported
abstract: A Pakistani security official has reported a new American airstrike, saying a drone killed six foreign militants on Tuesday in the North Waziristan tribal region.
lead_paragraph: A Pakistani security official has reported a new American airstrike, saying a drone killed six foreign militants on Tuesday in the North Waziristan tribal region. It was not immediately possible to confirm the report independently. The strike was reported to be the 10th such attack since Pakistan began an operation in North Waziristan in June to crack down on militants. The official, who asked not to be identified because he was not authorized to speak to the news media, said the target was Dawa Toi, a valley near the Afghan border, and said, “The valley is infested with local and foreign militants.” Pakistan condemned the drone strike and demanded that they end.

headline: Flip Your Skateboard Into Furniture
abstract: Through a project sponsored by Converse, one writer learns how to recycle old decks into a new stool.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Saturday, a group of teenagers and young 20-something skaters gathered in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, to repurpose old, worn-out boards into functional, modern furniture. Mostly clad in hoodies, with power tools in hand, the crafters worked with a quiet focus on building stools and low benches as sawdust whirled through the air. Some popped ollies and flips in between taking turns with the belt sander, while others chatted up the pro skater Quim Cardona. While the event felt like a mellow hangout, it was actually organized by Converse as part of its ongoing series, the Cons Project Creative Recycling, aimed at skating enthusiasts between the ages of 13 to 24.

headline: The Fast, for the Curious
abstract: For those inspired by Cathy Horyn’s purge in “Famine or Feast,” a global guide to deprivation-oriented detox spas.
lead_paragraph: In “Famine or Feast” in T’s upcoming Luxury Issue, the writer Cathy Horyn, before undertaking a Black Forest binge, completes a harrowing experiment in deprivation at Buchinger Wilhelmi, a therapeutic fasting clinic in southern Germany. On the menu: 250 calories a day, liver compresses and enemas, and the promise of feeling she “could change the world” at the conclusion of her 10-day stay. Here, for those inspired to follow suit (but not to try this at home), a list of like-minded detox facilities on two continents.

headline: Anya Hindmarch’s World of Inspiration
abstract: The beloved British accessories designer turns to playful inspirations to breathe a little life and laughter into luxury.
lead_paragraph: The beloved British accessories designer turns to playful influences to breathe a little life and laughter into luxury.

headline: At Home and Away With the Decorator Robert Kime
abstract: For England's most revered interior designer, a humble farmhouse is an ideal respite from his urbane London apartment.
lead_paragraph: For England’s most revered interior designer, a humble farmhouse is an ideal respite from his urbane London apartment.

headline: Exercising but Gaining Weight
abstract: A substantial number of people who take up an exercise regimen wind up heavier afterward than they were at the start, but a simple strategy may improve people’s odds of actually dropping pounds with exercise.
lead_paragraph: Exercise has innumerable health benefits, but losing weight may not be among them. A provocative new study shows that a substantial number of people who take up an exercise regimen wind up heavier afterward than they were at the start, with the weight gain due mostly to extra fat, not muscle.

headline: Word of the Day | waffle
abstract: This word has appeared in 149 New York Times articles in the last year.
lead_paragraph: waffle •\ˈwä-fəl, ˈwȯ-\• noun and verb

headline: What’s On TV Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (13, 49) EMPEROR’S GHOST ARMY Believing it would defend and serve him in the afterlife, Qin Shi Huang, the first emperor of a united China, was buried 2,200 years ago in an enormous underground mausoleum surrounded by a life-size terra-cotta army (above) 9,000 strong: warriors carrying bronze crossbows, spears and swords; cavalry, horses and chariots; administrators; and even acrobats, strongmen and musicians. “Nova” investigates how and why the figures were made, and the technology behind their lethal weapons.

headline: Rothko and Johns Paintings Are Stars of a Sluggish Auction for Sotheby’s
abstract: Despite some high prices paid for works by Mark Rothko and Jasper Johns, the week of big-money contemporary art auctions got off to a sluggish start on Tuesday evening at Sotheby’s.
lead_paragraph: The week of big-money contemporary art auctions got off to a sluggish start on Tuesday evening at Sotheby’s, where collectors could not be bullied by high estimates and tastes veered toward abstract rather than figurative paintings.

headline: Scenes From the ‘Concert for Valor’
abstract: Performers at the concert included Bruce Springsteen, Dave Grohl and Carrie Underwood, who sang with the official chorus of the United States Air Force.
lead_paragraph: Performers at the concert included Bruce Springsteen, Dave Grohl and Carrie Underwood, who sang with the official chorus of the United States Air Force.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, November 12, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “He says wonderful things, but he doesn’t put them together all the time, so you’re left at times puzzling over what his intention is.”

headline: Corrections: November 12, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Wednesday, November 12, 2014.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Big Banks Are Fined $4.25 Billion in Inquiry Into Currency-Rigging
abstract: The fines come as regulators are increasingly targeting a business culture in the financial industry that they say encourages improper conduct by its employees.
lead_paragraph: The traders called themselves “the players” and “the three musketeers” as they joined forces and shared information to “double team” their clients and manipulate currency rates.

headline: U.S. to Revise Bush Policy on Treatment of Prisoners
abstract: The Obama administration will tell the United Nations that it will observe a treaty to restrict cruel treatment of detainees in some places abroad.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A treaty ban on cruel treatment will restrict how the United States may treat prisoners in certain places abroad, the Obama administration is expected to tell the United Nations on Wednesday, according to officials.

headline: Politicians and Climate Experts React to U.S.-China Emissions Pact
abstract: Reactions from the former United States vice president, politicians and climate experts on pledges by China and America to cut carbon emissions.
lead_paragraph: President Obama and President Xi Jinping of China pledged on Wednesday to control their countries’ carbon emissions, in what American officials described as a breakthrough in the effort to combat climate change.

headline: Afghan Opium Cultivation Rises to Record Levels
abstract: United Nations officials attributed at least part of the increase to politicians’ need for campaign cash during the protracted election season.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Afghan opium cultivation again rose to historic levels in 2014, United Nations officials reported on Wednesday. And in a sign of how deeply entwined drug trafficking and the Afghan political system have become, the officials said the protracted elections this year were at least part of the cause.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Weapons Directed by Robots, Not Humans, Raise Ethical Questions
abstract: Why do some fear that an ethical boundary is being crossed with weapons like these?
lead_paragraph: In “Weapons Directed by Robots, Not Humans, Raise Ethical Questions,” John Markoff writes about missiles that rely on software to decide what to target and whom to kill.

headline: Test Yourself | Review of Call of Duty: Advanced Warfare
abstract: Here are the first six paragraphs of the Nov. 11 video game review, “In This Future War, Soldiers Are Part Superhero.” Can you choose the best word or phrase for each blank?
lead_paragraph: Below are the first six paragraphs of the Nov. 11 video game review, “In This Future War, Soldiers Are Part Superhero.”

headline: Welcome to the Failure Age!
abstract: In this economy, losers will be the biggest winners.
lead_paragraph: When you pull off Highway 101 and head into Sunnyvale, Calif., the first thing you notice is how boring innovation looks up close. This small Silicon Valley city, which abuts both Cupertino, the home of Apple, and Mountain View, the site of the Googleplex, is where Lockheed built the Poseidon nuclear missile. It’s where the forebear of NASA did some of its most important research and where a prototype for Pong debuted at a neighborhood bar. Countless ambitious start-ups — with names like Qvivr, Schoolfy, eCloset.me and PeerPal — appear in Sunnyvale every year. Aesthetically, though, the city is one enormous glass-and-stucco office park after another. Its dominant architectural feature, the five-story headquarters of Yahoo, a few minutes from Innovation Way, looks about as futuristic as a suburban hospital.

headline: Taking Pictures, Raising Children
abstract: A generation of female photographers is looking to one another for advice and support as they raise children while still going on assignment overseas.
lead_paragraph: Since World War II the image of the international photojournalist has been of a swashbuckling raconteur and ladies man. Whatever family life he had back home rarely got in the way of work or pleasure.

headline: What Have Been Your Experiences With Catcalling or Other Kinds of Street Harassment?
abstract: Had you seen the viral video “10 Hours of Walking in NYC as a Woman” we post here? What is your reaction to it? Do you think your reaction depends on whether you are female or male? Why or why not?
lead_paragraph: Hollaback!, an anti-street harassment organization, recently released this video, taken with a hidden camera.

headline: In Control, Republican Lawmakers See Budget as Way to Push Agenda
abstract: Congressional Republicans have plans to transform Medicare and Medicaid and to cut taxes for high earners, measures once out of reach with Democrats controlling the Senate.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Next year, House Republicans will try again to transform Medicare and Medicaid, repeal the Affordable Care Act, shrink domestic spending and substantially cut the highest tax rates through the budget process. Then they will leave it to the new Senate Republican majority to decide how far to press the party’s small-government vision, senior House aides said this week.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Bits of Dance and Chess Found in a Vanished Style of Play
abstract: The documentary “Red Army” shows a style of hockey played by the Soviets in the 1970s and ’80s that remains unsurpassed for its grace, speed and intricacy.
lead_paragraph: Gabe Polsky did not set out to make a movie for hockey fans. The real subject of his documentary “Red Army,” he said, is the rise and fall of the Soviet Union.

headline: With Amazon’s Echo, You Are Never Alone
abstract: Amazon introduces another device to make shopping easier — and Amazon inescapable.
lead_paragraph: Amazon is the most ceaselessly inventive company of the era. This, employees say, is one of the great virtues of working there; you can introduce a product without a million meetings or its being focus-grouped to death. Nor does Amazon seem hugely protective of the Amazon brand, which also speeds up innovation. It is not afraid of being disliked.

headline: Fruitful Visit by Obama Ends With a Lecture From Xi
abstract: The Chinese and American presidents’ news conference laid bare stubborn differences over issues like press freedom.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The White House pushed very hard for President Xi Jinping to take questions during his news conference with President Obama at the end of their two days of meetings Wednesday. It did not want a repeat of the stilted, scripted encounter Mr. Obama had with Mr. Xi’s predecessor, Hu Jintao, in 2009 on his first trip to China as president.

headline: New York Today: Drop the Phone, Cyclist
abstract: Wednesday: Texting bikers beware, a mixed bag of weather, and why it’s hard to catch a cab in the rain.
lead_paragraph: Good Wednesday morning. It’s foggy out there.

headline: China’s Stealth Fighter Takes to the Skies Above Air Show
abstract: Airshow China 2014 also featured commercial and other military jets from the United States, Russia, Europe, China and elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: The second public flight of the J-31 fighter jet began on Wednesday with a steep ascent, then a slow circle in the cloudy sky over the airfield in the southern city of Zhuhai, where thousands had come to watch China’s new stealth aircraft in action.

headline: Daily Report: Internet Giants Largely Stay Out of Net Neutrality Push
abstract: Companies like Facebook and Google have stayed away from mobilizing their users to support an issue that primarily affects smaller Internet upstarts.
lead_paragraph: Silicon Valley’s giant companies have been quiet lately on the question of whether the government should protect an open Internet, which they have previously argued is vital to innovation. Do not count on them staking out a stronger position even though President Obama has stepped into the fray, and Washington looks to be gearing up for an epic battle over the rules that govern the Internet, Farhad Manjoo reports.

headline: Today in Politics
abstract: Members of Congress return for a session that, for many of them, will be a long goodbye.
lead_paragraph: The Farewell Parties Are Just Beginning

headline: No More Stalling. Am I Going to Lay Off Workers or Not?
abstract: We’re still losing money, but we ran the numbers on the total costs of doing a layoff — and here’s what we found.
lead_paragraph: I am not going to do it. Why not? Five reasons.

headline: The Descent of Philae Toward the Comet in Tweets
abstract: The European Space Agency’s 220-pound lander, named Philae, is marking its fall toward the comet, known as 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko, in Tweets.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, at 4:05 a.m. Eastern time, the 220-pound lander, named Philae, detached from the Rosetta spacecraft and was pulled downward by the gravity of the comet, known as 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko. Signals from Rosetta will take nearly 30 minutes to travel more than 300 million miles to mission control in Darmstadt, Germany.

headline: Israeli Police Officer Held in Deaths of 2 Teenagers
abstract: Further charging tensions, a mosque in the West Bank was damaged in a suspected arson attack and a firebomb was thrown at a synagogue in northern Israel.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — An Israeli border police officer has been arrested on suspicion of involvement in the fatal shooting of two Palestinian teenagers in the West Bank during a protest in May, officials said on Wednesday.

headline: Mark Zuckerberg Adopts Obama’s Approach to Dressing
abstract: Wearing the same T-shirts or suits every day may leave time for the really big decisions.
lead_paragraph: But wait, you say upon reading this headline. Doesn’t Mark Zuckerberg, the Facebook chief executive, wear a gray T-shirt every day, while President Obama wears a dark gray or blue suit?

headline: Morning Agenda: Big Banks Fined in Currency Case
abstract: Five big banks are fined $3.3 billion in a currency manipulation scandal. | Sears chief turns to financial engineering. | Detroit still faces pension risk.
lead_paragraph: British, American and Swiss regulators fined five of the world’s biggest banks ‒ UBS, HSBC, the Royal Bank of Scotland, JPMorgan Chase and Citigroup ‒ a combined $3.3 billion on Wednesday for conspiring to manipulate the foreign currency market, the latest scandal to hit an industry facing increased scrutiny and mounting legal costs for its past sins, Chad Bray and Jenny Anderson report in DealBook. The fines come as regulators are increasingly targeting a business culture in the financial industry that they say encourages improper conduct by its employees. The banks could still face criminal charges in the matter.

headline: Now, the Final Chapter. O.K., Half of It.
abstract: The “Hunger Games” franchise, as did the Harry Potter and “Twilight” series, hopes to demonstrate the art in splitting a final chapter into two installments.
lead_paragraph: A friend is telling you a great story when, halfway in, she suddenly stops. To hear the rest, she tells you, you’ll have to wait. Not a day, à la Scheherazade, or a week, as with a CBS drama. A year.

headline: On Set | Peter Philips on Makeup
abstract: The creative and image director of Christian Dior makeup talks about designing looks for fashion shows.
lead_paragraph: The creative and image director of Christian Dior makeup talks about designing looks for fashion shows.

headline: Americans Don’t Expect Much From Obama, Poll Says
abstract: The latest Pew poll shows how the public has lost confidence in President Obama, although the congressional leadership in Congress doesn’t fare much better.
lead_paragraph: Americans are skeptical that President Obama will be able to get anything done in the next two years, according to a Pew poll released this morning.

headline: An Online Store Whose T-Shirts Tacitly Support Ai Weiwei Is Shut Down
abstract: Taobao, the Alibaba-owned Chinese website similar to Ebay, has told an artist that his virtual T-shirt shop has been shuttered. The reason? Possibly the T-shirt’s oblique support for the artist Ai Weiwei.
lead_paragraph: There were plenty of happy shoppers and merchants on Tuesday as Chinese consumers spent $9.3 billion via the online shopping brontosaurus Alibaba, breaking last year’s record for Singles’ Day, an e-commerce holiday dedicated to naked consumerism.

headline: Ireland Sets Water Fees, Angering Thousands
abstract: Protesters say free water is a human right, but economists say use charges promote efficiency.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Across the richly green Irish countryside, trouble is stirring, strangely enough, over water.

headline: Bain Capital and Apax Make $8.8 Billion Offer to Oi for Portuguese Assets
abstract: The offer from Apax Partners and Bain Capital to the Brazilian telecommunications operator Oi could lead to a bidding war with Altice of France.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil – The private equity funds Apax Partners and Bain Capital have made an $8.8 billion offer for the Portuguese assets of the Brazilian telecommunications operator Oi, a move that could lead to a bidding war with Altice of France.

headline: Daily Clip Report
abstract: Daily Clip Report is a collection of articles about the media and The Times that is emailed each day to senior executives and newsroom managers here.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

headline: Susquehanna Bancshares in Deal to Be Sold to BB&T
abstract: The deal will give the BB&T Corporation a bigger foothold in Pennsylvania, Maryland, New Jersey and West Virginia.
lead_paragraph: The BB&T Corporation, a big lender based in North Carolina, is doing something most of its peers have shied away from since the financial crisis: buying another bank.

headline: In Search of Brooklyn
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: Moving from Queens to Brooklyn, the author likened it to his grandfather’s moving from Russia to the Lower East side a century ago.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Obama and Xi Announce Climate Deal
abstract: President Obama spoke after the United States and China, the world’s top carbon polluters, agreed to reduce emissions following nine months of negotiations and two productive days of meetings.
lead_paragraph: President Obama spoke after the United States and China, the world’s top carbon polluters, agreed to reduce emissions following nine months of negotiations and two productive days of meetings.

headline: Macy’s Sales Fall in Third Quarter as Retailers Struggle to Attract Wary Shoppers
abstract: Despite managing to increase its quarterly profit, Macy’s lowered its outlook for the year.
lead_paragraph: Macy’s reported lackluster sales for its third quarter, a sign that the department store giant had not overcome some of the broader challenges facing the retail industry.

headline: Dow Chemical to Raise Dividend and Increase Stock Buybacks
abstract: Both steps fall short of the big breakup of Dow Chemical being advocated by the activist hedge fund manager Daniel S. Loeb.
lead_paragraph: Dow Chemical may still be resisting a call by the activist hedge fund manager Daniel S. Loeb to break itself up, but it is taking more steps to return money to its shareholders.

headline: 1939: Jamming of BBC Radio Addressed
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Britain planned hitting back against radio jamming in 1939.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — If jamming of British Broadcasting Corporation broadcasts in foreign languages continues, the English radio will retaliate with similar measures, the corporation said here today [Nov. 12]. Secret listening posts throughout England have been collecting evidence indicating that reception of B. B. C. broadcasts in Hungarian, Czech, Polish and German have been made unintelligible by conflicting radio waves, the B. B. C. said. Only short-wave programs have been interfered with so far and the jamming is intermittent, it was reported. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Nov. 13, 1939

headline: War Reporting as Art in the Flatiron District
abstract: The artist Cindy Kane collected reporting notes, credentials and other mementos from Times reporters and editors for an exhibit that provides an intimate glimpse into life as a war reporter.
lead_paragraph: “Soldiers are our boots on the ground, but journalists are our eyes on the ground,” said Cheryl McGinnis, curator of the artist Cindy Kane’s current exhibition in Manhattan’s Flatiron district.

headline: China’s Climate Change Plan Raises Questions
abstract: Analysts and policy advisers wonder if the climate accord reached by the U.S. and China goes far enough, and how Beijing will meet its targets.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — When the presidents of China and the United States pledged on Wednesday to reduce or limit carbon dioxide emissions, analysts and policy advisers said, the two leaders sent an important signal: that the world’s largest economies were willing to work together on climate change.

headline: The Things Traders Say, Foreign Exchange Edition
abstract: Foreign exchange traders employed colorful code names like the 3 Musketeers as they plotted ways to “mangle” the currency markets.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – It has become a common occurrence whenever a major bank settles with regulators over misconduct: the lewd and, sometimes, cringeworthy language traders use to communicate daily emerges in chats or emails.

headline: A Sweet Breakfast Memory That Connects With the Wrong Market
abstract: Christopher Pouy founded Cow Wow Cereal Milk to bring a taste of his past to today’s children. But the milk is proving more popular with an older set.
lead_paragraph: COW WOW CEREAL MILK is a two-year-old  company that makes milk in breakfast cereal flavors. Founded by Christopher Pouy, a former advertising copywriter seeking to capitalize on a childhood love, it is based in Los Angeles and employs 10. By putting a child-friendly cow on the package and giving his flavors names like Fruity Trudy and Chocolate Chip Cathy, Mr. Pouy branded his product for 5- to 12-year-olds.

headline: Americans Say They Want Privacy, but Act as if They Don’t
abstract: People are doubtful about the safety of their personal information online or on cellphones. Yet it does not necessarily change their behavior, according to a new poll.
lead_paragraph: Americans say they are deeply concerned about privacy on the web and their cellphones. They say they do not trust Internet companies or the government to protect it. Yet they keep using the services and handing over their personal information.

headline: 53 Seats and Counting: Republican Wins Alaska Senate Race
abstract: The Associated Press reported that the vote count, which has taken more than a week, showed the race to be out of reach for Senator Mark Begich.
lead_paragraph: Republicans appear to have pulled out another Senate victory, giving them at least 53 seats in the chamber, after The Associated Press called the Alaska race early Wednesday for the Republican challenger, Dan Sullivan, over the Democratic incumbent, Senator Mark Begich.

headline: First Draft Focus: A Red Carpet Welcome
Questlove to Curate Taste Talks Food Festival
abstract: The drummer, producer and culinary entrepreneur, will participate in formulating the programs for the food festival next year.
lead_paragraph: Questlove, the drummer, producer and culinary entrepreneur, will receive top billing at the third annual Taste Talks festival in the fall of 2015. His official title is curator for the three days of symposiums, tastings, cooking demonstrations, dinners and music offered in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

headline: Taylor Swift Versus Spotify
abstract: The growth of music streaming services does not appear to be hurting the industry’s revenue.
lead_paragraph: Is streaming music bad for musicians? That may be the conclusion some people have drawn from Taylor Swift’s decision to pull her songs from Spotify, the popular streaming music service that is based in Sweden. But there is reason for skepticism.

headline: Will ‘Serial’ Change How We Talk About Crime?
abstract: The popular podcast has already spawned online investigations — and an extended debate over the ethics of amateurs trying to solve crimes.
lead_paragraph: If you’re among the one million people who reportedly listen to each episode of “Serial,” you already know that the podcast centers on the 1999 death of the high school student Hae Min Lee, and the conviction of her ex-boyfriend Adnan Syed for her murder. You’ve followed the show’s host, Sarah Koenig, as she tries to determine whether Mr. Syed really killed Ms. Lee. You may or may not know (though the size of the latter category is shrinking) that parallel investigations of the crime are taking place on Reddit and elsewhere, and that those investigations are inspiring debates of their own.

headline: Boehner and McConnell Criticize Climate Deal With China
abstract: Republican leaders in the House and Senate were quick to blast the climate deal reached between the Untied States and China.
lead_paragraph: Speaker John A. Boehner was one of the first critics of the climate deal struck between the United States and China, releasing a statement early Wednesday deploring the deal as “the latest example of the president’s crusade against affordable, reliable energy that is already hurting jobs and squeezing middle-class families.”

headline: First Draft Focus: McConnell Addresses His Freshman Class
abstract: Senator Mitch McConnell welcomes new Republican Senators-elect to the Capitol.

headline: Marrakesh Express
abstract: A French take on tagine, from Daniel Boulud.
lead_paragraph: The chef Daniel Boulud has a long history with tagine, the North African stew that takes its name from the elegant earthenware pot in which it is cooked. Thirty years ago, he said recently, he tasted a tagine cooked by a Moroccan magician and cook named Baby Dahane. The taste lingered with him. “I loved the soulful, Berber-style delicate preparation,” he said, “the crossroad of spice and flavor and the smell, the taste, the combination of spices and vegetables.”

headline: The New American Love Story, Lived in the Shadows
abstract: “Preparation for the Next Life,” Atticus Lish’s first novel, is a slow-building, unsentimental love story depicting blinkered lives at the American margins.
lead_paragraph: Atticus Lish’s first novel, “Preparation for the Next Life,” is unlike any American fiction I’ve read recently in its intricate comprehension of, and deep feeling for, life at the margins.

headline: Brooklyn’s Sleepy Enclave, Vinegar Hill, Awakens
abstract: Nestled within the gritty urban boundaries of this waterfront enclave, interspersed with warehouses and industrial buildings, are some of the city’s most beguiling scraps of streetscape.
lead_paragraph: The Brooklyn waterfront enclave of Vinegar Hill is a tiny carpet remnant of a neighborhood, a rough-edged but charmingly idiosyncratic swatch of land largely cut off from the city around it. At its northern fringe is the dystopian sprawl of a colossal Con Edison substation that separates residents from the tantalizingly close East River. To the east is the fenced 300-acre Brooklyn Navy Yard industrial park. To the south is a mountain range of public housing and the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway.

headline: Obama Aims to Lift the Global Economy, and Maybe Himself
abstract: Mr. Obama will arrive at an international economic meeting in Australia hoping to press European and Asian leaders to get their economies moving again — and perhaps buoy his own presidency.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Facing a Republican resurgence that is blocking virtually every policy move, President Obama will arrive at an international economic meeting in Australia this weekend hoping to press European and Asian leaders to get their economies moving again — and perhaps buoy his own foundering presidency.

headline: Alex From Target: The Other Side of Fame
abstract: A social media phenomenon tells the full story of instant web celebrity.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago, 16-year-old Alex Lee was your run-of-the-mill teenager.

headline: Fears Rise as Russian Military Units Pour Into Ukraine
abstract: The NATO confirmation comes after days of reports from Ukrainian and European officials of tanks crossing into eastern Ukraine in scenes reminiscent of Russia’s invasion of Crimea.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Tanks and other military vehicles pouring over the border from Russia into eastern Ukraine. Nightly artillery battles in the region’s biggest city, Donetsk, and reports of fighting around another regional capital. And now, sightings of the “green men,” professional soldiers in green uniforms without insignia, the same type of forces that carried out the invasion of Crimea last spring.

headline: Landing on a Comet, a European Space Agency Mission Aims to Unlock the Mysteries of Earth
abstract: The ambitious mission succeeded, despite a potential showstopper problem, when a signal arrived at Darmstadt, Germany, just after 11 a.m. Eastern time.
lead_paragraph: In a technological feat that gives scientists their first opportunity to dig into a remnant of the early solar system, the European Space Agency’s Rosetta mission successfully placed a small spacecraft on the surface of a speeding comet on Wednesday.

headline: Website Explores Sugar’s Effects on Health
abstract: SugarScience.org, a new website, seeks to educate the public on how too much sugar makes people sick.
lead_paragraph: Most people know that too much sugar can be bad for you. But now a dozen scientists at three universities have started a new website called SugarScience.org to educate the public on precisely how too much sugar can make people sick.

headline: Scientists Celebrate Spacecraft Landing
abstract: Scientists at the European Space Agency react after their Philae lander arrived at its destination on Wednesday for the first extended examination of a comet.
lead_paragraph: Scientists at the European Space Agency react after their Philae lander arrived at its destination on Wednesday for the first extended examination of a comet.

headline: A Season’s Worth of Music in a Weekend at Knoxville’s Big Ears Festival
abstract: The 2015 Big Ears Festival packs three days with performances by the Kronos Quartet, Terry Riley, Rhiannon Giddens and more.
lead_paragraph: Downtown, in the musical sense, seems to be expanding southward. Big Ears, a festival in Knoxville, Tenn., in which indie classical, pop and jazz composers and ensembles rub shoulders, has announced its 2015 roster, and it reads like a season listing for Greenwich Village and Brooklyn, compressed into a single weekend, March 27-29.

headline: ‘Buddha,’ Paroled
abstract: Freddie Cox was convicted of second-degree murder. In part because he maintained his innocence, he was denied parole until this year, 28 years after his imprisonment.
lead_paragraph: Freddie Cox was convicted of second-degree murder. In part because he maintained his innocence, he was denied parole until this year, 28 years after his imprisonment.

headline: A Claim of Innocence Is No Longer a Roadblock to Parole
abstract: Parole boards are changing some of their long-held views on inmates admitting guilt, as shown in the case of Freddie Cox, a Brooklyn man convicted of murder.
lead_paragraph: BEACON, N.Y. — After 28 years in prison, Freddie Cox emerged from the Fishkill Correctional Facility, not quite a free man, but free enough.

headline: What You Get for ...$1,900,000
abstract: This week’s properties included a house with water views in Maine, a Miami Beach house with a pool, and a lodge in Wisconsin.
lead_paragraph: CAMDEN, ME.

headline: 1964: Medicare Foe Says He’ll Act
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: A Republican opponent agreed to usher through the Medicare bill in 1964.
lead_paragraph: KENSETT. Ark. — An important opponent of the administration’s health-care bill said today he would move to speed congressional action on the measure if President Johnson wishes. Rep. Wilbur D. Mills, D; Ark., chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said he would bring up the medicare measure early next year. ‘‘If the president wants it first and tells me he does that’s the way we’ll be working,’’ he said. Mr. Johnson said during the campaign that the measure was ‘‘just at the top’’ of his legislative ‘‘must list.’’ Rep. Mills’s statement was good news for backers of the proposal. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Nov. 13, 1964

headline: Miscellaneous Thoughts on 2016
abstract: From Rand and Rubio to Hillary and her “rivals.”
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column argued that as of right now, policy-oriented Republicans should be rooting for strong showings by Marco Rubio and Rand Paul in the 2016 primaries, because Rubio and Paul are 1) the two politicians who seem to have thought most seriously about what the next G.O.P. agenda should look like, and 2) have important, interesting, worth-debating differences on the form that agenda should take. The column didn’t say much about whether either man was likely to actually win the nomination, mostly because I don’t think that much has changed since the last time I wrote about the two of them: Rubio still looks more like the kind of candidate who wins G.O.P. nominations, an asset that the press may be underrating the moment, while Paul still has the harder road (probably slightly more difficult now given the shifting foreign policy landscape), because he just has more potential points of tension with the traditional Republican coalition, donors and wonks and voters alike.

headline: Audio Equalizer and Enhancement Apps Beyond the Smartphone Sound
abstract: If you’re not satisfied with the quality of music produced by your smartphone’s player, there are plenty of options a sharper listening experience.
lead_paragraph: YOU’VE probably heard musicians like Neil Young complain over the last few years about the sound quality of digital music. But thanks to a new generation of so-called audio enhancement apps, your music’s sound quality doesn’t have to entirely depend on your smartphone.

headline: App Smart | Enhance Your Music
abstract: Kit Eaton reviews LouderLogic, DFX Music Player and Headquake, three apps that help enhance the sound on your smartphone.
lead_paragraph: Kit Eaton reviews LouderLogic, DFX Music Player and Headquake, three apps that help enhance the sound on your smartphone.

headline: 36 Hours in Dublin
abstract: Explore street view, find our points of interest and sign in to your Google account to save your map.
lead_paragraph: Explore street view, find our points of interest and sign in to your Google account to save your map.

headline: House Hunting in ... Toronto
abstract: Apart from hitting a small speed bump in 2008-2009, Toronto’s housing market has seen steady and strong price growth since 1996.
lead_paragraph: AN EDWARDIAN MANSION IN THE ROSEDALE NEIGHBORHOOD

headline: After Victory Laps, Settling In as Rookies
abstract: For incoming House freshmen, going to Congress is like going to college, with orientation on the dos and don’ts of Capitol Hill and a tough search for housing.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ruben Gallego arrived here Sunday night, crashed on a friend’s air mattress and went apartment-hunting Monday morning, only to discover it costs $1,900 to rent a 400-square-foot studio on Capitol Hill. He spent that afternoon working from his laptop on the second floor of a Dunkin’ Donuts, talking on his cellphone while pacing about in his stocking feet.

headline: Pickling and Chemotherapy
abstract: A reader shares his recipe for pickled vegetables.
lead_paragraph: An interesting response to this week’s pickle piece:

headline: Back for More: Return of the Pulp Fiction Contest
abstract: A man, a dame, a 1950s book cover: “Tough Kid From Brooklyn.” Tell us how the story begins. It’s City Room’s 2014 New York Pulp Fiction Contest.
lead_paragraph: Updated, Dec. 23 | Meet, and read, the contest winners, and thanks again to all who submitted!

headline: VW to Allow Labor Groups to Represent Workers at Chattanooga Plant
abstract: The U.A.W., which lost a vote in February to represent the workers, hailed the policy because it would mean partial recognition of the union and regular discussions with management.
lead_paragraph: Volkswagen announced a new policy on Wednesday that was likely to allow several labor groups, including the United Automobile Workers, to represent employees at the company’s Chattanooga, Tenn., plant.

headline: A Soon-to-Be Grandma, Ready to Learn
abstract: This spring, my older daughter announced that she was pregnant. And I realized almost immediately that I knew nothing about today’s birthing or parenting issues. I had a lot of catching up to do.
lead_paragraph: With two grown daughters in stable, marital relationships, it was, according to my friends, only a matter of time before I would join the band of grandparents. “Are they pregnant yet?” became the standard greeting of friends who lived far away and did not track my everyday movements. And I responded in kind: “how are you? Because me, I’m not a grandma yet.”

headline: On the Trail of Paddington Bear
abstract: The Paddington Trail in London features statues of the adventurous bear designed by celebrities like Benedict Cumberbatch and Kate Moss.
lead_paragraph: The Paddington Bear phenomenon began on Christmas Eve in London in 1956 when Michael Bond spotted a lone toy bear on the shelf at Selfridges and, feeling sorry for it, took it home to his wife.

headline: The Daily Gift: A Speaker in Three Dimensions
abstract: Boom Boom uses Bluetooth technology to pump up the volume — and more.
lead_paragraph: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.

headline: As Bud Selig Prepares Exit, Roger Clemens Case Sticks Around
abstract: Clemens was deposed by Richard Emery in July in connection with Brian McNamee’s defamation suit against the former pitcher. A copy of the deposition was made available to The Times.
lead_paragraph: As Bud Selig prepares to depart as Major League Baseball’s longtime commissioner, he is leaving a few items behind.

headline: Should Cow Wow Sell to Little Children or Big Children?
abstract: Chris Pouy couldn’t help but wonder: Had he picked the wrong audience for his drink?
lead_paragraph: We just published a case study about an advertising copywriter, Chris Pouy, who was tired of buffing the brands of others and started his own company, Cow Wow, to sell fun, cereal-flavored milks to children ages 5 to 12. In late 2012, Mr. Pouy introduced Fruity Trudy and Chocolate Chip Cathy near the company’s Los Angeles offices.

headline: Randy Jackson Ends His Run on ‘American Idol’
abstract: Mr. Jackson served 12 years as a judge and one year as a mentor to the contestants on the show. He was the last original judge on “Idol.”
lead_paragraph: Little about the original “American Idol” — including big ratings — remains now that Randy Jackson has decided to leave the singing competition after 13 years as a regular participant on the show.

headline: Fears of Inflation Stem From Worrisome Origins
abstract: Hedge fund managers howl about “fake” economic data, but the paranoia over inflation is rooted in troubling episodes, Jesse Eisinger writes in The Trade column.
lead_paragraph: The anger of the investing class has curdled into paranoia.

headline: Jean-Claude Juncker Breaks Silence Over Luxembourg Tax Issues
abstract: The former prime minister of Luxembourg, now the president of the European Commission, denied that his “ambition was to organize tax evasion in Europe.”
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Jean-Claude Juncker, head of the European Union’s executive arm, took responsibility on Wednesday for the way Luxembourg was run during his time in charge, breaking his silence after a flood of embarrassing revelations about his home country’s role as a global tax haven.

headline: Ways of Seeing
abstract: Two new books show how photography can bring a picture book to life.
lead_paragraph: The picture-book version of the French film “The Red Balloon” was a treasured possession of my 1970s childhood. I was enthralled not just by the story of the lonely boy and his mysterious balloon companion but also — and perhaps even more — by the photography. Each page of the book is a still from the movie, a thrillingly lucid, beautifully stylized window into the real world. The photos were of Paris, not fancy Paris but the gray, gray Paris of crumbling buildings and dim alleyways. The camera made each pockmarked wall look like an elaborate Modernist painting, with the little boy dressed in soft dove-gray himself a lovely detail in it — and then set against all the grayness on each page was that miraculous balloon. It glided across the scene, redder than any red and bigger than any balloon I’d ever seen, a beacon of pure joy and a testament to the possibility that a bit of magic could float right into your tough everyday life.

headline: 36 Hours in Dublin
abstract: After decades of tumultuous change, a more refined wave of affluence has reached Dublin, where visitors will find a restaurant renaissance, musical creativity and a glorious sense of history.
lead_paragraph: After decades of tumultuous change, a more refined wave of affluence has reached Dublin, where visitors will find a restaurant renaissance, musical creativity and a glorious sense of history.

headline: 36 Hours in Dublin
abstract: Bike along the Liffey River, peel back layers of Ireland’s history, dig into a booming culinary scene and, sure, go for a Guinness during a weekend in the Irish capital.

headline: Goldman Sachs Names 78 New Partners
abstract: Goldman Sachs has added 78 executives to its ranks of partners, one of the most sought-after honors on Wall Street.
lead_paragraph: The vaunted list of partners at Goldman Sachs had 78 names added to it on Wednesday.

headline: A Primer on How Currency Manipulation Worked
abstract: Regulators looked at bank trading around the time each day that the benchmark rate, or “fix,” was set.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Some of the world’s biggest banks have agreed to pay regulators in Britain, the United States and Switzerland more than $4 billion for conspiring to manipulate benchmark foreign currency rates.

headline: Mexico’s Bold Move on Debt Restructuring Contracts
abstract: Mexico has filed in the United States for an issue of bonds that would include new, improved collective action clauses specifically written to keep holdout investors like Paul Singer at bay.
lead_paragraph: Take that, Paul Singer!

headline: ‘I’ve Always Loved People Watching Me’
abstract: Rachel Tucker talks about her role in “The Last Ship,” and about growing up in Belfast, Northern Ireland.
lead_paragraph: Some people say Sting’s new Broadway musical, “The Last Ship,” is about the songs. Others, that it’s about the good, struggling workingmen of northern England. Others, who have seen Rachel Tucker’s performance as Meg, the hometown love whom the hero leaves behind, will say that it’s about the woman.

headline: Raging Hormones at Exam Time
abstract: That season in hell commonly called mid-adolescence promises to turn especially hot — and chilly — in Simon Stephens’s “Punk Rock.”
lead_paragraph: That season in hell commonly called mid-adolescence promises to turn especially hot — and chilly — in Simon Stephens’s “Punk Rock,” which opens on Monday at the Lucille Lortel Theater. This portrait of the evil that lurks in the hearts of unhappy teenagers, preparing for exams in a private school, evoked both shivers and huzzahs from London critics in 2009.

headline: Transcript of Clemens Deposition
abstract: The transcript of the July, 2014 deposition of Roger Clemens in the Clemens-Brian McNamee defamation lawsuit.
lead_paragraph: The transcript of the July, 2014 deposition of Roger Clemens in the Clemens-Brian McNamee defamation lawsuit.

headline: Second Ebola Outbreak in Mali Eclipses Early Success
abstract: The West African nation of Mali, which just beat its first outbreak of Ebola, has confirmed a second one that is larger and more threatening, global health authorities said on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: The West African nation of Mali, which just beat its first outbreak of Ebola, has confirmed a second one that is larger and more threatening, global health authorities said on Wednesday.

headline: A Celebratory Air as New G.O.P. Senators Have a Look Around
abstract: Senate Republicans on Wednesday welcomed the reinforcements to the Capitol after last week’s sweeping election win.
lead_paragraph: Senate Republicans were in a celebratory mood Wednesday as the reinforcements arrived from last week’s sweeping election win. The newcomers posed for a photo with Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, whom they will help make majority leader on Thursday.

headline: YouTube Music Key Is Introduced as New Rival in Streaming
abstract: As YouTube pushes into paid content, other online music outlets are being forced to defend or change their business models to better compensate artists.
lead_paragraph: For nearly a decade, YouTube has offered a smorgasbord of free music, making just about every song imaginable — from Top 40 to ukulele covers — available at a click. But soon the site, whose more than one billion monthly visitors make it the world’s most popular music platform, will start charging for additional perks.

headline: The Shadow in the Chador
abstract: Ana Lily Amirpour creates an Iranian town in California oil country for her vampire film, “A Girl Walks Home Alone at Night.”
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The heroine of “A Girl Walks Home Alone at Night” is not your typical Hollywood vampire. She’s Iranian, for one thing, and does most of her late-night feeding in a chador. She loves dance music and skateboarding, and has seen Elvis and Black Sabbath live.

headline: A Brief History of Failure
abstract: From the longbow to the Dvorak keyboard, the road to innovation is paved with failed designs and forgotten artifacts.
lead_paragraph: From the longbow to the Dvorak keyboard, the road to innovation is paved with failed designs and forgotten artifacts.

headline: Taylor Swift’s ‘1989’ Reigns at No. 1
abstract: Ms. Swift’s album continued to dominate the album chart in its second week, selling 402,000 copies.
lead_paragraph: Taylor Swift’s “1989” remains at the top of the Billboard 200 for a second week, not surprisingly, with sales of 402,000 copies during the week ending Nov. 9, the magazine and Nielsen SoundScan reported. That is a drop of 69 percent from Ms. Swift’s first-week sales, but it means that in the two weeks since the album was released, it has sold nearly 1.7 million copies, an extraordinary number these days. By contrast, the disc holding the No. 2 sales spot – the 52nd installment of the “Now That’s What I Call Music!” – sold 59,000 in its second week on the chart, after 103,000 last week, for combined sales that are less than a tenth of Ms. Swift’s.

headline: Peril, and Daring, at 1 World Trade Center as Window Washers Are Trapped
abstract: As the workers dangled 69 stories above the street, emergency crews cut a hole in a window of the tower and pulled them, unhurt, into the building.
lead_paragraph: For more than an hour on Wednesday afternoon, two window washers commanded the concern of New York City.

headline: Roger Clemens Deposition Transcript
abstract: The transcript of the July, 2014 deposition of Roger Clemens in the Clemens-Brian McNamee defamation lawsuit.
lead_paragraph: The transcript of the July, 2014 deposition of Roger Clemens in the Clemens-Brian McNamee defamation lawsuit.

headline: Today in Small Business: Demise of the Internet Sales Tax
abstract: American retail workers steal more than shoplifters. Pinterest says its male users have doubled in the past year. A company gets $100 million to remake the cash register.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: New Orleans Police Routinely Ignored Sex Crimes, Report Finds
abstract: Five detectives responsible for investigating sex crimes followed up on only 14 percent of reported cases in three years, a city audit has concluded.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — A scathing examination of this city’s Police Department has concluded that five detectives tasked with investigating sex crimes failed to pursue hundreds of reported cases, finding records of follow-up efforts in only 14 percent of such calls over three years.

headline: NATO Speaks on Russian Forces in Ukraine
abstract: The Supreme Allied Commander Europe of NATO, Gen. Philip M. Breedlove, confirmed that Russian troops were moving into eastern Ukraine, but that NATO was unsure of their numbers or intentions.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Allied Commander Europe of NATO, Gen. Philip M. Breedlove, confirmed that Russian troops were moving into eastern Ukraine, but that NATO was unsure of their numbers or intentions.

headline: Mosque Is Damaged in West Bank Fire
abstract: Residents and officials surveyed the damage to a mosque in a Palestinian village in the West Bank after what was said to be an arson attack.
lead_paragraph: Residents and officials surveyed the damage to a mosque in a Palestinian village in the West Bank after what was said to be an arson attack.

headline: Endorsing Paul and Rubio in 2016 (for Senator, Not President)
abstract: The anti-tax group is endorsing six senators for re-election two years from now, all of them Republicans who won their seats as part of the Tea Party wave of 2010.
lead_paragraph: The Club for Growth PAC is already backing candidates in the 2016 election, but not that 2016 election.

headline: What the Climate Accord Could Change
abstract: The possible effects for the coal and automobile industries of the landmark agreement between the United States and China.
lead_paragraph: The possible effects for the coal and automobile industries of the landmark agreement between the United States and China.

headline: Reading The Times With Patricia Marx
abstract: The staff writer for The New Yorker — and author whose latest book, “Let’s Be Less Stupid,” publishes this summer — says she reads the paper on her computer late at night.
lead_paragraph: Patricia Marx is a staff writer for The New Yorker and an author. Her latest book, “Let’s Be Less Stupid,” publishes next summer.

headline: A Tower Clock in Danger of Losing Its Purpose
abstract: There has been a lot of commotion lately over the future of 346 Broadway in Manhattan, especially the great four-faced clock that surmounts the building.
lead_paragraph: Has the XIth hour arrived for the landmark tower clock at 346 Broadway?

headline: Vegetarian Thanksgiving: Bread Salad Inspired by Stuffing
abstract: A reader, Jessica Benoit, offers this fall version of panzanella, inspired by her first Thanksgiving abroad and thoughts of the traditional stuffing her family ate during holidays in New England.
lead_paragraph: Panzanella is a Tuscan summer bread salad, often made to use up stale bread. The typical panzanella consists of chunks of stale bread and tomatoes, cucumbers, onion and basil, dressed with olive oil and vinegar.

headline: ‘Follow Me Around’ and the Long, Strange Trip to a Times Correction
abstract: Disagreements on chronology in a book excerpt and magazine cover story about Gary Hart and the Miami Herald.
lead_paragraph: Most corrections are simple. The Times gets something wrong – inevitable when it publishes well over 100,000 words a day – gets a complaint, and quickly publishes a correction. This may happen dozens of times in a typical week.

headline: Casting Doubt on Appeal, Court Rejects Bail for Ex-SAC Capital Trader
abstract: Mathew Martoma, a portfolio manager for Steven A. Cohen’s former hedge fund, is now waiting for a judge to set a new date for him to start a nine-year prison term.
lead_paragraph: Mathew Martoma’s bid to stay out of prison pending an appeal of his insider trading conviction did not last much past lunchtime.

headline: Angel Collinson Takes Alaska
abstract: Get in the mind of Angel Collinson, a twenty-four year old big mountain skier who is making waves in the traditionally male dominated sport.
lead_paragraph: Get in the mind of Angel Collinson, a twenty-four year old big mountain skier who is making waves in the traditionally male dominated sport.

headline: Wheelies: The Scion Concept Edition
abstract: Scion says it will introduce the iM Concept at the Los Angeles auto show next week; Chrysler announces pricing for the Ram ProMaster City compact van.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Dan Sullivan, G.O.P. Senate Challenger in Alaska, Wins Senate Race
abstract: Senator Mark Begich narrowly lost his re-election bid to Dan Sullivan after a count of absentee ballots.
lead_paragraph: Senator Mark Begich of Alaska, a Democrat who squeezed into office in 2008 by a narrow margin in a conservative state, narrowly lost his re-election bid as a count of absentee ballots a week after the election put his opponent, Dan Sullivan, over the top, according to The Associated Press.

headline: De Blasio, Arriving Late, Angers Attendees of Flight 587 Memorial
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio missed a moment of silence for victims of a 2001 plane crash, providing perhaps the most striking example to date of his habit of tardiness.
lead_paragraph: Since taking office, Mayor Bill de Blasio has made a habit of keeping people waiting. Business leaders have languished in meeting rooms. Reporters have assembled before empty lecterns.

headline: Rescuing the World Trade Center Window Washers
abstract: Two window washers became trapped outside the 69th story of the newly completed One World Trade Center in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Two window washers became trapped outside the 69th story of the newly completed One World Trade Center in Manhattan.

headline: Bank of England Officials Cleared of Wrongdoing in Currency Manipulation
abstract: An inquiry found that no one at the central bank was involved in unlawful behavior, but a top official was fired after he failed to follow internal policies.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – An independent inquiry released on Wednesday found that no one at the Bank of England was involved in unlawful or improper behavior related to the foreign exchange market, but a top official was fired this week after the central bank said he failed to follow internal policies.

headline: Style in the Kallio Neighborhood of Helsinki, Finland
abstract: A Finnish actress has a dazzling smile, thanks to a crystal on a tooth.
lead_paragraph: Sonja Sorvola likes to mix minimalism with bold pieces, something she describes as a flirty divergence from the clean and tailored look often associated with Scandinavian style. While walking recently in the Kallio neighborhood of Helsinki, Finland, Ms. Sorvola, an actress, wore vintage Céline loafers, Zara pants and an asymmetrical wrap cardigan from Stockholm. This interview has been edited and condensed.

headline: On Climate Change, Voters Are as Partisan as Ever
abstract: Members of Congress tend to tread carefully on the climate debate, and last week’s midterm elections showed why they are wise to do so.
lead_paragraph: The climate change agreement reached between President Obama and President Xi Jinping of China has quickly drawn a mix of praise and scorn among American lawmakers who woke up to the news. Unsurprisingly, the responses fell largely along party lines.

headline: Video: Young Woman Skis Lines and Makes Waves
abstract: Meet Angel Collinson, a 24-year-old big mountain skier who is making strides in a traditionally male-dominated sport.
lead_paragraph: Behind the Line is a video series produced by Teton Gravity Research that takes you into the minds of skiers. In each episode, the athletes will look back on a line, a jump or a session, and discuss the moment.

headline: Text to Text | The Fall of the Berlin Wall: Reporting in 1989 and Remembering 25 Years Later
abstract: In this Text to Text, we compare the moment of euphoria when the wall fell in 1989 with today’s Berlin, a transformed city in which many do not remember the oppressive divisions of the past. In follow-up activities, students can evaluate the choices made since 1989 and decide if the Cold War is really over.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-five years ago this week, East Germans danced atop the concrete wall that had sealed off their communist-ruled world from the West.

headline: A Major Breakthrough on Climate Change
abstract: After years of futile efforts, China and the United States agree to cooperate in a meaningful way on global warming.
lead_paragraph: The deal jointly announced in Beijing by President Obama and China’s president, Xi Jinping, to limit greenhouse gases well beyond their earlier pledges is both a major diplomatic breakthrough and — assuming both sides can carry out their promises — an enormously positive step in the uncertain battle against climate change.

headline: Best Wishes, Harry Reid Style
abstract: Senator Harry Reid congratulates Senator Mitch McConnell.

headline: Indian Doctors Respond to Sterilizations
