abstract: A team of doctors rushed to central India after at least a dozen women died and others became seriously ill following mass sterilization surgeries meant for population control.
lead_paragraph: A team of doctors rushed to central India after at least a dozen women died and others became seriously ill following mass sterilization surgeries meant for population control.

headline: U.S. Accepts Trinity’s Plan to Test Design of Guardrail
abstract: The ET-Plus, made by Trinity Industries and suspected of malfunctioning during crashes, will be tested by a research organization in San Antonio.
lead_paragraph: The federal government has accepted Trinity Industries’ plans for testing highway guardrail products that are suspected of malfunctioning during crashes and potentially slicing through vehicles, even as lawmakers and lawyers criticized their adequacy.

headline: Landrieu and Cassidy Race to Be First With a Pipeline Vote
abstract: Bill Cassidy, the Republican candidate headed for a Senate runoff against Senator Mary Landrieu, Democrat of Louisiana, are both trying to get ahead with Lousisna’s powerful oil industry by introducing legislation to approve the pipeline.
lead_paragraph: The Louisiana Senate fight moved to the halls of Congress on Wednesday as Senator Mary Landrieu, the Democrat, and Representative Bill Cassidy, her Republican challenger, both pushed for votes to approve the Keystone XL pipeline.

headline: When All Else Fails, Embryo Donation Offers Hope
abstract: After four years of infertility and many failures, this little baby popsicle of an embryo was our best hope at finally becoming parents.
lead_paragraph: I doubt if anyone having trouble conceiving wakes up thinking: What about adopting an embryo? In the crushing world of infertility, that seems like an even more distant option. The fertility clinic in Seattle told me we only qualified to be a part of its embryo-donation program because we had been such “failures” in trying to conceive. For the first time in our four-year battle with infertility, I was happy to admit our shortcomings.

headline: Financial Aid, Simplified: A Better College Calculator
abstract: Wellesley's net-price calculator is simpler than the typical one. As a result, most students who start using it finish the process, in a few minutes.
lead_paragraph: The financial-aid calculators maintained by colleges are a case study in both flawed bureaucracy and flawed customer service. As part of a 2008 higher-education law, Congress required colleges to build the calculators — online tools to let families estimate how much they’d really have to pay to attend a specific college.

headline: U.S. Tells U.N. Panel of Steps to Revise Interrogation Policy
abstract: The acting State Department legal adviser told a United Nations panel that monitors torture that the United States had used cruel treatment after the Sept. 11 attacks.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration told a United Nations panel in Geneva on Wednesday that the United States had tortured terrorism suspects after the Sept. 11 attacks but that it had since taken steps to prevent any future use of unlawful, coercive interrogation techniques.

headline: Nationalist Youths Attack U.S. Sailors in Turkey
abstract: The United States Embassy called the attack “appalling,” and the Turkish authorities arrested 12 people, saying such behavior was “in no way tolerable.”
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Members of a Turkish nationalist youth group assaulted three visiting American sailors in Istanbul on Wednesday, hurling balloons filled with red paint at them, putting white sacks over their heads and calling them murderers.

headline: The Places Are Set, but Not for All
abstract: The lingering theatrical convention of casting Caucasians in roles that call for Asians incites exasperation in Han Ong’s play “Chairs and a Long Table.”
lead_paragraph: A bitter satire and a realist drama, a position paper and a cri de coeur, Han Ong’s “Chairs and a Long Table” mingles rage, rational argument and bleak comedy. In a faceless New York conference room, four Asian-American actors and a white P.R. consultant gather to strategize for a coming forum. A fictional theater on the opposite coast, the Laguna Rep, has just announced it will present “The Center of the World,” a new play set in Imperial China. But the casting has incited controversy.

headline: Busting a Barrier, Preserving the Seams
abstract: A handful of clothing companies were founded within the last year to cater to muscular athletes whose proportions fall outside the average body type.
lead_paragraph: Beth Newell and Adil Abubakar hit a snag early in their attempt to start a clothing company. The manufacturer was having difficulty believing that their measurements were accurate.

headline: Monte dei Paschi Reports Nearly $1 Billion Loss in Third Quarter
abstract: The loss comes as Monte dei Paschi, which is based in Italy, is struggling to make up a capital shortfall exposed by the European Central Bank.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Monte dei Paschi di Siena, Europe’s oldest bank and one of its most troubled, on Wednesday reported a loss of 797 million euros, or $991 million, in the third quarter after it drastically increased the amount of money set aside to cover problem loans.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Meet the Republicans’ Top Guy on the Environment, James Inhofe
abstract: The Senator once called the E.P.A. a “Gestapo bureaucracy.”
lead_paragraph: No sooner did President Obama and President Xi Jinping of China announce goals for combatting climate change than Senator Jim Inhofe denounced them. The Oklahoma Republican called the accord a “non-binding charade” on Wednesday and told The Washington Post that he would do his utmost to let environmental devastation continue apace. In his actual words: “As we enter a new Congress, I will do everything in my power to rein in and shed light on the EPA’s unchecked regulations.”

headline: A Private Tour of a New Brooklyn Cafe’s Colombian Coffee Farms
abstract: Devoción, which opens in Williamsburg on Sunday, shows T how it’s been roasting artisanal beans in Bogotá since 2006.
lead_paragraph: Since opening its first roaster in Bogotá in 2006, the Colombian company Devoción has sourced and roasted what its owner Steven Sutton categorizes as “third-wave coffee,” a term he reserves for the highest-quality artisanal beans. Now, Sutton and his business partners sell 150 tons of coffee each year in the United States and Colombia. And this fall, in anticipation of its first stateside outpost, a flagship roaster and cafe that opens in Brooklyn’s Williamsburg neighborhood on November 16, Devoción invited T onto its coffee farms for a peek at where it all began.

headline: Questions Raised as Barclays Takes a Step Back
abstract: The bank says it is serving investors by deferring a settlement. Any gain needs to outweigh the loss of a quick-deal discount, contends George Hay of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Barclays is once again exposed.

headline: Deal on Carbon Emissions by Obama and Xi Jinping Raises Hopes for Upcoming Paris Climate Talks
abstract: The emissions targets announced by President Obama and the Chinese leader are expected to be at the heart of a 2015 international climate treaty.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The historic announcement by President Obama and President Xi Jinping of China that they will commit to targets for cuts in their nations’ carbon emissions has fundamentally shifted the global politics of climate change. The agreement has given a fresh jolt of optimism to negotiations aimed at reaching a new international climate treaty next year in Paris, where the American and Chinese targets are expected to be the heart of the deal.

headline: Foreign Exchange Settlement Shows the Lessons Banks Have Learned
abstract: Perhaps the biggest lesson from the settlement was seen after other cases involving big fines — there will be little real change in how global banks act, Peter J. Henning writes in the White Collar Watch column.
lead_paragraph: The settlements by five global banks for manipulating the foreign currency markets show a strategy based on strength in numbers: The more banks that are disciplined, the less any one of them will be the focus of public attention for their violations. The total fine of $4.25 billion imposed by British, American and Swiss regulators sounds like a lot of money, but no one bank has to bear the brunt of the bad publicity.

headline: Thanksgiving Office Hours: Ask All Your Questions
abstract: Sam Sifton and Melissa Clark are answering your Thanksgiving cooking questions on Monday, Nov. 17, at 1 p.m. Eastern time, on The New York Times Facebook page.
lead_paragraph: How’s your holiday planning going? You have an order in for a turkey? You’ve decided whether to brine? You know what side dishes you’re going to cook? What pies? Do you know how to set the table? Are you going to have place cards? (Do you know who’s coming?) What’s the wine situation? Is there going to be enough?

headline: Turkish Nationalists Attack U.S. Sailors
abstract: A video posted by a nationalist group, the Turkish Youth Union, shows three American sailors being attacked in Istanbul.
lead_paragraph: A video posted by a nationalist group, the Turkish Youth Union, shows three American sailors being attacked in Istanbul.

headline: Ask Not for Whom the Cell Tolls
abstract: The quirky mix in Anne-Sophie Mutter’s recital at Carnegie Hall included Sebastian Currier’s “Ringtones” and pieces by André Previn, Beethoven and Franck.
lead_paragraph: Phones! Phones, ringing in the concert hall!

headline: Driven | 2015 Cadillac ATS Coupe
abstract: Cadillac builds another driver’s car, now it just needs to get the word out.
lead_paragraph: Cadillac builds another driver’s car, now it just needs to get the word out.

headline: Video: The 2015 Cadillac ATS Coupe Is Not Your Aunt’s Coupe DeVille
abstract: Cadillac has brought the coupe form to its ATS line, aiming to compete with German cars like the Audi A5 and BMW 4 Series.
lead_paragraph: UPDATED

headline: Who Is Xi Jinping?
abstract: When Xi Jinping became the president of China in 2013, New York Times reporters discussed his background.
lead_paragraph: When Xi Jinping became the president of China in 2013, New York Times reporters discussed his background.

headline: Risk Model Seen as Reducing Military Suicides
abstract: The computer model identifies a range of factors related to suicide that could allow doctors to follow high-risk soldiers closely and take preventive measures.
lead_paragraph: Military doctors could reduce suicides among soldiers with psychiatric conditions by using a new screening system that flags those at highest risk of taking their own lives, a new study suggests.

headline: Inside the Senate’s ‘Inner Sanctum’
abstract: A view from our colleague Stephen Crowley inside “the inner sanctum” of the Senate, which is normally closed to staff members and journalists.
lead_paragraph: Our colleague Stephen Crowley provides a view inside “the inner sanctum” of the Senate, which is normally closed to staff members and journalists.

headline: ‘Old’ Masters, Still in Glorious, Youthful Form
abstract: Godard, Federer, Williams, Brady and Manning get better with age — or at least have aged very, very well.
lead_paragraph: This fall, it’s great to be old — or at least, older. Across a number of fields, star performers who are over the traditional retirement age are showing they can still compete with young upstarts. Below, a sampling of this season’s “old” masters:

headline: Justices Hear Challenge to Alabama Redistricting
abstract: Black and Democratic lawmakers in Alabama said the state Legislature relied too heavily on race in 2012 by maintaining high concentrations of black voters in some districts.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Wednesday wrestled with the role race may play in drawing legislative maps.

headline: A Sorrow Transcended by Beauty
abstract: William Kentridge’s version of “Winterreise,” featuring the baritone Matthias Goerne and the pianist Markus Hinterhäuser, received its American premiere at Alice Tully Hall.
lead_paragraph: Schubert’s astonishing “Winterreise” is like a dramatic monologue, a tale told in 24 songs, to poems by Wilhelm Müller. The singer becomes the protagonist of this bleak story about a young man jilted by his beloved, who now fancies someone else. Bitter, despairing and longing for death, he leaves her house at night and wanders a snowy path by the river where they once enjoyed time together. His tears freeze on his face. He passes a graveyard, which in his mind seems an inviting inn. He finally encounters a pathetic man playing a hurdy-gurdy and asks to join him.

headline: White House Nominates Lazard Banker to Treasury Post
abstract: If approved by the Senate, Antonio Weiss, the global head of investment banking at Lazard and a significant donor to the Democratic party, would oversee the Treasury Department’s work on fiscal policy and operations.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration said on Wednesday that it would nominate Antonio Weiss, a top mergers deal maker, as the Treasury Department’s top official for domestic finance matters.

headline: Inquiry Into SpaceShip Two’s Crash Says ‘Feathers’ Were Unlocked Prematurely
abstract: The surviving pilot of the SpaceShip Two crash told investigators he did not know that the co-pilot had unlocked two movable parts at the back of the craft.
lead_paragraph: The surviving pilot of the space plane that crashed in the California desert on Oct. 31 has told investigators that he did not know that the co-pilot, who was killed, had unlocked the craft’s “feathers,” movable parts at the back of the craft that are supposed to slow it down for re-entry.

headline: Minnesota Orchestra Removes ‘Interim’ From President’s Title
abstract: Kevin Smith has been appointed president and chief executive of the Minnesota Orchestra.
lead_paragraph: The Minnesota Orchestra has appointed Kevin Smith its new president and chief executive, the chairman of the orchestra’s board, Gordon M. Sprenger, announced Wednesday. Mr. Smith was elected to the position by a unanimous vote of the board, in effect confirming him in the role in which he has been acting in an interim capacity since Sept. 1, when the previous president and chief executive, Michael Henson, stepped down.

headline: On Income Stagnation
abstract: It’s the economic inequality, stupid.
lead_paragraph: Sorry about lack of posting; I’m scrambling on a couple of fronts, most crucially textbook revisions …

headline: A Call to Reinstate Tony Awards for Sound Design
abstract: A petition is calling for the restoration of two awards, for best sound design for a play and for a musical, that were eliminated by a Tony committee in June.
lead_paragraph: Seeking to influence a Tony Awards committee meeting on Thursday, Broadway sound designers have submitted a petition with 32,495 signatures urging the committee to reverse its decision to eliminate the Tonys for best sound design for a play and for a musical. Among the signatories are the Tony winners Hugh Jackman, Lin-Manuel Miranda, Diane Paulus and Stephen Sondheim.

headline: Gun Control Can Win at the State Level
abstract: Results in Washington and Colorado indicate that gun safety isn’t a lost cause.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to stronger gun safety laws, all politics is increasingly local.

headline: Floating Gracefully Into Madness
abstract: Natalia Osipova was the shining lead in the Mikhailovsky Ballet’s United States debut, “Giselle, ou les Willis,” at Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: The Mikhailovsky Ballet of St. Petersburg, reinvented in 2007 by the Russian businessman Vladimir Kekhman, is a curious entity. Natalia Osipova and Ivan Vasiliev, two of Russian ballet’s brightest lights, are principals. At one point, the Spanish contemporary choreographer Nacho Duato was brought in as its artistic director.

headline: China Deals
abstract: It would be big news in a rational world.
lead_paragraph: I wish that I believed that logic and reason played any role in the politics of climate change. Because if I did, the news of the US-China deal on carbon emissions would be a moment for sudden new optimism.

headline: Twitter Speaks Up With Growth Strategy Intended to Soothe Wall Street
abstract: The social network, which had been battered by executive turmoil and slow growth, broke a long silence about its strategy and product plans, and its stock price rose by 7.5 percent on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Twitter is finally learning how to go beyond a tweet to explain what it is doing, and Wall Street likes what it hears.

headline: Secure the Roots, Then Reach Out
abstract: “Seeds,” the new album by TV on the Radio, is an attempt by the band to stay true to its roots while reaching for new audiences.
lead_paragraph: Blame David Sitek’s cats, at least in part, for the urgently clanging sound, somewhere between a gamelan and a fire alarm, that opens TV on the Radio’s sixth album, “Seeds.”

headline: For Some, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi Falls Short of Expectations in Myanmar
abstract: Human rights advocates and even members of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi’s political party are raising questions about her performance in the broader political arena.
lead_paragraph: KAWHMU, Myanmar — The pastel-painted vocational school hacked out of the bamboo jungle is a long way from the international salons where Myanmar’s symbol of resistance, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, is now an established figure.

headline: Top Prospect’s Injury Renews Concerns About Fighting
abstract: Connor McDavid, 17, a top prospect for the 2015 N.H.L. draft, is expected to miss five to six weeks after injuring his hand in a fight during a game with his junior team, the Erie Otters.
lead_paragraph: Connor McDavid, the No. 1 prospect for next June’s N.H.L. draft, is expected to miss five to six weeks after breaking his right hand Tuesday night in a fight during a junior hockey game.

headline: Keeping Broadway’s Steps Alive
abstract: American Dance Machine for the 21st Century, a repertory company for musical-theater dance, made its debut at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Works of ballet and modern dance have a chance of surviving in repertory, but the choreography in Broadway musicals generally lives and dies with productions of those musicals. Even revivals don’t always save what can be saved.

headline: New York’s Miserable Voter Turnout Isn’t an Accident
abstract: Incompetent Albany politicians like the system just the way it is.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers have become much too accustomed to civic embarrassment. You’d think the state would cringe to see that it came in fourth from the bottom in voter turnout in last week’s midterm election. Only 28.8 percent of eligible voters showed up, a level of indifference that the Editorial Board called “shameful” in this morning’s editorial. That’s the lowest turnout for a gubernatorial election since the state began keeping records.

headline: Window Washers Dangle From Tower
abstract: Two window washers were suspended precariously from the side of the World Trade Center tower, 69 floors above the street.
lead_paragraph: Two window washers were suspended precariously from the side of the World Trade Center tower, 69 floors above the street.

headline: Tours of Duty and the Price Paid at Home
abstract: “Basetrack Live” draws from video testimonials, photography and a website to recount the experiences of Marines in Afghanistan and their families stateside.
lead_paragraph: “When I was in Afghanistan, all I wanted to do was come back to America. But when I got home to America, there was this empty feeling, and I just wanted to go back to Afghanistan.”

headline: Good Pictures, Bad Timing
abstract: When a legendary curator chided Will Brown to find his way as a photographer, he set aside his pictures of his Philadelphia neighborhood. Today, they attest to the changes in the area.
lead_paragraph: When a legendary curator chided Will Brown to find his way as a photographer, he set aside his pictures of his Philadelphia neighborhood. Today, they attest to the changes in the area.

headline: Internet Firms Are Far Behind Cable Companies in Political Donations
abstract: The gap is slowly closing between the two sides in a coming debate over Internet regulation.
lead_paragraph: As a debate in Washington on Internet regulation hits a new phase, the gulf in political giving between the cable industry and Internet companies — which find themselves on opposite sides of the net-neutrality issue — remains large.

headline: Patricia Clarkson’s Beauty Routine
abstract: The actress takes her makeup cues from her mother, wearing red lipstick as her signature.
lead_paragraph: Patricia Clarkson, 54, has been acting for almost three decades, including lauded roles for film (“The Untouchables” and “Pieces of April”), television (“Frasier” and “Six Feet Under”) and theater. Her latest stage appearance is on Broadway, in “The Elephant Man” (previews started on Friday), in which she plays the pivotal Mrs. Kendal opposite Bradley Cooper. A native of New Orleans, Ms. Clarkson lives in Manhattan, in the West Village.

headline: The Jonathan Gruber Controversy and Washington’s Dirty Little Secret
abstract: It’s common for laws to be structured in ways that might not be very efficient but sound good for political consumption.
lead_paragraph: Suppose that Congress decides that everyone in America should have an iPhone. There are two ways it can do this:

headline: Pictures of the Day: Turkey and Elsewhere
abstract: Turkey and More — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: Turkey and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: In Shake-Up, Iraqi Premier Replaces 36 Commanders
abstract: It was the first public effort by Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi to put his mark on the security forces battling Islamic State militants.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — The recently installed Iraqi prime minister removed 36 military commanders in a sweeping shake-up on Wednesday, in his first public attempt to put his mark on the Iraqi security forces battling to retake territory from Islamic State militants.

headline: In the Words of Xi Jinping: Unraveling an Ancient Saying
abstract: The Chinese president’s idiom appeared to warn foreign journalists that if they want to avoid visa difficulties, it is up to them to satisfy Beijing.
lead_paragraph: Wait — isn’t belling the cat a good thing?

headline: For the Hard Work of Looking Good
abstract: Blue in Green and the Real McCoy’s in SoHo pass the men’s wear tests.
lead_paragraph: Buying clothes is easy; buying inspiration is hard. So come shop with me. Not to Blue in Green or the Real McCoy’s — we’ll get to them later — but let’s start in Midtown, at Kinokuniya, hot spot for Japanese printed matter. Down in the basement, plop down in the bustling magazine section, right by the full rack devoted to the men’s wear bibles.

headline: Kelsey Grammer to Join Broadway ‘Finding Neverland’
abstract: Mr. Grammer is to play the largely comic role of Charles Frohman, the theater producer of “Peter Pan” playwright J.M. Barrie.
lead_paragraph: Emmy Award winner Kelsey Grammer will return to Broadway this spring in the new musical “Finding Neverland,” playing the largely comic role of Charles Frohman, the theater producer of “Peter Pan” playwright J.M. Barrie, according to a show advertisement to be published on Sunday in The New York Times.

headline: J.C. Penney Reports Flat Sales
abstract: Consumer spending continues to hurt the retailer, whose net sales were below analysts’ expectations.
lead_paragraph: J.C. Penney reported flat sales growth on Wednesday in a sign that the troubled department store chain continues to suffer from sluggish consumer spending as it undergoes a major corporate turnaround.

headline: Nov. 12, 2014 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Turkey, Hong Kong, Afghanistan and the United States.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Turkey, Hong Kong, Afghanistan and the United States.

headline: Louis Vuitton Celebrates Monogram
abstract: A party for a new Louis Vuitton collection draw s lots of celebrities.
lead_paragraph: A party for a new Louis Vuitton collection draw s lots of celebrities.

headline: Louis Vuitton’s Famous Fans Celebrate a New Line of Bags
abstract: Nicole Kidman, Charlotte Gainsbourg and Chloë Sevigny were among the stars at a dinner at the Museum of Modern Art.
lead_paragraph: CHLOË SEVIGNY COMES from a long line of monogrammers.

headline: Victory for Polish Players at Rand Senior Teams
abstract: A deal from the Rand Senior Teams final at the world championships in China last month.
lead_paragraph: Bridge can be a strange game at times. Suppose you and your partner do not reach the ideal spot, suffering from a noticeable paucity of trumps. That possibility might not occur to your opponents. They might assume you have landed on your feet and as a consequence misdefend.

headline: With 2 New Jets, Chinese Manufacturer May Become Global Contender
abstract: The Commercial Aviation Corporation is getting attention after showcasing its two biggest projects at Airshow China.
lead_paragraph: ZHUHAI, China — In a private room at Airshow China set aside for discreet deal making, the Commercial Aviation Corporation of China has hung a picture of President Xi Jinping sitting in the cockpit of one of its new planes.

headline: Chelsea Clinton and Lupita Nyong’o Honored at the Glamour Women of the Year Gala
abstract: At the magazine’s Women of the Year gala, the honorees come from fashion and policy, comedy and philanthropy.
lead_paragraph: It was 10:30 p.m. at the restaurant Harlow on East 56th Street, and Samantha Power, the United States ambassador to the United Nations, was making her way to her dinner table.

headline: Taking a Fan’s-Eye View of a Much-Loved Band
abstract: “Pulp: A Film About Life, Death & Supermarkets,” a documentary by Florian Habicht, looks at the band Pulp through the eyes of its fans.
lead_paragraph: “Pulp: A Film About Life, Death & Supermarkets” puts a neighborhood spin on the typical rock documentary. Though there are the expected scenes of the Britpop rockers performing onstage and discussing their careers, the film is largely an affectionate look at the Pulp’s fans and its hometown, Sheffield, England.

headline: No Video. No Photos. No Names. Inside New York’s Ebola Monitoring Operation.
abstract: Anemona Hartocollis, a Times health reporter, chronicles her visit inside New York City’s Ebola monitoring operation.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s health department runs a 24-hour-a-day operation that defends against Ebola; its efforts include tracking more than 300 people for symptoms of the disease.

headline: The Ace Hotel Introduces Bottled Cocktails (and a Negroni Recipe)
abstract: The Downtown Los Angeles branch of the trendsetting hotel has debuted a collection of pre-mixed drinks. Here, how to make a batch of one classic for an instant party of eight.
lead_paragraph: House-pickled cocktail onions and orange juice à la minute have made the contemporary barfly more sophisticated than ever, but also more demanding. Drinks must be diluted just so, the choice of ingredients exact — and it all has to be done now, now, now. Many hotel bars, like those at the Ace and the Mystic, are leading the charge, which has only furthered public perception of the hotel-room minibar as an outdated amenity: Why settle for a rum and Coke when a perfectly mixed mojito is just an elevator ride away?

headline: Democrats Look to Raise Senator Warren’s Profile
abstract: Democrats said Wednesday that there was strong interest in raising Senator Elizabeth Warren’s profile in the Senate.
lead_paragraph: Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts was a hit on the campaign trail for Democrats and is a strong fund-raising draw — a fact that was not lost on Senate Democrats despite their pasting in last week’s elections.

headline: Fashion Plus Street Wear
abstract: Mark Anthony Green, a writer and artist, on what he’s wearing now. Also, ankle boots in burgundy, stacked rings and more shopping news.
lead_paragraph: Mark Anthony Green, a writer and artist, will show his hand- and machine-stitched text-based works at Art Basel in Miami Beach and in Mexico City early next year.

headline: U.S. Cracks Down on Debt Brokers Who Exposed Consumers’ Financial Details
abstract: More than 70,000 people may be at risk for identity fraud after debt brokers posted personal information about them online.
lead_paragraph: As part of a multiyear government crackdown on scams that target people in financial distress, a federal court in Washington has ordered two consumer debt brokers to notify more than 70,000 people that they may be at risk for identity or debt fraud after the companies posted financial details and other personal information about them online.

headline: Supreme Court Lets Gay Marriages Proceed in Kansas
abstract: The justices, with Antonin Scalia and Clarence Thomas dissenting, lifted a temporary stay that had been issued on Monday.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Wednesday allowed same-sex marriages to proceed in Kansas, lifting a temporary stay issued Monday by Justice Sonia Sotomayor.

headline: Met Asks Stars to Share Fiscal Pain
abstract: The Metropolitan Opera is asking its soloists, including some of its best-known stars, to voluntarily reduce their pay by as much as 7 percent to match the salary cuts other performers agreed to.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Opera, whose financial struggles led it to cut the pay of its orchestra, chorus, stagehands and other workers last summer after a labor battle, said Wednesday that it was also asking its solo singers voluntarily to lower their fees, including some of opera’s biggest stars.

headline: The Season’s Statement Topcoat
abstract: Discerning buyers are opting for tailored topcoats in interesting colors, fabrics and longer and larger silhouettes. Here are some options.
lead_paragraph: Discerning buyers are opting for tailored topcoats in interesting colors, fabrics and longer and larger silhouettes. Here are some options.

headline: Cisco Systems Income Falls, but Quarterly Revenue Sets Record as Pressures Mount
abstract: The once-dominant networking equipment manufacturer is battling more well-funded competitors and technology changes that threaten profits.
lead_paragraph: Cisco Systems, the world’s largest maker of the networking equipment that it says “powers the Internet,” could use a little energy of its own.

headline: North of Normal
abstract: The season’s new topcoat isn’t beige in color or in spirit. It’s a longer, fuller boundary pusher.
lead_paragraph: It’s mid-November, the afternoons stop short in darkness and the polar vortex, like a seasonal allergy, is coming to town.

headline: Bayou Meets Broadway: Staging ‘Duck Dynasty’
abstract: Members of the Robertson family of the A&E reality series “Duck Dynasty” have convinced a team from Broadway to bring their story to the stage, in Las Vegas for starters.
lead_paragraph: They’re not exactly the von Trapps trilling about edelweiss, but the Robertson family of the reality series “Duck Dynasty” wants to sing to you about faith and food, duck calls and swamp moss. And they’ve convinced a team from Broadway to bring their story to the stage, in Las Vegas for starters.

headline: Samuel Zell Said to Be Among Bidders for Albertsons Stores
abstract: Albertsons is looking to sell more than 100 grocery stores to help gain approval for a planned merger with the rival grocer Safeway.
lead_paragraph: Samuel Zell has his sights on the grocery business.

headline: Racy Gay Scenes in ‘How to Get Away With Murder’ Draw a Following
abstract: A gay TV character portrayed in a no-holds-barred way on “How to Get Away With Murder” is a draw at gay bars.
lead_paragraph: John Grauwiler was seated on a Chesterfield sofa in the back lounge area of the Atlas Social Club, a Hell’s Kitchen gay bar, on a Thursday night a couple of weeks ago, watching an episode of the new ABC series “How to Get Away With Murder.”

headline: The Sunny Palette of Jonathan Adler
abstract: Refreshing the Eau Palm Beach Resort & Spa with ocean and citrus colors.
lead_paragraph: Last year, when Jonathan Adler was asked to redesign the 309 guest rooms and suites of the Eau Palm Beach Resort & Spa in Manalapan, Fla., he worked with three colors.

headline: What’s the Best Way to Accessorize a Small Living Room?
abstract: Pay attention to the size of your furniture and the quantity of your knickknacks.
lead_paragraph: Q. ­What’s the best way to accessorize a sofa and coffee table in a small living room?

headline: It Goes Up and Stays Up
abstract: A new waterproofing system allows you to paper almost any part of your home.
lead_paragraph: Until recently, humid spaces like showers and kitchen backsplashes were hostile to wallpaper. But a new waterproofing system from Wall & Deco, an Italian company, allows you to paper almost any part of your home. With the Wet System, patterns are printed on 37-inch-wide fiberglass rolls and supplied along with a primer, adhesive and protective finish. Once installed, the material is resistant to dampness, yellowing, abrasion and harsh cleaning products. Wet System can be applied to most surfaces, including plasterboard, PVC and ceramic tiles. It is available in any of Wall & Deco’s hundreds of customizable designs, including, from left, Hanami and Hanamachi, for $250 a square yard. Information: 305-865-8577 or imoderni.com.

headline: Discounts at Kikkerland, Design Within Reach, Garnet Hill and Michele Varian
abstract: Sales on kitchen items, furniture and home accessories.
lead_paragraph: Ole Jensen melamine kitchenware for Room Copenhagen is 50 percent off at Kikkerland, from Thursday to Nov. 19 (a colander, about $40, is now about $20); 493 Avenue of the Americas (West 12th Street), 212-262-5000, kikkerland.nyc.

headline: Twentieth-Century Express Stop
abstract: A store specializing in American midcentury modern sets up in the Flatiron district.
lead_paragraph: After 18 years and two Hamptons locations, John Heilmann and Tim DiSalvo have opened a Homenature shop in Manhattan. Mr. Heilmann said that he chose the 6,000-square-foot loftlike space in the Flatiron district because the area “is such a home furnishings destination — you can walk around this neighborhood and get your whole house done.” Designed by Peter Weed, the shop offers upholstery and case goods, bedding, rugs and tabletop accessories all based on American midcentury designs. The owners also formed partnerships with textile companies like Libeco, a producer of Belgian linen, to develop fabrics that they sell by the yard. But the star just may be the lighting based on fixtures that once hung in the Prime Burger diner in Midtown. Mr. DiSalvo rescued the originals as the restaurant was about to be demolished and reproduced them. “How could we not?” he asked. Homenature is at 7 West 18th Street, 212-675-4136, homenature.com.

headline: Gravy Boats: Dripping With Charm
abstract: In time for Thanksgiving, sauce boats that put a finishing touch on the table.
lead_paragraph: A gravy boat may not be the kind of thing you use every day, but on Thanksgiving it’s hard to imagine doing without one.

headline: In Los Angeles, a Public Display of Affection
abstract: A house veiled in corrugated aluminum panels with countless cutouts of the Hebrew word for “love.”
lead_paragraph: When people ask Bob Hale about the house that he and his wife, Maxine Morris, built two years ago for their family in Los Angeles, he has a standard response. “I like to say I have a house wrapped in love,” Mr. Hale said.

headline: A Wineglass That’s Always Tipsy
abstract: There’s really no need for separate glasses for red and white wine now, and think how much table space you’ll save at your formal banquet.
lead_paragraph: Ron Arad, the Israeli-born, London-based designer, doesn’t appreciate a fussy table setting and is anything but a wine snob. Speaking at a press conference in Istanbul earlier this year, he said that the subtleties of wineglass varieties eluded him; a vintage registers on his palate as good or bad, no matter the size or shape of its container. Having been asked to create glassware for the Turkish manufacturer Pasabahce, he accepted that different vessels were necessary for red and white wine, but saw no reason that they couldn’t be conjoined. That is how he came up with the Red/White goblet, into which you can pour either color simply by which way you turn the glass. The goblet is one of eight pieces Mr. Arad designed for the Pasabahce glassware collection called Nude (the name refers to the objects’ transparency). It will be available in spring and cost $150 for a pair. Information: 212-683-1600.

headline: Frankie Grande, Ariana Grande’s Half Brother, Stars in ‘Rock of Ages’
abstract: Mr. Grande, an ex-captive on ‘Big Brother,’ returns to his Broadway roots.
lead_paragraph: “I’ve always loved Franz’s quirky lust for life and new things,” said Frankie Grande, 31, as he prepared for his Broadway star turn this week in the long-running musical “Rock of Ages.” “Everything is new and shiny and pretty to him.”

headline: A Rethought Bronze Age
abstract: Ingrid Donat, a French metal artist, on making limited-edition furniture, a calling encouraged by Giacometti’s brother.
lead_paragraph: Ingrid Donat, a sculptor who lives and works outside Paris, makes furniture of cast bronze. Her limited-edition pieces, which can weigh over 1,000 pounds, have streamlined forms and geometric patterning inspired by Art Deco design and primitive African art. Each is the result of a painstaking process involving drawings, wax models, prototypes, casting, welding, chiseling, sandblasting and patinating. One recent piece took two years to complete and required 15 helpers.

headline: Leaving Shame on a Lower Floor
abstract: With walls made of glass, the bathrooms in the penthouse apartments of new Manhattan towers leave little to the imagination. But only the birds will get an eyeful.
lead_paragraph: ­Among the many vertiginous renderings for the penthouse apartments at 432 Park Avenue, the nearly 1,400-foot-high Cuisenaire rod that topped off last month, is one of its master (or mistress) of the universe bathrooms, a glittering, reflective container of glass and marble. The image shows a huge egg-shaped tub planted before a 10-foot-square window, 90 or more stories up. All of Lower Manhattan is spread out like the view from someone’s private plane.

headline: Rehabbing an Old Piano
abstract: Here’s what you’ll need.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you’ll need.

headline: Crafts Classes With a Boozy Twist
abstract: Women (and some men) are going to bars to bring together two great American pastimes: crafts and drinking.
lead_paragraph: On first glimpse, the scene at Phebe’s, a burger-and-beer place on the Bowery in Manhattan, had all the usual elements of Monday night revelry. A dense crowd of men and women packed around the bar to eat wings, sip from bottles and watch the New York Giants take on the Indianapolis Colts on the overhead televisions.

headline: Cheap Piano With Strings Attached
abstract: Sure the Steinway was only $50, but the hidden costs of the writer’s D.I.Y. project to fix it up were incalculable.
lead_paragraph: ­Even these days, when cheap secondhand pianos are in plentiful supply, having been tossed aside to make way for compact, sophisticated keyboards, not many people can brag about owning a Steinway. Fewer own one that’s not worth bragging about. And then there’s the guy who actually went out of his way to buy one that’s not worth bragging about.

headline: Comcast Reiterates Net Neutrality Position at Showcase for New Product
abstract: At a media event in San Francisco on Wednesday, Comcast showed a new version of X1, its new TV operating system, and answered questions about President Obama’s recent call for strict net neutrality rules.
lead_paragraph: Comcast wants to be more than a wire for your television content and Internet. It also wants to be a serious technology company rivaling Apple and Google — an idea that has troubled supporters of a free and open Internet.

headline: Store Openings and Sales in New York City
abstract: The luxury Italian men’s wear label Caruso will open its first store; a showroom marks down some of the coolest emerging brands and more shopping news.
lead_paragraph: Openings

headline: Sedition Fight in Malaysia
abstract: A British colonial-era law is being used to charge and investigate politicians, activists, academics and students in Malaysia. But a law professor is challenging its constitutionality.
lead_paragraph: A British colonial-era law is being used to charge and investigate politicians, activists, academics and students in Malaysia. But a law professor is challenging its constitutionality.

headline: The Civil Rights of Pregnant Women
abstract: Doctors discuss medical ethics and the concepts of patient autonomy and informed consent.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Food Carts at a Temple of Fine Art
abstract: Readers question the museum’s position and ask what the city’s rules are for vendors.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Response to President Xi Jinping
abstract: The Times will not alter its coverage to suit the whims of the Chinese leader or any other government.
lead_paragraph: During their summit meeting in Beijing, President Obama and President Xi Jinping of China made much of their agreement to ease visa restrictions for businessmen, students and tourists.

headline: Life Imitates Propaganda in Egypt
abstract: Talking politics with a foreigner in a cafe in Cairo now strikes some Egyptians as grounds for arrest.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, as the forces of revolution and counterrevolution struggled for control in Egypt, a mysterious public service announcement warned Egyptians against the seemingly innocuous behavior of chatting with foreigners in cafes.

headline: A Mustache Comeback? Not So Fast
abstract: A number of scruff-chic stars are trying to revive this retro motif, but it carries serious baggage.
lead_paragraph: When James Franco was photographed at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art’s Art & Film gala this month with a shaved head and Ned Flanders mustache, Twitter users were not kind.

headline: Pakistan Seeks Dissidents’ Arrest
abstract: Warrants were issued for the opposition leaders Imran Khan and Muhammad Tahir-ul Qadri for their part in leading a protest movement.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A Pakistani court has issued warrants for the arrest of the opposition leaders Imran Khan and Muhammad Tahir-ul Qadri for their part in a protest movement that paralyzed the Pakistani capital last summer, state television reported late Wednesday.

headline: Campaign Contributions: Does Money Equal Speech?
abstract: Readers respond to a column by Joe Nocera, “Big Money Wins Again in a Romp.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Marijuana Arrests
abstract: Edward Lemansky, a reader, writes that “the real issue is selective enforcement.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Woman of Many Lands
abstract: Mary Buhr, a reader, shares her experience of acquiring citizenship in Germany and the United States.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Stop China’s Ivory Trade
abstract: Aviva Cantor, an animal-rights activist, urges the United States and others to press China.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Coloring Real Life With Animation
abstract: Animation is an important component in three recent documentaries, and their directors explain why they used that device.
lead_paragraph: How to make that long talking-head interview visually interesting? What to do if certain images essential to your story aren’t available? These are common issues that documentary makers resolve with help from all kinds of tools: archival footage, re-enactments and even animation.

headline: Summary of FIFA Investigation on World Cup Bidding Is Set to Be Released
abstract: Hans-Joachim Eckert, the German judge reviewing a report on the investigation into FIFA’s awarding of the 2018 and 2022 World Cups, will release a summary of his findings on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The German judge reviewing a report on the investigation into FIFA’s awarding of the 2018 and 2022 World Cups will release a summary of his findings on Thursday, although he is not expected to recommend that either host country lose its rights to the tournament.

headline: The Map Apps That Move You in the Right Direction
abstract: Improvements to navigation systems keep on coming, and a new rival may mean the competition will heat up.
lead_paragraph: IT’S been a long time since most of us carried a stand-alone GPS device around with us. The smartphone gets us where we need to go, thanks to built-in mapping and navigation.

headline: Protect Those Who Protect Our Food
abstract: We need new labor laws for restaurant, farm and slaughterhouse workers.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — EVERY year, 5.5 million people are sickened by norovirus, a highly contagious gastrointestinal bug. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, norovirus is the leading cause of food-borne illness in the United States and is spread primarily by “infected food workers.” Last year cooks, waiters and other workers were involved in about 70 percent of the outbreaks.

headline: Under the Ships in the Suez Canal
abstract: Invasive species are crossing into the Mediterranean.
lead_paragraph: THIS summer, President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt announced that the Suez Canal would be expanded — to around double its size. The canal is the fastest way to sail from Asia to Europe, a shortcut that brings Egypt $5 billion of revenue a year. But in addition to hosting 10 percent of the world’s shipping traffic, the canal is a major conduit for invasive species.

headline: Law in the Raw
abstract: The Supreme Court’s decision to take up the Affordable Care Act again raises a question: Is it a court? Or a collection of politicians in robes?
lead_paragraph: Nearly a week has gone by since the Supreme Court’s unexpected decision to enlist in the latest effort to destroy the Affordable Care Act, and the shock remains unabated. “This is Bush v. Gore all over again,” one friend said as we struggled to absorb the news last Friday afternoon. “No,” I replied. “It’s worse.”

headline: Race, to the Finish
abstract: Let’s review how we got to this point where African-Americans vote so overwhelmingly Democratic and are suspicious of Republican motives.
lead_paragraph: Last week, the economist and former Richard Nixon speechwriter Ben Stein went on Fox News and delivered a racial tirade completely detached from the the anchor’s line of questioning.

headline: New York Initiative to Help Other Cities Clear Rape-Kit Backlogs
abstract: Cyrus R. Vance Jr., the Manhattan district attorney, announced a program to assist other jurisdictions with untested rape kits, which number in the hundreds of thousands nationally.
lead_paragraph: In 2000, New York had 17,000 untested rape kits, a yearslong accumulation of potential evidence in some of the city’s most violent crimes. Over the next four years, in a push to clear the backlog, the city had the kits tested. The result was 49 indictments connected to unsolved cases in Manhattan alone.

headline: Hasbro Is Said to Be in Talks to Buy DreamWorks Animation
abstract: The DreamWorks chief executive, Jeffrey Katzenberg, is said to be seeking more than $30 a share for the studio, Hollywood’s smallest.
lead_paragraph: Shrek could soon share a home with the Transformers and little ponies like Fluttershy and Twilight Sparkle if their corporate parents are able to seal a deal.

headline: Why I Don’t Kill Myself
abstract: Little by little, the slow third-world bus of my demons had been making its way back to me.
lead_paragraph: I told the psychiatrist I was depressed. “Have you ever thought of killing yourself?” she said. I could see her getting ready to check off “Poses danger to self or others” and send me away, the way my oldest brother had once been sent away, with a diagnosis of schizophrenia, and dosed heavily with Thorazine. Come to think of it, maybe he committed himself, but I know the part about the Thorazine was right. I stole one of his pills once, ate it and got into the shower, and almost passed out on the tiles.

headline: Congress Returns After 6 Weeks Away, but Immediate Actions Are Few
abstract: The denouement of Election Day continued to play out as the House and the Senate scheduled dueling votes to try to influence the outcome of the unresolved Louisiana Senate race.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As newly victorious and recently vanquished members of Congress descended Wednesday on Capitol Hill, defeated Democrats trudged in for some of their final votes, ebullient Republicans toured their new digs, and the denouement of Election Day continued to play out as the House and the Senate scheduled dueling votes to try to influence the outcome of the lone unresolved Senate race in Louisiana.

headline: Germany: 9 Held in Antiterrorism Raids
abstract: The police in the Cologne area detained nine men early Wednesday and searched at least 20 homes in raids against people suspected of supporting terrorism.
lead_paragraph: The police in the Cologne area detained nine men early Wednesday and searched at least 20 homes in raids against people suspected of supporting terrorism. Two, a 58-year-old Pakistani and a 31-year-old German, are suspected of helping at least five men from Germany travel to Syria and join terrorists there, the federal prosecutor’s office said in a statement. The seven other suspects helped such efforts, it said, by stealing from schools and churches, and preparing vehicles and false documents. The Pakistani and the German were specifically accused of supporting the Islamic State and two other terrorist groups.

headline: Churchill Downs to Buy Big Fish Games for Up to $885 Million
abstract: Churchill Downs, which owns casinos and racetracks, has become the latest company to make a bold move into mobile game.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — The company behind the Kentucky Derby may already have the greatest two minutes in sports. Now, it is betting big on two of the hottest words in technology as well: mobile games.

headline: The Lame-Duck Dynasty
abstract: Keeping up with Congress these days is almost like watching a reality TV show. What would we name it?
lead_paragraph: How am I going to get you interested in the lame-duck Congress? Did you even know they came back? Perhaps it’s like reports that Randy Jackson is leaving “American Idol” — the amazing news is that “American Idol” is still on the air.

headline: Iran: Pentagon Rebuts Claim on Drone
abstract: Iran’s claim to have not only replicated but test-flown its version of a sophisticated bat-winged American spy drone captured in late 2011 is a gross exaggeration, the Pentagon said Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Iran’s claim to have not only replicated but test-flown its version of a sophisticated bat-winged American spy drone captured in late 2011 is a gross exaggeration, the Pentagon said Wednesday. A spokesman, Col. Steve Warren, said at a news briefing that “there is no way it matches American technology,” playing down reports in Iran’s press that Iranian technicians had reverse-engineered the RQ-170 stealth aircraft, made an exact replica and tested it in flight this week. The original American drone, made by Lockheed-Martin, was captured 140 miles from the border with Afghanistan. American officials attributed the loss of the drone to a technical malfunction. The Iranians displayed it publicly, rejecting President Obama’s request that they return it to the United States.

headline: J.C. Penney and Macy’s Post Lackluster Sales Before Holidays
abstract: Sales were tepid at both chains, causing executives to wonder when improvements in the economy and employment would become palpable in their stores.
lead_paragraph: J.C. Penney and Macy’s both reported lackluster sales in the third quarter, the latest sign that despite low gas prices and improving job numbers, retailers just cannot persuade shoppers to spend.

headline: A Video Network Devoted to ‘All Things Home’
abstract: As an executive at a furniture company in North Carolina, Jason Harris discovered how well video could sell and decided to start an online video network dedicated to home décor.
lead_paragraph: PART of the lore of CBS is how William S. Paley, who built the company into a communications empire, became its president in 1928: Commercials for the family’s cigar business on a station that was part of the struggling CBS radio network increased sales so much that Paley realized what a powerful advertising medium radio could be.

headline: Jameis Winston Hearing Is Postponed
abstract: A disciplinary hearing concerning the allegation that the Florida State quarterback raped a fellow student in late 2012 has been postponed to Dec. 1 after his lawyer requested more time to prepare.
lead_paragraph: A disciplinary hearing to examine whether Jameis Winston violated Florida State’s honor code has been postponed to Dec. 1 after his lawyer requested more time to prepare, according to a person with knowledge of the proceedings.

headline: Politicians, Teens and Birth Control
abstract: Teenagers may be terrible at planning ahead, but politicians and our country are, too, by failing to invest in comprehensive sex education and birth control.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a story of utter irresponsibility: About one-third of American girls become pregnant as teenagers.

headline: De Blasio Balancing His Promises With Reality
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio is championing liberal values nationally, but at home, he is being criticized by the same police critics whose cause he backed during his campaign.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio on Wednesday issued a broadside to national Democrats, urging the party to embrace liberal values and attributing its midterm losses to a lack of fidelity to the progressive cause.

headline: Marge Roukema, Congresswoman, Dies at 85; Backed Family Leave
abstract: Mrs. Roukema was a Republican whose moderate views often put her at odds with her party, most notably in her support of the Family and Medical Leave Act.
lead_paragraph: Marge Roukema, an outspoken 11-term Republican congresswoman from northern New Jersey whose moderate views on social issues often put her at odds with her own party, most notably in her dedication to winning approval for the Family and Medical Leave Act, died on Wednesday in Wyckoff, N.J. She was 85.

headline: Florida Finds Tricky Balance Over Feeding of the Homeless
abstract: How to feed, help and handle the ever-present homeless population in a state that draws an outsized share of the dispossessed is a growing debate.
lead_paragraph: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. — As dusk settled over the city’s main beach, Arnold Abbott, frail but determined, broke the law late Wednesday afternoon. Mr. Abbott, a 90-year-old World War II veteran, stood on the pavement and piled tilapia and rice and beans on plates for dozens of homeless people. A crowd stood and watched, waiting to see what the police would do.

headline: In China, Blunt Talk to Reporters on Access
abstract: China’s leader, Xi Jinping, appeared to state as policy something long hinted: a link between unfavorable news coverage and denials of reporters’ visas.
lead_paragraph: For years, Western news organizations had tried to interpret the Chinese government’s position toward critical press coverage, sensing that Beijing would punish journalists for reports it did not like by miring visa requests in bureaucracy, or simply declining them.

headline: Pressure Mounts on F.C.C. Chief Over Net Neutrality Rules
abstract: As Tom Wheeler tries to thread the needle of politics and public policy, he must face down Congress and a technology industry wary of regulations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Even before President Obama issued his forceful call this week for “the strongest possible rules” to protect an open Internet, Tom Wheeler, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, was in a tight spot.

headline: Climate Goals Pledged by China and the U.S.
abstract: Last year’s historic agreement includes a new goal for U.S. carbon emissions and a commitment by China to curb its emissions and rely more heavily on renewable and nuclear sources of energy.
lead_paragraph: Last year’s historic agreement includes a new goal for U.S. carbon emissions and a commitment by China to curb its emissions and rely more heavily on renewable and nuclear sources of energy.

headline: A Quake Warning, Before It Strikes
abstract: The University of California, Berkeley, is working on a smartphone app that would warn users before a quake hits.
lead_paragraph: A 10-second warning may not sound like much, but when it comes to earthquakes, it’s enough time to take cover.

headline: Andy Murray Hits Significant Bumps After Minor Surgery
abstract: Murray has struggled since undergoing what his management team called “minor back surgery” in September 2013, but has shown flashes of his old self at the ATP World Tour Finals, where he will play Roger Federer on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The way this year has unfolded for Andy Murray, not many fans would have expected a routine journey for him at the ATP World Tour Finals.

headline: Army Cuts Hit Officers Hard, Especially Ones Up From Ranks
abstract: Faced with declining budgets, the Army has had to cut its force, and, for reasons the Army has not explained, the largest group of officers being pushed out — nearly one in five — began as enlisted soldiers.
lead_paragraph: FAYETTEVILLE, N.C. — For all the insecurities of war, Capt. Elder Saintjuste always figured the one thing he could count on from the Army was job security.

headline: A New Model for Affordable Housing
abstract: Astoria Cove on the East River in Queens is an example of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s commitment to create or save 200,000 affordable apartments in 10 years.
lead_paragraph: Get ready for Astoria Cove, a development on the East River in Queens, with 1,700 apartments, a new school, supermarket, green spaces and other amenities over 2.2 million square feet. The project won the approval of the City Council’s Land Use Committee on Wednesday, all but assuring that the full Council will approve it by the end of the month. It will transform a neglected stretch of waterfront. It is also a crucial test of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s ability to meet his soaring promises on affordable housing.

headline: Daniel Meltzer, Protector of the Beacon Theater, Dies at 74
abstract: A writer and teacher with a varied career, Mr. Meltzer led the successful fight to rescue one of New York City’s most grandiose showplaces from being turned into a discothèque.
lead_paragraph: Daniel B. Meltzer, a writer and teacher and perfervid New Yorker who led the successful fight to rescue one of the city’s most grandiose showplaces, the cavernous Beacon Theater, from transformation into a discothèque, died on Nov. 6 in Manhattan. He was 74.

headline: Wanting to Help Others, but in Need of Some Himself
abstract: Over the past year, Miguel Rodriguez’s desire to have a positive impact has intensified, though it was not always so clear.
lead_paragraph: Miguel Rodriguez’s new interview attire — shiny black shoes; dapper white, blue and black dress shirts; three handkerchiefs; and three regimental-striped ties — led not to a position on Wall Street, but to a job installing solar panels on city roofs. And that is just the way he likes it.

headline: Climate Accord Relies on Environmental Policies Now in Place
abstract: The United States and China should both be able to meet the stated goals by aggressively pursuing policies that are largely underway, analysts said.
lead_paragraph: For all the pronouncements about the United States and China reaching a historic climate pact, the agreement they announced Wednesday does not signal a seismic shift in policies by either nation, experts said.

headline: In Deaths of Dogs in Arizona, a Human Story of Loss and Intrigue
abstract: The deaths of 22 dogs in June at a boarding business in Gilbert, Ariz., remain a big story, with a senator’s son indicted and people still mourning their pets.
lead_paragraph: GILBERT, Ariz. — They had names like Snickers and Zoey, Maci and Buick. They were golden retrievers, beagles, Shih Tzus — dogs coddled by owners reluctant to leave them with strangers.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 12, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Debts Canceled by Bankruptcy Still Mar Consumer Credit Scores
abstract: The practice, under investigation by the Justice Department, affects tens of thousands of Americans, impairing their ability to secure housing and jobs.
lead_paragraph: In the netherworld of consumer debt, there are zombies: bills that cannot be killed even by declaring personal bankruptcy.

headline: Carol Ann Susi, Unseen Actress on ‘Big Bang Theory,’ Is Dead at 62
abstract: Ms. Susi was a character actress best known for the off-screen role of a haranguing mother on the CBS sitcom “The Big Bang Theory.”
lead_paragraph: Carol Ann Susi, a character actress who was seen on numerous television shows but who was best known for a role in which she was only heard — the always off-screen mother of a character on the CBS sitcom “The Big Bang Theory” — died on Tuesday in Los Angeles. She was 62.

headline: In Climate Deal With China, Obama May Set 2016 Theme
abstract: The landmark agreement to cut greenhouse gas pollution is a bet by President Obama that the environment will be a winning cause for Democrats.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s landmark agreement with China to cut greenhouse gas pollution is a bet by the president and Democrats that on the issue of climate change, American voters are far ahead of Washington’s warring factions and that the environment will be a winning cause in the 2016 presidential campaign.

headline: A Soup Kitchen Where Even the Staff Is Needy
abstract: “Grand Concourse,” by Heidi Schreck, goes behind the scenes at a soup kitchen in the Bronx.
lead_paragraph: Matters of faith and friendship, and secrets and lies, are blended into the stew in “Grand Concourse,” a modest but likable new play by Heidi Schreck set in a church soup kitchen in the Bronx. Ms. Schreck’s drama, which opened on Wednesday night at Playwrights Horizons, unfolds mostly during the busy work days in the kitchen, where piles of chopped vegetables are poured into big vats under the brisk supervision of a nun named Shelley, played by the ever-excellent Quincy Tyler Bernstine.

headline: Go Hand to Hand
abstract: Tracy Gray has her own way of stacking things.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — I was of two minds about Tracy Gray’s puzzle.

headline: Split Fortunes for Giants’ Fragile Ground Game
abstract: While it appeared Rashad Jennings, the Giants’ leading rusher, would return to action Sunday after missing the last four games, Jacquian Williams, the team’s top tackler, will not play because of a concussion.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Rashad Jennings, the Giants’ top running back, has missed the last four games because of a knee sprain, and each of those games featured an anemic Giants running attack and ended in a Giants loss. But it now appears that Jennings, who is running again without discomfort, will return to the team’s lineup for Sunday’s game against the San Francisco 49ers.

headline: No More Jail Time in New York Cannibal Case
abstract: Gilberto Valle, a former New York City police officer whose conviction for conspiracy to kidnap, kill and eat women was overturned, was sentenced to time served on a lesser charge.
lead_paragraph: From the beginning, he had been called the Cannibal Cop.

headline: Health Officials Reassess Strategy to Combat Ebola in Liberia
abstract: As the rate of new infections has slowed, American and Liberian officials are debating whether to shift money that was planned for the centers into other programs to combat future outbreaks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the rate of new Ebola infections in Liberia has slowed, American and Liberian officials are debating whether to build all 17 planned Ebola treatment centers in the country or to shift money from the Obama administration that was planned for the centers into other programs to combat future outbreaks.

headline: Whose Work Is Homework?
abstract: Should parents help their children with homework? Or do they end up doing more harm than good?

headline: Cy Young Winners: Clayton Kershaw Is Unanimous, Corey Kluber Is Unexpected
abstract: The Dodgers’ Kershaw was named the National League Cy Young Award winner for the third time, while the Indians’ Kluber beat out Felix Hernandez for the A.L. honor.
lead_paragraph: Clayton Kershaw signed a $215 million contract extension last winter after winning another National League Cy Young Award for the Los Angeles Dodgers. He lived up to the paycheck with an extraordinary season, the best in a glittering career that began with a first-round draft selection.

headline: U.A.W. Urges N.F.L. to Bargain Changes
abstract: The United Automobile Workers has called on the league to collectively bargain any changes to its personal conduct policy.
lead_paragraph: The United Automobile Workers has called on the N.F.L. to collectively bargain any changes to its personal conduct policy. In a letter sent to the league last week, the union, one of the nation’s largest, said the “league’s go-it-alone and unilateral management actions” have “resulted in fan backlash, sponsor unrest and damage to the sterling N.F.L. brand.”

headline: Harry Pearson, Founder of Absolute Sound, Dies at 77
abstract: Mr. Pearson was a journalist and audiophile who founded a magazine for connoisseurs of high-fidelity audio in the 1970s.
lead_paragraph: Harry Pearson, a journalist and audiophile who founded The Absolute Sound, a magazine for connoisseurs of high-fidelity audio in the 1970s and the locus of a backlash against CDs in the 1980s, died on Nov. 4 in Sea Cliff, N.Y. He was 77.

headline: Fishermen in Brazil Save a River Goliath, and Their Livelihoods
abstract: Efforts to save the pirarucu, one of the world’s largest freshwater fish, have been a success while offering a strategy for fending off a broader freshwater extinction crisis.
lead_paragraph: TEFÉ, Brazil — As the howler monkeys roared near this outpost in the far reaches of the Amazon rain forest, Valdenor da Silva grasped his harpoon and guided his canoe through the dazzling floodplain mosaic of lakes and channels in a quest for his prey.

headline: Connecticut Father’s Activities Detailed on Day Son Died in Hot Car
abstract: Kyle Seitz, 36, left his 15-month-old son, Benjamin, unattended for hours on July 7 in Ridgefield, Conn. If convicted, he could serve up to a year in prison.
lead_paragraph: DANBURY, Conn. — In some ways, this past July 7 was like any other summer day for the Seitz family.

headline: Web of Incentives in Fatal Indian Sterilizations

lead_paragraph: AMSENA, India — Rekha Nirmalkar already had children, and her family was poor. So when a local health worker offered her twice her husband’s daily wages to get sterilization surgery, she jumped at the chance.

lead_paragraph: It would be the first desalination plant on the Hudson River, converting the brackish waters of the lower Hudson salted by ocean tides into fresh water that the residents of Rockland County would drink.

headline: Decree by Sisi Could Lead Egypt to Free Journalist
abstract: The decree enabling the president to deport non-Egyptians convicted of crimes could aid an imprisoned journalist, Peter Greste.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi issued a law on Wednesday allowing him to deport non-Egyptians convicted of crimes to their home countries, a move that could lead to the release of at least one of three journalists from the Al Jazeera English news channel who have been imprisoned for almost a year.

headline: As Last-Gasp Shot Fails, Knicks Can Only Sigh
abstract: The Knicks faced an Orlando team playing its second game in 27 hours but could not take advantage.
lead_paragraph: The Orlando Magic arrived at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday for their second game (in two countries) in a 27-hour span. They were hoping to avoid the pitfalls of the dreaded back-to-back, one of the more exhausting realities of the N.B.A. schedule.

headline: Researchers to Test New Treatments in Countries Hit Hardest by Ebola
abstract: Until now, experimental treatments have mainly been available to the small number of patients treated in the United States and Europe, not Africans at the epidemic’s epicenter.
lead_paragraph: Researchers on Wednesday announced that they would soon begin the first clinical trials to test experimental treatments for Ebola in the West African countries most affected by the outbreak.

headline: Financial Pressures Ease on Students, Studies Say

lead_paragraph: After years of steep increases in college prices and student debt, turning both into major economic and public policy concerns, the real costs of college and student borrowing have leveled off, according to three studies being released on Thursday.

headline: Gift From Ballmer Will Expand Computer Science Faculty at Harvard
abstract: Mr. Ballmer, the former Microsoft chief executive, will make a financial contribution to Harvard that will enable the school to expand its computer science faculty by about 50 percent.
lead_paragraph: Harvard University counts two of the most successful computer programmers in the world — William H. Gates, the Microsoft co-founder, and Mark Zuckerberg, the Facebook chief executive — as former students. But the university, one of the most respected overall in the world, has never quite made its way into the elite tier of computer science programs.

headline: A Warhol Leads a Night of Soaring Prices at Christie’s
abstract: A 1963 Andy Warhol painting of Elvis Presley pointing a gun sold for nearly $82 million, contributing to an $852.9 million auction total.
lead_paragraph: Elvis Presley, as depicted in Warhol’s 1963 painting, looked ready for a shootout, staring at the viewer with his gun pointed. But there was no need to pull the trigger: The singer beat out Warhol’s Marlon Brando, along with 78 other works Christie’s had packed into its contemporary art sale on Wednesday night in Manhattan. While Elvis took home the evening’s top price — selling for nearly $82 million — it was just one big number in a night filled with soaring prices.

lead_paragraph: Shortly after Francisco Cervelli signed with the Yankees on March 1, 2003, five days before his 17th birthday, he made his way to the team’s minor league complex in Tampa, Fla. There, he met Derek Jeter, who gave him a pair of spikes as a gift. It was a gesture that made Cervelli, of Venezuela, feel instantly welcome.

headline: A Heart Simulator, Meant to Help the Real Thing

lead_paragraph: Imagine, as a surgeon or medical student, being able to walk around inside an immersive three-dimensional simulation of a beating heart.

headline: Kansas Announces Big Budget Gap; True Gap May Be Even Larger

headline: Latin America Is Losing Its Catholic Identity
abstract: The Roman Catholic Church’s claim on the region is lessening as a younger generation turns to Protestantism, a Pew study found.
lead_paragraph: These are heady days for Roman Catholics in Latin America. For the first time, one of their own is serving as pope, providing a visible reminder of the importance the region plays in the global church.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 2 P.M. (TCM) GIGI (1958) A teenage tomboy (Leslie Caron) in Belle Epoque Paris is forced by her grandmother (Hermione Gingold) to be educated as a courtesan at the hand of her great-aunt (Isabel Jeans) in this movie musical, directed by Vincente Minnelli from the novel by Colette, with a book and score by Lerner and Loewe, and production design by Cecil Beaton. Maurice Chevalier is the man about town whose blasé bachelor nephew (Louis Jourdan) treats Gigi like a sister — until suddenly he doesn’t. “There won’t be much point in anybody trying to produce a film of ‘My Fair Lady’ for a while,” Bosley Crowther wrote in The New York Times, noting the similarities between that musical and “Gigi.” “But don’t think this point of resemblance is made in criticism of the film, for ‘Gigi’ is a charming entertainment that can stand on its own two legs. It is not only a charming comprehension of the spicy confection of Colette, but it is also a lovely and lyrical enlargement upon that story’s flavored mood and atmosphere.”

headline: U.S. Policy Makers Could See Opportunity in China’s Rise
abstract: “It would be a mistake to view increased frictions as the result of inattention or clumsy policy,” says Ely Ratner, deputy director of the Asia-Pacific Security Program at the Center for a New American Security.
lead_paragraph: The relationship between the United States and China has been in the spotlight this week as President Obama and President Xi Jinping dined with each other in Beijing, took short walks in the wintry night air and announced agreements on climate change, trade and military cooperation. On Wednesday, after eating his fill of Peking duck during the visit, his second to China since taking office, Mr. Obama flew to Myanmar, while Mr. Xi returned to the business of governing the world’s most populous nation.

headline: New Recall by Honda After Death in Malaysia Is Tied to Takata Airbag

headline: Why Are So Few Blockbuster Drugs Invented Today?
abstract: Our high-tech process of pharmaceutical research is broken — and the solution might be old-fashioned trial and error.
lead_paragraph: In the fall of 1999, a young chemical engineer named Todd Zion left his job at Eastman Kodak to enroll in the Ph.D. program at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. While looking for a subject to research, Zion noticed a grant proposal, never funded, that another graduate student had written on the subject of drug delivery. One possibility mentioned in the proposal was the development of a kind of insulin that would automatically respond to changes in blood-sugar levels, becoming active only when needed to maintain healthy levels around the clock. If it worked, the sugar-sensitive version could transform the lives of the six million people with diabetes in the United States who use insulin. No longer would they have to test their blood-sugar levels multiple times per day and try to calculate how much insulin to take. The self-regulating insulin would curtail high sugar levels, which raise the risk of long-term complications, and eradicate, or at least reduce, the most dangerous short-term complication: hypoglycemia, when sugar levels fall so low that they can cause confusion, unconsciousness, seizures and even death.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | European Space Agency’s Spacecraft Lands on Comet’s Surface
abstract: What is the Philae, and when and where did it land?
lead_paragraph: In “Landing on a Comet, a Mission Aims to Unlock the Mysteries of Earth,” Kenneth Chang covers the European Space Agency’s ambitious mission.

headline: Good Pictures, Bad Timing
abstract: When a legendary curator chided Will Brown to find his way as a photographer, he set aside images he had made of his Philadelphia neighborhood. Today, those photos attest to the changes in the area.
lead_paragraph: Occasionally, the wrong advice at the wrong time can have devastating effects on a photographer’s confidence. Such was the case in 1974, when Will Brown, then 37, showed his photographs to John Szarkowski, the Museum of Modern Art’s legendary curator.

headline: Obama Prods Myanmar Back Toward Democracy

headline: Tuning Out Colleague’s Protests, Judge Clears FIFA World Cup Bidding

lead_paragraph: One soccer official asked a potential World Cup host for personal favors, like a job for a relative, and found them readily granted. Other executives were more circumspect, requesting million-dollar investments in their home countries instead of direct payments. Still others simply dealt in cold cash.

lead_paragraph: LONDON – DP World, the Dubai port operator, said on Thursday that it had agreed to acquire Economic Zones World, a developer and operator of industrial parks, for $2.6 billion in cash, including debt.

headline: Another ‘Putin Tiger’ Reported to Have Crossed Into China
abstract: Ustin, one of three Siberian tigers the Russian president released in May, was reported to be on Bolshoi Ussuriysky Island, which sits in Russia and China.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia drew attention at an economic summit meeting in Beijing this week when he draped a blanket over the shoulders of China’s first lady and awkwardly clapped President Obama on the arm. But while Mr. Putin has now left China for meetings in the Russian city of Vladivostok, his legacy remains.

headline: Ebola and the Lost Children of Sierra Leone
abstract: Shutting schools doesn’t assure safety from Ebola. It damages chances for a nation’s recovery.
lead_paragraph: Arriving at Port Loko, one of the largest towns in the north of Sierra Leone, is like reaching a country under siege. In the face of Ebola, the 500,000 inhabitants of this district have been sealed off from the world, stigmatized like a cellblock of criminals, and left largely to fend for themselves. Even to bring them food and schoolbooks, you need a government pass. And they are not alone. Counting other districts under quarantine, more than a third of the nation cannot move freely.

lead_paragraph: Hasbro is in talks to buy DreamWorks Animation in a deal that would be an unusual union of toy maker and animation studio, Andrew Ross Sorkin and Michael J. de la Merced report in DealBook, citing people briefed on the matter. Should a deal be reached, it would come more than a month after the studio held talks with another prospective buyer, the Japanese telecommunications company SoftBank. Under the current terms of the proposed deal, Hasbro would pay a mix of cash and stock, though an exact price has not yet been determined, one of the people said.

headline: Mandated to Be a Best Seller
abstract: “Quotations of Chairman Mao” at the Grolier Club includes many versions of “The Little Red Book” that became a de rigueur accessory in Chinese pockets.
lead_paragraph: “QUOTATIONS FROM CHAIRMAN MAO” is the book that gave new meaning to the term “must-read.” First published in 1964, and distributed by the hundreds of millions, it was the catechism of the Cultural Revolution, a compendium of snippets from speeches and writings by Mao Zedong that each and every Chinese citizen was expected not just to flip through, but also to study, memorize and recite.

headline: Pfizer and Aid Groups Team Up on Contraceptive for Developing World
abstract: Groups including the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation aim to help bring an easier-to-inject form of Depo-Provera to 69 countries.
lead_paragraph: Depo-Provera, an injectable contraceptive given once every three months, is already a popular choice of women in developing countries, who value the convenience and discretion of not having to take a daily birth control pill.
