headline: A Guide to Tokyo, From an Outsider (and Insider)
abstract: The author, who once lived in Tokyo, shares some of her favorite spots, as well as her struggles with alienation in the city.
lead_paragraph: By 3 a.m., I was dancing to “Material Girl” with a Japanese man in a plaid vest. We were on the crowded dance floor of a disco on the second floor of a nondescript office building tucked at the end of a little alley in Shinjuku Ni-chome, Tokyo’s gay district.

headline: Readers Respond: On the Truth About the Wars
abstract: Readers wrote about a public reckoning for our wars in Iraq and Afghanistan and the sacrifices of our troops in comments on Daniel P. Bolger’s Op-Ed, “The Truth About the Wars.”
lead_paragraph: New York Times readers accustomed to expressing dissent about United States military action around the world welcomed Daniel P. Bolger’s candid call for an end to mythmaking about the “two failed wars” in Iraq and Afghanistan.

headline: 1939: Light at Night in Paris criticized
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Light at Night in Paris Criticized by Officials in 1939.
lead_paragraph: A halo of light, which would be visible to enemy airplanes miles away, hangs over Paris at night, representatives of the Passive Defense organization complained yesterday in a meeting in Paris.

headline: India Discusses Public Food Stockpiling
abstract: India’s commerce minister, Nirmala Sitharaman, announced an agreement between her country and the United States on public stockpiling of food, clearing the way for a global trade deal.
lead_paragraph: India’s commerce minister, Nirmala Sitharaman, announced an agreement between her country and the United States on public stockpiling of food, clearing the way for a global trade deal.

headline: It’s McConnell, Unanimously
abstract: Senator Mitch McConnell was elected unanimously as incoming Senate majority leader. Caucus gives him a standing ovation.
lead_paragraph: G.O.P. Leader’s New Role Could Take Strained White House Ties to Next Level

headline: Liberia President, Citing Ebola Gains, Ends State of Emergency
abstract: President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf said she would not extend the state of emergency, which had angered critics.
lead_paragraph: MONROVIA, Liberia — President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf of Liberia announced an end to a national state of emergency in an address broadcast across the nation on Thursday, citing progress in the fight against Ebola.

headline: Fantasy Football: Week 11 Matchup Breakdown
abstract: Tom Brady, Philip Rivers, Frank Gore and DeSean Jackson are among the players with favorable matchups in Week 11.
lead_paragraph: Now is a good time to reflect on and appreciate the consistency and flat-out greatness of Peyton Manning.

headline: Boy George Ailment Forces Culture Club to Cancel Tours
abstract: Boy George, the lead singer of Culture Club, has a throat polyp and the band has canceled its American and British tours.
lead_paragraph: The American and British tours that Culture Club announced during the summer have been canceled, a spokeswoman for the band said Thursday, because Boy George, the band’s flamboyant lead singer, has developed a throat polyp. The polyp was discovered this week, and Boy George’s doctor has advised him not to sing and that an operation may be required.

headline: Liberal Donors Looking 6 Years Ahead
abstract: Meeting in Washington this week, an alliance of liberal philanthropists is laying plans for what it hopes will be a long-term resurgence of progressive ideas.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — There was no ideological soul-searching, few recriminations aimed at political strategists, and little backbiting or assignment of blame.

headline: A Technicolor Tribute to a Retiring Congressman
abstract: Representative Howard Coble is retiring from the House at the end of this year, and taking his cadre of signature madras jackets with him to North Carolina.
lead_paragraph: Representative Howard Coble, 83, a Republican, is retiring from the House at the end of this year, and taking his collection of madras jackets with him to North Carolina.

headline: Nothing a Little Brushwork Can’t Fix
abstract: Amy Ferguson and Matt Land in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn
lead_paragraph: After eight years mostly in Greenwich Village rentals, Amy Ferguson was hankering for a change. Friends were moving to Brooklyn. The Village started to seem too rich and too crowded.

headline: A Timepiece Designed to Withstand the Elements
abstract: Montblanc’s TimeWalker Extreme Chronograph DLC has a leather band that is resistant to scratches, fire and water.
lead_paragraph: In this weekly series, the men’s fashion editors of T invite creative personalities to put their own aesthetic spin on a new watch. Here, the illustrator Jay Riggio captures a timepiece from Montblanc.

headline: Boston Symphony and Andris Nelsons to Celebrate Tanglewood Center’s 75th Anniversary
abstract: There will be nothing understated this summer when the Boston Symphony Orchestra celebrates the 75th anniversary of its summer music academy, the Tanglewood Music Center: Andris Nelsons will conduct the center’s orchestra in a performance of Mahler’s “Symphony of a Thousand” featuring three choruses and a roster of star soloists on Aug. 8.
lead_paragraph: There will be nothing understated this summer when the Boston Symphony Orchestra celebrates the 75th anniversary of its summer music academy, the Tanglewood Music Center: Andris Nelsons will conduct the center’s orchestra in a performance of Mahler’s “Symphony of a Thousand,” featuring three choruses and a roster of star soloists including Christine Goerke, Klaus Florian Vogt and Matthias Goerne. Those who cannot make it to the Berkshires for the concert, scheduled for Aug. 8, can watch it on a free live webcast.

headline: Car Bombs Explode in Eastern Libya
abstract: A crowd surrounded burning vehicles in Tobruk, Libya, on Wednesday after two car bombs exploded near the Parliament.
lead_paragraph: A crowd surrounded burning vehicles in Tobruk, Libya, on Wednesday after two car bombs exploded near the Parliament.

headline: When Patients Don’t Follow Up
abstract: Should patients be held responsible for not showing up for follow-up tests and procedures? Does the medical profession have an ethical and legal duty to try to track down the individuals?
lead_paragraph: Several years ago, I saw a woman with unexpectedly high blood pressure. Her readings were as high as 140/110, way above the normal value of 120/80. Though she was otherwise healthy, she was at risk of a stroke.

headline: The Chief of Viacom Says Nielsen Is Outdated
abstract: Philippe Dauman said that a large portion of the viewing of Viacom networks occurs through mobile apps and other platforms that Nielsen does not include.
lead_paragraph: Faced with ratings and advertising declines, the chief executive of Viacom criticized the television research firm Nielsen on Thursday for failing to keep pace with the way people watch TV.

headline: Harems in the Sea
abstract: The marine crustacean Paracerceis sculpta gathers a harem inside a sea sponge — and then he has to fight to keep his mates from frontal, sneak and cross-dresser attacks.
lead_paragraph: The marine crustacean Paracerceis sculpta gathers a harem inside a sea sponge — and then he has to fight to keep his mates from frontal, sneak and cross-dresser attacks.

headline: ISIS Chief Emerges, Urging ‘Volcanoes of Jihad’
abstract: Countering rumors that he was dead, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the Islamic State leader, issued a new call to arms in an audio clip posted online.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Dispelling rumors of his injury or death, the leader of the militant group that calls itself the Islamic State issued a new call to arms on Thursday in a 17-minute speech, belittling President Obama’s plan to send more soldiers to Iraq and urging disciples to “erupt volcanoes of jihad everywhere.”

headline: Keeping Mates Close and Competition Out in an Ocean Sponge
abstract: Evolution has come up with many strategies for successful mating. For one kind of marine crustacean, that means a game of cat and mouse with mates and competitors.
lead_paragraph: Males go to great lengths to get mates. One strategy, played out in many animals including humans, is for the male to gather as many females as possible in a harem.

headline: Comet Landing Bumpier Than Initially Thought
abstract: The European Space Agency lander is sitting in a skewed position on the comet’s surface, compromising some aspects of the $1.75 billion Rosetta mission.
lead_paragraph: This historic landing of a spacecraft on a comet on Wednesday turned out to be not one but three landings as the craft hopped across the surface.

headline: Strikes by U.S. Blunt ISIS but Anger Civilians
abstract: Residents of Raqqa are angry at the U.S. because food and fuel prices have soared, power blackouts have prevailed and order is now threatened by a power vacuum.
lead_paragraph: SANLIURFA, Turkey — American airstrikes on the Syrian city of Raqqa, the vaunted capital of the Islamic State’s self-proclaimed caliphate, have scattered its fighters and disrupted the harsh system they had imposed, residents and visitors there say. But they see no gratitude toward the United States.

headline: 15 Are Charged With Defrauding Banks and Other Lenders of $20 Million
abstract: The defendants, many of them members of an extended family, secured loans by overstating their income and bank account balances, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: WHITE PLAINS — Many of the defendants were on Medicaid and were receiving food stamps. One couple even claimed they were homeless.

headline: Duracell Deal Shows Buffett’s Hunger for Acquisitions
abstract: Warren E. Buffett has an appetite for large and creatively structured acquisitions. A look back at some of his recent deals.
lead_paragraph: Warren E. Buffett’s deal-making engine is humming.

headline: ‘Basetrack Live,’ the Story of a Marine’s Deployment, and His Return Home
abstract: Using authentic videos and images, the production offers a realistic perspective on the trials of relationships during deployment, and on how social media can be useful tools.
lead_paragraph: No millennial worth his iPhone remembers life before social media. While previous generations’ warfighters wrote letters or phoned home over spotty connections, Marines today can post on Instagram photos of themselves sitting atop cans of ammunition. In 2010, the photojournalist Teru Kuwayama and his collaborators embedded in Afghanistan to start a Facebook page for the First Battalion, Eighth Marines to communicate with loved ones. Far from resulting in just another live-stream of minutiae, their Basetrack project became a way for deployed troops to maintain relationships with their families. The resulting trove of photos and videos provide ample fodder for “Basetrack Live” — the onstage story of one corporal’s deployment and homecoming, and the effects on his family.

headline: A Freud Museum Exhibition Plumbs Meanings
abstract: The Sigmund Freud Museum in Vienna is the site of an exhibition by the artist Brandt Junceau.
lead_paragraph: Enter and you’re drawn to a headless, 300-pound male plaster figure suspended from the ceiling. Continue through a set of white doors and nine headless terra-cotta statues placed side by side on one of two white desks pull your attention away from the small, wood-framed mirror attached to the center of the window.

headline: White House Hints at a Pipeline Veto
abstract: President Obama has largely left the cap on his veto pen, but that might not be the case for much longer.
lead_paragraph: President Obama has largely left the cap on his veto pen, but that might not be the case for much longer.

headline: Warren’s Leadership Job Could Be Liberal Liaison
abstract: Democratic leaders are hoping to make Elizabeth Warren a liaison to the party’s liberal groups, to ensure that they have a voice in leadership meetings.
lead_paragraph: Democratic leaders in the Senate are hoping to elevate Elizabeth Warren, Democrat of Massachusetts and a folk hero to the progressive wing of the party, to the leadership team in a nod to the party’s base, said a Democratic aide familiar with the role being considered.

headline: Amazon and Hachette Resolve Dispute
abstract: The accord allows the publisher to set prices on its e-books, a major issue in a battle that led Amazon to discourage sales of Hachette books.
lead_paragraph: Hachette won an important victory on Thursday in its battle with Amazon: the ability to set its own prices for e-books, which it sees as critical to its survival. But even as the publisher and retailer announced a negotiated peace after sparring since January, hardly anyone seemed in the mood for celebratory fireworks.

headline: Today in Small Business: Avoiding Bad Yelp Reviews
abstract: Did this “cereal milk” start-up target the wrong market? Should small businesses have to offer health insurance to part-time workers? The ultimate list of start-up competitions, hackathons, business-plan contests and more.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Russia to Curtail Nuclear Security Efforts With U.S.
abstract: The move, which could undermine two decades of cooperation, is a byproduct of the general downturn in relations between Russia and the United States.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Russia has informed the United States that it is planning to reduce its participation next year in a joint effort to secure nuclear materials on Russian territory, a move that could seriously undermine more than two decades of cooperation aimed at ensuring that nuclear bomb components do not fall into the hands of terrorists or a rogue state.

headline: To A.P. or Not to A.P., That Is the Question
abstract: Advanced Placement courses can be a real boon to students motivated by intellectual curiosity and a love of learning. But for students looking to please their parents or for those in pursuit of transcript padding and other false academic idols, A.P. courses can be an unpleasant and unhealthy slog.
lead_paragraph: Last month, “SCD” asked about the value of Advanced Placement and International Baccalaureate courses:

headline: Rolls-Royce Resurrects Professional Driver Course
abstract: The automaker says the White Glove program seeks to train drivers that match the quality of its high-end cars.
lead_paragraph: About a century ago, when Rolls-Royce began to acquire its sterling reputation, the maharajahs and magnates who imported the cars from England discovered that in many parts of the world, good drivers were harder to find than good cars. So they had Rolls-Royce train drivers to match its cars.

headline: Lincoln Center to Rename Avery Fisher Hall
abstract: Lincoln Center is essentially paying the Fisher family $15 million to drop the name so that the New York Philharmonic can lure a donor to finance a major renovation of its home.
lead_paragraph: Since its adolescence more than four decades ago, the New York Philharmonic’s home at Lincoln Center has been known as Avery Fisher Hall. Now, as the orchestra prepares for a major renovation expected to cost more than $500 million, the Fisher family has agreed to relinquish the name so the Philharmonic and Lincoln Center can lure a large donor with the promise of rechristening the building.

headline: When the Script Is Screaming for Blood
abstract: As “Tamburlaine, Parts I and II” prepares to open, a look at productions that have needed that most theatrical of special effects.
lead_paragraph: The director Michael Boyd had plans for a small lake of blood. Onstage at the Polonsky Shakespeare Center in Brooklyn, during a break in rehearsal for “Tamburlaine, Parts I and II,” he pointed with his foot to the spot where he wanted a hole drilled. Through it, blood would be pumped from beneath the stage. If all went well, it would gradually creep up the skirt of a character standing there. “We’ve designed a costume that’s very absorbent,” he said.

headline: New York Live Arts Names New Director
abstract: Thomas O. Kriegsmann is to be its director of programs, a new position that will include artist development projects.
lead_paragraph: New York Live Arts, the Chelsea dance theater directed by the choreographer Bill T. Jones, has appointed Thomas O. Kriegsmann as its director of programs, a new position that will include artist development projects, as well as programming at the theater. Although the theater is the home of the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company, it also presents a hefty season of performances by other artists, including an annual Live Ideas festival.

headline: Sliding Oil and Gas Prices Give Americans More Money to Spend
abstract: The effect of cheaper crude oil and gasoline is especially significant for those Americans largely left behind by an anemic economic recovery.
lead_paragraph: American consumers are going to enjoy a more bountiful Christmas this year, thanks in part to a most unlikely source: Saudi Arabia.

headline: Tips for Last-Minute Holiday Travel
abstract: Haven’t made your plans for traveling around Thanksgiving and Christmas? Here’s some advice to help you make savvy choices.
lead_paragraph: Planning to travel over the holidays? Still haven’t made reservations? It’s not too late to find an affordable Thanksgiving or Christmas getaway. You might even end up saving more on a hotel than travelers who booked when it was still beach weather. And while airlines have a captive audience this time of year, there are ways to save. So here’s to the dawdlers and spur-of-the-moment decision makers. This procrastinator’s guide to holiday travel is for you.

headline: Obama Plan May Allow Millions of Immigrants to Stay and Work in U.S.
abstract: Ignoring Republican protests, President Obama will assert his executive authority to order a broad overhaul of the immigration system, including a plan to give work permits to millions, officials said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama will ignore angry protests from Republicans and announce as soon as next week a broad overhaul of the nation’s immigration enforcement system that will protect up to five million unauthorized immigrants from the threat of deportation and provide many of them with work permits, according to administration officials who have direct knowledge of the plan.

headline: Fantasy Football: Picks for Week 11
abstract: For Week 11, Packers receiver Jordy Nelson is a must-start and some other picks that fantasy players may want to consider are Bengals’ A.J. Green and 49ers’ Frank Gore.
lead_paragraph: For Week 11, Packers receiver Jordy Nelson is a must-start and some other picks that fantasy players may want to consider are Bengals’ A.J. Green and 49ers’ Frank Gore.

headline: Executive Women, Finding (and Owning) Their Voice
abstract: Four chief executives describe the importance of taking stands, and of making sure they’re heard.
lead_paragraph: Four chief executives describe the importance of taking stands, and of making sure they’re heard.

headline: D.W.I. Charge for ‘Cake Boss’ Star
abstract: Bartolo Valastro Jr., known as Buddy, was pulled over by officers in Midtown after they saw him driving his yellow 2014 Corvette erratically around 1 a.m. on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Bartolo Valastro Jr., the bakery owner known on reality television as the “Cake Boss,” was arrested early Thursday in Manhattan and charged with driving while intoxicated, according to the police.

headline: Being a Father Is Good for Your Career, but Don’t Get Carried Away
abstract: Social scientists are discovering that men who take leave and other time off work for child care pay a price, just as working mothers do.
lead_paragraph: Employers reward fatherhood by paying higher wages to men with children. But if fathers take time away from work for their children, whether for childbirth or pediatrician appointments, employers penalize them.

headline: Obama Pushes for Democracy in Myanmar
abstract: President Obama met with lawmakers in Myanmar on Thursday and discussed how the country could move toward a “genuine democracy.”
lead_paragraph: President Obama met with lawmakers in Myanmar on Thursday and discussed how the country could move toward a “genuine democracy.”

headline: Wheelies: The Parade of Progress Edition
abstract: A restored G.M. Futurliner from the Parade of Progress to appear at a Washington car show; G.M. to cut a shift at its Cadillac plant in Lansing, Mich.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: The Factory to the World Needs a Hand
abstract: For more than a decade, China and its neighbors have seemingly lived by a tacit agreement: Trade more, play down disputes and enjoy the rising wealth. But wariness and fragility are setting in.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — It’s a measure of the glum global economic outlook these days that even in the fastest growing region in the world, the developing economies of East Asia, there is pessimism and widespread anxiety.

headline: Top U.S. General Says He’s Open to Using Ground Troops to Retake Mosul
abstract: President Obama’s top military adviser said he would consider deploying a limited number of American forces to fight alongside Iraqi troops moving to retake areas held by militants.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s top military adviser said Thursday that he would consider deploying a limited number of United States forces to accompany Iraqi troops on complex offensive operations to retake Mosul and other areas under control of Sunni militants.

headline: ‘Knife Fights,’ by John A. Nagl
abstract: John A. Nagl writes about his 20-year struggle to prod the Army into adapting to the modern reality of guerrilla war.
lead_paragraph: The cliché has it that armies always prepare to fight the last war. But in the years after the conflict in Vietnam, the United States Army did almost exactly the opposite. American generals, defeated by a guerrilla insurgency, strove mightily to pretend it had never happened, and prepared for the fight they preferred, a big-army-versus-big-army duel like the kind that unfolded in World War II.

headline: Hopes Are Low for G-20 Summit in Brisbane
abstract: Leaders will gather in Australia this weekend, but their interactions are likely to be strained by events in Ukraine, territorial disputes in Asia and war in the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — It will shut down a city for two days, cost hundreds of millions of dollars and oblige 20 of the world’s top leaders to make long journeys to the east coast of Australia. So it would be a bit of a letdown if the Group of 20 summit meeting in Brisbane on Saturday and Sunday failed to accomplish very much.

headline: ‘The Invisible Front,’ by Yochi Dreazen
abstract: Through the story of one family, Yochi Dreazen examines the military’s response to rising numbers of post-Iraq and -Afghanistan suicides.
lead_paragraph: When Jeff Graham was killed in Iraq in 2004, the Kentucky State Legislature passed a resolution hailing the young second lieutenant. Tens of thousands of fans applauded when his boyish face was displayed on the scoreboard at a University of Kentucky basketball game. Hundreds of mourners waved American flags as his hearse passed. One sergeant even named his son after the fallen hero.

headline: ‘Napoleon: A Life,’ by Andrew Roberts
abstract: The French emperor as soldier, statesman, intellectual and flawed visionary.
lead_paragraph: On July 22, 1789, a week after the storming of the Bastille in Paris, Napoleon Bonaparte wrote to his older brother, Joseph, that there was nothing much to worry about. “Calm will return. In a month.” His timing was off, but perhaps he took the misjudgment to heart because he spent the rest of his life trying to bring glory and order to France by building a new sort of empire. By the time he was crowned emperor on Dec. 2, 1804, he could say, “I am the Revolution.” It was, according to the historian Andrew Roberts’s epically scaled new biography, “Napoleon: A Life,” both the ultimate triumph of the self-made man, an outsider from Corsica who rose to the apex of French political life, and simultaneously a “defining moment of the Enlightenment,” fixing the “best” of the French Revolution through his legal, educational and administrative reforms. Such broad contours get at what Napoleon meant by saying to his literary hero Goethe at a meeting in Erfurt, “Politics is fate.”

headline: Wicker Picked to Lead National G.O.P. Senatorial Committee
abstract: Senate Republicans today handed the job of protecting their new majority to Senator Roger Wicker of Mississippi, who was elected chairman of the National Republican Senatorial Committee.
lead_paragraph: Senate Republicans today handed the job of protecting their new majority to Senator Roger Wicker of Mississippi, who was elected chairman of the National Republican Senatorial Committee.

headline: John Cook Leaving The Intercept to Return to Gawker
abstract: Mr. Cook, who was the editor in chief of The Intercept, will become deputy editor of investigations at Gawker.
lead_paragraph: John Cook, the editor in chief of The Intercept, the newsmagazine started by the billionaire eBay founder Pierre Omidyar, will leave his position to return to his previous employer, Gawker Media, where he will oversee investigations.

headline: Decades of Neglect Show Starkly as Indian Schools Cry Out for Repairs
abstract: Officials are working to improve congressionally funded schools in 23 states on reservations with decaying facilities where students struggle to meet academic standards and teacher turnover is high.
lead_paragraph: BENA, Minn. — When temperatures drop and snow falls, students bundle themselves in heavy coats inside Marlene Stately’s classroom. Winter comes early and bites hard on this Indian reservation in northern Minnesota, and the pole barn that houses part of the Bug-O-Nay-Ge-Shig School offers limited protection from the elements.

headline: Obama and Scalia, United on Broadband as a Utility
abstract: If the net neutrality dispute makes it to the Supreme Court, broadband might make for strange bedfellows.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON – The number of issues on which President Obama agrees with Justice Antonin Scalia probably could be counted on one hand. But one such agreement is a doozy – that broadband Internet service should be regulated as a utility.

headline: Freer Trade Between the U.S. and India
abstract: A new agreement should help advance global trade negotiations known as the Doha round.
lead_paragraph: The United States and India have reached an agreement that should help advance the much-delayed global trade negotiations known as the Doha round. It should clear the way for the 160 members of the World Trade Organization to simplify customs rules and procedures, making it easier for countries to trade with each other.

headline: Fostering Growth With Greater Economic Cooperation
abstract: Takehiko Nakao, president of the Asian Development Bank, explains how the Group of 20, which is meeting in Australia this weekend, can bolster economies and fight corruption.
lead_paragraph: Leaders from the Group of 20 are meeting in Brisbane, Australia, on Saturday and Sunday to discuss greater economic cooperation, with the goal of increasing growth in member countries. Takehiko Nakao, president of the Asian Development Bank, spoke with Sonia Kolesnikov-Jessop.

headline: Afghanistan Militants Attack Coalition Convoy
abstract: The convoy belonging to the American-led coalition forces was attacked twice by suicide bombers, officials said, but suffered no casualties.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — A convoy of vehicles belonging to the American-led coalition forces was attacked twice by suicide bombers in eastern Afghanistan on Thursday, a military spokesman and local authorities said. The convoy suffered no casualties, but at least one Afghan civilian was killed, as were the bombers, they said.

headline: Democratic Caucus Keeps Reid as Leader, but Airs Frustration
abstract: Senate Democrats voted on Thursday to keep Senator Harry Reid of Nevada as their leader, but Democrats expressed frustration with the party’s direction.
lead_paragraph: Senate Democrats voted on Thursday to keep Senator Harry Reid of Nevada as their leader, but his victory came only after a nearly four-hour closed-door meeting, where 28 caucus members expressed their frustration with the party’s direction after an Election Day drubbing.

headline: Fantasy Football: Week 11 Player Tiers
abstract: Quarterback Ben Roethlisberger disappointed fantasy owners last week and falls to Tier 3 against the Titans this week.
lead_paragraph: In this statistical model, I apply a clustering algorithm called the Gaussian mixture model to an aggregation of expert ranking data provided by Fantasypros.com. The algorithm finds natural tiers and clusters within the data. The charts that result visualize the tiers and help you decide your starting lineup each week.

headline: Little Rock Celebration Draws Clinton Supporters, Faithful and Hopeful
abstract: As friends, aides and donors gather for the 10th anniversary of the William J. Clinton Presidential Center, thoughts will turn to Hillary Rodham Clinton’s ambitions.
lead_paragraph: For the 10th anniversary of the William J. Clinton Presidential Center in Little Rock, Ark., organizers have urged the guests to focus on Bill Clinton’s accomplishments, rather than his wife’s presidential ambitions.

headline: Existentialism and Romantic Love in a Philosophy 101
abstract: In a series of classes, the New York Public Library’s Jefferson Market branch will offer guidance on applying existential philosophy to affairs of the heart.
lead_paragraph: The Miser’s obsession with philosophy has probably introduced as much static as clarity into his pursuit of life’s vexing questions. But the idea that the discipline can be a source of consolation has endured, from Boethius’ sixth-century opus “The Consolation of Philosophy” to Alain de Botton’s similarly titled but considerably lighter self-help treatise from 2000.

headline: A Higher Quit Rate Among Employees Actually Offers Hope
abstract: Despite a recent rise in the rate, which points to more confidence in the economy, the number suggests the recovery is unfinished.
lead_paragraph: Over recent months, Janet Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, has suggested that it is worth focusing on the quit rate, which is the proportion of workers who quit their jobs in any given month. By her telling, the willingness of workers to quit will rise only when they become more confident that they are likely to be rehired.

headline: Scientists Describe Bumpy Comet Landing
abstract: A technical issue led to the rough landing the European Space Agency’s Philae lander made as it settled on a comet.
lead_paragraph: A technical issue led to the rough landing the European Space Agency’s Philae lander made as it settled on a comet.

headline: Conserving Stained-Glass Records at Corning Museum
abstract: The Corning Museum of Glass library is to start unfurling about 7,000 drawings and paintings from the Whitefriars stained-glass factory; a black film poster collection is for sale.
lead_paragraph: British stained-glass scholars largely ignore Victorian manufacturers, concentrating instead on their country’s less-plentiful medieval and Arts and Crafts windows. And now, two of three collections of documents from 19th-century glass companies in London that landed in America are being broken up.

headline: 1978 | ‘Farewell, Etaoin Shrdlu’
abstract: David W. Dunlap, a Metro reporter for The Times, took us back to the moment when the paper stopped being produced with Linotype machines.
lead_paragraph: David W. Dunlap is a Metro reporter and writes the Building Blocks column. He has worked at The Times for 39 years.

headline: FIFA Looks at Itself and Nods in Approval
abstract: Maybe FIFA should be our example for all that’s right and good. Even after years of ethics scandals, maybe we’ve been wrong about it the whole time.
lead_paragraph: FIFA, the money-printing outfit in Zurich that serves as soccer’s world governing body, said on Thursday that it “welcomes the fact that a degree of closure has been reached.”

headline: In the Water and in Sync
abstract: A swimmer with a dance background finds that synchronized swimming is easier to watch than it is to perform.
lead_paragraph: I’VE spent more time than I should probably admit watching clips of black-and-white era Busby Berkeley movies online. Growing up, I studied ballet for years and found the precise yet imaginative choreography he created for his films’ graceful water scenes mesmerizing. Still, it didn’t occur to me until recently that I could turn those YouTube binges into an after-work exercise routine.

headline: Why the One Percent Hates Obama
abstract: He’s raised their taxes more than you realize.
lead_paragraph: A peculiar aspect of the Obama years has been the disconnect between the rage of Obama’s enemies and the yawns of his sort-of allies. The right denounces financial reform as a vast government takeover — and lobbies fiercely against it — while the left dismisses reform as symbols without substance. The right accuses Obama of being a socialist stealing the money of hard-working billionaires, while the left dismisses him as having done nothing to address inequality.

headline: FIFA Official on World Cup Bids Inquiry
abstract: Jerome Valcke, FIFA’s secretary general, reacted to news that Michael J. Garcia, chairman of the investigatory chamber of FIFA’s ethics committee, plans to appeal a decision on World Cup bidding.
lead_paragraph: Jerome Valcke, FIFA’s secretary general, reacted to news that Michael J. Garcia, chairman of the investigatory chamber of FIFA’s ethics committee, plans to appeal a decision on World Cup bidding.

headline: Craftsy, an E-Learning Site for Makers, Raises $50 Million
abstract: Craftsy, something of a hybrid of YouTube and Etsy, wants to get much, much bigger.
lead_paragraph: The executives at Craftsy want to make one thing clear: Arts and crafts aren’t just for children anymore.

headline: $9 Million to Settle Case for 2 Wrongly Convicted
abstract: The agreement, made with two men convicted in a 1989 double murder in Manhattan, is the latest in a series of settlements made with people who were caught up in flawed prosecutions.
lead_paragraph: Two men who spent 16 years in prison before their convictions in a 1989 double murder in Manhattan were overturned have agreed to accept $9 million to settle their lawsuits against New York City, the state and the city Housing Authority.

headline: On Elite Campuses, an Arts Race
abstract: Harvard and other top private universities are spending heavily to upgrade museums and build more artistic centers.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — Closed for six years, the Harvard Art Museums reopen here Sunday after a radical overhaul by the architect Renzo Piano. He saved only the shell of the chaste, red-brick Fogg Museum and its interior courtyard, extending it upward in sheets of glass and elegant trusswork. Galleries wrap the new public space, but so do a materials lab, an art-conservation suite and a study center, where students, faculty and visitors can learn from the collection of 250,000 objects.

headline: Showcases for Art in Silicon Valley
abstract: A $235 million arts district is well underway at Stanford University, signaling that in Silicon Valley, art matters.
lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, Calif. — The birthplace of Yahoo and Google, Stanford University is now ramping up and showing off its cultural resources.

headline: Trash Talk
abstract: Questions about discarded items, dispensing college advice, sharing a daughter’s diagnosis and retail therapy.
lead_paragraph: My wife and I had a beautiful carpet that became infested with moths. We had it professionally cleaned, but we still found moth larvae in it. So we put the carpet out with our garbage cans. Sadly, we neglected to label it: “Infested with moths.” Later, we saw a neighbor carting it away before dawn. Should we tell him the rug is infested, letting him know we saw him rummage through our trash?

headline: Frustrated Democratic Senators Vent, but Re-Elect Reid to Be Their Leader
abstract: The victory for Mr. Reid came after a nearly four-hour closed meeting when 28 Democratic senators expressed frustration with the party’s direction.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Democrats voted to retain Senator Harry Reid of Nevada and the other senior members of their leadership on Thursday, putting off for now the uncomfortable question of how to inject new energy into a party that many worry is failing to cultivate a new generation of leaders.

headline: Rage of the Traders
abstract: No, it’s not justified.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes the absurdity of what passes for economic wisdom surpasses even my highly adapted expectations. I really, truly expected that even Wall Street would consider PeterPaul Singer’s hyperinflation in the Hamptons rant embarrassing, and try to pretend that it never happened. But no; apparently it’s being passed around eagerly by traders and big shots who think it’s the greatest thing since sliced foie gras.

headline: Adoptees Like Me ‘Flip the Script’ on the Pro-Adoption Narrative
abstract: I don’t know how to solve the broader problems with adoption, or even my own. But I’m relieved that more adoptees are finding a way to talk about the reality: not all adoptions end in rainbows and bubbly baby smiles.
lead_paragraph: I can’t remember not knowing I was adopted. My parents told me early, believing, as most of us do, that honesty always reigns. My biological mother, then a 20-year-old student, relinquished her rights to me when I was born in 1977.

headline: Physician, Sing Thyself
abstract: “Allegro,” a Rodgers and Hammerstein musical about father-and-son doctors, is being revived Off Broadway, creating a new chance to consider the medical themes it raises.
lead_paragraph: Aside from Dr. Jekyll and Dr. Frankenstein, there are not a lot of doctors in Broadway musicals.

headline: Christopher Williams
abstract: Christopher Williams continues his exploration of photography as an art medium in his show at David Zwirner.
lead_paragraph: Roland Barthes was the patron saint of the Pictures Generation, which used ideas from essays like “Rhetoric of the Image” and “The Death of the Author” to create mass-media-inspired and appropriation works. The Conceptual photographer Christopher Williams, who is slightly younger, has looked instead to Vilém Flusser, a Czech-Brazilian philosopher who argued that photography is an apparatus whose “program” might be altered in ways that ultimately transform society.

headline: Pathologist Is Witness in Ferguson Death Inquiry
abstract: In a sign that the proceedings might be coming to an end, the pathologist, Dr. Michael M. Baden, who was hired by the family of Michael Brown, discussed Mr. Brown’s wounds.
lead_paragraph: CLAYTON, Mo. — The forensic pathologist hired by the family of Michael Brown testified before a St. Louis County grand jury on Thursday, an indication that the proceedings might be nearing their final stages, the family’s lawyers said.

headline: Unraveling Why Some Mammals Kill Off Infants
abstract: A new study suggests that the behavior of male animals killing unrelated infants evolved independently in a number of separate animal lineages.
lead_paragraph: In the early 1970s, Sarah Blaffer Hrdy, then a graduate student at Harvard, traveled to India to study Hanuman langurs, monkeys that live in troops, each made up of several females and a male.

headline: ‘Think Pieces Were Made for Millennials Who Majored in English’
abstract: A poet who writes poems with the titles of online “think pieces” talks to Op-Talk about click bait, media language, and how Internet publishing might be influencing poetry.
lead_paragraph: “You Are Invisible.” “Australia, It Doesn’t Have to Be This Way.” “In Defense of the American Bro.”

headline: How to Make an Ethics Probe Disappear
abstract: When a House member under investigation leaves his job, his case departs with him.
lead_paragraph: As the lame duck Congress plays out its final days, five departing House members are breathing sighs of relief. They have been the focus of long-running ethics investigations, but their cases will depart with them from the public record, closed without any official findings. The slates will be instantly cleaned under a provision of the often arcane House ethics rules, which critics complain encourages procrastination and shady behavior.

headline: In L.A., Unproduced Film Scripts Find New Life Onstage
abstract: A new event series from the screenwriting organization The Black List casts hot young actors in table readings for the public. The next one takes place Saturday night.
lead_paragraph: For most films, the table read — an organized talk-through of the script — is a critical, if perilous, milestone. It can be a harrowing experience for everyone involved, as producers keep a watchful eye on potential glitches: a lack of chemistry between the stars, the hint of a humdrum performance, glaringly obvious plot problems. It can also be the pivotal moment when a script that has lingered in development for years finally gains momentum. Either way, it is typically done behind closed doors, open only to those closest to the production.

headline: Both Sides Gain in Buffett-Duracell Deal
abstract: The one drawback for Procter & Gamble is that it is losing a longtime shareholder, Robert Cyran and Kevin Allison of Reuters Breakingviews write.
lead_paragraph: Warren E. Buffett’s multibillion-dollar deal for Duracell is more positive than negative. Berkshire Hathaway is paying for its latest acquisition by trading its stake in Procter & Gamble, valued at $4.7 billion, for the consumer stalwart’s battery unit. Swapping a reliable staple for a declining business looks odd. But the transaction is structured in a way that means both sides are getting a decent deal.

headline: What We’re Reading Now
abstract: Food news from Fort Lauderdale to Denmark.
lead_paragraph: A 90-year-old man in Fort Lauderdale, Florida has vowed to continue feeding the homeless “as long as there is breath in my body,” despite a new city ordinance that bans giving food to the needy in public places. (The aged agitator has already been arrested twice.) Twenty other cities have passed similar measures since January 2013 in order to encourage those in need to seek food from established shelters. Critics say the legislation criminalizes an act of charity and does nothing to solve the fundamental problem of homelessness itself.

headline: Republicans Savor Sweet Victory
abstract: Cake being taken out of a Senate G.O.P. luncheon.

headline: Artworks of the Flesh Are Manifest
abstract: The first major exhibition on Bartholomeus Spranger, at the Met, shows him to be a very good painter who had a knack of being in the right place at the right time.
lead_paragraph: Though far from a household name today, Bartholomeus Spranger (1546-1611) was famous in his own lifetime. Working in Prague as a court artist for the Holy Roman emperor Rudolf II, he painted and drew Mannerist-style allegories involving nude and nearly nude gods and goddesses athletically entwined in anatomically improbable positions. His images were copied by expert engravers and disseminated widely.

headline: Samantha Power, U.S. Ambassador, Issues Warning on Anti-Semitism in Europe
abstract: The ambassador, a top aide to President Obama, made her comments against the backdrop of rising anti-Semitic attacks in Europe,
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Against the backdrop of what several speakers called an unmistakable rise in anti-Semitism in Europe, the American ambassador to the United Nations warned on Thursday that the increase in attacks poses a threat to European values, and urged leaders to step up their efforts to thwart anti-Jewish sentiment.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Dancers Who Twist Their Bodies and Their Art Form
abstract: With “Sadeh21,” the Batsheva Dance Company brings Ohad Naharin’s often-imitated choreography to the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: Batsheva Dance Company, the foremost contemporary dance troupe of Israel, is 50. For nearly half its life, though, it has been less a national company than a vehicle for the choreography and aesthetic of its artistic director, Ohad Naharin. His style has become hugely influential. Imitators abound across the globe. But the 18 Batsheva dancers who performed the United States premiere of Mr. Naharin’s “Sadeh21” (2011) at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Wednesday are the real thing.

headline: Taken Down by Twisted Ambition
abstract: Starring Steve Carell and Channing Tatum, “Foxcatcher,” directed by Bennett Miller, tells the true-crime story of an Olympic wrestler and his multimillionaire sponsor.
lead_paragraph: In “Foxcatcher,” an eerie horror story about one American have and one have-not, a startlingly transformed Steve Carell plays John Eleuthère du Pont, the chemical company heir. A dabbler extraordinaire and apparent fantasist whose family fortune was partly created on battlefields across the world — as a producer of gun powder, dynamite and plutonium — the real du Pont collected monumental amounts of shells, birds and stamps as well as guns and, as the wealthy can do, other human beings. Among the most remarkable of these was an Olympic wrestler, Mark Schultz, who, as embodied by Channing Tatum, is the latest in a seemingly never-ending line of poetic male primitives.

headline: Net Neutrality and the Hazards of the Bully Pulpit for Obama
abstract: President Obama’s call for limits on preferential treatment of content by Internet providers could polarize the issue.
lead_paragraph: Imagine you are President Obama. You have about two more years in office, but your agenda is dead on arrival in the Republican-controlled Congress that takes over in January. What do you do?

headline: Borrowers in Hungary Learn Tough Lessons
abstract: The story of how Hungarians wound up deeply in debt in Swiss francs is partly a story of European overconfidence during the boom before the credit crisis. But it is also a story of how poor regulation of banks can be disastrous.
lead_paragraph: For many people in Central and Eastern Europe, a new experience began a quarter-century ago. Communist governments collapsed, and the wide world of private ownership, democracy and free markets opened up suddenly.

headline: With the Candidates in Accord, Voters in Romania Wonder Whom to Trust
abstract: Voters must decide which of the two candidates can best be trusted to continue an open and strong democracy in Romania and avoid the strongman tactics used by the president of neighboring Hungary.
lead_paragraph: BUCHAREST, Romania — On the surface, the presidential election on Sunday is a contest between two political veterans who agree on most of the important issues, from battling endemic corruption to continuing Romania’s fervent embrace of the European Union and the United States.

headline: Sexual Abuse Case Dropped Against Intern at Preschool
abstract: Malthe Thomsen, a teaching student from Copenhagen, was arrested in June after a colleague accused him of inappropriately touching students.
lead_paragraph: A nearly five-month investigation into claims that a student teacher had inappropriately touched youngsters at a preschool in Manhattan ended on Thursday with the dismissal of all criminal charges.

headline: Post-Mortems of Victims Point to Tainted Medication in India Sterilization Deaths
abstract: Autopsies of women who died at a government sterilization camp suggest that “spurious medicines” were to blame, not unsanitary conditions or rushed surgery, a medical official said.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Post-mortem examinations of several women who died after surgery at a government sterilization camp last weekend in central India suggest that tainted medications might be to blame, rather than the unsanitary conditions or the assembly-line haste of the operations, a district medical officer said Thursday.

headline: Warmer World Might See More Lightning
abstract: A model of predicted lightning strikes estimates an increase on the order of 50 percent if warming continues unchecked through this century.
lead_paragraph: To the ever-growing list of projected effects from global warming, add a curious entry: a potentially huge jump in lightning strikes in the United States.

headline: Samsung Turns to BlackBerry for Better Security
abstract: BlackBerry has boasted that its network and software, as well as special hardware within its phones, provide a level of security for corporate and government users that its competitors cannot match.
lead_paragraph: The rapid rise of Android-based smartphones was a prominent factor in BlackBerry’s profound decline. Now BlackBerry is counting on some Android phones to ensure its future.

headline: Loeb Attacks Dow Chemical After Talks Over Board Seats Break Down
abstract: Daniel S. Loeb, the activist hedge fund manager, has been pressing for a breakup of Dow Chemical and has been rebuffed in his attempt to name two directors.
lead_paragraph: Daniel S. Loeb is finally taking off the gloves in his fight with Dow Chemical.

headline: Richard Ford’s ‘Let Me Be Frank With You’
abstract: Richard Ford’s aging Everyman surveys his life, and the battered New Jersey landscape, after Hurricane Sandy.
lead_paragraph: Bangety, bangety, bangety, boop. That’s how Frank Bascombe encapsulates the arc of his almost seven-decade life while examining his end of a conversation with a woman who’s appeared, just before Christmas, at the front door of his home in Haddam, N.J. “I could’ve told her,” he thinks, in response to a speck of autobiography she’s divulged, that “I’d gone to Michigan, have two children, an ex-wife and a current one, that I’d sold real estate here and at the Shore for 20 years, once wrote a book, served in an undistinguished fashion in the Marines and was born in Mississippi — bangety, bangety, bangety, boop.” This flip summary, of course, is the outline to one of the more essential stories in contemporary American fiction: Frank Bascombe’s life and times, to which Richard Ford has devoted 1,352 pages spread over three previous volumes (“The Sportswriter,” 1986; “Independence Day,” 1995; and “The Lay of the Land,” 2006). Droll, bemused, hyper-observant, occasionally exasperating and punctuated by sighs of both resignation and contentment (often at the same time), Bascombe’s voice has offered a running commentary on the last four decades of, as he put it in “The Sportswriter,” “the normal applauseless life of us all.”

headline: His Own Man
abstract: Richard Ford has said it was “never my intention” to make the character Frank Bascombe an Everyman.
lead_paragraph: This week, Jonathan Miles reviews Richard Ford’s “Let Me Be Frank With You,” the fourth book narrated by the remarkably ruminative New Jerseyan Frank Bascombe. In a 2006 interview with The Guardian, Ford recalled writing the first Bascombe novel, “The Sportswriter” (1986). “I knew that if I wrote this book and it really was a bust, then I was toast,” he said. “That was it. My agent, Amanda Urban, said, ‘Ford, if this doesn’t work, you’re done.’ ”

headline: Reddit Chief Executive Resigns as Company Shuffles Top Ranks
abstract: Ellen Pao will be the company’s interim chief executive. One of its co-founders, Alexis Ohanian, is also returning to Reddit full-time.
lead_paragraph: Reddit, the popular online community message board, wants to grow up into a viable business. Now, it is going to try to accomplish that under new management.

headline: Two Months In, Top Analyst Casts Gaze to December
abstract: Phil Steele, who has been writing a highly regarded college football preview magazine for 20 years, offers some thoughts on the year-end awards and playoff.
lead_paragraph: Phil Steele, a college football analyst, has watched every Football Bowl Subdivision game this season as part of the research for his annual College Football Preview magazine and for his role as a member of the voting committee for 15 postseason awards, including the Heisman Trophy. In August, Steele provided us with his conference forecast. We caught up with him again to get his thoughts on this season’s first two wild months. This interview has been edited and condensed.

headline: Beyond the Casting Couch. Way Beyond.
abstract: Giving in to a lecher might help a young actress get her foot in the door, but when the soul follows, as it does in “Starry Eyes,” the trouble begins.
lead_paragraph: A pretty young actress. A casting call. A private meeting with the lecherous man who has the power to give her the role. “Starry Eyes” tries to wring a horror movie out of this tired old setup but, halfway in, seems to realize it has nothing new to offer and becomes a mere gorefest.

headline: Sarah McEneaney: ‘Studio Living’ and Hannah Wilke: ‘Selected Work 1963-1990’
abstract: Performance art of a sort becomes permanent in exhibitions by Sarah McEneaney and Hannah Wilke at Tibor de Nagy.
lead_paragraph: Sarah McEneaney’s paintings resemble art-savvy folk art. But they are also abstractions in which intense planes of color define boxy shapes and plunging perspectives that are then festooned with the details of Ms. McEneaney’s life as an artist. An energetic push-pull between form and narrative ensues. First we see red and pink, then we see tile, bricks and walls, and then a woman engaged primarily in two activities: painting and not painting.

headline: Arturo Herrera
abstract: Mr. Herrera has left his Disney-inspired work for riskier, more personal terrain in a show at Sikkema Jenkins & Company.
lead_paragraph: It’s never too late to step up your game. Arturo Herrera could have continued with his essentially one-trick-pony career, exemplified by large droopy wall pieces in thick felt with cutout shapes based on Walt Disney characters — that you could see if you were so informed.

headline: Cotton Mills, Venom and Dead Ends
abstract: Zeke and Simon Hawkins’s “Bad Turn Worse” begins with $20,000 missing from a safe in a Texas cotton mill town.
lead_paragraph: A juicy neo-noir like “Bad Turn Worse” doesn’t have to make total sense to grab you. All it has to do is spit like a snake enough times to show that it means business. And this small, nasty directorial debut by the brothers Zeke and Simon Hawkins, from a screenplay by Dutch Southern, has a whole den of poisonous reptiles from which to sample venom.

headline: Alexander Ross: ‘Recent Terrestrials’
abstract: Animal and vegetable references can be seen in Alexander Ross’s “Recent Terrestrials,” his exhibition of paintings at David Nolan.
lead_paragraph: Why do painters still paint? One reason is that it’s an efficient way to obsess over the insoluble mind-body problem. People have physical bodies and nonphysical consciousness, but no one knows exactly how they connect. Similarly, paintings are material objects and vehicles of immaterial imagination, and the relationship between those two aspects remains magnetically mysterious.

headline: To Save Us All From Satan’s Power
abstract: In “Kirk Cameron’s Saving Christmas,” Mr. Cameron stages his version of an intervention to bolster seasonal cheer and put the Bible back in the holidays.
lead_paragraph: “Kirk Cameron’s Saving Christmas” begins with its host, the former star of “Growing Pains” and now an evangelical Christian, sitting in an easy chair in front of a fully decorated Christmas tree. In his view, the holiday is under siege. “There are some people who would love to put a big wet blanket on all of this,” he says. “They don’t want us to love Christmas so much and celebrate it the way we do.”

headline: Sterilization Surgeon Defends Himself
abstract: Dr. R. K. Gupta, who performed sterilizations on at least 12 Indian women who later died, says it was tainted medication that killed them and not complications from the procedures he performed.
lead_paragraph: Dr. R. K. Gupta, who performed sterilizations on at least 12 Indian women who later died, says it was tainted medication that killed them and not complications from the procedures he performed.

headline: 500 Prompts for Narrative and Personal Writing
abstract: Here are 500 student opinion questions that invite narrative and personal writing, all together in one place.

headline: Net Neutrality Review Could Give Comcast an Out in the Time Warner Cable Deal
abstract: Comcast is locked into its deal with Time Warner Cable unless it gets a timely assist from the Federal Communications Commission, Steven Davidoff Solomon writes in the Deal Professor column.
lead_paragraph: Comcast’s acquisition of Time Warner Cable has already drawn many heated detractors to urge the Federal Communications Commission to reject the deal. Now, it has been hit been hit yet again by President Obama’s endorsement of net neutrality. Comcast may have buyer’s remorse, but it may find that ironically, the only way out is to have the F.C.C. block this deal. M.&A. makes strange bedfellows indeed.

headline: A Strong Editorial, as The Times Struggles With Chinese Visas and Business Concerns
abstract: The editorial board response was “really quite simple” after the Chinese president’s statement.
lead_paragraph: Michael Forsythe, once a reporter at Bloomberg News and now at The Times – covering China for each — packed a lot into 140 characters Thursday morning when he tweeted:

headline: Halliburton Is in Talks to Buy Rival Baker Hughes
abstract: A deal between Halliburton and Baker Hughes would unite two of the biggest oilfield services providers and would be one of the biggest energy deals in years.
lead_paragraph: Halliburton is in talks to buy Baker Hughes, a potential acquisition that would unite two of the biggest oil field services providers in what would be one of the largest energy deals in years, Baker Hughes confirmed on Thursday.

headline: Alvin Dark, 92, Dies; Led Giants to Pennants as Captain and Manager
abstract: A top shortstop, Dark led the New York Giants’ pennant-winning teams in the 1950s, then managed them into the World Series in San Francisco. But his comments about minority players shadowed him.
lead_paragraph: Alvin Dark, who was the All-Star shortstop and captain of the New York Giants’ pennant-winning teams in the 1950s and went on to manage the team to a pennant in San Francisco, but who was later shadowed by controversy over his attitude toward black and Latino players, died on Thursday at his home in Easley, S.C. He was 92.

headline: Elizabeth Warren Should Be a Partner, Not Just a Consultant
abstract: She’s joining the Democratic leadership table as a “strategic policy adviser.”
lead_paragraph: Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts will now have a seat at the Democratic leadership table, which should make for some interesting lunch conversations. Ms. Warren cares passionately about economic policy, but she will be joining a group that’s far more passionate about politics and strategy and legislative maneuvering.

headline: The Woods Are Dark and So, So Deep
abstract: Two movies directed by Josephine Decker, “Butter on the Latch” and “Thou Wast Mild & Lovely,” revel in cryptic lyricism.
lead_paragraph: There’s a devilishly fun moment in “Butter on the Latch” when a woman recounts an unusually rejuvenating visit to a notorious East Village massage parlor. Isolde (Isolde Chae-Lawrence) tells the anecdote to Sarah (Sarah Small) at a Balkan-music retreat somewhere in the California woods. The apparently improvised bit is nicely timed, part of catching up between friends, but the scene also expresses something about where storytelling takes us and what lies around the corner, mirroring a sensation native to desire and its tantalizing pleasures and dangers.

headline: Met’s First Plans for the Whitney’s Old Home
abstract: The Metropolitan Museum of Art will take over the Whitney’s old space with a 2016 exhibition about unfinished works of art.
lead_paragraph: The lines that recently snaked around the Whitney Museum of American Art are gone. So is the hulking sculpture of Popeye that could be spied in the courtyard. Since the Jeff Koons retrospective closed there on Oct. 19, the only signs of life have been moving trucks and cranes as the Whitney prepares to exchange its Madison Avenue home, designed by Marcel Breuer, for its new place in the meatpacking district this spring. The Breuer won’t stay empty for long, however: In March 2016, the Metropolitan Museum of Art will take over, at least for eight years.

headline: Think Twice Before Choosing Knee Replacement
abstract: Are people too quick to undergo knee-replacement surgery?
lead_paragraph: For someone whose knee is sore and creaky, the prospect of replacing it with a new, metal-and-plastic version of the joint can be beguiling. The surgery seems so easy and to promise so much: better mobility, less pain, an approximation, almost, of youth. But there is growing evidence that knee-replacement surgery may be too seductive — and that many people considering the procedure would be better served to first try other ways to improve their knees.

headline: Cursed by Guilt and a Creepy Sense That Punishment Is Coming
abstract: Kiyoshi Kurosawa’s “Penance” follows four young women who were traumatized by a classmate’s murder and by their own puzzling failure to identify the killer.
lead_paragraph: Like some infinitely more routine horror movie, the fateful stories of Kiyoshi Kurosawa’s “Penance” radiate outward from a terrible shared trauma. In the prelude, set 15 years ago, a stranger abducts a girl in front of her four friends, who then learn she has been murdered in the school gym. Out of shock or fear, they can’t identify the killer to the police. Instead of commiserating, the victim’s wealthy mother lashes out and (over snacks) condemns them to a lifetime of atonement.

headline: Taking Copycatting to a Higher Level
abstract: “Sturtevant: Double Trouble” is the Elaine Sturtevant career retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art.
lead_paragraph: The first thing you see in “Sturtevant: Double Trouble,” the Museum of Modern Art’s taut and feisty retrospective of the American artist Elaine Sturtevant, is work by artists far better known than Ms. Sturtevant herself.

headline: A Test For Climate Hawks
abstract: Has the liberal quest for a global climate regime just been vindicated?
lead_paragraph: The just-announced U.S.-China agreement (really an Obama-China agreement, of course, in this age of executive-branch creativity) on greenhouse gas emissions is being widely hailed by liberals as proof positive that their theory of climate change policy and politics was basically correct. First the U.S. had to “show leadership” by promising to cut emissions, many self-styled climate hawks had argued during the debates over cap and trade and the president’s E.P.A. regulations, because then and only then the world’s developing economies would be pressured/shamed/persuaded into following along. And so it has come to pass, they now suggest: First came Obama’s emission targets and greenhouse gas rules, and then, not that long delayed, came the first formal Chinese pledge to cap their emissions by a date certain.

headline: Google to Quadruple Computer Science Prize Winnings to $1 Million
abstract: The Turing prize for computer science will be quadrupled to $1 million, a jump funded by Google.
lead_paragraph: The A.M. Turing Award is often called the Nobel Prize of computer science. Now, thanks to Google’s largess, it will be a Nobel-level prize financially: $1 million.

headline: Wedding Q.&A.
abstract: A heart-to-heart talk on black tie, and sorting relationships in the aftermath of parting ways.
lead_paragraph: A Heart-to-Heart Talk on Black Tie

headline: North Miami Leaders and Former Museum Board Settle Dispute over Museum Assets
abstract: The city of North Miami and the former board of the Museum of Contemporary Art there have settled a dispute over how to divvy up assets from the museum.
lead_paragraph: The city of North Miami and the former board of the Museum of Contemporary Art have reached a settlement in their long-running dispute, the Miami Herald reported, citing a joint statement released Wednesday.

headline: New York City F.C. to Sport a Familiar Look
abstract: The new M.L.S. team’s home jerseys, unveiled on Thursday, closely resemble those worn by New York City’s parent club, Manchester City.
lead_paragraph: New York City F.C. will enter Major League Soccer next season on the Yankees’ turf, but when they do so it will be in Manchester City’s colors.

headline: Embracing HTTPS
abstract: In light of a growing number of cyber security and data privacy concerns, replacing HTTP with its secure alternative, HTTPS, is becoming increasingly important.
lead_paragraph: In light of a growing number of cyber security and data privacy concerns, replacing HTTP with its secure alternative, HTTPS, is becoming increasingly important.

headline: In Ethiopia’s Capital, a Resurgent Jazz Scene
abstract: Several venues featuring different jazz styles have sprung up in Addis Ababa in recent years, more than two decades after an evening curfew was lifted.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Sunday evening, a stylish audience in their 20s packed Mama’s Kitchen, a wood-and-glass lounge on the fourth floor of an otherwise closed shopping center near the Bole International Airport in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia’s capital. They were there to hear an adventurous young pianist, Samuel Yirga, as he careened between free jazz, études, R&B and the popular local style known as Ethio-jazz, a bewitching genre that fuses jazz with traditional Ethiopian music.

headline: FIFA’s Puskas Award: Vote for the Goal of the Year
abstract: Soccer fans around the world can select one goal from among 10 of the best from around the world this year in an online poll.
lead_paragraph: There is actually some news from FIFA that involves the game on the field. Imagine that.

headline: Jon Stewart on Facial Hair, Folk Music and Making His First Film
abstract: The “Daily Show” host-turned-director sits down with T on the eve of the release of his behind-the-camera debut, “Rosewater.”
lead_paragraph: When Jon Stewart took an extended hiatus from “The Daily Show” last summer to direct his first feature film, no one knew what to expect. That’s because Stewart, one of the most influential comedians of his generation, was not abandoning his hosting duties to helm a sharp-tongued satire or an ironic political farce. Instead, the 51-year-old New Yorker hauled a small crew to Jordan to film his own adaptation of “Then They Came for Me,” the Iranian-Canadian journalist Maziar Bahari’s account of his 118 days spent in captivity at an Iranian prison during that country’s Green Movement, which followed the contentious 2009 elections. The result is “Rosewater,” an earnest and at times harrowing film, out Friday, which stars Gael Garcia Bernal as Mahari and tracks both the horrors and the absurdities of life under an authoritarian regime. T sat down with Stewart last week to discuss his first foray behind the camera, facing movie critics for the first time and how he envisions his eventual “Daily Show” farewell.

headline: On the Trail of a Fearsome Escape Artist
abstract: In “Drug Lord: The Legend of Shorty,” filmmakers set out to find the kingpin Joaquín Guzmán Loera, obtaining remarkable access to insiders in Mexico’s criminal culture.
lead_paragraph: In a sense, the documentary “Drug Lord: The Legend of Shorty” is an experiment that went awry. The project began as an effort by two filmmakers to see if they could find Joaquín Guzmán Loera, known as El Chapo, or Shorty, who was one of the world’s most wanted drug traffickers.

headline: Like Father, Unlike Son
abstract: “Brahmin Bulls,” Mahesh Pailoor’s debut feature, is a father-and-son story that hinges on an interesting complication of sympathies.
lead_paragraph: “Brahmin Bulls,” a warm if ultimately slight debut feature from Mahesh Pailoor, hinges on an interesting complication of sympathies. Invited to a conference in Los Angeles, Ashok (Roshan Seth), an academic in Boston, decides to go there and pay a visit to his son, Sid (Sendhil Ramamurthy), an architect on the verge of a divorce. Ashok has an ulterior motive: He yearns to reunite with Helen (Mary Steenburgen), a flame he hasn’t seen in 20 years. The film raises the prospect of an autumnal fling, but it has less conventional goals in mind.

headline: Firefighter Accidents Are Linked to Sleep Problems
abstract: More than 60 percent of deaths of firefighters are caused by heart attacks and traffic accidents, and a new study suggests that one important cause is sleep disorders.
lead_paragraph: More than 60 percent of deaths of firefighters are caused by heart attacks and traffic accidents. Sleep disorders may be an important contributing factor, a new study suggests.

headline: Fox News Interview on Bin Laden Raid Draws Over 3 Million Viewers
abstract: Part Two of a talk with Robert O’Neill, the ex-Navy Seal who says he personally shot to death Osama bin Laden, is the channel’s most popular documentary.
lead_paragraph: The second night of a two-night interview with the former Navy Seal who says he personally shot to death Osama bin Laden attracted the biggest audience for a documentary in the history of the Fox News Channel.

headline: Afghan Leaders Miss Goal for Choosing Cabinet
abstract: President Ashraf Ghani had promised to have a cabinet in place within 45 days of his inauguration in a coalition with his rival, Abdullah Abdullah.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — President Ashraf Ghani’s honeymoon with the Afghan public is not over yet, but he has now officially broken his first campaign promise — to form a new government within 45 days after his inauguration.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘Rosewater’
abstract: Jon Stewart, the director of “Rosewater,” narrates a sequence from his film.
lead_paragraph: Jon Stewart, the director of “Rosewater,” narrates a sequence from his film.

headline: Nordstrom Reports Higher Sales and Profit for Third Quarter
abstract: The results were a sign that retailers with a more affluent clientele have had greater success at navigating through the tough economic climate affecting other major department store chains.
lead_paragraph: Nordstrom said on Thursday that its sales and profit rose in the third quarter, another sign that retailers with a more affluent clientele have had greater success at navigating through the tough economic climate affecting other major department store chains.

headline: Under the Spell of a Name
abstract: Some first names are warning signs that say, “Watch out, here comes heartbreak.”
lead_paragraph: A palm reader once told me I was going to marry a man named Andrew. I guess it could still happen, but I wouldn’t bet money on it. I have been married once and it wasn’t pretty. I have no plans to let it happen again, though if it does, odds are it won’t be to an Andrew.

headline: In the Thrall of an Electric Preacher
abstract: In Stephen King’s “Revival,” a boy is befriended by a charismatic minister with whom he will reconnect in eerie and unsettling ways as an adult.
lead_paragraph: You can fall down a very deep rabbit hole just pondering the list of names to whom Stephen King dedicates “Revival,” his second skin-crawler published this year. (“Mr. Mercedes” arrived in June.) Some, like Bram Stoker and H. P. Lovecraft, are familiar. Others, like August Derleth, the author of more than 100 books that Mr. King must have devoured as a boy and a seminal figure in the creation of Lovecraft’s Cthulhu Mythos horror genre, are so far out of the mainstream that they can prompt long, dreamy voyages of discovery.

headline: The Seeds of an Urban Protest
abstract: “Occupy the Farm,” directed by Todd Darling, looks at a 2012 grass-roots standoff over plans to sell a section of farmland owned by the University of California.
lead_paragraph: Just causes don’t always inspire good documentaries, and while “Occupy the Farm” might garner sympathy for the grass-roots movement that gives the film its title, that doesn’t mean its argument is even close to being fairly constructed. Rather than present an evenhanded assessment of the issues at stake, the director, Todd Darling, is so busy fist-pumping for urban farming — and so dazzled by his granola heroes — that naysayers must be demeaned and denigrated.

headline: Secret Service Blunders Eased White House Intruder’s Way, Review Says
abstract: A report by the Department of Homeland Security noted “performance, organizational, technical” and other failures that allowed a man to get inside the White House in September.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An intruder was able to climb a fence and enter the White House in September because of a succession of “performance, organizational, technical” and other failures by the Secret Service, according to a damning review of the incident by the Department of Homeland Security.

headline: Pictures of the Day: India and Elsewhere
abstract: Photographs from India, Afghanistan, Turkey and China
lead_paragraph: Photographs from India, Afghanistan, Turkey and China

headline: Nov. 13, 2014 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from India, Afghanistan, Israel and China.
lead_paragraph: Photos from India, Afghanistan, Israel and China.

headline: Jon Stewart Narrates a Scene From ‘Rosewater’
abstract: The director discusses an interrogation sequence from his film.
lead_paragraph: The comedian and “Daily Show” host Jon Stewart gets serious for his directorial debut, “Rosewater,” about the journalist Maziar Bahari and his time imprisoned in Iran after the 2009 election there. In this video, Mr. Stewart discusses the film’s first interrogation scene, where Bahari (Gael García Bernal) is questioned by the man he will come to know as Rosewater (Kim Bodnia).

headline: Like a Wiser Dorothy’s Yen for Kansas
abstract: “Always Woodstock” centers on an aspiring singer-songwriter who strikes out in New York City and moves back to her childhood home.
lead_paragraph: “I watched you sleep, and I thought, this is the most beautiful person ever made,” coos Noah (James Wolk), a dreamboat with a dimpled chin who works at a family clinic in “Always Woodstock.” Catherine (Allison Miller), the object of his fawning adoration, is an aspiring singer-songwriter who moved back from big, bad New York City to her childhood home in Woodstock, N.Y., after being fired from her job at a big, bad record company. The night she meets Noah, she winds up at his clinic after drinking herself into oblivion at the karaoke bar he owns.

headline: What’s at Stake for the Secret Service
abstract: Some background on the chain of mistakes at the Secret Service and the importance of leadership as the agency tries to get past its difficult stretch.
lead_paragraph: Some background on the chain of mistakes at the Secret Service and the importance of leadership as the agency tries to get past its difficult stretch.

headline: When the ‘Pure-Blood’ Sort Are Cannibals
abstract: In “Wolves,” directed by David Hayter, a teenager awakens from a terrible dream to find that his parents have been killed and that he is acquiring lupine form.
lead_paragraph: As unoriginal as its title, David Hayter’s “Wolves” is yet another hoary, hairy transformation narrative featuring lycanthropy as a metaphor for coming of age. In the case of Cayden (Lucas Till), a golden-boy quarterback, manhood means more than mastering rage and making peace with a first name that no one can spell. It also means that shaving could now be a full-body chore.

headline: The Good Doctor Checks Out, Again
abstract: The New York Deaf Theater presents “The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde” with a cast that signs the dialogue.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Hyde could have been a contender.

headline: Surreal Journey of a Rock That Would Be Art
abstract: “Levitated Mass” chronicles the transport of a 340-ton boulder through Southern California to a sculptor’s installation at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: “Nothing ever happens on this street,” one young woman says as a gargantuan tractor-trailer crawls past, bearing a humongous boulder and surrounded by a swarm of anxious construction engineers. “And now something amazing just happened.”

headline: Boehner Leaves Shutdown ‘On the Table’
abstract: Shutdown politics is in the air in Washington.
lead_paragraph: It’s that time of year.

headline: When Mother Nature Stops Being Maternal
abstract: “Nature’s Fury: The Science of Natural Disasters” examines the immense forces wielded by earthquakes, volcanoes, tornadoes and hurricanes.
lead_paragraph: Humanity has an extraordinary talent for causing catastrophes; we are even likely, as many have suggested over the past century — to be responsible for the coming apocalypse. But really, we are second-rate. Take a look at the images of cataclysm at the American Museum of Natural History’s exhibition opening on Saturday — “Nature’s Fury: The Science of Natural Disasters” — and see how immense the forces are that nature wields, how impossible it is to control them, how difficult it has been to predict their effects.

headline: Arkansas Governor to Pardon Son in 2003 Drug Offense
abstract: Gov. Mike Beebe’s decision followed an October recommendation by the Arkansas Parole Board that Kyle Beebe’s application for a pardon was “with merit.”
lead_paragraph: Gov. Mike Beebe of Arkansas, before leaving office in January, plans to issue a pardon to his son, who was convicted of a felony drug offense more than a decade ago.

headline: A Teacher on a Mission to Erase Evil
abstract: There is more under the surface than a moviegoer might guess on first glance at “Miss Meadows,” whose title character is played by Katie Holmes.
lead_paragraph: Between “Serial Mom” and “God Bless America,” not to mention the moonlighting criminals who populate binge television, vigilantes in sheep’s clothing are familiar by now. “Miss Meadows” gives the old perverse routine a whirl with a weirdly soul-baring Katie Holmes as a prim-and-proper gunlady, but despite an eccentric streak (which turns erratic), the script doesn’t allow much room for the premise to take flight.

headline: A Journalist Imprisoned in Iran, Escaping With Ghosts
abstract: “Rosewater,” from Jon Stewart, tells the story of an Iranian-born journalist who was arrested in Iran in 2009 and accused of being an agent for foreign intelligence organizations.
lead_paragraph: Among its virtues, “Rosewater,” the directorial debut of Jon Stewart, is an argument for filmmakers to start their trade after they’ve looked beyond the limits of their own horizons. This fictional movie tells the story of the real Maziar Bahari, an Iranian-born journalist living in London who was arrested in Iran while covering the 2009 elections for Newsweek. Accused of being an agent for foreign intelligence organizations, he was thrown into the Evin Prison, where he was interrogated and beaten, partly for the surreal reason that he had appeared on “The Daily Show With Jon Stewart.” Mr. Stewart’s interest in the material is obviously personal, but his movie transcends mere self-interest.

headline: Cruising for Fares, a Song in His Heart
