abstract: The Serbian film “Love Hunter” centers on an ambitious Serbian musician trying to succeed in New York while making ends meet as a cabdriver.
lead_paragraph: “Love Hunter” kicks off on an energetic note, when a taxi passenger, having discovered that her driver is a musician, offers a hefty tip if he can cheer her up with a song. Milan (Milan Mumin, of the Serbian band Love Hunters) pulls over, retrieves a guitar from his trunk and gives her a sidewalk concert. At once fantastical and gritty, this sort of uninflected street vignette sets the movie apart.

headline: Refinancing to Increase Equity
abstract: A Freddie Mac report finds a greater share of homeowners refinancing into shorter-term loans, and a modest number pulling cash out of their homes.
lead_paragraph: A greater share of homeowners are refinancing into shorter-term loans, while the number pulling cash out of their homes remains modest.

headline: Let the Drinking Games and Self-Pity Begin
abstract: In Chris Lowell’s “Beside Still Waters,” a weekend reunion of old high school friends turns into whiskey-lubricated nostalgia.
lead_paragraph: When a character name-checks Ernest Hemingway and Gertrude Stein right out of the gate, it suggests that the people we’re about to meet are at least capable of intelligent conversation. But don’t get your hopes too high: The seven childhood friends who reunite as adults in “Beside Still Waters” may be educated, but they still manage to spend most of their weekend getting wasted, naked and indiscreet.

headline: A $40 Million Thank You for Joan Weill’s Service to Ailey Foundation
abstract: More than $40 million has been raised in honor of Joan H. Weill, who is stepping down as chairwoman of the Alvin Ailey Dance Foundation.
lead_paragraph: Joan H. Weill is going out with a bang. After her 14 years as chairwoman of the Alvin Ailey Dance Foundation and 20 years on the board, the company on Thursday evening announced that more than $40 million had been raised in honor of her retirement.

headline: A Cultural Escape North of Melbourne
abstract: Bendigo, a town that struck it rich in Australia’s 19th-century gold rush, has other treasures to offer now.
lead_paragraph: Ninety-five miles north of Melbourne, Bendigo struck it rich in Australia’s 19th-century gold rush. In its heyday, it was the biggest gold strike in the world, financing ornate hotels, halls and civic structures. Within a century the mines were depleted and the economy shrank, but recently the town of 85,000 has emerged as a cultural escape for Melburnians as a new wave of entrepreneurs and institutions has adapted the historic Victorian storefronts and grand bank buildings to new uses. The former jail is set to reopen as the 1,000-seat Ulumbarra Theater in 2015, but weekenders will already find renewal aplenty.

headline: Comedy Listings for Nov. 14-20
abstract: A selected guide to improv, stand-up and other comedy shows in New York City.
lead_paragraph: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Theater Listings for Nov. 14-20
abstract: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.
lead_paragraph: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: A San Francisco Art Space Looks to Reinvent Itself With Help From Some Famous Friends
abstract: The Lab, a haven for the city’s experimental scene for 30 years, is hosting a telethon-style performance piece this weekend to raise funds. Lydia Lunch, Devendra Banhart and Grouper are pitching in.
lead_paragraph: “We are flying by the seat of our pants,” says Dena Beard, the new executive director of the Lab, a nonprofit experimental music and art space in San Francisco’s Mission District. “But it ends up that that’s the right way to go for this type of thing.” She’s talking about Telethon, a 24-hour performance-art-piece-as-fund-raiser that will bring together members of the city’s underground for a Jerry Lewis-style broadcast live via YouTube beginning at noon on November 15. With only days to go, Beard was still finalizing the roster of artists manning the fund-raiser’s phone bank, a lineup which includes local stars like the muralist Chris Klink. The Napa native Sofia Coppola donated artwork for auction; even James Franco has pitched in, providing a video shout-out to promote the event.

headline: Movie Listings for Nov. 14-20
abstract: A critical guide to movies playing at theaters, as well as a selected overview of film series and festivals.
lead_paragraph: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Tony Committee to Review Decision on Sound Design Award
abstract: The Tony rules committee will review a request to restore awards for sound design, but not in time for the 2014-15 season.
lead_paragraph: The Tony Awards administration committee, which oversees the annual honors for Broadway plays and musicals, on Thursday asked the rules committee for the Tonys to review a request by theatrical sound designers, Broadway actors, and many others to restore Tony Awards for best sound design for a play and for a musical. The administration committee eliminated those two awards in June, prompting widespread outcry among Broadway artists and leading sound designers to organize an online petition – signed by 32,495 people – urging the committee to reverse itself.

headline: Pop, Rock & Cabaret Listings for Nov. 14-20
abstract: A selected, critical guide to performances of rock, pop, cabaret and more in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Jazz Listings for Nov. 14-20
abstract: A selected, critical guide to performances in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Events in Connecticut for Nov. 16-22, 2014
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Opera & Classical Music Listings for Nov. 14-20
abstract: A selected, critical guide to classical music performances in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Plain on the Plains
abstract: In “The Homesman,” Hilary Swank and Tommy Lee Jones help three women driven to madness by the frontier get back East.
lead_paragraph: Plenty of words might describe Mary Bee Cuddy, the Nebraska farmer played by Hilary Swank in “The Homesman.” A paragon of pioneer self-sufficiency, she is capable and conscientious, industrious and morally upright. Her prosperity looks like the visible reward of a sturdy work ethic, and she takes pride in her tidy and well-appointed wooden house, set amid the sod-sided hovels of her fellow homesteaders.

headline: Dance Listings for Nov. 14-20
abstract: A selected guide to dance performances in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Museum & Gallery Listings for Nov. 14-20
abstract: A selected guide to exhibitions and installations in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Events in Westchester for Nov. 16-22, 2014
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: The Glamorous Life, With All Its Woes
abstract: In Gina Prince-Bythewood’s “Beyond the Lights,” a pop star lives a lonely life before meeting a police officer with ambitions of his own.
lead_paragraph: “Beyond the Lights,” Gina Prince-Bythewood’s occasionally silly, frequently stirring romantic melodrama, was originally going to be called “Blackbird,” after the Nina Simone song at its yearning heart. That song, a blunt, anguished, barely metaphorical reckoning with the intimate psychic violence of racism and sexism, is performed several times by Noni, the film’s suffering pop star. The first time is as a young girl (played by India Jean-Jacques) at a South London talent show, where we are introduced to the two forces that will rule her destiny: a stunning vocal gift and a ruthless stage mother.

headline: Spare Times for Children for Nov. 14-20
abstract: A selected guide to cultural events for children, teenagers and families in New York City.
lead_paragraph: ‘Minimón’

headline: Events on Long Island for Nov. 16-22, 2014
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Spare Times Listings for Nov. 14-20
abstract: A selected guide to readings, exhibitions, walking tours and other cultural events in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Around Town

headline: Legalize and Regulate Sports Betting
abstract: Gambling on professional games should be safe and regulated.
lead_paragraph: BETTING on professional sports is currently illegal in most of the United States outside of Nevada. I believe we need a different approach.

headline: A Child Is Gone. The Questions Linger.
abstract: In “The Missing,” a Starz mini-series, a 5-year-old’s disappearance leads to years of secrecy and deceit.
lead_paragraph: What is the worst thing that could happen? Parents always have an answer to that question. Nothing is as bad as a murdered or missing child.

headline: Virgin America Raises $306 Million in I.P.O.
abstract: The low-cost airline backed by Richard Branson is preparing for a new life as a publicly traded company.
lead_paragraph: Virgin America raised about $305.9 million in its initial public offering on Thursday, meeting expectations as the low-cost airline backed by Richard Branson prepares for a new life as a publicly traded company.

headline: Truck Traffic in Mind, Port Agency Considers Plans for a Slow Boat to Brooklyn
abstract: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey released a draft study designed to explore upgrading a rail-barge system that ferries freight from New Jersey to Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: The potatoes about to cross New York Harbor had completed all but the last few miles of their journey by rail from Idaho. To get to their final destination, though, they had to be rolled onto a piece of transportation technology straight out of the 19th century: a slow barge to Brooklyn.

headline: Turning Seduction Into Mere Prettiness
abstract: Case Scaglione conducted the New York Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall in a program of Debussy, Glazunov and Prokofiev’s Symphony No. 5.
lead_paragraph: In an ideal performance of Debussy’s “Prélude à l’après-midi d’un faune” — a revolutionary work that broke new ground with its use of harmony — the sinuous melodies, chromatic language and innovative structure that once puzzled audiences now invariably seduce listeners.

headline: Events in New Jersey for Nov. 16-22, 2014
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: A Showcase for Browsers and Buyers
abstract: “The Salon: Art & Design” at the Park Avenue Armory features upscale pieces with international influences that span many categories.
lead_paragraph: “The Salon: Art & Design,” the toniest of the November fairs (and certainly the one with the most aristocratic title), reminds you how the categories of art and design tend to blur in the rarefied world of ultra-high-end décor. Installed at the Park Avenue Armory for a third season, it caters to browsing design aficionados as well as trophy-condo buyers and their interior designers with a mix of furniture from the 18th to the 21st centuries and an even wider range of art (and in the lounge, for those with V.I.P. cards, caviar “made by hand from sustainably farmed white sturgeon.”)

headline: Then We Could Swing a Cat From a Chandelier
abstract: “Dumb and Dumber To” reunites Jim Carrey and Jeff Daniels, adds Kathleen Turner and relies heavily on diaper gags.
lead_paragraph: In “Dumb and Dumber To,” Peter and Bobby Farrelly — and the stars Jim Carrey and Jeff Daniels — have boldly if unoriginally returned to the scene of their inaugural crime: their 1994 directing debut, “Dumb and Dumber.” An anti-classic of its disreputable, guffawing type, it wasn’t the first movie to elevate human idiocy into an intentional art; Jerry Lewis and “Caddyshack,” among many others, got there long before Lloyd (Mr. Carrey) and Harry (Mr. Daniels) hit the road in their memorably fuzzy puppy-mobile with the wagging tongue.

headline: New Museum Triennial to Examine the ‘Surround Audience’
abstract: The show, opening in February, will delve deeply into what one of its curators, Lauren Cornell, describes as “a contemporary condition wherein we are encircled by a ‘smarter’ and more participatory world.”
lead_paragraph: The New Museum announced on Thursday that its triennial, which focuses on emerging artists and opens its third iteration on Feb. 25, will feature 51 artists and collectives from more than 25 countries and will delve deeply into what one of its curators, Lauren Cornell, describes as “a contemporary condition wherein we are encircled by a ‘smarter’ and more participatory world.”

headline: Prison Officials Seeking Ways to Recruit and Retain Guards
abstract: Turnover among corrections officers has been rising statewide in Texas since 2006, according to department data.
lead_paragraph: BEEVILLE, Tex. — Seventeen soon-to-be corrections officers in blue-and-gray uniforms listened attentively as Maj. Robert Lopez explained the importance of their professional appearance and warned them of the corrupting influences they will face on the job.

headline: New York City’s Week in Pictures: Nov. 13
abstract: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include images from Veterans Day and a visit with a rat starring on Broadway.
lead_paragraph: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include images from Veterans Day and a visit with a rat starring on Broadway.

headline: Warner and Tencent Announce Licensing Deal
abstract: Warner will grant Tencent, the Chinese Internet company, licenses to use its music through Tencent’s various outlets online.
lead_paragraph: In the music industry’s latest effort to make money from China, the Warner Music Group has signed an extensive licensing deal with Tencent, one of China’s biggest Internet businesses, the companies announced on Thursday.

headline: Ebola Scare Behind It, Texas Is Bracing for the Next Viral Crisis
abstract: The biomedical researcher appointed by Gov. Rick Perry to head a state task force on infectious diseases suggests it’s only a matter of time.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — Texas recently closed the book on its first cases of Ebola. The remaining people still being monitored after having come into contact with the man who died of the disease in Dallas last month, or with two nurses who contracted it, were cleared a week ago. But the virus, or something like it, can be expected to return, said the new head of a state task force on infectious diseases.

headline: This Week’s Movies | Nov. 14, 2014
abstract: The New York Times film critics review “Foxcatcher,” “Rosewater” and “Beyond the Lights.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “Foxcatcher,” “Rosewater” and “Beyond the Lights.”

headline: A Local Prize Could Ease a Loss’s Sting
abstract: Leticia Van de Putte has options after her unsuccessful campaign for lieutenant governor. The Democrat may stay in the State Senate or run for mayor of San Antonio.
lead_paragraph: Leticia Van de Putte’s decision to run for lieutenant governor always had a win-or-win-by-losing flavor to it. The Democrat’s campaign came in the middle of her current Senate term. Had her run been successful, she would be on her way to the corner office outside the Legislature’s upper chamber. A loss was largely without cost. She remains a senator, and while Democrats are still the minority party, the Senate is the kind of place where an experienced player in the minority can sometimes exercise real power.

headline: GTT ★
abstract: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.
lead_paragraph: Our quirky, discerning picks for

headline: Goldman Sachs Recasts Its Reputation to Woo Tech Talent
abstract: In recruiting programmers from elite universities, Wall Street runs up against the idea that Silicon Valley is the technological promised land.
lead_paragraph: A panel of Goldman Sachs employees spent a recent Tuesday night at the Columbia University faculty club trying to convince a packed room of potential recruits that Wall Street, not Silicon Valley, was the place to be for computer scientists.

headline: For a Liberian Family, Ebola Turns Loving Care Into Deadly Risk
abstract: The Doryen family, unbowed survivors of Liberia’s civil war, saw seven members die from the virus in a matter of months and lost its sense of unity.
lead_paragraph: MONROVIA, Liberia — Days after Kaizer Dour died of Ebola at the edge of a mangrove swamp, strangers carried his rotting corpse in a dugout canoe for a secret burial. Out on an uninhabited, bush-covered island, far from the national basketball court where Kaizer won acclaim as one of Liberia’s most valuable players last season, the strangers fulfilled one of the most important duties of a Liberian family — burying the young man.

headline: In India, Latrines Are Truly Lifesavers
abstract: In taking on one of the country’s biggest health challenges, rural villagers need not only toilets, but behavior change.
lead_paragraph: The mural on the wall outside of Chandramani Jani’s home is more message than art. It depicts a sari-clad woman relieving herself behind a bush, looking worried as a man advances. A large thought bubble suggests the woman wishes for a toilet of her own, clean and complete with the privacy of a door.

headline: Ex-Executive Donald Blankenship Is Indicted in Disaster at Coal Mine
abstract: Donald L. Blankenship was accused of looking away from hundreds of safety violations to produce more coal while avoiding the cost of following safety laws.
lead_paragraph: The former chief executive of the company involved in the nation’s worst coal mine disaster in 40 years, in which 29 men died in West Virginia in 2010, was charged on Thursday with widespread violations of safety rules and deceiving federal inspectors.

headline: Many Forces Are Pulling DreamWorks Animation in Diverse Directions
abstract: A deal with Hasbro could feed DreamWorks’ need for growth and its push into toys and other merchandise while risking its focus and independence.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Walt Disney is a big studio built around smaller units: Marvel Entertainment, Pixar and the classic Disney animation shop, among others.

headline: Clayton Kershaw and Mike Trout Run Away With M.V.P. Votes
abstract: Kershaw became the first National League pitcher to win both the Cy Young and M.V.P. awards since Bob Gibson in 1968.
lead_paragraph: The connection is unmistakable, now more than ever, though Sandy Koufax always maintains that Clayton Kershaw is his own man, and not a protégé. Koufax deeply admires Kershaw, the modern ace of the Los Angeles Dodgers, and asked to present him with the Cy Young Award last January at the baseball writers’ dinner in New York.

headline: A Review of the Sept. 19 White House Incident
abstract: A report by the Department of Homeland Security noted “performance, organizational, technical” and other failures that allowed a man to get inside the mansion in September.
lead_paragraph: A report by the Department of Homeland Security noted “performance, organizational, technical” and other failures that allowed a man to get inside the mansion in September.

headline: With a Whisper, Pfister Takes a Comedic Jab at Highbrow Faucet Commercials
abstract: A new ad from Pfister parodies a classic Calvin Klein Obsession commercial to poke fun at campaigns that portray household faucets as luxury goods.
lead_paragraph: HOUSEHOLD faucets are the essence of functionality, but they are often advertised as luxury goods. Last year, for example, one of the leading faucet brands, Moen, introduced a television commercial in which a model in an evening dress sashays into a bathroom and puts on a gleaming, oversize necklace. The necklace then slips from her neck and, through digital animation, scatters into pieces on the counter, reassembling as a faucet. “Statement piece for your bathroom,” says a voice-over.

headline: An Agreement on Climate Change
abstract: Readers discuss the accord between the United States and China.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Doctors as Targets
abstract: Donna McKay of Physicians for Human Rights writes that when medical relief workers are perceived as enemies, “the horrific effects of disease and war are further amplified.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Net Neutrality
abstract: William F. Baker of Fordham University writes that the Internet should be treated “like a utility, not a luxury.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Gov.-Elect Larry Hogan, a Republican, Stands Tall in Democratic Maryland
abstract: The perfect political alchemy of low voter turnout, the languid campaign of his opponent and his own strong grass-roots base gave Mr. Hogan a decisive four-point victory.
lead_paragraph: DUNDALK, Maryland — Um, Larry who?

headline: For Equity in Teaching
abstract: Lynette Guastaferro of Teaching Matters writes that “teacher quality matters a lot, but so does the hyper-concentration of poor children in disadvantaged schools.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Mayor de Blasio’s Lateness
abstract: Debbie Plumer, a reader, writes that the mayor’s lateness is more than a personality trait.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Federally Contracted Food Workers Strike Over Wages
abstract: Hundreds took part in a one-day strike in Washington as labor groups called on President Obama to prioritize federal contracting to employers that pay $15 an hour.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The cafeteria lines in the Capitol Visitors Center and the National Zoo may have moved slower on Thursday after hundreds of federally contracted food service workers went on a one-day strike.

headline: A Fatally Flawed Switch, and a Burdened G.M. Engineer
abstract: Interviews with employees and documents turned over to Congress reveal a midlevel engineer who tried to satisfy orders for a smoothly functioning switch that would help G.M. improve the image of its cut-rate small cars.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Raymond DeGiorgio was just another obscure engineer at General Motors — until the company blamed him for starting the worst safety crisis in its history.

headline: Psychologists to Review Role in Detainee Interrogations
abstract: The nation’s largest organization of psychologists will investigate whether it supported the government’s use of torture in the interrogation of prisoners during the Bush administration.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The nation’s largest organization of psychologists will conduct an independent review into whether it colluded with or supported the government’s use of torture in the interrogation of prisoners during the Bush administration.

headline: Jurgen Klinsmann, Back in London, Sees Exhibition as Important Test for U.S. Men’s National Team
abstract: Klinsmann is set to coach a young United States team as it challenges Colombia in a friendly international match that he says could be a steppingstone on the path to the next World Cup.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In the drizzle outside Craven Cottage, the stadium that is home to Fulham, one of England’s oldest professional teams, the knots of fans who gathered during training sessions Thursday night for a shot at the autographs of their heroes had two men atop their lists.

headline: Portugal: Legionnaires’ Disease Alert
abstract: An outbreak of Legionnaires’ disease has killed at least five people and sickened more than 300 in Portugal, the World Health Organization reported Thursday.
lead_paragraph: An outbreak of Legionnaires’ disease has killed at least five people and sickened more than 300 in Portugal, the World Health Organization reported Thursday. It said Portuguese health authorities had first taken notice a week earlier, identifying 17 cases in Villa Franca de Xira, a suburban area of Lisbon. Since then, the W.H.O. said, the disease has spread rapidly and is now “considered to be a major public health emergency.” The precise cause of the outbreak remained under investigation, but the W.H.O. said health officials in the affected area had taken protective steps, including increasing the chlorine used in tap water and issuing public warnings to “avoid showers, Jacuzzis and whirlpools.” Legionnaires’ disease is a type of pneumonia caused by the Legionella bacteria, which survive in water or mist. It is named after a 1976 outbreak that afflicted people who attended a convention of the American Legion in Philadelphia.

headline: The Agency Moment
abstract: A bold letter from George Eliot in July 1852 exemplifies the moment she took the wheel in her life. Everyone comes to that point eventually.
lead_paragraph: George Eliot was an emotionally needy young woman. Throughout her 20s, she fell for a series of inappropriate and unavailable men, craving their affection. At one point, she got herself involved in a bizarre tangle with an editor and two other women. It was like a tragic farce as the women competed for his sympathy, complete with shifting alliances, slammed doors and storms of tears.

headline: Pentagon Studies Reveal Major Nuclear Problems
abstract: The Pentagon will spend billions on emergency fixes to its nuclear weapons infrastructure, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel will announce Friday, after two studies found “systemic problems.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon will have to spend billions of dollars over the next five years to make emergency fixes to its nuclear weapons infrastructure, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel will announce on Friday, after two separate Pentagon studies concluded that there are “systemic problems across the nuclear enterprise,” according to senior defense officials.

headline: Turkey: After an Attack on U.S. Sailors, 12 Suspects Are Charged and Released
abstract: Twelve Turks arrested in Istanbul in connection with a videotaped assault on three visiting American sailors were charged on Thursday with insult, inflicting injury and violating Turkey’s protest and rally law, but all of them were released, Turkey’s Anadolu news agency reported.
lead_paragraph: Twelve Turks arrested in Istanbul in connection with a videotaped assault on three visiting American sailors were charged on Thursday with insult, inflicting injury and violating Turkey’s protest and rally law, but all of them were released, Turkey’s Anadolu news agency reported. It said prosecutors were still investigating the assault, which happened on Wednesday. It was unclear when the suspects would reappear in court. The sailors, out of uniform, had just left their ship, the guided missile destroyer Ross, when the assailants from a nationalist youth group taunted them with anti-American insults, lobbed balloons filled with red paint at them and pulled bags over their heads. Turkish officials have denounced the attack.

headline: Who Burned Atlanta?
abstract: The story behind the city’s destruction is more complex than we remember.
lead_paragraph: At 7 a.m. on Nov. 16, 1864, Maj. Gen. William T. Sherman accompanied the last corps of his Union army as it left Atlanta to begin a virtually uncontested “March to the Sea,” which would end in Savannah five weeks later. Three miles outside the city, he stopped for a final look back. “Behind us lay Atlanta smoldering and in ruins, the black smoke rising high in the air and hanging like a pall over the ruined city,” he recalled. Presently a nearby infantry band struck up John Brown’s anthem. “Never … have I heard the chorus of ‘Glory! Glory! Hallelujah!’ done with more spirit.” The men were proud of what they had done.

headline: Window Washing Skills Beyond a Robot’s Reach
abstract: Despite the risks shown by the scaffolding collapse at 1 World Trade Center, window washing is the purview of humans, because machines are ill suited to it.
lead_paragraph: As a pair of window washers clung to a scaffold dangling outside the 68th floor of 1 World Trade Center on Wednesday, the captivating drama left some below wondering: Why were they up there at all?

headline: Obama, Down but Not Out, Presses Ahead
abstract: Following deep losses in the midterm elections, President Obama has flexed his muscles on climate change, immigration and Internet neutrality.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama emerged from last week’s midterm election rejected by voters, hobbled politically and doomed to a final two years in office suffering from early lame-duck syndrome. That, at least, was the consensus in both parties. No one seems to have told Mr. Obama.

headline: China, Coal, Climate
abstract: The agreement between China and the United States on carbon emissions is a pretty big deal.
lead_paragraph: It’s easy to be cynical about summit meetings. Often they’re just photo ops, and the photos from the latest Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation meeting, which had world leaders looking remarkably like the cast of “Star Trek,” were especially cringe-worthy. At best — almost always — they’re just occasions to formally announce agreements already worked out by lower-level officials.

headline: A House Is Not a Credit Card
abstract: Mortgages should be used to buy homes, not for refinancing.
lead_paragraph: THIS fall, federal regulators made a controversial decision to back down from tough new underwriting standards for mortgages. Some affordable-housing advocates, allied with parts of the corporate housing industry, had successfully argued that the proposed standards would make it too hard for people to qualify, thereby reducing homeownership and hurting the housing market. Last summer, that same trump card stopped a bipartisan bill to reform the mortgage market, more than six years after Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac had to be taken over by the government.

headline: Kerry Is Optimistic After Meeting Over Holy Site in Jerusalem
abstract: John Kerry met with the leaders of Jordan, Israel and the Palestinian Authority to discuss the site known to Muslims as the Noble Sanctuary and to Jews as Temple Mount.
lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan — Secretary of State John Kerry said on Thursday that Jordan, Israel and the Palestinians were committed to taking “concrete steps” to ease strife over a volatile holy site in the Old City of Jerusalem.

headline: Big and Bold on Immigration
abstract: President Obama could use his law-enforcement discretion to spare millions from deportation. The sooner he acts, the better.
lead_paragraph: President Obama is apparently ready to go big, as he promised, to fix immigration on his own — to use his law-enforcement discretion to spare perhaps five million unauthorized immigrants from deportation. Aides speaking anonymously have told The Times that Mr. Obama is considering some options for executive action that would give parents of children who are citizens or legal residents, as well as people who were brought here illegally as children, temporary legal status and permission to work.

headline: The Fed and Full Employment
abstract: The job market is improving. But absent a surge in the pace of improvement, it will still be too weak to withstand raising interest rates.
lead_paragraph: In late 2012, when the unemployment rate was 7.8 percent, Ben Bernanke, then the Federal Reserve chairman, said that the Fed would not raise interest rates as long as unemployment was above 6.5 percent. At that time, he expected the jobless rate to stay above 6.5 percent until at least mid-2015, which dovetailed with an earlier Fed projection for rate increases starting around mid-2015.

headline: A Smarter Approach to Airline Safety
abstract: All that time devoted to policing shoes could be better spent observing passengers.
lead_paragraph: John Pistole, who announced recently that he would retire as head of the Transportation Security Administration at the end of the year, saw it as his mission to transform the agency from a bureaucracy that took a “one size fits all” approach to airplane security to one that takes a more “risk based” approach. That needed change is far from complete.

headline: Iraq and Kurds Reach Deal on Oil Exports and Budget Payments
abstract: A standoff began earlier this year when Kurdish officials angered Baghdad by exporting oil produced in their region directly to Turkey and not through the Iraqi Oil Ministry.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Iraq’s central government and the autonomous region of Kurdistan reached an interim agreement on Thursday over oil exports and budget payments, at least temporarily easing a bitter dispute that has threatened the government’s stability.

headline: Race, Politics and Drawing Maps
abstract: Did Alabama go too far in moving thousands of black voters into districts that were already majority-minority?
lead_paragraph: As long as politicians are entrusted with drawing legislative maps, they will use their pen to gain partisan advantage. Courts generally do not interfere with that process, but there are limits to this where race is involved. The problem is figuring out which motive — race or partisanship — underlies the redistricting. On Wednesday, the Supreme Court considered this issue in a thorny case that could have significant implications for the future of the Voting Rights Act.

headline: At 9 Years Old, Her Troubles Were Just Beginning
abstract: A childhood trauma left Paulette Bermudez, now 58, with post-traumatic stress disorder. Other ailments and accidents have left her worried and unable to pay her bills.
lead_paragraph: When Paulette Bermudez was 9 years old, a man climbed through the window of her family’s third-floor apartment in Brooklyn, grabbed her and held a knife to her neck. He threatened her mother, then locked up Ms. Bermudez. In a closet, she thinks. She does her best to forget the details.

headline: U.N. Commission Presses U.S. on Torture
abstract: A United Nations panel that monitors compliance with an antitorture treaty expressed skepticism Thursday about American law enforcement and national security practices.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A United Nations panel that monitors compliance with an antitorture treaty expressed skepticism Thursday about American law enforcement and national security practices.

headline: The Parole Paradox
abstract: Should prisoners for whom there is strong evidence of innocence be required to admit guilt to be granted parole?

headline: Shift on Marijuana Policy Was a Long Time Coming, and Too Late for One Man
abstract: Police will no longer file charges against people who display small amounts of marijuana in public, though that has not helped Anthony Welfare, who lost his job in August over a misdemeanor.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Welfare closely followed this week’s news that New York City no longer will bring criminal charges against people who are seen with small amounts of marijuana, as long as they are not smoking it in public.

headline: Taking Issue With the Grind of the N.B.A. Season
abstract: Michele Roberts, the leader of the league’s players union, addressed quality-of-life issues that affect players with strong opinions that prompted a response from Adam Silver, the N.B.A. commissioner.
lead_paragraph: No sooner had Oklahoma City defeated Boston on Wednesday night than the Celtics’ disappointment was washed away by the anticipation of Friday night’s game at home against the Cleveland Cavaliers and the Big 3 of LeBron James, Kevin Love and Kyrie Irving.

headline: The Wasp Goddess, Imperious, Vulnerable and (Gasp) Unmasked
abstract: After an absence of nearly a decade, the famed chanteuse Lypsinka (John Epperson) returns in a trilogy of shows invoking female impersonation by women themselves.
lead_paragraph: Some women never seem to get older, because they never looked young to begin with. You know, the kind who make you think they must have been born 35, in their bountiful prime and in full makeup. You can’t help wondering, though, about what really lurks behind the lipstick, and if the mask they’re wearing ever feels too tight.

headline: What Might Break People’s Trust
abstract: Joe Krozel wiggles his way out of some tricky fill.
lead_paragraph: Administrivial Deb-Amlen-In-N.Y.C. Fun Times Alert! Pencils up, New York! If you plan to be in New York City on Sunday, Nov. 16, come hang out with me at the Ace Hotel, located at 20 West 29th Street, as I show people that they can solve the Sunday crossword puzzle with a minimum of tears and bloodshed. The fun starts at 11 a.m. E.T. and it’s open to the public. Hope to see you there, and if you are a Wordplayer, please be sure to come up and say hi. If you’re not around this weekend, the Ace has added two additional dates — December 14, 2014 and January 18, 2015 — so put it on your calendar and come solve with me! Click here for more information.

headline: E-Cigarettes Gain Among High School Students, C.D.C. Finds
abstract: About 4.5 percent of American high school students used electronic cigarettes in 2013, up from 2.8 percent in 2012, according to a survey.
lead_paragraph: The share of American high school students who use e-cigarettes rose to 4.5 percent in 2013 from 2.8 percent in 2012, according to a survey of youth tobacco use released on Thursday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The share of middle school students who use e-cigarettes remained flat at 1.1 percent over the same period.

headline: Gisèle Masson Dies at 89; Fed the Famous at La Grenouille
abstract: Mme. Masson was known to visit tables, especially during dessert, at her classic French restaurant on the East Side of Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Gisèle Masson, the grande dame of La Grenouille, the classic French restaurant on the East Side of Manhattan that was a favorite of high-society types and celebrities of various stripes, of fashion moguls and publishing executives, died on Nov. 5 in Paris. She was 89.

headline: Nowhere to Run in Eastern Ukraine
abstract: A cease-fire has been in effect in the rebel areas of eastern Ukraine since September, but severe depopulation is a clear sign that war is once again looming.
lead_paragraph: DONETSK, Ukraine — Teachers preside over half-empty classrooms. Cars breeze through streets once chronically choked with traffic. Restaurant windows are boarded up.

headline: In Sharp Pivot for N.B.A., Commissioner Backs Sports Betting
abstract: In an article on the Op-Ed page of The New York Times, Adam Silver argued that laws governing sports gambling should be changed.
lead_paragraph: N.B.A. Commissioner Adam Silver broke from years of precedent by calling for the legalization of sports gambling in an article on the Op-Ed page of The New York Times on Friday.

headline: Sudan and Rebels Under Pressure to Find Path to Peace
abstract: Talks that began Wednesday are seen as part of a comprehensive national dialogue that includes finding a way to greater political freedom.
lead_paragraph: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia — After several postponements, negotiations between Sudan’s government and rebels resumed here this week in an effort to bring peace to the worn-torn country.

headline: At Trial, Epilepsy and Questions of Blame in a Fatal Crash
abstract: Vincent Zanfardino, who had an epileptic seizure while driving in 2012 that led to a deadly crash, had been repeatedly warned by his doctor not to drive, a Bronx prosecutor said.
lead_paragraph: Vincent Zanfardino had been repeatedly warned by his doctor not to drive before he had an epileptic seizure behind the wheel two years ago and crashed into another car, killing a 25-year-old man, a Bronx prosecutor said Thursday.

headline: Delford Smith, Founder of Aviation Company, Dies at 84
abstract: Mr. Smith, whose company flew military support missions during several wars, was known for his determination to preserve the Spruce Goose, the world’s largest flying boat, which remains an attraction at the Evergreen Aviation and Space Museum.
lead_paragraph: Delford Smith, who founded a major international aviation company but who may be most remembered for his determination to preserve the mammoth seaplane known as the Spruce Goose — built in the 1940s by the wealthy recluse Howard Hughes — died on Nov. 7 at his home in Yamhill County, Ore., near Portland. He was 84.

headline: Plan for a Desalination Plant Is Halted by New York State Officials
abstract: Opponents, including environmental groups, applauded the decision to put an end to the $150 million project, which would have been built on Haverstraw Bay.
lead_paragraph: In a decision hailed by local residents and environmental groups, New York State officials on Thursday ordered a company that provides water to most of Rockland County and parts of Orange County to drop its efforts to build a desalination plant on the Hudson River in an effort to boost its water supply.

headline: Framing New York
abstract: A photographer’s view of the city that is in his mind and in his heart.
lead_paragraph: I was born in New York, but left with my family when I was young. I grew up in South Florida, where I spent most of my time in the ocean, surfing. In 1998, I returned to the city to work with the photographer Bruce Weber.

headline: This Teacher Spends Life Being Taught
abstract: Steve Kerr, who coaches the Warriors, has an approach that reflects many influences, like Lute Olson and Phil Jackson.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Steve Kerr grinned when he was asked to recall his first basketball practice at Arizona.

headline: Resurrecting the Artistry, and the Name, of a Singular Guitar Craftsman
abstract: After spending the past few years researching John D’Angelico’s instruments, three business partners have reproduced two of his original handmade guitars.
lead_paragraph: When John D’Angelico died in 1964, at the age of 59, he left behind a line of guitars that he had made by hand, one by one, in his shop below his apartment on Kenmare Street on the Lower East Side. His archtop guitars produced a stirring sound that could stand up to horns and percussion in big bands, and became some of the most coveted instruments in the world.

headline: Gus Vlahavas, 76, Who Ran a Brooklyn Culinary Haven, Dies
abstract: The ice cream parlor was a family institution, opened in 1936 by Mr. Vlahavas’s grandfather.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday mornings, Tom’s restaurant in Brooklyn is so popular that people line up outside just to be served old-fashioned diner cuisine like chocolate egg creams and all manner of pancakes. It has been that way for years, and until the owner, Gus Vlahavas, died this month at 76, the patrons’ patience was rewarded with the free coffee, cookies, sausage bits and orange slices he handed out while they waited.

headline: Struggling Avalanche Find an Answer Against the Rangers
abstract: The Colorado Avalanche have only five wins in 18 games to start the season after defeating the Rangers on Thursday night.
lead_paragraph: Joe Sakic remembers well his early years with the Quebec Nordiques, when he and his fellow young teammates Mats Sundin and Owen Nolan were scoring in bunches for the struggling team.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 13, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbersfor New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Prosecutions of Parents Can Vary After Children Left in Sweltering Cars Die
abstract: The case of Kyle Seitz, who forgot to drop off his toddler at day care in Connecticut, has raised questions about whether prosecuting a neglectful driver is warranted, or if the parent had been punished enough already.
lead_paragraph: Haley Wesley, Lyn Balfour and Mikey Terry each had a different experience with the criminal justice system.

headline: A Successor Shares Martin Brodeur’s Stamina
abstract: Cory Schneider is set to make his career-high 17th straight start Friday night in Washington against the Capitals.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — When the Devils acquired Cory Schneider in a draft-day trade in 2013, they acquired the heir apparent to the legendary goaltender Martin Brodeur.

headline: Brushing Off a French Stigma That Doggie Bags Are for Beggars
abstract: Authorities in Lyon, France, are promoting doggie bags, long stigmatized as a sign of poverty, in local restaurants to curb food waste.
lead_paragraph: LYON, France — Fabrice Moya, a chef with a boyish grin who opened a restaurant by the same name here 12 years ago, has no problems with doggie bags.

headline: A New One-Stop Shop for Practical, Internationally Sourced Home Goods
abstract: The Japanese home wares vendor Momoko Mizutani has opened her first brick and mortar shop in London’s East End.
lead_paragraph: Three years ago, Momoko Mizutani gathered a collection of finely crafted homewares she’d accumulated while traveling and opened a store, Objects for Use, in London’s East End. Mizutani’s items were pragmatic and of diverse origin — doughnut pans from Denmark, five-kilo sauerkraut pots from Germany, woven bamboo baskets from Japan — and they represented her interests in ethical craftsmanship and traditional techniques as much as her own personal history. Originally from Japan, Mizutani moved to London as a teenager to study product design, and the objects she selected reflected her bicultural identity. “Each item was made for a specific purpose in one culture but could be used in new ways,” she says. “They each suggested a sense of place.”

headline: Where the Wild Things Are
abstract: Warm and fuzzy winter pieces range from the bold to the understated, all with extra fluff this season.
lead_paragraph: Warm winter pieces are putting their fuzziest feet forward this season via Muppet-like textures and shaggy shapes. Bold colors create a floral motif on a Michael Kors angora sweater and the appearance of a cuddly face on Fendi’s hairy handbag. The color-blocked fur on a pair of Brian Atwood shoes and Peter Pilotto collar add extra oomph to any outfit, while the understated fluff on a pair of Max Mara ‘S Max cuffs or a Michael Kors hat will complement any wardrobe all season long.

headline: An Anemic Auction Yields Just $52 Million at Phillips
abstract: The night surpassed its low estimate, but fell far short of its high estimate of $67.7 million, during a week when prices at Sotheby’s and Christie’s soared.
lead_paragraph: Even after more than $1 billion worth of contemporary art sold at Sotheby’s and Christie’s earlier this week — an unprecedented sum for any auction season — there were still a few shoppers with the itch to spend. But at Phillips on Thursday evening, they spent carefully.

headline: Word of the Day | downcast
abstract: This word has appeared in 45 New York Times articles in the last year.
lead_paragraph: downcast •\ˈdau̇n-ˌkast\• adjective

headline: Nebraska: Center to Treat Ebola Patient
abstract: An Ebola patient in Sierra Leone will be transported to a hospital on Saturday if he is healthy enough to make the trip, hospital officials said.
lead_paragraph: An Ebola patient in Sierra Leone will be transported to a hospital in Nebraska on Saturday if he is healthy enough to make the trip, hospital officials said on Thursday night. The patient, who recently tested positive for Ebola, would be the third person treated for the virus at Nebraska Medical Center’s special biocontainment unit in Omaha. The hospital said in a statement that that the man would be evaluated for possible treatment by a medical crew flying to Sierra Leone. “The members of the crew will determine whether the patient is stable enough for transport — if he is, he would arrive in Omaha sometime Saturday afternoon,” the statement said. The hospital previously treated two Americans: Ashoka Mukpo, a freelance cameraman released last month, and Dr. Rick Sacra, a missionary released in September. Eight of the nine people treated for the virus in the United States have recovered from it.

headline: What’s on TV Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (CBS) HOLLYWOOD FILM AWARDS Queen Latifah hosts the first televised ceremony, live from the Hollywood Pavilion in Los Angeles, of this event, founded in 1997 and billed as “the official launch of the awards season.” Janelle Monáe is to perform; Amy Adams, Steve Carell, Benedict Cumberbatch, Johnny Depp, Robert Downey Jr., Angelina Jolie, Jared Leto, Keira Knightley, Michael Keaton and Channing Tatum are scheduled to appear. Red-carpet coverage leads in at 7:30; Charlie Rose, Norah O’Donnell and Gayle King will interview winners and recap the evening’s highlights in “The CBS Hollywood After Party,” at 10.

headline: South Korea Suspends Asiana Flights Between Incheon and San Francisco
abstract: The penalty is for the 2013 crash that killed three passengers, the first fatal airliner disaster in the United States in more than four years.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — South Korea’s transport ministry decided on Friday to suspend Asiana Airlines’ flights between Incheon, South Korea, and San Francisco for 45 days as a penalty for the crash of one of its jets in the United States last year.

headline: Corrections: November 14, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Friday, November 14, 2014.
lead_paragraph: NATIONAL

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, November 14, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “They were together, a strong family, but this Ebola broke the entire family apart.”

headline: E.U. Accuses Starbucks and Netherlands of Making Unfair Tax Deal
abstract: The arrangement helped lower taxes for the coffee company, creating unfair advantages over other European Union countries, authorities said.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — European Union authorities have accused the Netherlands of making a special deal with Starbucks that helped the company lower its taxes, creating unfair advantages over other countries in the bloc.

headline: Q. and A.: Edward J. Ramotowski on Implications of the New U.S.-China Visa Policy
abstract: The State Department official discusses how the new visa policy came about, what remains to be done and where the United States stands to benefit.
lead_paragraph: The United States and Chinese governments announced on Monday a significant easing of visa regulations that would grant 10-year multiple-entry business and tourist visas for each others’ citizens. Students and exchange visitors could receive five-year visas. Under previous rules, most visitors received only one-year visas. China already sends the largest number of nonimmigrant foreign visitors to the United States, recently overtaking Mexico. The visa changes are expected to accelerate that increase.

headline: Eurozone Eked Out Growth in Third Quarter
abstract: The euro economy grew 0.6 percent in the third quarter on an annualized basis, raising concern that the Continent’s troubles will ripple out.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The European economy is barely managing to pull out of a rut, raising concern among global policy makers that continued sluggishness in the eurozone’s richest countries may begin to ripple beyond the Continent’s borders and pose risks to the recovery in the United States.

headline: North Korea to Send Senior Envoy to Russia
abstract: North Korea is seeking to improve its ties with Russia as a possible counterbalance to China.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, plans to send a senior envoy to Moscow, state-run media announced on Friday, as the country seeks to improve its relations with Russia.

headline: Gold Bars, Moldy Cash and a Chinese Official’s Mom Who Can Explain It All
abstract: Anticorruption investigators say they found in a family home some 120 million renminbi in cash, 37 kilograms of gold bars and ownership documents for 68 homes, including seven in expensive parts of Beijing.
lead_paragraph: Chinese newspapers provided a valuable life lesson on Friday: If you stumble over 37 kilograms of gold bars and more than 40 boxes holding $20 million or so of moldy cash in a closet, don’t panic! Ask your mother.

headline: Test Yourself | Alex From Target: The Other Side of Fame
abstract: Can you choose the best word or phrase to complete each blank?
lead_paragraph: Below are the first seven paragraphs of the Nov. 12 article “Alex From Target: The Other Side of Fame.”

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | In Deaths of Dogs in Arizona, a Human Story of Loss and Intrigue
abstract: What happened to more than a dozen dogs left at Green Acre Dog Boarding?
lead_paragraph: In “In Deaths of Dogs in Arizona, a Human Story of Loss and Intrigue,” Rick Rojas writes about the deaths of 22 dogs in June at a boarding business in Arizona.

headline: An Elusive Roof of One’s Own in Lisbon
abstract: A project about squatters and the homeless in Lisbon examines the overlooked casualties of Portugal’s economic troubles.
lead_paragraph: They don’t live, they survive.

headline: How Much Do Your Parents Help With Your Homework?
abstract: Are you happy with the way your parents support you with your homework? Or do you wish they would handle it differently? Why?
lead_paragraph: What’s the homework situation in your family? How much do your parents help with your homework? And in what ways?

headline: Q. and A.: Kung Tsui-chang on Life as the Heir to Confucius
abstract: Kung Tsui-chang, a 39-year-old businessman in Taiwan who is the 79th-generation direct descendant of Confucius, discusses what it was like growing up in the family of such a famous figure.
lead_paragraph: Kung Tsui-chang is a 39-year-old businessman in Taiwan who is the 79th-generation direct descendant of Confucius. He inherited the title of Sacrificial Official to Confucius from his grandfather, Kung Te-cheng, who died in 2008. The position was created by the Republic of China in 1935 after it abolished the title of Duke of Yansheng, a noble rank in Imperial China given to the descendants of the Chinese scholar and philosopher.

headline: ABN Amro to Cut Jobs in Shift to Digital
abstract: ABN Amro said on Friday that it would spend about $187 million on upgrading its digital banking operations and cut up to 1,000 full-time jobs by 2018.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — ABN Amro, the state-owned Dutch lender, said on Friday that it planned to cut up to 1,000 jobs in its retail bank and invest significantly in its digital platform over the next four years, as customers increasingly conduct their financial lives online.

headline: Obama and Aung San Suu Kyi Meet Again, With Battle Scars
abstract: President Obama met with Daw Aung San Suu Kyi in a show of support for Myanmar’s reform process, despite evidence of the nation’s backsliding.
lead_paragraph: YANGON, Myanmar — The last time President Obama met with Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, in 2012, it was in the glow of Myanmar’s opening to the West — a historic turn toward democracy that handed Mr. Obama a diplomatic victory and catapulted Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi, the pro-democracy icon, from house arrest to the political front lines.

headline: The Philae Lander Is Onboard Comet 67P
abstract: The European Space Agency’s Rosetta mission successfully landed a small craft on the surface of a comet.
lead_paragraph: The European Space Agency’s Rosetta mission successfully landed a small craft on the surface of a comet.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: New York Today: The Week in Pictures
abstract: Friday: Life inside a clock tower, clearing and cold, and an alarm clock for a tardy mayor.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this semi-wintry Friday.

headline: Week 11 N.F.L. Matchups
abstract: This week’s games feature a trip to Lambeau Field for the Philadelphia Eagles, who are playing behind a resurgent Mark Sanchez, and will face a Green Bay Packers team that is 41-10 when Aaron Rodgers starts on their home field.
lead_paragraph: Eagles (7-2) at Packers (6-3)

headline: Thomas Middelhoff, Ex-Chief of Bertelsmann, Gets 3-Year Prison Term Over Misuse of Funds
abstract: Mr. Middelhoff had faced criminal charges for having the German retailer Arcandor pay for private flights and other personal expenses.
lead_paragraph: In the dour environs of German executive suites, Thomas Middelhoff always stood out. In a nation of engineers, he was a deal maker, a salesman and a digital prophet who tried to turn the staid media giant Bertelsmann into an Internet company.

headline: Art Spawned by Hong Kong Protest; Now to Make It Live On
abstract: Art lovers and historians are scrambling to find ways to preserve the explosion of art that has arisen in public spaces occupied by pro-democracy demonstrators.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Thousands of pastel Post-it notes, marked with messages of support for pro-democracy demonstrators, form a fluttering collage that snakes around the wall of a staircase outside Hong Kong government headquarters. Nearby stands “Umbrella Man,” a 12-foot-tall wood sculpture of a figure holding a bright yellow umbrella.

headline: Daily Report: E-Book Standoff Is Over, but Fear of Amazon Persists
abstract: The accord allows the publisher to set prices on its e-books, a major issue in a battle that led Amazon to discourage sales of Hachette books
lead_paragraph: Hachette won an important victory on Thursday in its battle with Amazon: the ability to set its own prices for e-books, which it sees as critical to its survival. But even as the publisher and retailer announced a negotiated peace after sparring since January, hardly anyone seemed in the mood for celebratory fireworks, David Streitfeld reports.

headline: First Look at Health Insurance Rates for Next Year Is Encouraging
abstract: Premiums are barely rising in major cities, according to two studies, but shopping around is a key.
lead_paragraph: Early evidence suggests that competition in the new Affordable Care Act marketplaces is working, at least in some areas. Health insurance premiums in major cities around the country are barely rising.

headline: 1914: Indian Infantry Routs Turks
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The Turkish army was chased from a fort in 1914.
lead_paragraph: ADEN — (delayed in transmission) The shells of a British cruiser have demolished the Turkish forts at Sheikh Said, near Perim. Indian infantry, which was landed from a transport under the enemy’s fire, has blown up the guns and magazines of the position. The Turks fled in disorder before the irresistible advance of the Indians. Some of them were captured and brought here. The British casualties were slight. Three native infantrymen were killed and a few were wounded. Two British officers were wounded. There were no naval casualties. The enemy’s losses, on the other hand, were considerable. Sheikh Said is an important strategical position, commanding the Straits of Bab-el-Mande. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Nov. 15, 1914

headline: Building a Serious Website Without Serious, or Any, Coding Skills
abstract: Bubble, a cloud-based tool, is for users who have never written a line of code.
lead_paragraph: For many start-ups, a website is just the business’s online presence, a place to be found. For other start-ups, however, the website is the business. Think Airbnb, Match.com, Kickstarter or eBay. Generally, entrepreneurs who want to build that kind of business either have to employ software engineers or be software engineers. But Bubble, a cloud-based tool, hopes to change that.

headline: Today in Politics
abstract: House Democrats took a beating in the Republican wave on election night, but they’ve been doing pretty well ever since.
lead_paragraph: And Then There Were 5: Races Still Awaiting a Victor

headline: Morning Agenda: Net Neutrality’s Effect on Comcast
abstract: Net neutrality could give Comcast a way out of its Time Warner Cable acquisition. | Warren E. Buffett’s deal for Duracell satisfies a number of his deal-making preferences. | Virgin America to begin trading. | Goldman seeks to lure tech talent.
lead_paragraph: NET NEUTRALITY COULD AFFECT COMCAST’S DEAL | Comcast’s $45 billion deal for Time Warner Cable may have seemed like a good idea earlier this year. But now that President Obama has endorsed net neutrality, Comcast might have buyer’s remorse, Steven Davidoff Solomon writes in the Deal Professor column. Given how much detractors have urged the Federal Communications Commission to reject the deal, Comcast may now find, ironically, that the only way out is to have the F.C.C. block the transaction. “This F.C.C. battle all comes down to whether bigger in and of itself is a problem, and President Obama’s statements only add to the troubles for this deal,” Mr. Davidoff Solomon writes.

headline: U.S. to Give $3 Billion to Climate Fund to Help Poor Nations, and Spur Rich Ones
abstract: The pledge, on the heels of an announcement that the United States and China will commit to curbing greenhouse gas emissions, is expected at the Group of 20 summit meeting this weekend.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama announced on Saturday that the United States will contribute $3 billion to a new international fund intended to help the world’s poorest countries address the effects of climate change.

headline: How Did Obama Lose American Voters?
abstract: Many observers look to the record — say, the botched rollout of Healthcare.gov — but maybe the president’s disconnect with voters goes to the office, not the man.
lead_paragraph: In December 2012, 56 percent of Americans approved of President Obama’s leadership. About 40 percent disapproved.

headline: Pizza, Dubstep and the Fight for Net Neutrality
abstract: Groups that support a free and open Internet turned held an unusual protest that involved pizza and dance music outside the F.C.C.’s offices.
lead_paragraph: Groups that support a free and open Internet turned a protest outside the Federal Communications Commission headquarters into a party on Thursday night, as they tried to pressure the agency to keep the web that way and celebrated President Obama’s support of their effort.

headline: International Arts Events Happening in the Week Ahead
abstract: A slideshow of arts events taking place across the world this coming week.

abstract: Elizabeth Emanuel decides to try crowdfunding to support her brand.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Emanuel, one-half of the design team that made the sartorial meringue that went round the world (otherwise known as Princess Diana’s wedding dress), is back and taking a somewhat … different approach to her business, now called the Art of Being.

headline: Sweden Says Mystery Vessel in Its Waters Was a Foreign Submarine
abstract: Although the craft was never found, and numerous reports at the time said it was Russian, the authorities did not blame any particular country for the intrusion.
lead_paragraph: Swedish officials said Friday that a mysterious vessel detected in the waters off Stockholm last month was a foreign submarine that had violated its territorial waters.

abstract: Daily Clip Report is a collection of articles about the media and The Times that is emailed each day to senior executives and newsroom managers here.

headline: NYTLNreads | Send Us a Photo That Shows Teaching or Learning With The New York Times
abstract: This week we received two photos of people enjoying The New York Times that we just couldn’t keep them to ourselves. And they made us wonder what other interesting images we might get if we just asked. Send us yours for a future installment of NYTLNreads.
lead_paragraph: This week we received two photos we just couldn’t keep to ourselves — and they made us wonder what other interesting images teachers and students might send in if we just asked.

abstract: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

abstract: Maurizio Cattelan and Pierpaolo Ferrari of Toilet Paper magazine have applied their cheeky brand of humor to housewares.
lead_paragraph: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.

headline: Bittersweet Sixteen
abstract: There are lots of milestones as kids move through adolescence: 10, when you enter double digits; 13 when you become a teenager; 18 when you finish high school. But when you are a kid with a driver’s license and access to a car, 16 is a game changer.
lead_paragraph: Sixteen is when they slip out the door. It happens so unexpectedly you hardly notice. Until you do.

headline: Nicola Sturgeon Becomes Leader of Scottish National Party
abstract: Ms. Sturgeon moved into the job after 10 years as deputy leader and immediately suggested that the party might seek a new referendum on independence.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — After 10 years as deputy leader, Nicola Sturgeon moved into the top job of the pro-independence Scottish National Party on Friday and immediately suggested that the party might seek another referendum on separation from the United Kingdom after the defeat of an independence vote in September.

headline: The Folklore of Finance: Beliefs That Contribute to Investors’ Failure
abstract: Investors are misled by overconfidence, inability to focus on long-term goals amid distractions, and distrust of professional advisers, a study found.
lead_paragraph: WHEN most people think of folklore, they think of ancient stories passed down through the ages. The tales may be instructive, amusing or both, but few take them as entirely true. Still, they represent an oral tradition that once helped people make sense of the world.

headline: Obama Meets Myanmar’s Opposition Leader
abstract: President Obama and Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the Myanmar opposition leader, spoke after meeting at her residence in Yangon.
lead_paragraph: President Obama and Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the Myanmar opposition leader, spoke after meeting at her residence in Yangon.

lead_paragraph: Obama and Aung San Suu Kyi Meet Again, With Battle Scars

headline: The Policy at the Heart of the Jonathan Gruber Controversy
abstract: The line between what constitutes federal taxes or spending and what doesn’t is often debatable.
lead_paragraph: The controversy this week around the comments of a health economist, Jonathan Gruber, about President Obama’s health law has centered on his most explosive remarks, captured on video, about the “stupidity of the American voter” and the suggestion that the law was passed dishonestly. It was those blunt remarks that have Republicans in Congress talking about a new round of hearings to assail the law and, one imagines, a man who helped create its intellectual architecture.

headline: Hatching a Pilot
abstract: The story of one writer’s path from idea to network series candidate.
lead_paragraph: You with your feet up, remote in one hand and beverage in the other, being all judge-y about this fall’s new network dramas and sitcoms. Just take a moment, will you, and think of us writers gutting ourselves trying to create them. Think of us lumbering from lot to Hollywood lot, fingernails in our teeth and oil in our bowels, pitching what we hope you’ll be criticizing next fall.

headline: Choosing to Live Abroad in Retirement
abstract: Older Americans who relocate with a foreign-national partner or spouse have many matters to consider, especially taxes and health care.
lead_paragraph: IT began with a spontaneous kiss from a man she had met only a few days earlier, in a restaurant in Vence, a small town in the South of France. “It was shocking to me,” recalled Patrice Smith, when the handsome Dutch computer engineer so impetuously bussed her.

headline: Mysterious Visitor, Clad in Fur, Puts Paris on Edge
abstract: A large animal on the loose on the outskirts of Paris is not a tiger but another species of feline, news agencies reported.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Police officers were sent to guard schools, while hundreds of security officers scoured large areas near the French capital. Spooked drivers locked their car doors. Residents cowered at home, fearful that a menacing tiger would devour them whole.

headline: Domestic Violence and Homelessness: Reporter’s Notebook
abstract: Mia Navarro discussed how she put together her report on the connection between domestic violence and New York City’s rocketing homeless shelter population.
lead_paragraph: On Nov. 10, Mia Navarro wrote an article about the connection between domestic violence and New York City’s rocketing homeless shelter population. Here she supplies insight into how she put her affecting — and disturbing — story together.

headline: Win or Lose on Sunday, Social Media Is a Draw
abstract: Teams are promoting themselves more creatively through Facebook, Instagram and Twitter, but struggling N.F.L. squads have learned that criticism from the disgruntled comes with the territory.
lead_paragraph: Jerry Knaak knows the Oakland Raiders’ record, but he also has a job to do. So the day after the Raiders lost in Seattle to drop to 0-8, Knaak, their director of digital media, set about reviewing a Twitter post promoting the midseason report on the team’s website.

headline: 1964: C.I.A. Notes Split in Red Bloc
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: the C.I.A. chief discussed the Soviets in 1964.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Central Intelligence Agency Director John A. McCone said last night [Nov. 14] that the “depth of the schism” between the Soviet Union and Communist China is greater than generally believed and that “the problems of repairing it appear insurmountable.” In his first public address since taking office more than three years ago, Mr. McCone admitted that the fall of Soviet Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev was “a distinct surprise to us.” But he also said the ouster was an equal surprise to the Soviet party Presidium. “They didn’t know they had the strength to remove him until they sat down to their final meeting on Oct. 14,” Mr. McCone said. The C.I.A. director gave his agency credit for predicting Communist China’s first nuclear explosion “almost to the day.” To defeat the ultrasophisticated security apparatus in every Communist country, he said, required the use of highly refined technical devices. In analyzing recent events in the Soviet Union, Mr. McCone said the Russian people resented their government’s tremendous expenditure on military hardware while they were forced to go without. He said this internal problem was ‘‘created by the Soviets’ spending beyond their resources.” — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Nov. 16, 1964

headline: Love and Reflux
abstract: Is acid indigestion eroding your sex life as well as your esophagus?
lead_paragraph: A few months ago, after months of throat and bronchial problems, I was told I had a silent form of gastroesophageal reflux disease, or GERD.

headline: French Hunt Wild Cat in Paris Suburbs
abstract: French officials discussed the search for a large cat, originally thought to be a tiger, that was first spotted close to Disneyland Paris on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: French officials discussed the search for a large cat, originally thought to be a tiger, that was first spotted close to Disneyland Paris on Thursday.

headline: Virtual Reality Fails Its Way to Success
abstract: For decades, V.R. was a complete flop. But now with the nausea-free Oculus Rift, it may be a total win.
lead_paragraph: Of all the praise heaped upon Oculus, the virtual-reality company that Facebook acquired for $2 billion earlier this year, perhaps the most significant has been this: non-nauseating. I can testify to that after my visit last month to the groovy downtown Manhattan offices of Relevent, a marketing agency that has created a virtual-reality demo for HBO to help promote its hit series “Game of Thrones.” Without much small talk, Ian Cleary, Relevent’s vice president of “innovation and ideation,” escorted me into a steampunk cage the size of a phone booth, made of iron and wood. He fitted me with headphones and the Oculus Rift, as the company’s flagship product is called, a blocky set of black maxigoggles with an internal screen positioned inches from the eyes. I promptly lost awareness of the screen, and after a few seconds, a bass speaker under the floorboards began to boom. All I knew next was that I was shooting up, as in an outdoor elevator, to a windy summit and then trudging through lightly packed snow — crunch, crunch, crunch — onto a vertiginous ledge of ice.

headline: Warren Opposes a Treasury Nominee With Wall Street Ties
abstract: Elizabeth Warren will not vote to confirm Antonio Weiss, a Wall Street investment banker nominated this week to be Treasury undersecretary for domestic finance.
lead_paragraph: Less than 24 hours after ascending to a leadership post in the Senate Democratic caucus, Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts is flexing her populist, anti-Wall Street muscle and opposing a high-profile Obama administration nominee.

headline: The Death of the Private Eye
abstract: Now that we have Facebook and the N.S.A., who needs a gumshoe?
lead_paragraph: Imagine, for a second, a modern private-detective movie. A weeping wife is seated in the smoky, wood-paneled office of Skip Tracer, private investigator and overwrought cliché. She suspects that her husband is having an affair and wants Skip to tail him. He agrees, shakes on it, then cruises hubby’s Facebook profile to find that — quite by accident, being both a rookie adulterer and lousy with his iPhone settings — he has publicly announced his presence at one of those by-the-hour joints, right around the corner. Skip escorts his client to the precise latitudinal and longitudinal coordinates, where she catches her soon-to-be-ex in flagrante delicto. Case closed. Having unearthed no leads about jewel-encrusted falcons or municipal water theft, our modern P.I. vanishes back into the past, deserting a present moment that doesn’t have much use for him anyway.

headline: What if an Athlete Wants to Bet on Himself?
abstract: A Rose by any other name; the great pumpkin scam.
lead_paragraph: An athlete who bets against his team — or himself — clearly has a conflict of interest in the outcome of the game. It’s not obvious to me, however, why an athlete betting in favor of his team (or himself) would be doing anything unethical whatsoever. What am I missing? GRAHAM SINGER, CHICAGO

headline: The Ice-Bucket Racket
abstract: A viral stunt unlocks secrets about how we give to charity.
lead_paragraph: Ever since the ice-bucket challenge swept the Internet this summer, raising more than $115 million for A.L.S. research, a legion of imitators has sprung up to try and cash in themselves. In the approaching holiday season, as fund-raising appeals swell, we can now smash a pie in our faces, snap selfies first thing in the morning or take a photo of ourselves grabbing our crotches, among other tasteful gestures, to express solidarity with various worthy causes. But the failure of these newer gimmicks to enjoy anywhere near the same popularity as the frigid original demonstrates the peculiar and finicky nature of our altruism — a psychological puzzle that both scientists and economists are trying to decipher.

headline: My Country of Origin? It’s Complicated
abstract: The police officer asked where I was from. Finally, the answer meant something.
lead_paragraph: In April, I was stopped at a police checkpoint at 2 in the morning. Being pulled over for any other reason is a drag; being pulled over for a sobriety check when you’re cold sober is exhilarating. It doesn’t matter where you are in life; for those five minutes, you’re an all-star. “Can you recite the alphabet starting at D and ending at W?” Can I ever! Watch me nail it. “I need you to count backward from 97 to 63.” I hope you’re recording this. Because you’re going to be so impressed you’re going to want to play it for all your friends back at the station.

abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: MY CAPTIVITY IN SYRIA

lead_paragraph: Mina Andreeva, the European Commission deputy chief spokeswoman, called new economic growth in the eurozone “a small piece of good news,” but warned policymakers not to become complacent.

headline: For Democrats, Turnout Efforts Look Successful (Though Not Elections)
abstract: The turnout effort was relatively successful, even though Democrats failed to mobilize enough voters to win several important races.
lead_paragraph: The Democrats invested millions of dollars in a vaunted field operation to mobilize the young and nonwhite voters who do not usually participate in midterm elections. Yet it was not enough to save Democrats from a Republican landslide.

headline: Nina Jacobson Isn’t Afraid to Fight Hollywood’s Old Guard
abstract: The producer of “Mockingjay,” the newest “Hunger Games” movie, on bringing a female protagonist to the silver screen, with bow and arrow in tow.
lead_paragraph: The producer of “Mockingjay” talks with Taffy Brodesser-Akner about getting the most out of the “Hunger Games” franchise (without being too grabby) and the rise of the female protagonist.

abstract: The European aeronautics group also reported that net profit in its third quarter had fallen 41 percent.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The Airbus Group warned Friday that the costs associated with a much-delayed military transport plane could increase after the European aerospace giant failed to meet a deadline for equipping the aircraft with combat capabilities.

headline: Going Blind a Little at a Time
abstract: Her eyes were healthy, so why couldn’t she see?
lead_paragraph: Her eyes were healthy, so why couldn’t she see?
