abstract: A reporter went to Prospect Park seeking to measure the speed of anything that moved, from footballs to sea lions.
lead_paragraph: A radar gun seems like such an elegantly simple device in the hands of a cop or a coach.

headline: Fresh Pumpkin Pie
abstract: Melissa Clark’s trick for making creamy pumpkin pie: use fresh butternut squash instead of canned pumpkin.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Clark’s trick for making creamy pumpkin pie: use fresh butternut squash instead of canned pumpkin.

headline: Deciding Whether to Disclose Mental Disorders to the Boss
abstract: Telling an employer or supervisor about a mental disability carries potential risks and benefits, so it merits careful consideration.
lead_paragraph: ABOUT six months ago, Patrick Ross knew things had reached a breaking point at work. An angry email he had sent to a superior — combined with occasional temper flare-ups and brusque interactions with colleagues — was endangering his job of two years as deputy director of communication at the United States Patent and Trademark Office.

headline: Ask Well | Are Eggs Good for My Heart?
abstract: Readers asked Well, are eggs heart-healthy after all? Watch this video before you eat.
lead_paragraph: Readers asked Well, are eggs heart-healthy after all? Watch this video before you eat.

headline: If It Moves, Clock It
abstract: Armed with a radar gun, the reporter Andy Newman attempts to measure the speed of a running dog, a kite and a sea lion in Prospect Park.
lead_paragraph: Armed with a radar gun, the reporter Andy Newman attempts to measure the speed of a running dog, a kite and a sea lion in Prospect Park.

headline: Feit, Maker of Handmade Luxury Shoes, Sets Up Shop in NoLIta
abstract: The minimalist accessories label has opened its first store in North America on Prince Street.
lead_paragraph: For brothers Josh and Tull Price, “handmade” isn’t just a promise on a label but the basis of their burgeoning brand, Feit. The founders of the luxury shoe and accessories line, which is currently sold online and at specialty stores like Dover Street Market, are old-school cobblers disguised as contemporary conscientious creatives. Their designs are intentionally minimal to show off technique; the limited-run, slow-fashion approach is tailored to ensure a smaller environmental impact. Now, the Australian-born duo has opened their second stand-alone store and first in North America in NoLIta. The 500-square-foot space was conceived with the artist Jordana Maisie and is being touted as an installation, rather than a traditional shop. “We wanted to create a space that would allow the elements of craft and creativity to come to the forefront,” Tull says.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE PARTHENON ENIGMA,  by Joan Breton Connelly. (Vintage, $17.95.) Since the Enlightenment, the Parthenon — that glorious Athenian temple built between 447 and 432 B.C. — has been venerated as the definitive symbol of Western democratic values. Deftly challenging conventional wisdom, Connelly reaches back across millenniums to reinterpret the building’s 525-foot-long sculptured frieze, seeing in the “elaborate narrative tableau” not a snapshot of a civic festival but rather a mythical tale of human sacrifice.

headline: Indian State Recalls Pills Linked to Sterilization Deaths
abstract: Officials in Chhattisgarh State issued an urgent warning to practitioners to cease distribution of the antibiotic ciprofloxacin after at least 15 deaths were linked to contaminated pills.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The women who died after sterilization surgery in the Indian state of Chhattisgarh might have been given antibiotic pills contaminated with rat poison, a senior official said on Friday.

headline: An #AskDrH Question on Energy Science for Obama’s Science Team
abstract: I ask President Obama’s science adviser how the president plans to work with Republicans to renew American energy research.
lead_paragraph: John P. Holdren, President Obama’s science adviser, is soliciting questions via Vine, Twitter, Facebook and Instagram. Here’s mine, as submitted via Twitter:

abstract: What is the current recommendation on eating eggs and heart health?
lead_paragraph: Question:

headline: A ‘Side Show’ Number for Times Square
abstract: A digital billboard will broadcast the Act I finale of the Broadway musical “Side Show” on Monday.
lead_paragraph: The sideshows of Times Square have been gone for decades. But a bit of their spirit will be resurrected there on Nov. 17 when a digital billboard will broadcast the Act I finale of the Broadway revival of the musical “Side Show,” live from the St. James Theater.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE LAUGHING MONSTERS,  by Denis Johnson. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $25.) Johnson’s cheerfully nihilistic novel about two scammers and rogue spies in Africa derives much of its situation from several of his early journalistic pieces.

headline: Virgin America Soars in Stock Debut
abstract: In midmorning trading, the airline’s stock price was up more than 27 percent, to $29.36, giving the company a market valuation of about $1.3 billion.
lead_paragraph: Shares in Virgin America rose more than 27 percent on Friday morning, as the low-cost airline backed by Richard Branson began its new life as a publicly traded company.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: John Cleese, whose memoir “So, Anyway. . .” is No. 9 on the hardcover nonfiction list, once wrote to a fan: “I am very very very very very very important.”
lead_paragraph: Completely Different: “So, Anyway. . . ,” a memoir by the British comedian and actor John Cleese, enters the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 9. Is Cleese the funniest movie star of all time? Last summer, when Time Out London ranked the Top 100 comedies, Cleese and his accomplices in Monty Python had two films among the top five — “Life of Brian” at No. 3 and “The Holy Grail” at No. 5 — while “The Meaning of Life” came in at No. 58. Cleese also appeared in a couple of non-Python movies on the list: “Clockwise” at No. 80 and, with his Python sidekick Michael Palin, “A Fish Called Wanda” at No. 87. (This dominance may explain why the American Film Institute, compiling a similar project in 2000, stayed true to its name and limited the choice to American films.)

headline: The President Who Never Earned His Varsity Letter
abstract: Football played a surprisingly large part in Richard Nixon’s life.
lead_paragraph: For a president who never made the front line of his college squad, football played a surprisingly large part in Richard Nixon’s life.

headline: Divided by a Windfall
abstract: Leaving the Mitchell-Lama program paves the way for market-rate sales at Southbridge Towers. Sound good? Not everyone thinks so.
lead_paragraph: Most New Yorkers would look upon the good fortune of the residents of Southbridge Towers with envy. They paid, on average, $17,500 for their Lower Manhattan apartments, many with stunning East River views. The average maintenance fee in the middle-income development in the financial district near South Street Seaport is $620 a month. And soon, their fortunes could soar even higher.

headline: Daniel Bolger’s ‘Why We Lost’
abstract: In “Why We Lost,” Daniel Bolger says abysmal generalship doomed American efforts in Iraq and Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: The author of this book has a lot to answer for. “I am a United States Army general,” Daniel Bolger writes, “and I lost the Global War on Terrorism.” The fault is not his alone, of course. Bolger’s peers offered plenty of help. As he sees it, in both Afghanistan and Iraq, abysmal generalship pretty much doomed American efforts.

headline: Claire Prentice’s ‘Lost Tribe of Coney Island’
abstract: In the early 1900s, an American huckster brought despair to a group of Filipino tribespeople.
lead_paragraph: In 1904, two years after America’s victory in the Philippine-American War, the United States government tried to put the best face on its colonization of the archipelago of more than 7,000 islands. Thirteen hundred Filipinos from a dozen tribes were put on display at the St. Louis Exposition, in replicas of their home villages, intended to reinforce an underlying message that our “little brown brothers,” in the words of William Howard Taft, were not ready to govern themselves. The most popular exhibit in this “human zoo” were the Igorrotes, who ate dog meat and hunted heads. The man in charge of the Igorrote village, Truman Hunt, had served as a medical doctor during the war and stayed on, eventually rising to become the lieutenant governor of Bontoc Province.

headline: Letters: ‘Uncommon Woman’
abstract: Readers respond to recent reviews of Brian Morton’s “Florence Gordon,” Matt Bai’s “All the Truth Is Out” and more.
lead_paragraph: ‘Uncommon Woman’

headline: The Internet and the Mind
abstract: New books by Ian Leslie, Daniel J. Levitin, Judy Wajcman and Michael Harris.
lead_paragraph: CURIOUS  The Desire to Know and Why Your Future Depends on It  By Ian Leslie  Basic Books, $26.99.

headline: ‘More Awesome Than Money,’ by Jim Dwyer
abstract: Four university students tried to create a nonprofit, privacy-protected alternative to Facebook.
lead_paragraph: Books about technology start-ups have a pattern. First there’s the grand vision of the founders, then the heroic journey of producing new worlds from all-night coding and caffeine abuse, and finally the grand finale, immense wealth and secular sainthood. Let’s call it the Jobs Narrative. The trouble is that Silicon Valley now believes its own press, and the proliferation of “great men in history” stories from the grinding code-mills of Northern California is contributing to a bigger problem of exclusion and exploitation.

headline: ‘On His Own Terms: A Life of Nelson Rockefeller,’ by Richard Norton Smith
abstract: Nelson Rockefeller, the subject of a new biography, was a big-government, big-spending liberal — and a Republican.
lead_paragraph: “I am imaginative,” Nelson Rockefeller said of himself near the end of his life. “I am not bright.”

headline: ‘William Wells Brown,’ by Ezra Greenspan
abstract: Born into slavery, William Wells Brown escaped to freedom and reinvented himself as an author, lecturer and doctor.
lead_paragraph: If the publishing industry reflects the American zeitgeist, things have changed when it comes to black American historical figures. As a graduate student at Harvard decades ago, I came across William Wells Brown, the fugitive slave, abolitionist, lecturer, travelogue writer, novelist and performer whose wide-ranging intelligence turned a gaze on white people (for a change). Back then he was to be found in only one full-length biography, William Edward Farrison’s “William Wells Brown: Author and Reformer” (1969). Published by the University of Chicago Press in the twilight of the “second Reconstruction” and at the dawning of African-American studies, it depicted Brown as a representative black American. In the absence of the biographical scholarship coming after 1969, Brown’s colleagues remained ill defined. Farrison’s biography was reviewed only in publishing trade papers and a couple of history journals. What was the problem?

headline: ‘Thrown,’ by Kerry Howley
abstract: A writer finds sublime poetry in the world of mixed martial arts.
lead_paragraph: It probably started with Homer. The “Iliad” includes some snappy sports reporting, and writers ever since have been probing athletes for signifiers, for metaphor amped by grit under pressure.

headline: ‘Tennessee Williams,’ by John Lahr
abstract: Tennessee Williams spun unhappiness into dramatic gold, John Lahr’s study shows.
lead_paragraph: Tennessee Williams’s career began and ended very badly. The boffo finish of his first Broadway-bound play, “Battle of Angels” (1940), was a big onstage fire — a special effect that generated so much smoke a number of theatergoers fainted while others bolted for the exits. “If ever the professional debut of a major playwright was a greater fiasco,” John Lahr writes in his new biography of Williams, piquantly subtitled “Mad Pilgrimage of the Flesh,” “history does not record it.” Five years and a lot of crummy jobs later, Williams clawed his way back with a play that would make him famous, “The Glass Menagerie,” whose premiere almost proved an even bigger disaster. Laurette Taylor, plucked from a long alcoholic oblivion to play Amanda Wingfield, was found an hour and a half before opening curtain in an alley outside the stage door, soaking wet in the rain and all but dead drunk. Occasionally pausing to vomit in a bucket offstage, she gave the performance of her life and thus saved our greatest postwar playwright from almost certain ruin.

headline: China’s Rise as Arms Supplier Is Put on Display
abstract: The world’s fourth-largest exporter of arms is now encouraging smaller private domestic companies to enter the field.
lead_paragraph: ZHUHAI, China — Queen Bee anti-tank rocket system. Halberd supersonic target drone. Sky Dragon 12 surface-to-air missile system.

headline: ‘Man Alive,’ by Thomas Page McBee
abstract: A transgender writer’s memoir of forgiveness and discovery.
lead_paragraph: What makes a man? We know it’s not quite enough to be born one. It never has been, really: In America, manhood has long been bound up in aspiration, a thing more ideological than biological.

headline: ‘The Deluge,’ by Adam Tooze
abstract: Between the Great War and the Depression, the world was remade by American economic and military power.
lead_paragraph: The defining political fact of the modern world is American power. The supremacy of the American colossus is still so imposing, it leaves former rivals scrambling for labels beyond “superpower”: The former French foreign minister Hubert Védrine called the United States the hyperpuissance, while for the German commentator Josef Joffe, it was the überpower.

headline: Verbatim: A Kitchen Ambush for Hagel
abstract: Secretary of Defense Chuck Hagel responds to a reporter’s question as to why he had a bandage on his face.
lead_paragraph: — Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel responding to a reporter’s question about why he had a bandage on his face, adding, “I’ve had more bandages than this on my face in my career and been in tougher spots.”

headline: Patricia Cornwell’s ‘Flesh and Blood,’ and More
abstract: In Cornwell’s new thriller, Kay Scarpetta’s expertise is needed with a murder victim, a man once accused of being a terrorist.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a steamy romantic scene for you, right out of Patricia Cornwell’s new thriller, FLESH AND BLOOD (Morrow, $28.99): “I trace the second cervical vertebra down to C7, gently, slowly digging my fingertips into the Longus colli muscle, feeling him relax.” The sexual hoyden showing off her bedroom technique is Dr. Kay Scarpetta, the chief medical examiner for the state of Massachusetts and an awesome force in the field of forensic science. Scarpetta and her husband, the F.B.I. profiler Benton Wesley, are getting in the mood for a sybaritic vacation in Florida when her expertise is suddenly needed with a murder victim, a man once accused of being a terrorist who has been killed by two shots from a sniper’s rifle. The use of copper bullets is unusual enough to make this case interesting. But with the coming Boston Marathon trial stoking anti-Islamic passions, and President Obama in town to speak against the indiscriminate hostility toward Muslims, the terrorism angle is also a factor. So much for that vacation.

headline: Call to Congress: End Loophole for Tax on Elite
abstract: Ending the policy that lets Wall Street’s top managers pay less tax on their compensation could be common ground for reform-minded Democrats and Republicans.
lead_paragraph: Now that Republicans control both houses of Congress, they need to show they can accomplish something, and President Obama has just two years to burnish his legacy. So the search is on for bipartisan consensus.

headline: Afghan President Out to Ease Relations on Visit to Pakistan
abstract: President Ashraf Ghani of Afghanistan will meet with Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif and Pakistani military officials to discuss curbing terrorism on the shared border.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD — Hoping to recast an often strained relationship with a crucial neighbor, President Ashraf Ghani of Afghanistan made his first state visit to Pakistan on Friday.

headline: How Bobby Shmurda Danced Into the Hot 100
abstract: The 20-year-old East Flatbush rapper Bobby Shmurda has just jumped from No. 8 to No. 6 on the Billboard chart.
lead_paragraph: The 20-year-old East Flatbush rapper Bobby Shmurda has just jumped from No. 8 to No. 6 on the Billboard chart.

headline: The Trick to Great Pumpkin Pie
abstract: Most recipes call for canned pumpkin. But for something fresher, brighter and more complex tasting, consider squash instead. (Article plus video.)
lead_paragraph: You can make pumpkin pie anytime, but it’s essential at Thanksgiving, where a thick and creamy slice — preferably buried under a mound of whipped cream — is the classic followup to the meal.

headline: Health Care’s Next Test: Getting More to Enroll
abstract: The Obama administration is embarking on a crucial effort to re-enroll the seven million who are covered and to attract more uninsured Americans, as a three-month enrollment period begins.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s Affordable Care Act will face a substantial new test starting Saturday, when the second enrollment period for buying health insurance under the law begins and proponents embark on a three-month mission to persuade millions more Americans to sign up.

headline: Sewing Up a Loose End on West End
abstract: Two towers are rising at Riverside Center, an eight-acre development in the low West 60s near the Hudson River that is the last piece of the Riverside South mega-project.
lead_paragraph: A drawn-out and often divisive plan to create a new neighborhood atop railroad tracks on the Far West Side — and, surprisingly, one having nothing to do with Hudson Yards — is embarking on its final phase.

headline: Dreaming of the Departed
abstract: Nighttime visitations from lost family members are not uncommon among caregivers.
lead_paragraph: I ran into my father at a deli the other day. An undramatic encounter: I was waiting at the counter for a takeout order when I spotted him sitting at a corner table, yakking with friends from his senior residence, their walkers and canes carefully folded or propped against the wall.

headline: In a Soft-Spoken Romanian Prosecutor, Some See an ‘Earthquake’
abstract: Those caught in the sights of Laura Codruta Kovesi, who, as head of Romania’s anticorruption agency, is leading a vigorous drive against graft, denounce her as a Stalinist.
lead_paragraph: BUCHAREST, Romania — TELEVISION crews are on permanent standby outside the offices of Laura Codruta Kovesi, ready to transmit live images of the next episode of Romania’s most talked about and, for the country’s corruption-addled business and political elite, most terrifying drama in 25 years.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘Napoleon: A Life’
abstract: This week, Andrew Roberts talks about his new biography of Napoleon; Alexandra Alter has news from the literary world; Yochi Dreazen discusses “The Invisible Front”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Andrew Roberts talks about his new biography of Napoleon; Alexandra Alter has news from the literary world; Yochi Dreazen discusses “The Invisible Front”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Facts & Figures: Americans Like Their ‘Obamacare’
abstract: Seventy-one percent of survey respondents said their coverage was good or excellent.
lead_paragraph: A large majority of Americans say they like the insurance coverage they obtained through government exchanges, which were set up by the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘Napoleon: A Life’
abstract: This week, Andrew Roberts and Yochi Dreazen.
lead_paragraph: This week, Andrew Roberts and Yochi Dreazen.

headline: Popcast: Bobby Shmurda Dances Into the Hot 100
abstract: The 20-year-old East Flatbush rapper Bobby Shmurda has just jumped to No. 6 from No. 8 on the Billboard chart.
lead_paragraph: “Hot Boy,” by the 20-year-old East Flatbush rapper Bobby Shmurda, with hyper-local lyrics about guns, drugs and money, has just jumped to No. 6 from No. 8 on the Billboard chart.

headline: After Losses, Liberal and Centrist Democrats Square Off on Strategy
abstract: The debate will help shape the last two years of the Obama White House and the Democratic presidential primaries to come.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Democrats’ widespread losses last week have revived a debate inside the party about its fundamental identity, a long-running feud between center and left that has taken on new urgency in the aftermath of a disastrous election and in a time of deeply felt economic anxiety.

headline: Expert in X’s and O’s Was Inspired by His Father, a Man of Letters
abstract: Steve Lavin has been through painful times as the men’s basketball coach at St. John’s, but he always looks to the lessons his father taught him.
lead_paragraph: At a corner table in a cozy restaurant in the West Village — Steve Lavin’s neighborhood — he had to strain his voice to be heard above the din of the dinner crowd. This didn’t inhibit him. It’s a coach’s way of life.

headline: Elvis’s First Recording Up for Auction
abstract: The acetate disc on which Elvis recorded his first two songs in 1953 will be sold at auction on Jan. 8, which would have been his 80th birthday.
lead_paragraph: Having dipped a toe into the world of memorabilia auctions in August, Graceland, Elvis Presley’s estate in Memphis – now a shrine to the singer – is holding a second Elvis auction on Jan. 8, which would have been his 80th birthday.

headline: Window Washers, in Trouble at World Trade Center, ‘Just Grabbed On’
abstract: The two workers stranded 827 feet in the air on Wednesday said they began their morning the way they always did: performing security checks.
lead_paragraph: When Juan Lizama and Juan Lopez went to work cleaning windows on Wednesday morning, they were prepared. Before they descended from the side of 1 World Trade Center, they had secured not only themselves to the rigging but also all of their equipment.

headline: Finding the Right African Safari
abstract: The new website Your African Safari helps travelers assess operators and itineraries.
lead_paragraph: Knowing how, when and where to book that first safari can be complicated, said Jennifer Goetz, a founder of Your African Safari, a new website dedicated to helping travelers research and locate a reliable safari company that’s right for them.

headline: How to Be French (When Asking for a Cigarette)
abstract: Readers share their takes on “becoming French” in response to Pamela Druckerman’s recent op-ed.
lead_paragraph: Pamela Druckerman’s Tuesday op-ed, How to Be French, on formally and culturally becoming a French citizen, might seem to have a very specific audience. But it quietly rose to become the most emailed story on NYTimes.com, and more than 300 commenters shared their thoughts.

headline: Book Reviewer Tell-All: Dwight Garner on Reading, Reviewing and Avoiding Blindness
abstract: Dwight Garner is a book critic for The Times. It’s an eye-taxing, though terrific, job. Here is a sense of how he does it.
lead_paragraph: Dwight Garner is a book critic for The Times. Here is a sense of how he does his sometimes eye-taxing job.

headline: Alibaba, the I.P.O. Darling, Is Also the Star of Hedge Fund Reports
abstract: Shares of Alibaba wound up in the portfolios of many well-known money managers in the third quarter.
lead_paragraph: Alibaba, the Chinese e-commerce website, was the hot initial public offering of the year on Wall Street. And not surprisingly, shares of Alibaba wound up in the portfolios of many well-known money managers in the third quarter.

headline: Weekend Auto Calendar: Auctions Everywhere
abstract: Classic-car auctions will be held in Texas, California and Florida; N.H.R.A. and Nascar wrap up the 2014 season.
lead_paragraph: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend:

headline: Vows | A Dog, Then a Family
abstract: Frank Nussbaum, a real estate developer, never felt ready to settle down until he went out with Carlye Adler, a writer and single mom.
lead_paragraph: Frank Nussbaum, a real estate developer, never felt ready to settle down until he went out with Carlye Adler, a writer and single mom.

headline: House Tour | The Fonseca Family Home
abstract: The writer Isabel Fonseca pays homage to her childhood home.
lead_paragraph: The writer Isabel Fonseca pays homage to her childhood home.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Beyond the Lights’
abstract: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Beyond the Lights.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Beyond the Lights.”

headline: Isabel Fonseca on the House on West 11th Street
abstract: The writer pays homage to her childhood home — the hub of her family’s creativity and a refuge in a changing Greenwich Village.
lead_paragraph: The writer pays homage to her childhood home — the hub of her family’s creativity and a refuge in a changing Greenwich Village.

headline: Europe Takes Aim at Deals Created to Escape Taxes
abstract: As global authorities ramp up efforts to close tax loopholes, companies are lobbying against proposed reforms.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — American companies have plowed more money into the Netherlands than any other country in the world — for five years running.

headline: Tensions Over Park Behavior as Homelessness Rises in New York City
abstract: Encampments in public spaces are prompting concern in neighboring communities about conduct such as public urination and sleeping on benches.
lead_paragraph: In Harlem River Park in Manhattan, homeless men can be seen sleeping on benches around the basketball courts and sprawled out on a soccer field by day, then hunkering under an overpass at night.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Foxcatcher’
abstract: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Foxcatcher.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Foxcatcher.”

headline: Nevada Provides Test Case in Debate Over a Skills Gap
abstract: Some economists question whether Nevada can provide enough qualified workers to operate a planned Tesla plant.
lead_paragraph: Employers increasingly complain they can’t find enough workers to fill jobs that require more than a high school diploma but not quite a bachelor’s degree. Some economists say the principal reason for a so-called skills gap is that employers aren’t willing to pay more to attract these employees. But new research argues that the problem is real, in part because work-force development has shriveled.

headline: How Can Community Colleges Get a Piece of the Billions That Donors Give to Higher Education?
abstract: LaGuardia Community College in Queens faces the challenge of marketing its worthy but unglamorous mission to raise money.
lead_paragraph: Last year at its annual gala, LaGuardia Community College, arguably the most ethnically diverse college in the country, honored Marilyn Skony Stamm, the chief executive of a global heating and air-conditioning business. A child of the South Side of Chicago who had gone to Northwestern on scholarship, Ms. Stamm maintained a committed interest in education and joined LaGuardia’s foundation board six years ago, proving herself a skilled networker for an institution with minimal capacity for soliciting money.

headline: And Puppy Makes Four
abstract: If Frank Nussbaum wanted to date Carlye Adler, he’d have to show he could commit. To prove he was capable, he bought a bulldog and named him Bunk. The rest is history.
lead_paragraph: Carlye Rebecca Adler and Frank Joshua Nussbaum were married Saturday evening at Caneel Bay Resort in St. John in the United States Virgin Islands. Peter S. O’Brien, who was ordained by the Universal Life church, led a ceremony that will incorporate Jewish elements.

headline: Wheelies: The Blue Devil Returns Edition
abstract: The first of the National Corvette Museum’s casualties from the sinkhole returns home; automakers pledge to protect consumer data in connected vehicles.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: The Garden at the Frick, and How It Grew
abstract: Henry Frick’s house has been altered before. But a new plan is meeting with howls.
lead_paragraph: The Frick Collection’s proposed expansion is the latest preservation argument to arise on the Upper East Side, as the addition would mean the loss of the intimate 1977 garden tucked away on 70th Street off Fifth Avenue.

headline: If You’re Not Rich, Divorce Can Be Financially Devastating
abstract: Overall, a man’s income drops 23 percent after divorce, while a woman’s income drops 41 percent.
lead_paragraph: There is a long list of women* who have amassed personal fortunes by divorcing rich husbands — and as far as I can tell, they deserved every penny. This week Sue Ann Hamm joined it when a court ordered her ex-husband, Harold Hamm, the Oklahoma oil man, to pay her  some $1 billion in cash and assets, or about $38 million per year of a 26-year marriage.

headline: House Passes Bill Directing Obama to Proceed on Oil Pipeline
abstract: The House vote and another scheduled for Tuesday in the Senate are chiefly intended to be a political maneuver by Republican and Democratic leaders in the battle for a Louisiana Senate seat.
lead_paragraph: The House voted 252 to 161 on Friday to approve a bill that would direct the federal government to move forward on the Keystone XL oil pipeline, ahead of a vote scheduled for Tuesday in the Senate that could send the measure to President Obama’s desk.

headline: Self-Promotion, but With Self-Respect
abstract: How to ensure — without bragging — that management understands your accomplishments? The answer may lie in adjusting your mind-set.
lead_paragraph: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

headline: House Votes to Pass Pipeline Bill
abstract: The House on Friday voted 252 to 161 to approve a bill that would direct the federal government to move forward on the Keystone XL oil pipeline.
lead_paragraph: House Passes Bill Directing Obama to Proceed on Oil Pipeline

headline: Operatives’ Emails Echo Infighting of 2008 Clinton Campaign
abstract: The leaking of emails between Democratic operatives Robby Mook and Marlon Marshall to a network of political friends echoed the type of infighting and backstabbing that helped unwind Mrs. Clinton’s last presidential campaign in 2008.
lead_paragraph: Taken in isolation, the emails between the Democratic operatives Robby Mook and Marlon Marshall to a network of political friends called the “Mook Mafia” aren’t particularly incriminating.

headline: Same-Sex Couples Petition Supreme Court on Right to Marriage
abstract: After a lower-court ruling upholding bans on gay marriage, advocates want the Supreme Court to rule on the constitutionality of same-sex marriages.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Gay and lesbian couples filed petitions on Friday asking the Supreme Court to decide whether there is a constitutional right to same-sex marriage. The petitions arrived eight days after the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit, in Cincinnati, upheld bans on same-sex marriage in Kentucky, Michigan, Ohio and Tennessee.

headline: Yale Medical School Removes Doctor After Sexual Harassment Finding
abstract: Dr. Michael Simons, who a committee found had sexually harassed a postdoctoral researcher at the school, was removed as head of the Cardiovascular Research Center.
lead_paragraph: Yale Medical School has removed a doctor after a finding of sexual harassment as director of its Cardiovascular Research Center, the latest development in a nearly five-year-old case that has agitated the institution.

headline: New York Public Library Names New Chairman
abstract: Evan R. Chesler, the chairman of the law firm Cravath, Swaine & Moore, will take over as the library chairman from Neil L. Rudenstine.
lead_paragraph: The New York Public Library is expected to name a new chairman at its board meeting on Tuesday. Evan R. Chesler, the chairman of the law firm Cravath, Swaine & Moore, will replace Neil L. Rudenstine, who announced in October that he would step down.

headline: Capping a Strong Performance With an Exit Strategy
abstract: “Finish Big” and “Succession,” examine how entrepreneurs and corporate chieftains alike can be assessed on their departures, Jonathan A. Knee writes in a joint book review.
lead_paragraph: Everyone likes to make a graceful exit. It increases the likelihood that your time will be remembered fondly. You may even be invited back. And many of us were raised to think that a timely departure is the right thing to do.

headline: Walmart’s Dark November, Ralph Rucci’s Departure, and Who Is Beyonce?
abstract: Plus, Kendall picks Chanel, Calvin Klein’s “controversy” and more from the week in style.
lead_paragraph: All the week’s fashion news that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Asking Justices to Decide on Gay Marriage
abstract: Gay and lesbian couples filed a petition on Friday asking the Supreme Court to decide whether there is a constitutional right to same-sex marriage.
lead_paragraph: Same-Sex Couples Petition Supreme Court on Right to Marriage

headline: Grace Gets Three Michelin Stars in Latest Chicago Guide
abstract: The restaurant, barely two years old, joins Alinea as Chicago three-star winners.
lead_paragraph: Grace, a Chicago restaurant barely two years old, has just been awarded three stars from the Michelin Guide. It is only the second restaurant in the city to claim that distinction, joining Alinea. Last month, Michelin gave three stars to Benu and Saison in San Francisco, the first in that city, although two Napa Valley restaurants, the French Laundry in Yountville and the restaurant at Meadowood in St. Helena, have long had three stars in the annual rankings.

headline: Vegetarian Thanksgiving: Really Big Beets
abstract: One of Food Editor Sam Sifton’s favorites: If you want to wow your Thanksgiving crowd, serve up a really big beet as a vegan main course that even the meat-eaters will want to share.
lead_paragraph: This year for Well’s Vegetarian Thanksgiving we’re highlighting some of our favorite recipes from Vegetarian Thanksgivings past. Here’s one of Food Editor Sam Sifton’s favorites, Really Big Beets, a reader-submitted recipe from 2014. See more of Well’s Vegetarian Thanksgiving selections at NYT Cooking.

headline: Justice Dept. Apologizes for Inaccuracy in National Security Letters Case
abstract: The Justice Department said telecommunications companies could disclose receiving the letters, which seek customer records, when in fact they cannot.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department has apologized to a federal appeals court for providing inaccurate information about a central issue in a case challenging the constitutionality of a disputed law-enforcement power known as national security letters.

headline: Florida State Player Fled Crash but Got Only Traffic Tickets
abstract: The Tallahassee police initially labeled an accident involving a Florida State football player as a hit and run, a criminal act, but later decided to issue him two traffic tickets, an examination by The New York Times found.
lead_paragraph: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. — In the early morning hours of Oct. 5, as this college town was celebrating another big football victory by Florida State University, a starting cornerback on the team drove his car into the path of an oncoming vehicle driven by a teenager returning home from a job at the Olive Garden.

headline: Shubert Organization to Complete Acquisition of New World Stages
abstract: The Shubert Organization, which owns 17 Broadway 40 theaters, is expected to complete a seven-figure deal Monday to take over the New World Stages, the Off Broadway complex of theaters on West 50th Street.
lead_paragraph: The Shubert Organization, which owns 17 of Broadway’s 40 theaters, is expected to complete a seven-figure deal on Monday to take over New World Stages, the Off Broadway complex of five subterranean theaters on West 50th Street, according to two theater executives with knowledge of the transaction. They spoke on condition of anonymity because Shubert business is meant to be confidential.

headline: Inflation Truth, Really
abstract: We are not Argentina, and Argentina is not us.
lead_paragraph: I’m in Argentina for the day — literally (stuff came up, forcing me to make this a very quick visit; sorry, no time for media interviews or anything not already booked). And I thought it might be worth telling people something they may not know about the history of MIT’s Billion Prices Project.

headline: Comparing Two Hit and Run Cases
abstract: A starting cornerback for the Florida State University football team left the scene of a collision on Oct. 5 but was not charged with a hit-and-run, an examination by The New York Times found. That contrasts with another case in the same area in the same month.
lead_paragraph: A starting cornerback for the Florida State University football team left the scene of a collision on Oct. 5 but was not charged with a hit-and-run, an examination by The New York Times found. That contrasts with another case in the same area in the same month.

headline: Today in Small Business: ‘Next Generation of Lender or Boiler Room?’
abstract: • Retail sales rebounded in October. Sliding oil and gas prices are giving Americans more money to spend. And Walmart tries a new kind of Black Friday.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: WNYC Sets Replacement Schedule for ‘Soundcheck’
abstract: The station’s nightly music show will be going online-only, and is to be replaced mostly with repeats of other programming.
lead_paragraph: WNYC has set a replacement schedule for “Soundcheck,” the nightly music show hosted by John Schaefer that is going online-only next week.

headline: Dear Dr. Psych Mom: I’m Almost a Parent Myself, and My Parents Are Smothering Me
abstract: I am 30 years old, married and pregnant with our first child. My parents’ overprotectiveness worries me a lot, especially now that I’m going to be a mom.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Psych Mom is Samantha Rodman, a clinical psychologist who practices in Maryland. She answers questions as “your friendly neighborhood blogapist” at DrPsychMom.com.

headline: Behind the G.O.P.’s Misleading Shutdown Statements
abstract: Mitch McConnell said he wouldn’t shut down the government. John Boehner said he wouldn’t rule out that possibility.
lead_paragraph: Senator Mitch McConnell said yesterday that he would not shut down the government, over immigration or anything else, after he takes over as Majority Leader in January. On the same day, Speaker John Boehner refused to rule out a shutdown. Both were being deceptive, but Mr. McConnell, as usual, was a little more clever about it.

headline: Video Reviews of ‘Foxcatcher,’ ‘Rosewater’ and ‘Beyond the Lights’
abstract: Times critics on “Foxcatcher,” “Rosewater” and “Beyond the Lights.”
lead_paragraph: In this week’s video, Times critics share their thoughts on “Foxcatcher,” “Rosewater” and “Beyond the Lights.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: Home Sales Around the New York Region
abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Friday Night Music: Suzanne Vega, I Never Wear White
abstract: More great new music.
lead_paragraph: I know, it’s early afternoon, but I’m on the road, and probably won’t have a later chance. Sorry, all her Joe’s Pub shows this weekend are sold out:

headline: A Boyish Patriarch Leaps Over Boundaries
abstract: As the conductor Michael Tilson Thomas nears 70, he still seeks out musical adventures.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Sitting in the airy studio on the top floor of his home here, a restored 1906 house in the Pacific Heights neighborhood, the conductor Michael Tilson Thomas recently said that a lot of old pictures and concert programs have been turning up lately in connection with “this birthday thing.”

headline: New Black Fest to Present Short Works Responding to Michael Brown Shooting
abstract: “Hands Up: Six Testaments” consists of monologues or “performance essays” prompted by the shooting of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Mo.
lead_paragraph: The New Black Fest, which last year commissioned 10-minute works on Trayvon Martin, race and privilege, will present a free showcase of works on Monday called “Hands Up: Six Testaments,” a project inspired by events in Ferguson, Mo., where in August a police officer fatally shot Michael Brown, an unarmed black teenager.

headline: The Quiet Bravery of a Doomed Revolt
abstract: The choreographer Jonah Bokaer’s exhibition “October 7, 1944” pays tribute to four women who helped ignite an uprising at Auschwitz.
lead_paragraph: “What do you think of when I say ‘archive’?” asked Rachel Lithgow, the executive director of the American Jewish Historical Society. A solitary place of research, perhaps, with “big old filing cabinets with dusty paper and some person with granny glasses?” she suggested. Certainly not the site of a new commission centered on that least sedentary, most physically alive of art forms: dance.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: After Military Service, Taking Advantage of Educational Benefits
abstract: More than 1.4 million people have used benefits available under the Post-9/11 G.I. Bill, but there are a host of other options as well.
lead_paragraph: A host of educational benefits are available to those who have served in the United States armed forces, but figuring out which program a service member is eligible for can sometimes be a challenge.

headline: Battle Over Immigration Poses Risks for G.O.P.
abstract: While some Republicans rule out a government shutdown, others are talking about the possibility, in reaction to President Obama’s plan to act on immigration.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s looming action on immigration is the first real opportunity for the new Republican leadership in Congress to demonstrate they can avoid the pitfalls of opposing the president’s policies at all costs and instead unite around a governing agenda of their own.

headline: The Big Money Behind the Push for an Immigration Overhaul
abstract: Many of the gains made by advocates for immigrants to the United States were helped by hundreds of millions in donations from liberal foundations.
lead_paragraph: When President Obama announces major changes to the nation’s immigration enforcement system as early as next week, his decision will partly be a result of a yearslong campaign of pressure by immigrant rights groups, which have grown from a cluster of lobbying organizations into a national force.

headline: A New Brooklyn Condo With a Prewar Aesthetic
abstract: The building, rising on the border of Boerum Hill and Downtown Brooklyn, offers floor plans that favor designated rooms over big open spaces.
lead_paragraph: The goal for 265 State Street was to create a towering, 20-story condominium with a design sensibility that takes its cues from the nearby brownstone-dotted neighborhood of Boerum Hill.

headline: Troubles at Petrobras Raise Broader Questions for Investors
abstract: Few emerging market companies are as widely held by equity and bond investors as Petrobras, long seen as a benchmark for developing markets.
lead_paragraph: When the world’s most indebted company postpones an earnings release due to a widening corruption scandal, a wobble in the markets is to be expected.

headline: Work to Do, but Novak Djokovic Sews Up Top Year-End Ranking
abstract: Djokovic dispatched Tomas Berdych on Friday in his final round-robin match of the ATP tournament in London to reach the semifinals and also secure the year-end No. 1 ranking.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Novak Djokovic is still the third man, the bendable champion who breaks serve so often yet still ranks behind Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal in career achievement and global recognition.

headline: For Ferguson Grand Jury, Details and Responsibilities Are Abundant
abstract: Grand juries usually hear just the outline of a case, but prosecutors are presenting all their evidence in the Michael Brown shooting, making for a long and exhaustive process.
lead_paragraph: After hearing testimony for nearly three months in the death of Michael Brown, the 18-year-old unarmed African-American who was shot by Officer Darren Wilson on a Ferguson, Mo., street on Aug. 9, a St. Louis County grand jury is nearing a decision on whether to bring criminal charges.

headline: In India, Jewels a Maharani or Grandmother Could Love
abstract: On a recent trip to Jaipur, a global center for gem cutting, I indulged in visits to jewelry shops, as my grandmother often did.
lead_paragraph: My grandmother was an avid traveler, and in every place she visited — Bangkok, Cairo, Rome — she would buy a piece of jewelry. My sisters and I could rummage through her jewelry box, and take a virtual tour of the world.

headline: Talking Ships With Sting
abstract: The artist, who wrote the music and lyrics for the new musical, “The Last Ship,” talks about growing up “in the shadow of a shipyard,” performing on the S.S. Oriana and more.
lead_paragraph: Sting was breaking a promise he had made to himself.

headline: You’d Have to Search Long and Hard to Find Another Artist Like This
abstract: At a museum in Paris, Sven Sachsalber finds a needle in a haystack.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — On Friday evening here visitors in the basement of the Palais de Tokyo watched, amused and then surprised, as Sven Sachsalber, an Italian artist based in New York, literally did the figuratively near-impossible.

headline: Texas, 3 Ways
abstract: Exploring an Asia Town in Houston, a green space in Dallas and a border neighborhood in El Paso.
lead_paragraph: You might say that a certain otherness has always characterized Texas as a whole — and by “whole,” I refer to that entire 269,000-square-mile sui generis behemoth on the map, mallet-headed and dainty-footed, with a single dorsal wing and a swollen belly that appears to contain two or three neighboring states.

headline: Equatorial Guinea Replaces Morocco as Africa Cup Host
abstract: Morocco had wanted the Cup delayed until June 2015 or early 2016, saying it was concerned that Ebola could be spread by visitors.
lead_paragraph: Equatorial Guinea has agreed to host Africa’s most important soccer tournament early next year after Morocco refused, citing fear about the possible spread of Ebola.

headline: After Emotions Are Stirred, a Cocktail Goes for Clarity
abstract: A quest for transparency regarding the Affordable Care Act, and a way to quench your thirst.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday, Americans who don’t have health insurance through their employer or the government can go to HealthCare.gov to enroll in a health insurance plan. The rollout was nothing less than a fiasco last year, but this year it should go better. There will still be some confusion — we provide some answers here — but the software is expected to work, and the process is more transparent.

headline: Letter From the Editor: Health Care Drama
abstract: A Supreme Court case and a newly surfaced video of an economist’s remarks are reigniting controversy over the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: It’s the biggest expansion of government and Washington’s biggest response to inequality in decades. So no wonder it’s the political story that won’t die.

headline: Stuff We Liked: Health Care Is a Focus, but Dogs Get a Look, Too
abstract: A roundup of interesting sites from around the web suggested by The Upshot staff.
lead_paragraph: We like to share the interesting articles and graphics we find on the web.

headline: Pedigree on a Prime Block
abstract: An Upper East Side townhouse owned by the former wife of the billionaire George Soros was the most expensive real estate sale in the city this week.
lead_paragraph: An Upper East Side townhouse distinguished by a front facade with two levels of copper-clad bay windows above fluted columns, a glass solarium/breakfast room overlooking a 26-foot-deep rear garden, and a pedigree dating to 1869, sold for $31 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Do You Want To Know About Your Brain?
abstract: New research suggests many people don’t think that much about brain science. Should they?
lead_paragraph: Do you devour the latest neuroscience news, eager to learn more about how your brain works? Or do you click past it to something else, something more applicable to your life? If you’re in the latter camp, you may be in the majority. A new study suggests that many people just don’t pay that much attention to brain science, and its findings may raise a question: Is “neuro-literacy” really necessary?

headline: Some Back-of-the-Envelope Calculations in Deal for Baker Hughes
abstract: The plunge in oil prices provides a fresh rationale for a combination of Halliburton and its rival Baker Hughes, if Halliburton can find cost cuts, Kevin Allison of Reuters Breakingviews writes.
lead_paragraph: Baker Hughes may be worth more than investors think. Shares of the No. 3 American oilfield services firm rose 15 percent on Thursday after news broke of deal talks with the No. 2 company, Halliburton. A back-of-the-envelope calculation suggests that Halliburton, worth $46 billion, should be willing to pay nearly 40 percent more than Baker Hughes’ $22 billion undisturbed market valuation to seal a deal.

headline: The Surprisingly Elusive Number That Suggests Full Employment
abstract: This measurement is an important one for central bankers because it can influence policy concerning inflation.
lead_paragraph: Last month the national unemployment rate fell from 5.9 to 5.8 percent, ticking one-tenth of a point closer to the rate of full employment in the American job market. Of that, I’m confident. What that rate of full employment is, no one knows. As the Federal Reserve prepares to begin removing its monetary support from the economy, acknowledging that uncertainty becomes increasingly important.

headline: Two in Ricin Terrorism Plot Are Each Sentenced to 10 Years in Prison
abstract: Samuel J. Crump and Ray H. Adams, who were arrested in 2011, were convicted on charges connected to possession of ricin for use as a weapon.
lead_paragraph: GAINESVILLE, Ga. — Ending a case that involved questions about the line between rhetoric and criminal conduct, a judge on Friday sentenced two men to a decade each in prison for their roles in a plot that included using ricin in a series of attacks in major cities.

headline: Jasmin Shokrian, Designer to the Art World, Pops Up at MOCA
abstract: Starting Saturday, the L.A.-based label will take over part of the museum’s gift shop for the holiday season.
lead_paragraph: Jasmin Shokrian may create clothing for a living, but she’s very much a creature of the art scene. Her degree is in fine art; her clients are the sort of women who either work in galleries and museums or frequent them. Now the Los Angeles-based designer is making her first foray into retail in typically unfashiony fashion: by commandeering a section of MOCA’s gift shop. Starting tomorrow, the space will sell styles from Shokrian’s fall collection and her new men’s wear offerings, as well as furniture, beauty goods and accessories from her network of creative friends, such as Régime des Fleurs fragrances, home objects from the design studio Apparatus and jewelry made especially for the shop by Annie Costello Brown. “It’s a sliver of what I would do if I had a store,” Shokrian says. As for her now-classic tops and totes that read Je Pars Habiter à Los Angeles: They’ll be there, along with matching iPhone 6 cases, just in time for the holidays.

headline: Where the Sofas Come and Go
abstract: Marissa Webb, the global creative director of Banana Republic, lives in a downtown loft with her fiancé, Guillaume Sivadier.
lead_paragraph: When NYC & Company is ready to replace Taylor Swift as its Global Welcome Ambassador, it should consider enlisting Marissa Webb, the global creative director of Banana Republic, who is as charismatic as any pop star. Born in Korea, Ms. Webb was raised in Pennsylvania, lived in Hoboken while she studied at the Fashion Institute of Technology and now lives in the quintessential loft near Union Square.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Autumnal Mood
abstract: It’s as true today as it ever was — fall in New York is pure magic.
lead_paragraph: It’s as true today as it ever was — fall in New York is pure magic.

headline: Weekend Reading: Round 2 of the Foreign Exchange Inquiry
abstract: Now that the big banks have been fined and vulgar chat room messages exposed, “other numpty’s in mkt” are watching as the currency-rigging case shifts to criminal misconduct.
lead_paragraph: Now that the big banks have been fined and vulgar chat room messages exposed, “other numpty’s in mkt” are watching as the currency-rigging case shifts to criminal misconduct.

headline: Cooking More Tacos and Looking for Recipes for Leftover Oatmeal
abstract: Chicken and dumplings. Shake and Bake pork chops. Baked potatoes. If it weren’t for the night we’re having chorizo, I’d be pretty sure I’d turned into my mother.
lead_paragraph: We ate well last week. Korean Grilled Beef Lettuce Wraps were a hit both for dinner, and in lunches (and a fantastic friend suggested this slow cooker version for too-snowy-to-grill days ahead). Slow cooker flank steak fajitas were ridiculously easy and delicious. And fried rice — the only food for which I am willing to act as a short-order cook — is one of those things I know every one in our family will enjoy.

headline: Cadillac Unveils ATS-V.R. Racecar
abstract: Powered by a modified aluminum twin-turbo 3.6-liter V6, the 600-horsepower car meets F.I.A. GT3 racing specifications, Cadillac says.
lead_paragraph: Cadillac announced Friday that, in addition to the sporty ATS-V model it confirmed this week, it was introducing the ATS-V.R. racecar. It unveiled the car, which will be available next year, at the Circuit of the Americas in Austin, Tex.

headline: Window Washers on Dangle at Trade Center
abstract: Juan Lopez and Juan Lizama, window washers who were left dangling from 1 World Trade Center after a malfunction on their scaffold, talked about the fear and how happy they were to be rescued.
lead_paragraph: Juan Lopez and Juan Lizama, window washers who were left dangling from 1 World Trade Center after a malfunction on their scaffold, talked about the fear and how happy they were to be rescued.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
abstract: In the news: Ebola, sugar and breast cancer exams. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: In the news: Ebola, sugar and breast cancer exams. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: A Bar Born to Be in Pictures
abstract: Bizarre in Bushwick, Brooklyn, was supposed to be at the core of a movie, and its bartender was set to be a star. That never happened. But like any good film, there’s a twist.
lead_paragraph: EXTERIOR, NIGHT: In a turbulent part of Brooklyn that condo developers have so far ignored, a seductive glow radiates from the windows of a three-story, 19th-century mansion, out of place among abandoned lots and fast-food joints.

headline: Cadillac Signs Lease for Headquarters in Hudson Square
abstract: Johan de Nysschen, president of Cadillac, says the move to the 16-story Manhattan office building is part of the brand’s expansion.
lead_paragraph: Cadillac has signed a lease for 34,000 square feet on the top two floors of 330 Hudson Street, the building’s owner said in a statement Thursday. The 16-story building is in Manhattan’s Hudson Square neighborhood, and will serve as the luxury automotive brand’s new global headquarters starting next year.

headline: Updated: Why Shopping Is So Important in Health Enrollment
abstract: Many people who renew will face big price increases, while much better deals are available for similar plans.
lead_paragraph: This article was updated Nov. 20 with rate information from all 50 states.

headline: A Reading of “Marriage Nests” by Jill Bialosky
abstract: The American poet offers her view of the somber realities of matrimony.
lead_paragraph: The American poet offers her view of the somber realities of matrimony.

headline: Consumers Satisfied With Health Exchanges, Poll Finds
abstract: Consumers who bought health insurance through the Affordable Care Act exchanges say they are satisfied with their purchases.
lead_paragraph: The Affordable Care Act’s second enrollment period, which begins this weekend, has been ushered in with a litany of criticism about everything from rate hikes to old comments from one of the people who helped craft the law.

headline: F.C.C. Asks AT&T for Details on Plans to Halt Fiber Expansion
abstract: After AT&T’s chairman said the company would pause fiber expansion plans until the F.C.C. decided how to regulate broadband internet, the agency asked for documentation of what fiber projects would be halted, among other things.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON – When Randall L. Stephenson, AT&T‘s chairman and chief executive, said this week that the company would halt some of its plans for fiber-optic expansion until federal regulators decided on a net neutrality policy, at least one important party was listening: the Federal Communications Commission.

headline: A Player With a Modern Ear Explores the New in Traditional Fugues
abstract: Pierre-Laurent Aimard played Book I of Bach’s “The Well-Tempered Clavier” at Carnegie Hall on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Like most pianists, Pierre-Laurent Aimard studied Bach’s seminal “The Well-Tempered Clavier,” the two books of paired preludes and fugues in all the major and minor keys, when he was a student. But when, at 19, he became a founding member of Pierre Boulez’s Ensemble InterContemporain, the important modern music group in Paris, Mr. Aimard turned into a new-music specialist. Bach was among the composers he put on the shelf during those years.

headline: Smithsonian Unveils $2 Billion Plan to Renovate Its Museums and Public Spaces
abstract: A Danish architecture firm has come up with a master plan to renovate and redesign parts of the Smithsonian Institution’s campus on the National Mall.
lead_paragraph: The Smithsonian Institution has announced the details of a new $2 billion plan to renovate the area of museums and gardens in its South Mall campus, including a “revitalization” of the Castle, its administrative headquarters.

headline: Less than 50 Days Till Christmas
abstract: Dakota Fanning, Baz Luhrmann and Catherine Martin unveil Barneys holiday windows.
lead_paragraph: Dakota Fanning, Baz Luhrmann and Catherine Martin unveil Barneys holiday windows.

headline: Quivering and Curving
abstract: Ivy Baldwin’s “Oxbow,” at BAM Fisher, is less a complete dance than a movement study with patched-together phrases.
lead_paragraph: An oxbow, in case you don’t know, is the bend in a river that curves in the shape of a U. It’s also the title of Ivy Baldwin’s perplexing new dance, the most compelling part of which is its set. Placed toward the back of the stage under purposely murky lighting, the design resembles a gnarled, twisted tree growing on the side of a cliff. Its serpentine lines, some delicate and others knotty with erosion, give this dancing space a well-needed frame.

headline: Out of Unravelings and a Loss, a New Star
abstract: A couple with a big age gap saw their ideas diverge, and their marriage dissolve.
lead_paragraph: Mary Warner Greenway and Bernard Rogers were married — he for the third time, she for the second — on June 16, 2001, in Basalt, Colo. Their wedding, which appeared in the Vows column on June 24, 2001, took place outside his log cabin, a meticulously built place filled with books, Navajo rugs, a stuffed bear and thick down quilts covering the beds like new snowfalls.

headline: Barneys’ Holiday Party Designed by Baz Luhrmann
abstract: Barneys’ holiday windows were unveiled on Thursday with ice dancers, step-troupers, opera singers, a cappella warblers and two break-dancing elves.
lead_paragraph: Thanksgiving turkeys aren’t yet in the oven, but the Rockettes were already kicking, the Empire State Building was lit up red and green and, over on Madison Avenue, Barneys’ holiday windows were unveiled on Thursday with ice dancers, step-troupers, opera singers, a cappella warblers and two break-dancing elves.

headline: A Hunt for Inspiration
abstract: For David Stark, an event designer who helps plan parties including the Whitney Museum Gala, a typical Sunday includes time with his husband, a trip to a museum and a nap.
lead_paragraph: The typical Sunday for most people rarely includes planning a dinner for 4,000. But for David Stark, an event designer, it often does. “It is a lot of odd hours,” Mr. Stark, 47, said of his work, which includes the Whitney Museum Gala on Nov. 19. Even if your own parties are more modest, Mr. Stark had some advice: “Oftentimes hosts think their job is over once they’ve set the table and put the food out,” he said. “I feel the process begins when people walk in the door. You brought them together because you like them, so don’t drop the ball on the socialization aspects of the evening.” Mr. Stark lives in Brooklyn Heights with his husband, Migguel Anggelo — a singer, dancer and actor — and a complete collection of “Golden Girls” episodes.

headline: Your Wedding Accessories
abstract: The Vows section publishes an occasional series of photos called Wedding Album. This month’s theme was unique wedding accessories.
lead_paragraph: The Vows section publishes an occasional series of photos called Wedding Album. This month’s theme was unique wedding accessories.

headline: Tune In to The Times
abstract: Over the past week, New York Times reporters and contributors participated in interviews regarding their coverage and other top news stories. Here are highlights from television and radio.
lead_paragraph: Emily Bazelon, a staff writer for The New York Times Magazine, joined “The Colbert Report” on Comedy Central to discuss the Supreme Court and the latest on health care reform.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Autumnal Mood
abstract: It’s as true today as it ever was — fall in New York is pure magic.
lead_paragraph: It’s as true today as it ever was — fall in New York is pure magic. The foliage’s tiptop colors were reflected in the clothes of passers-by. But the big surprise: women wearing moody combinations of black, gray and white.

headline: On the Market in Miami
abstract: A roundup of apartments and houses priced from $949,000 to $6.9 million.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties in Miami, Fla.:

headline: National Cathedral Holds Muslim Prayer Service
abstract: Followers of Islam attended a Friday prayer session that was the first of its kind at the church in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Followers of Islam attended a Friday prayer session that was the first of its kind at the church in Washington.

headline: Evening Hours | Fall Festivities
abstract: The party season is in full swing.
lead_paragraph: The party season is in full swing.

headline: Is Quantum Entanglement Real?
abstract: Einstein thought not. But experiments suggest so.
lead_paragraph: FIFTY years ago this month, the Irish physicist John Stewart Bell submitted a short, quirky article to a fly-by-night journal titled Physics, Physique, Fizika. He had been too shy to ask his American hosts, whom he was visiting during a sabbatical, to cover the steep page charges at a mainstream journal, the Physical Review. Though the journal he selected folded a few years later, his paper became a blockbuster. Today it is among the most frequently cited physics articles of all time.

headline: A Diesel BMW for the Long Haul
abstract: For 2015, BMW is offering an X3 with a turbo diesel engine for $1,500 more than the base gasoline-burning turbo 4.
lead_paragraph: TESTED 2015 BMW X3 xDrive28d

headline: What the Birds See
abstract: Jeffrey Milstein, 70, takes photographs of airplanes taking off, and of airports and other transportation hubs from the sky.
lead_paragraph: As the holiday season approaches, many New Yorkers may be dreading a packed slog through one of the metropolitan area’s three major airports. But if they had Jeffrey Milstein’s vantage point, they might see the airports in a more flattering light.

headline: Suddenly, a 3-Wheel Traffic Jam
abstract: New models are breathing life into a category of machine that can deliver the thrills of a vintage sports car and the excitement of a motorcycle, without the risk of tipping over at stoplights.
lead_paragraph: Children who begin their vehicular life on tricycles typically migrate to 2-wheelers by the time they start kindergarten, eventually graduating to 4-wheelers. Now some grown-ups are returning to their 3-wheel roots, though without the pedals this time around.

headline: Low to the Ground and Out of This World
abstract: Polaris, which makes motorcycles, A.T.V.s, snowmobiles and off-road utility buggies, has conjured up an alternative form of 3-wheel transportation that’s hard to classify.
lead_paragraph: Living in the same home for nearly 30 years, I am accustomed to the neighborhood teenagers asking, “What kind of car is that?” when a new model to be reviewed arrives in my driveway.

headline: Strength in Odd Numbers
abstract: With the 3-wheeled Slingshot, Polaris aims to blow open what has been a minor market niche.
lead_paragraph: With the 3-wheeled Slingshot, Polaris aims to blow open what has been a minor market niche.

headline: Figuring Out if a Financial Institution Is Too Big to Fail
abstract: MetLife’s argument against its designation as systemically important is part of a larger debate about when the government can use numbers to justify its actions, David Zaring writes in the Another View column.
lead_paragraph: David Zaring is associate professor of legal studies at the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania.

headline: Giving Thanks in the South Pacific
abstract: Norfolk Island, an Australian territory, is offering visitors an opportunity to experience its Thanksgiving tradition.
lead_paragraph: A Thanksgiving Immersion Package and the Norfolk Island Food Festival are being offered for the first time on Norfolk Island, a small island just a short flight from Sydney, Brisbane and Auckland.

headline: A Certain Metaphysical Attraction
abstract: For Jennifer Pastore and Mark Hannah, a chance encounter at a bookstore cafe — and a gradual falling into place.
lead_paragraph: For a guy who was then the director of academic communications at Parsons the New School for Design in New York, Mark Hannah was at a surprising, embarrassing loss for words.

headline: Five Decades of Patter
abstract: Sal Locascio, 87, tells of driving celebrities like Judy Garland, Joe DiMaggio and Gregory Peck.
lead_paragraph: With a half-century’s worth of experience driving a yellow cab in New York City, Sal Locascio, 87, knows the streets as well as anyone.

headline: Lost Key? Copies From the Cloud
abstract: A company is placing kiosks in New York-area 7-Eleven stores that will let people make car keys without having to go to a dealership.
lead_paragraph: When Greg Marsh moved to New York three years ago, he discovered that his girlfriend often lost her keys and he had to spend hundreds of dollars changing the locks on their apartment.

headline: Steering Wheels That Do Much More Than Turn Corners
abstract: The steering wheel in a Formula One racecar does more than direct the car’s path. A driver can make more than a dozen adjustments, like limiting his pit speed and shifting gears, without lifting a hand from the wheel.
lead_paragraph: Modern cars put a variety of controls at the driver’s fingertips: Switches and buttons for the cruise control, navigation and audio systems, among other functions, all jostle for the limited real estate on the steering wheel.

headline: U.S. Men Make Employment Gains
abstract: The unemployment rate for men dipped below that of women for the first time since 2006, and the number of private sector jobs held by men reached a new peak.
lead_paragraph: THE men are finding work.

headline: Paradise Regained
abstract: The centerpiece of this issue is the power of books.
lead_paragraph: This issue kicks off with a droll riff by our critic at large Andrew O’Hagan about the great luxury of the Internet. It is too easy to be nostalgic for the good old days before smartphones were appendages of our bodies — days rewarded by patience and hassle and banal chitchat with acquaintances you’d rather not run into at the supermarket. Instead of closing us off to conversation and delight, technology has actually given us more time for the kind of analog pleasures this issue highlights — like reading, experiencing art, riding a bicycle and hiking in the woods.

headline: How Gwyneth Paltrow’s Goop Has Become a Role Model for Other Celebrities
abstract: What do Gwyneth Paltrow and her new partner in her lifestyle company Goop want? “World domination.”
lead_paragraph: Gwyneth Paltrow, the 42-year-old Oscar-winner, conscious-uncoupler and Tracy Anderson devotee, is changing.

headline: I Nearly Died. So What?
abstract: We love redemption narratives. But crises don’t always impart lessons.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — FOUR years ago this fall, I spent several days in a medically induced coma after contracting a freakishly severe case of flea-borne typhus. A bacterial infection caused by fleabites led to liver failure, kidney problems, meningoencephalitis and, among other complications, a particularly deadly condition called disseminated intravascular coagulation.

headline: Passing Through Time, Never Alone
abstract: In “I Am With You,” by the choreographer Hilary Easton, students mingle with professionals, and Ms. Easton is with them all, even when she is not onstage.
lead_paragraph: Over the last two decades, in addition to choreographing thoughtful works for her company, Hilary Easton has earned a high reputation as an educator. Her day job, at Juilliard, might help explain the presence of teenage students in her new dance “I Am With You.”

headline: Dreamy Collections of Little Nemo and Moomin
abstract: “The Complete Little Nemo” and “Moomin: The Deluxe Anniversary Edition” are vast and enchanting collections of vintage comic strips.
lead_paragraph: The fantasy writer Neil Gaiman once wrote, “Tales and dreams are the shadow-truths that will endure when mere facts are dust and ashes and forgot.”

headline: The Brotherhood of the Stay-at-Home Dad
abstract: The National At-Home Dad Network draws men from around the country who band together to fight the stigma (and swap recipes).
lead_paragraph: DENVER — “Choo-choo-wa! Choo-choo-wa! Choo-choo-wa-wa-wah!”

headline: Twisting Their Flesh as Symbols of Virility
abstract: The Bessie Award-winning dancer Jaro Vinarsky presents “Animalinside,” a new duet with Marek Mensik.
lead_paragraph: Of the many unsettling images in “Animalinside,” a new duet by the Slovakian choreographer Jaro Vinarsky, the first is the hardest to forget. On Thursday at Abrons Arts Center, frothy lounge music played as the audience filed into the Experimental Theater. Then darkness fell, and a tense wail hijacked the soundtrack, like a siren stuck at one pitch.

headline: Rare Ferns: Thriving in Fumes and Grime
abstract: The blunt-lobed cliff fern and the smooth cliff brake are part of a “novel ecosystem” above an old viaduct on Park Avenue in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Some people still believe that cities are biological wastelands, infested with pigeons, rats and weeds gone amok, no place for serious scientific study. But a new concept has gradually emerged among die-hard naturalists and researchers.

headline: Standing Up to Aggression, or Ensuring Security
abstract: Should Russian actions in Ukraine scuttle U.S. cooperation on securing and cutting nuclear stockpiles?

headline: Jeffrey Deitch Is Back on the Art Auction Scene
abstract: Mr. Deitch is back in New York and has a new book and new catalog, new artist collaborations and more.
lead_paragraph: Call the cops, there’s Yukon gridlock at Christie’s.

headline: Inventing a Drybar for Meditation
abstract: Suze Yalof Schwartz says Unplug, her new Los Angeles meditation studio, is for “Type A personalities: clean, modern, secular, effortless to attend.”
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — I’ll just be honest: I expected Suze Yalof Schwartz and her new guided meditation studio to be highly annoying.

headline: Smile, You’re on Aura Camera
abstract: Magic Jewelry on Centre Street specializes in feng shui, crystals and horoscope readings, but it is also the only place in the city that photographs auras.
lead_paragraph: At Magic Jewelry, on Centre Street just off Canal, one can buy all manner of healing crystals and semiprecious stones. But most of the people who filed into the tiny shop on a recent rainy Saturday were there to have their auras captured.

headline: Resinging the Song of a Life Cut Short
abstract: “Aaliyah: The Princess of R&B,” which has its premiere Saturday night on Lifetime, stars Alexandra Shipp as the young singer who died in a 2001 air crash.
lead_paragraph: Telling someone’s life story, warts and all, requires the alignment of several parties who ordinarily might not share a goal. People who want the subject treated hagiographically have to see eye to eye with people who want to acknowledge the fullness of a person, even the failures. Plus, there is the matter of ownership — sometimes the people with legal rights to a story aren’t best suited to tell it.

headline: Economist’s Inflammatory Remarks
abstract: A remark made by Jonathan Gruber, a health economist who advised the White House on the Affordable Care Act, has been interpreted by critics of the law to mean that it was passed dishonestly.
lead_paragraph: A remark made by Jonathan Gruber, a health economist who advised the White House on the Affordable Care Act, has been interpreted by critics of the law to mean that it was passed dishonestly.

headline: James Middleton Will Put a Happy Face on Your S’mores
abstract: James Middleton, brother of Kate and Pippa Middleton, is looking to become a marshmallow kingpin with Boomf.
lead_paragraph: Late on Wednesday afternoon, as many Manhattanites’ eyes trained on the harrowing scene at 1 World Trade Center, James Middleton was cocooned in a 15th-floor suite at the Ritz-Carlton on Central Park South, regarding the lush carpet of autumn foliage beneath.

headline: Team Landrieu Not Shy on Pipeline Politics
abstract: Senator Mary L. Landrieu’s campaign has not hesitated to embrace her stance on the XL Pipeline ahead of her runoff election against Representative Bill Cassidy.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a pivot to the pipeline.

headline: Facebook Will Curtail Unpaid Ads by Brands
abstract: The company said it was responding to feedback from its users, who were complaining about too many promotional posts.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook’s executives are not terribly worried about upsetting people these days.

headline: A Maestro Returns, First There, Now Here
abstract: Jiri Belohlavek, chief conductor of the Czech Philharmonic for the second time in his career, brings the orchestra to Carnegie Hall on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: For the most prominent Czech conductor of his generation, the rejection hit uniquely close to home. Jiri Belohlavek had been chief conductor of the Czech Philharmonic  for just a year when its musicians won the right to elect their leaders freely in 1991. They voted him out.

headline: The Comfort Women and Japan’s War on Truth
abstract: The Abe government is determined to rewrite the imperial military's history of wartime sexual slavery.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In 1942, a lieutenant paymaster in Japan’s Imperial Navy named Yasuhiro Nakasone was stationed at Balikpapan on the island of Borneo, assigned to oversee the construction of an airfield. But he found that sexual misconduct, gambling and fighting were so prevalent among his men that the work was stalled.

headline: Vigilant Eye on Gender Pay Gap
abstract: Employers who actively manage pay equity tend to have positive ripple effects, consultants said, including more women in their senior ranks.
lead_paragraph: The first step is admitting you have a problem, but it’s another thing to actually address it.

headline: Lift Bridge for Metro-North Trains Is Getting Big Repairs
abstract: The Harlem River Lift Bridge will undergo a $47.2 million overhaul that includes electrical upgrades and replacement cables to raise and lower the crossing.
lead_paragraph: In 1954, the Supreme Court outlawed racial segregation in public schools. The Senate censured Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, whose scowling rants about Communist subversion had prompted witch hunts. The Grand Ole Opry in Nashville advised a skinny young truck driver named Elvis Presley to stay behind the wheel.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Ron Lieber, Kenneth Chang and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Ron Lieber, Kenneth Chang and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Recipes for Health: Beans for Your Thanksgiving Table
abstract: If you haven’t started thinking about vegetarian main dishes for Thanksgiving, now is the time.
lead_paragraph: If you haven’t started thinking about vegetarian main dishes for Thanksgiving, now is the time. This year I am focusing on beans from North America. I have been enjoying a number of heirloom beans native to the Southwest and Mexico, and they were the inspiration for these dishes, most of which also incorporate other foods native to the Americas – squash, corn, potatoes, sweet potatoes, tomatoes.

headline: Facts About Foghorns and Garbage on the Sidewalk
abstract: Foghorns in Midtown Manhattan, and the law regarding bags of restaurant garbage left on the sidewalk.
lead_paragraph: Q.
