It was remarkably foggy one morning this week, and it reminded me of a foggy day last winter, when I could have sworn I heard a foghorn as I sat one afternoon in the theater district. Is that possible? I’ve lived in Manhattan since childhood, and I don’t remember hearing one before. Are there foghorns in the waters off Manhattan or, for that matter, anywhere else in New York City?

headline: A New Holiday Tradition for the Dutch: Arguing About Blackface
abstract: A celebration of St. Nicholas in the Netherlands now includes an annual fight over the traditional depiction of his dark-skinned helper, Black Pete.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of Dutch citizens plan to don blackface this weekend for parades in honor of St. Nicholas, who according to local lore is accompanied by a dark-skinned helper know as Zwarte Piet, or Black Pete.

headline: New York City Agency Subpoenas 2 Santander Auto Lenders
abstract: The subpoenas were issued as part of an investigation into possibly misleading subprime lending practices at dealerships that sell used cars.
lead_paragraph: The New York City Department of Consumer Affairs said on Friday that it was investigating whether dealerships that sell used cars might have misled low-income borrowers into taking out expensive loans with hidden fees.

headline: Vintage Americana and Spicy Chicken
abstract: Until 1898, when Queens and the other boroughs were consolidated to create the modern New York City, Flushing was an independent town with its own magistrates.
lead_paragraph: Until 1898, when Queens and the other boroughs were consolidated to create the modern New York City, Flushing was an independent town with its own magistrates. FLUSHING TOWN HALL is one of the last vestiges of what Flushing looked like before it became a nexus of glass and concrete, Asian restaurants and stores.

headline: Buying the Farm, Building a Subdivision
abstract: A quick assignment on a farm turned into a two-decade look at what happened when developers transformed the farmland into a suburban subdivision.
lead_paragraph: A quick assignment on a farm turned into a two-decade look at what happened when developers transformed the farmland into a suburban subdivision.

headline: Inside T’s Luxury Issue
abstract: This winter, T delves deeper: into the best-known works of literary luminaries; into the extremes of food consumption, from fasting to feasting; even into world-saving, with the artist Olafur Eliasson.
lead_paragraph: T’s Luxury Issue offers an intimate look at some of literature, art and design’s most respected figures. In the issue’s centerpiece, authors including Philip Roth, George Saunders, Marilynne Robinson and Lydia Davis revisit, in candid prose, the circumstances and motivations that shaped some of their greatest works. (They also share annotated pages from those books — a sampling of a December auction of annotated first editions by 75 authors to benefit the PEN American Center, the range of which can be seen on T’s website.) Next, we celebrate the master decorator Robert Kime, whom we encounter at his picturesque farmhouse in the north of England; Rita Konig tours the property and gets a firsthand look at the English eclecticism that Kime has brought to his high-profile clients’ homes for decades. The polymath Danish artist Olafur Eliasson opens the doors to his sprawling studio in a converted brewery in Berlin and explains how art is just one of the ways — along with politics, philanthropy and cooking — he hopes to change the world. Elsewhere, Cathy Horyn answers the question, “To fast or feast?” by doing both in Germany’s Black Forest; Andrew O’Hagan opines that, yes, life really is better in the iPhone age; Christine Smallwood puzzles over a bizarre new theme park in Rome dedicated to Italian film; and one of T’s very own editors explores New York City on three wheels in an ode to the trusty and stylish, if oft-forgotten, tricycle. See all stories from the issue >>

headline: Pictures of the Day: Turkey and Elsewhere
abstract: Photographs from Turkey, India, Ukraine and China
lead_paragraph: Photographs from Turkey, India, Ukraine and China

headline: Nov. 14, 2014 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Turkey, India, Ukraine and China.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Turkey, India, Ukraine and China.

headline: A Bar for Whitman and Other Adventurers
abstract: New books take a look at Walt Whitman and his fellow bohemians, writers on their love for New York, and Hurricane Sandy’s power.
lead_paragraph: Long before New York artists and writers convened regularly at the Algonquin and, later, Elaine’s, an eclectic group distinguished largely by crushing poverty and creative potential gravitated to a subterranean saloon — decidedly not a salon — named Pfaff’s.

headline: A Latin Musician Translates a Meeting of Cultures
abstract: The Panamanian singer Rubén Blades took a step out of his comfort zone in performing with the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra.
lead_paragraph: The reality that jazz and Afro-Latin music have been mixed for a century can sometimes lead to the myth that a musician trained in one tradition is effectively trained in the other, and that fluency runs both ways at all times, in all places.

headline: Twitter Mistakenly Labels F.S.U. Article as Spam, for a Time
abstract: Twitter said a New York Times article reporting apparent special treatment of football players by the local police had been mistakenly flagged as spam by an outside organization.
lead_paragraph: Florida State University’s football program has been the focus in recent months of news reports detailing misconduct by its players and lenient treatment by the local police force. The latest appeared Friday when The New York Times reported that two of the university’s football players appeared to have received special treatment from the local police after a car crash.

headline: Classic French Bistro, Dash of Romance
abstract: Pascal and Sabine combines strong style, traditional Gallic dishes and inventive cocktails.
lead_paragraph: When Smith, the talented hospitality group that owns five restaurants in New Jersey, opened Porta in Asbury Park in 2011, it achieved a near miracle. The group made Italian food, a culinary staple in the Garden State, seem fresh and new. At Pascal and Sabine, which opened last December, it has done the same thing with French food. Dinner here manages to be both excellent and fun.

headline: Bridge Books for Intermediate Players
abstract: A look at some of the worthwhile bridge books published this year.
lead_paragraph: As we approach the gift-giving holiday season, let’s start to look at some of the worthwhile bridge books published this year.

headline: A Sponsor Steps Away From the Edge
abstract: Clif Bar, a maker of nutrition bars with long ties to the climbing community, dropped its sponsorship of five climbers because of the risks they took, sparking a debate about how much risk should be rewarded.
lead_paragraph: Moments before the San Francisco premiere of “Valley Uprising,” a documentary about the evolution of rock climbing in Yosemite National Park, Gary Erickson, the Clif Bar founder, was asked to stand and be acknowledged. He waved to the crowd inside a packed theater and received a warm ovation.

headline: Disney Announces New Digital and Mobile Products
abstract: In a news conference at its headquarters, the company revealed plans for a redesigned ESPN.com, an app-based children’s learning service, and sales of its films on Vudu.
lead_paragraph: BURBANK, Calif. – Disney on Friday announced several digital and mobile projects, including a redesign of ESPN.com, an app-based children’s learning product called Imagicademy and sales of its films on Walmart’s streaming service, Vudu.

headline: Along With German Food, a Cultural Tradition
abstract: Plattduetsche Park Restaurant, one of the few German restaurants left on Long Island, is part of a center that includes a beer hall, soccer teams and dance clubs.
lead_paragraph: It’s the perfect time of year to enjoy German food. The Oktoberfest hoopla is over and nippy weather is just beginning.

headline: The Strip
abstract: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.
lead_paragraph: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: Raw Bars Thriving in Season
abstract: From Onsets to Kusshis, tips on how and what to eat at oyster bars in Westchester County.
lead_paragraph: With the days growing shorter and colder, we are reminded that the darkness and the falling temperature are the price we pay for living in the beautiful Northeast. Yet at this time of year, oyster lovers rejoice. Restaurants with raw bars bustle at their blackboards, chalking up the oysters of the moment and standing by to add the names of those that will soon be ready for harvest.

headline: Player Ratings: Colombia (2), U.S. (1)
abstract: Rating the performance of American players in Friday’s international friendly against Colombia.
lead_paragraph: A troublesome pattern may be emerging for Jurgen Klinsmann’s United States national team.

headline: In a Snug Setting, Homey Italian Fare
abstract: At Quartina, thoughtful touches are plentiful, on and off the restaurant’s traditional menu.
lead_paragraph: Some restaurants are so romantic, cozy and spirit-warming that upon entry your anticipation soars, sometimes so high that it can’t always be realistically met by the food itself.

headline: Islamic State Says It Plans to Issue Its Own Currency
abstract: The leaders of the Islamic State have created their own currency, part of a grandiose plan to restore the caliphate era that dominated the Middle East more than 1,300 years ago.
lead_paragraph: They have paraded their own flag, formed courts and ministries and issued license plates. Now, the leaders of the Islamic State, the violent jihadist group that has seized parts of Syria and Iraq, have created their own currency, part of a plan to restore the caliphate era that dominated the Middle East more than 1,300 years ago.

headline: Debates on the Existence of the Divine
abstract: “Freud’s Last Session,” a play by Mark St. Germain, is at the Schoolhouse Theater in Croton Falls through Nov. 27.
lead_paragraph: It started, as many good things do, at Harvard. That’s where, in 1967, Dr. Armand M. Nicholi Jr., a psychiatrist, began teaching a seminar on the rationalist, atheist philosophy of Sigmund Freud. Under pressure from students, he has said, he widened the syllabus to include a more religious point of view as well, adding the writings of the Christian apologist C. S. Lewis to the course. He called it “The Question of God.”

headline: British Royal Couple Planning New York Visit for December
abstract: Prince William and Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge, will visit the Sept. 11 memorial and stop at a youth organization during a three-day stay in the city.
lead_paragraph: The Duchess of Cambridge will tour a children’s center with the first lady of New York City. The Duke will, in the spirit of royal opacity, attend “a technology themed event, hosted by a New York-headquartered technology company,” an announcement said.

headline: Apple Pay Gives Glimpse of Mainstream Appeal for Mobile Payments
abstract: While still far from a dominant payment system, Apple’s product has provided faint signs that mobile payment use could become widespread after years of sputtering.
lead_paragraph: For years, tech companies have dreamed of a future in which people ditch their wallets and pay for things with their smartphones. And for years, that has not happened.

headline: Obama’s Plan for Immigration Reform
abstract: Readers are divided over the president’s decision to use executive orders to overhaul immigration policy.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: To Help Language Skills of Children, a Study Finds, Text Their Parents With Tips
abstract: Preschoolers performed better on literacy tests when their parents received text messages with tips on how to help them, a study in San Francisco found.
lead_paragraph: With research showing language gaps between the children of affluent parents and those from low-income families emerging at an early age, educators have puzzled over how best to reach parents and guide them to do things like read to their children and talk to them regularly.

headline: Bills Coach Stumbles on Fourth-Down Decisions, and Questions
abstract: In reply to questions about his fourth-down decisions in a loss Thursday, Coach Doug Marrone offered very little in the way of a strategic rationale.
lead_paragraph: In a big game against the Miami Dolphins, full of playoff implications, the Buffalo Bills didn’t try their hardest to win. At least that was the conclusion of the NYT 4th Down Bot, which thought the Bills made two damaging decisions Thursday night, kicking a field goal on fourth-and-goal from the Dolphins’ 3-yard line and punting on fourth-and-6 near midfield.

headline: Revenue and Losses Both Rise for Postal Service
abstract: The United States Postal Service increased its operating revenue for the second year in a row, with the agency’s annual report showing a 9.1 percent gain from shipping and package services.
lead_paragraph: The United States Postal Service increased its operating revenue for the second year in a row, with the agency’s annual report showing a 9.1 percent gain from shipping and package services. The agency also reported a $5.7 billion net loss, compared with $5 billion in 2013. Officials said those figures are due to a congressional mandate that requires them to prefund health benefits for future retirees. According to the report, the service was unable to make the required contribution by the Sept. 30 deadline, noting that it would likely default on its prefunding obligations in 2015 and 2016. Overall mail volume was down this year.

headline: Those Who Vote and Those Who Don’t
abstract: Readers respond to an editorial, “The Worst Voter Turnout in 72 Years.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Landlords and Risk
abstract: A professor of political science says government need not ensure that landlords make a profit on their investments.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Weekly Wrap
abstract: Highlights from Times Insider for the Week of Nov. 10.
lead_paragraph: Hello, Insiders.

headline: The Rats of New York
abstract: The Mayor’s Alliance for New York City’s Animals discusses the Trap-Neuter-Return solution to managing the cat population, which in turn manages the rats.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Cellphones in New York City Schools
abstract: A teacher in the Bronx laments the end of a ban.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Some Retailers Promote Decision to Remain Closed on Thanksgiving
abstract: Last year, more retailers decided to open on Thanksgiving, but this year others are promoting their decision to remain closed on the holiday.
lead_paragraph: This Thanksgiving, the open-versus-shut debate has grown even louder.

headline: Stopping the Next Amphibian Apocalypse
abstract: We have a chance to prevent a fungus from killing salamanders.
lead_paragraph: FOR the past 25 years we have watched helplessly as a wide range of amphibians around the world have died from a pathogenic fungus, known as Bd (Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis). Now, yet another fungal contagion appears to have been unleashed. This one is spreading among salamanders in parts of Europe and threatens devastation.

headline: F.D.A. Optimistic on Visas for China Staff
abstract: The Food and Drug Administration expects to receive long-delayed visas soon for employees bound for its China offices, an agency official said.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration expects to receive long-delayed visas soon for employees bound for its China offices, an agency official said. The F.D.A. is trying to expand its presence in China to 26 American staff members from eight, but for nearly a year China has not issued the required visas. The F.D.A. commissioner, Dr. Margaret A. Hamburg, who is to visit China next week, said on Friday, “We have every reason to believe that we will be getting the visas very shortly.” Christopher Hickey, director of the F.D.A.’s China operation, said that it had filled the gaps by bringing in experts temporarily, but that short-term workers often lack deep knowledge of trends that years in the country provide. About 15 percent of Americans’ food is imported, including 80 percent of seafood and 50 percent of fresh fruit, and an increasing share of it is coming from China. It is also a major world producer of active ingredients for drugs.

headline: Congress Extends Itself
abstract: Lots of temporary tax breaks have expired. Do you want them extended? We have a definitive NO from the Koch brothers.
lead_paragraph: Let’s play: So You Think You Can Make Tax Policy!

headline: Face to Face With the Fed, Workers Ask for More Help
abstract: The Federal Reserve Board met with about 30 workers and activists at its headquarters on Friday in a gesture of concern for struggling Americans.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Jean Andre traveled from Queens to the Federal Reserve Board’s stately headquarters here on Friday to tell the people who make monetary policy that he needs their help. He cannot find regular work on film and photo shoots. The jobs he does find pay less.

headline: Algeria: President Hospitalized in France, Reports Say
abstract: President Abdelaziz Bouteflika, who was hospitalized for months last year after a stroke, has been admitted to a French hospital in the city of Grenoble, news agencies reported Friday, citing French police officials.
lead_paragraph: President Abdelaziz Bouteflika, who was hospitalized for months last year after a stroke, has been admitted to a French hospital in the city of Grenoble, news agencies reported Friday, citing French police officials. Mr. Bouteflika, 77, has led Algeria for 15 years and was re-elected to a fourth presidential term in April despite his evident ill health. He has flown to France for medical care several times since his stroke. Any deterioration of his health raises questions about presidential succession in Algeria, a volatile North African state. The Algerian government has not yet made any comment about his visit to France or the state of his health.

headline: 150 Years Later, Wrestling With a Revised View of Sherman’s March
abstract: The Union general’s March to the Sea was brutal, but his troops were careful to destroy only the South’s war machine, a strategy historians now deem effective and legal.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — This city would seem a peculiar place for sober conversation about the conduct of William T. Sherman.

headline: Rare Vaccine-Derived Polio Discovered in 2 Countries
abstract: Cases of paralysis caused by mutating polio vaccine have been found in South Sudan and Madagascar, the World Health Organization said Friday.
lead_paragraph: Cases of paralysis caused by mutating polio vaccine have been found in South Sudan and Madagascar, the World Health Organization said Friday. New rounds of vaccination will be conducted in December in both areas. The two paralysis cases in South Sudan were in a displaced-persons camp where revaccination is relatively easy, the W.H.O. said, while testing suggests that the one case in Madagascar did not spread far. “Vaccine-derived polio paralysis” is a rare but small risk inherent in oral vaccine, so the polio eradication campaign is trying to introduce injectable vaccine wherever it is safe and practical. The injectable vaccine contains a “killed” virus that cannot mutate. But it provides less protection than the live, weakened virus in oral vaccine, is more expensive and is much harder to give. Only 279 cases of polio have been detected in the world this year, almost all of them in Pakistan or in Pakistani families in Afghanistan.

headline: Tip on Medicare Spurs Insider Trading Investigation
abstract: Federal regulators are looking into whether a report by Height Securities that led to stock price jumps among health insurers was based on information obtained illegally.
lead_paragraph: With only 20 minutes remaining in the trading day, a Washington-based broker-dealer, Height Securities, blasted out a “flash report” to nearly 200 clients, including some of the biggest hedge funds on Wall Street, predicting that Medicare was about to raise some reimbursement rates.

headline: Appeals Court Throws Out Suit by Columbia Professor
abstract: Sylvia Nasar, a journalism professor, claimed that Columbia’s journalism school had mishandled funds generated by an endowment from the Knight Foundation.
lead_paragraph: A New York State appeals court on Thursday dismissed a lawsuit by a professor at the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism who had accused the school of misdirecting $4.5 million in funds tied to her endowed professorship.

headline: Hasbro Said to End Talks to Take Over DreamWorks Animation
abstract: The end of talks between the two would be the second demise of a potential takeover of DreamWorks Animation since the fall.
lead_paragraph: Hasbro has ended talks with DreamWorks Animation, people briefed on the matter said on Friday, ending discussions that would have united the parent companies of the Transformers and Shrek.

headline: The Fate of Medicaid Expansion
abstract: Midterm election results mean longer odds for this important goal of the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: Hopes for expanding Medicaid — an important goal of the Affordable Care Act — suffered a blow in the midterm elections. Several Republican governors who oppose expansion held on to their offices in close races and Republicans tightened their grip on state legislatures, which often have the final say on whether to expand.

headline: Culpability in the Upper Big Branch Disaster
abstract: The criminal indictment of a former coal mine chief executive is a step toward justice.
lead_paragraph: For the families of the 29 miners who died in the Upper Big Branch coal mine explosion four years ago, the criminal indictment of Donald Blankenship, the mine’s chief executive at the time, is a step toward justice. A federal grand jury accused Mr. Blankenship of conspiracy to violate safety laws and scheming to foil investigators’ safety visits, among other charges. The word “greed” was not used, but the indictment left no doubt about the priorities that led to the worst mine disaster in 40 years: “produce more coal, avoid the costs of following safety laws, and make more money.”

headline: Jane Byrne, Only Woman to Lead Chicago, Dies at 81
abstract: Ms. Byrne stunned Chicago’s Democratic machine in 1979 when she was elected mayor after sharply criticizing the incumbent for his handling of a devastating winter.
lead_paragraph: Jane M. Byrne, who stunned Chicago’s Democratic machine in 1979 when she was elected mayor after sharply criticizing the incumbent for his handling of a devastating winter — a victory that made her the city’s first female mayor, though her tenure lasted just one term — died on Friday in Chicago. She was 81.

headline: Report Offers Mixed View of Ex-Watchdog at Department of Homeland Security
abstract: An investigator appointed to look into Charles K. Edwards’s time as inspector general says there was no evidence he had awarded contracts to unqualified companies or destroyed telephone records.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — He incessantly “busted” the “chops” of the officials he was supposed to be investigating to get his wife a job. He had his staff doing research for his doctoral dissertation and reviewing his wife’s graduate school homework. And when Charles K. Edwards, the acting inspector general for the Department of Homeland Security from 2011 to 2013, met with his Ph.D. adviser in Florida, it was on a taxpayer-financed trip.

headline: His Subway Listeners Venture Above
abstract: An underground violinist greets his fans in a more conventional performance space.
lead_paragraph: As the subway busker put down his violin, the spontaneous delight of New Yorkers caught in the daily grind of the raucous subway system seemed to burst like fireworks into a standing ovation and shouts of “Bravo!”

headline: Why the F.C.C. Should Heed President Obama on Internet Regulation
abstract: Preventing the creation of fast and slow lanes on the Internet would correct an old mistake.
lead_paragraph: Big telecommunications companies and many Republicans in Congress have criticized President Obama’s proposal for strong rules to prevent the creation of fast and slow lanes on the Internet. They claim this is heavy-handed government regulation. But in fact, it is correcting an old mistake.

headline: Building Bridges Where Needed on Chicago’s South Side
abstract: Rami Nashashibi is trying to replace mutual suspicion with respect and understanding between two groups that have clashed in the past.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Rami Nashashibi drove down the tattered corridor of West 63rd Street, passing the occasional church or auto-repair shop or check-cashing spot, mostly skirting blocks that had been vacant so long they had dirt trails cutting through the high weeds. Near the corner of Racine, he pulled to the curb outside the grocery calling itself A Lot To Save.

headline: Where Federal Health Exchange Rates Will Rise
abstract: A map of upcoming changes in federal health exchange rates.
lead_paragraph: A map of upcoming changes in federal health exchange rates.

headline: In Ditmas Park, Armed Robbers Prey on Businesses and Their Patrons
abstract: A troubling pattern has emerged: Armed robbers in hooded sweatshirts and masks are hitting local businesses not just for the cash in the registers, but for patrons’ belongings, too.
lead_paragraph: The group of writers met at the trendy Brooklyn cafe as they did each week, to talk about their works in progress. Surely none of them, during discussions of character and twists of plot, guessed that a masked gunman would barge into their circle on Thursday night and rob them of their laptops.

headline: Net Neutrality Rules
abstract: Why is it so hard to achieve a deal when it’s something that everyone wants?
lead_paragraph: Is there anybody out there who opposes net neutrality?

headline: ISIS ‘Slave Market Day’
abstract: In a video posted in October 2014 on YouTube, a group of men believed to be Islamic State fighters are shown sitting in a room bantering about buying and selling Yazidi girls on “slave market day.”
lead_paragraph: In a video posted in October 2014 on YouTube, a group of men believed to be Islamic State fighters are shown sitting in a room bantering about buying and selling Yazidi girls on “slave market day.”

headline: Yazidi Girls Seized by ISIS Speak Out After Escape
abstract: A few of the thousands of young women from the minority Yazidi religion who were kidnapped by the Islamic State told of a systemized industry of slavery.
lead_paragraph: KHANKE, Iraq — The 15-year-old girl, crying and terrified, refused to release her grip on her sister’s hand. Days earlier, Islamic State fighters had torn the girls from their family, and now were trying to split them up and distribute them as spoils of war.

headline: Will Other Leagues Join N.B.A.? Don’t Bet on It
abstract: Professional sports leagues that back the prohibition of betting on their games often tiptoe around their own opposition, but not all leagues have voiced a willingness to go as far as N.B.A. Commissioner Adam Silver.
lead_paragraph: There is no shortage of ways for fans to bet on sports, even though federal law forbids gambling on games in almost all states: Fantasy leagues, state-run lotteries and neighborhood bookies, as well as online offshore ones, will take a fan’s action.

headline: City in Ukraine Tied to Masochism Finds Link Painful, Sure, but Some Like It
abstract: Residents of the western Ukrainian city of Lviv are of two minds on the reputation of Leopold von Sacher-Masoch.
lead_paragraph: LVIV, Ukraine — Taras Demlan was out for a quiet drink with friends in the western Ukrainian city of Lviv, a beguiling jewel of Hapsburg architectural splendor, and his companions persuaded him to try the specialty of the house.

headline: Moment Resonates, Quietly, at UMass
abstract: Derrick Gordon, the first openly gay player in Division I men’s basketball, is happy to find his coming out barely causes a ripple at UMass.
lead_paragraph: AMHERST, Mass. — As Derrick Gordon’s name was announced during the introduction of the Massachusetts basketball team’s starting lineup Friday, a spotlight swung around the arena, and cheerleaders waved their pompoms. The Who’s “Baba O’Riley” played. There was a loud cheer at the sound of Gordon’s name. Yet nothing signified the occasion as anything extraordinary.

headline: Christie’s Chief of Staff Quits for a Hospital Job
abstract: Kevin O’Dowd, a close lieutenant of Gov. Chis Christie’s since his days as United States attorney, is resigning to become an executive at Cooper Hospital in Camden.
lead_paragraph: The chief of staff to Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey is leaving his job to work in the private sector, an indication of how the scandal surrounding the closing of access lanes to the George Washington Bridge last year continues to drag on the administration.

headline: Weinstein Brothers Lose Dispute Over Profits to ‘Hobbit’
abstract: Bob and Harvey Weinstein had sought at least $75 million in compensation from sequels to “The Hobbit.”
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – An attempt by Bob and Harvey Weinstein to profit from the second and third “Hobbit” movies has failed.

headline: Halliburton Raises Pressure on Baker Hughes by Targeting Its Board
abstract: The threat to replace Baker Hughes’s entire board followed an impasse in merger negotiations and set up a fight for control of a major oil services company.
lead_paragraph: A fight for control of a major oil field services company appeared to be brewing on Friday, as Baker Hughes disclosed that its larger rival Halliburton had threatened to replace its entire board.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 14, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Bill Clinton, in Little Rock, Defends His Record With an Eye to Other Chapters
abstract: The speech came after a day of panel discussions at the William J. Clinton Presidential Library in which former White House aides discussed the former president’s foreign and domestic policies.
lead_paragraph: LITTLE ROCK, Ark. — In front of a crowd of his former White House aides, on a podium set up inside his presidential library, Bill Clinton on Friday defended his legacy as one of policy breakthroughs achieved amid partisan battles, a record that may soon take on fresh relevance.

headline: One Drug or 2? Parents See Risk but Also Hope
abstract: A steadily rising number of parents face a wrenching choice about whether to add antipsychotic drugs like Risperdal to stimulants like Adderall to treat children for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.
lead_paragraph: CONCORD, Calif. — Every time Matthias is kicked out of a school or day camp for defying adults and clashing with other children, his mother, Joelle Kendle, inches closer to a decision she dreads. With each morning of arm-twisting and leg-flailing as she tries to get him dressed and out the door for first grade, the temptation intensifies.

headline: Falling Behind on Rent After Family Tragedies
abstract: After his mother’s death, a sister’s accident and a son’s illness, Johnny Glenn had little left to pay for the apartment he has lived in for 43 years.
lead_paragraph: Underneath Johnny Glenn’s cavalier exterior lies a formidable consternation.

headline: In College Football, Now the Trophies Precede the Rivalries
abstract: Nebraska and Wisconsin played on Saturday for the Freedom Trophy, one in a series of awards created to address the rivalry vacuum caused by the realignment of conferences.
lead_paragraph: MADISON, Wis. — Two weeks from Saturday, Wisconsin and Minnesota will play for the 124th time. Their rivalry is the most prolific in major college football, one that goes back to the 1890s.

headline: Uber Said to Announce Music Partnership With Spotify
abstract: The two buzzy start-ups will work together to offer personalized music to Uber passengers.
lead_paragraph: Uber has long proclaimed to be “everyone’s private driver.” Soon, those drivers will be able to play your own tunes while you ride.

headline: Cosby Is Off Another Show as Rape Accusations Swirl
abstract: Bill Cosby, in an interview aired Saturday on NPR, refused to answer questions about allegations that he sexually assaulted several women decades ago.
lead_paragraph: Criticism of one of television’s most beloved stars, Bill Cosby, is escalating with renewed attention to allegations that he sexually assaulted women in several incidents decades ago.

headline: Cost of Coverage Under Affordable Care Act to Increase in 2015
abstract: Many Americans with health insurance bought under the Affordable Care Act could face substantial price increases next year — in some cases as much as 20 percent.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Friday unveiled data showing that many Americans with health insurance bought under the Affordable Care Act could face substantial price increases next year — in some cases as much as 20 percent — unless they switch plans.

headline: Millions Due in Back Pay to Dancers at Manhattan Strip Club
abstract: Rick’s Cabaret, a club in Midtown, owes more than $10 million in back pay to dancers who performed there without being paid hourly wages, a judge ruled.
lead_paragraph: Rick’s Cabaret, a strip club in Midtown Manhattan, owes more than $10 million in back pay to about 1,900 dancers who performed there without being paid hourly wages, a federal judge ruled on Friday.

headline: James A. Lebenthal, Muni Bond Expert, Dies at 86
abstract: Mr. Lebenthal turned the tax-free financial instruments called munis into household words with radio and television ads.
lead_paragraph: James A. Lebenthal, America’s best-known municipal bond salesman, who turned the tax-free financial instruments called munis into a household word with radio and television ads dramatizing how ordinary investors built subways, sewers, bridges and schools, died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 86.

headline: Affordable Care Act Supporter Ignites Fury With a Word: ‘Stupid’
abstract: Jonathan Gruber, an M.I.T. professor, appears in a video saying the American people were fooled about how the health care law works.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Three years ago, as President Obama fought for re-election, his team was more than happy to have Jonathan Gruber, a well-known Massachusetts Institute of Technology professor, mouthing off.

headline: Excursions for Some Rock Collectors
abstract: A sparkling, well-filled and manageable Saturday puzzle by Peter Wentz.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — I nearly wept with joy when I solved Peter Wentz’s puzzle. We’ve had a rough week as far as fill goes, in my humble opinion, so it made me feel a lot happier to see a minimum of junk today.

headline: Ernest Kinoy, a Writer of TV’s ‘Roots,’ Dies at 89
abstract: Mr. Kinoy wrote television scripts that ranged from “Playhouse 90” presentations to “Victory at Entebbe.”
lead_paragraph: Ernest Kinoy, who wrote Broadway musicals, Hollywood screenplays and Emmy Award-winning episodes of “The Defenders” and “Roots,” died on Nov. 10 in Townshend, Vt. He was 89.

headline: Saturday’s College Football Games to Watch
abstract: No. 1 Mississippi State plays No. 4 Alabama, with each team controlling its destiny to win a national championship.
lead_paragraph: 1 MISSISSIPPI STATE at 4 ALABAMA

headline: Knicks’ Hopes of Ending Skid Are Dashed at the Buzzer
abstract: Trey Burke’s jumper from the left corner at the buzzer lifted the Jazz over the Knicks, ruining a 46-point night from Carmelo Anthony.
lead_paragraph: The Knicks entered Friday’s contest against the downtrodden Utah Jazz — yet another weak opponent — with the earnest hope that their moribund start to their season could be reversed.

headline: To Nets Coach Lionel Hollins, Scrappiness Counts
abstract: The Warriors’ 14 offensive boards and 19 second-chance points on Thursday left Hollins calling for more aggressive play from his team.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Lionel Hollins offered a small but revealing look into his values as Nets coach on Thursday night.

headline: Amid Little Fanfare, Americans Lose in London
abstract: American fans were notable mainly by their absence as the United States lost to Colombia, the world’s third-ranked team, in an international friendly.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Tens of thousands of Americans live and work in London, and they flock in sellout numbers to help fill the 80,000-seat Wembley Stadium when N.F.L. teams come to town for the regular-season games that are now an annual fixture here.

headline: Alexander Grothendieck, Math Enigma, Dies at 86
abstract: His gift for abstraction excavated new ground in algebraic geometry and supplied a theoretical foundation for the solving of some of the most vexing conundrums of modern mathematics.
lead_paragraph: Alexander Grothendieck, whose gift for deep abstraction excavated new ground in the field known as algebraic geometry and supplied a theoretical foundation for the solving of some of the most vexing conundrums of modern mathematics, died on Thursday in Ariège, in the French Pyrenees. He was 86.

headline: Dorian Paskowitz Dies at 93: Doctor and Surfer Lived an Endless Summer
abstract: Mr. Paskowitz gave up a lucrative medical practice to embark, with his family, on a peripatetic and celebrated surfing life.
lead_paragraph: Dorian Paskowitz, a Stanford-educated doctor who gave up a lucrative medical practice to embark, with his family, on a peripatetic and celebrated surfing life, died on Monday in Newport Beach, Calif. He was 93.

headline: Obama Offers Assurances of U.S. Shift Toward Asia
abstract: Visiting Australia, President Obama said the United States could be a force for order as Asia faced threats like a nuclear-armed North Korea and disputes between China and its neighbors.
lead_paragraph: BRISBANE, Australia — President Obama sought to give new momentum to his strategic shift to Asia on Saturday, telling an audience of students here that the United States could be a force for order in a fast-growing region shadowed by threats like a nuclear-armed North Korea and maritime disputes between China and its neighbors.

headline: The Strip — 2013
abstract: Cartoons about current affairs from 2013.
lead_paragraph: Cartoons about current affairs from 2013.

headline: The Strip — 2012
abstract: Cartoons about current affairs from 2012.
lead_paragraph: Cartoons about current affairs from 2012.

headline: An Ear for Jazz and a Nose for Business
abstract: While he and his wife renovated a bed-and-breakfast, Kenneth D. Kitchings, set aside a room for his dream nightclub, and it has taken off.
lead_paragraph: The life of a jazz club is often brief and brutal, and that of the Side Door, a small room tucked away in sleepy Old Lyme, might have been expected to follow that pattern. But in the 18 months since Kenneth D. Kitchings opened the club, it has secured a spot on many a jazz musician’s itinerary — and not everyone is surprised.

headline: Onstage, a Classic About Racism and Tolerance
abstract: The theatrical version of “To Kill a Mockingbird” is part of the Bay Street Theater’s “Literature Live!” program, and all students are admitted free.
lead_paragraph: Before ticketholders even take their seats, they hear sporadic bird chirping. The audience has entered 1930s Maycomb County in Alabama, the setting for “To Kill a Mockingbird,” Harper Lee’s profoundly moving novel, which has been adapted for the stage by Christopher Sergel.

headline: The Practical Art of Quilting
abstract: An exhibition of quilts made by African-American women includes samples of simple patterns to elaborate records of history.
lead_paragraph: Quilts made by African-African women in the rural South — historically one of the least represented groups in the institutional art world — have become widely popular in recent decades. The spike of interest coincides with a growing focus on craft and folk art, possibly because of major museum exhibitions, like one at the Whitney Museum of American Art in 2002 featuring the quilts of Gee’s Bend, a hamlet in southwest Alabama.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (Starz) THE MISSING A 5-year-old British boy vanishes during a family vacation in France, sending his parents (James Nesbitt and Frances O’Connor) on a yearslong search to find out what happened to him. In this new eight-part mystery, Tcheky Karyo plays the French detective who initially leads the investigation, then comes out of retirement when a clue emerges eight years later; Jason Flemyng is the police representative on the British side; and Arsher Ali is the aspiring journalist merciless in his quest for a scoop. “What begins as a wrenching but contained tragedy ripples out into widening and intersecting circles of secrecy and deceit,” Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. “It’s a formula used not just in television and movies but also novels by Richard Price and Tana French.” But, she added, " ‘The Missing’ is imaginatively written, well cast, chillingly believable and quite addictive. This kind of story has been told this way before, but somehow that doesn’t make this telling any less compelling.”

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, November 15, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “I want to know more about what it means for him to be on two medications, and no one can really tell me.”

headline: Corrections: November 15, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, November 15, 2014.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: The Strip
abstract: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.
lead_paragraph: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: Deporting Human Rights Abusers
abstract: A look back at the role of commanding officers in El Salvador’s civil war, where the military committed massacres and other atrocities. Efforts to deport some of these retired generals have yet to be successful.
lead_paragraph: When three Maryknoll nuns and a lay churchwoman were raped and killed in El Salvador in December 1980, the story sparked global outrage. Although five Salvadoran national guardsmen were eventually tried and convicted, no higher-ups were ever held responsible for the murders.

headline: Hong Kong Activists Kept From Flying to Beijing
abstract: The students calling for free elections had proposed a meeting with China’s prime minister, but they were turned away Saturday at the Hong Kong airport.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A group of pro-democracy activists from Hong Kong were prevented Saturday from boarding a flight to Beijing, where they had hoped to lobby the Chinese government to heed their calls for free elections.

headline: Vegetarian Thanksgiving: Caramelized Onion and Fennel Risotto
abstract: For vegetarians and other Thanksgiving guests who are tired of sweet potatoes and root vegetables, try this hearty risotto flavored with a taste of fall.
lead_paragraph: How do you feed a vegetarian or vegan Thanksgiving guest who doesn’t like sweet potatoes?

headline: Pakistanis Optimistic on Ties After Afghan Leader’s Visit
abstract: As President Ashraf Ghani met with Pakistan’s prime minister on Saturday, officials were upbeat about a possible reset in the relationship.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Afghanistan’s new president, Ashraf Ghani, met with Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif here on Saturday, ending a state visit that left Pakistanis optimistic about a new start for the countries’ often acrimonious relationship.

headline: Electrical Scalp Device Can Slow Progression of Deadly Brain Tumors
abstract: An electrical device glued to the scalp can slow cancer growth and prolong survival in people with the deadliest type of brain tumor, glioblastoma, researchers have found.
lead_paragraph: An electrical device glued to the scalp can slow cancer growth and prolong survival in people with the deadliest type of brain tumor, researchers reported on Saturday.

headline: The Daily Gift: An Aphrodisiac Powder to Warm Up Winter Nights
abstract: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.
lead_paragraph: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.

headline: College Football Scenarios: Six Teams, Four Spots
abstract: We cut through the rankings turmoil to tell you which teams have the inside track.
lead_paragraph: We cut through the rankings turmoil to tell you which teams have the inside track.

headline: The Voice That Sends Help
abstract: A 911 dispatcher in Hartford has taken emergency calls for the last 10 years. Each call, she says, makes her stronger.
lead_paragraph: Pamela Bullock-Galloway, 52, is an emergency telecommunications operator for the city of Hartford.

headline: Another Widening Gap: The Haves vs. the Have-Mores
abstract: Whether they are buying yachts, diamonds or art, the extremely rich are often leaving the merely rich in the dust.
lead_paragraph: Philip Rushton has been selling private jets to the global rich for more than three decades. In just about every economic cycle, sales of small jets and big jets tended to move together — rising and falling with financial markets and fortunes of the wealthy.

headline: The Gang That Always Liked Ike
abstract: How President Eisenhower found camaraderie among a group of wealthy, loyal businessmen.
lead_paragraph: For a window into a president’s soul, look at his closest personal friends. Dwight D. Eisenhower liked to decompress with a circle of wealthy businessmen who sometimes called themselves “the Gang.” Among these friends were William E. Robinson, a New York Herald Tribune executive and later president of Coca-Cola; Ellis D. Slater, president of Frankfort Distillers; Clifford Roberts, an investment banker and Augusta National Golf Club chairman; W. Alton Jones, head of the Cities Service oil company (now Citgo); and George E. Allen, a lawyer-financier-lobbyist.

headline: A Plumbing Problem for the Internet (and the Stock Market)
abstract: How the net neutrality debate has jostled the stock price of one keeper of the pipes.
lead_paragraph: I don’t entirely agree with W. Hodding Carter, the author of a quirky history of pipes and drains called “Flushed: How the Plumber Saved Civilization.”

headline: 1914: Sir Ernest Shackleton Outlines His Polar Projects
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Sir Ernest Shackleton reveals the route of his Trans-Antarctic Expedition in 1914.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As already reported in the HERALD, the Shackleton expedition has left Buenos Aires for the South Polar regions. Sir Ernest Shackleton, in a cablegram to the “Daily Chronicle,” gives some final details of his projects.

headline: Putin Gets a Cool Reception From G-20
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia faced a chorus of criticism at a summit meeting, where the fighting in Ukraine threatened to overshadow talk of global economics.
lead_paragraph: As President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia joined world leaders for the Group of 20 summit meeting in Brisbane, Australia, on Saturday, he faced criticism from President Obama and other leaders over the conflict in Ukraine.

headline: Buying the Bricks for Your Online Storefront
abstract: E-commerce services help mom-and-pop shops achieve a more polished web presence.
lead_paragraph: These days, I do nearly all my shopping online. Amazon whisks household supplies like dish soap and paper towels to my doorstep in a day or two, and grocery services like FreshDirect and Good Eggs can quickly restock my fridge and pantry.

headline: Borrowers, Beware: The Robo-Signers Aren’t Finished Yet
abstract: In Florida cases now pursued by debt collectors, some of the underlying foreclosures were based on dubious documents.
lead_paragraph: Remember the robo-signers, those mortgage loan automatons who authenticated thousands of foreclosure documents over the years without verifying the information they were swearing to?

headline: No Love for a Bench
abstract: This week’s subjects include sidewalk benches placed by businesses; co-op landlords facing possible foreclosure; and basement flooding.
lead_paragraph: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: Hotels Providing Packages With a View to the Parade
abstract: Hotels along the route of the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade will offer some particularly good views of this year’s event.
lead_paragraph: The Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade has been a New York City tradition since the 1920s, and attracts 3.5 million spectators in the city. Guests at several hotels along the route — on Central Park West and South and Avenue of the Americas — will get some particularly good views of this year’s event.

headline: Variety: A Packed Acrostic
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon choose a quote that might just reunite me with a long lost passion.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — I had a brief fling with Russian literature when I was younger, but I found as life got busy that I just didn’t have the brain power to stick with books that were more complex than the chapter books I read to my children. Now that my kids are nearly grown, maybe I’ll get back into Tolstoy and Dostoevsky.

headline: No. 1 With a Bullet: ‘Nadeshot’ Becomes a Call of Duty Star
abstract: Three years ago, Matt Haag was flipping burgers at McDonald’s. Today he makes his living playing video games and has 1.5 million YouTube subscribers.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Matt Haag, a professional video game player, makes close to a million dollars a year sitting in a soft chair smashing buttons. It is a fantastically sweet gig, and he will do about anything to keep it.

headline: Living Out Knicks Dream, Complete With Nightmares
abstract: Dennis Doyle has decided to combine his passions for writing, traveling and the Knicks by attending all of the team’s 82 games this season. But what about all the losing?
lead_paragraph: Dennis Doyle knows how strange it must sound, his giving up his career as a lawyer to hit the road with his favorite sports team.

headline: Finishing Asia Tour, Obama Promotes More Ambitious Foreign Policy
abstract: The scorecard for President Obama’s Asia trip looks drastically different from the last one, with a landmark climate-change agreement and a trade deal with China.
lead_paragraph: BRISBANE, Australia — When President Obama ended his last trip to Asia in the Philippines in April, he delivered a defense of his foreign policy as a slow, steady pursuit of American interests — casting himself as a batter who hits singles and doubles, but avoids reckless errors.

headline: More Federal Agencies Are Using Undercover Operations
abstract: Once largely the domain of the F.B.I., undercover work has increased across federal agencies as policies have changed, according to officials, former agents and documents.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The federal government has significantly expanded undercover operations in recent years, with officers from at least 40 agencies posing as business people, welfare recipients, political protesters and even doctors or ministers to ferret out wrongdoing, records and interviews show.

headline: Top General Arrives in Baghdad to See U.S. Contribution in Fight Against ISIS
abstract: On his first visit to Baghdad since the beginning of the American-led military campaign against the Islamic State, Gen. Martin E. Dempsey said he wanted to get a sense of how the troops were doing.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — The top United States military officer arrived here Saturday on his first visit since the beginning of the American-led military campaign against the extremists who call themselves the Islamic State.

headline: To the End, Kobe Bryant Is a Shooting Guard, Hot or Cold
abstract: The Lakers’ star established the career record for most missed field-goal attempts, a category in which leaders generally reach the Hall of Fame.
lead_paragraph: Being a prolific outside shooter in the N.B.A. requires an almost comical amount of optimism. A player has to accept that more than half of his shots will miss but has to retain the confidence to thrust the ball toward the rim every time he has the chance.

headline: In Egypt, Jihadists Release Video of an October Attack
abstract: The 30-minute video was the first to be released by the militant group, Ansar Beit al-Maqdis, since publicly declaring its affiliation on Monday with the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egypt’s most lethal jihadist group has released a video that appears to show its militants carrying out an attack that killed more than 31 soldiers in the Sinai Peninsula last month, raising new questions about the readiness of the government’s troops to confront the insurgency.

headline: A Former Police Officer Will Get a Posthumous Honor
abstract: Pat Burns, Mike Modano, Rob Blake, Peter Forsberg, Dominik Hasek and the referee Bill McCreary will be inducted into hockey’s hall of fame in Toronto on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Pat Burns liked to joke that he was two things: a police officer and hockey coach.

headline: Some New Frustrations as Health Exchange Opens
abstract: The system opened Saturday and performed much better than last year, but some consumers reported long delays in trying to buy insurance and access their accounts at HealthCare.gov.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The health insurance marketplace opened for business on Saturday and performed much better than last year, but some consumers reported long, frustrating delays in trying to buy insurance and gain access to their own accounts at HealthCare.gov.

headline: The Unwisdom of Crowding Out (Wonkish)
abstract: It’s worse than even Keynesians say.
lead_paragraph: I am, to my own surprise, not too happy with the defense of Keynes by Peter Temin and David Vines in VoxEU. Peter and David are of course right that Keynes has a lot to teach us, and are also right that the anti-Keynesians aren’t just making really bad arguments; they’re making the very same really bad arguments Keynes refuted 80 years ago.

headline: Advice and Accolades for UConn’s Breanna Stewart
abstract: The key to the top-ranked Huskies’ success this season will center on Breanna Stewart’s performance and growth as a team leader, attributes she refined during a month abroad with the national team.
lead_paragraph: HARTFORD — Breanna Stewart’s junior year at Connecticut began with a specialized course for a select group of student-athletes.

headline: How the G.O.P. Can Court the Working Class
abstract: A new Republican economic approach could still revolve around cutting taxes, but the cuts would no longer be focused on the affluent.
lead_paragraph: A defining feature of Republican economic policy for decades has been its benefits for the well off. The stated goals of that policy have been to shrink government and lift economic growth, but the main method has been cutting taxes much more for high-income families than others. At the same time, the party has opposed an expansion of health insurance for low- and middle-income families, increases in the minimum wage and college financial aid and extensions of jobless benefits.

headline: Sunday Shows: What We’re Watching
abstract: President Obama said he would act unilaterally to overhaul immigration policy, an announcement that will dominate the conversations on the Sunday talk shows.
lead_paragraph: Despite protests from conservatives, President Obama has said he will act unilaterally on immigration, issuing executive orders that will protect up to five million unauthorized immigrants from deportation.

headline: Winless Driver Could Wear the Crown
abstract: Although he has not finished first all year, Ryan Newman has a chance to capture the Sprint Cup title in Nascar’s last race of the season.
lead_paragraph: HOMESTEAD, Fla. — Ryan Newman can do something Sunday that no one else has done: win a Nascar Sprint Cup title without winning a race during the season.

headline: Do It For Utica!
abstract: To address shrinking populations, a call to coital arms.
lead_paragraph: I love two places in this world. One of them is Denmark, and so I was dismayed to discover that it has a serious procreation problem. The birthrate is the lowest it’s been in more than a quarter century, prompting the country to revise its sexual education curriculum. The new program is called, “This is how you have children!”

headline: Who Are We?
abstract: ISIS forces a painful look in the mirror for Arab Muslims.
lead_paragraph: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates — THE 9/11 suicide attack, spearheaded by 19, mostly Saudi, young men in the name of Islam, ignited a debate in the Sunni Arab world about religion and how their societies could have produced such suicidal fanatics. But it was quickly choked off by denial, and by America’s failed invasion of Iraq. Well, conversations here in Dubai, one of the great Arab/Muslim crossroads, make it clear that the rise of the Islamic State “caliphate” in Iraq and Syria, and its barbaric treatment of those who are against them — moderate Sunnis or Shiites, Christians, other minorities and women — has revived this central debate about “who are we?”

headline: Delusions of the Democrats
abstract: Demographics will not save them. A vision might.
lead_paragraph: DEMOGRAPHICS is not enough.

headline: The Fable of Rand Paul
abstract: He has captured the media’s imagination. He’s unlikely to capture the Republican nomination.
lead_paragraph: “THE most interesting man in politics” is what Politico Magazine crowned Rand Paul in September, when it placed him at the top of a list of 50 people to keep an eye on. And Time magazine used those exact six words, in that exact order, next to a photograph of Paul on its cover last month.

headline: ‘Prophylactic’ Suicide
abstract: Readers debate whether aid-in-dying rights should be expanded to those who are not terminally ill.
lead_paragraph: Readers debate whether aid-in-dying rights should be expanded to those who are not terminally ill.

headline: The Civil War’s Environmental Impact
abstract: Northern and Southern armies cut down roughly two million trees.
lead_paragraph: The Civil War was the most lethal conflict in American history, by a wide margin. But the conventional metric we use to measure a war’s impact – the number of human lives it took – does not fully convey the damage it caused. This was an environmental catastrophe of the first magnitude, with effects that endured long after the guns were silenced. It could be argued that they have never ended.

headline: On Smushing Bugs
abstract: Dispensing death and clemency capriciously, killing on petulant impulse, granting pardons at whim — it’s complicated.
lead_paragraph: When my kitchen became infested with ants this summer, as it does every year, I put out ant traps, which, in another annual rite, did exactly nothing. So I did what I always end up doing — inefficiently smushing the ants one by one. Sometimes I’ll massacre dozens at a time in a fit of pique after catching them glutting themselves in my sugar bowl, but then, seeing a single ant moping around on the counter looking sort of forlorn and hangdog, I’ll hesitate. He looks like maybe he’s not having such a great day already. Getting smushed is the last thing this guy needs.

headline: After Three Days on the Town in New York, European Sailors Head Home
abstract: More than 450 marines and sailors from Holland, Spain and England were set to depart after a three-day shore leave in New York City.
lead_paragraph: More than 450 visitors from Holland, Spain and England were set to depart on Saturday from the passenger ship terminal on the West Side of Manhattan. But they are not typical tourists leaving on a cruise ship.

headline: Drawing Strength From the Gifts Her Mother Left Behind
abstract: The death of a parent brought Makia Green, a college student, mounting needs and surprises. But she inherited her mother’s drive, persistence and devotion to education.
lead_paragraph: In their final days together, the last gift Makia Green gave her dying mother was a vision of the future.

headline: Police Examine Death of a Boy and an Attack on a Girl
abstract: A boy died in the Bronx after being found unconscious in his bed early Saturday morning, and in Brooklyn a man was charged with assaulting his 2-year-old stepdaughter.
lead_paragraph: The police are investigating the death of a 3-year-old boy in the Bronx after his grandmother found him unconscious in his bed early Saturday morning, the authorities said.

headline: In Flawed Giants’ Season, a Bit of Perfection
abstract: The place-kicker Josh Brown has made each of his nine field-goal attempts and 24 of 24 extra-point attempts.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Within a failing organization, it is rare when one person — and only one person — is indisputably blameless for the dysfunction. If everything seems to be going wrong on every noticeable level, how can one person be above the taint of collapse and error?

headline: New Senators Tilt G.O.P. Back Toward Insiders
abstract: When Republicans take over the Senate in January, most of the members of the party’s freshman class will be people whose careers blossomed in the government bureaucracy that some politicians loathe.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — They have spent at least 70 collective years in government: five sitting members of Congress, two civil servants from the George W. Bush administration, a pair of state legislators and a former governor.

headline: Applications by the Dozen, as Anxious Seniors Hedge College Bets
abstract: The escalation in the number of schools on students’ lists is driven by several factors, but perhaps the strongest is plain old fear.
lead_paragraph: Six college applications once seemed like a lot. Submitting eight was a mark of great ambition. For a growing number of increasingly anxious high school seniors, figures like that now sound like just a starting point.

headline: Cold Numbers on G.M. Crisis: A Peek Inside
abstract: Kenneth Feinberg, a compensation expert, leads a team that determines who the victims are and how much money they should receive.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — If this Monday is like almost every other one this fall, the death toll from General Motors’ defective ignition switch will rise.

headline: A Familiar Anger Begins to Boil Again in Mexico
abstract: The shocking reports about the mass disappearance of college students have stoked the anger of many Mexicans toward corrupt politicians and police officers.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The fate of 43 college students missing and presumed killed and burned to ashes in a mass abduction in September has bred ire and indignation in many corners of Mexico.

headline: Sunday’s Matchup: 49ers (5-4) at Giants (3-6)
abstract: Jason Pierre-Paul needs to disrupt San Francisco quarterback Colin Kaepernick and chase down running backs heading to the opposite side of the formation.
lead_paragraph: 1 p.m., Fox

headline: Warning Signs From Commodity Prices
abstract: Lower-priced fuels and metals are providing a windfall — and a cause for worry.
lead_paragraph: For many consumers and businesses the recent drop in commodity prices has provided a tidy windfall — one analyst estimated that the typical American household would save $400 a year thanks to lower gasoline prices. But the tumbling price of fuels, metals and other commodities is also sending a warning about the global economy.

headline: The Great Immigration Betrayal
abstract: Using executive authority to protect millions of people from deportation is a dangerous idea.
lead_paragraph: IN the months since President Obama first seem poised — as he now seems poised again — to issue a sweeping executive amnesty for millions of illegal immigrants, we’ve learned two important things about how this administration approaches its constitutional obligations.

headline: When Whites Just Don’t Get It, Part 4
abstract: In this installment in a series on race, responding to a common refrain that, where the history of slavery and racism is concerned, it’s time to move on.
lead_paragraph: WHEN I write about racial inequality in America, one common response from whites is eye-rolling and an emphatic: It’s time to move on.

headline: A Final Dash on an Iran Deal
abstract: The chances for a comprehensive permanent accord that would limit the country’s nuclear program must be kept alive.
lead_paragraph: After a year of work, the major powers and Iran face a Nov. 24 deadline for completing an agreement that would limit Iran’s nuclear program in exchange for lifting sanctions. While a final round of negotiations is set for this week, high-level talks in Oman last week apparently failed to achieve a breakthrough on important issues, leading to growing speculation that the deadline will not be met.

headline: The Shifting Ebola Epidemic
abstract: Recent gains in controlling the virus have been encouraging, but the world must guard against complacency.
lead_paragraph: Recent gains in controlling the Ebola epidemic in West Africa have been encouraging, but they offer no reason for complacency. In Liberia, the hardest-hit country, the rate of new infections has declined in some areas, and several treatment units have been reporting empty beds for more than a month. But in adjacent Sierra Leone the number of new cases has shot upward, while in Guinea, where the epidemic started, the incidence of new cases appears to have stabilized over all, with growth in some districts and declines in others. All told, Ebola has infected more than 14,000 people in West Africa and killed more than 5,000 of them.

headline: R. Luke DuBois
abstract: A data visualization expert on “All the King’s Men,” Hüsker Dü and the potential of Project Tango.
lead_paragraph: R. Luke DuBois is a composer, conceptual artist and an associate professor at New York University’s Polytechnic School of Engineering. His art and his teaching focus on the visualization of data.

headline: In Malaysia, Activists Draw Attention to Colonial-Era Sedition Act
abstract: The Sedition Act, a British colonial-era law, is being used to charge and investigate politicians, activists, academics and students. But a law professor is challenging its constitutionality.
lead_paragraph: A Malaysian high school student was investigated, suspected of sedition, after he “liked” an “I Love Israel” Facebook page. Two bloggers were charged after creating and posting a Ramadan greeting with a photo of two people enjoying pork stew. And a student activist was sentenced to a year in prison for a public statement advocating an overthrow of the government.

headline: Oil Dispute Takes a Page From Congo’s Bloody Past
abstract: Virunga National Park in the Democratic Republic of Congo has become a battleground pitting economic development against environmentalism.
lead_paragraph: VIRUNGA NATIONAL PARK, Democratic Republic of Congo — The trouble started when a British company suddenly appeared in this iconic and spectacularly beautiful national park, prospecting for oil.

headline: Obama’s Immigration Plan Could Affect Millions
abstract: President Obama’s executive action plans may allow up to five million unauthorized immigrants to stay in the United States and obtain work permits.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s executive action plans may allow up to five million unauthorized immigrants to stay in the United States and obtain work permits.

headline: Giancarlo Stanton Is a Power Hitter Negotiating a Power Contract
abstract: Stanton, 25, may become the first player with a $300 million deal, as the Marlins are discussing an extension that could stretch for 13 years.
lead_paragraph: In many ways, Giancarlo Stanton is the perfect choice to have the richest contract in baseball history. He just turned 25, and he has a spotless image and ferocious power in an era of declining offense.

headline: Fresh Voices Must Be Heard
abstract: Young composers and young (and younger) performers are featured in three events this week.
lead_paragraph: Young composers and young (and younger) performers are featured in three events this week. The New York Philharmonic’s Contact! new-music series kicks off Monday with an evening of works by Missy Mazzoli, Timo Andres and Daniel Bjarnason (with Ingram Marshall a septuagenarian interloper), all brought together by the composer John Adams, who hosts. (7:30 p.m., SubCulture, 45 Bleecker Street, East Village; 212-875-5656, nyphil.org.) On Wednesday, the Juilliard School opens a three-performance run of Rossini’s ebullient rarity “Il Turco in Italia,” conducted by Speranza Scappucci and directed by John Giampietro. (8 p.m., Lincoln Center; juilliard.edu.) And on Thursday, the Brooklyn Youth Chorus gives the first of four performances of “Black Mountain Songs,” an evening-length staged program of works by Bryce Dessner, Richard Reed Parry, Caroline Shaw, Nico Muhly and others, based on the landmark midcentury collaborations at Black Mountain College in North Carolina. (7:30 p.m., Harvey Theater, Brooklyn Academy of Music, 651 Fulton Street, Fort Greene; 718-636-4100, bam.org.)

headline: Grace Helbig’s Digital Path to Fame
abstract: The Internet comic Grace Helbig belongs to a generation of YouTube stars who are making a good living reaching large fan bases without traditional media.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Grace Helbig sounds almost blasé about the prospect of becoming the female face of late-night television.

headline: Mother and Son, Weighing Coiffure
abstract: The title “Bad Hair” may suggest a slapstick comedy, but there’s nothing slapstick and not all that much comic about this subtle, striking film.
lead_paragraph: The title “Bad Hair” may suggest a slapstick comedy, but there’s nothing slapstick and not all that much comic about the subtle, striking film of that name that begins a two-week run at Film Forum on Wednesday. The movie, from Venezuela, is about a boy named Junior (Samuel Lange) who is obsessed with straightening his thick, curly hair for a school identification photo.

headline: Greeting an Album With Stark Sounds
abstract: The brutal, atonal, harrowing sounds made by Pharmakon belong to multiple traditions but sit comfortably in none of them.
lead_paragraph: The brutal, atonal, harrowing sounds made by Pharmakon belong to multiple traditions — industrial music, surely, along with musique concrète and maybe shock art — but sit comfortably in none of them. But then, sitting comfortably isn’t really something you associate with Pharmakon, the nom de noise of Margaret Chardiet, who lives in Brooklyn and has become an unmissable young firebrand in her field.

headline: Cézanne’s Muse, at Least on Canvas
abstract: Paul Cézanne’s second-most frequent portrait subject was his wife, Marie-Hortense Fiquet.
lead_paragraph: Of all the portraits that Paul Cézanne painted during his lifetime (1839-1906), his most frequent subject was himself. Second came his wife, Marie-Hortense Fiquet (1850-1922). The exhibition “Madame Cézanne,” opening Wednesday and running through March 15 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, will present 23 of the 29 images of her that Cézanne is known to have made. They don’t give much away. Far from idealized as a woman or a beloved mate, she usually appears stiffly reserved, a dignified enigma. In fact, not a lot is known about her. She was 19 and working as a part-time artist’s model when he, 11 years older, met her and started an affair that produced a child, Paul (1872-1947). Cézanne kept the relationship and the child a secret from his wealthy parents for fear of their disapproval but eventually married Hortense, in 1886. His letters to friends suggest that he regarded her as a shallow and irritating person. He excluded her from his will, leaving everything to their son. Yet he painted her repeatedly over more than 20 years. Go figure. (212-535-7710, metmuseum.org.)

headline: A Rich Heritage With a Club Pulse
abstract: Like people, dance companies have family trees.
lead_paragraph: Like people, dance companies have family trees. Artistically, Lester Horton begat Alvin Ailey, who begat Dwight Rhoden and Desmond Richardson. Mr. Rhoden and Mr. Richardson, both former principal dancers with the venerable Ailey company, founded Complexions Contemporary Ballet in 1994 to pursue their own vision of a multicultural dance that combined modern, ballet and jazz. In these ingredients, it bears the DNA of its heritage. But as a product of the 1990s, the Complexions aesthetic also internalized the sleek and sexy (and some say superficial) Era of the Supermodel, with the internal pulse of an all-night club.

headline: Standing Tall to Fight Poaching
abstract: In China, when Yao Ming speaks, people listen.
lead_paragraph: In China, when Yao Ming speaks, people listen. Trading on this former basketball superstar’s towering stature in his home country, WildAid has named Mr. Yao a spokesman on behalf of Africa’s severely threatened elephant and rhino populations to help curb China’s multi-billion-dollar lust for illegal wildlife products.

headline: Mishandling Rape
abstract: Colleges are seeing sexual assault where it doesn’t exist while letting dangerous men go free.
lead_paragraph: OUR strategy for dealing with rape on college campuses has failed abysmally. Female students are raped in appalling numbers, and their rapists almost invariably go free. Forced by the federal government, colleges have now gotten into the business of conducting rape trials, but they are not competent to handle this job. They are simultaneously failing to punish rapists adequately and branding students sexual assailants when no sexual assault occurred.

headline: After Beating Princeton, Yale Could Share Ivy Title
abstract: The Bulldogs’ offense led the way to a fifth straight win to mark the 100th anniversary of the Yale Bowl’s opening.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN — When the Yale Bowl opened, on a wintry November afternoon in 1914, its turf was covered with hay. The field was soggy; it had snowed the day before. But the first event was a cross-country meet, so it scarcely mattered. The runners raced out one tunnel and back in through the other.

headline: Head of Music-Video Source Will Step Down From Post
abstract: Rio Caraeff, who has led Vevo since its beginning in 2009, will depart at the end of the year.
lead_paragraph: The chief executive of Vevo, the online music-video platform that supplies some of the most popular material on YouTube, is leaving the company, according to a memo he sent to employees on Friday.

headline: Still Logging in Sweet Home
abstract: The timber industry of Southern Oregon has shrunk because of environmental protection, mechanization and consolidation, leaving once-prosperous towns like Sweet Home searching for the next step.
lead_paragraph: The timber industry of Southern Oregon has shrunk because of environmental protection, mechanization and consolidation, leaving once-prosperous towns like Sweet Home searching for the next step.

headline: Town That Thrived on Logging Is Looking for a Second Growth
abstract: In a town in Oregon that long relied on logging, the old jobs are long gone and the food bank has a more secure future than remaining industry.
lead_paragraph: SWEET HOME, Ore. — The great forest just east of town beckoned to Dan Rice when he was a young man, as it had to his father and grandfather before him, both proud loggers in a time that now survives mostly in black-and-white photos and in the talk of old men. He and his brothers kept the family log-trucking business going, he said, hauling to mills now mostly automated, partly in obligation to the legacy.

headline: Don’t Quit Your Day Job
abstract: Celebrities should not quit their day jobs, according to Andrew J. Ries.
lead_paragraph: Administrivial Deb-Amlen-in-New-York-City Fun Times Alert! Pencils up, New York! If you missed this weekend’s solving fun at The Ace Hotel, they have added two more dates — Dec. 14, 2014, and Jan. 18, 2015 — so put it on your calendar and come solve with me! The Ace Hotel is at 20 West 29th Street in New York, so if you are planning to be in the New York area during the holiday season, please stop by and hang out. Click here for more information.

headline: Familiar Ring of Triumph Since the Days of Truman
abstract: The Victory Bell, first sounded on campus by President Harry S. Truman in 1946, is rung by seniors, hoisted by underclassmen, after Rams victories.
lead_paragraph: Of all the tools of learning on Fordham’s Bronx campus, probably none are more rudimentary or more valuable in providing motivation than the Victory Bell. It sits in front of the 89-year-old Rose Hill Gymnasium, a stately reminder of the perils of war and the triumph that can be achieved in classrooms and on fields of play.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers respond to recent articles in the Sports section of The Times.
lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Obama’s Immigration Plan Could Grant Papers to Millions, at Least for Now
abstract: Executive actions that President Obama is expected to announce as early as this week could offer legal documents to as many as five million immigrants in the country illegally.
lead_paragraph: Changes to the immigration enforcement system that President Obama is expected to announce as early as this week could offer legal documents to as many as five million immigrants in the country illegally, nearly double the number who received protection from deportation under amnesty legislation in 1986.

headline: Kakha Bendukidze Dies at 58; Pushed Post-Soviet Market Change
abstract: Mr. Bendukidze, a biologist and later a wealthy businessman in the final years of the Soviet Union, became an architect of economic and governmental changes in his native Georgia.
lead_paragraph: Kakha Bendukidze, a biologist who became a wealthy businessman in the final years of the Soviet Union and, later, an architect of sweeping economic and governmental changes as a senior official in his native Georgia, died Thursday in London. He was 58.

headline: In Shift, Pakistanis Fleeing War Flow Into Beleaguered Afghanistan
abstract: Pakistani military’s continuing offensive against Islamist militants in the North Waziristan tribal region has forced an exodus of at least 1.5 million residents.
lead_paragraph: GULAN CAMP, Afghanistan — Through three decades of war, waves of Afghans have fled their homes along the eastern border areas, many of them seeking shelter in the Pakistani tribal regions next door.

headline: Fatal Encounter in Ferguson Took Less Than 90 Seconds, Police Communications Reveal
abstract: Newly released audio and video offer glimpses into the fatal run-in between Michael Brown, an unarmed black teenager, and a white police officer, Darren Wilson.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — Audio of police radio communications and video from surveillance cameras at the Ferguson Police Department offer new details from the day that Michael Brown, an unarmed black teenager, was shot dead by a white police officer in August.

headline: Iraq and U.S. Find Some Potential Sunni Allies Have Already Been Lost
