abstract: The United States and the Iraqi government want to enlist Sunni tribes to fight the Islamic State, but many of them have already been co-opted or conquered.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — When the militants of the Islamic State entered the Sunni Arab area of Al Alam, they gave its tribal leaders a message of reconciliation: We are here to defend you and all the Sunnis, they said, so join us.

headline: Public Charter Schools That Failed to Meet Texas Standards Are Still Operating
abstract: A district with seven campuses was told that they could no longer be called open-enrollment charter schools, but opened their doors anyway.
lead_paragraph: FARMERS BRANCH, Tex. — One recent morning, Branch Park Academy looked like any other bustling suburban middle school.

headline: In Texas, Beef Council Hopes to Rope In a Younger Crowd
abstract: The beef industry tries to attract he so-called millennial generation, who are less inclined to eat meat and more likely to encounter advertising on phones and computer screens.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN — It has been 22 years since the racing violins and xylophonic beats of the composer Aaron Copland’s “Hoe-Down” from his ballet “Rodeo” poured out of television sets, making “Beef. It’s What’s for Dinner” one of the most recognizable advertising campaigns of the early 1990s.

headline: Tours Take Border Guide Back to an Earlier Life
abstract: As she did on horseback decades ago, Mimi Webb Miller is again taking visitors on tours across the border in Texas, returning to a region of Mexico that, in a sense, still haunts her.
lead_paragraph: TERLINGUA, Tex. — Decades ago, Mimi Webb Miller ran horseback tours here, entertaining travelers with excursions across the boundary separating Presidio, Tex., from Ojinaga, Mexico, to one of Mexico’s most beautiful and least visited regions.

headline: Austin Lineup Changes as the Players Shift
abstract: The longevity of the departing crowd of Republicans has thrown off the natural rhythm of change in Austin, both inside and outside the Capitol.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN — After 14 years of one governor, 12 years each with the same lieutenant governor and attorney general and little turnover in other elected statewide offices, it seems downright strange to change officeholders and top aides in the state’s biggest agencies.

headline: The Clintons Look to the Past, for Now
abstract: In her first public event since the midterm elections, and before she announces whether she will run for president in 2016, Hillary Rodham Clinton took part in a carefully staged appearance with her daughter.
lead_paragraph: LITTLE ROCK, Ark. — Hillary Rodham Clinton’s in-between phase started here on Saturday, at a carefully staged appearance with her daughter and surrounded by old friends.

headline: Roger Federer Shows He Can Still Generate Sparks in the Twilight of His Career
abstract: Roger Federer, who defeated Stan Wawrinka on Saturday, will face Novak Djokovic on Sunday for the title in the ATP World Tour Finals.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — You would have been forgiven for thinking that Roger Federer had done it all at age 33, with 17 Grand Slam titles and 302 weeks at No. 1 already in the bank.

headline: Facing the Best, the Tide, as Usual, Are Better
abstract: The Bulldogs’ Dak Prescott threw a touchdown pass with 15 seconds remaining, but No. 4 Alabama held on to upend No. 1 Mississippi State.
lead_paragraph: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. — Nick Saban clutched the lectern with one hand and pulled his other hand down his face, clearly perturbed. He had been asked if Alabama practiced any harder during the week in preparation for the program’s latest biggest game, against No. 1 Mississippi State and its star quarterback, Dak Prescott.

headline: Parks Department Will Try to Reopen Lasker Rink at Central Park
abstract: The skating rink at the north end of Central Park had announced it was closing for repairs just weeks into the season.
lead_paragraph: A day after the skating rink at the north end of Central Park abruptly announced that it was closing for the season, the parks department said on Saturday that it would try to make repairs so that it could reopen at some point this winter.

headline: Four Workers Are Killed in Gas Leak at Texas Chemical Plant
abstract: At a DuPont chemical plant in La Porte, Tex., 20 miles east of Houston, four workers were killed early Saturday by the gas methyl mercaptan.
lead_paragraph: Four Texas workers died and a fifth was hospitalized Saturday morning after a hazardous gas leak at a DuPont chemical plant east of Houston.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Suzanne Vega Saturday (Personal)
abstract: Better than ever.
lead_paragraph: Notes:

headline: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, November 16, 2014
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, November 16, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “They’re coming up here not just to be against things, but to do things. I think it’s a very positive aspect of this class.”

headline: Georgia Dominates Auburn, but a Late Injury Dampens the Celebration
abstract: No. 16 Georgia’s punishing 34-7 victory over No. 9 Auburn kept alive its hopes of winning the East Division and advancing to the SEC championship game.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS, Ga. — It was all going so splendidly for No. 16 Georgia on Saturday night. The Bulldogs star running back Todd Gurley was shaking off rust from not playing for more than a month because of an N.C.A.A. suspension, and the Georgia defense was dominating the fast-paced spread offense of Auburn.

headline: The Complexities of Matrimony
abstract: The Korean artist Lee Bul’s landscape reflects the chaos and harmony of Jill Bialosky’s contemplation of the fraught nature of relationships.
lead_paragraph: The Korean artist Lee Bul’s landscape reflects the chaos and harmony of Jill Bialosky’s contemplation of the fraught nature of relationships.

headline: Famine or Feast?
abstract: Is it more rewarding to subsist on broth and cold mountain treks at a German clinic for 10 days or to settle into five-course Michelin-starred meals? One writer heads to the Black Forest to find out.
lead_paragraph: Is it more rewarding to subsist on broth and cold mountain treks at a German clinic for 10 days or to settle into five-course Michelin-starred meals? One writer heads to the Black Forest to weigh the merits of the purge and the binge.

headline: At Dior, Icing on the Cake
abstract: Sugary pastel eyeliner made from strips of satin conjures worlds of romance and solace.
lead_paragraph: Sugary pastel eyeliner made from strips of satin conjures worlds of romance and solace.

headline: Shira Lahav, Michael Gladstone
abstract: The wedding took place in Short Hills, N.J.
lead_paragraph: Shira Yaffa Lahav and Michael Hamilton Gladstone were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Mendel Solomon at the Hilton Short Hills in Short Hills, N.J.

headline: Lily Hayes Kaufman, Matthew Salzberg
abstract: The bride is the writer and director of a web series set to debut in January; the groom is the founder of an e-commerce company.
lead_paragraph: Lily Hayes Kaufman was married Saturday evening to Matthew Blake Salzberg at the Rainbow Room in Manhattan. Bryanne A. Hamill, who retired as a family court judge from the Kings County Family Court in Brooklyn, officiated.

headline: Francesca Perkins and Darryl Austin
abstract: The bride and groom are lawyers.
lead_paragraph: Francesca Jeanine Evelyn Perkins and Darryl Emanuel Austin were married Saturday in New Orleans. Jesse A. Watley, a Roman Catholic deacon, performed the ceremony at the Academy of the Sacred Heart Chapel.

headline: Jenna Segal, Jordan Zahn
abstract: The couple were married at the Four Seasons Hotel in Chicago.
lead_paragraph: Jenna Elyse Segal and Jordan Michael Zahn were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Carl Wolkin at the Four Seasons Hotel in Chicago.

lead_paragraph: Thomas Lorenzo O’Briant Jr. and David Harris Boul were married Saturday by Mayor Rahm Emanuel at City Hall in Chicago.

lead_paragraph: Zindziswa Lara McCormick, the daughter of Helena Pohlandt-McCormick and Michael T. McCormick of St. Paul, was married Saturday to Timothy Edward Drinan, a son of Martha K. Hirst of Manhattan and Robert K. Drinan of Brooklyn. Jeremiah Kittredge, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated at Dawn Ranch Lodge in Guerneville, Calif.

headline: Judy Harvey, Matthew Henjum
abstract: The bride is a lawyer in the environment and natural resources division of the Justice Department; the groom is a lawyer at a nonprofit group that seeks to protect Chesapeake Bay.
lead_paragraph: Judy Baker Harvey and Matthew Brian Henjum were married Saturday at the Eastern Market’s North Hall, a private and community events space, in Washington. The Rev. Louise Green, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated.

headline: Hannah Edman, Michael Bornmann
abstract: The couple were married at the Please Touch Museum in Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: Hannah Francine Edman and Michael Nicholas Bornmann were married Saturday evening by Cantor Ellie Shaffer at the Please Touch Museum in Philadelphia.

headline: Timothy Walther, Barry Stinson
abstract: They were wed at Brix Vineyard in Napa, Calif.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Timothy James Walther and Barry Lynn Stinson were married Monday at Brix Vineyard in Napa, Calif. The officiant was Lisa Lewis, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event.

abstract: The couple were married at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.
lead_paragraph: Katherine Alice Jollon and Michael James Colsher were married on Saturday at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York. The Rev. William J. Bergen, a Roman Catholic priest and the church’s associate pastor, performed the ceremony.

headline: Kathleen Brady, Alban Labauge
abstract: The couple were married at the Old Daley Inn on Crooked Lake in Averill Park, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: Kathleen Erin Brady and Alban Labauge were married Saturday at the Old Daley Inn on Crooked Lake in Averill Park, N.Y. Matthew Curran, a Universal Life minister and a friend of the couple, officiated.

headline: Michael Monroe, Adam McCollum
abstract: The ceremony took place at the Forbes Magazine Galleries in New York.
lead_paragraph: Michael John Monroe and Adam Rhea McCollum were married Saturday at the Forbes Galleries, a reception space within the publishing company’s office in New York. Mark Grischke, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

headline: Halli Zung, Joshua Silverman
abstract: The bride is a family physician; the groom is an assistant professor in the department of radiation oncology at N.Y.U.’s medical school.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Halli Greer Zung and Dr. Joshua Seth Silverman were married Saturday evening at the Woodbury Jewish Center in Woodbury, N.Y. Rabbi Raphael Adler officiated, with Cantor Uri Aqua taking part.

headline: Stephanie Dorman, Brett Gurwitz
abstract: The couple were married at the Oyster Point Hotel in Red Bank, N.J.
lead_paragraph: Stephanie Lynn Dorman and Brett Rudin Gurwitz were married on Saturday by Rabbi Alan Katz at the Oyster Point Hotel in Red Bank, N.J.

headline: Hadley Beier-Green and Zachary Rolf
abstract: The bride oversees the annual fund campaign at St. Bartholomew’s Church and the groom oversees an education program at the Central Synagogue, both in New York.
lead_paragraph: Hadley Beier-Green, the daughter of Carol A. Beier and Richard W. Green of Topeka, Kan., was married Saturday to Zachary Martin Rolf, a son of Shelley Silverman Rolf and Martin P. Rolf of Great Barrington, Mass. Rabbi Peter J. Rubinstein officiated at the home of the bride’s parents.

headline: Raine Katz and Michael Levoff
abstract: The bride is a marketing strategist in New York for Google; the groom is the vice president of corporate communications in New York for Genting Americas.
lead_paragraph: Raine Halley Katz, a daughter of Laura Jill Katz and Ira Marc Katz of Cranbury, N.J., was married Friday evening to Michael Francis Levoff, the son of Elaine Joyce Simon and the stepson of Neil Simon of New York. Libby Kelson-Fulcher, a Universal Life minister, officiated at the Four Seasons Resort Hualalai in Kailua-Kona, Hawaii.

headline: Rachel Lexier, Curtis Nagle
abstract: The bride works in public relations; the groom is a stock analyst.
lead_paragraph: Rachel Mauri Lexier, the daughter of IIlene Sue Altman and Richard M. Altman of Denver, was married Saturday to Curtis Smyser Nagle, the son of Susan N. Nagle and Frederick S. Nagle of Bedford, N.Y. Allison Dolan Hall, a Spiritual Humanist minister, officiated at the Union Club in Manhattan.

headline: Giselle Barcia and Daniel Schuker
abstract: Two Yale Law School graduates are married at the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Giselle Barcia, the daughter of Daniel R. Barcia of Miami and the late Maria I. Barcia, was married Saturday evening to Daniel Joseph Theodore Schuker, the son of Maria M. Tatar of Cambridge, Mass., and Stephen A. Schuker of Charlottesville, Va. Judge Jesse M. Furman of Federal District Court in New York officiated at the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington.

headline: Happenstance or Not, It Worked
abstract: Mr. Steinsdoerfer was introduced to Ms. Trudeau at a party. Little did he know, she had already seen his picture three days before.
lead_paragraph: Rachel Grandison Trudeau, the daughter of Jane Pauley and Garry Trudeau of New York, was married Saturday evening to Robert Gary Steinsdoerfer, a son of Mary Ann Steinsdoerfer and Gary R. Steinsdoerfer of Crystal Lake, Ill. The Rev. Erik Kolbell, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated at Gotham Hall, an event space in New York.

headline: Corrections: November 16, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on November 16, 2014.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: What’s On TV Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (HBO) THE NEWSROOM With Rebecca (Marcia Gay Harden) charged with defending the network against a lawsuit, Will (Jeff Daniels) tries to protect Neal (Dev Patel) in the aftermath of the Department of Defense leak. Charlie (Sam Waterston, above) and Leona (Jane Fonda) go up against the half-siblings (Kat Dennings and Chris Smith) of Reese (Chris Messina) in a hostile-takeover attempt. And Sloan (Olivia Munn) worries that Don (Thomas Sadoski) may be cashing in on insider information. In “The Comeback,” at 10, HBO asks Valerie (Lisa Kudrow) to bring back Jane (Laura Silverman), the producer who followed her around on “Room and Bored.” Valerie’s publicist, Billy (Dan Bucatinsky), meanwhile, gets her an appointment with the celebrity stylist Brad Goreski (as himself) for the Golden Globes.

headline: Obama Says Russia’s Arming of Separatists Breaks Pact With Ukraine
abstract: President Obama edged closer to describing Russia’s military incursions in Ukraine as an invasion and said Russians were supplying heavy arms to separatists in violation of an agreement Moscow signed.
lead_paragraph: BRISBANE, Australia — President Obama edged closer to describing Russia’s military incursions in Ukraine as an invasion, saying on Sunday that the Western campaign to isolate Moscow would continue, though additional sanctions were unnecessary for now.

headline: Kabul Attack Intended for Lawmaker Kills 3
abstract: The lawmaker who was apparently the target of the attack, Shukria Barakzai, is an outspoken legislator who has campaigned for women’s rights and has run underground schools for girls.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — A suicide bomber attacked an armored car carrying a prominent Afghan women’s rights leader and member of Parliament in Kabul on Sunday morning, killing three people and wounding 32 others, Afghan officials said.

headline: Obama Calls Islamic State’s Killing of Peter Kassig ‘Pure Evil’
abstract: President Obama called the execution of Mr. Kassig, a 26-year-old aid worker, “an act of pure evil” after it was revealed in a video on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: GAZIANTEP, Turkey — Islamic State militants released a chilling videotape on Sunday showing they had beheaded a fifth Western hostage, an American aid worker the group had threatened to kill in retaliation for airstrikes carried out by the United States in Iraq and Syria.

headline: Lessons in Living While Dying, From Pop
abstract: My kids have learned a new vocabulary, including words like lymphoma, chemotherapy, radiation, tumor and bone marrow. But they have also learned something important about being flexible, helping out, keeping a sense of humor and taking care of their elders.
lead_paragraph: We’ve been waiting for the results of Pop’s bone marrow biopsy all week. My children’s grandfather moved back in with us six weeks ago when he started having excruciating headaches. My husband, a physician, feared Pop’s cancer had returned. Visits to specialists, a tissue biopsy and a series of scans determined that it had, this time as a mass behind his left eye.

headline: The Daily Gift: Colorful, Customizable Book Sets
abstract: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.
lead_paragraph: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.

headline: 1889: Upheaval in Brazil
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: A revolution broke out in Brazil in 1889.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — News of the Revolution in Brazil was cabled here from London, and also cabled to Secretary Blaine by Consul-General Dockezy, at Rio Janeiro. Messrs. Charles R. Flint & Co., of this city, received the following cable from Rio Janeiro yesterday [Nov. 15]: — “A Revolution has broken out here. The Brazilian armies are in control. The Ministry has resigned. The Revolution is for the purpose of forming a Republic.” A coffee merchant in San Francisco is reported to have received a despatch from Rio to the effect that Dom Pedro has been deposed and that Brazil is now a Republic. An attempt was made to assassinate Baron de Landeris, Minister of Marine.

headline: Assembling the International Space Station
abstract: A look at the main stages of the International Space Station's construction.
lead_paragraph: A look at the main stages of the International Space Station's construction.

headline: Broward County Sheriff's Office Internal Affairs Report
abstract: The Sheriff's Office investigated deputies regarding possible favorable treatment of a suspect in a domestic violence arrest.
lead_paragraph: The Sheriff's Office investigated deputies regarding possible favorable treatment of a suspect in a domestic violence arrest.

headline: Nostalgia Helps ‘Dumb and Dumber To’ Top the Box Office
abstract: The aging nitwits of “Dumb and Dumber To” – a sequel 20 years in the making – defeated the “Big Hero 6” kids to win the weekend box office race.
lead_paragraph: The aging nitwits of “Dumb and Dumber To” – a sequel 20 years in the making – defeated the “Big Hero 6” kids to win the weekend box-office race. Costing roughly $40 million to make, “Dumb and Dumber To” (Universal Pictures) took in an estimated $38.1 million at North American theaters, according to Rentrak, which compiles ticketing data.

headline: Puerto Ricans Once Found Solace in Churches, but the Pews Are Now Empty
abstract: As church attendance wanes, Roman Catholics are reminded of the contributions made by Puerto Ricans in the 1950s.
lead_paragraph: The hum of prayers being said in Spanish echoed inside the cool, softly lighted sanctuary of St. Brigid Roman Catholic Church in the East Village, where about a dozen people clutching rosary beads encircled the statue of Our Lady of Divine Providence.

headline: Vast Space and Art to Fill It
abstract: The Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art is set to announce on Monday that it will forge long-term partnerships with big names in contemporary art.
lead_paragraph: Taking another leap in its evolution from a disused 19th-century factory complex into a 21st-century center for visual and performing arts, the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art is set to announce on Monday that it has forged six new 15- to 25-year partnerships with big names in contemporary art, including James Turrell; the Robert Rauschenberg Foundation; the Easton Foundation, which controls the estate of the sculptor Louise Bourgeois; Laurie Anderson; and Jenny Holzer.

headline: Routine Trip Turns Fatal as a Man Is Pushed in Front of a Subway Train
abstract: The assailant who pushed a 61-year-old man to his death at a Bronx station was still at large, the police said.
lead_paragraph: Far from the city’s major Chinese enclaves, a couple left their Bronx apartment on Sunday headed to Chinatown for breakfast on a crisp fall morning. A few blocks to the D train. A short wait on the platform.

headline: U.S. Intelligence Chief Describes Mission to Free Detainees in North Korea
abstract: James R. Clapper Jr. said the North was disappointed he had not come bearing a “breakthrough” in relations, and he had not been certain Kenneth Bae and Matthew Todd Miller would be freed until hours before they left North Korea.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The director of national intelligence, James R. Clapper Jr., described on Sunday his secret mission to seek the release of two Americans held in North Korea as a series of grim encounters with officials who expressed disappointment that he had not come bearing a “breakthrough” in relations.

headline: Lawyer Defends Cosby Over Assault Claims
abstract: In a statement on Sunday, the lawyer dismissed assertions against Mr. Cosby as both old and previously discredited.
lead_paragraph: In response to accusations of sexual assault against Bill Cosby, his lawyer released a statement Sunday, dismissing the assertions as both old and previously discredited and promising that no one representing Mr. Cosby would comment further on them.

headline: Whisked Out of Jail, and Back to the N.F.L.
abstract: A domestic abuse case involving Phillip Merling, a former Miami Dolphin, provides an example of lenient treatment of players by law enforcement agencies whose employees work off-duty jobs for football teams.
lead_paragraph: Even after sheriff’s deputies arrived at her Weston, Fla., home, Kristen Lennon remained in the bathroom, afraid to leave. Minutes earlier, she had fled there for safety as she called 911, telling the operator that her fiancé had thrown her on the bed and hit her in the face and head. She was two months pregnant.

headline: Japan Through the Looking Glass
abstract: A credibility loss to hope for.
lead_paragraph: There are indications that Shinzo Abe may indeed do the right thing and postpone the planned rise in Japan’s consumption tax. Let’s hope so. But many people are still treating this as an agonizing choice. For example, Gavyn Davies frames it as a choice between recovery and fiscal sustainability, although he sort of acknowledges that this may be a false dilemma.

headline: Roger Federer Withdraws Before Year-End Final With Novak Djokovic
abstract: Roger Federer said a back injury sustained late in his semifinal victory Saturday had left him unfit to play.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It was an anticlimactic year-end tournament, with no sign on court of the injured Rafael Nadal and an unfortunate surplus of lopsided matches and disgruntled fans.

headline: 1914: Fearing Espionage, Officials in London Search Travelers’ Luggage
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: To guard against German spies, government officials in London began questioning travelers and examining their belongings.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — New and rigorous measures to guard against German spies masquerading in the rôle of Continental tourists were put into operation yesterday [Nov. 15], and provided interest and excitement for travellers leaving Victoria station for cross-Channel ports. Not a single passenger on the early morning three o’clock train for Flushing escaped the close scrutiny of Government officials and Scotland Yard detectives. Mr. Basil Miles, with despatches from the American Embassy for Berlin, and Mr. Jarvis Bell, who left for Rotterdam, were among the few permitted to pass without questioning or without an examination of baggage.

headline: Allergan Nears a Deal With Actavis to Block a Takeover by Valeant
abstract: At $62.5 billion, a deal between the drug makers Actavis and Allergan would be one of the biggest mergers of the year.
lead_paragraph: After months of fending off unwanted takeover advances from Valeant Pharmaceuticals International, Allergan, the maker of Botox, is close to completing its strongest defensive move yet: selling itself to another bidder.

headline: Dutch Investigators Collect Debris From Malaysian Plane Downed Over Ukraine
abstract: The wreckage from the Malaysia Airlines jet that was shot down will be sent to the Netherlands, where officials will study it as part of the investigation.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Investigators on Sunday began winching large pieces of wreckage from the Malaysia Airlines passenger jet shot down over Ukraine last summer onto trucks to transport them back to the Netherlands, the Dutch Safety Board announced in The Hague.

headline: AIDS Group Wages Lonely Fight Against Pill to Prevent H.I.V.
abstract: A growing consensus in favor of Truvada is opposed by one vocal man, Michael Weinstein, and his nonprofit organization.
lead_paragraph: News articles often describe Truvada, the daily medication that has been shown to greatly reduce the risk of contracting H.I.V., as controversial. But they tend to cite one specific Truvada opponent: Michael Weinstein, the outspoken president of the Los Angeles-based AIDS Healthcare Foundation.

headline: Parachuting Into a Garret, and Feeling Right at Home
abstract: The rising soprano Sonya Yoncheva stepped into the role of Mimì in “La Bohème” at the Metropolitan Opera.
lead_paragraph: In the third act of Puccini’s “La Bohème,” Mimì, the tubercular seamstress, says goodbye. “Addio,” she tells Rodolfo, her poet lover, at the end of the aria “Donde lieta usci,” and then repeats it for emphasis: “Addio, senza rancor.”

headline: Florida Fires Will Muschamp With Two Games to Play
abstract: Under Muschamp, who will remain in the position for the two remaining games, the Gators have a 5-4 record this season and finished 4-8 last season.
lead_paragraph: Will Muschamp, who has compiled a 27-20 record in four seasons as Florida’s football coach, was fired Sunday, though he will remain at the helm for the team’s last two regular-season games, against Eastern Kentucky and No. 1 Florida State.

headline: You Seem Sad, Janacek. Cheer Me Up, Schubert.
abstract: The pianist Jeremy Denk played Schubert, Janacek, Haydn, Mozart and Schumann at his recital at the 92nd Street Y.
lead_paragraph: “Oh, there are loads of rules,” Nick Hornby wrote of mixtapes in the novel “High Fidelity.” Jeremy Denk predictably broke them all in a series of piano works by Janacek and Schubert in his very satisfying recital at the 92nd Street Y on Saturday.

headline: Rolling With Changes, the Knicks Get a Win
abstract: Carmelo Anthony and J. R. Smith scored 28 points each as the Knicks ended a seven-game losing streak against the hapless Nuggets.
lead_paragraph: In their quest to include the mercurial J. R. Smith as a functional component of their offense, the Knicks’ coaches have continued to press him: to take extra shots at practice, to watch more game film, to listen to every morsel of instruction they provide.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
abstract: Account assignments, miscellaneous news from advertising agencies and more.
lead_paragraph: Accounts

headline: Showcase to Earn Their Spurs
abstract: ABT Studio Company, the training troupe for American Ballet Theater, ranged from Petipa to Merce Cunningham at the 92ns Street Y.
lead_paragraph: Ballets are strange, delicate worlds within worlds. Certain dances shatter to pieces if they’re not interpreted by veterans who know how to penetrate a role from the inside out; others flourish with students in early bloom. The dancers of ABT Studio Company fall, delightfully, somewhere in between.

headline: A Portfolio With Room for Partying
abstract: In NBC’s “State of Affairs,” Katherine Heigl plays a national security adviser whose slain fiancé was the son of the president.
lead_paragraph: Three major broadcast networks now have a series about a high-powered woman in the administration — or near it, since Olivia Pope, the heroine of “Scandal,” is in and out of the Oval Office as the president’s off-and-on mistress and consultant.

headline: A Player Worth Remembering
abstract: The New York City bridge community lost one of its most popular members, Kathy Anday-Fallenius, on Nov. 9.
lead_paragraph: The New York City bridge community lost one of its most popular members, Kathy Anday-Fallenius, on Nov. 9.

headline: Ignobly Fading Away From the Rolling Stones
abstract: Brian Jones, founder of the Rolling Stones but largely airbrushed from that band’s history, is now the subject of a biography by Paul Trynka.
lead_paragraph: Brian Jones is to the Rolling Stones what Leon Trotsky was to the Russian Revolution: organizer, ideologist and victim of a power struggle. Jones founded the group, gave it its name and recruited the schoolboys Mick Jagger and Keith Richards, who then marginalized him, eventually expelling him from the band. Since his death in 1969, a month after he was forced out, Jones has largely been airbrushed from the group’s history.

headline: ‘Gone Girl’ Wins Big at Hollywood Awards
abstract: The mystery-thriller took home the top prize at the 2014 Hollywood Film Awards on Friday night in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: The mystery-thriller “Gone Girl” took home the top prize at the 2014 Hollywood Film Awards on Friday night in Los Angeles. But while an array of Hollywood A-listers, including Angelina Jolie, Ben Affleck and Johnny Depp, showed up for the event’s first televised ceremony, audiences at home did not. The program, which was hosted by Queen Latifah and carried by CBS, attracted about four million viewers at its peak, according to the website TVbythenumbers.com. The previous Friday, the network’s usual lineup (“The Amazing Race,” “Hawaii 5-0” and “Blue Bloods”) peaked at 11.4 million. Now in its 18th year, the Hollywood Film Awards are selected by an anonymous panel of industry insiders and executives and honor movies released or scheduled for release in the calendar year. “The Imitation Game,” which has a Nov. 28 release date, was one of the evening’s most lauded films, with acting honors for Benedict Cumberbatch and Keira Knightley and a directing prize for Morten Tyldum. The cast of “Foxcatcher” won best ensemble.

headline: In India, Growth Breeds Waste
abstract: Indians are getting dirtier as they get richer, but cleaning up is still someone else's job.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, INDIA — There is, we are told, a small island of plastic in the middle of the Pacific Ocean. There was, we are told, a fatberg plucked out of the sewers of London. But nowhere in the world is dirt as visible as in India. It is so visible that for many Indians who return from America, even from New York, it isn’t the Grand Canyon or the Met they remember. It’s how clean the streets were.

headline: Games Let You Become Your Own Worst Enemy
abstract: In two new video games in the Assassin’s Creed series, you have the task (and pleasure) of fighting against your former comrades.
lead_paragraph: Know your enemy by playing as your enemy. Video games have toyed with that idea for many years, and a new interactive historical epic called Assassin’s Creed Rogue tries it once again.

headline: In Ferguson, Tactics Set for Grand Jury Decision in Michael Brown Case
abstract: As a grand jury prepares to decide whether to indict Darren Wilson, a police officer, in the killing of Michael Brown, organizations are planning ways to react.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — Several dozen people gathered in a dim church basement here on Thursday night to share plans for what to do if a grand jury chooses not to indict the white police officer who shot Michael Brown, an unarmed black youth, three months ago. Among their ideas was to descend in large numbers on the nearby county seat of Clayton at 7 a.m. on the day after the grand jury’s announcement to snarl business.

headline: By Turns Restrained and Rowdy, in a Playful Revolutionary Tale
abstract: Performing for the first time in the United States, the Mikhailovsky Ballet presented “The Flames of Paris” at the David H. Koch Theater.
lead_paragraph: The Mikhailovsky Ballet of St. Petersburg, currently on its first visit to the United States, is an intriguing amalgamation. Though its history dates back to the 1930s, its rise to international stature is recent. In 2007, the Russian tycoon Vladimir Kekhman took over as general director, infusing the institution with funds that have allowed it to poach ballet masters and star dancers from its better-known — and stylistically opposed — Russian rivals, the Mariinsky and the Bolshoi.

headline: Solange Knowles Marries Alan Ferguson
abstract: Solange Knowles, the younger sister of Beyoncé Knowles, was married Sunday afternoon to Alan Ferguson, near the bride’s home in New Orleans.
lead_paragraph: Solange Piaget Knowles and Alan Gerard Ferguson were married Sunday afternoon near the bride’s home in the Faubourg Marigny district in New Orleans. The ceremony took place at the Marigny Opera House, a nondenominational church supported by the Marigny Opera House Foundation.

headline: A Show, Evolving, Makes a Point of Remaining Timeless
abstract: The “Radio City Christmas Spectacular” returns with familiar songs and some modern touches.
lead_paragraph: Radio City Music Hall hasn’t changed. Its cavernous red-and-gold Art Deco auditorium (né 1932) is as grand as ever in this year’s “Radio City Christmas Spectacular,” with two Wurlitzer organs booming holiday music. The Rockettes, a company that has been part of the Christmas show since 1933, will charm your socks off. If you’ve seen them do the “Wooden Soldiers” number only on television at the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade lately, let me be the first to remind you: It is so much more fabulous in person.

headline: Reforms in Myanmar
abstract: Stuck in the delivery room.
lead_paragraph: Stuck in the delivery room.

headline: Treasury Auctions for the Week of Nov. 17
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: And Now, a Movie Hours in the Making!
abstract: “Constit2tion,” a movie by committee conceived, written and shot in just over 24 hours, screened to a packed house early Sunday at the Upright Citizens Brigade Theater.
lead_paragraph: In the wee hours of Sunday morning, a packed house at the Upright Citizens Brigade Theater in Chelsea watched the premiere of a new film: “Constit2tion.” It was warmly — nay, raucously — received, with whooping and hollering throughout, but it is a very safe bet that “Constit2tion” will not win any Oscars. It will not bring home a Golden Globe. Even an Independent Spirit award seems well out of reach.

headline: Still Fading, Giants Fail to Exploit 49ers’ Slips
abstract: Everything was set up for the Giants to break their four-game losing streak, but even with all the help they were getting from the 49ers they could not avoid their own costly errors.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The San Francisco 49ers fumbled four times Sunday. They failed to recover a Giants onside kickoff. They botched a field-goal attempt with a bad snap. The 49ers were all but giving away the game.

headline: Conditioned to Destroy, but Then a Softening
abstract: In “Kill Dil,” set in India, a woman steps into the lives of two men raised to be killers.
lead_paragraph: Like most Bollywood movies, “Kill Dil” is a cocktail of familiar ingredients. Here, the mix is one part outlaw buddy film with one part romance, served with songs and twists.

headline: Privacy Concerns for ClassDojo and Other Tracking Apps for Schoolchildren
abstract: Many teachers say the ClassDojo app helps them record classroom conduct, but critics are wary of such apps’ ramifications for data privacy and fairness.
lead_paragraph: HUNTER, N.Y. — For better or for worse, the third graders in Greg Fletcher’s class at Hunter Elementary School always know where they stand.

headline: Part of a Table Setting
abstract: Tom McCoy lets us in on a little secret about his theme.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — This is the kind of theme that sneaks up on you but, coming from Tom McCoy, I’m not surprised. It took me a while to peel away all the layers hidden in his colorful puzzle from Nov. 9, and it wasn’t until I literally got to the bottom of today’s puzzle that I realized what all of the people of note in the theme entries had in common.

headline: Sirius XM Has Setback in Lawsuit
abstract: Judge Colleen McMahon of United States District Court in Manhattan said the 1960s band the Turtles had rights to its recordings under New York State law.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in New York has ruled against Sirius XM over an obscure copyright issue that has galvanized the music industry: royalties for recordings made before 1972.

headline: John Oliver’s Complicated Fun Connects for HBO
abstract: Mr. Oliver’s show, “Last Week Tonight,” is counterintuitive to the prevailing conventions of television, but has been a smash hit.
lead_paragraph: Every once in a while, it’s nice to be wrong about something.

headline: To Reconnect With Consumers, Revlon Looks for Love
abstract: The beauty brand will unveil a new theme, “Love is on,” on Tuesday as it seeks to burnish its slipping reputation in the industry.
lead_paragraph: LOVE is, according to the muses, a many splendored thing, strange, an open door, for the very young, a simple thing, the answer, the drug and in the air. And according to a new campaign for a beauty marketer seeking to burnish its mainstay brand, love is also on.

headline: Unilever, Suing Over Rival’s Use of ‘Mayo,’ Changes Own Website
abstract: The maker of Hellman’s products added the word “dressing” to comments from consumers on Hellman’s website that referred to Hellman’s mayonnaise dressing with olive oil as simply “mayonnaise.”
lead_paragraph: Last Friday, changes suddenly began appearing on websites associated with mayonnaise.

headline: Okinawa Voters Replace Governor With Opponent of U.S. Base
abstract: Takeshi Onaga, a former mayor of the capital, unseated Hirokazu Nakaima, who had agreed to move a Marine airfield but keep it on the island.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Dealing a new blow to plans by Japan and the United States to relocate a busy Marine air base on Okinawa, the island’s voters handed a landslide victory on Sunday to an anti-base candidate for governor, rejecting the Tokyo-backed incumbent.

headline: Fighting Female Genital Mutilation
abstract: In Egypt, a shocking 91 percent of women have been cut.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — I AM a 47-year-old Egyptian woman. And I am among the fortunate few of my countrywomen whose genitals have not been cut in the name of “purity” and the control of our sexuality.

headline: Stricter British Pay Rules Should Apply to More Bankers, Lawmakers Say
abstract: A new report recommends changes that aim to improve accountability and better protect retail accounts from riskier investment banking activities.
lead_paragraph: More bankers should fall under tough new proposed pay rules in Britain, some British lawmakers say.

headline: Lost in Rawlsland
abstract: We have the absurd situation of a huge philosophical literature on social justice in which racial injustice is barely mentioned.
lead_paragraph: This is the second in a series of interviews with philosophers on race that I am conducting for The Stone. This week’s conversation is with Charles Mills, the John Evans Professor of Moral and Intellectual Philosophy at Northwestern University and the author of several books, including the influential 1997 work “The Racial Contract.” — George Yancy

headline: When ‘Mom’ Becomes Her Identity
abstract: Readers react to an essay in which the writer objects to total strangers calling her “Mom” and viewing her through that lens.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Dingo’s Got My Baby’: Trial by Media
abstract: In 1982, an Australian mother was convicted of murdering her baby daughter. She was later exonerated, but soon fell victim to a joke that distracted the world from the real story.
lead_paragraph: In 1982, an Australian mother was convicted of murdering her baby daughter. She was later exonerated, but soon fell victim to a joke that distracted the world from the real story.

headline: Kickstarter Campaign Focuses on Public Radio
abstract: An appeal from the public media company PRX to fund its podcast network Radiotopia comes as new attention is being focused on podcasts.
lead_paragraph: A Kickstarter campaign offering backers the opportunity to participate in “remaking public radio” through podcasts raised $620,412 by the time it ended Friday, making it the most-funded radio or podcast project on the crowdfunding site.

headline: Defying Expectations, Japan’s Economy Falls Into Recession
abstract: The country’s gross domestic product shrank by an annualized pace of 1.6 percent in the most recent quarter, threatening a planned tax increase.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japan’s economy unexpectedly fell into recession in the third quarter, a painful slump that called into question efforts by Prime Minister Shinzo Abe to pull the country out of nearly two decades of deflation.

headline: Vindication at Last for a Woman Scorned by Australia’s News Outlets
abstract: Lindy Chamberlain of Australia said that a dingo had entered a tent where her baby lay, and made off with her, but it took 30 years for her to get vindication and closure.
lead_paragraph: To American ears, the word can seem odd, even comical: dingo. Sounds a lot like “dingbat.” Wasn’t that what Archie Bunker called his wife, Edith, on “All in the Family”?

headline: State Department Targeted by Hackers in 4th Agency Computer Breach
abstract: The agency was forced to temporarily shut down its unclassified email and public websites after the attack on its computer systems.
lead_paragraph: The State Department on Sunday became the fourth government agency to announce a breach of its computer systems in recent weeks, after an infiltration forced the agency to temporarily shut down its unclassified email system and public websites.

headline: Chinese Investors Back Horror Film That May Never Debut in China
abstract: Several Chinese investors are funding a horror film called “Abattoir” that may not be approved by strict film censors in their home country.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — For better or worse, a small group of Chinese movie investors over the last few weeks crossed one of the last cultural barriers to full membership in the Hollywood club: They backed a bloody horror flick.

headline: In Colorado, Calls to Change a Restaurant’s Name From ‘Illegal Pete’s’
abstract: The national debate over the use of the term “illegal immigrant” has fixed on an unlikely lightning rod: the liberal-minded, pro-immigrant owner of a Mexican restaurant chain in Colorado.
lead_paragraph: FORT COLLINS, Colo. — The national debate over the use of the term “illegal immigrant,” which has become anathema to people who support relaxed immigration rules, has fixed on an unlikely lightning rod: the liberal-minded, pro-immigrant owner of a Mexican restaurant chain.

headline: Some Hiccups, but Federal Health Exchange Website Is in Good Health
abstract: The Obama administration said Sunday that 100,000 people had submitted applications for health insurance on the first day of open enrollment, although some returning customers had trouble remembering their usernames and passwords.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration said Sunday that 100,000 people had submitted applications for health insurance on the first day of open enrollment, and it offered practical advice to consumers who had been locked out of their accounts.

headline: Public Grieving for Pop Singer Is Startling for Iran
abstract: Iranian authorities were caught off guard over the weekend when thousands of people joined spontaneous gatherings around the country to mourn and remember a pop singer who died of cancer at age 30.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Iranian authorities were caught off guard over the weekend when thousands of people joined spontaneous gatherings around the country to mourn and remember a pop singer who died late last week.

headline: Vice Hires Alyssa Mastromonaco, Former Official in Obama White House, as a Top Executive
abstract: Alyssa Mastromonaco, who left the White House as deputy chief of staff for operations this year, will become Vice’s chief operating officer.
lead_paragraph: Vice Media, the news and entertainment group, is expected to announce Monday that it has hired Alyssa Mastromonaco, a former Obama administration official, as its chief operating officer.

headline: Marshall Project Kicks Off With Look at Legal Delays
abstract: The nonprofit led by Bill Keller, a former executive editor of The New York Times, is focusing on the criminal justice system.
lead_paragraph: The Marshall Project, a nonprofit news organization focused on the American criminal justice system and led by Bill Keller, a former executive editor of The New York Times, went live this weekend, the latest in a crop of start-ups seeking a place in an increasingly fragmented journalism landscape.

headline: Thyroid Cancer: Decisions About Tests and Treatment
abstract: A patient and a doctor discuss the medical odds and options.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Classroom Breakfasts?
abstract: Irene Bernstein Pechmèze, a reader, takes issue with an editorial supporting the idea.

headline: How Wages Can Rise
abstract: Rosalind S. Paaswell, a reader, writes that adding unions to the mix will change the dismal picture.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Gains in the ‘Sharing Economy’
abstract: Michael Petricone of the Consumer Electronics Association responds to an editorial.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Palestinian Shot by Israeli Troops at Gaza Border
abstract: A spokeswoman for the Israeli hospital where the wounded Palestinian was taken for treatment said he was a 10-year-old boy.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israeli forces patrolling the border with the Gaza Strip shot and wounded a Palestinian as he approached the border fence on Sunday and took him to an Israeli hospital, according to the military. A spokeswoman for the hospital said the Palestinian was a 10-year-old boy.

headline: Retailers’ Earnings, Fed Minutes and a Panel on Wall St.
abstract: Home Depot, Target and Lowe’s will report their third-quarter results this week, offering a hint at consumers’ outlooks; and the Fed will release minutes from its last meeting.
lead_paragraph: RETAILERS’ RESULTS TO OFFER MORE CLUES ON SPENDING

headline: Agencies Look for Cause of Fatal Gas Leak in Texas
abstract: The Environmental Protection Agency, the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality and the Chemical Safety Board were investigating at a DuPont plant in La Porte, Tex., where four workers died.
lead_paragraph: LA PORTE, Tex. — One day after a leak of toxic gas killed four workers at a DuPont chemical plant here, federal and state agencies were assembling to investigate the accident and response.

headline: Inequality, Unbelievably, Gets Worse
abstract: Have we become inured to the struggles of the working class?
lead_paragraph: THE Democrats’ drubbing in the midterm elections was unfortunate on many levels, but particularly because the prospect of addressing income inequality grows dimmer, even as the problem worsens.

headline: Eike Batista’s Insider Trading Case in Brazil to Test a Much-Criticized Justice System
abstract: Many in the nation will be closely following the case of Eike Batista, once one of Brazil’s richest men, to see if the system can shed its reputation for leniency on white-collar crime.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil – When it comes to insider trading in the United States, government officials have built careers on successful prosecutions. Hedge funds have been shut down, and regulators have ensnared even low-level employees who traded on confidential tips.

headline: Families Can Crumble Under Deportation Threat
abstract: To hear Sara Martinez’s story is to encounter precisely the kind of ordeal that President Obama aims to alleviate with sweeping executive actions on immigration.
lead_paragraph: Sara Martinez never wanted her two daughters to grow up poor and anxious about life, the way she had in Ecuador. But that is what happened.

headline: Adrian Peterson’s Path to Reinstatement Is Bogged Down in N.F.L.'s Complex Process
abstract: Peterson, the Vikings running back suspended during a child abuse investigation, skipped a disciplinary hearing on Friday and had an arbitration hearing scheduled Monday.
lead_paragraph: When the N.F.L. put Minnesota Vikings running back Adrian Peterson on the commissioner’s exempt list, it solved one problem but created another. After Peterson was arrested in September on suspicion of hitting his 4-year-old son with a stick, the Vikings benched him for one game, reinstated him and then benched him again after an uproar from fans and sponsors.

headline: In Public Land Sale, Not All of Spain Is Buying
abstract: There has been a rise in proposed land deals that politicians hope will fill treasuries and that critics see as a possible repeat of a real estate bubble that led to an economic crisis.
lead_paragraph: CASTELLAR DE LA FRONTERA, Spain — La Almoraima, a farming estate at the edge of a nature reserve, is prized by environmentalists. Home to one of Europe’s largest cork forests, it is a rare place where deer and boar roam wild within sight of the Rock of Gibraltar.

headline: Absent a Cause, Kevin Ollie Leads a UConn Team Motivated by Desire
abstract: For Ollie and his young Huskies team, it will be business as usual as they set out to retain their N.C.A.A. title.
lead_paragraph: The Kevin Ollie story keeps getting better.

headline: Favorite Concedes Presidency in Romania
abstract: Prime Minister Victor Ponta conceded Romania’s presidential runoff election late Sunday night to the center-right candidate, Klaus Iohannis, the mayor of the Transylvanian city of Sibiu.
lead_paragraph: BUCHAREST, Romania — In a surprising turnaround, Prime Minister Victor Ponta conceded Romania’s presidential runoff election late Sunday night to the center-right candidate, Klaus Iohannis, the mayor of the Transylvanian city of Sibiu.

headline: In New Napoleonic Era, His Hats and Stockings Rise to Power
abstract: The prices of the emperor’s belongings have risen relentlessly, including a hat that sold for about $2.4 million at a Paris auction, making it difficult for French museums to compete.
lead_paragraph: FONTAINEBLEAU, France — Surveying the glittering collection of Napoleonic objects laid out in an auction hall near Paris, Bruno Ledoux said he had a good reason for his interest in a set of baby clothes belonging to Napoleon Bonaparte’s son.

headline: Indictment of Ex-Official Raises Questions on Mississippi’s Private Prisons
abstract: The state’s longest-serving corrections commissioner, Christopher B. Epps, faces charges that he pocketed more than $1 million while clearing the way for the private-sector prisons.
lead_paragraph: JACKSON, Miss. — In 1982, Christopher B. Epps, a young schoolteacher, took a second job as a guard at the facility known as Parchman Farm, the only prison operated at the time by the Mississippi Department of Corrections.

headline: Flower Man of Harlem Recaptures His Corner
abstract: Five months after forcing Sonny Gibbs from his spot on the edge of a Harlem playground because he did not have a vending permit, New York City has welcomed him back.
lead_paragraph: Sonny Gibbs is back on his corner.

headline: Federal Investigation Into Painkillers Targets N.F.L. Teams’ Medical Staffs
abstract: Called administrative in nature, the investigation was seeking to verify that properly licensed personnel were the only ones distributing the medications to players.
lead_paragraph: Federal drug enforcement agents questioned medical-staff members from the San Francisco 49ers and several other teams on Sunday as part of a continuing investigation into the distribution of painkillers in the N.F.L.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 16, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Fear of Ebola Opens Wary Villages to Outsiders in Guinea
abstract: In Guinea’s Forest Region, villages that have refused outside help to fight the Ebola outbreak are starting to soften their resistance.
lead_paragraph: DANDANO, Guinea — “Bring out your sick!” the chief shouted angrily at the crowd, shaking his fist and warning of illness and death for the whole village if it did not obey.

headline: Times Square’s Biggest and Most Expensive Digital Billboard Is Set to Shine
abstract: The new screen is eight stories tall and nearly as long as a football field, spanning the entire block from 45th Street to 46th Street on Broadway.
lead_paragraph: In an era when digital screens large and small proliferate but attention is increasingly scarce, some marketers are making a huge bet that one of the biggest displays in the world will captivate audiences.

headline: Second Chances for Teen Offenders
abstract: Limiting access to juvenile records is crucial to preventing young people from being permanently impaired by outgrown transgressions.
lead_paragraph: The first juvenile courts were established more than a century ago on the principle that children deserve special care under the law because they are vulnerable, because their transgressions tend to be nonviolent and because they can be expected, on the whole, to outgrow their youthful misbehavior.

headline: Deadline Extended for G.M. Accident Claims
abstract: The administrator of a G.M. fund to compensate victims of accidents caused by a flawed ignition switch has extended the deadline for claims to Jan. 31.
lead_paragraph: The families of people killed or injured in crashes involving General Motors cars that had a deadly ignition switch defect will have an extra month to submit claims for payment under G.M.’s victim compensation program.

headline: Playing Politics With Tar Sands Oil
abstract: The Keystone XL pipeline should not be rushed through by lawmakers more worried about their political futures than the nation’s well-being.
lead_paragraph: Just when President Obama marches forward on the issue of climate change, Congress scuttles backward.

headline: Kevin Harvick Outduels Ryan Newman for Sprint Cup Title
abstract: Harvick capped his first season driving for Stewart-Haas Racing with his first Nascar Sprint Cup championship.
lead_paragraph: HOMESTEAD, Fla. — Kevin Harvick captured his first Nascar Sprint Cup championship in thrilling fashion by edging Ryan Newman to win the Ford EcoBoost 400 on Sunday.

headline: In Death, Girl, 2, Is Caught in Fight Over Organs
abstract: Thaiya Spruill-Smith is technically dead but hooked up to machines because her mother wants her organs to help others, while her father says that would be a desecration.
lead_paragraph: For more than two days, the 2-year-old girl has remained in a Brooklyn hospital bed, technically dead but hooked up to machines keeping her organs alive for other children.

headline: A Cuban Brain Drain, Courtesy of the U.S.
abstract: It is hypocritical for Washington to praise Cuba’s efforts in fighting Ebola while inviting Cuban doctors working abroad to defect.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State John Kerry and the American ambassador to the United Nations, Samantha Power, have praised the work of Cuban doctors dispatched to treat Ebola patients in West Africa. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recently sent an official to a regional meeting the Cuban government convened in Havana to coordinate efforts to fight the disease. In Africa, Cuban doctors are working in American-built facilities. The epidemic has had the unexpected effect of injecting common sense into an unnecessarily poisonous relationship.

headline: La fuga de cerebros en Cuba, cortesía de EE.UU.
abstract: Invitar a médicos cubanos en el exterior a defeccionar muestra hipocresía, dado que Washington aplaude su labor combatiendo el ébola.
lead_paragraph: El Secretario de Estado John Kerry y la embajadora estadounidense ante Naciones Unidas, Samantha Power, han elogiado la contribución de médicos cubanos que atienden a pacientes con ébola en África occidental. Los Centros para el Control y la Prevención de Enfermedades, una agencia federal norteamericana, recientemente envió a un funcionario a una reunión regional organizada por el Gobierno cubano en La Habana, para coordinar la lucha contra la epidemia. En África, los médicos cubanos están laborando en instalaciones construidas por Estados Unidos. El virus ha tenido el inesperado efecto de inyectarle sentido común a una relación innecesariamente tóxica.

headline: Iran Nuclear Pact Faces an Array of Opposing Forces
abstract: As negotiations resume this week, there is skepticism among leaders in the United States and many of its allies that a deal can be struck.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Obama wrote last month to Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, urging him to overcome a decade of mistrust and negotiate a deal limiting Tehran’s nuclear ambitions, it was perhaps the president’s last effort to reach a reconciliation with Iran that could remake the Middle East.

headline: A Reserve So Deep, You Could Drown
abstract: Hugh Jackman stars in Jez Butterworth’s Broadway play “The River,” a poetic tease of a drama.
lead_paragraph: Hugh Jackman isn’t giving anything away these days. And reticence, it turns out, becomes him. Who knew?

headline: Mysteries of Heaven and Earth
abstract: In “Our Lady of Kibeho,” a girl’s visions of the Virgin Mary spread beyond her Rwandan village school.
lead_paragraph: The teenage girl, a young 17, seems incapable of deception. Her voice rises into a bright squeal when she becomes excited. Her eyes have a limpid clarity that suggests no subterfuge. She is docile and abashed by authority, even though her bubbly nature keeps her long, elegant limbs in constant nervous motion. She doesn’t even wear shoes.

headline: A Nanny’s Loud Cellphone Voice
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A toddler being pushed in her stroller on the Upper West Side made it clear what she thought of her attendant’s behavior.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: ‘The Newsroom’ Recap: It’s ‘Godfather’ Trivia Night
abstract: The lawyer bests the news anchor — which may be surprising to a few.
lead_paragraph: Season 3, Episode 21: “Run”

headline: ‘Homeland’ Recap: Oh, the Heartbreak of Saul
abstract: And what about that I.S.I. dreamboat Aasar Khan?
lead_paragraph: Season 4, Episode 8, “Halfway to a Donut”

headline: Moving Past a Gruesome Injury
abstract: Kevin Ware, a former Louisville guard who sustained a gruesome leg injury in the N.C.A.A. tournament in 2013, is now playing at Georgia State.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Kevin Ware anonymously traversed the Georgia State campus one day last week between the gym and classes in astronomy, history and journalism. The uninterrupted commute on foot was typical. If Ware draws attention going about his daily routine, it more likely stems from mistaken identity — he resembles a younger André 3000, the noted rap artist from Atlanta — than from his one shining moment under unimaginable duress.

headline: When Government Succeeds
abstract: There is a lot of good news that Republicans don’t want you to notice.
lead_paragraph: The great American Ebola freakout of 2014 seems to be over. The disease is still ravaging Africa, and as with any epidemic, there’s always a risk of a renewed outbreak. But there haven’t been any new U.S. cases for a while, and popular anxiety is fading fast.

headline: Link Opens Between Hong Kong and Shanghai Stock Markets
abstract: The connection will strengthen the two cities’ roles as global financial centers and open the door to $4.2 trillion pool of capital.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China took a leap into the international markets on Monday, allowing mainland residents to trade shares in Hong Kong for the first time and foreigners to invest in Chinese companies that had largely been off limits.

headline: Airbnb Introducing Print Magazine, Pineapple
abstract: The quarterly publication, whose debut issue contains no advertising, will be distributed to the company’s hosts, people who rent rooms to travelers.
lead_paragraph: Following in the footsteps of other digital brands like CNET and WebMD, Airbnb is getting into the print magazine business.

headline: Partisanship Breaks the Government
abstract: The Republicans’ goal is to have a destructive fight.
lead_paragraph: This could be a rather heated winter. All three branches of government are on course to collide over partisan politics, constitutional authority and scope of power, particularly as vested in the executive branch.

headline: Considering the Place of the Working Parent in the Kitchen
abstract: The recent home-cooking movement can stir up feelings of anxiety and guilt for parents as they balance the ideal and the reality of feeding their families.
lead_paragraph: Every November, I close my eyes and conjure up memories of Thanksgivings past. I remember roasted turkeys and hams, homemade stuffing and cranberry sauce, collard greens and candied yams, pecan and pumpkin pies, and my joyful mother in the center of it all.

headline: A Boy’s Injury Rallies a County
abstract: A community in Indiana came together after an 11-year-old sustained a severe head injury during a game.
lead_paragraph: HAYDEN, Ind. — Erin Stoner, a teacher at Hayden Elementary School, gave the information to her sixth-grade class straight, without sugarcoating it or tiptoeing around it.

headline: Amazon Moves to Extend Cloud-Computing Dominance
abstract: Amazon Web Services already has the largest share of the worldwide cloud-computing market, and is looking for ways to expand the range of services it offers.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Most people know about Amazon’s ambitions to sell you everything from books and movies and smartphones to power tools and auto parts.

headline: After Seeking Help, a Student Finds a Path to a Job
abstract: With the support of a former math teacher and the Community Service Society, Lidio Rodriguez gained the training he needed to work in information technology.
lead_paragraph: For Lidio Rodriguez, 21, the decision to attend college had little to do with laying a foundation for his future. It was, instead, out of a more basic need for a roof over his head.

headline: Ex-Rangers Return, Thriving Anew
abstract: Ryan Callahan, Brian Boyle and Anton Stralman, all former Rangers, have helped keep the Tampa Bay Lightning near the top of the Eastern Conference, and on Monday they will face their old team for the first time.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — They started their hockey careers in cold places like Rochester, Hingham, Mass., and Sweden, and rose to fame in New York. But this season, amid Tampa’s palm trees, imitations of Moorish palaces and retirees in golf carts, Ryan Callahan, Brian Boyle and Anton Stralman are thriving as never before.

headline: Carl Schlesinger, 88, Dies; Helped Usher Out Hot Type
abstract: Mr. Schlesinger, a former typesetter at The New York Times, helped make a documentary about the last night the newspaper was made using hot-metal type.
lead_paragraph: Carl Schlesinger, a former typesetter at The New York Times who helped make an award-winning film about one particularly memorable night on the job — July 1, 1978 — the last time the newspaper was made using hot-metal type, died on Nov. 9 in Paramus, N.J. He was 88.

headline: Popular Demand
abstract: Popular songs tend to be popular everywhere: “Habits (Stay High),” by Tove Lo, above, was not only the most played song on traditional radio, but also No. 10 on Billboard’s Digital Songs chart.
lead_paragraph: Popular songs tend to be popular everywhere: “Habits (Stay High),” by Tove Lo, above, was not only the most played song on traditional radio, but also No. 10 on Billboard’s Digital Songs chart.

headline: ‘The Good Wife’ Recap: In a Campaign Commercial, Alicia Shows Off Her Acting Chops
abstract: Alicia lays down the law with Peter.
lead_paragraph: Season 6, Episode 9: “Sticky Content”

headline: A Major Trade Leaves Questions in Two Cities
abstract: The Knicks’ victory over Denver suggested that they were the clear winners of the Carmelo Anthony deal involving Danilo Gallinari, but Knicks fans should still question the long-term wisdom of the trade.
lead_paragraph: There was a moment in the second quarter Sunday when Carmelo Anthony had the ball in the post with Danilo Gallinari between him and the rim.

headline: ‘The Affair’ Recap: Do You Prefer Cole or Noah?
abstract: Noah doesn’t seem too swift, at least when it comes to Oscar.
lead_paragraph: Season 1, Episode 6

headline: Tomas Young, Army Veteran, Dies at 34; Critic of Iraq War in Film
abstract: Mr. Young was the subject of a film that showed the devastating human cost of the war and argued that it should have never been fought.
lead_paragraph: Paralyzed from the chest down, the Iraq War veteran is seen in a 2007 documentary film taking dozens of pills for spasms, pain and depression. He speaks agonizingly about his sexual problems. Viewers watch him marry and, eight months later, divorce.

headline: M.T.A. Expected to Raise Fares and Tolls
abstract: Board members are expected to discuss a 4 percent increase across the system’s trains, buses, tunnels and bridges at a meeting this week.
lead_paragraph: Subway and bus fares will rise again in March. The only questions are by how much and for which riders.

headline: In Playoff Rankings, a Strong Finish Could Outweigh Strength of Schedule
abstract: Where the College Football Playoff selection committee slots Wisconsin after its big victory Saturday might reveal how it deals with an under-discussed dynamic: the question of timing.
lead_paragraph: MADISON, Wis. — As the snow fell on a Wisconsin team that was demolishing Nebraska on Saturday, the crowd shouted, “Mel-vin Gor-don,” and “Heis-man.” The chants seemed appropriate given that on only 25 carries across the first three quarters, Gordon rushed for a Football Bowl Subdivision record 408 yards and 4 touchdowns.

headline: At Educational Event, a Modern Legal Interpretation of a Biblical Story
abstract: Alan M. Dershowitz took on his former Harvard Law School student, Eliot Spitzer, at a New York synagogue during a mock trial over the actions of the biblical figure Abraham.
lead_paragraph: The facts were undeniable: The defendant, one Abraham (no known surname), had teetered on the brink of stabbing his son Isaac to death, only to be stopped by divine intervention.

headline: Man Sought in Subway Homicide
abstract: Video released by the NYPD shows a man wanted for questioning in Sunday’s murder of Wai Kuen Kwok, 61, at the 167th Street subway station in the Bronx.
lead_paragraph: Video released by the NYPD shows a man wanted for questioning in Sunday’s murder of Wai Kuen Kwok, 61, at the 167th Street subway station in the Bronx.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, November 17, 2014
lead_paragraph: Today we offer our prayers and condolences to the parents and family of Abdul-Rahman Kassig, also known to us as Peter.

headline: F.C.C. Chief Aims to Bolster Internet for Schools
abstract: Tom Wheeler, the F.C.C. chairman, is expected to propose raising the annual cap on school Internet spending by $1.5 billion, to $3.9 billion.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With a goal of fiber-optic lines reaching to every school and a Wi-Fi connection in every classroom, Tom Wheeler, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, is expected on Monday to propose a 62 percent increase in the amount of money the agency spends annually to wire schools and libraries with high-speed Internet connections.

headline: David Isay Wins 2015 TED Prize for StoryCorps, an Oral History Project
abstract: David Isay founded the group that gets people to record meaningful 40-minute conversations. He will be listened to at the TED annual conference in March.
lead_paragraph: In March, David Isay, the founder of the oral history project StoryCorps, will give his first TED talk — typically, a big-idea lecture delivered in a large hall while pacing alone on stage with an unseen, wireless microphone.

headline: With Bold Park Plan, Mogul Hopes to Leave Mark on New York’s West Side
abstract: Barry Diller, the billionaire chairman of IAC/InterActiveCorp, has pledged $130 million toward a park and performance space that would sit atop a platform off the Hudson River shoreline.
lead_paragraph: It would be a bold addition to the Manhattan waterfront — a $170 million, futuristic park built atop an undulating platform 186 feet off the Hudson River shoreline with a series of wooded nooks and three performance venues, including an amphitheater.

headline: Word of the Day | venial
abstract: This word has appeared in five New York Times articles in the past three years.
lead_paragraph: venial •\ˈve-ne-əl, -nyəl\• adjective

headline: What’s On TV Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (HBO) BANKSY DOES NEW YORK (2014) In October 2013, the British street artist known as Banksy began a monthlong residency in New York City, posting one exhibit a day in an unannounced location and prompting a scavenger hunt as residents searched the five boroughs for works whose images, but not locations, were revealed ahead of time on Banksy’s Instagram account. Fans rushed to catch fleeting glimpses of stenciled graffiti, sculptures, videos and performance art touching on subjects like fast-food wages, animal cruelty in the meat industry, civilian casualties in Iraq and hypocrisy in the art world — and perhaps the anonymous artist. Eventually Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg condemned Banksy for defacing public and private property; some members of the press claimed that the New York Police Department was hunting him. This documentary, above, directed by Chris Moukarbel, chronicles the mayhem with the help of user-generated content from Banksy’s followers and foes.

headline: #CalvinStrong
abstract: After Calvin Clark, 11, sustained a severe head injury in a youth football game this month, his Indiana community has shown its support in many ways.
lead_paragraph: After Calvin Clark, 11, sustained a severe head injury in a youth football game this month, his Indiana community has shown its support in many ways.

headline: Corrections: November 17, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on November 17, 2014.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: N.B.A. Game of the Week: Clippers at Heat
abstract: Thursday’s meeting between Los Angeles and Miami may help show whether the early play of two of last season’s top teams is a good indicator of their playoff potential.
lead_paragraph: Every week, The New York Times will choose one essential game to watch, highlighting hot teams, winning and losing streaks and statistical intrigue in the N.B.A.

headline: Chinese Bear That Became the Symbol of a Movement Dies
abstract: Oliver, as the bear was called, was rescued in 2010 by the advocacy group Animals Asia after spending 30 years in bear-bile farms. His dramatic journey to a new life was captured in the documentary “Cages of Shame.”
lead_paragraph: A brown bear that became a symbol of animal suffering and also of hope for change in China died last week at a sanctuary in the western city of Chengdu, the Hong Kong-based advocacy group Animals Asia announced.

headline: Apple Links China’s UnionPay Cards to App Store
abstract: Chinese users can now use China UnionPay cards to buy items in the App Store.
lead_paragraph: After a long wait, Apple’s Chinese customers can pay for goods in its App Store with the country’s most popular credit and debit card service, paving the way for new growth in virtual spending on the media, games and apps Apple offers online.

headline: Reckitt Benckiser Plans December Spinoff of Pharmaceutical Arm
abstract: If the spinoff is approved by shareholders, the stand-alone drug business would be called Indivior and begin trading on the London Stock Exchange on Dec. 23.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The British consumer goods company Reckitt Benckiser said on Monday that it planned to proceed with a spinoff of its pharmaceutical business to existing shareholders next month.

headline: Burkina Faso Names Ex-Diplomat as Interim Leader
abstract: Michel Kafando, 72, was chosen more than two weeks after the ouster of President Blaise Compaoré, who fled the country in the face of mass protests.
lead_paragraph: OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso — After days of intense political wrangling, a committee of political, military, religious and traditional authorities in Burkina Faso named a former foreign minister and veteran diplomat on Monday to oversee a transition to new elections following the ouster of President Blaise Compaoré.

headline: Test Yourself | A Rat on Broadway
abstract: Here are the first seven paragraphs of the Nov. 10 article “White Rodent Finds Fame on the Great White Way: ‘The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time’ Has an Unexpected Star: A Rat Named Toby” Can you choose the best word for each blank?
lead_paragraph: Below are the first seven paragraphs of the Nov. 10 article “White Rodent Finds Fame on the Great White Way: ‘The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time’ Has an Unexpected Star: A Rat Named Toby”

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Million-Dollar Gamers
abstract: What is it like to be a highly paid professional video game player?
lead_paragraph: In “No. 1 With a Bullet: ‘Nadeshot’ Becomes a Call of Duty Star,” Conor Dougherty writes about professional video game players and their lives in front of and away from their screens.

headline: Newspaper Calls on Chinese Academics to Cut the Criticism
abstract: A Chinese newspaper’s look into university professors’ criticism of China has triggered an online debate about academic freedom and whether scholars have a patriotic duty to refrain from criticizing the country and its political system.
lead_paragraph: A Chinese newspaper’s look into university professors’ criticism of China has triggered an online debate about academic freedom and whether scholars have a patriotic duty to refrain from making overly negative comments about the country, its society and its political system.

headline: Buying the Farm, Building a Subdivision
abstract: A quick assignment on a farm turned into a two-decade look at what happened when developers transformed the farmland into a suburban subdivision.
lead_paragraph: Scott Strazzante thought he had a quick newspaper assignment photographing a farm in suburban Chicago. Instead, he spent the next 20 years documenting life there and on the suburban subdivision that replaced it.

headline: What Is the Perfect Number of College Applications to Send?
abstract: What are the advantages and disadvantages of sending applications to 20 or more colleges and universities?
lead_paragraph: College-bound students often have a dream school, but they apply to other schools as well, just in case the acceptance letter from the dream school doesn’t arrive.

headline: Avian Flu Detected in the Netherlands and Britain
abstract: It was not clear if the outbreaks at poultry farms in the two countries were linked, but a British veterinary official said wild birds may have carried the disease.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Health officials moved to combat outbreaks of bird flu at poultry farms in Britain and the Netherlands on Monday, culling thousands of chickens and ducks to avert the spread of infection.

headline: Pfizer to Pay up to $2.9 Billion in Cancer Drug Deal With Merck of Germany
abstract: The alliance between the American and German companies is expected to strengthen Merck’s oncology business in several important markets, including the United States.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Merck of Germany said on Monday that the American drug giant Pfizer had agreed to pay $850 million upfront and as much as $2 billion later in a deal to jointly develop one of Merck’s cancer drugs.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: What you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: New York Today: Pull Out the Coats
abstract: Monday: A coat drive returns, rain, and the Bergdorf Goodman holiday windows are revealed.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this rainy Monday.

headline: Pope Francis Confirms U.S. Visit for Next Year
abstract: The trip, his first to the country as pontiff, will include an international gathering in Philadelphia. He is also expected to make a stop in New York.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — Pope Francis confirmed Monday that he will make his first papal visit to the United States in September to attend an international meeting in Philadelphia on the theme of family, as part of an American journey that is also expected to include a stop in New York.

headline: Daily Report: Privacy Concerns Over Classroom Tracking Software
abstract: Many teachers say the ClassDojo app helps them automate the task of recording classroom conduct, but some critics say such apps are being adopted without sufficiently considering the ramifications for data privacy and fairness.
lead_paragraph: One morning in mid-October, Greg Fletcher walked to the front of a third-grade classroom at Hunter Elementary School, where an interactive white board displayed ClassDojo, a behavior-tracking app that lets teachers award points or subtract them based on a student’s conduct. On the board was a virtual classroom showing each student’s name, a cartoon avatar and the student’s scores so far that week, Natasha Singer reports.

headline: Dag Skattum Is Set to Return to JPMorgan as a Vice Chairman
abstract: The former co-head of global mergers and acquisitions is expected to rejoin the bank as vice chairman for Europe, the Middle East and Africa.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Dag Skattum, the former co-head of global mergers and acquisitions at JPMorgan Chase, is expected to rejoin the bank in January as vice chairman for Europe, the Middle East and Africa.

headline: Got Milk? Might Not Be Doing You Much Good
abstract: Repeated studies have shown that for adults, milk and the nutrients it contains make little difference to health.
lead_paragraph: Almost no one will dispute that when a baby is born, breast milk is the best nutrition a mother can provide. All mammals nurse their young, and breast milk benefits a newborn infant in ways above and beyond nutrition. In fact, until 1 to 2 years of age, the American Academy of Pediatrics, the World Health Organization, the Institute of Medicine and more promote breast-feeding as optimal.

headline: Halliburton and Baker Hughes Agree to Friendly $34.6 Billion Merger
