abstract: Halliburton will buy its rival, paying 1.12 of its shares and $19 in cash for each Baker Hughes share, averting a hostile takeover battle but leaving open questions of whether the deal will survive antitrust scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: Halliburton agreed on Monday to buy its rival Baker Hughes for about $34.6 billion, uniting two big oil field services providers in a friendly deal only days after a hostile takeover battle appeared to be brewing.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Nov. 17, 2014
abstract: On Mondays, we publish a Times photo without a caption, headline or other information about its origins. Join the conversation by posting about what you see, and why. A live discussion is offered from 9 a.m. to 2 p.m. Eastern time.
lead_paragraph: Updated: Nov. 18, 2014

headline: Today in Politics
abstract: It’s time for the lame-duck Congress to get serious about what it will do — or won’t do.
lead_paragraph: It’s a Make-or-Break Week for Congress

headline: We Built the Company on Social Media. Here’s Why We’re Re-Thinking Everything
abstract: When YouTube came along, we realized it was perfect for us: Let’s tell customers, in a video, exactly what we’d tell them if they walked into the store. But that was then.
lead_paragraph: There’s nothing like thinking about the history of social media to make you feel old. When my husband, Doug, and I opened our yarn shop in the spring of 2002, Mark Zuckerberg had just graduated from high school, MySpace was more than a year from being launched, and the “smartest” phone out there was the Palm.

headline: Contractionary Policies Are Contractionary
abstract: But don’t tell the Germans.
lead_paragraph: Terrible numbers from Japan. Probably the drop was overstated — I don’t have any special knowledge here, but other indicators didn’t look quite this bad. But still, no question that the ill-considered sales tax hike of the spring is still doing major damage.

headline: ClassDojo: A Tale of Two Classsrooms
abstract: Teachers are adapting ClassDojo, a popular behavior tracking app, to their own teaching styles and the temperaments of their students.
lead_paragraph: Greg Fletcher, an amiable third-grade teacher at Hunter Elementary School, in Hunter, N.Y., uses a variety of old-school techniques to get his young students to settle down to their studies in the morning.

headline: Activist Hedge Fund Takes Aim at Canadian Pipeline Giant
abstract: Sandell Asset Management wants TransCanada to use master limited partnership’s more aggressively and to spin off its power business.
lead_paragraph: Three months ago, Sandell Asset Management took on a midsize restaurant operator. Now the activist hedge fund has its sights set on one of Canada’s biggest energy companies.

headline: Morning Agenda: Halliburton’s Deal for Baker Hughes
abstract: Halliburton agrees to buy Baker Hughes. | Allergan is near a deal with Actavis. | Hong Kong-Shanghai stock link opens. | A test for Brazil’s judicial system.
lead_paragraph: Halliburton agreed on Monday to buy Baker Hughes for about $34.6 billion, uniting two big oil field services providers in a friendly deal only days after a hostile takeover battle appeared imminent, DealBook’s Michael J. de la Merced reports. Under the terms of the transaction, Halliburton will pay 1.12 of its shares and $19 in cash for each Baker Hughes share. That was valued at about $78.62 as of Nov. 12, the day before news of the deal discussions became public.

headline: The Next Big Thing in Online Shopping: The Offline Connection
abstract: The independent-boutiques site Farfetch now lets you return goods at any participating store.
lead_paragraph: Just in time for Cyber Monday, that post-Thanksgiving at-your-laptop shopping extravaganza, comes another step forward in the online shopping experience.

headline: Briton and Frenchman Tentatively Identified in Islamic State Execution Video
abstract: French officials and the father of a missing British man tentatively identified two European men among those who executed Peter Kassig, an American aid worker, in a video released by the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A Briton and a Frenchman were tentatively identified on Monday among a group of executioners seen in video clips released a day earlier by the Islamic State militant group that announced the beheading of an American aid worker.

headline: Activists Take Their Pipeline Protest to Landrieu’s Lawn
abstract: Environmental activists are preparing to descend on the Capitol Hill home of Senator Mary Landrieu at 8:30 a.m. this morning, to protest her renewed push for the Keystone XL pipeline.
lead_paragraph: Environmental activists descended on the Capitol Hill home of Senator Mary L. Landrieu this morning to protest her renewed push for the Keystone XL pipeline. They rallied in front of her house, helped out by the giant inflatable pipeline that they first made famous when they wrapped it around the White House in protest three years ago.

headline: Daily Clip Report
abstract: Daily Clip Report is a collection of articles about the media and The Times that is emailed each day to senior executives and newsroom managers here.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

headline: Upcycling Coins, Plastic Bags and Keys for Social Change
abstract: Joanne Hayek and Tatiana Fayad, the founders of the Lebanese company Vanina, mix high-tech design with traditional craftsmanship.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — When high inflation hit the Lebanese economy in 2007, two designers turned their country’s weakened currency into gold.

headline: Higher Education in the Wearable Arts
abstract: In recent years, jewelry schools have popped up to satisfy the yearning for knowledge of how a diamond is set and a watch calibrated.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — It used to be that pretty much everyone except James Bond could enjoy a glass of Bollinger without knowing the month the grapes were picked and from which hillside. We are in an age of connoisseurship, and people want to know which cow produced their cheese and which sheep their sweater.

headline: Is That Rock for Real?
abstract: They look identical to their peers found in nature, but grown diamonds still struggle with an image problem.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — Lisa Bissell studied the six pink diamonds lined up like candies on a white tray in her Midtown Manhattan office. “All of these were born in the last couple months,” she said. She pointed to a round fancy pink diamond weighing 1.2 carats. “This one may be six months older, but they’re all babies,” she said. “That’s how I look at them.”

headline: A Silent Partner Toiling for the Famous
abstract: Mathon Paris is little known among consumers, but its handworked jewelry has earned a global following.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Last month, as he looked through a small cardboard suitcase containing his father’s silver models, Frédéric Mathon, the head of the jewelry firm Mathon Paris, saw potential in some classic designs.

headline: A Start-Up Incubator With a Fashion Focus
abstract: A program in New York provides "nuts and bolts" to support new designers.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The jewelry designer Sara Beltrán owes part of her success to a Jaipur rickshaw taxi driver she met when on a business trip. From helping her find her house, to production and business contacts, he made the introductions. But a local connection can take you only so far. The Council of Fashion Designers of America is helping Ms. Beltrán develop her jet-set beach-vibe brand Dezso into a profitable global enterprise with its in-house incubator program.

headline: Oasis of Artisanry in the Berkshires
abstract: On any given afternoon, astute collectors can be found browsing the cases at McTeigue & McClelland, a fixture of western Massachusetts for 18 years.
lead_paragraph: GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass. — This small New England town in the heart of the Berkshires, a hilly region of rural western Massachusetts, welcomes a summer influx of city dwellers from New York and Boston drawn to its tranquil setting, colonial-era charm and plethora of cultural goings-on, from museums to symphonies.

headline: Reinventing the Medieval Guild
abstract: With courses and subsidized studio spaces, a London center offers support for goldsmiths at the start of their careers.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — For young craftsmen, making a name among well-established brands is perhaps the hardest part of the trade. To do so, the artisans working at London’s Goldsmiths’ Center have the backing of a group that follows the spirit of medieval guilds.

headline: Doctor Being Treated for Ebola in Omaha Dies
abstract: Dr. Martin Salia, who died on Monday of Ebola, was two weeks into his illness and presented a steep challenge for treatment.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — This time, the challenge of Ebola was much steeper for the doctors and nurses at Nebraska Medical Center, one of a handful of hospitals specially designated to handle cases of the deadly virus in the United States.

headline: U.S. Mobile Payments Market to Boom by 2019, Research Firm Says
abstract: After a survey of a dozen payments industry companies, the research firm Forrester said it expected mobile-based payments in the United States to reach as high as $142 billion in volume over the next five years.
lead_paragraph: Just a few years ago, the idea of paying for things at the checkout counter with your smartphone seemed like a technology company pipe dream.

headline: Zoetis to Buy Abbott’s Animal Health Assets
abstract: The animal health care company Zoetis, which has attracted the interest of the deal maker William A. Ackman, has made a deal of its own.
lead_paragraph: Zoetis, the animal health care company that has recently attracted the interest of the activist investor William A. Ackman, has made a deal of its own.

headline: The Daily Gift: A Refreshing Treat for the Party Host
abstract: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.
lead_paragraph: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.

headline: McCain Lines Up Allies for an Assault on Sequestration
abstract: Senator John McCain is lining up supporters old and new to protect Defense Department spending.
lead_paragraph: SIMI VALLEY, Calif. — Senator John McCain, who will become chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee when Republicans take control of Congress, took to the stage over the weekend at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library, an architecturally fetching shrine to the patron saint of Pentagon spending.

headline: Rachel Noerdlinger, a Top City Hall Aide, Takes a Leave of Absence
abstract: Rachel Noerdlinger, the chief of staff to Mayor Bill de Blasio’s wife, Chirlane McCray, said that after the arrest of her son on Friday, she believed she needed to spend more time with her family.
lead_paragraph: The end came at Gracie Mansion, where Mayor Bill de Blasio, his wife and her top aide gathered on Sunday to discuss a decision none of them had wanted to make.

headline: Allergan Escapes Valeant’s Pursuit, Agreeing to Be Bought by Actavis
abstract: The $66 billion acquisition by Actavis would be the largest deal this year and would thwart the takeover effort of Valeant and William A. Ackman.
lead_paragraph: After seven months of bids, bluster and lawsuits, the hedge fund manager William A. Ackman and Valeant Pharmaceuticals appear to be giving up their pursuit of Allergan, the maker of Botox, as another big drug maker has trumped their hostile bid.

headline: What Ties Say About Work Today
abstract: When C.E.O.s dress casually, are they glossing over the power differentials at their companies?
lead_paragraph: Few aspects of work culture are as semiotically loaded as the tie. It signals masculinity, class status (or, at least, participation in a white-collar profession) and an adherence to a particular code of business etiquette. Some companies have deemed this code outdated, and the tie with it — but Robin Hardman wonders if they’re lying to themselves.

headline: Burkina Faso’s Interim Leader Speaks
abstract: Burkina Faso’s interim president, Michel Kafando, promised to return the country to democracy in the wake of a brief military takeover.
lead_paragraph: Burkina Faso’s interim president, Michel Kafando, promised to return the country to democracy in the wake of a brief military takeover.

headline: For Boehner, the Benefits of Turning 65
abstract: Representative Nancy Pelosi has a birthday wish for Speaker John A. Boehner.
lead_paragraph: A few hours later, Mr. Boehner thanked Ms. Pelosi.

headline: 1914: France’s Champagne Prospects
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: 1914: France’s Champagne Prospects Good Inspite of the War.
lead_paragraph: M. Charles Heidsieck, writing from Rheims on the prospects of the champagne vintage, alludes to the tragic events that have happened in that district of France. In spite of the ravages of war, it seems that 1914 promises so far to be a notable year for champagne. When August began there was excellent promise of a successful grape harvest, the vines having escaped frost in the spring and having had fine weather in the early summer. Some damage was done during the advance of the German troops, but after September 13, when Rheims was reoccupied by the Allies, nearly the whole area of the vineyards was cleared of the enemy. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Nov. 18, 1914

headline: Hong Kong Clears an Area of Pro-Democracy Protesters
abstract: The authorities met no resistance, with student protesters saying they would not oppose a court order to remove barricades around a tower near government headquarters.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Hong Kong government moved to clear pro-democracy protesters from a small area in front of an office building on Tuesday morning in the first move against the demonstrators in weeks. The authorities met no resistance, with student protesters saying they would not oppose the court order.

headline: An Incipient Threat to Our Hearts
abstract: A new study demonstrates the sometimes devastating consequences of ignoring nonobstructive coronary artery disease, a condition which has often been treated as insignificant.
lead_paragraph: Millions of Americans are walking around with deposits in their coronary arteries that do not obstruct blood flow to their hearts — at least, not until a piece of the plaque ruptures and forms a blood clot, causing a heart attack.

headline: Health Care Law Recasts Insurers as Obama Allies
abstract: Antagonism over profits and regulation has given way to rising revenue for an industry, and legal and logistical support for the administration.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Americans shop in the health insurance marketplace for a second year, President Obama is depending more than ever on the insurance companies that five years ago he accused of padding profits and canceling coverage for the sick.

headline: A Test Run for a Protest
abstract: In Ferguson, Mo., protesters rehearsed for a confrontation. A grand jury’s decision is expected any day now on whether to charge a white police officer in the death of an unarmed black 18-year-old.
lead_paragraph: A weekend passed in Ferguson, Mo., but the waiting went on.

headline: Study Finds Alternative to Anti-Cholesterol Drug
abstract: The finding, which showed that the drug ezetimibe lowers LDL cholesterol, can help millions who cannot tolerate statins or do not respond to them sufficiently.
lead_paragraph: For the first time since statins have been regularly used, a large study has found that another type of cholesterol-lowering drug can protect people from heart attacks and strokes.

headline: A Birthday Bash for Terry Riley at the Ecstatic Music Festival
abstract: The festival will include an 80th-birthday concert for Mr. Riley, new works performed by the Bang on a Can All Stars and a concert of John Zorn music.
lead_paragraph: An 80th birthday concert for Terry Riley, a program of new works performed by the Bang on a Can All Stars and a concert of John Zorn’s music are among the highlights of the fifth Ecstatic Music Festival, which will run from Jan. 15 to April 16.

headline: Inheriting a Payroll of Rich Possibilities
abstract: Farhan Zaidi spent 10 years in Oakland, where he earned the admiration of General Manager Billy Beane. With the Dodgers, who hired Zaidi this month as general manager, he will have vast resources to exploit.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — The first player whom Farhan Zaidi ever sought to acquire was Ken Griffey Jr. Zaidi tried to pull him out of a box.

headline: Injury to Bono Pulls Plug on U2 ‘Tonight Show’ Residency
abstract: A weeklong residency by U2 on “The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon” has been canceled after Bono was injured in a bicycle accident.
lead_paragraph: A bicycling accident in Central Park, in which U2’s singer, Bono, was injured, has forced the band to cancel its weeklong residency on “The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon.” The first of the group’s five appearances on the show was to have been Monday evening. But in a short message posted on the U2 website on Sunday, the band (minus Bono) announced the postponement.

headline: 1964: Ceiling TV for Teaching?
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: 1964 Ceiling TV for Teaching in France?
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Educational television took the teacher out of the classroom. Next it may put his image on the ceiling in reverse.

headline: Peru Prepares to Host Climate Talks as its Indigenous Forest Defenders Die
abstract: The resource rush on Peru’s Amazon frontier is exacting a rising toll on indigenous communities, a rights group warns.
lead_paragraph: The nonprofit group Global Witness makes some valuable points in a new report offering Peru a path to cut the violence on its poorly governed resource frontier in the Amazon. The report, “Peru’s Deadly Environment,” is being released today at a Manhattan event organized with the Alexander Soros Foundation.

headline: Bank of England Chief Suggests Rules on Salaries May Be Needed, Too
abstract: Mark Carney, the governor of the Bank of England, said European caps on bonuses were distorting the ability to claw back pay and that salaries might need to be regulated as well.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Just when bankers thought pay rules in Britain could not become any more complicated, the head of the Bank of England said on Monday that they might need to be.

headline: Billions of Dollars Mend Health Insurers’ Rift With Obama
abstract: Once a favorite political punching bag for President Obama, the health insurance industry has reaped big benefits from the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: Once a favorite political punching bag for President Obama, the health insurance industry has reaped big benefits from the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Merkel Issues Rebuke to Russia, Setting Caution Aside
abstract: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany asked whether Russia’s annexation of Crimea and moves in eastern Ukraine meant a return to the days of Moscow deciding the its neighbors’ fates.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Tit-for-tat expulsions of diplomats. Russian naval ships showing up as world leaders meet in Australia. Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany telling Russia sternly to play by 21st-century rules — and President Vladimir V. Putin practically spitting fury over Western reaction to his annexation of Crimea.

headline: Two Very Different Biennials, a Slumber Party for Creative Types and More From the Art Calendar
abstract: Plus, the first U.S. solo shows by international artists Adriana Varejao and Claude Rutault and more happenings to see in the week ahead.
lead_paragraph: T’s list of happenings worth visiting in the week ahead.

headline: New Jonathan Franzen Novel, ‘Purity,’ Coming in September
abstract: Mr. Franzen’s publisher described “Purity” as a multigenerational American epic, centered on a young woman named Purity Tyler.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Franzen’s fans will have plenty to read next year. There’s a forthcoming biography of the author by Philip Weinstein, an English professor at Swarthmore College. And in September, Farrar, Straus & Giroux will release Mr. Franzen’s fifth novel, “Purity.”

headline: No Allergan Deal, but a $2.6 Billion Profit for Ackman
abstract: William Ackman appears to have been thwarted in his effort to partner with Valeant Pharmaceuticals on a takeover of Allergan, but losing may still feel like winning.
lead_paragraph: Depending how you look at it, William A. Ackman either had a very good day or a very bad one.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Big Wins for Harvick, Enders-Stevens, MacCachren
abstract: Kevin Harvick won the 2014 Sprint Cup title, Erica Enders-Stevens became the first woman to win the championship in the N.H.R.A. Pro Stock car class.
lead_paragraph: Kevin Harvick won a tense finale for the Nascar Sprint Cup series Sunday in Homestead, Fla., edging the three other drivers vying for the 2014 season championship.

headline: What to Wear This Week: Nov. 17
abstract: Stock up on cold-weather gear that can endure the season’s unpredictable climate and the urban grind.
lead_paragraph: The annual New York Cares coat drive begins Monday, perfectly timed with a very chilly week ahead. As temperatures descend in Midtown, make winter dressing less of a head throb and let your outerwear do all the work.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
abstract: Elvis Presley’s music backs a Heineken ad. Who knew?
lead_paragraph: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
abstract: White Castle named Resource/Ammirati as its agency of record to handle creative tasks.
lead_paragraph: Gael Angoula joined Code Worldwide, London, in a new post, marketing manager. He had been the United Kingdom managing director at SmartBeacon, London.

headline: The Navajo Nation Sheep Problem
abstract: Can you help Navajo clan representatives divide strings of sheep so that they’re all happy?
lead_paragraph: This week’s problem was suggested by Dave Auckly, a professor of mathematics at Kansas State University. Dr. Auckly found the basic idea for the puzzle in the fraction section of Gordon Hamilton’s Math Pickle website while collecting problems and activities for the Navajo Nation Math Circle Project. Let’s give it a try. Here’s —

headline: Top Democrats Urge Obama to Act Alone on Immigration
abstract: In a letter to President Obama, top Senate Democrats Monday urged the president to move forward unilaterally on immigration, saying they “strongly support” his plan to offer legal protection to some of the undocumented immigrants already in the country.
lead_paragraph: In a letter to President Obama, top Senate Democrats on Monday urged him to move forward unilaterally on immigration, saying they “strongly support” his plan to offer legal protection to some of the undocumented immigrants already in the country.

headline: U.S. Considering Outside Help to Close Development Gap
abstract: The United States Soccer Federation is discussing the enlistment of Double PASS, a Belgian firm, to strengthen its club academies and itself.
lead_paragraph: For football players aspiring to their sport’s biggest stage, the obvious path is simple: Star in high school, go to a big-time Division I college and be drafted by an N.F.L. team. For would-be basketball players, the formula is pretty much the same (except some even skip the college part these days).

headline: Gorillas Are More Fragile Than You Think: A Dispatch From Congo
abstract: On Nov. 16, Jeffrey Gettleman wrote about a struggle over oil exploration in Africa’s national parks that pits economic development against environmental preservation. Here he chronicles his experience in Virunga National Park.
lead_paragraph: On Nov. 16, Jeffrey Gettleman wrote about a struggle over oil exploration in Africa’s national parks that pits economic development against environmental preservation. Here’s the story of his experience in the Democratic Republic of Congo.

headline: Volkswagen Recalls 400 Cars, and N.H.T.S.A. Investigates Honda and Infiniti
abstract: VW is recalling some 2015 Jettas and Passats for a seat defect; N.H.T.S.A. is investigating Honda and Infiniti for steering problems.
lead_paragraph: Volkswagen is recalling about 400 Jettas and Passats from the 2015 model year because the front seat backs may move unexpectedly, startling the driver and potentially causing a crash, according to a report the automaker posted on the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration website.

headline: Book Review Podcast: ‘Napoleon: A Life’
abstract: Andrew Roberts talks about his new biography of Napoleon, and Yochi Dreazen discusses “The Invisible Front: Love and Loss in an Era of Endless War.”
lead_paragraph: In The New York Times Book Review, Duncan Kelly reviews Andrew Roberts’s new biography of Napoleon. Mr. Kelly writes:

headline: ‘Shoah’s’ Long Route to the Web
abstract: Only after a restoration, a re-release and a DVD version was streaming a consideration. And other notable documentaries have yet to make it online.
lead_paragraph: It seems natural these days to assume that any well-known, critically lauded, historically important modern film can be watched, legally, somewhere on the Internet. So I was surprised to see the announcement that “Shoah,” Claude Lanzmann’s monumental 1985 documentary about the Holocaust, would be available for streaming for the first time at SundanceNow Doc Club.

headline: A Scheduling Note: Keystone Pipeline
abstract: Vote on Senator Mary Landrieu’s Keystone XL Pipeline legislation is scheduled for 6:15 pm on Tuesday, as of now.

headline: HSBC’s Swiss Private Bank Charged in Belgium Tax Fraud Inquiry
abstract: The unit is accused of helping wealthy individuals hide billions of dollars in assets by creating offshore companies in places like Panama and the Virgin Islands.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The Swiss private banking arm of HSBC has been charged by Belgian authorities with assisting wealthy individuals to avoid paying taxes on several billion dollars in assets.

headline: “Let It Breathe”
abstract: A new song by Jaden Smith.
lead_paragraph: A new song by Jaden Smith.

headline: PCH
abstract: A new song by Jaden Smith.
lead_paragraph: A new song by Jaden Smith.

headline: A Final Visit
abstract: A look at the new instruments and repairs planned for the Hubble Space Telescope.
lead_paragraph: A look at the new instruments and repairs planned for the Hubble Space Telescope.

headline: ScienceTake | How Birds Count
abstract: Researchers are exploring the mathematical abilities of New Zealand robins.
lead_paragraph: Researchers are exploring the mathematical abilities of New Zealand robins.

headline: Today in Small Business: How Costco Codes Its Prices
abstract: Solving marijuana’s banking problem. The “ugly side” of Yelp. Are we running out of chocolate and turkeys?
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Walkabout: A Bigger, Better Mass MoCA; an Airplane Apartment on Airbnb
abstract: A weekly capsule of travel news curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: More Mass Already one of the country’s most celebrated modern art museums, Mass MoCA, in North Adams, Mass., will be the largest after a $55 million expansion, scheduled to be completed in 2017. (The Washington Post)

headline: Ads for American Airlines Seek ‘Great’ Results
abstract: “Going for great” is the theme of an American Airlines campaign highlighting an effort to strive for greatness.
lead_paragraph: Years before the phrase “American exceptionalism” became a staple of foreign policy debates, American Airlines proclaimed its exceptionalism in ads with themes like “Something special in the air” and “We’re American Airlines. Doing what we do best." Now, when many passengers would be skeptical of American — or any airline — declaring how wonderful it is, a campaign acknowledges that superiority is a destination to which American is still flying.

headline: Luxe Valet App Eliminates the Headache of Finding a Parking Spot
abstract: While at first blush Luxe Valet, an on-demand parking service, may seem bourgeois and inefficient, it and other similar services could radically alter how large cities work.
lead_paragraph: Every few years, I come across a new tech service that completely upends how I navigate urban life.

headline: Firestorm Erupts in Anti-Smoking Massachusetts Town
abstract: Residents of Westminster object to becoming the first in the country to ban the sale of cigarettes, e-cigarettes, cigars and chewing tobacco.
lead_paragraph: WESTMINSTER, Mass. — The fury — and make no mistake, it is white-hot fury — went way beyond the ordinary wrath of offended citizenry. A plan here to ban the sale of tobacco has ignited a call to arms.

headline: Uber Loves ‘Obamacare’
abstract: The head of the company loved by Republicans praised the health reform law.
lead_paragraph: It should come as no surprise that the chief executive of Uber, Travis Kalanick, likes the Affordable Care Act, a.k.a. “Obamacare.” After all, the law is designed to help people whose employers don’t provide them with health insurance get coverage through government-run exchanges and subsidies. That is, people like the independent contractors who drive Uber taxis.

headline: Erasing Sony and Nook E-Readers
abstract: Plus, using Apple’s AirDrop to move files between iOS and OS X.
lead_paragraph: Q. How do you remove personal information from a Sony Reader or the Barnes & Noble Nook before passing them on to other people?

headline: Actavis and Halliburton Deals Make for Biggest ‘Merger Monday’ of 2014
abstract: Merger Monday turned into mega-merger Monday as more than $105 billion worth of deals were announced.
lead_paragraph: On Wall Street, there are “merger Mondays.” Sometimes, there are mega merger Mondays.

headline: Facebook Testing Collaboration Tools for Businesses
abstract: The company is testing a new product called Facebook@Work, which will allow users to collaborate on projects through group chats and document collaboration with co-workers.
lead_paragraph: Facebook has long been a place to go online to get a brief respite from your digital work for a look at baby photos, friends’ status updates or anything other than a computer screen filled with Excel spreadsheets.

headline: N.F.L. Was Family, Until Wives Reported Domestic Abuse
abstract: The former wives of two players said they felt isolated and powerless when they were urged to stay quiet about violence and avoid causing disruptions.
lead_paragraph: CINCINNATI — Mercedes Sands and her husband, Robert, a safety for the Cincinnati Bengals, started fighting early, just a few months after they were married. But when Ms. Sands drove her car into a neighbor’s house while trying to flee, knocking herself unconscious and prompting a visit from the police, the Bengals became alarmed.

headline: One Mealworm, Two Mealworms: More Evidence Birds Can Count
abstract: A recent experiment in a natural setting seemed to confirm research done in controlled settings.
lead_paragraph: Evidence has been mounting for a while that birds and other animals can count, particularly when the things being counted are items of food. But most of the research is done under controlled conditions.

headline: Saud bin Mohammed al-Thani, Big-Spending Art Collector, Is Dead
abstract: Sheikh Saud, as Qatar’s culture minister, spent an estimated $1.5 billion on world art and objects.
lead_paragraph: Sheikh Saud bin Mohammed al-Thani, a Qatari royal relative who was one of the world’s most prolific and idiosyncratic buyers of art, antiquities, jewelry, vintage cars and dinosaur fossils until corruption charges left him in debt, died on Nov. 9 at his home in London.

headline: Police Vow ‘24/7’ Manhunt in Fatal Subway Push
abstract: A man sought for questioning in the death of a subway rider at the 167th Street station in the Bronx had faded from view.
lead_paragraph: For several minutes after the fatal shoving of a subway rider on Sunday morning, a man sought by the police for questioning appeared to behave as if nothing abnormal had happened.

headline: Seeing the ‘Invisible Patient’
abstract: Physicians too often fail to address the needs of caregivers, a clinical review finds.
lead_paragraph: Not once in the years I cared for my mother did any of her physicians ask me how I was doing. When was the last time I saw my own physician? Was I eating properly? Sleeping enough? Depressed?

headline: Court Conflict Raises Question of Who Decides the Law, and the Breaker
abstract: Insider trading cases are casting a spotlight on whether courts should defer to administrative agencies in determining criminal violations, Peter J. Henning writes in the White Collar Watch column.
lead_paragraph: It is a basic principle taught in every American government class: Congress enacts the laws and the executive branch enforces them. If only life were so simple. No law is perfectly clear, and circumstances change over time, opening up statutes to new interpretations.

headline: Connected, Yet Often Drifting Apart
abstract: When an extended family lives together, not everyone is happy with a sophisticated Wi-Fi system.
lead_paragraph: The first change we made when we moved into my parents’ house four years ago was to set up a sophisticated Wi-Fi system. With two teenage children still living with us, my older brother in residence looking for a job, and my husband and I working from home, a strong Internet signal was imperative to everyone’s survival.

headline: Goldman, JPMorgan and Morgan Stanley Executives to Be Questioned at Commodities Hearing
abstract: Two days of Senate hearings are the culmination of a two-year investigation into the role that Wall Street banks play in the commodities markets.
lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs executives will again come in for a grilling at a congressional hearing this Thursday.

headline: First Draft Focus: Christie on the Hill
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey leaving the Capitol after addressing new Republican members at a lunch on Monday.

headline: Quandary: Between Unknown Cousins and the Children’s Table, Thanksgiving Can Be Hard for Kids
abstract: Now is the moment to prepare children for Thanksgiving: show pictures of past gatherings, remind them of the names that go with faces and talk about things like interrupting, playing with younger cousins, new foods and appreciating gifts but not expecting them.
lead_paragraph: In the Weekly Quandary, we pull from the comments, the weekly open thread or email a question that we know (or at least suspect) plagues more than one parent. You — the readers — provide the advice: How have you made this work better in your family? This week’s quandary is a classic this time of year: You know and love your Cousin Alice, but your child has never met her, or hasn’t seen her in years, or has special needs that mean that even the relatively short distance between this Thanksgiving and last makes Cousin Alice a stranger.

headline: For Obama, Executive Order on Immigration Would Be a Turnabout
abstract: President Obama is poised to ignore his longtime opposition to a decision that would shield immigrants from deportation without an act of Congress.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama is poised to ignore stark warnings that executive action on immigration would amount to “violating our laws” and would be “very difficult to defend legally.”

headline: A Tactical Victory for Baker Hughes in Halliburton Deal
abstract: The merger would bring scale. Yet antitrust concerns and integration challenges may make a rich premium hard to justify, says Kevin Allison of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: The Baker Hughes chief executive must be feeling satisfied.

headline: Viewing Others Through a Prism of Money
abstract: Assumptions about others’ wealth can affect our judgment; learn to recognize what colors your behavior.
lead_paragraph: Last year, a guy made headlines because he was caught using a lowly flip phone. In a world of gold iPhones and palm-size phablets, it does seem a little odd that someone would still use such a low-tech device. But it was the identity of the person using the phone that got everyone’s attention: Jerry Jones, owner of the Dallas Cowboys.

headline: Warmer Waters Could Scuttle Activity of Crabs
abstract: Small crabs found on California’s shores may be capable of adapting to a warming climate, but the effort will leave them little energy for tasks like reproduction.
lead_paragraph: Small crabs found on California’s shores may be capable of adapting to a warming climate, but the effort will leave them little energy for tasks like growth and reproduction, researchers are reporting.

headline: Riding a Comet to Find Our Origins
abstract: Denton Ebel, curator of meteorites at the American Museum of Natural History, talks about how Comet 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko could help us to learn about the birth of our solar system and planet.
lead_paragraph: Denton Ebel, curator of meteorites at the American Museum of Natural History, talks about how Comet 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko could help us to learn about the birth of our solar system and planet.

headline: The Plight of Monarch Butterflies
abstract: New research could implicate efforts to help the Monarch butterfly in actually hurting their chances of long-term survival.
lead_paragraph: New research could implicate efforts to help the Monarch butterfly in actually hurting their chances of long-term survival.

headline: Who’s Afraid of Executive Action?
abstract: The case against the “no big deal” theory of the president’s promised immigration move.
lead_paragraph: As a follow-up to my latest shrill-but-accurate column on the president’s plan to bypass Congress and make immigration policy on his own, let me say something (not for the first time) about the common claim that this isn’t really a case of the president making law on his own, because everything he’s doing is potentially provisional, and subject to reversal by a future president. Here’s Slate’s Josh Voorhees, offering a version of that argument:

headline: Brooklyn Hospital Is Told to Keep Girl, 2, on Life Support Amid Organ Donation Fight
abstract: A Family Court judge ordered a one-day stay in the custody battle between the parents of Thaiya Spruill-Smith, who was declared brain-dead last week.
lead_paragraph: A judge on Monday ordered a Brooklyn hospital to keep a 2-year-old girl on life support for at least another day, as her parents argue over whether her organs should be donated.

headline: On This Day: Congress Comes to Washington
abstract: The sixth Congress made its move to Washington on this day in 1800.
lead_paragraph: Newly elected members of Congress walked wide-eyed through the Capitol last week, soaking in their surroundings and the history of the place.

headline: Draghi Sounds Hopeful Note on Europe’s Economy, but Reassures That E.C.B. Is Ready to Act
abstract: Mario Draghi repeated that the European Central Bank was ready to take extra measures to help the economy if its current path wasn’t effective enough.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The president of the European Central Bank on Monday gave a slightly more optimistic assessment of the eurozone’s economy, saying that a decline in bank lending appears to have reversed and pointing out that the economies in most countries in the region are growing.

headline: E.U. to Toughen Sanctions on Ukrainian Separatists, but Not Russia
abstract: The bloc decided to widen sanctions on individuals in Ukraine while pushing for a diplomatic solution to Russia’s involvement there.
lead_paragraph: The European Union’s foreign ministers decided on Monday to impose more sanctions on individual separatists in Ukraine, but shied away from toughening sanctions against Russia despite its recent military incursions into Ukraine.

headline: Jaden and Willow Smith on Prana Energy, Time and Why School Is Overrated
abstract: On the occasion of the release of their new albums this month, the offspring of Jada Pinkett Smith and Will Smith sat down with T for their first-ever joint interview.
lead_paragraph: One of the gifts of being young is that particular blend of self-confidence and self-consciousness. Jaden and Willow Smith have managed to turn this form of heady teenage introspection into expression instead of ennui. Willow, the 14-year-old musician whose debut single, “Whip My Hair,” went platinum when she was not yet a teenager, explains that the gift of life is “looking at nature and being, like, ‘Wow, I am so lucky to have a body and to breathe and to be able to look at this.’ ” To which her older brother Jaden, a 16-year-old actor and musician, adds: “And the huge, terrible thing the world would be missing by not expressing yourself.” To that end, both Jaden and Willow, the children of Jada Pinkett Smith and Will Smith, released new albums this month, including two tracks by Jaden that make their public debut here.

headline: Church of England Approves Plan Allowing Female Bishops
abstract: The archbishop of Canterbury predicted that half of the church’s bishops could be women within a decade.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Church of England overturned centuries of tradition on Monday with a final vote allowing women to become bishops, with the first appointments possible by Christmas.

headline: Developing a Taste for Human Blood
abstract: Domestic mosquitoes love human blood, but once preferred to feast on furrier animals. What accounts for the change in taste?
lead_paragraph: Domestic mosquitoes love human blood, but that is an evolutionary adaptation: At one time they actually preferred furrier animals.

headline: Governor Activates Missouri National Guard
abstract: Gov. Jay Nixon of Missouri said the National Guard will play a limited role, providing security at command posts, fire stations and other locations.
lead_paragraph: Anticipating protests after the grand jury’s decision in the death of Michael Brown, Gov. Jay Nixon of Missouri activated the National Guard on Monday.

headline: That Litany of Complaints Is Attractive
abstract: Virtual life is less appealing than the physical in “I See You,” Kate Robin’s two-hander at the Flea Theater.
lead_paragraph: If you still enjoy that favorite sport of the “i” age — complaining about the omnipresence of electronic devices and the shortage of real conversation — the Flea Theater has a play, and a woman, for you. If, on the other hand, you’ve heard that particular whine too often and have made your peace with the new reality of modern life, you might have problems with the Flea’s latest offering, a world premiere by Kate Robin called “I See You.”

headline: Doctor Describes How Ebola Patient Died
abstract: Dr. Daniel W. Johnson, the director of critical care at the University of Nebraska Medical Center, discussed how Dr. Martin Salia died after being brought to the hospital with advanced Ebola symptoms.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Daniel W. Johnson, the director of critical care at the University of Nebraska Medical Center, discussed how Dr. Martin Salia died after being brought to the hospital with advanced Ebola symptoms.

headline: Seeing Jupiter’s Red in the Lab
abstract: Jupiter’s Great Red Spot is a result of chemicals being broken down by sunlight, researchers report.
lead_paragraph: Jupiter’s Great Red Spot is a result of chemicals being broken down by sunlight, researchers report. The scientists, at NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory, blasted ammonia and acetylene gases, both found on Jupiter, with ultraviolet light. This produced a reddish material with light-scattering properties similar to those of the spot.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: In Performance | Alysha Umphress
abstract: Ms. Umphress, with Brett Rowe on piano, sings the number “I Can Cook, Too” from the 2014 Broadway revival of the 1944 musical “On The Town.”
lead_paragraph: Ms. Umphress, with Brett Rowe on piano, sings the number “I Can Cook, Too” from the 2014 Broadway revival of the 1944 musical “On The Town.”

headline: Why More Diversity on Wall Street Might Fight Bubbles
abstract: Traders working in their own ethnic group were more likely to drive prices to irrational levels than traders in mixed groups, a study found.
lead_paragraph: Would more racial diversity on Wall Street make financial bubbles less likely to develop?

headline: Newark Airport Lands Big-Name Chefs
abstract: Paul Liebrandt, Dale Talde and other acclaimed chefs are opening restaurants in a United terminal.
lead_paragraph: First-class dining, even for passengers holding tickets in coach, is coming to United Airlines Terminal C at Newark Liberty International Airport. Some 28 new restaurants are planned, with concepts devised by 24 high-profile chefs, including Alex Stupak, Einat Admony, Amanda Freitag, Paul Liebrandt, Jacques Torres, Alex Guarnaschelli and Dan Kluger.

headline: Safety in Numbers
abstract: The specific antigens given in vaccines represent only a small portion of the daily stimuli the immune system has to deal with.
lead_paragraph: Q. Can receiving multiple vaccines (like hepatitis a, typhoid and tetanus) shortly before traveling abroad weaken one’s resistance to a cold or the flu?

headline: How It Feels to Land a Spacecraft on a Comet
abstract: Claudia Alexander, a scientist on the Rosetta Project, talked to Op-Talk about the challenges scientists of color face, the importance of mentorship and her reaction to Philae’s wondrous landing.
lead_paragraph: “People tend to learn science from somebody that takes them out and shows them cool things,” says Claudia Alexander. Now the planetary scientist has experienced what’s arguably one of the coolest things in recent memory: As a project scientist on the United States Rosetta Project, she is part of the team that put a spacecraft on a comet for the first time ever. That spacecraft, Philae, lost battery power last week, but according to The Guardian, scientists believed they’d gotten 80 percent of the data they wanted by Friday. And Vox’s Joseph Stromberg called Philae’s outing “a huge success.”

headline: Snakes Leave Identity Within Their Fang Marks
abstract: DNA information can show what kind of antivenin to use, or if one is even needed.
lead_paragraph: Getting a DNA swab from the fang marks of a snake bite can accurately identify the type of snake, a team working in Nepal has found.

headline: Ben Ray Lujan to Helm Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee
abstract: Representative Nancy Pelosi named Representative Ben Ray Lujan, a 42-year-old congressman from New Mexico, to succeed Representative Steve Israel as the chair of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee.
lead_paragraph: Representative Nancy Pelosi named Representative Ben Ray Lujan, a 42-year-old congressman from New Mexico, to succeed Representative Steve Israel as the chair of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee.

headline: Another Bitcoin Auction to Be Held by U.S. Marshals
abstract: The latest auction is for $19 million in Bitcoins found on computer hardware belonging to Ross Ulbricht, who is accused of creating the now-defunct online bazaar Silk Road.
lead_paragraph: The United States Marshals Service announced on Monday that it would auction 50,000 Bitcoins, worth around $19 million, seized in connection with the now-defunct online bazaar Silk Road.

headline: A Diverse Mix of Pupils, Learning Civilized Dissent
abstract: The New York Debate League stands out for pitting middle school students from elite private institutions against those who might be the first in their family to attend college.
lead_paragraph: The issues could stock a Sunday talk show: body cameras for the police, Ebola panic and more. Yet the points and rebuttals came not in shouts from politicians and pundits, but from pre-teenagers formally debating topics that occasionally hit close to home in their disparate neighborhoods.

headline: A Strong Start for Emma Stone in ‘Cabaret’
abstract: The Broadway revival of “Cabaret” had solid ticket sales last week for the first set of performances starring Ms. Stone.
lead_paragraph: The Broadway revival of “Cabaret” had solid ticket sales last week for the first set of performances starring the film actress Emma Stone, who is making her Broadway debut in the role of Sally Bowles. According to box office data released on Monday, the show grossed $686,271 for eight performances, or 68 percent of the maximum possible amount; 85 percent of seats were filled. While Ms. Stone might have been expected to be a bigger draw instantly, given her fan base from movies, tickets can be expensive: The average paid admission was $112.39 last week. And sales were surely affected by the absences of the show’s leading man, the Tony Award winner Alan Cumming; he was on vacation for four performances.

headline: Julianne Moore in Architectural Balenciaga
abstract: The star softened a graphic texture-blocked dress with romantic red lips and feminine waves.
lead_paragraph: The Star: Julianne Moore

headline: A Reporter Reveals Ebola’s Effect on One Family
abstract: The Times’s Norimitsu Onishi tracked the progression of the deadly virus and the damage it did to one family in Liberia.
lead_paragraph: Kaizer Dour’s family survived Liberia’s 14-year-long civil war, but they could not survive the Ebola virus. Last week Norimitsu Onishi told the stories of a family torn apart by Ebola. Here’s what it took to piece it together.

headline: An Upgrade for Newark’s United Hub
abstract: Terminal C, the United Airlines hub at Newark Liberty International Airport, will receive a renovation that includes new restaurants and free use of iPads in waiting areas.
lead_paragraph: United Airlines announced on Monday the details of a $120 million renovation plan to bring its hub at Terminal C in Newark International Liberty Airport in line with other major airports in the United States.

headline: One Day, Two Deals and a Changed Calculus of Deal-Making
abstract: As the Allergan and Baker Hughes deals show, companies are struggling to justify a case against activist investors and hostile bidders, Steven Davidoff Solomon writes in the Deal Professor column.
lead_paragraph: It has been awhile since we’ve seen a deal day like Monday, with Halliburton announcing that it had reached a $34.6 billion deal to buy Baker Hughes and Allergan selling itself to Actavis for $66 billion. The deals show that the merger and acquisitions market is changing in some obvious and not so obvious ways that may change how companies are bought and sold.

headline: ‘Interstellar’: The Cinema of Physicists
abstract: If the movie “Interstellar” requires a 324-page book to explicate it, can it be considered a totally successful work of art?
lead_paragraph: The Earth is a dying dust bowl where a blight is destroying all the crops and oxygen. Schoolchildren are being taught that the moon landings were faked to bankrupt the Russians, and NASA is a secret agency consisting of a dozen scientists huddling underground. The Yankees are a barnstorming troupe who play games in cornfields and let ground balls go through their legs.

headline: Mayday, a Super PAC to Fight Super PACs, Stumbles in Its First Outing
abstract: But its founder, Lawrence Lessig, a Harvard Law School professor who has long opposed big money in politics, is not giving up.
lead_paragraph: Lawrence Lessig grandly created his Mayday super PAC about six months ago to fight big money in political campaigns.

headline: A Time for Revisiting Real Fears
abstract: Walking through the dark ruins of a defunct Soviet installation brings back memories of the Cuban missile crisis and makes apparent the continuing possibility of a nuclear attack.
lead_paragraph: In the late 1970s amateur radio operators began hearing raucous bursts of electronic chatter flooding the airwaves and interfering with normal operations. Cutting across the high-frequency bands, the staccato signals resembled a rapidly chopping helicopter blade or the steady fire of a machine gun. Some thought the sound was more like a woodpecker, and that was the name that stuck.

headline: Democrats Shake Lineup in House Political Team
abstract: Ben Ray Luján of New Mexico will lead the party’s campaign efforts in the House, and Steve Israel of New York will work to communicate its agenda.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Democrats, searching for a new generation of leaders and with an eye on the increasingly important Latino vote, have selected Representative Ben Ray Luján of New Mexico to lead the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee.

headline: Weight Lifting Pries Open Doors to a Hermit Kingdom
abstract: North Korea is in talks to hold a world championship weight lifting event, although a International Weightlifting Federation official said a junior event was more likely than one at the senior level.
lead_paragraph: North Korea, the world’s most reclusive country and an outsider in sports for decades, is in talks with the International Weightlifting Federation to host a world championship event, according to the organization’s top official.

headline: The Voice of Karadenes
abstract: Listen to Ted Karadenes sing a short clip of one of his favorite songs, “Can’t Help Falling in Love” by Elvis Presley.
lead_paragraph: Listen to Ted Karadenes sing a short clip of one of his favorite songs, “Can’t Help Falling in Love” by Elvis Presley.

headline: Angelina Jolie, Kristen Stewart and Reese Witherspoon at the Hollywood Film Awards
abstract: Here are some of the red carpet moments.
lead_paragraph: The Hollywood Film Awards took place on Friday, with the movie “The Imitation Game” proving to be the biggest winner. Here are some of the top red-carpet moments.

headline: A Pundit Explains What’s Wrong With Washington
abstract: It’s him!
lead_paragraph: Or, actually, demonstrates by example what’s wrong with Washington.

headline: Even the Democratic Caucus Can Fail to Accommodate Pregnancy
abstract: Although it is primarily Democrats and President Obama who continue to push for the Pregnant Workers Fairness Act, a Democratic representative who is pregnant cannot get an exception on Democratic Caucus voting rules.
lead_paragraph: Representative Tammy Duckworth of Illinois, who is expecting a baby in December, has asked the House Democratic Caucus leadership to allow her to vote by proxy in committee member elections next week. Her doctor has advised Ms. Duckworth (who lost both legs when her helicopter was shot down in Iraq) not to travel to Washington in the late stages of her pregnancy.

headline: Two U.S.T.A. Board Members Will Be Replaced
abstract: The terms of Ray Benton and Jeff Williams conclude at the end of the year, amid controversy around potential conflicts of interest.
lead_paragraph: Amid controversy around potential conflicts of interest, two United States Tennis Association board members will be replaced effective in January 2015, the organization confirmed Monday.

headline: The Follies, the Oscars, the Troops
abstract: Richard Zoglin’s new biography, “Hope: Entertainer of the Century,” follows Bob Hope through vaudeville days, Hollywood films, the Oscars, the U.S.O. tours and seeming irrelevance.
lead_paragraph: Richard Zoglin’s revelatory new biography of Bob Hope makes staggering claims for its subject. Is it enough to say that “for the way he marketed himself, managed his celebrity, cultivated his brand and converted his show business fame into a larger, more consequential role for himself on the public stage, Bob Hope was the most important entertainer of the century”? No, it’s not. Mr. Zoglin adds that “one could argue, without too much exaggeration, that he was the only  important entertainer.”

headline: Speed Reading
abstract: A book in which complex kinetic concepts are made simple, and simply spectacular,

headline: Verbatim: Channeling Gehrig (Sort of )
abstract: Representative Steve Israel joked about handing off the D.C.C.C. chairmanship.
lead_paragraph: Representative Steve Israel of New York said, jokingly, about handing off the chairmanship of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee.

headline: A Master of Memory in India Credits Meditation for His Brainy Feats
abstract: A guru’s protégé memorizes objects by the hundreds before admiring crowds.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — The young man sat cross-legged atop a cushioned divan on an ornately decorated stage, surrounded by other Jain monks draped in white cloth. His lip occasionally twitched, his hands lay limp in his lap, and for the most part his eyes were closed. An announcer repeatedly chastised the crowd for making even the slightest noise.

headline: From an Egyptian-American Prisoner on Hunger Strike in Cairo, a Letter Home
abstract: Mohamed Soltan, who has been incarcerated for more than a year since his arrest at a street protest, wrote to his family on his 27th birthday.
lead_paragraph: Mohamed Soltan, an Egyptian-American in prison in Cairo awaiting trial for more than a year after his arrest at a street protest, entered the 294th day of a hunger strike on Sunday, his 27th birthday.

headline: National Guard Would Play Limited Role, St. Louis Mayor Says
abstract: Mayor Francis G. Slay said troops operating within the city of St. Louis would have a “secondary role” in responding to any protests, and that police officers would be the ones dealing directly with demonstrators.
lead_paragraph: The mayor of St. Louis said Monday that he supported Gov. Jay Nixon’s decision to send the Missouri National Guard to his city in case there is unrest after the grand jury returns.

headline: For the Monarch Butterfly, a Long Road Back
abstract: The migratory population of monarch butterflies is plummeting and well-meaning efforts by enthusiasts may be contributing to its plight.

headline: In Paris, a Culinary Homage to the French Master Alain Passard
abstract: Over the weekend, the chef’s chef was honored by a series of meals cooked up with a cast of his protégés, who once worked at his Michelin-starred L’Arpège restaurant.
lead_paragraph: So many chefs today are admired by the general public, but “chef’s chefs,” the rare few whose mastery of the art sends their peers into fits of envy and adulation, are an elite club. In Paris, the king of them all is probably Alain Passard, whose restaurant L’Arpège, next to the Musée Rodin in the Seventh Arrondissement, has held three Michelin stars since 1996.

headline: An Architect’s Vision
abstract: The architect of the Capitol posted a time-lapse video of the scaffolding being constructed that currently surrounds the building’s dome.
lead_paragraph: For your viewing pleasure: The architect of the Capitol posted a time-lapse video of construction of the scaffolding that currently surrounds the building’s dome.

headline: As Japan Falls Into Recession, Europe Looks to Avoid It
abstract: To revive long-term growth, analysts say deep-seated changes to economies are needed, but such moves are politically difficult.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Japan looked like the model for economic revival. Growth was back on track. The stock market was surging. Inflation, which had eluded Japan for decades, was even returning.

headline: F.T.C. Penalizes TRUSTe, a Web Privacy Certification Company
abstract: The commission said that TRUSTe deceived consumers about its recertification program and allowed itself to be falsely portrayed as a nonprofit corporation.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission on Monday penalized TRUSTe, a company that certifies websites for compliance with various privacy standards, saying it had deceived consumers about its recertification program and allowed itself to be falsely portrayed as a nonprofit corporation.

headline: Nov. 17, 2014 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Israel, Czech Republic, Syria and Greece.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Israel, Czech Republic, Syria and Greece.

headline: Kim Deal, Beyond the Pixies
abstract: The alt-rock pioneer, who split from The Pixies last year, has begun releasing material under her own name — like “Biker Gone,” which premieres here.
lead_paragraph: Though she is best known as the bassist of the iconic alt-rock band the Pixies — whose membership she departed, seemingly for good, in June 2013, following a successful run of reunion tours — Kim Deal has proven to be a linchpin for all of her musical projects. Besides fronting a 1995 album by the Amps (on which she was billed as “Kim Ampersand”), Deal also served as the leader and sole consistent member of the Breeders — whose albums, like 1993’s platinum breakout “Last Splash,” often sold better than those of the band for which she was first known. But starting in early 2013, even before her split with the Pixies was confirmed, Deal began trickling out the first music to be released under her name only — a group of seven-inch singles appropriately titled the “Kim Deal Solo Series.”

headline: Researchers Announce Advance in Image-Recognition Software
abstract: Scientists have created artificial intelligence software able to recognize the content of photos and videos with such accuracy that it can sometimes mimic humans.
lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — Two groups of scientists, working independently, have created artificial intelligence software capable of recognizing and describing the content of photographs and videos with far greater accuracy than ever before, sometimes even mimicking human levels of understanding.

headline: State of Emergency Declared in Missouri for Grand Jury’s Decision on Ferguson
abstract: Gov. Jay Nixon’s announcement allows him to activate the Missouri National Guard in preparation for a grand jury decision on whether to indict a white police officer for shooting to death an unarmed black teenager.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — Gov. Jay Nixon declared a state of emergency on Monday, allowing him to activate the Missouri National Guard in preparation for a grand jury decision on whether to indict a white police officer for shooting to death an unarmed black teenager, Michael Brown, three months ago.

headline: Microsoft Billionaire Reboots Seattle Movie Temple
abstract: What do you do when you are a billionaire and a movie buff? If you are Paul G. Allen, you turn the iconic theater you already own into a state-of-the-art theater.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — The modern technology industry that Paul G. Allen, the co-founder of Microsoft, helped create is constantly giving people new ways to watch movies without stepping into a theater, from smartphones to tablets to streaming video on a big-screen television.

headline: A House Fit for Murder, Madmen and Fashion Models
abstract: The Gustav Mayer House, an 1855 Italianate mansion on Staten Island, is only partly restored, because its moody decay has proved irresistible for photo shoots in slick magazines.
lead_paragraph: The stars Mary-Kate Olsen and Lauren Hutton are laughing on a beat-up couch in their Harper’s Bazaar shoot, dressed for a bohemian ball, the plaster walls behind them cracked and humming in the afternoon light. In a Cosmopolitan U.K. spread, the model Megan McNierney totters down the stairs past a fresco of the Italian countryside, a Hitchcockian madman in pursuit. For a Vs. magazine feature, the actress Amber Heard reclines in a claw foot tub, wearing leather, lace, a commandant’s hat and knee-high boots, a riding crop clutched with menace in her hands.

headline: From Mali to Israel, a Musical Bridge
abstract: Vieux Farka Touré and Idan Raichel, on the eve of a concert in Manhattan, talk about their unusual collaboration.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli pianist Idan Raichel was at the airport in Berlin in 2008 when he spotted the Malian guitarist Vieux Farka Touré and decided to introduce himself. From that chance encounter has blossomed one of the most fruitful and intriguing collaborations in the grab-bag genre known as world music, a pair of critically acclaimed CDs and an enduring cross-cultural friendship.

headline: An Insider’s Look Before They Were Hip Hop Stars
abstract: Lisa Leone’s intimate and relaxed portraits of hip-hop figures — from rappers to graffiti writers — reveal the eye of a fellow traveler.
lead_paragraph: Lisa Leone’s intimate and relaxed portraits of hip-hop figures — from rappers to graffiti writers — reveal the eye of a fellow traveler.

headline: Subscribe to the Morning Briefing Email Newsletter
abstract: What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox. Monday through Friday.
lead_paragraph: What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox. Monday through Friday.

headline: An Icy Hot Spot Where the Chill Scintillates
abstract: Among the latest releases, Azealia Banks, One Direction, Andy Stott and the Oliver Lake Organ Quartet.
lead_paragraph: AZEALIA BANKS

headline: Regardless of Offstage Worries, Onstage It’s All Artistry
abstract: The Czech Philharmonic, under the leadership of Jiri Belohlavek, returned to Carnegie Hall with works by Dvorak and Janacek.
lead_paragraph: The Czech Philharmonic, a world-class orchestra that visits New York too rarely these days, made its first appearance at Carnegie Hall since 2004 on Sunday afternoon. Its absence, which may relate to its perilous financial state and organizational difficulties of recent decades, has made it hard to judge from afar how it may be faring artistically after those very problems under the leadership of Jiri Belohlavek, its chief conductor since 2012.

headline: The Brain’s Depths and Romancing the Bomb
abstract: Letters to the editor and online comments.
lead_paragraph: Neuroscience

headline: National Guard to Help Police St. Louis
abstract: Mayor Francis G. Slay described the National Guard’s role in policing St. Louis in case of unrest after a decision by the grand jury in the Michael Brown case, which is expected later this month.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Francis G. Slay described the National Guard’s role in policing St. Louis in case of unrest after a decision by the grand jury in the Michael Brown case, which is expected later this month.

headline: Dr. Irving Peress, Target of McCarthy Crusade, Dies at 97
abstract: When Dr. Peress, a dentist serving in the Army, was promoted to major, Senator Joseph R. McCarthy said he was convinced it was part of “special treatment for Communists.”
lead_paragraph: Senator Joseph R. McCarthy’s anti-Communist crusade had reached a fever pitch in 1954 when Irving Peress, a New York dentist who had been drafted into the Army, became the beneficiary of a seemingly routine promotion from captain to major.

headline: Schubert, Dvorak and a Sub
abstract: A young substitute violist helped the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center explore works by Dvorak, Chausson and Schubert.
lead_paragraph: An intriguing debut marked the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center’s otherwise routine concert at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday afternoon. With the British violist Lawrence Power unable to make it to New York because of a fever, in stepped Matthew Lipman, 22, a Juilliard student who is scheduled to join the CMS Two program for young musicians, next year.

headline: Sometimes Brevity Is the Soul of Music
abstract: The Met Chamber Ensemble performed works by Anton Webern at Weill Recital Hall on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Anton Webern, born in 1883, composed as if trying to obey Twitter’s character limit: His stark, tiny “Three Little Pieces for Cello and Piano” (Op. 11) encompasses about 140 notes. An elegantly rendered, concise statement is impressive in any literary or musical genre, although in Webern’s chilly, atonal miniatures brevity often seems a baffling extreme.

headline: At the Guggenheim, a Legendary German Art Disco Is Reborn for One Night Only
abstract: On Saturday, the museum staged a re-creation of the infamous Creamcheese club, a hub for the European creative class from 1967 to 1976.
lead_paragraph: After the horrors of World War II, German national identity was primed for an anything-goes reinvention — and creation always needs a laboratory. This past Saturday evening, the Guggenheim transformed into a re-creation of a decades-old Dusseldorf discotheque called the Creamcheese club, where visual artists and musicians tussled with ideas of originality, abstraction and innovation. The Guggenheim’s one-night-only event paid homage to a space that from 1967 to 1976 served as a revolving door to nearly all of Germany’s globally influential creative class.

headline: Less Talk, More Therapy
abstract: After years on a shrink’s couch, I finally found what I was looking for — on a massage table.
lead_paragraph: My first session with Ann E. began as they all would: I stood against a wall wearing only a sports bra and underwear while she stood against the opposite wall, looking me over. She had me face north, south, east and west, and each time her eyes seemed to be tracing invisible lines down my body.

headline: Some Ad Hoc Diplomacy in a Button-Down Era
abstract: “Cold War Roadshow,” on PBS’s “American Experience,” looks at Nikita S. Khrushchev’s visit to America in 1959.
lead_paragraph: In his best-known films, like “Guerrilla: The Taking of Patty Hearst” and “Oswald’s Ghost,” the documentarian Robert Stone has focused on riveting bursts of violence in American history. His appealing new film does the opposite, looking at a moment of ad hoc diplomacy that may have made America safer at a time when the ultimate violence — nuclear war — seemed to be just one misunderstanding away.

headline: Bringing Nixon’s World to Life, Detail by Detail
abstract: Harry Shearer, whose many voices are heard on “The Simpsons,” portrays Richard M. Nixon in the online series “Nixon’s the One.”
lead_paragraph: Harry Shearer knows something about playing American icons. He’s been the voice of Montgomery Burns, Ned Flanders and Principal Skinner on “The Simpsons” for 25 years. So playing Richard M. Nixon is no stretch. The question is, why did he go to England to do it?

headline: So Far Away, Yet So Near to Us
abstract: Even no-nonsense scientists and engineers find themselves personalizing their surrogate explorers.
lead_paragraph: “Philae is talking to us,” announced the manager in charge of the little piece of machinery that had just achieved the first landing on a comet, a frozen remnant from the formation of the solar system. “We are on the comet.”

headline: Bodies Pile Up, but Business Goes On
abstract: “Firestone and the Warlord,” a 90-minute “Frontline” special Tuesday on PBS, is an example of the reason we bother to scrutinize history.
lead_paragraph: With more than enough horror stories coming out of Africa lately you may have little appetite for revisiting a gruesome chapter of Liberian history from a quarter-century ago. But “Firestone and the Warlord,” a 90-minute “Frontline” special Tuesday on PBS, is an example of the reason we bother to scrutinize history. Its troubling questions are not easily answered, but merely examining them might be useful for anyone venturing into unstable areas today.

headline: Ripples of the Big Bang Are Seen Through ‘The Times’
abstract: In 1927, Georges Lemaître, an astronomer from Belgium, first proposed the theory that the universe was born in a giant primeval explosion. Four years later, The New York Times mentioned his new idea.
lead_paragraph: An occasional column looking back at The New York Times’s first reference to some standbys of science.

headline: Margherita Missoni’s Sunny Instagram, Willow Smith’s Insightful Twitter and More
abstract: All the places you should be hanging out online this week.
lead_paragraph: Every week, T rounds up five captivating online destinations you should be visiting often.

headline: Kassig’s Parents Speak After His Death
abstract: The parents of Peter Kassig, an American aid worker and former soldier who was held hostage and then beheaded by the Islamic State, have spoken publicly for the first time since his death.
lead_paragraph: The parents of Peter Kassig, an American aid worker and former soldier who was held hostage and then beheaded by the Islamic State, have spoken publicly for the first time since his death.

headline: The Best Odds for a Colon Test
abstract: Small financial incentives helped persuade people to take a slightly unpleasant screening test.
lead_paragraph: The fecal occult blood test is an inexpensive and effective screening tool for colorectal cancer, but it requires taking a smear of one’s own feces and mailing it to a laboratory, a procedure many are reluctant to follow.

headline: Nuclear Agency Rules Are Ill-Suited for Plant Decommissioning, Leader Says
abstract: Allison M. Macfarlane offered a look at the Nuclear Regulatory Commission and the industry before she steps down at year’s end.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Nuclear Regulatory Commission’s rules are not geared for supervising the decommissioning of nuclear reactors, the task that will occupy much of its time in the coming years, the head of the agency, Allison M. Macfarlane, said Monday.

headline: Justice Department Is Weighing Civil Suit Against Angelo Mozilo
abstract: This summer, federal prosecutors were said to be close to filing a lawsuit. But the acting United States attorney for the Central District of California has had lingering questions about the litigation.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors are wrestling with whether to file a civil fraud lawsuit against Angelo R. Mozilo, the former chief executive of Countrywide Financial, which was at the center of the subprime mortgage boom and bust, people briefed on the matter say.

headline: Is 'Big Marijuana' Inevitable?
abstract: What's the right approach to legalizing recreational marijuana?

headline: Obesity Is Tied to Pollutants
abstract: Exposure to secondhand smoke and roadway traffic may be tied to increased body mass index in children and adolescents, a new study suggests.
lead_paragraph: Exposure to secondhand smoke and roadway traffic may be tied to increased body mass index in children and adolescents, a new study suggests.

headline: At Brigham Young, Students Push to Lift Ban on Beards
abstract: A student petition is urging university officials to repeal a decades-old ban on beards on the campus of the Mormon Church’s flagship academic institution.
lead_paragraph: PROVO, Utah — The dark pants, tightly knotted ties and crisp white shirts that once defined the Mormon man are nearly absent at Brigham Young University, the Mormon school that dominates this city.

headline: Rethinking Sherman’s March
abstract: Did the general really cut a swath of wanton destruction across Georgia — or is most of the damage a postwar fiction?
lead_paragraph: The March to the Sea has come down to us as an act of savage brutality perpetrated by one of the great villains of American history. Just the mention of William Tecumseh Sherman’s name conjures images of burning cities, ransacked plantations and terror stricken women and children, à la “Gone with the Wind.” Even after the passage of 150 years and dozens of scholarly books on the general and his march, most conversations about Sherman continue to generate more heat than light.

headline: SunEdison and TerraForm Buy First Wind, Gaining a Toehold in Turbines
abstract: SunEdison said the purchase would make it the world’s largest renewable energy development company.
lead_paragraph: SunEdison, a company that grew from making chemicals and components for solar modules to become one of the leading developers of solar farms, is making an acquisition that will give it a foothold in the wind power business.

headline: Jamie Horowitz, Newly Hired to Oversee ‘Today,’ Is Fired at NBC
abstract: Mr. Horowitz, a former ESPN executive, is leaving after only 10 weeks in a move attributed to a series of conflicts with staff and management.
lead_paragraph: In a new round of turmoil at the long-roiling NBC morning show “Today,” Jamie Horowitz, a former ESPN executive brought in 10 weeks ago to supervise the show, was fired on Monday after what several people at the network said was a series of conflicts with members of the show’s staff as well as the management of NBC News.

headline: Jesus, Francis and the Church Today
abstract: Readers respond to a Sunday Review essay, “Jesus and the Modern Man,” by James Carroll.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Pay Phones in New York City Will Become Free Wi-Fi Hot Spots
abstract: Officials say adding the kiosks with free Internet access will help close the digital divide, while others worry the city may be creating a monopoly.
lead_paragraph: The modern New York pay phone will provide no shelter from the rain, no alcove for the quarreling couple seeking a private moment to reconcile. It will afford little refuge to the prospective superhero requiring a wardrobe change.

headline: Egypt Will Expand Its Security Zone Near Gaza Strip
abstract: The discovery of smuggling tunnels will lead to the doubling of a secured buffer zone in the border town of Rafah, officials said.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egypt’s military said on Monday that it intended to double the size of a secured buffer zone in a town bordering the Gaza Strip after discovering smuggling tunnels across the frontier that were longer than expected, according to state news media.

headline: Ex-Bertelsmann Chief Remains in Jail
abstract: The court said there was a risk the former head of Bertelsmann might flee to avoid a prison sentence for embezzlement and tax evasion.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Thomas Middelhoff remained in jail on Monday after a judge said he needed more time to decide whether Mr. Middelhoff, the former chief executive of the German media company Bertelsmann, should be released while he appealed a conviction on charges of embezzlement and tax evasion at another company.

headline: Global Number of Youths Is Highest Ever, U.N. Reports
abstract: A United Nations report said the fate of the world’s adolescent population depended on governments’ ability to provide health care, education and jobs.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — There are more adolescents today than ever before in human history. Whether they lift their nations to prosperity — or tear them to shreds — will depend, the United Nations warns in a new report, on how swiftly governments can respond to their demands for decent education, health care and jobs.

headline: Sudan: Peace Talks Adjourn
abstract: Talks between the Sudanese government and a rebel group adjourned in Ethiopia on Monday, to be reconvened at a date yet to be determined.
lead_paragraph: Talks between the Sudanese government and a rebel group adjourned in Ethiopia on Monday, to be reconvened at a date yet to be determined. “We have moved a good way forward,” said the African Union’s chief mediator, former President Thabo Mbeki of South Africa, pictured. “We are not too far from concluding the kind of peace agreement the country needs.” This was the seventh round of negotiations between the government and the Sudan People’s Liberation Movement-North, a rebel group in South Kordofan and Blue Nile, southern states along the border with South Sudan.
