Fighting broke out in the two areas in June 2011, when fighters once allied with rebels in South Sudan refused to disarm.

headline: Avery Fisher Hall, in Search of a New Name
abstract: Readers respond to a front-page article about the planned renovation and renaming of the home of the New York Philharmonic.

headline: Coal Rush in India Could Tip Balance on Climate Change
abstract: The country has a voracious and growing demand for energy, and officials see coal as the best way forward. However, experts predict dire consequences.
lead_paragraph: DHANBAD, India — Decades of strip mining have left this town in the heart of India’s coal fields a fiery moonscape, with mountains of black slag, sulfurous air and sickened residents.

headline: Clean Mining a Deception in Kentucky, Groups Say
abstract: Environmental activists are again accusing the coal company Frasure Creek Mining of simply duplicating pollution reports to steer clear of regulators.
lead_paragraph: In a state where coal-country creeks run red with iron, Frasure Creek Mining has been unusually clean of late: Amid tens of thousands of measurements that it submitted to Kentucky regulators in 2013 and early 2014, fewer than 400 exceeded the state’s limits for water pollution from coal-mine runoff.

headline: A Nobel Laureate’s View of a Senator’s Energy Choices
abstract: Burton Richter, a Nobel laureate, urges Senator Mitch McConnell to look out for the interests of both his state and his country.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Electronic Health Records: How Systems Share
abstract: The Electronic Health Record Association writes that progress is being made toward “interoperability” of electronic health systems.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Landrieu Tries to Gather Enough Votes on Keystone Pipeline
abstract: As senators prepare to vote Tuesday, Senator Mary L. Landrieu, Democrat of Louisiana, hopes her effort will help her in a close runoff election.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Mary L. Landrieu of Louisiana continued to work on Tuesday to round up votes for the Keystone XL oil pipeline, part of a last-minute effort to help her survive a close runoff and one of the toughest battles of her political career.

headline: Blue Jays Stake Future on Former Yankee
abstract: Catcher Russell Martin, who helped the Pirates to consecutive wild-card berths, built on that success by agreeing with the Blue Jays on a five-year, $82 million contract.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees had good intentions after the 2012 season, vowing to cut back on long-term contracts and move forward without a bloated payroll and heavy taxes. One of the sacrifices was catcher Russell Martin.

headline: Inspired by Airlines, Hotels Increase Fees
abstract: Marriott and Hilton recently announced they would charge a penalty if a guest canceled a reservation at the last minute.
lead_paragraph: IN recent years, the airline industry has generated billions in revenue by charging fees on top of base fares. Now the hotel industry seems to be having the same idea.

headline: Putin Plays Hardball
abstract: Striking back at a critic of Russian capitalism by putting a dead man on trial.
lead_paragraph: This week marks the fifth anniversary of Sergei Magnitsky’s death in a Russian prison. He was 37 years old, a member of the emerging middle class who worked as a lawyer for a man named Bill Browder, the leader of the largest Russia-only investment firm in the world. Browder’s company, Hermitage Capital Management, started with $25 million during the Wild West-era of early Russian capitalism and had $4.5 billion in assets by the early 2000s.

headline: Ackman Has Luck of a Loser, to the Tune of $2.2 Billion
abstract: William A. Ackman and Valeant Pharmaceuticals lost their hostile battle to buy Allergan and still came away with a total of $2.6 billion.
lead_paragraph: Heads he wins. Tails he wins.

headline: Small Airports: The Scourge of a Seasoned World Traveler
abstract: Varun Mehta, a vice president for Clutch Group, has been traveling around the world all his life but still runs into problems in sleepier cities.
lead_paragraph: I GREW UP in Rochester, and I started flying when I was about 1. My parents were born in India and came to the United States with a suitcase and $60 in cash. It’s a typical immigrant story, and once they got settled and started working, they would save money to make a trip back to India to see family.

headline: Obama in Winter
abstract: Why has the Obama administration been behaving so strangely since the midterms?
lead_paragraph: They say failure can be a good teacher, but, so far, the Obama administration is opting out of the course. The post-midterm period has been one of the most bizarre of the Obama presidency. President Obama has racked up some impressive foreign-policy accomplishments, but, domestically and politically, things are off the rails.

headline: Setback in Atlantic City for Man Hoping to Save Parents’ Home
abstract: A judge ruled that an agency developing the tourism and gambling industries was legally able to exercise eminent domain on a building.
lead_paragraph: Charlie Birnbaum will have to go to a higher court to defend his parents’ home in Atlantic City, which he wanted to keep as something of a shrine.

headline: President of Colombia Halts Peace Talks With Rebels After General Is Seized
abstract: Describing what occurred as a kidnapping, President Juan Manuel Santos said that he had directed the country’s peace negotiators not to travel to Havana for a new round of talks with the guerrillas.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — In the first major setback in peace talks intended to end 50 years of guerrilla warfare, President Juan Manuel Santos of Colombia on Monday suspended negotiations with the country’s main rebel group and accused it of taking an army general and two other people captive.

headline: Bill Frenzel, Key Voice on Economics in House, Dies at 86
abstract: Mr. Frenzel had been appointed to governmental panels by presidents of both parties since ending his 20-year career in Congress, and he was a guest scholar at the Brookings Institution.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Bill Frenzel, a longtime Republican member of the House of Representatives from Minnesota who was a leading voice, respected by both parties, on trade, tax and budget policy while never serving in the majority, died on Monday at his home in McLean, Va. He was 86.

headline: Miss Honduras Is Target of Search
abstract: The beauty queen and her sister were last seen getting into a car to go to a party on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The police in Honduras said Monday that they were intensifying their search for Miss Honduras, María José Alvarado, 19, who has been missing since Thursday, along with her sister Sofía, 23.

headline: M.T.A. Issues Plans on Higher Fares and Tolls
abstract: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority presented two plans for more expensive pay-per-ride MetroCards.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority released its proposals on Monday for higher fares and tolls and began its campaign to win over riders and drivers skeptical of what are now routine increases.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 17, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: North Korea Acts to Stop U.N. Resolution on Rights
abstract: On the eve of a United Nations vote that could hold leaders of North Korea accountable for rights violations, diplomats said that they had rarely seen such frenetic action from the nation.
lead_paragraph: Worried about a looming United Nations vote on human rights that could possibly lead to criminal charges — or at least acute humiliation — North Korea has countered in recent weeks with an unusually robust mix of diplomacy, denials and threats.

headline: Mega-Mergers Popular Again on Wall Street
abstract: A pair of deals announced on Monday, worth $100 billion, brought the year’s total for American companies to $1.5 trillion, the highest since 2000.
lead_paragraph: Stocks are surging, corporate executives are ambitious and debt is cheap. The result is one of the biggest booms ever in mergers and acquisitions.

headline: Timeline: A Rocky Path to Allergan’s Deal
abstract: A timeline of the events that led to Allergan’s agreement to be acquired by Actavis in the face of a hostile takeover.
lead_paragraph: A timeline of the events that led to Allergan’s agreement to be acquired by Actavis in the face of a hostile takeover.

headline: ‘Gotham’ Recap: Exploding Cash, Unmasking Moles
abstract: On Monday a notable character arrives, young love blossoms and the plot thickens in the Gotham City underworld.
lead_paragraph: Season 1, Episode 9, “Harvey Dent”

headline: FIFA’s Farcically Shady Behavior
abstract: An investigative report on the bidding process for the 2018 and 2022 World Cups brought closure to nothing and has led to calls for boycotts.
lead_paragraph: When FIFA, the group that oversees international soccer, published a summary of an investigative report on Thursday largely clearing Russia and Qatar of corruption in their bids to host the 2018 and 2022 World Cup tournaments, it said it welcomed “the fact that a degree of closure has been reached.” That statement turns out to have been as specious as the summary itself. Far from resolving anything, it has led soccer elites, including the leader of a European league, to attack FIFA’s credibility and consider quitting the organization.

headline: Colombian Peace Process at an Impasse
abstract: The timing of a halt in peace talks between the government and the country’s main rebel group could not have been worse.
lead_paragraph: Peace talks between the Colombian government and the country’s main rebel group came to an abrupt halt on Sunday when President Juan Manuel Santos suspended the process in response to the mysterious abduction of a senior army general.

headline: M&C Saatchi Buys a Stake in SS&K
abstract: After two unsuccessful tries to crack the New York market, the London-based agency is buying a minority stake in a successful shop to serve as an outpost.
lead_paragraph: THERE may not be a saying that advises: “If at first you don’t succeed, try, try advertising.” But if there were, the executives of M&C Saatchi might qualify as fervent believers. After two unsuccessful tries by the London-based agency to crack the competitive New York market, M&C Saatchi is buying a minority stake in a successful New York shop, SS&K, which will serve as the M&C Saatchi outpost there.

headline: Four Questions About the Four-Team College Football Playoff
abstract: There are seven zero- or one-loss major-conference teams. None will play each other.
lead_paragraph: The 12-member committee charged with determining the four teams to make the first College Football Playoff will release its latest rankings Tuesday. It will then release two others, on Nov. 25 and Dec. 2, before the final rankings, on Dec. 7 — which are the only ones that truly matter.

headline: Reverently and Defiantly, Czechs Honor Velvet Revolution’s Anniversary
abstract: In Prague, some Czechs celebrated by pelting President Milos Zeman with debris as he unveiled a new memorial at a university campus.
lead_paragraph: PRAGUE — Marta Kubisova sat in a small back room of the cafe at the Lucerna Cinema, pulled a skinny cigarette from a silver case and rattled a long strand of pearls as she remembered the Velvet Revolution.

headline: The Impolitic Jonathan Gruber
abstract: The careless remarks of an economist about the Affordable Care Act were an insult to Americans and were largely wrong.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Gruber, a health economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, is a strong supporter of health care reform. But his careless comments at academic forums last year, caught on videotapes that surfaced recently, can only harm the reform cause. Mr. Gruber said in one comment that the Affordable Care Act relied on a “lack of transparency” and the “stupidity of the American voter” to gain passage. He said in another comment that the “Cadillac tax” on expensive employer-provided health insurance passed only because voters were “too stupid to understand it.”

headline: Intersection | Hoboken, N.J.
abstract: Born and raised in Hoboken, Caitilin Gallagher, a buyer at Eileen Fisher, says she likes to shop for “special pieces” that make her feel good.
lead_paragraph: Born and raised in Hoboken, Caitilin Gallagher, a buyer at Eileen Fisher, says she likes to shop for “special pieces” that make her feel good.

headline: A Crucial Vote on the Surveillance Bill
abstract: Cracking down on the abuses of Americans’ privacy is important enough to pass the USA Freedom Act now, instead of waiting for the next Congress.
lead_paragraph: The Republican Party is so badly fractured that it is impossible to tell what steps it will take on domestic surveillance once it assumes control of Congress in January. Its rising libertarian wing wants to crack down on abuses of Americans’ privacy, but many of its leaders express full support for any action the intelligence agencies want to take.

headline: Don’t Let Those Neat Uniforms Fool You
abstract: “Punk Rock,” Simon Stephens’s tender, ferocious and frightening play, inspires wonder that anybody makes it to the end of adolescence.
lead_paragraph: Something is seriously wrong with the characters in “Punk Rock,” Simon Stephens’s tender, ferocious and frightening play at the Lucille Lortel Theater. They wear their nerves dangerously close to the skin, and their moods swing unhinged. They think of themselves as the best and the worst of all possible beings. And almost all the time, they hurt, in both the active and passive senses of the word.

headline: United by Life, Divided by Dreams
abstract: Being a freak is virtually the new normal, so the timing couldn’t be better for the thrilling Broadway revival of “Side Show.”
lead_paragraph: Being a freak is virtually the new normal, so the timing couldn’t be better for the thrilling Broadway revival of “Side Show” that blazed open Monday night at the St. James Theater. The musical by Bill Russell and Henry Krieger, about conjoined twins searching for love and fame, or maybe just a half-measure of happiness, seems eerily appropriate for an era in which oddballs, outliers and anybody with a desperate need for the spotlight — and a way with a webcam — can achieve celebrity of some kind.

headline: Piece of Cake
abstract: Jacob McDermott proves that might is right.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — I began my workweek feeling very special. Unless you’re a physician, there really aren’t that many jobs where the first word you encounter on a Monday morning is ANAL. But there it is, at 1 Across. Happy Monday, everyone!

headline: ‘Sleepy Hollow’ Recap: My Mama, the Ghost
abstract: Let’s help the writers out with a Top 10 list of modern phenomena that Ichabod hasn’t discovered yet.
lead_paragraph: “Sleepy Hollow,” Season 2, Episode 9: “Mama”

headline: East Ramapo School Board Is Criticized by New York State Monitor
abstract: Henry M. Greenberg, the state-appointed monitor, stopped short of calling for a state takeover of the Rockland County district, but he did recommend appointing a fiscal overseer who could overrule the school board’s decisions.
lead_paragraph: A monitor appointed by the state to investigate the East Ramapo School District in Rockland County delivered a sharply critical report on Monday, saying the board had shown favoritism to the Orthodox Jewish students who attend private schools in the district and calling on the Legislature to give the district additional money while overhauling its governance.

headline: Berlin After the Wall: A Microcosm of the World’s Chaotic Change
abstract: Twenty-five years after the fall of the Berlin Wall, the city’s identity is still a work in progress.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Not far from the Brandenburg Gate, Potsdamer Platz was a no man’s land during the Cold War. Then the Berlin Wall fell, and the German authorities made it a petting zoo for celebrity architecture. The corporate headquarters of Germany’s new global swagger.

headline: The Custodian of the Song in His Heart
abstract: Ted Karadenes is 67 and shares a one-bedroom apartment with two other men, subsisting on catering work and federal benefits. For his retirement, he plans to play music in subway stations.
lead_paragraph: As a toddler in Rockville Centre, on Long Island, Ted Karadenes monitored the pulse of the grown-up parties his parents often hosted at home. When things got too quiet he looked for something tall, like a chair, clambered up and broke into song.

headline: Delusions Led to 2 Killings, Psychologist Says at Trial
abstract: The lawyers for Christian Falero say he was too deluded during the fatal stabbings of neighbors in Manhattan to know right from wrong.
lead_paragraph: A naked man who fatally stabbed two of his neighbors and wounded two others in Manhattan believed he was a character from the movie “The Matrix,” and was under the delusion he had to save the world, a psychologist testified on Monday.

headline: P.R. Firm Urges TransCanada to Target Opponents of Its Energy East Pipeline
abstract: The public relations firm Edelman advised the Canadian pipeline company to investigate groups that opposed one of its projects and to spread any unflattering findings.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — The advice from a top American public relations firm was simple: A Canadian pipeline company should take aim at its opposition.

headline: A Little Help Amid the First Hints of Winter
abstract: New York Cares opened its 26th annual coat drive at the Bowery Mission on the Lower East Side.
lead_paragraph: New York Cares began its 26th annual coat drive on Monday as temperatures dipped into the 40s. Coats will be collected through December at the Bowery Mission on the Lower East Side.

headline: Facing Three Former Teammates, Rangers Flail in Loss to Lightning
abstract: Emotions ran high at Madison Square Garden, with Ryan Callahan, the former Rangers captain, scoring twice for Tampa Bay.
lead_paragraph: The teams knew emotions would run high.

headline: Farewell to Elaine Stritch, the Lady Who Lunched Like No Other
abstract: “Everybody Rise: A Celebration of Elaine Stritch” brought out the bright lights of New York Monday night in tribute to the longtime star who died in July.
lead_paragraph: The theater community braved a seemingly endless downpour on Monday to celebrate the singular performer Elaine Stritch, who died in July at 89 after a career that spanned more than 60 years, many of them spent onstage, where she felt most at home, whether in New York or in London or on tour.

headline: A Forest Threatened by Keystone XL
abstract: The pipeline would add to the ruin caused by the mining of the tar sands.
lead_paragraph: CALGARY, Alberta

headline: In Sea of New Faces, Nets Run Aground Against the Heat
abstract: The Heat came out on top in a game between teams that have changed a great deal from when they met in the conference semifinals last season.
lead_paragraph: The last meeting between the Nets and the Miami Heat finished with LeBron James posturing on the scorer’s table at American Airlines Arena, pounding his chest, celebrating another playoff series win on another trip to the N.B.A. finals.

headline: Push in U.N. to Intercept Jihadists’ Oil
abstract: A United Nations panel urges the seizure of oil trucks entering and leaving territory controlled by jihadists in Iraq and Syria and a moratorium on antiquities sales from those countries.
lead_paragraph: A United Nations panel has urged the Security Council to order all countries to seize oil trucks coming in and out of territory controlled by jihadists in Iraq and Syria and to impose a global moratorium on the sale of antiquities from the two countries.

headline: Giants Seek to Revitalize Moribund Running Game
abstract: The five passes intercepted off Eli Manning on Sunday were only one element that led to the Giants’ fifth straight defeat. The team also continued to struggle on the ground.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Eli Manning stood at his locker Monday and spoke of how restlessly he slept after tying his career high with five interceptions in the Giants’ 16-10 loss to the San Francisco 49ers on Sunday.

headline: Man Arrested in Connection With Manhattan Jewelry Store Robbery
abstract: The police are still looking for two other suspects who are seen in a video of the robbery in the diamond district on Veterans Day.
lead_paragraph: The police have arrested a man in connection with the midday robbery last week of a jewelry store in Manhattan’s diamond district, and they were searching for two other suspects who were involved.

headline: A.E.G. to Bring Its Music Festivals to AXS TV
abstract: Next year, AXS TV will broadcast 70 hours of live music from five of A.E.G.'s festivals, including Coachella and the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival.
lead_paragraph: A.E.G., one of the world’s biggest concert promoters, has a portfolio of popular music festivals including Coachella and the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival. It also owns a stake in AXS TV, a fledgling cable television channel trying to establish itself in a crowded market.

headline: Sites Are Set For N.C.A.A.s
abstract: Brooklyn and Des Moines will host N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament games for the first time in 2016, and Madison Square Garden will again host a regional during the 2017 tournament.
lead_paragraph: Brooklyn and Des Moines will host N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament games for the first time in 2016, and Madison Square Garden will again host a regional during the 2017 tournament.

headline: Word of the Day | amalgamate
abstract: This word has appeared in seven New York Times articles in the past two years.
lead_paragraph: amalgamate •\ə-ˈmal-gə-ˌmat\• verb

headline: Honda to Replace Airbags Throughout U.S.
abstract: The automaker told federal regulators it would replace potentially defective airbags in regions outside the high-humidity areas in which a formal recall was issued.
lead_paragraph: Honda will replace potentially defective airbag inflaters in cars nationwide, according to statements the automaker gave federal safety regulators earlier this month. In doing so, it bows to pressure from lawmakers and auto safety experts who had questioned automakers’ limiting of the latest airbag recalls to high-humidity regions.

headline: Uber Executive’s Comments Leave Company Scrambling
abstract: Comments from Uber’s senior vice president for business during a private dinner last week suggested a way the company might combat what it saw as antagonistic media coverage.
lead_paragraph: Emil Michael is responsible for many high-profile business partnerships struck by Uber, the popular ride-hailing start-up, and he has engineered some of the company’s publicity stunts.

headline: What Bourbon Producers Can Teach the Oil Industry
abstract: In both cases, the long period between investment in and availability of a finished product means supply and demand can be badly misaligned.
lead_paragraph: The market for crude oil is in veritable free fall. The price of a barrel has dropped 30 percent since June, and the ripples have only begun, with analysts warning of everything from bankruptcies of Texas oil fields to economic troubles in big oil-producing nations like Venezuela and Nigeria.

headline: What’s On TV Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (ANIMAL PLANET) SAVING AFRICA’S GIANTS WITH YAO MING The graphic images of mutilated animals are heartbreaking. So are the statistics — only six northern white rhinos left in the world (a seventh died last month), their horns believed by some cultures to contain medicinal properties; more than 20,000 African elephants killed in 2013 for ivory to be carved into trinkets. In an effort to curb China’s multibillion-dollar lust for illegal wildlife products, WildAid has named the former basketball star Yao Ming as a spokesman for Africa’s severely threatened elephants and other wildlife. This special follows Mr. Yao, above, to the Samburu National Reserve in Kenya and the Kariega Game Reserve in South Africa to witness the brutality poachers inflict on these animals. As Mr. Yao states in a public-service announcement, “When the buying stops, the killing can too.”

headline: Suicide Attack in Afghan Capital Kills 2
abstract: A truck laden with gravel and explosives detonated near the gate of a base for foreign contract workers in Kabul on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — A suicide attack targeted a base for foreign contract workers in Kabul on Tuesday morning, killing at least two security guards, the authorities said.

headline: Israel Shaken by 5 Deaths in Synagogue Assault
abstract: Four men, including three Americans, were killed when two Palestinian assailants stormed a synagogue. A police officer and the attackers also died.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Orthodox Jewish men were facing east, to honor the Old City site where the ancient temples once stood, when two Palestinians armed with a gun, knives and axes burst into their synagogue Tuesday morning, shouting “God is great!” in Arabic. Within moments, three rabbis and a fourth pious man lay dead, blood pooling on their prayer shawls and holy books.

headline: Corrections: November 18, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Tuesday, November 18, 2014.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, November 18, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “They’re just taking away everyday freedoms, little by little. This isn’t about tobacco, it’s about control.”

headline: Umbrellas Come Out at Hong Kong Graduation Ceremonies
abstract: The president of Hong Kong Baptist University, Albert Chan, refused to hand out diplomas to students who carried umbrellas onto the stage during graduation ceremonies.
lead_paragraph: Prof. Albert Chan, president of Hong Kong Baptist University, told graduates on Monday to “start small, but dream big” and use all available opportunities to pursue their passions.

headline: A Road Test of Alternative Fuel Visions
abstract: After many years and billions of dollars of research, hydrogen cars are joining electric cars in showrooms, and advocates will likely spar over which is more practical.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Remember the hydrogen car?

headline: Polaroid Photographers Plead Their Case
abstract: Five photographers who regularly shoot with Polaroid instant cameras and film explain their hopes for a revival of Polaroid film by a company in the Netherlands.
lead_paragraph: Five photographers who regularly shoot with Polaroid instant cameras and film explain their hopes for a revival of Polaroid film by a company in the Netherlands.

headline: Building a Nuclear Deal With Iran
abstract: Will the Nov. 24 deadline for an agreement be met? Or will the process collapse?
lead_paragraph: Will the Nov. 24 deadline for an agreement be met? Or will the process collapse?

headline: EasyJet Profit Climbs as Battle for Business Passengers Intensifies
abstract: The budget carrier has tried to increase revenue by adding options like priority boarding, which are intended to appeal to business travelers.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — With Europe’s economic slump threatening to further crimp company budgets, the battle for business travelers is growing ever more heated among the region’s airlines.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Teaching Civilized Dissent, Regardless of Background
abstract: Why does the article’s author call debate “the fading art of civilized dissent”? Do you agree that civilized dissent is a fading art? Why?
lead_paragraph: In “Teaching Civilized Dissent, Regardless of Background,” Alan Schwarz writes about a recent debate tournament in the New York region.

headline: Test Yourself | Quitting His Job to Hit the Road With the Knicks
abstract: Here are the first 10 paragraphs of the Nov. 15 article “Living Out Knicks Dream, Complete With Nightmares.” Can you choose the best word for each blank?
lead_paragraph: Below are the first 10 paragraphs of the Nov. 15 article “Living Out Knicks Dream, Complete With Nightmares.”

headline: Auto Sales in Europe Rise for 14th Consecutive Month
abstract: Sales were again led by Spain, up 26.1 percent from October 2013, helped by incentives. Among major European markets, only France saw a decline.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — European auto sales kept their momentum in October, industry data showed on Tuesday, growing for a 14th straight month from their nadir last year.

headline: How Disney Turned ‘Frozen’ Into a Cash Cow
abstract: Or: Why an Elsa dress is like prescription drugs.
lead_paragraph: The Patriot Center at George Mason University, half an hour west of Washington, is a popular place to watch concerts, college athletics, professional wrestling and other events that command the attention of the adult world. But no event in the 29-year history of the arena has attracted as many people or earned as much money as last month’s performances of “Disney on Ice Presents ‘Frozen.’ ” For six days, waves of little blue-and-white Princess Elsas — and quite a few costumed parents — sang the movie’s hit song, “Let It Go,” at the top of their lungs, enjoyed $15 snow cones, posed for $25 pictures with cardboard cutouts and waved plastic sticks, which had miraculously become $28 magic wands.

headline: The Dark Side of Zootopia
abstract: Modern zookeeping’s longstanding trend toward cage-free, 3-D dioramas is influencing the way we shape natural habitats too.
lead_paragraph: It’s near closing time, but you’re safely ensconced within a mirrored glass bubble, wafting above the wilds of America. A pair of grizzlies, directly below, gaze up at their reflections on your ride’s mute and fleeting surface as the late-afternoon sunlight casts long shadows across the third and final themed continent of the day. Asia is already but a faint early-morning memory, a quick flight of steps down off the central plaza to the mouth of the nameless river that gently winds past padding tigers, bamboo panda cottages and the nearly touchable legs of wading elephants. Africa — after a quick cafe lunch back at the plaza — you chose to traverse by foot, allowing you the illusion of mingling with the lions, gorillas, zebras and treetop-grazing giraffes.

headline: What Are the Best Teaching Methods for Getting Students to Behave Well in Class?
abstract: Do you think a system of extrinsic rewards and punishments, with points being given for good behavior or taken away for bad, is an effective way to motivate students?
lead_paragraph: Have you ever been in a class where all the students were focused and engaged? And the class seemed to run perfectly? Or have you experienced the opposite — where most students were misbehaving or, at the very least, distracted? Why do students behave in one teacher’s class — but then misbehave in another’s?

headline: An Insider’s Look Before They Were Hip-Hop Stars
abstract: Lisa Leone’s intimate and relaxed portraits of hip-hop figures — from rappers to graffiti writers — reveal the eye of a fellow traveler.
lead_paragraph: The sharp features and bedroom eyes are eminently familiar. But the sun-dappled portrait of Snoop Dogg Lisa Leone took in 1993 surprises. The rapper appears not just young — this was just before the release of his first solo album — but soft.

headline: Premiere of ‘Hunger Games’ Film Postponed in China
abstract: The release of “The Hunger Games: Mockingjay — Part 1″ was scheduled for Friday but has now been pushed back to early next year. No official reason for the delay has been announced.
lead_paragraph: The Chinese release date for “The Hunger Games: Mockingjay — Part 1” has been pushed back to early next year. The film, which had its world premiere in London on Nov. 10, was originally scheduled to hit theaters in China on Friday, the same day as its premiere in several other countries, including the United States.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Prolific Shooter Aims Higher
abstract: Playing for the Reno Bighorns, Brady Heslip has been scoring 1.4 points per minute in a barrage of 3-pointers, but he has his eye on the N.B.A.
lead_paragraph: Since scoring 78 points and drilling 20 3-pointers in his first two games with the Reno Bighorns of the N.B.A. Development League, Brady Heslip has tried to move on. By going to practice. By watching episodes of “The Walking Dead” with his teammate David Stockton.

headline: New York Today: Thanksgiving Patterns
abstract: Tuesday: Our holiday habits according to Google, blistering cold, and the end of pay phones.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this incredibly cold Tuesday.

headline: Deaths Linked to Terrorism Are Up 60 Percent, Study Finds
abstract: The report by the nonprofit Institute for Economics and Peace comes as Western governments try to reverse gains by militants in Syria and Iraq.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As Western governments grapple with heightened apprehension about the spread of Islamic militancy, an independent study on Tuesday offered little solace, saying the number of fatalities related to terrorism soared 60 percent last year.

headline: Thailand Is Searching for Scores of Uighurs Who Fled China
abstract: The escapees, almost all women and children, left a shelter in southern Thailand in several separate groups this month, and about 120 remain at large.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The Thai authorities said Tuesday that they were searching for about 120 ethnic Uighurs who fled China and were detained in southern Thailand by the police earlier this year but escaped this month from a shelter there.

headline: What ‘Democracy’ Means in China Is Not What Australia’s Abbott Thinks
abstract: An awkward moment ensued after Prime Minister Tony Abbott of Australia mistakenly praised President Xi Jinping of China for a commitment to democracy that Mr. Xi never made.
lead_paragraph: An evening that should have capped a day of triumph for Prime Minister Tony Abbott of Australia resulted in awkwardness when he mistakenly praised President Xi Jinping of China for a commitment to democracy that Mr. Xi never made.

headline: Calling Early Elections in Japan, Abe Rolls the Dice on the Economy
abstract: The prime minister’s pledge to hold elections next month reflects worries that his economic revival program and his popularity are faltering, experts say.
lead_paragraph: IWAKUNI, Japan — When his popularity was soaring at home, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe declared in Washington a year ago, “Japan is back.”

headline: With New Tablet, Nokia Returns to Devices
abstract: The N1, with a 7.9 inch display and run on Google’s Android operating system, will pit the Finnish company against its longtime ally Microsoft.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Nokia is getting back into the device business.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | Nov. 11-17, 2014
abstract: Have you been following the news? Take our quiz to see what you know and to learn more, and look for a new edition each week on Tuesday morning.
lead_paragraph: Have you been following the news?

headline: Daily Report: TRUSTe, Web Privacy Certifier, Is Penalized by F.T.C.
abstract: The Federal Trade Commission said that TRUSTe deceived consumers about its recertification program and allowed itself to be falsely portrayed as a nonprofit corporation.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission on Monday penalized TRUSTe, a company that certifies websites for compliance with various privacy standards, saying it had deceived consumers about its recertification program and allowed itself to be falsely portrayed as a nonprofit corporation, Edward Wyatt reports.

headline: Am I Too Important to Do Real Work?
abstract: For years I’ve heard that leaders need to delegate and stay out of the daily work. But what if the work isn’t getting done?
lead_paragraph: In my post last week, I explained why I decided not to lay off people at my parts-finishing business — even though the inevitable result is that we are going to have some red ink.

headline: Today in Politics
abstract: In the Senate, an overhaul of domestic spying operations is on the line.
lead_paragraph: With Snowden Long Gone, Senate Examines Domestic Spying Again

headline: How the Great Wage Slowdown Hurts Democrats
abstract: History is clear: When incomes are stagnant, the president is not popular, and his party tends to suffer.
lead_paragraph: It’s a simple rule: A weak economy makes for an unpopular president. President Obama is on course to become the fourth president of the last six to leave office with an approval rating well below 50 percent. Each of the previous three — both Bushes and Jimmy Carter — also had something else in common: Median family income fell during their presidencies.

headline: Morning Agenda: Return of the Mega-Merger
abstract: Wall Street is on pace for a big year of deal-making. | William A. Ackman may have lost Allergan, but he still came away a winner. | The Justice Department is weighing a civil suit against Angelo R. Mozilo, the former chief executive of Countrywide Financial. | U.S. plans second Bitcoin auction.
lead_paragraph: RETURN OF THE MEGA-MERGER | Mega-mergers are back. Mergers worth $100 billion, made on Monday, put Wall Street on pace for a year of deal-making rivaling those during the dot-com bubble and the private equity upsurge just before the financial crisis, DealBook’s David Gelles writes. The announcement of two mega-deals ‒ Actavis’s $66 billion acquisition of the Botox maker Allergan and Halliburton’s $34.6 billion takeover of the oil field services firm Baker Hughes ‒ made Monday a symbolic tipping point, Mr. Gelles writes. With those transactions, about $1.5 trillion in deals targeting United States companies have been announced this year, the most since 2000, according to Thomson Reuters.

headline: Solange Knowles, Amal Clooney and the Return of the Wedding Trousseau
abstract: Just one stunning wedding gown isn’t enough for today’s bride.
lead_paragraph: Solange Knowles’s much-ballyhooed wedding on Sunday heralded the advent of what will probably be numerous fashion trends: capes, all-white bridesmaid ensembles and so on. But the one that I think may really take hold is the return of the wedding trousseau. No longer is one great bridal dress enough. Now a major nuptial event demands many.

headline: Rome Opera’s Management and Musicians Agree to End Standoff
abstract: The agreement, which the opera said would save 3 million euros a year, will keep the musicians on staff in exchange for pay cuts and a pledge not to go on strike.
lead_paragraph: Backing away from its proposal to fire 182 musicians and hire them back as freelancers, the management of the Rome Opera announced on Tuesday that it had reached an agreement with the musicians that would keep them on staff in exchange for pay cuts and a pledge not to go on strike.

headline: Daily Clip Report
abstract: Daily Clip Report is a collection of articles about the media and The Times that is emailed each day to senior executives and newsroom managers here.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

headline: We Are Penn State
abstract: At a bronze statue of Joe Paterno, the former Penn State football coach, a critic and fans spar over his legacy.
lead_paragraph: At a bronze statue of Joe Paterno, the former Penn State football coach, a critic and fans spar over his legacy.

headline: In Performance: Alysha Umphress of ‘On the Town’
abstract: Ms. Umphress and the pianist Brett Rowe perform the number “I Can Cook, Too” from the Broadway revival of the 1944 musical.
lead_paragraph: This week’s video features the actress Alysha Umphress and the pianist Brett Rowe performing the number “I Can Cook, Too” from the Broadway revival of “On the Town,” the 1944 musical with music by Leonard Bernstein, and book and lyrics by Betty Comden and Adolph Green. In this jazzy song, Hildy (Ms. Umphress), a New York City cab driver, boasts to a sailor about her prowess in the, um, kitchen. “My gravy will lose you your mind,” she sings. The show, directed by John Rando, is at the Lyric Theater.

headline: Brooklyn, Planet Earth
abstract: It’s not news that we write a lot about Brooklyn, but we now seem to be using the borough as the measuring stick or point of comparison for everywhere.
lead_paragraph: What’s next? Describing Manaus as the Williamsburg of the Amazon? Katmandu as the Cobble Hill of Nepal?

headline: ‘We Are Penn State’
abstract: At a bronze statue of Joe Paterno, the former Penn State football coach, a critic and fans spar over his legacy.
lead_paragraph: On July 12, 2012, the former F.B.I. director, Louis Freeh, issued a report on the Penn State child sex abuse scandal that pinned blame on much more than a football team: University leadership, the town itself and, most controversially, Penn State’s legendary football coach, Joe Paterno, were all implicated. That morning, we were at Penn State filming our feature documentary about the scandal, “Happy Valley.”

headline: Home Depot Posts a Strong 3rd Quarter Despite a Data Breach Disclosure
abstract: The home improvement retailer, the target of a cyberattack affecting as many as 56 million customers, beat analysts’ expectations with $1.5 billion in net earnings.
lead_paragraph: Home Depot, the country’s largest home-improvement retailer, booked robust gains in sales and profit in its third quarter, as a brightening economic picture spurred more people to buy homes and renovate them.

headline: A City Girl Confronts Country Silence
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: On a summer vacation, Michigan at night proved eerily quiet to a teenager who had grown up near Queens Boulevard.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: The Daily Gift: Margiela’s Luxe Leather Bookmark
abstract: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.
lead_paragraph: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.

headline: A Deadly Attack in Israel
abstract: Four people died in a bloody assault on a synagogue in West Jerusalem on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Four people died in a bloody assault on a synagogue in West Jerusalem on Tuesday.

headline: Asia Pushes Hard for Clean Energy
abstract: More than $250 billion a year will pour into renewable energy generation, two-thirds of Asia’s power investment, but the use of fossil fuels is also growing.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Even as China’s economy begins to cool, its hunger for energy is still climbing.

headline: Goodell Bars Peterson for Rest of Season and Says He Could Miss Games in 2015
abstract: N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell said that the earliest Adrian Peterson could be reinstated was April 15 and that it would hinge, in part, on his willingness to take part in counseling.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. has suspended Adrian Peterson, the Minnesota Vikings’ star running back, for at least the remainder of the season without pay, the league announced Tuesday, two weeks after he pleaded no contest to hitting his child.

headline: Should You Pack Your Child’s Lunch?
abstract: New research shows school lunches can actually be healthier than the ones kids bring from home.
lead_paragraph: We often hear that making meals at home is the healthiest way to eat (so often, in fact, that there’s been a backlash). But new research suggests that lunches at school cafeterias may actually be healthier than the ones parents pack for their kids. And the results may have larger implications for how families eat.

headline: It’s a Light Green Lifestyle
abstract: Jen Boulden was a serial start-up entrepreneur before founding Ideal Bite, a green-lifestyle email subscription service sold four years later to Disney. She now runs JenB TV.
lead_paragraph: Jen Boulden was a serial start-up entrepreneur before she decided to go back to school for a master’s degree in  environmental policy and management at George Washington University, in 2004. That same year, she co-founded a daily green-lifestyle email subscription service, Ideal Bite, sold four years later to Disney with 318,000 daily subscribers, for $20 million. Ms. Boulden remained with the venture, overseeing its growth to more than 500,000 daily subscribers until Disney shut it down in 2010. She then started JenB TV, a green lifestyle website on which she posts  advice weekly.

headline: Emissions Loophole Stays Open in E.U.
abstract: The decision followed fears that companies facing high costs of compliance and competitive pressures would move their polluting operations elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — The European Union agreed last month to keep open until 2030 a loophole allowing some of its biggest atmospheric polluters to avoid bearing an increasing share of the costs of cutting global-warming emissions.

headline: Growing Coral to Keep a Sea Claim Above Water
abstract: Two tiny uninhabited islets in the Pacific are at the forefront of Japanese research into coral reefs and of Tokyo’s claim to a vast economic zone.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Amid warnings that rising sea levels caused by global warming could lead to the disappearance of some entire island states, two tiny uninhabited islets in the Pacific are at the forefront of Japanese research into the preservation and regeneration of coral reefs.

headline: Attack on Jerusalem Synagogue
abstract: Four people were killed while worshiping in a synagogue in an ultra-Orthodox neighborhood in West Jerusalem on Tuesday. Police said the two Palestinian attackers were killed.
lead_paragraph: Four people were killed while worshiping in a synagogue in an ultra-Orthodox neighborhood in West Jerusalem on Tuesday. Police said the two Palestinian attackers were killed.

headline: Indonesia’s Central Bank Raises Benchmark Interest Rate as Gas Prices Jump
abstract: The new president’s first major policy move prompted an immediate response from Bank Indonesia to fend off an expected spike in inflation.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Responding to the first major policy move of Indonesia’s new president, which sent gasoline prices up 30 percent on Tuesday, the country’s central bank held an unscheduled meeting and increased its benchmark interest rate in an effort to combat inflation.

headline: Holding Back the Sahara
abstract: Overgrazing and climate change are the major causes of the desert’s advance. Eleven countries are planting trees in a 4,400-mile long belt to fend off its encroachment.
lead_paragraph: WIDOU THIENGOLY, Senegal — Old people in Widou Thiengoly say they can remember when there were so many trees that you couldn’t see the sky.

headline: The Circular Economy of Recycled Paper
abstract: By cutting down on waste, and using recycled and alternative fibers, a Dutch mill has put a new face on an industry often linked to deforestation.
lead_paragraph: ROERMOND, The Netherlands — Three times a week, tanker trucks make an hourlong journey from a baby-food factory in Nunspeet, in the central Netherlands, to a paper mill in the southeastern city of Roermond.

headline: How Has the Social Role of Poetry Changed Since Shelley?
abstract: Adam Kirsch and Leslie Jamison discuss how the role of poetry has changed since Shelley called poets the “unacknowledged legislators of the world.”
lead_paragraph: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. Shelley once called poets the “unacknowledged legislators of the world.” This week, Adam Kirsch and Leslie Jamison discuss how the social role of poetry has changed since then.

headline: As Sharpton Rose, So Did His Unpaid Taxes
abstract: The Rev. Al Sharpton, who has been honored by Mayor Bill de Blasio and President Obama, has regularly sidestepped taxes, rent and other bills.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Al Sharpton, who came to prominence as an imposing figure in a track suit, shouting indignantly at the powerful, stood quietly on a stage last month at the Four Seasons restaurant, his now slender frame wrapped in a finely tailored suit, as men in power lined up to exclaim their admiration for him.

headline: In 2019 World Track Championships, Qatar Adds Second Sports Jewel
abstract: The tiny Persian Gulf nation, also the site for soccer’s World Cup in 2022, will host the event in Doha, which was picked ahead of Barcelona, Spain, and Eugene, Ore.
lead_paragraph: The tiny, wealthy Persian Gulf nation Qatar was awarded another major global sporting event Tuesday as track and field’s world governing body shrugged off recent controversy and chose Doha as the host city of the 2019 world championships.

headline: Democrats, by Acclamation, Retain Pelosi as Leader
abstract: House Democrats have reelected Representative Nancy Pelosi to minority leader post.
lead_paragraph: House Democrats on Tuesday elected Representative Nancy Pelosi of California to serve as minority leader for another two years.

headline: Chris Algieri, a Boxer from Long Island, Says He’s Set for Manny Pacquiao
abstract: Algieri, a 30-year-old former kickboxer who once pondered retirement, will face Pacquiao, the holder of multiple world titles, on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Chris Algieri’s rise from unknown boxer to a champion worthy of fighting the superstar Manny Pacquiao on Saturday in Macau began when he saw another boxer beaten nearly to death.

headline: 1939: Veterans Miss Fox Hunts
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: 1939: Veterans Miss Fox Hunts and other sports at the front.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — This war does not measure up to the last one from the sportsman’s point of view, in the opinion of British veterans who are again serving at the front.

headline: The Floating Gardens of Bangladesh
abstract: Farms — with a duck coop, fish enclosures and a vegetable farm moored to the riverbank — are helping Bangladeshis live with rising waters.
lead_paragraph: CHARBHANGURA, Bangladesh — Each year the brown waters of the Gumani river swell during the summer monsoon, creeping over the surrounding fields to flood Charbhangura, a village of 2,500 people in the Pabna district of northwest Bangladesh.

headline: Abu Dhabi Energy Company Aims for Solar-Powered Travel
abstract: The Solar Impulse experimental flight program is one of a slew of international projects in which Masdar, a renewable energy company, has invested.
lead_paragraph: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates — Masdar, Abu Dhabi’s renewable energy company, is hosting the first attempt at a round-the-world flight by a solar-powered aircraft, due to start from the emirate in March.

headline: Japanese Premier Calls for Elections
abstract: Shinzo Abe, the Japanese prime minister, called for early elections to seek a new mandate on his economic policies after data showed the country falling into recession.
lead_paragraph: Shinzo Abe, the Japanese prime minister, called for early elections to seek a new mandate on his economic policies after data showed the country falling into recession.

headline: First Draft Focus: Say Freeze!
abstract: It was a morning of smiles and shivers as freshman House members stood in below-freezing temperatures for their class photo outside the Capitol on Tuesday.

headline: French Doggie Bags? The Backstory
abstract: Aurelien Breeden looked into a campaign, aimed at curbing food waste, that encourages the French to take home their leftovers. But can the doggie bag shake the stigma and catch on?
lead_paragraph: The doggie bag is coming to France. Aurelien Breeden looked into a campaign, aimed at curbing food waste, that encourages the French to take home their leftovers. For the French, who rarely ask to carry out food that they haven’t finished (though they may ask to take home an unfinished bottle of wine), the doggie bag is associated with being cheap. Can it shake the stigma and catch on? Mr. Breeden thinks it may be too soon to tell.

headline: Debbie Harry to Sing at Café Carlyle
abstract: The Café Carlyle lineup includes Debbie Harry, the Blondie singer, among others.
lead_paragraph: It’s not your grandfather’s cabaret series. The lineup announced Tuesday by the Café Carlyle includes short residencies by several singers whose recordings once climbed the rock, R&B and pop charts, including Debbie Harry, best known as the singer of the punk-era band Blondie following in the footsteps of the New York Dolls frontman, David Johansen (in his Buster Poindexter persona), who sang at the Carlyle in October.

headline: In Immigration Fight, Republicans Explore Alternatives to a Shutdown
abstract: A number of Republicans say the government should be kept open even as their party fights President Obama’s immigration plan.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Americans for Prosperity, a group founded by the billionaire Koch brothers, has held informal conversations with Republican lawmakers on Capitol Hill in recent weeks, cautioning them against fighting President Obama’s promised executive order on immigration with a strategy that could lead to a government shutdown.

headline: Man Charged With Fatal Shoving of New York Subway Rider
abstract: Kevin Darden, 34, charged with murder after Wai Kuen Kwok, 61, was shoved into the path of a train on Sunday, was also a suspect in a Nov. 6 shoving episode.
lead_paragraph: A man was charged late Tuesday in the fatal shoving of a subway rider in the Bronx after he was taken into custody earlier in the day in a separate assault at a Manhattan subway station this month, the police said.

headline: Hey Guys, the Russians Aren’t Buying Pabst After All
abstract: There is no longer need to man the hipster barricades. A report that a Russian brewer had acquired the Pabst Brewing Company turned out to be erroneous.
lead_paragraph: Remember in September when it was announced that Oasis Beverages had acquired the Pabst Brewing Company? Well, it turns out that never happened.

headline: Ariel Pink on Gender-Bending, His Aversion to Suits and the Pleasures of Red Clogs
abstract: The eccentric Los Angeles-based singer-songwriter discusses his bewilderment at other people’s grooming routines, accidentally inventing “throwback hipster chic” and why he wears a Bart Simpson T-shirt to the airport.
lead_paragraph: Ariel Pink, the famously unfiltered L.A.-based purveyor of eccentric, ironic indie pop, has been in rare form of late. Advance tracks from his new record, “Pom Pom,” which came out yesterday on 4AD, have been well received, as have his live shows, two ingenious Grant Singer-directed music videos and a visit to Staten Island’s pint-size PS22 Chorus. But Pink has also managed to upset feminists, Eurythmics fans and supporters of late-period Madonna (including Grimes), thanks to choice remarks in interviews. If there’s no such thing as bad publicity, then “Pom Pom” is the album of the year.

headline: To McConnell, It’s the ‘Cassidy’ Keystone Bill
abstract: Mitch McConnell, the Republican leader of the Senate, does not want Democrats to claim all the credit if a bill to build the Keystone XL oil pipeline moves forward.
lead_paragraph: Mitch McConnell, the Republican leader of the Senate, does not want Democrats to claim all the credit if a bill to build the Keystone XL oil pipeline moves forward.

headline: ‘He’s Gone.’ A Daddy, Deployed
abstract: In this moment, just after their father has been deployed, I can’t safeguard their hearts; I am unable to spare these tears. It’s a powerless feeling, before the sun is up.
lead_paragraph: The distinct pitter-patter of her 3-year-old feet on our weathered hardwood floor awakens me. The sun is still hidden from the horizon, and any other morning I would pull her into my bed in the dark silence, with the intention of us both catching a little more sleep. Instead, today she looks at the empty pillow next to me, and with heavy sadness in her eyes, only offers, “He’s gone.” Two little words for one little girl — half statement, half question — hoping the outcome has changed overnight, from a month at sea to just a normal day at work.

headline: Shutdown Politics Makes Some Republicans Wary
abstract: Republicans fear that talk of another government shutdown could backfire.
lead_paragraph: Republican leaders have made clear that “all options” are on the table when it comes to deterring President Obama from using his executive powers for an immigration overhaul.

headline: Andrew M. Cuomo’s ‘All Things Possible’
abstract: From New York to Washington and back, Andrew M. Cuomo reflects on his life’s defining moments.
lead_paragraph: The origins of Andrew M. Cuomo’s new political memoir are as revealing as anything contained within its pages. In 2012, 16 successful months into the governor’s first term, an Albany columnist for The New York Post set out to write a Cuomo biography, and Cuomo agreed to cooperate. But his relationship with The Post subsequently soured, and last year he announced he would be writing his own book — for the same publisher, which has since backed away from the first book.

headline: Pier A Harbor House Opens Downtown
abstract: Peter Poulakakos has turned an imposing historic site into a restaurant with decks overlooking New York Harbor.
lead_paragraph: Headliner

headline: 1964: Italy Ousts Two U.A.R. Envoys
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Diplomats were expelled from Rome in 1964.
lead_paragraph: ROME — The Italian government today [Nov. 18] expelled two United Arab Republic diplomats caught trying to ship a bound, drugged prisoner to Cairo in a trunk labeled ‘‘diplomatic mail.’’ Italian police said the crated man, 28-year-old Josef Dahan, had worked as a spy first for the U.A.R. government and later for Israel. They said that Mr. Dahan, a Moroccan-born linguist, was an Israeli citizen. [In Jerusalem, police said Mr. Dahan is an Israeli defector with a criminal record. They said his real name was Mordecai ben Masuud Louk and that he had defected to Egypt in 1961. They denied that he had ever spied for Israel. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Nov. 19, 1964

headline: Landrieu Calls Ad for Her Challenger Sexist and Ageist
abstract: The days of dirty campaign ads might seem like ages ago, but election season remain in full swing in Louisiana.
lead_paragraph: With the midterm election two weeks in the rearview mirror, it may seem that the time for pointed campaign ads has passed. But election season remains in full swing in Louisiana, where Senator Mary L. Landrieu is making a final push to keep her seat in a December runoff.

headline: Collecting Debts on Dubious  Foreclosures
abstract: Some borrowers who lost their homes in the bust are now being hounded for debts related to foreclosures that were based on unlawful robo-signed documents.
lead_paragraph: In early 2012, when five big banks settled with government officials over foreclosure abuses in the housing bust, the settlement sum, $26 billion, was actually a small price for the banks to pay. It was small compared to the economic damage from the banks’ reckless lending and abusive foreclosures. And it was small compared to what the banks got in return.

headline: U.S. Agencies Review Policy on Hostages
abstract: The review includes how the government deals with hostage’s relatives, but a prohibition on paying ransom is not being reconsidered.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration confirmed on Tuesday that it was reviewing its policy on securing the release of United States citizens taken hostage abroad, but that the ban on paying ransom would not change.

headline: Two Approaches on Expiring Tax Breaks
abstract: How the Senate and the House have been addressing nearly 60 tax breaks and other rules that are set to expire at the end of the year.
lead_paragraph: How the Senate and the House have been addressing nearly 60 tax breaks and other rules that are set to expire at the end of the year.

headline: Heart Drug, Losartan, Falls Short of Promise in a Study
abstract: The new study found there was no difference in the aortic growth rate between those taking losartan and those taking the standard treatment.
lead_paragraph: The idea seemed compelling: A blood pressure drug was found to block the effects of a gene mutation that causes Marfan syndrome, a condition that leads to terrible heart problems. The drug worked in mice with a gene that causes Marfan, doing just what everyone hoped it would do. A pilot study with 17 children showed the drug seemed to work in them, too, although there was no group that, for comparison, did not get the drug.

headline: Carl Sanders, 89, Dies; Led Georgia in ’60s
abstract: In his single term as governor, Mr. Sanders cautiously navigated the racial turmoil of the time, promoting Georgia as a region of relative calm amid the storms of the South.
lead_paragraph: Carl E. Sanders, who as a young Democratic governor of Georgia in the mid-1960s helped spur Atlanta’s growth while taking what for a white politician in the South were progressive stances on race and segregation, earning him a reputation as an early leader of the “New South,” died on Sunday in Atlanta. He was 89.

headline: Time Runs Out for ‘Rock of Ages’
abstract: The Broadway jukebox musical “Rock of Ages” will close Jan. 18, its producers said.
lead_paragraph: “Rock of Ages,” the jukebox musical that was built on guitar-driven 1980s hair-band hits and that became a long-running Broadway hit, will play its final performance on Jan. 18, its producers announced Tuesday. The show will by then have played 2,328 Broadway performances (and 22 previews), first at the Brooks Atkinson Theater, where it opened in 2009, and then at the Helen Hayes Theater, to which it transferred in 2011.

headline: It’s Crunch Time in Congress for Tax Breaks
abstract: With only a few days left in the legislative session, Congress will decide whether to renew 56 tax provisions set to expire.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Georgia Aquarium is hardly a showcase in Atlanta urban renewal. The largest marine exhibit in the United States sits near the World of Coca-Cola museum, CNN headquarters, the city’s lavish sports stadiums and its famed Centennial Olympic Park — an area more playground than poverty-stricken.

headline: Sony Executive Is Cautious as Music Streaming Grows
abstract: Kevin Kelleher, the chief financial officer of Sony Music Entertainment, said Taylor Swift’s feud with Spotify has raised questions about the value of free music.
lead_paragraph: Taylor Swift’s feud with Spotify continues to reverberate throughout the music industry, with a top Sony executive questioning the value of free music as streaming services grow around the world.

headline: President Named for Lucas Museum in Chicago
abstract: Leaving one populist museum in Bentonville, Ark., for another in Chicago.
lead_paragraph: Headed from one kind of American-themed, billionaire-founded museum to another, Don Bacigalupi, president of the Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art in Bentonville, Ark., will become the founding president of the museum that the director George Lucas is planning for Chicago’s lakefront.

headline: First Draft Focus: From the Heart
abstract: A briefing book for the White House chief of staff, Denis R. McDonough, had a note from one of his children attached to it as he sat in a meeting on  Ebola in the White House on Tuesday.

headline: Michael Gennaro Will Head Goodspeed Musicals
abstract: Mr. Gennaro, currently the executive director at Trinity Repertory Theater, will succeed Michael Price.
lead_paragraph: For 46 years, Goodspeed Musicals has been synonymous with Michael Price, who is known for keeping a vintage barber chair in his office and standing at the foot of the grand staircase at the end of performances to personally greet departing patrons after musicals like “Little Johnny Jones,” “Going Up” and “Annie” – which originated there.

headline: Organic Farms Become a Winner in Putin’s Feud With the West
abstract: With often cheaper imports unavailable, some agricultural activists hope to see a boost in local farming, but for consumers the self-imposed sanctions have so far served mostly to raise food prices.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Boris Akimov’s cellphone, which quacks like a duck, started to sound like a whole flock soon after President Vladimir V. Putin imposed sweeping food sanctions barring many Western imports last August.

headline: The Flaws in Valeant’s Activist Deal Effort
abstract: The drug maker has tried a seven-month M.&A. experiment that corporate chiefs should think twice about repeating, say Richard Beales and Robert Cyran of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Valeant Pharmaceuticals has tried a seven-month M.&A. experiment that its boss, J. Michael Pearson – and other corporate chiefs – should think twice about repeating.

headline: Today in Small Business: ‘Unrealistic Value Expectations’
abstract: A “beloved cookbook destination” loses its lease. A start-up that claims better search technology for real estate agents raises $6 million. Is celebrity-branded marijuana coming?
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Model Railroad Builders Win Auction, but Must Raise Money to Pay the Tab
abstract: Forced to put four model railroads up for sale, including a set that once attracted millions in Manhattan, Clarke and Barbara Dunham now hope to raise enough to cover the purchase.
lead_paragraph: POTTERSVILLE, N.Y. — You could forgive Clarke Dunham if the events of the last few months have him feeling as if he were a character in a Frank Capra movie — special dispensation, naturally, accorded to anyone who calls Pottersville home.

headline: Thanksgiving Recipes Across the United States
abstract: We’ve scoured the nation for recipes that evoke each of the 50 states (and D.C. and Puerto Rico). These are our picks for the feast. Dig in, then tell us yours.
lead_paragraph: We’ve scoured the nation for recipes that evoke each of the 50 states (and D.C. and Puerto Rico). These are our picks for the feast. Dig in, then tell us yours.

headline: Bill to Restrict N.S.A. Data Collection Blocked in Vote by Senate Republicans
abstract: Democrats and a handful of Republicans who supported the measure failed to secure the 60 votes they needed to take up the legislation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Republicans on Tuesday blocked a sweeping overhaul of the once-secret National Security Agency program that collects records of Americans’ phone calls in bulk.

headline: Key Republican Votes to Watch on N.S.A. Overhaul
abstract: Backers of the proposed National Security Agency overhaul are working to line up Republican supporters to break the 60-vote threshold.
lead_paragraph: As the Senate heads toward an important procedural vote this evening on a proposed National Security Agency overhaul, backers of the measure are working to line up Republican supporters to break the 60-vote threshold.

headline: Voter ID Laws Scrutinized for Impact on Midterms
abstract: After an Election Day that featured a wave of new voting restrictions, the results are being picked over to see if the rules swayed any outcomes.
lead_paragraph: In North Carolina, early voting was cut by seven days. In Kansas, 22,000 people were stopped from registering to vote because they lacked proof of citizenship. And in Texas, Democrats say the country’s toughest voter ID law contributed to a one-term congressman’s losing a tight race to his Republican rival.

headline: Uber Attacks the Press
abstract: A senior vice president said the company intended to dig up dirt on reporters.
lead_paragraph: Success appears to have bred arrogance and vindictiveness at Uber. That is the only conclusion to draw from the news that a senior executive at the company said it planned to uncover and spread personal information about journalists who wrote critical articles.

headline: The Structure of Obamacare
abstract: It’s been clear and open all along.
lead_paragraph: The big revelation of this week has been how many political pundits have spent six years of the Obama administration opining furiously about the administration’s signature policy without making the slightest effort to understand how it works. They’re amazed and in denial at the suggestion that it has the same structure as Romneycare, which has been obvious and explicit all along; they are shocked, shocked to learn that it uses the mandate as an alternative to taxing and spending, which has always been completely obvious and open.

headline: Thanksgiving Office Hours: Ask All Your Questions
abstract: Sam Sifton, Eric Asimov and Melissa Clark are answering your Thanksgiving cooking questions on Monday at 1 p.m. Eastern time, on The New York Times Facebook page.
lead_paragraph: The phones are ringing here in our offices, our email servers straining, our social-media accounts pinging or going beep: panicky readers, spouses, cousins, sources, friends. Can you buy parsley in Telluride on Thanksgiving morning? A family of five just invited themselves to dinner, and we’re up to 22 for the meal — can we say no? Do you have a recipe for venison, since my sister just got her first buck and wants me to cook some for the feast? How can we help others while celebrating our own bounty? Should we play music during the meal? What wines should we drink? And how do you make kuchen, anyway?

headline: Shubert Organization Taking Over New World Stages
abstract: The Shubert Organization, which owns 17 of Broadway’s 40 theaters, completes a deal to take over New World Stages, an Off Broadway complex with five small theaters.
lead_paragraph: The Shubert Organization, which owns 17 of Broadway’s 40 theaters, has completed a deal to take over New World Stages, the Off Broadway complex with five small theaters that could now become home to Shubert-related projects, leaders of the organization announced Tuesday. The terms were not disclosed, but theater executives familiar with the negotiations said that acquiring the lease from its current holder, the European producer Stage Entertainment, was a seven-figure deal. The current productions at New World Stages will continue to run.

headline: Philadelphia Casino Project Adds to Frenzy in Northeast Gambling Market
abstract: The rush to build casinos is only intensifying in the region, which is widely regarded as the most competitive market in the country despite flat or falling gambling revenues.
lead_paragraph: A $425 million project with a casino and a boutique hotel rising in the stadium district of Philadelphia is the latest entrant into the tumultuous world of East Coast gambling.

headline: The Editor’s Daughter, Tempered by Homelessness, Picks Up Her Pen
abstract: Hermione Lee’s biography “Penelope Fitzgerald: A Life” paints Fitzgerald, who died in 2000, as a complicated human being who battled through difficult times to begin her career as an author when she was in her late 50s.
lead_paragraph: The English writer Penelope Fitzgerald (1916-2000) didn’t publish her first book until she was nearly 60 and wasn’t much noticed, at least in the United States, until she was in her 80s. Many found her easy to overlook and easy to condescend to. She tended to comport herself, as Julian Barnes, an admirer of her novels, put it, like “some harmless, jam-making grandmother who scarcely knew her way in the world.”

headline: India Isolates Ebola Survivor at an Airport
abstract: The man was successfully treated in Liberia, and blood tests after he flew home were negative, but signs of the virus were found lingering in his semen.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — A 26-year-old Indian man who recovered from Ebola was being held at a quarantine facility at the New Delhi airport as a cautionary measure after his semen tested positive for the virus, health officials announced Tuesday.

headline: Vamo Start-Up Simplifies Booking of Complex Trips
abstract: The start-up, whose name plays off of vámonos, Spanish for “let’s go,” is designed to be a marriage of the convenience of Web travel booking with the insight of a travel agent.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — If you want to fly to Paris or London for a few days, online travel booking sites like Expedia, Orbitz and others have that down pat. The process gets a little more ungainly when a traveler is planning a more complicated trip and wants to know how adding and subtracting destinations will affect price.

headline: Choosing Fast and Cheap Over High-End Chic in Yokohama, Japan
abstract: In a land of Michelin-starred restaurants, sampling “B-grade gourmet.”
lead_paragraph: It was breakfast time in Yokohama Station, a half-hour by train from Tokyo, and I was having some of the best soba noodles of my life. The chewy buckwheat strands were sublime, the broth deeply savory and piping hot. A fresh-cracked egg floated on top, its yolk a gorgeous sunrise orange.

headline: Arguing the Church
abstract: In conversation with Father James Martin, and some related thoughts on intra-Catholic disputes.
lead_paragraph: At America Magazine today, there’s a very long dialogue between myself and Father James Martin of the Society of Jesus, the prolific author and commentator, that jumps off from my recent, perhaps-slightly-controversial column on Pope Francis and the situation within the Roman Catholic Church. I’m very grateful to Father Martin and the editors at America for putting the conversation together, and hopefully our dialogue will be interesting to readers, even if we did not exactly resolve every intra-Catholic division across our 6,000-odd words of back and forth.

headline: From the Makers of AnonyWatch™, Introducing … The Monocle Meter™
abstract: Accepting reader contributions for fake trends and sheer silliness in the paper of record.
lead_paragraph: Ever since I wrote a column early this year about a Times story reporting a supposed monocle trend,  people have been sending me their candidates for other stories that deserve a similar shout-out. This goes beyond trends to any Times story whose premise may be dubious or whose qualities of self-parody — intentional or otherwise — induce a certain level of eye rolling.

headline: Viber Messages for the World to See
abstract: Viber built its name on private messaging and phone calls. But the four-year-old start-up now plans to try something different: letting users share their chats with the world at large.
lead_paragraph: Viber built its name — and the foundation for its $900 million takeover by the Japanese retailing giant Rakuten this year — on private messaging and phone calls.

headline: In the Hippie Stronghold of Ojai, Calif., a New Design Store for Modern Bohemians
abstract: In the Field brings emerging designers and contemporary furniture to the picturesque hamlet 90 miles north of L.A.
lead_paragraph: If there’s a single object that symbolizes the state of things in Ojai, California, it may be the handcrafted, eco-sensitive children’s tepee for sale at In the Field, a new boutique which opened this past weekend. In this picturesque city of 8,000, mindfulness is a long-standing way of life, not a fresh buzzword. But with a growing stream of full- and part-time denizens migrating 90 miles northward from Los Angeles, Ojai’s cultural atmosphere is also becoming more design-conscious. The latest signal of this shift is the self-described “lifestyle” store that the actor and interior designer Channon Roe and his wife, the former Ford model and actress Bianca, opened this past Saturday.

headline: Deal Tips From Buffett and Berkshire’s Other Managers
abstract: Much like their leader, Warren Buffett, the chief executives of Berkshire Hathaway’s subsidiaries are a savvy group of acquirers. Lawrence A. Cunningham, in the Another View column, explains why.
lead_paragraph: Lawrence A. Cunningham, a professor of business law at George Washington University and a former deal lawyer at Cravath, Swaine & Moore, has written numerous business books including, most recently, “Berkshire Beyond Buffett: The Enduring Value of Values.” This post is excerpted from that book.

headline: Former Controller of Medical Nonprofit Is Charged With Embezzling $1.8 Million
abstract: Karen Alameddine, who oversaw the financial affairs of the Hereditary Disease Foundation, was accused of diverting money for her personal use.
lead_paragraph: A former official of the Hereditary Disease Foundation, a New York-based nonprofit group that supports research into genetic illness, has been charged with embezzling more than $1.8 million of the organization’s funds and using the money for personal expenses.

headline: FIFA Turns Over Report on World Cup Bidding to Swiss
abstract: FIFA’s president filed the complaint with Switzerland’s attorney general on the recommendation of the judge who heads the organization’s ethics committee.
lead_paragraph: Days after declaring that its investigation into the bidding for soccer’s 2018 and 2022 World Cups had not found any evidence pointing to a corruption of that process, FIFA announced on Tuesday that it was turning over the report from the inquiry to the Swiss authorities because it suspected that its investigators had uncovered criminal activity.

headline: It’s Best Not to Make Him Angry
abstract: Christopher Marlowe’s “Tamburlaine, Parts I and II,” at the Polonsky Shakespeare Center, makes no apologies for its bloody conquering hero.
lead_paragraph: The mass-murdering title character of Christopher Marlowe’s “Tamburlaine,” a man proud to call himself “the scourge of God,” has never been big on apologies. Not for him the regretful introspection of short-tempered Shakespearean tyrants like Macbeth, Lear or even nasty old Richard III.

headline: Jerusalem Synagogue Victim Descended From Storied Dynasty of Hasidic World
abstract: Rabbi Moshe Twersky was the grandson of a Hasidic grand rabbi who settled in the United States decades before the end of World War II.
lead_paragraph: Rabbi Moshe Twersky, one of the four men killed on Tuesday at a Jerusalem synagogue, was a descendant of one of the oldest Hasidic dynasties of Europe — the Twerskys.

headline: WhatsApp Adds Android Encryption
abstract: The popular messaging platform is getting more secure with technology from Open Whisper Systems.
lead_paragraph: Facebook’s WhatsApp, the popular messaging app, is getting a security upgrade. WhatsApp messages on Android phones are now encrypted all the way through the transmission process and on their own servers using respected, open-source encryption techniques developed by Open Whisper Systems.

headline: Keystone Pipeline Pros, Cons and Steps to a Final Decision
abstract: What is the pipeline, what would it do, who wants to build it and why is it the subject of so much debate?
lead_paragraph: Q. What is the Keystone XL pipeline?

headline: Regulators Warn Against Reimbursing Employees for Health Premiums
abstract: Even now, however, the issues remain complex and open to interpretation.
lead_paragraph: Since the implementation of the Affordable Care Act, many small businesses have been intrigued by the possibility that they might be able to stop dealing with health insurance entirely and instead offer their employees a stipend to go buy insurance on the individual exchanges. But in a clarification issued in early November, the federal government appears to have taken a stand against that strategy.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
