lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: How Much Did Health Insurance Rates Go Up? It’s Complicated
abstract: Here’s our guide to various ways of analyzing the new numbers on Affordable Care Act premiums.
lead_paragraph: Americans could find the new insurance rates for the Affordable Care Act in online marketplaces last week. Prices of many plans went up. But just how much depends on how you measured them.

headline: Goldman Sachs Dismisses Trader Linked to Currency Inquiry
abstract: Frank Cahill’s chats from his time at HSBC were cited by British regulators in announcing settlements with banks last week, according to a person briefed on the matter.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Goldman Sachs has dismissed a currency trader because of his ties to an inquiry into potential manipulation of benchmark currency rates, a person briefed on the matter said on Tuesday.

headline: Mets Bring In Fences, Again
abstract: Citi Field renovation No. 2, unveiled on Tuesday and limited to right-center field, should give a boost to hitters like David Wright, Lucas Duda and Curtis Granderson.
lead_paragraph: Baseball’s “Moneyball” era has brought drastic changes in how managers handle their pitching staffs and where they position players on the field. Armed with newly revealing statistical analysis, scouts assess players differently, and fans view the game differently.

headline: Iraqi Troops Seen Inside Besieged Oil Refinery
abstract: The televised scenes of triumphant Iraqi troops appeared to confirm reports that Islamic State militants had been driven from the Baiji refinery in northern Iraq.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Iraqi state television on Tuesday displayed images of triumphant soldiers inside the Baiji refinery, the first confirmation of many previous reports that government forces had broken a siege by the extremists who call themselves the Islamic State.

headline: S.E.C.’s Delay on Crowdfunding May Just Save It
abstract: While the S.E.C. dawdles, states are rushing to adopt their own crowdfunding rules, Steven Davidoff Solomon writes in the Deal Professor column.
lead_paragraph: While the Securities and Exchange Commission dawdles, states are rushing to adopt their own crowdfunding rules. Ironically, it may just be the thing that rescues crowdfunding from a regulatory death grip.

headline: Vegetarian Thanksgiving: Vegan Mac N Cheez
abstract: Vegan diners and people who can’t tolerate dairy will enjoy this creamy, velvety version of macaroni and cheese — without the dairy.
lead_paragraph: Macaroni and cheese casserole is a great standby for a holiday table that includes picky eaters, particularly children. But it is not an option for children who can’t tolerate foods with dairy.

headline: A Chilling New Music Video From an Up-and-Coming Electronic Artist
abstract: The unsettling visual for the Irish artist Talos’s song “Bloom” was directed by Brendan Canty and Conal Thomson of Feel Good Lost, who also helmed Hozier’s “Take Me to Church” video.
lead_paragraph: “Bloom” is only the second track the 27-year-old Cork, Ireland, native Eoin French has released under his Talos moniker, but its taut, chilling complexity belies his newcomer status. “The song is essentially about change and how we’re all, in a weird way, kind of terrified of it,” French says, “and the idea of someone changing and morphing into something a lot darker.”

headline: After a Slow Start, the Rodgers Show Hits Its Stride
abstract: Green Bay (7-3) leads the N.F.L. in points scored, courtesy of 276 points over the last seven games, and Aaron Rodgers is a leading candidate for most valuable player.
lead_paragraph: When an athlete is having an excellent season, it is common for the home fans to break into chants of “M.V.P.” from time to time. This year, in Green Bay, a five-letter cheer may be more appropriate.

headline: In Hong Kong, One-Bedroom Apartments That Could Fit in a Bedroom
abstract: As property costs in the city continue to soar, even once improbable living spaces — such as so-called microflats — are getting snapped up at astronomical prices.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — There are breathtaking views of Victoria Harbor from a 23rd-floor apartment that recently sold for $722,000 in the new Le Riviera building. The high-end German appliances and marble countertops evoke European luxury. In the entrance of the building, colorful wire mesh sculptures by Spanish artists hang from the ceiling.

headline: Landrieu Argues for Keystone Pipeline
abstract: Senator Mary Landrieu, Democrat of Louisiana, urges the Senate to pass the Keystone bill by arguing that it will provide energy independence for the country.
lead_paragraph: Senator Mary Landrieu, Democrat of Louisiana, urges the Senate to pass the Keystone bill by arguing that it will provide energy independence for the country.

headline: Texas ID Law Keeps Hundreds of Ballots From Being Counted
abstract: Provisional ballots cast by nearly 500 voters in Texas on Nov. 4 never became official — part of the fallout from the state’s tough voter ID law
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON – Provisional ballots cast by hundreds of voters in Texas on Nov. 4 never became official in the days after the election, part of the little-noticed fallout from the state’s tough voter ID law.

headline: Colombian Forces Search for General Seized by Rebels
abstract: The rebel group issued a statement from the site of the negotiations calling the general and two others seized with him “enemy military personnel.”
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — Government troops and airplanes scoured northwestern Colombia searching for Gen. Rubén Darío Alzate on Tuesday, as his capture by guerrillas over the weekend threatened to upend peace talks meant to end a 50-year insurgency.

headline: In Test for Premier, Italians Rally Against Plan to Relax Labor Rules
abstract: A tentative plan by Prime Minister Matteo Renzi that could roll back some worker protections has drawn tens of thousands to the streets.
lead_paragraph: ROME — In Naples, demonstrators blocked traffic. In Padua, Pisa and Milan, they clashed with the police. Here, they lobbed eggs at government buildings and climbed to the top of the Colosseum to unfurl a protest banner.

headline: AT&T and Starbucks Bring Wireless Phone Chargers to Some Coffee Shops
abstract: Wireless power charging has been around for years, but most people do not use it. AT&T and Starbucks are teaming up to try to make wireless charging more popular.
lead_paragraph: Wireless device charging has been around for years, but most people still stick with old-fashioned cords. Now AT&T and Starbucks are teaming up to try to make this power technology more popular in the mainstream.

headline: In Beverly Hills, Three Sisters Open a New One-Stop Beauty Spot
abstract: Jenn, Kristie and Ashley Streicher share their favorite spots to eat, shop, work out and glam up in their new neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: It’s often been said that Los Angeles is a youth-obsessed kind of place, which may be why the city’s hair and makeup experts are sometimes celebrities in their own right. Among this talented pack are the California-born Streicher sisters, who are something of a beauty triumvirate in town, each skilled in a different craft. There’s the older sister Jenn, a makeup artist for regulars like Emily Blunt and Claire Danes. Then there’s the middle sibling Kristie, who first trained as a makeup artist but rose to stardom with her signature “feathered brow” (and counts an NYC flagship in addition to her L.A. outpost). And the hairstylist Ashley, the baby of the bunch, who rumples and tousles the manes of the Hollywood set, including Elijah Wood and Hailee Steinfeld.

headline: United Nations Urges North Korea Prosecutions
abstract: The vote by a General Assembly committee came nine months after a panel of inquiry said North Korean leaders could be held criminally responsible.
lead_paragraph: United Nations members voted decisively on Tuesday for a groundbreaking resolution that condemns North Korea for human rights abuses and for the first time recommends the prosecution of its leaders for crimes against humanity at the International Criminal Court.

headline: In Switzerland, Charlie Chaplin in Focus
abstract: A promotion at the the Beau-Rivage Palace in Lausanne, Switzerland, coincides with a museum exhibit about the actor Charlie Chaplin.
lead_paragraph: The English actor Charlie Chaplin was a regular guest at the Beau-Rivage Palace in Lausanne, Switzerland, in the Lake Geneva region, and now the 168-room property has a “City Lights Package” to coincide with the “Chaplin, Between War and Peace” exhibition at the nearby Musée de l’Elysée.

headline: Verbatim: The Right Impression
abstract: Josh Earnest, the White House press secretary, said the president does not support and would veto any Keystone XL pipeline bill.
lead_paragraph: – Josh Earnest, the White House press secretary, when asked if President Obama was leaving open the option of not vetoing Keystone XL pipeline legislation if it comes to his desk.

headline: Death Without Regrets
abstract: When my physician told me in 1999 that I would live somewhere between 1 and 20 years, I quit my job and resolved to live my life as fully as I could.
lead_paragraph: I think that few of us consider the impact of our daily activities on the final accounting anyone might render at the time of our death. Because I have had cancer for more than 15 years now, I have had a lot of time to think about this.

headline: Restaurant Report: The Lost Kitchen in Freedom, Me.
abstract: The menu at this small-town spot changes daily and reflects the freshest ingredients from the surrounding area.
lead_paragraph: We drove right by Freedom, in central Maine, past grazing bulls and empty chicken houses, before realizing our mistake and finally locating the aptly named restaurant the Lost Kitchen.

headline: Bank of Tokyo Fined for ‘Misleading’ New York Regulator on Iran
abstract: More than a year after paying a steep penalty for doing business with Iran, one of the world’s biggest banks is back in regulators’ cross hairs.
lead_paragraph: More than a year after paying a steep penalty for doing business with Iran, one of the world’s biggest banks is back in regulators’ cross hairs.

headline: My Three Sons and All Their Troubles
abstract: In “Straight White Men,” personal issues come to the surface when a widower and his three sons gather for the holidays.
lead_paragraph: They bestride the world, or at least the West, like colossi. Thronging the halls of Congress and, until just recently, the Oval Office. Running giant corporations. Meeting and greeting at powwows in Switzerland. I speak of the species known as the straight white male, the most unoppressed of the world’s peoples. They are feared, envied, occasionally attacked and derided. But pitied? Not so much.

headline: California Paper Asks Its Employees to Produce, Then Deliver, the News
abstract: Facing difficulties with distribution, The Orange County Register has asked its workers to help out, especially on Sunday and Thanksgiving morning.
lead_paragraph: As financial troubles continue to plague the newspaper industry, some companies are coming up with new ways to trim their year-end costs. At The Orange County Register, it involves some old-fashioned shoe leather.

headline: Senate Defeats Bill on Keystone XL Pipeline in Narrow Vote
abstract: Senator Mary L. Landrieu, Democrat of Louisiana, had hoped to get the legislation through in advance of her uphill runoff election fight back home.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Democrats, by a single vote, stopped legislation that would have approved construction of the Keystone XL pipeline, one of the most fractious and expensive battles of the Obama presidency.

headline: De Blasio Dumps Rachel Noerdlinger, Accuses the Press of McCarthyism
abstract: The mayor said the press had smeared his wife’s chief of staff for political purposes.
lead_paragraph: “Something’s gone wrong here,” said Mayor Bill de Blasio on Monday, in impromptu remarks about the departure of Rachel Noerdlinger, chief of staff to his wife, Chirlane McCray.

headline: Missouri Governor Announces Members of Ferguson Commission
abstract: Gov. Jay Nixon named members of the Ferguson Commission to address the unrest after the shooting of an unarmed black teenager by a white police officer.
lead_paragraph: An African-American pastor and a white civic leader will lead a state-appointed Ferguson Commission that will work toward “healing and positive change” in the St. Louis area, Gov. Jay Nixon of Missouri announced  Tuesday.

headline: Wheelies: The Runaway Fusion Edition
abstract: Ford recalls 65,000 Fusion sedans for a software problem that can cause roll-aways; Consumer Reports issues a warning about counterfeit Chinese tires.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Koolhaas-Designed Miami Beach Arts Center to Open Next Year
abstract: Called Faena Forum, the 50,000-square-foot institution, at 32nd Street and Collins Avenue, will be dedicated to the development of cultural programming.
lead_paragraph: A new Miami Beach arts center designed by Rem Koolhaas is to open in December 2015, its founder, Alan Faena, is set to announce.

headline: A Carbon Tax Could Bolster Green Energy
abstract: Despite technological innovations, investment in alternative power generation is lagging. But one tool could trim carbon emissions on a meaningful scale.
lead_paragraph: A couple of years ago, the smart money was on wind. In 2012, 13 gigawatts worth of wind-powered electricity generation capacity was installed in the United States, enough to meet the needs of roughly three million homes. That was some 40 percent of all the capacity added to the nation’s power grid that year, up from seven gigawatts added in 2011 and just over five in 2010.

headline: Neighbors Mourn Harlem Squatter, Known Widely but Not Well
abstract: Seemingly everyone who passed a lot on Park Avenue and 126th Street knew Baruba I. Dahomey, who lived there in a trailer, but nobody really knew him.
lead_paragraph: Outside the cluttered lot, the flicker of candles said something mournful had happened. Neighbors and others who regularly walked past realized that Baruba had died.

headline: Mickalene Thomas Creates a Wine Label
abstract: The artist repurposed her joyous, colorful collage portrait “Untitled #3,” from her recent exhibition “Tête de Femme,” for a new collaboration with Bedell Cellars.
lead_paragraph: Michael Lynne, the former CEO of New Line Cinema, is a longtime art collector and supporter; as an entertainment lawyer in the 1970s and ’80s, he represented artists like Julian Schnabel and Jean Michel Basquiat in exchange for some of the works they were creating. Today, he is both the owner of the North Fork, Long Island, winery Bedell Cellars and a Museum of Modern Art trustee — which is how, at a MoMA party in May, he found himself seated next to his friend, the artist Mickalene Thomas, whose work he also collects. “They were actually serving his wine,” Thomas remembers, “and the bottles had Barbara Krugers on them, and Eric Fischls.” Bedell’s long-running series of artist collaborations has also featured works by Chuck Close, Ross Bleckner, April Gornik and Howard Schatz. Tapping Thomas to contribute a label was a natural next step — and an uncomplicated one. “He just sort of asked if I would be interested, and I said sure, it’d be fun,” Thomas says. “It was just one of the easiest projects to do.”

headline: Does Ahab Now Need an Icebreaker?
abstract: On PBS, “Invasion of the Killer Whales” and “Killer Landslides” examine nature in flux.
lead_paragraph: From the episode titles on Wednesday, it might seem like theme night on PBS, and, in a way, it is. “Nature” has an episode called “Invasion of the Killer Whales,” and right afterward in many markets, “Nova” has one titled “Killer Landslides.”

headline: The Racist Origins of Felon Disenfranchisement
abstract: Laws that stripped felons of the vote were designed to target African-Americans.
lead_paragraph: The state laws that barred nearly six million people with felony convictions from voting in the midterm elections this month date from the late 19th and early 20th centuries, when Southern lawmakers were working feverishly to neutralize the black electorate.

headline: When Is a Chocolate Shortage a Good Thing?
abstract: There may be less chocolate to go around and more people going for it, but there is a silver lining.
lead_paragraph: Milk chocolate, dark chocolate — or not enough chocolate?

headline: Rodrigo Niño
abstract: Mr. Niño, founder and chief executive of Prodigy Network, a real estate developer that specializes in crowdfunding for its real estate projects.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Niño, 45, is founder and chief executive of Prodigy Network, a developer that specializes in crowdfunding. Its projects include three extended-stay hotel condominiums, two in partnership with Korman Communities.

headline: Fantasy Football: Week 12 Waiver Wire Picks
abstract: Since the fantasy football playoffs are just two weeks away for many leagues, the wires are quite barren in the majority of leagues.
lead_paragraph: An early happy holidays to those of you who have been hanging onto Browns receiver Josh Gordon for 11 weeks.

headline: If Either Halliburton or Baker Hughes Call Off Deal, It Would Be Costly
abstract: In a filing on Tuesday, Baker Hughes laid out how much it and its would-be buyer would have to pay in case the deal collapses.
lead_paragraph: If the proposed takeover of Baker Hughes by Halliburton falls apart, it will cost at least one of the companies dearly.

headline: De Blasio’s Approval Rating Wanes, but Is Still Solid, Quinnipiac Poll Finds
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio received the support of 49 percent of New Yorkers, with a sharp racial divide over his performance.
lead_paragraph: Nearing the end of his first year in office, Mayor Bill de Blasio is receiving waning, if still fairly robust, support from New Yorkers, with a sharp racial divide over his performance, according to a poll released on Tuesday.

headline: Contrite Over Failed Urban Renewal, Washington D.C. Refreshes a Waterfront
abstract: The Wharf, a new development on the Potomac waterfront in the southwest quadrant of the city, is an effort to shed the area’s urban renewal image.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Potomac waterfront in the southwest quadrant of the nation’s capital was once a symbol of urban renewal’s high hopes and then of its crushing failure. It is undergoing a significant redevelopment that promises to remake the little-used mile-long stretch along the river’s Washington Channel into a vibrant, mixed-use community.

headline: Senate Panel to Look Into MoneyPak Prepaid Scams
abstract: Phone scams involving reloadable prepaid debit card products will be the subject of a Senate committee hearing on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Phone scams involving reloadable prepaid debit card products like the popular MoneyPak card will be the subject of a Senate committee hearing on Wednesday.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Peter Eavis, Graham Bowley and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Peter Eavis, Graham Bowley and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Fans May Like Home Runs, but They Love a Winner
abstract: On Tuesday, Mets General Manager Sandy Alderson unveiled the pitching-rich team’s latest attempt to win more games than it loses: It moved in the right-center-field fence.
lead_paragraph: In movable outfield walls the Mets trust.

headline: A Dream Piano, Played by a Dreaming Pianist
abstract: Aaron Parks opened a new jazz series, Jazzhaus at Klavierhaus, with piano standards and improvisation.
lead_paragraph: Aaron Parks took a moment, during the homestretch of an hourlong solo piano performance in Midtown on Monday night, to acknowledge the inward turn of his state of mind. “I’m just up here kind of dreaming,” he said, with an obliging half-grin. It wasn’t an apology; it didn’t feel like a disclaimer. Mr. Parks, working within his usual radius of essential poise, was simply checking in, making sure that he was being understood.

headline: Netanyahu and Abbas Condemn Attacks
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority denounced Palestinian attacks at a synagogue in West Jerusalem that killed four people.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority denounced Palestinian attacks at a synagogue in West Jerusalem that killed four people.

headline: The New Republic at 100: A Century of Bickering
abstract: With the magazine celebrating its 100th anniversary, a former Yahoo News executive was hired for the top of the masthead, setting off speculation about a new direction.
lead_paragraph: The New Republic will celebrate its 100th birthday on Wednesday with a black-tie gala in Washington featuring remarks by Bill Clinton and Ruth Bader Ginsburg, a performance by Wynton Marsalis and a 400-person guest list studded with boldface names.

headline: U.S. Regulators Call for Takata Airbag Recall to Be Extended Nationwide
abstract: Facing growing criticism, a federal agency moved to widen a safety recall that has been limited to a few areas associated with high humidity.
lead_paragraph: In a significant shift, federal safety regulators on Tuesday called on automakers to conduct a nationwide recall of vehicles that contain driver’s-side airbags made by the Japanese supplier Takata.

headline: American Ballet Theater and Segerstrom Center in California to Open Ballet School
abstract: American Ballet Theater and the Segerstrom Center for the Arts in Costa Mesa, Calif., will open the American Ballet Theater William J. Gillespie School on the Segerstrom campus in September, both organizations announced on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: American Ballet Theater and the Segerstrom Center for the Arts in Costa Mesa, Calif., will open the American Ballet Theater William J. Gillespie School on the Segerstrom campus in September, both organizations announced on Tuesday. The school, which will be open to students ages 3 to 14, is named after William J. Gillespie, an Orange County resident who has been on Ballet Theater’s board since 1999. Alaine Haubert, a former dancer and ballet mistress with Ballet Theater, has been appointed principal of the school.

headline: $2.6 Billion to Develop a Drug? New Estimate Makes Questionable Assumptions
abstract: Tufts Center for the Study of Drug Development released a figure. But there are many reasons to be skeptical of this estimate.
lead_paragraph: The Tufts Center for the Study of Drug Development has just released its newest estimate for the cost to develop and bring a drug to market. At $2.6 billion, this figure is bound to get a lot of attention. We should take this announcement with a grain of salt, however. While it is no doubt expensive to create a drug, such announcements have come under attack before, often with good reason.

headline: Father Prevails, Halting the Donation of His Brain-Dead Daughter’s Organs
abstract: Health law says that the parents of Thaiya Spruill-Smith have an equal say in what happens to her organs, and because they disagree, donation will not occur.
lead_paragraph: The fight over the fate of a 2-year-old Brooklyn girl’s organs ended on Tuesday, with the girl’s father prevailing in his wishes to keep her body intact.

headline: A Power Struggle, Roots and All
abstract: In “Bad Hair,” a Venezuelan boy’s ideas about his appearance add to his mother’s troubles.
lead_paragraph: In a quietly transfixing scene from the Venezuelan director Mariana Rondón’s “Bad Hair,” the camera gazes through the eyes of a 9-year-old, Junior (Samuel Lange), as he and a playmate (María Emilia Sulbarán) survey the teeming Caracas housing development across the street and make up stories about its residents. What they see in a giant building that resembles a dingy, crumbling factory is a social microcosm of the impoverished Venezuelan capital, where the threat of violence hangs in the air.

headline: Forest City Ratner Buys Out Partner in Brooklyn Residential Tower
abstract: The 32-story building will be part of the developer’s Pacific Park project, but construction may not resume for weeks.
lead_paragraph: The battle over one of the slowest moving residential towers in New York City’s history is over.

headline: Tarnished Halos at Penn State
abstract: Joe Paterno, college football and the world of State College, Pa., home to Penn State, are examined in “Happy Valley,” a documentary built around the Jerry Sandusky child abuse case.
lead_paragraph: The people on screen in “Happy Valley,” Amir Bar-Lev’s powerful new documentary, frequently describe Penn State football as a religion. This is almost not a metaphor. The film pays periodic visits to a large outdoor mural in State College, Pa., where Nittany Lion luminaries are depicted as if they were figures in an Italian Renaissance tableau of biblical luminaries. At one point, a halo is painted in over the head of Joe Paterno, the former Penn State head football coach who died in 2012, a few months after being fired from the position he had held for 46 seasons. Mr. Bar-Lev’s interview subjects sometimes describe Paterno as a god or a saint, and he is almost universally recalled as a beloved and benevolent patriarch.

headline: All Together Now: Smile
abstract: & Other Stories, a much-anticipated spinoff of the Swedish chain H­&­M, opens in SoHo.
lead_paragraph: “IF IT MAKES YOU feel happy, do it,” advises a notecard mounted on a shelf of succulents by the Broadway entrance of & Other Stories, a much-anticipated spinoff of the Swedish chain H & M that arrived last month next to the big Prada mother ship. (R.I.P., Guggenheim SoHo.)

headline: Keystone Vote Unlikely to Change Odds for Mary Landrieu
abstract: Even a successful vote on the pipeline would have been too little too late to help the Louisiana Democrat’s re-election bid.
lead_paragraph: It is not much exaggeration to suggest that there’s one real reason that the Senate voted on whether to advance the Keystone pipeline: Senator Mary L. Landrieu.

headline: Stars Attend ‘The Imitation Game’ Premiere in New York
abstract: Keira Knightley, Benedict Cumberbatch and other actors host the New York premiere and after party.
lead_paragraph: Keira Knightley, Benedict Cumberbatch and other actors host the New York premiere and after party.

headline: Beyond the Stereotyped South
abstract: Tamara Reynolds looks at the American South as a native, going beyond the obvious to capture the region’s spirit.
lead_paragraph: Tamara Reynolds looks at the American South as a native, going beyond the obvious to capture the region’s spirit.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Israel and Elsewhere
abstract: Israel and More — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: Israel and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Nov. 18, 2014 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Israel, Syria, Mombasa and Iran.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Israel, Syria, Mombasa and Iran.

headline: Live ‘Side Show’ Simulcast Wasn’t Live After All
abstract: Producers of the musical substituted a previously recorded video clip.
lead_paragraph: A bid to make Broadway history by broadcasting a scene from the opening night performance of the musical “Side Show” live in Times Square didn’t come off as planned, though the crowd that gathered to watch in the rain may not have known what they were missing at all.

headline: House Democrats Keep Leaders After Losses
abstract: Representative Nancy Pelosi was re-elected as the party’s leader in the chamber, despite quiet dissent among some representatives.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Democrats, after bruising midterm election losses, opted on Tuesday to stick with their current party leaders.

headline: Fanfare for the Common Man (and a Band)
abstract: “Pulp: A Film About Life, Death & Supermarkets” is a documentary that returns to Sheffield, England, hometown of that alternative rock band, which had its heyday in the 1990s.
lead_paragraph: There was a time in the 1990s in Britain when everyone seemed to be singing Pulp songs. Kitchen sink stories of awkward lust and washing dishes, of inept sex and inevitable aging, they left lewd, lingering images of blue collar yearning. As written by Jarvis Cocker, a founder of the group and its gyrating frontman, the music at its best evoked Chris Difford and Glenn Tilbrook’s work for Squeeze, whose 1979 hit “Up the Junction” remains a tiny miracle of songwriting.

headline: In Turkey, the Arts Flourish, but Warily
abstract: As Istanbul attempts to stake its claim as a global art capital, artists say they are increasingly subject to state pressure or intervention by the Turkish government.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — At a glittering dinner on an island in the Bosporus here last week, Ali Gureli, the chairman of Contemporary Istanbul, the city’s annual art fair, told hundreds of international collectors, gallery owners and artists that Istanbul had secured its place as a global art capital.

headline: ClassDojo Adopts Deletion Policy for Student Data
abstract: The maker of ClassDojo, a popular classroom app, said that starting in January it plans to keep students’ behavioral records for only one school year.
lead_paragraph: The maker of ClassDojo, a popular behavioral tracking app used in schools across the United States, announced revisions on Tuesday in the way it retains student information.

headline: Stylistically Diverse, but United by One Soul
abstract: John Adams selected five works by four composers for the season’s opening concert of the Contact! series, presented on Monday at SubCulture.
lead_paragraph: For the composer John Adams, hosting the New York Philharmonic’s Contact! program at SubCulture in the East Village on Monday night must have felt like getting back to basics in contemporary music. Two days earlier, the Metropolitan Opera had presented the final performance of Mr. Adams’s opera “The Death of Klinghoffer,” which at the start of its run drew hundreds of protesters angry over this ruminative work’s attempt to grapple with a brutal terrorist act. The last performance played to a sold-out house; Mr. Adams and the cast received a prolonged ovation.

headline: Applying to College: Race to the Summit
abstract: The application dartboard: Readers, including a college admission officer and parents, respond to a front-page article.

headline: Alabama Takes Top Spot in the College Football Playoff Rankings
abstract: The Crimson Tide, who defeated previously undefeated Mississippi State on Saturday, were ranked first by the committee, followed by Oregon, Florida State and the Bulldogs.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday night, when it released its fourth set of rankings, the College Football Playoff’s 12-member selection committee told the five major conferences how it really felt about them.

headline: K.K.R. and Clayton, Dubilier & Rice Said to Plan Joint Bid for PetSmart
abstract: Three months after PetSmart put itself up for sale, private equity firms are preparing a joint bid, a person briefed on the matter said.
lead_paragraph: Three months after formally putting itself up for sale, PetSmart appears to have drawn takeover interest from at least two private equity firms.

headline: Please Address Me as ‘Dr.’ or ‘Professor’
abstract: Margaret Betz, a philosophy professor, responds to a Sunday Review article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Storm Over Jonathan Gruber’s ‘Stupidity’ Remark
abstract: Readers discuss the health economist’s reference to the “stupidity of the American voter.”

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
abstract: Notable properties that have been recently listed for sale, sold or leased.
lead_paragraph: RECENT SALE

headline: A Sustainable Solution for the Corn Belt
abstract: A creative new approach to Midwestern agriculture, involving indigenous prairie plants, has the potential to unite farmers and environmentalists.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to imagine maintaining the current food system without Iowa. Yet that state — symbolic of both the unparalleled richness of our continent’s agricultural potential and the mess we’ve made of it — has undergone a transformation almost as profound as the land on which cities have been built. A state that was once 85 percent prairie is now 85 percent cultivated, most of that in row crops of corn and soybeans. And that isn’t sustainable, no matter how you define that divisive word.

headline: How Medical Care Is Being Corrupted
abstract: Doctors have to choose between themselves and their patients.
lead_paragraph: WHEN we are patients, we want our doctors to make recommendations that are in our best interests as individuals. As physicians, we strive to do the same for our patients.

headline: In Overhaul, Pizza Hut Tries Adventurous Menu Offerings and a Dash of Irreverence
abstract: America’s largest pizza seller is confronting sagging sales by overhauling its 56-year-old brand with revamped recipes, a new catchphrase and a series of cheeky television spots.
lead_paragraph: MUCH is at stake as Pizza Hut begins on Wednesday what executives are calling the biggest campaign in its 56-year history, promoting changes in just about every aspect of its identity: products, packaging, logos, color palettes, uniforms and websites.

headline: In Sales of Luxuries, Geography Matters
abstract: A market research firm also discovered that those who bought luxury goods often spent a disproportionate amount of their income on them.
lead_paragraph: Luxury automakers from Audi to Mercedes-Benz reported record sales last year. Their vehicles made up more than one million of the 16 million sold in the United States in 2013, adding to the millions of older luxury vehicles already speeding along America’s highways.

headline: The Thrill of the Hunt for Discount Prices
abstract: Why don’t aggregators compare prices of retail items like clothing? Because neither retailers nor shoppers really want them to.
lead_paragraph: The Internet can tell us how long it takes to walk the length of the Great Wall of China (10 months), how many girlfriends George Clooney has had (lots) and even how many snowflakes fall in a year (about a septillion). But consumers still can’t quickly and easily compare prices for a leather purse (big enough to tote a laptop, please) or a 10-quart aluminum stockpot.

headline: Judge Declines to Drop Felony Charges in 1 World Trade Center Jump
abstract: Three men who parachuted from the 1,776-foot tower showed a “callous disregard” for the community’s safety, a State Supreme Court judge said.
lead_paragraph: Three sky divers who parachuted off 1 World Trade Center moved a step closer to trial on Tuesday as a judge declined to throw out felony charges against them, saying they had shown a “callous disregard” for the safety of the community.

headline: An Encounter Along Sherman’s March
abstract: Family lore and the divided legacies of the March to the Sea.
lead_paragraph: My great-grandfather John Langhans enlisted in September 1864, joined the 154th New York Volunteer Infantry in Atlanta, and made the subsequent marches through Georgia and the Carolinas under Maj. Gen. William T. Sherman. He went on to live another 60 years, but when he died, the headline of his obituary identified marching with Sherman as the central event of his life.

headline: Player Ratings: Ireland (4) vs. United States (1)
abstract: Player ratings from the United States national team’s 4-1 loss to Ireland in Dublin on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: On a cold night in Dublin, the United States national team suffered its worst second half collapse in years and ended its 2014 schedule on the wrong end of a 4-1 rout by Ireland in an exhibition match on Tuesday night.

headline: New YouTube Music Plan Faces Challenge
abstract: Irving Azoff has asked YouTube to remove from its music plan thousands of songs by the Eagles, John Lennon and other songwriters associated with Mr. Azoff’s new music publishing venture.
lead_paragraph: YouTube unveiled its long-awaited subscription music plan last week, giving the music industry a potentially big new source of revenue.

headline: The Case for Black With a Capital B
abstract: It’s not just a color — it’s the identity of a people.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — I WAS sitting in my office at Temple University when I overheard an exchange between a colleague and his student. The student had come to see her professor to go over a paper, and he was patiently explaining that the abundance of grammatical mistakes detracted from her compelling content. I sympathized with my colleague as he pointed out error after error. Until he came to this one.

headline: From Profits to Politics
abstract: Americans soured on government are giving a different breed of leaders a chance.
lead_paragraph: Just two years ago, during his first term at the helm of Colorado, John Hickenlooper did a quick mental survey of his fellow governors and realized something that he found surprising.

headline: Did Dubai Do It?
abstract: On a visit to Dubai, several conversations pondered whether the crown jewel of the United Arab Emirates caused the Arab awakening.
lead_paragraph: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates — Ever since the Arab awakening in late 2010, America has lurched from one policy response to another. We tried decapitation without invasion in Libya; it failed. We tried abdication in Syria; it failed. We tried democratization in Egypt, endorsing the election of the Muslim Brotherhood; it failed. We tried invasion, occupation, abdication and now re-intervention in Iraq and, although the jury is still out, only a fool would be optimistic.

headline: In a City Wary of Skyscrapers, a New Tower May Rise
abstract: Plans for a 42-story landmark in a somewhat undistinguished part of Paris have raised the alarm for traditionalists who have not approved a new skyscraper in four decades.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The last skyscraper built in Paris opened in 1973, an unadorned dark block, rising 59 stories — the Montparnasse Tower. It was considered a disaster. To this day, Parisians joke that the tower offers the best views in the city, because it is the only place from which you cannot see it. City officials went to work banning future skyscrapers altogether.

headline: Norwegian Filmmakers Apologize for Fake Syria Video
abstract: A short film, shot in the style of witness video from Syria and posted on YouTube, provoked a torrent of criticism.
lead_paragraph: Norwegian filmmakers apologized on Tuesday for planting fake video of the war in Syria on YouTube last week, and removed the original footage following a torrent of criticism from journalists and rights advocates who said such deceptions undermine their efforts to document real abuses.

headline: Executive’s Aggressive Push to Revamp ‘Today’ Prompts His Dismissal
abstract: Jamie Horowitz was almost immediately at odds with the very managers at NBC News who hired him, according to one senior NBC executive.
lead_paragraph: The top executive at NBC’s “Today” show who was fired on Monday after just 10 weeks on the job alienated key decision-makers at NBC News by pushing too hard and too quickly for potential changes on the show, especially among the prominent, on-air names, according to senior executives with knowledge of his departure.

headline: Horror in Jerusalem
abstract: The murder in West Jerusalem of four men at prayer, including three rabbis, is a tragedy for all Israelis and Palestinians.
lead_paragraph: There is no comprehending the murder of four men, including three rabbis, at a synagogue complex in a neighborhood of West Jerusalem on Tuesday.

headline: Jewish Victims, All From One Jerusalem Street, Were a Congregation’s ‘Wise Scholars’
abstract: Four Jewish men killed Tuesday while praying at their neighborhood synagogue all lived on the same block, and three were rabbis — one the scion of a celebrated Hasidic dynasty.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The car crawled slowly through the streets of Har Nof, a loudspeaker on its roof, broadcasting psalms and announcing the funeral at 2 p.m. of Rabbi Moshe Twersky, one of four Jewish men killed at prayer on Tuesday morning when two Palestinians armed with a gun and butcher knives stormed a neighborhood synagogue complex.

headline: Europe’s Central Bank Defies Its Own Rules in Cyprus Bailout
abstract: The European Central Bank proposed that Cyprus inflate the value of Cyprus Popular Bank’s collateral, so the E.C.B. might funnel more emergency loans, email indicates.
lead_paragraph: In July 2012, a top official at the European Central Bank emailed the head of the central bank of Cyprus with some advice on how to keep the country’s second-largest financial institution from failing.

headline: The Anatomy of the General Motors Recall Coverage
abstract: Assembling the tale of G.M.’s faulty ignition switch, which led to the deaths of at least 13 people, took months of digging by a team of reporters and editors.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, auto safety regulators called for vehicles with airbags made by Takata, a Japanese supplier, to be recalled nationwide. Earlier this year, General Motors also announced huge recalls; in February it began recalling 2.6 million cars because of a defective ignition switch. Later, Times reporters revealed that the company had misled families who had lost loved ones because of the faulty vehicles. Bob Goetz, assistant editor for the Business desk, describes the all-hands-on-deck approach to presenting the monthslong story on the greater impact of auto recalls.

headline: De Niro and New York Town End Fight Over Property Taxes
abstract: Representatives of the actor Robert De Niro and the town of Gardiner, N.Y., came to an agreement over the assessed value of his 98-acre property and taxes due.
lead_paragraph: Unlike most of Robert De Niro’s work, this drama has a happy ending.

headline: Anti-E.U. Party in Britain Strives for Wider Clout
abstract: Even as it stands a good chance to win a second seat in Parliament, the U.K. Independence Party has lost the support of its founder, who deplores it as xenophobic.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Last month the brash, populist U.K. Independence Party won its first seat in Parliament, capitalizing on resentment against immigration, disenchantment with the European Union and a general disaffection with politicians.

headline: Manhattan’s D.A. Addresses a National Problem
abstract: Cyrus Vance Jr. said that once New York State is completely current, he will pay to help other cities reduce their large backlogs of untested rape kits.
lead_paragraph: Manhattan’s district attorney, Cyrus Vance Jr., made a public commitment last week to use $35 million in civil forfeiture assets he controls to help other jurisdictions reduce their large backlogs of untested rape kits.

headline: Long-in-the-Tooth Dental Advice
abstract: Many people over age 65 lack dental insurance, a benefit that isn’t covered by traditional Medicare, and those eligible for Medicaid have limited coverage, depending on where they live.
lead_paragraph: Terry O’Brien, 73, a retired administrative assistant in Billerica, Mass., recently had to make a tough decision about her dental care.

headline: A Citizen’s Guide to Buying Political Access
abstract: Precisely how much money it takes to gain access is up for debate, but even politicians themselves have admitted that big donors get special treatment.
lead_paragraph: David G. Herro, a well-known money manager in Chicago, has given more than $2 million to political campaigns and causes over the last seven years. So perhaps it is not too surprising that a United States senator and other prominent politicians have dropped by his offices just to chat.

headline: Profiles in Online Identity Cleansing
abstract: Privacy and anonymity are featured on new social apps, and many websites now offer services that help protect or erase personal information.
lead_paragraph: When a stranger knocked on her door three years ago, Susan Manion decided to do more to protect her private information. As a musician in Northern Illinois, she was used to people getting in touch. But her work had started to draw unwanted attention.

headline: Finding a Retirement Haven to Suit You
abstract: When choosing a place to live, retirees should consider whether a community reflects their values, and if it can meet their social and health care needs.
lead_paragraph: More than 10 years ago, Barbara Zierten and her husband retired to a small town in California’s scenic “gold country,” in the Sierra Nevada foothills.

headline: Science (and Quacks) vs. the Aging Process
abstract: Researchers are optimistic about recent efforts to delay the effects of aging and, perhaps, extend life spans.
lead_paragraph: For thousands of years, people have sought to escape or outrun their mortality with potions, pills and elixirs, often blended with heavy doses of hope and will.

headline: The True Cost of ‘Daddy, Can I Have a Pony?’
abstract: Those considering equine ownership need to take into account not only the purchase price, but also upkeep, insurance, veterinary bills and entry fees.
lead_paragraph: In third grade, Amanda Ferrara persuaded her parents to let her take horse-riding lessons. She had always loved animals, and her parents, Bronx born but living in a rural part of Westchester County, N.Y., agreed. Nine years later, her family owns one horse and leases two more.

headline: Adrift, but Anchoring to Each Other
abstract: A couple struggling through a difficult financial period find it hard to talk honestly with each other about their situation.
lead_paragraph: On July 30 — the day before our son’s eighth birthday — my husband arrived home early from his office with some unwelcome news: The ad agency he worked for had decided to cut costs and eliminate his position.

headline: Congress Must Act on War Authority
abstract: Though the U.S. is fighting ISIS in Iraq and Syria, our elected leaders continue to shirk their constitutional responsibility.
lead_paragraph: The United States is fighting a new and costly war in Iraq and Syria. Yet, for months, members of Congress have ducked their constitutional responsibility for warmaking. They have neither initiated a meaningful debate on the use of American force against the Islamic State, which is known as ISIS, nor shown any inclination to vote on whether to endorse or modify the mission.

headline: Constitutional Limits of Presidential Action on Immigration
abstract: Does the president have the power to decide whether to exempt millions of unauthorized immigrants from deportation and other enforcement action?

headline: The Under-the-Tray-Table Upgrade
abstract: As airlines expand first-class service and crowd coach passengers into tighter spaces, a reporter tries bribing airline and airport employees, as well as passengers, to get an upgrade.
lead_paragraph: Flying is not what it used to be. What was once glamorous now feels like walking through a mall to get to a cattle chute. Airlines are expanding first class and squeezing coach passengers into tighter quarters. Every spare inch of space and every service from bag-checking to expedited security has a price.

headline: In Compromise Plan, Limited Fracking Is Approved for National Forest in Virginia
abstract: Ninety percent of the George Washington National Forest will be closed to hydraulic fracturing and conventional oil and gas drilling.
lead_paragraph: Drilling for oil and natural gas will be mostly off-limits in the largest national forest in the East, whose streams bring drinking water to Washington and Richmond, Va., the federal government said Tuesday.

headline: Defective Takata Airbag Grows Into Global Problem for Manufacturer
abstract: What began as a largely American problem for Takata is taking on widening proportions, involving drivers and regulators in multiple countries.
lead_paragraph: SIBU, Malaysia — Law Suk Leh, late in her pregnancy, was driving in the industrial outskirts of this steamy riverside city when her 2003 Honda City collided with a turning car.

headline: Vatican’s New Tone Gains a Voice in Chicago as Blase Cupich Becomes Archbishop
abstract: Blase J. Cupich of Chicago took his seat as archbishop in the nation’s third-largest Catholic archdiocese, part of the pope’s effort to reshape church leadership.
lead_paragraph: In Pope Francis’ most significant move yet to reshape the leadership of the Roman Catholic Church in the United States, Blase J. Cupich took his seat in Chicago on Tuesday as archbishop of the nation’s third-largest Catholic archdiocese and called on the church not to be afraid of change.

headline: In Jerusalem’s ‘War of Neighbors,’ the Differences Are Not Negotiable
abstract: Many worry that the cycle of violence may be worsened by the growing focus on a holy site that Jews and Muslims both revere.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Amid the condemnations from all corners of Tuesday’s deadly attack at a Jerusalem synagogue, there were also disturbing signs of celebration. A cartoon of a bloody meat cleaver like the one used in the attack that killed four Orthodox Jews circulated on social media. Residents of the Gaza Strip paraded in the streets singing victory songs, giving out candy, waving flags.

headline: Following Her Mother’s Example, in Addiction and Then in Sobriety
abstract: When Nicole Gurley took her first dose of heroin, at 15, her mother was already a drug addict. With help, both got sober, and meaningful jobs.
lead_paragraph: Nicole Gurley followed her mother’s path; first to her detriment and later to her salvation. Both women are former drug addicts who can now jointly celebrate their sobriety.

headline: U.N. Urges Arab World to Denounce Islamic State
abstract: The United Nations’ top human rights official on Tuesday called on the Security Council to back efforts to overturn the extremist group’s “ideology of violence.”
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The United Nations’ top human rights official called on the Muslim world to denounce the “monstrous” crimes of the extremist group that seeks to establish an Islamic state in Iraq and Syria, calling its actions both a violation of international law and Islamic tenets.

headline: Cyprus Government Report Points Fingers on Bank Collapse
abstract: “The Cyprus Popular Bank was insolvent before the haircut of the Greek bonds. After the haircut, the bank had little chance to survive,” the 40-page study concludes.
lead_paragraph: How can a midsize bank torpedo an entire economy?

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 18, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Uber, a Start-Up Going So Fast It Could Miss a Turn
abstract: The company is facing its toughest challenge yet — curbing its ugliest, most aggressive impulses before its win-at-all-cost culture begins to turn off investors, potential employees and the public.
lead_paragraph: In just four years of operation, Uber has ignited a new global ride-sharing industry with the promise of transforming urban transportation and helping many people get by without owning cars.

headline: Opposition to N.F.L. Settlement Centers on Coverage for Neurological Disease
abstract: A federal judge will begin hearing arguments for and against the proposed deal on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: During his nine-year career as an N.F.L. linebacker, Jesse Solomon was a solid contributor, a 12th-round draft pick who rarely missed games despite numerous injuries. After 116 games with five teams, he retired in 1995 after a quadriceps tendon separated from his kneecap.

headline: Republicans Sure Love to Hate Unions
abstract: The 2014 election was a major defeat for labor, but the question of who will represent the interests of economically struggling voters is still open.
lead_paragraph: A paradox of American politics is that Republicans take organized labor more seriously than Democrats do.

headline: Bucks, Young and Rebuilding, Look to Jabari Parker to Lead the Way Back
abstract: Parker, the second pick in June’s draft, landed in Milwaukee as both a celebrity and a savior, given the task of helping to revive a moribund franchise.
lead_paragraph: ST. FRANCIS, Wis. — The Bucks rookie forward Jabari Parker has a favorite moment from his brief N.B.A. career. A few weeks ago, his high school, Simeon Career Academy in Chicago, sent busloads of students two hours north to Milwaukee to see a game against the visiting Bulls. Parker had friends and family members in the stands while he squared off against a childhood hero, Derrick Rose, another Simeon graduate.

headline: Honduras: 2 Arrested in Disappearance of Miss Honduras and Her Sister
abstract: The police said they arrested two suspects Tuesday in the disappearance last Thursday of Miss Honduras, María José Alvarado, 19, and her sister Sofía, 23.
lead_paragraph: The police said they arrested two suspects Tuesday in the disappearance last Thursday of Miss Honduras, María José Alvarado, 19, and her sister Sofía, 23. One of the suspects, Plutarco Ruiz, is the boyfriend of Sofía Alvarado. The police did not identify the other suspect. Video footage showed officers raiding what it said was Mr. Ruiz’s home, protected by a large gate. The two women attended a birthday party for him last Thursday but have not been since. Ms. Alvarado was scheduled to leave for the Miss World contest in London on Wednesday.

headline: Words of Certainty
abstract: Jacob Stulberg is certain you’ll like his puzzle.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Jacob Stulberg made his New York Times debut nearly a year ago with a puzzle that was just golden, in my opinion. Today, he’s back with a puzzle that is mildly multidirectional.

headline: The Murphys Don’t Know What to Do With Their House
abstract: In Sharyn Rothstein’s “By the Water,” a couple whose house was destroyed by Hurricane Sandy have to decide whether to rebuild or move away.
lead_paragraph: “By the Water,” a new play by Sharyn Rothstein, might be called a kitchen sink drama that’s conspicuously missing a kitchen sink. Also absent: Furniture, save a tattered plaid couch. And walls. The living room in which the play takes place, in a beachside Staten Island house ravaged by Hurricane Sandy, does feature a giant picture window — without the glass.

headline: Republicans React to Keystone Defeat
abstract: Senators Mitch McConnell of Kentucky and John Hoeven of North Dakota, the co-sponsor of the Keystone XL pipeline bill, discussed their strategies for passing it next year.
lead_paragraph: Senators Mitch McConnell of Kentucky and John Hoeven of North Dakota, the co-sponsor of the Keystone XL pipeline bill, discussed their strategies for passing it next year.

headline: Woman’s Remains Being Tested for Ebola in New York
abstract: The woman, who died of an apparent heart attack on Tuesday, had returned to the United States 18 days earlier from West Africa, city health officials said.
lead_paragraph: A woman who died of an apparent heart attack at a New York City hair salon on Tuesday will be tested for the Ebola virus out of “an abundance of caution” because she had recently been in West Africa, city health officials said.

headline: For One Staten Island Campaign, a Special Prosecutor Instead of an Auditor
abstract: Criminal charges are being brought over expenditures and filings that are routinely corrected or penalized through audits by the Campaign Finance Board.
lead_paragraph: Washed ashore in the afternoon tide of prisoners in the Staten Island criminal court were two men standing before a judge, hands clasped behind their backs, looking a bit dazed. The men, David Jones, 71, and David Thomas, 57, faced a rack of felonies including grand larceny, criminal possession of stolen property and conspiracy.

headline: Hong Kong Protesters Try to Break Into Legislative Building
abstract: Demonstrators thought to be from a more militant protest group smashed windows, and the main student groups leading the sit-ins around the complex distanced themselves from the actions.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Demonstrators attempted to break into Hong Kong’s legislative building late Tuesday night and early Wednesday by smashing windows. Police officers in riot gear used pepper spray to help quell the protest and arrested four men.

headline: Bangladesh Intercepts Ship Holding 600 Trafficking Victims
abstract: The passengers aboard the ship, mostly from Bangladesh or Myanmar, had been heading to Malaysia, the Bangladeshi Navy said.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The Bangladeshi Navy said Tuesday that it had intercepted a small ship holding more than 600 victims of human trafficking the day before.

headline: The Sale of Manhattan, Retold From a Native American Viewpoint
abstract: “Purchase of Manhattan,” a one-night-only concert opera, treats the deal for the island, arranged by the Dutch official Peter Minuit, as perhaps not outright theft, but a taking.
lead_paragraph: Peter Minuit does not come off well in Brent Michael Davids’s concert opera “Purchase of Manhattan.”

headline: Knicks Take Another Giant Step Backward
abstract: The Knicks turned in another feeble performance on defense and had a late comeback fall short as their teetering season took another step toward irrelevance.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — Derek Fisher and Jason Kidd were N.B.A. point guards two years ago. Tuesday night, they faced off for the first time as N.B.A. coaches.

headline: Charles Champlin, Critic and Memoirist, Dies at 88
abstract: Known as a graceful, knowledgeable writer with a gentlemanly respect for the art of film, Mr. Champlin was the lead movie critic for The Los Angeles Times from 1967 until 1980 and reviewed books thereafter.
lead_paragraph: Charles Champlin, an arts critic and memoirist best known for his writing about movies for The Los Angeles Times, died on Sunday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 88.

headline: At Meeting, Senators G.M. Bryan Murray Discusses Illness
abstract: Murray, who is in the final stage of colon cancer, said he had disclosed the details to encourage others to be tested for the disease.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Days after announcing that he had advanced colon cancer, Bryan Murray of the Ottawa Senators carried on his duties Tuesday at the N.H.L. general managers’ meeting.

headline: Deal by Cystic Fibrosis Foundation Raises Cash and Some Concern
abstract: The foundation is to announce that it will receive $3.3 billion after it helped finance the development of drugs for the deadly lung disease.
lead_paragraph: About 15 years ago, the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation made what was considered a risky foray for a nonprofit organization into the world of business. It began giving money to a small biotechnology company to entice it to develop drugs for the deadly lung disease.

headline: Does Exercise Really Make Us Smarter?
abstract: A new study asks whether the apparent cognitive benefits from exercise are real or just a placebo effect.
lead_paragraph: Exercise seems to be good for the human brain, with many recent studies suggesting that regular exercise improves memory and thinking skills. But an interesting new study asks whether the apparent cognitive benefits from exercise are real or just a placebo effect — that is, if we think we will be “smarter” after exercise, do our brains respond accordingly? The answer has significant implications for any of us hoping to use exercise to keep our minds sharp throughout our lives.

headline: Fidelity Makes a Virtual City of Stocks
abstract: The financial services giant took a look at the virtual reality goggles from Oculus Rift, and saw a three-dimensional city made of money. Buildings are stocks, their height determined by price and footprint by trading and shares.
lead_paragraph: In this town, everywhere could be the financial district.

headline: Composer Aims to Capture the Spirit of Detroit
abstract: Detroit is the next installment in Tod Machover’s series of urban symphonies, which includes works focused on Toronto; Edinburgh; and Lucerne, Switzerland.
lead_paragraph: Tod Machover, a musical visionary at the M.I.T. Media Lab who has written a series of urban symphonies that attempt to capture the spirit of cities around the world, is taking on his first American city: Detroit, which he will portray in a new work called “Symphony in D.”

headline: Word of the Day | epilogue
abstract: This word has appeared in 45 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: epilogue •\ˈe-pə-ˌlȯg, -ˌläg\• noun

headline: Jason Kidd, About to Face Nets, Again Sheds Little Light on His Departure
abstract: Kidd, who left the Nets during the off-season, had the Bucks playing .500 ball ahead of Tuesday’s game against the Knicks.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — On the eve of his return to Brooklyn, Milwaukee Bucks Coach Jason Kidd had little to say about his acrimonious departure from the Nets during the off-season.

headline: What’s on TV Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (13, 49) TO CATCH A COMET As part of PBS’s “Think Wednesday” programming block, this documentary chronicles the challenges facing the European Space Agency’s spacecraft Rosetta across 10 years and four billion miles as it chased down the Comet 67P/ChuryumovGerasimenko — a 2.5-mile-wide ball of rock, ice and dust moving faster than 40,000 miles an hour — and released the Philae, a 220-pound lander the size of a washing machine, onto the comet’s surface last Wednesday.

headline: Corrections: November 19, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Wednesday, November 19, 2014.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, November 19, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “This is a war of neighbors. And the religious dimension makes it even more horrifying.”

headline: China’s Industrial Heartland to Push Overflow Abroad
abstract: Hebei Province plans to shift some of its steel, cement and glass-making capacity elsewhere over the next decade, mostly likely to Africa and other countries in Asia.
lead_paragraph: The northern Chinese province of Hebei plans to shift some of its steel, cement and glass-making capacity abroad over the next decade, mostly likely to Africa and other countries in Asia, as part of an effort to reduce excess capacity and control polluting factories, the state news agency Xinhua reported.

headline: Test Yourself | Beards at Brigham Young
abstract: Here are the first eight paragraphs of the Nov. 17 article “At Brigham Young, Students Push to Lift Ban on Beards.” Can you choose the best word for each blank?
lead_paragraph: Below are the first eight paragraphs of the Nov. 17 article “At Brigham Young, Students Push to Lift Ban on Beards.”

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | For the Monarch Butterfly, a Long Road Back
abstract: What efforts should government, scientists or ordinary citizens take to save the monarch butterfly and its annual migration?
lead_paragraph: In “For the Monarch Butterfly, a Long Road Back,” Liza Gross writes about challenges facing monarch butterflies.

headline: Mexican Leader Offers Asset Disclosure
abstract: President Enrique Peña Nieto’s announcement appeared to be an attempt to quiet a scandal involving his wife’s purchase of an opulent new home.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — President Enrique Peña Nieto said Wednesday that he would disclose details of his assets, a day after his wife promised to give up an opulent new home in one of this city’s most expensive neighborhoods.

headline: Should You Feel Guilty About Killing Spiders, Ants or Other Bugs?
abstract: When you see a bug in your home, what do you do? Do you leave it alone? Do you kill it, or ask someone else to? Or do you try to catch it and set it free outside?
lead_paragraph: When you see a bug in your home, what do you do? Do you leave it alone? Do you kill it, or ask someone else to do the dirty work for you? Or do you ever try to catch it and set it free outside? Why do you make those choices?

headline: Beyond the Stereotyped South
abstract: Tamara Reynolds looks at the American South as a native, going beyond the obvious to capture the region’s spirit.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes the hardest place to photograph is in your own backyard: When everything is familiar, it’s a challenge to make things look interesting. Yet, Tamara Reynolds has done just that in “Southern Route,” looking hard at the American South, which she calls home, and offering a searing, honest portrayal of the country’s most stereotyped region.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: New York Today: Wicked Cold
abstract: Wednesday: single-digit wind chills, a new marijuana policy takes effect, and Al Sharpton’s tax issues.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this frozen Wednesday.

headline: At Glacial Pace, Olympics Weigh Change
abstract: Reform proposals announced Tuesday by the International Olympic Committee are designed to make bidding for the Olympics, particularly the Winter Games, less daunting by making it cheaper and easier.
lead_paragraph: The Olympics went on sale this week. Maybe you saw the fliers?

headline: Obama Is Said to Scrap Child-Care Rules in G.O.P. Outreach
abstract: The president is planning to scrap a few new rules in an effort to persuade Congress to pass an immigration bill, according to people familiar with the plan.
lead_paragraph: It’s a presidential double-dog dare to Republicans.

headline: Fracas Puts Hong Kong Protests in New Light
abstract: A violent clash between demonstrators and the police underscored the difficulty the authorities face in evicting people from their barricaded tent cities.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The most violent clashes between pro-democracy demonstrators and the police here in a month have underscored the difficulty the authorities face in evicting people from the barricaded tent cities that have blocked some of the city’s busiest streets since late September.

headline: Why Voter ID Laws Don’t Swing Many Elections
abstract: The number of registered voters who do not seem to have photo ID is seriously overstated, giving the group the power to affect only the closest races.
lead_paragraph: Many people have understandably blamed low turnout for the Democratic Party’s misfortune on Nov. 4, but some have gone a step further.

headline: Israeli Forces Demolish Home of Palestinian Who Used a Car to Kill 2
abstract: Security forces evacuated a five-story building and destroyed the apartment of the mother of Abdel Rahman al-Shaloudy, who killed a baby and a young woman last month.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — As Israelis and Palestinians grappled on Wednesday with the new-old reality of spiraling violence, Israeli security forces revived a controversial antiterrorism policy, demolishing the East Jerusalem home of a Palestinian man who plowed his car into pedestrians last month, killing a baby and a young woman.

headline: Daily Report: Uber, a Start-Up in Need of a Cultural Shake-Up
abstract: The start-up is facing its toughest challenge yet — curbing its ugliest, most aggressive impulses before its win-at-all-cost culture begins to turn off investors, potential employees and the public.
lead_paragraph: In just four years of operation, Uber has ignited a new global ride-sharing industry with the promise of transforming urban transportation and helping many people get by without owning cars, Farhad Manjoo writes in his State of the Art column.

headline: A Start-Up Lets College Students Skip Washing Their Sheets
abstract: Afresheet makes a fitted, disposable, 100-percent recyclable bed sheet.
lead_paragraph: The Pitch: Many college students loathe having to wash and change their bedsheets, but because their beds serve many purposes  — as a couch, a kitchen table and a study desk, to name a few — those sheets can get pretty dirty. Afresheet makes a fitted, disposable, 100 percent recyclable bottom sheet.

headline: Today in Politics
abstract: Republican leaders in the House stuck with an (almost) all-male lineup of committee leaders.
lead_paragraph: In the House, G.O.P. Picks 20 Chairmen and 1 Chairwoman. Again.

headline: Comeback by Bill Cosby Unravels as Rape Claims Re-emerge
abstract: After Netflix delayed a stand-up special, NBC announced it was dropping plans to develop a new sitcom starring the comedian, the latest fallout from rape accusations.
lead_paragraph: In the twilight of a long and celebrated career, Bill Cosby was experiencing the kind of comeback few longtime performers enjoy.

headline: Morning Agenda: Inside the E.C.B.’s Cyprus Mess
abstract: Documents show the E.C.B. defied is own rules in the Cyprus bailout. | Delay by the S.E.C. delay could actually save crowdfunding. | Uber scrambles after executive’s comments.
lead_paragraph: Confidential communications from the European Central Bank during the Cyprus banking crisis show how the central bank has been wiling to ignore its own bylaws and dictate policy to sovereign governments to prevent wider financial contagion in the eurozone, Landon Thomas Jr. reports in DealBook. Documents show that the E.C.B. effectively proposed that the central bank of Cyprus inflate the value of Cyprus Popular Bank’s collateral, so that it might funnel more emergency loans to the failing bank. This appears to be violating the E.C.B.’s core principle that it may not become involved in the rescue of a bankrupt bank by resorting to its printing press.

headline: In Syria, Doctors Become the Victims
abstract: America must help protect medical personnel from Assad’s bombs.
lead_paragraph: “Working in a field hospital is like death,” a surgeon told us two weeks ago in Turkey, where more than two dozen Syrian doctors and other health workers had come for training. As if treating victims of the Syrian Army’s weapon of choice, the barrel bomb, wasn’t enough, they themselves were often victims of those same terrible devices.

headline: Germany’s Foreign Minister, a Man in the Middle
abstract: Frank-Walter Steinmeier embodies the continued tension in Germany over how aggressively the country should assert itself on the world stage and how forcefully to confront Russia.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — When Frank-Walter Steinmeier became Germany’s foreign minister for the second time almost a year ago, he was looking for Berlin to assume an expanded international role, commensurate with its economic clout and stability.

headline: French Nuclear Giant Areva Says Future Is Uncertain, Prompting a Sell-Off
abstract: The state-owned company said that it was suspending its financial outlook for 2015 and 2016, citing delays to an important project in Finland.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Areva, the French nuclear technology giant, has warned of an uncertain outlook for its business amid delays to important projects and sluggishness in the global atomic energy sector, sending its stock tumbling on Wednesday.

headline: Kik Messaging Start-Up Raises $38.3 Million and Acquires Service Based on GIFs
abstract: The moves are aimed at helping Kik Interactive achieve its goal of becoming the Western version of WeChat, the enormously successful messaging service in China.
lead_paragraph: In its race to become one of the dominant messaging start-ups, Kik Interactive is betting that nearly $40 million in new financing will help — as well as the quirky animated images known as GIFs.

headline: A Second Frenchman Is Identified as Appearing in ISIS Beheading Video
abstract: French officials said they believe Michaël Dos Santos, 22, was among the militants in a video that included a clip of a beheaded American aid worker.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Both were “boys next door” who recently converted to Islam and came under the spell of Islamic jihadists through the Internet. Both were apparently self-radicalized and traveled to Syria on their own. Both turned to the web to promote the Islamic State, with one posting images of a female Kurdish soldier’s severed head on his Twitter profile.

headline: Gone Girls, Found
abstract: The authors of “Gone Girl” and “Wild,” both made into films this season, talk about confounding stereotypes and making their work relevant to men as well as women.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The pairing of Gillian Flynn and Cheryl Strayed seems at once too obvious and not obvious enough.

headline: A Hint of Frustration by a Leader of California’s Next Generation
abstract: California’s attorney general, Kamala Harris, has let slip her frustration with the political longevity of Gov. Jerry Brown.
lead_paragraph: There is a long list of California Democrats yearning to run for governor or Senate, offices all currently held by Democrats over 70.

headline: Woman Who Died in Brooklyn Tests Negative for Ebola
abstract: The woman who died, apparently of a heart attack, in a Brooklyn hair salon had recently come to the United States from Guinea.
lead_paragraph: A woman who died, apparently of a heart attack, at a Brooklyn hair salon and who had recently been in one of the countries most affected by the Ebola outbreak tested negative for the virus, New York City health officials said on Wednesday.

headline: China Seeks to Become a ‘Polar-Region Power’
abstract: A day earlier, President Xi Jinping boarded a Chinese icebreaker in Tasmania and attended the signing of an agreement with Australia to strengthen their collaboration in Antarctica.
lead_paragraph: China is entering a “brand-new historical era” in polar development, a senior Chinese official said in commentary published on Wednesday, a day after President Xi Jinping boarded a Chinese icebreaker and attended the signing of an agreement with Australia to strengthen their collaboration in Antarctica.

headline: A Sudden Schism Emerges Between Abe and the Bank of Japan Governor
abstract: Japan’s prime minister has postponed a planned tax increase championed by Haruhiko Kuroda, the bank’s governor, in a sharp break from their partnership.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The Japanese prime minister and central bank governor have cooperated so closely over the last two years that their relationship is routinely likened to a three-legged race. Bound at the ankles and moving in sync, they have hustled toward their declared goal of ending economic stagnation.

headline: Daily Clip Report
abstract: Daily Clip Report is a collection of articles about the media and The Times that is emailed each day to senior executives and newsroom managers here.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

headline: Snow Piles Up in Buffalo Area, With More Expected; at Least 7 Die
abstract: A lake-effect storm has left parts of western New York buried under five feet of snow, a total that is likely to grow in the next several days.
lead_paragraph: BUFFALO — Liza Smith knows snow. But she had never seen anything like what she encountered on Tuesday morning on the New York State Thruway.

headline: Armory to Offer Works by Laurie Anderson and Marina Abramovic
abstract: The Park Avenue Armory’s 2015 season will include the latest installment of Laurie Anderson’s “Language of the Future” series and a collaboration between Marina Abramovic and the pianist Igor Levit.
lead_paragraph: The premiere of a new installment of Laurie Anderson’s  “Language of the Future” series, a multimedia installation by Philippe Parreno, and “Goldberg,” a collaboration between the performance artist Marina Abramovic and the pianist Igor Levit, are among the major attractions in the Park Avenue Armory’s 2015 season, which the armory announced Wednesday. The season begins on March 25 with the premiere of “FLEXN,” a previously announced collaboration between the choreographer Reggie “Regg Roc” Gray and the director Peter Sellars.

headline: The Daily Gift: A Digital Camera With Exotic Wood Detail
abstract: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.
lead_paragraph: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.

headline: Remembering Smith’s Bar and Grill
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A seedy Midtown bar, which has just closed, had memories for a former law student at Fordham and his opera-loving father.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Verbatim: Restoring Excellence at the Secret Service
abstract: Joseph P. Clancy, acting director of the Secret Service, is to testify before Congress.
lead_paragraph: — Joseph P. Clancy, acting director of the Secret Service, will say in testimony before Congress today. He calls recent security breaches at the White House “simply inexcusable.”

headline: Obama’s Immigration Plan Could Shield Five Million
abstract: New details about the broad reach of the president’s planned executive action on immigration emerged as he prepared to speak to the nation in a prime-time address on Thursday night.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Up to four million undocumented immigrants who have lived in the United States for at least five years can apply for a program that protects them from deportation and allows those with no criminal record to work legally in the country, President Obama is to announce on Thursday, according to people briefed on his plans.

headline: Demanding Toilet Justice for the Women of China
abstract: On World Toilet Day, petitioners across China called on cities to install two women’s toilets for every men’s toilet.
lead_paragraph: The battle for bathroom justice for Chinese women took on new life on Wednesday, as activists rallied across the country to demand that the government mandate that more women’s toilets be made available.

headline: Target’s Profit Rises 3.1 Percent, Beating Expectations
abstract: After problems with its Canadian expansion and a breach of customer data, Target exceeded analysts’ predictions to report that earnings rose 3.1 percent to $352 million in the third quarter.
lead_paragraph: After several quarters of troubled earnings, Target beat expectations on Wednesday by reporting that its profits had risen in the third quarter, a sign that it is recovering from the fallout of its huge data breach last year.

headline: Military Officer Named Interim Prime Minister in Burkina Faso
abstract: The appointment of Lt. Col. Isaac Zida was depicted as a trade-off for the military’s agreement to install a civilian president.
lead_paragraph: OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso — The military officer who seized power in Burkina Faso after the ouster of President Blaise Compaoré last month was named on Wednesday as prime minister in a transitional government intended to steer the country to elections within a year.

headline: 1914: Turcos Drive Germans Out
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Algerian soldiers chase German soldiers out of a French village in 1914.
