lead_paragraph: LONDON — The English public was delighted to learn through the news from the front to-day [Nov. 19] that those picturesquely-dressed, magnificently-built warriors from Algeria, which the French group under the common name of Turcos, had taken a distinguished part in the fighting. Tracy-le-Val, between the Oise and the Aisne, which a few days since was captured from the Germans, was the object of a fierce charge on the part of the Kaiser’s troops on Tuesday, who essayed to retake it. They were at first successful. It was then that the Algerian contingents showed their mettle. They fell upon the German forces with all the fury and disregard for their own lives for which these fighters of the desert are famous, and turned a German capture into a German rout. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Nov. 20, 1914

headline: Delicious Medicine for the Body and Soul
abstract: Health soup, and other dishes for when illness strikes.
lead_paragraph: Like most people I know, I spent much of the autumn . . . sick. Sick with the sort of mild but hydra-headed illness that in me, and in other people of general good health, eventually beats its own retreat. I carried on — stoically, I hope — gripped by a deep desire, same as everyone’s, to “get well soon.”

headline: “Please Don’t Abandon Me”
abstract: Yesterday, I returned from the prison in Multan where my wife, Asia Bibi, was transferred eight months ago. She was sentenced to death for blasphemy, which she did not commit.
lead_paragraph: Note: Asia Bibi, a Christian Pakistani woman, was sentenced to death for blasphemy against Islam in 2010. The year before, while picking fruit with Muslim women, she took a sip of water from the local well. She was immediately accused of making the water impure by ​the other workers, ​who told her that they could no longer use the well. A​ccording to her husband, Ashiq Masih, and others, men and women started beating her and accusing her of making derogatory remarks against the Islamic prophet Muhammad, a charge she denies. Asia is currently in prison waiting to be hanged after losing an appeal ​on ​Oct. 16. She has told her story in a memoir, Blasphemy: A Memoir: Sentenced to Death over a Cup of Water, written with French journalist Anne-Isabelle Tollet.

headline: Where Science Meets Alchemy
abstract: Submicroscopic particles of gold and silver create unusual optical effects.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Nanotechnology has become a familiar term in both science and manufacturing, from methods of cancer detection to long-lasting fabric softener.

headline: Fiscal Responsibility Claims Another Victim
abstract: Oy, Japan.
lead_paragraph: A few more thoughts on Japan.

headline: Israel Destroys Palestinian Home
abstract: Early Wednesday, Israeli security forces destroyed the family home of Abdel Rahman al-Shaloudy, a Palestinian man who killed a baby and a young woman with his car last month.
lead_paragraph: Early Wednesday, Israeli security forces destroyed the family home of Abdel Rahman al-Shaloudy, a Palestinian man who killed a baby and a young woman with his car last month.

headline: 1964: U.S. Force in Vietnam Grows
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The U.S. sends more troops to Vietnam in 1964.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON —United States sent another 1,200 military men into South Vietnam this month, officials disclosed today [Nov. 19]. More American air-transport units also have been thrown into the struggle. The additional manpower brings U.S. military strength in Vietnam to about 21,200 men — up 5,000 since midsummer, sources said. Some of the reinforcements are U.S. Special Forces. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Nov. 20, 1964

headline: Deportation Reprieve May Exclude Parents of Young Immigrants
abstract: Parents of youths already granted a reprieve under a deferred action program could be excluded from the executive order planned by President Obama.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Every time Berzabeth Valdez heads out to work from her mobile home on the outskirts of Houston, it crosses her mind that she might not come back.

headline: A Dam Revival, Despite Risks
abstract: Developing countries are continuing to build large infrastructure projects despite concerns about their environmental impact and the fact they are displacing people.
lead_paragraph: While some dams in the United States and Europe are being decommissioned, a dam-building boom is underway in developing countries. It is a shift from the 1990s, when amid concerns about environmental impacts and displaced people, multilateral lenders like the World Bank backed away from large hydroelectric power projects.

headline: New Factor in Campus Sexual Assault Cases: Counsel for the Accused
abstract: Lawyers have appropriated the tools often used to fight misconduct and turned them against the prosecution, confronting higher education’s approach to the issue.
lead_paragraph: As the Columbia University student tells it, the encounter was harmless fun: A female freshman invited him into her suite bathroom, got a condom, took off her clothes and had sex with him. But as that young woman later described it to university officials, the encounter was not consensual. The university suspended him for a year.

headline: As One Clinton ‘Super PAC’ Winds Down, Another Ramps Up
abstract: About 40 donors are expected to attend an event hosted by Correct the Record, part of a Democratic super PAC that defends Hillary Rodham Clinton against attacks, including Republican criticism of her handling of the assault on a U.S. mission in Benghazi.
lead_paragraph: As supporters of Ready for Hillary, a “super PAC” pushing a 2016 presidential run by Hillary Rodham Clinton, gather in New York on Friday to discuss how the group will wind down ahead of a likely campaign, another group will convene a private meeting to explain to major donors how it plans to ramp up in the coming months.

headline: Legal Status, but Without a Key Benefit
abstract: The president’s plan to provide work permits for up to five million people would not make them eligible for subsidies under the Affordable Care Act, an official said.
lead_paragraph: Obama’s Immigration Plan Could Shield Five Million

headline: From India, Chemicals for Cleaning Up
abstract: An interview with Pramod Chaudhari, the founder of Praj Industries, which speciales in bioethanol, waste-water and biochemical technologies.
lead_paragraph: An engineer by training, Pramod Chaudhari founded Praj Industries in Pune, India, in 1983. The company, which started with 10 full-time employees, started supplying technology for waste water treatment and distilleries. Now, with 1,300 employees working out of 12 offices, and five manufacturing plants, the company specializes in bioethanol, waste-water and biochemical technologies.

headline: Far, Far Below Ground, Directing Water to New York City Taps
abstract: A 350-foot-deep shaft in Orange County will connect to a tunnel and eventually bypass a leaky section of the Delaware Aqueduct, which provides about half of the city’s daily water supply.
lead_paragraph: NEWBURGH, N.Y. — City government often looks small. Petty, even. The parking ticket. The real estate tax bill. Sanitary inspection grades. Window-guard surveys. The fruitless call to 311 at 2 a.m. to complain about jackhammers outside.

headline: Honduran Beauty Queen and Her Sister Are Found Dead 6 Days After Disappearing
abstract: The Honduran police said María José Alvarado and her older sister, Sofía, had been shot and buried on a riverbank.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — María José Alvarado was to travel from Honduras to London on Wednesday to compete with some of the world’s most glamorous young women in the Miss World pageant. Instead, seven months after she was crowned Miss Honduras, the police there said that her body, and that of her older sister, had been pulled from the sand of a riverbank near where she disappeared.

headline: The Side Effects of Consumerism
abstract: In the United States, packaging makes up about 30 percent of all municipal solid waste. Mindful of the environment and their bottom lines, companies are trying to reduce that.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — British supermarkets are selling beer in glass bottles that are a third lighter than they were a few years ago. Unilever, which makes products like Dove cleansers and Sure deodorant, has pledged to reduce its packaging by a third by 2020. Dell is cushioning computers and server parts with wheat straw and a compostable, mushroom-based material, instead of Styrofoam.

headline: Fugitive Guru Arrested After Standoff With Police
abstract: Spiritual leader, Baba Rampal Maharaj, had been barricaded in his compound with thousands of supporters in a weeklong standoff that had left six people dead.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — A self-styled “godman,” or guru, was arrested late Wednesday after a tense weeklong standoff with the police, who had attempted to storm the heavily fortified compound where he was blockaded with an estimated 15,000 followers.

headline: Building a Community on Polluted Land
abstract: A Dutch urban experiment has turned a former industrial area into an office, studio and commercial space that produces its own power and minimizes waste.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — Although Amsterdam’s latest urban experiment, De Ceuvel, is built on solid ground, there’s much that reminds its denizens — artists, entrepreneurs, designers, sustainability experts — of its past as a commercial shipyard.

headline: Malaysia’s Prime Minister Says Fast-Growing Nations Have Role in Curbing Warming
abstract: The prime minister of gas-rich Malaysia sees a climate-friendly path ahead.
lead_paragraph: KUALA LUMPUR — In the opening talk at a two-day meeting here on Asia’s clean energy options, Prime Minister Najib Razak of Malaysia provided fresh evidence of a shift in the longstanding diplomatic tussle over who does what to slow global warming.

headline: What Keystone Really Creates: Talking Points for Republicans
abstract: The pointless debate about the pipeline played directly into Republican hands.
lead_paragraph: Time is supposedly short in a lame-duck Congressional session, but the Senate had plenty of hours to waste yesterday on a pointless debate about the Keystone XL pipeline — one that played directly into Republican hands.

headline: Rockville Centre, L.I., an Urbanized Suburb
abstract: The once-sleepy village of Rockville Centre, in southwest Nassau County, is becoming more walkable and workable through an ongoing “smart growth” program.
lead_paragraph: When Nancy Summers, a retired psychologist, decided to sell her house in Rockville Centre, she dreamed of starting a new life in Manhattan. But when she discovered that apartments there were “ridiculously priced,” she transferred that dream to a place much closer to home.

headline: Junk Bonds Flourish Amid Low Interest Rates, but So Do Default Worries
abstract: Extremely low interest rates and a thirst for speculation have made the junk bond market bigger than ever, and one market veteran says the next wave of defaults will be bigger than ever, too.
lead_paragraph: A big wave of defaults in the junk bond market may be on the way. But some say there may be no reason for investors in the sector to worry.

headline: Hands-On Approach, From Afar
abstract: Stéphane Quintal, the N.H.L.'s new senior vice president for player safety, said he wanted players, teams and fans to understand the reasoning behind calls.
lead_paragraph: In a dark, windowless room in Manhattan last week, seven men sat at a row of desks and control panels watching more than a dozen televisions tuned to hockey. They talked to one another steadily in a low murmur until one said loudly, “Look at New Jersey-Minnesota.”

headline: What You Get for ... $2,000,000
abstract: This week’s properties include modern houses in California and Missouri and a Lowcountry design in South Carolina.
lead_paragraph: SAN RAFAEL, CALIF.

headline: Thanksgiving Cocktail Recipes From Jockey Hollow Bar & Kitchen
abstract: Christopher James, the head bartender at New Jersey’s recently opened restaurant, shares impressive, make-ahead libations for holiday entertaining.
lead_paragraph: At Jockey Hollow Bar & Kitchen, which the restaurateur Chris Cannon recently opened in Morristown, N.J.’s landmark palazzo Vail Mansion, the handcrafted libations are already making a name for themselves. “One table of 18 ordered all of our cocktails in one shot and expected them to arrive immediately, like they came in a can,” recalls Cannon of the restaurant’s first Saturday night service last month. Soon, the head bartender Christopher James, previously of the Garden State’s other bucolic culinary oasis, the Ryland Inn, realized he needed to rejigger the bar program to offer less time-consuming concoctions.

headline: George W. Bush’s ‘41: A Portrait of My Father’
abstract: George W. Bush’s “41,” an affectionate biography of his father, takes readers through the touchstones of an extraordinary life.
lead_paragraph: As the winter of 2012 approached, nearly 20 years after he had left the White House, former President George H. W. Bush checked into a Houston hospital with a bad cough that worsened by the day. Despite increasing pain, he retained his fuddy-duddy sense of humor. “It’s not the cough that carries you off,” he joked one day to his visiting son and daughter-in-law. “It’s the coffin you go off in.”

headline: House Hunting in ... Los Cabos, Mexico
abstract: The housing market in Los Cabos, Mexico, had been improving but was dealt a setback by the recent hurricane.
lead_paragraph: A FOUR-BEDROOM HOUSE WITH OCEAN VIEWS

headline: Misteaks
abstract: My head talks about them.
lead_paragraph: I’ve made a few. Here’s me talking with Business Insider about the big ones and what I learned.

headline: Wheelies: The Virtual Future Subaru Edition
abstract: The company reveals an edgy all-digital concept designed for a video game; G.M. production of pickup trucks may be higher in 2015 than original estimates said.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Up Next, a Classic Who Loves Old Films
abstract: At 82, Robert Osborne brings a lifetime of Hollywood research, experience and friendships to his role as the marquee host of Turner Classic Movies.
lead_paragraph: Out on the sidewalks of the Flatiron district, a Manhattan without melodrama shuffles along. But just inside a building on East 23rd Street, a white-haired man dressed to kill aims his baby blues right where you live, and utters the password to your grand escape.

headline: Classical Playlist: Handel’s ‘Messiah,’ Beethoven, Schumann and More
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: BEETHOVEN: Piano Concerto No. 5, Choral FantasyLeif Ove Andsnes, pianist and conductor; Mahler Chamber Orchestra(Sony Classical 43058862; one disc)With this new recording, the superb Norwegian pianist Leif Ove Andsnes completes his “Beethoven Journey,” a multiyear project capped by his recordings of the five Beethoven concertos with the Mahler Chamber Orchestra. The last album in the series offers his vibrant, elegant, uncannily clear-textured accounts of the mighty “Emperor” Concerto and, joined by the fine Prague Philharmonic Choir, the episodic Choral Fantasy. Every note speaks in Mr. Andsnes’s distinguished playing. And he proves an insightful conductor, drawing comparably lucid and lively music-making from the excellent orchestra. (Anthony Tommasini)

headline: What It Means to Be a ‘Dad’
abstract: A new archetype of the dad is rising online, and he may be changing how we think about fatherhood.
lead_paragraph: The dad wants to talk about bulk shopping. He is concerned that Halloween has gone too far. He really wants you to look at last year’s YouTube videos.

headline: Vote on Energy Panel’s Top Democrat Is a Rebuke to Pelosi
abstract: House Democrats on Wednesday picked Representative Frank Pallone Jr. of New Jersey to be the top Democrat on the House Energy and Commerce Committee, issuing a rebuke to their newly re-elected minority leader, Representative Nancy Pelosi of California.
lead_paragraph: House Democrats on Wednesday picked Representative Frank Pallone Jr. of New Jersey to be the top Democrat on the House Energy and Commerce Committee, issuing a rebuke to their newly re-elected minority leader, Representative Nancy Pelosi of California.

headline: Pregnant With a Boy? Even in 2014, Some Call That ‘Lucky’
abstract: I was pregnant: I didn’t want to engage people in a discussion on gender. I wanted to take a nap. Still, I was alarmed to hear repeatedly that it was somehow preferable to have a boy instead of a girl.
lead_paragraph: Today on the blog, we’re talking sex—specifically, our children’s biological genders, how we as parents think about that gender and the ways it affects everything from our interactions with well-meaning strangers to our own emotions around becoming a parent. The post below, along with Three Girls? ‘I Feel Sorry for Their Father.’ and It’s a Boy, and It’s Okay to Be Disappointed form part of a single conversation: what does it mean to “have” a boy or a girl?

headline: Three Girls? ‘I Feel Sorry for Their Father’
abstract: Almost everywhere we go— a hike on a mountain trail, a restaurant, an art museum– unsolicited comments about the same sex of my children follow.
lead_paragraph: Today on the blog, we’re talking sex—specifically, our children’s biological genders, how we as parents think about that gender and the ways it affects everything from our interactions with well-meaning strangers to our own emotions around becoming a parent. The post below, along with Pregnant With a Boy? Even in 2014, Some Call That ‘Lucky’ and It’s a Boy, and It’s Okay to Be Disappointed form part of a single conversation: What does it mean to “have” a boy or a girl?

headline: It’s a Boy, and It’s Okay to Be Disappointed
abstract: When the ultrasound technician found that white blob between the legs of my baby on the computer screen, I cried.
lead_paragraph: Today on the blog, we’re talking sex—specifically, our children’s biological genders, how we as parents think about that gender and the ways it affects everything from our interactions with well-meaning strangers to our own emotions around becoming a parent. The post below, along with “Pregnant With a Boy? Even in 2014, Some Call That ‘Lucky’ “ and “Three Girls? ‘I Feel Sorry for Their Father.’ ”  form part of a single conversation: What does it mean to “have” a boy or a girl?

headline: Cadillac Unveils the 2016 ATS-V
abstract: The V version of the compact ATS adds a 445-horsepower twin-turbo V6 that is capable of launching the car from 0-60 in 3.9 seconds.
lead_paragraph: Cadillac introduced the V-series to its ATS lineup Tuesday evening at the Los Angeles auto show. The ATS is the marque’s smallest and lightest car, and as with other V cars, the ATS-V will pack a lot of power onto that diminutive frame.

headline: 1868: The Klan Terrorizes Tennessee
abstract: This feature looks at the first time famous names or terms appeared in The Times.
lead_paragraph: This feature looks at the first time famous names or terms appeared in The Times. Have an idea for someone or something you would like to read about? Send a suggestion in the comments section.

headline: Sphinx Prize Honors Three Musicians
abstract: The violinist Danielle Belen, the soprano Janai Brugger and the flutist Demarre McGill will be recognized for artistic excellence.
lead_paragraph: The Sphinx Organization’s mission, since the violinist Aaron Dworkin founded it, in 1996, has been to foster a passion for classical music – and the skills to perform it, as soloists, chamber players and in orchestras – in young black and Hispanic musicians. Since 2012, Sphinx has also awarded an annual medal of excellence to three young musicians who have shown what the organization describes as “artistic excellence, outstanding work ethic, a spirit of determination and great potential for leadership.” The awards include a $50,000 grant for career development.

headline: Jason Collins, the N.B.A.'s First Openly Gay Player, Retires
abstract: Collins, who became the N.B.A.'s first openly gay player as a Net after coming out in 2013 while a free agent, announced his retirement after 13 seasons.
lead_paragraph: Jason Collins, who last season became the first openly gay player in the N.B.A., announced his retirement from basketball on Wednesday in a news conference at Barclays Center.

headline: Toning Down the Tweets Just in Case Colleges Pry
abstract: Warned that colleges are increasingly investigating digital histories, high school students are cleaning up their public social media activity.
lead_paragraph: Admissions officers at Morehouse College in Atlanta were shocked several years ago when a number of high school seniors submitted applications using email addresses containing provocative language.

headline: Chasing Entrepreneurial Opportunity in the Affordable Care Act
abstract: The Affordable Care Act has opened up entrepreneurial opportunities for start-ups like Stride Health, a recommendation engine for health insurance.
lead_paragraph: Some foes of the Obama administration’s Affordable Care Act portray the law as nothing less than socialist-style government control of American health care. Noah Lang, a health care entrepreneur, is not one of those people.

headline: Four Pakistani Men Sentenced to Death for ‘Honor Killing’
abstract: The father, a brother and two cousins of Farzana Parveen, who was bludgeoned to death on a busy street for marrying the man of her choice, were found guilty of the killing.
lead_paragraph: LAHORE, Pakistan — A Pakistani court sentenced four men to death on Wednesday for the murder of Farzana Parveen, a pregnant woman who was bludgeoned to death in May for marrying the man of her choice.

headline: Rivalry Earns Its Pinstripes

lead_paragraph: Tucked away in the mountains of eastern Pennsylvania is a great college football rivalry many fans have never heard of.

headline: Today in Small Business: Pastry, Coffee and Cats

lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Viruses as a Cure
abstract: Our bodies are home to trillions of viruses, and new research hints that some of them may actually be keeping us healthy.
lead_paragraph: When we talk about viruses, usually we focus on the suffering caused by Ebola, influenza and the like. But our bodies are home to trillions of viruses, and new research hints that some of them may actually be keeping us healthy.

headline: Obama to Make Thursday Immigration Announcement
abstract: Tomorrow night, President Obama will address the nation on new executive action on immigration.

headline: Shepard’s Take on Oedipal Doom
abstract: Stephen Rea stars in “A Particle of Dread (Oedipus Variations),” the latest play by Sam Shepard.
lead_paragraph: Sam Shepard’s plays often deal with fallout from long-buried secrets and family tensions, so it somehow seems natural that he has turned to Greek tragedy for inspiration. His latest, “A Particle of Dread (Oedipus Variations),” which opens Sunday after two weeks of previews, is a fragmented tale that reimagines Sophocles’ “Oedipus Rex,” about a man who cannot escape a prophecy that ultimately dooms him.

headline: Mayor Bill de Blasio Takes a Day to Pursue a National Profile
abstract: Mr. de Blasio, who was scheduled to meet with Obama aides and fellow liberals in Washington, looked unruffled by his recent problems in New York City.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For Mayor Bill de Blasio, it was a day when New York City seemed very far away.

headline: Opponents of N.F.L. Concussion Settlement Make Case for Altering It
abstract: A United States District Court judge heard hours of arguments about the fairness of the deal between the N.F.L. and its former players.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — After hundreds of court filings over the past 16 months, opponents of the preliminary settlement between the N.F.L. and the 5,000 former players who sued the league for hiding the dangers of concussions urged a federal judge on Wednesday to alter key parts of the deal.

headline: Connecticut Insurance Commissioner  to Join Evercore
abstract: Thomas B. Leonardi will be joining the investment bank as a senior adviser, focusing on the insurance industry.
lead_paragraph: The insurance commissioner of Connecticut, Thomas B. Leonardi, will be joining the investment bank Evercore as a senior adviser, focusing on the insurance industry

headline: Twine, the Video-Game Technology for All
abstract: The text-based creation tool has brought a new artistry — and a new diversity — to the medium.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps the most surprising thing about “GamerGate,” the culture war that continues to rage within the world of video games, is the game that touched it off. Depression Quest, created by the developers Zoe Quinn, Patrick Lindsey and Isaac Schankler, isn’t what most people think of as a video game at all. For starters, it isn’t very fun. Its real value is as an educational tool, or an exercise in empathy. Aside from occasional fuzzy Polaroid pictures that appear at the top of the screen, Depression Quest is a purely text-based game that proceeds from screen to screen through simple hyperlinks, inviting players to step into the shoes of a person suffering from clinical depression. After reading brief vignettes about what the main character is struggling with — at home, at work, in relationships — you try to make choices that steer your character out of this downward spiral. The most important choices are those the game prevents you from making, unclickable choices with red lines through them, saying things like “Shake off your funk.” As your character falls deeper into depression, more options are crossed out. You can’t sleep; you can’t call a therapist; you can’t explain how you feel to the people you love. In the depths of depression, it all feels impossible.

headline: A First-Person History Lesson From Robert Rubin
abstract: The release of an interview Robert Rubin gave nine years ago offers a window into the thoughts of the rich and powerful, William D. Cohan writes in the Street Scene column.
lead_paragraph: For the last 25 years or so, Robert E. Rubin, a former co-senior partner at Goldman Sachs when it was a private partnership, has played an inordinately important role in Washington. Some of his extraordinary influence has been overt, as when he served President Clinton as head of the National Economic Council and then as Treasury secretary, and some of it has been subtler but no less significant. For instance, his fingerprints are all over the Obama administration’s cabinet and its economic team: Timothy F. Geithner, Lawrence H. Summers, Peter R. Orszag, Gene B. Sperling, Jason Furman, Jacob J. Lew, Michael Froman and Sylvia Mathews Burwell at one time or another have had — or still have — close ties to Mr. Rubin.

headline: Uber Scandal Highlights Silicon Valley’s Grown-Up Problem
abstract: The core values of start-up culture can conflict with the responsibilities that come with being an economically important company.
lead_paragraph: Uber’s latest scandal is a doozy: A top executive of the ride service reportedly described a Nixonian plan to dig up dirt on journalists who criticize it and sully their reputations.

headline: Vegetarian Thanksgiving: A Squash Main Course
abstract: This combination of acorn squash, corn and beans offers a delicious main course for vegan diners.
lead_paragraph: When Maria Marlowe, a New York resident, switched to a vegan diet eight years ago for health reasons, she tried to persuade her family to do the same.

headline: Obama to Detail Immigration Plans in Address on Thursday
abstract: President Obama said he would deliver the 8 p.m. speech from the White House to announce “steps that I can take to start fixing our broken immigration system.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama will speak to the nation in a prime-time address on Thursday, asserting his authority to protect up to five million undocumented immigrants from deportation, the White House said, and setting in motion an immediate confrontation with Republicans about the limits of a president’s executive powers.

headline: 36 Hours in Seattle
abstract: Seattle is in boom mode, and for visitors that means creative restaurants, a vibrant nightlife scene and stunning art.
lead_paragraph: Seattle is in boom mode, and for visitors that means creative restaurants, a vibrant nightlife scene and stunning art.

headline: Soundhawk Smart Listening System: A Hearing Helper
abstract: A device and app from Soundhawk, made to help people hear in certain settings, addresses problems that have hindered use of such devices in the past.
lead_paragraph: MILLIONS of Americans have some degree of hearing difficulty, but only a small percentage regularly wear hearing aids. People in the hearing sciences have long argued that technology is partly to blame.

headline: 36 Hours in Seattle
abstract: Shake off the charcoal skies and wet weather to discover colorful art, a vibrant food scene, sweeping views and more during a weekend in the Emerald City.
lead_paragraph: The sky is often gray, the residents tend to be muted (except when cheering their teams), calm waters lap the green cityscape, but beneath its mild exterior, Seattle has always careened wildly between boom and bust. For better or worse, boom is the mode of the day. Though the tunnel project designed to give the waterfront a highway-free makeover is currently stalled, the rest of downtown is roaring with new construction and high-end repurposing of historic buildings. The food has never been better, and the traffic never worse. Fall days can be wet, but as any photographer will tell you, the city is at its loveliest when slicked with rain.

headline: Audi’s Prologue Concept Marks New Styling Direction
abstract: The company says the car’s design will influence the next generation A8, A7 and A6.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — What’s next for Audi styling, which is due for a major update in the next year or two? The German automaker offered a sneak peek Wednesday at the 2014 Los Angeles auto show with the introduction of its flagship-size Prologue coupe concept. While there were no plans announced to put the Prologue into production, the company said its styling would influence the look of the next generation of A8, A7 and A6 models.

headline: Low Inflation Replaces Joblessness as Reason Fed Won’t Raise Rates
abstract: Minutes of the October meeting of Federal Reserve policy makers indicate they see little reason to change course and expect steady economic and job growth to continue.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The sluggish pace of inflation is replacing unemployment as the main reason the Federal Reserve is not ready to start raising interest rates.

headline: An Open-Air Bentley With Upper-Crust Roots

lead_paragraph: A sparring match with an activist is a bigger deal for TransCanada than the company’s troubled Keystone XL pipeline.

lead_paragraph: Miami’s trendiest hotels reside in South Beach, but the Thompson Miami Beach, opening Nov. 21, adds to the growing number of stylish addresses in the area just north, known as Mid-Beach.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Protesters Attack Hong Kong Legislature
abstract: A small group of pro-democracy protesters stormed Hong Kong’s legislature late Tuesday and early Wednesday. Pro-democracy lawmakers condemned the violence, saying it damaged their movement.
lead_paragraph: A small group of pro-democracy protesters stormed Hong Kong’s legislature late Tuesday and early Wednesday. Pro-democracy lawmakers condemned the violence, saying it damaged their movement.

headline: Video: BMW Expands Its Lineup With the 2015 X4 xDrive35i
abstract: A more carlike version of the X3 crossover, the X4 has the same ground clearance, but a swept profile also cuts cargo space by 10 cubic feet.
lead_paragraph: In a simpler time, the BMW lineup was pretty straightforward. There were 3, 5 and 7 Series offerings, and, from time to time, a 6 Series, too. There were powertrain selections, of course, and it was possible to choose among two-door coupes, wagons and convertibles. But that was about as wild as the choices got.

headline: Are Some Professions Less Honest Than Others? Bank on It, Researchers Find
abstract: Bankers have gotten a bit of a bad rep over the last decade, owing to a variety of scandals. A new study may not help.
lead_paragraph: As banking scandals have mounted over the past decade, some critics have suggested that the industry simply harbors a dishonest culture. Now, three economists from the University of Zurich have tested the idea.

headline: Cory Arcangel Teams Up With the Musician and Composer Chris D’Eon at the Met
abstract: On Saturday, the Arcangel-composed series “Dances for the Electric Piano” will be staged for the first time in the United States. Listen to it here.
lead_paragraph: When the multimedia artist Cory Arcangel was in Montreal preparing for his first major Canadian exhibition at DHC/ART last year, he couldn’t resist contacting the Canadian keyboardist and avant-garde composer Chris D’Eon. Though Arcangel is a celebrated figure in the art world, he also studied classical guitar at the Oberlin Conservatory of Music and is a composer; he calls himself a “huge fan” of D’Eon, who has released two albums including a collaboration with his fellow Canadian Grimes. Despite Arcangel’s fame, he had no idea whether D’Eon would even know who he was. D’Eon did, and went on to perform some of Arcangel’s compositions alongside his own at an event in Montreal later that year.

headline: Teacher’s New Pet: An App That Tracks Students
abstract: Natasha Singer takes us into the classroom where she did her reporting for an article on ClassDojo, a behavior-tracking app used by teachers, and into the controversy the app has created.
lead_paragraph: On Nov. 17, the Times technology reporter Natasha Singer wrote about ClassDojo, an app teachers use to track — and manage — classroom behavior. Using the app, teachers can, for example, show the class who has followed directions or forgotten homework.

headline: Obama Makes Pitch to Expand High-Speed Internet Access to Schools

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Wednesday took a break from crisis and gridlock to advance two often-overlooked priorities focused on children, one to wire more of the nation’s schools to the Internet and the other to overhaul child care for low-income families.

headline: Florida and F.T.C. Accuse Firms of Deceptively Selling Tech Support
abstract: The Federal Trade Commission and the State of Florida say the companies used software designed to trick consumers into thinking their computers had bugs or errors that needed to be fixed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Trade Commission and the State of Florida on Wednesday announced that they had obtained a court order to temporarily shut down and freeze the assets of two telemarketing operations that the commission said had deceptively sold more than $120 million in technical support services and software.

headline: Electricity in the Air
abstract: Christine Andreas, performing at 54 Below, has a voice that gives everything she sings a sense of urgency.
lead_paragraph: The most thrilling rendition of “La Vie en Rose” this side of Edith Piaf: That would describe Christine Andreas’s performance of Piaf’s passionate signature song, at 54 Below on Tuesday evening.

headline: 10 From One Family Are Killed in Sinai Blast
abstract: Residents of the area and a neighbor of the family said the home had been hit by missiles, possibly fired by an Egyptian Army helicopter or drone.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Ten members of one family, including children, were killed late Tuesday when munitions struck a home in the northern Sinai Peninsula, a region that has been the site of fierce battles between the Egyptian military and insurgent fighters, military officials and witnesses said Wednesday.

headline: Ryan Planning for Tax Overhaul and Health Law Repeal
abstract: Representative Paul D. Ryan, the new chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, said that a broad overhaul of the tax code depended on the administration’s engagement.
lead_paragraph: Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin, the newly minted chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, predicted Wednesday that a broad overhaul of the tax code would move forward, whether President Obama issues an executive order on immigration or not, but its success would depend on the administration being engaged on the issue.

headline: Where There’s No Smoke, There’s the Word of the Year

lead_paragraph: “Vape” has been named Oxford Dictionaries’ international word of the year for 2014, triumphing over a field that also included “bae” (a term of endearment originating in African-American English), “indyref” (a Twitter-friendly term for the Scottish independence referendum) and “slactivism” (look it up).

headline: Republicans Lash Out on Immigration Plan
abstract: Within minutes of the announcement that President Obama will take executive action on immigration, Republicans hit back.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s executive action on immigration has been brewing for awhile, and within minutes of today’s announcement, Republicans hit back.

headline: Tommy Tune Joins the Cast of ‘Lady, Be Good’ for Encores!
abstract: Mr. Tune will appear in the coming Encores! production of George and Ira Gershwin’s 1924 musical.
lead_paragraph: The nine-time Tony Award-winning actor Tommy Tune will appear in a New York musical for the first time in many years in the coming Encores! production of “Lady, Be Good,” the show’s producers announced on Wednesday.

headline: The Strange Religious Future
abstract: On the importance of expecting some version of the unexpected.
lead_paragraph: I had the privilege of being part of a Fordham University event last night on the future of religion, responding (along with a rather more distinguished fellow panelist) to remarks by the religion journalist and academic Molly Worthen on the roots of institutional faith’s present-day developed-world decline. There was, I think, some basic agreement among all of the panelists about some of the patterns and shifts we’re experiencing right now (the decline of institutional authority, the working out of the sexual revolution, the rise of the so-called “nones”), and then a number of interesting things were said about the possible unknowns that might either accelerate or redirect current trends: There was discussion of how institutional-cum-orthodox forms of faith might experience some sort of revival, of how spiritual-but-not-religious forms of faith might represent the vanguard of an entirely new era of religious understanding, and of how religious forces outside the developed world (Islam, Pentecostalism, Chinese Christianity) might matter more to the West itself than a Western-centric vision allows.

headline: New Opposition to Lazard Banker’s Nomination to Treasury Post
abstract: A group of community bankers raised many of the same concerns as Senators Elizabeth Warren and Richard Durbin about the naming of Antonio Weiss to a top Treasury job.
lead_paragraph: Since the Obama administration nominated Antonio Weiss, a senior deal maker at Lazard, for a high-level position at the Treasury Department, the move has drawn criticism from some unusual quarters.

headline: Secret Service Arrests Man Within Block of White House
abstract: The man approached officers on foot a block from the White House. A subsequent search of his car produced a hunting rifle and ammunition.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Secret Service arrested an Iowa man outside the White House on Wednesday who had a hunting rifle and ammunition in his car, according to law enforcement officials.

headline: First Draft Focus: A Capitol Lottery
abstract: Congressional staffers play the office lottery in the halls of the Capitol.

headline: Brooklyn Girl in Organ Donation Dispute Dies After Being Taken Off Life Support
abstract: Thaiya Spruill-Smith,2, who was declared brain-dead last week, had been on life support while her parents tried to reach a consensus on whether her organs should be donated.
lead_paragraph: With the fate of her organs decided, Thaiya Spruill-Smith, a Brooklyn girl who was declared brain-dead after being violently shaken, was taken off life support and died on Wednesday morning.

headline: Polanski’s Musical Gets More Nibbles
abstract: Roman Polanski discusses why he’s excited by the Parisian production of his musical “Dance of the Vampires.”
lead_paragraph: PARIS — For those who savor a good Broadway catastrophe, “Dance of the Vampires” is near the top of the shortlist of infamy. But for the Oscar-winning film director Roman Polanski, that flop 2002 musical, based on his 1967 film “The Fearless Vampire Killers,” deserves — no, demands — another chance.

headline: Sleepy Jones Sets Up Shop on Both Coasts
abstract: The loungewear line has opened a lifestyle boutique in SoHo and will debut another in Santa Monica tomorrow.
lead_paragraph: Just in time for hibernation season, Andy Spade, Anthony Sperduti and Chad Buri have opened the first brick-and-mortar outpost for their loungewear line Sleepy Jones. The year-old label was previously housed in a pop-up shop on the Bowery in downtown Manhattan and otherwise only available online. The new store is located a stone’s throw from Opening Ceremony on Howard Street and stocks the brand’s playful pajamas as well as an array of design-centric lifestyle goods, like Postalco notebooks, Fredericks and Mae game sets, Hopewell Quilts and assorted vintage accessories. And lest those on the West Coast fear missing out, a second store will follow on its heels tomorrow in Santa Monica. Here, exclusively for T, the brand debuts a film shot in Italy in celebration of the openings, “L’Isola di Sleepy Jones,” created by Spade and the director Oscar Boyson.

headline: Time Lapse of Lake-Effect Snowstorm
abstract: A rush of cold air from the north set the perfect conditions for the moisture coming off the Great Lakes to create sprawling snow bands across Buffalo.
lead_paragraph: A rush of cold air from the north set the perfect conditions for the moisture coming off the Great Lakes to create sprawling snow bands across Buffalo.

headline: For Cyber Monday, Hotel Deals With an American Accent
abstract: Cyber Monday deals include discounts at hotels ranging from the Mission Point Resort on Mackinac Island in Michigan to the Wigwam in Arizona.
lead_paragraph: It’s usually the promise of sun and sand during the cold winter months that wins the favor of Cyber Monday shoppers looking for a cheap getaway. But this year historic hotels across the country might give Caribbean beachfronts a run for their money with the promise of picturesque settings, luxury renovations and solid savings.

headline: Shopping and Eating Amid History in Richmond, Va.
abstract: For years, Church Hill has been a neighborhood to avoid after dark. But these days, the 18th-century enclave has some of the city’s most appealing shops and dining spots.
lead_paragraph: For decades, the 18th-century Church Hill neighborhood of Richmond, Va., has been a don’t-go-after-dark spot. One of the city’s oldest residential enclaves, its historic townhouses, gas lamps and St. John’s Church — where Patrick Henry proclaimed “Give me liberty” — have long been tended to by a small band of passionate preservationists in an area of encroaching crime and poverty. But undervalued real estate and unparalleled views of downtown and the James River have increasingly drawn a fiercely loyal, self-starter set of residents. These days, Church Hill has some of the city’s most appealing shops and dining spots.

headline: Nov. 19, 2014 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Israel, Britain, Egypt and Indonesia.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Israel, Britain, Egypt and Indonesia.

headline: A Guide to Buying Just About Anything
abstract: This collection of stories provides counsel on buying things that go beyond everyday shopping —from a horse to political change to a longer life.
lead_paragraph: The basics you probably know by now, at least for the things you buy frequently. How to buy a book online. Pick a good apple in the supermarket. Find sneakers that fit.

headline: When Calls for Revenge Overwhelm China’s Courts
abstract: As the top court tries to shift the nation away from the death penalty, a family in a murder case in Sichuan demands “a life for a life.”
lead_paragraph: ‘‘Shut up!’’ shouted Feng Wei, a judge from the Sichuan Higher People’s Court, banging his gavel. We were in a courtroom here, about 60 miles southeast of Chengdu, the provincial capital. At stake was the life of Li Yan, sentenced to death in 2011 for killing her husband during an argument.

headline: Food Fight: Researching and Debating the Future of G.M.O.’s
abstract: In this lesson, students will learn about the science behind G.M.O.’s, and they will explore questions about the consequences, both intended and unintended, related to their use.
lead_paragraph: Overview | Over 50 countries and the state of Vermont require that genetically modified organisms, or G.M.O.’s, are labeled. More than 20 other states are considering similar laws. But what’s the fuss? G.M.O. ingredients are already in most pantries and refrigerators in the United States — in the form of canola oil, corn cereals, soy products and refined sugar. Are these genetically modified plants a threat to human health and natural ecosystems? Or are they a biotech solution to crop blight and other diverse problems?

headline: Skiing in a No Fall Zone
abstract: Teton Gravity Research traveled to the Grand Teton National Park to ski Mount Moran’s three classic lines: the Sickle, East Horn and Skillet.
lead_paragraph: Teton Gravity Research traveled to the Grand Teton National Park to ski Mount Moran’s three classic lines: the Sickle, East Horn and Skillet.

headline: Senate Report Finds Goldman and JPMorgan Can Influence Commodities
abstract: A Senate panel found that banks assumed a role of such significance in the commodities markets that it became possible for them to influence the prices that consumers pay.
lead_paragraph: A two-year Senate-led investigation is throwing back the curtain on the outsize and sometimes hidden sway that Wall Street banks have gained over the markets for essential commodities like oil, aluminum and coal.

headline: Apple’s Plans for Beats Music Start to Take Shape
abstract: Apple plans to include its Beats music service in future versions of iOS, its mobile software system for iPhones and iPads.
lead_paragraph: Apple’s plans for Beats, the company it acquired for $3 billion earlier this year, are coming into sharper focus.

headline: Ford Unleashes a Powerful Mustang
abstract: The sixth-generation Mustang gets Shelby treatment, including a 500-plus-horsepower V8 engine and track-oriented components.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The latest Shelby GT350 Mustang was put on display here at the 2014 Los Angeles Auto Show on Wednesday as something of a homage to the late performance guru Carroll Shelby. The car is based on the recently introduced sixth generation of Ford’s classic pony car.

headline: Billboard, Changing the Charts, Will Count Streaming Services
abstract: Billboard and Nielsen SoundScan will start adding streams to the formula behind the Billboard 200.
lead_paragraph: Streaming music services like Spotify have brought big changes to the music industry. But one important part of the business has not kept up: Billboard’s album chart.

headline: How OkCupid Has Become More Inclusive on Gender and Sexuality
abstract: The dating site is drawing praise for offering users some new choices.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to meeting potential partners (or, at least, looking at their profiles), OkCupid offers users lots of choices. But critics have pointed out an area where the service provides much less choice: identifying one’s own gender and sexuality. At least for some users, though, that’s changing — and many see it as an important step toward inclusivity.

headline: Video: Skiing in a No Fall Zone
abstract: Teton Gravity Research traveled to the Grand Teton National Park to ski Mount Moran’s three classic lines: the Sickle, East Horn and Skillet.
lead_paragraph: Behind the Line is a video series produced by Teton Gravity Research that takes you into the minds of skiers. In each episode, the athletes will look back on a line, a jump or a session, and discuss the moment.

headline: Reading The Times With Sarah McNally
abstract: The owner of McNally Jackson Books in Manhattan says that as soon as she had a steady income, she began seven-day delivery of The Times.
lead_paragraph: Sarah McNally owns McNally Jackson Books in Manhattan. She says that as soon as she had a steady income, she began seven-day delivery of The Times.

headline: Al Sharpton Criticizes New York Times Report on Unpaid Taxes
abstract: The Rev. Al Sharpton said his tax liens had been paid down and that he was “current on all taxes” he was obligated to pay under settlement agreements.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Al Sharpton on Wednesday sharply criticized a New York Times article that explored his history of unpaid taxes, rent and other bills, calling the report “misleading and totally out of context.”

headline: Senate Report on Wall Street’s Role in Commodities
abstract: A two-year Senate-led investigation is throwing back the curtain on the outsized and sometimes hidden sway that Wall Street banks have gained over the markets for essential commodities like oil, aluminum and coal.
lead_paragraph: A two-year Senate-led investigation is throwing back the curtain on the outsized and sometimes hidden sway that Wall Street banks have gained over the markets for essential commodities like oil, aluminum and coal.

headline: Keira Knightley and Benedict Cumberbatch Celebrate ‘The Imitation Game’
abstract: Ms. Knightley and Mr. Cumberbatch were among the stars celebrating the New York premiere of “The Imitation Game.”
lead_paragraph: Keira Knightley had just arrived at Tavern on the Green to celebrate her new movie, “The Imitation Game,” but the hour was fast approaching.

headline: Harvest and Thanksgiving Picture Books
abstract: New picture books include Salina Yoon’s “Penguin and Pumpkin.”
lead_paragraph: New picture books include Salina Yoon’s “Penguin and Pumpkin.”

headline: The Best Selling Sports Books
abstract: An Olympic runner’s story of survival in World War II topped the list of the best-selling sports books in October 2014, according to the New York Times best-seller list.
lead_paragraph: The best-selling sports books in October 2014, according to the New York Times best-seller list.

headline: Federal Tax Liens Against Sharpton and Raw Talent
abstract: A list of federal tax liens against the Rev. Al Sharpton and one of his businesses, Raw Talent. Document types marked as “Release of Federal Lien” signify that the amount has been paid off by a prior lien.
lead_paragraph: A list of federal tax liens against the Rev. Al Sharpton and one of his businesses, Raw Talent. Document types marked as “Release of Federal Lien” signify that the amount has been paid off by a prior lien.

headline: Chained to the Verities of Hunger and Heartbreak
abstract: “Something Rich and Strange,” an anthology of stories by Ron Rash, explores the bleak pull of Appalachia for those who have left or seemingly cannot leave.
lead_paragraph: Ron Rash occupies an odd place in the pantheon of great American writers, and you’d better believe he belongs there. He gets rapturous reviews that don’t mean to condescend but almost always call him a Southern or Appalachian writer, and Mr. Rash has said he can hear the silent, dismissive “just” in those descriptions. He also baffles anyone who thinks that great talent ought to be accompanied by great ambition. Mr. Rash has planted himself at Western Carolina University and eluded the limelight that his work absolutely warrants.

headline: ThyssenKrupp, an Old European Conglomerate, Tries to Learn a New Business Style
abstract: The chief executive’s attempt to turn the company into a nimble global competitor has been constrained by a moribund regional economy and a legacy emphasis on low-profit steel.
lead_paragraph: ESSEN, Germany — Heinrich Hiesinger was stunned by what he found in early 2011 when he became chief executive of ThyssenKrupp, one of Europe’s biggest and oldest industrial companies.

headline: New York State Tax Warrants Against Sharpton and Revals
abstract: Open New York State Tax Warrants against the Rev. Al Sharpton and one of his businesses, Revals Communications Inc. A spokesman for the New York State Department of Taxation and Finance said the amount now due on each of the warrants has increased since they were filed, to a current total of $916,179.13, from an original total of $694,238.58.
lead_paragraph: Open New York State Tax Warrants against the Rev. Al Sharpton and one of his businesses, Revals Communications Inc. A spokesman for the New York State Department of Taxation and Finance said the amount now due on each of the warrants has increased since they were filed, to a current total of $916,179.13, from an original total of $694,238.58.

headline: Legendary Seducers, Meeting in the Twilight
abstract: In “Story of My Death,” the director and writer Albert Serra imagines the paths crossing of the hedonistic Casanova and a bloodthirsty Dracula.
lead_paragraph: According to Casanova’s extravagant, improbable memoir, “The Story of My Life,” his earliest childhood memory involves being locked in a chest by a witch to treat childhood nosebleeds and hallucinating a bejeweled woman descending from the chimney. It should therefore surprise no one that Albert Serra’s “Story of My Death,” which stars Casanova, also co-stars Dracula — here, a sveltely pompadoured, pug-face figure in black who invites farm girls back to his castle with the far-out line “We go way beyond.”

headline: Shopping With Lindsay Duncan, but Coming Home Empty-Handed
abstract: Ms. Duncan sees herself as an actress “who’s been in pretty decent stuff for a long, long time.”
lead_paragraph: Just before a recent preview performance of the revival of Edward Albee’s 1966 play “A Delicate Balance,” there was a little flurry of excitement along the eighth row when Ralph Fiennes, the actor, slunk in next to his frequent companion, Amanda Harlech, the longtime muse of Karl Lagerfeld. As befits this station, Ms. Harlech was wearing a most extraordinary pair of trousers, which flared out at the hips like lamb chops.

headline: The Leonora Opens in Chelsea
abstract: A space that strives for a select crowd and sees D.J.s rotate every night.
lead_paragraph: A “semiprivate” clubhouse for the creative set is the latest attempt to pump new life into the Chelsea bottle-service scene. The Leonora is hoping to cultivate an atmosphere of exclusivity to lure celebrities from their urban aeries for a paparazzi-free night on the town.

headline: Travelogue Cocktails With Reality Chaser
abstract: From “Barmageddon” on truTV to the National Geographic Channel’s “Chug,” the television industry is going on a bender.
lead_paragraph: Poor alcohol. It used to have very little competition for television time, since other mind-altering substances were illegal and thus rarely given starring roles. But lately an old newcomer, marijuana, has been generating the TV and Internet buzz, as it were, as relaxed laws have made pot eligible to be something other than the basis for stoner jokes.

headline: Warren Pushes Democrats to the Left, but Not Too Hard
abstract: Senator Elizabeth Warren outlined her vision for the Democratic Party at a meeting of party donors.
lead_paragraph: If ever there was a setting for Senator Elizabeth Warren to outline the contours of a presidential campaign, or push her party in a more liberal direction, it was Wednesday afternoon at a conference by the Center for American Progress.

headline: Fall Fashion, Always in Sync
abstract: Black-and-white looks, as chic as ever; sweater dresses, for cozying up or socializing and more shopping news.
lead_paragraph: At a recent series of splashy events, Oscar winners, chart-toppers and ingénues demonstrated that classic black and white is back, as chic as ever. None followed a formula: Emma Watson looked divine in an off-the-shoulders top and tailored evening pants from Balenciaga; Marion Cotillard played with proportions in Dior; and Melissa George was daring in a white lace blouse that revealed her nude brassiere. If you’re thinking about an investment in something special for holiday festivities, remember that black and white, endlessly versatile, is unlikely to let you down.

headline: The Learning Curve Has Ups and Downs
abstract: The Mikhailovsky Ballet continues its season at Lincoln Center with “Three Centuries of Russian Ballet.”
lead_paragraph: Classicism evolves, Diaghilev said. But from what into what? You might well hope that “Three Centuries of Russian Ballet” — the name of the program presented on Tuesday night by the Mikhailovsky Ballet at the David H. Koch Theater — would show us how the grand sophistication of 19th-century ballet evolved by way of the modernist intensity of the 20th to the cultural complexity of the 21st. Or give us another arc of comparably historical seriousness. This triple bill, however, not only proved depressing and trivial, it also charted a process of flashy thrills and artistic deterioration.

headline: Beer for Me, Apple Juice for Her
abstract: Beer gardens are booming nationally, as they provide a go-to destination for family outings, play dates and toddler birthdays.
lead_paragraph: When Ashley Primis was preparing for her daughter’s first birthday party last year, she wanted it to be memorable. So Ms. Primis, 35, ordered a buffet of child-friendly foods; decorated the tables with toys, coloring books and bubbles; and bought a gigantic pink Geronimo balloon on Etsy.

headline: Late Success for Latecomer to Late Night
abstract: “The Nightly Show With Larry Wilmore” will debut Jan. 19 on Comedy Central and focus on underdogs.
lead_paragraph: Larry Wilmore is not about to be spoiled by sudden success.

headline: Migrating Wildlife Depends on More Than Wilderness, Report Finds
abstract: New maps document seasonal migrations of elk, moose, bighorn sheep, pronghorn antelope and mule deer in Wyoming.
lead_paragraph: New details of seasonal migrations in Wyoming show that deer, elk and other animals depend not only on wilderness areas but on private and multiuse government lands.

headline: Social Media Bots Offer Phony Friends and Real Profit
abstract: Bots number in the millions, for good reason.
lead_paragraph: I am the ruler of worlds. Let me rephrase that: I am the ruler of one very small world of social media bots.

headline: A Tabloid ‘Fake Sheikh,’ Bane of Crooks and Royalty, Finds He’s Now the Story
abstract: For years, the British reporter Mazher Mahmood has baited celebrity targets in order to produce scoops, but now an unflattering glare has been turned on him.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Mazher Mahmood was 21 when he first posed as a wealthy sheikh. A reporter from Birmingham, England, intent on exposing a prostitution ring at a local hotel, he donned a white robe he had bought for 12 pounds at an Islamic bookshop, checked into the hotel, the Metropole, and persuaded the concierge to send women to his room.

headline: A Deal From the District 3 Autumn Leaf Regional
abstract: The most successful player at the District 3 Autumn Leaf Regional in Danbury, Conn., last month was Alex Ornstein.
lead_paragraph: The most successful player at the District 3 Autumn Leaf Regional in Danbury, Conn., last month was Alex Ornstein. He won 53.65 master points, 1.68 more than Sharon Goldman and Melih Ozdil (all of New York City).

headline: Cosby Won’t Respond to Allegations
abstract: During an interview on Nov. 6 with The Associated Press, Bill Cosby refused to respond to allegations of sexual assault after the reporter brought up recent reports.
lead_paragraph: During an interview on Nov. 6 with The Associated Press, Bill Cosby refused to respond to allegations of sexual assault after the reporter brought up recent reports.

headline: Two of Golf World’s Legends Trade Shots
abstract: The World Golf Hall of Fame writer Dan Jenkins and the 14-time major winner Tiger Woods have engaged in the literary equivalent of a muckfest.
lead_paragraph: NAPLES, Fla. — It figures. You go to a women’s golf tournament and a mud wrestling match breaks out. Not here at Tiburon Golf Club, where the best players on the L.P.G.A. Tour will hit their opening shots Thursday and the last one standing Sunday in the season-long Race to CME Globe will walk away with a $1 million bonus.

headline: The Lessons of a Rosetta Scientist’s Shirt
abstract: A British physicist sets off a shower of criticism with his fashion sense.
lead_paragraph: IF THERE IS any doubt that image is an equal opportunity issue — one that affects all of us, not just presidential candidates and red carpet celebrities — the Matt Taylor controversy, also known on Twitter as #shirtgate and #shirtflap (among other things), should put it to rest.

headline: A Playoff, of Sorts, in Bach’s Court
abstract: The Mutter Virtuosi, a string orchestra of Anne-Sophie Mutter’s protégées, joined her in concert at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: If Tuesday’s Carnegie Hall concert had been a carnival, the barker’s pitch would have written itself: “Step right up and try to outplay the Magnificent Mutter!”

headline: Picking Your Car’s Computerized Brain
abstract: New smartphone-connected devices use a car’s diagnostic port to help drivers track fuel usage, troubleshoot mechanical problems, find parking and more.
lead_paragraph: EVEN with their high-tech gadgets and computerized machinery, most cars still do a pretty poor job of providing helpful information about things like mechanical problems and fuel use — and of connecting to the devices we use the most, our phones.

headline: Shaving on the Edge (Both of Them)
abstract: A new generation is discovering the safety razor.
lead_paragraph: After 13 years of creating products to combat razor burn, bumps on the neck and other shaving woes, the men’s grooming company Jack Black decided it was time to attack the problem at the source. And so last year, the company, instead of embracing new technology, began selling a nearly 150-year-old invention: the safety razor.

headline: On This Day: ‘A New Birth of Freedom’
abstract: On this day in 1863, President Abraham Lincoln delivered the Gettysburg Address.
lead_paragraph: If there were a Hall of Fame for presidential speeches, the one celebrating an anniversary today would be a first-ballot selection.

headline: Society Dress Codes Require Decoding
abstract: Between “Cocktail Glamour” and “Black Tie Fly,” it’s easier to stay home, order takeout and watch a DVD.
lead_paragraph: It used to be so simple. Get an invitation to a nice dinner, and the dress code was crystal clear: “black tie” or “cocktail attire.”

headline: Uprooted Syrian Youths Express Themselves
abstract: Brendan Bannon worked with refugee children in Jordan to help them use photography to document their environment and express themselves.
lead_paragraph: Brendan Bannon worked with refugee children in Jordan to help them use photography to document their environment and express themselves.

headline: Discounts at Thomas Paul, Matter, Haand and Areaware
abstract: Sales on lamps, ceramics, pillows, spirits-related items and more.
lead_paragraph: Thomas Paul’s sample and warehouse sale takes place Friday through Sunday, with up to 80 percent off decorative pillows, bedding, bath items, kitchen textiles and gift items (22-inch square linen pillows, $110, will be $35); 9 North Moore Street (Varick Street).

headline: Open With Care (for Nordic Design)
abstract: Ana Denmark founded Skandicrush to sell Scandinavian housewares by subscription. Her name is a happy accident, or maybe destiny?
lead_paragraph: The success of Birchbox, the monthly beauty sample subscription box, has spawned many emulators. There are subscription boxes for nail polish, for organic snacks, for homemade food and handmade items. What there aren’t many of, Ana Denmark, 32, noticed, was a subscription box for housewares, particularly the clean and simple home goods from Scandinavia that she favors. After checking out dozens of boxes in the name of research, Ms. Denmark launched Skandicrush in August, sending out her first $50 package to subscribers in October. Currently running a one-woman, self-financed business, with inventory stored in her stepson’s bedroom (he’s at college), Ms. Denmark hopes to eventually expand the site into e-commerce, so you can get that butter dish after the box is gone. And she has ideas for some other boxes that don’t involve moisturizers or mixed nuts. She spoke to a reporter from her house in San Francisco. (This interview has been condensed and edited.)

headline: Bringing Sous Vide to the Home Cook
abstract: The cooking-in-a-bag technique that started in restaurants is poised to go mainstream as prices fall for the gadgetry involved.
lead_paragraph: Appliance manufacturers have lately been building a surge of high-tech, high-end gadgets for our kitchens, but a lot of them are pretty useless. Who needs a refrigerator with a built-in tablet computer, or an oven that can be turned off from afar? My guess is you’d be fine skipping many of these doodads.

headline: The Connected Kitchen
abstract: If there’s a cooking trend, chances are, there’s a product for the home cook. The technology columnists Molly Wood and Farhad Manjoo review their favorite new kitchen gadgets.
lead_paragraph: If there’s a cooking trend, chances are, there’s a product for the home cook. The technology columnists Molly Wood and Farhad Manjoo review their favorite new kitchen gadgets.

headline: Storybook Buildings, Authors Unknown
abstract: The mystery isn’t just who made them or where they came from, but why they’re still so affordable.
lead_paragraph: Hillsborough, N.C. — Few know exactly what to call the collection of Americana that fills Steven Burke and Randy Campbell’s Greek Revival compound.

headline: For Teenagers, Early School Start Means More Car Crashes, Study Finds
abstract: Teenage drivers who have a later school start time have fewer car accidents, according to a new study in The Journal of Clinical Sleep Medicine.
lead_paragraph: Teenage drivers who sleep later have fewer car accidents, a new study suggests.

headline: Obama Names Fatigue Specialist to Lead Traffic Safety Agency
abstract: The announcement, after a series of auto safety crises, comes almost a year after the departure of the previous top regulator.
lead_paragraph: In the face of a series of safety crises, President Obama moved Wednesday to fill a longstanding vacancy at the primary automotive safety agency.

headline: Nutcrackers: Masters of the Hard Shell
abstract: Chris Cosentino, a San Francisco chef, shops for practical and aesthetically pleasing nutcrackers.
lead_paragraph: As a child, Chris Cosentino loved using the simple wooden nutcrackers his grandfather made to separate nuts from their shells. And there were always plenty of bowls of nuts sitting around his grandparents’ homes.

headline: The Calculus of Climbing at the Edge
abstract: The risks I take are for myself, not for my corporate sponsors.
lead_paragraph: YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, Calif. — SEVEN years ago, when I started free soloing long, hard routes in Yosemite — climbing without a rope, gear or a partner — I did it because it seemed like the purest, most elegant way to scale big walls. Climbing, especially soloing, felt like a grand adventure, but I never dreamed it could be a profession. However, over the years sponsors came to me one by one. I assumed that they wanted me to represent their companies because they supported what I was doing.

headline: One of Our Closets Has a Mothball Smell. Should We Try to Fix It?
abstract: Mothballs not only smell unpleasant but their chemicals can be harmful. Consider one botanical alternative.

headline: Inside Bunny Mellon’s World
abstract: Reflecting refined simplicity, thousands of items are part of what one designer calls “the Super Bowl of grande-dame auctions.”
lead_paragraph: “Bunny wanted the space to present her own perfected self,” Mac Griswold, the cultural landscape historian and writer, was saying on Monday evening. “She had a highly developed sense of imperfect perfection.”

headline: Street Style in Hoboken, N.J.
abstract: Caitilin Gallagher, born and raised in Hoboken, was recently wearing a multicolored nearly floor-length cape that stood out for its style and practicality.
lead_paragraph: ­Often considered an extension of New York City, Hoboken, N.J., is home to commuters and young families as well as college students. High-rise developments line the waterfront, while the city’s storied institutions, like Carlo’s Bake Shop, remain intact. Caitilin Gallagher, born and raised in Hoboken, was walking along Washington Street to her parents’ house on a chilly fall afternoon recently. Her multicolored nearly floor-length cape stood out for its style and practicality. She kept the rest of her outfit comfy-casual but added a few polished accessories. This interview has been edited and condensed.

headline: Perry and Walker Threaten to Sue Over Immigration Order
abstract: The legal threats represent the latest escalation in the Republican Party’s campaign to stop the president from rewriting the nation’s immigration system without the consent of Congress.
lead_paragraph: BOCA RATON, Fla. — Govs. Rick Perry of Texas and Scott Walker of Wisconsin said Wednesday that they were weighing lawsuits to block President Obama from taking executive action granting new legal protections to five million undocumented immigrants.

headline: Home (Mostly) From Rome
abstract: Kevin Walz’s East Harlem apartment has textures, colors and artifacts influenced by a long Italian sojourn.
lead_paragraph: In September 1994, Kevin Walz, a recent widower, packed up his two young daughters and left New York for Italy. Nineteen years later to the very day, he was in a plane over the Atlantic, moving back home.

headline: Oud: Short Name, Big Effect
abstract: The heady, and usually pricey, fragrance happens to be the highlight of a handful of new products.
lead_paragraph: ­For those who love it, the intensely woody scent of oud incites a kind of delirium. And this fall, its fans are in luck: The heady, and usually pricey, fragrance happens to be the highlight of a handful of new products.

headline: Meet Jaysea DeVoe, One of the Youngest Yoga Teachers in the United States
abstract: Ms. DeVoe, 13, is among the youngest yoga teachers in the United States and something of a minor celebrity in her local yoga community.
lead_paragraph: On a sunny Saturday morning on Catalina Island, a group of students planted their feet on the pebbled beach and unfurled their yoga mats. Jaysea DeVoe, their 80-pound instructor, stood before them, clad in black-and-white striped yoga pants, giggling like the eighth grader she is.

headline: Blown Out of the Water
abstract: An Austrian artist and Venetian glassblower reimagine the plastic water bottle.
lead_paragraph: Davide Fuin, a master glassblower on the Venetian island Murano, was not amused to receive a box of plastic water bottles from Manuel Gorkiewicz. In fact, “he was very grumpy about it,” said Mr. Gorkiewicz, an artist in Vienna, who asked Mr. Fuin to create glass versions of the bottles, which had been trimmed to form a carafe, a beer glass, a wineglass and a schnapps glass. “To convince him, I told him, ‘It is like an ugly person that you will turn into a beautiful sculpture.’ ” The collection, which will be sold starting on Friday at UrbanGlass in Brooklyn, evolved (Mr. Fuin might say, “devolved”) from Mr. Gorkiewicz’s idea to update Adolf Loos’s Drinking set no. 248, crystal barware first produced in 1931 by Lobmeyr. “I made an ironic comment on this by using trashy, not very ecological things, which are around us every day,” he said. The carafe-and-five-glass set is $700. Information: urbanglass.org.

headline: Now, a Place for All of Those Place Mats
abstract: Chilewich place mats (and other products) are available in a dedicated shop in the Flatiron District.
lead_paragraph: Before Sandy Chilewich redefined the place mat, this workhorse of the tablescape was sometimes lacy, sometimes homely and almost always hard to clean. Chilewich, the company she founded in 2000, introduced sturdy mats woven of extruded strands of vinyl that are low-maintenance enough to be washed with a damp cloth and sophisticated enough to be sold by the Museum of Modern Art.

headline: Rooms That Set the Scene
abstract: “Novel Interiors” connects real homes to literary classics.
lead_paragraph: Lisa Borgnes Giramonti had families from books in mind when researching “Novel Interiors: Living in Enchanted Rooms Inspired by Literature” (due next month, $35). Scouting homes in Southern California, Manhattan and New Jersey, she found details evoking British moors and New England cottages.

headline: At a Gay-Specific Bookstore, Just Books on a Shelf Won’t Do
abstract: A gay bookstore gets a new home in the Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual and Transgender Community Center in Greenwich Village.
lead_paragraph: An independent bookstore opened last month with a performance by Gio Black Peter, a downtown artist. Wearing only black boxers, he stood on a translucent plastic tarp and read a poem entitled, “The Morning Star,” flanked by two beer-drinking men.

headline: For Opening Ceremony and Intel’s MICA Smart Bracelet, Beauty Beats Brains
abstract: The fashion brand and Intel work together on a smart bracelet.
lead_paragraph: FOR A LITTLE LESS than a year, Opening Ceremony and Intel have been working together to create a bracelet that can check your email and remind you when you have a meeting. And what happens when fashion designers and techies work together?

headline: Store Openings, Events and Sales in New York City
abstract: Belgian accessories label Kipling opens its first New York store; Todd Snyder is having a sample sale and more news.
lead_paragraph: ­On Thursday, Valley Nails, the downtown salon that put nail art on the map, opens a second location in Chelsea. The cozy space, fitted with Kubikoff chairs and custom nail tables created by the owner Nina Werman and the architecture and design studio Aviva Novick, will provide services like classic nail art for all 10 fingers ($15 to 25) and accent nail art to be applied to two digits ($10 to 20), with basic manicures starting at $30. At 237 West 15th Street. ­

headline: Is That Chervil Winking at Me?
abstract: Seed-package art renders vegetables and herbs with creativity and passion. Showing a little leg helps, too.
lead_paragraph: A seed should be fecund, no apologies. Yet certain vegetables may advertise their potency a little too insistently. That is, anatomically. O.K., pornographically.

headline: The Killings at a Jerusalem Synagogue
abstract: Readers react to the tragedy in Israel.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Partnership With CNBC Adds Context to Its News
abstract: Boxes of financial statistics are appearing as NBCUniversal News Group announces a strategic investment in Kensho that includes a larger agreement specifically with CNBC.
lead_paragraph: Fans of CNBC will wake up on Thursday to see a new set of sophisticated analytics putting daily financial news into historical context. The analytics will tell viewers and visitors to the CNBC website, for example, how energy stocks have historically responded after a huge snowstorm, or how stocks of Apple suppliers have typically performed after an iPhone release.

headline: Do School Behavior-Tracking Apps Help or Hurt?
abstract: Criticism and praise for ClassDojo, a classroom behavior-tracking app.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Senate’s Vote on the Keystone Pipeline
abstract: Readers react to the defeat of a bill despite intense lobbying by Senator Mary L. Landrieu of Louisiana.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Nurses Urge Leniency Over Refusal to Force-Feed at Guantánamo Bay
abstract: The case of a medical officer who refused to force-feed hunger strikers is the latest flash point in a heated debate over medical workers’ role in interrogation and torture.
lead_paragraph: The case of a Navy medical officer who refused to force-feed prisoners on a hunger strike at Guantánamo Bay prompted the country’s largest nursing organization on Wednesday to petition the Defense Department for leniency, citing professional ethical guidelines that support the officer’s decision.

headline: My Leftist Dentist
abstract: Ellen D. Murphy, a reader, offers a fond recollection.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Indonesia’s View on Growth
abstract: The Indonesian Embassy responds to an editorial.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Republicans Fed Up With NBC Host’s Immigration Questions
abstract: Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana tried to cut off an immigration discussion with Chuck Todd of NBC.
lead_paragraph: BOCA RATON, Fla. — How much do Republicans dislike talking about immigration these days?

headline: Cashing In on a Mortgage
abstract: Should refinancing come with greater restrictions to protect home buyers?

headline: Meeting U.S. Envoy, Putin Appears to Soften His Tone
abstract: Upon receiving the new American ambassador to Russia, President Vladimir V. Putin said Moscow and Washington could find avenues of cooperation despite recent tensions.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said Wednesday that Moscow and Washington could find avenues of practical cooperation if the partnership were based on “mutual respect and pragmatism.”

headline: NASA CO2 Animation Recalls 1859 Account of the Global Flow of this Gas
abstract: A new NASA visualization and an 1859 account by America’s first oceanographer make the same point about carbon dioxide.
lead_paragraph: A new NASA visualization shows how heat-trapping carbon dioxide from human sources mixes and spreads around the planet, and in so doing recalls for me a stirring 1859 description of the atmosphere written by Matthew Fontaine Maury, widely considered America’s first oceanographer. I quoted him in my 1992 book on global warming, centering on this phrase: “It is only he girdling encircling air, that flows above and around all, that makes the whole world kin.” Here’s the relevant excerpt:

headline: Mail Monitoring Rarely Denied, Postal Service Says
abstract: Out of about 6,700 requests to gather information for law enforcement agencies last year, only 10 were rejected, according to testimony at a congressional hearing on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States Postal Service granted almost all of the nearly 6,700 requests from law enforcement agencies last year to monitor the mail of Americans for use in criminal and national security investigations, Postal Service officials told a House panel on Wednesday.

headline: Harvard Students Move Fossil Fuel Stock Fight to Court
