abstract: Seven undergraduate, graduate and law students filed a lawsuit on Wednesday against the president and fellows of Harvard College for what they call “mismanagement of charitable funds.”
lead_paragraph: A group of Harvard students, frustrated by the university’s refusal to shed fossil fuel stocks from its investment portfolios, is looking beyond protests and resolutions to a new form of pressure: the courts.

headline: Colombia: Agreement Is Reached to Release General Held by Rebels
abstract: The country’s largest rebel group has agreed to free a captured army general and four other captives, officials said Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: The country’s largest rebel group has agreed to free an army general and four other captives, officials said Wednesday. The general’s capture on Sunday led President Juan Manuel Santos to suspend peace talks with the rebel group, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC. The deal to free the general, Rubén Darío Alzate, was announced in Havana by representatives of the governments of Cuba and Norway, facilitators of the peace talks, held in Havana for the past two years. The announcement said that the Colombian government and the FARC had agreed on the conditions necessary for the captives’ release and that they would be freed as soon as possible. The general will be released along with an army corporal and a military lawyer who were captured with him. Two other soldiers taken captive in a separate episode this month are also to be released, the officials said.

headline: For Goldman, Government Gift From 2008 Crisis Keeps Giving
abstract: The emergency changes that the government made in 2008 did far more than save Goldman and Morgan Stanley. They also bestowed special privileges that have persisted.
lead_paragraph: During the financial crisis in 2008, the government made a supremely generous move that most likely saved Goldman Sachs from collapse.

headline: Dressing Like My Mother
abstract: Clothes weren’t just indulgences. They were armor.
lead_paragraph: My mother used to dress up for airports and emergency rooms. When I was 3 and cracked my forehead open on a doorjamb, she had me change — I believe into a smocked white dress, an interesting choice for a child with a head wound — before we drove to the emergency room at NewYork-Presbyterian.

headline: Protesters Return to Cairo’s Streets to Mark an Anniversary
abstract: At least 48 protesters were arrested near Tahrir Square at rallies in memory of activists killed in clashes with the police in 2011.
lead_paragraph: At least 48 protesters were arrested in downtown Cairo on Wednesday as small groups of activists marched and chanted slogans in memory of colleagues killed in clashes with the police three years ago.

headline: A Pitch to Persuade Smartphone Snappers to Step Up to Nikons
abstract: Nikon is introducing a campaign this week aimed at the millennial consumers who are taking more photographs than ever, but with smartphones.
lead_paragraph: WHEN Paul Simon sang, “I got a Nikon camera, I love to take a photograph so, Mama, don’t take my Kodachrome away,” the idea of Kodachrome film disappearing was unexpected enough to make for a memorable lyric. All these years later, Kodachrome has indeed gone away, a fate that Nikon is fervently hoping to avoid.

headline: Uber’s Privacy Practices Questioned by Senator Franken
abstract: In a letter, Senator Al Franken asked Travis Kalanick, Uber’s chief executive, to explain how the company uses the data it collects on its users.
lead_paragraph: The relationship between the media and Uber has been strained as of late. It is not going so well on Capitol Hill, either.

headline: Thursday’s Matchup: Chiefs (7-3) at Raiders (0-10)
abstract: A look at how Kansas City and Oakland match up for Thursday night’s game.
lead_paragraph: 8:25 p.m. Eastern, NFL Network

headline: The Solid South Will Rise Again
abstract: The region has become so Republican, particularly since President Obama was elected, that there isn’t much left there for the Democrats to salvage.
lead_paragraph: Democrats have abandoned Senator Mary Landrieu of Louisiana, who is in a tough runoff election. (Tough is the mild way of putting it. Polls show her down by double digits to her Republican opponent.)

headline: Do Politicians Love Kids?
abstract: If American politicians are looking for a genuinely bipartisan issue to work together on, here’s a suggestion: invest in early education.
lead_paragraph: We Americans love children.

headline: Immigration Has Republican Governors Seething and Facing Practical Challenges
abstract: New legal protections for five million illegal immigrants would thrust the issue back into the states, creating issues like the granting of driver’s licenses or in-state college tuition.
lead_paragraph: BOCA RATON, Fla. — President Obama’s impending executive action on immigration is unleashing the fury of Republican governors who now control a clear majority of the nation’s statehouses — and not entirely for the reasons that partisans might expect.

headline: Chinese Interests Look to Malaysia for Cheap Iron Ore, and Profits
abstract: CAA Resources, controlled by China, reopened “Iron Hill,” a dormant iron mine in Bukit Besi, Malaysia, and is ramping up production despite the ore’s falling price.
lead_paragraph: BUKIT BESI, Malaysia — Giant mining equipment has stripped away the palm trees and other vegetation from a jungle bluff here with a Malay name that translates to “Iron Hill.” Huge power shovels gouge long furrows down cliffs of fuchsia clay, scooping out the shiny black iron ore at their base.

headline: Firefox Makes Yahoo Its New Default for Search, Replacing Google
abstract: Marissa Mayer, Yahoo’s chief executive, signaled with the deal with Mozilla that she still believes search is a part of the company’s future.
lead_paragraph: After a lucrative 10-year relationship, Mozilla is breaking up with Google and switching to Yahoo as the default search provider for its popular Firefox web browser.

headline: Times Square’s Costumed Characters Resist Push to Rein Them In
abstract: Hello Kitty, Batman and the Penguin were among the pop culture icons who appeared at a New York City Council hearing to oppose a bill that would require the performers to obtain licenses.
lead_paragraph: Hello Kitty, the Big Apple, the Penguin, the Joker and several other heroes, villains and pop culture icons appeared before the New York City Council on Wednesday to testify against a proposed bill that would regulate the ubiquitous and, occasionally, aggressive presence of costumed characters in Times Square.

headline: Missouri Attorney General Puts Limit on Contributions
abstract: Chris Koster, a Democrat, said he would refuse money from any company he had investigated after allegations that he dropped out of a multistate inquiry of an energy drink maker and settled for less than other states received in a case against a drug company.
lead_paragraph: Attorney General Chris Koster of Missouri, a Democrat whose plans to run for governor in 2016 have been hurt by reports that his office may have given preferential treatment to campaign contributors and lobbyists, announced a new policy Wednesday banning donations from any company that he had targeted for investigation.

headline: More Than a Battle, Kobani Is a Publicity War
abstract: The fractious Kurdish diaspora has pulled together against ISIS in the hope of creating a homeland in the area that is technically part of Syria.
lead_paragraph: SURUC, Turkey — Two months after the United States began bombing militants attacking Kobani in northern Syria, the fate of the obscure border town has become the defining battle of the broader contest with the Islamic State — to solidify, or roll back, its borders and ambitions.

headline: Chrysler Unveils a More-or-Less New 300
abstract: With a significant midcycle refresh of its 300 sedan, Chrysler tries to boost flagging sales.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The 2015 version of Chrysler’s 300 sedan is just new enough to be noteworthy. The 300, the brand’s flagship, was unveiled Wednesday at the Los Angeles Auto Show with a new front-end treatment, new electronic technology and new trim lines named after hip-sounding American cities. Hip-sounding, at least, to Chrysler’s marketers.

headline: Pakistani, Held in Iraq, Wins a Round in Court
abstract: The plaintiff, who was detained in Iraq in 2004, says he was tortured on and off for a decade, first by British and then by American troops.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A British court ruled Wednesday that a Pakistani man who was detained by British troops in Iraq on suspicion of links to terrorism but never charged could sue the British government over how he was treated.

headline: New Management Layer Suggested for Port Authority
abstract: A commissioner of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey proposed inserting two more highly paid executives into the agency’s top ranks.
lead_paragraph: In the 14 months since the unannounced closing of lanes of traffic to the George Washington Bridge, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has faced truckloads of criticism. But few, if any, of those critics have suggested that the problem was not enough layers of management.

headline: Three Bills to Curb Corporate Wrongdoing
abstract: Responding to the General Motors safety scandal, the bills would deter corporations from covering up defects and punish individuals and companies that do.
lead_paragraph: When it was learned this year that General Motors had long failed to notify regulators and the public about fatal ignition-switch defects, the outrage in Congress was bipartisan. Recent reports in The New York Times that the Japanese manufacturer Takata hid deadly airbag defects are also sure to inspire rebukes from members of both parties. Takata has rebutted the reports, but lawmakers have appropriately scheduled a hearing for Thursday and called for a criminal inquiry by the Justice Department.

headline: Ukraine’s Slow Collapse
abstract: Vladimir Putin, the Russian president, is largely responsible for the impasse in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: The crisis in Ukraine has reached an impasse. The cease-fire signed in Minsk, Belarus, in September never really took hold, but at least it provided a cover for efforts to reduce the level of fighting and focus on stabilizing and reforming the Ukrainian economy as a prelude to a serious, long-term search for a resolution of the crisis. Now even the fig leaf of cease-fire is gone. Russian armored vehicles are rolling into eastern Ukraine — disowned, of course, by Moscow.

headline: Jordan’s Open Door Is Now Only Cracked, Leaving Syrians Stranded
abstract: Thousands of Syrians, mostly women and children, have been stranded for weeks on Jordan’s border, according to aid agencies who say Jordan appears to be increasingly turning away Syrians fleeing war.
lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan — Thousands of Syrians, mostly women and children, have been stranded for weeks on Jordan’s border, according to international aid agencies who say Jordan appears to be increasingly turning away Syrians fleeing war at home.

headline: Unicef Plans a Global Singalong of John Lennon’s ‘Imagine’
abstract: An app invites users to sing along to several renditions of the song, by Lennon as well as Katy Perry, Angelique Kidjo and others.
lead_paragraph: Have you always thought you had the perfect harmony vocal line for John Lennon’s “Imagine” – or just thought the recording would have been a bit more interesting if you were singing along? The United Nations is offering you that chance.

headline: New Whitney Museum Building to Open in May
abstract: The Whitney Museum of American Art will open its new home, in a building designed by Renzo Piano, on May 1.
lead_paragraph: The Whitney Museum of American Art’s new Renzo Piano-designed building in Manhattan’s meatpacking district is to open on May 1.

headline: N.S.A. Phone Data Collection Could Go On, Even if a Law Expires
abstract: Senate Republicans on Tuesday night used a filibuster to block consideration of a bill to end and replace the N.S.A. phone records program.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A little-known provision of the Patriot Act, overlooked by lawmakers and administration officials alike, appears to give President Obama a possible way to keep the National Security Agency’s bulk phone records program going indefinitely — even if Congress allows the law on which it is based to expire next year.

headline: Analyst Sues New York City Council Over Firing
abstract: Artyom Matusov was fired after contacting reporters to question statistics on the use of force by police officers that the police commissioner presented to the Council in September.
lead_paragraph: A former policy analyst for the New York City Council filed a federal lawsuit on Wednesday claiming he was fired in September for publicly voicing his criticism over testimony given by William J. Bratton, the police commissioner, at a public hearing.

headline: At Long Last, Immigration Action
abstract: President Obama will use executive authority to change immigration policy, and rightly so, because he has given up waiting for Congress to act.
lead_paragraph: President Obama says he will speak to the nation on Thursday night about making major changes to immigration policy, including shielding several million unauthorized immigrants from deportation. He intends to do this under executive authority, because he has given up waiting for Congress to act.

headline: New Scrutiny of Goldman’s Ties to the New York Fed After a Leak
abstract: The perceived coziness between the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and Wall Street banks has been questioned after a recent leak.
lead_paragraph: From his desk in Lower Manhattan, a banker at Goldman Sachs thumbed through confidential documents — courtesy of a source inside the United States government.

headline: Your School Lost Every Game? Hey, Better Luck in the Postseason
abstract: High school football teams with losing records routinely enter the playoffs because there are not enough competitive teams to go around.
lead_paragraph: LOGANSPORT, La. — The Louisiana high school football playoffs opened last Friday, but it hardly felt encouraging as the East Iberville Tigers boarded a bus for a five-hour ride north toward certain defeat. The team was 0-10 for a second consecutive season, so overmatched that four players decided not to make the trip.

headline: Ebola Response in Liberia Is Hampered by Infighting
abstract: Poor coordination and serious disagreements between Liberian officials and the donors and health agencies fighting the epidemic are hindering results.
lead_paragraph: The global response to the Ebola virus in Liberia is being hampered by poor coordination and serious disagreements between Liberian officials and the donors and health agencies fighting the epidemic, according to minutes of top-level meetings and interviews with participants.

headline: Takata’s Switch to Cheaper Airbag Propellant Is at Center of Crisis
abstract: The auto supplier began using ammonium nitrate in airbags in 2001, but the compound is highly sensitive to temperature changes and can combust violently.
lead_paragraph: The new airbag propellant was supposed to be the next big thing for Takata in 1998. An engineer for the company, Paresh Khandhadia, declared it “the new technological edge” in an interview with a trade magazine then.

headline: Reaction to Uber Tactics Highlights Tech Journalists’ Fine Line Between Critic and Booster
abstract: Comments by an Uber executive about spying on a tech journalist have roiled the outspoken, competitive and often conflicted group of publications that cover Silicon Valley.
lead_paragraph: Monday night, BuzzFeed reported that an Uber executive had considered investigating the private life of the tech journalist Sarah Lacy because of her negative coverage of the company. Ms. Lacy responded almost instantaneously — and she was not happy.

headline: University of California Is Set to Raise Tuition
abstract: Despite protests and a last-ditch effort by Gov. Jerry Brown to block an increase in costs, the University of California Board of Regents approved a plan to raise tuition 27.6 percent over five years.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Over the protests of hundreds of angry and chanting students, a panel of the University of California Board of Regents gave preliminary approval Wednesday to a plan to raise tuition 27.6 percent over five years, turning aside a last-ditch effort by Gov. Jerry Brown to block it.

headline: Ebola’s Economic Cost Re-Examined
abstract: The World Bank chief economist for Africa said the cost may be $3 billion or $4 billion, not the worst-case outcome of more than $32 billion.
lead_paragraph: Ebola’s economic cost to sub-Saharan Africa may only be a fraction of the worst-case forecast made last month because of progress since then in halting the spread of the disease, a World Bank official said Wednesday, but he warned against relaxation in the containment effort.

headline: Criminal Complaint Against Kevin Darden
abstract: Mr. Darden was arraigned on charges he killed a man by shoving him in front of a subway train in the Bronx.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Darden was arraigned on charges he killed a man by shoving him in front of a subway train in the Bronx.

headline: Tough Times for Penguins
abstract: That new era of bipartisan cooperation in Washington didn’t last long. Still, we’re doing better than the king penguins.
lead_paragraph: Scientists say that fur seals in the Antarctic are having sex with the penguins.

headline: Suspect in Fatal Bronx Subway Push Has a History of Legal Trouble
abstract: Kevin Darden, 34, who is charged with murder, has a lengthy arrest record punctuated by charges of assault, menacing and attempted arson.
lead_paragraph: For most of his adult life, wherever Kevin Darden went, he found trouble with the law. There were arrests on minor charges, like theft and marijuana possession, and on bigger ones — choking a girlfriend; punching a 73-year-old stranger; and menacing Midtown Manhattan pedestrians with a metal broomstick.

headline: A Hammer Comes Down in Colombia on an Honor for Britain
abstract: An activist took things into his own hands after a historical marker commemorating the death of British and American troops was unveiled in a ceremony attended by Prince Charles.
lead_paragraph: CARTAGENA, Colombia — The strange events that unfolded here in recent days involved, in one way or another, Prince Charles of England; George Washington’s older brother Lawrence; the British admiral after whom Mount Vernon was named; a one-eyed, one-legged Spanish seaman who has been dead for 273 years; and an angry animal rights activist with a hammer.

headline: Cuomo Discusses Response to Snowstorm
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said that equipment from all over New York and neighboring states would be taken to Buffalo and western New York to deal with the powerful storm.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said that equipment from all over New York and neighboring states would be taken to Buffalo and western New York to deal with the powerful storm.

headline: As Ferguson Grand Jury Report Looms, Police Say They Don’t Fear Protests
abstract: A grand jury will soon decide whether to indict the officer who shot Michael Brown. Many police departments across the country said they were preparing for protests but expecting little trouble.
lead_paragraph: As a grand jury in St. Louis nears a decision on whether to indict a white police officer in the fatal shooting of a black teenager, activists are planning scores of protests across the nation, leading the F.B.I. to warn of potential violence and some cities to take the threat seriously.

headline: Hometown Boy, Recycled
abstract: John Doyle, known for his revivals, has his way with “Allegro,” a 1947 musical that followed Rodgers and Hammerstein’s blockbuster successes.
lead_paragraph: Having your own personal Greek chorus has never sounded all that appealing. Who wants to be surrounded by a lot of second-guessing Everypeople, the way poor Oedipus and Electra were, while having to listen to observations like: “Boy, that was a stupid move, you shortsighted fool. You’re doomed, doomed!”?

headline: Having a Sense of Pride
abstract: Will Timothy Polin reveal his secret identity in this puzzle?
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — Today we learn that our constructor, Timothy Polin, may have a secret identity. Once you finish the puzzle and read the notepad, which says, “After completing this puzzle, connect nine appropriate letters in order to discover an image associated with 44 Down,” you will find out who he really is.

headline: Bills Get Snow Day and Logistics Headache
abstract: With Ralph Wilson Stadium already covered by four feet of snow, the Bills were unable to practice in preparation for Sunday’s scheduled home game against the Jets.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Allen Iverson, the former point guard of the Philadelphia 76ers, questioned the value of practice in a 2002 rant that became as memorable as anything he did on the court. The Buffalo Bills can only hope he is correct.

headline: A Social Climber in Pursuit of Love, Literature and Other Things
abstract: “The Underclassman” is adapted from F. Scott Fitzgerald’s earliest novel, loosely based on his days at Princeton.
lead_paragraph: Edmund Wilson, what a sweetheart! Seems that before he became a pre-eminent literary critic, he was a really swell guy, a hell of a pal.

headline: Passing Rate Declines by 20% as State Uses New Certification Exams for Teachers
abstract: The fall in certifications resembles, in some respects, the state’s experience with the Common Core, a set of more rigorous learning standards for students that has been adopted by New York and most other states.
lead_paragraph: New York State saw a significant drop in the number of candidates who passed teacher certification tests last year as tougher exams were introduced, state officials said on Wednesday, portraying the results as a long-needed move to raise the level of teaching and the performance of teacher preparation schools.

headline: Willy Burgdorfer, Who Found Bacteria That Cause Lyme Disease, Is Dead at 89
abstract: Dr. Burgdorfer’s familiar finding while conducting tick surgery solved the mysteries of an ailment that had affected scores of people.
lead_paragraph: Willy Burgdorfer, a medical entomologist who in 1982 identified the cause of what had been a mysterious affliction, Lyme disease, died on Monday at a hospital in Hamilton, Mont. He was 89.

headline: Massachusetts Town Votes to End Bid for Tobacco Ban
abstract: A week after a public hearing of angry citizens was cut short, the Board of Health in Westminster, Mass., voted to stop pursuing a proposed ban on tobacco.
lead_paragraph: In the face of a revolt by townspeople, the Board of Health in Westminster, Mass., voted Wednesday to drop a proposal to ban the sale of all tobacco and nicotine products.

headline: Jimmy Ruffin, Singer of a Memorable Motown Hit, Dies at 78
abstract: Mr. Ruffin was best known for the plaintive “What Becomes of the Brokenhearted,” a hit in 1966.
lead_paragraph: Jimmy Ruffin, a soul singer best known for his plaintive 1966 Top 10 hit “What Becomes of the Brokenhearted,” died on Monday in a Las Vegas hospital. He was 78.

headline: Indiana: Rites Set for American Killed by Islamic State
abstract: A funeral service for Peter Kassig, a former Army Ranger who was beheaded last weekend by Islamic State extremists, will be held Friday at an Islamic center in Fishers, Ind.
lead_paragraph: A funeral service for a former Army Ranger who was beheaded last weekend by Islamic State extremists will be held Friday at an Islamic center in Fishers, Ind. The center, the Al Huda Foundation, said in a statement that it was “honored to host this service” in memory of Peter Kassig, an aid worker who disappeared in Syria while delivering medical supplies. Mr. Kassig, the third American killed by the Islamic State, adopted the Muslim name Abdul-Rahman after spending more than a year in captivity. Over the summer, Mr. Kassig was able to smuggle a letter to his family in which he detailed fears for his life. “Just know I’m with you. Every stream, every lake, every field and river,” Mr. Kassig wrote. “In the woods and in the hills, in all the places you showed me. I love you.”

headline: The Secret Life of Passwords
abstract: We despise them – yet we imbue them with our hopes and dreams, our dearest memories, our deepest meanings. They unlock much more than our accounts.
lead_paragraph: We despise them – yet we imbue them with our hopes and dreams, our dearest memories, our deepest meanings. They unlock much more than our accounts.

headline: North Korea: Plutonium Extraction May Be Restarting, Institute Says
abstract: An American research institute reported Wednesday that North Korea might be preparing to reprocess spent nuclear fuel to extract weapons-grade plutonium at its main nuclear complex north of its capital, Pyongyang.
lead_paragraph: An American research institute reported Wednesday that North Korea might be preparing to reprocess spent nuclear fuel to extract weapons-grade plutonium at its main nuclear complex north of its capital, Pyongyang. The organization, the U.S.-Korea Institute at Johns Hopkins University, reported on the website 38 North that recent commercial satellite imagery of the North’s Yongbyon Nuclear Scientific Research Center showed evidence of a lengthy reactor shutdown. It suggested fuel rods might have been removed from the reactor in preparation for extracting plutonium from the spent rods. Also on Thursday, North Korea warned that the recent vote at the United Nations to refer the North’s leaders to the International Criminal Court for prosecution for crimes against humanity left the country no option but to consider another nuclear test..

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 19, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: U.N. Security Council Calls to Block Recruiting of Militants
abstract: The United Nations Security Council unanimously adopted a statement asking all countries to thwart foreign-born militants who have sought to join extremist groups.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations Security Council unanimously adopted a statement on Wednesday asking all countries to thwart foreign-born militants who have sought to join the Islamic State, the Nusra Front and other extremist groups whose violent campaigns have convulsed the Middle East. The Security Council statement, which reflected the recommendations of a United Nations panel made public on Monday, said all countries should take steps to block the sale of smuggled oil and antiquities that the Islamic State uses to help finance itself.

headline: Knicks Fall Once More As Defense Is Listless
abstract: The night after Carmelo Anthony said his left knee has bothered him since Oct. 30, he contributed 20 points and 4 rebounds, but the Knicks still lost their ninth in 10 games.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — The hunt for encouraging moments during another dreary Knicks loss — their ninth in 10 games — began and ended with Carmelo Anthony.

headline: The Secret Life of Passwords
abstract: We despise them – yet we imbue them with our hopes and dreams, our dearest memories, our deepest meanings. They unlock much more than our accounts.
lead_paragraph: Howard Lutnick, the chief executive of Cantor Fitzgerald, one of the world’s largest financial-services firms, still cries when he talks about it. Not long after the planes struck the twin towers, killing 658 of his co-workers and friends, including his brother, one of the first things on Lutnick’s mind was passwords. This may seem callous, but it was not.

headline: New York City Council Hearing on Fee for Bags Becomes Heated
abstract: Council members discussed creating a 10-cent charge for each single-use checkout bag at retail and grocery stores.
lead_paragraph: For years, the plastic bag has doubled as a sort of urban tumbleweed, sweeping across New York City sidewalks and encroaching ominously on its waterways, clustering on subway tracks and drifting airborne to the tree limbs of residential blocks.

headline: R.A. Montgomery, 78, Dies; Published Choose Your Own Adventure Series
abstract: Mr. Montgomery recognized the potential of a book that let the reader choose between two actions and endings.
lead_paragraph: You are a young publisher searching for the next trend in children’s fiction in 1975 when a first-time author submits a peculiar manuscript that lets readers decide the protagonist’s fate. Do you publish the book or send the author packing?

headline: As Nets Take On Bucks, the Boos, and the Win, Go to Jason Kidd
abstract: The Brooklyn crowd jeered Kidd, the Bucks’ new coach, who had an acrimonious split with the Nets over the summer. But an improving Milwaukee team pulled out a victory at Barclays Center.
lead_paragraph: The sounds coming from the stands at Barclays Center shifted wildly over the course of Wednesday night, from hissing jeers to raucous roars to stunned quiet.

headline: A Lesson in the Cost of Resilience From a Mother Securing Her Family’s Future
abstract: To escape abuse, Yolanda Peguero, 36, uprooted her three children to a new home. Now she is pursing her registered nurse degree, and says she will not let her past get in her way.
lead_paragraph: Protecting her family has come with costs that Yolanda Peguero is willing to pay. They are part of parenthood. Getting her children to understand them, however, has proved more challenging.

headline: Sharing Password Stories
abstract: People explain the origins of their most personal keepsake passwords.
lead_paragraph: People explain the origins of their most personal keepsake passwords.

headline: The Secret Life of Passwords
abstract: For some people, passwords protect dreams, secrets, even fears, and serve as a daily reminder of what matters most.
lead_paragraph: For some people, passwords protect dreams, secrets, even fears, and serve as a daily reminder of what matters most.

headline: Lost Numbers
abstract: Howard Lutnick had to rebuild Cantor Fitzgerald after losing nearly 700 people on Sept. 11, 2001, beginning with a search for the passwords only they knew.
lead_paragraph: Howard Lutnick had to rebuild Cantor Fitzgerald after losing nearly 700 people on Sept. 11, 2001, beginning with a search for the passwords only they knew.

headline: Google Play Store Opens to Chinese Developers
abstract: Google said it would offer Chinese developers a way to sell mobile applications outside of mainland China by giving them access to its Play Store, which runs on Android phones and tablets.
lead_paragraph: One of Silicon Valley’s favorite parlor games is to guess when Google will push to do more business in mainland China, a market it mostly left in 2010 over concerns about censorship.

headline: John T. Downey Dies at 84; Held Captive in China for 20 Years
abstract: Mr. Downey became the longest-serving American prisoner of war by surviving more than 20 years in Chinese prisons after being shot down over Manchuria in 1952.
lead_paragraph: John T. Downey, a former C.I.A. agent who became the longest-serving American prisoner of war by surviving more than 20 years in Chinese prisons after he was shot down over Manchuria in 1952, died on Monday at a hospice in Branford, Conn. He was 84.

headline: National Book Award Goes to Phil Klay for His Short Story Collection
abstract: Mr. Klay won the fiction award for his debut collection, “Redeployment,” which draws on his experience as a Marine who served in Iraq.
lead_paragraph: Phil Klay won the National Book Award for fiction on Wednesday night for his debut short story collection, “Redeployment,” which draws on his experience serving as a Marine in Iraq and captures the terror, boredom and occasionally the humorous side of war.

headline: Facebook Shuttle Bus Drivers Vote to Unionize
abstract: The bus drivers say they are inadequately paid and endure a stressful work schedule of split shifts.
lead_paragraph: In a rare win for labor in Silicon Valley, the shuttle bus drivers who ferry Facebook employees to and from work voted on Wednesday to unionize, 43 to 28.

headline: The Elder Statesman Opens Its First Retail Outpost in L.A.
abstract: Greg Chait’s CFDA-award-winning knitwear line has set up shop in a converted bungalow off Melrose Avenue.
lead_paragraph: Greg Chait founded his playful luxury knitwear line the Elder Statesman on the principle that classic craftsmanship and the finest materials don’t have to feel stuffy. The same is true of the brand’s first store in its hometown of Los Angeles, which opens this weekend in a converted West Hollywood bungalow just off Melrose Avenue. “The good news about the space is that it isn’t locked,” Chait says of the open floor plan. “I left it with a living, breathing vibe, one that would represent the creative freedom instilled in the goods we make.” The 1,600-square-foot structure is housed next to an outdoor courtyard of equal size, while the interior, created in collaboration with the influential design firm Commune, features skylights and succulents as well as more personal details like Chait’s grandmother’s artwork and a carefully chosen assortment of found objects. “It’s really all about less details,” Chait says, “but ones that are strong and honest.”

headline: Finland’s Foremost Fashion Line Introduces Housewares
abstract: Samuji, whose clothes are sold at boutiques like Maryam Nassir Zadeh and Mohawk General Store, is launching Koti, a range of handcrafted linens and kitchen goods.
lead_paragraph: For Samu-Jussi Koski, the founder and head designer of the emerging Helsinki-based fashion brand Samuji — whose richly textured, well-tailored men’s and women’s pieces are carried by such influential boutiques as Maryam Nassir Zadeh and Mohawk General Store — launching a home line has been on the to-do list since day one. “I wanted a complete world, not only a fashion label, but something deeper,” says Koski, who previously served as the creative director at Marimekko. “We started with women’s clothes a year ago, we introduced men’s and now, there’s Koti, the Finnish word for ‘home.’”

headline: Times Square Seen Through Fresh Eyes
abstract: A series from the Brooklyn-based photographer Zachary Smith captures the meta sight of tourists snapping their own shots.
lead_paragraph: In this weekly series, T’s photo editors share the most compelling visual projects they’ve discovered.

headline: Minivans Fare Poorly in Tests Mimicking a Collision
abstract: Three minivans received a Poor rating from the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety in its small overlap front crash test.
lead_paragraph: The Insurance Institute for Highway Safety said on Thursday that three minivans had failed its “small overlap” front crash test, with one van experiencing the deepest intrusion into the passenger compartment of any vehicle ever evaluated in the test.

headline: Word of the Day | impenitent
abstract: This word has appeared in three New York Times articles in the past two years.
lead_paragraph: impenitent •\im-ˈpe-nən-tənt\• adjective

headline: Undermanned and 0-10: Welcome to the Playoffs
abstract: The East Iberville High School football team, like other teams across the United States, reached the playoffs despite having a losing record.
lead_paragraph: The East Iberville High School football team, like other teams across the United States, reached the playoffs despite having a losing record.

headline: General Motors Is Sued by Arizona for $3 Billion Over Recalls
abstract: The suit is the first major legal action to be taken against the automaker over its record number of vehicle recalls this year.
lead_paragraph: The attorney general of Arizona said on Wednesday that the state had filed suit against General Motors, claiming that the automaker had defrauded the state’s consumers of an estimated $3 billion.

headline: Knicks’ New D-League Team Mirrors the Parent Club, Right Down to the Losses
abstract: Westchester, which shares an ownership, a nickname and a practice center with the Knicks, is also learning the triangle offense in a partnership that should be beneficial for both clubs.
lead_paragraph: WHITE PLAINS — As soon as he was named the coach of the Knicks’ new Development League affiliate in early October, Kevin Whitted attached himself to everything the big club was doing: shadowing practices, coaches’ meetings and film sessions, soaking up all he could.

headline: Giants’ Eli Manning Defends His Play and Deflects Criticism of Tom Coughlin
abstract: Manning, coming off a game in which he threw five interceptions, said he could “still play at an extremely high level” and wanted to be a Giant for the rest of his career.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Eli Manning had one of the worst games of his N.F.L. career on Sunday, throwing five interceptions as the Giants lost to the San Francisco 49ers. But the performance has not shaken Manning’s confidence or his desire to remain a Giant for the rest of his career.

headline: With Cam Talbot in Net, Rangers Continue Mastery of Flyers at the Garden
abstract: Kevin Klein and Rick Nash scored, and Talbot had 31 saves as the Rangers defeated the Flyers at Madison Square Garden for the ninth straight time.
lead_paragraph: The Rangers would be thrilled to see the Philadelphia Flyers visit as often as possible.

headline: Kevin Long, Mets’ Hitting Coach, Also Works From the Mound
abstract: The team is hoping that Kevin Long, who throws batting practice left-handed to lefty hitters, will help Curtis Granderson and Lucas Duda.
lead_paragraph: Kevin Long is left-handed.

headline: Fantasy Football: Week 12 Matchup Breakdown
abstract: Tony Romo, LeSean McCoy and T. Y. Hilton are among the players with favorable fantasy football matchups this weekend.
lead_paragraph: The Colts’ defense has somehow managed to allow the most fantasy points in a single game this season to a quarterback (Ben Roethlisberger’s 56 in Week 8) and, after Patriots running back Jonas Gray’s 44-point performance last weekend, a running back. Is it Jaguars receiver Cecil Shorts’s turn this weekend?

headline: What’s on TV Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (Starz Cinema) THE PATIENCE STONE (2013) A beautiful young Afghan woman (Golshifteh Farahani) confesses her fears, resentments and dreams to her much older husband (Hamidrez Javdan, above, with Ms. Farahani), a comatose guerrilla fighter with a bullet in his neck — things she might never say if he were awake — in this drama directed by Atiq Rahimi, adapted from his 2008 novel. The film’s outline mirrors an Afghan myth, “The 70-Year-Old Corpse,” which Richard M. Dorson, the editor of the book “Folktales Told Around the World,” said “had been told by women ‘as a healthy expression of their stifled feelings in a male-dominated world,’ ” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “That pretty much distills the fictionalized world represented in ‘The Patience Stone,’ although Mr. Rahimi takes a rather more poetic approach to the same subject, using universals (Man and Woman) as proxies in a battle that, as the story progresses, takes on an abstract quality. Yet while there may be truths in some universals, it’s hard to forget that this tale has its roots in a bitterly real world.”

headline: North Korea Threatens to Conduct Nuclear Test
abstract: North Korea said the actions would be in response to a United Nations committee’s recommendation to prosecute North Korean leaders for rights violations.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea said on Thursday that the country had no option but to consider another nuclear test after the recent “political provocation” by the United Nations to try to indict the North’s leaders for crimes against humanity.

headline: Gunman at Florida State Spoke of Being Watched
abstract: Investigators were trying to determine why the man opened fire in a campus library. He was shot and killed by the police.
lead_paragraph: The gunman who shot three people at a library on Florida State University’s main campus in Tallahassee early Thursday was an alumnus who said the government was watching him, and he detailed his fears in a written journal and videos, the authorities said.

abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Thursday, November 20, 2014.

abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, November 20, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “It’s getting so hard to call my mom. I’ve had to tell her, ‘There is a victory coming, and I don’t know if you’re part of it.'”

headline: Deadly School Van Crash Revives Concerns Over Safety Standards
abstract: A collision with a commercial truck hauling sand in Shandong Province killed 11 kindergartners and the driver.
lead_paragraph: A school van crash in the eastern Chinese province of Shandong has reignited longstanding fears about the safety of the country’s children as they travel to school each day.

headline: ThyssenKrupp Posts First Annual Profit in 3 Years
abstract: In an apparent sign of confidence, the German industrial conglomerate said it would propose paying a small dividend after a three-year suspension.
lead_paragraph: ThyssenKrupp, the German steel maker and industrial conglomerate, reported its first annual net profit in three years on Thursday. And in an apparent sign of confidence, the company proposed paying a small dividend of 11 cents a share for the first time in three years.

lead_paragraph: After months of repair work, the classical music station WQXR began giving out instruments received during a donation drive to some passionate young musicians.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | ‘Extreme’ Snowstorm Pummels Western New York
abstract: Where has a powerful snowstorm swept, creating snowdrifts as high as houses, trapping people in their homes and forcing hundreds of motorists to abandon their cars on roads that were quickly buried in blizzard-like conditions?
lead_paragraph: In “ ‘Extreme’ Snowstorm Pummels Western New York,” Sara Dinatale, Lauren D’Avolio and Marc Santora write about the weather emergency facing the Buffalo area.

headline: China Detains an American Who Assists North Koreans

lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A Korean-American aid worker who lived in China on the border with North Korea for more than a decade has been detained by the Chinese authorities, his lawyer said Thursday.

headline: Chris Christie Is Back
abstract: A year after bridge-gate, the governor of New Jersey has completed an unlikely comeback. So what’s next?
lead_paragraph: “If I fix this, you have to start the story with it,” Chris Christie told me, yanking the string of the venetian blind in the diner window. We were eating a late lunch at a place called Howley’s, next to a motor lodge on South Dixie Highway, in West Palm Beach. It was the last Sunday in October, nine days before the midterm elections, and the 4 p.m. twilight was beaming directly into the eyes of the governor of New Jersey. Christie’s communications director, Maria Comella, had already tried and failed to lower the blinds, inadvertently bunching them up even more. I had given it a shot, too. Finally, Christie rose and maneuvered himself across the booth to make his own attempt. Walking with a slight limp, which he occasionally does after sitting for a while, Christie grabbed the strings, one in each hand, tugged a few times and grunted. Then, after a final jerk, the blinds fell splendidly into place.

headline: Uprooted Syrian Youths Express Themselves
abstract: Brendan Bannon worked with refugee children in Jordan to help them use photography to document their environment and express themselves.
lead_paragraph: In 2003, Brendan Bannon was teaching photography to H.I.V.-infected Romanian children in a workshop titled “The Most Important Picture.” One girl, Carla, moved him deeply when she explained why she chose a self-portrait as the “most important picture” she had taken: When she was gone, others could look at it and remember her.

headline: Drive Brings Thousands of Instruments for Aspiring Musicians in Public Schools
abstract: New Yorkers gave more than 2,900 unwanted instruments, from accordions to xylophones, in response to an effort organized by the classical radio station WQXR.
lead_paragraph: For aspiring musicians in New York City public schools, a working instrument can be a rare commodity.

headline: What Are You Thankful For?
abstract: As Thanksgiving approaches, what are you grateful for? Why?
lead_paragraph: As Thanksgiving approaches, what are you grateful for? Why?

headline: Chief of Ferry Company in South Korea Is Given 10-Year Jail Sentence
abstract: Kim Han-sik, 71, the head of the Chonghaejin Marine Company, was convicted of accidental homicide and embezzlement over the sinking of the ferry Sewol in April.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The head of the company whose ferry sank in April, killing more than 300 people in one of South Korea’s worst disasters in decades, was convicted on Thursday of accidental homicide and embezzlement and sentenced to 10 years in prison.

headline: Royal Bank of Scotland Fined $88 Million Over Technology Failure
abstract: A software problem in June 2012 left more than 6.5 million customers at R.B.S., National Westminster Bank and Ulster Bank unable to access their accounts.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – British regulators fined the Royal Bank of Scotland 56 million pounds, or about $88 million, on Thursday over a technology failure that left millions of customers unable to access their accounts for several weeks in 2012.

headline: Man Stabs 7 Hospital Workers to Death in China, Police Say
abstract: The suspect, a 27-year-old employee at the military hospital, famous for gatherings of Communist Party leaders, had no known motive, according to a police statement.
lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — A man fatally stabbed six nurses and a manager on Thursday at a Chinese military hospital in a seaside area famous for gatherings of Communist Party leaders, police officials in China said. One other nurse was injured in the attack.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: New York Today: Plastic Bag Talk
abstract: Thursday: Weighing in on a 10-cent plastic bag fee, a warmer day, and a silent performance group.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this thawing Thursday.

headline: In Step to Lower Carbon Emissions, China Will Place a Limit on Coal Use in 2020
abstract: The State Council, China’s cabinet, released details of an energy strategy that includes capping coal consumption at 4.2 billion tons.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China plans to set a cap on coal consumption in 2020, an important step for the country in trying to achieve a recently announced goal of having carbon dioxide emissions peak by around 2030.

headline: Washington Post Releases Free App for Kindle, in First Collaboration With Amazon
abstract: The ideas and preoccupations of Jeff Bezos, who bought The Post last year, have quietly reshaped the paper, including a new focus on international growth.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In recent months, The Washington Post has been worried about reducing “cognitive overhead.”

headline: India’s Lethal Birth Control
abstract: Official policies of mass female sterilization are not only outdated but dangerous.
lead_paragraph: There’s no secret to reducing population growth: Women who are informed about and given access to contraception choices have fewer children. Yet India persists in a cruel strategy of bringing down birthrates through mass female sterilization. In poorer states with high birthrates, health workers are driven by threats and induced by incentives to cut any corners necessary to meet government targets.

headline: Economic Activity Slows in Eurozone, Survey Shows
abstract: The Markit purchasing managers’ index slipped to 51.4 in November, from 52.1 in October, but stayed above 50, indicating expansion.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — More gloomy economic data for the eurozone arrived on Thursday, with activity dropping to a 16-month low as France weakened further and manufacturing slowed in Germany, a private sector survey showed.

headline: Kerry and French Counterpart Meet Ahead of Iran Nuclear Talks in Vienna
abstract: The secretary of state sought to close ranks with an important ally before joining the negotiations over Tehran’s nuclear program.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Secretary of State John Kerry met with his French counterpart here on Thursday as he sought to close ranks with a key negotiating partner before heading to Vienna for a crucial round of negotiations over Iran’s nuclear program.

headline: Daily Report: Applicants Sanitize Online Profiles as More Colleges Pry
abstract: Warned that colleges are increasingly investigating digital histories, high school students are cleaning up their public social media activity.
lead_paragraph: Admissions officers at Morehouse College in Atlanta were shocked several years ago when a number of high school seniors submitted applications using email addresses containing provocative language, Natasha Singer reports.

headline: Social Media Deepens Partisan Divides. But Not Always.
abstract: Studies find that to keep a broad perspective online, just as in the real world, it helps to have a range of friends.
lead_paragraph: If there seems to be an unbridgeable gulf between conservatives and liberals in the United States, social networking sites might be partly to blame, according to a new study.

headline: Checking In on an Entrepreneur With Too Many Start-Ups
abstract: The actual splitting of the two vastly different ventures, legally and financially, so each could “live or die on its own,” took more time and effort than Mr. Badshah expected.
lead_paragraph: As we reported last year in a case study, Aseem Badshah has a happy but vexing problem — deciding how to manage two promising start-ups. In the end, he decided to split them up and focus his energy on the one he thought had greater potential. But the transition was not easy.

headline: Today in Politics
abstract: Republican options for stopping President Obama’s immigration action may be limited because Congress doesn’t control the immigration agency’s finances.
lead_paragraph: Washington Holds Its Breath Over Immigration Speech

headline: Britain Drops Its Challenge to Cap on Banker Bonuses
abstract: The country abandoned its effort after an adviser to the Court of Justice of the European Union rejected all of the country’s claims on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain on Thursday dropped its challenge to the European bonus cap after an adviser to the Court of Justice of the European Union rejected all of the country’s claims.

headline: Morning Agenda: Goldman’s Ties to New York Fed Under Fire
abstract: A recent leak calls into question the links between the New York Fed and Wall Street banks. | Senate criticizes banks’ role in commodities. | Fed shifts concern to low inflation. | New opposition to Lazard banker’s nomination to Treasury post.
lead_paragraph: A recent leak has called into question the perceived coziness between the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and Wall Street banks, DealBook’s Jessica Silver-Greenberg, Ben Protess and Peter Eavis report. A Goldman Sachs banker received confidential information from a former colleague who was still working at the New York Fed, providing Goldman a window into the New York Fed’s private insights, including details about at least one of Goldman’s clients, lawyers briefed on the matter said. The incident illustrates the blurred lines between Wall Street and the government and the potential conflicts of interest that can result.

headline: Mike Nichols, Urbane Director Loved by Crowds and Critics, Dies at 83
abstract: One of America’s most decorated directors, Mr. Nichols had a protean résumé of critic- and crowd-pleasing work, including “The Graduate” in film and “The Odd Couple” on stage.
lead_paragraph: Mike Nichols, one of America’s most celebrated directors, whose long, protean résumé of critic- and crowd-pleasing work earned him adulation both on Broadway and in Hollywood, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 83.

headline: With Bad Economic News for Japan, Abe’s Magic Seems to Evaporate
abstract: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s stimulus program faces opposition from a powerful ministry, while some economists say it doesn’t go far enough in restructuring the economy.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Is this the end of Abenomics? And if so, why did it fail?

headline: NRG Seeks to Cut 90% of Its Carbon Emissions
abstract: The company, which operates coal and other conventional power plants, plans for a reduction of 50 percent by 2030 and 90 percent by 2050.
lead_paragraph: NRG, which built a leading electricity business from coal and other conventional power plants, is aiming to reduce its carbon emissions 50 percent by 2030 and 90 percent by 2050, the company said on Thursday.

headline: In a Video, ISIS Fighters Call for Attacks in France
abstract: The seven-minute clip, released by an Islamic State affiliate, appears to be part of an intensifying effort to recruit young Europeans.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A new propaganda video from the militant group Islamic State shows three French fighters calling on Muslims in France to carry out attacks there or join the group’s fight in Iraq and Syria, according to a jihadist monitoring organization.

headline: Technip of France Offers to Buy Oil Services Firm CGG

lead_paragraph: LONDON – Technip of France said on Thursday that it had approached CGG, an oil services company, about a potential takeover and offered to acquire the smaller company for about 1.46 billion euros, or about $1.8 billion.

headline: Tiptoeing (on Point) Through the Tulips
abstract: The ritual of presenting flowers to ballerinas onstage is complex: how many, what kind, who gives and gets them, and how they are bestowed and received.
lead_paragraph: London — Breathing hard, the Royal Ballet dancers lined up onstage here to take their bows after the premiere of David Dawson’s new piece last season. Out came the ushers bearing armfuls of flowers from the company. Then, to the shock of insiders and disapproval of traditionalists, bouquets were handed to the men as well as the women. Long-suffering balletomanes reeled back in their seats. Twitter was abuzz.

headline: The Most Globally Influential French Fashionistas?

lead_paragraph: Vanity Fair France has compiled its latest list of the “Most Influential French People in the World,” and it is, I have to say, kind of surprising — at least when it comes to the top 40 names, and fashion.

headline: Fiction Echoes Political Fact in Hong Kong TV Drama
abstract: Hundreds of thousands of Hong Kong residents tuned in Wednesday to watch the first episode of “The Election,” a 15-part series depicting a political tussle that bears a remarkable resemblance to the current turmoil on the city’s streets.
lead_paragraph: Over the past two months, hardly a day has gone by when Hong Kong residents have not been exposed to protests and politics.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama chose confrontation over conciliation on Thursday as he asserted the powers of the Oval Office to reshape the nation’s immigration system and all but dared members of next year’s Republican-controlled Congress to reverse his actions on behalf of millions of immigrants.

headline: Swedish Court Upholds Order for Arrest of Julian Assange

headline: At Senate Airbag Hearing, Evasion and Uncertainty

headline: Gabrielle Hamilton: By the Book
abstract: The chef and author of “Prune” and “Blood, Bones and Butter”: “The perfectness of reading is when a book hits you and you hit it and . . . you are completed in a way you have never been before.”
lead_paragraph: The chef and author of “Prune” and “Blood, Bones and Butter”: “The perfectness of reading is when a book hits you and you hit it and . . . you are completed in a way you have never been before.”

headline: Up From Rubble to Lead a Revolution
abstract: The latest installment of the “Hunger Games” films is a vague yet stirring liberation story that echoes real-life struggles against oppression around the world.
lead_paragraph: There’s a clever bit in the latest “Hunger Games” in which Katniss Everdeen, the boundary-smashing butch goddess of dystopian cinema, acts in a propaganda video. The idea is for Katniss, who’s both the spark of a revolution and its flinty strength, to rouse the masses with a heroic scene. Slicked up in lipstick and a Joan of Arc breastplate, she delivers her lines — “with energy,” the video director hopefully instructs her — but the scene needs tweaks. Eventually, they get it right, and the video ends with a call to “join the fight,” an exhortation that’s clearly addressed to more than one audience. It’s a funny, self-aware moment, given how extreme the stakes have become in this fascinating and strange pop epic.

headline: Scottish Visit in Gowns (and Kilt)
abstract: In “Masterpieces From the Scottish National Gallery,” the Frick welcomes 10 works by the likes of Sargent, Botticelli and Reynolds.
lead_paragraph: Among the lesser-known idiosyncrasies of the Frick Collection is that it has never had a painting by John Singer Sargent, the in-demand Gilded Age portraitist. But Sargent’s “Lady Agnew of Lochnaw,” a supremely stylish dark-haired beauty afloat in a voluminous white satin and chiffon tea gown, looks so at home at the Frick that visitors may mistake her for a resident.

headline: Mayor de Blasio and Cardinal Dolan: Beyond the Church-State Separation
abstract: In the months since Mayor Bill de Blasio took office, he and Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan have forged a useful relationship blessed by good timing and apparent affection.
lead_paragraph: It was to become the parable of the mayor and the cardinal’s cookies.

headline: Arrests Made in Protests at Police Station
abstract: At least five demonstrators were arrested late Wednesday during a protest that included repeated attempts to block traffic outside Ferguson’s police station.
lead_paragraph: At least five demonstrators were arrested late Wednesday during a protest that included repeated attempts to block traffic outside Ferguson’s police station.

headline: Throwback Thursday | Thanksgiving at Times of National Turmoil
abstract: Times archival articles about Americans celebrating Thanksgiving even as they coped with Great Depression, World Wars I and II, the wars in Vietnam and Afghanistan, Hurricanes Katrina and Sandy, and the 9/11 terrorist attacks.
lead_paragraph: Above a photo of President Johnson and his family at dinner, the headline on the  front page of The New York Times for Nov. 26, 1965 read “Thanksgiving Celebrations: On a Ranch in Texas and In a War Zone in South Vietnam.” The article began:

headline: The Secret Lives of Passwords
abstract: For some people, passwords protect dreams, secrets, even fears, and serve as a daily reminder of what matters most.
lead_paragraph: For some people, passwords protect dreams, secrets, even fears, and serve as a daily reminder of what matters most.

headline: Davis Cup Is a Challenge Roger Federer Has Yet to Conquer
abstract: Federer and Stan Wawrinka will lead Switzerland as it tries to win its first Davis Cup when it takes on France, a nine-time champion.
lead_paragraph: LILLE, France — This Davis Cup final does not quite represent the ultimate challenge for Roger Federer as he tries to tick one of the last empty boxes on his tennis wish list.

headline: There’s No Proof of Surveillance Abuse?
abstract: The world, of course, doesn’t know the full extent of the program or its abuses, because it is secret.
lead_paragraph: One of the big points made by the Republican senators who shot down the surveillance bill on Tuesday was that there was no proof the National Security Agency’s program of collecting millions of Americans’ telephone records had ever been abused. The bill would have stopped the existing programs of bulk collection.

headline: Making the Most of Puberty on the Scale of a Planet
abstract: Access to education and jobs can make the world’s huge youth population an asset.
lead_paragraph: I once used the title “Puberty on the Scale of a Planet” to convey how the human species seems to be going through the same awkward transition we all experience as individuals in moving from often-reckless teen ebullience to the more measured life strategies of adulthood.

headline: Muslim Brotherhood Leader Arrested in Egypt
abstract: With the arrest of the last senior Brotherhood leader not in prison, the government’s main channel of communication with the group was closed off.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The last remaining senior leader of the Muslim Brotherhood who was not in prison was arrested on Thursday by the Egyptian police, closing off the government’s main channel of communication with the group.

headline: Conversation Starters for Beyond the Thanksgiving Table
abstract: Talking about gratitude and giving around the Thanksgiving table is a great time to start a new family tradition: jump starting better conversations every night.
lead_paragraph: Next week, we will gather around tables and perhaps pause for a few minutes to ask our dining companions a question: What are you thankful for?

headline: How Switzerland Came to Dominate Watchmaking
abstract: The way the country reached the pinnacle of the luxury timepiece trade offers insights into the industrial age and into this very particular market.
lead_paragraph: ST.-IMIER, Switzerland — In some respects, very little has changed at Cadrans Flückiger S.A., a dial maker founded here, in the French-speaking part of the Jura Mountains, in 1860.

headline: That Medical Test Costs $50, or Is It $500?
abstract: In many ways our health care system is like an all-you-can-eat buffet. Someone else appears to be paying for it, so who cares how much it costs?
lead_paragraph: When I was growing up in Lexington, Ky., in the late 1970s, we used to go to an all-you-can-eat buffet called Duff’s. It was the cheapest restaurant in town. My father and mother ate for $2 apiece, my brother and I were charged $1, and my little sister, who was 3, ate free. After my father paid the cashier, we’d sprint over to the smorgasbord and fill our plates. We’d fill them again and again. If the fried chicken got cold, my father would tell us to throw it out and get more. We gorged; we took advantage; we were wasteful — because we perceived it as free. We’d eat so much that one of us would invariably get sick on the way home.

headline: Mike Nichols, Lauded Director, Dies at 83
abstract: Mr. Nichols, one of America’s most decorated directors, had a protean résumé of critic- and crowd-pleasing work that earned him adulation both on Broadway and in Hollywood.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Nichols, one of America’s most decorated directors, had a protean résumé of critic- and crowd-pleasing work that earned him adulation both on Broadway and in Hollywood.

headline: Video Game Meets History, and France Rebels Again
abstract: Critics say the video game’s latest version is excessively sympathetic to the monarchy and disrespectful to the revolutionaries who overthrew King Louis XVI.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Perhaps only in France could a video game provoke an earnest philosophical debate over the decadence of the monarchy, the moral costs of democracy, the rise of the far right and the meaning of the state.

headline: 1914: Prince of Wales Passes Busy Day at the Front
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: 1914: Prince of Wales Passes Busy Day at the Front
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Prince of Wales, now on General French’s Staff at the front, had a busy day yesterday. [Nov. 19]

headline: Becoming the Symbol of Street Harassment
abstract: I did not seek to become the symbol of street harassment when I participated in a video for Hollaback!, but I am grateful to be a part of this movement to end it.
lead_paragraph: I feel like the Mockingjay. For those of you who are not Hunger Games fans, Katniss, the protagonist in Suzanne Collins’ story, is thrust into being the face of the revolution. Katniss did not initially choose to present herself as the Mockingjay, a symbol of rebellion, but she agrees with the cause and does everything within her power to assist the group she believes in.

headline: Apples of His Eye
abstract: “The Eye Collection: Visionary Mexican Modern Design” features 150 lots.
lead_paragraph: After amassing more than 3,000 examples of art and design, in what is known as the Eye Collection, Alexandre Lemaire has decided to let some go. Mr. Lemaire, an entrepreneur in Mexico City, said, “The pieces need to travel, live and know other owners.”

headline: Settlement Is Reached in Fatal ‘Midnight Rider’ Film Accident
abstract: The family of Sarah Jones, a crew worker killed by a train on the set of the film about the rock star Gregg Allman, settled with 11 defendants in a civil suit.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The family of Sarah Jones, a crew worker who was killed by a freight train this year on the set of the independent film “Midnight Rider,” reached a settlement with 11 defendants in a civil suit over her death, a lawyer for the family said.

headline: Harnessing a Piece of the Past
abstract: Incorporating famous materials into their products is a new way for young watch companies to infuse their timepieces with a sense of history.
lead_paragraph: On a December morning, just over a century ago, the Wright Flyer made its historic 12-second flight on a windy beach in Kitty Hawk, North Carolina.

headline: A Brooklyn Apartment? Make It Postwar.
abstract: Chrissy Hunt and Sean Oliver went looking for a newer apartment in Manhattan and Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: For four years, Chrissy Hunt lived in a third-floor walk-up in Chelsea, first with her sister, then with a roommate and then with her boyfriend, Sean Oliver.

headline: Device Could Help Keep Thieves at Bay
abstract: The Opuss Tracker, which is small enough to be hidden inside a watch box, emits a signal that can be tracked on a GPS device or a smartphone.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — High-value watch and jewelry thefts in the past two years have left owners of luxury stores in France feeling deeply vulnerable.

headline: Returning to a Feminine Classic
abstract: Born in the heady years of the Jazz Age, small, jewel-covered timepieces are back again, encouraged by the growing wealth of working women.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The cocktail watch, a delicate and glamorous spin on the women’s wristwatch, was a bejeweled accessory during the party-all-night years of the Jazz Age.

headline: Chinese Are Buying Back Antique Timepieces
abstract: Daryn Schnipper, chairwoman of the international watch division at Sotheby’s, speaks about the impact of Asian watch collectors on the market.
lead_paragraph: Daryn Schnipper is chairwoman of the international watch division of Sotheby’s. She spoke with Nina Siegal.

headline: In a Small Space, a Big Issue
abstract: The lack of space on our wrists pose a challenge to designers of wrist-worn devices. Issues like the size of screens can make smart watches less attractive.
lead_paragraph: After successfully leading revolutions in home computers, portable digital music players and smart phones, Apple has done much to raise interest in the future of wrist-worn computers with its arrival in the growing smart watch market.

headline: 1939: 7,000,000 More Cars Predicted on U.S. Highways
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: A high increase in the number of automobiles and trucks on the highways of the United States is predicted in 1939.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The number of automobiles and trucks in operation on the highways of the United States will be increased by another 7,000,000 during the next twenty years, Pyke Johnson, vice-president of the Automobile Manufacturers Association, predicted today in an address before the annual convention of the American Automobile Association here. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Nov. 21, 1939

headline: Diane Lane Will Return To New York Stage
abstract: Ms. Lane will star opposite Tony Shalhoub in the Lincoln Center Theater production of Bathsheba Doran’s “The Mystery of Love and Sex.”
lead_paragraph: Diane Lane, whose last New York stage appearance was in a 1978 New York Shakespeare Festival production of “Runaways” when she was 13, will return to play one of the four principal roles in the Lincoln Center Theater production of “The Mystery of Love and Sex” a new play by Bathsheba Doran. The Off Broadway production begins previews at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater on Feb. 7, and opens on March 2.

headline: Function, Plus Fashion
abstract: Makers of luxury timepieces, including Jaeger-LeCoultre, Chanel and Chaumet, are placing sophisticated functionalities into sparkling cases.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — There’s a ripple of excitement in the hushed confines of the Jaeger-LeCoultre boutique on the Place Vendôme. Caroline Jame, the boutique manager, has returned from the vault and is about to open a box containing a rarity: The Nodo, a name meaning knot in Italian.

headline: McConnell Makes Final Plea to Obama on Immigration
abstract: Mitch McConnell, the Senate minority leader and incoming majority leader, accused the president of prioritizing politics and his own legacy over good policy.
lead_paragraph: Mitch McConnell, the Senate minority leader and incoming majority leader, took to the Senate floor on Thursday morning to make a final plea urging President Obama not to move forward with his plan to overhaul immigration enforcement through executive action.

headline: Remembering Mike Nichols: Twitter Tributes and Times Reviews
abstract: Mr. Nichols oversaw an impressive array of work, and was remembered warmly by friends on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Mike Nichols, one of the few directors to achieve commercial and critical success in Hollywood and on Broadway, died on Wednesday. He was 83.

headline: Tune In to The Times
abstract: Mark Leibovich discusses his Times Magazine cover story on Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey on MSNBC’s “Morning Joe.”
lead_paragraph: Mark Leibovich, chief national correspondent for The New York Times Magazine, joined MSNBC’s “Morning Joe” to discuss his new cover story on Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey.

headline: Watchmakers Introduce Bigger and Bolder Models
abstract: In an era of smartwatches, both men and women are drawn to bolder dials and mechanics, and many brands are producing larger timepieces.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — Jordy Cobelens was a 22-year-old Dutch disc jockey, working in Amsterdam electro clubs in 2005, when he noticed that a lot of the club kids around him were wearing bigger and bigger wristwatches.

headline: State of Arizona v. General Motors
abstract: Arizona’s lawsuit contends G.M. intentionally misled consumers through its advertising, website and public statements, and that some of its top leaders were complicit in the alleged misdeeds. It seeks $3 billion in compensation.
lead_paragraph: Arizona’s lawsuit contends G.M. intentionally misled consumers through its advertising, website and public statements, and that some of its top leaders were complicit in the alleged misdeeds. It seeks $3 billion in compensation.

headline: Supreme Court Allows Same-Sex Marriages to Proceed in South Carolina
abstract: The Supreme Court declined to hear an emergency application from South Carolina officials to stay a lower court ruling allowing same-sex marriages.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Over the dissents of two justices, the Supreme Court on Thursday allowed same-sex marriages to proceed in South Carolina, rejecting an emergency application seeking a stay of a judge’s order striking down the state’s ban on such unions.

headline: When Are You Not Working?
abstract: For some Americans, the answer seems to be “never.”
lead_paragraph: “I’m guessing I will do my last work-related task at 12:15 a.m.,” writes Nicole Dieker at The Billfold. “How about you?”

headline: Student Debt: A Calculator Focused on College Majors
abstract: Most college graduates earn enough to repay their student loans. The bigger problem is that they’re asked to do so when they are earning the least.
lead_paragraph: Student debt seems on its way to becoming a significant political issue, for better or worse. When a recent Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll asked people about a long list of domestic and foreign policy proposals, none received more support – 82 percent – than reducing the cost of student loans. When the 2016 campaign gets underway, candidates will most likely come forth with various plans to address the issue.

headline: Florida Police Describe Campus Shooting
abstract: Tallahassee and Florida State University police described early reports of a gunman in front of the campus library, in an episode in which three people were injured and the suspect was killed.
lead_paragraph: Tallahassee and Florida State University police described early reports of a gunman in front of the campus library, in an episode in which three people were injured and the suspect was killed.

headline: A White Flower by O’Keeffe Blooms Green: $44.4 Million
abstract: “Jimson Weed (White Flower No. 1)” by Georgia O’Keeffe sells for $44.4 million, nearly three times its high estimate.
lead_paragraph: One of Georgia O’Keeffe’s classic flower paintings — “Jimson Weed (White Flower No. 1)” from 1932 – sold at Sotheby’s on Thursday morning for $44.4 million, nearly three times its $15 million high estimate.

headline: Vegetarian Thanksgiving: Food Allergies and Autumn Quinoa
abstract: When food allergies forced her to learn to cook, Johanna Bond dove in. The result: A quinoa dish with apples and cheddar that is perfect for a fall celebration.
lead_paragraph: On a Friday night a little more than a year ago, my hands blanched to white and began to shake as intense nausea hit me over dinner at a favorite neighborhood restaurant. My gums and tongue tingling, I nearly yelled to my boyfriend as we walked out, “I think we need to go to the emergency room. Now.” I didn’t know it at the time, but I had developed life-threatening food allergies that would change the way I eat and the way I live.

headline: French Fighters Appear in New ISIS Video
abstract: Excerpts of a short film released by an Islamic State affiliate, Al Hayat Media Center, show fighters burning their French passports and calling for jihad.
lead_paragraph: Excerpts of a short film released by an Islamic State affiliate, Al Hayat Media Center, show fighters burning their French passports and calling for jihad.

headline: A New Cook in the Kitchen
abstract: Molly Yeh, a Brooklyn food blogger, moves to the Midwest and learns how to make lefse, a culinary tradition of her fiance’s Norwegian-American family.
lead_paragraph: Molly Yeh, a Brooklyn food blogger, moves to the Midwest and learns how to make lefse, a culinary tradition of her fiance’s Norwegian-American family.

headline: Seeking Acts of Kindness During the Buffalo-Area Snowstorm
abstract: During this barrage of snow and warnings, friends and strangers have bravely ventured out to help those in need. Have you seen any unselfish acts? Tell us.
lead_paragraph: A lake-storm effect is pummeling the Buffalo area, stranding people in their cars and indoors, cutting power for thousands of residents, and wreaking havoc on homes. The region is bracing for three more feet of snow by day’s end on Thursday.

headline: Where Is the Outrage Over Foreign Exchange Manipulation?
abstract: Until directors and senior executives are held accountable, bank scandals will continue to occur, Mayra Rodríguez Valladares writes in the Another View column.
lead_paragraph: Mayra Rodríguez Valladares is managing principal at MRV Associates, a capital markets and financial regulatory consulting and training firm based in New York. On Twitter, she is @MRVAssociates.

headline: That Book! It’s ...It’s ...Aaaaaaahhhh!
abstract: For “The Babadook,” the writer-director Jennifer Kent created, with the help of the illustrator Alex Juhasz, a real pop-up book for filming.
lead_paragraph: “If it’s in a word, or it’s in a look, you can’t get rid of the Babadook.”

headline: Verbatim: From the Roman Senate to Ours
abstract: Senator Ted Cruz quoted from Cicero’s The First Oration Against Catiline, with a few tweaks such as subbing “Mr. Obama” for “Catiline,” on the Senate floor in addressing the president’s expected executive action on immigration.
lead_paragraph: Senator Ted Cruz quoted from Cicero’s First Oration Against Catiline, with a few tweaks, such as subbing “Mr. Obama” for “O Catiline,” on the Senate floor in addressing the president’s expected executive action on immigration.

headline: Amid Mutual Suspicion, Turkish Premier Visits Iraq
abstract: The visit by Prime Minister Ahmet Davutoglu was a vivid example of a scramble in Middle East politics as former rivals are seeking to come together to defeat ISIS.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — When the Turkish prime minister’s motorcade made its way along the airport road on Thursday morning to Baghdad’s fortified Green Zone, once a terrifying journey with the constant threat of snipers and car bombs, the vehicles instead passed by palm trees, manicured lawns and a fountain — the landscaping work of a Turkish company.

headline: Seasonal Cheer (and Tours) in Iceland
abstract: “Christmas in Iceland” trips organized by IsramWorld include tours of Reykjavik and the Geysir geothermal area.
lead_paragraph: Iceland is known for its especially picturesque holiday season, and this year, the New York City-based tour operator IsramWorld has created a “Christmas in Iceland” trip.

headline: Online Retailer Cnova Shares Rise on Trading Debut
abstract: The spinoff of the online businesses of former Brazilian retailer Grupo Pão De Açúcar and France’s Casino went public on the Nasdaq market, rising nearly 6 percent by midday.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Shares of the e-commerce company Cnova, a spinoff of the online businesses of former Brazilian retailer Grupo Pão De Açúcar and France’s Casino, edged up on their American trading debut on the Nasdaq stock market on Thursday.

headline: ‘One Problem With Skate Skiing: It’s Hard’
abstract: I always thought “classic” Nordic-style cross-country skiing was boring. So I tried its zippy younger brother. Here’s how that went.

headline: Smells Like Teen Spirit, in All Its Pain
abstract: Seven actors draw on their adolescence to animate “Punk Rock,” a drama about the power, vulnerability and confusion of youth, set at a private school in England.
lead_paragraph: Stagehands were still cleaning blood spatter from the walls of the “Punk Rock” set when seven members of its cast bounded into the lobby on a recent Thursday night. They’d quickly changed from soiled prep school uniforms into clean street clothes and traded British accents for American ones, except for Lilly Englert, who comes by her London intonations naturally.

headline: Mercedes Revives the Maybach Name Again
abstract: A new, higher-end version of Mercedes-Benz’s S-Class sedan has been rebadged as the Mercedes-Maybach S600.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Time, misfortune and unrealistic expectations have conspired over the years to kill the Maybach marque, but it just won’t die.
