The latest attempt to revive the luxury automaker, under the banner of a new Mercedes-Maybach nameplate, was put on display Wednesday at the 2014 Los Angeles Auto Show.

headline: Burning the Franchise At Both Ends
abstract: On voter ID laws and non-citizen voting.
lead_paragraph: My colleague Nate Cohn has written a piece this week, not his first, on why claims that voter ID laws can swing elections to the G.O.P. are extremely overstated, and why even though the laws keep more Democrats than Republicans from the polls, any meaningful disenfranchisement happens on the margins, and only matters when a race is closer-than-close.

headline: 1944 | Proving Ground for Pot Roasts
abstract: The Times has had a history of in-house kitchens to test recipes before readers do.
lead_paragraph: David W. Dunlap is a Metro reporter and writes the Building Blocks column. He has worked at The Times for 39 years.When he introduced the newly renamed Food section two weeks ago, Sam Sifton noted that it was not such a new name after all, since it could be traced to the days in the 1950s when The Times’s greatest food writer, Craig Claiborne, joined what was then called the “Food Fashions Family Furnishings” page.

headline: Another Bit of Action on the Immigration Front
abstract: Homeland Security officials announced they would give temporary protected status to people currently living in the United States from the three countries most affected by the Ebola epidemic: Liberia, Guinea and Sierra Leone.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration seems to be trying to dispatch all its immigration business in a single day.

headline: A Mother and Daughter, Reunited After Foster Care, and Talking
abstract: The news tends to dwell on the tragedies, but most children who enter foster care go home to parents—like me—who repair their families and refuse to give up hope.
lead_paragraph: Most people know very little about parents in child welfare outside of the terrible stories that make the nightly news. These constant portrayals of child deaths leave most Americans under the impression that parents who have had their children removed committed horrific abuse — and deserve no compassion.

headline: A Nuclear Deal Is Likely to Hit Hurdles in Iran
abstract: Whatever deal is reached in Vienna between Secretary of State John Kerry and Iranian negotiators, it may not matter if hard-liners have their way.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Far from the flashing cameras and microphones in Vienna, where Secretary of State John Kerry is joining Iranian and United States diplomats in a final push to reach a compromise on Tehran’s nuclear program, a different sort of political drama unfolded in the Iranian capital this week: Hard-liners got together to criticize the objects of their “worries,” as they put it, the moderates advocating a deal.

headline: Today in Small Business: Why Typewriters Are Coming Back
abstract: What the Uber scandal says about start-up culture. How social entrepreneurs are changing the world. An experienced entrepreneur talks about work/life imbalance.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: ArtPrize Expands to Dallas
abstract: The contemporary-art contest ArtPrize, in which the public can bestow as much as $200,000 on an artist, is expanding into Dallas.
lead_paragraph: ArtPrize, the contemporary-art contest in which the public can bestow as much as $200,000 on an artist, is expanding from its base in Grand Rapids, Mich., where it was founded five years ago and has become an economic boon to the city.

headline: Clash, Crash, Redemption
abstract: In “Clothes Clothes Clothes Music Music Music Boys Boys Boys,” Viv Albertine, the former guitarist and songwriter with the Slits, recalls being a groundbreaking woman in the world of punk rock.
lead_paragraph: Viv Albertine has a lot of good stories to tell in “Clothes Clothes Clothes Music Music Music Boys Boys Boys,” her new memoir. The title comes from a little chant that her disappointed mom used to aim in her direction when she was a teenager.

headline: Living an Upright Life, as a Nun and a Coach
abstract: Sister Lisa Maurer coaches kickers and punters at the College of St. Scholastica in Duluth, Minn., which is 10-0 entering the N.C.A.A. Division III playoffs.
lead_paragraph: DULUTH, Minn. — The celebration after the College of St. Scholastica won its fourth consecutive conference football championship resembled an extended family gathering this month. Oblivious to the numbing cold, players, coaches, family members and students lingered on the field, exchanging hugs and posing with the Upper Midwest Athletic Conference championship banner.

headline: Take My Wife. S’il Vous Plaît.
abstract: An exhibition that opened this week at the Metropolitan Museum of Art is the first-ever exhibition devoted to Cézanne’s portraits of his wife.
lead_paragraph: Hortense Fiquet Cézanne is one of the great mystery women in art. She sat for 29 paintings by her husband and smiles in none of them. More often than not, she is portrayed indoors, a matronly woman with her hair primly parted in the middle and her dress buttoned up almost to her chin. Yet there is something appealing about her plainness. She is nothing like her contemporaries in Impressionist pictures, who pass their days at boating parties and picnics, their long dresses billowing in the breeze, sunlight warming their skin. Madame Cézanne, by contrast, looks as if she does not get out of the house much and could use a break.

headline: Bill Cosby’s Sudden Fall, Explained Sociologically
abstract: Social science can cast light on why long-ignored rape allegations against the comedian are now being taken seriously.
lead_paragraph: How did Bill Cosby suddenly become radioactive?

headline: Mazda Enters the Small Crossover Market With the CX-3
abstract: Compact crossovers have become strong sellers, so Mazda introduced one of its own, adding its signature driver-friendly flair to the package.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Automakers claim to have discovered a new segment of vehicle: the small, city-friendly crossover. In actuality, this category was discovered some years ago, it’s just that automakers left it behind as they kept building bigger and bigger versions of the utilitarian little crossovers introduced in the mid-1990s.

headline: Chris Christie, Media Critic
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie weighs in on a New York Times Magazine cover depicting him posing for a selfie with a frightened-looking baby.
lead_paragraph: In our colleague Mark Leibovich’s cover article on Chris Christie, the New Jersey governor suggested an opening for the article, and Mr. Leibovich obliged.

headline: Senate Spars With Goldman Sachs Over Commodities
abstract: Goldman executives locked in a testy public face-off with members of Congress, fighting suggestions that the bank had taken too large a role in the commodities market.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Goldman Sachs executives spent Thursday locked in a testy public face-off with members of Congress, fighting suggestions that the bank had taken too large a role in the commodities market.

headline: John Cameron Mitchell to Return as Star of ‘Hedwig and the Angry Inch’
abstract: Mr. Mitchell will step in for eight weeks to the role he originated.
lead_paragraph: Hedwig fans, brace yourselves: John Cameron Mitchell is coming to Broadway to reprise his legendary performance in the title role of “Hedwig and the Angry Inch,” a show about a transgender East German rock musician that he developed in the 1990s to acclaim from critics and cult followers. He will begin performances Jan. 21 and continue for eight weeks, the producers announced on Thursday, with Mr. Mitchell already mulling ways to combine his old hard-bitten, improvisational style with the new, breakneck choreography of “Hedwig’s” Broadway incarnation.

headline: A New Cook in the Kitchen
abstract: Molly Yeh, a Chicago-born food blogger, teaches Sam Sifton how to make traditional Norwegian-American lefse. (Article plus video.)
lead_paragraph: Thanksgiving in America reflects the experience of family and heritage, region and climate, and of what happens when someone from one set of circumstances falls in love with another.

headline: Huffington Post Is Said to Be in Talks to Host a Jill Abramson Journalism Start-Up
abstract: Ms. Abramson, a former executive editor of The New York Times, and the journalist Steven Brill are said to be in talks with Arianna Huffington.
lead_paragraph: Jill Abramson, a former executive editor of The New York Times, and the journalist Steven Brill are in talks with The Huffington Post to host a new journalism site that would run long articles monthly and pay writers advances of up to $100,000, according to people briefed on the discussions.

headline: Malicious Software Said to Spread on Android Phones
abstract: Lookout, a security company, says it has been tracking malware that over the last two years has become more sophisticated as it hit millions of devices.
lead_paragraph: For years security researchers have warned that it was only a matter of time before nasty digital scourges like malicious software and spam would hit smartphones.

headline: The Bills on Fourth Down: Bad Strategy and Yet Not Out of the Ordinary
abstract: Coach Doug Marrone has done his team few favors on fourth down, but his decisions reflect a cautious leaguewide approach.
lead_paragraph: Strange but true: The NYT 4th Down Bot is big in Buffalo.

headline: Thai Protesters Are Detained After Using ‘Hunger Games’ Salute
abstract: The demonstrators, later released, adopted the three-finger gesture to protest a coup by the Thai Army and its authoritarian government during a speech by the prime minister.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — A Thai theater chain has withdrawn the latest “Hunger Games” movie after several student protesters were detained for using a gesture taken from the films, a three-finger salute of resistance to authoritarian government.

headline: Bono Suffered Multiple Fractures in Bike Accident
abstract: Details emerge about the nature of injuries suffered by Bono in a bicycle accident in Central Park.
lead_paragraph: When U2 announced the cancellation of its weeklong residency on “The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon” earlier this week the band offered only a brief, almost offhand explanation: “Bono has injured his arm in a cycling spill in Central Park and requires some surgery to repair it,” a message on the U2 website said. On Wednesday, NewYork-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell Medical Center and Hospital for Special Surgery, where the singer was treated, released more details.

headline: More Judges Question Use of Fake Drugs in Sting Cases
abstract: A number of judges have questioned a federal agency’s tactic of “stash-house stings,” saying it draws small-time criminals into major crimes.
lead_paragraph: The three men gathered in a Los Angeles warehouse, bringing a 12-gauge shotgun, a .38 revolver, zip ties for handcuffs and a duffel bag to carry the 20 to 25 kilograms of cocaine, worth more than $500,000 wholesale, they expected to steal.

headline: FIFA Ethics Report Will Get Independent Review
abstract: The ethics committee chairmen, Michael J. Garcia and Hans-Joachim Eckert, will let an auditor decide whether to release Garcia’s findings to FIFA’s executive committee.
lead_paragraph: The small group of people who have seen a secret FIFA report on corruption in the World Cup bidding process will soon grow by at least one. And possibly by even more.

headline: At Holiday Party, Obama Encounters a Guest With Family Ties
abstract: The White House hosted a dinner on Wednesday night for hundreds of immigration advocates and lawyers, including Margaret Wong, who represented two members of President Obama’s family who sought legal immigration status.
lead_paragraph: At a holiday party last night at the White House for President Obama’s donors and supporters, Margaret Wong congratulated the president on his decision to protect millions of undocumented immigrants from deportation with executive action.

headline: The Lexus LF-C2 Concept: Topless, Not Convertible
abstract: The company has had a less than fruitful relationship with convertibles in the past.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Lexus LF-C2 concept, introduced here on Wednesday at the 2014 Los Angeles auto show, is the ultimate in topless motoring. Seriously. It has no top at all. That’s because, Lexus announced, it’s a “roadster concept.” In Lexus’ thinking, it doesn’t need a top.

headline: Living With Cancer: Gravy Days
abstract: This November I am a lucky woman, reveling in the unearned bounty of more time and a thicker earthly existence than I had ever expected.
lead_paragraph: When I was diagnosed in November 2008, I began counting forward, assuming I would die by November 2013, at the latest. Prognosis for late-stage ovarian cancer is three to five years, even with state-of-the-art treatment. November, which happens to be the month of my birthday, became a memento mori: an annual observance of my projected end. A statistical approximation, the prognosis tolled in my ears like a death sentence.

headline: What Is President Obama’s Immigration Plan?
abstract: The plan would grant as many as five million unauthorized immigrants temporary reprieve from deportation and provide many of them with authorization to work in the U.S.
lead_paragraph: The plan would grant as many as five million unauthorized immigrants temporary reprieve from deportation and provide many of them with authorization to work in the U.S.

headline: A Recipe for Wrath (Grapes Optional) in Minnesota
abstract: The state is stunned over the choice of grape salad in a Times Thanksgiving project.
lead_paragraph: As Thanksgiving spreads go, this one was lavish.

headline: Indiana Governor Weighs Suit to Stop Obama on Immigration
abstract: Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana is leaning toward filing a lawsuit to halt the president’s immigration action, he said in an interview, making him the third Republican governor to threaten such a move.
lead_paragraph: BOCA RATON, Fla. — Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana is leaning toward filing a lawsuit to halt President Obama’s immigration action, he said in an interview, making him the third Republican governor to threaten such a move.

headline: Behind the Urbane Wit, a Crackling Fervor for His Art
abstract: Mike Nichols’s most essential quality was his passion for actors and acting.
lead_paragraph: When the lights are dimmed on Broadway Friday night in honor of the director Mike Nichols, who died on Wednesday at 83, the neighborhood where he plied his trade for half a century will feel even darker than usual. Mr. Nichols emanated a luminous glamour that was once commonplace in the theater, but now flickers only fitfully in an increasingly corporate, profit-driven, financially anxious world.

headline: Living Higher, Thanks to Barley
abstract: A study of ancient life on the Tibetan Plateau indicates it was the ability to grow barley that allowed humans to establish permanent settlements at very high altitudes.
lead_paragraph: A study of ancient life on the Tibetan Plateau — the so-called roof of the world — says it was the ability to grow barley that allowed humans to establish permanent settlements at very high altitudes.

headline: Fernando Alonso Out, Sebastian Vettel In, for Ferrari Next Season
abstract: Alonso, who has driven for the Ferrari racing team since 2010, will be replaced next season by Vettel, who has driven for the Red Bull team since 2009.
lead_paragraph: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates — The Ferrari racing team on Thursday announced the end of one era and the beginning of another as it said goodbye to a two-time world champion and welcomed a four-time world champion.

headline: Fantasy Football: Picks for Week 12
abstract: The Bears have only one victory in their last four games, but win or lose, quarterback Jay Cutler is going to throw the football, which is good news for receivers Brandon Marshall and Alshon Jeffrey.
lead_paragraph: The Bears have only one victory in their last four games, but win or lose, quarterback Jay Cutler is going to throw the football, which is good news for receivers Brandon Marshall and Alshon Jeffrey.

headline: Hotel Review: Radisson Blu Warwick Hotel, Philadelphia
abstract: This refurbished property inside a landmark building is situated in the center of the city, close to a number of top attractions.
lead_paragraph: Rooms from $289.

headline: Marco’s Restaurant in Brooklyn Is Closing
abstract: The year-old sibling of Franny’s drew warm reviews but was “not profitable enough,” according to an owner.
lead_paragraph: After a little more than a year in business, Marco’s, the sibling of the 10-year-old Brooklyn restaurant Franny’s, will close after the dinner dishes are cleared on Dec. 13. The reason, said Francine Stephens, who owns both restaurants with Andrew Feinberg, is that Marco’s was “not profitable enough.”

headline: A Limited-Edition G-Shock With a Vintage Feel
abstract: Casio’s iconic, virtually indestructible silhouette gets a new, luxe treatment for fall.
lead_paragraph: In this weekly series, the men’s fashion editors of T invite creative personalities to put their own aesthetic spin on a new watch. Here, the illustrator Jay Riggio captures a timepiece from Casio.

headline: More Light Needed on Wall Street’s Revolving Door
abstract: Going from a financial regulator to the private sector can raise conflicts, but cross-fertilization is valuable, contends Daniel Indiviglio of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: The dizzying revolving door between Wall Street and the United States government risks an overdone response. Going from a job as an overseer to the private sector, or moving in the other direction, can raise conflicts. Such shifts warrant clear rules, but cross-fertilization has value.

headline: Ideas for E.L.L.s | Teaching About Food
abstract: The topic of food has the potential to fulfill all the prerequisites necessary for creating an engaging and effective language-development lesson. Here are many ideas and resources for teaching the topic.
lead_paragraph: The topic of food has the potential to fulfill all the prerequisites necessary for creating an engaging and effective language-development lesson:

headline: Hispanic Voters Are Important for Republicans, but Not Indispensable
abstract: Contrary to conventional wisdom, the G.O.P can regain the White House in 2016 without improving its appeal among Hispanics. It just will be harder.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s plan to defer deportation and grant work permits for up to five million undocumented migrants is having two utterly predictable results: outrage from congressional Republicans, and speculation about how the politics will play in 2016.

headline: Mayor de Blasio Urges ‘Culture Change’ at Rikers Island
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio, in his most extensive comments on the violence at the New York City jail complex, said he would visit it in December to see problems for himself.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio declared on Thursday that Rikers Island “deeply needs a culture change” and called ending the pervasive violence at the jail complex a top priority of his administration, acknowledging that he had previously underestimated the level of dysfunction there.

headline: Carnitas El Atoradero in the South Bronx
abstract: The restaurant could be just another tiny taqueria, but the decorations and ingredients speak to the chef’s Mexican heritage.
lead_paragraph: The plastic cups arrived on a terra-cotta plate, one cup filled with a pickled pig’s knuckle, another with a hank of goat sloughed off the bone and unraveling. There were sips of soup, too, shining with fat, and a dark sauce that tasted like smoke incarnate.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: H Is for Helicopter, G Is For Guilt — What’s Your Modern Parent Letter?
abstract: If Q is for Quinoa, E is for Equipped (for Everything) and M is for Meltdown, what’s your nominee for the modern parent’s alphabet?
lead_paragraph: Here at Motherlode, we’ve fallen — hard — for “Q is for Quinoa, A Modern Parent’s ABC.” From “A App” to “Z Zumba” it’s an alphabet that encapsulates a certain 21st-century parent experience, and the illustrations perfectly capture every age from “B Babiators” to “U Unreasonable” to “D Drama.”

headline: The New Republic’s Party Includes Bill Clinton, Toasts and Whispers of Unease
abstract: Chris Hughes, the owner, gives a speech about looking toward the future and embracing experimentation. The editors talk about protecting the past.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The New Republic has made a specialty of viciously skewering Democrats over the years, and few have endured tougher jabs than Bill Clinton.

headline: At Odds in the City’s Parks
abstract: In reporting the conflict between parkgoers and the homeless, a reporter finds some unexpected insight.
lead_paragraph: Last week, Lisa Foderaro reported on the tension between New York City’s parkgoers and the growing homeless population that has taken refuge in these public spaces. The reporting process required approaching people she might not have otherwise, and she had some unexpected encounters along the way.

headline: An Easier Death, and Less Costly, Too
abstract: Saving money isn’t really the point of hospice care. Still, a new study found that cancer patients in hospice incurred lower costs in the last year of life than those not in hospice.
lead_paragraph: Saving money isn’t really the point of hospice care. Helping dying patients have the best possible remaining life, followed by a good death, is really the purpose.

headline: Bulls’ Derrick Rose Takes a Seat, and a Stand
abstract: Rose, the former M.V.P. and Chicago’s starting point guard, should be applauded, not pilloried, for the long view he has taken with his health.
lead_paragraph: Derrick Rose, the Chicago Bulls’ phenomenal, injury-prone point guard, offered one of the wisest insights I’d heard from a young player about negotiating injury and longevity in pro sports.

headline: Uprooted by War, Focused on Joy
abstract: Young Syrians in a refugee camp in Jordan captured how sports provide a diversion from lives uprooted by war.
lead_paragraph: Young Syrians in a refugee camp in Jordan captured how sports provide a diversion from lives uprooted by war.

headline: Tips for Traveling While Pregnant
abstract: A doctor shares advice on precautions to take before the trip and what to do on the plane.
lead_paragraph: Between babymoons and business trips, more and more women are traveling during their pregnancies.

headline: Enigmatic Dreamer’s Flora and Fauna
abstract: An exhibition at Matthew Marks centers on the small paintings by the reclusive landscape artist Albert York (1928-2009).
lead_paragraph: The Chelsea art district has some spectacularly extroverted exhibitions going on now. There are two jam-packed Picasso shows, one at Gagosian on 21st Street and another at Pace; there’s a Takashi Murakami extravaganza at Gagosian’s 24th Street gallery; and David Zwirner has big, crazily surrealistic paintings by Neo Rauch on 19th Street and a selection of cheerfully unruly works by Franz West on 20th Street. Then, at Matthew Marks on 24th Street, there’s the opposite of all that: an exhibition of small paintings by Albert York (1928-2009), who was about as introverted and reticent as an artist could be without disappearing altogether from the art world. Presenting 37 small paintings dating from 1963 to 1992, it’s a beautiful, soul-stirring show.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
abstract: In the news: cholesterol, milk and colon cancer screening. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: In the news: cholesterol, milk and colon cancer screening. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: A Figaro on a Big Stage, Another in Your Lap
abstract: New York has two productions of “Il Barbiere di Siviglia”: one glossy, sweet and rich in laughs at the Met and one up close and intimate from LoftOpera.
lead_paragraph: Two Barbers of Seville plied their trade in New York this week. On Tuesday, the Metropolitan Opera revived Bartlett Sher’s winning production of Rossini’s comic classic “Il Barbiere di Siviglia,” with Michele Mariotti conducting. The title role was sung by the charismatic baritone Christopher Maltman, who made a spectacular entrance atop a wagon pulled by adoring citizens. He oozed sex appeal during his opening aria, “Largo al factotum,” wearing a magnificent red Phrygian cap like a royal insignia.

headline: Error Reported in Health Enrollment Numbers
abstract: Immigration is the story of the day, but President Obama’s health law is also under fresh fire following a report that enrollment figures were overstated.
lead_paragraph: Immigration is the story of the day, but President Obama’s health law is also back in the spotlight following a report that enrollment figures were overstated.

headline: A Wealth of Modern Dance
abstract: Hodworks performs, members of New York University’s dance faculty present their work, and an exhibition about the Batsheva Dance Company is on view.
lead_paragraph: For the Miser, one of the immediate benefits of moving north was far greater access to modern dance, a discipline he wasn’t exactly encouraged to take an interest in back home, where he was raised in a culture inclined to produce more traditionally staid and stoic Southern males. Two performances and an exhibition this weekend exemplify New York’s rich modern dance scene, at prices perfectly suited to the less-than-rich.

headline: Argentina’s Case Has No Victors, Many Losers
abstract: With no international debt restructuring mechanism in place, holders of bonds in default are left with rulings by national courts that can be contradictory.
lead_paragraph: The winners have gained nothing.

headline: Exercise That’s Aided by Vivid Mimicry
abstract: Participants in FlowCycle classes ride on bicycles that mimic actual road conditions.
lead_paragraph: I’M biking on a wide road in Tucson, and an S.U.V. passes me as I try to catch up to my team, pedaling ahead on the shoulder next to cactuses and other desert shrubbery. I lean sideways into the turn, clenching my abs as I balance.

headline: Tennessee’s Haslam Elected Chairman of Republican Governors Association
abstract: Gov. Bill Haslam of Tennessee was elected chairman of the Republican Governors Association.

headline: Fantasy Football: Week 12 Player Tiers
abstract: In the middle tiers, quarterbacks Tony Romo and Colin Kaepernick have favorable matchups against Tampa Bay and Washington.
lead_paragraph: In this statistical model, I apply a clustering algorithm called the Gaussian mixture model to an aggregation of expert ranking data provided by Fantasypros.com. The algorithm finds natural tiers and clusters within the data. The charts that result visualize the tiers and help you decide your starting lineup each week.

headline: Pretty Crowded for an Empty Nest
abstract: A wealthy suburban couple suddenly find their best friends turning up at their door and seeking sanctuary in Edward Albee’s “A Delicate Balance.”
lead_paragraph: Hope arrives in the form of dread toward the end of the first act of Edward Albee’s “A Delicate Balance,” which opened on Thursday night in a revival at the Golden Theater. Up to that point in this production, directed by Pam MacKinnon, it’s been hard to detect much feeling of any kind within the carefully color-coordinated, dust-free, energy-free environs that have been installed onstage.

headline: Renewed Interest for Lockwood de Forest’s Designs
abstract: A gallery show of brass filigree panels by the furniture designer Lockwood de Forest is one of several exhibitions featuring his work.
lead_paragraph: The 19th-century taste maker Lockwood de Forest went through career phases, painting moonlit landscapes, importing antiques, designing interiors and furniture and running a workshop in India. Not much material from any of his pursuits has emerged until this year; now about 7,600 of his brass filigree panels, made at his Ahmedabad workshop, have come on the market.

headline: New at JetBlue: Baggage Fees
abstract: JetBlue says it will add seats to planes and charge more for passengers who check bags.
lead_paragraph: JetBlue has finally succumbed to the latest trends in raising airline revenue: adding seats and baggage fees.

headline: Hans Haacke
abstract: Mr. Haacke’s show at Paula Cooper includes a sly installation exploring the web of power and money around the Koch brothers.
lead_paragraph: An ecologist in the broadest sense of the term, Hans Haacke has been working valiantly to promote sane thinking about the real world and its interwoven systems for more than four decades. This exhibition brings together new and old works to synergistic effect.

headline: The Old Country Never Goes Away
abstract: Haitian exiles in New York City are forced to confront the pain of their shared history in “Stones in the Sun.”
lead_paragraph: “Stones in the Sun” is a wrenching portrait of Haitian exiles struggling to build new lives in New York City after fleeing their country in the late 1980s. Jean-Claude Duvalier had departed, but his generals remained in power and continued his reign of terror. The film, written and directed by Patricia Benoit, is a powerfully acted exploration of the different ways that people deal with the traumatic wounds of the past.

headline: Saying ‘No’ to Force-Feeding at Guantanamo Bay
abstract: A Navy nurse refused to force-feed prisoners. Now he might get kicked out of the military, without benefits.
lead_paragraph: The Navy is persecuting a nurse with 18 years of military service for refusing to perform a procedure that the American Medical Association condemns as unethical. That is, for refusing to force-feed prisoners on a hunger strike at Guantanamo Bay. Now the American Nurses Association is pushing back.

headline: Into the Woods, With Sketchpad
abstract: “The Untamed Landscape: Theodore Rousseau and the Path to Barbizon” at the Morgan Library & Museum is Rousseau’s first retrospective in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a century and a half after his death, the 19th-century French landscape painter Théodore Rousseau is having his first retrospective in the United States. “The Untamed Landscape: Théodore Rousseau and the Path to Barbizon,” at the Morgan Library & Museum, features only drawings and oil studies — a total of 65 — but it’s an incisive prism for examining his sensibility and achievement. Rousseau (1812-67) could overwork his paintings, but he rarely missed on paper.

headline: Snooze, You Lose
abstract: Questions about Thanksgiving invitation responses, advice about big announcements, holiday potluck changes and acceptable timing for guests.
lead_paragraph: I am starting to resent the people who can’t quite commit to coming to my Thanksgiving dinner. One close friend says she needs to “keep it open,” and has no idea when she will be able to confirm because her partner is having a hard time. Another says he’d like to drop by “at some point,” but doesn’t know when because he wants to go to another dinner first. This is driving me crazy. A lovely group is coming, and there are others I would like to invite if I can resolve these uncommitted guests. What can I do?

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘A Girl Walks…’
abstract: The director Ana Lily Amirpour narrates a sequence from her film.
lead_paragraph: The director Ana Lily Amirpour narrates a sequence from her film.

headline: Think Back: America’s Immigration Debate
abstract: The Times’s Sam Tanenhaus explains government efforts to keep immigrants out of the country and links President Reagan’s amnesty for Latino Americans to today’s debate.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Sam Tanenhaus explains government efforts to keep immigrants out of the country and links President Ronald Reagan’s amnesty for Latino Americans to today’s debate.

headline: Iran Said to Free Imprisoned Pioneer Blogger
abstract: A prominent Iranian blogger, Hossein Derakhshan, was released from Evin Prison in Tehran, where he had been held for six years.
lead_paragraph: A pioneering Iranian blogger convicted of crimes including blasphemy, obscenity and seditious propaganda has been freed from prison after six years, he said Thursday in posts on social networks widely reported in Iran’s press.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
abstract: Ukraine and More – Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: Ukraine and More – Pictures of the Day

headline: Nov. 20, 2014 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Ukraine, India, Lithuanian and China.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Ukraine, India, Lithuanian and China.

headline: A Sign of Protest
abstract: Protest poster along West Florrissant in Ferguson, Mo.
lead_paragraph: https://twitter.com/alanblinder/status/535537228080898048

headline: Ex-Senator Jim Webb Explores Presidential Candidacy
abstract: The Virginia Democrat formed an exploratory committee for 2016, while recognizing the odds against him.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Former Senator Jim Webb of Virginia has announced a presidential exploratory committee, becoming the first candidate in either party to take such an overt step toward a White House bid. He called for economic justice and a restrained foreign policy, and vowed to “re-establish a transparent, functioning governmental system in our country.”

headline: Weekend Entertainments from the Archives of The New York Times
abstract: Turkeys were clearly on Nugent’s mind in late November 1937, when he wrote an essay under the headline “Pity the Pilgrim Fathers.”
lead_paragraph: 77 YEARS AGO

headline: New Leader at CBS News as Another Returns to ‘60 Minutes’
abstract: CBS cast the moves as an orderly transition. Mr. Fager had been running the news division while serving as executive producer of “60 Minutes.”
lead_paragraph: CBS News announced a shake-up in leadership on Thursday, elevating David Rhodes to the top position in the division, while moving the chairman, Jeff Fager, back to running the network’s flagship news program, “60 Minutes,” full time.

headline: Tunisians Are Shaken as Young Women Turn to Extremism
abstract: A recent raid on suspected Islamist radicals, which killed five young women, highlights a generation in turmoil in the place where the Arab Spring began.
lead_paragraph: TUNIS — Leila Mustapha Saidi returned home on a recent day to find her daughter Henda missing, along with her computer. Mrs. Saidi, who had watched her daughter grow religious and “obsessed” with the conflict in Syria, said she feared she had run off to join Islamist fighters there.

headline: Agency Cites Improper Loan Approval for New Tappan Zee Bridge
abstract: The State Authorities Budget Office said in a report that officials did not follow proper procedures before approving the use of federal clean-water funds for the bridge’s construction.
lead_paragraph: New York State officials proceeded in almost furtive fashion — without sufficiently informing the public or holding enough open meetings — in approving a $511 million loan from federal clean-water funds for the construction of a new Tappan Zee Bridge, an investigation by an independent state budget office reported on Thursday.

headline: Ana Lily Amirpour Narrates a Sequence From ‘A Girl Walks Home Alone at Night’
abstract: The director discusses a sequence from the film.
lead_paragraph: In this video, the director Ana Lily Amirpour discusses a sequence from her Persian vampire thriller featuring Sheila Vand and Mozhan Marnò.

headline: Attorneys General for Sale
abstract: States have to pass laws to stop the aggressive pressure from big businesses and special interests of their chief legal officers.
lead_paragraph: Every state has laws regulating lobbying, but almost all of those laws apply to lobbying members of state legislatures, not attorneys general. For the most part, states never anticipated that their chief legal officers would be the subject of aggressive pressure from big businesses and special interests.

headline: Reaching Out Between the Bars
abstract: Released after two years in an Iranian cell, Joshua Fattal struggled to shed his prison-bound self.
lead_paragraph: UPDATED: You can now hear this essay read by the actor Joshua Jackson, followed by a conversation with the writer Joshua Fattal, in Modern Love: The Podcast. Look for the “play” button below.

headline: Sotheby’s Chief to Step Down; Drew Fire From Loeb
abstract: After the hedge fund manager Daniel Loeb called for sweeping changes, the auction house said the departure of William Ruprecht was “by mutual consent.”
lead_paragraph: The chairman and chief executive of Sotheby’s is stepping down, the auction house said on Thursday, a little more than a year after the billionaire hedge fund manager Daniel S. Loeb derided the company as “an old master painting in desperate need of restoration” and demanded sweeping changes.

headline: 2014 National Book Awards: A Stop-Motion
abstract: A stop-motion featuring the books of the winners and the finalists.
lead_paragraph: A stop-motion featuring the books of the winners and the finalists.

headline: Get Off My Lawn, Werewolf
abstract: In “Late Phases,” Nick Damici stars as a blind Vietnam veteran taking on a retirement village’s supernatural foe.
lead_paragraph: LATE PHASES

headline: A New Proposal for South Street Seaport Museum
abstract: The museum would be saved, redesigned and possibly moved closer to historic ships under a proposal presented Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: The South Street Seaport Museum would be saved, redesigned and possibly moved closer to historic ships under a proposal presented Wednesday by the Seaport’s developer, the Howard Hughes Corporation. “We’re completely committed to the long-term viability — making sure the museum is not only vibrant but sustainable,” David Weinreb, the company’s chief executive, said in an interview. In its revised proposal for the pier, unveiled at a meeting of a community-working group, Hughes said there would be money for the museum.

headline: 2014 National Book Awards: Highlights
abstract: A video montage of the evening’s best moments from behind the podium.
lead_paragraph: A video montage of the evening’s best moments from behind the podium.

headline: Steven Cohen’s Firm to Stop Paying Bonuses for Best Trading Ideas
abstract: Steven A. Cohen continues to take steps to send a message that his $10 billion family office will not run afoul of the law.
lead_paragraph: Steven A. Cohen continues to take steps to send a message to federal authorities that his $10 billion family office will not run afoul of the law in the way his former hedge fund did.

headline: Gego and Gerd Leufert: ‘A Dialogue’
abstract: An exhibition at Hunter College explores the art of European émigrés who made a life together pursuing rarefied forms of linear abstraction.
lead_paragraph: As scholarship on modern art in Latin America continues to unfold, Hunter College helps fill out the record with a small, perfectly poised exhibition of work by Gego (Gertrude Goldschmidt, 1912-1994) and Gerd Leufert (1914-1998), European contemporaries who emigrated at different times to South America. They met and made a life together in Venezuela, and had a significant influence on both the art world there and on each other.

headline: Most Heavy Drinkers Are Not Alcoholics
abstract: Most people who drink too much are not alcoholics, suggesting that they can be helped more easily than previously believed, a new government study shows.
lead_paragraph: Most people who drink to get drunk are not alcoholics, suggesting that more can be done to help heavy drinkers cut back, a new government report concludes.

headline: Suki Waterhouse Wears Romantic Burberry
abstract: The model evened out her ethereal look with a pair of chunky platform heels.
lead_paragraph: The Star: Suki Waterhouse

headline: Susan Te Kahurangi King: ‘Drawings From Many Worlds’
abstract: Ms. King’s show at the Andrew Edlin Gallery puts Looney Tunes characters like the Road Runner and Sylvester the Cat in some nasty new predicaments.
lead_paragraph: Since the early 1960s, the New Zealand artist Susan Te Kahurangi King, 63, has been reworking Looney Tunes characters like a rogue animator, abstracting, distorting and disassembling them in surreal and psychedelic landscapes. A small installation of her drawings was the undisputed hit of this year’s Outsider Art Fair. She is now making her gallery debut, with a bigger presentation, organized (like her art fair display) by the independent curator Chris Byrne.

headline: Albert Oehlen: ‘Fabric Paintings’
abstract: Mr. Oehlen’s scintillating Fabric Paintings, now around 20 years old and barely seen before, are featured at Skarstedt.
lead_paragraph: A big “Wow” is in order. Albert Oehlen’s scintillating Fabric Paintings, now around 20 years old, are quite a sight — and they’ve barely been seen before. According to the Skarstedt gallery, this show is their international debut as a group. It presents 14 of the 20 that Mr. Oehlen made from 1992 to 1996, and mostly kept in his studio.

headline: For Phil Klay, a National Book Award Winner, War Is ‘Too Strange’ to Process Alone
abstract: Phil Klay, an Iraq war veteran, New York Times contributor and winner of the 2014 National Book Award for fiction, calls for a greater mutual accounting between veterans and civilians about our nation’s recent wars.
lead_paragraph: Phil Klay, an Iraq war veteran who first wrote for The New York Times in 2010, won the National Book Award for fiction on Wednesday for his short story collection, “Redeployment.”

headline: A Restless and Turbulent Unconscious
abstract: “The Sleepwalker” is a spare study of two couples that digs into issues about class, domestic abuse, sibling rivalry and mental illness, but refrains from easy answers.
lead_paragraph: The Norwegian director Mona Fastvold, who makes her feature debut with the thriller “The Sleepwalker,” knows her way around mood. This spare study of two couples — Andrew (Christopher Abbott) and Kaia (Gitte Witt), who has inherited an estate they are renovating; and Kaia’s sister, Christine (Stephanie Ellis), and her wealthy boyfriend, Ira (Brady Corbet) — is set in Massachusetts but has a Scandinavian sense of reserve.

headline: The End Is Here, Onstage
abstract: Lemi Ponifasio’s “Birds With Skymirrors” gets its United States premiere at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: While many artists may feel moved to address climate change, the matter has special urgency for the Samoan choreographer Lemi Ponifasio and the members of his company, Mau. In a program note for his “Birds With Skymirrors,” which had its United States premiere on Wednesday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Howard Gilman Opera House, Mr. Ponifasio explains that many of the performers hail from low-lying atolls in the Pacific. In that part of the world, “Radical climate change is not an apocalypse about to happen,” he warns. “It is already here.”

headline: From Hymns to Hard-Driving Euphoria, a Quartet That Likes to Mix It Up
abstract: Frank Kimbrough and three musicians who perform on his new album, “Quartet,” played form-shifting selections Wednesday at the Jazz Standard.
lead_paragraph: The jazz pianist Frank Kimbrough has a gift for flowing ethereality, along with a fondness for earthy rapture. He’s a deft proponent of lyrical abstraction, though he knows when to let a melody have its say. His style is rooted in a pliability of form and feeling, which explains why almost all of the best moments in his early set at the Jazz Standard on Wednesday were suffused with a sense of transition.

headline: Comic Complications Swathed in White Terry Cloth
abstract: “Il Turco in Italia,” a Rossini comic opera, presents a challenge to those attempting to untangle its plot.
lead_paragraph: Any shortlist of the most confusing plots in comic opera — and there is lots of competition — would place Rossini’s “Il Turco in Italia” right near, or even at, the top. That this daffy opera, introduced at La Scala in Milan in 1814, is such a tangle of romantic intrigue and overlapping story lines may be one reason it isn’t staged very often.

headline: A Holy Man in India, Descended From New York Fashion
abstract: Nicholas Vreeland, a grandson of the fashion editor Diana Vreeland and the leader of a Buddhist monastery in India, is profiled in “Monk With a Camera.”
lead_paragraph: MONK WITH A CAMERA

headline: For 124 Families, This Lottery’s Jackpot Was an Affordable New Home in Manhattan
abstract: The Sugar Hill Development has begun to fill up with the winners of a lottery that, in a testament to the demand for affordable housing in New York City, attracted 48,000 families.
lead_paragraph: Anette Christopher took a few steps into her new apartment and dropped to her knees, arms stretched toward the ceiling. “It’s everything I dreamed of,” she said through her tears. “It took me a long time to be happy like this. I worked very hard for this.” After a hushed prayer of thanks, Ms. Christopher put on her eyeglasses to read and sign the lease to her home.

headline: A Redesign of Dracula’s Cape
abstract: A Persian-speaking, chador-wearing vampire is the main character in Ana Lily Amirpour’s “A Girl Walks Home Alone at Night.”
lead_paragraph: By the time the vampire in the chador is skateboarding down a dark, desolate street, the director Ana Lily Amirpour has ensured that “A Girl Walks Home Alone at Night” will roll on in your memory. The vampire, a Persian-speaking waif called the Girl (Sheila Vand), also wears a striped fishing shirt and an occasional smear across her mouth that isn’t lipstick. She’s taken the skateboard from a nameless tyke (Milad Eghbali), whose indomitable quality and threadbare clothes evoke the children populating Abbas Kiarostami’s early films and, in turn, those of Italian neorealism. Whatever the inspiration, the kid is just one of a number of character types drifting through Ms. Amirpour’s cinematic fun house.

headline: Phil Klay’s Literary Salon on the F Train
abstract: The morning after winning the National Book Award, Mr. Klay spotted a commuter reading a book by another National Book Award winner — his mentor, Colum McCann.
lead_paragraph: I’m a book voyeur on the subway, a game that has become less fun in the era of e-readers and smart phones. So when I see someone reading a print book, my eyes perk up.

headline: Bills-Jets Game Is Moved to Detroit as Snow Blankets Buffalo Area
abstract: The N.F.L. decided to relocate the game, scheduled for Sunday at Ralph Wilson Stadium, to Detroit’s Ford Field on Monday night.
lead_paragraph: ORCHARD PARK, N.Y. — A storm that has dumped more than six feet of snow in the Buffalo area this week, prompting officials to declare a state of emergency, led to the N.F.L.’s decision Thursday to relocate the Bills-Jets game, scheduled for Sunday at Ralph Wilson Stadium, to Detroit on Monday night.

headline: A New Destination for African Art
abstract: “Luminós/C/ity.Ordinary Joy” inaugurates the new Ethelbert Cooper Gallery of African and African American Art at Harvard.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — A few weeks before the revamped Harvard Art Museums reopened here, a new university-affiliated art space, the Ethelbert Cooper Gallery of African & African American Art, made its debut in modest quarters, two former storefront offices off Harvard Square, filling a slot that other local institutions left all but empty. The raw spaces were unpromising, to say the least, but the architect David Adjaye has done miracles in linking them and carving out eight nichelike galleries for the first show, "Luminós/C/ity.Ordinary Joy: From the Pigozzi Contemporary African Art Collection,” for which he also served as curator along with Mariane Ibrahim-Lenhardt.

headline: Perfect Timing on the Right Side of the Tracks
abstract: A photographer who went to document New York City’s bridges and elevated train tracks discovered worlds of activity underneath them.
lead_paragraph: A photographer who went to document New York City’s bridges and elevated train tracks discovered worlds of activity underneath them.

headline: Metropolitan Opera’s Deficit Swells to $22 Million
abstract: The company faces its most serious shortfall in decades, but says a new business model and endowment drive will put it on better footing.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Opera’s deficit ballooned to an estimated $22 million last year, the company said Thursday, as weaker-than-expected contributions and ticket sales combined with expenses related to the company’s labor talks to create its most serious shortfall in decades.

headline: Equity-Building Mortgage Challenged
abstract: The Urban Institute questions the effectiveness of a proposal for a low-cost, 15-year mortgage intended to help low- and middle-income borrowers build equity.
lead_paragraph: A proposal by the American Enterprise Institute for a low-cost, 15-year mortgage intended to help low- and middle-income borrowers build equity has attracted considerable attention over the last two months, including in this column. But the concept is getting some pushback from the Urban Institute.

headline: Highlights From the 2014 National Book Awards Ceremony
abstract: Here, courtesy of the National Book Foundation, a video montage of the evening’s best moments from behind the podium.
lead_paragraph: Last night, the National Book Foundation presented awards to this year’s winners in the categories of fiction (Phil Klay for “Redeployment”), nonfiction (Evan Osnos for “Age of Ambition: Chasing Fortune, Truth, and Faith in the New China”), poetry (Louise Glück for “Faithful and Virtuous Night”) and young people’s literature (Jacqueline Woodson for “Brown Girl Dreaming”). The American author Daniel Handler hosted the 2014 National Book Award ceremony and benefit dinner, which took place at the Cipriani ballroom in New York City and saw humorous and emotional acceptance speeches from celebrated writers. Here, courtesy of the foundation, a look at some of the evening’s best moments from behind the podium.

headline: An Orientation in Several Shades
abstract: “4 Moons” is Sergio Tovar Velarde’s look at gay boys and men in today’s Mexico.
lead_paragraph: One new couple is trying to get things together. One longtime couple is trying not to break apart. One paunchy, white-bearded man in a towel is trying to get some satisfaction in a steam room. And one angelic 11-year-old is learning that his priest doesn’t want to hear about a young boy’s sexual stirrings. With those stories, Sergio Tovar Velarde’s “4 Moons” (“Cuatro Lunas”) paints a spirited and sensitive portrait of gay boys and men in 21st-century Mexico.

headline: Romantic Passion With a Whiff of Ambiguity
abstract: A retrospective devoted to the French filmmaker Jean Grémillion at the Museum of the Moving Image highlights his peculiar blend of fantasy and fatalism.
lead_paragraph: In a short scene in his documentary “The Thorn in the Heart,” Michel Gondry gathers the aging residents of his aunt’s village in southern France and shows them a movie. He projects the film, Jean Grémillon’s 1941 melodrama “Remorques,” on a large screen in a clearing in the woods, and the townspeople sit as if in a cathedral, the faces of Jean Gabin and Michèle Morgan hovering above them while the soft, flickering light reflects onto the trees.

headline: Comedy Listings for Nov. 21-27
abstract: A selected guide to improv, stand-up and other comedy shows in New York City.
lead_paragraph: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Theater Listings for Nov. 21-27
abstract: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.
lead_paragraph: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Movie Listings for Nov. 21-27
abstract: A critical guide to movies playing in theaters, as well as a selected overview of film series and festivals.
lead_paragraph: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Federal Site Helps Consumers Avoid Financial Fraud
abstract: The site, run by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, helps people check the registrations and disciplinary histories of financial professionals.
lead_paragraph: PERHAPS it’s a caller urging you to invest in precious metals like gold or silver, and even offering to arrange a loan to help you do so. Or perhaps it’s a radio advertisement, offering fast profits from investing in exotic foreign currencies.

headline: Chapter 6 Has Great Advice for Gangsters
abstract: A self-help guide affects a large ensemble of characters in “Reach Me,” set in the greater Los Angeles area.
lead_paragraph: Casting Sylvester Stallone as a gossip-site publisher obviously modeled on Matt Drudge is one of many counterintuitive ideas that backfire in “Reach Me.” In this preposterous ensemble piece, residents of the greater Los Angeles area become better people through the extended influence of a motivational book.

headline: Activists Wield Search Data to Challenge and Change Police Policy
abstract: The use of public data on stop and search is an alternative tactic as communities who say they are unfairly targeted seek to rewrite their relationship with the police.
lead_paragraph: DURHAM, N.C. — One month after a Latino youth died from a gunshot as he sat handcuffed in the back of a police cruiser here last year, 150 demonstrators converged on Police Headquarters, some shouting “murderers” as baton-wielding officers in riot gear fired tear gas.

headline: America’s 11 Million
abstract: The demographics of America’s undocumented immigrants, more than half of whom have been in the United States for more than 10 years and nearly a third of whom own homes.
lead_paragraph: The demographics of America’s undocumented immigrants, more than half of whom have been in the United States for more than 10 years and nearly a third of whom own homes.

headline: 5 Guantánamo Inmates Are Sent to Eastern Europe
abstract: The Obama administration has been struggling with where to send four Yemenis among the five released prisoners, because Yemen is chronically unstable.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The government transferred five low-level Guantánamo Bay prisoners to Eastern Europe on Thursday. Four of the men were Yemenis, and their resettlement was a significant policy change in the Obama administration’s effort to close the prison at the naval base in Cuba.

headline: Charles XVI: An Inept Hunter, but You Can Count on Him
abstract: A restored version of the animated “The King and the Mockingbird,” an adaptation of a Hans Christian Andersen story, has a New York run.
lead_paragraph: The French animated film “The King and the Mockingbird” has been more influential than known or seeable, at least in the United States. The movie is belatedly opening here in a subtitled restoration, with special dubbed showings for children.

headline: Pop, Rock & Cabaret Listings for Nov. 21-27
abstract: A selected, critical guide to performances of rock, pop, cabaret and more in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Sifting the Ashes of Bible Belt Church Fires
abstract: Theo Love’s “Little Hope Was Arson” looks at the scars inflicted by 10 church fires over five weeks.
lead_paragraph: There’s nothing fancy about “Little Hope Was Arson,” a documentary on the 2010 church fires in East Texas, and that’s the beauty of it. The filmmaker, Theo Love, presents the people in the story as they are, without passing judgment and without apology, whether they are investigators or pastors or just ordinary folks caught up in the inexplicable. It’s Americana unvarnished and, because of that, as absorbing as it is respectful.

headline: Despite Setbacks, Filmmaker Zhang Yimou Moves Forward
abstract: This has been a year of ups and downs for Mr. Zhang, who first rose to global fame in the early 1990s with art-house movies like “Raise the Red Lantern” and “Red Sorghum.”
lead_paragraph: Under a sky ablaze with fireworks, more than 600 drummers decked out in brilliant red filled the square between the Water Cube and Bird’s Nest stadiums in Beijing last week to welcome leaders to the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit meeting. The spectacle recalled the dazzling opening ceremony of the 2008 Beijing Olympics, and no wonder — both were choreographed by the renowned Chinese filmmaker Zhang Yimou.

headline: Another Kind of Mystery Date
abstract: Having two relationships at once causes complications for a graduate student in the comedy “All Relative.”
lead_paragraph: “All Relative,” a tepid romantic comedy written and directed by J. C. Khoury, thinks it’s being surprising, but really it’s merely weaving several male sex fantasies together and making nothing insightful out of the resulting story.

headline: When Three Into One Equals More
abstract: The Fogg, Sackler and Busch-Reisinger museums have reopened as the Harvard Art Museums, designed by Renzo Piano.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — Six years is a long time for an art museum to go dark, and at Harvard, make that two museums, and eventually three. Such was the case when the university decided to unite its three very different museums — the Fogg (Western European and North American art), the Busch-Reisinger (art from German-speaking Europe) and the Arthur M. Sackler (Asian, Middle Eastern and Mediterranean art) — under one new Renzo Piano roof. Closings started in 2008, with a promised 2013 reopening. The clock ticked. The date passed. Still no lights, but much discontent, inside and out.

headline: Jazz Listings for Nov. 21-27
abstract: A selected, critical guide to performances in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Agreeing on the Really Big Stuff, Like the Proposal
abstract: Two men who don’t have all that much in common on the surface find that they ultimately agree on the important things in life.
lead_paragraph: Steven Okuley and Richard Dusseau often say that, if they had looked for love online, where matches are generally made according to similarities and common ground, they would have never met.

headline: Opera & Classical Music Listings for Nov. 21-27
abstract: A selected, critical guide to classical music performances in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Making Music, Not War
abstract: The spoils of war in Angola were hardly treasures: just more poverty and rubble, but the people still found inspiration for a national concert, chronicled in “Death Metal Angola.”
lead_paragraph: Frankly, death metal sounds a lot scarier in its Wikipedia entry than it looks in this documentary from Jeremy Xido.

headline: Dance Listings for Nov. 21-27
abstract: A selected guide to dance performances in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Close Encounters of the Woodsy, Slasher Kind
abstract: Directed by Colin Minihan, “Extraterrestrial” draws on themes and bits from other films for its tale of malevolent aliens.
lead_paragraph: You would never mistake the horror movie “Extraterrestrial” for the Steven Spielberg classic “E.T. the Extraterrestrial,” but you might be surprised by the number of scenes this picture borrows from other movies: the threatened woman in the phone booth, from the first “Matrix”; furtive, emaciated, long-armed aliens, as in “Dark Skies” and countless other films; “Paranormal Activity"- style snatches of “found” video. A character grabs a carving knife at one point, and, you guessed it, there are young people imperiled in a cabin in the woods.

headline: Smoldering Dance, Unadorned
abstract: “Flamenco Flamenco,” by Carlos Saura, presents performances by some of the great ones of the field.
lead_paragraph: For decades now, Carlos Saura has been cinema’s chief archivist of Iberian performing arts, most notably with his “Flamenco Trilogy” in the early 1980s, and more recently with a documentary on Portugal’s fado tradition. “Flamenco, Flamenco,” a sequel to his “Flamenco,” from 1995, collects more impassioned song and dance.

headline: A Father’s Plea for Peace
abstract: Michael Brown’s father taped a public service announcement pleading for peace ahead of a grand jury’s decision on whether Officer Darren Wilson will be indicted in Mr. Brown’s death.
lead_paragraph: As businesses in Ferguson, Mo., braced themselves for potential riots, Michael Brown’s father taped a public service announcement pleading for peace ahead of a grand jury’s decision on whether Officer Darren Wilson will be indicted in Mr. Brown’s death. The decision could come as soon as this weekend. At the same time, Jeff Roorda, a Missouri state representative and business manager for the St. Louis Police Officers Association, told The Associated Press that Officer Wilson was confident that he would not be indicted. In an interview, Neil Bruntrager, a lawyer for Officer Wilson, dismissed the comment. “The only expectation we have is that they will look at everything thoroughly,” he said of the grand jury.

headline: In for a Penny, in for a Pound, and Better Work Conditions
abstract: “Food Chains” is a documentary of a labor struggle waged by workers who each bring hundreds of pounds of tomatoes to market each day.
lead_paragraph: However you look at it, “Food Chains” is a mouthful. Gathering at least three films under one rousing umbrella — the fair-wage struggle of tomato pickers in Florida — this emphatic and empathetic documentary (directed by Sanjay Rawal and narrated by Forest Whitaker) presents the plight of our farm laborers as modern-day slavery.

headline: When Activist Investors Aim at Strong Companies
abstract: In the Another View column, Bill George examines four situations — Amgen, PepsiCo, DuPont, and Allergan — to see where activist investors have it wrong.
lead_paragraph: Bill George is a professor of management at Harvard Business School and a former chairman and chief executive of Medtronic.

headline: Museum & Gallery Listings for Nov. 21-27
abstract: A selected guide to exhibitions and installations in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Some in G.O.P. Fear That Their Hard-Liners Will Alienate Latino Voters
abstract: Some Republicans say their party has the greater challenge in framing their stand on immigration in a way that does not antagonize Latinos and others.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — All but drowned out by Republicans’ clamorous opposition to President Obama’s executive action on immigration are some leaders who worry that their party could alienate the fastest-growing group of voters, for 2016 and beyond, if its hottest heads become its face.

headline: Her Family Valued
abstract: Can the public accept that a beleaguered public figure might in reality resign for her family?
lead_paragraph: No matter how many hundreds of thousands of words, typically in the form of anodyne blog posts and women’s magazine articles, have been devoted to the subject of how crucial it is to achieve work-life balance, most of us still find it virtually impossible to believe the political or business figure who abruptly leaves a vaunted position and cites as the reason the need to burrow down in the cocoon of family.

headline: ‘Deep Down Dark,’ by Héctor Tobar
abstract: In 2010, the world was riveted by the struggle of 33 Chilean miners entombed nearly half a mile underground.
lead_paragraph: In 1987, a toddler who became known to the world as Baby Jessica fell into an abandoned well in a backyard in Midland, Tex., where she was stuck for 58 hours. Watching the coverage as a 7-year-old, I couldn’t get an answer from the newscasters or my parents that explained why it was taking so long for so many smart grown-ups to solve such a simple problem. Even now, I find it hard to believe that the human race can be outmatched by such a primitive adversary as a hole in the ground.

headline: ‘Embattled Rebel,’ by James M. McPherson
abstract: James M. McPherson reconsiders Jefferson Davis, the Confederate president and military commander.
lead_paragraph: Among the verses Union Army soldiers sang to the tune of “John Brown’s Body” as they marched through the rebellious South was one about hanging Jeff Davis from a sour apple tree. For many of them, as for Abraham Lincoln and his administration, Davis was a rebel and a traitor who was waging bloody war against the United States in defense of slavery and the world it made possible. Who better deserved the punishment that treason customarily imposed? But from the rebel point of view, Davis was president of what they called the Confederate States of America — Lincoln and others referred to it as the “so-called Confederacy” — and thus, according to their constitution, the “commander in chief” of the rebellion and the government they had hastily ­established.

headline: A Secret Life in Zurich
abstract: Stefan Haupt’s “The Circle” tells the story of a gay Swiss couple, from their (dramatized) meeting in the 1950s to documentary interviews today.
lead_paragraph: Stefan Haupt’s “The Circle” takes its name from an underground journal and gay club in Zurich in the mid-20th century. Our entrance to this corner of history comes through the story of Ernst Ostertag and Röbi Rapp, which is told through documentary interviews with this sweet, be-sweatered elderly couple and a conscientious dramatization of their courtship in the 1950s.

headline: ‘Philip Larkin: Life, Art and Love,’ by James Booth
abstract: James Booth’s new biography of Philip Larkin demonstrates why the poet’s work is great.
lead_paragraph: James Booth’s new biography of Philip Larkin is not very exciting, perhaps because Booth has the sense to leave the exciting writing to Larkin. But it is very welcome. If you believe that Larkin (1922-85) wrote some of the best English-language poems of modern times, then it has been a trial to see his questionable track record as an everyday human being get in the way of his reputation as an artist.

headline: Sherman’s Maps
abstract: How the general used a surprisingly sophisticated set of data to plan his famous march across Georgia.
lead_paragraph: In March of 1864, William T. Sherman succeeded Ulysses S. Grant as the commanding general of the Military Division of the Mississippi. Grant, who had moved up to command all the Union armies, instructed Sherman to strike against Gen. Joseph E. Johnston’s army in Georgia, and then penetrate the deep interior of the Confederacy in order to inflict as much damage as possible on the resources that fueled the rebellion. These instructions became the basis for the Atlanta campaign, where Sherman’s three armies advanced from northwestern Georgia to Atlanta from May to September. Subsequently — and more notoriously — Sherman continued the assault by spreading his men into a moving front up to 60 miles wide as they marched to Savannah and then up through the Carolinas.

headline: Spare Times for Children for Nov. 21-27
abstract: A selected guide to cultural events for children, teenagers and families in New York City.
lead_paragraph: ‘Four Seasons: A Spinning Planet’

headline: Health Enrollment Counting Error Shows Where System Is Still Broken
abstract: Without a finished computer system for data sharing between the government and insurers, officials miscounted customers from 289 Excel spreadsheets.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration’s overcounting of the number of people enrolled in Affordable Care Act health plans reveals how all the glitches in the government’s computer system have yet to be worked out.

headline: This Week’s Movies | Nov. 21, 2014
abstract: The New York Times film critics review “The Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part 1,” “A Girl Walks Home Alone at Night” and “Happy Valley.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “The Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part 1,” “A Girl Walks Home Alone at Night” and “Happy Valley.”

headline: Bill de Blasio Defends Al Sharpton After Report on Tax Woes
abstract: The New York City mayor began his defense of Mr. Sharpton, a close ally whose access to the administration has attracted scrutiny, by calling him an “important civil rights leader.”
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio defended the Rev. Al Sharpton on Thursday amid questions over his unpaid taxes, emphasizing Mr. Sharpton’s work on civil rights issues and adding that he knew “a lot of good people” who had struggled with tax troubles.

headline: Spare Times Listings for Nov. 21-27
abstract: A selected guide to readings, exhibitions, walking tours and other cultural events in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Around Town

headline: New York City’s Week in Pictures: Nov. 20
abstract: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include a couple of cold days and a visit by Batman to a City Council hearing.
lead_paragraph: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include a couple of cold days and a visit by Batman to a City Council hearing.

headline: An Obamacare Do-Over
abstract: A Republican way forward on federal health policy.
lead_paragraph: MANY political analysts were surprised by how close I came to winning the Virginia Senate race earlier this month. I received more than a million votes running on a five-point plan for economic growth, and the first point was a specific proposal to replace the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Difficult Decisions in Treating A.D.H.D.
abstract: Medical professionals and a parent react to an article about a mother’s agonizing over whether to give her son an antipsychotic.

headline: Israelis Confiscate Weapons Bound for East Jerusalem
abstract: The police arrested five Arab citizens of Israel after discovering two shipping containers with knives, swords and fireworks.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Thousands of commando-style knives, swords, fireworks and small devices capable of delivering an electric shock were found hidden in two shipping containers supposedly loaded with Christmas decorations, the Israeli police and customs authority said Thursday.

headline: Watch: President Obama Announces Executive Action on Immigration
abstract: President Obama announces executive actions on immigration.

headline: Obama’s Immigration Action Has Precedents, but May Set a New One
abstract: The president’s use of executive powers to confer a quasi-legal status on millions of unauthorized immigrants is broader than similar initiatives by some Republican presidents.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s action to shield millions of undocumented immigrants from deportation and grant them work permits opens a new front in the decades-long debate over the scope of presidential authority.

headline: Fighting Ebola in Liberia: The C.D.C. Director’s View
abstract: Tom Frieden discusses the progress made despite the challenges.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Airbus Wins Delta Order on Promise of Delivery
abstract: Boeing was the loser in the heated contest, in part because it couldn’t deliver planes quick enough for Delta.
lead_paragraph: Airbus scored a big victory over Boeing on Thursday when Delta Air Lines said it would buy 50 new planes from Airbus, including its newest long-range A350 aircraft.

headline: Rent-Stabilized Leases Shielded in Bankruptcy
abstract: Lawyers said that not protecting such a lease would have made it easier for landlords to evict rent-stabilized tenants if they file for bankruptcy.
lead_paragraph: In a decision with implications for millions of tenants, New York State’s highest court ruled Thursday that a lease for a rent-regulated apartment is a public benefit and cannot be seized as an asset in a personal bankruptcy.

headline: Private Sector in Health
abstract: Robert I. Field of Drexel University writes that “the symbiosis between the government and private insurers under the Affordable Care Act should come as no surprise.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Used as Sex Slaves by Japan
abstract: Grace Wang, an adviser to the Taiwan Benevolent Association of America, writes that the women should be listed in the Unesco Memory of the World Register.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Voting Law, Trashed
abstract: Stanley Farb, a reader, writes that voter suppression “is a stain on our democracy.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Reveal Mental Disorder?
abstract: Felicia Nimue Ackerman, a reader, warns against an employer’s possible reprisal.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Animals Have Rights, Too
abstract: William Crain, the author of “The Emotional Lives of Animals and Children,” writes that it’s time we consider the rights and preferences of other species as well as our own.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Reaction Before the Action
abstract: Reaction to the president’s speech on immigration, before he actually made it.
lead_paragraph: President Obama hasn’t started to speak, but supporters and critics are already weighing in:

headline: Obama’s Speech: The Duel on Twitter and Beyond
abstract: Reaction to the President’s statement announcing his executive action on immigration.
lead_paragraph: President Obama announced his executive action on immigration tonight in a speech from the East Room of the White House. Reaction has been percolating all day, and escalated as the president wrapped up his remarks.

headline: 7th Accuser Joins Claims of Assault by Bill Cosby
abstract: Therese Serignese, 57, accused Bill Cosby of drugging and having sex with her after one of his shows in Las Vegas in 1976.
lead_paragraph: A seventh woman has stepped forward publicly with allegations that the comedian and actor Bill Cosby sexually assaulted her decades ago.

headline: Jim Parsons, ‘Big Bang Theory’ Star, to Promote Intel as Innovator
abstract: Mr. Parsons, who portrays the genius nerd Sheldon Cooper on the comedy series, is featured in a campaign that is scheduled to begin on Monday.
lead_paragraph: THE technology giant Intel, eager to make a bigger bang in a crowded and competitive category, is turning to a comedic actor who makes a “Big Bang” several times a day.

headline: The Democrats’ Immigration Problem
abstract: Obama’s good policy is a bad move for his party.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — PRESIDENT OBAMA’S executive order eliminating the threat of deportation for millions of undocumented immigrants is good policy. It is the right thing to do. But it is a dangerous move for the Democratic Party.

headline: Ferguson Looks to Holiday Shopping Rush With Unease
abstract: With a grand jury expected to decide any day whether to indict a police officer in Ferguson, Mo., local businesses fear that protests will disrupt the holiday shopping season.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — Honoring the 21st-century tradition of holiday retail, Best Buy is planning to open its St. Louis-area stores at 8 a.m. on Black Friday, promising early-bird discounts on flat-screen televisions, iPads and laptop computers.

headline: New York City’s Unemployment Rate Drops to Lowest Level in Six Years
abstract: The decrease in the city’s jobless rate in October, to 6.4 percent, capped the steepest decline of any quarter in the 38 years on record, the state’s Labor Department said.
lead_paragraph: The plunge in New York City’s unemployment rate continued in October, falling to 6.4 percent, its lowest level in six years, the state’s Labor Department reported on Thursday.

headline: Sculptor Offers Another Clue in 24-Year-Old Mystery at C.I.A.
abstract: The artist who created Kryptos, an enigmatic puzzle-in-a-sculpture in a courtyard at C.I.A. headquarters in Langley, Va., has decided that it is time for a new hint.
lead_paragraph: The artist who created the enigmatic Kryptos, a puzzle-in-a-sculpture that has driven code breakers to distraction since it was installed 24 years ago in a courtyard at C.I.A. headquarters in Langley, Va., has decided that it is time for a new clue.

headline: Perils, Platforms and a Prize
abstract: The Hong Kong-born multiplatform artist Paul Chan has won the 2014 Hugo Boss Prize, presented by the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation.
lead_paragraph: The Hong Kong-born artist Paul Chan has won the $100,000 Hugo Boss Prize, the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation announced on Thursday.

headline: Colombia’s Data-Driven Fight Against Crime
abstract: What Mayor Rodrigo Guerrero did to make Cali, Colombia, safer was remarkable because it worked, and because of the novelty of his strategy.
lead_paragraph: One Monday in 1988, El Mundo newspaper of Medellín, Colombia, reported, as it did every Monday, on the violent deaths in the city of two million people over the weekend. An article giving an hour-by-hour description of the deaths from Saturday night to Sunday night was remarkable for, among other things, the journalist’s skill in finding different ways to report a murder. “Someone took the life of Luís Alberto López at knife point … Luís Alberto Patiño ceased to exist with a bullet in his head … Mario Restrepo turned up dead … An unidentified person killed Néstor Alvarez with three shots.” In reporting 27 different murders, the author repeated his phrasing only once.

headline: G.M.’s Victims Get an Extension
abstract: Allowing an extra month for the owners of defective cars to submit claims for death and serious injuries is the right call.
lead_paragraph: The administrator of a compensation fund General Motors set up to pay victims of an ignition switch defect that could cause cars to turn off while they were being driven made the right call when he extended the deadline by a month for people to submit claims for deaths and serious injuries.

headline: Falling Wages at Factories Squeeze the Middle Class
abstract: A new study from the National Employment Law Project shows that real wages for manufacturing workers declined three times as much as for workers as a whole.
lead_paragraph: For nearly 20 years, Darrell Eberhardt worked in an Ohio factory putting together wheelchairs, earning $18.50 an hour, enough to gain a toehold in the middle class and feel respected at work.

headline: The Duchess of Alba, an Unconventional Aristocrat, Dies at 88
abstract: The flamboyant Spanish aristocrat was head of the five-century-old House of Alba. Her outspokenness and unconventional choices of marriage partners made her a media sensation.
