lead_paragraph: MADRID — The Duchess of Alba, a flamboyant Spanish aristocrat known for her lifestyle, her vast wealth, her art collection and her unmatched list of titles, died on Thursday in her palace in Seville. She was 88.

headline: A New Clue to ‘Kryptos’
abstract: The creator of Kryptos, a sculpture that contains an 865-character encrypted message, has released a second clue for the final unsolved section.
lead_paragraph: The creator of Kryptos, a sculpture that contains an 865-character encrypted message, has released a second clue for the final unsolved section.

headline: Ebola Spread Has Slowed in Liberia, C.D.C. Says
abstract: The international response to the epidemic, coupled with more effective action by local communities, has stopped its exponential spread in Liberia, the agency said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The international response to West Africa’s Ebola epidemic, coupled with more effective action by local communities, has stopped the exponential spread of the disease in one of the hardest-hit countries, Liberia, the director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said on Thursday.

headline: Long-Sought Roof for U.S. Open Is Taking Shape at Arthur Ashe Stadium
abstract: A retractable roof over Ashe Stadium is moving from the realm of imagination into reality in the coming months.
lead_paragraph: During last summer’s United States Open, the evidence of roof construction at Arthur Ashe Stadium was hidden under large flower planters and inside a bar.

headline: Love and Gravity
abstract: Christopher Nolan’s “Interstellar” illustrates how modern science has changed the way we look at love, philosophy and religion.
lead_paragraph: Most Hollywood movies are about romantic love, or at least sex. But Christopher Nolan’s epic movie “Interstellar” has almost no couples, so you don’t get the charged romance you have in normal movies where a man and a woman are off saving the world.

headline: Set Back by Hardship, a Student Athlete Runs Up Against an Age Restriction
abstract: Lawyers for Jason Puello, who, at 19, is too old to play for the basketball team, say that basing eligibility on when students’ birthdays fall means that the Education Department treats winter and spring sports differently.
lead_paragraph: Word came to Jason Puello in September that he was too old to play basketball in his senior year, when he would have been the starting center at a small alternative public high school in Washington Heights.

headline: After Criticism, Fed Will Study Wall St. Oversight
abstract: On the eve of a Senate hearing on bank regulation, the Fed issued a surprise announcement that it would review crucial aspects of its bank supervision.
lead_paragraph: Under pressure to show that it is up to the task of regulating giant Wall Street firms, the Federal Reserve issued a surprise announcement on Thursday that it would review crucial aspects of its bank supervision.

headline: Suffer Little Children
abstract: Today’s immigrants are the same as our parents and grandparents were. President Obama is doing the decent thing with his immigration initiative.
lead_paragraph: The Tenement Museum, on the Lower East Side, is one of my favorite places in New York City. It’s a Civil War-vintage building that housed successive waves of immigrants, and a number of apartments have been restored to look exactly as they did in various eras, from the 1860s to the 1930s (when the building was declared unfit for occupancy). When you tour the museum, you come away with a powerful sense of immigration as a human experience, which — despite plenty of bad times, despite a cultural climate in which Jews, Italians, and others were often portrayed as racially inferior — was overwhelmingly positive.

headline: University of California to Raise Tuition Despite Protests
abstract: Over the objections of students and the governor, the Board of Regents of the University of California adopted increases of up to 5 percent in each of the next five years.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — As students with sleeping bags staged a sit-in at the University of California, Berkeley, and the police stood by watchfully, the Board of Regents of the University of California gave final approval on Thursday to a contentious plan to raise tuition steadily over five years, which students across the state protested as unaffordable.

headline: Health Insurance Enrollment for Exchanges Was Overcounted
abstract: The Obama administration acknowledged on Thursday that it overcounted the total number of people signed up for health insurance through the Affordable Care Act exchanges.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration acknowledged on Thursday that it overcounted the total number of people signed up for health insurance through the Affordable Care Act exchanges. Marilyn B. Tavenner, administrator of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, said in September that 7.3 million people were enrolled. But Bloomberg News reported Thursday that the figure included nearly 400,000 people with stand-alone dental plans, prompting the administration to revise the enrollment figure to 6.7 million as of Oct. 15. The discrepancy was discovered by the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee, which had asked for the enrollment records. About eight million people had signed up for health plans by May, according to the administration, but many are no longer enrolled. At the time, the Health and Human Services Department broke out the number who had signed up for dental but not medical plans, saying that 1.1 million people had done so. In a statement, the Department of Health and Human Services said it still estimated that a total of 9.1 million people would have medical coverage through the exchanges by the end of next year. “The mistake we made is unacceptable,” Sylvia Mathews Burwell, the department’s secretary, wrote on Twitter.

headline: Obama’s Immigration Address
abstract: In a prime-time speech, President Obama announced a series of executive actions to grant work permits and temporary reprieves from deportation to as many as five million undocumented immigrants.
lead_paragraph: In a prime-time speech, President Obama announced a series of executive actions to grant work permits and temporary reprieves from deportation to as many as five million undocumented immigrants.

headline: Christina Kim Handles Downs and Ups by Dealing Openly With Depression
abstract: Having struggled with depression and years of inconsistency on the golf course, Kim recently won her first North American title in nine years and is feeling good about herself and her game.
lead_paragraph: NAPLES, Fla. — It took Christina Kim six holes to card her first par Thursday at the L.P.G.A.’s Tour Championship. While hardly ideal, Kim saw her birdie, bogey, double bogey, birdie, bogey start at Tiburon Golf Club as a perfect metaphor for golf and for life.

headline: 2 Worlds of Hong Kong, and a Fatal Intersection
abstract: The recent deaths of two women cast a spotlight on how impoverished housemaids are drawn to the city’s seedy bars to earn money through prostitution.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The banker, Rurik George Caton Jutting, a Cambridge graduate, came from London in 2013, one of thousands of expatriates who arrive in Hong Kong every year to pursue jobs in banking and burnish their résumés with Asia experience. Mostly men, they often live expense-account-subsidized lives in luxury high-rise apartments, patronizing trendy Western bars at night and socializing at members-only tennis and yacht clubs on weekends.

headline: Senate Democrats Clash With White House on C.I.A. Torture Report
abstract: A group of Senate Democrats accused the White House of trying to censor significant details in a report on the Central Intelligence Agency’s use of torture.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a tense confrontation with President Obama’s closest adviser on Thursday, a group of Senate Democrats accused the White House of trying to censor significant details in a voluminous report on the use of torture by the Central Intelligence Agency.

headline: In New Jersey, a Court Fight Over Sports Betting
abstract: Sports leagues have opposed efforts by the State Legislature and racetracks to allow sports gambling, but their arguments at a hearing were not against legalization itself, but how it would be carried out.
lead_paragraph: TRENTON — The lawyers battling to allow sports betting in New Jersey did not contain their disdain for the leagues that oppose it.

headline: Militants in Benghazi Attack Tied to a Qaeda Affiliate
abstract: A United Nations document in support of sanctions against a group accused in the attack on the U.S. diplomatic mission cites its support for Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The Libyan militant group accused of leading the attack on the United States diplomatic mission in Benghazi two years ago had previously helped train a dozen fighters who went on to participate in a deadly attack on an Algerian gas plant, according to a United Nations Security Council document justifying new sanctions on the group, Ansar al-Shariah.

headline: Pregnant Lawyer Fails in Bid to Delay Trial
abstract: A request by a lawyer in the corruption case involving Malcolm A. Smith, a Democratic state senator, to postpone the trial because she was in the sixth month of a high-risk pregnancy was denied.
lead_paragraph: A Long Island lawyer’s request to postpone a trial until next September because she was in the sixth month of a high-risk pregnancy was denied on Thursday after a contentious hearing in federal court in White Plains.

abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: F.D.A. Approves Hysingla, a Powerful Painkiller
abstract: The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday approved a long-acting opioid painkiller that contains pure hydrocodone, which some addiction experts fear will be abused.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday approved a powerful long-acting opioid painkiller, alarming some addiction experts who fear that its widespread use may contribute to the rising tide of prescription drug overdoses.

headline: A Top Chinese Flyweight Is a Heavyweight at Home
abstract: Zou Shiming is “the poster boy for boxing in China,” according to the veteran promoter Bob Arum, and his picture has been front and center ahead of the fight between Manny Pacquiao and Chris Algieri.
lead_paragraph: MACAU — Given Manny Pacquiao’s popularity, it is not surprising to see images of him lining the halls of a hotel this week.

abstract: President Obama explained actions his administration would take on the immigration system, and who those actions would and would not affect.
lead_paragraph: President Obama explained actions his administration would take on the immigration system, and who those actions would and would not affect.

lead_paragraph: A look back at the career of the acclaimed director Mike Nichols, who died Nov. 20, 2014.

abstract: President Obama defended his authority to act on immigration and challenged Congress to pass its own legislative overhaul of the system.

headline: Sunday at the Opera With Edgar
abstract: “Little Dancer,” the new musical directed and choreographed by Susan Stroman, features a ballerina with street cred.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Many decades have passed since ballet played a significant role in musical theater, which may be one reason “Little Dancer,” a new musical directed and choreographed by Susan Stroman, about the girl immortalized in the Edgar Degas statue of the title, has a whiff of the antique about it. This polished and pretty if less than transporting show, with book and lyrics by Lynn Ahrens and music by Stephen Flaherty, features a dramatic ballet in which the young heroine relives the rapturous highs and demoralizing lows of her life.

headline: Call From the Rear
abstract: Kevin Christian leads us into the weekend.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — It will not come as a surprise to anyone who frequents this blog that people feel very strongly about their crossword puzzles.

abstract: President Obama argued that rounding up and deporting all undocumented immigrants in the United States would be not only unrealistic, but also immoral.
lead_paragraph: President Obama argued that rounding up and deporting all undocumented immigrants in the United States would be not only unrealistic, but also immoral.

headline: Louisiana: Oil Rig Explosion Kills One
abstract: An explosion on an oil and gas platform in the Gulf of Mexico on Thursday killed one and injured three others, according to federal officials.
lead_paragraph: An explosion on an oil and gas platform in the Gulf of Mexico on Thursday killed one and injured three others, according to federal officials. The Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement reported that the accident occurred just before 3 p.m. on a platform operated by Houston-based Fieldwood Energy. The three who were injured were being treated at an onshore medical facility, the agency said. According to a statement from the company, one of the injuries was serious. The platform, 12 miles off the Louisiana coast, was not in production at the time and the Coast Guard had so far found no pollution in an inspection of the site.

headline: The ‘Doll Lady’ of Mount Vernon
abstract: Elaine Baez makes clothes for dolls as a form of therapy, and then sells the dolls on the streets of Mount Vernon, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: Elaine Baez makes clothes for dolls as a form of therapy, and then sells the dolls on the streets of Mount Vernon, N.Y.

headline: Amid Years of Psychiatric Turmoil, a Glue Gun Helps Keep Her Life Intact
abstract: Elaine Baez collects plain, unused or discarded dolls and resurrects them as her own pieces of art. She said the dolls “keep my nerves together.”
lead_paragraph: Elaine Baez dresses her models in brightly colored fabric, paints their nails, slicks their hair with gel and pierces stud earrings into their tiny hands to look like rings. She washes them thoroughly.

headline: U.S. Lays Out Limits It Seeks in Iran Nuclear Talks
abstract: American negotiators want to slow the Iranian nuclear program so that it would take at least a year to make material for a bomb if Iran decided not to abide by the deal.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA — As six world powers and Iran race to meet a Monday deadline for an agreement that would constrain Iran’s nuclear program, the United States has staked out an ambitious goal for what an accord should accomplish.

headline: Nazi-Era Art Collection Appears to Find a Home
abstract: The Kunstmuseum Bern is set to accept the trove, which was amassed by a Nazi-era art dealer and kept private for decades by his son, Cornelius Gurlitt.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — A collection of more than 1,000 artworks obtained by a Nazi-era art dealer and kept private for decades by his son is expected to be accepted by the Kunstmuseum Bern, a small museum in Switzerland, fulfilling the son’s final wish.

headline: Austin Takes the Far Right in Moderation
abstract: As illustrated by the declining momentum of a challenge to House Speaker Joe Straus, a Republican moderate, the party establishment came out of the election stronger in Texas, too.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — The rapidly fizzling challenge to House Speaker Joe Straus undercuts a noisy populist wing of the Republican Party in favor of an establishment hoping to quell what it regards as an unnecessary storm of temper tantrums and manufactured drama.

headline: Both Ends Want Bullet Train; It’s Those in Middle Who Object
abstract: A proposed bullet train would cover the four-hour drive between Dallas and Houston in 90 minutes. But the noise and the route possibilities concern rural residents along the way.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — Steve Drake regularly makes the nearly four-hour drive from this city to Houston to visit his fiancée’s family. So he was excited about the news that a private company intended to build a bullet train that would cut that trip to 90 minutes.

lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — Bradford Gilde, a Houston lawyer, stumbled across some unexpected evidence as he was preparing to sue Aruba Petroleum on behalf of a North Texas couple who believed fumes from the company’s natural gas wells were making them sick.

abstract: In a conversation intercepted by American investigators, the official suggested that his government was receiving secrets from a prominent former diplomat with the State Department.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American investigators intercepted a conversation this year in which a Pakistani official suggested that his government was receiving American secrets from a prominent former State Department diplomat, officials said, setting off an espionage investigation that has stunned diplomatic circles here.

lead_paragraph: A 33-year-old Bronx man was charged on Thursday with manslaughter in connection with the death of his wife’s 3-year-old grandson, the authorities said.

lead_paragraph: HYATTSVILLE, Md. — She was not going to believe it until she saw it with her own eyes: President Obama speaking on the big television screen, saying he would give protection from deportation to millions of immigrants in the country illegally.

headline: Food Bank Chief Fuels Up on Faith and Breakfast
abstract: Margarette Purvis, who runs the nonprofit Food Bank for New York City, says her Mississippi roots and her grandmother influenced her desire for good food and company on Sundays.
lead_paragraph: Margarette Purvis, a Mississippi native now living in Harlem, runs the nonprofit Food Bank for New York City, which will provide 80,000 turkeys to food pantries and soup kitchens for Thanksgiving Day. Ms. Purvis, who declined to give her age — “I’m a true Southern woman” — said she saw all types of people lining up for meals these days, including many who were “more educated.” For her part, Ms. Purvis will be in Mississippi for the holiday, enjoying family and food, and if they live up to expectation, she will most likely pronounce them “yummy.”

headline: Harland Stonecipher, Insurance Pioneer, Dies at 76
abstract: Mr. Stonecipher, an insurance salesman, started Pre-Paid Legal Services after his difficulties with legal costs from an auto accident.
lead_paragraph: Harland C. Stonecipher, an insurance salesman whose legal problems after a head-on car crash prompted him to pioneer a new way for people to insure against future legal costs, died on Nov. 10 in Ada, Okla. He was 76.

headline: A Game of Plates
abstract: Five friends from law school days gathered at the East Village restaurant to enjoy a special menu featuring dishes drawn from the “Game of Thrones” novels.
lead_paragraph: A few months ago, Gabe Thompson, the chef at L’Apicio, an Italian restaurant in the East Village, started reading the “Game of Thrones” novels by George R. R. Martin. Already a fan of the bloody, beardy HBO drama based on the books, Mr. Thompson was struck by how obsessed the original works were with culinary matters. “They were all about food,” he said the other day. The insight had prompted an epiphany: Why not host a “Games of Thrones” feast, matching dishes taken from, or inspired by, the books with beers produced by Ommegang, the Belgian-style brewery near Cooperstown, N.Y., that recently released a limited-edition line of “Game of Thrones” beer? When the dinner was announced this month, the 35 seats sold out almost immediately. And on Tuesday night, a ravenous crowd of “Games of Thrones” fans — including five old friends from law school — descended on L’Apicio’s private dining room for a hearty, medieval-style repast.

headline: Helping Felix Avoid Oscar
abstract: Taking cues from online dating services, MatchPad seeks to match renters on how they mesh in areas like extroversion and cleanliness.
lead_paragraph: They are among the most pressing questions to confront someone moving to New York City: Where will I live, and with whom? When I arrived here, I was so desperate for a place that I took the first one available (leading immediately to my first bad-roommate arrangement). It is situations like these that a new app called MatchPad is designed to help users avoid.

headline: Colonial Williamsburg Plans Expansion and $600 Million Campaign
abstract: The campaign calls for enlarging Williamsburg’s art museums, the first major expansion of the facility since it opened in 1985.
lead_paragraph: Colonial Williamsburg’s art museums are to expand as part of a $600 million campaign, the foundation that runs the historic site in Williamsburg, Va., is to announce on Friday.

lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — A day of mostly peaceful antigovernment mass marches on Thursday to protest the disappearance, and presumed murders, of 43 college students ended with clashes with the police who tried to prevent some demonstrators from damaging the National Palace in the city center.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — The populist U.K. Independence Party won its second seat in the British Parliament early Friday with a striking victory that threatened to destabilize the Conservative Party of Prime Minister David Cameron.

lead_paragraph: A project run by the photographer Brendan Bannon in the Zaatari refugee camp in Jordan gave young people digital cameras to chronicle the details of their lives, which were shaken by war in Syria, their home country.

headline: What’s on TV Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (Showtime) LOST SONGS: THE BASEMENT TAPES CONTINUED (2014) The director Sam Jones watches as Rhiannon Giddens, Jim James, Taylor Goldsmith, Marcus Mumford and Elvis Costello compose and record music at Capitol Studios in Los Angeles, with the help of the producer T Bone Burnett, for two dozen lyrics written by Bob Dylan in the summer of 1967 and only recently rediscovered. The result of the collaboration, “Lost on the River: The New Basement Tapes,” followed the release this month of “The Basement Tapes Complete,” a six-disc set of the 1967 recordings made by Mr. Dylan and the Band in upstate New York. “It’s a project that could have easily capsized under its own self-consciousness and the weight of the Dylan legacy,” Jon Pareles wrote in The New York Times about the new album. “But the personalities of the songwriters, who are bandleaders on their own, push through.”

headline: Japan Orders Takata to Investigate Flawed Airbags
abstract: The transportation department’s demand breaks with tradition by turning its focus directly toward a parts supplier, rather than to an automaker.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japan stepped up pressure on the airbag supplier Takata on Friday over safety problems that have been linked to at least five deaths outside the country and led to a Senate hearing in Washington.

abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, November 21, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “To those members of Congress who question my authority to make our immigration system work better, or question the wisdom of me acting where Congress has failed, I have one answer: Pass a bill.”

headline: Chinese Journalist Accused of Stealing State Secrets Affirms Innocence at Trial
abstract: Analysts said Gao Yu’s case was aimed at silencing a voice that gave the world rare glimpses into internal Communist Party politics.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Amid heavy security, Gao Yu, a journalist accused of stealing state secrets, went on trial in Beijing on Friday in a closely watched case analysts said was aimed at silencing a voice that gave the world rare glimpses into internal Communist Party politics.

headline: Should Millions of Undocumented Immigrants Be Allowed to Live in the U.S. Without Fear of Getting Deported?
abstract: Should unauthorized immigrants in the United States be allowed to apply for citizenship eventually? Or, do you believe that undocumented immigrants should be required to leave?
lead_paragraph: An estimated 11.4 million unauthorized immigrants reside in the United States. On Thursday night, President Obama announced that he is taking a series of executive actions to grant up to five million of them permits to work in the United States and temporary reprieve from deportation. What do you think?

headline: Perfect Timing on the Right Side of the Tracks
abstract: A photographer who went to document New York City’s bridges and elevated train tracks discovered worlds of activity underneath them.
lead_paragraph: How does a photographer drawn to intimate, personal moments capture 700 miles of elevated infrastructure for cars, trucks and trains in New York City?

headline: Latin Grammys Wait for Obama, Then Quickly Move On
abstract: Although it was delayed for the president’s speech, the awards show quickly shifted its focus to giddy excess and over-the-top onstage productions.
lead_paragraph: The 15th annual Latin Grammy Awards had a serious warm-up act: President Obama announcing his executive actions to shield many undocumented immigrants from deportation. The Spanish-language network Univision, which broadcast the Latin Grammys live from the MGM Grand Garden Arena in Las Vegas, delayed the start of the awards to show the president’s entire speech.

headline: China’s Millenniums-Old Salt Monopoly No Match for Economic Reform
abstract: The country plans to scrap its state monopoly on the sale of salt, a move that would mark the end of a system that can be traced back to 685 B.C.
lead_paragraph: China plans to scrap its state monopoly on the sale of salt, marking the end of a system with nearly 2,700 years of history. The move is intended to bolster competition, the Beijing Youth Daily reported, citing the Ministry of Industry and Information Technology.

headline: Mario Draghi Says E.C.B. Will ‘Do What We Must’ to Stoke Inflation
abstract: In a speech, the European Central Bank’s president indicated that further stimulus measures were likely to be taken in a bid to avert deflation.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Mario Draghi, the European Central Bank president, strongly signaled on Friday that he and his colleagues were preparing a new round of powerful monetary stimulus to jolt the flagging eurozone economy.

headline: As Verrazano Bridge Turns 50, a Myth About Its Tolls Persists
abstract: Ever since the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge opened on Nov. 21, 1964, Staten Islanders and Brooklynites have maintained that they were promised a toll-free bridge, but no proof exists to back that claim.
lead_paragraph: A cloud of discontent that always seems to be menacing Staten Island, where people are accustomed to feeling ill used by the rest of New York City, is darker than usual these days.

headline: Police Question Indian Guru and Find Arsenal in His Compound
abstract: The police said homemade bombs and firearms were found inside his vast compound, which included a hall the size of two football fields where he would deliver sermons.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The police on Friday began questioning a self-styled Indian “godman” who was seized after security forces stormed his compound in northern India, where he had barricaded himself with about 15,000 followers for more than a week. An extensive cache of weapons was found inside, the police said, including ammunition stored underneath the “throne” from which he preached.

headline: Q. and A.: Kevin Niu on Movies and the Hunger for Horror in China
abstract: Despite being about to receive his Ph.D. in physics from Harvard, Kevin Niu plans to eschew the academic life to follow his calling in the entertainment industry.
lead_paragraph: In a few months, Kevin Niu is set to receive his Ph.D. from Harvard in physics. He’s studying nanotechnology, where he has focused on gallium nitride, which is used in the manufacture of Blu-ray Discs. So what’s he going to do with that Harvard degree? Go back to his native China and teach physics? Work at a prestigious laboratory? No. He’ll be spending time in Louisiana, producing a horror movie called “Abattoir.”

headline: In China, Success Depends on Mastering a Different Set of Details
abstract: Discussing a common business problem candidly, the owner of an auction company was cautioned, would make her look stupid, and she was warned about wearing green for a speech.
lead_paragraph: What you wear, how you speak and even how you stand are part of your image. In China, those are not the details that really matter — especially for foreigners.

headline: Student Crossword | Thanksgiving

headline: Daily Report: Nintendo, Seeking a New Sales Hit, Releases Amiibo Figurines
abstract: On Friday, Nintendo will release two products. One, the video game Super Smash Bros., follows the company’s traditional strategy of updating a top-selling franchise for a next-generation console. But the other release, a collection of toy figurines that will interact with the game, brings the company into an already flourishing market — one that allows it to take more advantage of popular characters like Mario and Luigi.
lead_paragraph: Nintendo may have stopped its sharp fall. To start climbing again, the video game company is expanding its playbook, Gregory Schmidt reports.

headline: Morning Agenda: China Cuts Rates
abstract: China cuts benchmark interest rates for the first time since July 2012. | Fed to review bank oversight. | Sotheby’s chief to step down. | Goldman and Senate spar over commodities.
lead_paragraph: CHINA CUTS RATES | China has cut benchmark interest rates for the first time since July 2012, Bloomberg News reports. The one-year deposit rate was lowered by 0.25 percentage points to 2.75 percent, while the one-year lending rate was reduced by 0.4 percentage points to 5.6 percent, effective on Saturday, the People’s Bank of China said on its website on Friday. The move is a departure for the People’s Bank of China, which had focused on selective monetary easing and liquidity injections as the country heads for its slowest full-year growth since 1990. European stocks and United States stock index futures were higher after the announcement. ​

headline: Seasoned Hams, and a Dash of Diva
abstract: Daniel Schmid’s “Tosca’s Kiss,” a portrait of opera stars in retirement, is out on DVD in a 30th anniversary edition.
lead_paragraph: “In opera, everything is based upon the not-true,” Tchaikovsky noted in his diary. But that’s not necessarily true of opera movies, at least not “Tosca’s Kiss.” Set in Casa Verdi, the slightly shabby Milanese palazzo turned rest home for elderly cantanti d’opera, Daniel Schmid’s semi-staged, cinéma vérité documentary is founded on the sad fact that if we live, we will age, decline and die.

headline: Officer’s Errant Shot Kills Unarmed Brooklyn Man

At the same time, a man and his girlfriend, frustrated by a long wait for an elevator, entered the seventh-floor stairwell, 14 steps below. In the darkness, a shot rang out from the officer’s gun, and the 28-year-old man below was struck in the chest and, soon after, fell dead.

headline: Toward a Truth That Defies Precision
abstract: Creating works based on a raw real-life event, like “The Death of Klinghoffer,” holds dangers as well as opportunities.
lead_paragraph: As far as I could tell, there were no protesters in the vicinity of Lincoln Center on Nov. 15 before a Saturday matinee, the final performance of “The Death of Klinghoffer” at the Metropolitan Opera. This was a big change from the opening night of the Met’s season in September and the premiere of the “Klinghoffer” production last month, when hundreds of angry demonstrators gathered to denounce this opera by the composer John Adams and the librettist Alice Goodman as an anti-Semitic work that dared to humanize terrorists. Of course, Saturday is the Jewish Sabbath. But the only sign I saw being held outside the Met at the sold-out matinee said, “I need a ticket!” in big red letters.

headline: Sorry, No One’s Sitting There

lead_paragraph: When my wife and I go to the movies, I typically buy a third reserved seat so I can keep the seat next to me empty. I prefer — but by no means need, either physically or psychologically — the extra space. My wife finds this new habit of mine rather absurd and extravagant. I agree. But is it unethical? WILL, AUSTIN, TEX.

headline: Branden Jacobs-Jenkins Is, and Is Not, Writing About Race
abstract: In his latest work,"War,” the 29-year-old playwright again turns questions of identity on their heads.
lead_paragraph: “You realize it’s backing up,” Branden Jacobs-Jenkins said casually, as I turned around, midstreet, to find myself within two inches of a moving car. “No,” I managed, suddenly terrified, forgetting about the notes I had been taking. Jacobs-Jenkins touched my elbow, and his smile reassured me to start breathing again. “Not today,” he intoned, as I slid out of harm’s way and into Blue State Coffee in New Haven, Conn.

headline: Apples From Thanksgiving Start to Finish
abstract: Apples will see their way from the beginning to the end of my Thanksgiving meal.
lead_paragraph: There are many reasons to visit New York in the fall, and apples are one of them. I was reminded of this when I found myself at the small Lincoln Center farmers’ market on a Saturday in late October. I had been testing apple recipes at home in Los Angeles the previous week for this week’s Recipes for Health, and now I regretted that I didn’t have more recipes to test, so generous was my choice of apples. (This did not stop me from buying quite a selection and enjoying them, just about the healthiest snack on earth, throughout the week.)

lead_paragraph: Ryan Breymaier is hardly known outside the national sailing community. In the port cities Barcelona and Les Sables-d’Olonne, France, he is recognized as a skipper of some of the most challenging racing sailboats in the world.

lead_paragraph: Without ever having sailed together before, Ryan Breymaier and Pepe Ribes crossed the Atlantic Ocean in a 60-foot monohull, one of five boats in the June 2014, IMOCA Ocean Masters New York to Barcelona race.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Richard Ford, whose latest Frank Bascombe book is on the extended hardcover fiction list, had originally named his character Frank Slocum.
lead_paragraph: Né Slocum: Richard Ford’s story collection “Let Me Be Frank With You” — No. 17 on the extended hardcover fiction list after debuting last week at No. 14 — is his fourth book to feature Frank Bascombe, following three novels: “The Sportswriter” (1986), “Independence Day” (1995) and “The Lay of the Land” (2006). By now, in other words, Bascombe is as familiar as your next-door neighbor, having staked his place not just in suburban New Jersey but in contemporary literature. So I was startled to learn, while talking to Ford at an event last spring, that the character was originally named not Bascombe but Slocum. “I had a working notion,” Ford explained in a follow-up email, “that Frank was figuratively a man sailing alone around the world — like Joshua Slocum, who wrote ‘Sailing Alone Around the World,’ a book I loved.” But when Ford sent his manuscript for “The Sportswriter” to the poet Donald Hall, a longtime friend and mentor, Hall reminded him that Joseph Heller’s novel “Something Happened” also had a protagonist named Slocum. “So I was stuck,” Ford said, “with a finished novel narrated by a character I didn’t have a name for. This was very vexing, I hardly need say. I’d always felt a character’s name was totemic.” Ford set out to rechristen his protagonist, deconstructing “Slocum” and deciding he required a two-syllable, trochaic name that emphasized its vowels rather than its consonants. “I had a friend who had a middle name that was like Bascombe,” he said, “but I didn’t want to steal my friend’s name. So I rejiggered it into Bascombe — a name I’d never heard before but that sounded persuasive. I was actually surprised at how easily I made the transition from one loyalty to another. It was instructive.”

lead_paragraph: UNTHINKABLE: Iran, the Bomb, and American Strategy,  by Kenneth M. Pollack. (Simon & Schuster, $18.) Pollack, a Mideast expert and former C.I.A. analyst, scrupulously assesses America’s options in its intractable clash with Iran — from negotiations and sanctions to military strikes and nuclear containment — and comes to a sobering conclusion: “Going to war with Iran to try to prevent it from obtaining a nuclear arsenal would be a worse course of action than containing Iran, even a nuclear Iran.”

abstract: Some residents of Egypt, Maine, fear a communal settlement and its enigmatic leader; others are irresistibly attracted.

headline: A ‘No Wing’ Author
abstract: Carolyn Chute is as unclassifiable and unruly in her books as she is in person.
lead_paragraph: In the race for most eccentric contemporary author, whoever’s in second place probably can’t see Carolyn Chute. The writer, whose novel “Treat Us Like Dogs and We Will Become Wolves” is reviewed by Bill Roorbach this week, lives several turns off the beaten path in western Maine, where she founded the 2nd Maine Militia. In a 2008 profile of Chute in The Times, Charles McGrath described the group’s political philosophy as “essentially one of cheerful, nonpartisan economic populism.”

headline: Three Thoughts on an Amnesty
abstract: The scope and implications of the president’s immigration move.
lead_paragraph: 1) The first thing to say is that it could have been worse. In the end, the White House accepted (and publicly, since they released the memo) a limiting principle contrived by its own Office of Legal Counsel, and only extended work permits to parents of citizens and green card holders, rather than widening its initial DACA grant to protect parents of those protected immigrants as well. The White House also declined to make some of the other moves — involving agricultural workers and others — that were bruited in advance; it did expand the existing DACA program itself by changing age limits and moving the eligibility date for arrival from 2007 to 2010, but that’s just a further exercise of a power that the White House had already claimed.

headline: What I Discovered by Visiting Every Disney Park

lead_paragraph: Some people loathe Disney World, and I understand why. The artificiality, all those people gnawing on turkey legs, the standing in line, that infernal “It’s a Small World” song looping and looping — I get it.
