headline: It’s Time for Obama to Tighten Rules on Gas Leaks
abstract: An array of environmental groups have endorsed ways the Obama administration can cost-effectively cut leaks of methane from gas and oil facilities.
lead_paragraph: Environmental groups with varied stances on the merits of natural gas and the controversial extraction method best known as fracking have endorsed a set of cost-effective steps the Obama administration could take to stanch gas leaks from wells and other gas and oil facilities. Such emissions contribute to harmful local air pollution and — because the main constituent of natural gas is heat-trapping methane — global warming.

headline: 1914: Paris Theatres to Reopen
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: 1914: Paris Theatres, Cinemas and Restaurants to Reopen.
lead_paragraph: Paris is likely to assume a much more normal appearance this week than it has done since the beginning of the war, for M. Malvy, the French Minister of the Interior, yesterday officially stated that the Government’s decision to allow the reopening of theatres, concerts and cinemas, which has already been announced in the HERALD, was to come into immediate effect.

headline: New Tina Satter Play Among Offerings at the Kitchen
abstract: Ms. Satter’s “Ancient Lives,” a darkly comic coming of age story with roots in 1980s teen films, will open the winter season.
lead_paragraph: A new play by Tina Satter and installments of Synth Nights, an ongoing electronic music series, are among the highlights of the Kitchen’s winter 2015 season, the Chelsea arts center announced on Friday.

headline: Today in Small Business: ‘Big Cannabis’ Is Coming
abstract: How the president’s immigration plan could help cities like Detroit. A lot of notable investors — and a former head of the Small Business Administration — are investing in a payroll start-up. A seasoned traveler says you can be more productive on a plane without Wi-Fi.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today. And by the way, I’ll be on vacation next week. See you in December!

headline: Why This Troop Leader Quit the Girl Scouts
abstract: As a former Girl Scout Troop Leader, I have a theory about why membership is dropping. It’s not the badges. It’s not the cookies. It’s the endless, endless forms.
lead_paragraph: Forget the turkey; it’s Girl Scout cookie time! Yet each year I’m finding it harder to track down my Thin Mints, and not just in my neighborhood. A recent Associated Press article notes that national membership in the Girl Scouts has fallen 27 percent from a peak of 3.8 million in 2003.

headline: Suddenly, Sri Lanka Presidential Elections Become a Real Contest
abstract: In a surprise, the president’s health minister, who also was the general secretary of the ruling party, quit to run as the opposition candidate.
lead_paragraph: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — President Mahinda Rajapaksa’s health minister quit on Friday to become the opposition candidate in the election set for January, surprising the incumbent with a united and robust challenge to his bid for an unprecedented third term.

headline: Protesting Injustice, Accepting Fame
abstract: The Irish singer Hozier talks about his fast rise on the Billboard chart and his great fear.
lead_paragraph: Hozier may write slow, brooding songs, but fame has come hard and fast for this 24-year-old Irish singer-songwriter. In early 2013, Hozier, born Andrew Hozier-Byrne, was still playing local gigs in his native Bray and recording at home. This fall, a viral music video helped push his first single, “Take Me to Church,” into the Top 10 of the Billboard Hot 100 chart.

headline: Early Results Are Disappointing in Japan’s Economic Program
abstract: With the nation’s economy again in recession, Japan’s prime minister has called an election for next month.
lead_paragraph: JAPAN’S economy is in recession again, and the government is calling an election.

headline: Hillary Clinton Takes Sides on Immigration
abstract: She could have stayed quiet. Instead, she backed the president’s executive action.
lead_paragraph: Presumably with the 2016 presidential race in mind, Hillary Clinton has sometimes bet that the best position is to have no position at all. She has refused, for instance, to say whether she favors the Keystone XL oil pipeline.

headline: China
abstract: New books by Val Wang, Xiaolu Guo, Tim Clissold and Liu Zhenyun.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING BASTARD

headline: New York Fed Is Criticized on Oversight
abstract: “Is the Federal Reserve up to the task of regulating financial institutions that are so large and complex?” the chairman of a Senate panel asked William C. Dudley.
lead_paragraph: The government agency that watches over Wall Street came in for repeated rounds of criticism on Friday at a Senate hearing into its regulatory track record.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘Deep Down Dark’
abstract: This week, Héctor Tobar discusses “Deep Down Dark”; Alexandra Alter has news from the literary world; George Guidall talks about narrating the audiobook of “Gravity’s Rainbow”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Héctor Tobar discusses “Deep Down Dark”; Alexandra Alter has news from the literary world; George Guidall talks about narrating the audiobook of “Gravity’s Rainbow”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: After Outcry, Britain Bars ‘Pickup Artist’ From Entering
abstract: The British government refused to grant a visa to Julien Blanc, a 25-year-old American, after a public outcry over his abusive techniques.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — This week, Julien Blanc became possibly the first man ever denied a visa on grounds of sexism.

headline: Torrisi Italian Specialties to Close
abstract: The popular Italian restaurant will be replaced by a more formal place.
lead_paragraph: Torrisi Italian Specialties, the little restaurant that spawned a mini-empire now called Major Food Group, will end its five-year run on Jan. 1 after a final New Year’s Eve dinner.

headline: Fear of Kim Kardashian’s Derrière
abstract: Are you appalled by a behind that balances a glass of champagne? Or hoping Santa buys you one for Christmas?
lead_paragraph: I spend a fair amount of time trying to duck Kim Kardashian, but what with her bold attempt to break the Internet last week, I thought I owed it to her to look at the pictures of her behind on the cover of Paper magazine balancing a glass of champagne.

headline: Miller and Tysen Win $50,000 Music Theater Award
abstract: Chris Miller and Nathan Tysen have won the Fred Ebb Award, given for excellence in music theater songwriting.
lead_paragraph: Chris Miller and Nathan Tysen are the winners of the Fred Ebb Award, a prize given annually since 2005 for excellence in music theater songwriting; the prize is for composers or songwriting teams who have not yet achieved significant commercial success. The award includes a $50,000 cash prize, as well as a showcase performance produced by the Fred Ebb Foundation, which presents the awards in association with the Roundabout Theater Company.

headline: Google Experimenting With Removing Ads for a Fee
abstract: Google started experimenting with a new way to let users contribute to websites in exchange for fewer ads.
lead_paragraph: An oft-heard saying in Silicon Valley is that “information wants to be free.” Google is running a test to see if users feel the same way.

headline: R.B.S. Overstated Capital Ratio in European Stress Test
abstract: The bank said that it did not properly recognize certain tax credits on theoretical losses as part of a stress test.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The Royal Bank of Scotland said on Friday that it overstated its capital ratio in a recent European-wide stress test to examine its ability to survive a potential financial crisis or severe economic downturn.

headline: Weekend Auto Calendar: Tight Competition in the Formula One Season Finale
abstract: Lewis Hamilton leads the season points standings by only 17 going into the finale; American Endurance Racing hosts an amateur race at Lime Rock Park.
lead_paragraph: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend:

headline: A Nest for Nomads
abstract: The actor Brian Cox lives in a Brooklyn high-rise with his wife, Nicole Ansari, and their two sons.
lead_paragraph: Sure, Brian Cox felt a pang or two when he sold his seven-bedroom house in Sherman Oaks, Calif. “It was a wonderful space,” said the celebrated Scottish-born actor whose credits include the first two movies in the “Bourne” franchise, “Braveheart,” “Deadwood” on HBO and the TNT mini-series “Nuremberg,” for which he won an Emmy. Trivia buffs, take note: Mr. Cox played Hannibal Lecter — in the 1986 movie “Manhunter” — years before Anthony Hopkins sank his teeth into the role.

headline: Holder Offers Recommendations on Public Protests
abstract: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. offered guidance to law enforcement agencies and urged protesters to be restrained.
lead_paragraph: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. said Friday that the Justice Department had issued new recommendations to law enforcement agencies about the management of public protests.

headline: The Man Behind the Hacking: Talking to Guccifer
abstract: Back in November 2014, the reporter Andrew Higgins described what it was like to meet the hacker known as Guccifer in a Romanian prison. In May 2016, as part of a deal with the Justice Department, Guccifer pleaded guilty to federal charges that he hacked the email accounts of Secretary of State Colin Powell, a member of the Bush family and former Clinton advisor Sidney Blumenthal.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights from The New York Times. In this piece from November 2014, Andrew Higgins described what it was like to meet Marcel-Lehel Lazar, the hacker known as Guccifer, in a Romanian prison. Initially famous for revealing that former President George W. Bush had taken up painting, Guccifer more recently exposed Hillary Clinton’s private email address and boasted that he got into her private server as well (though he has provided no evidence to back up that claim). In May 2016, as part of a deal with the Justice Department, Guccifer pleaded guilty to federal charges that he hacked the email accounts of Secretary of State Colin Powell, a member of the Bush family and former Clinton advisor Sidney Blumenthal.

headline: Vegetarian Thanksgiving: Skyping the Holiday Meal
abstract: A technology-assisted holiday meal has become a cherished Thanksgiving memory.
lead_paragraph: Are you missing the big family gathering for Thanksgiving this year? Try dining by Skype.

headline: Bain Capital Raises $4.3 Billion for European Fund
abstract: Many private equity deal makers are investing at a healthy clip in Europe, particularly as soaring stock markets are making potential acquisitions in the United States appear prohibitively high.
lead_paragraph: Bain Capital has raised a fresh fund for private equity buyouts in Europe.

headline: Extolling Moderation to Get Cubans Talking About Politics
abstract: Two former journalists have created a space in Havana where dissidents, communists, artists, exiles and intellectuals alike can discuss national issues.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — FROM a lectern covered in a lacy, white cloth at a provincial Cuban church center last month, Roberto Veiga González and Lenier González Mederos took turns talking before about 60 intellectuals and activists about the value of political dialogue.

headline: Getting a Senior Discount? Here’s How to Give It Away
abstract: The Boomerang Giving project, which helps channel senior discounts to charity, is among innovative ways that older people are finding to practice philanthropy.
lead_paragraph: THREE dollars can go a long way.

headline: ‘Penelope Fitzgerald: A Life,’ by Hermione Lee
abstract: Hermione Lee’s latest biography is of the English novelist Penelope Fitzgerald, a late bloomer who published her first book at 58 and became famous at 80.
lead_paragraph: (This book was selected as one of The New York Times Book Review’s 10 Best Books of 2014. For the rest of the list, click here.)

headline: Manhattan Rowhouses With the Welcome Mat Out Back
abstract: The inside-out tenement, with residential entrances moved to the back and stores inserted at the ground level, was born of economic necessity.
lead_paragraph: In the taxonomy of the lesser building types of New York — the de-stooped rowhouse, the two-story taxpayer, the midblock sliver building — one is so obscure that even Linnaeus could be forgiven for overlooking it.

headline: Letter From the Editor: Facing the Reality of Win-Lose Situations
abstract: Many issues are maddeningly complicated, forcing us to prioritize our values.
lead_paragraph: I first became aware of Alan Dershowitz through cable television, and I initially didn’t understand why many people seemed to consider him a brilliant law professor rather than just another talking head. But seven years ago, while reporting an article  for The Times Magazine that had little to do with Mr. Dershowitz, I ended up attending a lecture he gave at Harvard, as part of a class called Morality and Taboo. During it, I started to understand why he’d been invited on so many television shows in the first place: He has an unusual ability to bring the essence of big issues to the surface.

headline: An Obama Voter Leads a Lawsuit Against Obama
abstract: Who is Jonathan Turley?
lead_paragraph: House Republicans were hoping the third time was the charm when they hired Jonathan Turley, a law professor at George Washington University, to handle their lawsuit against the Obama administration.

headline: Stuff We Liked: Names That Lean Left or Right
abstract: One of the articles that caught our eye pointed out that certain names tended to be more popular with Republicans or Democrats.
lead_paragraph: As we zip around the web, sharing with you the stuff our staff liked, let’s just get the eye candy out of the way: the political leanings of first names. The maker of a baby name app, Nametrix, noticed that certain names tended to be more popular with Republicans or Democrats. We’re not sure that it is statistically valid, but the chart is fun — right, Jasmine and Duane? (And we know why it looks good to us; it closely resembles an innovative 2012 New York Times graphic by Mike Bostock, Shan Carter and Matthew Ericson.)

headline: The President’s Executive Order Is Not Just About Unauthorized Immigrants
abstract: Life will be a little easier for skilled workers and foreign graduates of American universities.
lead_paragraph: In addition to helping 5 million unauthorized immigrants, the executive actions President Obama announced Thursday should make life a little easier for skilled workers and foreign graduates of American universities.

headline: ‘The Chain,’ by Ted Genoways
abstract: In the tradition of “The Jungle,” a journalist investigates the hidden costs — animal, human, environmental — of cheap meat.
lead_paragraph: Every working day, tractor-trailers from Iowa, Nebraska and Minnesota deliver about 30,000 hogs to a pair of slaughterhouses controlled by Hormel Foods. One of the plants is in Austin, Minn., the other in Fremont, Neb.; and both produce meat for the inexpensive, highly processed edible product known as Spam. In “The Chain: Farm, Factory, and the Fate of Our Food,” Ted Genoways describes in appalling detail what goes into that Spam. The ingredients on the label — pork with ham, salt, water, modified potato starch, sugar and sodium nitrite — may sound harmless. But Genoways argues that the industrial system behind those little cans is inextricably linked to a variety of social problems: animal cruelty, water pollution, food-borne illness, worker exploitation, a rise in anti-immigrant sentiment, government corruption and largely unchecked corporate power. Once celebrated with some irony by Monty Python, “lovely Spam, wonderful Spam” looms as a sinister force in “The Chain,” a hidden source of misery in the nation’s heartland.

headline: ‘Gravity’s Rainbow,’ Read by George Guidall
abstract: A skilled audiobook performance brings new life to “Gravity’s Rainbow” at age 41.
lead_paragraph: “Gravity’s Rainbow,” Thomas Pynchon’s gargantuan parable of rocketry, sex and a whole bunch of other stuff, turned 41 this year — six years older than its author when it was first published. What happens when a novel whose scenes of coprophagia and pedophilia moved Pulitzer trustees to cancel the prize in 1974 (when Pynchon seemed poised to win) eases into middle-aged, canonical respectability? Well, for one thing, it gets an audiobook release. Since the mid-1980s, a George Guidall recording has been floating around, like some mythical lost rocket part — no one had heard it, but all Pynchon fans knew someone who knew someone who had — but in October a new version, authorized and rerecorded and burned onto 30 compact discs — hit the stands. How on earth, I wondered as I stripped the wrapper, is poor Mr. Guidall going to render the sudden outbreaks of crazed capitals, or librettos in which stoners with guitars pastiche Rossini, the instructions helpfully stating “(bubububoo[oo] oo [sung to opening of Beethoven 5th, with full band])”? He turns out to do it in a slow and deep-voiced manner, beneath whose calm avuncularity you can detect anxiety, even mania, bubbling but never quite erupting — although I could have sworn I heard him, in the silence at the end of CD 30, racing out the door to buy a year’s supply of those Thayer’s Slippery Elm Throat Lozenges the hero Slothrop sucks, or perhaps to check himself into the book’s White Visitation mental hospital.

headline: ‘Fahrenheit 451,’ Read by Tim Robbins
abstract: Is “Fahrenheit 451” a parable about censorship or an indictment of the cultural distraction of technology?
lead_paragraph: One ordinary evening in the not too distant past, I discovered I had exhausted all the offerings of the futuristic entertainment devices designed to help me tolerate the present. There was nothing that interested me on my high-definition television, neither on my 700 channels of cable nor on my 300 hours of recorded DVR programming, and no one to amuse me on my telephone that is also a camera or on my electronic tablet that is also a web browser. So I roused the desktop computer that is also my audio library from its digital slumber, inserted a shiny disc into its silver frame, and listened as a Hollywood movie star read “Fahrenheit 451” to me.

headline: Jason Segel Reads ‘Nightmares!’
abstract: Twelve-year-old Charlie must confront his own fears to save his brother from the netherworld.
lead_paragraph: Multitalent is a funny thing — ­possessing it and beholding it. Often, the multitalented are cautious, aware that special judgment awaits, cocked and spring-loaded in a way it wouldn’t be if they had stuck to their original skill. We are more inclined to buy your banjo album or artisanal fig bars if you’re a movie star, but also more inclined to zero in on their flaws: too much banjo. If the multi happens to be one of those people who push their projects on us like a corn gavage down a duck’s throat — eat this, buy this, love this, don’t you love this? — our suspicions only deepen.

headline: Dan Stevens Reads Homer Translations
abstract: Dan Stevens reads Robert Fitzgerald’s classic translations of Homer.
lead_paragraph: Toward the end of Homer’s “Iliad,” the Greek hero Achilles organizes a series of athletic competitions as part of the funeral rites for his fallen comrade Patroclus. As contestants line up for the chariot race, Nestor, the aged leader of the Pylians, gives his son Antilochus some unsought advice. Cling to the turning mark, Nestor directs, as translated by Robert Fitzgerald:

headline: ‘Something Rich and Strange,’ by Ron Rash
abstract: Ron Rash’s stories portray the Appalachian landscape in all its brutal, exquisite complexity.
lead_paragraph: “One place comprehended can make us understand other places better,” Eudora Welty wrote in 1956. It is not an easy feat for a writer to portray a region so fully that enduring truths are found in local circumstance. The poet, novelist and short-story writer Ron Rash has accomplished this with his fictional account of the very real Watauga County in western North Carolina.

headline: ‘All My Puny Sorrows,’ by Miriam Toews
abstract: In Miriam Toews’s novel, a writer travels to a Winnipeg hospital to spend time with her sister, who has attempted suicide.
lead_paragraph: In a 2013 exchange that’s become famous in literary circles, the novelist Claire Messud took to task an interviewer at Publishers Weekly who observed that she — the interviewer — wouldn’t want to be friends with the protagonist of Messud’s most recent novel and asked if Messud herself felt the same way.

headline: ‘A Chosen Exile,’ by Allyson Hobbs
abstract: A cultural history of passing examines individual stories and questions the meaning of racial identity.
lead_paragraph: One of the best birthday presents anybody ever gave me was a “calling card” by the conceptual artist Adrian Piper. I was in college at the time, and it felt like the ultimate inside joke handed from one racially ambiguous person to another.

headline: Nuruddin Farah’s ‘Hiding in Plain Sight’
abstract: The terrorist killing of a Somali U.N. official brings strife to his family in Nuruddin Farah’s novel.
lead_paragraph: “Hiding in Plain Sight” begins with a threat. One evening in Mogadishu, Aar, a logistics officer for the United Nations, receives a letter in the mail. It consists of a single, misspelled word, but it’s terrifying all the same: deth! Aar wants to return to his home in Nairobi on the first flight out, but at the last minute, he decides to stop by the office to pick up photos of his children. As he steps out with the pictures in hand, Shabab militants strike the building.

headline: ‘The Port Chicago 50’ and ‘The Family Romanov’
abstract: Two audiobooks for young readers tell stories about the past.
lead_paragraph: For the past 20 years there has been a cassette tape in our car with a title along the lines of “Teach Yourself Morse Code.” While not exactly riveting material, this is possibly the first nonfiction audiobook I can remember listening to, and it’s a perfect example of why nonfiction works well in the format. The human voice lends life to words on a page. The tonal subtleties of a skilled narrator can captivate listeners with a commitment that readers of the written word must bring to a text on their own. Steve Sheinkin’s “The Port Chicago 50: Disaster, Mutiny, and the Fight for Civil Rights” and Candace Fleming’s “The Family Romanov: Murder, Rebellion and the Fall of Imperial Russia” are excellent works in their own right, but both books gain a layer of engagement through vibrant spoken narrations.

headline: The End of Biography
abstract: How can thousand-page biographies continue to compete for the attention of readers?
lead_paragraph: They land on my doorstep every day for weeks, their sharp report the sign that a new shipment has arrived. Others are thrust into my hands by the doorman, at first with jocularity, then annoyance, bulky packages that I wrestle into the elevator, dropping half of them on the floor. I have agreed to be a judge for a literary prize, and by the time the postal onslaught ends, there are 107 more books in my house than there were before — an addition no one but me would notice, so jammed is every available space with the evidence of a bibliophile’s intractable habit. Still, it’s a lot of books. I arrange them in piles in the guest room; soon, they’re as high as a stone wall.

headline: Stephen King’s ‘Revival’
abstract: Two men are locked in a battle of wills in Stephen King’s novel of fanaticism and what might exist on the other side of life.
lead_paragraph: There is a children’s joke that goes something like this: Why was Dr. Frankenstein never lonely?

headline: ‘The Republic of Imagination,’ by Azar Nafisi
abstract: Azar Nafisi uses three classic novels as a window on American society.
lead_paragraph: “I was the only foreigner in the English Department and took it as a personal affront that she thought I could not understand Twain or Faulkner as well as she did,” Azar Nafisi writes of a fellow student at the University of Oklahoma. “Of what value is a novel if you have to have been born in a certain latitude in order to enjoy it?”

headline: What Makes Employee Resilience Possible
abstract: The dawn of the digital age promised some relief, from capitalism’s demands for “more, bigger, faster.” But just the opposite has occurred, Tony Schwartz writes in the Life@Work column.
lead_paragraph: Capacity is the sort of flat, familiar word we don’t typically give a second thought. It’s also the key to a high-performance work culture and a sustainably productive life.

headline: Amid Snowstorm, Bills Shrug, Bundle Up and Make Their Way to Detroit
abstract: The N.F.L. considered ease of travel for Bills fans and tried to preserve some of the team’s geographic advantage before moving the game against the Jets to Detroit from Buffalo on Monday night.
lead_paragraph: CHEEKTOWAGA, N.Y. — Tight ends Lee Smith and Scott Chandler loaded up their suitcases, said goodbye to their families and hitched rides on snowmobiles. Wide receiver Chris Hogan started walking.

headline: Riots in Mexico City
abstract: Protesters and police clashed Thursday in Mexico City’s main square over the government’s handling of the disappearance and apparent massacre of 43 student teachers.
lead_paragraph: Protesters and police clashed Thursday in Mexico City’s main square over the government’s handling of the disappearance and apparent massacre of 43 student teachers.

headline: Boehner on Obama’s Immigration Action
abstract: Speaker John A. Boehner said President Obama’s executive action on immigration had sabotaged chances for bipartisan legislation.
lead_paragraph: Speaker John A. Boehner said President Obama’s executive action on immigration had sabotaged chances for bipartisan legislation.

headline: Popcast: London Calls Mary J. Blige
abstract: Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss Mary J. Blige and her new album, “The London Sessions.”
lead_paragraph: Mary J. Blige, the radiant gravitas-machine of American R&B, traveled to London earlier this year to work with a group of musicians and producers who revere her. They include Sam Smith, Disclosure, Emeli Sande, Naughty Boy, Sam Romans and Jimmy Napes. They’re all currently making hits, and they’re all interested in updates of various styles that Ms. Blige, 43, has direct or indirect connection with, from sad ballads to club music.

headline: Ailing Cher Cancels Rest of Tour
abstract: Cher has canceled the last 29 concerts in her “Dressed to Kill” tour because of an illness.
lead_paragraph: Cher has canceled the remaining 29 concerts in her “Dressed to Kill” tour, which was to have run through February (with a concert at Madison Square Garden on Dec. 15) because of illness, she announced on her website on Friday.

headline: Allure of ISIS for Pakistanis Is on the Rise
abstract: The Islamic State is not operating in Pakistan, officials say, but militants are beginning to invoke its name and some are pledging their allegiance.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Across Pakistan, the black standard of the Islamic State has been popping up all over.

headline: Biden Condemns Russian Action in Ukraine
abstract: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. denounced Moscow’s behavior as a “flagrant violation of the bedrock principles of the international system.”
lead_paragraph: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. denounced Moscow’s behavior as a “flagrant violation of the bedrock principles of the international system.”

headline: Anti-Government Protest Forces Biden to Skip a Kiev Stop
abstract: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. had to beat a hasty retreat on Friday at the sight of an unruly crowd of Ukrainians in Kiev protesting the new government amid continuing unrest in that former Soviet republic.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. had to beat a hasty retreat on Friday at the sight of an unruly crowd of Ukrainians in Kiev protesting the new government amid continuing unrest in that former Soviet republic.

headline: Daniel Handler Apologizes Over ‘Racist’ Comment at National Book Awards
abstract: The author, who hosted the awards ceremony Wednesday night, apologized profusely for what he described as a racist comment.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Handler apologized for a racially tinged joke he made as the host of the National Book Awards, when he referred with mock incredulity to African-American author Jacqueline Woodson’s watermelon allergy.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘Deep Down Dark’
abstract: This week, Héctor Tobar and George Guidall.
lead_paragraph: This week, Héctor Tobar and George Guidall.

headline: In Geneva, a Skating Rink With a View (and Brunch)
abstract: The hotel La Réserve Genève in Switzerland will feature a skating rink inside a heated tent–bar and restaurant included.
lead_paragraph: While Switzerland’s largest lake, Lake Geneva, never freezes, the waterfront hotel La Réserve Genève will simulate seasonal conditions when it opens its outdoor Winter Lodge on Saturday.

headline: Private Banking Firms Turn to Niche Marketing for Clients
abstract: Firms are creating units to serve a variety of ethnic groups, races, genders and members of the lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender communities.
lead_paragraph: CAN the financial needs of affluent African-Americans, women and members of the lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender communities be better served apart from mainstream wealth management clients?

headline: Five Stories of Classic
abstract: An Upper West Side brownstone that was once owned by the fashion designer Perry Ellis re-enters the market.
lead_paragraph: A brownstone at 37 West 70th Street, with airy panache and a profusion of French casement windows thanks to a rigorous 1980s restoration by its former owner, the fashion designer Perry Ellis, has re-entered the market at $17.95 million.

headline: New-York Historical Society to Open Center for Women’s History
abstract: The Center for the Study of Women’s History is expected to open in December 2016.
lead_paragraph: The New-York Historical Society plans to establish a new Center for the Study of Women’s History, to be included within the Henry Luce III Center for the Study of American Culture, the society announced on Friday. The center, which will include both permanent and rotating exhibitions, is expected to open in December 2016.

headline: 1939: Mine Sinks Japanese Liner
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Germany’s underwater warfare sinks ships in 1939.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — German mines, laid secretly off the east coast of England, today [Nov. 21] claimed the 11,930-ton Japanese motor liner Terukuni-Maru, while the 329-ton steam trawler Sea Sweeper, the Fleetwood trawler Thomas Hankins and the Boston (England) trawler Delphine were all sunk by enemy action, the Sea Sweeper in the North Sea and the Thomas Hankins in the Irish Sea. Meanwhile, the Admiralty announced the loss of the 520-ton British minesweeper Mastiff by a mine explosion off the east coast of England, bringing the toll of Germany’s unrestricted under-water warfare during the last five days to sixteen vessels. The loss of the Mastiff, completed last year at a cost of £46,000, was announced in an Admiralty communiqué which declared that the mine sweeping trawler was lost off the east coast “by the explosion of a German mine. The next of kin of casualties have been informed.” One seaman is dead and five missing. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Nov. 22, 1939

headline: Greek Budget Forecasts Growth, but Creditors Are Skeptical on Deficit
abstract: The troika of international lenders is wary of the projections amid political uncertainty in the country.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — The Greek authorities presented a budget Friday that forecasts healthy growth after a deep recession and includes substantial tax cuts for the first time in four years. But the upbeat assessment lacked the approval of the country’s international creditors, who remain skeptical that Greece can meet economic targets amid political uncertainty.

headline: As Immigration Rules Shift, Migrants’ Joy Is Tempered
abstract: Some expressed confusion about how they would obtain the new documents that would allow them to obtain work permits under the president’s plan. And immigrants who came here legally expressed betrayal.
lead_paragraph: HYATTSVILLE, Md. — For 14 years, José Alberto Piña, a Mexican immigrant without legal papers, worked on the same landscaping crew at a Maryland golf course. It was outdoor work, running sprinklers, mowing and trimming. He liked it, Mr. Piña said, and his boss liked him.

headline: There’s a Giant Contradiction at the Heart of the U.S. Economy
abstract: Three theories about why important economic clues are pointing different ways.
lead_paragraph: Suppose you told an economist these facts and only these facts: Long-term interest rates have fallen sharply over just a few months. Prices for oil and other much-needed commodities have been in free fall in the face of weak demand. Markets are predicting that inflation will be low in the years ahead and that the central bank will keep interest rates lower for longer.

headline: A Memorial to Her Son, Until the Bank Got in the Way
abstract: A mother’s wish to donate her late son’s savings to a scholarship fund proved harder than she anticipated.
lead_paragraph: Email haggler@nytimes.com. Keep it brief and family-friendly, include your hometown and go easy on the caps-lock key. Letters may be edited for clarity and length.

headline: Father’s Criticism, Amplified
abstract: Klay Thompson’s ascent with the Golden State Warriors has left his father, Mychal, the former Laker and current Lakers broadcaster, with mixed emotions.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Boys, as many parents are equipped to recognize, can be knuckleheads. And so when Golden State Warriors guard Klay Thompson, who led a life of privilege growing up, decided a couple of seasons ago that he was going to be the tough guy, shoving Indiana Pacers center Roy Hibbert from behind during a kerfuffle between the teams, his father instantly recognized it.

headline: British Insurer Aviva Close to $8.8 Billion Deal for Friends Life
abstract: The deal would create an insurance, savings and asset-management giant in Britain.
lead_paragraph: Aviva P.L.C. announced on Friday that it was in advanced talks to acquire the Friends Life Group for 5.6 billion pounds, or $8.8 billion, in stock, a deal that would create an insurance, savings and asset-management giant in Britain.

headline: Grand Jury Still Working; County Gets Ready
abstract: Preparations have begun for the moment when St. Louis County, Mo., will announce a grand jury’s decision on the possible indictment of a police officer in the shooting death of a young black man.
lead_paragraph: CLAYTON, Mo. — St. Louis County on Friday began making preparations for the grand jury decision on whether to indict Officer Darren Wilson in connection with the Aug. 9 shooting death of Michael Brown.

headline: The Making of a Washington Power Couple
abstract: Early in the Obama administration, before David Krone became persona non grata at the White House, he seemed poised to connect the Houses of Harry Reid and Barack Obama by marriage.
lead_paragraph: Early in the Obama administration, before David Krone became persona non grata at the White House, he seemed poised to connect the Houses of Harry Reid and Barack Obama by marriage.

headline: Lee Nguyen of New England Revolution Closes a Global Circle
abstract: Nguyen will lead the New England Revolution against the Red Bulls when they open their M.L.S. Eastern Conference finals series on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Lee Nguyen knows how it feels to be treated like a rock star.

headline: In Brooklyn’s Industry City, a Market for Objects Made in America
abstract: American Field, an event taking place in Sunset Park this weekend, will host 75 lines that manufacture in the U.S. including Shinola and Pendleton.
lead_paragraph: Speaking from his company’s Industry City warehouse in Brooklyn’s Sunset Park, Mark Bollman, the founder of the men’s wear line Ball and Buck, mentions the like-minded occupants of the historical manufacturing complex. “One of our neighbors does stained glass, another is a woodworker and made our desks and chairs, and someone does 3-D printing,” he says. “These buildings were used to outfit troops going to serve in World War II” — in fact, Industry City, then named Bush Terminal, established the borough as an international seaport around the turn of the century — “and, from an energy standpoint, it’s old-world manufacturing meets the new wave of maker culture.” This weekend, the space will add shoppers to the mix with the opening of Bollman’s American Field pop-up market.

headline: In Alabama Town, Obama Immigration Move Brings Hope and Sneers
abstract: The wave of Latinos hit Albertville in the 1990s, and eventually the city of 21,000 settled into its new reality, whether people liked it or not. And many have not.
lead_paragraph: ALBERTVILLE, Ala. — Residents here have long grown accustomed to the bright flourish of Hispanic flavor that has come to define their otherwise traditional Southern downtown: The bustle of La Popular, the supermarket stocked with coconut and mango, across from the sober white steeple of the First Baptist Church. The restaurant called El Sol King Pollo, with its tripe tacos and menudo, across Main Street from the Paisley Patch Boutique, with its gingham backpacks and monogrammed gifts for children.

headline: F.C.C. Chairman Says Agency Will Not Rush Net Neutrality Rules
abstract: The chairman, Tom Wheeler, said he had not spoken with President Obama since the president publicly urged the F.C.C. to reclassify broadband Internet access as a utility.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON – The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission said on Friday that the agency was taking its time formulating a net neutrality policy because he wanted to be able to defend the rules against an inevitable court challenge, which he expects whatever policy the commission approves.

headline: Alibaba’s Finance Arm, Ant Financial, Is a Mystery to Most Investors
abstract: Investors in Alibaba can’t reliably estimate the worth of the finance arm Ant Financial, writes John Foley in Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Alibaba’s finance arm is one of the secrets of the Chinese e-commerce group’s success. Yet investors in the listed Alibaba Group don’t control a single share of the business, and can’t reliably estimate its worth. That puts them at a disadvantage to a select group of insiders with a seat on both sides of the table.

headline: In a Queens Court, Women in Prostitution Cases Are Seen as Victims
abstract: Human Trafficking Intervention Court in Queens, the model for a statewide program, offers a deal: Get counseling instead of a record.
lead_paragraph: By 9:30 a.m. on a Friday, the defendants start filing into the fluorescent-lit hallway outside Judge Toko Serita’s courtroom in Queens Criminal Court in Kew Gardens, checking anxiously for their names on a sheet of paper behind glass. Many of the women are Chinese and find that their names, typed in English, are misspelled.

headline: The Diplomatic Effort, and What a Final Agreement Might Look Like
abstract: The United States, its allies, and other nations possessing nuclear weapons are striving to reach a deal with Iran to limit its nuclear power to peaceful uses.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA — Everything about the nuclear negotiations with Iran, now approaching a crucial moment, is complex: the international politics, the implications for the Middle East, and the science of how to prevent a nuclear energy project from turning into a nuclear weapons program. Here are answers to questions about the lead up to the diplomatic effort and what a comprehensive agreement might look like.

headline: Yangon’s Hero, Wielding Power of Stop and Go
abstract: As liberalization swamps Myanmar’s largest city with cars, a young police sergeant adept at managing the flow has been winning praise — and quite a few tips.
lead_paragraph: YANGON, Myanmar — For 12 hours nearly every day, Sgt. Khin Myint Maung stands in one of the most chaotic intersections in this chronically gridlocked city, untangling traffic snarls with patience and unflagging good humor.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Report on the Life of Adam Lanza Before the 2012 Shooting
abstract: A 114-page report provided new details into Adam Lanza’s life leading up to the massacre at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn.
lead_paragraph: A 114-page report provided new details into Adam Lanza’s life leading up to the massacre at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn.

headline: Adam Lanza’s Mental Problems ‘Completely Untreated’ Before Newtown Shootings, Report Says
abstract: A Connecticut panel’s examination into the life of Mr. Lanza, who killed 26 people at Sandy Hook Elementary School, showed he did not receive treatment for various psychiatric and physical ailments.
lead_paragraph: Medical experts at Yale University had called for drastic measures to help Adam Lanza in the years before he shot and killed 26 people at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn., but those calls “went largely unheeded” by his mother, who was also shot to death, according to a new study.

headline: In Berlin, Still Partying in the Ruins
abstract: An aspect of reunification — the emergence of techno and a do-it-yourself club scene — has endured as a cornerstone of the city’s identity.
lead_paragraph: Sunrise on a Sunday morning is barely noticeable in Berghain, the club that has been the citadel of techno music in Berlin for a decade. Its main dance floor is a perpetually dark place illuminated, infrequently, by flashing lights overhead and packed, hour after hour, with increasingly sweaty dancers. Its D.J.s play marathon sets that run nonstop, night and day, through weekends and into Monday afternoons, sustaining the metronomic mayhem of untrammeled Berlin techno: giant, booming drumbeats and bass lines bearing down and building up again and again, with relentless impact.

headline: Martoma Starts Serving 9-Year Sentence for Insider Trading
abstract: Most of the other former hedge fund traders convicted in the government’s long-running inquiry have already paid their debt to society.
lead_paragraph: Mathew Martoma has started his nine-year prison term for insider trading at a “low security” federal prison in Miami at a time that most of the former hedge fund traders and analysts also convicted in the federal government’s long-running investigation have paid their debt to society.

headline: Holder on Public Safety and Free Speech
abstract: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. said Friday that the Justice Department had issued new recommendations to law enforcement agencies about the management of public protests.
lead_paragraph: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. said Friday that the Justice Department had issued new recommendations to law enforcement agencies about the management of public protests.

headline: A Son Writes His Own Ticket
abstract: Atticus Lish, author of the well-received novel “Preparation for the Next Life,” took a circuitous path to his career.
lead_paragraph: At a pivotal moment in Atticus Lish’s novel, “Preparation for the Next Life,” his heroine takes a grueling trip around Queens in a pair of deteriorating shower shoes. She intends to “just go and keep going until the world ended or she ended.” The closely detailed recitation of her journey comes straight from a notebook Mr. Lish kept when he took that same walk.

headline: Blame the Princess
abstract: Women may be leaning in and branching out, but they’re still seeking to become the brides they saw when they were children.
lead_paragraph: In a Vogue magazine spread before Amal Alamuddin married George Clooney, the fashion designer Oscar de la Renta proclaimed that the wedding gown was “the most important dress in the life of a woman.” He probably wasn’t considering what a woman would wear, say, as she accepted a Nobel Peace Prize, or was being sworn in as the president of the United States.

headline: How to Arrive at the Best Health Policies
abstract: Randomized trials are highly effective for suggesting ways to improve health care delivery, but they’re also rare. That may be changing.
lead_paragraph: When the 48-year-old man from Oregon didn’t have insurance, he felt he had no place to go but the emergency room. The man, who has diabetes, went to the emergency room often when he suffered from kidney stones. “Emergency rooms, from what I understand, they can never turn you away,” he said. “I mean, you don’t have much options when you don’t have insurance.”

headline: Tune In to The Times
abstract: New York Times reporters and contributors participated in interviews regarding their coverage and other top news stories.
lead_paragraph: Over the past week, New York Times reporters and contributors participated in interviews regarding their coverage and other top news stories. Below are highlights from television and radio.

headline: Jordan Arrests Muslim Brotherhood Official Over Criticism of United Arab Emirates
abstract: The deputy head of the Muslim Brotherhood, Zaki Bani Rushaid, was detained over an article he wrote accused the United Arab Emirates of sponsoring terrorism.
lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan — The Jordanian authorities have arrested a senior leader of the Muslim Brotherhood for criticizing the United Arab Emirates, the spokesman for the Brotherhood’s political wing said Friday.

headline: Yiddish Isn’t Enough
abstract: Naftuli Moster is calling attention to shortcomings in secular education at Hasidic Jews’ schools in New York.
lead_paragraph: Naftuli Moster was a senior at the College of Staten Island when he first heard the word “molecule.” Perplexed, he looked around the classroom. Nobody else seemed confused. Yet again, because of gaps in his early education, Mr. Moster was ignorant of a basic concept that everybody else knew.

headline: Ryan Gosling’s Sexy Snub, Models in Latex and What Karl Lagerfeld Is Cooking Up Next
abstract: Plus, normcore just misses the Oxford treatment, a furry fall and more from the week in style.
lead_paragraph: All the week’s fashion news that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Measuring the Apology of the Atlanta Hawks
abstract: In the fourth installment of the Apology Metrics series, Dov Seidman invites readers to participate in a survey on the apology of Steve Koonin for the Atlanta Hawks.
lead_paragraph: This is the fourth apology in our Apology Metrics series in which we present apologies for readers to assess. Our goal is not to evaluate apologies as theatrical performances but to evaluate the apologizer’s behavior over time to see whether there has been genuine change. The survey for this apology will be predictive rather than retrospective. We will follow up with a retrospective evaluation after at least a year.

headline: Photos From the Los Angeles Show
abstract: A look at some notable models from this year’s show.
lead_paragraph: A look at some notable models from this year’s show.

headline: Officer Darren Wilson Said to Have No Plans to Return to Ferguson Police
abstract: Officer Darren Wilson is reportedly in talks with Ferguson city officials about resigning from the police department.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — Darren Wilson, the officer who fatally shot 18-year-old Michael Brown in August, has no intention of returning to the Ferguson Police Department, people close to him said on Friday.

headline: Soaking Cranberries, and Heading Into Thanksgiving Week
abstract: Isn’t the rule that no one has to cook anything over Thanksgiving week that isn’t for Thanksgiving?
lead_paragraph: You know what I won’t be cooking next week?

headline: Ford Announces Fuel Economy Numbers for the 2015 F-150
abstract: The 2.7-liter EcoBoost model is tops among gas-powered full-size pickups, but Ram’s 1500 EcoDiesel leads the segment’s overall fuel economy ratings.
lead_paragraph: Ford announced Environmental Protection Agency fuel-economy estimates Friday for its all-new, mostly aluminum-body 2015 F-150 pickup, claiming better numbers than other full-size gasoline-power pickups on the market in the United States.

headline: Pictures of the Day: The West Bank and Elsewhere
abstract: The West Bank and More — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: The West Bank and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: White House Taps First Female Pastry Chef
abstract: The White House has shattered a glass ceiling — in its kitchen.
lead_paragraph: The White House has shattered a glass ceiling — in its kitchen.

headline: Comparing College Costs the Easy Way
abstract: College Abacus aggregates cost calculations from up to three colleges at a time on its own website, but is blocked by some institutions.
lead_paragraph: If you’re a shoestring start-up trying to get noticed in an enormous industry, there’s nothing that helps more than having big players try to ban you. But from financial services to airlines, the pattern repeats itself again and again, as the lumbering giants seek to destroy rather than cooperate.

headline: Turkey Hash Is a Great Thanksgiving Leftovers Dish
abstract: Chop up that remaining turkey and add those extra vegetables.
lead_paragraph: What do you like better: Thanksgiving proper or leftovers from the feast? Both can be delectable, but even if all the guests leave with doggy bags, in most households, masses of leftovers are still a given.

headline: Weekend Reading: Is the New York Fed a Cop or a Fire Warden?
abstract: Under rising scrutiny for its ties to Wall Street, the Federal Reserve played defense in separate Senate panels on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Under rising scrutiny for its ties to Wall Street, the Federal Reserve played defense in separate Senate panels on Friday.

headline: Officials Revise Goals on Containing Ebola After Signs of Wider Exposure in Mali
abstract: The leaders of the United Nations and the World Health Organization said nearly 500 people in Mali and Guinea had been exposed to a sickened imam who had been misdiagnosed.
lead_paragraph: The leaders of the United Nations and the World Health Organization expressed renewed alarm on Friday about Ebola’s tenacity in Africa and, in particular, its potential to ravage a fourth country, Mali, where they said hundreds of people had been exposed to an infected cleric who died last month.

headline: Nov. 21, 2014 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from the West Bank, Kashmir, Spain and Germany.
lead_paragraph: Photos from the West Bank, Kashmir, Spain and Germany.

headline: Theater Owners Join Effort to Add Captioning to Films
abstract: A trade group representing the owners of some 80 percent of American theaters allied itself with advocacy groups for the deaf and hearing-impaired.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The National Association of Theater Owners on Friday joined major advocacy groups for the deaf and hearing-impaired in joint recommendations to the Department of Justice for an anticipated rule regarding captioning equipment in movie theaters.

headline: Keeping Up With Kendall Jenner
abstract: The model may not yet be as famous as her big sister Kim Kardashian. But she’s working on it.
lead_paragraph: When it was announced last week that Kendall Jenner would be the new face of Estée Lauder, a coveted contract that in the past has gone to actresses like Gwyneth Paltrow and Elizabeth Hurley and supermodels like Joan Smalls, the company did not promote the news by way of the usual public-relations machine, with news releases or email blasts.

headline: Priests as Husbands and Fathers?
abstract: How would the Catholic Church change if clerical marriage became more common?

headline: Taubman Hires Top Sports Banker
abstract: Paul J. Taubman is bringing Don Cornwell, a managing director who specializes in sports team deals, to his boutique investment bank.
lead_paragraph: Paul J. Taubman continues to poach talent from his former employer.

headline: On the Market in the New York Region
abstract: This week’s properties include four-bedroom homes in Katohah, N.Y., and Clifton, N.J.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties in the New York region:

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: This week’s properties are in the Financial District loft, on the Upper West Side and in Brooklyn Heights.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties in New York City:

headline: How to Defeat the Impulse Buy
abstract: The key to true self-control? Cultivate your sense of gratitude.
lead_paragraph: AS Thanksgiving approaches, so does the holiday shopping season. Once again, a day traditionally meant to celebrate gratitude will inaugurate a month of rampant consumerism.

headline: After Rocky Transition, Tunisia Is Set for First Democratic Presidential Vote
abstract: The front-runner, Beji Caid Essebsi, promises stability to a country that has had a few rocky years since kicking off the Arab Spring.
lead_paragraph: TUNIS — Less than a month after electing a new Parliament, Tunisians will vote Sunday in their first-ever open democratic presidential election, completing a tumultuous democratic transition begun with their revolution nearly four years ago.

headline: Book Review Podcast: ‘Deep Down Dark’
abstract: Héctor Tobar discusses “Deep Down Dark: The Untold Stories of 33 Men Buried in a Chilean Mine, and the Miracle That Set Them Free.”
lead_paragraph: In The New York Times Book Review, Mac McClelland reviews Héctor Tobar’s “Deep Down Dark: The Untold Stories of 33 Men Buried in a Chilean Mine, and the Miracle That Set Them Free.” Ms. McClelland writes:

headline: Biden Assails Russian Intervention in Ukraine as ‘Unacceptable’
abstract: Marking a year since the start of protests that ousted the last government, the American vice president also called on Kiev to complete a range of reforms.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. in Kiev on Friday condemned Russia for its “unacceptable” military intervention in Ukraine, while exhorting Ukraine’s newly elected government to complete its democratic and anticorruption reforms.

headline: When a Passion for Ferraris Turns Into a Commitment
abstract: Shortly after he saw Ferrari win the 1951 Carrera Panamericana race in Mexico, Rodolfo Junco de la Vega bought a 1951 Ferrari 212 Inter. Sixty-three years later, he still owns the car.
lead_paragraph: The 1951 Carrera Panamericana road race made a lasting impression on a journalist, Rodolfo Junco de la Vega, then in his 20s, who witnessed a winning performance by powerful sports cars from the nascent Ferrari factory.

headline: Protest Sites in Ferguson
abstract: Where people protested in the weeks after the shooting and in recent days.
lead_paragraph: Where people protested in the weeks after the shooting and in recent days.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Happy Valley’
abstract: The Times critic A. O. Scott Reviews “Happy Valley.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott Reviews “Happy Valley.”

headline: A Compact That Wins Style Points, but Misses the Bull’s-Eye
abstract: Dodge dropped its chic Dart sedan into the compact-car market two years ago, and although it’s attractive and distinctive, it has not made much of a splash.
lead_paragraph: The Toyota Corolla isn’t much different from a Nissan Sentra that looks like a Volkswagen Jetta or a Chevy Cruze and might as well be a Hyundai Elantra. Compact car buyers are obsessed with value, dependability and economy. Style? Not so much.

headline: 100 Candles and Quite a Few Darts
abstract: Dodge has just turned 100, and from the moment the first Dodge was completed on Nov, 14, 1914, the cars gained a reputation as reliable and unpretentious.
lead_paragraph: John and Horace Dodge got a jolt of free publicity in 1916. Two years after the brothers began producing their own vehicles, General John J. Pershing used a fleet of 250 Dodge-built cars to chase Pancho Villa and his gang into Mexico. After one shootout, a young lieutenant, George S. Patton, returned with the bodies of three of Villa’s men strapped across the hoods of three Dodge Brothers touring cars. Photos of the gory scene made Patton and the Dodge Brothers’ cars famous — well, more famous.

headline: Verbatim: Whatever It Takes
abstract: President Obama, in Las Vegas, on the measures he was willing to take to get the House of Representatives to vote on an immigration bill.
lead_paragraph: – President Obama, in Las Vegas, on what he was willing to do to get the House of Representatives to vote on an immigration bill.

headline: On Sundays, This Chimney Sweep Is a Wrestler
abstract: Cesar Granados, 39, owns a chimney cleaning company, but on Sunday, he becomes the wrestler known as Super Astro.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, Cesar Granados, 39, hauled his aching body two stories up a shaky aluminum ladder onto the peaked roof of a house in the Pelham Parkway section of the Bronx and began sweeping out the chimney.

headline: Creamy Broccoli and Potato Soup
abstract: Melissa Clark makes broccoli and potato soup with grated Parmesan and a drizzle of olive oil.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Clark makes broccoli and potato soup with grated Parmesan and a drizzle of olive oil.

headline: A Century of Dodge
abstract: A history of Dodge in pictures, from its early reputation as reliable and unpretentious to its troubles and rebranding efforts today.
lead_paragraph: A history of Dodge in pictures, from its early reputation as reliable and unpretentious to its troubles and rebranding efforts today.

headline: Inequality and Crises: Scandinavian Skepticism
abstract: Low Gini, bad slump.
lead_paragraph: In early December I’m supposed to talk at a Columbia conference on inequality and its consequences, and one issue I’ll have to address is the ongoing question of whether rising inequality makes countries more vulnerable to financial crises, makes it harder to recover from such crises, or in some other way degrades performance.

headline: Rhode Island Investigating Former State Attorney General
abstract: A former Rhode Island attorney general is being investigated on suspicion of lobbying former colleagues without registering as a lobbyist.
lead_paragraph: Rhode Island officials are investigating whether a former attorney general violated state lobbying rules by making appeals to his former colleagues on behalf of a Nevada gambling casino, among other corporate clients, even though he had not registered as a lobbyist.

headline: ISIS Taunts United States and Britain in New Video
abstract: In a video released Friday, John Cantlie, a British journalist being held by the Islamic State, called on the United States and Britain to negotiate prisoner swaps or pay ransoms.
lead_paragraph: ERBIL, Iraq — The extremist organization known as the Islamic State taunted the United States, in a video released Friday on jihadist websites, for its failed mission to rescue Western hostages held by the group in Syria.

headline: Buffalo Snow on Social Media
abstract: Residents in the Buffalo area used social media to post video of one of the worst storms in recent memory to hit western New York.
lead_paragraph: Residents in the Buffalo area used social media to post video of one of the worst storms in recent memory to hit western New York.

headline: Bill Cosby Rape Allegations: Readers Respond
abstract: As the actor’s comeback attempt derails, readers debate the validity of rape allegations against him.
lead_paragraph: Timothy R. Williams is a news assistant and comment moderator for The Times.

headline: Reimagined ‘Robin Hood’ To Land on Broadway
abstract: The production originated at the Royal Shakespeare Company and has also played at the American Repertory Theater.
lead_paragraph: “The Heart of Robin Hood,” which has been called a romance, a drama and a comedy, can now call itself headed for Broadway, the producers announced Friday.

headline: Time’s Running Out for the Torture Report
abstract: Republicans and the White House don’t want it to be made public.
lead_paragraph: Republicans take over the Senate in just a few legislative days. And when they do, they will probably snuff out the last possibility of releasing a huge report on the use of torture by the Central Intelligence Agency during the Bush-Cheney Administration.

headline: A Show Now Fully Recovered
abstract: The 2014 edition of the Los Angeles auto show features one of the strongest selections of vehicles in recent memory and has a level of automaker support and participation not seen since the 1990s.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It’s back, and it’s back on a scale that is well matched to this car-centric city.

headline: ‘A Girl Walks Home Alone at Night’
abstract: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “A Girl Walks Home Alone at Night.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “A Girl Walks Home Alone at Night.”

headline: Broccoli and Potato Soup With Rich, Complex Flavors
abstract: Searing the broccoli florets on one side adds dimension to this soup. (Article plus video.)
lead_paragraph: Sometimes it’s an ingredient that makes a dish shine: an unexpected jolt from lime pickle, say, or the toasty sweetness of a well-placed drizzle of maple syrup. But sometimes it’s all about technique. And such is the case with this broccoli and potato soup.

headline: ‘The Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part 1’
abstract: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “The Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part 1.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “The Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part 1.”

headline: To Delete or Not to Delete: That’s the Uber Question
abstract: Customers are deleting the company’s on-demand taxi app after Emil Michael, a senior vice president, suggested spying on its critics.
lead_paragraph: Call it Uber Angst.

headline: Dave Hickey, Live at ‘The Peacock Room’
abstract: An artIst remakes Whistler’s historic room. A critic goes off topic.
lead_paragraph: The convergence of art, money and patronage was the topic at D.C. Moore Gallery in Chelsea on Thursday night. Taking it on were Darren Waterston, one of the gallery’s artists, and the critic Dave Hickey, the iconoclastic author of “Air Guitar: Essays on Art and Democracy” and “Pirates and Farmers: Essays on Taste.”

headline: Insider Tips: Thanksgiving Recipes
abstract: Reporters and editors from the Food section and Times Cooking app suggest Thanksgiving recipes.
lead_paragraph: This week, reporters and editors from the Food section and Times Cooking app suggest Thanksgiving recipes.

headline: A ‘Wonder-full’ Love Story Ends
abstract: Peter Cott and Kenneth Leedom, interviewed in 2013, were a couple for almost 60 years, until Mr. Cott’s death on Nov. 14.
lead_paragraph: Peter Cott had just learned he had bladder cancer when he was interviewed last year for a Metropolitan cover article about his 58-year love affair with a man named Kenneth Leedom (“58 Years and Counting. A Love Story,” Sept. 8, 2013). The prognosis at the time was not bad, the couple said. They were newlyweds, declaratively in love, theatrical of bearing, refreshingly salty in their conversation. They were my mother’s neighbors.

headline: The Contested Site in Jerusalem
abstract: The holy site in Jerusalem’s Old City, which Jews call Temple Mount and Muslims call the Noble Sanctuary, has long been a flash point in the conflict between Israelis and Palestinians.
lead_paragraph: The holy site in Jerusalem’s Old City, which Jews call Temple Mount and Muslims call the Noble Sanctuary, has long been a flash point in the conflict between Israelis and Palestinians.

headline: Amid Attacks, Obama Presses Congress to Move on Immigration
abstract: President Obama returned to the Las Vegas high school where he called for an immigration overhaul last year, as he defended his recent executive actions.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — President Obama opened up a campaign on Friday to convince Americans that five million undocumented immigrants should be protected from deportation as he told an audience of mostly Latino high school students that Congress had to revamp what he called the nation’s broken immigration system.

headline: Mozart Melts Into Dark Shostakovich
abstract: Mozart’s Sinfonia Concertante in E flat for Violin, Viola and Orchestra was paired with Shostakovich on Thursday night at Avery Fisher Hall.
lead_paragraph: While listening to Mozart’s Sinfonia Concertante in E flat for Violin, Viola and Orchestra at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday evening, it was hard not to imagine how much better the work will sound when the hall’s dreary acoustics are refreshed as part of a future renovation and renaming project.

headline: William Spoor Dies at 91; Turned Pillsbury Into a Food Industry Giant
abstract: Mr. Spoor grew up in poverty and worked his way to becoming chief executive and chairman of Pillsbury, where he was known as a demanding and abrasive leader.
lead_paragraph: William Spoor, who rose from poverty to become chief executive of Pillsbury and transform it into a food products mega-company, died on Nov. 14 at his home in Salt Lake City. He was 91.

headline: Minnesota Opera President Resigns
abstract: Kevin Ramach, the president and executive director of the company since 2012, resigned abruptly on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The Minnesota Opera has long been regarded as a solid, polished regional company with a reputation for commissioning new work. But like many opera companies and orchestras, it has faced budget difficulties in recent years, and those tensions appear to have taken a toll on company’s management. Kevin Ramach, the president and executive director of the company since 2012, and its production manager for six years before that, resigned abruptly on Thursday, saying by way of a company announcement that he wanted to “return to my creative interests.” The Star Tribune reported that Mr. Ramach’s predecessor, Allan Naplan, had resigned after only a year on the job.

headline: Gurlitt’s Museum Bequest Is Challenged
abstract: A cousin has challenged the will of Cornelius Gurlitt hours before the Swiss museum he named in May as his sole heir was poised to accept his bequest of hundreds of artworks.
lead_paragraph: A cousin has challenged the will of Cornelius Gurlitt hours before the Swiss museum he named in May as his sole heir was poised to accept his bequest of hundreds of artworks collected by Gurlitt’s father, an art dealer for Hitler. It was not certain whether the move would affect the decision of the Kunstmuseum Bern, expected by early next week. Uta Werner, a cousin of Mr. Gurlitt, applied Friday to the Munich court that is handling his estate for a certificate of inheritance on behalf of herself, several of her children and some other relatives, Thomas Pfaff, a spokesman for the family, said in a statement.

headline: First Draft Focus: The Week in Pictures
abstract: The week in political pictures.

headline: Christmas With Death, Heels and Uplift
abstract: “Christmas Under Wraps,” “The Santa Con” and “The Tree That Saved Christmas” are among the best new holiday films on TV this season.
lead_paragraph: When did the holiday television movie become part of the fabric of Christmasness, as ubiquitous as Mariah Carey or sickeningly sweet lattes? This season there are at least 30 new films on seven networks, a procession that began on Nov. 1 (“One Starry Christmas,” Hallmark) and continues through Dec. 20 (“Back to Christmas,” Ion), along with hundreds of reruns from years past. That’s a lot of uplift and bad sweaters.

headline: Oregon Health Study: The Surprises in a Randomized Trial
abstract: The study upended conventional thinking about health insurance, and many of the individual stories were compelling and surprising in their own right.
lead_paragraph: The Oregon Health Study upended a lot of conventional thinking about health insurance. The study made use of a 2008 state lottery that randomly assigned some low-income Oregon residents to get insurance from Medicaid and others to remain uninsured. Then it followed them for two years to see what happened.

headline: Ferguson Officer Who Killed Teenager Is Said Not to Be Returning to Duty
abstract: The white police officer who fatally shot an unarmed black teenager in August will not return to the city’s police department, those close to him said on Friday, as the region braced for a grand jury’s decision on his fate.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — The white police officer who fatally shot an unarmed black teenager here over the summer, setting off months of protests, will not return to duty in the city’s police department, those close to him said on Friday, as the region braced for a grand jury’s decision on whether to indict him.

headline: A Proper Farewell for a Homeless Man Who Was Rich in Friendship
abstract: Friends of Eric Glenn Smith, a fixture on Broadway and 80th Street in Manhattan who died this year, raised money so he would not need to be buried in potter’s field.
lead_paragraph: By some standards, the gathering of about 15 mourners scattered in the pews of the chapel inside a Harlem funeral home might seem a sparse turnout.

headline: New York Chancellor Is Criticized for Remarks on Charter Schools
abstract: Carmen Fariña said at a conference that some charter schools push students out before they take state tests and later replace them with high-scoring children.
lead_paragraph: Charter school advocates on Friday demanded that the New York City schools chancellor, Carmen Fariña, release data to support her accusation that those schools push some students out before they take state tests and later replace them with high-scoring children.

headline: A Symbolic Protest at the Old Courthouse
abstract: At noon on Friday a handful of people performed a mock lynching across the street from the Old Courthouse in St. Louis as a silent protest of the police killings of Michael Brown and Vonderrit D. Myers Jr.
lead_paragraph: ST LOUIS — At noon on Friday a handful of people performed a mock lynching across the street from the Old Courthouse here as a silent protest of the killings of Michael Brown, who was killed in August by a police officer in Ferguson, Mo., and Vonderrit D. Myers Jr., who was killed in October by an off-duty police officer in St. Louis. It was a symbolic location. In 1847, a slave named Dred Scott came to the Old Courthouse to sue for his freedom.

headline: Amid Familiar Repertoire, the New York Premiere of an Oceanic Journey
abstract: Over two evenings at Carnegie Hall, Michael Tilson Thomas led the San Francisco Symphony in programs traversing Mahler and Samuel Carl Adams’s “Drift and Providence.”
lead_paragraph: Over the 20 seasons in which Michael Tilson Thomas has led the San Francisco Symphony, audiences have come to expect panoramic, innovative programming and clean, incisive playing. But since their four concerts at the American Mavericks festival in March 2012, their Carnegie Hall programs have become predictable.

headline: A Youthful Tribute to a Fallen Friend of Art
abstract: The National’s Bryce Dessner and the Brooklyn Youth Chorus pay tribute to a shuttered arts college with a 90-minute staged choral work.
lead_paragraph: When he was a child, the Brooklyn-based composer and guitarist Bryce Dessner went to a summer camp in the mountains of North Carolina not far from where Black Mountain College had been. This pathbreaking institution was founded in a 1933 as a college with arts at the core of its mission. Until it closed in 1957, faculty members like Josef Albers, John Cage, Willem de Kooning and Buckminster Fuller worked so collaboratively with students that it was hard to know who was learning from whom.

headline: The Young Barber and the Innkeeper’s Daughter, Romping Again
abstract: Natalia Osipova and Ivan Vasiliev reprised their roles in “Don Quixote” at the Mikhailovsky Ballet’s season at the David H. Koch Theater.
lead_paragraph: Natalia Osipova and Ivan Vasiliev performed their first “Don Quixote” together, on tour with the Bolshoi Ballet, in 2007, the same year that the Russian businessman Vladimir Kekhman took over as general director of the Mikhailovsky Ballet of St. Petersburg. Their debuts as Kitri, the feisty daughter of an innkeeper, and Basilio, the youthful barber she wants to marry against her father’s wishes, caused a sensation. Similar shock waves were felt throughout the dance world when, in 2011, they announced their decision to jump ship from the Bolshoi in Moscow to the relatively intimate Mikhailovsky.

headline: In a New Performance Piece, Tilda Swinton Turns Fashion Into Art
abstract: The actress interacts with audience members’ jackets in “Cloakroom,” a new show opening tomorrow as part of Paris’s Festival d’Automne.
lead_paragraph: The actress Tilda Swinton has for several years collaborated with Olivier Saillard, the director of Paris’s Palais Galliera fashion museum, on an annual performance for that city’s Festival d’Automne. In 2013, they did “Eternity Dress,” in which a garment was tailor-made — from measuring and patterning to cutting and sewing — for the actress before a live audience. The year prior, Saillard and Swinton created a piece called “The Impossible Wardrobe,” in which Swinton walked a selection of beautiful, fragile historical garments from the Palais Galliera’s archives (Napoleon’s tailcoat, an ermine collar worn by Sarah Bernhardt) down a runway.

headline: Audience of Ghosts, Taking Orders
abstract: Audience members are shrouded beneath sheets in Luke George’s “Not About Face,” a work that investigates issues surrounding belief, power, conformity and the art of pretending.
lead_paragraph: Instead of seats, we have sheets.

headline: Giving His Ex-Wife the Third Degree
abstract: Mac Rogers’s “Asymmetric,” at the 59E59 Theaters, is an espionage thriller in which a retired C.I.A. interrogator is called on to question his own ex-wife.
lead_paragraph: The fluorescent lights overhead on the spare set of Mac Rogers’s espionage thriller “Asymmetric,” now at the 59E59 Theaters, establish the clinical atmosphere, buttressed by percussive electronic music from the sound designer, Jeanne Travis. The milieu is the Washington intelligence establishment, and the C.I.A.’s former ace interrogator, Josh Ruskin (Sean Williams), is yanked out of his drunken retirement by his successor, Zack (Seth Shelden), to extract information from a renegade ex-colleague.

headline: When Is a War Over?
abstract: What an Army major and Alexander the Great tell us about America’s 13 years in Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: WARS always hurry their participants, as the Roman poet Horace once wrote of the epics that recount them, “into the middle of things, as if they were already known.” Wars plunge us violently and deeply into other people’s histories, myths and legends. Perhaps few know this better than one of my West Point colleagues, a major who recently visited my class, full of future Army officers, to discuss his deployment to the Afghan province of Nuristan, high and remote in the Hindu Kush, where ancient legacies coexist with modern war.

headline: Poor, Violent and Up for a Dogfight
abstract: Who killed a fighting dog? That’s the mystery involving a sheriff and a backwoods winemaker in “Pitbulls,” at Rattlestick Playwrights Theater.
lead_paragraph: Lusty soap operas about the crazy ways of sneaky, unwashed hillbillies have gone missing on New York stages in recent years. In olden days, when  “Tobacco Road” ruled Broadway in the 1930s, slick urbanites couldn’t get enough of such moonshine. But now, except for those occasions when Tracy Letts (“Killer Joe”) is feeling folksy and perverse, that genre has been reduced to festering on reality television.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Anne Barnard, Richard Sandomir and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »
