headline: Police Agree to Some of Protesters’ Rules of Engagement
abstract: The authorities will abide by many of the rules of engagement proposed by demonstrators once the grand jury decision is announced regarding the shooting death of Michael Brown by Officer Darren Wilson, officials said Friday.
lead_paragraph: CLAYTON, Mo. — The authorities will abide by many of the rules of engagement proposed by demonstrators once the grand jury decision is announced regarding the shooting death of Michael Brown by Officer Darren Wilson, officials said Friday.

headline: Readers Respond: On a Republican South
abstract: Readers wrote about race and politics in the South in reaction to a Charles Blow column, “The Solid South Will Rise Again.”
lead_paragraph: As Republican control and racially polarized politics have grown in the American South during the Obama presidency, so has the willingness of many Southerners to speak frankly about racial divisions in their comments to the Times.

headline: Tackling the Story of Domestic Abuse and the N.F.L.
abstract: Steve Eder details how his series on how the National Football League handles domestic abuse came together.
lead_paragraph: It took a graphic video of Ray Rice punching his fiancée in the elevator of an Atlantic City hotel to instantly change the conversation on domestic violence in the National Football League. Steve Eder, an investigative sports reporter for The Times, explains how his subsequent reporting delved into abuse in the context of the league’s close-knit culture.

headline: Schools Are Closed in Anticipation of Unrest
abstract: Eight schools in one district in the Ferguson area will be closed on Monday and Tuesday in anticipation of a grand jury decision on whether to indict a white police officer in the fatal shooting of Michael Brown in August.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. – Eight schools in one district in the Ferguson area will be closed on Monday and Tuesday in anticipation of a grand jury decision on whether to indict a white police officer in the fatal shooting of an unarmed black teenager in August.

headline: Choosing to Look at ‘War Porn’
abstract: Some of the most gruesome images of war, Christoph Bangert argues, should not be hidden, but seen so viewers can get a full documenting of the costs of war.
lead_paragraph: Some of the most gruesome images of war, Christoph Bangert argues, should not be hidden, but seen so viewers can get a full documenting of the costs of war.

headline: Immigration Enriches You and Me
abstract: Immigration has not diminished our country, but hugely enriched it.
lead_paragraph: A BOOK, “The Christian Examiner,” warns that “ill-clad and destitute” immigrants are “repulsive to our habits and our tastes.”

headline: Crisis Negotiators Give Thanksgiving Tips
abstract: Who better than a hostage negotiator to help you navigate that family land mine known as Thanksgiving?
lead_paragraph: The hurt feelings and the culture of psychological entrapment. The long-dormant resentments that seem to redouble like fingernails on a corpse.

headline: How to Find a Job With Meditation and Mindfulness
abstract: Meditation studios and conferences catering to Type A careerists are becoming a new networking hub.
lead_paragraph: Meditation has been good for Olivia Chow’s career.

headline: Tiptoeing Through Kurdistan
abstract: The hospitality is overwhelming, but so are the grievances and the conflicts.
lead_paragraph: KARS, Turkey — “WE have enemies.”

headline: Looking Again at the Sins of the Father
abstract: The Pearl Theater revival of George Bernard Shaw’s 1905 “Major Barbara,” pitting poverty against wealth, is directed by David Staller.
lead_paragraph: Inescapably playful and undeniably serious, George Bernard Shaw’s 1905 “Major Barbara” pits youth against age, poverty against wealth, faith against armored tanks. You might be surprised which side you ultimately take.

headline: Isaac Mizrahi, Bridge-Playing Designer
abstract: Celebrities enjoy bridge, but finding out who they are can be difficult, because they tend to play only socially.
lead_paragraph: What bridge-playing celebrities can you name?

headline: Dining in a Pirate Ship of Sorts in Brighton Beach
abstract: Located in Brooklyn, Gambrinus Seafood Cafe offers shellfish, nautical décor and Russian speakers in generous portions.
lead_paragraph: Located in the aptly named Little Odessa neighborhood of Brighton Beach, Gambrinus Seafood Cafe trades in kitsch and shellfish in generous post-Soviet portions. To walk through the wooden doors of this restaurant on the last stretch of Ocean Parkway before it ends at Surf Avenue is to stumble upon a Neverland cove in the middle of a nonstop theme party. Every flat surface is encrusted with nautical décor, busty pirate mannequins hang from the ceiling and oversize flat screens play music videos on an endless loop.

headline: ‘Vape’ Joins Pot Lingo as Oxford’s Word of the Year
abstract: The 2014 Word of the Year is now part of the lexicon of legal marijuana.
lead_paragraph: “Back in my day, it was just weed; it was just getting high,” said Joel Schneider, 55, sipping a cup of coffee. “Vaping? No. We’d never heard of vaping.”

headline: In Europe, a Resolution to Break Up Google
abstract: The nonbinding resolution could increase pressure on Europe’s the competition commissioner to bring formal charges against Google.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Legislators at the European Parliament who have long sought tough antitrust action against Google called on Friday for a resolution suggesting that Google be broken up into separate companies.

headline: Cousin of Cornelius Gurlitt Challenges Will That Leaves Collection to Swiss Museum
abstract: A cousin of the late Cornelius Gurlitt, whose art trove is being studied to determine if works had been looted by the Nazis, is challenging his will, which named a Swiss museum as his lone heir.
lead_paragraph: A cousin has challenged the will of Cornelius Gurlitt hours before the Swiss museum he named in May as his sole heir was poised to accept his bequest of hundreds of artworks collected by his father, a leading art dealer for Hitler.

headline: Whitney Museum Says Goodbye to Its Old Home
abstract: Chuck Close and Donna Karan were among the guests at the gala to honor 98 artists and bid farewell to a historic building.
lead_paragraph: The youngish man in wire-rimmed Wayfarers glanced across the dinner table at Hermine Heller, who was fixing him with a puzzled stare. “You’re Lyle,” Ms. Heller suddenly announced to the artist Lyle Ashton Harris, the object of her fascination and the subject of a Chuck Close portrait displayed in her home. “You’ve been hanging on my wall for the last 12 years.”

headline: Netflix Snags New Series Created by Tina Fey and Robert Carlock
abstract: “Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt,” starring Ellie Kemper, will be unveiled on the streaming service in March.
lead_paragraph: Tina Fey, a signature star of NBC, and her “30 Rock” collaborator Robert Carlock will not be bringing their new series to that network, and will instead be moving it to Netflix, it was announced Friday.

headline: Retreats of the Gilded and Bronzed
abstract: Three new books shed sun-drenched light on the world’s most luxurious cold-weather retreats, from Monte Carlo to the Caribbean to Palm Beach.
lead_paragraph: When she was writing “The House of Mirth,” more than 100 years ago, Edith Wharton sent her character Lawrence Selden to a fashionable town on the Riviera to flee Lily Bart and the New York winter. There, admiring the “exotic coquetry of architecture, the studied tropicality of the gardens” and groups of beautiful people “loitering” against the backdrop of purple mountains, he sought refuge from Lily and from Manhattan’s “interminable perspective of snow-burdened days.” You may have heard of the place the novelist sent him: It’s called Monte Carlo.

abstract: The president of the Chesapeake Bay Foundation writes about the important role that oysters play.

headline: Bratton Calls Police Shooting Accidental
abstract: William J. Bratton, the New York police commissioner, said that the fatal shooting of an unarmed man by a police officer in Brooklyn Thursday was accidental and that the victim was a “total innocent.”
lead_paragraph: William J. Bratton, the New York police commissioner, said that the fatal shooting of an unarmed man by a police officer in Brooklyn Thursday was accidental and that the victim was a “total innocent.”

headline: Settlement in Apple Case Over E-Books Is Approved
abstract: A deal in the antitrust case would give consumers $400 million in cash and e-book credits, and lawyers $50 million. But an appeal is still pending.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Friday approved a settlement in which Apple could begin paying $400 million to as many as 23 million consumers related to charges that it violated antitrust law by conspiring with publishers to raise e-book prices and thwart efforts by Amazon.

headline: Columbia Will Take Look at Football Team’s Futility
abstract: With the team on a 20-game losing streak, the university president, Lee C. Bollinger, ordered a comprehensive review of the football program, but supported Coach Peter Mangurian.
lead_paragraph: For all its intellectual might, Columbia seemingly cannot find a way to win a football game.

headline: Inquiry Focuses on Leaked Documents at Starr King School for the Ministry
abstract: Two students at the Unitarian Universalist seminary in Berkeley, Calif., have been given conditional graduation after they were ensnared in a flubbed presidential search.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Last May, the night before she was to graduate from Starr King School for the Ministry, in Berkeley, Calif., Suzi Spangenberg pulled up in her car to the school’s graduation dinner. Before going inside with her son, Ms. Spangenberg, a candidate for ordination as a Unitarian Universalist, checked her iPhone. She was shocked by the email she found.

headline: Change in Health Care Law Would Take Aim at Consumer Inertia
abstract: Instead of being re-enrolled in their previous plan if they took no action, people could be switched to the cheapest plan in the same category.
lead_paragraph: People who bought Affordable Care Act health plans for 2014 but who don’t go back to shop again for 2015 will automatically keep the plan they first chose, even if its price goes way up.

headline: Reported Environmental Incidents in North Dakota’s Oil Industry
abstract: Database of more than 8,600 oil and brine spills related to North Dakota‘s oil industry.
lead_paragraph: Database of more than 8,600 oil and brine spills related to North Dakota‘s oil industry.

headline: Mary McCartney’s Candid Camera
abstract: Paul McCartney’s daughter’s iPhone shots may be found on Instagram and in her new book, “Monochrome & Colour.”
lead_paragraph: Mary McCartney, 45, is the very definition of a “someone.” The oldest child of the musician Paul McCartney and Linda McCartney, Mary grew up amid wealth, privilege and celebrity. Now a professional photographer based in London, Ms. McCartney has an all-access pass to a vast assortment of glossy events and glittering parties, as well as a long list of elite corporate clients, including Mandarin Oriental Hotel Group and her kid sister Stella’s fashion label.

headline: Rob Moose: Breathing New Life Into Classical Music
abstract: Meet Mr. Moose, a co-founder and the violinist of yMusic, an experimental chamber music sextet, as well as a member of the Grammy-winning folk rockers Bon Iver.
lead_paragraph: AGE 32

headline: Stephen Merchant: When ‘Hello Ladies’ Says Goodbye
abstract: After the conclusion of “Hello Ladies,” Stephen Merchant’s latest sitcom, the actor is trying to figure out his place in the comedic firmament.
lead_paragraph: Last Monday at the American Airlines Theater near Times Square, Stephen Merchant, who is 6 feet 7 inches tall, was on stage attempting to lift Peter Dinklage, who is about 4-foot-5, onto his back.

headline: E.P.A. Postpones Setting Standards for Biofuel Blends
abstract: The agency’s move comes in response to a glut in the domestic oil market and significant public comment about the proposed targets.
lead_paragraph: The Environmental Protection Agency quietly announced on Friday that, after much delay, it had been unable to decide this year on a rule setting levels for the amount of biofuel it would require to be blended into conventional vehicle fuels.

headline: Woman Is Arrested With Firearm and Ammunition Outside White House
abstract: For the second consecutive day, the Secret Service on Thursday arrested someone outside the White House for possessing a firearm and ammunition.
lead_paragraph: For the second consecutive day, the Secret Service on Thursday arrested someone outside the White House for possessing a firearm and ammunition. Shortly after President Obama completed his address to the nation on immigration, plain-clothed Secret Service officers on Pennsylvania Avenue noticed a woman with a handgun holstered on her belt, law enforcement officials said. Uniformed officers confronted the woman and arrested her, the officials said.  The woman, April Lenhart, 23, of Michigan, was charged with possession of an unregistered firearm and unregistered ammunition. One official said that Ms. Lenhart refused to be interviewed by the Secret Service after the incident.

headline: Friday Night Music: Jessica Hernandez and the Deltas
abstract: A pick-me-up on a cold night.
lead_paragraph: I have no idea who recommended this, and I normally wouldn’t have thought it was my style, but there’s no arguing with sheer unadulterated joyousness:

headline: Evening Hours | Warm Celebrations
abstract: Despite the sudden cold, the parties continued.
lead_paragraph: Despite the sudden cold, the parties continued.

headline: In Zimbabwe’s Succession Battle, Mugabe Pulls the Strings
abstract: President Robert Mugabe is presiding over — and possibly choreographing — an increasingly fierce internal scramble for the rewards of high office.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In August, he stood shoulder to shoulder in Beijing with President Xi Jinping of China. Then, in September, he addressed the United Nations to condemn “the evil machinations of Western countries” seeking his overthrow. And just this month, he eulogized a neighbor and political ally at the state funeral of President Michael Chilufya Sata of Zambia.

headline: Recovered Data May Show if I.R.S. Targeted Conservatives
abstract: The Treasury Department has recovered missing data from Internal Revenue Service systems that may include emails and other documents relevant to inquiries into whether the agency had singled out conservative groups.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury Department has recovered missing data from Internal Revenue Service systems that may include emails and other documents relevant to inquiries into whether the agency had singled out conservative groups for special scrutiny, congressional investigators said Friday. The documents belonged to Lois Lerner, a former I.R.S. official whom Republicans have accused of politically motivated misconduct. The I.R.S. has said that Ms. Lerner’s computer hard drive crashed in mid-2011, destroying thousands of her emails and other data sought by investigators. Republicans in Congress, incensed by what they describe as the agency’s effort to thwart investigators, have questioned its claims that the documents are unrecoverable. On Friday, the inspector general of the Treasury Department informed the Senate Finance Committee that a forensic examination had turned up documents thought to have been destroyed. The inspector general “plans to assess whether this data can be converted into a readable format and then produce these materials to the committee as soon as they have fully recovered and evaluated them,” the committee said in a written statement.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Thanksgiving Season
abstract: It’s Thanksgiving week, and the city is full of holiday imagery.
lead_paragraph: It’s Thanksgiving week, and the city is full of holiday imagery.

headline: V.F.W. Goes Gender-Neutral, Recognizing Female Veterans
abstract: The Veterans of Foreign Wars of the United States has won congressional approval to alter the wording of its charter to recognize female veterans.
lead_paragraph: When the Veterans of Foreign Wars of the United States secured its congressional charter in 1936, “veterans” were usually men and the spouses of those who fell in battle were “widows.” That, of course, is now very different. (Indeed, even during World War II several hundred thousand women served in the United States military, including nurses and members of the Women’s Army Corps.) Now, more than 15 percent of active-duty United States service members are female. So the V.F.W. is changing, too, winning congressional approval to alter the wording of its charter. No longer is it “a national association of men” who served in wartime; it is one of “veterans.” And it is no longer to assist “widows” — rather, “surviving spouses.” The changes, approved at the national convention, were made in bills just passed by the House and Senate. “We didn’t change our congressional charter to be politically correct,” the V.F.W. National Commander, John W. Stroud, said in a statement. “We changed it because being an eligible service member or veteran is what’s important to our great organization, not one’s gender.”

headline: Grand Tour of the Self
abstract: The latest and most obnoxious tool in the kit of digital narcissism.
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain — From the castle grounds atop Montjuic, you can see the warrens of the old city running into the Dr. Seussian spires of the new one that sprouted from Antoni Gaudí’s imagination. Below or up high, Barcelona is a tapas menu of urban surprise.

headline: Madagascar: Plague Outbreak Kills 40
abstract: The World Health Organization reported that an outbreak of plague, the infamous scourge that killed millions in the Dark Ages, has been recorded in parts of Madagascar.
lead_paragraph: The World Health Organization reported Friday that an outbreak of plague, the infamous scourge that killed millions in the Dark Ages, has been recorded in parts of Madagascar, the Indian Ocean island nation off the coast of southeastern Africa. In an alert posted on its website, the W.H.O. said at least 119 plague cases, including 40 deaths, had been confirmed since the nation’s Health Ministry identified the first case nearly three months ago. The statement said cases had been reported in seven regions, including the capital, Antananarivo, raising the “risk of a rapid spread of the disease due to the city’s high population density and the weakness of the health care system.” Efforts to combat the outbreak, the statement said, have been hampered because fleas, the primary spreader of the disease, have developed resistance to an insecticide used to kill them.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Thanksgiving Season
abstract: It’s Thanksgiving week, and the city is full of holiday imagery.
lead_paragraph: It’s Thanksgiving week, and the city is full of holiday imagery. In the Greenmarket at Union Square the colors and freshness of the produce stand out. Some vendors carved out pumpkins and gourds and filled them with water and flowers, a great idea for the table on Thursday. Shoppers carried armloads of autumnal berries, grasses and flowers. A vendor carved a face on the side of a vegetable. Many women seemed dressed to match the white pumpkins. Just as the last of the golden ginkgo leaves formed a backdrop for fashion and the lions, adding to the spirit was the arrival of the Rockefeller Center tree.

headline: Mr. Obama’s Wise Immigration Plan
abstract: The initiative is a good start, bringing reasons for encouragement, tempered with caution.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s speech Thursday night on immigration ended on a high, hopeful note. Mr. Obama, quoting Scripture’s admonition to welcome and protect the stranger, told millions who have lived and worked here for years, many of them Americans in all but name: We cannot fix your situation yet, but for now we will not expel you, because we have better hopes for you here.

headline: Judge Rejects Overhaul of Illinois’s Beleaguered State Pension System
abstract: The law, passed in 2013, was found to violate a clause of the state’s Constitution declaring pensions to be contracts that the state cannot impair.
lead_paragraph: An Illinois judge on Friday rejected the state’s effort to bolster its shaky public pension system, giving public workers a reason to rejoice that could prove short-lived.

headline: F.S.U. Coach’s Call-In Show Is a No-Sin Zone
abstract: On his radio call-in show, Jimbo Fisher, the Florida State football coach, hears plenty of praise, but no questions about the team’s off-field scandals.
lead_paragraph: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. — “What is it about this team, this year, that throughout your career you’ll always remember?”

headline: Will Pot Pack New York’s Courts?
abstract: The new marijuana rules will overload the summons system.
lead_paragraph: THIS week the New York City Police Department shifted from making arrests to issuing tickets for possessing small amounts of marijuana. The problem is that most people, frankly, do not understand how summons court, which processes such tickets, operates.

headline: Obama Asks Ferguson Protesters for Peace
abstract: In an interview with ABC News, President Obama said that protesters in Ferguson, Mo., should “keep protests peaceful” and that there would be no excuse for violence.
lead_paragraph: In an interview with ABC News, President Obama said that protesters in Ferguson, Mo., should “keep protests peaceful” and that there would be no excuse for violence.

headline: Saturday’s College Football Games to Watch
abstract: No. 24 U.S.C. takes on No. 11 U.C.L.A. in one of college football’s best rivalries, and Yale plays Harvard in “The Game.”
lead_paragraph: 24 U.S.C. at 11 U.C.L.A.

headline: In a Shift, Obama Extends U.S. Role in Afghan Combat
abstract: President Obama’s order would allow American forces to carry out missions against the Taliban and other militant groups threatening American troops or the Afghan government, sources said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama decided in recent weeks to authorize a more expansive mission for the military in Afghanistan in 2015 than originally planned, a move that ensures American troops will have a direct role in fighting in the war-ravaged country for at least another year.

lead_paragraph: Part 15: The musician reflects on the difference between his approach to world music and that of the indie frontman Damon Albarn.

headline: Plant: Recording ‘No Quarter’
abstract: Part 12: The musician talks about working with Gnawa musicians in Morocco for his 1994 album with Jimmy Page.
lead_paragraph: Part 12: The musician talks about working with Gnawa musicians in Morocco for his 1994 album with Jimmy Page.

headline: Plant: Led Zeppelin Lyrics
abstract: Part 9: The musician talks about how an “infatuation with history” shaped him as a young songwriter.
lead_paragraph: Part 9: The musician talks about how an “infatuation with history” shaped him as a young songwriter.

headline: Plant: Leadbelly and Children’s Music
abstract: Part 14: The musician explains the lineage of the song “Poor Howard” on his new album.
lead_paragraph: Part 14: The musician explains the lineage of the song “Poor Howard” on his new album.

headline: Plant: The Sensational Space Shifters
abstract: Part 7: The musician explores the musical ideas behind his new album, “lullaby and … The Ceaseless Roar.”
lead_paragraph: Part 7: The musician explores the musical ideas behind his new album, “lullaby and … The Ceaseless Roar.”

headline: Plant: Not for Senior Citizens
abstract: Part 13: The musician explains how he feels about doing arena shows.
lead_paragraph: Part 13: The musician explains how he feels about doing arena shows.

headline: Uber’s Rough Ride
abstract: The car-service app has engineering talent and business savvy. All it lacks is some grown-ups to manage it.
lead_paragraph: The Uber app is a thing of beauty.

headline: Plant: The Best Concerts I’ve Ever Seen
abstract: Part 16: The musician discusses the Gambian griot Juldeh Camara and recalls his favorite concerts he’s attended.
lead_paragraph: Part 16: The musician discusses the Gambian griot Juldeh Camara and recalls his favorite concerts he’s attended.

headline: Plant: ‘When the Levee Breaks’
abstract: Part 17: The musician talks about why Led Zeppelin wouldn’t play certain songs live.
lead_paragraph: Part 17: The musician talks about why Led Zeppelin wouldn’t play certain songs live.

headline: Plant: Singing With Ali Farka Touré
abstract: Part 11: The musician recalls his 2003 trip to Mali and explains what he learned from playing with musicians there.
lead_paragraph: Part 11: The musician recalls his 2003 trip to Mali and explains what he learned from playing with musicians there.

headline: Plant: Remembering Ahmet Ertegun
abstract: Part 10: The musician reflects on his solo career and reminisces about his relationship with the music mogul Ahmet Ertegun.
lead_paragraph: Part 10: The musician reflects on his solo career and reminisces about his relationship with the music mogul Ahmet Ertegun.

headline: Roger Federer Is Dealt an Unlikely Defeat at Davis Cup
abstract: The Frenchman Gaël Monfils defeated Federer in straight sets in the Davis Cup final, but Federer’s teammate Stan Wawrinka helped the Swiss to a 1-1 tie with a victory over Jo-Wilfried Tsonga.
lead_paragraph: VILLENEUVE D’ASCQ, France — The largest crowd to watch an officially sanctioned tennis match got nothing but a tie on Friday, which is good for all those who like their Davis Cup with a hearty helping of suspense.

headline: TimesTalks | Robert Plant: Preview
abstract: The rock icon talks about his long career, his evolution as a songwriter, his passion for North African music and his hunger for collaboration.
lead_paragraph: The rock icon talks about his long career, his evolution as a songwriter, his passion for North African music and his hunger for collaboration.

headline: This Time, the Protesters in Ferguson May Decide to Pass
abstract: Some former protesters said they were unsure if they would again join the demonstrations that are expected after a grand jury decides whether to indict Darren Wilson, a white police officer, for killing Michael Brown, 18.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — When protests broke out here after the police shooting of an unarmed black teenager in August, James Bass knew he had to hit the streets. His father lived in Ferguson, he lived close by, and like many young black men in the St. Louis area, Mr. Bass wanted his voice to be heard.

headline: Four Decades of Solitary in Louisiana
abstract: Albert Woodfox — the last incarcerated ‘Angola 3’ prisoner, who may finally be freed — has endured punishment that is barbaric beyond measure.
lead_paragraph: Richard Nixon was president when Albert Woodfox landed in solitary confinement, along with another inmate, both convicted of the 1972 murder of a Louisiana prison guard named Brent Miller.

headline: Internal Delphi Email on Defective Ignition Switch
abstract: This email is the first publicly disclosed document showing Delphi’s long-time concerns with the switch and demonstrates how G.M. pushed Delphi to manufacture a defective part.
lead_paragraph: This email is the first publicly disclosed document showing Delphi’s long-time concerns with the switch and demonstrates how G.M. pushed Delphi to manufacture a defective part.

headline: A Longtime Islander Is Taking Winning in Stride
abstract: If there is a skater who personifies the low-key, hard-working ethos of the team, it would be Frans Nielsen, who has been an Islander longer than anyone else on the roster.
lead_paragraph: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — The Islanders are a humble group after a rocky 2013-14 season, when expectations were high only to be dashed by injuries and too many early losses.

headline: Dr. Donald F. Steiner, Diabetes Researcher, Dies at 84
abstract: Dr. Steiner, whose discoveries were used by insulin manufacturers to improve their products, wrote hundreds of articles as a professor at the University of Chicago.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Donald F. Steiner, a researcher whose discoveries transformed scientists’ understanding of insulin and other hormones and led to major improvements in the treatment of diabetes, died on Nov. 11 at his home in Chicago. He was 84.

headline: A Billionaire’s Hudson River Project
abstract: A privately financed plan for the old Pier 54 gets the go-ahead. Why isn’t public money as available for great public spaces?
lead_paragraph: So, what do you think of the latest idea for Hudson River Park: a performance space, with forested glades and an amphitheater, on an undulating platform over Pier 54?

headline: Why Congress Can Impeach Obama
abstract: There’s a strong case for it. But that doesn’t make it a good idea.
lead_paragraph: NOW that President Obama has granted legal relief to as many as five million undocumented immigrants, Republicans are thrashing about for an effective response. Only a few hard-liners are talking about impeachment now, but more could join them out of frustration with their other options.

headline: A Push for Legal Aid in Civil Cases Finds Its Advocates
abstract: An experiment in California is providing legal help to low-income renters who otherwise would have faced their landlords, and the landlords’ lawyers, alone in court.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Lorenza and German Artiga raised six children in a rent-controlled bungalow here, their only home since they moved from El Salvador 29 years ago.

headline: G.M. ‘Bullied’ Manufacturer Over Poorly Designed Part, Email Says
abstract: The email between employees of Delphi, the manufacturer, discussed pressure from a G.M. engineer over an ignition switch that is linked to at least 33 deaths.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — General Motors pressured a supplier to continue producing a substandard ignition switch a decade ago and leaned on the company to improve it even though it could not be fixed, a newly disclosed email shows.

headline: Richard Eder, Arts Critic and Foreign Correspondent, Dies at 82
abstract: A journalist with a literary bent, Mr. Eder wrote with an easy grace and a practiced eye for detail.
lead_paragraph: Richard Eder, a former foreign correspondent for The New York Times who became a film and drama critic there and eventually won a Pulitzer Prize for his book reviews in The Los Angeles Times, died on Friday in Boston. He was 82.

headline: ISIS Releases New Propaganda Video
abstract: In the latest video released by the Islamic State, the British hostage John Cantlie described a failed rescue attempt and encouraged the United States and Britain to negotiate with his captors.
lead_paragraph: In the latest video released by the Islamic State, the British hostage John Cantlie described a failed rescue attempt and encouraged the United States and Britain to negotiate with his captors.

headline: Public Housing Patrols Can Mean Safety or Danger
abstract: The fatal shooting of a Brooklyn man by a police officer underscores the dangers of patrols in stairwells throughout New York’s 334 public housing complexes.
lead_paragraph: For a police officer, the stairwells of New York City’s public housing complexes can be menacing places of drug deals, domestic disputes, thievery and gang violence, where nerves can cause missteps that, in an instant, can end in tragedy.

headline: Where El Nuevo Herald Is Read
abstract: Saturday fun with David Steinberg.
lead_paragraph: Administrivial Win Valuable Prizes Alert! There’s a new tournament in town, and it’s called the Indie 500. Hosted by New York Times constructors Evan Birnholz, Andy Kravis, Neville Fogarty, Peter Broda and Erik Agard, it will take place on May 20, 2015 in Washington, D.C. and has nothing to do with race cars but will most definitely rev your solving engines. Also, they are generously opening submissions to a fifth constructor. That could be you! Look at you, with a puzzle in a tournament. You really rock, you know that? Show these guys what you can do by clicking here.

headline: Struggling to Overcome Depression and Return to the Working World
abstract: Kevin Williams, who has not held a job since 2006, has begun looking for work with the help of Brooklyn Community Services.
lead_paragraph: Idleness has a way of creeping up on Kevin Williams.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 21, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Britain: 12 Are Injured in Blast at Hotel
abstract: More than a dozen were hurt in what the police said they suspected was a natural-gas explosion in the basement of a central London hotel just before midnight Friday.
lead_paragraph: At least 12 people were hurt in what the police said they suspected was a natural-gas explosion in the basement of a central London hotel just before midnight Friday. The Hyatt Regency London — The Churchill, a luxury hotel in Portman Square, was evacuated temporarily after the blast, which was believed to be in a kitchen area, and injured people were treated at the scene, the Metropolitan Police said. Six people were taken to hospitals. Most of the injured were believed to be kitchen staff. None of the injuries were thought to be life-threatening. Dennis Luwer, who lives opposite the hotel, told the BBC that a hole had been blown in the side of the building.

headline: Son’s Killing Prompts Woman to Seek Child Welfare Inquiry
abstract: A mother whose 3-year-old was beaten to death in his grandmother’s home is demanding an investigation of New York City’s child welfare agency.
lead_paragraph: Poseidon Quinones had parents, but neither of them was deemed fit to care for him by New York City’s child welfare agency.

headline: At Sotheby’s Interiors Auction, an Intimate Portrait of an Heiress
abstract: At Friday’s auction of pieces once owned by the late heiress Bunny Mellon, there were chairs galore, cat portraits and a number of porcelain vegetable soup tureens.
lead_paragraph: If there was one word to describe the collection of shabby chairs, chipped console tables, battered settees and assorted porcelain replicas of vegetables once owned by the late heiress, and apparent magpie, Rachel Lambert Mellon, known as Bunny, and auctioned off at Sotheby’s on Friday afternoon, it was “patina.”

headline: Texas, No Longer in Panic Mode, Defeats California to Win 2K Classic
abstract: Texas, which got 21 points and 13 rebounds from Jonathon Holmes, recorded 10 blocks in beating California in the championship game at Madison Square Garden.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, almost to the day, Texas lost to Division II Chaminade in the Round of 8 at the Maui Invitational. Panic spread through the Texas fan base, with the vitriol directed namely at Coach Rick Barnes, who once recruited Kevin Durant, LaMarcus Aldridge and D. J. Augustin, and now seemed to be at a crossroads with the program.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (HBO) HELLO LADIES: THE MOVIE (2014) Stephen Merchant reprises his role as Stuart Pritchard, the gawky British transplant desperate to enter the realm of the beautiful people in Los Angeles — who are loath to let him in. In this 80-minute film, which wraps up the canceled series, Stuart learns that his former girlfriend is in town with her husband and sets out to impress them by hiring a Russian model to play his latest love.

headline: For Some Fans, Accusations of Rape Crumble Bill Cosby’s Wholesome Image
abstract: The change in Mr. Cosby’s image from best-known father to accused serial abuser has caused discomfort akin to confronting the dark past of a family member.
lead_paragraph: As woman after woman has come forward to accuse Bill Cosby of sexual assault, there has been growing public revulsion, but also a nagging question: Did it have to be Cliff Huxtable?

headline: Hong Kong Moves to Refashion Itself as a Global Hub of Creativity
abstract: Private investors are working with the government to nurture local creative talent in a city better known for cargo ports and finance.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — When Candace Campos moved from the United States to Hong Kong six years ago, she encountered few hurdles to opening her own interior design company.

headline: The Strip
abstract: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.
lead_paragraph: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: A Community in Connecticut Remembers World War I
abstract: “Over There: Washington and the Great War,” commemorates the 100th anniversary of the start of World War I, largely through the eyes of the men and women of Washington, Conn., population 3,200, both those who served and those who stayed behind.
lead_paragraph: A visitor might be excused for getting a little shellshocked while roaming through the Gunn Memorial Library and Museum in the town of Washington in Litchfield County.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, November 22, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “Hurting others or destroying property is not the answer. No matter what the grand jury decides, I do not want my son’s death to be in vain. I want it to lead to incredible change — positive change, change that makes the St. Louis region better for everyone.”

headline: Corrections: November 22, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, November 22, 2014.
lead_paragraph: SPORTS

headline: In St. Louis, a Mock Lynching
abstract: A handful of people performed a mock lynching across the street from St. Louis’ Old Courthouse as a silent protest of the police killings of Michael Brown and Vonderitt D. Myers, Jr.
lead_paragraph: A handful of people performed a mock lynching across the street from St. Louis’ Old Courthouse as a silent protest of the police killings of Michael Brown and Vonderitt D. Myers, Jr.

headline: Weekly Wrap
abstract: This week on Times Insider.
lead_paragraph: Hello Times Insiders,

headline: The Daily Gift: A Spinning Studio, Brought Home
abstract: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.
lead_paragraph: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.

headline: Digging Into the Cheddar
abstract: A cheese grader at Cabot Creamery in Vermont was trained in cheese-making and dairy-control techniques at three universities.
lead_paragraph: Craig Gile, 34, is a cheese grader for the Cabot Creamery Cooperative in Cabot, Vt.

headline: The Introvert on the Podium
abstract: With practice and an acquired trick or two, a writer learns to thrive as a public speaker.
lead_paragraph: Editors’ note: Here’s one of our favorite stories from the archives, now being featured in our Smarter Living collection.

headline: The Week That Shook the Fed
abstract: For a secretive institution, assorted challenges to how it uses its power. Or doesn’t.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve Board prefers to operate in a shroud of secrecy, and its officials really don’t like having to answer to anybody.

headline: Does Wall Street Like Gridlock? It Depends on the Grid
abstract: Historically, shared political power in Washington seems to have little connection to stock market returns — until you slice and dice how the power has been divided.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street likes gridlock. That claim has been made for decades.

headline: Brewing Your Own Beer, With Help From an App
abstract: A company called Brewbot is aiming to market a 4-foot-tall machine that allows amateurs and professionals to brew craft beer, and to even devise their own recipes.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, craft beers were scarce in the pubs of Northern Ireland. The taps were dominated instead by megabrands like Guinness, Harp and Heineken.

headline: Conspicuous Consumption? Yes, but It’s Not Crazy
abstract: Clearly, many rich people like to display their incredible wealth. Yet, generally, they think they know value when they see it.
lead_paragraph: There’s no denying the over-the-top flavor of much high-end consumption these days. A Reinast toothbrush, of solid titanium, sells for $4,200 even though it may not get your teeth any cleaner than a $2 toothbrush from Walgreens. Then there’s the Greubel Forsey Double Tourbillon 30° Technique, a platinum wristwatch that sells for scores of thousands of dollars. Its intricate mechanical works may be a masterpiece of traditional engineering, but for that, you might keep your day-to-day appointments just as well with a $40 Timex.

headline: A ’70s Experiment, Relived in SoHo
abstract: Once upon a time, there was a lot of affordable loft space in SoHo.
lead_paragraph: Once upon a time, there was a lot of affordable loft space in SoHo. The dance and video artist Cathy Weis still occupies one such space — WeisAcres, she calls it — and this year, she has been opening the sprawling studio on Sunday nights for performances, film screenings and conversations. The free series, Sundays on Broadway, has been a low-key delight, and it continues this week with a program organized by the choreographer Catherine Galasso.

headline: Hey, I’m Going 55. Cough Up the Cash.
abstract: “Crowd Control,” a 12-part series on the National Geographic Channel, explores unconventional ways to get people to do what they are usually reluctant to do.
lead_paragraph: Don’t think about this too hard, or you’ll be dismayed, but paying people to drive at the speed limit seems to be a better behavior modifier than pointing out to them that they might run over a small child or frail grandmother (or get a ticket).

headline: Gyrating Antidote to Holiday Pounds
abstract: Time Warp, a festival that started in Germany in 1994 and favors the crisp, abstract, un-pop propulsion of minimal techno, is making its first United States appearance.
lead_paragraph: Dancing off Thanksgiving can be done pre-emptively or post-facto. Time Warp, a festival that started in Germany in 1994 and favors the crisp, abstract, un-pop propulsion of minimal techno, is making its first United States appearance. It includes 19 D.J.s over two nights, among them techno and house stalwarts like Dubfire, performing as a “live hybrid” Friday, and Sven Vath, Richie Hawtin and Josh Wink on Saturday. (9 p.m., 39th Street Pier, Sunset Park; time-warp.de/usa.)

headline: From Tragic ‘Tess’ To Prancing Bear
abstract: A nine-film retrospective, Nastassja Kinski: From the Heart presented by the Film Society at Lincoln Center, runs from Thursday through Dec. 3.
lead_paragraph: Nastassja Kinski was barely 20 when she starred in Paul Schrader’s erotic horror film, “Cat People,” as one of the last descendants of a prehistoric race whose women mated with leopards. In the heat of sex with humans, the women morphed into savage black felines who killed their lovers. The 1982 movie has a memorable score by Giorgio Moroder.

headline: When Authorship Is Beside the Point
abstract: “By Proxy,” a group show, that runs through Jan. 17 at the James Cohan Gallery in Chelsea.
lead_paragraph: Since Marcel Duchamp’s Big Bang of 1913, when he declared mundane store-bought objects — a snow shovel, a dog-grooming comb — to be art if artists said so, cosmic echoes of the ready-made idea have bounded around the aesthetic universe in powerful and unpredictable ways.

headline: A Beethoven Teaser and a Rare ‘Cyrano’
abstract: The Dutch conductor and violinist Jaap van Zweden was not well known in America when he took over as music director of the Dallas Symphony Orchestra in 2008.
lead_paragraph: The Dutch conductor and violinist Jaap van Zweden was not well known in America when he took over as music director of the Dallas Symphony Orchestra in 2008. Appointing this dynamic musician proved wise. The orchestra and audiences in Dallas embraced him. Having made an enthusiastically received debut with the New York Philharmonic in 2010, he returns this week.

headline: At Spain’s Door, a Welcome Mat for Entrepreneurs
abstract: A nation is beckoning foreign brains and money with the kind of immigration reform that Silicon Valley can only envy.
lead_paragraph: Last year, after more than a decade in Silicon Valley, Stacia Carr helped sell the company she was running and went looking for a change of pace.

headline: The Fight for $15.37 an Hour
abstract: Forces both inside and outside the traditional labor movement united to campaign for a higher minimum wage for hotel workers in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: Most Sunday mornings last summer, Julia Gould set up a table at the Hollywood Farmers Market. Alongside stalls selling shiitake mushrooms, free-range poultry and orange-blossom honey, she was selling an idea: a $15.37-an-hour minimum wage for the city’s hotel workers — more than twice the federal minimum wage and one of the highest minimum wages in the nation.

headline: Cruising to Christmas Markets
abstract: Most major river cruise companies offer itineraries along the Danube, Main and Rhine rivers when holiday pop-ups are in full swing.
lead_paragraph: What started as a way to increase off-season occupancy has turned into a high-occupancy rush as river cruise lines capitalize on the Christmas markets of Europe.

headline: An Upper East Side Mansion for $50.25 Million
abstract: An Italianate palazzo-style mansion on the Upper East Side is the sale of the week.
lead_paragraph: A formidable Italian Renaissance-style limestone mansion, built in 1909 as a 17,000-square-foot private home and later occupied by the now-defunct art gallery Knoedler & Company for nearly four decades, sold for $50.25 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Variety: Sit for a Spell
abstract: Will Shortz challenges us to find as many six-letter words as possible.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — If this Variety Puzzle looks somewhat familiar to you, it’s because you are probably jonesing for Will Shortz’s 3-D Word Hunt, which has appeared in the winter for the last few years. I’m told that there is no set schedule for that particular puzzle, but Sit for a Spell turns out to be a nice substitute.

headline: A Deep 2016 Republican Presidential Field Reflects Party Divisions
abstract: With more than a dozen potential candidates and a fast start to the 2016 campaign, the party appears headed to an unusual free-for-all.
lead_paragraph: BOCA RATON, Fla. — Republican presidential primaries have for decades been orderly affairs, with any momentary drama mitigated by the expectation that the party would inevitably nominate its tested, often graying front-runner.

headline: The Wisdom of Peter Schiff
abstract: No, seriously, almost.
lead_paragraph: No, seriously. Well, sort of. Danny Vinik sends us to the latest from Schiff, who made a big splash in 2008-2009 predicting runaway inflation if not hyperinflation; he was a favorite of Glenn Beck’s.

headline: Disappearing Glaciers Could Change Western Ecosystem
abstract: In 30 years, there may be no glaciers left in Glacier National Park in Montana.
lead_paragraph: In 30 years, there may be no glaciers left in Glacier National Park in Montana.

headline: Climate Change Threatens to Strip the Identity of Glacier National Park
abstract: In a century, the number of glaciers in Montana’s Glacier National Park, on the Canadian border, has dropped to about 25 from 150.
lead_paragraph: GLACIER NATIONAL PARK, Mont. — What will they call this place once the glaciers are gone?

headline: Thousands of Iraq Chemical Weapons Destroyed in Open Air, Watchdog Says
abstract: A report by a watchdog group reveals the United States recovered thousands of chemical weapons in Iraq from 2004 to 2009 and destroyed almost all of them in secret and via open-air detonation.
lead_paragraph: The United States recovered thousands of old chemical weapons in Iraq from 2004 to 2009 and destroyed almost all of them in secret and via open-air detonation, according to a written summary of its activities prepared by the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons, the international body that monitors implementation of the global chemical weapons treaty.

headline: Unlawful Assembly Arrests in Ferguson
abstract: More demonstrators were arrested in Ferguson, Mo.
lead_paragraph: Three people were charged with unlawful assembly overnight in protests in Ferguson, Mo., law enforcement authorities said early Saturday, as the St. Louis region awaits a grand jury’s decision on whether to indict a white police officer who shot an unarmed black teenager.

headline: Mistrust Threatens Delicate Balance at a Sacred Site in Jerusalem
abstract: A site in the Old City of Jerusalem, known to Jews as the Temple Mount and to Muslims as the Noble Sanctuary, has been a flash point since the advent of modern Zionism.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Amid roiling unrest over a contested Old City holy site, the Palestine Liberation Organization this month declared that the name used for the site by Jews, the Temple Mount, was “null and void.” Instead, the group said, the compound — “a symbol for all Palestinians” — must be called Al Aqsa Mosque or the Noble Sanctuary.

headline: Missouri Governor, Trying to Keep Balance on Ferguson, Finds It’s Easy to Slip
abstract: Caught between polar opposite viewpoints, Gov. Jay Nixon has faced withering criticism over his handling of the crisis that followed the shooting of an unarmed black man.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — From the very first days of the protests over the police shooting of an unarmed black man here, Gov. Jay Nixon of Missouri has been accused of hitting the wrong notes at the wrong times.

headline: Daniel Snyder Bellows in Comic Opera of the Redskins
abstract: Heading into Sunday’s game against the 49ers, the Redskins are 3-7 and in the midst of another losing season. Since Snyder bought the team in 1999, the Redskins have gone 109-147.
lead_paragraph: Once upon a time, the Redskins were a bedrock franchise of the N.F.L., a perennial playoff team and a winner of three Super Bowls. The paranoiac coach George Allen took calls from the paranoiac president Richard Nixon, who even drew up a few plays for the team. Quarterbacks Sonny Jurgensen, Joe Theismann, Billy Kilmer and Doug Williams piled up wins. Many years, all that Republicans and Democrats could agree upon was their passion for this team.

headline: The Impact of Obama’s Immigration Plan Across California
abstract: The patchwork of regulations in President Obama’s executive action will resonate in different ways for foreign workers in Silicon Valley, farmworkers in the Central Valley and entrepreneurs in Los Angeles. The changes may prevent deportation of more than half of the roughly 2.5 million who are in the state illegally.
lead_paragraph: The patchwork of regulations in President Obama’s executive action will resonate in different ways for foreign workers in Silicon Valley, farmworkers in the Central Valley and entrepreneurs in Los Angeles. The changes may prevent deportation of more than half of the roughly 2.5 million who are in the state illegally.

headline: A Mississippi Stadium, a Civil Rights Crucible
abstract: On Oct. 21, 1967, teams from two historically black colleges, Jackson State and Grambling, desegregated Veterans Memorial Stadium in Jackson, Miss.
lead_paragraph: The night before federal marshals escorted James Meredith onto the campus of the University of Mississippi, where he was trying to become the first black student to enroll, the university’s highly ranked football team faced Kentucky. That game, on Sept. 29, 1962, was played in the state of Mississippi’s largest and most prestigious showcase, Veterans Memorial Stadium in Jackson, the capital.

headline: The Bay Area and Silicon Valley
abstract: While there are a significant number of unauthorized workers in this area, much of the focus has been on legal, temporary workers. San Francisco and San Jose are among the top areas that request H-1B visas for highly skilled workers, and the president’s plan disappointed the tech community by not increasing the cap on the number of H-1Bs issued. The plan does help fill science and technology jobs by expanding a program that allows foreign students to remain in the country temporarily for training.
lead_paragraph: While there are a significant number of unauthorized workers in this area, much of the focus has been on legal, temporary workers. San Francisco and San Jose are among the top areas that request H-1B visas for highly skilled workers, and the president’s plan disappointed the tech community by not increasing the cap on the number of H-1Bs issued. The plan does help fill science and technology jobs by expanding a program that allows foreign students to remain in the country temporarily for training.

headline: Studying for the Test by Taking It
abstract: The process of testing can deepen learning.
lead_paragraph: PROTESTS are flaring up in pockets of the country against the proliferation of standardized tests. For many parents and teachers, school has become little more than a series of workout sessions for the assessment du jour.

headline: The Race Conversation
abstract: Readers respond to a series of columns by Nicholas Kristof about racial inequality.
lead_paragraph: Readers respond to a series of columns by

headline: The Making of an Imperial President
abstract: How Barack Obama ended up embracing the executive overreach he once campaign against.
lead_paragraph: LET me be clear, as he likes to say: I believe that President Obama was entirely sincere when he ran for president as a fierce critic of the imperial executive. I believe that he was in earnest when he told supporters in 2008 that America’s “biggest problems” involved “George Bush trying to bring more and more power into the executive branch and not go through Congress at all.” I believe he meant it when he cast himself as a principled civil libertarian, when he pledged to defer to Congress on war powers, when he promised to abjure privileges Bush had claimed.

headline: Promiscuous College Come-Ons
abstract: The hucksterism of schools makes it harder for students to navigate the admissions process with any sanity and real success.
lead_paragraph: BETWEEN the last application season and the current one, Swarthmore College, a school nationally renowned for its academic rigor, changed the requirements for students vying to be admitted into its next freshman class.

headline: John Mackey
abstract: The co-founder of Whole Foods on synchronicity, his travel rice cooker and eating junk food on the Appalachian Trail.
lead_paragraph: John Mackey is the co-founder and co-chief executive officer of Whole Foods Market, the nation’s largest chain of natural foods supermarkets.

headline: Faster Broadband for Schools and Libraries
abstract: The F.C.C. commissioner’s proposal to modestly raise taxes to bolster the agency’s E-Rate program is reasonable and justified.
lead_paragraph: Next month, the Federal Communications Commission will consider a proposal from its chairman, Tom Wheeler, that would raise taxes on phone lines by a modest 16 cents a month to make sure that every public school and library has reliable and fast Internet connections. The commissioners should vote yes.

headline: The Piecemeal Assault on Health Care
abstract: The Republicans are not interested in improving any provisions of the Affordable Care Act. They are bent on its destruction.
lead_paragraph: Now that they will dominate both houses of Congress, Republicans are planning to dismantle the Affordable Care Act piece by piece instead of trying to repeal it entirely.

headline: Jerusalem’s Train to Nowhere
abstract: Instead of normal urban life, a trail of blood.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — ON Tuesday, two young Palestinian men from East Jerusalem attacked a synagogue at the city’s western edge. Wielding butcher knives, axes and a gun, they murdered four Jewish worshipers and wounded several others, including a policeman who later died. They were both shot at the scene.

headline: Dealing With North Korea’s Brutality
abstract: The United Nations is finally addressing the regime’s crimes and moving closer to a referral to the International Criminal Court.
lead_paragraph: A United Nations committee has sided with millions of powerless North Koreans by voting to condemn their government for human rights abuses and recommending the prosecution of the regime’s leaders for crimes against humanity at the International Criminal Court. The General Assembly is expected to do the same and then put the issue to the Security Council.

headline: Stampeding Black Elephants
abstract: What happens when some 6,000 park rangers, scientists, environmentalists and others gather to brainstorm how to guard and expand the earth’s protected areas?
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — I PARTICIPATED in the World Parks Congress in Sydney last week and learned a new phrase: “a black elephant.” A black elephant, explained the London-based investor and environmentalist Adam Sweidan, is a cross between “a black swan” (an unlikely, unexpected event with enormous ramifications) and the “elephant in the room” (a problem that is visible to everyone, yet no one still wants to address it) even though we know that one day it will have vast, black-swan-like consequences.

headline: The Conflict and the Coverage
abstract: The public editor responds to reader complaints on fairness in Middle East news reports.
lead_paragraph: THIS is the column I never wanted to write.

headline: Companions in Misery
abstract: What can Schopenhauer, philosophy’s best known pessimist, tell us about New Yorkers?
lead_paragraph: I had just arrived home from my summer vacation — a week in a Minnesota cabin whose brochure warned “no crabbiness allowed” — when I came upon a study that declared New York the “unhappiest city in America.” I doubt many people were surprised by the results — New Yorkers, both in lore and reality, can be hard to please, and famously outspoken about their grievances — but as a born-and-raised New Yorker, and as a philosopher, I was suspicious of how the study defined happiness.

headline: Writing to the Beat
abstract: Shakespeare, Hemingway and Poe had their own rhythm.
lead_paragraph: Rhythm has informed my writing from as early as I can remember. It all began with the beat.

headline: After Fans Jump Around, Wisconsin’s Band Keeps the Place Hopping
abstract: The University of Wisconsin marching band helps to turn every game at Madison’s Camp Randall Stadium into a raucous celebration.
lead_paragraph: Before there was “Jump Around,” there was “You’ve Said It All.”

headline: The ‘Rules’ of Psychotherapy
abstract: Would I talk to my patient about myself?
lead_paragraph: When Julia first appeared in my office, she was approaching her 35th birthday. She had resolved it would be her last.

headline: Central Valley
abstract: Nearly 40 percent of immigrants in the Central Valley are estimated to be here illegally, and nearly half of them are employed in agriculture. Some farmworkers may benefit from the president’s executive action because they have children born in the United States. But for the many farmworkers who have no family here, their status will remain the same.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 40 percent of immigrants in the Central Valley are estimated to be here illegally, and nearly half of them are employed in agriculture. Some farmworkers may benefit from the president’s executive action because they have children born in the United States. But for the many farmworkers who have no family here, their status will remain the same.

headline: G.O.P.-Led Benghazi Panel Bolsters Administration
abstract: The House Intelligence Committee has joined previous panels in rejecting the most damning accusations about the handling of the 2012 attacks on American outposts.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A report released late Friday about the fatal 2012 attacks in Benghazi, Libya, left Republicans in the same position they have been in for two years: with little evidence to support their most damning critiques of how the Obama administration, and then-Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton, responded to the attacks.

headline: Thrill Is Gone; So Is Donovan
abstract: Landon Donovan has made no secret that the responsibility and the trappings that came with being the standard-bearer of American soccer for more than a decade had long ago become a burden.
lead_paragraph: CARSON, Calif. — For someone who can make playing soccer look so easy, Landon Donovan has never been shy about conveying how hard the sport can be for him. He has made no secret that the responsibility and the trappings that came with being the standard-bearer of American soccer for more than a decade had long ago become a burden, and that in recent years he had begun to view his talent not so much as a gift, but as an obligation.

headline: Landon Donovan on His Sabbatical, His Time in Europe and His Retirement
abstract: The Los Angeles Galaxy midfielder discusses his sabbatical, his plans for retirement and the reasons his foray to Everton went better than his years in Germany.
lead_paragraph: Los Angeles Galaxy midfielder Landon Donovan, who will retire after Major League Soccer’s playoffs, sat down with Billy Witz in October to discuss the end of his career for a profile that appeared in Sunday’s Times. Among the other topics of discussion that day:

headline: Hour’s Drive Outside Kabul, Taliban Reign
abstract: In the absence of international troops or their air support, the Taliban have eclipsed the legitimacy of government forces in several parts of Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: CHARKALAH, Afghanistan — The explosion ripped through the floor of the Humvee, tearing a hole in the armored vehicle and injuring the district governor. The crack of Taliban gunfire followed.

headline: Jersey City: A Flower Blossoming as a New Colossus
abstract: Jersey City, New Jersey’s second-most-populous city, has enjoyed a cultural rise, and a handful of imminent additions are contributing to the artistic bustle.
lead_paragraph: On a warm Saturday in Jersey City last month, the siren call of the sofa and cable television was probably a bit muted for many residents.

headline: In Iran Talks, U.S. Seeks to Prevent a Covert Weapon
abstract: Unstated during negotiations is the fear of a “sneakout,” the risk of a bomb being produced at an undetected facility, or built from fuel and components obtained from one of Iran’s few trading partners.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA — Behind the efforts to close a nuclear deal with Iran this weekend lies a delicate question that has been little discussed in public: how to design an agreement to maximize the chances that Western intelligence agencies would catch any effort to develop an atomic bomb at a covert site.

headline: The Downside of the Boom
abstract: North Dakota took on the oversight of a multibillion-dollar oil industry with a regulatory system built on trust, warnings and second chances.
lead_paragraph: North Dakota took on the oversight of a multibillion-dollar oil industry with a regulatory system built on trust, warnings and second chances.

headline: An Eye for the 20th Century
abstract: The Neuberger Museum of Art in Purchase is showing pieces from the collection of Roy R. Neuberger, who focused on artists of his own era.
lead_paragraph: In his mid-20s and residing in Paris, Roy R. Neuberger read a biography of Vincent van Gogh that crystallized his commitment to contemporary art. Appalled by van Gogh’s struggles to sell his paintings during his lifetime, Mr. Neuberger returned to New York determined to find a way to support artists in the United States. Until his death in 2010, at the age of 107, he did just that.

headline: Asia’s ‘Big Guy’ Spreads Cash and Seeks Influence in Pacific Region
abstract: As China seeks to assert itself as the dominant economic power and strategic partner in Asia, President Xi Jinping has visited Australia, New Zealand and Fiji bestowing largess.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — When China’s leader, Xi Jinping, visited the Australian state of Tasmania last week, he was greeted by a front page of the local newspaper written in Chinese. He ate the island’s salmon, which will soon be available in China, and met a rare beast known as the Tasmanian devil.

headline: Roger Federer Has Davis Cup Within Reach
abstract: Switzerland was one victory from winning its first Davis Cup after Roger Federer and Stan Wawrinka defeated their French opponents in doubles.
lead_paragraph: VILLENEUVE D’ASCQ, France — Cowbells, anyone?

headline: Barriers Set Up Around St. Louis County Police Headquarters
abstract: Officials in Clayton, Mo., set up barriers around the county Police Headquarters on Saturday and prepared to restrict traffic near the courthouse where grand jurors have been deliberating.
lead_paragraph: CLAYTON, Mo. — Officials here set up barriers around the county Police Headquarters on Saturday and prepared to restrict traffic near the courthouse where grand jurors have been deliberating, part of the St. Louis area’s continued preparations for unrest.

headline: Fighting to Preserve Sag Harbor’s Literary Flavor
abstract: Rising rents and the loss of most of its bookstores have put a community on Long Island at a crossroads.
lead_paragraph: There was a time, less than a decade ago, when five bookstores contributed to the literary mystique in Sag Harbor. You could smell it on a deep inhale: the salty air, the worn wood, the books.

headline: Roll Over, Mahler: U.S. Orchestras Are Shrinking
abstract: The current cost-cutting trend in American orchestras often means management seeks to fill slots with freelancers rather than full-timers.
lead_paragraph: Composers have long dreamed of bigger orchestras.

headline: Far From Perfect, Harvard Ends Impeccably Against Yale
abstract: After losing a 17-point lead, the Crimson scored the winning touchdown against Yale with 55 seconds left to complete a 10-0 season, the 17th undefeated season in Harvard football history.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — With a brisk wind in his face, more than 30,000 chilled fans in thrall and an unblemished season on the line, Harvard quarterback Conner Hempel paid all of the above no heed. His right shoulder sore and wobbly, his team similarly shaken after surrendering a 17-point lead, Hempel coolly directed a winning drive Saturday in a wild finish.

headline: An Old Recipe for Success at Sherwood’s, in Larchmont
abstract: Despite the throwback menu — or maybe because of it — the customers are still lining up at Sherwood’s.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-five years in, Jack Hekker, the owner of Sherwood’s in Larchmont, knows he may have to make a few changes.

headline: In Ferguson, Protesting and Waiting
abstract: Demonstrators took to the streets again on Friday night as they awaited a grand jury’s decision on whether to indict Officer Darren Wilson in the fatal shooting of Michael Brown.
lead_paragraph: Demonstrators took to the streets again on Friday night as they awaited a grand jury’s decision on whether to indict Officer Darren Wilson in the fatal shooting of Michael Brown.

headline: Marshall, Aiming High, Earns Few Style Points in Latest Win
abstract: Marshall may be undefeated, but it committed two turnovers and 11 penalties to go with kicking-game blunders in a difficult win on Saturday, which will not help its hopes of playing in a major bowl game.
lead_paragraph: BIRMINGHAM, Ala. — Unbeaten Marshall escaped with a 23-18 victory over Alabama-Birmingham on Saturday, but the Thundering Herd were in no mood to discuss how an unimpressive performance could affect their chances of playing in a New Year’s bowl game.

headline: The Real Thing, Like ‘Spicy Numbing’ Frogs
abstract: For diners who want authentic Sichuan cuisine prepared as it is in China, not the ubiquitous American versions, Sichuan Pepper offers the chance.
lead_paragraph: So here’s a dining situation that brims with promise. You’re at a restaurant devoted to a particular regional cuisine, and every patron except you is from that region — as is the waiter, who’s attempting gently to steer you away from Menu Item X toward something you will “like more.”

headline: Bidding in Government Auction of Airwaves Reaches $34 Billion
abstract: Prices are likely to rise further because the auction has no definite end and could continue for days or weeks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A government auction of airwaves for use in mobile broadband has blown through presale estimates, becoming the biggest auction in the Federal Communications Commission’s history and signaling that wireless companies expect demand for Internet access by smartphones to continue to soar.

headline: Arizona State’s Elevation to Division I Alters Hockey’s Profile in the West
abstract: The Sun Devils’ promotion to N.C.A.A. status opens college hockey to the West and to a metropolitan area of four million people, and it gives the N.C.A.A. a 60th Division I program.
lead_paragraph: On a sunny 74-degree day in Tempe, Ariz., as most other college hockey teams were snowed in or coping with freezing temperatures, Arizona State made a surprise announcement that it would join N.C.A.A. Division I next season.

headline: New Jersey Restaurants Offer Training and Work-for-a-Meal Programs
abstract: Several restaurants in the state have made a mission of providing more than just pleasant dining experiences.
lead_paragraph: On a break from working the cash register at Kula Cafe here recently, Lanashia Paige, 19, contemplated her future in the restaurant business.

headline: Community Leaders Criticize Police Over Fatal Shooting of Unarmed Brooklyn Man
abstract: Two days after the man was shot and killed by a police officer in a housing project, critics of the New York Police Department demanded a thorough investigation into the shooting.
lead_paragraph: Two days after an unarmed black man was shot and killed by a police officer in a darkened stairwell of a Brooklyn housing project, community leaders expressed exasperation with the pace of change at the New York Police Department.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers react to recent articles in the Sports section of The Times.
lead_paragraph: Growing Criticism Confronts The N.F.L.

headline: Surround Sound
abstract: Patrick Berry gets us coming and going.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — First, if you are wondering, 66 Across needs to be pronounced “ROTSY” (ROTC) PAPARAZZI in order for it to work. The Reserve Officers Training Corps is abbreviated ROTC and sometimes pronounced as a kind of acronym.

headline: With Borscht and Rifle Scopes, Volunteers Power Ukraine Forces
abstract: Volunteers are offering not only support but at least a glimmer of hope that poorly funded Ukrainian government troops can hold their own.
lead_paragraph: DNEPROPETROVSK, Ukraine — In a cramped kitchen that smelled strongly of cabbage and beets, a small army of women labored into the night, preparing what would become dried borscht to supply Ukrainian soldiers in the field.

headline: Shoppers on Long Island Are Getting a Culinary Lift
abstract: Mall food, long associated with quick-service fast food, is diversifying, with destination restaurants, artisanal offerings and wine bars.
lead_paragraph: It was a Friday night at Roosevelt Field mall in Garden City, and after doing some shopping, Andrea Morra sat with her husband, Christopher, at Havana Central and sipped pink rum punch through a straw. A framed poster of Lucy and Desi presided over the restaurant’s tropical-themed banquettes, slow-moving ceiling fans and crowded bar. As Mr. Morra dug into guava-glazed pork ribs, a live salsa band set up for the evening performance.

headline: An Ethnic Chinese Christian, Breaking Barriers in Indonesia
abstract: Basuki Tjahaja Purnama, the new leader of Jakarta, the capital of the most populous Muslim-majority nation, says his faith and ethnicity are not political handicaps.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Jakarta, the sprawling Indonesian megacity of 10 million people, has a new governor with a difference.

headline: Giants and Tom Coughlin Near a Crossroads
abstract: The Giants’ 3-7 record has raised questions about the job security of Coach Tom Coughlin and General Manager Jerry Reese.
lead_paragraph: During an August interview a week before the Giants’ opening game, one of the team’s owners, John Mara, spent nearly an hour analyzing the changes that had been made to the roster in the off-season.

headline: Europe Takes Stronger Measures, Albeit Symbolic, to Condemn Israeli Policies
abstract: After years of growing frustration, European politicians are embracing symbolic steps to support a Palestinian state.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — European nations, Israel’s largest trading partners and a historical bastion of support, are taking stronger measures to support Palestinian sovereignty and condemn what many see as aggressive, expansionist Israeli policies.

headline: Monday’s Matchup: Jets (2-8) at Bills (5-5)
abstract: The Jets’ secondary has to be better if it is to contain Sammy Watkins, Buffalo’s rookie standout, who had an 84-yard reception against the Jets in Week 8.
lead_paragraph: 7 p.m. Monday, in Detroit

headline: Sunday’s Matchup: Cowboys (7-3) at Giants (3-7)
abstract: The Giants’ Dominique Rodgers-Cromartie, who may be the healthiest he has been in weeks, will be asked to stop Dez Bryant, who caught nine passes for 151 yards against the Giants in Week 7.
lead_paragraph: 8:30 p.m., NBC

headline: Texas Man Treasures Finds in Updike’s Trash
abstract: In his collection, The Other John Updike Archive, Paul Moran has chronicled material others deemed unworthy of saving.
lead_paragraph: MANCHACA, Tex. — A man can get rich off his old emails and aborted novels, if that man is Ian McEwan. This spring, Mr. McEwan, 66, the Booker Prize-winning author of “Atonement” and “On Chesil Beach,” fetched $2 million for his archive from the Harry Ransom Center at the University of Texas at Austin.

headline: The Election Is Over, but Many Candidates Are Still Running
abstract: In the aftermath of the midterms, losers and even some winners are already scrambling for their next jobs, creating vacancies in both chambers of the Legislature.
lead_paragraph: The Texas Legislature will start the 2015 session with a handful of empty chairs and unfinished elections.

headline: Injuries Can Help in the Long Run
abstract: When David Robinson was injured, it positioned the San Antonio Spurs in a draft that yielded Tim Duncan and helped to create an N.B.A. dynasty.
lead_paragraph: At home on Friday night, the Oklahoma City Thunder were leading the underwhelming Nets, 53-49, at halftime. In any other season, a victory would have been all but certain, but in this season of rapidly diminishing expectations for Oklahoma City, the Thunder slowly let the game go the Nets’ way.

headline: For One Night, She Felt Like Cinderella at the Ball
abstract: In and out of foster care since age 4, Taylor Turntime figured she would have to skip her senior prom. Then, a fairy godmother from the Children’s Aid Society stepped in.
lead_paragraph: Little things can make a big difference. Things like a dress. And going to the prom.

headline: Tight Bond Between Abbott and Aide
abstract: Daniel Hodge, who started out sorting mail for a Greg Abbott campaign, is leading the governor-elect’s transition team, and is expected to play a central role in his administration.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — After his decisive election as the next governor of Texas earlier this month, one of Greg Abbott’s first orders of business was naming Daniel Hodge to lead his transition team.

headline: Saints Revisit Days of Futility, Without the Fun
abstract: New Orleans is contending for the N.F.C. South title, but only because the Saints, at 4-6, appear no more mediocre than the rest of the division.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — For two decades starting in the late 1960s, fans supported the New Orleans Saints as lovable losers. O.K., they were not always lovable. The Saints once lost so many games that they lost a consonant and became the Aints. Some fans wore bags on their heads. But they still showed up as clever contrarians.

headline: After Years With Caregivers, Cherishing Her Independence
abstract: After many years in the foster care system, Dejulaira Lopez, 21, who has spastic quadriplegia, learned independent living skills and moved into her own apartment in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: For Dejulaira Lopez, trust is in short supply. At 2 years old, she became a ward of the state and spent the next 18 years in more than half a dozen foster homes, where, she said, she often experienced physical and emotional abuse.

headline: Opening Her Home to Many Children, and Worrying About Keeping Out the Cold
abstract: A foster mother who has taken more than 40 children into her Bronx home over the years is struggling to pay the bills.
lead_paragraph: A row of free-standing two-story houses sits on a quiet street in the Bronx near Soundview Park. On one of the houses, dark red brick and trim complement the cream-colored siding. In early October, orange curtains and fake spiders hung in the bay window and a plastic pumpkin sat below them.

headline: In Ferguson, Preparation and Anticipation as Grand Jury Decision Nears
abstract: On Saturday, workers erected barriers around the St. Louis County Police Headquarters as the area awaited a grand jury’s decision on whether to charge an officer in Michael Brown’s death.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — The grand jury weighing charges against a white police officer who shot an unarmed black teenager has not reached a decision and will continue considering the case, people with knowledge of it said Saturday. It is possible that the grand jury will not meet again until Monday.

headline: Raleigh Trevelyan, Chronicler of a Notable Family, Dies at 91
abstract: Mr. Trevelyan’s books included a biography of Walter Raleigh and a look at the experiences of his many relatives in British India.
lead_paragraph: Raleigh Trevelyan traced his family across five centuries of British history, a rich delta of ancestor-achievers that included Sir Walter Raleigh, the 16th-century explorer; Thomas Babington Macaulay, an influential 19th-century politician; and a parade of historians, colonial governors, military men and martyrs of various rebellions across the empire.

headline: Victor Elmaleh, 95, Builder and Entrepreneur, Is Dead
abstract: Mr. Elmaleh imported the first Volkswagens to the United States, developed $7 billion worth of real estate and won national championships in handball and squash.
lead_paragraph: One translation of Victor Elmaleh’s Arabic last name is “the master,” and he lived up to it. He imported some of the first Volkswagens to the United States. He developed $7 billion worth of real estate. He painted more than 4,000 watercolors, most of them small-scale, which were shown in many gallery exhibitions. He won national championships in handball and squash and a squash tournament at 81.

headline: After Snow, Western New York Prepares for Floods
abstract: As western New York continues to remove up to seven feet of snow from some areas, officials warned that a forecast of rising temperatures and rain could lead to widespread flooding.
lead_paragraph: BUFFALO — As dump trucks, plows and payloaders continued laboring to clear snow as high as seven feet, western New York girded on Saturday for the feared second act of the storm — widespread flooding.

headline: Los Angeles
