abstract: Unauthorized immigrants in Los Angeles are among the most settled in the country — many have been here at least 10 years. They contribute to about 7 percent of the region’s economy. This area, which has more than one million unauthorized immigrants, had the largest number of people who were approved for a two-year deportation deferral under the president’s initial program that began in 2012.
lead_paragraph: Unauthorized immigrants in Los Angeles are among the most settled in the country — many have been here at least 10 years. They contribute to about 7 percent of the region’s economy. This area, which has more than one million unauthorized immigrants, had the largest number of people who were approved for a two-year deportation deferral under the president’s initial program that began in 2012.

headline: Turmoil Over Immigration Status? California Has Lived It for Decades
abstract: President Obama’s executive action on immigration was almost anticlimactic to many people in California.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — There may be no better place than California to measure the contradictions, crosswinds and confusion that come with trying to change immigration law.

headline: Lawyer Who Represented Bin Laden Kin Is Sentenced in Tax Case
abstract: Stanley L. Cohen, who defended a son-in-law of Osama bin Laden against terrorism charges, was sentenced to 18 months in prison on Friday for impeding the Internal Revenue Service.
lead_paragraph: A defense lawyer who represented a son-in-law of Osama bin Laden on terrorism charges was sentenced to 18 months in prison on Friday for impeding the Internal Revenue Service.

headline: Boy, 12, Shot and Wounded by Cleveland Police Officer
abstract: The authorities said the boy brandished what turned out to be a fake gun on a playground, then reached for it when two officers arrived.
lead_paragraph: A Cleveland police officer shot and wounded a 12-year-old boy who was carrying what turned out to be a fake pistol outside a recreation center on Saturday after witnesses said the boy had brandished the gun on a playground, the authorities said.

headline: Chrysler Details Its Plans to Improve Recall Efforts
abstract: The company was responding to criticism from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration over its slow progress in fixing Jeeps that were recalled last year.
lead_paragraph: Chrysler agrees with federal regulators that roughly 1.6 million Jeeps being recalled over a deadly fire hazard in rear-impact crashes are not being fixed quickly enough, and it plans to improve, according to a letter the automaker sent to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration on Friday.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 22, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: One Game In, Knicks’ Jose Calderon Has More Wins Than 76ers
abstract: Granted a reprieve from the usual rigors of the N.B.A. schedule, the Knicks took advantage by defeating the 76ers with help from Jose Calderon, who made his season debut Saturday at Madison Square Garden.
lead_paragraph: About 10 minutes before the opening tip, Jose Calderon stood at midcourt while a Knicks trainer massaged his right leg. Injuries had kept Calderon out of the lineup since training camp, but he was set to make his season debut Saturday night at Madison Square Garden. His mere presence was a source of hope for the Knicks.

headline: A Controversial Prosecutor
abstract: A look at Robert P. McCulloch, the St. Louis County prosecutor in the grand jury case of Officer Darren Wilson. Protesters argue that he should have recused himself from the case.
lead_paragraph: A look at Robert P. McCulloch, the St. Louis County prosecutor in the grand jury case of Officer Darren Wilson. Protesters argue that he should have recused himself from the case.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, November 23, 2014
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, November 23, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “My parents are going to be able to qualify under this program.”

headline: Amanda Murphy, Anthony Piccirillo
abstract: The bride and groom, both lawyers, were married at the Cathedral Basilica of the Sacred Heart in Newark.
lead_paragraph: Amanda Marie Murphy, the daughter of Tina M. Murphy and Daniel P. Murphy of Lebanon, N.J., was married Friday to Anthony Carmen Piccirillo, a son of Debra A. Piccirillo and Stephen J. Piccirillo of Vernon, N.J. The Rev. Stephen M. Fields, a Roman Catholic priest who is an associate professor of theology at Georgetown University, performed the ceremony at the Cathedral Basilica of the Sacred Heart in Newark.

headline: Lindsay Addison, Stephen Hauss
abstract: The couple, both lawyers, married at the National Museum of Women in the Arts in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Lindsay Margaret Addison and Stephen Michael Hauss were married Saturday at the National Museum of Women in the Arts in Washington. Judge Frank D. Saylor IV of the United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts, for whom the groom was a law clerk from 2006 to 2007, officiated.

headline: Kimberly Eskow, Aaron Sobel
abstract: The couple were married at the Ritz-Carlton in McLean, Va.
lead_paragraph: Kimberly Brooke Eskow and Aaron Fausto Sobel were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Stephanie Bernstein at the Ritz-Carlton in McLean, Va.

headline: Shannon Coughlin, Matthew Shane
abstract: The couple were married at the Church of St. Francis Xavier in New York.
lead_paragraph: Shannon Kasey Coughlin and Matthew Owen Shane were married Saturday at the Church of St. Francis Xavier in New York. The Rev. Joseph G. Marina, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Julie Wertheimer, Benjamin Waxman
abstract: The couple, who both work in government, were married at the Cira Centre in Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: Julie Michelle Wertheimer and Benjamin Robert Waxman were married Saturday evening by Rabbi George Stern in the atrium at the Cira Centre, an office high-rise in Philadelphia.

headline: Amy Wolf, Kevin Malone
abstract: The couple were married at the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park.
lead_paragraph: Amy Elizabeth Wolf, the daughter of Barbara C. Wolf and Steven J. Wolf of New York, was married in New York Saturday evening to Kevin Louis Malone, the son of Pamela M. Morris of Austin, Tex., and Kenneth M. Malone of Sonoma, Calif. Rabbi Ari Lorge officiated at the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park.

headline: Lauren Margulis, Daniel Bader
abstract: The bride is a speech-language pathologist; the groom is a climatologist.
lead_paragraph: Lauren Michelle Margulis, the daughter of Felice J. Margulis and Justice Ira H. Margulis of Hollis Hills, Queens, was married Saturday evening to Daniel Adam Bader, the son of Barbara Bader and Gary Bader of East Hills, N.Y. The bride’s father officiated, with Cantor Sol Zim assisting at the Lawrence Yacht and Country Club in Lawrence, N.Y.

headline: Mariam Khan and David Levine
abstract: The couple work in Washington, she at the United Nations Foundation, he at the White House.
lead_paragraph: Mariam Said Khan and David Joshua Levine were married Saturday evening at the National Press Club in Washington. Yohannes A. Abraham, the chief of staff for the office of public engagement and the office of intergovernmental affairs at the White House, officiated with permission from the District of Columbia.

headline: Jacklyn Fleer, Bradley Cohen
abstract: The couple were married at the Yale Club of New York City.
lead_paragraph: Jacklyn Sara Fleer, a daughter of Lynn K. Fleer and Saul M. Fleer of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married Saturday to Bradley Dean Cohen, a son of Michele S. Cohen and Barry P. Cohen of Sydney, Australia. Rabbi Scott B. Weiner officiated at the Yale Club of New York City.

headline: Steven Sumser and Michael Engler
abstract: Steven Sumser, a real estate broker, married Michael Engler, a director and producer of television programs.
lead_paragraph: Steven Alexander Sumser and Michael Charles Engler are to be married Sunday at their apartment in New York. Dr. Kurtis Birusingh, a Universal Life minister, is to officiate.

headline: Rebecca Karp and David Leaf
abstract: The couple married at the Lighthouse at Chelsea Piers in New York.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Rebecca Sara Karp, the daughter of Dr. Susan R. Rosenthal and Dr. George I. Karp of East Brunswick, N.J., was married Saturday evening to Dr. David Evan Leaf, a son of Jeanette B. Leaf and Dr. Robert J. Leaf of Mamaroneck, N.Y. Rabbi Norton D. Shargel officiated at the Lighthouse at Chelsea Piers in New York.

headline: Bitsy Sather and Jay Wainwright
abstract: The couple work in New York, she as an account director at Mood Media, he as the chief development officer for Le Pain Quotidien.
lead_paragraph: Laura Whitney Sather and Jonathan Mayhew Wainwright Jr. were married Saturday at the Maidstone Club in East Hampton, N.Y. The Rev. Denis C. Brunelle, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

headline: Kathryn Weeks, Bryan Howard
abstract: Wherever the bride and groom live, you can be sure it will be energy efficient.
lead_paragraph: Kathryn Frances Weeks and Bryan Mark Howard were married in Washington Saturday at St. Francis Hall, a part of the Franciscan Monastery U.S.A. The ceremony was led by Matthew Lee Ashley, a friend of the couple who was granted permission by the District of Columbia.

headline: Lucila Pescarmona and Bud Nolan
abstract: The bride, who works for her family’s winery, and the groom a strategist for a media and information company, were married in Buenos Aires.
lead_paragraph: Lucila Maria Pescarmona and Robert Bernard Nolan III were married Friday at the Civil Registry Office in Buenos Aires. Liliana Sofia Gurevich, a justice of the peace, officiated. On Nov. 29, the couple is to take part in a blessing ceremony led by the Rev. Juan Carlos Vignoli, a Roman Catholic priest, at the Roman Catholic Church of Luján de Cuyo in Mendoza, Argentina.

headline: First the Patience, Then the Passion
abstract: Mr. Pissonnet de Bellefonds avoided exchanging contact information with Ms. Canney for four months. Then he surprised her with a kiss.
lead_paragraph: Colleen Marie Canney and Olivier Benjamin Thibault Pissonnet de Bellefonds were married Friday at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. James Mitchell, an employee of the New York City Clerk’s Office, officiated.

headline: Morgan Osthimer and Aaron Schoonhoven
abstract: The bride works at Christie’s; the groom is a producer at a documentary and reality television production company.
lead_paragraph: Morgan Alexis Osthimer and Aaron Lee Schoonhoven were married Saturday evening at the Pacific Union Club in San Francisco. Charles E. Osthimer IV, the bride’s brother, who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

headline: Corrections: November 23, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on November 23, 2014.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Manny Pacquiao Defeats Chris Algieri by Unanimous Decision
abstract: Pacquiao retained his World Boxing Organization welterweight championship by defeating Algieri, a Long Island native, in 12 rounds.
lead_paragraph: MACAU — Manny Pacquiao defeated Chris Algieri by unanimous decision Sunday at the Venetian Macao to retain his World Boxing Organization welterweight championship.

headline: Marion Barry, Washington’s ‘Mayor for Life,’ Even After Prison, Dies at 78
abstract: Mr. Barry was a flamboyant and polarizing mayor of the nation’s capital who went to prison on a cocaine charge and then made one of the most improbable comebacks in the history of American politics.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Marion S. Barry Jr., a sharecropper’s son and civil rights pioneer who became a flamboyant and polarizing mayor of Washington, went to prison on a cocaine charge and then recaptured City Hall in one of the most improbable comebacks in the history of American politics, died early Sunday in Washington. He was 78.

headline: Prosecution of Uighur Students Underscores Perils of Chinese Clampdown
abstract: At least three students are expected to stand trial on Tuesday on charges of having worked for the imprisoned activist Ilham Tohti.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Ambitious and fluent in Mandarin, the young Uighur strivers from the Xinjiang region of northwest China had earned coveted slots at the nation’s top university for ethnic minorities. Most were the first in their families to attend college.

headline: Coming Back Home to a Lower East Side Tenement
abstract: Rita Ascione, whose family once lived in a cramped Lower East Side tenement, returned to her old building, now preserved as a museum.
lead_paragraph: When Rita Ascione, 88, recently visited the tenement at 97 Orchard Street where she lived in the 1930s, she noticed that the neighborhood had changed dramatically. But the old building itself remained largely the way she remembered it: That’s because it was preserved by the Lower East Side Tenement Museum, which now occupies the space.

headline: What Cloud Computing Means to Your Job
abstract: The next big technology migration will change how workplaces are organized. Bad news, middle managers: You’re going to get less important.
lead_paragraph: Technology has been accused of making many a job disappear, like the production line or the accounting office. And it is not done yet.

headline: Biking Napoleon’s Route
abstract: The tour company Ride and Seek is offering a history-focused, 45-day cycling trip from Paris to Moscow called the Napoleon Expedition.
lead_paragraph: Following in the footsteps of Europe’s greatest conquerors isn’t easy. That’s why Ride and Seek, an international tour company in Sydney, Australia, suggests doing it on a bike. Next summer the group is introducing its second “epic” historical cycling tour, the Napoleon Expedition, a 45-day journey from Paris to Moscow.

headline: Our Marriage Ended. Our Family Did Not.
abstract: Of course we tried staying together for the sake of our son. Until one night, during one of our fine-tuned feuds, our shouting woke up the baby.
lead_paragraph: My birth plan was eight pages long. At 26, I hadn’t planned my pregnancy, so I was determined that our baby’s debut would be precise. Throughout those nine months, I read any parenting book I could get my swollen fingers on, dog-earing every other page. I considered whether our baby boy would be circumcised, how many months I would breast-feed, what preschool he would attend. I’d carefully carved out the details for any possible mishaps and milestones of our son’s little life — except for one. I never considered what would happen if I divorced the man who’d made me a mother.

headline: ‘Blind Massage’ Wins Golden Horse Award for Best Feature
abstract: The accolade, given each year to a Chinese-language film, is widely considered Asia’s most important film prize.
lead_paragraph: The director Lou Ye’s “Blind Massage” — a bittersweet tale set in a massage parlor run by blind masseurs — won for best feature film at the 51st Golden Horse Awards in Taipei, Taiwan, on Saturday. The accolade, given each year to a Chinese-language film, is widely considered Asia’s most important film prize.

headline: The Daily Gift: Soft Pillows Handmade Using Traditional Techniques
abstract: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.
lead_paragraph: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.

headline: Packers’ Aaron Rodgers Throws Off Defenders With His Voice
abstract: Rodgers is a master of the hard count, using rhythm and inflection before the snap of the ball to exploit opponents’ aggressiveness and expose their intentions.
lead_paragraph: During every Green Bay training camp, an inexperienced defensive lineman rotates in for a play or two, and quarterback Aaron Rodgers stifles a laugh. He glances at the Packers’ defensive line coach, Mike Trgovac, who knows precisely what Rodgers is about to do but is powerless to stop it.

headline: China Said to Turn Reef Into Airstrip in Disputed Water
abstract: A report from IHS Jane’s says the operation is intended to coerce other countries to relinquish territorial claims in the South China Sea.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A major reclamation project by the Chinese government on a tiny reef 500 miles from the mainland would enable China to land military aircraft there, expanding its reach into the contested South China Sea, analysts have said.

headline: Iran Nuclear Negotiators, Facing Key Differences, Weigh Extending Deadline
abstract: Western and Iranian officials said on Sunday that with issues still unresolved on an agreement to curb Iran’s nuclear program, they might consider prolonging the talks beyond Monday.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA — With a deadline for an agreement to curb Iran’s nuclear program just a day away, American officials finally acknowledged Sunday that the two sides would not reach a deal by Monday’s deadline but would probably extend the talks a second time to explore a series of possible solutions.

headline: Obama Acknowledges Broad Gaps Between 2 Sides in Iran Nuclear Talks
abstract: President Obama, in a television interview broadcast Sunday, called differences in talks between Iran and the United States over Iran’s nuclear program “significant.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The gap in negotiations over the Iranian nuclear program remains “significant,” President Obama said in an interview broadcast Sunday, a day before the deadline for the talks.

headline: Blast at Game Kills Dozens in Afghanistan
abstract: Explosives were detonated in a crowd gathered to watch a game between a village team and players from a neighboring district in Paktika Province.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — As many as 40 people were killed Sunday after a suicide bomber detonated explosives in a crowd gathered for a volleyball match in a village in eastern Afghanistan, a spokesman for the provincial governor said.

headline: When Their Workday Ends, More Fathers Are Heading Into the Kitchen
abstract: As parents juggle the demands of their jobs with the desire to prepare home-cooked meals, men are increasingly in front of the stove.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes, Joe Kreisberg ponders the question during his morning commute. Sometimes, he considers it at his desk at an advertising agency in Manhattan or on his afternoon stroll for a caffeinated pick-me-up.

headline: Survivors Pulled From Ruins After Quake in Japan
abstract: A magnitude-6.7 quake near the city of Nagano injured at least 40 people, damaged dozens of buildings and forced hundreds into emergency shelters.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Police officers and firefighters rescued almost two dozen people, including a 2-year-old toddler, from beneath their collapsed houses on Sunday, a day after a powerful earthquake shook mountainous central Japan. At least 40 people were injured, but no deaths were reported.

headline: 1914: Churches Of Ypres Are Targets For German Guns
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The churches of Ypres are targets for German guns in 1914.
lead_paragraph: IN BELGIUM — When the history of the terrific fighting in and around Ypres is written — Ypres, where the Huns have repeated the sacrilege and outrages of Louvain and Rheims, where once more they have selected the cathedral, churches, town hall and all the beautiful examples of Flemish architecture as the special targets of their heavy artillery — it will add another chapter of infamy to the record of German ‘‘kultur’’ in this great war. Filled with fierce joy over the destruction of the imposing Hall of the Draper; and of the classic little Town Hall, the Huns have added the beautiful cathedral of Ypres to the sacrifices which Belgium has made for freedom. I have been in many towns and villages desolated and ruined by the Germans during this war, and everywhere I have noted the terrible truth that the temples of God — the beautiful churches of France and Belgium — have been picked in advance of all other edifices for destruction. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Nov. 24, 1914

headline: Latest ‘Hunger Games’ Film Opens Big, but Not as Big as the Previous One
abstract: The third “Hunger Games” movie, “Mockingjay Part 1” (Lionsgate), sold an estimated $123 million in tickets at North American theaters over the weekend.
lead_paragraph: The third “Hunger Games” movie, “Mockingjay Part 1” (Lionsgate), sold an estimated $123 million in tickets at North American theaters over the weekend — by far Hollywood’s largest opening of the year but one that nonetheless marked a substantial comedown for the mega-franchise.

headline: Brown Family’s Lawyer Criticizes Process
abstract: A lawyer representing the family of Michael Brown again called the grand jury process reviewing the shooting “completely unfair” in an interview on Sunday with ABC News.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — Benjamin Crump, a lawyer representing the family of Michael Brown, the unarmed black teenager killed by a white police officer in August, again called the grand jury process on the review of the shooting “completely unfair” in an interview on Sunday with ABC News.

headline: Israeli Cabinet Approves Nationality Bill
abstract: The draft legislation emphasizes Israel’s Jewish character above its democratic nature, proposing to define Israel as the nation-state of the Jewish people, a move opposed by Arab citizens.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Israeli cabinet on Sunday approved contentious draft legislation that emphasizes Israel’s Jewish character above its democratic nature in a move that critics said could undermine the fragile relationship with the country’s Arab minority at a time of heightened tensions.

headline: Parents Charged in Shooting of 9-Month-Old Girl in Brooklyn
abstract: The girl’s father, who the police said was cleaning a gun in the family’s East New York home that went off accidentally, was charged with several crimes, including assault.
lead_paragraph: The parents of a 9-month-old girl who was shot in the hip at her home in Brooklyn were charged on Sunday in connection with the shooting, the police said.

headline: What’s On TV Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (13, 49) JAY LENO: THE MARK TWAIN PRIZE Mr. Leno, above, the 17th recipient of the Mark Twain Prize for American Humor, is honored at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington in this ceremony, taped on Oct. 19. In addition to hosting “The Tonight Show” from 1992 to 2014 (with time off in 2009 and 2010), Mr. Leno makes more than 100 live stand-up appearances annually; shows off his car collection in his online series, “Jay Leno’s Garage”; writes children’s books; does voice-over work; and writes a monthly column in Popular Mechanics magazine. Among the friends and colleagues cheering him here are Garth Brooks, Kristin Chenoweth, Kevin Eubanks, Jimmy Fallon, Chelsea Handler, Robert Klein, Al Madrigal, Seth Myers, Jerry Seinfeld, J. B. Smoove, Wanda Sykes, Jamie Foxx and Betty White. “What an honor!” Mr. Leno said when he learned about the award. “I’m a big fan of Mark Twain’s. In fact, ‘A Tale of Two Cities’ is one of my favorite books.”

headline: FBI Declassifies Additional Portions of 2010 Inspector General Report on Problems With Exigent Letters
abstract: In response to a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit filed by The New York Times, the FBI has declassified additional portions of a 2010 inspector general report about “exigent letters” and other informal requests for telephone records. The new version contains about 125 words or passages that were previously redacted.
lead_paragraph: In response to a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit filed by The New York Times, the FBI has declassified additional portions of a 2010 inspector general report about “exigent letters” and other informal requests for telephone records. The new version contains about 125 words or passages that were previously redacted.

headline: Watercolor Attributed to Hitler Sells for $161,000
abstract: A watercolor believed to have been painted by Adolf Hitler sold about $161,000 (130,000 euros), on Saturday at a German auction house, Reuters reported.
lead_paragraph: A watercolor believed to have been painted by Adolf Hitler sold for about $161,000 (130,000 euros), on Saturday at a German auction house, Reuters reported.

headline: 12-Year-Old Boy Dies After Police in Cleveland Shoot Him
abstract: The boy was shot Saturday in the torso outside a recreation center after, the police said, he reached for what turned out to be a fake gun in his waistband, and he died later on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Officials in Cleveland were investigating the police shooting of a 12-year-old boy who died on Sunday, a day after an officer shot him outside a recreation center when he reached for a weapon that turned out to be a fake pistol.

headline: Release of Evidence Used by Grand Jury Is Uncertain
abstract: A St. Louis County circuit court judge had not yet agreed to the release of records from grand jury proceedings in the Darren Wilson case, a court official said in a statement on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: A St. Louis County circuit court judge had not yet agreed to the release of records from grand jury proceedings in the Darren Wilson case, a court official said in a statement on Sunday, an indication that there is no guarantee that the public will receive access to transcripts and recordings detailing what has happened in the grand jury room.

headline: 1939: French Join Americans in Thanksgiving Rites
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Americans in Paris celebrate Thanksgiving with locals in 1939.
lead_paragraph: Despite the alarms of war, Thanksgiving Day was observed by Americans in Paris yesterday with traditional religious and festive rites at the American Church and Pershing Hall, where American war veterans congregated with their French comrades to enjoy a real Thanksgiving dinner in a spirit of good fellowship recalling the dramatic days of 1914-18.

headline: Sudan and Rebels in Darfur Region Begin Peace Talks
abstract: The conflict in the region in western Sudan started in 2003, when rebels there accused the central government in Khartoum of discrimination, negligence and marginalization.
lead_paragraph: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia — Talks between the Sudanese government and two rebels groups from the Darfur region began here in the Ethiopian capital on Sunday.

headline: Obama Defends His Use of Executive Authority on Immigration
abstract: President Obama rejected Republican claims of unconstitutional overreach, adding that he had been “very restrained” in his use of executive authority.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama, in an interview broadcast on Sunday, said he rejects Republican criticism that he has exceeded his authority in moving to spare millions of undocumented immigrants from deportation, adding that he has been “very restrained” in his use of executive authority.

headline: Roger Federer Burnishes Legacy as the Swiss Capture a Long-Sought Title
abstract: Federer won the match that gave Switzerland the Davis Cup title over France, one of the few major tennis accomplishments that had eluded him.
lead_paragraph: VILLENEUVE D’ASCQ, France — It looked like an ending, with the confetti floating down and a record crowd watching Roger Federer and his Swiss teammates celebrate for the first time with the big, bright and shiny Davis Cup.

headline: Afghanistan Quietly Lifts Ban on Nighttime Raids
abstract: The government of President Ashraf Ghani has cleared the way for special forces raids, blocked by former President Hamid Karzai, to resume in 2015.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The government of the new Afghan president, Ashraf Ghani, has quietly lifted the ban on night raids by special forces troops that his predecessor had imposed.

headline: Sailing Off on a Gender Bender
abstract: Drag queens are among the cast of characters in “Fabulous! The Queen of the New Musical Comedies,” a play set on a cruise ship.
lead_paragraph: Twice, I thought I saw Patti LuPone onstage. They were just look-alikes, but “Fabulous! The Queen of New Musical Comedies,” which occupies the microscopic stage at the New Write Act Repertory Theater, has its fair share of other divas.

headline: Red Bulls Fall to Revolution in First Game of Conference Finals
abstract: The Red Bulls took a major step backward, conceding two vital away goals that gave the New England Revolution an edge heading into the return match on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: HARRISON, N.J. — The Giants’ and the Jets’ seasons are disasters. The Knicks and the Nets? Whatever. November is still a bit too early to pass judgment on the Rangers, the Islanders and the Devils. The Yankees and the Mets? Seek therapy.

headline: The Prescription for Japan’s Economy?
abstract: More Abenomics.
lead_paragraph: More Abenomics.

headline: Fleeing Ukraine With Little More Than Wit
abstract: In “A Backpack, a Bear and Eight Crates of Vodka,” Lev Golinkin recounts how his family fled Ukraine and started anew in the United States.
lead_paragraph: It came as a great surprise to Lev Golinkin when he discovered, at the age of 9, that there was more than one town named Lafayette in the United States.

headline: Celebrating Half a Century of Creativity
abstract: The American Composers Orchestra opened its 38th season with a program at Zankel Hall celebrating the composer Meredith Monk.
lead_paragraph: Meredith Monk, the composer, vocalist, director and choreographer whose multidisciplinary works have influenced a couple of generations of American artists, is being celebrated this season for 50 years of creativity in New York. On Friday night, the day after she turned 72, the essential American Composers Orchestra opened its 38th season with a program at Zankel Hall titled “Monk’s Sphere,” conducted by the ensemble’s music director, George Manahan, the first of its two Orchestra Underground concerts in that popular subbasement performance space at Carnegie Hall.

headline: A Club Celebrates Being a Drawing Card
abstract: The most-attended bridge club in the United States last year was the Hartes Club in White Plains, with 13,622.5 tables.
lead_paragraph: The most-attended bridge club in the United States last year was the Hartes Club in White Plains, with 13,622.5 tables.

headline: Beyoncé Repackaged for the Holidays
abstract: Beyoncé has repackaged her latest hit album with two new songs and four remixes, as well as a live DVD and a calendar.
lead_paragraph: Last December, Beyoncé surprised her fans with a new, self-titled album, which after only three weeks sold 1.3 million copies, making it one of the top sellers of the year.

headline: As Temperatures Warm in Buffalo Area, Melting Snow Raises Fears of Flooding
abstract: As the emergency situation eased in Western New York, the governor warned residents that flooding “is a very real possibility” in the days ahead.
lead_paragraph: BUFFALO — With temperatures rapidly warming here, people began to emerge on Sunday in some of the areas worst affected by a series of lake-effect storms that dumped more than six feet of snow across the region last week and left at least 12 people dead.

headline: Seeking an Intimate Sound Across a Cavernous Expanse
abstract: Leonidas Kavakos and Yuja Wang presented a program of Brahms, Ravel and the rarely heard Respighi at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: In the most memorable chamber music concerts, the performances seem spontaneous; the listener can sense musicians feeding off one another’s energy, taking risks and enjoying a visceral experience together.

headline: How Colleges Deal With Rape Claims
abstract: Readers react to a Sunday Review essay that said current practices have “failed abysmally.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Plan for an Offshore Park in the Hudson
abstract: Environmental and political objections are raised to the billionaire Barry Diller’s proposal.

headline: Sealing Juvenile Records
abstract: Marcy Mistrett of the Campaign for Youth Justice writes that “the juvenile court must follow its original mandate and allow all young people to have a second chance.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Reasons to Refinance
abstract: Jeremy Potter, a mortgage company executive, writes that “barriers to obtain cash from refinance products will not eliminate the underlying pressure on homeowners who need their equity savings.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Safety on Chemicals
abstract: The American Chemistry Council calls for bipartisan legislation “that would support development of breakthroughs in sustainable chemistry.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Alastair Mitchell, on Running With Your Dreams
abstract: A chief executive describes what he calls the “big red bus test”: If a bus were about to run you over, what would be the one thing you’d regret not doing?
lead_paragraph: This interview with  Alastair Mitchell, the chief executive of Huddle, a cloud-based collaboration software company, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Alastair Mitchell, on Running With Your Dreams
abstract: A chief executive describes what he calls the “big red bus test”: If a bus were about to run you over, what would be the one thing you’d regret not doing?
lead_paragraph: This interview with  Alastair Mitchell, the chief executive of Huddle, a cloud-based collaboration software company, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Judaism Must Embrace the Convert
abstract: Our people believe in inclusiveness as well as chosenness.
lead_paragraph: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. — THE recent arrest of an Orthodox rabbi in Washington, who was charged with having watched women showering via a hidden camera installed at the mikvah, or ritual bath, at his synagogue, has drawn attention to the challenges faced by potential converts to Judaism. The scandal put a spotlight on the near-total control exercised by the rabbi over converts into the Jewish faith. The system lacks oversight. It leaves those wanting to become Jews vulnerable to exploitation.

headline: A Secret Falls From the Family Tree, and a Girl’s Identity Branches Out
abstract: In the documentary “Little White Lie,” a girl who grew up viewing herself as Jewish and white gradually begins to realize that her biological father was black.
lead_paragraph: The documentary “Little White Lie” would be provocative simply for what it says about race and identity. The director Lacey Schwartz grew up Jewish in Woodstock, N.Y., yet something seemed off. Her peers would ask if she was adopted. At Ms. Schwartz’s bat mitzvah, a member of her synagogue assumed she was an Ethiopian Jew. Her family attributed her darker skin to a Sicilian great-grandfather. Only gradually did Ms. Schwartz, now 37, begin to suspect what might seem obvious to an outsider: that her biological father was black.

headline: Texter’s Expression
abstract: Robert Seminara makes his debut in The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — If you are a member of the texting generation, you will be very familiar with today’s theme, although I have just been handed an update by my kids, who say that ROFL, or ROLLING ON THE FLOOR LAUGHING, is kind of passé already. If you can imagine.

headline: Good News on Energy
abstract: Reducing greenhouse gas emissions is simply another step in the transition to cleaner energy.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — WHEN the world’s two largest polluters join in establishing new goals for reducing emissions of climate-disrupting gases, criticism and skepticism are predictable. And there was plenty following the recent agreement between the United States and China to do just that.

headline: Virtual Worlds Invite Visitors Into the Story
abstract: Dragon Age: Inquisition shows that sophisticated storytelling in video games has become commonplace even as it remains the most experimental and contentious aspect of the medium.
lead_paragraph: There is no agreement among designers on the best way for video games to tell stories. Some games have branching plotlines and characters who live or die based on the player’s decisions. Others are tightly constrained and offer no choices that alter the narrative. Some use text to deliver information, while others use sound or moving images. Most mix all of those qualities.

headline: Visual Arts Come to the Theater as Genres Blend and Bend
abstract: “The House Is Open,” at the Bard College performing arts center, blurred the boundaries between dance and the visual arts.
lead_paragraph: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y. — With the recent proliferation of dance in museums, artists and curators have had to reimagine nontheatrical spaces — galleries, hallways, atriums — as sites for performance, a task more delicate and complicated than it might sound. But what if the challenge were inverted? What would happen, say, if a performing arts center temporarily reimagined itself as an art museum?

headline: With ‘Hunger Games’ Campaigns, Lionsgate Punches Above Its Weight
abstract: In its campaigns for the “Hunger Games” films, Lionsgate’s tiny marketing department has used mastery of social media and a culture of risk-taking to dazzle the legacy studios.
lead_paragraph: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — With its cutting-edge social-media campaigns for “The Hunger Games,” the tiny 27-person marketing department at Lionsgate has become a model for Hollywood’s legacy studios: scrappy, thrifty, forward-thinking.

headline: Indianapolis Star Newspaper Apologizes for Cartoon on Migrants
abstract: The Star removed a cartoon from its website after readers complained the drawing was racist for depicting an immigrant family climbing through a window to crash a white family’s Thanksgiving dinner.
lead_paragraph: The Indianapolis Star removed a cartoon from its website over the weekend after readers complained that the drawing was racist for depicting an immigrant family climbing through a window to crash a white family’s Thanksgiving dinner.

headline: A Lifesaving Transplant for Coral Reefs
abstract: A quick-grow laboratory technique, called microfragmenting, may make it possible to mass-produce reef-building corals for transplanting onto dead or dying reefs that took centuries to develop.
lead_paragraph: SUMMERLAND KEY, Fla. — David Vaughan plunges his right arm down to his elbow into one of nine elevated tanks where thousands of tiny colonies of coral are growing at an astonishing rate in shaded seclusion next to the Mote Tropical Research Laboratory.

headline: A Gander at Love
abstract: Geese are mean and geese are dumb. But this is not really about geese.
lead_paragraph: When people ask me what my father is like, I tell them about the geese.

headline: Sybil: A Brilliant Hysteric?
abstract: In the 1970s, the TV movie “Sybil” introduced much of the nation to multiple personality disorder and led to a controversy that continues to shape mental health issues.
lead_paragraph: In the 1970s, the TV movie “Sybil” introduced much of the nation to multiple personality disorder and led to a controversy that continues to shape mental health issues.

headline: Debate Persists Over Diagnosing Mental Health Disorders, Long After ‘Sybil’
abstract: After the book and film “Sybil” were released, diagnoses of multiple personality disorder skyrocketed. Was it more awareness by doctors, or overdiagnosis?
lead_paragraph: The notion that a person might embody several personalities, each of them distinct, is hardly new. The ancient Romans had a sense of this and came up with Janus, a two-faced god. In the 1880s, Robert Louis Stevenson wrote “Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde,” a novella that provided us with an enduring metaphor for good and evil corporeally bound. Modern comic books are awash in divided personalities like the Hulk and Two-Face in the Batman series. Even heroic Superman has his alternating personas.

headline: William H. Scheide, 100, Philanthropist, Is Dead
abstract: Mr. Scheide devoted his life to philanthropic and artistic pursuits striking in their range and depth.
lead_paragraph: William T. Scheide struck it rich in the Pennsylvania oil boom of the late 19th century and then surprised people by retiring at 42. For him, it was an easy decision. He had made more than enough money to do what he really wanted to do: buy books and read them.

headline: Treasury Auctions for the Week of Nov. 24
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Solar and Wind Energy Start to Win on Price vs. Conventional Fuels
abstract: The cost of electricity from wind and solar power plants has plummeted, making it cheaper than coal or natural gas in some places.
lead_paragraph: For the solar and wind industries in the United States, it has been a long-held dream: to produce energy at a cost equal to conventional sources like coal and natural gas.

headline: Tunisia Vote for Leader Likely to Go to a Runoff
abstract: Beji Caid Essebsi, a former prime minister, and Moncef Marzouki, the interim president, were leading but neither was expected to win a majority.
lead_paragraph: TUNIS — Tunisians turned out in steady, orderly lines on Sunday to vote in their first free and democratic presidential election, voicing confidence that they were turning the page on the often-fractious transition after the revolution of 2011.

headline: ‘Serial,’ Podcasting’s First Breakout Hit, Sets Stage for More
abstract: If podcasting’s model seems familiar — Netflix, anyone? — it’s no surprise that it will have similar transformative effects on traditional audio programming providers, like public radio.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, people will gather around tables everywhere and, well, talk about how bummed they are that “Serial,” the wildly popular podcast, is taking Thanksgiving off.

headline: In Delhi, Pushing Through the Wall (of Air Pollution)
abstract: Despite very high levels of air pollution in India’s capital city, the Delhi half-marathon is one of a growing number of running races across the country.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — They wore turbans, headbands, crazy wigs and baseball caps, but almost none of the runners in this city’s annual half-marathon wore masks Sunday despite air pollution levels that were among the worst in the world.

headline: Graft Hobbles Iraq’s Military in Fighting ISIS
abstract: The Iraqi military and police forces had been so pillaged by their own leadership that they all but collapsed this spring in the face of the advancing Islamic State fighters.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — One Iraqi general is known as “chicken guy” because of his reputation for selling his soldiers’ poultry provisions. Another is “arak guy,” for his habit of enjoying that anise-flavored liquor on the job. A third is named after Iraq’s 10,000-dinar bills, “General Deftar,” and is infamous for selling officer commissions.

headline: A Power Plant in California Goes Quiet, but the Stacks Still Tower
abstract: In Morro Bay, three smokestacks from a power plant share the scenery with a mountain of volcanic rock, and will probably not be going anywhere soon.
lead_paragraph: MORRO BAY, Calif. — The showpiece of this sparkling California fishing village is a 581-foot-high mountain of volcanic rock rising from the water, drawing gawkers and tourists from up and down the coast. Yet for 50 years, Morro Bay, which likes to call itself the Gibraltar of the Pacific, has been just as defined by a no-less-assertive landmark, staring down the rock from across the bay: three 450-feet-high power plant smokestacks, visible from 10 miles away.

headline: Home-Birth Film by Ricki Lake Prepares for Redelivery, Worldwide
abstract: An expanded version of “The Business of Being Born,” a documentary by the actress Ricki Lake that some experts say plays down the risks of delivering babies at home, will debut on Netflix.
lead_paragraph: One of the most talked about and provocative documentaries about childbirth is having its own rebirth.

headline: Notable Absence of New Ebola Quarantines at New York Area Airports
abstract: Since a nurse flew into Newark’s airport on Oct. 24 and was kept at a hospital for three days, no one else has been caught up in the quarantine dragnet at the New York and New Jersey airports.
lead_paragraph: A day after a doctor who had returned from Guinea about a week earlier became New York’s first Ebola case, the governors of New York and New Jersey announced that they would begin quarantining travelers who had been in contact with Ebola patients in West Africa.

headline: Bigger Than Immigration
abstract: For conservatives, this debate is really about the fear of seeing traditional power slip away.
lead_paragraph: Don’t let yourself get lost in the weeds. Don’t allow yourself to believe that opposition to President Obama’s executive actions on immigration is only about that issue, the president’s tactics, or his lack of obsequiousness to his detractors.

headline: After Manny Pacquiao Wins Again, Talk Turns to a Possible Foe
abstract: After dominating his bout with Chris Algieri in Macau, Pacquiao celebrated and discussed the possibility of facing Floyd Mayweather Jr.
lead_paragraph: MACAU — It was shortly after 4:30 p.m. local time when Manny Pacquiao entered his suite atop the north tower of the Venetian Macao. Approximately 100 people were there, waiting almost three hours after his fight to congratulate him on his unanimous decision victory over Chris Algieri.

headline: Rock Bottom Economics
abstract: It’s amazing and depressing that we’ve spent six years at the big zero.
lead_paragraph: Six years ago the Federal Reserve hit rock bottom. It had been cutting the federal funds rate, the interest rate it uses to steer the economy, more or less frantically in an unsuccessful attempt to get ahead of the recession and financial crisis. But it eventually reached the point where it could cut no more, because interest rates can’t go below zero. On Dec. 16, 2008, the Fed set its interest target between 0 and 0.25 percent, where it remains to this day.

headline: In Pursuit of an Oddly Shaped Comet
abstract: Scientists hope the Rosetta mission will help them decipher clues to the formation of the solar system.
lead_paragraph: It took more than a decade, and a looping trajectory that covered four billion miles, before a spacecraft launched by the European Space Agency caught up with a mysterious comet near Jupiter in August — and three more months before it gently lowered an automated probe to study what makes these primordial remnants from the early solar system tick. Last-minute malfunctions hampered the ability of the probe to complete its inspection of surface and subsurface conditions. Even so, the mission appears to be a history-making achievement.

headline: Fellowship or Internship? In Media, the Definition Has Become Fluid
abstract: BuzzFeed, Gawker, The Huffington Post and others offer fellowships that they say are above internships, but the lines are blurring at many media companies.
lead_paragraph: Since graduating from Wesleyan University last year, Rachel Pincus has completed two journalism internships and one in publishing. But now Ms. Pincus is pursuing fellowships.

headline: In Her Third Chance at Life, She Discovers an Appetite for Living
abstract: Lidia de los Santos, 21, overcame years of bullying and a suicide attempt to renew her life through faith, work and education.
lead_paragraph: Twice in her life, Lidia de los Santos has dropped onto the tracks of the New York City subway system, as the thundering of a coming train sounded through the tunnels.

headline: Iran Grants Bail to Woman From Britain Held 5 Months
abstract: Ghoncheh Ghavami, 25, who has dual citizenship, is appealing a one-year sentence for a conviction that has been linked to activism.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — A British-Iranian woman detained in Iran since June, whose case attracted international attention after her family said she had been arrested after trying to attend an all-male volleyball match, was released on bail on Sunday.

headline: A Step Forward on Child Care
abstract: The bipartisan support for a law that will help provide safe, affordable care offers hope that even more progress can be made. The country needs high-quality child care. And that will cost money.
lead_paragraph: Ensuring access to safe, good and affordable child care is crucial for helping to lift low-income parents out of poverty and build futures for their children. The child care bill signed on Wednesday by President Obama is a bipartisan step in the right direction, and it holds promise for further progress.

headline: Sting Climbs Aboard Foundering ‘Ship’
abstract: Sting, who wrote the music and lyrics for the struggling Broadway musical “The Last Ship,” will join the cast on Dec. 9.
lead_paragraph: Can Sting save his sinking ship on Broadway?

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
abstract: Account assignments, miscellaneous news from advertising agencies and more.
lead_paragraph: Accounts

headline: Sid Lee USA and Movember Take Relationship to New Level
abstract: Sid Lee, an ad agency, and Movember Foundation, a men’s health charity that is one of its clients, are moving in together, taking their relationship to a new level.
lead_paragraph: IF, as the saying goes, advertising is a relationship business, an agency, Sid Lee, and one of its clients, the men’s health charity known as the Movember Foundation, have entered the cohabitation stage.

headline: A Breakout Season for Lydia Ko, a Low-Key 17-Year-Old
abstract: Ko finished her first full season as a member of the L.P.G.A. Tour with a win at the Tour Championship on Sunday and a combined payday that was the richest in the tour’s history.
lead_paragraph: NAPLES, Fla. — Eleven days after Tiger Woods won the Masters in his first full season on the PGA Tour, an 8-pound, 8-ounce girl was born in Seoul, South Korea. Seventeen years later, Lydia Ko provided further evidence that the game’s next transcendent player, the crown prince to Woods’s king, may in fact be a princess.

headline: Will Texas Kill an Insane Man?
abstract: By any reasonable standard, Scott Panetti is mentally incompetent.
lead_paragraph: On Dec. 3, Texas plans to execute an inmate named Scott Panetti, who was convicted in 1995 for murdering his in-laws with a hunting rifle. There is no question that Mr. Panetti committed the murders. There is also no question that he is severely mentally ill, and has been for decades.

headline: N.B.A. Game of the Week: Pelicans at Wizards
abstract: Saturday’s meeting between a potentially underrated New Orleans team and Washington will test the Wizards, who have performed well but have not yet had many tough opponents.
lead_paragraph: As a season filled with parity continues, some of the teams off to fast starts are beginning to look less like early-season upstarts and more like legitimate contenders. In the Western Conference, the Grizzlies and the Warriors had each lost only two games going into Sunday. In the Eastern Conference, the Raptors, the Wizards and the Bulls have taken center stage as the Heat and the Pacers have declined.

headline: Week Ahead: Updates on Europe’s Economy, and an OPEC Meeting
abstract: The European Commission will offer infrastructure spending, and eurozone reports on inflation and jobs are due; OPEC ministers will meet, but output cuts are uncertain.
lead_paragraph: INVESTMENT PLAN IS EXPECTED FROM EUROPEAN COMMISSION

headline: In Brooklyn, 2 Young Men, a Dark Stairwell and a Gunshot
abstract: The bullet that killed Akai Gurley in a Brooklyn housing project stairwell was fired from the gun of a New York police officer, but exactly how it happened is still a mystery.
lead_paragraph: For two flights down a darkened Brooklyn stairwell, Akai Gurley descended, mortally wounded by gunfire but apparently unaware that the single shot had come from a police officer’s 9 millimeter weapon.

headline: ‘The Affair’ Recap: Alison Hits Brooklyn, ‘Girls’ Style
abstract: The show moves back to Brooklyn, with a different look and tone.
lead_paragraph: Season 1, Episode 7

headline: Freed & Fighting for China’s Environment
abstract: The environmental activist Wu Lihong was jailed for speaking out about pollution in China’s Lake Tai. Freed in 2010, he is still speaking out about China’s challenges to protect its waterways.
lead_paragraph: The environmental activist Wu Lihong was jailed for speaking out about pollution in China’s Lake Tai. Freed in 2010, he is still speaking out about China’s challenges to protect its waterways.

headline: Uncertainty Upends Lives as Ferguson Awaits Grand Jury Decision
abstract: Schools closed, rumors swirled and businesses felt repercussions as the silence of a grand jury investigating the police killing of Michael Brown upended normal life.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — At Spencer’s Bakery near the barricaded police station here, there have been fewer Thanksgiving orders, including for pumpkin pie.

headline: Despite Persecution, Guardian of Lake Tai Spotlights China’s Polluters
abstract: Despite pressure from Beijing, factories continue to dump toxic waste into waterways because the cost of violating the rules is lower than the cost of compliance.
lead_paragraph: ZHOUTIE, China — By autumn, the stench of Lake Tai and the freakish green glow of its waters usually fade with the ebbing of the summer heat, but this year is different. Standing on a concrete embankment overlooking a fetid, floating array of plastic bottles, foam takeout containers, flip-flops and the occasional dead fish, Wu Lihong, the lake’s unofficial guardian, shook his head in disgust.

headline: As Snow Fades, California Ski Resorts Are Left High and Very Dry
abstract: A snow drought and climate change present a growing challenge to the ski industry in California, which increasingly relies on man-made snow and activities other than skiing or snowboarding.
lead_paragraph: TWIN BRIDGES, Calif. — At ski areas up and down the jagged peaks of the Sierra Nevada, where California’s drought has hit historic proportions and the broader threat of climate change hangs heavy over an industry built on optimism, the man-made snow is flying.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 23, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Senator Paul’s War Resolution
abstract: Mr. Paul of Kentucky has asked Congress to declare war — something it has not done since World War II — on the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Paul of Kentucky has asked Congress to declare war — something it has not done since World War II — on the Islamic State.

headline: Nets Face Stiff Test; Then the Game Starts
abstract: John Welch, a 51-year-old assistant coach for the Nets, plays aggressive one-on-one defense in practice against the team’s much larger players.
lead_paragraph: As one of the best one-on-one players in the N.B.A., Joe Johnson has dispatched his share of the league’s most suffocating defenders. But his most stubborn adversary — the persistent thorn in his side, the one who will never go away — might be a 51-year-old assistant coach named John Welch.

headline: Rand Paul Calls for a Formal Declaration of War Against ISIS
abstract: Mr. Paul, a likely presidential candidate who has emerged as one of the Republican Party’s most cautious voices on military intervention, offered a very circumscribed definition of war.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Rand Paul is calling for a declaration of war against the Islamic State, a move that promises to shake up the debate over the military campaign in Iraq and Syria as President Obama prepares to ask Congress to grant him formal authority to use force.

headline: N.F.L. Players Union Deals With a Shifting Conduct Policy
abstract: It’s a union’s job to fight for its members’ rights, no matter what they have done wrong. And perhaps holding its nose, the players union has done just that.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Those looking at a tough Thanksgiving workweek — a snow plow driver in Buffalo, say, or a toll collector on the New Jersey Turnpike — can take solace in the knowledge that it could be worse: They could be working for the N.F.L. Players Association.

headline: Workers in Silicon Valley Weigh In on Obama’s Immigration Action
abstract: Despite drawbacks, some immigrants working in technology said the president’s actions could make work in the United States easier.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Silicon Valley’s constant stream of new apps and services depends on hundreds of thousands of foreign-born engineers to help create them. So the technology industry has been pushing for changes to the nation’s immigration policy for more than a decade to allow more skilled workers into the country.

headline: Nations Ponder How to Handle European Fighters Returning From Jihad
abstract: A young man who came back to Germany from fighting in Syria has confessed in court and said he would like “to live a totally normal life.”
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Months after Kreshnik B. slipped over Turkey’s border into Syria in 2013, convinced that it was his duty to help the people overthrow President Bashar al-Assad, he found himself desperate to go home. In a lengthy confession read in a Frankfurt court, the 20-year-old, wearing a black T-shirt and hoodie, said he realized that he could “achieve absolutely nothing” in Syria.

headline: Marion S. Barry Jr.: ‘A Complicated Man’ Whose Legacy Recounts Both Greatness and Blunders
abstract: Mr. Barry was a man venerated, disgraced and redeemed in a political career that spanned four decades and included four terms as mayor and six months in prison on drug charges.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Marion S. Barry Jr. was a man who knew how to make an entrance, even when he was late to church.

headline: Where Oil and Politics Mix
abstract: After an unusual land deal, a giant spill and a tanker-train explosion, anxiety began to ripple across the North Dakota prairie.
lead_paragraph: After an unusual land deal, a giant spill and a tanker-train explosion, anxiety began to ripple across the North Dakota prairie.

headline: Authors Sign Up to Raise Barnes & Noble’s Black Friday Sales
abstract: The struggling chain recruited 100 prominent authors, including Donna Tartt, David Mitchell and Dan Brown, to each autograph about 5,000 copies of their latest books, which will be on sale at its stores nationwide.
lead_paragraph: In an effort to increase holiday sales, which have fallen for the last two seasons, Barnes & Noble is hoping to lure customers into stores this Black Friday with something book lovers cannot download: signed copies.

headline: Call Out the Patricide Squad
abstract: “A Particle of Dread (Oedipus Variations),” the new play by Sam Shepard, opened on Sunday night at the Pershing Square Signature Center.
lead_paragraph: Though there’s no discounting the exponential possibilities of television spinoffs, it seems unlikely that a series called “CSI: Ancient Thebes”  will be appearing on your screens anytime soon. If you feel this leaves a yawning vacuum in your crime-show-addicted life, you might want to take a look at “A Particle of Dread (Oedipus Variations),” the new play by Sam Shepard that opened on Sunday night at the Pershing Square Signature Center.

headline: ‘The Newsroom’ Recap: Enter the Love Police
abstract: In a series full of office romances, who should pair off with whom?
lead_paragraph: Season 3, Episode 22: “Main Justice”

headline: ‘Homeland’ Recap: Was Saul Heroic? Or Something Else?
abstract: Carrie, at least, seems to have grown up.
lead_paragraph: Season 4, Episode 9: “There’s Something Else Going On”

headline: In Partisan Washington, Health Law Faces Grave Legal Technicalities
abstract: The Affordable Care Act faces grave danger because legislative repair work that was once routine has grown impossible.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In March 1997, two congressmen proposed a welfare law so detailed that it had 77 sections. Within a month it sailed through the House by voice vote.

headline: A Funeral for a Father
abstract: Gary Kwok, whose father, Wai Kuen Kwok, was killed when he was pushed off a Bronx subway platform into the path of an oncoming subway train on Nov. 16, led a funeral procession for him on Mulberry Street in Chinatown in Manhattan on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Gary Kwok, whose father, Wai Kuen Kwok, was killed when he was pushed off a Bronx subway platform into the path of an oncoming subway train on Nov. 16, led a funeral procession for him on Mulberry Street in Chinatown in Manhattan on Sunday.

headline: Slate’s Former Top Editor Takes Helm at Travel Site
abstract: David Plotz charted a course for a long quest to find new career after leaving Slate, but quickly arrived at the travel website Atlas Obscura.
lead_paragraph: As editor in chief of the pioneering online magazine Slate, David Plotz ran his own group of well-regarded writers, had a platform for podcasting and earned health insurance.

headline: Snow Brings Days of Tumult for Residents of Nursing Home Near Buffalo
abstract: A sagging ceiling prompted the evacuation of 177 frail elderly residents, who spent hours in a former shopping mall before being moved to temporary locations.
lead_paragraph: BUFFALO — Three days after one of their own died during a snow evacuation, residents of the Garden Gate Health Care Facility outside Buffalo were still wondering who she was and how it happened.

headline: Private Oncologists Being Forced Out, Leaving Patients to Face Higher Bills
abstract: Oncologists say they are being forced to sell or close their practices because insurers have reduced payments to them and because drugs are so expensive.
lead_paragraph: When Dr. Jeffery Ward, a cancer specialist, and his partners sold their private practice to the Swedish Medical Center in Seattle, the hospital built them a new office suite 50 yards from the old place. The practice was bigger, but Dr. Ward saw the same patients and provided chemotherapy just like before. On the surface, nothing had changed but the setting.

headline: Ray Sadecki, Who Helped Cardinals Win World Series, Dies at 73
abstract: Sadecki, a left-handed pitcher, won 135 games in his 18 seasons in the major leagues, finishing his career with the Mets.
lead_paragraph: Ray Sadecki, a pitcher who won 135 games during 18 seasons in the major leagues — including 20 wins with the St. Louis Cardinals in 1964, when he helped lead them to victory in the World Series — died on Nov. 17 in Mesa, Ariz. He was 73.

headline: Popular Demand
abstract: As the holiday shopping season begins, news and commentary about retailers soar. To devise the media value of online activity, a dollar value is assigned as if companies had bought ads. Target finished in the top spot.
lead_paragraph: As the holiday shopping season begins, news and commentary about retailers soar. To devise the media value of online activity, a dollar value is assigned as if companies had bought ads. Target finished in the top spot.

headline: ‘The Good Wife’ Recap: Alicia, the Scary Parent
abstract: And does anyone really think Cary is going to jail?
lead_paragraph: Season 6, Episode 10: “The Trial”

headline: Thanksgiving Holiday Closings in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut
abstract: Transit schedules, parking rules and various closings that will take effect on Thanksgiving.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK

headline: Debbie Dingell Ready for Spotlight as Her Husband, the ‘Dean’ of Congress, Steps Aside
abstract: As the wife of the longest-serving congressman in American history, Debbie Dingell has long been her husband’s fiercest protector. Now, she is Representative-elect Dingell.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the well-connected wife of the longest-serving congressman in American history, Debbie Dingell has long been her husband’s fiercest protector. So when Representative John D. Dingell Jr., the famously irascible Michigan Democrat, announced in February that he would retire after nearly 60 years, he gave her a tender shout-out.

headline: Well-Rested Rangers Post Second Straight Shutout
abstract: The Canadiens came into Madison Square Garden playing exceptional hockey, but the Rangers scored five unanswered goals against them.
lead_paragraph: The Montreal Canadiens skated onto the ice at Madison Square Garden on Sunday having won 16 of their first 22 games, a feat they last accomplished more than 50 years ago. They also arrived bent on avenging their six-game loss to the Rangers in May in the Eastern Conference finals.

headline: Bronx Library May Get a New Neighbor: Another Library
abstract: Putting a New York Public Library branch next to the Huntington Free Library and Reading Room is part of an $18 million plan that could help revitalize Westchester Square, a once-thriving commercial hub.
lead_paragraph: The red brick library in the Bronx was built in the early 1880s with a $15,000 bequest from Peter Van Schaick, a wealthy tobacco merchant who wanted to honor his late wife with a free reading room.

headline: Why Are Rockefellers Moving From 30 Rock? ‘We Got a Deal’
abstract: In 2000, the Rockefellers sold off 30 Rock, though they retained their presence in the building by keeping one floor as a rented space. Now, they have decided to leave the building entirely.
lead_paragraph: Ever since it opened in 1933, a 70-story limestone skyscraper has towered over mid-Manhattan as a symbol of global capitalism and of a prolific American family that remains synonymous with prodigious wealth.

headline: Security With a Portable Typewriter
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: The owner of a 1952 Smith Corona felt safer after getting it repaired, knowing that if the apocalypse comes, he can still type.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Marina Abramovic and Daniel Libeskind Collaborate on Furniture
abstract: The artist and the architect have teamed up to create a limited-edition table, which will be used in one of her performance acts.
lead_paragraph: Marina Abramovic has joined forces with the architect Daniel Libeskind and the furniture design firm Moroso to create a limited-edition table from her ongoing “Counting the Rice” performance, in which participants are instructed to sit down and separate lentils from rice for at least six hours while keeping a tally. “During the process, people go through many emotions,” Abramovic says. “They get bored, they get angry and then they have a feeling of timelessness.” The futuristic concrete pew recalls the oblique angles often seen in Libeskind’s work while reflecting the austerity of the performance. Any sense of asceticism, however, ends there — the first of 30 tables, which are being sold at auction, went for roughly $105,053 this fall at Fondation Beyeler in Basel.

headline: The New Marylebone
abstract: The quiet neighborhood has turned into London’s latest culinary destination.
lead_paragraph: Since the February opening of André Balazs’s Chiltern Firehouse — and its celebrity-packed restaurant — the quiet neighborhood of Marylebone has turned into London’s latest culinary destination. Away from the paparazzi, there’s Fischer’s, a new Viennese-style cafe from the restaurateurs behind the beloved Wolseley and the just-launched Beaumont Hotel. Nearby, at Beast, diners feast on Norwegian crab and Nebraskan steak around candelabra-topped communal tables set underground. For upscale Southern comfort, the Lockhart serves fried chicken with friggitelli peppers, while Carousel is the new headquarters of Shuttlecock Inc, which stages culinary events with themes like Canada Day and the golden age of air travel. And next spring, the crew behind Clerkenwell’s eccentric Zetter Townhouse will unveil a second location in the area, with a curiosity-filled lounge serving molecular cocktails and modern bistro fare.

headline: Word of the Day | ecclesiastic
abstract: This word has appeared in three New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: ecclesiastic •\i-ˌkle-ze-ˈas-tik\• adjective and noun

headline: What’s On TV Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 12:15 P.M. (Sundance) SIDEWAYS (2004) A divorced, unpublished writer (Paul Giamatti) and his best friend (Thomas Haden Church, above right, with Mr. Giamatti), a narcissistic actor about to marry for the first time, meet the women (Virginia Madsen and Sandra Oh) who will rock their worlds while touring California’s wine country. Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis said this film, from Alexander Payne, who won an Oscar with Jim Taylor for best adapted screenplay, was “deeply controlled, played with restraint and microscopic attention to detail.”

headline: A Great Catch, but a Victory Is Just Out of Reach
abstract: Odell Beckham Jr.'s remarkable one-handed touchdown reception wasn’t enough to save the Giants in a loss to Dallas.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Odell Beckham Jr. raised his right hand and turned the sticky palm of his Nike XXL Vapor Jet glove toward the spiraling football descending in his direction.

headline: Souvenirs of a Literary Alchemist
abstract: Gabriel García Márquez’s archive has been acquired by the University of Texas and includes manuscripts, correspondence, photos and personal artifacts related to his important books.
lead_paragraph: Gabriel García Márquez, who died in April at 87, was a strong critic of American imperialism who was banned from entry to the United States for decades, even after “One Hundred Years of Solitude” vaulted him to international celebrity and, in 1982, the Nobel Prize in Literature.

headline: Corrections: November 24, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on November 24, 2014.
lead_paragraph: NATIONAL

headline: Beijing Considers How to Harness the Wind to Blow Away Pollution
abstract: In a plan inspired by research on urban heat islands, city planners are looking at ways to create corridors that encourage wind flow through the Chinese capital.
lead_paragraph: When Beijing experiences bouts of pollution that blacken the skies and burn the lungs, residents often joke that the Chinese capital needs to build giant fans to clear out the toxic air. Mountains to the north and west help trap smog in the city, and a stiff breeze from Mongolia is the surest way to ensure somewhat cleaner air.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Imagining a Glacier National Park Without Glaciers
abstract: How quickly is the landscape and ecosystem at Glacier National Park changing, and why?
lead_paragraph: In “Climate Change Threatens to Strip the Identity of Glacier National Park,” Michael Wines writes about decreasing glaciers in the Rocky Mountains.

headline: Test Yourself | A History of the Presidential Turkey Pardon
abstract: Can you choose the best word to complete each blank?
lead_paragraph: Below are six paragraphs from the Nov. 27, 2013, article “A History of the Presidential Turkey Pardon.”

headline: Do Fans Put Too Much Pressure on Their Favorite Professional Athletes?
abstract: What are the standards to which fans hold professional athletes and are those standards ever unrealistic?
lead_paragraph: Heroes. Role models. Inspirations. These are just some of the ways sports fans think about their favorite players.

headline: Choosing to Look at ‘War Porn’
abstract: Some of the most gruesome images of war, Christoph Bangert argues, should not be hidden, but seen so viewers can get a full documenting of the costs of war.
lead_paragraph: Christoph Bangert has covered war and conflict in Afghanistan, Iraq and Gaza, often for The New York Times. His recently published book, “War Porn” (Kehrer Verlag), includes many explicit images and delves into questions of morality and censorship in conflict photography. His conversation with James Estrin has been edited.

headline: Onex to Pay Up to $4.64 Billion for Swiss Packaging Firm SIG Combibloc
abstract: SIG Combibloc, one of the world’s largest manufacturers of carton packaging for the food and beverage industry, has been part of Rank Group of New Zealand since 2007.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Toronto-based private equity firm Onex Corporation said on Monday that it had agreed to pay up to 3.75 billion euros, or about $4.64 billion, for the SIG Combibloc Group, a Swiss packaging company.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Tales of Marion Barry’s City
abstract: Marion Barry is gone, but the stories about the former Washington mayor may never die.
lead_paragraph: Whether you loved him or loathed him, knew him well or not at all, anybody who came across Marion S. Barry Jr., the former mayor of Washington, had a story to tell.

headline: New York Today: Lots of Weather
abstract: Monday: warm rain and high winds, a snowy Thanksgiving Eve, a civil rights investigation of a police shooting, and protecting a two-foot salamander.
lead_paragraph: Mother Nature is holding a pre-holiday weather sale this week: freakish warmth, wind, rain, snow — all this can, and will, be yours.

headline: Swiss Museum Accepts Art Trove Amassed Under Nazis
abstract: In agreeing to take the gift of more than 1,000 works, the Kunstmuseum Bern said it would ensure that any seized art in the trove was returned to its rightful owner.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — A Swiss museum will accept the bequest of an immense trove of art amassed by a Nazi-era art dealer, but will ensure that any looted art in the trove is returned to its rightful owner, museum officials said on Monday.

headline: Factions Seeking Escalation Put Pressure on Hong Kong Protest
abstract: Some demonstrators have grown impatient with the milder path and argue that only stronger action can win concessions from the Hong Kong government.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Most mornings for weeks, in one of the pro-democracy protest camps here, Wong Yeung-tat has berated, mocked and goaded the government and, increasingly, the student protest leaders and democratic politicians he deems too timid.

headline: Peace Effort With Taliban Is Excluding Women, Report Says
abstract: The document by Oxfam echoes the worries of many female leaders that a deal for peace with religiously conservative insurgents will wipe out women’s gains.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Afghan women have been systematically excluded from the government’s efforts to start peace talks with the Taliban, according to a report released on Monday by the international aid group Oxfam.

headline: 1939: France Recalls War Premier Georges Clemenceau
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: In 1939, the French commemorate the death of Georges Clemenceau.
lead_paragraph: Memories of Georges Clemenceau, France’s great War Premier, stirred many hearts on the tenth anniversary of the ‘‘Tiger’s’’ death yesterday. Facing a new German aggression, Frenchmen thought tenderly of the grim, old man who remained undaunted by adversity or internal menaces and summed up his policy in the famous words: ‘‘Je fais la guerre.’’ As Premier, Clemenceau made many trips to the front. Most of them were undertaken quite suddenly, without the knowledge of anyone except Alfred Brabant, his faithful chauffeur. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Nov. 25, 1939

headline: A Business Owner Blames Search Engines for Lost Sales
abstract: A lawsuit by Baldino’s Lock & Key in Virginia claims that search engines profit from knowingly listing unlicensed locksmiths.
lead_paragraph: At its peak, in 2007, Baldino’s Lock & Key in Lorton, Va., had annual sales of about $6.7 million, according to its owner, Mark Baldino, who has worked in the family locksmith business since he was in fifth grade. But beginning in 2008, sales started to decline, he said, falling to about $4.7 million in 2013.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Nov. 24, 2014
abstract: On Mondays, we publish a Times photo without a caption, headline or other information about its origins. Join the conversation by posting about what you see, and why. A live discussion is offered from 9 a.m. to 2 p.m. Eastern time.
lead_paragraph: Updated: Nov. 25, 2014

headline: Election Was Rough for Democrats. It Was Worse for West Virginia Democrats.
abstract: The switch started years ago, and now West Virginia seems to have completed the journey from being a Democratic-dominated state to a Republican one.
lead_paragraph: Election night was bad for Democrats all over the country, but arguably there were few states where it was worse for their future — and better for Republicans — than in West Virginia.

headline: Daily Report: Silicon Valley Responds to Obama’s Immigration Order
abstract: Despite drawbacks of the president’s executive order, some immigrants working in technology said it could make work in the United States easier.
lead_paragraph: Silicon Valley’s constant stream of new apps and services depends on hundreds of thousands of foreign-born engineers to help create them. So the technology industry has been pushing for changes to the nation’s immigration policy for more than a decade to allow more skilled workers into the country, Vindu Goel reports.

headline: British Telecommunications Giant BT Says It Is in Talks to Acquire O2
abstract: In a brief statement, BT said it was in discussions with shareholders of two of Britain’s mobile operators, including O2, about a possible takeover.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British telecommunications giant BT said on Monday that it was in early-stage takeover talks with O2, the British cellphone carrier owned by the Spanish company Telefónica.

headline: U.S. and Allies Extend Iran Nuclear Talks by 7 Months
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry says “new ideas surfaced,” as a temporary agreement remains in place and Iran gets $5 billion more in sanctions relief.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA — A yearlong effort to reach an enduring accord with Iran to dismantle large parts of its nuclear infrastructure fell short on Monday, forcing the United States and its allies to declare a seven-month extension, but with no clear indication of why they think they can ultimately overcome the political obstacles that have so far blocked a deal.

headline: Today in Politics
abstract: Republicans show no sign of leaving Benghazi behind and Democrats balk at a bipartisan tax deal.
lead_paragraph: Republicans Dismiss a Benghazi Report Rebutting Criticisms

headline: Aviva Shares Off Nearly 5 Percent After Takeover Bid for Rival
abstract: The British insurer said late on Friday that it had a preliminary agreement to acquire Friends Life Group in an all-share deal worth about $8.8 billion that would create Britain’s largest life insurer.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Shares of the British insurer Aviva declined nearly 5 percent in early trading on Monday after it reached a preliminary agreement to acquire its rival Friends Life Group in an all-share deal worth about 5.6 billion pounds, or about $8.8 billion.

headline: Morning Agenda: Challenges for the Fed
abstract: Last week was a rough one for the Federal Reserve. | Paul J. Taubman continues to poach talent from Morgan Stanley, his former employer. | Mathew Martoma has started his nine-year prison term for insider trading.
