lead_paragraph: ROUGH WEEK REVEALS CHALLENGES FOR THE FED | Last week was not a good one for the Federal Reserve, but it wasn’t so bad for anyone interested in understanding how the secretive institution works, Gretchen Morgenson writes in the Fair Game column. “It was fascinating to learn last week that the Fed is embarking on a soul-searching campaign,” she writes. Its inspector general will take up the “astonishing questions of whether the Fed’s big-bank examiners have what they need to do their jobs and whether they receive the support of their superiors when they challenge bank practices.”

headline: If Apple Will Poach From Fashion, Then Fashion Will Follow Suit
abstract: A former vice president at Apple has been consulting for the online retailer Net-a-Porter.
lead_paragraph: Much has been made of Apple’s snatching up fashion executives, whether the Burberry chief executive Angela Ahrendts or the former Saint Laurent chief executive Paul Deneve. Given the current love affair between the technology and fashion industries, it’s hard not to wonder why fashion never figured out that it might want to give the Silicon Valley behemoth a dose of its own medicine.

headline: Daily Clip Report
abstract: Daily Clip Report is a collection of articles about the media and The Times that is emailed each day to senior executives and newsroom managers here.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

headline: Calling Out Bill Cosby’s Media Enablers, Including Myself
abstract: Many journalists and biographers were in the know about the sexual assault accusations against Mr. Cosby. So what took so long for the story to become national news?
lead_paragraph: With public revulsion rising in response to snowballing accusations that Bill Cosby victimized women in serial fashion throughout his trailblazing career, the response from those in the know has been: What took so long?

headline: When Health Coverage Expansion Means Longer Waits for a Doctor
abstract: With more patients seeking care and the same number of providers, the outcome seems obvious. Yet research points to possible solutions.
lead_paragraph: One concern about the Affordable Care Act is that as more Americans get health insurance and start using it, those who already have coverage will have to wait longer for care.

headline: The Daily Gift: Subtly Scented Perfume Oil for Superchic Ladies
abstract: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.
lead_paragraph: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.

headline: Hagel Resigns Under Pressure as Global Crises Test Pentagon
abstract: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel’s passivity and lack of support in President Obama’s inner circle proved too much for an administration that found itself back on a war footing.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel resigned under pressure on Monday after President Obama determined that he had to shake up his national security team in the face of escalating conflicts overseas and hawkish Republicans reasserting themselves on Capitol Hill.

headline: Parents Find Themselves in the Limelight
abstract: It has been a whirlwind three months for Lesley McSpadden and Michael Brown Sr., the parents of Michael Brown Jr., and one of their lawyers said, while grieving for their son, they are also asking for justice and are pushing for systemic change.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — They have stood on stage at the BET Hip Hop Awards, met with United Nations officials in Geneva and spoken with supporters at the spot where their son was shot dead.

headline: ‘Casablanca’ Piano Sells for $3.4 Million at Bonhams
abstract: The painted upright in Rick’s Café Américain that was immortalized in the movie was among the items sold on Monday in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: The letters of transit — “signed by General de Gaulle, cannot be rescinded, not even questioned” — were hidden under its unusual hinged lid. It is golden yellow with touches of green and gold, a surprise to people who know it only from its black-and-white adolescence. It has a wad of chewing gum in a place where a wad of chewing gum really should not be.

headline: 2 Foreign Soldiers Are Said to Have Been Killed in Afghanistan
abstract: The attack, reported by Afghan officials, occurred when a bomb hidden in the median strip of an avenue in the capital went off.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — A bomb hidden in the median strip of an avenue in Kabul was detonated as a convoy of coalition troops passed by Monday morning, apparently killing two foreign soldiers, according to reports from Afghan officials.

headline: 1964: U.S. Consul Describes Massacre
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: A diplomat describes the Stanleyville massacre in 1964.
lead_paragraph: LEOPOLDVILLE, Congo — “When the rebels opened fire indiscriminately into the crowd they had forced onto the pavement, we jumped for cover wherever we found it.” This is how U.S. Consul Michael Hoyt described the Stanleyville massacre when he returned here today [Nov. 24] only a few hours after Belgian paratroopers entered the rebel-held city. The horror began when more than 250 hostages held in the Victoria Hotel were herded into Stanleyville’s main street. The rebels opened fire when shooting was heard at the airport. “It was wild shooting with women and children as likely to be hit as anyone,” said one refugee. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Nov. 25, 1964

headline: In Same-Sex Marriage Calculation, Justices May See Golden Ratio
abstract: Same-sex marriage will be banned in 15 states at most if the Supreme Court takes up the question this term or next. That could be an important number.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Constitution is not a math problem, but numbers can play a role in the Supreme Court’s calculations.

headline: A Persuasive Chart Showing How Persuasive Charts Are
abstract: A study finds that taking the same information and also showing it as a chart makes a presentation much more convincing.
lead_paragraph: Here at The Upshot, we love charts. And I have a chart to explain why.

headline: Time to Weigh Limits on Bankruptcy Filings
abstract: The Chapter 11 filing by Aereo prompts a larger question of whether bankruptcy courts should actively police debtors’ motives for filing cases, writes Stephen J. Lubben in the In Debt column.
lead_paragraph: Aereo, the digital video service that threatened to disrupt the television industry, has filed for bankruptcy. Given that the Supreme Court had ruled its entire business model illegal, one question may be, what took so long?

headline: Confession in Etan Patz Case Can Be Used at Trial, Judge Rules
abstract: The decision clears the way for a jury to decide if Pedro Hernandez is guilty of one of New York City’s most infamous crimes.
lead_paragraph: The confession of a man who told the police he strangled Etan Patz in 1979 can be admitted as evidence at his trial, a judge ruled on Monday.

headline: International Monitor’s Report on Chemical Weapons Recovery in Iraq
abstract: A report prepared by the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons detailed the recovery and destruction of 4,530 aging chemical weapons by American forces in Iraq from May 2004 through February 2009.
lead_paragraph: A report prepared by the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons detailed the recovery and destruction of 4,530 aging chemical weapons by American forces in Iraq from May 2004 through February 2009.

headline: A Quiet Wedding for Darren Wilson
abstract: Darren Wilson, the officer who fatally shot 18-year-old Michael Brown in August, applied last month for a marriage license.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — Darren Wilson, the officer who fatally shot 18-year-old Michael Brown in August, has been out of public sight ever since. Yet last month, he stepped into a St. Louis County office building, gave his name and applied for a marriage license.

headline: Catching the Catch on Camera
abstract: Those who saw still photographs of Giants receiver Odell Beckham Jr.'s catch on Sunday night might have wondered: How did the photographer capture that?
lead_paragraph: Those who saw Odell Beckham Jr.'s acrobatic catch live on Sunday night at MetLife Stadium probably could not fully appreciate it in real time. Those who saw it on video — millions, once the awe spread on social media — were dazzled by his seemingly impossible body control. And those who saw still photographs of the catch might have wondered, how did the photographer capture that?

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
abstract: Discovering the voice of Bravo, and readers react to an American Airlines campaign.
lead_paragraph: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
abstract: Alcon Surgical named HCB Health of Austin, Tex., its agency of record for its ophthalmic surgical brands.
lead_paragraph: Alcon Surgical, a division of Alcon, which has its United States headquarters in Fort Worth, expanded its relationship with HCB Health, Austin, Tex., by naming HCB Health as global and United States agency of record for its ophthalmic surgical brands, involving more than 20 brands in more than 50 countries. Billings were not disclosed. HCB Health had previously handled many marketing duties for Alcon Surgical, along with agencies that worked on a project basis.

headline: For Met Museum, a Major Gift of Works by African-American Artists From the South
abstract: The gift to the Metropolitan Museum of Art includes works by Thornton Dial and quilts made by the Gee’s Bend quilters of Alabama.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Museum of Art announced Monday that it had received a major gift of 20th-century works by African-American artists from the South, including 10 pieces by Thornton Dial and 20 important quilts made by the Gee’s Bend quilters of Alabama.

headline: A Look at Possible Contenders for Defense Secretary
abstract: Speculation on a possible replacement for Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel began even before his resignation was reported.
lead_paragraph: Speculation on a possible replacement for Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel, who is stepping down under pressure, began even before his resignation was reported by The Times.

headline: Can Brain Science Be Dangerous?
abstract: When it’s used inaccurately to fight problems like poverty, some critics fear neuroscience could hurt more than it helps.
lead_paragraph: The idea that poverty can change the brain has gotten significant attention recently, and not just from those lay readers (a minority, according to recent research) who spend a lot of time thinking about neuroscience. Policy makers and others have begun to apply neuroscientific principles to their thinking about poverty — and some say this could end up harming poor people rather than helping.

headline: Color Outside the Lines
abstract: This season, smeared, spotted and splattered clothing paints a pretty picture.
lead_paragraph: This season, smeared, spotted and splattered clothing paints a pretty picture.

headline: No Comment Necessary: Women ‘Created Differently’
abstract: The president of Turkey said “you cannot put women and men on an equal footing.”
lead_paragraph: Recep Tayyip Erdogan, the president of Turkey, is not a feminist.

headline: Fed’s New ‘Cop on the Beat’ Role Puts It in a Bind
abstract: The Fed has to balance the conflicting roles it plays as an overseer of the banks and as a law enforcement agency pursuing misconduct, Peter J. Henning writes in the White Collar Watch column.
lead_paragraph: Unlike the happy ending for George Bailey, the banker in “It’s a Wonderful Life,” last week was not pleasant for Wall Street banks and their primary regulator, the Federal Reserve. Pilloried at congressional hearings and the subject of a report in The New York Times about leaked confidential information, the Fed faces the question of whether it can ever hope to effectively control these giant financial institutions.

headline: Americans Relatively Sanguine About Online Privacy, Study Says
abstract: Sixty-two percent of American respondents told Ipsos, a polling firm, that they were more concerned about online privacy now than they were a year ago. By comparison, that worry had increased for 83 percent of respondents in Brazil, India and Nigeria during the same period.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — A survey released on Monday suggests that revelations about government online snooping provided by Edward Snowden did not raise concerns about online privacy to the same degree in the United States as in other countries. But it also indicates that a majority of Americans are worried about the security of personal information.

headline: Woman Cleared in Death Tied to G.M.’s Faulty Ignition Switch
abstract: Ten years after a crash that killed a passenger, a Texas woman’s guilty plea was overturned after it became clear that the switch was to blame.
lead_paragraph: Candice Anderson received the bittersweet news Monday in a Texas courtroom, fighting back tears, and her arm around the mother of the boyfriend she had felt responsible for killing in a car crash 10 years ago.

headline: In the Hamptons, a Fight Over Land Is Also One Over Water
abstract: A landowner wants to sell wooded lots to the Town of East Hampton to keep the land undeveloped and the aquifer pristine, but the previous owner’s family may stop the sale.
lead_paragraph: AMAGANSETT, N.Y. — It is not just the owls and crickets at night and the waves crashing off in the distance that make Alexander Peters so fond of his longtime second home, here among the East End woods. There is also the water that runs beneath his land and up through his taps.

headline: A 19th-Century-Style ‘Christmas Carol’ on the Upper East Side
abstract: A new performance of the Dickens Christmas classic recreates a 19th-century-style salon performance.
lead_paragraph: “A Christmas Carol,” the evergreen Dickens tale, has had a long afterlife, with a hefty catalog of film and stage adaptations, operas and even a cartoon musical version starring Mr. Magoo (with a score by Jule Styne and Bob Merrill). But even if you have a favorite version that you revisit every year – say, “Scrooge,” the magnificent 1951 film starring Alastair Sim, or perhaps the book itself – the Origin Theater has a production that might cut through the competition.

headline: Bunny’s Grand Finale: Auctions Draw $218 Million for Library
abstract: Home furnishings, from a child’s chair to rare porcelains, from the homes of Rachel Lambert Mellon, fetched more than $14 million.
lead_paragraph: When the hammer fell for the final time at Sotheby’s on Sunday night about 9 p.m., the collection of Rachel Lambert Mellon, known as Bunny, had been viewed by more than 5,000 visitors at the auction house, sold 98 percent of its 1,551 lots, and fetched a total of $218 million — more than double its $100 million estimate.

headline: Ian Stewart Presents: Dr. Watsup, Hemlock Soames and Clueless!
abstract: Can you crack this clueless puzzle from best-selling author Ian Stewart’s latest book, Professor Stewart’s Casebook of Mathematical Mysteries?
lead_paragraph: This week we take on a challenge from the acclaimed mathematician and best-selling author, Ian Stewart. The conundrum appears in his most recent book: “Professor Stewart’s Casebook of Mathematical Mysteries,” which follows the adventures of detective Hemlock Soames and his sidekick, Dr. John Watsup as they explore a range of mysteries including the hound of the basketballs, the affair of the above-average driver, and the enigma of the versatile tile.

headline: How to Talk About Race Without Talking About Race
abstract: The transformation of two words, “bro” and “basic,” reveals how difficult it is for Americans to talk about white people and white subcultures.
lead_paragraph: Way back when, “basic” was a computer language and “bro” was a greeting.

headline: Obama Praises Hagel at Resignation
abstract: President Obama called Chuck Hagel “no ordinary secretary of defense” during a news conference at which Mr. Hagel announced his resignation.
lead_paragraph: President Obama called Chuck Hagel “no ordinary secretary of defense” during a news conference at which Mr. Hagel announced his resignation.

headline: Flavors of Brazil in Bahia
abstract: The Uxua Casa Hotel & Spain Brazil is offering a cooking-centric stay.
lead_paragraph: The new Taste of Trancoso package at Uxua Casa Hotel & Spa in Bahia, the coastal Brazilian state, gives guests a chance to experience the local cuisine from several sources.

headline: An Open Letter to the Smolian Family
abstract: A letter sent by Hamptons environmental groups and activists calling for the Smolian family to allow the sale of woodlands in Amagansett, N.Y., to the town for preservation.
lead_paragraph: A letter sent by Hamptons environmental groups and activists calling for the Smolian family to allow the sale of woodlands in Amagansett, N.Y., to the town for preservation.

headline: Further Strains in Unresolved War Between Armenia and Azerbaijan Over Disputed Territory
abstract: Armenia announced funerals for three soldiers killed by Azerbaijan forces who downed a helicopter over Nagorno-Karabakh, the focus of their conflict.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Armenia announced on Monday ceremonial funerals for three soldiers killed this month when Azerbaijani forces shot down a helicopter in the fiercely disputed territory of Nagorno-Karabakh, an event that signaled a grave escalation in the more than 25-year-long conflict.

headline: Yik Yak, an Anonymous Messaging Start-Up, Said to Raise $62 Million
abstract: The round is the third round of venture capital fund-raising for Yik Yak in seven months, bringing the total amount of money raised to about $73 million.
lead_paragraph: Yik Yak, an anonymous messaging app, has closed a $62 million round of financing led by Sequoia Capital, a Silicon Valley venture capital firm, according to a person close to the deal.

headline: Taking the Long View of, Well, ‘The View’
abstract: In her “Me, My Mouth & I” routine, Joy Behar’s humor comes through on subjects like sex, “The View” and her upbringing in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: “She was way too divisive and loud among other things,” a commenter using the name juneinct posted in 2013 under an article on Joy Behar leaving “The View,” the ABC daytime talk show. “If she never appeared in public again, I would be extremely happy.”

headline: Low Vitamin D Tied to Higher Death Risk
abstract: A new study provides persuasive evidence that low serum vitamin D itself increases the risk of death.
lead_paragraph: Many observational studies suggest that low vitamin D levels are associated with an increased risk for disease, but it is not clear if low vitamin D is a cause or an effect of poor health. Now a new study, using a technique called Mendelian randomization, provides persuasive evidence that low serum vitamin D itself increases the risk of death.

headline: Symantec Discovers ‘Regin’ Spy Code Lurking on Computer Networks
abstract: The security company released a report Sunday night indicating that a powerful program that could only have been created by a “nation state” has been finding its way into computer systems for six years.
lead_paragraph: Security researchers say they have discovered a sophisticated piece of malicious code spying on researchers, governments, businesses, and critical telecommunications infrastructure since 2008.

headline: Bringing ‘Rent’ to Cuba
abstract: Havana will see its first full-fledged Broadway musical production in five decades, with a run of Jonathan Larson’s “Rent” starting in December.
lead_paragraph: Havana once had a thriving musical theater tradition, but since the revolution of 1959, fully staged shows have been rare in Cuba, and Broadway hits have been entirely absent. But that may be changing.

headline: Hagel Resigning as Defense Secretary
abstract: Chuck Hagel, whose resignation as defense secretary was announced Monday, said he would stay in the job and support the president until his successor was confirmed.
lead_paragraph: Chuck Hagel, whose resignation as defense secretary was announced Monday, said he would stay in the job and support the president until his successor was confirmed.

headline: Hey, Brothers, Can You Spare a Cough Drop?
abstract: A venerable cough drop brand that had all but disappeared tries a reintroduction and product expansion.
lead_paragraph: What is it with fraternal ties and ticklish throats? First came a revival last year of the venerable Pine Bros. brand of glycerin cough drops, rebranded as Pine Bros. Softish Throat Relief and promoted in commercials that featured Martha Stewart. Now, the vintage Smith Brothers brand of cough drops is poised to try a comeback, keeping its familiar brand symbol of a pair of bearded brothers and expanding into a line of health and wellness products.

headline: Man Arrested Near White House Pleads Guilty to Gun Charges
abstract: The man who was arrested last week near the White House with a hunting rifle and ammunition in his car, pled guilty today to misdemeanor weapons charges.
lead_paragraph: Renae Kapheim, who was arrested last week near the White House with a hunting rifle and ammunition in his car, pleaded guilty on Monday to misdemeanor charges of possession of an unregistered firearm and unlawful possession of ammunition.

headline: PCOS: An Infertility Issue That Is Little Understood
abstract: Polycystic ovarian syndrome affects as many as 10 percent of women of childbearing age, but its underlying cause is not fully understood and misdiagnosis can result in ineffective treatment.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes medical syndromes are named long before they are fully understood.

headline: Answering the Hard Questions on the A.C.A.: Which Employees Must Be Covered?
abstract: How can an employer know whether a worker with fluctuating hours will be entitled to insurance in advance of a given month?
lead_paragraph: Today, we return to our series attempting to answer questions about how the Affordable Care Act will affect small businesses. In our last installment, we addressed how to determine whether a business is subject to the law’s employer mandate. The next question is obvious: If a business is subject to the mandate, to which employees must it offer insurance in order to avoid the penalty?

headline: Mitch McConnell as Human Resources Officer
abstract: Senator Mitch McConnell has a high bar for the next defense secretary.
lead_paragraph: Senator Mitch McConnell doesn’t know who the next defense secretary will be, but that person evidently faces a tall order.

headline: You Can Freeze Your Eggs. You Can’t Freeze Time.
abstract: Apple and Facebook have started a useful conversation with the novel perk of enabling employees to freeze their eggs. But I have a message for women considering this option: it may not work.
lead_paragraph: Apple and Facebook have started a useful conversation with the novel perk of enabling employees to freeze their eggs. Other companies, from banks to Silicon Valley giants like Google, are said to be considering doing the same. Experts and analysts have speculated about the companies’ nefarious motives, how the new benefit will send the message that women should focus on work and delay having children.

headline: If Giving Feels So Good, Why Don’t We Do It?
abstract: For some people, but not everyone, life just seems better after giving to others.
lead_paragraph: In the Mormon Church, the first Sunday of each month is called Fast Sunday. As my kids have pointed out, however, it’s not because it goes by faster than any other Sunday. Quite the opposite, in fact.

headline: Finra Fines Citigroup Over Acts by Analysts
abstract: Citigroup agreed to settle the case with Finra for $15 million without admitting or denying the accusations, which involved interactions between the bank’s research analysts and its clients.
lead_paragraph: More than a decade after prosecutors cracked down on research analysts who served the interests of investment banks over the investing public, one firm at the center of that scandal — Citigroup — continued to blur the lines, according to a financial regulator.

headline: Neal Cassady’s Famous Lost Letter to Jack Kerouac to Be Auctioned
abstract: A 16,000-word letter that inspired Kerouac to rewrite “On the Road” has been found, and will be sold at auction in December.
lead_paragraph: The mythic, long-lost 1950 letter that inspired Jack Kerouac’s “On the Road” has been rescued from the dustbin of history — literally.

headline: Swiss Museum Discusses Nazi Art Trove
abstract: Christoph Schäublin, president of the Kunstmuseum Bern’s board of trustees, said they will accept works from the late Cornelius Gurlitt, whose trove included masterpieces looted by the Nazis.
lead_paragraph: Christoph Schäublin, president of the Kunstmuseum Bern’s board of trustees, said they will accept works from the late Cornelius Gurlitt, whose trove included masterpieces looted by the Nazis.

headline: Fairs in Amsterdam and Hong Kong, A New York Gallery Opens in the Caribbean and More from the Art Calendar
abstract: Plus, a calligraphy master on view in New York, photos of Soviet atomic test sites and more happenings to see in the week ahead.
lead_paragraph: T’s list of happenings worth visiting in the week ahead.

headline: Catching the Catch on Camera
abstract: Seven views from seven sports photographers that captured NY Giants Odell Beckham Jr.’s one-handed catch in Sunday’s game.
lead_paragraph: Seven views from seven sports photographers that captured NY Giants Odell Beckham Jr.’s one-handed catch in Sunday’s game.

headline: Kerry Announces Extension to Iran Talks
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry said officials have given themselves seven more months to reach an accord with Iran on its nuclear program, and that the talks had made “real and substantial progress.”
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State John Kerry said officials have given themselves seven more months to reach an accord with Iran on its nuclear program, and that the talks had made “real and substantial progress.”

headline: Staying Safe in Ferguson Protests
abstract: Taylor Payne was shot by the police with rubber bullets while protesting in the days after Michael Brown was killed in Ferguson. She’s worried about protester safety after a grand jury decision.
lead_paragraph: Taylor Payne was shot by the police with rubber bullets while protesting in the days after Michael Brown was killed in Ferguson. She’s worried about protester safety after a grand jury decision.

headline: From The Upshot: West Virginia’s Swing
abstract: The switch started years ago, and now West Virginia seems to have completed the journey from being a Democratic-dominated state to a Republican one.

headline: A Thanksgiving Table With Plenty of Emotional Room for Family
abstract: Loosen up on the controls for one day a year.
lead_paragraph: Living as I do with my parents, older brother, husband and two youngest children, I have to say that most Sunday evenings in our multigenerational home seem a lot like Thanksgiving. Sunday tends to be the night I cook a big dinner, as my older sister who lives nearby usually comes over that evening, as does a cousin or two and the odd visitor from out of town.

headline: Verbatim: Raised Voices
abstract: Joan Baggett, the assistant to the president for political affairs during Bill Clinton’s administration, described interactions with Hillary Clinton in a trove of recently released transcripts.
lead_paragraph: — Joan Baggett, assistant to the president for political affairs during Bill Clinton’s administration, said of Hillary Rodham Clinton. An interview of Ms. Baggett is part of a trove of transcripts from interviews with White House officials conducted in the early 2000s that shed light on the inner workings of Mr. Clinton’s White House.

headline: American Music Awards Red Carpet
abstract: Selena Gomez in Armani Privé, Jennifer Lopez in Reem Acra and Taylor Swift in custom Michael Kors were some of the standouts.
lead_paragraph: Selena Gomez in Armani Privé, Jennifer Lopez in Reem Acra and Taylor Swift in custom Michael Kors were some of the standouts.

headline: Finalists for Democratic National Convention Are Announced
abstract: The Democratic National Convention finalists for 2016 are Philadelphia, New York and Columbus, Ohio.
lead_paragraph: D.N.C. Picks New York City as a Finalist for Its 2016 Convention

headline: Protests Flare After Ferguson Police Officer Is Not Indicted
abstract: Darren Wilson was not charged in the fatal shooting of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Mo., which set off civil unrest over what protesters called a pattern of police brutality against young black men.
lead_paragraph: CLAYTON, Mo. — A St. Louis County grand jury has brought no criminal charges against Darren Wilson, a white police officer who fatally shot Michael Brown, an unarmed African-American teenager, more than three months ago in nearby Ferguson.

headline: Goldman to Disclose Profit It Made on Libyan Trades
abstract: The Libyan Investment Authority contends that trades made in 2008 were unfairly structured to make the bank a lot of money but leave the authority highly exposed.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Goldman Sachs will disclose how much it earned on a set of complex derivatives trades at the heart of a lawsuit brought by Libya’s sovereign wealth fund, the two parties decided before a hearing Monday.

headline: An Illustrated History of Great Films
abstract: In a new coffee-table tome, The Criterion Collection offers a retrospective of the past 30 years of contemporary covers it has commissioned for the classic movie titles it distributes.
lead_paragraph: Tucked into the back of “Criterion Designs,” a new coffee-table book from the Criterion Collection ($100), is a visual index of every cover the New York-based art-house and cinema video distribution company has ever produced. The tome, which will be released Nov. 25, celebrates the company’s 30th anniversary and its longstanding mission to “marry publishing and movies” for discerning fans of film.

headline: D.N.C. Picks New York City as a Finalist for Its 2016 Convention
abstract: The Democratic National Committee narrowed its list of possible presidential convention sites to three cities; the other contenders are Philadelphia and Columbus, Ohio.
lead_paragraph: New York City, vying to host the 2016 Democratic National Convention, has outlasted bids from the less-than-liberal states of Alabama and Arizona.

headline: BT in a Strong Position for Mobile M.&A.
abstract: The British fixed-line giant has a choice of two mobile networks to buy, O2 or EE, and few likely counterbidders, says Quentin Webb of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: BT is in a strong position for mobile mergers and acquisitions. It has shaken up British communications by moving into television and by preparing to start a novel mobile service of its own. Now the fixed-line giant finds itself with a choice of two wireless networks to buy, Telefónica’s O2 unit or Orange and Deutsche Telekom’s EE. There are few likely counter-bidders for either potential target.

headline: Art in a Whisky Glass, Neatly Explained
abstract: After having a Scotch years ago, a photographer saw beauty at the bottom. Then he got interested in the science behind the patterns.
lead_paragraph: Ernie Button, a photographer in Phoenix, found art at the bottom of a whisky glass. Howard A. Stone, a mechanical and aerospace engineering professor at Princeton, found the science in the art.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Hamilton Wins Formula One Title
abstract: Lewis Hamilton beat his teammate, Nico Rosberg, to win the drivers championship; Sam Bird won the Formula E race in Malaysia.
lead_paragraph: Lewis Hamilton, driving for the Mercedes team, won the season-ending Formula One race held in Abu Dhabi on Sunday evening, securing the 2014 championship title. It was Hamilton’s second drivers championship victory; he had also won the 2008 championship title. He lost the 2007 championship by a single point.

headline: Britain Plans to Expand Police Powers With Stronger Antiterrorism Legislation
abstract: The proposed measure would include travel restrictions and would make it illegal for insurance companies to reimburse ransom payments for hostage releases.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British government said Monday that it would introduce legislation giving the police the power to seize the passports of British and foreign citizens suspected of traveling to participate in terrorism-related activities and would make it easier for security services to track suspects online. The legislation would also make it illegal for British insurance companies to reimburse anyone who provided ransom payments to free hostages.

headline: A Sweet Crumb Cake for Your Thanksgiving Hostess
abstract: Bring along this decadent offering with honeyed pears that can compete with leftover pie.
lead_paragraph: One of the nicest hostess gifts I ever received at a dinner party was a jar of homemade marmalade and a brown paper bag full of biscuits, which my husband and I devoured the next morning as we cleaned up the mess.

headline: U.N. Report Shows an Increase in Trafficking of Children
abstract: One in three human trafficking victims is a child, most victims are female, and traffickers operate with wide impunity, the report on modern-day slavery said.
lead_paragraph: One in three human trafficking victims is a child, most victims are female, and traffickers operate with wide impunity, the United Nations said Monday in a report on modern-day slavery.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
abstract: Afghanistan and More — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: Afghanistan and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: No Disguising It: Red Sox Are Eyeing a Title Run
abstract: Pablo Sandoval is headed to Boston, bumping Hanley Ramirez to an already crowded outfield and opening an array of options for a team trying to rebuilding its starting rotation.
lead_paragraph: Someday soon, the Boston Red Sox will get around to shaking up their gridlocked outfield. For now, though, they keep adding to it, like squeezing another car onto a crowded highway, just in time for the holiday rush.

headline: Nov. 24, 2014 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Afghanistan, Syria, India and Yemen.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Afghanistan, Syria, India and Yemen.

headline: Vegetarian Thanksgiving: Pomegranate Salad
abstract: This colorful salad of red pomegranate seeds, Romaine lettuce and roasted sesame seeds, dressed with a fresh pomegranate juice and honey dressing, sets a festive tone for any holiday table.
lead_paragraph: The traditions of Thanksgiving are part of what makes it a favorite holiday. But sometimes it’s also about starting new traditions.

headline: How Will You Talk With Your Sons About Tamir Rice, Shot in the Park After Waving a Toy Gun?
abstract: When my son asked why it mattered what color the boy was, I told him. It matters because many, many people see something different, when they look at a boy who looks like Tamar Rice, than when they look at a boy who looks like you.
lead_paragraph: When you heard the news story about Tamir Rice, the 12-year-old Cleveland boy who was fatally shot by the police after he reached for a weapon that turned out to be a fake pistol, what, if anything, did you say to your own son or daughter?

headline: Three Arabs Are Arrested in Stabbings in Jerusalem
abstract: The police said they were investigating the stabbings as a possible terrorist attack that extended violence that has roiled the city for a month.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Three Arab men were arrested on suspicion of stabbing two Israeli Jews in the Old City on Monday, an Israeli police spokesman said, extending a spate of violence that has roiled Jerusalem for a month.

headline: Was Chuck Hagel a Failure or a Scapegoat?
abstract: Observers pointed to the defense secretary’s missteps during his tenure — but also see his resignation as a broader indictment of the administration’s handling of foreign policy.
lead_paragraph: After two years at the Pentagon, Secretary of Defense Chuck Hagel has resigned — or as many observers put it, “resigned,” in quotes.

headline: Ferguson and Other Cities React to Grand Jury Decision Not to Indict Darren Wilson
abstract: Journalists with The New York Times in Ferguson, Mo., are following a grand jury’s decision not to indict Darren Wilson, a white police officer, in the shooting death of Michael Brown, an unarmed black teenager who was killed on Aug. 9. Updates will resume on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Journalists with The New York Times in Ferguson, Mo., are following a grand jury’s decision not to indict Darren Wilson, a white police officer, in the shooting death of Michael Brown, an unarmed black teenager. On Monday night, the scene in downtown Ferguson grew increasingly unruly as the night wore on with the police using tear gas to disperse crowds who were throwing rocks and shattering store windows. Some businesses were looted, the police said. Protests also broke out in other cities, including New York, Los Angeles, Oakland and Seattle.

headline: New Broadway Musicals Off to Slow Start
abstract: The new musical comedy “Honeymoon in Vegas” had lukewarm ticket sales in its first preview performances; the other new musical still running, “The Last Ship,” has also seen slow sales.
lead_paragraph: This fall’s new batch of original musicals and musical revivals on Broadway continues to struggle at the box office. The new musical comedy “Honeymoon in Vegas” had lukewarm ticket sales for its first set of preview performances last week, according to audience data for Broadway shows released on Monday. The musical, adapted from a 1992 movie and starring Rob McClure (Broadway’s “Chaplin”) and the television veteran Tony Danza in the roles earlier played by Nicolas Cage and James Caan, grossed $366,136 for seven performances, or 37 percent of the maximum possible amount, with about two-thirds of the seats filled.

headline: Top Candidates to Succeed Hagel Are Longtime National Security Specialists
abstract: Michèle A. Flournoy and Ashton B. Carter are national security professionals whose Defense Department experience would be considered assets in managing the threat from the Islamic State, budget cuts and other challenges.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama, working to shift his team’s focus in confronting a raft of national security crises, is considering two former Defense Department officials as successors to Secretary of Defense Chuck Hagel, administration officials said Monday.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: In Performance | Quincy Tyler Bernstine
abstract: Ms. Bernstine plays a nun recalling her past in this scene from Heidi Schreck’s play “Grand Concourse,” set at a church soup kitchen in the Bronx.
lead_paragraph: Ms. Bernstine plays a nun recalling her past in this scene from Heidi Schreck’s play “Grand Concourse,” set at a church soup kitchen in the Bronx.

headline: Tom Sachs, Dustin Yellin and More at an Art-Themed Slumber Party
abstract: Creative Time’s annual Fall Ball benefit, held this past weekend, was a 12-hour sleepover party featuring performances, screenings and more interactive happenings.
lead_paragraph: Of the major organizations devoted to public art in New York City, Creative Time is known for being the most boundary-pushing and provocative — in the past 40 years, it has sponsored everything from an exhibition in a sanitation plant to a Steve Powers robotic waterboarding diorama to the towering Kara Walker sugar sculpture that took over Brooklyn’s former Domino factory this past summer. Thus, no one was surprised when the nonprofit announced that its Fall Ball benefit this year, which took over two floors at Neuehouse on Friday night, would take the form of an ambitious 12-hour sleepover party, complete with military cots and sunrise yoga. “Last year we had a dance party and it was a lot of fun, but the feedback we got was that people wanted more experiences,” said Creative Time’s development director Alyssa Nitchun, who came up with the idea. “So we’re like O.K., you want an experience? Here you go!”

headline: A Script to Play the Role of Guest Star
abstract: Filling your plate and keeping your wineglass upright are only two of the ways to contribute when someone else is the Thanksgiving host.
lead_paragraph: The deepest form of vicarious pleasure, if not the noblest, is the kind we feel when most of our joy in someone else’s achievement comes from not having done any of the work ourselves. This is the happiness of thinking about a friend’s newborn baby when you get into bed for a full night’s rest; the thrill of knowing that at the exact moment when your marathon-running co-worker is gasping across the finish line in Central Park, you are at home, not running; and the joy of skipping over all the articles on turkey thermometers and lump-free gravy because it’s not your turn to host.

headline: Defying Industry Trend, Virgin Hotels Resists Tacked-On Fees
abstract: As other hotels seek to increase revenue by adding fees and surcharges, Virgin is adopting no-fees and liberal cancellation policies.
lead_paragraph: A NEW hotel company plans to buck the trend when it opens its first property, in Chicago, in January by not charging travelers those annoying extra fees, while allowing reservation cancellations till late on the day a guest is scheduled to arrive.

headline: Handling a Thief in Business Class
abstract: Morgan Downey is chief executive of Money.Net, a financial start-up. On one flight, he awoke to find a seatmate taking food off his plate.
lead_paragraph: I WAS born and raised in Ireland. I graduated from university on a Saturday and took my first overseas flight the next day to New York City where I was going to start a job as a commodities trader. I remember landing at J.F.K. airport, getting off the plane, and walking through some sliding glass doors to get my first glimpse of America. There was this weird déjà vu moment like I had seen America before, but I think that was just due to all the American television I watched growing up, with shows like the “The A-Team,” “Star Trek,” “The Six Million Dollar Man,” “Sesame Street” and “Beverly Hills 90210” shaping my perception of the United States. But I still couldn’t believe how big the cars were.

headline: It’s Good to Be Rich: You Get a Lower Tax Rate
abstract: The top 400 taxpayers paid an average rate of 18 percent in 2010.
lead_paragraph: Newly released data from the Internal Revenue Service show that in 2010, the top 400 taxpayers had an average income of $265 million. That was $63 million more than in 2009, the depths of the downturn, and almost back to the group’s average in 2008. Recovery, in other words, was well underway for the 0.001 percent of the population. For most everyone else, the stimulus of 2009 was coming to a premature end, marking the start of the effort, still underway, to dig out of an economic pit without a shovel.

headline: University of Virginia’s Image Suffers After Campus Rape Report
abstract: The governing board will meet Tuesday to discuss complaints that the university has for years mishandled reports of sexual assaults.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. — The University of Virginia heads into an extraordinary meeting of its governing board on Tuesday struggling to find its footing, after a reported frat house gang rape rocked the university’s vaunted reputation and genteel self-image and unleashed complaints that it had mishandled and concealed sexual assaults for years.

headline: A Shake-Up Stops at One
abstract: The departure of Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel is part of a shake-up that does not address deeper doubts about the administration’s capacity to deal with a series of global crises.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Shortly after President Obama announced the resignation of Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel at the White House on Monday, he walked over to a meeting of his entire National Security Council staff, where he told the embattled group that they were critical to an ambitious foreign policy agenda.

headline: A Pajama Party for Art
abstract: Creative Time holds sleepover with friends and artists at NeueHouse.
lead_paragraph: Creative Time holds sleepover with friends and artists at NeueHouse.

headline: Just in Time for Art Basel, a First Look at Miami’s Newest Hotel
abstract: Ian Schrager, the hotelier who co-founded New York’s Studio 54, returned to his old stomping grounds to open The Miami Beach Edition in what was the Seville Hotel.
lead_paragraph: The hotelier Ian Schrager has returned to his old stomping grounds to open his newest property, the Miami Beach Edition, situated between South Beach and North Beach in what was formerly the Seville Hotel. The 68-year-old — who co-founded the original Studio 54 in New York and whose Delano Hotel, opened two decades ago, helped create the now-thriving hotel scene in South Beach — settled on the location because “it’s a new Miami now,” he says. “It’s international. It’s global.” Case in point: Art Basel Miami Beach kicks off its 2014 edition next week. During the international fair, the hotel will set the scene for many Basel-related events; and after long days at the booths, showgoers will be welcomed into the new Studio 54-inspired nightclub at the hotel, called Basement.

headline: Walkabout: Albania Opens Cold War Bunker; Swiss Museum Accepts Bequest of Nazi-Era Art
abstract: A weekly capsule of travel news curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: Uncovered A 106-room secret bunker in Albania, built in the 1970s by the Communist regime to survive a nuclear bomb, has been opened to the public for the first time. (BBC)

headline: Creative Time Has a Sleepover With Very Little Snoozing
abstract: An arts organization holds a sleepover benefit.
lead_paragraph: Creative Time is an arts organization that takes party-making seriously. So for its benefit last Friday, rather than try to drag donors to another seated dinner, it had a sleepover.

headline: Singing a Happy Song, Even at the Heart of Manhattan
abstract: In her new show at 54 Below, the singer Ann Hampton Callaway demonstrates an unshakable optimism, as well as her multirange voice.
lead_paragraph: “Promise yourself to be too large for worry, too noble for anger, too strong for fear, and too happy to permit the presence of trouble.”

headline: As Booth Brothers Held Forth, 1864 Confederate Plot Against New York Fizzled
abstract: Acting 150 years ago, saboteurs who were incensed by the Union Army’s scorched-earth campaign tried to set 19 hotels, a theater and P.T. Barnum’s Museum on fire.
lead_paragraph: On Nov. 25, 1864, at some point in the middle of Act II, after Brutus and his co-conspirators decide to assassinate Julius Caesar, the capacity crowd of 2,000 that had filled the Winter Garden Theater on lower Broadway was startled by the sudden clanging of fire-bells, coming from every direction.

headline: American Music Awards Red Carpet 2014: Selena Gomez and More
abstract: Selena Gomez in Armani Privé, Jennifer Lopez in Reem Acra and Taylor Swift in custom Michael Kors were some of the standouts.
lead_paragraph: At the American Music Awards on Sunday night in Los Angeles, Taylor Swift in custom Michael Kors, Jennifer Lopez in Reem Acra and Selena Gomez in Armani Privé were some of the standouts on the red carpet.

headline: Hopeless Romantics, Drink This Mystery Concoction if You Dare
abstract: A maid’s mistake is crucial in “The Love Potion,” the Boston Lyric Opera’s staging of Frank Martin’s “Le Vin Herbé.”
lead_paragraph: BROOKLINE, Mass. — At the Temple Ohabei Shalom here, two vertical lines of light emerge from a golden base. From the core of a temporary amphitheater, built where pews ought to be, they rise as parallel lasers until, up near the synagogue’s dome, they attenuate into dark air, together only in their dissolution.

headline: First Draft Focus: Presidential Medal of Freedom Ceremony
abstract: President Obama presented the Presidential Medal of Freedom to 19 people on Monday.

headline: High-Kicking Displays of Athleticism and Flash
abstract: In its 20th year, Complexions Contemporary Ballet, now in a two-week run at the Joyce Theater, is most intriguing as a study in branding.
lead_paragraph: In its 20th year, Complexions Contemporary Ballet is most intriguing as a study in branding. Founded by the former Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater principals Dwight Rhoden and Desmond Richardson, the troupe prides itself on multiplicity — claiming to champion “the artistic and aesthetic appeal of the multicultural” — yet operates within a distressingly narrow aesthetic spectrum.

headline: The Craziness Adds Up for an Antihero Cop
abstract: Michael Connelly continues his Harry Bosch series in “The Burning Room,” with a recent death that actually goes back a decade.
lead_paragraph: Michael Connelly’s Harry Bosch series has its highs and lows, but the latest installment is perched on a hilltop. “The Burning Room” is the best Bosch book in years, not only because of its sharp dialogue and fast-paced detective wizardry, but also because it neither dawdles nor lets Harry get moody. Among the things that Harry, the Los Angeles Police Department’s ace antihero, hasn’t time for here: moping about his exes, worrying about his daughter, broodily listening to jazz in the wee hours or fretting about the threat of retirement, which has hovered over him for quite a while now. “The Burning Room” finds Harry in his highest gear, making every minute of police work count.

headline: Albums From Rick Ross and Keith Jarrett
abstract: The hip-hop star Rick Ross and two jazz groups — the trio of Keith Jarrett, Charlie Haden and Paul Motian, from ’72, and the duo of Nels Cline and Julian Lage — have new albums out.
lead_paragraph: RICK ROSS

headline: Trey Gowdy Reappointed to Lead House Benghazi Inquiry
abstract: Speaker John A. Boehner announced that he was reappointing Representative Trey Gowdy, Republican of South Carolina, as chairman of the special committee on Benghazi for the 114th Congress that begins in January.
lead_paragraph: We reported this morning that congressional Republicans had no intention of backing off the House’s Beghazi investigation despite the release of an Intelligence Committee report that dispelled some claims about the attacks.

headline: Caviar at ‘Cabaret’, Doughnuts and Thanksgiving Balloons, and More Food News
abstract: During the preparations for the Macy’s parade, Dovetail is offering treats at the bar, and seasonal chocolate treats abound.
lead_paragraph: To Indulge: At the Kit Kat Klub, Caviar and Sparklers

headline: On the Trail of an Ancient Mystery
abstract: More than 100 years after it was found, and more than 2,000 years after it was believed to have been built, the Antikythera Mechanism continues to raise questions and provide answers.
lead_paragraph: A riddle for the ages may be a small step closer to a solution: Who made the famed Antikythera Mechanism, the astronomical calculator that was raised from an ancient shipwreck near Crete in 1901?

headline: Intrigue in the Middle East, This Time From Shakespeare
abstract: The Public Theater’s production of Shakespeare’s “Pericles, Prince of Tyre” moves along quickly, despite a plot loaded with details.
lead_paragraph: Last summer, the radio host Ira Glass prompted a Twitter tempest when he attended the Public Theater’s lackluster “King Lear” and tweeted:  “No stakes, not relatable. I think I’m realizing: Shakespeare sucks.”

headline: Angry Turkeys, Meet Grumpy Cats
abstract: The airwaves will teem with programming about animals in coming days, from another “Big Cat Week” on Nat Geo Wild to Destination America’s take on aggressive turkeys.
lead_paragraph: So much to do during Thanksgiving week. Make up the guest bedrooms. Prepare the dinner. Eat the leftovers. Nap. Eat more leftovers. Nap. Repeat for six or seven days. In short, no time to watch any television, except maybe a football game.

headline: A Smoldering Gypsy’s Smoldering Time, Down at the Old Bull Ring
abstract: Ballet Hispanico presented its take on “Carmen” on Saturday in Gustavo Ramírez Sansano’s “Carmen.maquia.”
lead_paragraph: “Carmen” began as a Frenchman’s fantasy of Spain, first in a novella by Prosper Mérimée and then, immortally, in Bizet’s opera. So it is no violation of authenticity for a choreographer, especially a Spanish one, to tell the tale in another style, even if that style is the angst-ridden expressionism of, say, Nederlands Dans Theater.

headline: Radiologists Are Reducing the Pain of Uncertainty
abstract: Radiologists are becoming more accessible to patients, but there are questions over whether the two parties will be able to handle dealing with each other when the results of scans are unwelcome.
lead_paragraph: When Dr. Jennifer Kemp’s husband got advanced rectal cancer, she got an unexpected patient’s-eye view of her profession.

headline: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome and the Brain
abstract: New research showing brain inflammation in patients with chronic fatigue syndrome may help scientists better understand how to treat the condition.
lead_paragraph: New research showing brain inflammation in patients with chronic fatigue syndrome may help scientists better understand how to treat the condition.

headline: Regrowing Coral
abstract: Scientists in the Florida Keys are using corals’ innate healing abilities to try to repopulate lost areas.
lead_paragraph: Scientists in the Florida Keys are using corals’ innate healing abilities to try to repopulate lost areas.

headline: Quicker Scan Results
abstract: A new movement may help patients receive test results directly from their radiologists, speeding up the process.
lead_paragraph: A new movement may help patients receive test results directly from their radiologists, speeding up the process.

abstract: Readers respond to President Obama’s policy change.

abstract: Dr. Martin P. Geller, a psychiatrist, writes that the term requires clarification for the general public.
