headline: Caught!
abstract: Former President George Bush gave a kiss to his wife, Barbara, on the “kiss cam” at a Houston Texans game on Sunday.

headline: What Determines the Color of Fish Flesh?
abstract: Fish that have white flesh are generally those that are resting or mostly inactive throughout their lives, while red-fleshed fish are usually long-distance swimmers.
lead_paragraph: Q. Why do some fish have white flesh, like flounder and tilapia, while others have red or orange flesh, like tuna and salmon?

headline: After Acid Rain, Lakes Are Turning to ‘Jelly’
abstract: Tiny, jelly-clad crustaceans known as Holopedium are thriving in some Canadian lakes after years of acid rain, threatening the food chain and “jellifying” the waters, biologists say.
lead_paragraph: Tiny, jelly-clad crustaceans known as Holopedium are thriving in some Canadian lakes after years of acid rain, threatening the food chain and “jellifying” the waters, say biologists. Unlike other “water fleas,” Holopedium can survive on very little calcium, making them ideally suited to the calcium-depleted waters of lakes exposed to pollution. But their hard, jelly-protected bodies cause problems for others, clogging up filtration systems, removing nutrients from the food chain and washing up in the form of “goo balls.” A study published in The Proceedings of the Royal Society B says the population of Holopedium in Ontario lakes doubled between the 1980s and mid-2000s.

headline: ScienceTake | Harnessing Gecko Power
abstract: Humans climb glass with a rig that uses gecko-inspired adhesive pads.
lead_paragraph: Humans climb glass with a rig that uses gecko-inspired adhesive pads.

headline: Climbing a Glass Building? Try a Gecko’s Sticky Pads
abstract: The lizard and, well, Spider-Man, have ideal tools for scaling slippery surfaces. Engineers have copied the gecko’s clingy foot pads.
lead_paragraph: An irresistible attraction to gecko feet is an occupational hazard for engineers who study how one thing sticks to another. Geckos can climb just about anything, including glass, and in 2002 scientists identified the force of molecular attraction that bonds dry gecko foot pads to a surface.

headline: A Place Where Lost Luggage Gets Another Shot
abstract: Unclaimed Baggage Center is a family business tucked away in Scottsboro, Ala., that sells items as varied as iPads, mink furs and mattresses.
lead_paragraph: SCOTTSBORO, Ala. — It is a secondhand store, one of a kind. Its name, Unclaimed Baggage Center, doesn’t quite say it all. Its shelves are stocked not only with luggage lost, forgotten or ditched by airline passengers; the store also carries all the contents of that stray luggage deemed suitable for purchase.

headline: Leading Surgeon Is Accused of Misconduct in Experimental Transplant Operations
abstract: A doctor who is considered a pioneer in the field of regenerative medicine has denied carrying out innovative operations without ethical approvals.
lead_paragraph: A prestigious medical institute in Sweden has begun an investigation of a surgeon who is considered a pioneer in the field of regenerative medicine, after complaints that he did not receive ethical approvals for experimental operations on patients and misled medical journals about the success of the procedures.

headline: Waiting for the Grand Jury Decision
abstract: Tension builds as activists await word of the grand jury decision about whether a white police officer should face charges in the fatal shooting of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Mo., in August.
lead_paragraph: Tension builds as activists await word of the grand jury decision about whether a white police officer should face charges in the fatal shooting of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Mo., in August.

headline: Obesity and Its Heart Complications
abstract: Does a girl who enters adolescence with a big woman’s body have a harder time socially than most teenagers? How about a boy whose fat conjures up female stereotypes?
lead_paragraph: “XL Love” is unfortunately titled, evoking the coarsest kind of reality TV, and the subtitle referring to America’s love life doesn’t help much. It turns out, though, that the book is substantially more thoughtful and less prurient than those labels suggest.

headline: Science Events: Minimalist Music and a Spotlight on Sex
abstract: An auditory scientist plans to help a New York audience make the most of some very minimal music and human sexual behavior is the focus of a yearlong show at London’s museum of medicine and art.
lead_paragraph: Events this coming month at the intersection of science and culture.

headline: Israel Narrows Its Democracy
abstract: In any form, the contentious bill that would officially define Israel as the nation-state of the Jewish people, reserving “national rights” only for Jews, should be defeated.
lead_paragraph: Since its founding in 1948, Israel’s very existence and promise — fully embraced by the United States and the world of nations — has been based on the ideal of democracy for all of its people.

headline: Ask Well: Can Athletes Be Vegans?
abstract: A reader asks about his 15-year-old son, an athlete who wants to switch to a vegan diet.
lead_paragraph: Question:

headline: Hookah, as Health Risk, Still Qualifies as Smoking
abstract: With its mix of tobacco and other flavorings through a water pipe, it may smell and taste better, but a study finds it far from harmless.
lead_paragraph: Smoking through a hookah is not harmless, according to a new study. In addition to the usual tobacco carcinogens, dangerous levels of benzene are inhaled from the lump of smoldering charcoal that ignites the moist tobacco mixture.

headline: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 2,337 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Defense has identified 2,337 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

headline: Alex Poots to Be Culture Shed’s Artistic Director
abstract: Mr. Poots is to give up his current positions as head of the Manchester International Festival and the Park Avenue Armory.
lead_paragraph: Over the last few years, Culture Shed, the visual- and performing-arts institution planned for the Far West Side of Manhattan, has been nurtured by prominent designers (Elizabeth Diller and David Rockwell); substantial city support ($75 million); and influential advocates (former Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and his deputy, Daniel L. Doctoroff). Hanging over the project was always a question: Who is going to run it?

headline: Brains of People With Chronic Fatigue Syndrome Offer Clues About Disorder
abstract: Two recent studies suggest that physiological factors may underlie chronic fatigue syndrome.
lead_paragraph: Patients with chronic fatigue syndrome are accustomed to disappointment. The cause of the disorder remains unknown; it can be difficult to diagnose, and treatment options are few. Research suggesting that an infection from a mouse virus may cause it raised hopes among patients a few years ago, but the evidence fell apart under closer scrutiny.

headline: What’s in a Slug?
abstract: Kyle Massey, an assistant news editor, explains the naming convention used for unpublished articles.
lead_paragraph: Kyle Massey is an assistant news editor. He has worked at The Times since 1999.

headline: Our Cats, Ourselves
abstract: Domestication happened to humans, too. We’ve evolved a lot like pets.
lead_paragraph: DAVIS, Calif. — IT’S commonplace to call our cats “pets.” But anyone sharing a cat’s household can tell you that, much as we might like to choose when they eat in the morning, or when they come inside for the night, cats are only partly domesticated.

headline: Is Harvard Unfair to Asian-Americans?
abstract: In a true meritocracy, whites would be a minority of the student body. That worries some people.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — NEARLY a century ago, Harvard had a big problem: Too many Jews. By 1922, Jews accounted for 21.5 percent of freshmen, up from 7 percent in 1900 and vastly more than at Yale or Princeton. In the Ivy League, only Columbia and the University of Pennsylvania had a greater proportion of Jews.

headline: You Won't Believe What Happened Next
abstract: Why is click bait so reviled?

headline: Getting to the Feeling Behind the Photos
abstract: A look at how ProPublica and Frontline collaborated to explore, through the lives of several subjects, the controversial relationship between Firestone and Charles Taylor of Liberia.
lead_paragraph: A look at how ProPublica and Frontline collaborated to explore, through the lives of several subjects, the controversial relationship between Firestone and Charles Taylor of Liberia.

headline: Bombs Hit Sole Civilian Airport in Libyan Capital
abstract: Commanders from Operation Dignity said they ordered the strikes because the airport and the capital had fallen under the control of the rival coalition Libya Dawn.
lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI, Libya — A fighter plane bombed the air base that was the last airport here in the Libyan capital on Monday in the latest escalation of a struggle for power that is threatening to tear apart the country.

headline: Bill Walker, Next Governor for Alaska, Traversed Unlikely Path
abstract: Mr. Walker had no party, little money and almost no chance of victory just two months before Election Day.
lead_paragraph: JUNEAU, Alaska — Sudden twists of fate make great political theater. In the rise of Bill Walker, Alaska’s unlikely next governor, it was a missed airplane flight on the Friday before Labor Day.

headline: Lawmakers Look for Ways to Provide Relief for Rising Cost of Generic Drugs
abstract: With the prices for some common generic medicines soaring over the past 18 months, state and federal lawmakers are trying to find relief for patients struggling to pay.
lead_paragraph: With the prices for some common generic medicines soaring over the past 18 months, state and federal lawmakers are trying to find relief for patients struggling to pay.

headline: Governor Emphasizes Respect and Safety
abstract: Jay Nixon, the governor of Missouri, discussed preparations for the announcement of a grand jury decision in Ferguson Mo.
lead_paragraph: Jay Nixon, the governor of Missouri, discussed preparations for the announcement of a grand jury decision in Ferguson Mo.

headline: Oklahoma: Education Waiver Is Restored for State
abstract: The Department of Education announced Monday that Oklahoma — which lost its No Child Left Behind waiver after repealing Common Core — would have its waiver reinstated.
lead_paragraph: Three months after Oklahoma lost its waiver from key provisions of No Child Left Behind, the signature Bush-era education law, the Obama administration has given it back for the rest of the school year. The Department of Education announced Monday that Oklahoma — which lost its waiver after repealing the Common Core, controversial academic standards that have been adopted by more than 40 states — would have its waiver reinstated because the state had adopted academic standards approved by Oklahoma’s colleges and universities. The waivers relieve states of meeting the requirement under the No Child law that all students in a school show proficiency in reading and math by 2014 or else the school would be declared failing. Since July, the Education Department has granted waiver extensions to 33 states.

headline: At Spanish Enclave, a Debate Over What Makes a Border
abstract: Spanish authorities, struggling to secure the borders to their enclaves in Africa, are facing a new legal challenge over the position of border fences.
lead_paragraph: MELILLA, Spain — By now, the images of African migrants sitting astride the fences that separate Moroccan and Spanish territory here — one of only two land borders between Europe and Africa — have become familiar the world over.

headline: Ohio: Shot Boy’s Toy Gun Looked Real, Police Say
abstract: The Cleveland police said Monday that the toy gun held by a 12-year old boy when he was fatally shot by a police officer was “indistinguishable” from a real weapon.
lead_paragraph: The Cleveland police said Monday that the toy gun held by a 12-year-old boy when he was fatally shot by a police officer was “indistinguishable” from a real weapon. The police also said that there was a videotape of the Saturday shooting of the boy, Tamir Rice, but that they had not decided when to release it to the public. The authorities said that Tamir had failed to raise his hands when a police officer requested that he do so and that he had been reaching for his waistband, where he had the toy gun, left, when he was shot. “The facsimile weapon in this incident is indistinguishable from a real firearm,” Police Chief Calvin Williams said. “Guns are not toys.”

headline: Yogurt May Lower Diabetes Risk
abstract: Regular consumption of yogurt may help lower the risk for Type 2 diabetes, a new study has found.
lead_paragraph: Regular consumption of yogurt may help lower the risk for Type 2 diabetes, a new study has found.

headline: F.D.A. Issues Caution on Use of Uterine Surgery Device That Can Spread Cancer
abstract: The agency warns that the tool ought not be used for most women, but critics complain that anything short of a ban is bad policy.
lead_paragraph: A power device used during uterine surgery in at least 50,000 women a year in the United States risks spreading cancerous tissue and should no longer be used in “the vast majority” of women, the Food and Drug Administration said on Monday.

headline: Report Faults Care of Peace Corps Volunteer
abstract: The Peace Corps inspector general cited “cascading delays and failures in treatment” as a factor in the death in 2013 of Nick Castle, a volunteer who fell gravely ill in China.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A Peace Corps doctor caring for a gravely ill volunteer in China ignored a fellow physician’s warnings that the volunteer needed intravenous fluids “in 30 minutes or he is going to die,” and altered her notes about his treatment after submitting them to headquarters for review, according to a confidential report by the agency’s independent watchdog.

headline: Video Analysis of Fatal West Bank Shooting Said to Implicate Israeli Officer
abstract: Analysis of video of the May shooting suggested that the officer was to blame, the boy’s father and an Israeli who reconstructed the shooting said.
lead_paragraph: One day after Israel charged an officer from its border police force with manslaughter in the shooting of a Palestinian teenager at a protest in the West Bank last May, the boy’s father and an Israeli architect who helped reconstruct the killing based on video evidence argued that the officer should be indicted on a murder charge instead.

headline: Health Care Delays Lead to Ouster of Veterans Hospital Director in Phoenix
abstract: The Department of Veterans Affairs fired the director of its Phoenix medical center, Sharon Helman, months after it was revealed that wait lists were manipulated to cloak long delays.
lead_paragraph: Under pressure from Republicans in Congress, the Department of Veterans Affairs on Monday fired the director of its Phoenix medical center, Sharon Helman, six months after she was placed on administrative leave amid revelations that hospital employees had manipulated wait lists to cloak long delays many veterans faced to see doctors.

headline: New York City and State to Pay $6.7 Million to Settle Murder Conviction Lawsuit
abstract: Israel Vasquez, a Bronx man, served more than 12 years in prison in the 1995 shooting of a Federal Express executive before the decision was overturned; he was killed in 2012.
lead_paragraph: New York City and New York State have agreed to pay a total of $6.7 million to settle lawsuits on behalf of a Bronx man who served more than 12 years in prison before his murder conviction was overturned in 2007.

headline: Savers, a Thrift Chain, Said to Pocket Money Meant for Charity
abstract: Savers Thrift Stores routinely keeps nearly all the money it raises from clothing drives and other donations, the Minnesota attorney general said in a report.
lead_paragraph: Minnesota’s attorney general has accused Savers Thrift Stores of pocketing more than $1 million that should have gone to charities including the Lupus Foundation of Minnesota and Vietnam Veterans of America.

headline: Trend Toward Top Ex-Players as Coaches Appears to Pay Off
abstract: Roger Federer’s decision to bring in Stefan Edberg was just one example of an elite tennis player turning to a former star for assistance.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The last point of the official 2014 season was fitting. Not only because Roger Federer won it to cap a resurgent year by securing the Davis Cup for Switzerland but also because Federer won it on his way to the net.

headline: As Bombing Toll Rises, Afghan Villagers Direct Anger at Government
abstract: Villagers of Yahya Khel, where a bomber killed 61 people Sunday, expressed anger at the Taliban but also at a national government they felt had offered them little.
lead_paragraph: YAHYA KHEL, Afghanistan — Three years ago, villagers from the dusty Afghan district of Yahya Khel, near the Pakistani border, rose up against the Taliban, driving the insurgents away. They say they did it on their own, winning themselves a degree of security that felt tolerable.

headline: Saks Flagship Store Is Appraised for Mortgage at $3.7 Billion
abstract: Hudson’s Bay took out a loan against the Saks Fifth Avenue flagship that valued the department store at nearly $4 billion, making it one of the most valuable retail properties in the country.
lead_paragraph: Many financiers have tried to make money from retailers through the ground beneath their stores.

headline: Surviving Andersonville
abstract: The story of one wounded Union soldier who lived through the horrors of the South’s worst prison camp.
lead_paragraph: On Nov. 21, 1864, several hundred paroled Union prisoners of war struggled aboard a flag-of-truce boat in Savannah, Ga. Among those who sailed that day for the North was an Iowa farm boy named James Landon. Debilitated by scurvy and hobbled by a gangrene-infected gunshot wound in the left thigh, he had survived a stint in Georgia’s Camp Sumter, better known as Andersonville. Landon was lucky to survive – Andersonville was the most notorious Civil War prison camp, an open-air cesspool where thousands of Union soldiers spent excruciating months and years after being captured.

headline: Nevada Lawmaker, Ira Hansen, Is Forced From Leadership Post Over Remarks on Minorities
abstract: A Reno newspaper disclosed that Mr. Hansen, the speaker-elect of the Assembly, had written published remarks full of derogatory remarks about blacks, women, Latinos and gays.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — In an Election Day filled with good news for the Republican Party this month, Nevada looked like a particularly bright spot: The party seized full control of the Nevada state government for the first time since 1929, sweeping to victory in the Assembly and the Senate and retaining control of the governor’s mansion in a state that President Obama had won twice.

headline: Leslie Feinberg, Writer and Transgender Activist, Dies at 65
abstract: Feinberg’s 1993 novel, “Stone Butch Blues,” is considered a landmark in the contemporary literature of gender complexity.
lead_paragraph: Leslie Feinberg, a writer and activist whose 1993 novel, “Stone Butch Blues,” is considered a landmark in the contemporary literature of gender complexity, died on Nov. 15 at her home in Syracuse. She was 65.

headline: Weight Watchers Serving Up Understanding to Those Who Eat Their Feelings
abstract: Weight Watchers is taking a celebrity-free approach to advertising with its new campaign, focusing on people’s tendency to seek solace in calories.
lead_paragraph: FOR an industry that aims to help change consumers’ habits, weight-loss brands themselves seem to take the same approach year in and year out: Hire celebrities who have lost weight through the programs to pitch them. Kirstie Alley is a spokeswoman for Jenny Craig, for example, and Marie Osmond for Nutrisystem. But now Weight Watchers, which featured Jessica Simpson in advertising earlier this year, is introducing a campaign that ditches the celebrity approach.

headline: Al Michaels, Known for a Miracle, Reflects on His Luck
abstract: Michaels, a sportscaster, has had plenty of flow and serendipity in his career, as his breezy new autobiography, “You Can’t Make This Up,” suggests.
lead_paragraph: Al Michaels was at a hotel restaurant in Manhattan one day last week, talking about John Madden and Cris Collinsworth, as well as John Wooden and Ken Dryden.

headline: Senator Elizabeth Warren’s Misplaced Rage at Obama’s Treasury Nominee
abstract: Senator Elizabeth Warren’s wrath toward Antonio F. Weiss is misdirected, and her understanding of the inversion deal on which she bases her opposition appears misinformed.
lead_paragraph: Less than 48 hours after President Obama nominated Antonio F. Weiss, a longtime adviser on mergers at the investment bank Lazard and a Democratic supporter, to become the under secretary of Treasury for domestic finance, Senator Elizabeth Warren denounced the appointment and said that she would vote against his confirmation.

headline: A Bearish Hedge Fund Bets Against the Bulls and Still Profits
abstract: Universa Investments, a hedge fund founded by Mark Spitznagel, has found a way to make money in an economic and financial collapse as well as in better times.
lead_paragraph: The stock market has been rising for years, hitting new highs almost every week. So how is it that one of Wall Street’s most bearish investors can claim to have profited strongly over this period?

headline: Pat Quinn, Coach Who Led Canada to Olympic Gold, Is Dead at 71
abstract: Quinn followed up a bruising career as a hockey player by steering Canada to its first Olympic gold medal in 50 years and twice winning coach-of-the-year honors in the National Hockey League.
lead_paragraph: Pat Quinn, a popular hockey coach who followed up a bruising playing career by steering Canada to its first Olympic gold medal in 50 years and twice winning coach-of-the-year honors in the National Hockey League, died on Sunday at a hospital in Vancouver. He was 71.

headline: Committed to Carbon Goals
abstract: The chief executive of NRG Energy is making his company part of the solution.
lead_paragraph: Since the early 1990s, the consensus view in the climate science community has been that if the world is going to escape the most catastrophic consequences of climate change, it needs to keep the average global temperature from rising more than 2 degrees Celsius, compared with preindustrial levels. A few years ago, the Presidential Climate Action Project issued a report in which it estimated that to meet that goal, global carbon dioxide emissions would need to be reduced by 60 percent by 2050 — and the industrialized world would need to reduce its emissions by 80 percent.

headline: Honda Failed to Report Defects’ Full Human Toll
abstract: An audit found that the automaker did not inform United States regulators of 1,729 claims of fatalities and injuries linked to a potential defect.
lead_paragraph: Honda Motor, already facing rising scrutiny over its handling of defective airbags, grossly underreported to federal regulators the number of deaths and injury claims linked to possible defects in its vehicles for more than 10 years, the Japanese automaker disclosed on Monday.

headline: With No Immediate Prospect of Sanctions Relief for Iranians, Support for President Slips
abstract: President Hassan Rouhani of Iran has in the eyes of many failed to deliver on pledges to get sanctions lifted, provide more freedoms and improve the economy.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — A year ago Iranians danced in the streets after they elected President Hassan Rouhani, mainly because he promised to get devastating sanctions lifted by starting negotiations over Iran’s nuclear program.

headline: F.D.A. to Require Calorie Count, Even for Popcorn at the Movies
abstract: The Food and Drug Administration announced a sweeping rule that will require chain restaurants and movie theaters to post calorie counts on their menus.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Food and Drug Administration announced sweeping rules on Tuesday that will require chain restaurants, movie theaters and pizza parlors across the country to post calorie counts on their menus. Health experts said the new requirements would help combat the country’s obesity epidemic by showing Americans just how many calories lurk in their favorite foods.

headline: ‘Gotham’ Recap: Gordon Plays a Rigged Game
abstract: Wanted: More of Gordon’s inner recklessness.
lead_paragraph: Season 1, Episode 10, “Lovecraft”

headline: The Unifying Leader
abstract: The only way for American political culture to change is for leaders to be more creative in their approach to collaboration.
lead_paragraph: Over the past two weeks, President Obama and Republicans in Congress have taken their conflicts to another level. I’m not here to apportion blame, but it would be nice if, in the future, we evaluated presidential candidates on the basis of whether they are skilled at the art of collaboration.

headline: New Strain of Bird Flu Prompts a Warning for Farmers
abstract: A new, lethal strain of bird flu detected this month on poultry farms in Britain and the Netherlands has now been reported in Germany, among both domesticated birds and a wild bird, international agriculture authorities said Monday.
lead_paragraph: A new, lethal strain of bird flu detected this month on poultry farms in Britain and the Netherlands has now been reported in Germany, among both domesticated birds and a wild bird, international agriculture authorities said Monday. A warning posted by the Food and Agriculture Organization and the World Organization for Animal Health said the new virus, H5N8, was the same as a strain that hit poultry, migratory birds and waterfowl in China, Japan and South Korea this year. Its discovery within such a short time in three European countries, the warning said, suggests that wild birds may have spread the virus. The warning said the virus posed “a significant threat” to poultry farmers in countries along the Black Sea and East Atlantic migratory routes of wild birds. While H5N8 has not affected humans, the warning said it was related to H5N1, the bird flu that caused an epidemic in 2005-6, causing the deaths of nearly 400 people and the culling of hundreds of millions of birds.

headline: The Incredible Shrinking Action in Atlantic City
abstract: The once-thriving casinos continue a long, painful slide from the glory days of the 1970s. The Trump Taj Mahal may be the next to close.
lead_paragraph: Back in the euphoria of 1976 when New Jersey voters legalized casinos, no one foresaw the scale of disaster now enveloping Atlantic City. Four of its 12 casinos had to close as revenues plunged this year, with a fifth threatening to go under by Christmas.

headline: A Problem Beyond Mr. Hagel
abstract: The defense secretary resigned, but the Obama administration’s core military problem is a national security policy that has been too incoherent and shifting.
lead_paragraph: Chuck Hagel, who was pressured to resign on Monday, was not a strong defense secretary and, after less than two years, appeared to have lost President Obama’s confidence.

headline: Even Under Microscope, Catch by Giants’ Odell Beckham Jr. Earns Applause
abstract: On the morning after one of the better catches in N.F.L. history, the play was being analyzed by physicists, mechanical engineers and sports scientists.
lead_paragraph: In living rooms and on websites across the country Sunday night, there was only one sporting question that mattered: How did Odell Beckham Jr. make that catch?

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 24, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: With Mother Ill, Her Daughters Helped Save Family
abstract: Vilmarie Garcia’s two daughters cared for their younger brother as she lay in a coma, and then helped keep the family afloat after his father died.
lead_paragraph: The last thing that Vilmarie Garcia remembers from Jan. 10 is her skin turning purple as the physicians at NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital put her in a drug-induced coma.

headline: A Nuclear Deal for U.S. and Iran Slips Away Again
abstract: Negotiations carried on in secret for months, but despite a thaw between the governments’ top envoys, the end result is only another extension.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA — By the time Secretary of State John Kerry and his Iranian counterpart checked into a luxury hotel near the famous beaches of Oman earlier this month, a long-sought deal that has eluded the last two American presidents to roll back Tehran’s nuclear program seemed to be slipping out of reach.

headline: Ferguson Officer Is Not Indicted
abstract: The St. Louis County prosecutor announced the decision of a grand jury not to indict Darren Wilson, the white police officer who fatally shot Michael Brown, an unarmed black teenager, in Ferguson, Mo.
lead_paragraph: The St. Louis County prosecutor announced the decision of a grand jury not to indict Darren Wilson, the white police officer who fatally shot Michael Brown, an unarmed black teenager, in Ferguson, Mo.

headline: Grand Jury Says Fraud Persists in Programs Meant to Diversify Contracts in New York City and State
abstract: A report found evidence of criminal fraud at the city and state level by several construction companies, spanning at least a decade and involving more than $10 million.
lead_paragraph: Current laws and regulations are not enough to prevent fraud in New York State and City programs meant to steer contracts to businesses owned by women and members of minority groups, according to a grand jury report released on Monday.

headline: An American Athlete
abstract: Jeffrey Wechsler offers a tribute to an important American.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — I am by no means a baseball expert, but even I know about “Joltin’ JOE” DIMAGGIO’s legendary 1941 HITTING STREAK.

headline: A Love Story and Its Voyeurs
abstract: Kneehigh Theater of Britain has brought “Tristan & Yseult” to St. Ann’s Warehouse, with characters who gather at the Club of the Unloved.
lead_paragraph: The lines between pleasure and pain keep blurring in Kneehigh Theater’s ecstasy-drunk “Tristan & Yseult,” which opened on Monday night at St. Ann’s Warehouse in Brooklyn. This is true not only for the doomed-to-love title characters, who notoriously have that whole Eros and Thanatos thing going, but also for the audience in their thrall.

headline: Pact Tightens Russian Ties With Abkhazia
abstract: The accord with the breakaway region of Georgia comes at a time of deep apprehension in the West over Russia’s expansionist aspirations.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin signed a treaty on Monday to expand Russia’s authority over Abkhazia, a breakaway region of Georgia, effectively giving the Kremlin a dominant role in military and economic policy and making it easier for residents of Abkhazia to obtain Russian citizenship.

headline: Bills Thrash the Jets in a Road Show of Resilience
abstract: Forced to play in Detroit after last week’s snowstorms in Buffalo, the Bills looked perfectly comfortable in routing the woeful Jets, who failed to end a two-game slide and keep pace in the A.F.C. wild-card race.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Nothing has been remotely normal for the Bills since a record snowfall buried the Buffalo region last week, canceled their formal preparations for their game against the Jets and left Ralph Wilson Stadium unplayable.

headline: Twitter’s C.F.O. Suffers a Social Media Faux Pas
abstract: On Monday, Anthony Noto, Twitter’s chief financial officer, appeared to accidentally disclose some confidential corporate strategy plans on the social network itself.
lead_paragraph: Twitter has long been criticized for being difficult for new users to understand. On occasion, it seems, the social network’s own executives have a hard time as well.

headline: Turkish President Says Women Shouldn’t Be Considered Equals
abstract: At an international conference on justice and rights, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan on Monday said that women should not be regarded as equal to men and condemned feminists for rejecting motherhood.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — President Recep Tayyip Erdogan on Monday used an international conference on justice and rights for women to declare that women should not be regarded as equal to men and that pregnancy presented an obstacle to equal opportunity in the workplace.

headline: Witnesses Told Grand Jury That Michael Brown Charged at Darren Wilson, Prosecutor Says
abstract: The most credible eyewitnesses to the shooting said the teenager had charged toward Officer Darren Wilson just before the fatal shots, the St. Louis County prosecutor said.
lead_paragraph: The most credible eyewitnesses to the shooting death of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Mo., said he had charged toward Police Officer Darren Wilson just before the final, fatal shots, the St. Louis County prosecutor said Monday night as he sought to explain why a grand jury had not found probable cause to indict the officer.

headline: This Time, the Yankees Shrug as the Red Sox Spend
abstract: On Monday, the Red Sox committed nearly $200 million to sign Pablo Sandoval and Hanley Ramirez in moves that resembled Yankees tactics of the past. But the Yankees barely flinched.
lead_paragraph: In years past, if the Boston Red Sox made a high-profile acquisition in the off-season, the Yankees sometimes reacted with one of their own.

headline: Viktor Tikhonov Dies at 84: Soviet Hockey Coach in ‘Miracle on Ice’
abstract: Tikhonov was the domineering coach of the powerful Soviet national hockey team that won three Olympic gold medals and one devastating silver — when the Soviets lost to the United States in the 1980 Lake Placid Games.
lead_paragraph: Viktor Tikhonov, the domineering coach of the powerful Soviet national hockey team known as the Big Red Machine that won three Olympic gold medals and one devastating silver — when the Soviets, shocking the hockey world, lost to the United States in the 1980 Lake Placid Games in the celebrated Miracle on Ice — died on Monday in Moscow. He was 84.

headline: In Protests From Midwest to Both Coasts, Fury Boils Over
abstract: Ferguson became a scene of chaos, anger and grief after a grand jury declined to indict Officer Darren Wilson in the fatal shooting of Michael Brown.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — Months of anger and frustration, in the end, led only to more anger and frustration.

headline: Paul Katz, Big-Picture Architect, Dies at 57
abstract: As president and managing principal of one of the world’s leading architectural firms, Kohn Pedersen Fox Associates, Mr. Katz was the mastermind of many of its major projects in Japan, Shanghai, London and New York.
lead_paragraph: Paul Katz, who as president and managing principal of one of the world’s leading architectural firms, Kohn Pedersen Fox Associates, was the mastermind of many of its major projects in Japan, Shanghai, London and New York, died on Nov. 20 in Manhattan. He was 57.

headline: In Latest Loss, Carmelo Anthony Hurts Back to Add to Knicks’ Woes
abstract: Troubled by what the team described as back spasms, Anthony left the court late in the first half and missed the remainder of the game.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Befitting his stature with the Knicks, Carmelo Anthony occupied two folding chairs on the bench in the second quarter. He sat silently with a towel draped across his shoulders, powerless to prevent the Rockets from building an early lead on Monday.

headline: Hacker Disrupts Government Websites in Canada
abstract: A gyrating banana greeted many visiting the pages for Parliament, the Supreme Court, the city of Ottawa and the Ottawa and Toronto police forces.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Since Friday, people turning to the websites of Canada’s Parliament, its Supreme Court, the city of Ottawa and the Ottawa and Toronto police forces have been occasionally greeted by a gyrating, anthropomorphic banana or, more frequently, an error message.

headline: ‘Sleepy Hollow’ Recap: A Weird Night That Seemed Strangely Familiar
abstract: Did the episode remind you of “Harry Potter”? And your best anagrams please.
lead_paragraph: “Sleepy Hollow,” Season 2, Episode 10: “Magnus Opus”

headline: Villanova Doesn’t Allow V.C.U. to Wreak Its Trademark Havoc
abstract: The Wildcats answered the Rams’ defensive pressure with a second-half barrage and won handily in the Legends Classic at Barclays Center.
lead_paragraph: November games in the college basketball season seldom materialize like the one Monday night at Barclays Center — not even the better matchups, the ones that are circled on calendars far ahead of time. Turnovers and missed shots are expected. Proper execution takes time.

headline: Obama Responds to Ferguson Decision
abstract: President Obama spoke about the grand jury’s decision not to indict the police officer who shot Michael Brown, calling for peace among protesters and restraint among law enforcement.
lead_paragraph: President Obama spoke about the grand jury’s decision not to indict the police officer who shot Michael Brown, calling for peace among protesters and restraint among law enforcement.

headline: Jimmy Fallon’s Name Goes on 30 Rock Marquee
abstract: The marquee, consistent with the building’s Art Deco architecture, announces that it is home to “The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon.”
lead_paragraph: Jimmy Fallon is getting top billing on one of New York’s landmark buildings with a new marquee that adorns the Avenue of the Americas entrance to 30 Rockefeller Plaza.

headline: Rex Ryan Probably Won’t Survive as Jets Plunge to New Depths
abstract: After the Jets’ latest embarrassing loss, to the Buffalo Bills, very few people in the organization have job security, least of all Ryan.
lead_paragraph: There are bad losses, and the Jets have had some of those in this horrid season. There are ugly losses, and the Jets have had some of those, too. Then there are pathetic losses, the kind that gets coaches — and, others, perhaps — fired, and that is what the Jets absorbed on Monday night.

abstract: This word has appeared in 25 New York Times articles in the past year.

headline: Michael Brown’s Mother, Stepfather React
abstract: Lesley McSpadden, mother of Michael Brown, and his stepfather, Louis Head, reacted to a grand jury’s decision not to indict Officer Darren Wilson.
lead_paragraph: Lesley McSpadden, mother of Michael Brown, and his stepfather, Louis Head, reacted to a grand jury’s decision not to indict Officer Darren Wilson.

headline: Wave of Anger After Ferguson Decision
abstract: A grand jury found no probable cause for any charge in the death of Michael Brown.
lead_paragraph: A grand jury found no probable cause for any charge in the death of Michael Brown.

headline: The Poison-the-Well Myth, and How Politics Really Works
abstract: If Republicans wanted to pass an immigration overhaul, they would do so, regardless of whether President Obama were being confrontational.
lead_paragraph: There are certainly some serious critiques of President Obama’s new immigration policy. It could encourage more illegal immigration in the long run. It may be another step toward an imperial presidency, detached from Congress. It definitely could have been executed less cynically, given that Mr. Obama all but admitted he delayed the announcement until after the midterms, in an (unsuccessful) effort to help Democrats on the ballot.

headline: Musical Ode to Xi Jinping and His Wife Goes Viral
abstract: “Xi Dada Loves Peng Mama” and its accompanying video were inspired by images of China’s top couple together in recent news coverage, the song’s lyricist said.
lead_paragraph: A musical homage to President Xi Jinping of China and his wife, Peng Liyuan, has circulated widely online in recent days, a sign of how the public face of Chinese leadership has changed since Mr. Xi took office two years ago.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (13) RETURN TO THE WILD In April 1992, Christopher McCandless, 24, left behind his middle-class life, gave away his money, changed his name and hiked into the Alaskan wilderness in a quest to live off the land. That September, his remains, weighing only 66 pounds, were discovered in the abandoned bus he had used for shelter. Mr. McCandless’s story was recounted by Jon Krakauer in the best seller “Into the Wild,” which was adapted into a 2007 film by Sean Penn, starring Emile Hirsch. This documentary, based on the recent book “The Wild Truth,” by Mr. McCandless’s sister Carine, draws on new information and previously unreleased letters written to her by Mr. McCandless that shed light on his disappearance.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, November 25, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “Everybody wants me to be calm. You know what them bullets did to my son!”

headline: Japan Calls for Speed in Repair of Takata Airbags
abstract: The Japanese Transport Ministry said it had ordered 10 domestic and foreign automakers to speed up efforts to notify owners and fix their vehicles.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japanese safety regulators said on Tuesday that they had ordered automakers to move more quickly to repair defective airbags made by the Takata Corporation, saying that nearly half of the more than two million vehicles recalled in the country were still being driven.

abstract: Documents and evidence presented to the grand jury that was deciding whether to indict Officer Darren Wilson in the shooting of Michael Brown.
lead_paragraph: Documents and evidence presented to the grand jury that was deciding whether to indict Officer Darren Wilson in the shooting of Michael Brown.

headline: Eli Lilly Gets European Approval to Sell Trulicity, a Type 2 Diabetes Drug
abstract: The move by the European Commission puts pressure on the company’s Danish rival, Novo Nordisk, the market leader in its category.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Eli Lilly, the American pharmaceutical giant, said on Tuesday that it had received European approval to sell its new drug for treating Type 2 diabetes, putting pressure on its Danish rival Novo Nordisk, the market leader in its category.

headline: Charles E. Schumer to Urge Democrats to ‘Embrace Government’
abstract: The senator from New York will urge his party to counter the Republicans’ argument that government is the source of the country’s ills.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — If history is really written by the victors, the story of what happened in the 2014 midterm elections will be about the failure of Democratic policies and a repudiation of the liberalism that President Obama champions.

lead_paragraph: Below are the first six paragraphs from a November 2011 article, “Prepare to Indulge.”

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Grand Jury Does Not Charge Ferguson Officer in Michael Brown Shooting
abstract: How did Michael Brown’s family respond to the announcement?
lead_paragraph: In “Protests Flare After Ferguson Police Officer Is Not Indicted,” Monica Davey, Julie Bosman and John Eligon report on Monday night’s events in Ferguson, Mo.

headline: The Business Tycoons of Airbnb
abstract: The sharing economy is supposed to offer a new kind of capitalism for regular folks. But a class of well-heeled professionals are outperforming the amateurs.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, when the monthly rent on his two-bedroom apartment rose to $5,000 from $2,800, a 35-year-old real estate agent in Lower Manhattan had a quick fix. Rather than move, or take on some random Craigslist subletter, he listed the smaller bedroom on Airbnb, the vacation-rental website. Eventually he was charging $175 a night for short-term stays. It earned him enough to cover the astronomical rent increase, said the agent, who insisted on anonymity to avoid professional and legal consequences.

headline: Do Online Death Threats Count as Free Speech?
abstract: After decades of declaring true threats as an exception to the rule against criminalizing speech, the Supreme Court will consider whether threats on social media count, too.
lead_paragraph: Exhibit 12 in the government’s case against Anthony Elonis is a screenshot of a Facebook post he wrote in October 2010, five months after his wife, Tara, left him. His name appears in the site’s familiar blue, followed by words that made Tara fear for her life: ‘'If I only knew then what I know now . . . I would have smothered your ass with a pillow. Dumped your body in the back seat. Dropped you off in Toad Creek and made it look like a rape and murder.'’

headline: Officer Darren Wilson’s Grand Jury Testimony in Ferguson, Mo., Shooting
abstract: Officer Wilson explained why, in his view, the episode with Michael Brown, whom he compared to a demon and Hulk Hogan, became violent.
lead_paragraph: Officer Wilson explained why, in his view, the episode with Michael Brown, whom he compared to a demon and Hulk Hogan, became violent.

headline: Getting to the Feeling Behind the Photos
abstract: A look at how ProPublica and Frontline collaborated to explore, through the lives of several subjects, the controversial relationship between Firestone and Charles Taylor of Liberia.
lead_paragraph: Joseph Sexton sent me one of his classic emails in May. “Liberia, june X-Y, You available?”

headline: What Is Your Reaction to the Grand Jury’s Decision in the Ferguson Case?
abstract: Have you been watching this case closely? Were you surprised by the grand jury’s decision? How do you think Ferguson and the St. Louis area will react to the news?
lead_paragraph: Darren Wilson, a white police officer, fatally shot Michael Brown, an unarmed African-American teenager, in Ferguson, Mo. this summer. In the wake of the shooting, Ferguson erupted in weeks of protest and anger. On Monday night, a St. Louis County grand jury announced its decision not to bring criminal charges against Officer Wilson.

headline: Proposed Regulations Aim to Clamp Down on Smoking in China
abstract: Hundreds of millions of people who smoke in China may face much tougher rules in the future, as draft regulations banning smoking in all indoor public places have been unveiled.
lead_paragraph: In a country where some primary schools are known as “tobacco elementaries” for accepting money from tobacco companies and displaying slogans such as “Tobacco Makes You Accomplished and Smart,” the Chinese government has released a  draft of anti-tobacco regulations that for the first time would ban smoking in all indoor public places.

headline: Steinhoff International to Buy Pepkor of South Africa for $5.7 Billion
abstract: The deal to acquire the operator of Pep, the largest retailer in Africa, is expected to expand Steinhoff’s footprint, particularly in the discount retail space.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Steinhoff International Holdings of South Africa said on Tuesday that it had agreed to acquire a majority stake in the investment holding company Pepkor for 62.8 billion rand, or about $5.7 billion, in shares and cash.

headline: Vista Equity Partners to Pay $1.1 Billion for British Software Maker
abstract: Advanced Computer Software said its board had unanimously recommended that shareholders vote in favor of the deal.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Vista Equity Partners has agreed to acquire the Advanced Computer Software Group, a British health care and business software maker, for 725 million pounds, or about $1.14 billion.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

abstract: Tuesday: Holiday volunteering, the calm before the snowstorm, and a proposed ban on rabbits.

headline: Hong Kong Police Remove Protesters’ Camp After a Night of Chaotic Clashes
abstract: More than 100 demonstrators were arrested as the authorities dismantled barricades protecting a site where pro-democracy protesters had camped since late September.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Hong Kong police seized control of a street on Wednesday that had served for two months as a base camp for pro-democracy protesters, who were forced into retreat after a night of clashes, pepper spray and more than 100 arrests.

headline: New Chief and Directors for Banco Santander
abstract: Ana Patricia Botín replaced the Spanish lender’s chief executive and reshaped the bank’s board in a significant shake-up.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It didn’t take long for Ana Patricia Botín to put her mark on Banco Santander.

headline: On Ferguson
abstract: Protesters came out after a jury brought no criminal charges against the officer who fatally shot Michael Brown.
lead_paragraph: Protesters came out after a jury brought no criminal charges against the officer who fatally shot Michael Brown.

headline: 1914: India’s Millions Loyal to Core
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The Maharajah of Idar says Indians are loyal to the Empire in 1914.
lead_paragraph: In an interview which he has given to the correspondent of the ‘‘Daily Telegraph’’ at Cairo, the Maharajah of Idar, the adopted son of the celebrated Pertab Singh, speaking of India’s loyalty, said: ‘‘If our Emperor should ask us for one, two or three million men, we shall let him have them.’’ The Maharajah, who is now on his way to the front, emphasized the importance of the wave of patriotism which inspires India, where the triumph of the cause of the Empire is ardently prayed for. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Nov. 26, 1914

headline: China Accuses 7 as Separatists
abstract: The seven studied at Minzu University of China under Ilham Tohti, an ethnic Uighur who was convicted of separatism in September and received a life sentence.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Seven students of Ilham Tohti, an imprisoned ethnic Uighur professor, went on trial on Tuesday in the western Chinese region of Xinjiang on charges of being members of a separatist group, said Li Fangping, a lawyer for Mr. Tohti.

headline: My Mission to Buy Small Business Health Insurance Begins Again
abstract: Based on past experience with the Affordable Care Act, this year’s search is likely to take about half of my working hours over a six-week span.
lead_paragraph: Every November, I return to my annual task of making a decision about health insurance. I’ve been offering this benefit to my employees for more than 20 years, and some aspects are predictable (cost increases) while others are different every year (my choice of plans, the consequences of dropping coverage.)

headline: Today in Politics
abstract: Repercussions of Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel’s resignation and a grand jury decision over the death of Michael Brown are dominating conversation in Washington.

headline: AirDrop Alternatives for Windows and Android
abstract: Plus, minimizing the translucent look of windows and menus in OS X Yosemite.
lead_paragraph: Q. Is there an equivalent of AirDrop for Windows computers and Android phones?

headline: Security in Ferguson Is Tightened After Night of Unrest
abstract: Gov. Jay Nixon deployed 2,200 troops to Ferguson, Mo., in an effort to avoid a repetition of Monday night’s violence, and broadly expanded their role in keeping the peace.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — Gov. Jay Nixon of Missouri said on Tuesday that he would increase the number of National Guard troops in this suburban St. Louis city and broadly expand their role in keeping the peace, after a night of arson, looting and rampaging demonstrators showed that weeks of preparation for a grand jury decision in the fatal shooting of Michael Brown had failed to prevent violence.

headline: Latest Updates: Protests Nationwide as More Troops Are Called to Ferguson
abstract: Following the events the day and evening after the release of the grand jury decision in the shooting of Michael Brown in Ferguson. Mo.
lead_paragraph: Wednesday’s coverage continues here.

headline: ING to Cut 1,700 Jobs and Invest $248 Million in Digital Push
abstract: The Dutch financial services company is the latest European lender to cut jobs and invest in technology to cater to customers who are conducting more of their financial business online.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Dutch financial services company ING Group said on Tuesday that it would cut 1,700 jobs in the Netherlands and invest 200 million euros, or about $248 million, to expand its digital services.

headline: Breaking Silence, Ayatollah Says Iran Is Standing Up to West in Nuclear Talks
abstract: After a deadline for a nuclear deal was extended, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei said world powers had tried and failed to bring Iran “to its knees.”
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — The day after a deadline for concluding a nuclear agreement was extended for seven months, Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, delivered his first remarks on the negotiations, saying that the West had failed to bring Iran “to its knees.”

headline: Morning Agenda: Misdirected Ire at Treasury Nominee
abstract: Senator Elizabeth Warren’s rage at President Obama’s Treasury nominee may be misplaced. | Bearish hedge fund going against the bulls still profits. | Twitter trips up its own chief financial officer. | Mortgage appraisal values Saks at $3.7 billion.
lead_paragraph: SENATOR’S MISPLACED IRE AT TREASURY NOMINEE | Senator Elizabeth Warren’s ire at President Obama’s Treasury nominee is misplaced, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in the DealBook Column. Almost immediately after the president nominated Antonio F. Weiss, a longtime adviser on mergers at the investment bank Lazard and a Democratic supporter, to become the under secretary of Treasury for domestic finance, Ms. Warren denounced the appointment and said she would vote against his confirmation. She said she was furious that the nominee was someone from Wall Street and suggested that Mr. Weiss’s work as an adviser on Burger King’s merger with Tim Hortons, which will result in a combined company based in Canada, should disqualify the him.

headline: In Performance: Quincy Tyler Bernstine in ‘Grand Concourse’
abstract: A scene from Heidi Schreck ‘s new play “Grand Concourse,” set in a church soup kitchen in the Bronx.
lead_paragraph: This week’s video features the actress Quincy Tyler Bernstine of Heidi Schreck ‘s new play “Grand Concourse,” set in a church soup kitchen in the Bronx. In this scene, Shelley (Ms. Bernstine), the nun who runs the kitchen, remembers how a dream about a high school crush guided her decision to join the church. “I understood that my body was holy,” she says. The show, directed by Kip Fagan, continues through Nov. 30 at Playwrights Horizons.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | Nov. 18-24, 2014
abstract: Have you been following the news? Take our quiz to see what you know and to learn more, and look for a new edition each week on Tuesday morning.
lead_paragraph: Have you been following the news?

headline: What Michael Kowalski of Tiffany Will Do Next (It’s Not What You Think)
abstract: The departing chief executive says he is going to become an environmental activist.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, Tiffany, the American jeweler and often-rumored acquisition target, held its annual holiday lunch, the last hosted by Michael J. Kowalski, the chief executive who will retire at the end of March 2015. (His successor, Frederic Cumenal, starts April 1, a.k.a. April Fool’s Day, but that is an unfortunate coincidence of accounting.)

headline: No, It Isn’t the Season
abstract: A seasonally appropriate reminder about one of the hoariest holiday clichés: “Christmas came early for so-and-so.”
lead_paragraph: My colleague Mark Bulik offered this reminder about one of the hoariest holiday clichés:

headline: Spielberg Deals Bill Clinton Into a Beloved Card Game
abstract: The director introduced Mr. Clinton to a new game during his 1996 re-election campaign.
lead_paragraph: President Clinton was staying at Steven Spielberg’s Hamptons home during the 1996 re-election campaign when he decided to switch card games.

headline: Failures Preceded British Soldier’s Killing
abstract: A report by a parliamentary committee on the killing of Lee Rigby outlined mistakes by British agencies and an American technology company preceding his death.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The two men who killed a soldier on a London street last year had figured in seven investigations by British intelligence agencies, and one of the men had threatened online to commit just such a murder five months before the attack, lawmakers said in a report issued on Tuesday.

headline: Daily Clip Report
abstract: Daily Clip Report is a collection of articles about the media and The Times that is emailed each day to senior executives and newsroom managers here.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

headline: 1939: Hungary to Defend Europe
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Hungary was said to be ready to stop Red Army advances to the west in 1939.
lead_paragraph: BUDAPEST — The moment Russian troops enter Bessarabia, the Hungarian Army will march into Transylvania to defend Central Europe against any further advance of Bolshevism, it was stated in semi-official Hungarian circles today. It is evident that the Hungarian government could not, for diplomatic reasons, make an open declaration to this effect. But it may be taken for granted, on good authority, that this will be its line of action, should the Soviets begin to expand in southeastern Europe. If the Russians should occupy Bessarabia, it is said here, it would be the sacred duty of Hungary to come out for the protection of Middle Europe against the Red peril. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Nov. 26, 1939

headline: The Verrazano-Narrows Bridge at 50
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A poetic tribute to the bridge spanning the narrows between Brooklyn and Staten Island, which opened on Nov. 21, 1964.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: The Daily Gift: Decorative Nails that Combine Form and Function
abstract: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.
lead_paragraph: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.

headline: At European Parliament, Pope Bluntly Critiques a Continent’s Malaise
abstract: Europe, he declared before the European Parliament in France, has lost its way, its energies sapped by economic crisis and a remote, technocratic bureaucracy.
lead_paragraph: STRASBOURG, France — The last pope to address the European Parliament, John Paul II, rejoiced at what he described as a “special moment in the history of this continent” in October 1988, as Communism was crumbling and Europe was drawing closer together.

headline: Amid Conflicting Accounts, Trusting Darren Wilson
abstract: In testimony from roughly 60 witnesses, there were varying accounts of the critical final moments, when Michael Brown stopped running, turned and moved back toward Officer Darren Wilson.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — In the end, it seems, it all came down to Officer Darren Wilson himself.

headline: Protests in Ferguson and Across the Country
abstract: After a grand jury chose not to indict a police officer in the death of Michael Brown, demonstrations turned violent in Ferguson, Mo., and spread to other cities.
lead_paragraph: After a grand jury chose not to indict a police officer in the death of Michael Brown, demonstrations turned violent in Ferguson, Mo., and spread to other cities.

headline: The Thanksgiving Recipes Googled in Every State
abstract: Which foods are unusually popular in each state on Thanksgiving.
lead_paragraph: Which foods are unusually popular in each state on Thanksgiving.

headline: Runoff Will Decide President of Tunisia
abstract: As no presidential candidate secured a majority, the two front-runners in the race will face each other, the election board announced on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: TUNIS — Tunisia’s first democratic presidential election will be decided in a runoff next month between the two leading candidates, President Moncef Marzouki and Beji Caid Essebsi, a former prime minister, the election board announced on Tuesday.

headline: Splurging on Opulent Holiday Displays at the Office
abstract: For the first time since the recession, many of Manhattan’s real estate firms are spending lavishly on decorations, some investing $1 million on displays.
lead_paragraph: MOUNT VERNON, N.Y. — Inside a warehouse on an industrial stretch of road here, workers holding bunches of red berries and glittery Christmas ornaments dash between aisles of boxes filled with ribbons and pine cones, as 18-foot candy canes made of chicken wire and garland tower above them.

headline: What Makes the Russian Literature of the 19th Century So Distinctive?
abstract: Francine Prose and Benjamin Moser discuss the great Russian writers and their approach to the human heart and soul.
lead_paragraph: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Francine Prose and Benjamin Moser discuss the great Russian writers and their approach to the human heart and soul.

headline: An Onion of a Novel, Demanding to Be Peeled
abstract: Ali Smith says her much-lauded new novel, “How to Be Both,” explores how every great narrative is always about what is on the surface and what is hidden underneath.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, England — One of the two separate but not separate narratives of Ali Smith’s mind-bending new novel, “How to Be Both,” begins when the mother of a girl named George says something during a car trip.

headline: A Gilded Getaway
abstract: La Réserve, a new Haussmann-style hotel and spa opening soon in the Eighth Arrondissement in Paris, harkens back to the grandeur of the Belle Époque.
lead_paragraph: Everything about La Réserve, a new Haussmann-style hotel and spa opening soon in the Eighth Arrondissement in Paris, harkens back to the grandeur of the Belle Époque. Like previous collaborations between the interior designer Jacques Garcia and the hotelier and vintner Michel Reybier (La Réserve’s Geneva property and the chateau at Reybier’s 225-acre vineyard in Bordeaux), the secluded 40-room residence is an exercise in effortless glamour, adorned with rare antiques and draped in ghost damask, papal purple and ballet-satin pink. For the full Baudelairian experience, there’s also a smoking parlor and round-the-clock butler service.

headline: Report on the Intelligence Relating to the Murder of Fusilier Lee Rigby
abstract: A British parliamentary committee investigating the killing of Lee Rigby pointed to mistakes by British intelligence but laid much of the blame on an American technology company.
lead_paragraph: A British parliamentary committee investigating the killing of Lee Rigby pointed to mistakes by British intelligence but laid much of the blame on an American technology company.

headline: The Lives of Alexander Grothendieck, a Mathematical Visionary
abstract: To say Alexander Grothendieck was the No. 1 mathematician of the second half of the 20th century cannot begin to do justice to him or his body of work.
lead_paragraph: Alexander Grothendieck, who died on Nov. 13 at the age of 86, was a visionary who captivated the collective psyche of his peers like no one else. To say he was the No. 1 mathematician of the second half of the 20th century cannot begin to do justice to him or his body of work. Let’s resist the temptation to assign a number to a man of numbers. There are deeper lessons to be learned from this extraordinary human being and his extraordinary life.

headline: What ‘Big Thing’ Would Reinvigorate the Democratic Party?
abstract: After the midterm debacle, liberals are looking for a compelling national vision.
lead_paragraph: “The party needs to fundamentally retool our thinking.” “We must speak to the aspirations and the anxieties of every American.” “We have extraordinarily real and deep problems.”

headline: New York Times Names Kinsey Wilson to Leadership Role
abstract: Mr. Wilson will be responsible for innovation and strategy, the newspaper announced on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times has appointed Kinsey Wilson, a former NPR executive and USA Today executive editor, to its masthead to oversee innovation and strategy, the newspaper announced on Tuesday.

headline: Wine by the Glass Goes High-End
abstract: Hotels are expanding their single-serving pours because of the Coravin, a wine preservation tool introduced last year.
lead_paragraph: Wine drinkers looking to order by the glass usually have limited choices, especially for high-end or hard-to-find vintages, but hotels around the country are expanding their single-serving pours because of the Coravin, a wine preservation tool introduced last year.

headline: Nation Reacts to Ferguson Decision
abstract: People around the country protested after a St. Louis County grand jury decided not to bring charges against Darren Wilson, a police officer who fatally shot an unarmed teenager.
lead_paragraph: People around the country protested after a St. Louis County grand jury decided not to bring charges against Darren Wilson, a police officer who fatally shot an unarmed teenager.

headline: Amid Uproar, Cosby Gets Standing Ovations at Florida Show
abstract: Despite a small protest outside a theater at Eastern Florida State College in Melbourne, Fla., Bill Cosby performed to applause without addressing accusations of sexual assault.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Fla. — The uproar over allegations that Bill Cosby had molested or assaulted several women, in some cases years ago, was almost nowhere in evidence on Friday night during a sold-out performance by the 77-year-old comedian on a college campus here.

headline: Philip Falcone, Hedge Fund Chief in Exile, Is Stepping Down
abstract: Mr. Falcone will receive a lump-sum payment of $20.5 million and a $19.8 million bonus. He rejected speculation that the payment might indicate he was in need of cash.
lead_paragraph: Philip A. Falcone, the hedge fund manager who made billions betting against the housing market and then lost a bundle trying to build a wireless network, is once again trying to reinvent himself.

headline: Have Your Holiday Travel Plans Changed Because of the Weather? Tell Us
abstract: Has the weather forecast changed your holiday travel plans? If so, how? The Times wants to hear your story for possible inclusion in our weather coverage.
lead_paragraph: The current weather forecast in the region is turning worse by the hour. Snow is expected Wednesday from Washington to Boston, and New York City might get its share, too. Depending on when the rain shifts to snow, the city could get between 2 to 6 inches.

headline: Vegetarian Thanksgiving: A Quinoa Stuffing
abstract: Vegans and non-vegans will enjoy this twist on a traditional stuffing, where quinoa replaces the bread and butternut squash, celeriac and hazelnuts add the flavors of fall.
lead_paragraph: Thanksgiving stuffing is a favorite tradition, but if it’s stuffed in the bird or made with meat-stock, it’s off limits to vegetarian and vegan diners.

headline: Traveling Solo With Children, and Playing the Deployment Card
abstract: With my husband deployed, my days of team man-on-man defense are over. I’m playing zone with two toddlers, and traveling, as we will this week, is the hardest game of all.
lead_paragraph: When talking about the possibility of having a third baby, my husband and I joke that the switch from man-on-man defense to zone is a game changer. With him deployed, I’m finding more and more that the one parent to two toddler ratio is a constant fast break. This week has been no exception.While helping my 3-year-old get a drink, my 2-year-old got into my makeup bag. When I heard that guilty voice yell from another room: “Mommy! Look at me!” I knew he had found trouble. Luckily, it was just a tube of lipstick. I got him (and our walls) cleaned up just in time to find my daughter “helping” clean by spraying liquid Clorox on my bag of groceries. Is bleach GMO free?

headline: Restaurant Review: Bar Bolonat in the West Village
abstract: The chef Einat Admony and the flavors of multiethnic Israel shine after the restaurant’s rough start.
lead_paragraph: Some restaurants hit the ground at full tilt. This review concerns one of the others, a place that stumbled at the start, as ungainly as a day-old giraffe, and only recently found its footing.

headline: SIG Deal Shows Private Equity’s Desire for Big Leveraged Buyouts in Europe
abstract: The deal for the Swiss packaging firm SIG, one of Europe’s biggest leveraged buyouts in five years, is an indication of a shortage of big targets for private equity firms, Reuters Breakingviews writes.
lead_paragraph: Private equity’s hunt for large European targets has landed a rare catch. The leveraged buyout of Switzerland’s SIG Combibloc for 3.75 billion euros, or $4.7 billion, has demonstrated that financial sponsors can still stretch to get a sizable transaction done.

headline: Jewels Without Gems
abstract: Instead of mining precious metals and stones to create her one-of-a-kind accessories, the Italian jewelry designer Olivia Monti Arduini makes her pieces out of porcelain.
lead_paragraph: Instead of mining precious metals and stones to create her one-of-a-kind accessories, the Italian jewelry designer Olivia Monti Arduini makes necklaces and bracelets — and even corsets, capes and vests — out of porcelain. There is a luminous quality to her pieces, one of which inspired a show of erotic jewelry in Madrid last spring, and a lightness of touch that belies her painstaking craft. Acknowledging that the average necklace takes about 20 hours to make by hand, Monti Arduini says with a laugh, “While I love the Zen-like concentration, I doubt I will ever find an assistant patient enough to help me.”

headline: 3rd-Quarter Growth Rate Is Revised Up, to 3.9%
abstract: The Commerce Department’s revised estimate of gross domestic product showed that consumers had already stepped up their pace of spending.
lead_paragraph: The nation’s economic output grew at an even faster rate during July, August and September than the government initially estimated, giving the economy its strongest six-month performance in more than a decade.

headline: O.E.C.D. Calls for Fiscal and Monetary Measures to Spur E.U. Growth
abstract: Leaders of the bloc should consider allowing more time for nations to bring government spending in line with European rules, the group’s chief said.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Top officials at the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development warned on Tuesday that weakness in the eurozone was a threat to the global economy and called on leaders of the European Union to carry out fiscal and monetary measures, in addition to structural reforms, to restore growth.

headline: Twitter Adds Coupons to Its Commerce Plans
abstract: Twitter Offers will allow advertisers to add coupons inside of tweets. The social media company hopes it will be a novel way for businesses to woo customers.
lead_paragraph: Twitter has long said it works best as a tool for serving up news on what’s happening, as it happens.

headline: Europe Takes Another Look at Net Neutrality
abstract: Some European lawmakers are pushing to loosen the net neutrality rules somewhat, allowing companies to potentially charge for faster access to their networks.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Just as the United States takes steps to secure people’s unfettered access to the Internet, Europe may soon backtrack on its own proposals.

headline: How Darren Wilson Saw Michael Brown in Ferguson
abstract: In his testimony, he said the unarmed teenager “looked like he was almost bulking up to run through the shots.”
lead_paragraph: After announcing that Darren Wilson, the police officer who killed Michael Brown this summer, would not be indicted, Ferguson officials made available Mr. Wilson’s testimony. Here’s how he described shooting the unarmed teenager.

headline: Underlings Again Seek the Upper Hand
abstract: An invention is part of the plot of “Horrible Bosses 2,” a sequel that tries to recapture the zany feel of the original film.
lead_paragraph: “Horrible Bosses 2,” one of the sloppiest and most unnecessary Hollywood sequels ever made, isn’t dirtier or more offensive than its 2011 forerunner. But it is infinitely dumber and not half as funny.

headline: France Postpones Warship Sale to Russia, Citing Ukraine Conflict
abstract: France agreed in 2011 sell two ships in a deal worth $1.6 billion, but the deal became a source of concern after Russia annexed the Crimean Peninsula.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — France will postpone handing over a sophisticated French-built warship to the Russian Navy “until further notice,” President Franςois Hollande said on Tuesday.

headline: A Task Force in Black Tuxedos
abstract: In the animated “Penguins of Madagascar,” the title animals will lose their cuteness if an octopus named Dave (voiced by John Malkovich) has his way.
lead_paragraph: “Penguins of Madagascar” promises a reasonable share of wit the minute it opens with a voice-over by Werner Herzog, in a sendup of his documentary on Antarctica, “Encounters at the End of the World.” That film posed the question of whether penguins could exhibit insanity. In the case of this spirited animated movie, the answer is assuredly yes.

headline: Thoughts on Race in America, as a Backdrop to Ferguson
abstract: With the renewed violence in Ferguson, we’re once again caught in a painful debate about race in America.
lead_paragraph: In Nov. 2014, the country saw renewed violence in Ferguson, Mo., after a St. Louis County grand jury’s decided not to bring charges against a police officer, Darren Wilson, who shot and killed an unarmed black teenager named Michael Brown.

headline: Hong Kong Protesters Confront Police
abstract: Pro-democracy demonstrators faced off against the police Tuesday after part of a protest site in the Mong Kok neighborhood of Hong Kong was cleared.
lead_paragraph: Pro-democracy demonstrators faced off against the police Tuesday after part of a protest site in the Mong Kok neighborhood of Hong Kong was cleared.

headline: Aggressive Neighbors in the Nursing Home
abstract: One in five nursing home residents was involved in mistreatment of a neighbor in the previous month, a new study found.
lead_paragraph: It will not surprise people who spend time in nursing homes — who live or work there, who volunteer or visit family members — that residents can lash out at each other.

headline: How Baseball Statistics Can Help Explain the Economy
abstract: To predict whether an improvement in economic growth is likely to last, it can be helpful to look at the less obvious clues.
lead_paragraph: Many analysts were downright jubilant about a Commerce Department report Tuesday that the economy grew at a 3.9 percent annual rate in the quarter from July through September, better than the 3.5 percent earlier estimated.

headline: The Punk Legend Viv Albertine Tells All
abstract: A new memoir by the onetime frontwoman of The Slits is titled “Clothes, Clothes, Clothes. Music, Music, Music. Boys, Boys, Boys.” and focuses on those three topics. A playlist culled from the book also appears here.
lead_paragraph: In the 1970s, Viv Albertine was fully entrenched in the English punk scene, a world defined for her by music, blokes and, often, violence. Albertine befriended now-infamous figures like Johnny Rotten and Sid Vicious of the Sex Pistols (Vicious unceremoniously kicked her out of their band Flowers of Romance). She dated the Clash founder Mick Jones after noticing his flamboyant dress in the cafeteria at their art college. And in the late ’70s, Albertine joined the legendary band the Slits as guitarist and they released “Cut,” one of the most influential punk albums of all time. All that, and Albertine wasn’t sure that these memories would make for a fascinating memoir.

headline: Pope Says Europe Seems ‘Elderly and Haggard’
abstract: He chastised European leaders for not doing enough to alleviate suffering.
lead_paragraph: European leaders should pay close attention to a speech Pope Francis delivered to the European Union Parliament on Tuesday, in which he chastised them for not doing enough to alleviate the suffering of the less fortunate.

headline: After Obama’s Immigration Action, a Blast of Energy for the Tea Party
abstract: Federal spending reductions and the battle against the Affordable Care Act are taking a back seat to immigration, to the point that party members are calling for Sarah Palin to oppose John McCain, who supports immigration overhaul.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In all its fury and unanimity, the response from the right to President Obama’s decision to change immigration policy without the consent of Congress was the manifestation of a major transformation within the Tea Party.

headline: Sharpton Announces Civil Rights Meeting
abstract: The Rev. Al Sharpton condemned the grand jury decision in Ferguson, Mo., and announced a meeting of civil rights leaders to determine a new activism strategy.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Al Sharpton condemned the grand jury decision in Ferguson, Mo., and announced a meeting of civil rights leaders to determine a new activism strategy.

headline: As Music Streaming Grows, Spotify Reports Rising Revenue and a Loss
abstract: The privately held music streaming service said it had about $1 billion in 2013 revenue, and $80 million in net losses.
lead_paragraph: Spotify, the company that has come to symbolize the growth of streaming music around the world, had more than $1 billion in revenue in 2013. But it has yet to turn a profit.

headline: A Quarterback Rating That Tries to Measure All the Little Things
abstract: The Colts’ Andrew Luck has ranked higher in Total Quarterback Rating — which measures positive plays that are otherwise ignored — than in the traditional passer rating.
lead_paragraph: In 2011, ESPN introduced Total QBR, or Total Quarterback Rating, a proprietary statistic intended to capture several of the hidden aspects of quarterback play. The next year, the Indianapolis Colts drafted quarterback Andrew Luck. And while he has helped revitalize the franchise, he has also served as one of the shining examples of how Total QBR credits players for positive plays that are otherwise ignored.

headline: What North Dakota Would Look Like if Its Oil Drilling Lines Were Aboveground
abstract: Conceptual illustrations of oil well bores in North Dakota
lead_paragraph: Conceptual illustrations of oil well bores in North Dakota

headline: As Protests Take a Turn, Holder Finds It Harder to Ease Racial Tensions
abstract: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr., who helped soothe protesters after the killing of an unarmed black teenager in the summer, now finds himself with limited options to calm the unrest in Ferguson.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Watching television from home as vandals smashed windows, set fires and looted, Attorney General Eric H.
