Holder Jr., saw that the streets of Ferguson, Mo., had changed since this summer when he helped soothe tensions there after the fatal shooting of an unarmed black teenager by a white police officer.

headline: Schumer Calls Passing Health Act in 2010 a Political Mistake
abstract: Senator Charles E. Schumer said Tuesday that it was a political mistake to pass the Affordable Care Act in 2010 because voters at the time were looking for relief from the recession — not universal health care.
lead_paragraph: One of the Senate’s top Democrats said Tuesday that it was a political mistake to pass the Affordable Care Act in 2010, because voters at the time were looking for relief from the recession — not universal health care.

headline: A Defense Against Hostile Takeovers Develops a Downside
abstract: The “poison put” began as a well-intentioned way to protect debt holders, but like any good idea, it got a little out of hand, writes Steven Davidoff Solomon in the Deal Professor.
lead_paragraph: A recent judicial decision may just upend the hidden world of companies and “poison puts,” a world that frankly could use some clarity.

headline: Farm to Table, Hawaiian Style
abstract: A recent wave of restaurants in Honolulu are finding inspiration in local ingredients, which are increasingly available to island chefs.
lead_paragraph: The crispy Chinese duck, served atop soft Japanese white bread with five-spice gravy and garbanzo mash, was unexpected, and robustly savory. “It’s like Asian Thanksgiving,” my dining companion said as she mopped up the gravy and I extracted the delicately crunchy pieces of duck at Honolulu’s light-filled, elegant MW Restaurant. “Something for everyone.”

headline: Chart Your Seating
abstract: The Thanksgiving meal is America’s most holy secular ritual. Set the table as if for a sacrament.
lead_paragraph: Thursday morning comes quickly out of the dark, and with it the promise of the Thanksgiving feast. Have you set the table yet? You should. Set it as if for a sacrament. The Thanksgiving meal is America’s most holy secular ritual.

headline: In Quiet Puglia, Lots of Classes
abstract: The Borgo Egnazia resort in Puglia is offering off-season classes in subjects like cooking, photography, and golf.
lead_paragraph: The Adriatic coast in Italy’s Puglia’s region is a popular summer vacation spot and usually tourist-free come colder weather, but the Borgo Egnazia resort is trying to lure an off-season crowd with its new Nowhere Else Academies.

headline: A Missed Chance for Tax Revenue: Congressional Parking
abstract: Congress keeps one perk: free parking.
lead_paragraph: When the newly elected Republican majority takes over the Senate and dozens of legislators from the House head back to their states in retirement, a lot of real estate will begin changing hands in the Capitol complex.

headline: Clues to Bees’ History, Tucked Away in Drawers
abstract: Scientists are dusting off old insect collections in museums in an effort to learn what has happened to bee populations.

headline: World Music Institute Names New Leaders
abstract: Par Neiburger has been named artistic director of the World Music Institute and Cynthia McVay was named acting executive director.
lead_paragraph: The World Music Institute, an organization that presents performances of traditional and folk music from around the globe, announced on Tuesday that it had appointed Par Neiburger as its new artistic director and Cynthia McVay as acting executive director. Both positions were held until recently by Karen Sander, who left the institute to become director of public programs at the CUNY Graduate Center.

headline: Reading the Subtleties of Islamic Fashion
abstract: There’s more to it than just the visual.
lead_paragraph: THERE ARE SO MANY fashion weeks these days, from the Big Four (London, New York, Paris and Milan) to Tokyo, Rio, Miami and Abu Dhabi, among others, that I often think I could pass the year going from one to another, the way John Cheever’s Swimmer stroked his way across the pools of the suburbs.

headline: The Meaning of the Ferguson Riots
abstract: Distrust of law enforcement presents a grave danger to the civic fabric of the United States.
lead_paragraph: The St. Louis County grand jury’s decision not to indict the white police officer who in August shot and killed Michael Brown, an unarmed black teenager, would have generated widespread anger and disappointment in any case. But the county prosecutor, Robert McCulloch, who is widely viewed in the minority community as being in the pockets of the police, made matters infinitely worse by handling this sensitive investigation in the worst possible way.

headline: Two Suicide Bombers Kill Dozens in Nigeria
abstract: The attack, which involved at least one female bomber, hit a market in Maiduguri, a city that was once headquarters to Boko Haram, the Islamist insurgent group.
lead_paragraph: MAIDUGURI, Nigeria — Two suicide bombers, at least one of them a woman, blew themselves up on Tuesday at a crowded market in this northeast Nigerian city, killing dozens of shoppers and merchants, including some who witnesses said were decapitated by the explosions.

headline: HBO Plans Documentary on Cobain
abstract: ‘Kurt Cobain: Montage of Heck’ is an authorized documentary about the Nirvana frontman.
lead_paragraph: “Kurt Cobain: Montage of Heck,” an authorized documentary about Nirvana’s frontman and songwriter, whose life and work still fascinate music fans 20 years after his suicide in 1994, will have its premiere on HBO in 2015, the network said. A specific date was not given.

headline: Supreme Court to Hear Challenge to Rules on Mercury From Power Plants
abstract: Industry groups, energy companies and 20 states are challenging the E.P.A.'s interpretation of the law and whether the costs of adhering to regulations should be taken into account.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court agreed Tuesday to hear a major challenge to the limits set by the Obama administration on emissions of mercury and other toxic pollutants from coal-fired power plants.

headline: The Damage in Ferguson
abstract: More than a dozen buildings in Ferguson, Mo., were significantly damaged in the rioting that followed the announcement that Darren Wilson, a white police officer, would not be indicted in the shooting death of Michael Brown, an unarmed black teenager.
lead_paragraph: More than a dozen buildings in Ferguson, Mo., were significantly damaged in the rioting that followed the announcement that Darren Wilson, a white police officer, would not be indicted in the shooting death of Michael Brown, an unarmed black teenager.

headline: Panel Rejects Sternest F.D.A. Warning for Steroid Shots
abstract: Recommending the toughest federal alert would have signaled to doctors that the risks of use outweighed any potential therapeutic benefit for patients.
lead_paragraph: SILVER SPRING, Md. — A panel of medical experts advising the Food and Drug Administration on Tuesday decided not to recommend slapping the sternest federal warning on steroid injections for neck and back pain, allowing their use to continue relatively unchanged. Millions of Americans get such treatments annually.

headline: Mu Ramen Headlines Restaurant Openings
abstract: A husband-and-wife team gets a new start in Long Island City after operating a pop-up that gained a big following.
lead_paragraph: Headliner Mu Ramen

headline: Justices Take a Major Environmental Case
abstract: Industry groups, energy companies and 20 states are challenging the E.P.A.’s interpretation of the law and whether the costs of adhering to regulations should be taken into account.
lead_paragraph: Supreme Court to Hear Challenge to Rules on Mercury From Power Plants

headline: A Dual Review of What’s New Starring Joan Collins and Alexander Wang
abstract: Joan Collins and Alexander Wang unwrap a festive handbag, a bankbreaking chocolate tree and some sausage soap.
lead_paragraph: Joan Collins, O.B.E.-decorated English actress, no-holds-barred memoirist and sharpclawed catfight queen whose cosmetics, skincare and fragrance line, Timeless Beauty, is available through QVC UK, takes on Alexander Wang, American fashion’s boy wonder and creative director of Balenciaga whose recent H&M collection further established the downtown scenester as a household name.

headline: E.U. Investment Plan Aims for Billions to Spur Economy
abstract: The idea is to finance big projects and small and midsize businesses. But most of the money would have to come from private lenders.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The European Union authorities are set to unveil a long-awaited investment plan on Wednesday with the ambition of channeling 315 billion euros into public infrastructure projects like transportation, communications and energy over the next three years.

headline: S.E.C. Settles Swiss Banking Secrecy Case With an HSBC Unit
abstract: The S.E.C. extracted a $12.5 million penalty, a fraction of the penalty assessed in a similar case against Credit Suisse.
lead_paragraph: Washington’s crackdown on Swiss bank secrecy gained steam on Tuesday, as HSBC’s private banking unit in Switzerland settled an investigation into how it had solicited American clients.

headline: Mazda Recalls 100,000 Cars for Defect in Tire Pressure Sensor
abstract: The automaker says some 2014-15 Mazda 6s may not alert the driver when all four tires are low; Land Rover and Mini also recall vehicles.
lead_paragraph: Mazda is recalling almost 100,000 Mazda 6 sedans from the 2014-15 model years because the federally mandated low-tire pressure warning system may not work, the automaker said in a report posted Tuesday on the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration website.

headline: A Warning on Nutmeg
abstract: This holiday season, measure your nutmeg carefully.
lead_paragraph: In these early days of the holiday season, as cooks begin sifting through recipes rich in spice and sugar, consider this small warning from toxicologists: Measure your nutmeg carefully.

headline: Obama Threatens to Veto $440 Billion Tax Deal
abstract: The president, saying that an emerging agreement to extend a number of existing tax cuts favored corporations over the middle class, delivered a setback to negotiations that have already been divisive.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With negotiators nearing an accord on permanent tax breaks for businesses worth $440 billion over 10 years, President Obama rallied Democratic opposition on Tuesday and promised a veto.

headline: First Look Abandons Plans to Publish The Racket After Matt Taibbi’s Departure
abstract: The company laid off nine employees hired for the online magazine, which was going to be led by Mr. Taibbi, a writer critical of Wall Street.
lead_paragraph: First Look Media, the $250 million news organization started by the billionaire Pierre M. Omidyar, announced on Tuesday that it had abandoned plans to publish The Racket, an online magazine that was to be run by the Rolling Stone writer Matt Taibbi, and will lay off most of the magazine’s staff.

headline: Vegetarian Thanksgiving: Vegetable Tarts, Big and Small
abstract: Vegetable tarts as appetizers or the main course make for a welcome addition to any Thanksgiving table.
lead_paragraph: A vegetable tart is a welcome addition to the Thanksgiving meal, offering vegetarian guests a hearty main course and tempting the turkey-eaters as a pleasing side dish.

headline: A Trio of New Holiday-Scented Hostess Presents
abstract: Redolent of spice, evergreens or fire, a spate of new candles and sprays are ideal for taking to Thanksgiving dinner or a winter cocktail party.
lead_paragraph: This season, chic new holiday scents make for nice hostess gifts that keep on giving, and taking one to Thanksgiving dinner or winter cocktail parties with a thoughtful note is thanks enough.

headline: A Raw Scene as Ferguson Turns Violent
abstract: Protests turned into riots in Ferguson, Mo., Monday night after a grand jury decided not to charge Officer Darren Wilson for the death of Michael Brown.
lead_paragraph: Protests turned into riots in Ferguson, Mo., Monday night after a grand jury decided not to charge Officer Darren Wilson for the death of Michael Brown.

headline: Instagramming the Ferguson Decision
abstract: A grand jury’s decision in Missouri not to indict Darren Wilson, a white police officer who fatally shot Michael Brown, an unarmed black teenager, set off a wave of video reactions on social media.
lead_paragraph: A grand jury’s decision in Missouri not to indict Darren Wilson, a white police officer who fatally shot Michael Brown, an unarmed black teenager, set off a wave of video reactions on social media.

headline: Covering the Ferguson Verdict Protests, With Kids in the Minivan
abstract: My 5-year-old has become a veteran of the protests I often cover as a journalist, so much so that she has her own explanations. “Did they shoot someone again, Mama?” she asked. “His parents must be very, very sad. It’s like that boy in the pictures in Times Square, remember?”
lead_paragraph: We didn’t rent a minivan yesterday afternoon so we could be ready to pack up our three children and head out to the streets after the Ferguson verdict to cover the protests in Union Square and Times Square. We rented a minivan in preparation for a Thanksgiving road trip.

headline: Brown Family Lawyer Calls for Change
abstract: Benjamin Crump, the attorney for Michael Brown’s family, called for changes in procedure after a grand jury decided not to indict the officer that fatally shot Mr. Brown.
lead_paragraph: Benjamin Crump, the attorney for Michael Brown’s family, called for changes in procedure after a grand jury decided not to indict the officer that fatally shot Mr. Brown.

headline: An Ex-Congressman Whose Retirement Plan Is Charity
abstract: Using leftover campaign funds to help favorite causes is common among current and former elected officials. But one man stands out.
lead_paragraph: For the past 12 years, the campaign account of John LaFalce, a former Democratic congressman, has acted like a mini-foundation for the charities and civic institutions of Western New York, giving small amounts of money around the year.

headline: A Pioneer’s Tribute Is Both a Reward and a Reminder
abstract: Charlie Sifford, who in 1961 became the first African-American to join the PGA Tour, on Monday was awarded the nation’s highest civilian honor by President Obama.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Charlie Sifford is a man of few words, but on Monday he was nearly moved to tears.

headline: The Slippery Slope of Silicon Valley
abstract: Are tech companies like Uber, Google and Facebook ethically challenged?
lead_paragraph: Ahh, Thanksgiving, the time of year to stop the daily drudgery and give thanks for what we have. To be grateful for our family, friends and health. Maybe this is also a perfect time to be thankful for all the wonderful things technology start-ups have done for society.

headline: Pope Francis Addresses European Union
abstract: In Pope Francis’ first address to the European Parliament, he called for a united response to the plight of migrants. “We cannot allow the Mediterranean to become a vast cemetery,” he said.
lead_paragraph: In Pope Francis’ first address to the European Parliament, he called for a united response to the plight of migrants. “We cannot allow the Mediterranean to become a vast cemetery,” he said.

headline: Fight Brews in Congress Over Spending Bill
abstract: Party leaders in the House spar over the Cromnibus, a combination of the omnibus spending bill and a short-term stop-gap spending measure.
lead_paragraph: It’s that time of year again — falling leaves, pumpkin pie and, yes, the fabled “Cromnibus.”

headline: I.O.C. Corrects Record on 1964 American Skating Pair
abstract: After a German team long ago had its silver medals stripped and then re-awarded, the International Olympic Committee updated its website to recognize Vivian and Ronald Joseph as bronze medalists.
lead_paragraph: A little more than 50 years after they skated in the 1964 Winter Games in Innsbruck, Austria, the American figure skaters Vivian and Ronald Joseph can finally call themselves Olympic bronze medalists — and, unlike in years past, they now have the International Olympic Committee to back up their claim.

headline: Unpredictable East Coast Storm Could Snarl Thanksgiving Travel
abstract: More than 20 million people live in the area under a winter storm warning, and some parts of New York and New Jersey could see 10 inches of snow on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: First the snows buried the Buffalo area, a result of a sudden rush of cold air that plunged much of the nation into a deep freeze. Then came the warmth, with temperatures in New York City soaring above 70 degrees on Monday.

headline: A Hong Kong Street Switches From Ships to (Michelin) Stars
abstract: A stretch of Wanchai, where ships once docked for repairs, is home to trendy dining spots and big-name chefs.
lead_paragraph: As rentals escalate in neighboring districts, the once nondescript Ship Street in Wanchai, Hong Kong — which sits on reclaimed land where ships once docked for repairs — is fast becoming the site du jour for trendy dining outposts headlined by a coterie of big-name chefs lining the narrow side street. Perhaps most telling of its gentrification is 18 Ship Street, where the street’s only preserved tong lau (pre-1960s Chinese shophouse) has been home to a private kitchen, Yin Yang, a Ship Street stalwart, since 2008. Yin Yang has recently relocated.

headline: Another Destination for a Player Often on the Move
abstract: Yael Averbuch will play for Kansas City in the National Women’s Soccer League, yet another move in a career that has taken her to Europe and beyond.
lead_paragraph: UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J. — Sometimes my life feels like a maze. I continually come to a fork in the road and I am presented with a tough decision. My entire career, I have been faced with choices, and I have sometimes felt compelled to create paths that weren’t offered.

headline: What Ferguson Says About the Fear of Social Media
abstract: The St. Louis County prosecutor, Robert McCulloch, called social media a “challenge” to the investigation in Ferguson, Mo. Did it actually challenge his authority?
lead_paragraph: “The most significant challenge encountered in this investigation has been the 24-hour news cycle and its insatiable appetite for something, for anything, to talk about. Following closely behind were the nonstop rumors on social media.”

headline: Kenneth P. Martin
abstract: Mr. Martin is the chief executive and president of REMCO, a company that provides building restoration and maintenance services.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Martin, 51, is the chief executive and president of REMCO, a company that provides building restoration and maintenance services. REMCO has worked on several iconic buildings throughout New York, such as Grand Central Terminal, St. Patrick’s Cathedral and the New York Stock Exchange. Its recent projects include work on One World Trade Center.

headline: Blood Brothers and Their Feuds, for Generations
abstract: A semi-staged version of the Stephen King-John Mellencamp musical, “Ghost Brothers of Darkland County,” stopped in New York on Monday during a national tour.
lead_paragraph: Bad blood flows down through the generations in “Ghost Brothers of Darkland County,” a Southern Gothic musical with a book by the literary spookmeister supreme, Stephen King; songs by John Mellencamp; and musical direction by T Bone Burnett. A semi-staged touring version of the show, directed by Susan V. Booth, made a pit stop in New York for one night only at the Beacon Theater on Monday, attracting a healthy crowd that seemed equally divided between King fans (like the guy in the shirt that screamed “Redrum”) and followers of either Mr. Mellencamp, whose pop-rock career dates back to the late ’70s, or Mr. Burnett, whose résumé includes a hefty 13 Grammys and music supervision for the first season of the terrific television series “Nashville.”

headline: Colombia to Receive Some García Márquez Effects
abstract: After selling Gabriel García Márquez’s archive to the University of Texas, his family is donating some of his personal artifacts to the National Library of Colombia.
lead_paragraph: There was an outcry in Colombia after the announcement on Monday that the archive of Gabriel García Márquez would go to the University of Texas instead of his native country. Many in the Colombian cultural establishment questioned why the national library had let such a valuable part of its patrimony slip away.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Profit Declines as Breakup Plan Begins
abstract: Sales declined for many major products, but Meg Whitman, the chief executive, was upbeat about her plans to turn around the company.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When celebrities break up, it is a “conscious uncoupling,” and done in a few weeks. At a big technology company, the split is no less deliberate, but considerably more complex.

headline: A Reading of “God and Me” by Edward Hirsch
abstract: The American poet questions his own belief in a higher power.
lead_paragraph: The American poet questions his own belief in a higher power.

headline: First Draft Focus: Chicago Greeting
abstract: Gov. Pat Quinn of Illinois, center, greets President Obama, with Mayor Rahm Emanuel of Chicago, left, at O’Hare International Airport on Tuesday. Mr. Obama was in Chicago to meet with community leaders to discuss immigration reform.

headline: In Moscow, a Financial District in Name Only
abstract: Moscow City was envisioned as a hub of emerging market finance, but Russia’s recent sanctions and economic troubles have kept buildings largely empty.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — In the coveted corner office, a bearded man in sweatpants scrambled eggs at a kitchenette, all the while taking in the serene beauty of the city lights twinkling far below.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Restaurant Report: La Parada in Cape Town
abstract: Despite inconsistent food, La Parada is the buzziest restaurant on Cape Town’s buzziest street.
lead_paragraph: If you’re an ambitious Cape Town chef worth your proverbial salt, you’re on Bree Street. Formerly the domain of mechanics’ shops, this downtown stretch has been recently hosting a culinary renaissance.

headline: To Russia, With Tough Love
abstract: Masha Gessen recounts the literary history of Moscow and describes why she’s become disillusioned with the city of her birth.
lead_paragraph: Dear Moscow,

headline: Soup, Salad and Stir-Fry With Thanksgiving Leftovers
abstract: Take advantage of the turkey that goes uneaten with dishes that will also serve as vehicles for other leftovers.
lead_paragraph: I love turkey sandwiches as much as the next person, but this year I have some other plans for my leftover meat: soup, salad and a stir-fry. Even better, these dishes will also serve as vehicles for other leftovers.

headline: Escaping the Friend Zone
abstract: In “Women Who Flirt,” a man’s good friend decides that she wants him to see her as something more.
lead_paragraph: You’ll never be confused about who the enemy is in “Women Who Flirt,” Pang Ho-cheung’s new romantic comedy. Hailey (Tang Sui) is the kind of passive-aggressive young woman who talks in a babyish voice to men, reacts to a scratch on her leg as if it might require amputation and bursts into tears at less than the drop of a hat, demanding at higher and higher volume to be consoled. In one restaurant scene, Hailey sobs like a stricken toddler and insists on being taken home after learning that her main course is a rabbit delicacy. (“Girls don’t eat bunnies!” she wails.)

headline: Stepping Back (Gracefully) From a Sculpture to Frame Its Story
abstract: The “Little Dancer” sculpture by Degas is the inspiration for the new musical by the same name, starring Tiler Peck of New York City Ballet.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Like the Dark Lady of Shakespeare’s sonnets and Vermeer’s “Girl With a Pearl Earring,” Degas’s “Little Dancer” has become both symbol and myth: She’s a source of fascination, inspiration and speculation. But, just as Alice in Wonderland and Peter Pan were based on real children, we know who inspired this 1881 sculpture: Marie van Goethem, a young dancer who joined the Paris Opera Ballet in 1880.

headline: Former Under Secretary of Defense Withdraws Her Name for Pentagon’s Top Post
abstract: Michèle A. Flournoy, who was seen as a leading contender to succeed Chuck Hagel as defense secretary, has asked not to be considered, citing family concerns.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Another leading candidate to be the next secretary of defense has pulled out of consideration.

headline: ‘Putin’s Kleptocracy,’ by Karen Dawisha
abstract: A damning account of Vladimir Putin’s rise to power and his plans to restore Greater Russia.
lead_paragraph: Now in his third (nonconsecutive) presidential term, Vladimir Putin presents himself as the strong and virtuous leader who rescued Russia from the chaos, corruption, penury and weakness of the 1990s.

headline: On Display, and on a Hot Seat
abstract: “Exhibit B,” a traveling show that mimics the human zoos of the colonial era, is prompting cries of racism in Europe.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Jelle Saminnadin plays a black odalisque, a seminude Congolese slave gazing in a gilded mirror. A leather bond encircles her neck and chains her to a bed of lace and pillows in a scene mimicking a colonial human zoo of the early 20th century.

headline: ‘Nothing Is True and Everything Is Possible,’ by Peter Pomerantsev
abstract: A British television producer’s foray into the “surreal heart” of 21st-century Russia.
lead_paragraph: The name “Vladimir Putin” is almost impossible to find in “Nothing Is True and Everything Is Possible: The Surreal Heart of the New Russia.” He usually appears only as “the President,” lording over and lurking behind the tales of tragedy and absurdity in Peter Pomerantsev’s captivating new book about modern Russia and its discontents.

headline: Equity Tries to Influence Show Tours
abstract: The union for professional actors wants audiences in Chicago, and then nationwide, to understand the distinction between Broadway and nonunion tours.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Some of the sets looked flimsy, the acting was uneven, and the signature red wig needed bounce. But none of that mattered to Lilly Hickman, 6, as she watched “Annie,” presented here by Broadway in Chicago, a booker of national musical tours.

headline: ‘The Georgetown Set,’ by Gregg Herken
abstract: In the 1950s and ’60s, administration officials, journalists and spies encountered one another in Washington’s Georgetown.
lead_paragraph: Gregg Herken had what must have seemed like a terrific idea — to revisit the large drama of the Cold War era by setting it on a small stage: Georgetown, the former port town on the Potomac River that became a celebrated Washington neighborhood. After all, its inhabitants once included such central figures as Dean Acheson, W. Averell Harriman and Allen Dulles, as well as journalists who not only got scoops from their neighbors but sometimes influenced and even participated in the events that they covered.

headline: ‘Limonov,’ by Emmanuel Carrère
abstract: After a career as a poet, butler and media celebrity, Eduard Limonov helped organize a group of nationalist thugs.
lead_paragraph: Everyone in Russia knows Eduard Limonov as the sinewy old man with the little goat beard, surrounded by a coterie of young hoodlums (members of his outlawed National Bolshevik Party, now called the Other Russia) — the snippy contrarian who gets arrested every other month when he comes out to protest for the right to free assembly, guaranteed by the Russian Constitution, and who, in his vagabond youth, lived as a down-and-out émigré in the New York of the 1970s.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Kate Zernike, Anne Barnard and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Governor Deploys More National Guard
abstract: Gov. Jay Nixon of Missouri said that a total of over 2,200 National Guard members would be in the Ferguson area after earlier protests led to rioting and looting.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Jay Nixon of Missouri said that a total of over 2,200 National Guard members would be in the Ferguson area after earlier protests led to rioting and looting.

headline: Pulling No Punches in a Round of Letters
abstract: “Selected Letters of Norman Mailer” presents 714 of the more than 45,000 pieces of correspondence he wrote to his wives, children, friends, critics and a Who’s Who of world culture and letters.
lead_paragraph: There were many reasons to hope that this collection of letters would be great or near-great, yet “Selected Letters of Norman Mailer” is mostly low-wattage, a rolling brownout of his vast intellect and talent. Mailer (1923-2007) loathed composing letters and tended to dictate them in industrial-size batches, as many as 50 in a day. Working on them made him feel slack and etiolated, like a marathoner forced to stagger around the track a second time.

headline: Pouring Shots and Shooting Portraits in the Old Times Square
abstract: In a Times Square bar called – fittingly – the Terminal, Sheldon Nadelman served drinks and made portraits of its denizens, from pimps and prostitutes to actors and nurses.
lead_paragraph: In a Times Square bar called – fittingly – the Terminal, Sheldon Nadelman served drinks and made portraits of its denizens, from pimps and prostitutes to actors and nurses.

headline: Take Cover: A Dispatch From Ferguson
abstract: John Eligon, a Midwest correspondent, is reporting in Ferguson, where protests broke out after a grand jury decided not to indict the police officer who shot and killed Michael Brown.
lead_paragraph: John Eligon is reporting on the protests in Ferguson, Mo. He tells what it was like on the ground after the verdict was announced Monday night. Follow him on Twitter for updates.

headline: Exploring Thanksgiving History in Massachusetts
abstract: The nonprofit group called Plymouth 400 has an exhibition in Massachusetts that focuses on the early Thanksgiving story.
lead_paragraph: The 400th anniversary of the Mayflower’s landing at Plymouth in 1620 is still a few years out, but the group charged with organizing festivities around the quadricentennial isn’t waiting to begin commemorations.

headline: University of Virginia Officials Vow to Combat Campus Rape Problem
abstract: The board that oversees the University of Virginia said it would come up with recommendations in response to allegations in Rolling Stone magazine of a gang rape.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. — Shocked, tearful and at times defensive, members of the board that oversees the University of Virginia insisted that they would combat the problem of sexual assault on campus after a magazine article reported a gang rape at a campus fraternity and allegations that the university was more concerned about its reputation than a history of sexual assault embedded in its hard-drinking social life.

headline: Cuomo’s Response to Buffalo-Area Snow: Praised, With Exceptions
abstract: The snowstorm that pummeled Buffalo and its southern and eastern suburbs last week combined two of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s preoccupations: extreme weather and western New York.
lead_paragraph: BUFFALO — It was threatening to snow again here on Tuesday. The temperature was falling, the winds were unpleasant and the skies were as gray as the pavement. Everything, in other words, seemed back to normal.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Kate Zernike, Anne Barnard and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Pierre Huyghe’s First Retrospective Lands at LACMA
abstract: One of Los Angeles’s most anticipated exhibitions of the year, it is also one of the city’s most seductive, inscrutable and generally impressive shows in recent memory.
lead_paragraph: Not only is the third and final stop at LACMA of the French artist Pierre Huyghe’s retrospective — which, following runs in Paris and Cologne, opens to the public today and is on view until Feb. 22, 2015 — one of Los Angeles’s most anticipated exhibitions of the year, it is also one of the city’s most seductive, inscrutable and generally impressive shows in recent memory. In truth, the water shortage is not the only drought to have withered Southern California in 2014. For whatever reasons — one might be MOCA’s transitional climate — there has also been a dearth of large-scale institutional shows by living artists to go above and beyond tidy, studious presentations of their work. The Huyghe retrospective, on the other hand, is messy, extravagant and unpredictable, inspiring a genuine sense of discovery even for those well-acquainted with his work.

headline: Thanksgiving’s Busy Week in Air Travel Is Now a Daily Routine
abstract: A travel trade group found that 13 of the nation’s top 30 airports already experienced Thanksgiving-like congestion and traffic at least one day a week.
lead_paragraph: Thanksgiving weekend has traditionally been the busiest time of the year for air travel, but that distinction is quickly becoming a thing of the past. With airlines merging and consolidating operations in fewer hubs, congestion that was once characteristic of the holiday is becoming more common at major airports all year round.

headline: Pictures of the Day: The United States and Elsewhere
abstract: The United States and More — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: The United States and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Nov. 25, 2014 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Egypt, Hong Kong, Kenya and the United States.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Egypt, Hong Kong, Kenya and the United States.

headline: Sony Pictures Computers Down for a Second Day After Network Breach
abstract: Sony Pictures’ computer systems were down for the second day in a row on Tuesday after hackers threatened to release files they claimed were stolen from the company’s network.
lead_paragraph: Sony Pictures Entertainment’s computer systems were down for the second day in a row Tuesday after hackers claimed responsibility for breaching the company’s network and defacing its website.

headline: Same Top 4 in Rankings, but College Football Playoff Keeps Things Interesting
abstract: Heading into the traditional rivalry weekend otherwise known as Hate Week, advocates for a four-team playoff seem vindicated: Several teams may still have a chance to play for a national title.
lead_paragraph: Before this season, those who favored going from a two-team playoff under the Bowl Championship Series to a four-team playoff — without expanding to six or eight teams, as some had hoped — cited the Goldilocks principle.

headline: Recent Commercial Transactions
abstract: Notable properties that have been recently listed for sale, sold or leased.
lead_paragraph: RECENT SALE

headline: Obama to Introduce Sweeping New Controls Aimed at Ozone
abstract: The regulation would be the latest in a series of E.P.A. controls on air pollution that wafts from smokestacks and tailpipes, and would probably set off a battle among all sides of the issue.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is expected to release on Wednesday a contentious and long-delayed environmental regulation to reduce ozone, a smog-causing pollutant linked to asthma, heart disease and premature death.

headline: Talking About Racism With White Kids
abstract: Having an “uncomfortable” talk with your white children about privilege, bias and racism? Good.
lead_paragraph: White parents need to be talking to our children about racism. As I’ve written before, more than once, not talking about racial differences doesn’t tell children that we don’t notice that people have different colored skin and differently textured hair. It tells them that we don’t talk about things like that.

headline: Its Grip on Oil Weakening, OPEC Will Meet on Prices
abstract: The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries meets in Vienna as the cartel finds it increasingly hard to influence world supply and price.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As oil prices continue to plummet, the once-dominant international cartel of producers is losing its sway over the global energy markets.

headline: U.S. Wants Teacher Training Programs to Track How Graduates’ Students Perform
abstract: The Department of Education is seeking to require states to develop rating systems for teacher preparation programs that could affect who receives federal grants.
lead_paragraph: The federal Department of Education announced preliminary rules on Tuesday requiring states to develop rating systems for teacher preparation programs that would track a range of measures, including the job placement and retention rates of graduates and the academic performance of their students.

headline: When Immigrants Lose Their Human Rights
abstract: Like the feudal system and slavery before it, our current immigration policy ignores our fundamental moral obligations.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s recent initiative on immigration has reignited the national debate on the issue. This interview, the first in a series on political topics, discusses philosophical ideas that underlie this debate. My interviewee is Joseph Carens, a professor of political science at the University of Toronto. He immigrated to Canada from the United States in 1985 at the age of 40 and is a citizen of both the United States and Canada. He is the author of “The Ethics of Immigration.” — Gary Gutting

headline: Protect Yourself While Shopping on Black Friday, and Beyond
abstract: To keep your money safe from hackers, many experts recommend using a credit card instead of a debit card both online and in stores.
lead_paragraph: Over the past year, so many data breaches at retail chains and restaurants have come to light that it’s hard to keep track. So what does that mean for shoppers, as the holiday season gets underway?

headline: In Ferguson, Issues of Race and Justice
abstract: Readers react to the decision not to indict a white officer in the shooting of a black teenager in Missouri.

headline: A Dearth of Legal Services
abstract: The shortage constitutes a shameful “tide of injustice,” says one city councilman.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Hagel’s Exit From Defense
abstract: John E. Stafford, a reader, writes that Chuck Hagel’s “cautionary voice will be missed.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: College Admission Games
abstract: Christopher B. Nelson of St. John’s College writes that “the weakening of college admission requirements helps neither applicant nor college.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Glacier(less) National Park
abstract: A reader suggests some new names for a victim of climate change.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Memories of Afghanistan
abstract: Gladys B. Lavine, a reader, writes about a personal experience in Torkham, Afghanistan, 60 years ago.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Shakespeare Folio Discovered in France
abstract: A first folio of Shakespeare’s plays — one of only 233 known examples — was discovered by chance in a public library near Calais, France.
lead_paragraph: First folios of Shakespeare’s plays are among the world’s rarest books, intensely scrutinized by scholars for what their sometimes-minute variations — each copy is different — reveal about the playwright’s intentions.

headline: How the Chicken Built America
abstract: The nation’s history is intertwined with that of the lowly fowl.
lead_paragraph: THIS season millions of Americans will celebrate with turkey on the table. The turkey is, after all, the native North American animal that Benjamin Franklin considered “a much more respectable bird” than the scavenging bald eagle. But while the eagle landed on the country’s Great Seal and the turkey gets pride of place at our holiday dinners, neither bird can claim to have changed American culture more than their lowly avian cousin, the chicken.

headline: The Problem With Prostate Screening
abstract: Two major studies on its benefits are deeply flawed.
lead_paragraph: TUCSON — SCIENTIFIC data from clinical trials provides the foundation of medical decision making, from a doctor’s prescription pad to sweeping public health policies. Public trust that the data is accurate and unbiased is the glue that binds our $3 trillion health care system. I worry that this trust, particularly when it comes to American men and their physicians and screening programs for prostate cancer, is now at risk.

headline: Holder Criticizes Violence in Ferguson
abstract: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. emphasized the need for protesters to honor the wishes of Michael Brown’s father by demonstrating peacefully.
lead_paragraph: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. emphasized the need for protesters to honor the wishes of Michael Brown’s father by demonstrating peacefully.

headline: Inquiry Into Rape Claims Against Irish Republican Army
abstract: Among those supplying information to the authorities is Gerry Adams, the president of Sinn Fein and a member of the Irish Parliament.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — The police and child protection agencies in Ireland are investigating rape and sexual abuse allegations against more than 30 former members of the Irish Republican Army, based on tips from people who were themselves once linked with the group.

headline: When Italians Meet Turkey
abstract: Our Thanksgiving menu tends to sprawl. But then so do our feelings.
lead_paragraph: Thanksgiving Day is almost upon us, and I haven’t yet summoned the nerve to tell Uncle Mario and Aunt Carolyn, who host it, that I may not arrive until a quarter past noon. That’ll make me more than an hour late, which by my rough arithmetic translates into 12 chilled shrimp, 15 mozzarella balls, four meatballs, a medium-size plate of stuffed mushrooms and a sizable wedge of frittata.

headline: For New York City Officers, Drawing Guns Is Based on Discretion, Not Rules
abstract: After the shooting death of a man in the Louis H. Pink Houses in Brooklyn, the notion of officers patrolling public housing complexes with guns unholstered strikes some as troubling.
lead_paragraph: There are some New York City police officers who can count on one hand the number of times they have drawn a gun, even over decades on the force.

headline: Disney Pairs Up With Turner to Promote TCM and Great Movie Ride
abstract: The collaboration between the two companies underlines how media giants are increasingly collaborating on content-marketing efforts.
lead_paragraph: THERE is a saying in Hollywood, attributed to Katharine Hepburn, about why the pairing of Fred Astaire and Gingers Rogers worked so well: “He gave her class, and she gave him sex.” Two familiar names in entertainment that are teaming up for another pas de deux may not be Astaire and Rogers, but they are giving each other something each wants.

headline: Steven Cohen’s Ex-Wife Gets Outside Financing for Lawsuit
abstract: Steven Cohen may have fended off the government for the most part, but his former wife is another story.
lead_paragraph: Steven A. Cohen may have fended off the government for the most part, but his former wife is another story. Patricia Cohen continues to pursue Mr. Cohen, claiming that the billionaire investor cheated her out of money during their divorce some two decades ago and potentially owes her millions of dollars.

headline: Food Power!
abstract: We should make our candidates take progressive positions on food. For anyone interested in better eating and better health, that’s important.
lead_paragraph: There are four basic ways to change the food system. I talk about three of them a lot: The first is to eat differently, focusing on good food and especially plants; the second is to bring change to your work, whether that means becoming a farmer or helping other people eat better through your role as a teacher, doctor, artist, techie, lawyer or journalist. The third is to work locally to effect change in, for example, school systems or municipal politics.

headline: Colombia: Rebels Free Two Soldiers
abstract: The country’s main rebel group on Tuesday released two low-ranking soldiers captured after a recent clash with government troops, but it remained unclear when it would free a general and two others it seized separately.
lead_paragraph: The country’s main rebel group on Tuesday released two low-ranking soldiers captured after a recent clash with government troops, but it remained unclear when it would free a general and two others it seized separately. The capture on Nov. 16 of the general, Rubén Darío Alzate, embarrassed the army and prompted President Juan Manuel Santos to suspend peace talks with the rebels, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia. The guerrillas later agreed to release the general. But they warned this week that military operations in the region where the general was captured could disrupt his release. Mr. Santos has promised to resume peace talks once the captives are freed.

headline: How the Civil War Created Thanksgiving
abstract: It took the war to make a regional New England holiday into a national one.
lead_paragraph: Of all the bedtime-story versions of American history we teach, the tidy Thanksgiving pageant may be the one stuffed with the heaviest serving of myth. This iconic tale is the main course in our nation’s foundation legend, complete with cardboard cutouts of bow-carrying Native American cherubs and pint-size Pilgrims in black hats with buckles. And legend it largely is.

headline: A Call to Save a 12th-Century Minaret, Heard Far and Wide
abstract: The Minaret of Jam, in a mountainous, remote region of Afghanistan, is leaning more and more, and officials fear it could fall.
lead_paragraph: JAM, Afghanistan — It is the place that launched a thousand postcards, back in the day when tourists still came in any numbers to Afghanistan: the Minaret of Jam.

headline: Increase in Tax Revenue Lifts New York City’s Finances
abstract: De Blasio administration officials presented an updated plan for the current fiscal year, and said future deficits had been reduced.
lead_paragraph: The de Blasio administration released an updated plan on Tuesday for the current fiscal year, painting a relatively rosy financial picture amid higher-than-anticipated tax revenue and strong returns on pension investments.

headline: New Frontier for Ebola
abstract: An outbreak of Ebola in Mali must be contained before it can get very far, and international agencies and donors can’t let their guards down.
lead_paragraph: The huge, impoverished country of Mali looks like the new frontier in the fight to control the Ebola epidemic in West Africa. The virus has killed thousands in Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone, the three countries where the virus first emerged, but it has not gained much of a foothold elsewhere. Small outbreaks of 20 cases in Nigeria and a single case in Senegal were declared over in October. Now the potential for many more cases in neighboring Mali has health authorities scrambling to contain a small outbreak before it can get very far.

headline: Lewis Baltz, Photographer of American Landscapes, Dies at 69
abstract: Mr. Baltz was part of the New Topographics movement, known for a seemingly dispassionate, affectless presentation of its subjects.
lead_paragraph: Lewis Baltz, whose caustic but formally beautiful black-and-white images of parking lots, office parks, industrial garage doors and the backs of anonymous warehouses helped forge a new tradition of American landscape photography in an age of urban sprawl, died on Saturday in Paris. He was 69.

headline: Despite Chaos, Police in Ferguson React With Restraint Not Shown After August Killing
abstract: The scene in Ferguson went from tense but civil before the announcement of the grand jury’s decision to a night of looting, fire and chaos.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — The night of smoke, fire, looting and chaos began not so much with an event, but a sound.

headline: Nancy H. Teeters, First Woman on Federal Reserve Board, Dies at 84
abstract: A liberal economist, Mrs. Teeters often criticized actions by her fellow governors.
lead_paragraph: Nancy H. Teeters, a liberal economist who was the first woman appointed to the Federal Reserve Board and who broke with tradition by openly criticizing decisions of fellow board members that she felt hurt consumers and working people, died on Nov. 17 in Stamford, Conn. She was 84.

headline: Negative Numbers Piling Up for the 76ers
abstract: Philadelphia’s loss to the Portland Trail Blazers on Monday was the team’s 14th straight — one loss short of the franchise record for consecutive defeats to start a season.
lead_paragraph: For the Philadelphia 76ers, the grind of an abysmal season has led to observations that are intended to seem optimistic but instead feel like the opposite.

headline: A Passion for Writing, About War and Love, Is Celebrated Decades Later
abstract: A Long Island man captured his World War II battlefield experiences in poetry and stories, which were privately published in January.
lead_paragraph: A mailman by day, John J. Donaldson wrote by night in his Long Island home, where he had “sacred space, a tenth of a Levittown living room,” said Peter S. Donaldson, his eldest son. “Everyone knew this corner. You didn’t touch the notepads, the pencils. Dad would be there all hours typing, working on drafts.”

headline: Who Will Save the Democratic Party From Itself?
abstract: Jim Webb makes the case for a sharper focus on “the very inequalities that our Constitution was supposed to prevent.”
lead_paragraph: Not everyone agrees that Hillary Clinton’s selection as the Democratic nominee is unstoppable. The first to challenge her is Jim Webb, a one-term former senator from Virginia.

headline: Seeking Par Off the Greens
abstract: Many doors once closed to female golfers, including those at the Royal and Ancient Golf Club, have opened, but other obstacles remain.
lead_paragraph: NAPLES, Fla. — The woman wanted to practice with her boyfriend, a professional golfer, at T.P.C. Scottsdale, a regular stop on the PGA Tour. Her boyfriend, Martin Piller, received a free bag of pristine balls and access to the back range, where he could work in peace, close to the chipping area and practice green and away from the 30-handicappers and snowbirds.

headline: State Investigating Woman’s Death After Nursing Home Evacuation
abstract: Ruth Snyder, 92, died soon after entering a nursing home where she was moved after being evacuated with other patients during the huge snowfall outside Buffalo.
lead_paragraph: The State Department of Health is investigating the death of an elderly woman after she was evacuated from a nursing home outside Buffalo during last week’s huge snowfall, a Health Department official said Tuesday.

headline: News Drumsticks
abstract: Need something to talk about over Thanksgiving dinner? Here are some suggestions.
lead_paragraph: Thanksgiving is a time for dinner-table conversation. If you’re short of news drumsticks to chew on, here are a few you may have missed.

headline: A Potent, Overlooked Greenhouse Gas
abstract: New rules to address methane emissions should be as tough as possible and national in scope.
lead_paragraph: Five years ago in Copenhagen, President Obama pledged to reduce America’s greenhouse gas emissions 17 percent below 2005 levels by 2020. In Beijing a few weeks ago, as part of a landmark agreement with China, he went one better by pledging a 26 percent to 28 percent cut by 2025. The first target will be hard to reach — and the second virtually impossible — without a determined effort on his part to cut methane emissions from the oil and gas industry.

headline: Mixed Motives Seen in Prosecutor’s Decision to Release Ferguson Grand Jury Materials
abstract: Some legal scholars charged that what looked like transparency and neutrality cloaked the county prosecutor’s real goal — to ensure that no indictment of the police officer occurred.
lead_paragraph: A day after the St. Louis County prosecutor took the rare step of releasing thousands of pages of grand jury testimony in the Michael Brown case, his move prompted a sharp debate among legal experts, some of whom charged that what looked like the prosecutor’s transparency and neutrality cloaked his real goal — to ensure that no indictment of the police officer occurred.

headline: Macy’s Thanksgiving Parade Brings Teenage Invasion to New York
abstract: More than 3,000 high school cheerleaders and marching band musicians have flown in from around the country to promenade in the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade.
lead_paragraph: There were ponytails and pompoms, the piercing squeals of teenage salutations and a pileup of girls sitting cross-legged in the middle of a hallway, blocking all traffic, oblivious to everything but their sparkly pink phones.

headline: U.S.-Led Raid Frees 8 Qaeda Hostages From a Yemeni Cave
abstract: The freed captives were six Yemeni citizens, a Saudi and an Ethiopian, who were unharmed, Yemeni officials said in a statement.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a predawn raid on Tuesday, United States Special Operations commandos and Yemeni troops rescued eight hostages being held in a cave in a remote part of eastern Yemen by Al Qaeda’s affiliate there, officials from both countries said.

headline: Group Seeks to Restore Retirement Pay for Army Officers
abstract: A bipartisan group of 15 senators has asked the Army to change a policy that strips some soldiers of their officer-retirement pay if the Army-wide draw down forces them to retire.
lead_paragraph: A bipartisan group of 15 senators has asked the Army to change a policy that strips some soldiers of their officer-retirement pay if the Army-wide drawdown forces them to retire. Currently, enlisted soldiers who become officers but have not served eight years before being forced to retire must retire at their highest enlisted pay — a difference of about $1,000 per month. In a letter to Army Secretary John McHugh, Senators Patty Murray, Democrat of Washington, and Johnny Isakson, Republican of Georgia, said that “to demote these soldiers in retirement is an injustice that devalues their service and will materially disadvantage them and their families for the rest of their lives.”

headline: Dodo Cheney, a Tennis Champion for Decades, Dies at 98
abstract: She won 391 tennis championships in the United States, most of them after she turned 55.
lead_paragraph: Dodo Cheney, a daughter of tennis royalty who wore lace and pearls as she rolled through generations of competitors on the way to winning 391 tennis championships in the United States, most of them after she turned 55, died on Sunday in Escondido, Calif. She was 98.

headline: U.N. Extends Help for South Sudan
abstract: The United Nations Security Council voted unanimously on Tuesday to extend its peacekeeping mission in South Sudan, where a nearly year-old civil conflict has killed thousands of civilians.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations Security Council voted unanimously on Tuesday to extend its peacekeeping mission in South Sudan, where a nearly year-old civil conflict has killed thousands of civilians, uprooted more than 1.5 million and put more than seven million at risk of hunger and disease.

headline: Focusing on Education for Family’s Success
abstract: After leaving an abusive husband, Naomi Bradshaw, 43, now emphasizes her and her three sons’ studies.
lead_paragraph: It is seldom easy to achieve one’s dreams, but Naomi Bradshaw, 43, wishes it had not been quite so difficult.

headline: Hagel’s Departure Bears Little Likeness to Rumsfeld’s Removal
abstract: Despite similar timing, after a disastrous midterm election, the exit of President Obama’s defense secretary, Chuck Hagel, did not represent the same kind of shift in policy that Donald H. Rumsfeld’s departure did.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With his party in a shambles after a disastrous midterm election and his administration ensnared in a messy war in the Middle East, the president stood in the East Room and showed his defense secretary the door.

headline: When Cops Kill
abstract: Does the infrequency with which police officers are held criminally liable in shootings show they are held to too low a standard or that they face too much criticism in such cases?

headline: Rescue Plan for a Marooned Miami Stadium
abstract: City officials and a private group agree on the need to renovate the modernist Miami Marine Stadium, seen as quintessential Miami, capturing the city’s playful nature and brash aspirations.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — In a young city predisposed to wrecking and rebuilding, impressive works of architecture can sometimes be discarded as effortlessly as last year’s runway accessories.

headline: Letterman’s Favorite Activity
abstract: The return of Michael S. Maurer.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — I liked this puzzle a lot for a few different reasons.

headline: First Decision of the Game: For Belichick and the Patriots, It’s No Tossup
abstract: There is one constant in the approach of Patriots Coach Bill Belichick: He will defer possession to the second half if New England wins the coin toss.
lead_paragraph: It is well known that New England Patriots Coach Bill Belichick likes to walk the unconventional line, whether it is going for it on fourth down, taking a deliberate safety or completely changing his offensive game plan in seven days.

headline: Last of 5 Men Pleads Guilty in 2010 Drug Theft at a Connecticut Warehouse
abstract: The robbery involving $60 million worth of pharmaceuticals at the Eli Lilly center in Enfield may have been the largest of its kind in the nation’s history.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN — On a blustery, rainy Saturday night in March 2010, five men arrived at an Eli Lilly warehouse in Enfield, Conn. Their trip from South Florida had been planned for two months, prosecutors said, and they were about to steal millions of dollars in prescription drugs.

headline: U.N. Urges Protection of Privacy in Digital Era
abstract: The United Nations adopted a resolution that signaled growing international attention on the issue of digital privacy, which it described as a human right.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The United Nations adopted a resolution on Tuesday urging all countries to protect the right to privacy in digital communications and to offer their citizens a way to seek “remedy” if their privacy is violated.

headline: Reaction to Ferguson Decision Shows Racial Divide Remains Over Views of Justice
abstract: The aftermath of the decision not to indict a white police officer in the fatal shooting of a black teenager revealed that the nation remains deeply divided about the justice system.
lead_paragraph: Paul McLemore, the first African-American to become a New Jersey state trooper, was on the streets of Newark in 1967 when riots following a police beating of a black taxi driver left 26 dead. He spent decades as a civil rights lawyer and years as a municipal judge in Trenton. His wife and children have gone on to enjoy accomplished careers.

headline: For Former Embassy Hostages, a Special Interest in Iran Talks
abstract: For the 39 Americans still alive who were held captive in Tehran for 444 days from 1979 to 1981, there has been no financial compensation from Iran and financial deals to extend the nuclear talks add to their anguish.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the United States agreed on Monday to extend the nuclear negotiations with Iran for another seven months, it was met with immediate protest from Republicans and some Democrats in Congress, as well as from hard-liners in Iran’s Parliament.

headline: Thousands Protesting Ferguson Decision Block Traffic in New York City
abstract: There were rallies in dozens of cities across the country in response to a grand jury decision not to indict Officer Darren Wilson in the shooting death of Michael Brown.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of protesters marched through the streets of New York City for the second night on Tuesday, chanting loudly and blocking traffic on some of Manhattan’s busiest streets to express outrage over the decision not to indict a white police officer in Ferguson, Mo., in the death of an unarmed black man.

headline: Obama Speaks About Ferguson Frustration
abstract: The day after a grand jury declined to indict Darren Wilson, President Obama addressed those unhappy with the decision, calling the concerns of the protesters “rooted in realities.”
lead_paragraph: The day after a grand jury declined to indict Darren Wilson, President Obama addressed those unhappy with the decision, calling the concerns of the protesters “rooted in realities.”

headline: North Korean Leader Assails American ‘Aggressors’
abstract: The government staged a huge rally Tuesday against an American-backed effort to refer the North’s leaders to an international court for rights abuses.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, condemned American “aggressors” as cannibals on Tuesday, as his government orchestrated a huge outdoor rally in Pyongyang to protest an American-supported move at the United Nations to refer the North’s leaders to an international court for human rights abuses.

headline: Jets Join Hands as They Tumble Downhill
abstract: The Jets’ offense, defense, special teams and coaching staff can all claim some responsibility for a 2-9 record.
lead_paragraph: The Jets lost again, and it doesn’t make a whole lot of sense to Rex Ryan.

headline: With Ad, Neighbors Zero In on Bill de Blasio in Truck Ramp Dispute
abstract: The dispute centers on an unused garbage transfer station on the shore of the East River, which is set to be reopened soon, over residents’ objections.
lead_paragraph: A battle in Mayor Bill de Blasio’s backyard could become the next big public-relations headache for City Hall.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 25, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: With Carmelo Anthony’s Back Ailing, Knicks’ Load Just Got Heavier
abstract: As Anthony recuperated after experiencing what the team described as back spasms, the rest of the Knicks were left to wonder how quickly he could return.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — After another loss in a season already brimming with them, J. R. Smith spotted Carmelo Anthony in the locker room. It was Monday night at the Toyota Center in Houston, and Smith knew enough to keep his distance.

headline: Bronx Driver Who Had Seizure Is Found Not Guilty in Fatal Crash
abstract: A jury cleared Vincent Zanfardino on charges of second-degree manslaughter, criminally negligent homicide and assault in a 2012 accident.
lead_paragraph: A Bronx man who had an epileptic seizure while driving two years ago and caused a crash that killed a 25-year-old man was cleared on Tuesday of all criminal charges.

headline: Schumer Criticizes Timing of Affordable Care Act
abstract: Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, said Tuesday that it was a political mistake to pass the Affordable Care Act in 2010 because voters were looking instead for relief from the recession.
lead_paragraph: Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, said Tuesday that it was a political mistake to pass the Affordable Care Act in 2010 because voters were looking instead for relief from the recession. Mr. Schumer, in remarks at the National Press Club, said Democrats should have built on the stimulus package that Congress passed to create programs to help middle-class Americans. “Unfortunately, Democrats blew the opportunity the American people gave them,” Mr. Schumer said, according to his prepared remarks. “We took their mandate and put all of our focus on the wrong problem — health care reform.” Republicans, he added, were able to exploit a sense among voters that Democrats were interested in creating new government programs that did not benefit them, helping to spawn the Tea Party movement.

headline: Report Faults New York City Hall for Closed-Door Meeting
abstract: An investigative report cited miscommunications between the mayor’s office and the Department of Education for the decision to bar reporters from a meeting at a public school in July.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s aides violated state law and city regulations in barring journalists from a meeting he attended with members of the Communications Workers of America at a Brooklyn public school in July, according to a new report by two city investigative agencies.

headline: Balanced Villanova Casts Aside Some Lingering Doubts
abstract: Villanova, the Big East’s only ranked team entering this season, has little star power but plenty of balance.
lead_paragraph: There was valid reason to be skeptical about No. 12 Villanova entering Monday’s marquee matchup against Virginia Commonwealth in the Legends Classic.

headline: Making Sense of Ferguson
abstract: Times reporters, editors and columnists recommend articles and books for those who want to better understand the events in Ferguson.
lead_paragraph: What article or book would you recommend for those who want to better understand events in Ferguson? We asked Times colleagues to weigh in.

headline: Egypt: Apartment Building Collapses
abstract: An apartment building in Cairo collapsed Tuesday, killing at least 19 people as rescuers and neighbors frantically dug through rubble with their hands to find survivors, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: An apartment building in Cairo collapsed Tuesday, killing at least 19 people as rescuers and neighbors frantically dug through rubble with their hands to find survivors, the authorities said. The building, in the eastern Matariya district, caved in around 1:30 a.m. as many inside slept, witnesses said. The collapse highlighted the longtime problem of shoddy construction across Egypt. Neighbors said several floors had been added illegally to the seven-story building. Egyptian developers frequently build without permits amid a housing shortage, rampant corruption and lax government oversight.

headline: Obama Faces Protests in Chicago That Immigration Plan Is Too Meager
abstract: Expecting a receptive audience, President Obama instead pared down a speech in Chicago on his immigration overhaul as protesters shouted for even more relief.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — It was supposed to be a triumphant homecoming for President Obama, and a chance to cast his executive action on immigration as the latest chapter in America’s history of welcoming foreigners.

headline: Trustee Moves to Repay Creditors in Mt. Gox Bitcoin Exchange
abstract: Kraken, a California-based Bitcoin exchange, will work with the trustee to return about 200,000 Bitcoin to Mt. Gox’s 127,000 creditors.
lead_paragraph: Customers of Mt. Gox, once the world’s largest Bitcoin exchange, are closer to getting back at least some of the money they lost this year when it shut down and announced that their funds had gone missing.

headline: Why Antioxidants Don’t Belong in Your Workout
abstract: Antioxidant vitamins are enormously popular with people who exercise, but studies suggest they can blunt the benefits of exercise both on the jogging track and in the weight room.
lead_paragraph: Antioxidant vitamins are enormously popular with people who exercise. The supplements are thought to alleviate muscle damage and amplify the effects of exercise. But recent studies have raised questions about whether antioxidants might be counterproductive for runners and other endurance athletes. And now a cautionary new experiment adds to those doubts by finding that antioxidants may also reduce the benefits of weight training.

headline: Chris Rock: The Times Interview
abstract: The filmmaker, actor and comedian Chris Rock discusses his career and his latest film, “Top Five.”
lead_paragraph: The filmmaker, actor and comedian Chris Rock discusses his career and his latest film, “Top Five.”

headline: What’s on TV Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (Animal Planet) THE WHALE: REVENGE FROM THE DEEP (2014) Martin Sheen portrays Old Thomas Nickerson, who reminisces about his stint as a cabin boy on the ill-fated final voyage of the whaling ship Essex in this two-hour adventure. Adapted from real-life accounts of the boat’s sinking — written by First Mate Owen Chase (Jonas Armstrong) and Capt. George Pollard Jr. (Adam Rayner), and said to have inspired Melville’s “Moby-Dick” — the movie was filmed in Malta and Britain, using high-tech equipment to recreate the stormy seas that left the crew members fighting for survival against one another and a whale that refused to go peacefully.

headline: Protests in New York Streets
abstract: In New York, thousands of protesters blocked streets on Tuesday night, protesting the decision not to indict a white police officer in Ferguson, Mo., for the fatal shooting of Michael Brown.
lead_paragraph: In New York, thousands of protesters blocked streets on Tuesday night, protesting the decision not to indict a white police officer in Ferguson, Mo., for the fatal shooting of Michael Brown.

headline: Protesters Flip Police Car in Ferguson
abstract: Protesters in Ferguson, Mo., flipped over a patrol car Tuesday evening. Tense demonstrations erupted in cities across the nation, although many of them were peaceful.
lead_paragraph: Protesters in Ferguson, Mo., flipped over a patrol car Tuesday evening. Tense demonstrations erupted in cities across the nation, although many of them were peaceful.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, November 26, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “People who try to stop these things are heroes, in my mind. I was disappointed that some members of the community resorted to violence.”

headline: Corrections: November 26, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Wednesday, November 26, 2014.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK

headline: Word of the Day | equity
abstract: This word has appeared in 19,500 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: equity •\ˈe-kwə-te\• noun

headline: Eat Turkey, Become American
abstract: Thanksgiving was my Korean family’s annual recommitment ceremony to the United States.
lead_paragraph: When I was growing up in northern Minnesota, our family’s Thanksgivings were straight out of a Norman Rockwell painting.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | The Thanksgiving Recipes Googled in Every State
abstract: What is the most distinct holiday dish searched for in your state, according to the Times analysis?
lead_paragraph: In “The Thanksgiving Recipes Googled in Every State,” The Times compiled a list of the most distinct holiday recipes searched for online by state.

headline: British Telecom Giant BT in Talks to Acquire EE
abstract: The announcement came days after BT said it was in talks with investors in two of Britain’s cellphone carriers about a potential takeover offer.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The European telecommunications giants Orange of France and Deutsche Telekom of Germany confirmed on Wednesday that they were in early-stage discussions to sell their joint venture EE to the British fixed-line provider BT.

headline: Zimbabwe’s Vice President Is Barred From Party Panel
abstract: Joice Mujuru, once seen as President Robert G. Mugabe’s heir apparent, was reported to have been disqualified because she had plotted to have him assassinated.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A power struggle over who will succeed President Robert G. Mugabe of Zimbabwe seemed to sharpen on Wednesday when the state news media reported that the country’s vice president, once seen as his heir apparent, had been disqualified from an important panel of the governing ZANU-PF party because she had plotted to have Mr. Mugabe assassinated.

headline: Test Yourself | An Amazing One-Handed Catch
abstract: Here are the first six paragraphs from the Nov. 24 article, “Even Under Microscope, Catch by Giants’ Odell Beckham Jr. Earns Applause.” Can you choose the best word for each blank?
lead_paragraph: Below are the first six paragraphs from the Nov. 24 article, “Even Under Microscope, Catch by Giants’ Odell Beckham Jr. Earns Applause.”

headline: Pouring Shots and Shooting Portraits in the Old Times Square
abstract: In a Times Square bar called – fittingly – the Terminal, Sheldon Nadelman served drinks and made portraits of its denizens, from pimps and prostitutes to actors and nurses.
lead_paragraph: The Times Square of the 1970s and ’80s offered more than enough noir for any would-be Weegee. But many pictures of its characters — menacing or tragic, crumpled or proud, flamboyant or anesthetized — look exactly like what they are: voyeuristic images, grabbed on the fly by photographers who quickly moved on to other subjects.

headline: What Is Your Reaction to the Sexual Assault Allegations Against Bill Cosby?
abstract: Do the allegations change how you feel about “The Cosby Show”? Would you still want to watch it?
lead_paragraph: Until recently, Bill Cosby was one of TV’s most beloved father figures for his role in the hit 1980s sitcom “The Cosby Show.” He now faces public allegations from at least 15 women — and the number is growing — that he raped them. Mr. Cosby’s lawyers have vehemently denied the allegations.

headline: European Legislator Urging the Breakup of Google Has Ties to a Law Firm
abstract: Andreas Schwab, a German member of the European Parliament, is “of counsel” at the law and lobbying firm CMS Hasche Sigle, which has represented some of the German publishing interests that have been eager to declaw Google.
lead_paragraph: Andreas Schwab, a German member of the European Parliament, has been making headlines in the last week after drafting a resolution that calls for the breakup of Google.

headline: Bean Sprouts Tainted With Banned Additive Are Again Found in China
abstract: Sprouts produced at a site on the southern outskirts of Beijing were treated with high levels of 6-benzyladenine, a plant hormone, to speed up the growth cycle and make them more attractive to buyers, The Beijing News reported.
lead_paragraph: Bean sprouts are back in the news for all the wrong reasons. Not for the first time, Chinese inspectors have found bean sprouts tainted with a banned food additive, in this instance in a production center on the southern outskirts of Beijing.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: New York Today: Snow Snarl
abstract: Wednesday and Thanksgiving: A wintry mess, especially north and west, but less snow in the city. Also: decent parade conditions, a firefighter saves a 6-year-old, and John Lennon’s last show.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this stormy getaway Wednesday.

headline: Establishing Her Position in the Post
abstract: Michele Roberts, the new leader of the N.B.A. players union, has forcefully questioned the league’s pay model, labeled its owners as replaceable and directly criticized Commissioner Adam Silver.
lead_paragraph: Late this summer, as Michele A. Roberts was finishing up one of her first long interviews as the newly appointed executive director of the National Basketball Players Association, she confessed to feeling some dread about moving into the spotlight of the news media.

headline: A Ferguson Protest, in the Shadow of the Capitol’s Dome
abstract: The Ferguson protests come to Washington.
lead_paragraph: The police were simply bystanders last night as protesters marching shoulder to shoulder clogged the streets in downtown Washington in a peaceful protest that was interrupted by at least one act of vandalism and a flag-burning.

headline: Reaction in Ferguson After the Decision in the Michael Brown Shooting
abstract: Journalists with The New York Times in Ferguson, Mo., have been following a grand jury’s decision not to indict Darren Wilson, a white police officer, in the shooting death of Michael Brown, an unarmed black teenager. More arrests were made overnight as protests also spread around the country. In an effort to quell violence in Ferguson, Missouri officials deployed additional National Guard troops.
lead_paragraph: Journalists with The New York Times in Ferguson, Mo., have been following a grand jury’s decision not to indict Darren Wilson, a white police officer, in the shooting death of Michael Brown, an unarmed black teenager. Live updates have ended.

headline: The Giving Tree: ‘Take What You Want, Leave What You Can’
abstract: Stocking the branches of the Giving Tree with candy, gloves and small gifts kept us busy, and grateful, all season long.

headline: Daily Report: Navigating Silicon Valley’s Slippery Moral Slope
abstract: Although (most) tech start-ups have been on better behavior in 2014, there have been dozens of instances when they acted poorly, even unethically.
lead_paragraph: Ahh, Thanksgiving, the time of year to stop the daily drudgery and give thanks for what we have. To be grateful for our family, friends and health. Maybe this is also a perfect time to be thankful for all the wonderful things technology start-ups have done for society, Nick Bilton writes in his Disruptions column.

headline: When a Business Owner Gets Cancer
abstract: The phone call came, and suddenly, disaster planning was no longer an abstract thought for my business. Without my involvement, there is no business.
lead_paragraph: In the spring of 2008, I had symptoms of what I thought was a heart condition. It made sense because I had a family history of heart disease. After several sleepless nights, I went to the doctor.

headline: China Asks for Help Identifying and Returning Fugitive Officials
abstract: In the absence of extradition treaties with the most popular destinations for Chinese fugitives — Australia, Canada and the United States — the countries should “reform their laws” and ease extradition,” a Foreign Ministry official said.
lead_paragraph: China wants other countries to do more to find and return Chinese officials suspected of having fled the country with purloined assets, a senior Foreign Ministry official said on Wednesday, as President Xi Jinping’s anticorruption campaign seeks to extend its reach abroad.

headline: Today in Politics
abstract: The potential political costs of the civil unrest in Ferguson, Mo.; speculation about Chuck Hagel’s replacement; and a look at Speaker John A. Boehner’s turkey brine recipe.

headline: Happy Thanksgiving
abstract: Happy Thanksgiving, and don’t forget to stop back on Monday, Dec. 1, for our next “What’s Going On in This Picture?”
lead_paragraph: We’re taking a brief break for the holiday, but we’ll return on Dec. 1 with our usual Monday offerings including “What’s Going On in This Picture?,” our daily Student Opinion question, 6 Q’s About the News and more. Plus, during the first week of December we’ll name the winners of our 15-Second Vocabulary Video Contest and announce our next student contest. Stay tuned!
