headline: Polio Crisis Deepens in Pakistan, With New Cases and Killings
abstract: The number of new Pakistani polio cases this year has hit 260, four times as many as last year, and four more anti-polio workers have been killed in the field.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Pakistan’s polio crisis has reached new depths this year, health officials say, intensified by a deadly mix of ruthless militant violence, large-scale refugee displacement and political chaos that has cemented the country’s role as the central global incubator of a disease that other conflict-torn countries have managed to hold in check.

headline: Ferguson, Still Tense, Grows Calmer
abstract: As the Missouri National Guard bolstered its presence and the police became more assertive, law enforcement officials effectively squashed much of the chaos from a night earlier.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — As residents swept broken glass from the sidewalks here on Wednesday and painted hopeful messages on boarded-up storefronts, public officials cautiously said that tighter security measures and hundreds of additional National Guard troops had helped stabilize this St. Louis suburb after a night of arson, looting and violence.

headline: Morning Agenda: Financing for Suit by Steven Cohen’s Ex-Wife
abstract: Steven A. Cohen’s ex-wife gets outside financing for her lawsuit. | ‘Poison puts’ develop a downside. | Trustee moves to repay Mt. Gox creditors. | Philip A. Falcone to Depart the Harbinger Group.
lead_paragraph: FINANCING FOR SUIT BY STEVEN COHEN’S EX-WIFE | Steven A. Cohen may have fended off the government for the most part, but his former wife is another story, DealBook’s Matthew Goldstein reports. Patricia Cohen continues to pursue Mr. Cohen, claiming that the billionaire investor cheated her out of money during their divorce some two decades ago and potentially owes her millions of dollars. Helping to fuel the long-running legal battle is Asta Funding, a financial backer of a Beverly Hills, Calif., firm that has provided litigation financing to Ms. Cohen. Asta and the firm that is financing Ms. Cohen’s lawsuit, Balance Point Divorce Funding, have an agreement to share in the proceeds of legal recoveries by clients. Ms. Cohen’s lawyers are scheduled to take a deposition from Mr. Cohen on Dec. 10.

headline: ‘O.K., Let’s Make Something Great’
abstract: Chris Rock and Questlove talk about working together on “Top Five,” which Mr. Rock wrote, directed and stars in as a stand-up comic turned unhappy film star.
lead_paragraph: There’s a scene in “Top Five,” the new film written by, directed by and starring Chris Rock, in which the action on screen and the soundtrack are in perfect harmony, precisely because they’re at complete odds.

headline: The Daily Gift: A Basket Purse Inspired by Jane Birkin
abstract: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.
lead_paragraph: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.

headline: Tech Toys That Go Beyond the Screen
abstract: Toys will soon be able to be controlled and updated through an Internet connection, and that may forever alter how we think about play.
lead_paragraph: When we talk about children’s access to digital technology, we often focus on “screen time,” but that term is a bit antiquated. Across the industry, the Internet is escaping the screen.

headline: A Window Washer Looks Back
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: The recollections of a man who used to work on a 30-story building in Lower Manhattan with a belt, a brush and a squeegee.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Daily Clip Report
abstract: Daily Clip Report is a collection of articles about the media and The Times that is emailed each day to senior executives and newsroom managers here.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

headline: Geno Smith Will Start for Jets Against Dolphins
abstract: Starting Smith on Monday – and the rest of the season, it seems – gives the Jets another, perhaps final, opportunity to evaluate the quarterback they drafted in the second round last year.
lead_paragraph: This season, the Jets have won two games and made two quarterback changes. They hope starting Geno Smith in their next game will help break the tie.

headline: Sharing Polling Numbers on Twitter: Decoding a Mystery
abstract: Twitter or obscure websites can easily transmit polling data, even when that may be an effort to circumvent the law.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps the most bizarre electoral news since the midterms is the allegation that Republican operatives and outside groups used clandestine Twitter accounts to share polling data.

headline: Exploring Stories of an Infamous Duo
abstract: “Send for the Million Men” uses original text, historical documents and “spontaneous storytelling” to explore the stories of Sacco and Vanzetti.
lead_paragraph: The trial and execution of the anarchists Sacco and Vanzetti, a scandalous cause célèbre during the 1920s, is the subject of the latest work from Joseph Silovsky, who creates theater mixing robotics, puppetry and video. “Send for the Million Men,” part of the season at the genre-blending Here Arts Center, will use original text, historical documents and “spontaneous storytelling” to explore the stories of Sacco and Vanzetti, who were convicted of killing two men during the armed robbery of a Massachusetts shoe factory, and whose execution sparked an international outcry.

headline: Keynes Is Slowly Winning
abstract: In the long run, wrong ideas are sort of dead.
lead_paragraph: Back in 2010, I had a revelation about just how bad economic policy was about to get; I read the OECD Economic Outlook, which called not just for fiscal austerity but for interest rate hikes — 350 basis points on the Fed funds rate by the end of 2011! — because, well, because.

headline: Elvis, Brooding and Alienated
abstract: “Flaming Star,” the 1960 Elvis Presley western directed by Don Siegel and steeped in racial animus, is now out on Blu-ray.
lead_paragraph: Directed by Don Siegel, the evocatively titled “Flaming Star” (1960), out on Blu-ray from Twilight, is arguably the best movie Elvis Presley ever made: a wide-screen western as steeped in racial animus as John Ford’s “The Searchers” (1956).

headline: Indian Factories Will Count and Sell Their Energy Savings
abstract: An innovative and closely watched program is designed to encourage many of the largest industrial plants to keep their energy use in check.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — India, the world’s third-largest producer of greenhouse gas, after China and the United States, has resisted international pressure to commit to capping planet-warming emissions. But when it comes to saving energy, India is moving ahead briskly.

headline: Yearning to Make the Connection
abstract: The writing-directing married pair behind “Still Alice,” about a woman struck by Alzheimer’s, are dealing with a different disease, A.L.S.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — One of this year’s surprise cinematic success stories centers on the independent film “Still Alice,” which tells the tale of an Ivy League linguistics professor dealing with early-onset Alzheimer’s.

headline: David Baldacci: By the Book
abstract: The author, most recently, of “The Escape” was a library rat growing up: “Libraries are the mainstays of democracy. The first thing dictators do when taking over a country is close all the libraries, because libraries are full of ideas.”
lead_paragraph: The author, most recently, of “The Escape” was a library rat growing up: “Libraries are the mainstays of democracy. The first thing dictators do when taking over a country is close all the libraries, because libraries are full of ideas.”

headline: Deep Dish From Sam Sifton, The Times’s Cooking Editor
abstract: With Thanksgiving rapidly approaching, Sam Sifton talks about his favorite places to eat and shop, his most daunting cooking challenge and the hazards of reducing a bottle of Cheerwine.
lead_paragraph: Q.

headline: “An American in Paris” Takes to the Stage
abstract: The stars align for the theatrical debut of a Gershwin classic.
lead_paragraph: The stars align for the theatrical debut of a Gershwin classic.

headline: 1914: Naval Squadron Shells Belgium
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: The Belgian coast is severely shelled in 1914.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — There was a heavy bombardment of Zeebrugge and Heyst (the sea end of the Bruges canal) by a British naval squadron on Monday afternoon. An unknown number of ships appeared unexpectedly through the mist, and at once began a heavy attack from between three and four miles’ range. A German battery at Heyst was knocked out of action. Hotels and buildings of which the Germans had taken possession were severely shelled, and a big building near the harbor was set on fire. Fugitives report that the Palace Hotel, in which the German Naval Staff was quartered, had been levelled to the ground. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Nov. 27, 1914

headline: A Dive Where Regulars Were Shot Regularly
abstract: Sheldon Nadelman took 2,600 photos from 1972 to 1982 when he was a bartender across Eighth Avenue from the Port Authority Bus Terminal.
lead_paragraph: Few movies capture the despair and degradation of 1970s New York better than “Taxi Driver.” So it is perfectly fitting that the Terminal Bar should have had a cameo role.

headline: 7 Officers Arrested in Beating of a Protester in Hong Kong
abstract: The arrests for the October beating were announced after the police cleared one of Hong Kong’s busiest shopping streets of encamped pro-democracy protesters.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Seven police officers were arrested in Hong Kong on Wednesday, accused in the beating of a pro-democracy protester last month.

headline: Reply All: The 11.16.14 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: WELCOME TO THE FAILURE AGE!

headline: Sri Lankan Kottu Roti, by Way of Staten Island
abstract: The country’s beloved street dish — made with flaky flatbread, eggs and aromatics — is part food, part show.
lead_paragraph: In the atlas of “Little” neighborhoods — the Little Italys, Little Tokyos, Little Indias of the world — New York’s Little Sri Lanka may be the littlest. It’s just one and a half blocks, and its groceries and restaurants share the Staten Island North Shore streetscape with bodegas and an Albanian pizzeria. But around here is where you’ll find one of the largest Sri Lankan communities in the United States — roughly 5,000 people, many of whom came to escape their homeland’s decades-long civil war, starting in 1983.

headline: Two Cocktails to Chill Your Chill Away
abstract: Distilled spirits can warm us up even when we cool them down.
lead_paragraph: As any New Yorker will recall, last winter was brutal. But when the first big storm rolled in, I knew just what to do. I grabbed a long-languishing bottle of crème de cacao and a not-quite top-shelf brandy, and I rooted through my pantry for whole nutmeg. Then I pulled on my boots and my parka and slogged to the deli for a pint of heavy cream. When I got home, I shook up the first brandy Alexander I had made, or even drank, in years, and declared it my official house cocktail of that whole interminable winter. For the next few months, I took great pleasure in greeting visitors with a drink at the ready and my nutmeg grater in hand. Brandy Alexanders proved irresistible to even the most stern, steadfast “I-don’t-like-sweet-stuff” sorts.

headline: The Iguana in the Bathtub
abstract: Hard lessons on a cold day in Florida.
lead_paragraph: When the temperature dipped below 40, iguanas started falling from the trees. Small, sleek green iguanas; big iguanas as long as four feet from snout to tail, scales cresting gloriously from their heads; orange-and-green iguanas, their muscled, goose-pimpled arms resolving into sharp claws. Iguanas were everywhere: in the bushy areas surrounding canals, on sidewalks, in backyards, lying helpless among the fallen, rotting fruit of mango and orange trees.

headline: Sarah Koenig Can’t Promise a Perfect Ending to ‘Serial’
abstract: Despite the wild popularity of the weekly true-crime podcast, the host insists on managing listener expectations.
lead_paragraph: The journalist talks with Taffy Brodesser-Akner about striking a balance between entertainment and journalism as she investigates a 15-year-old murder case.

headline: Should Free Office Food Be Taken Home?
abstract: The breakfast club; Preparation L (for lie).
lead_paragraph: My company offers certain food items free in our office pantry. Every morning, my co-worker Brandon eats a serving of Cheerios from the pantry while getting settled for the day. Would it be acceptable for him to take the cereal home the night before and eat it before going to the office? Brandon swears that he’s more productive after he eats, and taking the cereal home would allow him to eat on his time (instead of after arriving at the office). Since the food is offered freely, what’s the harm? DAVID McCORMACK, NEW YORK

headline: The Military’s Rough Justice on Sexual Assault
abstract: Why it’s so hard to prosecute crimes and protect the victims.
lead_paragraph: Col. Don Christensen, the chief prosecutor of the United States Air Force, sat in economy class on a flight to Venice and studied the folder of the sexual-assault case that would ultimately end his career. It was August 2012, and he was en route to Aviano Air Base to try a court-martial. Looking over the case, he could see why the judge advocate general, or JAG, at the base had requested him. Christensen had prosecuted more sexual-assault courts-martial than any other lawyer in the Air Force, and this case called for someone with experience. There would most likely be generals testifying. The accused himself was a senior officer. Even Christensen had seldom handled cases involving men of high rank. There was a simple reason for this: Victims were reluctant to report such officers, who enjoyed their own set of rules in the military justice system.

headline: The Mine Disaster That Shook Turkey
abstract: A mine fire in May killed 301 men, making it the worst industrial disaster in Turkish history. This is the story of two men who lived through it.
lead_paragraph: That morning, Tugba woke at 4 to clean the three-room stone house, which leaned into a hill full of apple trees. She and her husband, Ahmet, grew up here in Kayrakalti, a village in the western Aegean region of Turkey, between conservative Anatolia and the raki-and-cigarettes coast. Already, a bus that would pick up Ahmet for work was making its way through the area’s cypress trees and olive farms. Tugba had gone to the bedroom to nurse their daughter, who was just three days shy of her first birthday, and they had fallen back asleep, so Ahmet left without eating breakfast. Tugba was 18 and Ahmet 30, and sometimes they still blushed around each other; their faces shone with youth, hers heart-shaped, his angular and fair. That morning, Tugba, asleep with the baby who looked like her, did not say goodbye.

headline: Theo Jansen’s Lumbering Life-Forms Arrive in America
abstract: The Dutch artist is taking his strandbeests — huge, self-propelled, beach-striding contraptions made of PVC tubes — to Art Basel in Miami Beach.
lead_paragraph: On a blustery October afternoon, on a gently raised hill above Ypenburg, the Netherlands, roughly halfway between The Hague and Delft, the 66-year-old once-aspiring physicist Theo Jansen and several assistants busily prepared to launch an odd sort of species invasion. In a few weeks, Jansen’s strandbeests — the huge self-propelled beach-striding contraptions that Jansen has spent the better part of the past quarter-century conceiving, evolving and constructing from out of ever more ambitious concatenations of lightweight yellow PVC tubing and spiny white sails — would be strutting their improbably lifelike stuff up and down Miami Beach at Art Basel, to the drop-jawed amazement of all. But for the moment, Jansen had to carefully, with near-veterinary skill, slice and fold six of the wide-slung beests into two 40-foot-long shipping containers, so that they would survive the rigors of their Atlantic passage.

headline: A New Fleet of Spacecraft
abstract: The new generation of spacecraft, expected to be in use beginning in 2015.
lead_paragraph: The new generation of spacecraft, expected to be in use beginning in 2015.

headline: New York Schools Lose Millions Amid an Inquiry, Comptroller Says
abstract: The comptroller, Scott M. Stringer, said New York City had so far missed out on receiving as much as $120 million from the federal government because of an investigation into the Education Department.
lead_paragraph: New York City has been missing out on tens of millions of dollars a year in technology funding for schools from the federal government because of a continuing investigation into the Education Department, the city comptroller said this week.

headline: Studies Back Up That Few Elections Are Swung by Voter ID Laws
abstract: The Brennan Center for Justice points to large numbers of voters who can be disenfranchised, but that doesn’t mean many election results will change.
lead_paragraph: Last week, I wrote an article arguing that voter ID laws don’t swing many elections.

headline: Justice Ginsburg Has Stent Implanted
abstract: Justice Ginsburg has a stent implanted to address artery blockage.
lead_paragraph: Justice Ginsburg Is Recovering After Heart Surgery to Place a Stent

headline: Unhappy in Their Own Ways
abstract: Over 150 years of Russian literature.
lead_paragraph: Over 150 years of Russian literature.

headline: Polio Workers Killed in Pakistan Attack
abstract: Akbar Hussain Durrani, the home secretary of Baluchistan Province in Pakistan, said an attack on health care workers on Wednesday would not stop the country’s anti-polio campaign.
lead_paragraph: Akbar Hussain Durrani, the home secretary of Baluchistan Province in Pakistan, said an attack on health care workers on Wednesday would not stop the country’s anti-polio campaign.

headline: Justice Ginsburg Is Recovering After Heart Surgery to Place a Stent
abstract: Ruth Bader Ginsburg, 81, was expected to be at work on Monday after doctors placed a stent in her right coronary artery, a procedure known as coronary catheterization.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg underwent a heart procedure on Wednesday morning and was expected to leave the hospital within the next two days, the Supreme Court announced.

headline: East Coast Storm Disrupts Thanksgiving Travel
abstract: New York City saw less than a half-inch of snow, but suburbs to the north and west reported as much as 10 inches by Wednesday night.
lead_paragraph: The soggy slog home has begun.

headline: The Grand Concourse: Growing Signs of a Renewal
abstract: Walk the entirety of this extra-wide Bronx street to appreciate why it once had great cachet, with elegant apartment houses in Tudor, Beaux-Arts and, predominantly, Art Deco styles.
lead_paragraph: In some ways, it’s just another long city street, lined with housing, parks and shops.

headline: Gillian Wearing Goes Home
abstract: The Turner Prize-winning artist on returning to her roots in her new film.
lead_paragraph: The Turner Prize-winning artist on returning to her roots in her new film.

headline: For a Wintry Holiday, Airlines Waive Fees
abstract: Because of winter storm Cato several airlines are waiving fees to change or cancel flights.
lead_paragraph: Winter storm Cato is predicted to make its way up the Eastern states from North Carolina to Maine just in time to drop anywhere from one to six inches of snow in the Northeast and mid-Atlantic United States on one of the busiest travel days of the year.

headline: ‘Right to Be Forgotten’ Should Apply Worldwide, E.U. Panel Says
abstract: New guidelines from privacy regulators would require Google, in certain cases, to take down links in search domains in Europe as well as outside the region.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Europe is taking aim at Google, again.

headline: Tate Museums Offer Minecraft Maps of Famous Artworks
abstract: Tate Worlds presents virtual environments, like those found in the video game Minecraft, based on notable artworks from the museum’s collection.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — You can stop telling your children to get off the computer. The Tate museums and the wildly popular 3-D video game Minecraft have teamed up to create Tate Worlds, a series of virtual environments based on specific artworks. The game, which allows players to create their own virtual worlds, will use the paintings and sculptures, called maps, to generate activities or tasks that relate to the themes of the artwork.

headline: Letter From the Editor: The Search for Food
abstract: Web searching has become a tool of social science, a way to understand American life. You can also learn a few great recipes, as we did this week.
lead_paragraph: Internet access in the United States is now sufficiently close to ubiquitous that Google searching has become a tool of social science, a way to understand what Americans are thinking and doing. Searches for the words “vote” or “voting” have helped predict voter turnout in the last few elections. Searches on various flu symptoms help public-health researchers track epidemics. Search patterns can also help forecast the unemployment rate and vehicle sales.

headline: Stuff We Liked: The Sweet Season
abstract: The Upshot staff had such fun with our state-by-state Thanksgiving food searches that it made us hungry for more.
lead_paragraph: The Upshot staff had such fun with our state-by-state Thanksgiving food searches that it made us hungry for more.

headline: House Hunting in ... Cambridge, England
abstract: The Cambridge, England, housing market has been hot, based on sound fundamentals, with demand driven by Cambridge University, biotech and high-tech industries, and proximity to London.
lead_paragraph: A RENOVATED VICTORIAN SCHOOLHOUSE

headline: Vegetarian Thanksgiving: No-Bake Apple Pie
abstract: Instead of an oven, use a food processor to create this crisp, fresh apple pie. It was created for raw-food dieters, but it also gives home cooks a fast and refreshing dessert option that takes a fraction of the time of a traditional fruit pie.
lead_paragraph: Need more space in the oven this Thanksgiving? Try serving this raw apple pie for dessert, perfect for your vegetarian, vegan and raw foods guests, and especially for your over-booked oven.

headline: Fantasy Football: Week 13 Matchup Breakdown
abstract: Thanksgiving is here, which gives writers across the country an easy theme to work with. We’re not too proud to play along, fantasy football-style.
lead_paragraph: Thanksgiving is here, which gives writers across the country an easy theme to work with. We’re not too proud to play along, fantasy football-style:

headline: Another Word for ‘Mr. President’? Obama’s Action on Immigration Draws Suggestions
abstract: President Obama’s executive action on immigration provoked a furious reaction from the right — and some choice epithets.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s executive action on immigration has provoked outrage, especially on the right — and a range of epithets or comparisons, directly or in passing, to other figures of authority. Here are a few examples.

headline: After Ferguson, When Will We Listen?
abstract: The people of Ferguson are speaking. Will America listen?
lead_paragraph: The American justice system has proven time and again that if you are a person of color and/or poor in this country, your life does not matter as much. All one has to do is be suspicious and appear out of place — which is the definition of being poor and/or of color in our country — and state induced violence will always receive the benefit of the doubt.

headline: Failed Allergan Deal Strains Valeant’s Business Model
abstract: Valeant Pharmaceuticals has relied on acquisitions for growth, but it’s not so simple to keep buying and integrating companies, writes Jesse Eisinger in The Trade column.
lead_paragraph: Valeant Pharmaceuticals just spent the year in the “make William Ackman even richer” business.

headline: Afghans Are Surprisingly Optimistic
abstract: A new poll finds that 75.3 of Afghans think the national government is doing a good job.
lead_paragraph: After the lives lost and the billions spent and often wasted in Afghanistan,  it is easy for Americans to be discouraged about the country’s future. The Taliban continues to be a serious threat as does corruption, while the economy is largely dependent on dwindling international handouts.

headline: 36 Hours in Santa Fe
abstract: Explore street view, find our points of interest and sign in to your Google account to save your map.
lead_paragraph: Explore street view, find our points of interest and sign in to your Google account to save your map.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: PENELOPE FITZGERALD: A Life,  by Hermione Lee. (Knopf, $35.) In this delicate portrait, Lee takes on the challenge of an elusive late-bloomer, the great novelist and biographer who published her first book at 58 and became famous at 80.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: WEALTH AND POWER: China’s Long March to the Twenty-First Century,  by Orville Schell and John Delury. (Random House, $17.) Many countries revel in their victories, but China is driven by the humiliations it has suffered at the hands of foreigners over the past two centuries. Through 11 biographical sketches of Chinese intellectuals and political leaders — Wei Yuan, Sun Yat-sen, Deng Xiaoping — Schell and Delury trace the cultural origins of the country’s ascent from imperial doormat to global economic powerhouse.

headline: Shops on Wheels, but the Goods Aren’t Sold From the Trunk
abstract: Mobile businesses are increasing in cities across the United States, as entrepreneurs embrace the lower overhead and freedom to change locations.
lead_paragraph: Most weekday mornings, Jessie Goldenberg can be found driving around the Flatiron district or Lower Manhattan searching for just the right parking space for her truck. And Black Friday will be no different, as competition for consumer dollars heats up for the holiday season.

headline: Elegy for a Stranger
abstract: In a new picture book, a dog and a rat must decide what to do when they find a dead rabbit in the road.
lead_paragraph: One of Margaret Wise Brown’s more controversial picture books was “The Dead Bird,” published in 1958, in which a group of children find a dead bird, feel bad, but are then glad they found it because now they can “dig a grave in the woods and bury it. They could have a funeral and sing to it the way grown-up people did when someone died.”

headline: Harry Reid Wants to Talk About the Vatican
abstract: Senator Harry Reid shares a memory of a conversation with Cardinal Raymond Burke.
lead_paragraph: On a recent afternoon in the Senate majority leader’s office, Harry Reid decided he was done talking about his chief of staff, David Krone. Instead, he and his top aide wanted to chat about the Vatican.

headline: Classical Playlist: Dvorak, Haydn, Monteverdi and More
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: DVORAK: Symphony No. 6, American SuiteLucerne Symphony Orchestra, James Gaffigan, conductor(Harmonia Mundi 902188)The talented young American conductor James Gaffigan leads his Lucerne Symphony Orchestra in a powerful, polished account of Dvorak’s Sixth, glowing with sunshine in the first movement and crisply focused in the last. If there’s room for more feverish intensity in the Scherzo, Mr. Gaffigan and the orchestra largely get there by the end of the Finale, as they also do in a bonus: the gleaming, swirling American Suite, both tender and ferocious. (Zachary Woolfe)

headline: Don’t Believe the Hype: Holiday Sales Won’t Make or Break the Economy
abstract: Holiday spending is always closely watched — too closely — as an indicator of the nation’s economic health.
lead_paragraph: If there’s one thing that the news media across the country can agree upon every November, it is this: The holiday sales season is a time of huge stakes for the economy.

headline: Wheelies: The ‘Fix it Again, Tony’ Edition
abstract: Fiat announces an ad campaign that plays to an old, derogatory acronym; G.M. announces a less expensive way to use lightweight aluminum in vehicle production.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Intensive Thanksgiving
abstract: Before he lost his ability to speak, one of my son’s favorite questions was, “Mommy, what are you thankful for?” Over the Thanksgiving we spent in the intensive care unit, I continued to answer the question he could no longer ask.
lead_paragraph: The overtired resident approached the entry to my son’s hospital room.

headline: App Smart | Magic at Your Fingertips
abstract: Kit Eaton reviews three apps designed to help you dazzle friends and family with magic tricks that use your phone as a prop.
lead_paragraph: Kit Eaton reviews three apps designed to help you dazzle friends and family with magic tricks that use your phone as a prop.

headline: Reading The Times With Spike Feresten
abstract: Spike Feresten hosts the “Car Matchmaker” TV series on Esquire Network. He says he reads the paper with a hot cup of coffee and a locked door to “keep the kids away.”
lead_paragraph: Spike Feresten hosts the “Car Matchmaker” TV series on Esquire Network. He says he reads the paper with a hot cup of coffee and a locked door to “keep the kids away.” Here are his thoughts on Tuesday’s paper and The Times in general.

headline: A Little Abracadabra on the Phone
abstract: Numerous apps teach you how to fool your targets, and some even play a role in the trickery.
lead_paragraph: THOUGH few of us will ever be as deft at prestidigitation as Penn and Teller, or as slick at illusion as David Blaine, most of us already possess a tool for performing impressive conjuring tricks: a smartphone. With the right apps and a bit of practice, your smartphone can help you learn classic magic and even play a part in some 21st-century sleight of hand.

headline: Putin’s Power, and Cold Feet
abstract: Karen Dawisha’s longtime British publisher will not publish her latest, “Putin’s Kleptocracy.”
lead_paragraph: This week, Rajan Menon reviews “Putin’s Kleptocracy,” Karen Dawisha’s book about Vladimir Putin’s rise to power. The book argues, in part, that Putin has extensive links to organized crime.

headline: New Novellas About Family by Ludmilla Petrushev­skaya
abstract: In three tales, women contend with ne’er-do-well children and the pressures of communal living.
lead_paragraph: It is hard to resist Ludmilla Petrushev­skaya’s darkly comic new collection of ­novellas, “There Once Lived a Mother Who Loved Her Children, Until They Moved Back In.” The suffocating domestic life she renders so vividly begins before you even open the book. The cover itself is cleverly claustrophobic with the title crammed above a drawing of an unhappy family staring at a picked-over roast.

headline: ‘Stalin,’ by Stephen Kotkin
abstract: The first volume of a new biography argues that Stalin had social as well as organizational skills.
lead_paragraph: Two contrasting pictures emerge from the appraisals of Joseph Stalin written by his revolutionary colleagues and competitors. On the one hand, there was, for example, a fellow Georgian who knew Stalin in his early years as a Bolshevik organizer and who describes “his unquestionably greater energy, indefatigable capacity for hard work, unconquerable lust for power and above all his enormous particularistic organizational talent.” On the other, there are the unflattering judgments of his most virulent opponents in the Bolshevik hierarchy, from Leon Trotsky, who thought Stalin the “outstanding mediocrity of our party,” to Lev Kamenev, who considered the man who came to preside over the vast expanses of the reconstituted Russian empire “a small-town politician.”

headline: Spies Like Hers
abstract: The spy novelist Helen MacInnes portrayed Cold War intrigue with a keen understanding of the machinations of power.
lead_paragraph: This year’s news felt disarmingly retro. Israel bombing Gaza. Russia invading portions of Ukraine. A nuclear arsenal ramp-up by both America and Russia. Had we traveled back in time to the 1980s, albeit with a millisecond­-long news cycle sped up by smartphones and social media?

headline: ‘Tolstoy’s False Disciple,’ by Alexandra Popoff
abstract: The story of Tolstoy’s relationship with a conniving aristocrat.
lead_paragraph: In 1910, Lev Tolstoy died of pneumonia in a filthy house at a provincial train station. He had fled home at the urging of his closest disciple, Vladimir Chertkov, a cunning, talentless man. How did the ­mediocre Chertkov come to be beside Russia’s greatest writer as he died, even as Tolstoy’s wife, Sophia, stared through the window, denied entry? In “Tolstoy’s False Disciple,” Alexandra Popoff, the author of the biography “Sophia Tolstoy” and “The Wives: The Women Behind Russia’s Literary Giants,” draws on long unavailable archival materials, including Chertkov’s letters, to examine the relationship that tore apart Tolstoy’s family and threatened his literary legacy.

headline: Letters: Inside Attica
abstract: Readers respond to recent reviews of Richard Norton Smith’s biography of Nelson Rockefeller, Edward Hirsch’s “Gabriel” and more.
lead_paragraph: Inside Attica

headline: ‘Leningrad: Siege and Symphony,’ by Brian Moynahan
abstract: Shostakovich’s composition for a besieged Leningrad.
lead_paragraph: On May 1, 1945, Joseph Stalin proclaimed Leningrad a “hero city” for the bravery it showed during World War II. So it is fitting that the real hero of Brian Moynahan’s often harrowing “Leningrad: Siege and Symphony” is the city itself and not Dmitri Shostakovich, who composed his wartime Symphony No. 7 (“Leningrad”) in its honor.

headline: ‘George Marshall,’ by Debi and Irwin Unger with Stanley Hirshson
abstract: A fuller picture of the revered commander whom Truman called the “greatest military man” in U.S. history.
lead_paragraph: Where have all the great generals gone? The United States has been at war since 2001 — its longest period of uninterrupted conflict — and for considerable stretches of the last half-century. Yet during all those years the nation has produced no military commanders of undeniable greatness.

headline: Ismail Kadare’s ‘Twilight of the Eastern Gods’
abstract: The Moscow of Ismail Kadare’s novel is full of young writers who live and drink together.
lead_paragraph: The narrator of “Twilight of the Eastern Gods” is unnamed, but we might as well call him Ismail. Like Ismail Kadare, he is a student at the Gorky Institute for World Literature in Moscow in the late 1950s. He tells someone he’s writing a book about “a dead army commanded by a living general” — an allusion to Kadare’s 1963 novel, “The General of the Dead Army,” in which an Italian officer returns to Albania after the Second World War to disinter the bones of his soldiers. He’s also obsessed with the Albanian legend of Konstandin and Doruntine, which goes like this: When his sister Doruntine marries and moves far away, Konstandin promises his mother he will ride to fetch her for weddings and funerals; when he and all his brothers are killed, his ghost does the job, delivers his sister to the church and leaves her at the gate, saying, “You go on, I have something to do here.” This story would be the basis for Kadare’s novel “The Ghost Rider,” and by the end of “Twilight of the Eastern Gods” the narrator has become a sort of Konstandin figure himself. The Albanian dictator Enver Hoxha’s schism from the U.S.S.R. is occurring, and the narrator knows his days in Moscow are numbered. He’s become a ghost in the city, and it’s become ghostly to him. “Once upon a time there used to be a giant state whose name was Soviet Union,” he thinks.

headline: Short Stories
abstract: New books by Kathleen Founds, Kim Addonizio, David Gordon and Julia Elliott.
lead_paragraph: WHEN MYSTICAL CREATURES ATTACK!

headline: ‘Nothing but the Clouds Unchanged: Artists in World War I’
abstract: An anthology traces how armed conflict shaped the course of modern art.
lead_paragraph: World War I was the “first ­modern war,” with the major combatants Britain, France, Russia and the United States facing off against Germany and Austria-Hungary. But it had a less than straightforward relationship to modern art. It interrupted the ­intellectual work of Cubism, but answered Futurism’s calls for speed and violence. In unleashing horrifying devastation and disfigurement, it may also have incubated Dada and Surrealism.

headline: Ponytails and Pompoms
abstract: A poem for throngs of high-school cheerleaders and marching-band musicians in town to perform at the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade.
lead_paragraph: For the throngs of high-school cheerleaders and marching-band musicians in New York City to perform at the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade, a poem from a reader.

headline: E.P.A. Ozone Rules Divide Industry and Environmentalists
abstract: The sweeping regulation is aimed at smog caused by power plants and factories across the country, particularly in the Midwest.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Wednesday announced a long-delayed environmental regulation to curb emissions of ozone, a smog-causing pollutant linked to asthma, heart disease and premature death.

headline: 36 Hours in Santa Fe
abstract: No matter what the season, food, culture and nature buffs will find ample reason to linger in and around Santa Fe.
lead_paragraph: No matter what the season, food, culture and nature buffs will find ample reason to linger in and around Santa Fe.

headline: 36 Hours in Santa Fe
abstract: Winter offers a slower, less crowded Santa Fe experience, leaving time for visitors to savor culture, a cocktail or a green-chile cheeseburger.
lead_paragraph: In summer, Santa Fe bursts at the seams with arts fairs, opera and other flashy events. In winter, though, the schedule is less hectic, and the few tourists spend their days skiing outside town. This is when residents effectively reclaim the center, the walkable area from the old plaza to the newer Railyard district. The only glitz and glitter is the snow sparkling under a sunny blue sky and paper-bag lanterns glowing in the black night. In recent years, many of the city’s most loved institutions have expanded, been renovated or have even returned from the dead — and there’s no better time to enjoy them than the colder months, alongside Santa Feans who have been appreciating them for decades.

headline: 1964: Liner Slices Ship in Two
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: An Israeli ship collides with a Norwegian tanker in 1964.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — The 25,338-ton liner Shalom, pride of the Israeli merchant fleet, sliced a Norwegian tanker in two early today in heavy fog off the New Jersey coast. Nineteen of the tanker’s crew of 43 were killed, the Coast Guard said. No one was hurt on board the Shalom, which was en route to the Caribbean for a cruise. Most of the dead crewmen were in the stem section of the 12,723-ton tanker, Stolt Dagali, which sank almost immediately after the collision. Others were flung into the water, where they were picked up by helicopters and lifeboats. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Nov. 27, 1964

headline: Who’s Winning? The Night’s Quickest Wit
abstract: With Charles Barkley and Kenny Smith leading the way, TNT’s “Inside the N.B.A.” meanders in zany ways unlike other sports shows.
lead_paragraph: Beware professional athletes in suits telling jokes. They are rarely funny.

headline: Asking for a Raise, After 10 Years
abstract: It’s an awkward situation: A longtime assistant wants to approach her manager (and very good friend) about increasing her pay.
lead_paragraph: Recently, your Workologist made a return visit to a Minnesota Public Radio program, “The Daily Circuit,” and again had the pleasure (and challenge) of entertaining questions about workplace quandaries in real time.

headline: Changed Life for Brooklyn Boy Hit by Crossfire
abstract: For Gama Droiville, 13, who lost his right eye after being hit by errant bullets, the shooting was just the beginning of his ordeal.
lead_paragraph: Shifting slightly in a doctor’s office chair one day this month, Gama Droiville, 13, put on his new glasses.

headline: Coco Young, Muse to Artists and Designers, Steps Behind the Camera
abstract: A frequent subject of John Currin and Ryan McGinley and sometime model, the native New Yorker and budding photographer is publishing a visual exploration of narcissism.
lead_paragraph: Coco Young appreciates physical beauty, just like the photographers and artists — John Currin, Ryan McGinley, Richard Kern — who celebrate her as their muse. Now, in “Vanity,” her debut photography monograph (£30, out Monday from Bemojake), she shoots lovingly close images of skin, from color-saturated body scans to portraits of insouciantly nude subjects.

headline: Resignation of Top U.N. Relief Official Sets Up Clash
abstract: The announcement appeared to have to do not with her performance, but with political maneuvering at the United Nations by powerful member countries.
lead_paragraph: Valerie Amos, the top relief official at the United Nations, is resigning, Secretary General Ban Ki-moon said Wednesday, paving the way for a potential political showdown over her successor.

headline: Peter Boal to Perform in New York City Ballet’s ‘Nutcracker’
abstract: Those balletomanes who have never quite recovered from Peter Boal’s retirement, 10 years ago, as a principal dancer at New York City Ballet, can throw off the mourning garb. Mr. Boal, who left to become the artistic director of Pacific Northwest Ballet, will be back at City Ballet — for just one performance — as Herr Drosselmeier in “The Nutcracker” at the matinee of Dec. 13.
lead_paragraph: Those balletomanes who have never quite recovered from Peter Boal’s retirement, 10 years ago, as a principal dancer at New York City Ballet, can throw off the mourning garb. Mr. Boal, who left to become the artistic director of Pacific Northwest Ballet, will be back at City Ballet — for just one performance — as Herr Drosselmeier in “George Balanchine’s The Nutcracker” at the matinee of Dec. 13. (The season begins on Friday and runs through Jan. 3.)

headline: Helene Cooper on Chuck Hagel’s Resignation
abstract: Helene Cooper, Pentagon correspondent for The Times, joined MSNBC’s “Morning Joe” to discuss Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel’s resignation.
lead_paragraph: Helene Cooper, Pentagon correspondent for The Times, joined MSNBC’s “Morning Joe” to discuss Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel’s resignation.

headline: Newly Released Books
abstract: Among new novels are books by Frederick Barthelme, Brian Morton, Lindsay Hunter and Miriam Toews.
lead_paragraph: THERE MUST BE SOME MISTAKE

headline: G.M.'s Futurliner to Take Its Place Among Historically Important Vehicles
abstract: Futurliner No. 10, one of 12 G.M. built for its Parade of Progress, is scheduled for inclusion on the National Historic Vehicle Register.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One of the 12 buslike Art Deco Futurliner vehicles General Motors built for its Parade of Progress in the late-'30s has been scheduled for inclusion on the National Historic Vehicle Register, the Historic Vehicle Association said in an interview. Futurliner No. 10 is now here in advance of its scheduled display appearance at the Washington auto show in January.

headline: Realm at Stake, Playoff Masters Prepare to Collide
abstract: San Francisco and Seattle face each other in two of the next three weeks, and it looks as if at least one of those teams could miss the playoffs.
lead_paragraph: SANTA CLARA, Calif. — After the San Francisco 49ers won another close game on Sunday afternoon, Coach Jim Harbaugh watched that night’s nationally televised N.F.L. game with his family. During one network promotion for San Francisco’s game on Thanksgiving against the N.F.C. West rival Seattle Seahawks, NBC showed a gang of live turkeys. Harbaugh’s three youngest children were excited.

headline: Now, Anyone Can Buy a Drone. Heaven Help Us.
abstract: Pranksters’ antics are forcing public safety officials to look at the air above them, generally thought safe and secure, as a place for potential trouble.
lead_paragraph: Amateur photographers and Hollywood filmmakers turn to them for lush overhead shots. Geologists use them to look above the seas for oil-bearing rocks. Amazon executives are pushing to use them to plop packages onto doorsteps.

headline: In First Week, More Than a Million Apply for Health Insurance on Federal Website
abstract: The applications at the start of the three-month enrollment period showed that in contrast to initial problems last year, HealthCare.gov was working.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Obama administration officials said Wednesday that more than one million people had submitted applications for health insurance in the first week of this fall’s open enrollment period under the Affordable Care Act, and 45 percent of them had already selected health plans.

headline: A Letter From Camus to Sartre, Before They Were Enemies
abstract: A letter from Albert Camus to Jean-Paul Sartre surfaces, one apparently written in 1951 before they clashed.
lead_paragraph: PARIS – The two men were known to be bitter rivals. Jean-Paul Sartre once denounced the “philosophical incompetence” of Albert Camus and was said to have thrown out most of the letters he and Camus had exchanged.

headline: Marc Jacobs and Damien Hirst Team Up for Charity
abstract: The designer and the artist have collaborated with the art publisher Other Criteria on a limited run of T-shirts based on Hirst’s painting of Mickey Mouse, “Mickey.”
lead_paragraph: Five years ago, the artist Damien Hirst was invited by Disney to develop a piece inspired by Mickey Mouse. The result, “Mickey,” which recalled Hirst’s iconic spot paintings, was reproduced into a series of poster-size prints sold by the art publisher Other Criteria. In early 2014, Christie’s auctioned “Mickey” for just over $1.5 million, donating a portion of the proceeds to Kids Company, an organization that supports inner-city children in the U.K.

headline: Finding Takers for Lonely Leftovers in a Culinary Nook of the Sharing Economy
abstract: There are roughly 100 sites for sharing food in Germany, where concern about waste has grown in recent years.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Fresh from a bracing workout at the gym, Anton Kaiser gazed hungrily into a refrigerator, considering arugula, pineapple jam, salted butter and two bags of green grapes before reaching for a white bread roll, baked that morning. “I haven’t eaten all day,” he said, “so it’s great.”

headline: Bank of New York Mellon Fires Currency Trader After Internal Review
abstract: About 30 traders at various financial institutions have been suspended or fired after internal inquiries.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Bank of New York Mellon terminated a currency trader in London earlier this year for violating its code of conduct after an internal review of its foreign exchange operations, according to a person briefed on the matter.

headline: Drones Misbehaving
abstract: Drones are now soaring beyond their practical and recreational uses and are landing firmly in the hands of troublemakers and pranksters.
lead_paragraph: Drones are now soaring beyond their practical and recreational uses and are landing firmly in the hands of troublemakers and pranksters.

headline: U.S. Adds Planes to Bolster Drive to Wipe Out ISIS
abstract: The United States is shifting aircraft from Afghanistan to the Middle East, but the Islamic State, a hybrid between a conventional army and a terrorist network, has been difficult to target.
lead_paragraph: SHAW AIR FORCE BASE, S.C. — The United States is shifting more attack and surveillance aircraft from Afghanistan to the air war against the Islamic State, deepening American involvement in the conflict and presenting new challenges for the military planners who work here in central South Carolina, far from the targets they will pick for those aircraft.

headline: Diabetes Screening Lags in People With Hypertension
abstract: As many as a third of adults who have high blood pressure have not been screened for diabetes, despite the fact that guidelines call for them to be checked regularly, new research suggests.
lead_paragraph: As many as a third of adults who have high blood pressure have not been screened for diabetes, despite the fact that guidelines call for them to be checked regularly, new research suggests.

headline: Jian Ghomeshi, Canadian Radio Host Facing Sexual Assault Charges, Is Granted Bail
abstract: Jian Ghomeshi, the former host of “Q” for the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, faces four counts of sexual assault and one count of choking.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Until a month ago, Jian Ghomeshi was a celebrity with few peers at the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation. His weekday arts and entertainment radio program, “Q,” had brought younger listeners to the public broadcaster and raised its profile in the United States through syndication. Separately, he hosted both the network’s annual competition to select a book for all Canadians to read and Canada’s most valuable literary award, the Scotiabank Giller Prize.

headline: The Chefs behind Via Carota
abstract: Jody Williams and Rita Sodi invite T Magazine inside their new West Village restaurant, Via Carota.
lead_paragraph: Jody Williams and Rita Sodi invite T Magazine inside their new West Village restaurant, Via Carota.

headline: British Brothers Imprisoned for Attending Terrorist Training Camp in Syria
abstract: The brothers, Hamza and Mohommod Nawaz, were arrested last year while returning from Syria, and were said to have brought home ammunition as a trophy.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As the British government introduced a new counterterrorism law on Wednesday to increase surveillance on people suspected of involvement in jihad, two British brothers were jailed for conspiring to attend a terrorist training camp in Syria and unlawfully possessing ammunition.

headline: Thanksgiving Recipes: Reader Responses
abstract: Readers react to our article on each state’s most distinct Thanksgiving dishes, based on an analysis of Google searches.
lead_paragraph: We’ll be posting some reader responses and questions to our article on distinct Thanksgiving recipes, based on a state-by-state analysis of Google searches. If you have a question, feel free to leave it on Facebook or ask via Twitter.

headline: Some More Coffee, Mom?
abstract: In Mat Smart’s “Naperville,” a son moves back home to help his mother deal with losing her sight, but she finds that even her coffee is different.
lead_paragraph: From a brief plot summary — a son moves back to his hometown to help his mother deal with her blindness — you might expect the set for “Naperville” to be some sort of living room-bedroom combination, a domestic backdrop for yet another play about the Problem of Aging Parents. Instead, your eyes are greeted by a coffee shop, where the entire story unfolds. It is far from the last time that Mat Smart, the playwright, surprises you in this intricate, delightful comic drama, which is receiving a fine production by the Slant Theater Project at the June Havoc Theater.

headline: Telling My Son About Ferguson
abstract: I write and lecture about the horrors of our criminal justice system. Explaining the Darren Wilson decision to my child was much harder.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — MY son wants an answer. He is 10 years old, and he wants me to tell him that he doesn’t need to worry. He is a black boy, rather sheltered, and knows little of the world beyond our safe, quiet neighborhood. His eyes are wide and holding my gaze, silently begging me to say: No, sweetheart, you have no need to worry. Most officers are nothing like Officer Wilson. They would not shoot you — or anyone — while you’re unarmed, running away or even toward them.

headline: Wells Fargo Is the First Big Bank Simple Enough to Fail
abstract: The problems for other giant banks are complexity and interconnectedness, writes Daniel Indiviglio of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Wells Fargo is the first big bank to get its affairs in order. The $1.6 trillion lender secured a conditional stamp of approval from regulators for its living will. Less credible plans from 11 other titans suggest size isn’t the main issue. The real problems are complexity and interconnectedness.

headline: A Film That Might Inspire an Armchair Singalong
abstract: BYUtv takes a look at the story — and scandals — that underlie a famous holiday oratorio in “Handel’s Messiah.”
lead_paragraph: Not every piece of seasonal television fare is a sitcom’s Thanksgiving episode or a Hallmark Channel Christmas movie. On Thursday night, BYUtv broadcasts “Handel’s Messiah,” a decently made documentary about how one of the most beloved pieces of music ever created came to be.

headline: A Double Bill Riffs on Two Mystiques
abstract: DoublePlus, a series of double bills at Gibney Dance, featured works by Alex Rodabaugh and Rakiya A. Orange.
lead_paragraph: For its inaugural performance series at the newly renovated space at 280 Broadway, the Gibney Dance center passed the curatorial wand to a handful of respected choreographers. Each was asked to choose two up-and-coming artists to share a double bill as part of a six-week endeavor, DoublePlus.

headline: Greek Navy Aids Disabled Ship With Hundreds of Migrants
abstract: As many as 700 migrants were believed to be on the cargo ship, which was being towed in strong winds and high seas to the island of Crete.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Mounting its biggest and riskiest sea rescue in years, the Greek Navy towed a disabled freighter carrying hundreds of migrants toward the Aegean island of Crete on Wednesday, fighting strong winds and high seas, officials said.

headline: New Smog Rules: Good But Later Than They Had to Be
abstract: The former E.P.A. administrator suggests the same standards years ago.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration’s announcement on Wednesday of a proposed rule limiting emissions of smog-causing ozone in the atmosphere is, on one level, great news. Smog contributes heavily to asthma and other respiratory diseases, leading to needless deaths and hundreds of thousands of otherwise avoidable hospitalizations and emergency room visits. The proposed new standard would reduce the level of allowable ozone in the atmosphere from the current 75 parts per billion — a weak standard in place since 2008 — to a range of 65 and 70 parts per billion.

headline: Agency Issues Ultimatum on Nationwide Recalls to Airbag Maker Takata
abstract: A federal safety regulator gave the company until Tuesday to expand the recalls of potentially defective airbags or face legal action and penalties.
lead_paragraph: In a continuing standoff over the recall of defective airbags, federal safety regulators have demanded that Takata, the Japanese supplier of automotive parts, expand the recall nationwide, beyond the limited geographic area it currently covers.

headline: TransCanada Cuts Ties With Edelman Over Energy East Communications Plan
abstract: The pipeline company disagreed with the public relations firm’s proposal to use third parties to release unflattering findings on the project’s opponents.
lead_paragraph: TransCanada has cut ties with the American public relations firm Edelman, amid controversy over a proposed communications strategy for a major pipeline project.

headline: One Direction Outsells Taylor Swift
abstract: “Four,” the group’s fourth album, outsold Ms. Swift’s “1989,” which had reigned for three weeks at the top of Billboard’s chart.
lead_paragraph: Eventually, someone had to bump Taylor Swift from the top of the Billboard album chart. This week, that distinction belongs to One Direction.

headline: Another Feline Incursion From Russia Into China
abstract: Chinese officials said the tiger, Ustin, had crossed into frigid northeastern China, following in the footsteps of Kuzya, a tiger released in May.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The two dead goats in a farm building in northeast China each had a hole in its head the size of a human finger. Their skulls had been crushed. Three other goats were missing.

headline: What If We’re Wrong About Depression?
abstract: Some researchers say we need new ways of thinking about depression entirely — and that one day, therapy could start with a blood test.
lead_paragraph: What is depression? Anyone who has dealt with the condition knows what it can feel like — but what causes it, what sustains it, and what’s the best way to make it subside?

headline: That’s Amaro: Jody Williams and Rita Sodi on Their Favorite Postprandial Sips
abstract: The chefs discuss the four best options for the Italian digestif.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, when I first stepped into Via Carota, the forthcoming restaurant from Jody Williams and Rita Sodi in New York’s West Village, the two chef-entrepreneurs were taking care of a very important task: They were arranging bottles of amaro on the shelves behind the bar. “We’re hands-on,” Williams told me.

headline: Hotel Review: D.O.M. Hotel in Rome
abstract: This boutique property, opened late last year, offers a superb location and a good value for a five-star hotel.
lead_paragraph: ­Starting at 220 euros, (about $267, at $1.21 to the euro) for a Deluxe room.

headline: First Draft Focus: A Presidential Tradition, With Cheese
abstract: President Obama pardons Cheese, the official national Thanksgiving turkey, with his daughters, Sasha and Malia, at the White House on Wednesday.

headline: The Coolest Girl at the Party
abstract: A few words of advice for those looking for a little party magic.
lead_paragraph: A few words of advice for those looking for a little party magic.

headline: Fashion Tips for a Little Holiday Party Magic
abstract: The secret ingredient is ease — and a little bit of risk.
lead_paragraph: The coolest girl at the party knows the secret: perfectly done is overdone.

headline: Fantasy Football Isn’t Just a Man’s Game
abstract: The fast-growing fan sport of fantasy football has largely been portrayed as a male pastime, but a surge of women are grabbing the ball as well.
lead_paragraph: When Odell Beckham Jr. of the New York Giants caught a 43-yard touchdown pass last Sunday by snagging the ball from behind his head with one hand, among the beneficiaries of his impressive skill was Kim Meyer, head of public relations for Christian Dior Beauty.

headline: Chinese Artwork Brings Auction Record of $45 Million
abstract: A Chinese collector’s purchase of a Ming dynasty silk wall hanging for $45 million set a new record for a Chinese artwork sold at international auction.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A Chinese collector bought a Ming dynasty silk wall hanging for $45 million at a Christie’s auction in Hong Kong on Wednesday, setting a record for a Chinese artwork sold at international auction.

headline: At ‘Concept Shops,’ Thinking Matters as Much as Buying
abstract: Concept shops like Broken Arm are becoming popular in Paris, with cafes, curious items, clothing and a desire to make the shopper think.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Like “curate” and “capsule collection,” many of which I wish would be shot straight to the moon, “concept shop” is a term that has gradually infiltrated the retail lexicon, especially in philosophical Paris.

headline: Brown’s Parents Appear With Sharpton
abstract: The relatives of Michael Brown, Eric Garner and Akai Gurley attended a news conference with the Rev. Al Sharpton, where they prayed that their loved ones’ deaths would inspire positive change.
lead_paragraph: The relatives of Michael Brown, Eric Garner and Akai Gurley attended a news conference with the Rev. Al Sharpton, where they prayed that their loved ones’ deaths would inspire positive change.

headline: Sunset Overdrive, This War of Mine, Super Smash Bros. and Civilization
abstract: New video games include a Nintendo franchise showdown episode, a shooting-parkour combination and one inspired by the siege of Sarajevo.
lead_paragraph: SUNSET OVERDRIVE

headline: Inside the Truck
abstract: For mobile retail trucks, space is at a premium. Jessie Goldenberg of Nomad, based in New York City, gives a peek into the design of her 120-square-foot boutique.
lead_paragraph: For mobile retail trucks, space is at a premium. Jessie Goldenberg of Nomad, based in New York City, gives a peek into the design of her 120-square-foot boutique.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: So Is It a Murder, if the Corpse Is Undead?
abstract: “Bryant & May and the Bleeding Heart” is the latest case for Christopher Fowler’s detective from the Peculiar Crimes Unit.
lead_paragraph: Christopher Fowler’s latest book is the 11th installment in his delectably droll Bryant & May Peculiar Crimes Unit series, and his second book published in America this year. The other is “Film Freak,” described as a “grimly hilarious and acutely observed trawl” through the nether regions of the British film industry, where Mr. Fowler embarked on a try-anything career in the late 1970s.

headline: Being a Confident Redhead (Without Eyebrow Angst)
abstract: A new website aims to help redheads with pesky cosmetic quandaries.
lead_paragraph: One day in high school, when Adrienne Vendetti Hodges was being teased yet again about her copper-colored hair, she realized she had two choices. Give the guy the satisfaction of knowing he was bothering her or tell him: “I love my red hair. It’s awesome.”

headline: Germany Planning Quotas for Women in Boardrooms
abstract: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany said a bill, requiring that women make up at least 30 percent of the nonexecutive members of corporate boards, would be introduced in Parliament on Dec. 11.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Germany’s coalition government pledged Wednesday to introduce a bill mandating quotas for women on the supervisory boards of the country’s top companies, after a feud erupted this week when a leading conservative lawmaker told the minister of family affairs, a woman, to “stop whining” about the proposal.

headline: Are Flip Phones Having a Retro Chic Moment?
abstract: For some celebrities including Rihanna and Scarlett Johansson, an old-school flip phone is a big plus.
lead_paragraph: On Sept. 4, one image sent jolts through the disparate worlds of fashion and technology: Anna Wintour, the editor of Vogue and doyenne of all things chic, was photographed using a flip phone at the United States Open tennis tournament.

headline: Stuck Russian Plane Gets a Push, Possibly Symbolic, From Passengers
abstract: Dozens of passengers in Igarka, 100 miles north of the Arctic Circle, climbed out on Wednesday ostensibly to help push the aircraft onto the runway.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — If ever there was a moment to award bonus frequent flier miles, this would seem to be it.

headline: An Exercise in Stripping to Essentials
abstract: “Dawn,” choreographed by Adrienn Hod, is part of a series of dance works from Central Europe at Abrons Arts Center.
lead_paragraph: “Dawn,” by the Hungarian choreographer Adrienn Hod, is a very naked dance. At the beginning of this work, seen Sunday at the Abrons Arts Center Playhouse, four dancers — from Ms. Hod’s company, Hodworks — enter the stage in warm-up clothes and matter-of-factly undress. Over the next 45 minutes, they execute a series of daring physical tasks in this most unencumbered state.

headline: Angel Collinson Showcases Talent
abstract: Angel Collinson went to Alaska this March to test herself against some of the world’s largest mountains. What she accomplished pushed the boundaries of what women can do on a pair of skis.
lead_paragraph: Angel Collinson went to Alaska this March to test herself against some of the world’s largest mountains. What she accomplished pushed the boundaries of what women can do on a pair of skis.

headline: Toyota Recalls 30,000 Minivans for Airbag Problem
abstract: The automaker said a plastic hand grip mounted near the side-curtain airbag in the second row could contact passengers if the airbag deployed.
lead_paragraph: Toyota is recalling about 30,000 Sienna minivans from the 2015 model year, including about 25,500 in the United States, for a problem with plastic hand grips mounted near the side-curtain airbags, the automaker said in a news release Wednesday afternoon.

headline: A Deal From the Von Zedtwitz Life Master Pairs
abstract: A deal from the Summer Nationals in Las Vegas.
lead_paragraph: The American Contract Bridge League’s Fall North American Championships begin Thursday in Providence, R.I. The winners of the national titles will be experts at reading the defenders’ discards, one declarer-play skill that does not receive as many column inches as it deserves.

headline: When Glamour Speaks Your Name
abstract: A new book looks at the history of how black women used style and substance to counter stereotypes — or invisibility — in the mainstream.
lead_paragraph: A new book looks at the history of how black women used style and substance to counter stereotypes — or invisibility — in the mainstream.

headline: Beyond the Galaxy
abstract: Roland Mouret has arrived on Madison Avenue, eager to extend his brand and reach beyond his signature dress, the Galaxy.
lead_paragraph: Roland Mouret has arrived on Madison Avenue, eager to extend his brand and reach beyond his signature dress, the Galaxy.

headline: A Last-Minute Sensation
abstract: Sonya Yoncheva, a Bulgarian soprano, finds herself at a turning point as her career takes off, propelled by raw talent, serendipity and hard work.
lead_paragraph: Sonya Yoncheva, a Bulgarian soprano on the brink of stardom, received a phone call with a bold request last month at her home in Switzerland. Could she quickly learn the role of Mimì in Puccini’s “La Bohème,” fly to New York and sing the part onstage, for the first time, at the Metropolitan Opera just five weeks after giving birth to her first child?

headline: Is Roland Mouret More Than a One-Hit Wonder?
abstract: The designer made his name a decade ago with a signature dress, the Galaxy. “But it’s a tainted love,” he says.
lead_paragraph: On Nov. 11, as the Whitney Museum was preparing for its final wingding uptown, the first Roland Mouret boutique in America opened for business directly across the street on Madison Avenue. It was what they call a “soft” opening — so soft, it was difficult to hear. There was no party with flutes of Champagne sloshing perilously near the clothes, sparse media coverage and, during a visit a few days later, only one customer.

headline: A Wrenching Grief Assuaged With Beauty
abstract: “Beautiful Life,” the new album from the saxophonist Jimmy Greene, is a eulogy to his 6-year-old daughter, who was killed at Sandy Hook Elementary School two years ago.
lead_paragraph: There’s a calmly heartbreaking moment near the close of “Beautiful Life,” a poignant new album by the saxophonist Jimmy Greene. It arrives in “Little Voices,” an original poem read by the actress Anika Noni Rose. “All those precious little voices,” she says over a fluttery gospel groove. “Brightening our day, stealing our hearts, shaping our lives.” Then: “In the blink of an eye, they’re gone. Now there’s just silence where those little voices used to be.”

headline: What Waze Users Can Tell Us About Thanksgiving Travel Patterns
abstract: Waze, a community-based navigation app, finds that Thanksgiving driving patterns vary among its users depending on the city.
lead_paragraph: People who use Waze, a social mapping app that lets participants post real-time reports on traffic and weather to help users find the fastest routes, are helping the service better understand Thanksgiving travel patterns.

headline: Video: Angel Collinson’s Award Winning Segment from Alaska
abstract: Angel Collinson went to Alaska this March to test herself against some the world’s largest mountains. What she accomplished pushed the boundaries of what women can do on a pair of skis.
lead_paragraph: Angel Collinson impressed in a Teton Gravity Research film, “Almost Ablaze.” The first woman to open a Teton ski film, she was nominated for Best Female Performance at this year’s Powder Awards and was a finalist at the Banff Mountain Film Festival.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Hong Kong and Elsewhere
abstract: Hong Kong and More — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: Hong Kong and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Nov. 26, 2014 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Hong Kong, China, Syria and the United States.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Hong Kong, China, Syria and the United States.

headline: Readers Respond: On Ferguson
abstract: Readers wrote in comments on their skepticism, disappointment and distrust of police professionalism in response to the editorial “The Meaning of the Ferguson Riots.”
lead_paragraph: Following a grand jury’s decision this week not to bring charges in the police shooting of an unarmed black man in Ferguson, Mo., readers poured out their skepticism, disappointment and distrust of police professionalism in comments to the Times.

headline: Obama Builds Environmental Legacy With 1970 Law
abstract: Leaning on the Clean Air Act, President Obama has reshaped environmental policy more than any previous occupant of the White House.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama could leave office with the most aggressive, far-reaching environmental legacy of any occupant of the White House. Yet it is very possible that not a single major environmental law will have passed during his two terms in Washington.

headline: An Optimistic Realist Tours Earth’s Age of Humans
abstract: A lyrical nature writer explains her optimistic view of the deepening human imprint on the Earth.
lead_paragraph: When I spent a week in Ithaca, N.Y., as a visiting professor at Cornell earlier this fall, I finally got to meet Diane Ackerman, the author and poet best known for a string of lyrical and popular books on natural history and human nature. She had spent the last couple of years dug in on terrain that’s familiar here — the Anthropocene, a k a this era in which humans are powerfully jogging a host of planetary systems.

headline: Asian-American Admissions at Harvard
abstract: Readers including the writer Gish Jen, an alumna, respond to an Op-Ed article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: How Three It-Girls Turn It Up for Holiday Dressing
abstract: Mia Moretti and Margot, who perform together as The Dolls, and the artist-poet Cleo Wade are friends almost always dressed for a party.
lead_paragraph: The D.J. Mia Moretti and the violinist Margot (real name Caitlin Moe), who perform together as The Dolls, and the artist and poet Cleo Wade are almost always dressed as if for a holiday party. “It’s kind of hard for us to turn it up any more,” Ms. Moretti said. “We don’t really hold back other parts of the year.” These night life denizens are unafraid to clash prints or go for it with an oversize headdress. So ­we asked the threesome, who, with two other friends, are a part of a female art collective called Conversations, to put together a few party-going looks reflective of their signature styles. Perhaps you’ll take away a tip or two on how you can turn it up for the holidays.

headline: A Selfie for the Road: Me, Myself and Eiffel
abstract: Readers respond to a column by Timothy Egan, “Grand Tour of the Self.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: In Austen and Chekhov, a Test of Versatility
abstract: Members of the Bedlam troupe play multiple roles in productions of “The Seagull” and “Sense and Sensibility.”
lead_paragraph: Gossip gallops in Bedlam’s invigorating stage version of Jane Austen’s “Sense and Sensibility,” which runs through Dec. 21 at the Sheen Center. The would-be and might-have-been lovers in this enchantingly athletic take on the perils of Austen-style courtship, adapted by Kate Hamill and directed by Eric Tucker, find themselves pushed and pulled by the forces of speculation run rampant.

headline: When Cuban Doctors Are Lured to the U.S.
abstract: Readers react to two editorials in a series calling for normalizing relations with Cuba.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Office Cubicles Are the Worst
abstract: Readers complain about loss of privacy and rising blood pressure.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: In Newport, Historic Homes for the Holidays
abstract: In Newport, R.I., visitors can tour storied mansions decorated for Christmas.
lead_paragraph: Thanksgiving tables still haven’t been set, but that hasn’t stopped Christmas celebrations from starting in Newport County in Rhode Island. For the next five weeks, visitors can step back into the Gilded Age as part of Christmas at the Newport Mansions.

headline: The Downside of Eating Too Locally
abstract: Innovative red-state farmers need support from locavores.
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — TO appreciate the depth of our national political divide, look no further than our Thanksgiving tables. The organic turkeys and farmers’ market produce of coastal urbanites face off against the frozen Butterballs and rich gravies of our rural interior, each side equally contemptuous of the other. Or so it might seem.

headline: Fantasy Football: Week 13 Player Tiers
abstract: Tony Romo is coming off a 275-yard and four-touchdown game and a great matchup in the Cowboys-Eagles rivalry on Thanksgiving Day.
lead_paragraph: In this statistical model, I apply a clustering algorithm called the Gaussian mixture model to an aggregation of expert ranking data provided by Fantasypros.com. The algorithm finds natural tiers and clusters within the data. The charts that result visualize the tiers and help you decide your starting lineup each week.

headline: This Thanksgiving, Setting My Family Free
abstract: This year, I understand that my grown children are trying too hard to be with everyone in some fashion over a period of very few days allotted to that purpose.
lead_paragraph: This year, my brain finally grasped this obvious truth: As you grow older and your family expands, your chance of coming together for the holidays has to go down. Somehow, for decades, I had failed to see it coming. I had failed to do the math.

headline: Lasker Rink in Central Park Is to Reopen on Thanksgiving
abstract: Leaking valves that had threatened to shut down the skating rink for most of the winter have been repaired, the parks department said.
lead_paragraph: Lasker Rink in Central Park, a popular skating and hockey site that was expected to be closed for most of the winter, will reopen on Thanksgiving after undergoing extensive repairs.

headline: Lovegun, a New Gay Bar in Williamsburg
abstract: Giving the gay night-life circuit in Williamsburg a much-needed shot in the arm.
lead_paragraph: If Grindr killed the gay bar, no one told Benjamin Maisani. After opening bars in the East Village (Eastern Bloc, Bedlam) and, more recently, the crowded Hell’s Kitchen fray (Atlas Social Club), Mr. Maisani set his sights on Brooklyn, giving the gay night-life circuit in Williamsburg a much-needed shot in the arm with Lovegun.

headline: Openings, Sales and Shopping Events in New York City
abstract: The South Street Seaport Holiday Pop-Up Shops will host a new group of seasonal retailers and more shopping news.
lead_paragraph: ­Beginning Black Friday, the South Street Seaport Holiday Pop-Up Shops will host a new group of seasonal retailers. They include Whisper Editions, an online retailer that collaborates with artists and designers on limited-edition works, like a “whisper” clutch by Edie Parker and Fabian Baron ($1,400), and Brother Vellies, the desert boot label that creates artisanal jobs in Africa. At 89 South Street. ­

headline: New F.A.A. Report Tallies Drone Sightings, Highlighting Safety Issues
abstract: The list is not comprehensive, but it still provides a good idea of why the F.A.A. and others are increasingly concerned about the safe operation of drones.
lead_paragraph: Sales of drones to civilians are taking off and so are safety concerns about the proliferation of the unmanned vehicles buzzing the skies.

headline: Discounts at Ladies & Gentlemen Studio, Alessi, Artemide and Vermont Woods
abstract: Sales on serving pieces, decorative accessories, lamps and furniture.
lead_paragraph: All Ladies & Gentlemen Studio Superior servers, right, are 15 percent off through Sunday (originally $30 each, they are about $25 each); 425-610-7408, ladiesandgentlemenstudio­.com/shop.

headline: Textbook Beautiful
abstract: “Flora Illustrata” is a bibliophile’s guide to plants and a visual delight.
lead_paragraph: “Flora Illustrata” (Yale University Press, $50) is a book about books about plants, particularly the 123-year-old LuEsther T. Mertz Library of the New York Botanical Garden. Timed with an exhibition there through Jan. 19, the book is a history of research and scholarship, with subjects including the production of medieval and Renaissance herbals, 17th-century specimen hunts in South America and the commercialization of horticulture through seed packages. Because these activities depended on artistic renderings, “Flora Illustrata” is a treat for the eyes, whether reproducing a seven-headed hydra assigned by Linnaeus to the category “paradoxa,” or a 19th-century “Rareripe Peach.” Nostalgists will ache for the circa 1855 gardens that bordered the Hudson River near Newburgh, N.Y., and even a Victorian ad for Hanson Lettuce Seed, with a lettuce head unfurling as if ready to embrace the seed buyer in a crisp, cool hug.

headline: One Vase Can Lead to Another
abstract: Heath Ceramics’s studio director produced more than 150 vases in an experimental wave.
lead_paragraph: Having turned out some 120 candlesticks in a marathon creative session last year, Tung Chiang, the studio director of Heath Ceramics, has shifted his attention to vases. Over five months beginning in June, he threw, fired and glazed 158 of them in different sizes and shapes. (He was especially attentive to customers who had been asking for larger versions.) The results of his experiments will be unveiled on Dec. 6 at Heath’s San Francisco shop.

headline: Space Age Doodles Still Know How to Charm
abstract: The Galaxy lace curtain features mid-20th century design.
lead_paragraph: Dan Cooper, an Amherst, Mass., producer of cotton lace curtains with Victorian and Arts and Crafts motifs, has leapt into the mid-20th century with a new design, Galaxy.

headline: A Prefab, Fully Stocked
abstract: The stainless-steel Vipp house even comes with its own linens.
lead_paragraph: Vipp, a Danish company known for its industrial-chic garbage cans, has created a prefab house. The 600-square-foot galvanized-steel-and-glass structure comes completely furnished, mostly with Vipp products.
