It includes all interior furniture and lighting, a fully functional kitchen down to the dishes and glassware, a bed (in a sleeping loft) with linens, a bathroom, an outdoor shower and a fireplace.

headline: Fixes Came Too Late
abstract: The 1984 Pontiac Fiero made its debut with a captivating design and a midengine layout, but disappointment set in quickly as it developed a reputation for a stiff ride and lackluster quality.
lead_paragraph: The 1984 Pontiac Fiero made its debut with a captivating design, a midengine layout that conveyed sports car aspirations and a name that meant “proud” in Italian. The $8,000 base price attracted young buyers.

headline: 2 Fieros for Want of a Ferrari
abstract: A New Jersey man has gone through life owning several of his beloved Fieros, a small, plastic-body midengine sporty car that Pontiac offered in 1984-88.
lead_paragraph: PATERSON, N.J. — A visit with Onix Taveras and his Pontiac Fieros begins with a basement tour in his neat Cape Cod style home — and a chat about television. Displays of action figures, wall posters and scale models from the various “Star Trek” series give away his favorite show.

headline: Staying True to ’80s Cool
abstract: Onix Taveras fell in love with the Pontiac Fiero during the car’s brief 1980s heyday and has remained a faithful devotee ever since.
lead_paragraph: Onix Taveras fell in love with the Pontiac Fiero during the car’s brief 1980s heyday and has remained a faithful devotee ever since.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘Imitation Game’
abstract: Morten Tyldum narrates a sequence from ”The Imitation Game,” featuring Benedict Cumberbatch.
lead_paragraph: Morten Tyldum narrates a sequence from ”The Imitation Game,” featuring Benedict Cumberbatch.

headline: Dealers Move Beyond Doughnuts
abstract: Dealerships are offering perks that go beyond free food. Some have wine, original art and a way to exercise customers’ dogs.
lead_paragraph: FORT WORTH — Corrie Watson and her twin brother, Will Churchill, wanted a strategy to attract younger customers to their three sizable family-owned automobile dealerships and to keep them coming back for decades.

headline: Manual Locks: A Love Story
abstract: I bought a vehicle with push-button locks and crank windows, but it embarrassed my children. “Do we have to have this stupid car?” they’d say. “Nobody else we know has to lock the doors when they get out of the car.”
lead_paragraph: After a 12-year tour of duty in Michigan, my stalwart purple Plymouth Voyager finally succumbed to the road salt and crumbled into what looked like Martian dust. I was about to sign for a solid little Ford sedan with all the sex appeal of pleated khakis when I caught a bright flash of presidential blue out of the corner of my eye.

headline: A Terrestrial Rocket That Defies Gravity
abstract: Whatever other talents the Lamborghini Huracán possesses, its personality is defined by its incredible straight-line performance. It sucks the wind out of you.
lead_paragraph: The Lamborghini Huracán is quick. How quick? Quick enough that if you jumped off a cliff, you wouldn’t reach 60 miles per hour quite as soon as the Huracán can do it on a flat stretch of pavement. Car and Driver clocked this newest Lambo’s 0-to-60 run at 2.5 seconds, which means that you’re basically experiencing acceleration greater than gravity, but on a novel new vector — forward, toward the horizon.

headline: Thanks for Ripping Up Our Home
abstract: Most people can’t wait to see the back of their contractors. Imagine wanting to give them a party.
lead_paragraph: Last year, James LaForce, a co-owner of the public relations firm LaForce & Stevens, and Stephen Henderson, a writer, bought a 4,000-square-foot loft in Chelsea that was in need of major work. It had been owned since the 1970s by a photographer and his wife, and the entire back of the apartment had been turned into a darkroom and a graveyard for ancient photography equipment. “It looked like Thomas Alva Edison left 15 minutes ago,” Mr. Henderson said.

headline: Taunting the Big Bad Wolf
abstract: A house in Maryland was built with abundant varieties of wood but no nails.
lead_paragraph: CENTREVILLE, Md. — The two-story home Vicco von Voss built for his family here is more like a giant piece of custom-made furniture than a house.

headline: Sierra Leone to Eclipse Liberia in Ebola Cases
abstract: The World Health Organization reported more than 600 new cases of Ebola in the week that ended Sunday, more than half of them in Sierra Leone.
lead_paragraph: Sierra Leone will soon displace Liberia as the worst-hit of the West African countries ravaged by Ebola, the World Health Organization said Wednesday.

headline: In France, New Review of 35-Hour Workweek
abstract: The Socialist government is rethinking a law that was meant to create jobs but lately has been criticized for adding to the country’s economic woes.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — On a recent weekday, Ahlem Saifi caught a 5 a.m. Métro to get to her job as a passengers’ assistant at Orly Airport, where she often works 44 hours a week — well over France’s official 35-hour workweek.

headline: Just Don’t Call It a Lab
abstract: In Three Oaks, Michigan, a passive house that happens to be a laboratory.
lead_paragraph: When Joy Bergelson was planning the new field station here for the University of Chicago’s department of ecology and evolution, she wanted it to be environmentally responsible. She just wasn’t sure exactly what that meant.

headline: What Can I Do to Make My Outdated Parquet Floors Look More Presentable?
abstract: To freshen up your home’s parquet flooring, you don’t necessarily need to refinish.

headline: Video Shows Police Shooting 12-Year-Old
abstract: The Cleveland police released surveillance video showing officers fatally shooting a 12-year-old boy who was playing with a toy gun.
lead_paragraph: The Cleveland police released surveillance video showing officers fatally shooting a 12-year-old boy who was playing with a toy gun.

headline: Victorians’ Rejected Oddities
abstract: Julie Halls, a British historian, discusses proposals like an Aerial Machine Adapted for the Arctic Regions (though it “would be a complete death trap”).
lead_paragraph: Victorians loved their gizmos. As Julie Halls writes in “Inventions That Didn’t Change the World,” out next month from Thames & Hudson, eager amateur inventors sought copyright protection for such piquant devices as an Anti-Garotting Cravat. Ms. Halls, a specialist in 19th-century registered designs who works at the National Archives in London, uncovered books and books of schemes moldering on the shelves while she was researching her Ph.D. She does a lovely job investigating the social and cultural back stories that led to the design of an Improved Pickle Fork and a Bona Fide Ventilating Hat, to name just a few, revealing the Victorians to be not just ingenious but wildly insecure about their social status, their bodies and their safety. (This interview has been edited and condensed.)

headline: Simple, Even Retro, Toys Gain Favor This Christmas
abstract: Arts and crafts, robotic animals, retro toys and toys based on popular children’s movies are in high demand this year, as parents look for alternatives to digital diversions.
lead_paragraph: There is a moment in Seth MacFarlane’s comedy “A Million Ways to Die in the West,” set in the 1880s, where a boy rolls a hoop down the street with a stick.

headline: Video Shows Cleveland Officer Shot Boy in 2 Seconds
abstract: Tamir Rice, 12, was holding a fake “airsoft” gun when he was shot by the police on Saturday, the authorities said. He died the next day.
lead_paragraph: A police officer who shot and killed a 12-year-old boy outside a Cleveland recreation center fired within two seconds after the patrol car he was riding in pulled up next to the boy, a video released on Wednesday by the Cleveland police showed.

headline: New York City and Officer Found Liable in Fatal ’05 Shooting of a Teenager
abstract: The authorities said at the time that the 19-year-old had been wielding a knife, but a civil jury found New York City and the officer who fired the shots liable in his death.
lead_paragraph: In the hours after a Bronx teenager was shot and killed  by a New York City police sergeant on an October night in 2005, accounts of a tragedy crystallized into an orderly tale.

headline: Legal Fight Pits Sellers of Energy Against Buyers
abstract: A system under which big consumers shut down elevator banks or a production line at peak hours of electricity demand has been challenged by power producers, who lose their most valuable revenue hours.
lead_paragraph: Over the past few years, the federal government has nurtured the growth of an odd kind of player in the energy markets: companies that recruit consumers to unplug themselves when electricity use is high, in exchange for a price break.

headline: Thursday’s College Football Games to Watch
abstract: No. 6 Texas Christian, which is neck and neck with Baylor in the Big 12 and the College Football Playoff race, will face Texas.
lead_paragraph: 6 TEXAS CHRISTIAN at TEXAS

headline: Turkeys Receive Presidential Pardon
abstract: In an annual tradition, President Obama pardoned two turkeys, “Mac” and “Cheese,” who won’t become Thanksgiving dinner.
lead_paragraph: In an annual tradition, President Obama pardoned two turkeys, “Mac” and “Cheese,” who won’t become Thanksgiving dinner.

headline: An Executive Action Unlikely to Be Faulted
abstract: The tradition of sparing turkeys began in 1963 and morphed into a full presidential pardon for the first time in 1989.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama granted amnesty on Wednesday, but Republicans did not issue dire warnings of a constitutional crisis.

headline: Calories on Menus: Nationwide Experiment Into Human Behavior
abstract: Previous studies of the effect of posting calorie counts on menus reveal little or no change in behavior. But now there’s a really big sample size.
lead_paragraph: Now it’s official. Starting next November, menus in many places where Americans eat — like chain restaurants and some movie theaters, convenience stores and amusement parks — will have to list calories.

headline: Egypt: Rafah Border Crossing Is Opened Temporarily
abstract: Egypt temporarily opened its crossing on its border with Gaza on Wednesday for the first time in 30 days, allowing more than 250 Palestinians who had been stuck in Egypt to return to the coastal territory.
lead_paragraph: Egypt temporarily opened its crossing on its border with Gaza on Wednesday for the first time in 30 days, allowing more than 250 Palestinians who had been stuck in Egypt to return to the coastal territory. The Rafah crossing was expected to open again on Thursday. More than 2,500 Gazans are waiting to return from Egypt, according to the Palestinian diplomatic mission in Cairo. Egypt has strictly limited passage through the crossing and has clamped down on smuggling tunnels beneath the border in recent months amid accusations of Hamas involvement in attacks on Egyptian soldiers in Sinai. A recent United Nations report stated that the border’s closing had prevented thousands of Gazans from accessing medical treatment or education in Egypt and beyond.

headline: Fantasy Date With Twins Turns Sour for Manhattan Man, 84
abstract: Paul Aronson met Shaina Foster, 17, on a website that helps men “find your sugar baby.” She and her sister, Shalaine, are charged with kidnapping and stealing from him.
lead_paragraph: The website billed itself as a place where older men with money could meet young women interested in dating someone who could support them financially.

headline: The Power of Language in Ferguson
abstract: Protesters talked about the meaning behind the words on signs and T-shirts as demonstrations over the grand jury decision not to indict Officer Darren Wilson continued Tuesday evening.
lead_paragraph: Protesters talked about the meaning behind the words on signs and T-shirts as demonstrations over the grand jury decision not to indict Officer Darren Wilson continued Tuesday evening.

headline: Rebels in Yemen Strike at Rivals
abstract: The Houthis seized control of a compound belonging to one of the country’s most powerful tribal clans, the Al-Ahmar tribe.
lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen — The rebel group known as the Houthis seized control of a compound belonging to one of Yemen’s most powerful tribal clans on Wednesday, in the latest sign that the rebels, who stormed the capital in September, were seeking to consolidate their newly won power.

headline: Europe’s Modest Investment Plan
abstract: The new plan to bolster the European economy is inadequate and too complicated.
lead_paragraph: In announcing a plan to spur investment in public works and loans to small businesses, the European Union is finally acknowledging that it needs to do more to bolster its economy. Unfortunately, the new plan is inadequate and overly complicated.

headline: Oligarchs of Eastern Europe Scoop Up Stakes in Media Companies
abstract: Regional business groups, many strongly tied to their countries’ governments, are buying influential news outlets, raising alarms about press freedom.
lead_paragraph: BRATISLAVA, Slovakia — Across Eastern Europe, local oligarchs and investment groups — some directly connected to their countries’ political leadership — are snapping up newspapers and other media companies, prompting deep concerns among journalists and others about press freedom.

headline: Thursday’s N.F.L. Matchups
abstract: Detroit’s game against Chicago looks like it will be more competitive than it would have been a couple weeks ago, when the Lions were among the N.F.L.'s top teams and the Bears had allowed a combined 106 points in back-to-back losses.
lead_paragraph: Bears (5-6) at Lions (7-4)

headline: Making Calorie Counts Visible
abstract: New labels will help weight-conscious consumers and could improve public health.
lead_paragraph: The new regulations for posting calorie counts on menus and vending machines are a welcome response to combating the nation’s obesity epidemic, one person at a time. The rules posted by the Food and Drug Administration on Tuesday are surprisingly sweeping in the range of food items and establishments covered. They were well worth waiting for.

headline: For Son and Mother, a Relationship Scarred by a Brutal Crime Is Redeemed
abstract: Six years after Prince McClennahan’s mother was sent to prison and his own life fell apart, a sense of forgiveness is helping him put the pieces back together.
lead_paragraph: Prince McClennahan was 15 when his mother killed. It was a summer Sunday six years ago, at his Bronx apartment. He was babysitting for three younger siblings and the infant son of his mother’s partner, Olympia Peck. She and his mother, Angelique McClennahan, were at the movies.

headline: Mass Imprisonment and Public Health
abstract: A new report identifies the American incarceration epidemic as one of the greatest public health challenges of our time.
lead_paragraph: When public health authorities talk about an epidemic, they are referring to a disease that can spread rapidly throughout a population, like the flu or tuberculosis.

headline: Counting Benghazi Blessings
abstract: Congress has been very busy this year, so let’s give thanks for all the investigations into the 2012 attack on an American compound in Libya.
lead_paragraph: This year, in a break from tradition, I am giving thanks for the House Intelligence Committee’s final report on Benghazi.

headline: After Closing Schools, a Principal Fights to Save a Bronx High School
abstract: Santiago Taveras, once the public face for many school closings during the Bloomberg years, is now working on turning around the troubled DeWitt Clinton High School in the Bronx.
lead_paragraph: By 2:25 p.m. every school day, Santiago Taveras takes his position on the corner of Paul Avenue and the Mosholu Parkway in the Bronx, two muscled security guards by his side. A pair of police vans, lights flashing, park just across the street, and a half-dozen school safety agents in police uniforms patrol on foot.

headline: Germany: Merkel Repeats Tough Stance on Ukraine
abstract: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany told Germany’s Parliament on Wednesday that no military solution to the crisis with Russia was possible, but also that there was no way to lift sanctions under the present circumstances.
lead_paragraph: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany told Germany’s Parliament on Wednesday that no military solution to the crisis with Russia was possible, but also that there was no way to lift sanctions under the present circumstances. Patience and the long view are needed, she said. While Russia might have concerns about Ukraine’s joining a European Union trading and association agreement, she said: “None of that justifies or excuses Russia’s annexation of Crimea. Nothing of that justifies or excuses the direct or indirect participation by Russia in the fighting in Donetsk and Luhansk,” the separatist strongholds in eastern Ukraine. Also, NATO’s top commander in Europe visited Ukraine, and monitors for the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe reported Wednesday that they had been fired on in the east.

headline: Bill Cosby, UVA and Rape
abstract: Recent high-profile reports of sexual assaults should make us all pause and reflect on a culture that enables violence against women.
lead_paragraph: The world’s wrath and revulsion seem to be focused on Bill Cosby these days, as he goes in the public mind from “America’s Dad” to an unofficial serial rape suspect.

headline: Shades of Pond Hockey in 3-on-3 Overtime Experiment in A.H.L.
abstract: The American Hockey League, the N.H.L.'s top farm league, is testing a new seven-minute overtime, a rule change that could be a blueprint for making the shootout a rare event.
lead_paragraph: Few things in sports are as roundly reviled as the hockey shootout, but this season the American Hockey League is conducting an experiment that has become so successful it may render the shootout an endangered species.

headline: Nepal: Agreements Stall at South Asian Summit
abstract: South Asian leaders discussed trade and energy cooperation and regional peace in Katmandu on Wednesday, but did not reach a consensus on expected transportation and energy agreements.
lead_paragraph: South Asian leaders discussed trade and energy cooperation and regional peace in Katmandu on Wednesday, but did not reach a consensus on expected transportation and energy agreements. Hopes for a meeting between the leaders of India and Pakistan also appeared to fade. In opening remarks Wednesday at the South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation summit meeting, the first since 2011, Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India noted that it was the anniversary of the 2008 attacks on Mumbai, in which Pakistani gunmen killed 166 people. Relations between India and Pakistan were frozen after the attacks, and little progress has been made since. The signing of deals on the sharing of railroads, highways and energy had been expected, but unless one is achieved during a retreat on Thursday, the meeting could end without any agreements signed.

headline: Afghans Finally Get Good Governance, Without the Government
abstract: Other than the top elected officials and their immediate aides, the government is still being run by holdovers from the previous administration along with a hodgepodge of temporary appointees.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Afghans are being treated to the unfamiliar spectacle of their leaders trying to outdo one another in good governance, even as they remain hopelessly deadlocked on actually forming a new government.

headline: Minnesota Loses to St. John’s After Daquein McNeil Is Charged With Domestic Assault
abstract: McNeil, a sophomore guard, was formally charged with two felony counts of assault, the second arrest of a prominent Big Ten athlete on charges of domestic violence in the past two weeks.
lead_paragraph: St. John’s used an impressive second-half effort to beat Minnesota, 70-61, in the N.I.T. Season Tip-Off at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night, in a game in which the Gophers were missing an important reserve guard who was arrested Monday afternoon on charges of domestic violence.

headline: In New York Public Housing, Policing Broken Lights
abstract: One of the issues raised by Akai Gurley’s death isn’t necessarily that the “broken windows” theory has gone too far, but rather that in certain instances its most literal message has been fatally misunderstood or ignored.
lead_paragraph: Four days before a grand jury refused to indict the white police officer who shot and killed Michael Brown during an encounter in Ferguson, Mo., in August, Akai Gurley, an unarmed 28-year-old man, died as a result of a law-enforcement bullet in the Louis H. Pink Houses in East New York, in Brooklyn.

headline: Experts Weigh Officer’s Decisions Leading to Fatal Shooting of Michael Brown
abstract: Many experts said that Darren Wilson acted within the bounds of protocol, though some said the quick escalation of the fatal encounter could have been avoided.
lead_paragraph: In his first public interview this week, Darren Wilson, the white police officer who fatally shot an unarmed black teenager in Ferguson, Mo., was asked whether he could have done anything differently that would have prevented the killing.

headline: Fury After Ferguson
abstract: This is about whether black boys and men, as well as the people who love them, must fear both the criminal and the cop.
lead_paragraph: The reaction to the failure of the grand jury to indict in the shooting of an unarmed black teenager, Michael Brown, by a white police officer, Darren Wilson, touched something deep and ancient and anguished in the black community.

headline: No Shame in Giving Thanks for Some Story Lines
abstract: Although misconduct and violence dominated much of the sports landscape this year, a select few sports figures stood above the fray and provided reasons to be thankful.
lead_paragraph: In a sports year darkened, if not dominated, by domestic violence, child abuse, concussions, drunken driving and college academic scandals, those who stood tall deserve a Thanksgiving thank-you note more than ever.

headline: Allan Kornblum, Independent Publisher, Dies at 65; Sought the Undiscovered
abstract: Mr. Kornblum started Coffee House Press, an independent publisher known for finding and nurturing new authors.
lead_paragraph: Allan Kornblum, whose love for poetry and printing led him to start Coffee House Press, an independent publisher widely respected for finding and nurturing new authors, died on Nov. 23 at his home in St. Paul. He was 65.

headline: New York Police Dept. Aims to Curb Officers’ Cursing
abstract: Michael A. Julian, the department’s new head of training, sees reducing vulgar language as one way to improve police-civilian relations.
lead_paragraph: Most New York City police officers may not grow up cursing. But many learn the lingo, or perfect it, on the streets and then use it in encounters with civilians.

headline: Jill Martin Puts On Her Game Face
abstract: Ms. Martin covers New York Knicks games for the MSG Network, has a line of home organization products and is the author of several books.
lead_paragraph: Jill Martin covers New York Knicks games for the MSG Network, has a line of home organization products and is the author of several books. She also likes to undertake challenging projects for the “Today” show, including a 30-day technology detox and more recently, an attempt to break the Guinness world record for constructing the world’s largest high-heeled shoe, with the help of the designer Kenneth Cole (they were successful). A native of Plainview, on Long Island, Ms. Martin, 38, lives with a four-pound teacup Maltese named Bella who splits time between Ms. Martin’s two-bedroom apartment just off Gramercy Park and her parents’ home on Long Island.

headline: Thanksgiving Phrase
abstract: In which we give thanks for Stanley Newman.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — Happy Thanksgiving to our American readers, who, by now, have put away the turkey and the trimmings for those delicious leftover sandwiches.

headline: Rescuers in Yemen Sought American, Officials Say
abstract: A journalist held by a Qaeda affiliate was a target in a raid this week by Special Operations commandos and Yemeni troops, according to U.S. and Yemeni officials.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An American journalist held hostage in a remote part of eastern Yemen by Al Qaeda’s affiliate there was one of the main targets of a predawn raid carried out this week by United States Special Operations commandos and Yemeni troops, according to American and Yemeni officials.

headline: Bunny Briggs, Tap Dancing Virtuoso, Dies at 92
abstract: Mr. Briggs’s career bridged the history of tap from Bill (Bojangles) Robinson to Savion Glover.
lead_paragraph: Bunny Briggs, the elegant and versatile tap virtuoso whose career bridged dance eras, from Bill (Bojangles) Robinson’s to Savion Glover’s, died on Nov. 15 in Las Vegas. He was 92.

headline: After Disputed Verdict, Reckoning for Ferguson
abstract: In a way, the questions about the future of a few heavily damaged blocks of West Florissant Avenue in Ferguson are larger than the individual stores that lined it.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — It was never much, a faded commercial strip on a stretch that drew people from the apartments nearby for most of the essentials. You could pick up milk at the convenience store, get a manicure at Crystal Nails, wash your clothes at the Ferguson Laundry. On a busy Friday night, men would gather to talk and watch sports on television at the barber shop as they got straight razor shaves.

headline: Francis Fraser, Who Cashed In on His Cruelty, Dies at 90
abstract: Known as a British underworld enforcer and once suspected in as many as 40 deaths, Mr. Fraser turned his life of crime into a lucrative retirement by chronicling his own deeds in books and films.
lead_paragraph: Francis Fraser, a British underworld enforcer known as Mad Frankie, whose life of crime and torture led to a lucrative retirement chronicling his own grisly deeds in books, films and lectures, on stage and television, and as a “gangland” tour guide, died on Wednesday in London. He was 90.

headline: In NFL Network’s Partnership, Benefits Outlast CBS’s Schedule
abstract: A plan to broaden the audience for Thursday night games, which had been the exclusive domain of NFL Network, has worked, demonstrating anew the power of N.F.L. games.
lead_paragraph: The motivation behind CBS’s carrying a half-season of Thursday night N.F.L. broadcasts was to broaden the audience for games that had been the exclusive domain of NFL Network.

headline: Venezuela: President’s Rival to Be Charged as Plotter
abstract: The national prosecutor’s office said on Wednesday that it would charge a prominent opposition leader in what it called a plot to kill President Nicolás Maduro.
lead_paragraph: The national prosecutor’s office said Wednesday that it would charge a prominent opposition leader in what it called a plot to kill President Nicolás Maduro. The announcement did not provide details of the charges against the leader, María Corina Machado, but this year senior government officials accused her of organizing a conspiracy to kill the president. They showed what they claimed were a series of emails that they said implicated Ms. Machado and other opposition figures. They also said that Kevin Whitaker, a former State Department official who is now ambassador to Colombia, was implicated in the scheme. Ms. Machado is a former legislator and an ally of another politician, Leopoldo López, who was jailed this year after weeks of protests against the government. Mr. Maduro, a leftist who faces a severe economic crisis, has frequently said his enemies are plotting to kill or overthrow him.

headline: Judge on the Spot
abstract: One person in the country had the power to make the question of same-sex marriage eligible, in the minds of the justices, for Supreme Court review.
lead_paragraph: During the month that followed the Supreme Court’s refusal to take up any of the same-sex marriage cases that awaited the start of the new term on Oct. 6, I filled an occasional idle moment with this thought: What would it be like right now to be Jeff Sutton?

headline: Bill Cosby Gave Interview to Keep Charges Secret
abstract: Mr. Cosby gave an exclusive interview to the National Enquirer in 2005 in exchange for its agreement to drop a story about sexual assault allegations, he testified in a federal lawsuit.
lead_paragraph: Bill Cosby gave an exclusive interview to The National Enquirer in 2005 in exchange for a promise by the tabloid that it would drop a more damaging article about previously undisclosed sexual assault allegations, according to his testimony in a federal lawsuit.

headline: 11 Brooklyn Churches Hit in a String of Burglaries
abstract: Over the last two months, burglars have taken computers, cameras and money, but have left valuable religious items, at the churches of various denominations in the southwest part of the borough.
lead_paragraph: One Sunday morning this month, as worshipers streamed into the Fourth Avenue Presbyterian Church in Brooklyn, police officers inspected shattered glass and took note of an air-conditioner that had been pulled from a wall, clues in the theft of a few hundred dollars from the church’s coffers.

headline: Struggling Nets Find Team Even They Can Beat
abstract: Philadelphia trailed by only 1 point with 1 minute 13 seconds remaining but could not overpower the Nets, and with the loss, the 76ers dropped to 0-15.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Brett Brown, the coach of the Philadelphia 76ers, could sense that his team’s prolonged futility this season was reaching historic levels, but he did not quite know the specifics.

headline: Cranberry Growers Search for Ways to Share Their Bounty
abstract: As cranberry farmers bring in record harvests and berry prices plummet, the industry is trying to recast the fruit outside its usual Thanksgiving milieu.
lead_paragraph: WARRENS, Wis. — As you pack away the leftover Thanksgiving cranberry sauce (and there is always leftover cranberry sauce), consider the plight of Wisconsin’s cranberry growers.

headline: Lucien Clergue, Master and Promoter of Art Photography, Dies at 80
abstract: Mr. Clergue enjoyed a national stature in France for his modernist work, famous patrons and photography festival in Arles.
lead_paragraph: Lucien Clergue, one of the most acclaimed photographers in France and a founder of an annual festival in Arles that has become a mainstay of the art photography world, died on Nov. 15 in Nîmes, in the South of France. He was 80.

headline: U.S. Smoking Rate Dips Again
abstract: The smoking rate in the United States declined to 17.8 percent in 2013, down slightly from 18.1 percent the previous year, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported.
lead_paragraph: The smoking rate in the United States declined to 17.8 percent in 2013, down slightly from 18.1 percent the previous year, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported Wednesday. The report found a decline in the number of smokers in the United States — 42 million in 2013, down from 45 million in 2005 — despite an increase in population. The smoking rate has been dropping for decades, but the pace of the decline has slowed in recent years. The smoking rate was 20.9 percent in 2005 and stood at about 42 percent in 1965, when the federal government began systematically tracking it.

headline: Wyoming Devises Plan to Expand Medicaid
abstract: If it wins federal and state legislative approval, Wyoming will join 27 states that have added program coverage under the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With a plan released Wednesday by the administration of Gov. Matt Mead, a Republican, Wyoming has become the latest state seeking to expand Medicaid.

headline: Knicks Fare Badly in Reunion in Dallas
abstract: Without Carmelo Anthony, out with back spasms, the Knicks fell to the Mavericks, who got a big game from the ex-Knick Tyson Chandler.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — Carmelo Anthony made an early appearance at American Airlines Center on Wednesday night.

headline: Pregnant Woman, 27, Is Fatally Shot in Queens
abstract: Anastasia Massey returned to her apartment and found a gunman waiting outside her door, the police said. Her child was delivered in an emergency cesarean section but later died.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after dropping off her children at school on Wednesday, Anastasia Massey, 25 weeks pregnant, returned home and found a gunman waiting outside her Queens apartment, the police said.

headline: Winnings Lottery Numbers for Nov. 26, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: A Parthenon of Produce at United Brothers Fruit Market in Astoria
abstract: At all hours, the market in Astoria, Queens, draws customers with its overflowing piles of fruit and vegetables.
lead_paragraph: If Queens is the borough of the world, Astoria is its Mediterranean outpost. On 30th Avenue, where it is easier to order souvlakia on pita than a slice of pizza, and olive oil seems to exist as common currency, you will find United Brothers Fruit Market, the supply store for this enclave along the East River. Its signature yellow bag, a common neighborhood tumbleweed, is carried by Greek grandmothers and hipsters alike.

headline: Like a Spy, He Photographs Marriage Proposals in New York City
abstract: Vlad Leto, a graduate student at the School of Visual Arts, discreetly waits at the edges until someone gets on one knee.
lead_paragraph: “I’m like a spy,” said Vlad Leto, 30, before pointing his long-lens camera down on the crowded Rink at Rockefeller Center.

headline: Party Shoes for a Night on the Town
abstract: A festive low stacked heel is a joyfully practical choice.
lead_paragraph: A festive low stacked heel is a joyfully practical choice.

headline: Dressed-Down Diamond Timepieces
abstract: The new evening watches have an oversize masculinity that makes them fitting even for day.
lead_paragraph: The new evening watches have an oversize masculinity that makes them fitting even for day.

headline: Entering the Void
abstract: The Spanish artist Miquel Barceló closely examines the basic materials of life in response to Edward Hirsch questioning his own belief in a higher power.
lead_paragraph: The Spanish artist Miquel Barceló closely examines the basic materials of life in response to Edward Hirsch questioning his own belief in a higher power.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 A.M. (NBC) MACY’S THANKSGIVING DAY PARADE Matt Lauer, Savannah Guthrie and Al Roker host this 88th installment, with appearances by the Big Apple Circus, Cirque du Soleil, Renée Fleming, Nick Jonas, Kiss, Idina Menzel, Meghan Trainor, Quvenzhané Wallis and the Muppets of “Sesame Street,” as well as the Broadway casts of “A Gentleman’s Guide to Love & Murder,” “Honeymoon in Vegas,” “On the Town,” "Side Show” and “The Last Ship” with Sting. Soaring above it all: Snoopy and Woodstock, Spider-Man, SpongeBob SquarePants, Paddington Bear and, new this year, Eruptor from the Skylanders video game. The Taney Dragons Little League team from Philadelphia will lead the procession.

headline: With a New League, a Sport’s Sleeping Giant Begins to Stir
abstract: The creation of a professional league in India, backed with huge investments and Bollywood glamour, has prompted a level of excitement more common to cricket.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Indian soccer fans still dream of an alternate reality, one where their sport, not cricket, is the national obsession.

headline: Corrections: November 27, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Thursday, November 27, 2014.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, November 27, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “It’s now in the hands of all types of people — good people, bad people, tricksters, pranksters, kids.”

headline: Q. and A.: Zhang Lifan on the New Chinese Nationalism
abstract: The Chinese historian has become outspoken in recent years on the need for China to undertake ambitious economic and political changes.
lead_paragraph: The Chinese historian Zhang Lifan has become outspoken in recent years on the need for China to undertake ambitious economic and political changes. His family has been deeply involved in modern Chinese political life: Mr. Zhang’s father, Zhang Naiqi, served as the head of the national Food Department during the first years of the Communist government, but in 1957, he was labeled a rightist by Mao Zedong and tortured. He died in 1977, one year after Mao’s death.

headline: Toyota Widens Recall of Cars With Takata Airbags
abstract: The Japanese automaker and its minicar subsidiary, Daihatsu, said they were recalling a total of about 85,000 vehicles, all outside the United States.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Toyota widened a global recall on Thursday of vehicles containing potentially dangerous airbags made by the Takata Corporation, announcing its first recall of cars to fix problems with driver’s-side airbags. All of its recalls so far have been for passenger-side units.

headline: North Korea: Leader’s Sister Has Post in Ruling Party
abstract: North Korea’s state-run news media revealed Thursday that Kim Jong-un’s younger sister had become a senior official at the ruling Workers’ Party.
lead_paragraph: North Korea’s state-run news media revealed Thursday that the younger sister of the country’s leader, Kim Jong-un, had become a senior official at the ruling Workers’ Party, bolstering a widespread suspicion among outside analysts that she was emerging as an important player in his government. The North Korean media identified his sister, Kim Yo-jong, as “a deputy departmental director” of the party’s Central Committee. Ms. Kim, believed to be 27, is considered the relative closest to the North Korean leader. She has often accompanied her brother on his tours of factories and farms. Mr. Kim, believed to be 30, has no known male heir yet.

headline: British Embassy Vehicle Among Targets in 2 Kabul Attacks
abstract: The bombing near the embassy vehicle killed five people, officials said, and it was followed by a separate blast in another part of the Afghan capital.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — A dramatic increase of Taliban violence in Afghanistan’s capital in recent weeks culminated in two attacks on Thursday.

headline: Player’s Death From Cricket Injury Stuns Sport
abstract: Phillip Hughes’s death, in what was called a freakish accident, drew expressions of grief, shock and disbelief from fellow players and sporting figures around the world.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Two days after he was struck by a ball in what was called a freakish accident, an Australian cricketer, Phillip Hughes, died in a Sydney hospital on Thursday, drawing expressions of grief, shock and disbelief from fellow players and sporting figures around the world.

headline: Mayor’s Race Could Alter Balance of Political Power in Taiwan
abstract: A victory for Ko Wen-je, a physician who has cultivated an outsider image, would be a sharp defeat for Taiwan’s governing party in a city considered its stronghold.
lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — A doctor and political novice is favored to win Taipei’s mayoral election on Saturday, one of many races in which Taiwan’s governing party faces the prospect of its most serious setback in years.

headline: Indonesia Formally Pledges to Join China-Sponsored Regional Bank
abstract: Finance Minister Bambang Brodjonegoro has signed an agreement to join the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, intended to rival organizations like the World Bank.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Indonesia has signed an official memorandum of understanding to join a China-backed regional development bank intended to rival organizations like the World Bank and to further Beijing’s aspirations for a leadership role in Asia.

headline: British Firm Starts Hedge Fund for Social Services
abstract: Cheyne Capital is setting up a new fund to buy property that it will then rent to organizations that deliver services through the National Health Service.
lead_paragraph: When a potential hedge fund investor recently visited a mental health charity, he asked what the organization would need to help more people.

headline: Panel Details Plan to Give Scotland More Powers
abstract: Under new recommendations, the Scottish Parliament would set income tax rates and brackets, and the region would get a larger share of welfare spending and revenue from sales taxes.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Scotland was promised sweeping powers over taxation and welfare spending on Thursday under a proposed deal meant to address concerns that helped drive a Scottish attempt to secede from the United Kingdom in September.

headline: Malaysian Premier Says Sedition Act Will Stand
abstract: Prime Minister Najib Razak has backed away from his promise to abolish a sweeping law that has been used against the government’s opponents.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Malaysia’s prime minister on Thursday backed away from his promise to abolish a sweeping law that in recent years has been used against the government’s opponents.

headline: Hungry City: Fitzcarraldo in East Williamsburg, Brooklyn
abstract: At this restaurant in a corner of a 30,000-square-foot former warehouse, the food is Italian, mostly Ligurian, drawing from both the coast and the Alps of northern Italy.
lead_paragraph: Music rains down from a gramophone horn hung from a ceiling that curves like a ship’s hull. Spiky ferns half-spill out of hanging baskets; peacock-blue flowered tile runs underfoot. The front wall is all window, 12 feet tall with a grid of steel, looking out on almost unrelieved darkness.

headline: A Very Modern Take on a Classic Chinese Painting
abstract: The artist borrows the visual and conceptual framework of “Along the River During the Qingming Festival,” a 12-century painting, to produce a patchwork of vignettes of everyday Chinese society.
lead_paragraph: For a visual survey of recent headline-grabbing events in China, look no further than the latest photographic project by the artist Dai Xiang, inspired by the 12th-century scroll painting “Along the River During the Qingming Festival.”

headline: On Holiday, Ferguson Seeks to Salve Wounds
abstract: Residents painted art on boarded-up shops, a pastor of a destroyed church visited another worship space and the National Guard stood at the ready to secure the streets in the area.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — The people who came to this boarded-up downtown on Thursday morning knew they could not do much to salve Ferguson’s wounds. But it was Thanksgiving, and they felt they could not just sit home, either. So they brought paint brushes and prayers, thermoses of coffee and trays of drop biscuits, hoping to counterbalance the arsons, angry protests and racial strife.

headline: Thanksgiving Through the Years, Viewed Through Its Vocabulary
abstract: Turducken may come and go. Pumpkin pie is with us always.
lead_paragraph: As you prepare your Thanksgiving dinner, there’s a good chance that some of the dishes that were family traditions have been supplanted.

headline: E.U. Parliament Passes Measure to Break Up Google in Symbolic Vote
abstract: While the vote poses no immediate threat to the company, it symbolizes the growing resentment in Europe toward the American technology titan.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Europe’s resentment of the American technology giant Google reached a new noise level on Thursday as the European Parliament passed a nonbinding vote to break up the company.

headline: Greek Navy Tows Disabled Vessel Carrying Migrants to Safety
abstract: An estimated 700 people were on the 250-foot cargo ship that is now anchored off the Aegean island of Crete, according to the official.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — A disabled freighter carrying hundreds of migrants anchored off the Aegean island of Crete on Thursday after being towed by a Greek Navy vessel for more than 30 hours through strong winds.

headline: Five Economic Trends to Be Thankful For
abstract: Cheap gas, job growth, worker confidence, home prices and household debt offer positive signs for the future.
lead_paragraph: They say the news media likes to dwell on the bad, swapping silver linings for dark clouds. And in this miserable year of the Islamic State, Ebola and Ferguson, Mo., there have been plenty of dark clouds for us to report about.

headline: Morten Tyldum Narrates a Scene From ‘The Imitation Game’
abstract: Morten Tyldum discusses a sequence from from the film, featuring Benedict Cumberbatch.
lead_paragraph: In this video, the director Morten Tyldum discusses a sequence from his film, featuring Benedict Cumberbatch as the British mathematician and code breaker Alan Turing.

headline: Mikhail Baryshnikov and Robert Wilson Take On Nijinsky
abstract: The two will create a new work based on the diaries of the dancer and choreographer Vaslav Nijinsky, to have its premiere at the Festival di Spoleto in Italy in July 2015.
lead_paragraph: After their successful collaboration on adapting Daniil Kharms’s short story “The Old Woman” for the stage, Mikhail Baryshnikov and Robert Wilson are taking on another project. They will create a work based on the diaries of Vaslav Nijinsky, to have its premiere at the Festival di Spoleto in Italy in July 2015.

headline: Iran’s Supreme Leader Backs Further Nuclear Talks
abstract: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei’s opinion is crucial, as he has the final say over a potential deal.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, expressed support on Thursday for the extension of talks with Western powers on the country’s nuclear program.

headline: When Should You Shop? Right After Black Friday
abstract: A close look at the data suggests alternative approaches for people hoping to save money on items like electronics.
lead_paragraph: Want the best deals on electronics, but don’t feel like camping out for two weeks in front of Best Buy? Stay home on Friday, but don’t wait too long after that to shop online.

headline: The Daily Gift: Gourmet Jerky Made From Filet Mignon
abstract: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.
lead_paragraph: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.

headline: Rape Ruled Out in Case of 2 Indian Girls
abstract: The country’s top investigative agency said that the girls, whose bodies were found hanging from a mango tree, had committed suicide and that no rape or abduction was suspected.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — When the bodies of two teenage cousins were found hanging from a mango tree in the northern state of Uttar Pradesh in May, the police initially said the girls had been abducted and raped, in what seemed like yet another grisly crime against women in India.

headline: Build a Team, Then Rebuild a Musical
abstract: The agent Jack Tantleff worked to bring back the musical “Side Show” to Broadway.
lead_paragraph: Jack Tantleff thought he knew what the director Bill Condon would say. But when he asked Mr. Condon, “Why ‘Side Show’ and why now?” at a talkback after a recent performance of that Broadway musical, Mr. Tantleff didn’t realize the spotlight would turn on him.

headline: Gingerbread for a Cause
abstract: At Great Wolf Lodge resorts, life-size gingerbread houses are part of a charity initiative.
lead_paragraph: Gingerbread houses are a popular holiday tradition, and the Great Wolf Lodge, a group of 12 indoor water-park resorts in North America, is embracing it by giving guests and the public a chance to dine inside life-size versions.

headline: Seeing Is Disbelieving
abstract: The illusionist Adam Trent is making his Broadway debut with “The Illusionists — Witness the Impossible.”
lead_paragraph: By his own admission, Adam Trent has never held a real job — or at least not one that doesn’t involve plying a deck of cards. At 29, he has been a magician for nearly two decades, having been entranced by David Copperfield when he was 8. Growing up in Boulder, Colo., Mr. Trent began performing in a pint-size tuxedo while still in elementary school. Eventually, he put himself through college by doing sleight of hand.

headline: Italian Thanksgiving Shopping, a Cappella
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: Amid the chaos of a popular Italian grocery two days before Thanksgiving, a cheese buyer brought the crowd to a standstill.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: P. D. James, Creator of the Adam Dalgliesh Mysteries, Dies at 94
abstract: A consummate stylist, the British author and baroness accumulated numerous awards for the 18 crime novels produced during her 49-year writing career.
lead_paragraph: Phyllis Dorothy James White, who became Baroness James of Holland Park in 1991 but who was better known as “the Queen of Crime” for the multilayered mystery novels she wrote as P. D. James, died on Thursday at her home in Oxford, England. She was 94.

headline: Broken Codes, Both Strategic and Social
abstract: In “The Imitation Game” Benedict Cumberbatch plays Alan Turing, whose code-breaking work helped win World War II yet whose homosexuality led him to face indecency charges in Britain.
lead_paragraph: “The Imitation Game” is a highly conventional movie about a profoundly unusual man. This is not entirely a bad thing. Alan Turing’s tragically shortened life — he was 41 when he died in 1954 — is a complex and fascinating story, bristling with ideas and present-day implications, and it benefits from the streamlined structure and accessible presentation of modern prestige cinema. The science is not too difficult, the emotions are clear and emphatic, and the truth of history is respected just enough to make room for tidy and engrossing drama.

headline: International Arts Events Happening in the Week Ahead
abstract: A slideshow of arts events taking place across the world this coming week.

headline: “Gigi” — This One a Play — to Have an Off Off Broadway Run
abstract: The Storm Theater Company, an Off Off Broadway troupe, will in January revive the Anita Loos play “Gigi,” in which Audrey Hepburn made her Broadway debut in the title role in 1951.
lead_paragraph: The Anita Loos play “Gigi,” in which Audrey Hepburn made her Broadway debut in the title role in 1951, will be revived by Off Off Broadway’s Storm Theater Company in January, executives there announced on Thursday.

headline: OPEC Holds Production Unchanged; Prices Fall
abstract: The 30 percent decline in oil prices in recent months has shaken the solidarity of the 12-member Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA — The oil cartel OPEC decided on Thursday not to cut petroleum production, despite the plunge in prices in recent months that has indicated the diminishing clout of the organization.

headline: International Red Cross, Citing Numerous Crises, Plans Record Spending
abstract: The International Committee of the Red Cross said it needed a record $1.6 billion to confront humanitarian crises around the world.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Under pressure from the number and intensity of humanitarian crises around the world, the International Committee of the Red Cross said Thursday it was trying to raise a record $1.6 billion to fund its 2015 operations.

headline: 1939: Eleanor Roosevelt Ready to Testify
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: 1939: Eleanor Roosevelt Ready to Testify before the Dies Committee on the Investigation of un-American activities
lead_paragraph: Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt today said that she would gladly testify before the Dies Committee on the Investigation of un-American activities regarding alleged Communist control of the American Youth Congress.

headline: A Tight Budget and a Tighter Schedule
abstract: Lyndsie Guy and Megan Watson found a share in Bed-Stuy, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: When Lyndsie Guy moved to New York after completing a stint with AmeriCorps, she crashed with a friend in a Chelsea one-bedroom.

headline: On Ukraine Front Line, Sniper Fire and Shelling Leave Cease-Fire in Tatters
abstract: The Ukrainian military says it has recorded 3,412 rebel cease-fire violations, while separatists accuse Ukraine of shelling the eastern city of Donetsk.
lead_paragraph: PISKY, Ukraine — Since a cease-fire was declared in eastern Ukraine on Sept. 5, nearly 1,000 soldiers and civilians have died in a grinding conflict with rebel separatists that is being waged largely out of sight. That is almost a quarter of the 4,317 killed since April and an average of 13 a day, the United Nations estimates.

headline: Hong Kong Court Orders Joshua Wong, a Protest Leader, to Stay Away From Cleared Camp
abstract: Mr. Wong, a student who is the best-known face of the pro-democracy protest movement, was arrested when the police cleared away a street camp.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Joshua Wong, a student who is the best-known face of Hong Kong’s pro-democracy protest movement, was ordered by a court on Thursday to stay away from the area where he and other demonstrators were arrested when the police cleared away their street camp. Mr. Wong said he had been hit by police officers during the tense sweep.

headline: Growing Herds of Deer Aren’t Welcome at New York Parks
abstract: The influx concerns parks department officials because the animals can destroy a forest understory and chip away at the bark of developing trees.
lead_paragraph: Buck’s Hollow, in Staten Island’s Greenbelt, might sound like a natural home to whitetail deer, but the New York City parks department is doing its best to keep them out.

headline: Activists Help Pay for Patients’ Travel to Shrinking Number of Abortion Clinics
abstract: A Texas woman has founded Fund Texas Choice, to help finance lodging and transportation when nearby facilities are shut down.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — The young woman lived in Dallas, 650 miles from Albuquerque, but that was where she would have to go for an abortion, she was told. New state regulations had forced several of Dallas’s six abortion clinics to close, creating weekslong waiting lists. By the time the woman could get in, she would be up against the Texas ban on abortions after 20 weeks’ gestation.

headline: Gratitude, Woodworking and Music on the Home Front on Thanksgiving
abstract: Fitting in some analog home time, and music, amid the digital flow of work seeking a better planet.
lead_paragraph: I spend a lot of time analyzing global climate and energy trends, far-flung conservation efforts, work aimed at improving prospects for the world’s least fortunate and new technologies with promising future applications, the latest being a novel coating, described in Nature, that can in theory cool a building even on sunny days. Much of this screen and road time takes me away from my family, students and home.

headline: Bobby Storey, Veteran of Irish Republican Army, Detained in 1972 Murder
abstract: Mr. Storey, a prominent figure in the Sinn Fein political party, was questioned in Antrim about the abduction and killing of Jean McConville, a widowed mother of 10.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — A former senior Irish Republican Army commander was detained for questioning in Northern Ireland on Thursday in connection with a notorious 1972 murder case, his associates said.

headline: 1889: Priest Questions the Meridian of Greenwich
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Priest Questions the Meridian of Greenwich in 1889.
lead_paragraph: Father Tondini is a priest who proposes to sanctify geography, navigation and a quantity of other sciences by a very simple process. At present the civilized world marks distances and time from the meridian of Greenwich. Now, Greenwich is a purely secular place, and its meridian has not the least tinge of piety about it. This dissatisfies the good Father Tondini, and he therefore proposes that all the world should adopt the meridian of Jerusalem. In which case we should reckon time and distance from the Holy City, and thereby — so he thinks — prove ourselves to be Christians. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Nov. 28, 1889

headline: Macy’s 88th Annual Thanksgiving Day Parade
abstract: New balloons this year are a Red Mighty Morphin Power Ranger, Thomas the Tank Engine and Paddington Bear.
lead_paragraph: New balloons this year are a Red Mighty Morphin Power Ranger, Thomas the Tank Engine and Paddington Bear.

headline: Best at Everything? It’s Closer to True
abstract: M.I.T.’s football team, which has long been an afterthought at a university known for its academics, is 10-0 and in the second round of the N.C.A.A. Division III playoffs.
lead_paragraph: There is a comforting adage that many players on the football team at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology regularly use among themselves: The game on Saturday is the easiest part of their week.

headline: Deadly Attack on Indian Base Near Pakistan as Leaders Meet in Nepal
abstract: At least 10 people were killed in an attack in Kashmir, just as the leaders of India and Pakistan were exchanging pleasantries in Nepal.
lead_paragraph: KATMANDU, Nepal — At least 10 people were killed on Thursday in Kashmir when gunmen attacked an Indian Army base near the border with Pakistan, just as leaders of the two longtime rivals were exchanging pleasantries in Nepal.

headline: Using Doctors With Troubled Pasts to Market a Painkiller
abstract: Five of the 20 physicians who received the most money from Insys, maker of Subsys, a powerful painkiller, recently faced legal or disciplinary action.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Judson Somerville, a pain specialist in Laredo, Tex., received $67,000 in speaking fees, travel and meals in 2013 to promote a powerful and addictive painkiller called Subsys, according to a new federal database of payments that drug companies make to physicians.

headline: British Library Acquires Letters of Harold Pinter
abstract: The British Library has acquired more than 100 letters from Harold Pinter to add to its collection.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British Library announced on Thursday that it had acquired more than 100 letters that Harold Pinter wrote to two of his longtime friends, Henry Woolf and Mick Goldstein, mostly while he was in his 20s. The letters — written over a 12-year span — will join the library’s Harold Pinter Archive, a trove of manuscripts, photographs and personal correspondence that it acquired in 2007.

headline: From Carole King to a “Waitress:” Jessie Mueller Takes on a New Musical
abstract: Jessie Mueller, a Tony winner for “Beautiful: The Carole King Musical,” will take on title role in “Waitress”
lead_paragraph: Jessie Mueller, who won a best actress Tony Award in June for her acclaimed performance in the title role of “Beautiful: The Carole King Musical,” has found her next big theater project. She will star in the new musical “Waitress,” based on the 2007 film about a put-upon southern diner server (played by Keri Russell in the movie) who has a gift for making inventive pies and shares her thoughts about life as she prepares them.

headline: British Property Developer Files $3.5 Billion Claim Over Iceland Bank Inquiry
abstract: Vincent Tchenguiz contends that the accounting firm Grant Thornton, the Icelandic bank Kaupthing and three individuals were behind a flawed criminal inquiry into the bank’s collapse.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The British property developer Vincent Tchenguiz has filed a $3.5 billion claim in London against the accounting firm Grant Thornton, the Icelandic bank Kaupthing and three individuals, contending that they were behind a flawed criminal inquiry into the bank’s collapse.

headline: She’ll Be There
abstract: Baby Jane Dexter has returned to the Metropolitan Room, though her usually reliable voice betrayed her at times.
lead_paragraph: Few cabaret performers are more welcoming than Baby Jane Dexter, a singer with a booming gutbucket contralto who projects an open-armed empathy to her loyal fans. For the last several years, the message she has conveyed in her inspirational signature song, the R.E.M. classic “Everybody Hurts,” is an unspoken: “Come to Mama. We’re all in this together.”

headline: Under Pressure From Uber, Taxi Medallion Prices Are Plummeting
abstract: Market data suggests that the taxi business, which has undergone little change over many decades, is in the midst of a revolution.
lead_paragraph: In major cities throughout the United States, taxi medallion prices are tumbling as taxis face competition from car-service apps like Uber and Lyft.

headline: Ohio Exhibitions Highlight Ferdinand Brader
abstract: Three exhibitions in Canton, Ohio, spotlight the work of Ferdinand A. Brader, a 19th-century artist known for his pencil drawings of farms in Pennsylvania and Ohio.
lead_paragraph: FOLK ARTIST WHO LEFT

headline: Study on Cultural Memory Confirms: Chester A. Arthur, We Hardly Knew Ye
abstract: The broader significance of the report is that societies collectively forget according to the same formula as, say, a student who has studied a list of words.
lead_paragraph: Quick: Which American president served before slavery ended, John Tyler or Rutherford B. Hayes?

headline: Macy’s 88th Annual Thanksgiving Day Parade
abstract: Crowds gathered in Manhattan to watch the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade.
lead_paragraph: Crowds gathered in Manhattan to watch the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade.

headline: Ann Lislegaard Presents Three Intriguing Pieces
abstract: The Norwegian artist Ann Lislegaard presents pieces drawn from science fiction at Murray Guy.
lead_paragraph: The Norwegian artist Ann Lislegaard’s exceptionally elegant show presents three intriguing pieces based on famous works of science fiction.

headline: British Hedge Fund Titan Is Ordered to Pay Ex-Wife $531 Million
abstract: The divorce award between Chris Hohn and Jamie Cooper-Hohn underscores the immense wealth Mr. Hohn has accumulated at the helm of the Children’s Investment Fund.
lead_paragraph: A London high court judge has ordered Chris Hohn, founder of one of Britain’s largest and most successful hedge funds, to pay his former wife $531 million to settle their messy public divorce, according to statements made in court on Thursday.

headline: Running Against the Wind in Tandem
abstract: “Crossroads,” on CMT, which pairs rock artists with country stars, brings together the Detroit sounds of Bob Seger with the Georgia flavorings of Jason Aldean.
lead_paragraph: The CMT series “Crossroads” demands patience of its fans, generally doling out new installments only every few months. But that patience is always rewarded, and the episode having its premiere Friday night is particularly tasty.

headline: Songs Without an Expiration Date
abstract: Steve Tyrell celebrated a milestone when he opened his 10th holiday season show at Café Carlyle on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Steve Tyrell’s opening-night show at Café Carlyle on Tuesday was a milestone, both for the club and for Mr. Tyrell, who 10 years ago took over the cafe’s holiday slot previously occupied by Bobby Short. It didn’t seem so at the time, but Mr. Tyrell’s ascendance signaled a changing of the guard at the chic Upper East Side club, where the elegant Mr. Short had entertained bohemian socialites for more than three decades.

headline: Greeks Go on Strike Over New Austerity Measures
abstract: Thousands of Greeks walked off the job while government officials wrangled with international creditors over economic policy and a financial bailout.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Thousands of Greeks walked off the job on Thursday in a general strike to protest further austerity measures, while government officials wrangled with the country’s international creditors over economic policy and whether to extend Greece’s financial bailout.

headline: Moby Presents ‘Innocents,’ a Series of Photographs
abstract: Photographs by Moby, the pop musician, at the Emmanuel Fremin Gallery in Chelsea, feature a mysterious cult of masked figures.
lead_paragraph: MOBY

headline: At Macy’s Parade, Bands, Balloons and, This Thanksgiving, Protesters
abstract: Pockets of demonstrators marched intermittently along the route, protesting the grand jury’s decision not to indict the police officer who fatally shot Michael Brown, an unarmed black man, in Ferguson, Mo., in August.
lead_paragraph: The usual helium-filled characters, like Snoopy and the pudgy Pillsbury Doughboy, were out in force at the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade on Thursday. But this year, the parade had an edge: Pockets of protesters marched intermittently along the route, seeking to call attention to a grand jury’s decision on Monday not to indict the police officer who shot and killed Michael Brown, an unarmed black teenager in Ferguson, Mo., in August.

headline: Francesco Clemente Offers Contrasting Shows
abstract: “Two Tents,” Francesco Clemente’s show at the Mary Boone Gallery, portrays a kind of heaven with hard benches and a hell with busy bees.
lead_paragraph: The nomadic Neo-Expressionist painter Francesco Clemente is back, with two concurrent but very different shows: a spare, almost monastic solo show at the Rubin Museum and an abundantly sensual exhibition at Mary Boone in Chelsea. The gallery show, which enfolds visitors in Mughal-style canvas tents with vibrant painted interiors, plays to his strengths: a fluid hand and a rich, knowing synthesis of Eastern and Western figurative art.

headline: At a Paris Flea Market, Tips for Treasure Hunters
abstract: Over the past two years, the giant Marché aux Puces de Paris/St.-Ouen has become cool again. Here’s some guidance for conquering the sprawling stalls.
lead_paragraph: St.-Ouen. The name made me shudder. Whenever visitors asked me to take them to that vast set of flea markets just north of the Paris city line, I did my best to divert them elsewhere.

headline: A Doctor Will See You Now
abstract: “Remote Area Medical” chronicles a nonprofit group that stages free clinics in areas that lack access to basic health care.
lead_paragraph: If you were unaware that there are people in the United States who don’t receive proper health care, “Remote Area Medical,” a documentary about the nonprofit organization of that name, certainly shows you what they look like, in blunt, tooth-decaying detail. But beyond that, it maddeningly refuses to take a stand or explore the questions it raises.

headline: Beethoven, ‘Cyrano’ and Samplings From Film Scores
abstract: Jaap van Zweden conducted the New York Philharmonic on Wednesday night in a program of Beethoven, Erich Korngold and Johan Wagenaar.
lead_paragraph: The Dutch conductor Jaap van Zweden has been thriving as the music director of the Dallas Symphony Orchestra since his tenure began in 2008. At the time of his appointment, he was little known in the United States. Now 53, he is still introducing himself to the players and audiences of the New York Philharmonic. After making an impressive Philharmonic debut in 2012, he did not return until last week, for a program that included a well-received account of Shostakovich’s Eighth Symphony.

headline: Slashing His Wrists When the Phone Rings
abstract: “Before I Disappear” is Shawn Christensen’s feature-length expansion of his Oscar-winning short, “Curfew.”
lead_paragraph: All mood and no substance, “Before I Disappear” is Shawn Christensen’s feature-length expansion of his Academy Award-winning 19-minute film, “Curfew,” from 2012.

headline: A Touring Dancer’s Packing Steps
abstract: Glenn Allen Sims, who travels with the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, shares his suitcase strategies.
lead_paragraph: As a dancer who tours nine months a year with the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, Glenn Allen Sims has learned a thing or two about traveling. To maximize limited time in a city, he and his wife, Linda Celeste Sims, also a dancer with the company, rise early, getting in sightseeing before rehearsal that afternoon and eating dinner before their performance so they can turn in right after it.

headline: Euro Bond Yields
abstract: Check out their low, low rates.
lead_paragraph: The turkey gobblers aren’t here yet, so let’s take a moment to note the record lows being hit in European bond markets:

headline: When Fractions of a Second Can Change Whole Lives
abstract: The documentary “Touch the Wall” follows two world-class swimmers, Kara Lynn Joyce and Missy Franklin.
lead_paragraph: There is a bit of “A Star Is Born” in “Touch the Wall,” a documentary that traces the diverging fortunes of two Olympic-level swimmers. We watch Kara Lynn Joyce, a four-time silver medalist, as she joins a team in Colorado, where she trains alongside Missy Franklin, then in high school. Together, they prepare to try out for the 2012 United States Olympic team.

headline: New York City’s Week in Pictures: Nov. 28
abstract: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include the Macy’s Thanksgiving Parade and protests after the decision in Ferguson, Mo.
lead_paragraph: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include the Macy’s Thanksgiving Parade and protests after the decision in Ferguson, Mo.

headline: Go Read a Book, Kid. It Couldn’t Hurt You.
abstract: “The Babadook,” the Australian director Jennifer Kent’s debut feature, is a horror movie full of interlocking ambiguities.
lead_paragraph: I was an easily frightened child, and nothing scared me more than certain picture books. Something about the static images, the simple words and the unseen menaces hidden between pages made books much more sinister than, say, movies, and quite a few volumes that now seem perfectly innocuous were banished from my bedroom shelves. I had forgotten about this youthful phobia until I saw “The Babadook,” the debut feature by the Australian director Jennifer Kent. Or rather, until I came home from the screening, went to bed and woke up in the throes of the kind of nightmare that was the reason I had shunned those books in the first place.

headline: Spike Lee Script for “Do the Right Thing” to Receive Public Reading
abstract: Michael B. Jordan and John Turturro will take part in a reading of the script for Spike Lee’s “Do the Right Thing”
lead_paragraph: The actors Michael B. Jordan (“Fruitvale Station”) and John Turturro (“Barton Fink”) will join in a free reading on Friday evening of Spike Lee’s screenplay for “Do the Right Thing” at the Film Society of Lincoln Center, according to Blackout for Human Rights, a social justice group presenting the event.

headline: Remembering P. D. James: Times Reviews
abstract: A collection of Times reviews and features on the work of P. D. James.
lead_paragraph: The mystery novelist P. D. James became known as the “Queen of Crime” over her writing career. She died on Thursday at 94. Following is a collection of Times coverage of the author and reviews of her work.

headline: From Here (or There) to Eternity
abstract: “The Immortalists,” a documentary directed by David Alvarado and Jason Sussberg, looks at two scientists racing against time and its inevitable consequences.
lead_paragraph: David Alvarado and Jason Sussberg’s “The Immortalists” at first looks to be a horse race portrayal of two men competing to achieve eternal life through scientific means. Aubrey de Grey — his name seems lifted from a Poe story — is an amply bearded British scientist with a multipronged strategy for combating the deleterious effects of aging. His counterpart here is Bill Andrews, an American who likes to run ultramarathons and has his own petri dish proposal for cheating cell death.

headline: This Dieter Is Different (Trivial and Personal)
abstract: Periodic suffering works for me.
lead_paragraph: Julia Belluz has a nice piece about weight loss, which a lot of us will be thinking about tomorrow morning. Two things really resonated: The absence of any well-defined best diet, and the importance of tracking.

headline: Behind the Fanciful Creatures and Wide-Eyed Waifs
abstract: A documentary, “The Kingdom of Dreams and Madness,” looks within Studio Ghibli, the Japanese animation powerhouse.
lead_paragraph: “The Kingdom of Dreams and Madness” documents the inner workings of Studio Ghibli, the Japanese animation studio, at a time when its two most celebrated directors were making new films. The movie largely focuses on Hayao Miyazaki, who formally announced his retirement after “The Wind Rises” had its premiere in 2013. “The Tale of the Princess Kaguya,” by Isao Takahata (“Grave of the Fireflies”), Mr. Miyazaki’s discoverer and friendly rival, opened in New York this year.

headline: Home Sweet Home on the Isolated Ice
abstract: The documentary “Antarctica” reveals the community spirit among residents of the southernmost continent.
lead_paragraph: The extremes of “Antarctica: A Year on Ice” might seem routine to fans of nature documentaries, but the photographer and director Anthony Powell produces some dazzling imagery in his droll study of isolation way, way down under. His varied tour of Antarctica’s scientific stations and their long-term residents is like a jokey, expertly shot slide show from another world.

headline: Liberal Treasury Nominee’s Wall St. Prowess May Be a Vulnerability
abstract: Senate confirmation of Antonio Weiss as an under secretary of the Treasury could be hindered by corporate mergers he was involved in as an executive at Lazard.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In 2012, Antonio F. Weiss took his 15-year-old son, Nico, from the gilded aerie of their Manhattan apartment on Central Park West to Cleveland to canvass for President Obama’s re-election. Mr. Weiss, 48, was also the co-author of a white paper calling for higher taxes on the rich and has donated hundreds of thousands of dollars to the Democratic Party.

headline: Is Our Art Equal to the Challenges of Our Times?
abstract: We are in the midst of hard times now, and it feels as if art is failing us.
lead_paragraph: A. O. Scott and a panel of cultural figures ponder whether and how artists should address social issues like race and class through their work. Mr. Scott’s essay is below; the panel discussion is here.

headline: Who Knew the Classics Could Be So Combative?
abstract: “The Historian” centers on a divorced professor who clashes with a superior and walks an ethical tightrope.
lead_paragraph: In “The Historian,” life at a university classics department barely stops short of brawling. The movie conveys this hostile atmosphere almost immediately, when the domineering department leader, Dr. Valerian Hadley (William Sadler), corrects a student. “The Romans didn’t invent crucifixion,” he says. “They perfected it.” He uses the student for a pantomime demonstration.

headline: A New Home at the Frick for a Rare Murillo Work
abstract: The Frick has acquired a self-portrait by the 17th-century Spanish master Bartolomé Esteban Murillo.
lead_paragraph: The Frick Collection has always been rich in Spanish paintings, particularly works by Velázquez, El Greco and Goya. The museum’s founder, Henry Clay Frick, bought three canvases by El Greco on his travels to Spain, and they currently hang together as part of “El Greco in New York,” an exhibition organized in collaboration with the Frick, the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Hispanic Society to commemorate the 400th anniversary of the artist’s death.

headline: Who’s Who
abstract: Ken Burns, David Simon, J. Cole and other cultural figures discuss whether and how artists should address social issues.
lead_paragraph: KEN BURNS is a documentarian whose PBS series include “The Roosevelts: An Intimate History.” He is executive producer of “The Emperor of All Maladies,” due next year.

headline: Swiss Unveil Art Amassed by Dealer in Nazi Era
abstract: The collection, including paintings by Renoir, Cézanne, Monet, Manet and Gauguin, was squirreled away by Cornelius Gurlitt in a house in Salzburg, Austria.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Fresh mysteries and marvels of the art trove amassed by a Nazi-era art dealer and kept secret for decades unfurled on Thursday when the Swiss museum that inherited the collection revealed all 1,600 or so works to the world for the first time.

headline: Race, Class and Creative Spark
abstract: Cultural figures like David Simon, J. Cole, Patricia Lockwood and others discuss whether and how artists should address social issues like race and class through their work.
lead_paragraph: A. O. Scott and a panel of cultural figures ponder whether and how artists should address social issues like race and class through their work. The panel discussion is below; Mr. Scott’s essay is here.

headline: Klara Liden Unveils ‘It’s Complicated’
abstract: Klara Liden’s show “It’s Complicated” continues her transformations of space, materials and social relationships.
lead_paragraph: “It’s Complicated,” Klara Liden’s most ambitious New York show to date, is well named. Continuing Ms. Liden’s inspired yet homey and often utilitarian transformations of space, materials and social relationships, it presents a video and improvised furniture on each of two adjacent floors. While not as flashy as her last show — which filled the gallery with discarded Christmas trees — this one compellingly mixes art and life, labor and relaxation, and various bodies and limbs, animate and not.

headline: Germany and France Aim to Avert a ‘Lost Decade’
abstract: The French and German economy ministers called for a “New Deal” that would involve investment in Germany and economic overhauls elsewhere in the eurozone.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The economy ministers of France and Germany called on Thursday for urgent overhauls and a series of investments in both countries to help prevent them and the eurozone from falling into a stagnation trap.

headline: At Minnesota, a Staff Devoted to the Long Run
abstract: Seven of the 10 coaches on Jerry Kill’s staff at Minnesota have been with him for at least 14 years, and that consistency has helped give the Golden Gophers a chance at their first Big Ten title since 1967.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — It took a few moments for Matt Limegrover, Minnesota’s offensive coordinator and line coach, to remember the last time another university tried to lure him from Coach Jerry Kill’s staff. He surmised it might have been after the 2011 season, the first that he, Kill and Tracy Claeys, the defensive coordinator, spent with the Golden Gophers.

headline: GTT ★
abstract: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.
lead_paragraph: Our quirky, discerning picks for

headline: The Numbers Add Up to Republican Dominance
abstract: For all the talk about turning Texas blue, the state remains reliably and overwhelmingly red.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — Texas, a hothouse for Republicans, is a decidedly hostile environment for Democrats. If that was not obvious in the first readings of election results this month and in the continuation of the Republican winning streak in statewide races, a dive into the numbers shows the depth of the hole Democrats are trying to fill.

headline: Twangy, Jazzy, Stately, Holy
abstract: New holiday music albums include ones from Idina Menzel, Irvin Mayfield, Darius Rucker, the Blind Boys of Alabama and the cast of “Downton Abbey.”
lead_paragraph: THE holidays are a time for family, for reflection, for conspicuous consumption.
