For musicians, they’re a time to tackle old standards and see who comes out on top, or to try to record new ones, because there’s no bigger gift than hubris. Here, the pop and jazz critics of The New York Times reach down into their stockings and hope there’s no coal. (Prices may vary, depending on whether you’ve been naughty or nice.) JON CARAMANICA

headline: Texas Must Now Decide Where to Spend Oil Boom Money Dedicated to Roadwork
abstract: Texas voters overwhelmingly approved Proposition 1, which is expected to bring in billions of extra revenue for transportation spending. State officials remain uncertain of how much, and how to use the funding.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — Eighty percent of Texas voters approved a measure this month to increase transportation funding without raising taxes or fees. Proposition 1 is expected to add billions to the state highway fund by dedicating some of the tax revenue from the oil boom to road construction and maintenance.

headline: Lone Star State Bets Heavily on a Space Economy
abstract: County and Texas officials offered millions of dollars in incentives to lure SpaceX, billionaire Elon Musk’s space exploration company, to Brownsville, Tex.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — Someday capsules sent aloft from a New Mexico desert will whisk celebrity passengers on flights into suborbital space.

headline: Financial Incentives in Health Care
abstract: Doctors and an insurance association discuss an Op-Ed essay that said financial forces corrupt medicine and undermine trust in doctors.

headline: Food Safety and Worker Safety Are Inextricably Linked
abstract: Peter O’Driscoll of the Equitable Food Initiative and Ellen K. Silbergeld of the Bloomberg School of Public Health at Johns Hopkins respond to an Op-Ed article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Monitoring of Protests at the Supreme Court
abstract: Gabe Roth of Fix the Court writes that it’s no wonder the relationship between the public and the justices remains “strained.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Detroit’s Pension Benefits
abstract: The executive director of the National Conference on Public Employee Retirement Systems says pensions should not be seen as a threat to the city.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Shoppers Line Up for Black Friday Deals
abstract: Eager to make up for what has been a year of lackluster sales, retailers are offering eye-popping discounts that could increase traffic but also eat away at thinning profit margins.
lead_paragraph: Work crews were still cleaning up confetti from the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade when the lines began forming outside the storefronts in Herald Square. Some shoppers were there for the sales, starting across the nation earlier than ever this year. Others were there just to revel in the spectacle of what many retailers are now calling “Gray Thursday.”

headline: The Trick to Being More Virtuous
abstract: I was more polite when I carried the briefcase the Mormons gave me.
lead_paragraph: SEVERAL years ago, I visited Provo, Utah — in the heart of what its residents call “Happy Valley” — to deliver a lecture at Brigham Young University. My gracious hosts sent me home with a prodigious amount of branded souvenirs: T-shirts, mugs — you name it. The Mormons are serious about product placement.

headline: Remember the Sand Creek Massacre
abstract: The 1864 murder of 200 innocent Indians is still largely forgotten.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN — MANY people think of the Civil War and America’s Indian wars as distinct subjects, one following the other. But those who study the Sand Creek Massacre know different.

headline: An Inclusive Emerging Economy, With Africa in the Lead
abstract: About 10 million people in more than 60 countries now use village based savings groups, many in remote rural areas without any other financial services.
lead_paragraph: At a time when news about Africa has been dominated by Ebola, it’s worth observing that a highly encouraging change has been quietly spreading across the continent. Over the past five years, the number of Africans — mainly women — who have joined village-based savings and loan associations has soared to more than nine million. These groups are now operating in 40 countries in Africa. Globally, it’s estimated that 10.5 million people are members of formally trained savings groups in about 65 countries. (PDF) The big story about these groups, including their surprising success and emerging importance in development, comes from Africa.

headline: After a Time Without a Team, Ex-Ranger Michael Del Zotto Settles In With the Flyers
abstract: Del Zotto has established himself in the Flyers’ lineup after being traded by the Rangers and not finding a role in Nashville.
lead_paragraph: Michael Del Zotto acknowledged that being a visitor at Madison Square Garden was a strange feeling.

headline: Theater Listings for Nov. 28-Dec.4
abstract: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.
lead_paragraph: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Comedy Listings for Nov. 28-Dec. 4
abstract: A selected guide to improv, stand-up and other comedy shows in New York City.
lead_paragraph: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Conflicting Policies on Syria and Islamic State Erode U.S. Standing in Mideast
abstract: There is a broad sense on all sides that President Obama’s policies on Syria and the Islamic State remain contradictory.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — American and Syrian warplanes screamed over the Syrian city of Raqqa in separate raids this week, ostensibly against the same target, the Islamic State militants in control there.

headline: Israel Says Hamas Ring Plotted West Bank Attacks
abstract: The Shin Bet security agency says it broke up a network of operatives that sought to provoke a heavy-handed response from Israel in the West Bank that would undermine the Palestinian Authority there.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Shin Bet, Israel’s internal security agency, says it has exposed an extensive Hamas military infrastructure in the West Bank that was planning to carry out attacks on Israelis, according to a statement issued by the agency on Thursday.

headline: Movie Listings for Nov. 28-Dec. 4
abstract: A critical guide to movies playing in theaters, as well as a selected overview of film series and festivals.
lead_paragraph: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Beauty Brand Creates Campaign to Combat Mental Illness
abstract: The Philosophy cosmetics brand expects to raise $10 million over the next five years and will focus its efforts on mental health issues most affecting women.
lead_paragraph: NEARLY 40,000 Americans commit suicide annually, about the same number that die from breast cancer. But while countless brands adopt pink packaging to raise awareness during Breast Cancer Awareness Month in October, corporate support for mental illness, the cause of most suicides, is decidedly scant.

headline: Pop & Rock Listings for Nov. 28-Dec. 4

lead_paragraph: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

abstract: A selected, critical guide to performances in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Kindle Versus Ipad: Which Tablet Is Best for Kids?
abstract: When choosing a child’s tablet, remember that you are making a down payment toward a content library that will last for years. Making a hasty decision based on price may backfire.
lead_paragraph: As loving parents and grandparents, we are hardwired to seek out the best for our offspring, whether it be food, strollers or a college education. Strollers are generally straightforward purchases, but what about first tablets?

headline: Dance Listings for Nov. 28-Dec. 4
abstract: A selected guide to dance performances in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: U.S.-Backed Mortgages Put to Test in an Innovative Lawsuit
abstract: U.S. Bank, a division of U.S. Bancorp, is being accused of failing to engage with borrowers who missed payments.
lead_paragraph: When Hayward Ferrell of Huber Heights, Ohio, fell behind on his mortgage payments several years ago, his bank did not meet with him to try to work out a plan to make the loan easier to pay, he says.

headline: Museum & Gallery Listings for Nov. 28-Dec. 4
abstract: A selected guide to the visual arts in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Spare Times for Children for Nov. 28-Dec. 4
abstract: A selected guide to cultural events for children, teenagers and families in New York City.
lead_paragraph: ‘The Amazing Adventures of Harvey and the Princess’

headline: Urban Farmers Trade Goods and Stories at ‘Crop Swaps’
abstract: The swaps, which operate on the barter system, allow people to diversify their pantries while bolstering their relationships with others in their communities.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — The Bay Area is a culinary never-never land, a place where aspiring apiarists hire beekeeping coaches, and even 7-year-olds can discuss the virtues of Himalayan salt.

headline: Spare Times for Nov. 28-Dec. 4
abstract: A selected guide to readings, exhibitions, walking tours and other cultural events in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Around Town

headline: Friday’s College Football Games to Watch
abstract: U.C.L.A. can clinch the Pacific-12 South with a win over Stanford and earn the right to play Oregon for the conference championship.
lead_paragraph: STANFORD at 9 U.C.L.A.

headline: As Mexican Border Town Tries to Move On, Some Are Stuck in Limbo
abstract: Tijuana is promoting itself as a city on the rise, shaking off years of drug violence and declining tourism. But it remains a way station for the downtrodden heading for America or kicked out of it.
lead_paragraph: TIJUANA, Mexico — Under a gleaming midday sun, in the fetid drainage canal that is the Rio Tijuana, Valentin Gomez plunged a hypodermic needle of crystal meth just under a friend’s collarbone.

headline: With Naming Rights, ‘Perpetuity’ Doesn’t Always Mean Forever
abstract: The issue was recalled this month when Lincoln Center agreed to pay $15 million to expunge Avery Fisher’s name from Philharmonic Hall, in hopes of luring another donor.
lead_paragraph: After Philippe de Montebello agreed at breakfast two decades ago to name the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s Roman Sculpture Court, in perpetuity, for the philanthropists and antiquities collectors Leon Levy and his wife, Shelby White, Mr. Levy predictably, but politely, posed an impertinent question.

headline: For New Tappan Zee, Questions Persist Over How High the Tolls Will Climb
abstract: The discount afforded by one of the New York City area’s great travel bargains — crossing the Hudson River on the Tappan Zee Bridge — is likely to shrink, but no one can say by how much.
lead_paragraph: TARRYTOWN, N.Y. — One of the great travel bargains in the New York City area is crossing the Hudson River from Rockland County into Westchester County.

headline: The Ambition Explosion
abstract: China’s future may be determined as much by its spiritual struggle as by its new capitalist ethos.
lead_paragraph: In 1976, Daniel Bell published a book called “The Cultural Contradictions of Capitalism.” Bell argued that capitalism undermines itself because it nurtures a population of ever more self-gratifying consumers. These people may start out as industrious, but they soon get addicted to affluence, spending, credit and pleasure and stop being the sort of hard workers capitalism requires.

headline: A Tilt Toward NATO in Ukraine as Parliament Meets
abstract: At the convening of a new Parliament in Ukraine, President Petro O. Poroshenko urged the repeal of the country’s nonaligned status and a move toward joining NATO.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — As Ukraine’s new Parliament, firmly controlled by a coalition of pro-Western parties, convened for the first time on Thursday, President Petro O. Poroshenko urged lawmakers to repeal a 2010 law that codified the country’s nonaligned status in global affairs, and to instead pursue membership in NATO.

headline: Pollution and Politics
abstract: Like Obamacare, Republicans went on the attack over the E.P.A.’s proposed regulations to curb emissions of ozone. And we know why.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this week, the Environmental Protection Agency announced proposed regulations to curb emissions of ozone, which causes smog, not to mention asthma, heart disease and premature death. And you know what happened: Republicans went on the attack, claiming that the new rules would impose enormous costs.

headline: In Peru, a Fight Over Land Rights
abstract: Indigenous communities are standing up to loggers in a country that is one of the deadliest for environmentalists and activists.
lead_paragraph: In September, four indigenous activists who stood up to unscrupulous loggers in a remote region of Peru’s rain forest were slain. The deaths could have easily gone unnoticed. Their village, Saweto, is a seven-day canoe ride from the nearest city. There is minimal government presence in the country’s vast rain forest, which is home to more than 300,000 indigenous people.

headline: At 0-15, 76ers Are Perfecting the Art of Tanking
abstract: The 76ers say the team is undergoing a disciplined rebuilding plan, but others might see it as manipulation of the team’s roster and schedule to put themselves in a better draft position.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — An hour before the Philadelphia 76ers hosted the Nets on Wednesday night, Dan Norfleet stood inside the Septa station near the Wells Fargo Center, where he coordinates trains as they come and go. Norfleet is a familiar face to Philadelphia fans, and in his job he directs them — depending on the season — to the nearby baseball, football and basketball arenas.

headline: Mexican Leader, Facing Protests, Promises to Overhaul Policing
abstract: President Enrique Peña Nieto’s plan makes forces answerable to state and federal authorities, though observers questioned the credibility of a president who has had scandals of his own.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Facing waves of anger and frustration after local officials and the police were implicated in the disappearance and presumed murder of 43 college students, President Enrique Peña Nieto on Thursday proposed a broad plan to revamp local policing, stamp out corruption and establish the rule of law nationwide.

headline: Gay Men Should Be Allowed to Give Blood
abstract: The backward ban is out of step with medical research.
lead_paragraph: Although the American Red Cross regularly warns that the national blood supply is too low, the Food and Drug Administration arbitrarily excludes a slice of the population from becoming a donor. Any man who has had sex with another man since 1977 is “deferred” — a euphemism for “banned ” since the deferral lasts a lifetime.

headline: The New G.O.P. Showdown Threat
abstract: Republicans in Congress should not use the power of the purse to pressure the White House into backing off its executive order on immigration.
lead_paragraph: Senator Jeff Sessions of Alabama announced with great gravity the other day that Republicans had decided not to impeach President Obama over his plan to allow millions of immigrants to remain in this country without fear of deportation through his executive authority. But that concession is not the end of the matter. He is planning much more serious mischief: using Congress’s power of the purse to pressure the White House into backing off.

headline: In Ferguson, Officer Defused Eruptions as Crowds Grew Tense
abstract: Few law enforcers have done more on the ground to ease tensions than Jerry Lohr, a white lieutenant of the St. Louis County Police who is not above giving hugs.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — Late Wednesday, two nights after rioting left blocks of this suburban city in smoldering ruin, a small but angry crowd assembled at the police station on South Florissant Road.

headline: Eagles Come Out Strong Against Cowboys and Take Division Lead
abstract: Mark Sanchez, who was 20 of 29 passing for 217 yards, led Philadelphia in a rout of N.F.C. East rival Dallas.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — The fake was so good, a classic read-option sleight of hand, that a blue wave of Dallas Cowboys defenders crashed down the line of scrimmage toward LeSean McCoy like surf at high tide.

headline: Chinese Dissident’s Trial to Begin
abstract: Yang Maodong and another activist were set to go on trial in China on Friday, the latest adversaries of the Communist Party’s censorship likely to be convicted and imprisoned for years.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A prominent Chinese dissident, Yang Maodong, and another activist were set to go on trial in southern China on Friday, the latest adversaries of the Communist Party’s censorship and controls likely to be convicted and imprisoned for years on charges of disrupting public order.

headline: In Arizona, a Textbook Fuels a Broader Dispute Over Sex Education
abstract: The board in Gilbert, Ariz., said two pages in a biology textbook that discuss sexually transmitted diseases and contraception violated a state law passed in 2012.
lead_paragraph: GILBERT, Ariz. — The textbook, the one with the wide-eyed lemur peering off the cover, has been handed out for years to students in honors biology classes at the high schools here, offering lessons on bread-and-butter subjects like mitosis and meiosis, photosynthesis and anatomy.

headline: Despite Aid Push, Ebola Is Raging in Sierra Leone
abstract: After calling for an ambulance more than 35 times, a family in Sierra Leone, where Ebola has hit harder than in neighboring countries, waited for three days for help to arrive.
lead_paragraph: KISSI TOWN, Sierra Leone — Military choppers thunder over the slums. Nearly a thousand British soldiers are on the scene, ferrying supplies and hammering together new Ebola clinics. Crates of food and medicine are flowing into the port, and planeloads of experts seem to arrive every day — Ugandan doctors, Chinese epidemiologists, Australian logisticians, even an ambulance specialist from London.

headline: Lester Bernstein, 94, Dies; Wide-Ranging Journalist Edited Newsweek
abstract: Mr. Bernstein, who also wrote for The New York Times and Time magazine, helped arrange America’s first televised presidential debates when he was an NBC vice president in 1960.
lead_paragraph: Lester Bernstein, a former editor of Newsweek magazine who also wrote for The New York Times, was a foreign correspondent for Time magazine and, as a vice president of NBC in 1960, helped arrange America’s first televised presidential debates, died on Thursday at his home in Lido Beach, N.Y. He was 94.

headline: Time of Annual Madness
abstract: Tracy Gray reminds us of a revered American tradition.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — So there I was, cruising along with an unusually successful solving streak, when I ran into Tracy Gray’s Friday puzzle and totally tanked.

headline: Restoring Lost Names, Recapturing Lost Dignity
abstract: An obscure gravedigger has come to represent the 55,000 other people buried on the grounds of old psychiatric hospitals across New York State — many of them identified only by numbers.
lead_paragraph: OVID, N.Y. — For a half-century, a slight and precise man with an Old World mustache resided as a patient at the Willard State Psychiatric Hospital, here beside spectacular Seneca Lake. You are not supposed to know his name, but it was Lawrence Mocha. He was the gravedigger.

headline: A Son Seeks Art Looted by the East Germans
abstract: Between 1973 and 1989, the East German police seized more than 200,000 objects in hundreds of raids, according to experts and archives, and some are reclaiming the art.
lead_paragraph: Just after sunrise on a March morning in 1982, the secret police pounded on the door of Helmuth Meissner, a Dresden art collector known for his refined taste.

headline: Grateful for What’s Left, Not Mourning What’s Lost
abstract: Anna Maria Walsh has numerous health problems, but her resiliency has led her to win nomination to a Brooklyn community board and to work to help others with disabilities.
lead_paragraph: Stricken by polio as an infant, Anna Maria Walsh regained her lost mobility as a teenager, crediting a miracle for sparing her life and restoring her body.

headline: Anger Upstate Over Power Plan for New York City
abstract: Hudson Valley residents worry that proposals to add high-voltage electric transmission lines will cause disruptions including spoiled views and loss of homes and property.
lead_paragraph: RHINEBECK, N.Y. — Residents of the rolling landscape in much of the Hudson Valley have long lived with high-voltage electric transmission lines and the giant columns of hulking steel towers that look as though they were assembled out of a child’s Erector set. The lines have cut corridors through the countryside since at least the 1930s.

headline: Fordham Finds Key to Success, and Drills It Home
abstract: The ninth-ranked Rams take a 10-2 record and hopes for a championship run into their playoff opener against No. 25 Sacred Heart on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: When Joe Moorhead took over the football program at Fordham, after it struck bottom with a 1-10 record in 2011, the technical aspects of the sport were secondary to his emphasis on discipline, work ethic and attention to detail.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 27, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: The Future of Wearable Tech
abstract: Will consumers ever embrace wearable technology, or are the devices too intrusive?

headline: Japan to Ask Automakers to Recall Vehicles With Faulty Takata Airbags
abstract: An order from the Transportation Ministry on driver’s-side airbags would lead to the recall of an additional 200,000 vehicles in Japan, the transportation minister said.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japan will follow the United States in forcing automakers to recall all vehicles containing potentially dangerous driver’s-side airbags made by the Takata Corporation, the transportation minister, Akihiro Ohta, announced on Friday, saying the problem put Japan’s car-making reputation at risk along with drivers’ safety.

headline: Two Boys Trapped for Hours in a Snow Mound Are Rescued
abstract: Rescuers dug with shovels and their hands to free a 9- and 11-year-old who were buried under a seven-foot snow mound in a parking lot in Newburgh, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: Two boys in upstate New York were trapped under a seven-foot mound of snow for more than four hours before they were freed early Thursday by rescue workers and relatives who dug with their hands and shovels, the police said.

headline: Corrections: November 28, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on November 28, 2014.
lead_paragraph: NATIONAL

headline: What’s on TV Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (13) KRISTIN CHENOWETH: COMING HOME Ms. Chenoweth, above, journeys back to Broken Arrow, Okla., her hometown, to perform in the theater named for her, accompanied by a 13-piece orchestra and some Broadway friends. The playlist, culled from her new album, “Coming Home,” includes “I Could Have Danced All Night,” “My Coloring Book,” “Enough Is Enough,” “All the Things You Are,” “Over the Rainbow,” and “Popular” and “For Good” from “Wicked,” in which she originated the role of Glinda.

headline: Though Strain and Damage Are Visible, Uneasy Truce Holds in Ferguson
abstract: The police eased traffic restrictions along a main thoroughfare, but the National Guard maintained a large presence in the city, as did the Missouri State Highway Patrol.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — Gov. Jay Nixon said on Friday evening that he was calling a special legislative session to find a way to pay for mounting state costs for handling the unrest that has gripped this city.

headline: After Ferguson
abstract: Residents of Ferguson are still reeling from the protests that followed a grand jury’s decision not to indict the police officer who fatally shot Michael Brown.
lead_paragraph: Residents of Ferguson are still reeling from the protests that followed a grand jury’s decision not to indict the police officer who fatally shot Michael Brown.

headline: China Drafts Its First Domestic Violence Law, but Rights Advocates Say It Falls Short
abstract: Lawyers and women’s advocates welcomed the proposed national law, but said there were loopholes that would allow police officers to shirk taking action on those calls at their discretion.
lead_paragraph: For nearly two decades, Chinese feminists, lawyers and rights advocates have called for laws to tackle violence in the family. This week the government published a draft of what would be China’s first national law addressing the issue, and while activists welcome it as a step forward, they also say it falls short of what is needed.

headline: Q. and A.: Ann E. Carlson and Alex Wang on the U.S.-China Climate Accord
abstract: Alex Wang and Ann E. Carlson, law professors at the University of California, Los Angeles, who study environmental policy and regulations in the United States and China, responded to questions about the United States-China agreement on cutting greenhouse gases.
lead_paragraph: The biggest commitments to come out of President Obama’s recent visit to China involved climate change policy. The leaders of the two nations stood beside each other in Beijing and pledged to curb greenhouse gas emissions, sending the world a powerful message that climate change is important to both men, and that the two countries intend to work together on the issue.

headline: When Glamour Speaks Your Name
abstract: A new book looks at the history of how black women used style and substance to counter stereotypes — or invisibility — in the mainstream.
lead_paragraph: The 1960 publicity photo depicts a famous singer, a woman both statuesque and beautiful, smiling radiantly. A man kneels before her, adjusting her glistening gown. In the context of the image, the interaction between the two is metaphoric: a mortal kneeling before a goddess.

headline: European Union Gives Belgium, France and Italy Time to Comply on Budget Rules
abstract: The decision is a sign that the European Commission, the bloc’s executive arm, under Jean-Claude Juncker will be sensitive to calls to ease up on austerity.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The European Union authorities on Friday gave Belgium, France and Italy three more months to bring their budgets in line with legal requirements.

headline: Eurozone Inflation Rate Dips, Stirring Deflation Fears
abstract: Prices in Europe continue to rise at rates so low they pose an economic threat, while high unemployment continues to be a problem.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The eurozone inflation rate is slipping toward zero, even as the job market remains moribund, official data showed on Friday, highlighting the weak demand at the heart of the bloc’s economy and posing a test of the European Central Bank’s pledge to head off deflation.

headline: New York Today: Property Rights and Wrongs
abstract: Friday and the weekend: a mystery in a tree, clear but cold weather, and two boys are rescued from a snowbank.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this chilly Black Friday.

headline: Australia Promises Scrutiny After Death of Cricket Star Phillip Hughes
abstract: Officials, however, displayed little readiness to disrupt what one administrator called the game’s “finely tuned balance between bat and ball.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — With the world of cricket in shock after the death of an Australian player struck by a ball, organizers of the sport on Friday promised an investigation into safety measures, including the design of protective helmets. But they displayed little readiness to disrupt what one administrator called the game’s “finely tuned balance between bat and ball.”

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Week 13 N.F.L. Matchups
abstract: This week’s games include a matchup at Lambeau Field between New England, the league’s hottest team, and Green Bay, the game’s best home team.
lead_paragraph: Patriots (9-2) at Packers (8-3)

headline: A Facebook Change Makes It Harder for Political Campaigns to See Your Friends
abstract: The move to limit access is good for users’ privacy, but also probably for Facebook’s bottom line.
lead_paragraph: When you log in to a politician’s Facebook app, the campaign enjoys relatively easy access to your friends on the social network. But starting next year, that automatic access will go away.

headline: Shopping on a Phone Is Still Uncommon but Growing Fast
abstract: Sales on computers are growing much faster than sales in offline stores, and sales on mobile phones are growing faster still.
lead_paragraph: Throngs of people still camp out awaiting Black Friday doorbuster sales, but it is more for the sake of tradition and sport than for good deals. Those can just as easily be found online.

headline: 1964: Selassie Calls for Congo Parley
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: 1964: Haile Selassie Calls for African Summit Conference on the Congo.
lead_paragraph: ADDIS ABABA — Ethiopian Emperor Haile Selassie has called for an extraordinary African summit conference on the Congo situation, it was announced today. His request has been sent to all African heads of state, the announcement said.

headline: British Premier Plans Tougher Stance as Anti-Immigration Sentiment Grows
abstract: Prime Minister David Cameron said he would make Britain a less-attractive place for migrants to seek employment and would try to impose a four-year waiting period for social and welfare benefits.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — With his eye on a general election just five months away, Prime Minister David Cameron on Friday sketched out proposals to make Britain less attractive to immigrants that, he acknowledged, would require tough negotiations with European Union partners and changes to union treaties.

headline: India’s Economic Growth Slows to 5.3%
abstract: Manufacturing and agricultural output dragged on growth in the last quarter, raising pressure on Prime Minister Narendra Modi to expand his economic revival efforts.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — India’s economic growth slowed to 5.3 percent in the three months ended in September from a year earlier, government data showed Friday, supporting expectations of a delayed recovery in Asia’s third-largest economy, after China and Japan.

headline: Fall Rain: Central Park
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A poet’s description of a hard rain stripping the leaves from the trees.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Japanese Newspaper Prints Apology for Using the Term ‘Sex Slaves’
abstract: The conservative newspaper Yomiuri Shimbun said it was “inappropriate” to refer to the women who worked in World War II military brothels as slaves.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The Yomiuri Shimbun, the conservative newspaper that is the largest-circulation daily in Japan, has apologized for using the term “sex slaves” to refer to the women many historians say were coerced into working in a sprawling network of brothels supervised by the Japanese military during World War II.

headline: Can the New Creative Director Johnny Coca Reverse Mulberry’s Fortunes?
abstract: Céline’s former design director for accessories will join the troubled house in July.
lead_paragraph: After almost 18 months without a creative director — 18 months in which it issued numerous profit warnings — Mulberry finally named a new designer on Thursday: Johnny Coca, Céline’s former design director for accessories. Will he be able to turn around the brand’s fortunes?

headline: Abstract Notions of Assorted People
abstract: Richard Linklater, the director of “Boyhood,” has often been philosophically inquisitive, and never more so than with “Waking Life.”
lead_paragraph: Richard Linklater, the director of “Boyhood,” one of the year’s most acclaimed indies, has often been philosophically inquisitive, and never more so than with “Waking Life” (2001), screening Sunday at the Museum of the Moving Image as part of its See It Big! Animation series. As in “Slacker” (1991), Mr. Linklater’s debut feature, the camera wanders around Austin, Tex., but here, it largely follows a young man (Wiley Wiggins) as he meets assorted people and discusses consciousness, the nature of reality and other abstract notions.

headline: The Daily Gift: Pencils With a Personal Touch
abstract: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.
lead_paragraph: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.

headline: As Ebola Rages in Sierra Leone, a Lonely Death
abstract: While health officials are making headway against the Ebola epidemic in neighboring Liberia, the disease is still rampant here, despite a big international push.
lead_paragraph: While health officials are making headway against the Ebola epidemic in neighboring Liberia, the disease is still rampant here, despite a big international push.

headline: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
abstract: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

headline: Up Early in Pursuit of Deals, Black Friday Shoppers Find Small Crowds
abstract: Eager to make up for what has been a year of lackluster sales, retailers are offering eye-popping discounts that could increase traffic but also eat away at thinning profit margins.
lead_paragraph: Tinged with protests and wintry weather, Black Friday still lured crowds into stores across the country, even as some shoppers expressed exhaustion over what has become a long, drawn-out start to the holiday sales.

headline: Cashless Society? It’s Already Coming
abstract: Apple Pay is not going to replace the credit card, but it might well replace the wallet.
lead_paragraph: I’ve spent the past few weeks using Apple Pay, the mobile payments app on the iPhone 6 and 6 Plus, as much as possible. I sought out every opportunity to press my thumb to the smartphone’s screen to make a payment at a store.

headline: French Legislators Debate Stand on Palestinian Statehood
abstract: A nonbinding motion on the matter is expected to pass comfortably when it is put to a vote in the lower house of Parliament on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — French lawmakers debated on Friday a nonbinding motion to recognize a Palestinian state, following similar moves in other European nations amid increasing criticism of Israeli policies in Gaza, the West Bank and East Jerusalem.

headline: British Premier on Curbing Immigration
abstract: As a general election neared in Britain, Prime Minister David Cameron said the country must be able to control immigration while it upholds the idea of freedom of movement within the European Union.
lead_paragraph: As a general election neared in Britain, Prime Minister David Cameron said the country must be able to control immigration while it upholds the idea of freedom of movement within the European Union.

headline: What Jim Webb Will Bring to the Presidential Race in 2016
abstract: The former senator from Virginia may be the perfect anti-Hillary — or he may be out of step with his own party.
lead_paragraph: By all accounts, he is an extreme long shot, but Jim Webb has set up an “exploratory committee” to see about running for president in 2016.

headline: Pope Francis Starts 3-Day Turkey Visit
abstract: Pope Francis thanked Turkey for being a “witness” and helping refugees as he visited the country to strengthen ties with Muslim leaders.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis thanked Turkey for being a “witness” and helping refugees as he visited the country to strengthen ties with Muslim leaders.

headline: An Asylum’s Final Secrets
abstract: In New York, more than 55,000 deceased psychiatric patients lie in unmarked graves. Near the former Willard Asylum, a small committee has spent the past three years fighting to memorialize the dead.
lead_paragraph: In New York, more than 55,000 deceased psychiatric patients lie in unmarked graves. Near the former Willard Asylum, a small committee has spent the past three years fighting to memorialize the dead.

headline: Getting a Foothold
abstract: How to get a foothold in one of New York’s grand old buildings, including the Dakota, the San Remo, the River House, the Ansonia, One Sutton Place South and One Fifth Avenue.
lead_paragraph: Uptown and downtown, East Side and West, an elite cadre of prewar centenarians — give or take a decade — preside over Manhattan as if conscious of their pride of place, handsome and historic exteriors, and enduring stature.

headline: Give Unto Others
abstract: From a Marie Antoinette drinking bowl, modeled after her breast, to a shepherd’s blanket hand-loomed in Portugal, the most special gifts each have their own story to tell.
lead_paragraph: From a Marie Antoinette drinking bowl, modeled after her breast, to a shepherd’s blanket hand-loomed in Portugal, the most special gifts each have their own story to tell.

headline: She Knows When She’s Right
abstract: Suzan-Lori Parks talks about 3 a.m. inspiration and rewriting “Father Comes Home From the Wars.”
lead_paragraph: Suzan-Lori Parks shot up in bed at 3 a.m., her playwriting imagination on fire.

headline: For Afghans, the Fighting Now Knows No Season
abstract: Taliban insurgents continued a sudden pattern of intense assaults, another sign that the traditional fighting season has been prolonged.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Taliban insurgents pressed government forces on several fronts on Friday, killing at least eight Afghan soldiers in three separate episodes.

headline: Diminishing Returns Aren’t Waste (Wonkish)
abstract: Never mind that $6.8 trillion.
lead_paragraph: There’s a new paper out of China, claiming that more than a third of investment spending since 2008 was wasted. It’s a claim that resonates, given what we know about corruption, ghost cities, and all that. But as SR of The Economist points out, the paper itself doesn’t actually do what it claims. It doesn’t at all show that there has been a lot of waste — in fact, the data it cites are perfectly consistent with no waste at all.

headline: 1939: Textile Rationing Cards Issued
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: 1939: Nazis issue Textile Rationing Cards.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — German official insistence on its large supply of raw materials has been considerably weakened with the issuance of textile ration cards. Even ardent Nazis from a political point of view shook their heads when they were shown copies of the cards and said, ‘‘this is hard to take.’’

headline: Wedding Q.&A.
abstract: His friend Is not her friend, and a tomboy says no to the dress.
lead_paragraph: His Friend Is Not Her Friend

headline: Braise Your Way Through Winter
abstract: Tougher cuts, like beef short ribs, become savory and tender when cooked low and slow.
lead_paragraph: Carnivores, the season for meaty braises has arrived. Deep-flavored stews, amped up with assorted aromatics, are just right for cooking throughout the cold-weather months.

headline: In Turkey, Pope Francis Advocates Dialogue in Battling ‘Fanaticism’
abstract: Arguing that force alone would not defeat extremists, the pope emphasized the need for people of different faiths to focus on their commonalities.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — In his first visit as pope to a predominantly Muslim country, Pope Francis said in Turkey on Friday that interreligious dialogue, more than just military action, was required to combat the “fanaticism and fundamentalism” that threaten Christians and other religious minorities along the country’s southern border.

headline: New York Immigration Groups Prepare to Meet Demands of New Policy
abstract: President Obama’s executive actions on immigration are being seen by some officials and advocates as the biggest test yet for a network that could serve as a model for other states.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s sweeping executive actions on immigration present daunting logistical challenges across the nation, but especially in New York, which Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has called “the gateway for immigrants worldwide.”

headline: Amid Tumult, Michigan Football Aims to Reclaim Its Footing
abstract: Michigan must beat its biggest rival, Ohio State, on Saturday to become eligible to play in a bowl game, but the troubled program faces bigger challenges as the university’s sports culture is questioned.
lead_paragraph: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — Michigan football has had unsuccessful seasons in its storied history, but maybe none have been as disastrous as this one.

headline: After London, Protesters Interrupt Showing of ‘Exhibit B’ Near Paris
abstract: Critics say the installation by the South African artist Brett Bailey, which shows actors mimicking the human zoos that circulated in 19th- and 20th-century colonial Europe, perpetuates stereotypes about race.
lead_paragraph: PARIS – Protesters interrupted a showing of “Exhibit B,” a controversial art installation by Brett Bailey, near Paris on Thursday evening, demonstrating against what they said was a racist performance.

headline: Retirees Turn to Virtual Villages for Mutual Support
abstract: An offshoot of the sharing economy, virtual villages are popping up all over the country to offer older adults access to resources and social connections that help them age in place.
lead_paragraph: RICK CLOUD, 68, knew that he wanted to stay in his home in Austin, Tex., as he aged. But Mr. Cloud, who is divorced, was not sure how he could do that without relying on his two daughters.

headline: A New Condo Pushes SoHo’s Boundaries
abstract: A spate of development is transforming Avenue of the Americas on SoHo’s western edge into a residential neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: An unusual elliptical tower rising along the Avenue of the Americas on SoHo’s western edge has drawn many eyes as the most visible indication of a spate of development transforming the area’s primarily commercial streets into a residential neighborhood.

headline: A Jordanian Spins Comic Book Tales to Counter Terrorist Ideologies
abstract: Suleiman Bakhit creates Middle Eastern stories as an antidote to the mythologies that draw youth to terrorist groups like the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: OSLO — SULEIMAN BAKHIT has made a career of studying heroes.

headline: In Front Of Your Macroeconomic Nose
abstract: But invisible to those who will not see.
lead_paragraph: Simon Wren-Lewis says most of what needs to be said about Tyler Cowen’s attempted riposte to my post about Keynes rising. I’d add that Cowen seems to have missed my point; I wasn’t talking about the merits of the Keynesian case, which I believe have always been overwhelming, but about the way macroeconomics is discussed in the media and among VSPs in general. My sense is that this is shifting in a Keynesian direction, while Cowen is arguing (wrongly, I’d say) that it shouldn’t shift because of Osborne or something. Wrong answer to the wrong question.

headline: Two Dylan Songs You Probably Never Heard Of, but You Can Buy Them
abstract: The manuscripts of two early and virtually unknown Bob Dylan songs will be auctioned by Christie’s on Dec. 4.
lead_paragraph: The manuscripts of two early and virtually unknown songs by Bob Dylan – “Talking Folklore Center” and “Go Away You Bomb” – will be auctioned by Christie’s on Dec. 4 in New York, and in some ways the manuscripts’ provenance is as interesting as the pieces themselves. (Mr. Dylan may be in town to bid on them himself if he wants; the sale takes place the day after he finishes a five-concert run at the Beacon Theater that starts Friday night.)

headline: Rare in New York City, the Wild Cranberry Is Tart and Sweet
abstract: Cranberries, a fruit that helped the European settlers cure scurvy, are sometimes found growing wild in New York City.
lead_paragraph: The story of 17th-century Native Americans’ introducing European settlers to a small, water-loving, trailing vine has lasting appeal — we celebrate the gesture each Thanksgiving, now nearly 400 years later. The settlers named the innocuous plant “craneberry,” as its flowers’ reflexed petals and long, graceful stems reminded them of the head and neck of a crane. The tiny pink flowers must have seemed incomprehensibly delicate in the bleak wilderness of the “new world.”

headline: The Cinque Terre on a Budget
abstract: In this coastal corner of Italy, you can lounge on the beach, take in dazzling views and even indulge in a seafood splurge — all on a frugal budget.
lead_paragraph: The stunning profile stretched into the distance before me: miles of craggy coastline punctuated by five pastel villages, each nestled amid cliffs and sparkling sea. But on a pleasant afternoon in mid-October, only one other person was admiring this spectacular view of Cinque Terre, on the northwestern coast of Italy.

headline: Creature Comforts: The Vermont Country Store Catalog
abstract: As the days grow colder and darker, one writer finds contentment in the company’s frugal, anachronistic and entirely unflattering wares.
lead_paragraph: As the days grow colder and darker, one writer finds contentment in the company’s frugal, anachronistic and entirely unflattering wares.

headline: Construction Worker Dies After Ceiling Collapse at Staten Island Car Dealership
abstract: Delfino Jesus Velazquez Mendizabal, 43, became trapped under debris on Friday morning inside Dana Ford Lincoln on Staten Island. The construction company was involved in a previous fatal accident.
lead_paragraph: A construction worker died after part of a concrete ceiling in a Staten Island car dealership collapsed on Friday morning, the authorities said.

headline: Cricket Player’s Death Highlights Sport’s Dangers
abstract: The death of Phillip Hughes after being struck in the head by a ball has lead some to question whether changes are needed to make the game safer.
lead_paragraph: Phillip Hughes’s death has reverberated more widely than any previous cricket fatality. Earlier deaths, even that in 1998 of Raman Lamba, who had played for India before such status conferred instant celebrity, were essentially local tragedies.

headline: 6 Are Killed in Egypt After a Call for Protests Rattles the Authorities
abstract: The reaction to scattered violence showed officials’ anxiety over insurgent threats.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Six people were killed in political violence on Friday as a small and little-known Islamist group’s call for protests failed to turn out big numbers but still spooked the military-backed government into locking down the capital.

headline: Indian Army Indicts 9 Soldiers in Killing of 2 Civilians in Kashmir
abstract: The military had already acknowledged the shooting at a checkpoint as a mistake, but the move toward a court-martial was unusually swift.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The Indian Army has indicted nine of its soldiers in the killing of two civilians early this month in the Indian-administered portion of Kashmir, moving with unusual swiftness toward a court-martial in a case that provoked antigovernment demonstrations.

headline: And a Little Child Shall Lead Them
abstract: Ridley Scott’s “Exodus: Gods and Kings” features the 11-year-old Isaac Andrews as the voice and visage of the Almighty.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Ridley Scott’s 3-D “Exodus: Gods and Kings” has computer-generated plagues, waves and tornadoes. It has boat-chomping crocodiles, 400,000 digitally rendered Hebrew slaves and a sword-wielding Christian Bale as a “Gladiator”-like Moses.

headline: Those Artsy Early Birds Flew Away
abstract: Art Basel Miami Beach was supposed to make South Florida an art mecca. So what happened?
lead_paragraph: MIAMI BEACH — “It was a really devastating message,” the Miami art dealer Fredric Snitzer said, recalling the personal impact when Emmanuel Perrotin’s 13,000-square-foot outpost closed in 2010. “If he couldn’t make a go of it, what I am doing here?”

headline: French Lawmakers Debate Palestine
abstract: Members of the French National Assembly debated a bill on whether France should recognize Palestine as a state.
lead_paragraph: Members of the French National Assembly debated a bill on whether France should recognize Palestine as a state.

headline: With Art, Investing in Genius
abstract: In a record-breaking auction season in New York, fine art perceived to be innovative and influential attracted smart money from investors.
lead_paragraph: If there were any remaining doubts that “making money is art,” as Andy Warhol famously pronounced in his 1975 book, “The Philosophy of Andy Warhol,” they were surely vanquished on Nov. 12. His silk-screen print “Triple Elvis (Ferus Type),” an image taken from a Hollywood studio publicity shot showing Elvis Presley with a gun, sold for nearly $82 million at a Christie’s auction packed with bankers, hedge fund managers and art dealers.

headline: The Force Was With Them
abstract: The first “Star Wars” film in 1977 gave a much needed financial boost to Marvel Comics, which published a six-issue tie-in.
lead_paragraph: Cue the “Star Wars” theme music, please:

headline: ‘The Goldbergs’ Focuses a Nostalgic Lens on Family Dysfunction
abstract: In its second season on ABC, “The Goldbergs” has built a solid following and improved ratings by adhering to a formula now scarce on TV.
lead_paragraph: CULVER CITY, Calif. — Sitting in his office, Adam F. Goldberg, creator of the ABC sitcom “The Goldbergs,” had the impish grin of a kid in a toy store. Mostly because Mr. Goldberg’s office, on the Sony Pictures lot here, is filled, corner to corner, with toys.

headline: From the Ashes, a Proto-Punk Revival
abstract: John D Morton of the 1970s Cleveland bands the Electric Eels and X__X (pronounced Ex Blank Ex) is seeing a rediscovery of his recorded legacy.
lead_paragraph: One day in 1980, I reached a milestone in a Jewish boy’s journey into manhood: spending my bar mitzvah money on punk rock records. I was searching the racks at a record store for “Adult Books,” the debut single by the Los Angeles band X, and the only 45 that remotely fit the bill featured a couple of white X’s on the front cover, separated by a dash, above a photo of the bare backside of a woman bound at the ankles. The back-cover band photo corresponded somewhat to the group I’d read about in a zine — four members, one of them female — though the label credited the single to Drome Records instead of Dangerhouse. So a band name starting with “X,” a multigendered quartet, a record label beginning with “D,” a whiff of the forbidden: “Close enough,” I thought, and made my purchase.

headline: Modern Mythology, Yours for a Dime
abstract: A hefty and heavily illustrated new book, “75 Years of Marvel” (Taschen), emphasizes the comic book’s role in a cultural stew that includes film, TV, pop music and radio.
lead_paragraph: With today’s multiplexes muscle-bound from too many superheroes, and TV frantic with the antic shuffle of tiny zombie feet, S.H.I.E.L.D. spymasters and more, it’s easy to forget there was a time when mainstream comic books were in genuine conversation with the broader culture, instead of being meekly strip-mined for profit by other media.

headline: The Music Runs Through Her
abstract: Linda Celeste Sims, who joined the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater in 1996, is one of the troupe’s most soulful dancers, with a subtle power that is only deepening.
lead_paragraph: People used to tell Linda Celeste Sims that she looked like an Ailey dancer. She didn’t have a clue what that meant. “I knew it was a modern thing,” she said, “but I didn’t know the grandness.”

headline: A Singular World That Won’t Fade Away
abstract: The composer, vocalist, dancer, choreographer, director and filmmaker Meredith Monk celebrates the 50th anniversary of the start of her professional career.
lead_paragraph: The traffic was light, the sky dark, the sidewalks mostly empty on a bitterly cold recent Sunday evening in TriBeCa. Looking down shadowy side streets, it was possible, for a moment or two at a time, to imagine being back in the forbidding, exhilarating downtown New York of the 1970s.

headline: A New Tome Captures the Southern California Skate-Punk Scene of the ’80s
abstract: The photographs of Spot, a record producer and key figure of the era, are collected in a new volume, “The Sound of Two Eyes Opening.”
lead_paragraph: In punk and hardcore circles, the name Spot is legend. Born in Southern California, Spot produced albums for some of the most seminal bands of those scenes in the ’70s and ’80s — Black Flag, the Misfits, the Minutemen, the Meat Puppets and Hüsker Du among them. When he wasn’t behind the mixing board at SST Records, the label founded by Black Flag’s Greg Ginn, he was likely to be roller-skating the boardwalks — or behind the lens of his Nikon, photographing the skate ramps, the beaches, the house parties. Bruised and bloodied and tanned from the day’s skating, everyone would head to see whichever band was playing that night, and then Spot would stay up late in the darkroom afterwards. Those sleepless, exciting times are documented in Spot’s first book of photographs, “The Sound of Two Eyes Opening,” out Friday from Sinecure.

headline: 1957 | ‘Fidel Castro Is Still Alive’
abstract: David W. Dunlap, a Metro reporter and the writer of the Building Blocks column, explored the sometimes close connection between Mr. Castro and The Times.
lead_paragraph: David W. Dunlap is a Metro reporter and writes the Building Blocks column. He has worked at The Times for 39 years.

headline: Reindeer at the St. Regis
abstract: In New York City, reindeer will make an appearance on Dec. 13 at the St. Regis hotel.
lead_paragraph: Reindeer are a quintessential symbol of Christmas, and on Dec. 13, the St. Regis New York will celebrate the holiday by having two of them outside its doors in Midtown Manhattan from 11 a.m. to 3 p.m.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘Putin’s Kleptocracy’
abstract: This week, Karen Dawisha discusses “Putin’s Kleptocracy”; Alexandra Alter has news from the literary world; Stephen Kotkin talks about his new biography of Stalin; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Karen Dawisha discusses “Putin’s Kleptocracy”; Alexandra Alter has news from the literary world; Stephen Kotkin talks about his new biography of Stalin; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Matching the Way You Give to the Cause You Give To
abstract: Writing a check to a favorite cause works fine, but there are other methods of giving that may be more convenient and effective.
lead_paragraph: SCOTT STEVENS gives differently to charities depending on the cause. Money to National Public Radio is charged monthly to his credit card. He donates annually by check to the American Cancer Society in memory of his mother.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘Putin’s Kleptocracy’
abstract: This week, Karen Dawisha and Stephen Kotkin.
lead_paragraph: This week, Karen Dawisha and Stephen Kotkin.

headline: New York Taxi’s Retirement: A Quiet Life on Country Roads in Vermont
abstract: Mike Ruse, a lifelong Vermont resident, bought a cab for $1,000 from a Queens repair shop three years ago, and since then has put an additional 80,000 miles on it, much of them logged on vacation road trips.
lead_paragraph: SPRINGFIELD, Vt. — The yellow sedan parked in front of a convenience store here in the Green Mountains caught the eye of Lucille Stanley — the N.Y.C. TAXI markings on the vehicle’s flank could not be missed.

headline: An Insult Is Now a Name Tag
abstract: Starkville, the sleepy home of Mississippi State, has embraced its small-town status, and the tongue-in-cheek nickname Stark Vegas, as the Bulldogs’ football team has grown in prominence with several marquee wins.
lead_paragraph: STARKVILLE, Miss. — Just a few months ago, Starkville was known — when it was known at all — as a sleepy Southern town, even by the standards of sleepy Southern towns.

headline: A Cornucopia of Views
abstract: A full-floor apartment near the top of One57, with four bedrooms and spectacular park, river and cityscape views, is the sale of the week.
lead_paragraph: The allure of an entire floor with bird’s-eye views near the top of One57, the Extell Development Company’s glass-sheathed Midtown statement-maker at 157 West 57th Street, continued to persuade buyers to invest upward of $50 million in personal aeries there, as No. 80 traded for $52,952,500 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Italian and Palestinian Protesters Wounded by Israeli Forces
abstract: The two protesters were shot during a weekly protest in the West Bank village of Kufr Qadoum, according to local activists and Palestinian medical officials.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israeli forces shot and wounded an Italian activist and a Palestinian demonstrator with live ammunition on Friday during a weekly protest in the West Bank village of Kufr Qadoum, according to local activists and Palestinian medical officials.

headline: Oil Prices Are Plunging. Here’s Who Wins and Who Loses.
abstract: OPEC’s decision not to cut back production helps drivers and airline passengers, and will have ripple effects throughout the world economy.
lead_paragraph: While Americans were stuffing their faces with poultry Thursday, global oil markets were in chaos. And the implications are far-reaching.

headline: Black Friday in the U.S. and Europe
abstract: Shoppers from London, Glasgow, New York City and Washington, D.C., took part in Black Friday. The practice of offering low prices the day after Thanksgiving is spreading across the Atlantic.
lead_paragraph: Shoppers from London, Glasgow, New York City and Washington, D.C., took part in Black Friday. The practice of offering low prices the day after Thanksgiving is spreading across the Atlantic.

headline: Home Sales Around the New York Region
abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Book Review Podcast: ‘Putin’s Kleptocracy’
abstract: Karen Dawisha discusses “Putin’s Kleptocracy,” and Stephen Kotkin talks about his new biography of Stalin.
lead_paragraph: In a special issue of The New York Times Book Review devoted to the theme of Russia, Rajan Menon reviews Karen Dawisha’s “Putin’s Kleptocracy: Who Owns Russia?” Mr. Menon writes:

headline: A Respectful Deference to Elders Curdles Into a Fight Over Assets
abstract: The documentary “Black Heirlooms” dives into the intergenerational conversations about care and assets that one family did not have until too late.
lead_paragraph: The trailer opens with a picture of an olive green house, then a sunny yellow kitchen. A narrator extols the virtues of the world-famous chicken and dumplings that the family matriarch once made there.

headline: Fatal Attack Causes Chaos at Mosque in Nigeria
abstract: A state deputy police commissioner said 35 people were killed when militants set off explosions at the central mosque in the northern city of Kano.
lead_paragraph: KANO, Nigeria — Militants struck the central mosque in one of Nigeria’s biggest cities on Friday, intensifying the violence that has swept across the nation’s north in recent months.

headline: Ousted Greek Prime Minister Pushes for a New Party Leader, Perhaps Himself
abstract: George A. Papandreou, the former prime minister, called for an emergency congress of the Socialist party Pasok in a bid to wrest control from his successor.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Former Prime Minister George A. Papandreou, who was forced to step aside in 2011, has burst back onto the political scene here with a bid to wrest control of his Socialist party from his successor.

headline: Moving Pictures and Opportunity for Change
abstract: An innovative collaboration that began with documenting the lives of teenagers who were sex-trafficking victims hopes to engage viewers and spur them to act.
lead_paragraph: An innovative collaboration that began with documenting the lives of teenagers who were sex-trafficking victims hopes to engage viewers and spur them to act.

headline: Black Friday Embrace by British Retailers Brings Discounts and Disorder
abstract: The kickoff to Christmas shopping, imported from the United States, has stoked merchants’ sales but also drawn criticism from police officials.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Black Friday, virtually unknown here just a few years ago, has tightened its grip on British retailing, bringing with it scenes of disorder and chaos, at least two arrests and police criticism of the big stores that encourage shopper frenzy.

headline: Venezuelan Cuisine, With a Side of Cabaret
abstract: At Jojoto, in Branford, the TV personality Neil Fuentes serves as chef and showman, excelling at one more than the other.
lead_paragraph: Achieving culinary prowess, it could be argued, is a labor of love — one that requires talent but also devoted practice. The same could be said of show business; as well as talent, a single-minded dedication is usually needed to become a successful singer, dancer or actor. So, can a person do both? Is it possible to attain mastery as both a chef and as an entertainer?

headline: Inside the List
abstract: In “There Was a Little Girl,” No. 11 on the hardcover nonfiction list, Brooke Shields writes frankly and tenderly about her mother.
lead_paragraph: Mother and Daughter: The cover of Brooke Shields’s latest memoir, “There Was a Little Girl” (new on the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 11), shows the author sometime in the mid-1970s, relaxing happily on the lap of her mother and manager, Teri Shields, their hands touching and their heads tilted girlishly together. It’s a sweet and wholesome image, and a far cry from a photo that ran around the same time on the cover of New York magazine, depicting Brooke in full makeup with a haughty stare while her mother grasped her shoulders. “Meet Teri and Brooke Shields,” the cover read. “Brooke is 12. She poses nude. Teri is her mother. She thinks it’s swell.” Shields doesn’t mention that article in her book, which is subtitled “The Real Story of My Mother and Me,” but she does talk about the media uproar surrounding Louis Malle’s 1978 film “Pretty Baby,” in which she played an underage prostitute, and all of the racy jobs that followed. “There was a sense of fury and a need to assume that I was a victim,” she writes. “There was a firestorm, and Mom took most of the heat.” Although Shields writes frankly and painfully about her mother’s chronic drinking and poor career decisions, the book — which was prompted, she says, by her reaction to The New York Times’s obituary after Teri Shields died in 2012 — is mostly tender. “It is not a ‘Mommie Dearest’ tale. But I’m not holding her up on a pedestal, either,” she writes. “It is simply my turn to tell the story as I saw and felt it.”

headline: Japan Addresses Takata Airbag Flaw
abstract: The Transport Ministry plans to force expanded recalls of Takata devices, reflecting growing unease about the problem and its implications for Japanese carmakers.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — In April last year, Japan’s transportation minister was asked at a news conference about potentially dangerous airbags made by Takata, the Japanese auto parts supplier. About 700,000 cars had just been recalled in the country because of defective Takata airbags, part of a larger global recall that has since ballooned to include more than 14 million vehicles.

headline: Hong Kong Clashes Flare as Protesters Return to Camp
abstract: The police used pepper spray against pro-democracy demonstrators challenging a cordon at their dismantled protest site in the Mong Kok area of Hong Kong.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Clashes between the police and protesters flared in a crowded shopping district of Hong Kong on Friday night, days after the police dismantled a pro-democracy camp there.

headline: Laurie Sperring on Staying Clean
abstract: From prison, Laurie Sperring talks about the challenges of staying away from heroin that an addict faces.
lead_paragraph: From prison, Laurie Sperring talks about the challenges of staying away from heroin that an addict faces.

headline: Driving the Seam of Hispaniola
abstract: A road trip down the border between the Dominican Republic and Haiti reveals international strains and cultural highlights.
lead_paragraph: I’ve never liked the idea of bucket-list travel. Why make another to-do list when faced with your own mortality?

headline: Does Your Job Make You Happy?
abstract: In a corporate climate some see as profit-obsessed, some companies are actually focusing on worker wellbeing. But will the approach ever be mainstream?
lead_paragraph: On-site exercise equipment. Paid volunteer time. A wall of baking tools you can borrow. These may sound like the perks some flush tech companies extend to their engineers.

headline: A Home for the Headlines
abstract: A building reminiscent of an Italian campanile, the former headquarters of the Times, once presided over Times Square.
lead_paragraph: A structure that just missed the New York City landmarks preservation law of 1965 was the 1905 Times Tower at 42nd Street at Broadway. Reminiscent of the Florentine campanile by Giotto, it was an expansive gesture by The New York Times, then moving uptown from Park Row. The newspaper left the building around 10 years later, but the tower survived for 60 years before being stripped to its skin. By the time the landmarks law was passed, even the skeleton had disappeared from view.

headline: Please Forgive My Spotless Home
abstract: His sons want him to play, but housekeeping duties always seem to get in his way.
lead_paragraph: I was vacuuming the basement stairs when the ceiling started to shake. It was my two sons in the living room above, jumping between sofa and coffee table, their noises a dangerous mix of laughing and grunting that portended someone (the younger, usually) getting hurt.

headline: Even Among Harvard Graduates, Women Fall Short of Their Work Expectations
abstract: Both sexes have ambitious goals for their career and family life, a study finds, but entrenched factors seem to hold many women back.
lead_paragraph: Women are not equally represented at the top of corporate America because of the basic facts of motherhood: Even the most ambitious women scale back at work to spend more time on child care. At least, that is the conventional wisdom.

headline: U.N. Panel Cites Concerns With U.S. Security Practices
abstract: In a report delivered in Geneva, the United Nations Convention Against Torture found issue with domestic law enforcement practices and security policies.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The United States needs to make numerous changes to bring its security policies and domestic law enforcement practices fully into line with an international treaty banning torture and cruel treatment, a United Nations panel said Friday.

headline: Kindly Pipe Down
abstract: Questions about a friend’s pregnancy, taking sides in a breakup, requests for references and the role of step-grandparents.
lead_paragraph: I was friendly with this girl in high school. We are in our 20s now and will be seeing each other soon. I heard from friends that she got pregnant by accident last year, carried the baby and gave it up for adoption, rather than terminate the pregnancy. I was impressed. I don’t know anyone else who would do that. I want to tell her that I admire her, but I’m not sure how to bring it up. Any ideas? JANE

headline: Why C.E.O.s Are Growing Beards
abstract: A dialectical theory of facial hair and capitalism.
lead_paragraph: THESE are dark days for the shaving industry. After experiencing a century of fairly steady growth, makers of razors and other shaving equipment have seen revenues level off or fall in the last few years. Beards are back.

headline: Silent Worship
abstract: The deaf Catholic community of New York wonders about its future, since the Archdiocese announced it is merging a deaf parish with a larger, hearing congregation.
lead_paragraph: The deaf Catholic community of New York wonders about its future, since the Archdiocese announced it is merging a deaf parish with a larger, hearing congregation.

headline: Ray Rice Wins Reinstatement to N.F.L. in Arbitration
abstract: A former federal judge sided with Ray Rice, the former Baltimore Ravens running back who was penalized twice for knocking out his then-fiancée.
lead_paragraph: An arbitrator on Friday overturned the National Football League’s indefinite suspension of Ray Rice, the former Baltimore Ravens running back who knocked out his fiancée in an elevator altercation. The decision called the penalty “arbitrary” and in conflict with the facts of the case.

headline: On the Upper East Side, Silent Prayers to Save a Sanctuary for the Deaf
abstract: The Church of St. Elizabeth of Hungary, New York’s Roman Catholic parish for the deaf, is one of 31 churches in the archdiocese set to close.
lead_paragraph: The choir members filed up to the altar in robes the color of the red roses of Saint Elizabeth, the patron saint of their beloved church. They arrayed themselves on two risers and looked to the choir director for a cue. Then they raised their hands in unison and began to sign.

headline: On the Market in the New York Region
abstract: This week’s properties include a five-bedroom in Stamford, Conn., and a four-bedroom in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties in the New York region:

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: This week’s properties are a West Village loft, a co-op in Chelsea and a co-op in Park Slope.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties in New York City:

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
abstract: In the news: Type 2 diabetes, calorie counts and heavy drinkers. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: In the news: Type 2 diabetes, calorie counts and heavy drinkers. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Art of New York
abstract: A look at books about the Metropolitan Transportation Authority’s public art program, a vessel and its designer, and other topics.
lead_paragraph: Have friends with empty coffee tables? Here’s a selection of New York holiday gift books.

headline: Coming to a Theater Far, Far Into the Future
abstract: Lucasfilm’s teaser trailer for “Star Wars: The Force Awakens,” released online on Friday, stirs armchair critics to action.
lead_paragraph: This will be a day long remembered by fans of science-fiction fantasies, aficionados of mega-budget movie franchises and viewers who regard the “Star Wars” series with a reverence bordering on the religious.

headline: Trickier Time-Off Policies as Employers Test New Ideas
abstract: More companies are replacing traditional leave plans with alternative approaches. While some employees like the shift, others are bewildered or angry.
lead_paragraph: TRIBUNE PUBLISHING, owner of newspaper institutions like The Los Angeles Times, created a near riot in its newsrooms this month when it abruptly announced a major change to vacation and sick day policies for most employees beginning in the new year: no more separate vacation, sick and personal days. Under its new discretionary time-off policy, it would be up to each employee and supervisor to agree on almost all time off.

headline: Artistic Expression in a Repressive State
abstract: “This Leads to Fire: Russian Art From Nonconformism to Global Capitalism, Selections From the Kolodzei Art Foundation Collection” will run through Jan. 11 at the Neuberger Museum of Art in Purchase, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: “Still Life With Apples” is a small gouache of six rosy apples resting on a blue table, painted with gestural brush strokes by the artist Vladimir Yakovlev in 1973. It is a lovely picture; nothing about it appears contentious. Yet its very creation at that time in the Soviet Union was an act of political defiance.

headline: Yearning for a BB Gun and a Happy Family
abstract: “A Christmas Story: The Musical,” playing at the John W. Engeman Theater at Northport, is centered on a child’s concern that he won’t get the present he wants.
lead_paragraph: Don’t expect the Ghost of Christmas Past, or any other ghost, to pop up in “A Christmas Story: The Musical.” The entertaining show playing at the John W. Engeman Theater at Northport is nothing like “A Christmas Carol,” the dark-tinged tale by Charles Dickens that also became a musical. “A Christmas Story,” based on the popular 1983 film narrated by the humorist and radio personality Jean Shepherd (who also wrote the book that inspired the movie), is a sunnier Christmas yarn, centered on a child’s concern that he won’t get the present he wants.

headline: Leave Them Stirred, Not Shaken
abstract: Art-inspired barware and storage gift ideas for couples who like to the keep the party going.
lead_paragraph: Art-inspired barware and storage gift ideas for couples who like to the keep the party going.

headline: The Making of Harmony
abstract: “The Fabulous Lipitones,” in New Brunswick, works just fine without much glitter or glamour — its greatest pleasures spring from the simplest of intentions.
lead_paragraph: “The Fabulous Lipitones” doesn’t set out to be fabulous, and that makes this friendly show all the better. Indeed, this a cappella musical works just fine without much glitter or glamour — its greatest pleasures spring from the simplest of intentions.

headline: Obama Pushed ‘Fullest Extent’ of His Powers on Immigration Plan
abstract: Months before President Obama took action to reshape the nation’s immigration system, advisers huddled daily under orders to use “our legal authorities to the fullest extent” on the new policy, an official said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Months before President Obama took executive action last week to reshape the nation’s immigration system, Jeh C. Johnson, the secretary of Homeland Security, quietly convened a small group of advisers to explore the legal limits of the president’s powers.

headline: His Nightmares Starred Communists, Not Nazis
abstract: The centenary of the Polish-born composer Andrzej Panufnik will be celebrated at Kings Place in London on Sunday by Panufnik’s family and other artists and performers.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Composers’ lives are usually less interesting than lore has it, amounting to long hours at a desk, putting ideas on paper. But one relatively recent life reads like a John le Carré Cold War thriller. It is the story of Andrzej Panufnik, who was born into the Polish middle class in 1914, died an English knight in 1991 and, in between, led an existence plagued by war, politics and exile that twice stripped him of all he had achieved and forced him to start again.

headline: Use Caution in Updating Adobe Flash Player or Reader
abstract: Plus, how to display new purchases in iTunes.

headline: On Instagram, Celebrities Have Jokes ... Especially About Kim Kardashian
abstract: Joe Jonas, Ellen DeGeneres and others take to the photo-sharing application to mock other celebrities.
lead_paragraph: Imitation really is the sincerest form of flattery, it seems.

headline: Got a Best Seller? Chipotle May Come Calling
abstract: A number of companies are latching on to famous writers like Jonathan Safran Foer, who persuaded Chipotle to start an author series on bags and cups.
lead_paragraph: The author Jonathan Safran Foer was eating in a Chipotle not long ago with nothing to read when he had a truly “out of the box” idea: What if his meal’s packaging could display ennui-alleviating text?

headline: As Time Went By, They Never Lost Touch
abstract: Stephen Bogart and Carla Soviero were married Nov. 15, at the Skylark in New York.
lead_paragraph: Stephen Bogart and Carla Soviero were married Nov. 15, at the Skylark in New York.

headline: Tastes of a Bangkok Childhood
abstract: The more-than-a-decade-old Pimaan Thai Restaurant in Emerson turns out dishes its sister-owners remember eating while growing up, selections that rely on homemade ground pastes and fresh herbs.
lead_paragraph: Most casual suburban Thai restaurants aren’t known for their innovative menus, offering chicken satay, papaya salad and pad thai, with a few red or green curries thrown in.

headline: More Plot Twists Than ‘The Maltese Falcon’
abstract: Humphrey Bogart’s son and his longtime friend finally find the time is right for marriage.
lead_paragraph: Seventy years ago, Lauren Bacall and Humphrey Bogart burned up the silver screen as they fell in love while filming “To Have and Have Not.”

headline: Banksy Work to Be Offered for Sale in Miami
abstract: A work by Banksy that was defaced in Britain will be offered for sale at the Art Miami fair.
lead_paragraph: Art Buff, a work by Banksy that appeared in September in Folkestone, a British town on the English Channel, will be sent to Miami for sale by the owner of Palace Amusements, the building on which it appeared. The painting, which shows an elderly woman wearing headphones looking at an empty plinth, had been defaced and the Folkestone Herald reported that the family that owns the building did not want the responsibility of protecting the painting from further vandalism.

headline: A Deal From the Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams
abstract: The Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams is the premier event at the Fall North American Championships in Providence, R.I.
