lead_paragraph: The Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams is the premier event at the Fall North American Championships in Providence, R.I. It takes place Friday through Dec. 7, with play on the last day to be broadcast at bridgebase.com.

headline: A Pre-Thanksgiving Ritual: Cocktails, Catch-Ups and Maybe a Kiss
abstract: On Thanksgiving Eve, young adults are in bars looking for friends, old and new.
lead_paragraph: There was a short line outside the Stumble Inn on 76th Street and Second Avenue in Manhattan on Wednesday night. Women decked out in what seemed to be matching puffy coats huddled together under the bar’s overhang. Men wore Uniqlo flannel.

headline: A Holiday Respite With a Turkish Accent
abstract: Krinti, Turkish for “breadcrumbs,” is a four-month-old Mediterranean grill with an emphasis on Turkish cuisine located in a shopping center in Woodbury, on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: A must-add to this paper’s recent list of interesting restaurants for holiday shoppers on Long Island is Krinti, a Mediterranean grill with an emphasis on Turkish cuisine located in a shopping center in Woodbury. The four-month-old establishment is easy to find, with its name in blazing white letters affixed to a building outlined in tiny white lights. The food is memorable and the service exceptional.

headline: Ray Rice Suspension Ruling
abstract: Barbara S. Jones, a onetime district court judge, issued her decision Friday in the N.F.L.’s suspension of Ray Rice.
lead_paragraph: Barbara S. Jones, a onetime district court judge, issued her decision Friday in the N.F.L.’s suspension of Ray Rice.

headline: African Books for Western Eyes
abstract: The continent’s writers are being celebrated, but only for catering to Western tastes.
lead_paragraph: ABUJA, Nigeria — MY close friend Mercy, when she heard about my novel, congratulated me: I had found out “what the white people wanted to read and given it to them.”

headline: New York’s Next Big Thing
abstract: To attract conventions, develop a new convention center over the tracks at Sunnyside Yards in Queens.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK is the most diverse, dynamic city on Earth. More than 55 million people are projected to visit this year, bringing with them a total economic impact of more than $60 billion and supporting about 350,000 jobs.

headline: The Downside of Resilience
abstract: Children who suffer the least may also benefit the least from extra care.
lead_paragraph: BEHIND a half-century of policies to promote child development, there lies an assumption: that children are essentially equally affected by the environments they grow up in, and that positive interventions like preschool education should therefore help all children. But what if this isn’t true?

headline: A New Puccini Production Offers Explanations for Its Story’s Gaps
abstract: Puccini’s “Manon Lescaut” is playing at the Bavarian State Opera in Munich, with a different leading singer from the one originally planned.
lead_paragraph: MUNICH — What was it that so offended Anna Netrebko?

headline: Critiquing a Republican’s Alternative to Obamacare
abstract: Two readers disagree with a plan offered by Ed Gillespie, who was an unsuccessful G.O.P. candidate for the Senate.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Early Learning for Children at Risk
abstract: A parenting educator, the National Head Start Association and a clinical psychologist respond to a column by Nicholas Kristof.

headline: Bauble, Burger and Beer
abstract: Those with a taste for high-end pub food will find plenty to like at Winston in Mount Kisco, RiverMarket Bar and Kitchen in Tarrytown and Restaurant North in Armonk.
lead_paragraph: With Thanksgiving behind us, we’re in for it: Hanukkah, Christmas, Kwanzaa and New Year’s, with all their trimmings and trappings and snowballing expenses. What would the Grinch do? If you can’t stop it from coming, you might as well join in the fun and the feasting. One way to dine out during the holidays while guarding your solvency is to perch at the bar in a high-end restaurant that either has a dedicated bar menu or lets bar patrons pick and choose from the main menu. A boon is that bartenders, in our experience, offer unusually attentive, companionable service.

headline: Teams That Could Use Ray Rice
abstract: While no teams have openly showed interest in Rice, there are some teams that may be able to use Rice if he could prove in a tryout that he was in shape.
lead_paragraph: Finding a team willing to take on the public-relations hit of signing Ray Rice will be difficult. But anyone saying it is impossible is ignoring other famous cases of players returning after damaging incidents. Leonard Little, a defensive lineman, played 12 seasons in the N.F.L. after killing a 47-year-old mother in a drunken-driving accident. Donte Stallworth, a wide receiver, played three seasons after pleading guilty to manslaughter for killing a pedestrian in a hit-and-run accident that occurred after he had been drinking. And Michael Vick, the backup quarterback for the Jets, has played six seasons since serving a federal sentence in connection with a dogfighting ring that he participated in.

headline: A Poetry Personal and Political
abstract: Claudia Rankine mixes verse, prose and visual images in “Citizen,” a National Book Award poetry finalist.
lead_paragraph: A finalist for the National Book Award in poetry, Claudia Rankine’s “Citizen: An American Lyric” is audacious in form. But what is perhaps especially striking about the book is that it has achieved something that eludes much modern poetry: urgency.

headline: New York’s Holiday Windows
abstract: Celebrated displays keep the crowds coming back.
lead_paragraph: Celebrated displays keep the crowds coming back.

headline: Holiday Window Displays Lure Them Inside, by Dazzling Outside
abstract: A tour from Barneys New York to Bergdorf Goodman and Tiffany with Scott Pask, a designer for theater.
lead_paragraph: There’s a leering elf in the windows of Barneys New York caressing a supersize psychedelic mushroom and doing the splits.

headline: The Last Rites for Death by Audio
abstract: As eulogies go, the final showcase at Death by Audio, a D.I.Y. Williamsburg club, was a kicker, loud and sweaty and appropriately raucous.
lead_paragraph: As eulogies go, the final showcase at Death by Audio, a D.I.Y. Williamsburg club, was a kicker, loud and sweaty and appropriately raucous. Smelly, too. For seven years, the space hosted thousands of indie bands, becoming a launching pad for punks, noise acts, experimental electronica and underground rap, and a clubhouse for every self-respecting music obsessive in between. The programming for its last week of shows this month was a closely guarded secret, yet fans turned up in droves, waiting hours each night for one more chance to stomp the checkerboard floor, dive off the beaten-up stage and guzzle cheap beer in the back room.

headline: The End of Artificially Low Rates
abstract: Now they’re just naturally low.
lead_paragraph: For years those of us pointing to low interest rates as evidence that fiscal scolds were all wrong met, over and over again, one stock answer: those low rates were meaningless, because the Fed was buying up government bonds and keeping rates artificially low. There was a big logical problem with that story: How can the Fed do that without causing inflation? There was also the fact that rates failed to spike when the Fed temporarily ended QE in 2011 — one big thing I got right and Bill Gross got wrong. But the story line has persisted nonetheless.

headline: Collection’s Pissarro Is Called Looted Art
abstract: “Paris Kathedrale,” the Kunstmuseum Bern director says, is one work of its Gurlitt collection that the institution believes was plundered by the Nazis.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Minutes after the Kunstmuseum Bern in Switzerland revealed for the first time a list of artworks Cornelius Gurlitt had stashed in his second home near the Austrian Alps, its promise of full transparency seemed to clear away decades of murky silence about a delicate Pissarro painting showing the Louvre in Paris and bridges spanning the Seine.

headline: The Last Cinema in Paradise
abstract: The People’s Theater has enchanted the tiny town of Honokaa, Hawaii, since 1930. More than a place to watch movies, it holds history and memories. But can it survive the digital age?
lead_paragraph: The People’s Theater has enchanted the tiny town of Honokaa, Hawaii, since 1930. More than a place to watch movies, it holds history and memories. But can it survive the digital age?

headline: Turing’s Spirit Hovers at a Restored Estate
abstract: The museum at Bletchley Park, the World War II British code-breaking center, sheds light on methods and people, including Alan Turing.
lead_paragraph: BLETCHLEY, England — When “Captain Ridley’s shooting party” gathered here in late August 1938 as weekend guests at Bletchley Park, a Buckinghamshire country house,  they were accompanied by one of the finest chefs from the Savoy hotel. But the hunting that took place wasn’t the usual. The visitors were members of MI6 and the Government Code and Cypher School in Britain, scouting out a retreat for code breakers who would be needed in the coming war.

headline: Saving the People’s Theater in Hawaii
abstract: In a small town on the Big Island, where a 1930 cinema is a centerpiece of life, a physician and his daughter are working to keep the movies playing.
lead_paragraph: HONOKAA, Hawaii — Phaethon Keeney was 6 when she and her father, the physician for this old plantation town on the Big Island’s Hamakua coast, moved into a room behind the screen of the town’s old cinema, the Honokaa People’s Theater.

headline: Thanksgiving Weekend Blues
abstract: I wanted my Barcalounger and leftover turkey.
lead_paragraph: RIDGEWOOD, N.J. — THANKSGIVING weekend in 1990, I spent two hours at the loneliest place in the world for an obscure novelist — the book-signing table at a Waldenbooks in a suburban New Jersey mall.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Peter Baker.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Bridging Tacky and Tasteful
abstract: Nick Lowe, the British producer and songwriter, is ready to set off on a holiday-themed tour, starting Monday.
lead_paragraph: Nick Lowe, the British producer and songwriter, is surely up there with Bob Dylan, and Scott Weiland of Stone Temple Pilots, as one of the most surprising artists to record a Christmas album.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Peter Baker.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Elton John and Darren Walker on Race, Sexual Identity and Leaving the Past Behind
abstract: The two have taken wildly divergent paths to similar destinations, each heading up a foundation meant to improve the lives of others.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to imagine two people coming from worlds as different as those of Elton John and Darren Walker.

headline: Ex-Chief of Obama Security Works to Boost Scarred Secret Service
abstract: Joseph P. Clancy leads an agency marred by embarrassing incidents, particularly one in which an Army veteran with a knife penetrated the White House.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On his way to work every morning, Joseph P. Clancy passes his new obsession and likely legacy: the seven-and-a-half-foot fence that surrounds the White House.

headline: Do You Have a Light? Ralph Lauren Does
abstract: The company’s new Ricky bag extends its reach into fashionable tech.
lead_paragraph: Forget the wrist — that body part is so last season. Wearable tech has moved on for the holidays, and now it’s all about ... the crook of the elbow.

headline: Sterilization in India
abstract: Adrienne Germain, president emerita of the International Women’s Health Coalition, writes that the mass “sterilization camp” approach violates medical ethics and human rights.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Art Basel Miami Beach’s Not-to-Be-Missed Parties and Events
abstract: Starting Monday in Miami, culture, taste and excess all storm together to electric effect.
lead_paragraph: No matter what it looks like on social media, Art Basel is all about the art. Well, at least the original one in Basel, Switzerland is. As for the Miami Beach edition, which takes place in the coming week (officially Thursday through Sunday, though festivities begin as early as Monday), it is still a horde of ancillary art shows and performances, with the parodic parade of parties swirling around them. Here are 10 buzzworthy happenings where culture, taste and excess all combine to electric effect.

headline: Only 9 Breakup Days Left Till Christmas
abstract: Thinking of leaving your lover? Time is running out.
lead_paragraph: I am frankly surprised by the lack of public service reminders about this, but this coming week is your last chance to break up before Christmas.

headline: An Exam for Teachers
abstract: Howard Miller of Mercy College writes that teacher certification exams must be “pertinent to the purpose.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Caution on Heavy Drinking
abstract: The New York City Health Department writes that it is necessary to address both excessive drinking and addiction.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: At 80, Richard Chamberlain Is Ready to Speak Volumes
abstract: No more starring roles, thank you, but there may be some haiku left in him.
lead_paragraph: At 80, Richard Chamberlain isn’t so great with stairs these days, though in some ways he seems downright boyish, with a palpable aura of enthusiasm and a habit of tapping both hands on a tabletop when he lands on a topic that moves him.

headline: On Black Friday, Walmart Is Pressed for Wage Increases
abstract: Thousands descended on Walmarts across the country on one of the busiest shopping days of the year to protest what they said were the company’s low wages.
lead_paragraph: While millions of shoppers flocked to Walmart stores nationwide on Black Friday, thousands of protesters descended on Walmarts to protest what they said were the retailer’s low wages.

headline: Evening Hours | Youth and History
abstract: Honors for the elders and trains for the kids.
lead_paragraph: Honors for the elders and trains for the kids.

headline: The Sinking of the Greyhound
abstract: In late 1864, Confederate saboteurs sank a Union transport ship, almost killing three of the North’s highest-ranking officers.
lead_paragraph: In late November 1864, the Union troop transport Greyhound was steaming down the James River in Virginia from the Bermuda Hundred Plantation, where the army of Maj. Gen. Benjamin Butler had been bottled up for weeks. Butler’s superior, Lt. Gen. Ulysses S. Grant, had planned to send Butler due south toward Richmond, thereby trapping Gen. Robert E. Lee’s Army of Northern Virginia between two large concentrations of Union troops. But Butler soon found himself in a stalemate against entrenched Confederate forces, far outside Richmond.

headline: The Pain of the Watermelon Joke
abstract: The history is more than an ugly stereotype of African-Americans.
lead_paragraph: AS a child in South Carolina, I spent summers like so many children — sitting on my grandparents’ back porch with my siblings, spitting watermelon seeds into the garden or, even worse, swallowing them and trembling as my older brother and sister spoke of the vine that was probably already growing in my belly.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Thanksgiving
abstract: For many, Thanksgiving has stretched into five days of festivities.
lead_paragraph: For many, Thanksgiving has stretched into five days of festivities.

headline: Doing Some Heavy Lifting
abstract: The case of the former U.P.S. driver and her eight-year fight about whether she could handle a 21-pound package goes to the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: In their long, frequently triumphant but totally unfinished struggle for equal employment rights, women keep coming up against the matter of lifting heavy bundles.

headline: Ohio State Walk-On Is Missing
abstract: A football player and wrestler has not been seen since Wednesday morning.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — Around 1:30 a.m. Wednesday, Kosta Karageorge, an Ohio State football player and wrestler, sent a text message to his mother, apologizing if he had been an “embarrassment,” explaining that he had been affected by concussions.

headline: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 2,339 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Defense has identified 2,339 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: In Northern Ireland, a Wave of Immigrants Is Met With Fists
abstract: Racially motivated attacks have increased at a time when open borders in the European Union have led waves of illegal and legal migrants to Britain and Ireland.
lead_paragraph: BELFAST, Northern Ireland — More than 16 years after the Good Friday peace deal brought real hope that Protestants and Roman Catholics could live together in relative harmony, Northern Ireland is being racked by another wave of violence.

headline: In a Twitter Post, Malaysia Airlines Sends the Wrong Message
abstract: A tweet that was meant to appeal to adventurous travelers served as an unintentional reminder that the airline has lost two planes this year.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Malaysia Airlines tried to appeal to travelers’ sense of adventure in a year-end promotional campaign.

headline: Brooklyn’s Lubavitch Community: A Culture Captured by the Ultimate Outsider
abstract: Chie Nishio, a photographer born in Japan, chronicled the lives of Lubavitch-Chabad Hasidim in Brooklyn, including the movement’s leader, Rabbi Menachem Mendel Schneerson.
lead_paragraph: One day during Hanukkah 26 years ago, the grand rabbi of the Lubavitch-Chabad Hasidim briefly turned away from the hundreds of men gathered before him in synagogue to cast his eye toward the women’s balcony. Then he extended an arm, offering someone there a roll of nickels. That recipient, in turn, was meant to fulfill the rabbi’s design by giving the coins to charity.

headline: Free Fall in Oil Price Underscores Shift Away From OPEC
abstract: The inability or unwillingness of OPEC to curb production showed that it was no longer the dominating force behind global fuel supplies and prices.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Since the economically crippling oil embargo of 1973, every American president has pledged to seek and achieve energy independence.

headline: Denham Harman, 98, Dies; Sought Leverage on Aging
abstract: Dr. Harman’s ideas about free radical cell damage and the aging process were well ahead of his time.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Denham Harman, a research biochemist who asserted that old age was just another disease, and who drew support from medical experts for his claim that aging could be managed — if never quite cured — with vitamins and other so-called antioxidants, died on Tuesday in Omaha. He was 98 and lived in Omaha.

headline: A Conundrum for Saudis: Women at Work
abstract: A group of academics is joining the Saudi government in a project to lower the hurdles keeping women from becoming employed.
lead_paragraph: Claudia Goldin, a Harvard professor, is not just an expert on working women. As one of the nation’s most prominent economists, she also exemplifies the growing stature and independence of women in American society. So it was unusual to find Ms. Goldin covered in an abaya while meeting in Saudi Arabia not long ago with government officials from the kingdom in an opulent hotel that offered male-only seating areas and forbade women from using its spa.

headline: Protesters United Against Ferguson Decision, but Challenged in Unity
abstract: Activists are divided by aim and by geography, with goals of justice for Michael Brown or an end to lethal police force against minorities.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — Demonstrators forced the temporary closing of the St. Louis Galleria mall after staging a mass “die-in” on Friday afternoon, lying on the floor for four and a half minutes of silence to represent the hours that Michael Brown was left on the street after a police officer shot him dead.

headline: Team Sells Its Best Players, and Doesn’t Pay for It
abstract: After last year’s mediocre season, Southampton F.C. officials and fans feared this season would be worse, but despite the off-season turmoil the team’s results have been impressive.
lead_paragraph: SOUTHAMPTON, England — Les Reed remembers the venom. He remembers the anger and the worry and the stress. He remembers — much as he may try to forget — the cursing. Just moments after the end of Southampton F.C.'s final home match last season, Reed, the club’s executive director, sat in his seat at St. Mary’s Stadium and absorbed a steady stream of salty language from fans as they stomped up the aisles.

headline: Budget Problems? Kentucky and Elsewhere Find Answer in Bottle
abstract: The alcohol industry is booming in many states, fueled by a growing taste for whiskey and craft beer, and changes to regulations and tax policies.
lead_paragraph: LAWRENCEBURG, Ky. — Alcohol may not be single-handedly saving state and local budgets from the red, but it is certainly helping.

headline: Global Weakness, America’s Problem
abstract: The United States is not immune to the economic malaise abroad.
lead_paragraph: At their policy meeting in October, Federal Reserve officials were blasé about economic weakness in Asia and Europe. According to the minutes of the meeting, the Fed noted that growth in the United States “might be” slower than anticipated in the next year or two if global conditions were to deteriorate further.

headline: Improvements for Rikers Island
abstract: It will take vigilance to ensure that the old, abusive system is replaced by a more humane one.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio acknowledged last week that he initially underestimated the dysfunction that had allowed chronic violence and corruption to flourish at the Rikers Island jail complex, adding that he intended to make reforming this troubled system a top priority.

headline: A Rare Chance for Two Governors
abstract: The package of reforms for the Port Authority — a bistate feat — awaits the signatures of Andrew Cuomo and Chris Christie.
lead_paragraph: The infamous traffic jam last year on the George Washington Bridge — a bizarre political payback organized by aides to Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey — did one good thing. It focused lawmakers on the urgent need to reform the huge, secretive Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, the bistate agency that owns the bridge and other major facilities in the region.

headline: Wrestling With an Aging Arsenal
abstract: Our nuclear weapons need routine fixes and alert forces, and some sensible rethinking.
lead_paragraph: What do a wrench, a blast door and an intercontinental ballistic missile have in common? They are part of an American nuclear weapons program plagued by operational, personnel and leadership problems. Evidence of dysfunction has been mounting since 2007 when six nuclear missiles went missing for 36 hours after a crew at Minot Air Force Base in North Dakota mistakenly loaded them onto a plane and flew them across the country. Two recent Pentagon reports suggest that things have not improved.

headline: What Should the Pope Do in New York City?
abstract: The Vatican’s envoy to the United Nations disclosed this month that Pope Francis would almost certainly come to New York City in 2015. Here’s a list of a few prime possibilities for stops. What do you think he should do?
lead_paragraph: The Vatican’s envoy to the United Nations disclosed this month that Pope Francis would almost certainly come to New York City in 2015. Here’s a list of a few prime possibilities for stops. What do you think he should do?

headline: Ray Rice Ruling Highlights Roger Goodell’s Missteps
abstract: An arbitrator’s overturning of Rice’s suspension put yet another crack in the credibility and authority of the N.F.L. commissioner.
lead_paragraph: It’s a good guess that Roger Goodell, the once-powerful commissioner of the N.F.L., doesn’t want to hear about his mistakes anymore. Like how his willy-nilly punishments of players gone wrong have caused him to lose credibility, or how his efforts to stand up for those who have suffered from domestic violence seem only like public-relations moves.

headline: More Pastors Embrace Talk of Mental Ills
abstract: Matt Brogli, a Southern Baptist pastor in North Carolina, is among a growing number of evangelical clergy members sending mentally troubled congregants to secular professionals.
lead_paragraph: EAGLE SPRINGS, N.C. — The pastor’s phone rang in the midnight darkness. A man’s voice rasped: “My wife left me and I’ve got a shotgun in my mouth. Give me one reason why I shouldn’t pull the trigger.”

headline: Nicotine Without Death
abstract: The growing pains in the e-cigarette industry suggest a mix of cautious optimism and deep frustration among executives.
lead_paragraph: I attended Wells Fargo Securities’ “2nd Annual E-Cig Conference” last week, and if I had to describe the mood of the speakers it would be a cross between cautious optimism and deep frustration.

headline: Palestinian Refuge for 6 Decades, Now Flooded From Syria
abstract: The Syrian civil war has driven a wave of Syrians into Lebanon, roughly doubling the population of the Palestinian refugee camp of Shatila.
lead_paragraph: SHATILA CAMP, Lebanon — An enormous iron key hangs on a water tower above a crossroads in the Palestinian refugee camp of Shatila, just south of downtown Beirut. The sculpture alludes to the rusting keys that many families here treasure, from houses lost when they fled what became Israel in 1948.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 28, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Saturday’s College Football Games to Watch
abstract: It’s an appetizing post-Thanksgiving lineup of games on Saturday, including the Iron Bowl, Egg Bowl, Civil War and Apple Cup.
lead_paragraph: It is hard to imagine a better day of college football. From noon to prime time Saturday, rivals will square off in the distinctively named Iron Bowl, Egg Bowl, Civil War and Clean, Old-Fashioned Hate and Apple Cup as well as for Paul Bunyan’s ax. Division titles are on the line. Teams with nothing to lose versus those who think they deserve a spot in the College Football Playoff. Expect the unexpected.

headline: At Assisted-Living Home Set to Close, Holdouts Dig In as Services Dry Up
abstract: In the eight months since the operator of the Prospect Park Residence announced it was closing, the number of residents has dwindled to eight from more than 120, and most of the staff has left or been let go.
lead_paragraph: Mealtimes at the Prospect Park Residence, a building in the classical revival style overlooking Grand Army Plaza in Brooklyn, were once dignified affairs. The residents sat down to carefully folded napkins and pale-green tablecloths in a spacious dining room bustling with neighbors, medical aides and servers. The windows offered sweeping views of Prospect Park.

headline: Not Found in This Puzzle’s Answer
abstract: A wide open grid from Elizabeth C. Gorski.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — One of the things I like the most about Elizabeth C. Gorski’s puzzles is the sense of humor that pervades them. And the visuals. I think it’s safe to say that Ms. Gorski is the queen of the visual crossword-puzzle elements.

headline: Still Awaiting Union Ruling, Northwestern Players Focus on Field
abstract: As Northwestern waits for a decision on an appeal of a ruling that the school’s scholarship players are employees, the football team continues to focus on the game.
lead_paragraph: EVANSTON, Ill. — The day Northwestern football players voted on unionization in April, the ballots were impounded, carried away from Ryan Field in two shiny silver locked boxes. Seven months later, they have yet to be counted. College sports look markedly different anyway. N.C.A.A. governance has been overhauled; universities and conferences have pledged greater scholarship protection and better health care; a federal judge has ruled that players can be paid for the use of their images.

headline: Finding a Salve for His Depression on Two Wheels
abstract: For Paul Watson, riding his bicycle is not only his passion, but he says it also helps calm him down.
lead_paragraph: Paul Watson speaks haltingly in a low, soft voice. He is shy and moves around his world with careful steps, nodding to answer questions when he would rather not talk. But, in his quietest moments, his smile often speaks for him.

headline: Woman, 67, Dies From Injuries Caused by Fire in the Bronx
abstract: The 67-year-old woman was found badly burned after a fire broke out in the E. Roberts Moore Houses on Friday afternoon.
lead_paragraph: A 67-year-old woman died on Friday after she was badly burned in an apartment fire in the Bronx, the police said.

headline: Ready, Aim, Fire, Then Relax in the Lounge
abstract: A new wave of luxurious gun clubs is popping up around urban centers, modeled after country clubs to appeal to people who did not grow up in gun-owning households.
lead_paragraph: CENTENNIAL, Colo. — At a gun club in this Denver suburb, Marc Rabinoff sat in the V.I.P. lounge, amid a sea of leather couches, the fireplace at his back. The air smelled vaguely of perfume. At an adjacent range, his wife, Diana, fired bullets from her purple glitter pistol, her hands wrapped in gloves of leather and lace.

headline: Mary Hinkson, a Star for Martha Graham, Dies at 89
abstract: Ms. Hinkson, known for her dramatic power, was one of the first two black dancers to join the company.
lead_paragraph: Mary Hinkson, one of Martha Graham’s most important leading dancers, whose performances from the 1950s through the early ’70s were filled with unbridled dramatic power, died on Wednesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 89.

headline: Frank Yablans, Paramount Executive in Fertile ’70s, Dies at 79
abstract: Mr. Yablans spent time as president of Paramount Pictures while it released some of the most acclaimed movies of the 1970s and led MGM/UA in the 1980s.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Frank Yablans, a blunt-spoken filmmaker and studio executive who oversaw the release of the first two “Godfather” films while president of Paramount Pictures and later was both a producer and a writer of “Mommie Dearest” and “North Dallas Forty,” died on Thursday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 79.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, November 29, 2014
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, November 29, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “In human history, there has never been a better time to be a drinker.”

headline: Roberto Gómez Bolaños, Mexico’s Comedic Artist ‘Chespirito,’ Dies at 85
abstract: The actor, writer and director was known around the Spanish-speaking world for his iconic characters and widely viewed television shows.
lead_paragraph: Roberto Gómez Bolaños, a Mexican comic actor, writer and director familiar around the world for his characters El Chavo and El Chapulín Colorado, died on Friday in Cancún. He was 85.

headline: Sabah, Enduring Star in Arab World Entertainment, Dies at 87
abstract: Her fame in the Arab world as an entertainer endured for six decades.
lead_paragraph: Sabah, a prolific and provocative Lebanese singer and actress whose fame in the Arab world endured for six decades, died on Wednesday in Beirut. She was 87.

headline: In Return to Thunder, Westbrook Dominates the Knicks
abstract: Carmelo Anthony missed his second straight game for the Knicks, who struggled to keep up with a Thunder team that benefited from Russell Westbrook’s return.
lead_paragraph: OKLAHOMA CITY — After the officiant prayed for Russell Westbrook’s continued recovery as part of the pregame invocation here at Chesapeake Energy Arena, Westbrook approached the opposing bench and hugged Derek Fisher, a teammate not so long ago.

headline: Derek Fisher Returns to Oklahoma City, Where He Ended His Career
abstract: The game was the first trip back to Oklahoma City for Fisher, who closed out his playing career with the Thunder before he accepted the Knicks’ coaching job in June.
lead_paragraph: OKLAHOMA CITY — After spending two-plus seasons as his Thunder teammate, Oklahoma City Thunder guard Russell Westbrook said he knew it was going to be odd to see Knicks Coach Derek Fisher in a suit on the opposing sideline.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (Lifetime) GRUMPY CAT’S WORST CHRISTMAS EVER (2014) Grumpy Cat, above, the sourpuss feline who rose to fame via the Internet about two years ago; appeared on the cover of New York magazine; and published a book, “The Grumpy Guide to Life,” tries out her acting chops. With the help of the vocal talents of Aubrey Plaza, of “Parks and Recreation,” Grumpy plays a lonely cat living in a mall pet shop — no one wants to take her home. She discovers that she can communicate with a 12-year-old girl. All of which leads Grumpy reluctantly to thwart the kidnapping of an exotic dog she personally can’t stand and then, after the mall closes on Christmas Eve, rescue her new friend as well.

headline: Corrections: November 29, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on November 29, 2014.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: In Playoff Push, Baylor’s Style Is to Focus on the Task at Hand: Winning
abstract: Facing Texas Tech on Saturday, Baylor simply contends that a victory is what counts most, not politicking, even as the College Football Playoff committee looks on.
lead_paragraph: At No. 7 in the College Football Playoff, the Baylor Bears are perched on the periphery of the inaugural playoff system. But Coach Art Briles would not budge when pressed on the issue of style points or politicking.

headline: Conservationists Continue Push to Block Hong Kong Ivory Sales
abstract: Protesters gathered Saturday outside a Hong Kong department store that had been prominently selling ivory products, part of an effort to publicize the city’s key role in the trade.
lead_paragraph: Protesters gathered Saturday outside a Hong Kong department store that had been prominently selling ivory products, part of an effort to publicize the city’s key role in the trade, which activists say contributes to the poaching of elephants.

headline: Darren Wilson, Officer in Ferguson Shooting, Resigns From Police Dept.
abstract: The officer said in a letter that he hoped his resignation would “allow the community to heal,” his lawyer said. A grand jury declined on Monday to indict him for killing an unarmed black teenager.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — The white police officer a grand jury declined to indict last week in the fatal shooting of an unarmed black teenager has resigned from this city’s Police Department, his lawyer said on Saturday night.

headline: Egyptian Judges Drop All Charges Against Mubarak
abstract: The court’s decision means former President Hosni Mubarak could go free for the first time since his 2011 removal from office.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — An Egyptian court dropped all remaining criminal charges against former President Hosni Mubarak on Saturday in a sweeping repudiation of the Arab Spring uprising that forced him from power.

headline: Making Sense of Ferguson: Part 2
abstract: What article or book would you recommend to those who want to better understand events in Ferguson? We asked Times colleagues to weigh in.
lead_paragraph: What article or book would you recommend to those who want to better understand events in Ferguson? We asked Times colleagues to weigh in. Read recommendations from Nicholas Kristof, Tanzina Vega and others here.

headline: The Daily Gift: Handsome Cutting Boards With Leather Handles
abstract: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.
lead_paragraph: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.

headline: Saturday Morning Music: Stay Gold
abstract: Advice for the Swiss?
lead_paragraph: Sorry, family stuff was going on and I completely forgot to post last night. Meanwhile, Switzerland is about to vote on a proposal to keep 20 percent of its enormous reserves in gold which can never be sold.

headline: Biking New Zealand’s Wine Country
abstract: The new Tasman’s Great Taste Trail in New Zealand takes cyclists to the region’s wineries, breweries and cafes.
lead_paragraph: New Zealand is known for its Great Walks, but now it has Great Cycles — a series of 23 bicycle trails across the country.

headline: Attack in Western China Leaves at Least 15 People Dead
abstract: The police in Xinjiang shot dead 11 members of a gang who killed four people and wounded 14 in an attack on a busy street, official Chinese media said.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The police in Xinjiang, the volatile region of western China, shot dead 11 members of a gang who killed four people and wounded 14 in an attack on a street lined with restaurants and food stalls, official Chinese media said Saturday.

headline: Egypt Drops Case Against Mubarak
abstract: An Egyptian court drops its case against ousted president Hosni Mubarak on charges of ordering the killing of protesters in 2011.
lead_paragraph: An Egyptian court drops its case against ousted president Hosni Mubarak on charges of ordering the killing of protesters in 2011.

headline: When Vermin Come to Visit
abstract: This week’s topics include a threatening rats’ nest; a landlord’s responsibility to accommodate a disabled tenant; and a public drainage directed to private property.
lead_paragraph: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: Variety: A Spiny Acrostic
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon offer us a spiny acrostic.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — Today’s acrostic quote is a good example of why I’m glad they invented marketing. If someone hadn’t said, “You know what this LOBSTER stuff needs? A better image. Let’s put it next to some parsley, some melted butter and lemon wedges, and charge upwards of $10 a pound,” we might have missed out on one of the most incredible treats on the face of the Earth.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘Marco Polo’
abstract: John Fusco, creator of the Netflix series ”Marco Polo,” narrates a scene in which the 13th-century traveler enters the court of Kublai Khan.
lead_paragraph: John Fusco, creator of the Netflix series ”Marco Polo,” narrates a scene in which the 13th-century traveler enters the court of Kublai Khan.

headline: Still Dressing Up; Growing Up, Too
abstract: Slipknot has grown significantly on “.5: The Gray Chapter,” its fifth major-label album.
lead_paragraph: At nu-metal’s peak, Slipknot was the act with the grandest sense of theater, identifying band members with numbers, not names, and performing in ostentatious clown masks and jumpsuits, like the house band at a Stephen King fan convention. Its music was generally more straightforward, though: pummeling and direct, heavy on grinding drums and horror vocals.

headline: Who Knows What This Means?
abstract: The choreographer Neil Greenberg is allergic to the word “about” when it comes to discussing his dances.
lead_paragraph: The choreographer Neil Greenberg is allergic to the word “about” when it comes to discussing his dances. Aren’t the days of dances having to be about something long gone? Inspired by Susan Sontag’s “Against Interpretation,” Mr. Greenberg, in his new dance “This,” fights the idea that meaning must be assigned to choreography. His last work, “(like a vase),” presented four years ago, explored the tension created by the desire for meaning. In “This,” he goes further by focusing on dance as a crystallization of the performance moment.

headline: Acting Out a Nightmare
abstract: It’s a parent’s worst nightmare: You momentarily drop your child’s hand, and in a heartbeat he vanishes into the ether.
lead_paragraph: It’s a parent’s worst nightmare: You momentarily drop your child’s hand, and in a heartbeat he vanishes into the ether. So to portray Tony Hughes, a British father whose 5-year-old son, Oliver, disappears during a family vacation in France in “The Missing,” a mini-series shown Saturdays on Starz, James Nesbitt intended to mine his experiences with his own two daughters. And found that he couldn’t. “There’s an actual defense that causes us to pull the shutters up,” he said in a phone interview, “and we disallow ourselves from going there.”

headline: Influences and Exhibitions
abstract: As a pioneer of the Conceptual art movement, Allen Ruppersberg has influenced a younger generation of artists working today, as seen in a new show.
lead_paragraph: Known for everything from place mats made of laminated newspaper articles to stretched canvases featuring the entire handwritten text of Oscar Wilde’s “The Picture of Dorian Gray,” Allen Ruppersberg would seem like a tough act to follow. But as a pioneer of the Conceptual art movement — in 1971, he transformed a small Sunset Boulevard house into a functioning hotel that he revived for Frieze New York last May — he has influenced a younger generation of artists working today. Now the gallery Greene Naftali in Chelsea has assembled a group of those artists for the exhibition “The Novel That Writes Itself.”

headline: Dead Composers Stage a Comeback
abstract: Handel fans should be in for a treat Sunday when Emmanuelle Haïm leads Le Concert d’Astrée, a baroque ensemble, in excerpts from “Giulio Cesare.”
lead_paragraph: Readers of Think Denk, the pianist Jeremy Denk’s witty blog, have enjoyed his musicological observations and wit — which he recently channeled into a libretto. Inspired by Charles Rosen’s “Classical Style,” a textbook from the 1970s, Mr. Denk has created characters that include not only Mozart, Beethoven and Haydn (who have read a newspaper article declaring the death of classical music), but the Tonic and Dominant Chords. “The Classical Style: An Opera (of Sorts),” with a score by Steven Stucky, debuted at the Ojai Festival last summer. It will be performed on Thursday with a cast including the soprano Jennifer Zetlan and Robert Spano conducting the Knights. (7:30 p.m., Zankel Hall, Carnegie Hall; 212-247-7800, carnegiehall.org, limited availability.)

headline: How to Build an Empire, the Netflix Way
abstract: With “Marco Polo,” its lavish new series, the streaming service is placing one of its biggest bets yet on global expansion.
lead_paragraph: In the first episode of “Marco Polo,” Netflix’s coming original series, the Mongolian emperor Kublai Khan sits on a throne in his gilded palace and plots the future conquests of his growing empire.

headline: Tales Told Out of School in Pyongyang Cause Stir
abstract: A memoir by a Korean-American author about teaching English to adolescent boys at a private university in Pyongyang has angered the authorities and her former colleagues.
lead_paragraph: A memoir by a Korean-American author about teaching English to adolescent boys at a private university in Pyongyang was certain to anger the North Korean government.

headline: Pope Brings Message of Interreligious Peace to Istanbul
abstract: The pope’s visit to Turkey is considered a message of solidarity with the Ecumenical Patriarchate of the Orthodox Church, which represents nearly 300 million Orthodox Christians worldwide.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — On the second leg of his trip to Turkey, Pope Francis was welcomed on Saturday by curious bystanders and tourists from around the world as he visited the historical district here to deliver his message of further interreligious dialogue for peace.

headline: A Lesser Warning? Maybe
abstract: Swedish Match, a tobacco company, wants the F.D.A. to change course, by declaring its smokeless product as having “substantially lower risks to health than cigarettes.”
lead_paragraph: On a recent morning at a Starbucks in Richmond, Va., Patrik Hildingsson ordered a latte and, between sips, tucked a pouch of tobacco into his upper lip.

headline: Mark Strand, 80, Dies; Pulitzer-Winning Poet Laureate
abstract: To critics who said Mr. Strand’s poems were too dark he replied, “I find them evenly lit.”
lead_paragraph: Mark Strand, whose spare, deceptively simple investigations of rootlessness, alienation and the ineffable strangeness of life made him one of America’s most hauntingly meditative poets, died on Saturday at his daughter’s home in Brooklyn. He was 80.

headline: Studying Snus, a Smokeless Tobacco From Sweden
abstract: Much research has been conducted on the health effects of Swedish snus, a smokeless tobacco product. A look at the state of the science.
lead_paragraph: The warning label on cans of Swedish snus sold in the United States says that “this product can cause mouth cancer” and cautions that it “is not a safe alternative to cigarettes.”

headline: Slamming the Window on Investors
abstract: A bylaw change by JDS Uniphase squeezed a money manager’s campaign for change at the company.
lead_paragraph: It’s becoming a full-time job cataloging the contortions some companies go through to avoid addressing their shareholders’ concerns.

headline: Roger Ferguson of TIAA-CREF: Always Act as if You’re an Owner
abstract: A C.E.O. says he emphasizes personal accountability: “One of the phrases I use is that if you owned this company, what would you do? And if your colleagues were owners, what would you want them to do?”
lead_paragraph: This interview with  Roger Ferguson, chief executive of TIAA-CREF, the retirement services provider, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Taliban Overrun an Afghan Army Base
abstract: The insurgents killed as many as 14 soldiers in one of their deadliest attacks against Afghan soldiers this year, local officials said.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Taliban fighters overran an Afghan National Army outpost in Helmand Province in the country’s south late Friday night and by Saturday morning had killed as many as 14 soldiers in one of the insurgents’ deadliest attacks against Afghan soldiers this year, local officials said.

headline: For Accomplished Students, Reaching a Good College Isn’t as Hard as It Seems
abstract: Admission rates are misleading: It’s not that fewer students are accepted; it’s that applications have run riot.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, Harvard announced that it had accepted 5.9 percent of the nearly 35,000 students who applied for admission to the class of 2018. The next day, Stanford announced an even more exacting 5.07 percent admission rate, the lowest in the university’s history.

headline: The Absence of Two Stars May Have Lifted the Thunder’s Game
abstract: For 14 games, the Oklahoma City Thunder discovered what life was like without Russell Westbrook and Kevin Durant in the lineup: unpleasant. But the benefit is that the second unit has become more self-reliant.
lead_paragraph: OKLAHOMA CITY — The home locker room here at Chesapeake Energy Arena is nearly as big as a warehouse, except the carpet is nice and the center of the room features a shiny mosaic of the Oklahoma City Thunder logo. It is spacious and comfortable, with plenty of room for people to spread out.

headline: What We’re Watching: Sunday Shows
abstract: This week, thousands protested a grand jury’s decision to not indict a white police officer who shot dead a teenager in Ferguson, Mo. Conversations on the Sunday shows will center on law enforcement and protesters.
lead_paragraph: From Ferguson, Mo., to Los Angeles to New York City, thousands marched this week to protest a St. Louis County grand jury’s decision to not indict a white police officer who shot and killed an unarmed black teenager, Michael Brown. Benjamin Crump, a lawyer for the teenager’s family, will give insight on how Mr. Brown’s parents are coping with the decision on CBS’s “Face the Nation.”

headline: Pelicans Are in Anthony Davis’s Slipstream
abstract: Davis, 21, has proved to be much more than a shot-blocking rim protector for the New Orleans Pelicans; he leads the player efficiency ratings at 33.43, more than double the league average.
lead_paragraph: Everyone knew Anthony Davis was talented, but in a remarkable start to the season, he is showing that he may be the most valuable player in the N.B.A.

headline: Heroin Takes Over a House, and Mom, on New York’s Staten Island
abstract: Laurie Sperring’s addiction rapidly turned a modest condominium in a pastoral neighborhood into a locus for Staten Island’s ravenous heroin demand.
lead_paragraph: Darkness fell on Wood Court on Staten Island, and they came. Footfalls on the gravel path, their crunch-crunch-crunch setting dogs barking, babies wailing, parents peering out windows, night after night.

headline: On the Other Side of the Glass
abstract: A display artist at Bergdorf Goodman says the planning for its holiday windows usually starts a year in advance, and “we try to one-up ourselves every year.”

headline: Just Plane Ugly
abstract: Look! Up in the sky! It’s the very worst of us.
lead_paragraph: THE woman in 27E doesn’t have only one carry-on plus a small bag for a laptop or personal items. She has one carry-on plus a purse the size of a bassinet plus some canvas vessel for all of her electronics plus two different plastic totes for various pillows, blankets and possibly an ottoman and a coffee table. Shuffling down the aisle, she looks more like a Peruvian llama than anything human. She grunts and buckles.

headline: Japan Is Back in the Hunt for Whales
abstract: Peculiar politics were on display as Japan’s new whaling plan was announced.
lead_paragraph: Claiming purely “scientific” motives, Japan’s political leaders are cynically planning to resume whale hunting in the Southern Ocean, despite the International Court of Justice finding that the Japanese government regularly violated its obligations under the international ban against commercial whaling off Antarctica.

headline: In Praise of Impracticality
abstract: All the life-altering decisions I’ve made at first seemed misguided, misjudged or plain foolish. They weren’t.
lead_paragraph: I SAW a girl on a Manhattan-bound subway train one day wearing a knockoff Louis Vuitton head scarf and false eyelashes long enough to make a daddy longlegs envious. Her look — a sort of Sally-Bowles-does-Brooklyn — was complete with a matching knockoff L.V. handbag and umbrella. She was seated next to a young man who was as dashing in his way as she was adorable, but she took no notice of him as she was completely absorbed in a paperback titled something like “Becoming a Practical Thinker.”

headline: Can Mushrooms Treat Depression?
abstract: This psychoactive chemical isn’t just for hippies.
lead_paragraph: I TRIED magic mushrooms out of curiosity and in middle age. I’d been on the amateur mycological circuit for a couple of years, but hallucinogenic species were rarely mentioned at the foraging expeditions and conferences I attended. It’s almost as if they were the black sheep of mycology: embarrassing to serious taxonomy jocks. I read some books on the subject, but most were tripper’s guides that didn’t utilize, um, specific language or current science. Psychoactive mushrooms had been in a kind of scientific ghetto ever since they were criminalized in 1968. But now the drug derived from the mushroom, psilocybin, is finally being re-examined for its medical applications.

headline: Bernhard Misof
abstract: An Austrian evolutionary biologist on music, knives and perfection.
lead_paragraph: Bernhard Misof, an Austrian evolutionary biologist at the Alexander Koenig Zoological Research Museum in Bonn, Germany, is coordinating a comprehensive insect tree of life using genetic data from more than 1,000 species.

headline: Where Do We Go After Ferguson?
abstract: Ferguson illuminates our country’s racial divide.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — WHEN Ferguson flared up this week after a grand jury failed to indict the white police officer Darren Wilson for killing the unarmed black youth Michael Brown, two realities were illuminated: Black and white people rarely view race in the same way or agree about how to resolve racial conflicts, and black people have furious moral debates among ourselves out of white earshot.

headline: When Whites Just Don’t Get It, Part 5
abstract: How can we address the racial biases embedded in our society?
lead_paragraph: WE Americans are a nation divided.

headline: The Retreat to Identity
abstract: After Ferguson, it’s harder to make a case for optimism about race and politics in America.
lead_paragraph: LAST summer, around the anniversary of Martin Luther King Jr.’s “I Have a Dream” speech, I wrote a column making — gingerly — a case for optimism about race and politics in America.

headline: Hydrogen Cars, Coming Down the Pike
abstract: They could play an important role in fighting climate change, but a lot more refueling stations will be needed.
lead_paragraph: The once-distant promise of clean, affordable hydrogen-powered cars is starting to become a reality.

headline: Oil Drills and Spills
abstract: Readers discuss the environmental damage in North Dakota from oil extraction.
lead_paragraph: Readers discuss the environmental damage in North Dakota from oil extraction.

headline: When Doping Isn’t Cheating
abstract: If it makes an athlete faster, should Tylenol be banned?
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — THE undisputed facts of the case are that the South African cyclist Daryl Impey — the first African rider to wear the leader’s jersey at the Tour de France — visited a pharmacy in Durban on the eve of his country’s national road cycling championships in February. He purchased some pills to boost his race performance. A few months later, authorities announced that he had tested positive for probenecid, a substance sometimes used to mask the presence of other drugs.

headline: Homeownership and Wealth Creation
abstract: Economic forces that make homeownership less possible need to be in the forefront of political debate.
lead_paragraph: Since the housing bust, renting has been in and owning a home has been out, especially among young adults who in earlier decades would have been first-time home buyers. As the rate of homeownership has declined, from a peak of nearly 70 percent in 2004 to a 20-year low of 64.3 percent recently, the number of owner-occupied homes has barely budged, while the number occupied by renters has increased by nearly 25 percent.

headline: A Salad Chain’s Surprise Ingredient: Tech Money
abstract: Steve Case’s investment firm is betting on a young restaurant company, which is aiming to bring a tech-rooted notion — a seamless user interface — to its customers.
lead_paragraph: Why is a venture capital firm led by online pioneers backing a farm-to-table salad chain?

headline: The Art of the Amateur Online Review
abstract: Research into the language of online criticism finds insights into what today’s consumers are thinking — and discovers much literary ambition.
lead_paragraph: When Camilla Vásquez and her husband, Rubén, went to a dealership to shop for a new car last June, they found the salesman affable and low-key. To their surprise, Dr. Vásquez said, the hard sell began after the deal was sealed. That’s when the salesman pulled out a binder of online reviews he wanted the couple to use as models for reporting on their shopping experience.

headline: Pain Is Colorblind
abstract: What color was the trigger finger? Wrong question.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — THE fight was in the early rounds, and it was just the diversion I needed. I had spent the previous few days covering the Michael Brown case, caught up in the gloomy guessing game of what might happen if a grand jury decided not to indict the police officer who killed him.

headline: Epiphany, With Encyclopedias
abstract: We were college students, selling worthless books.
lead_paragraph: WAY back when I was in college, before the Internet, before the personal computer, back when only businesses had electric typewriters, I sold encyclopedias one summer to help pay for my senior year. And in doing so, I had an epiphany that helped me understand the extraordinary and enduring tension in America between anti-intellectualism and academic achievement.

headline: Sex and the Saints
abstract: The Mormon Church has done a fine thing in opening up about its past.
lead_paragraph: WHEN ushered into the master bedroom of the Mormon patriarch Brigham Young at his winter home in St. George, Utah, a few years ago, I felt duty-bound to ask an obvious question: Where did the other women sleep?

headline: Exchange-Rate Issue Is Cold Cash to N.H.L.
abstract: The decline in the value of the Canadian dollar against the United States dollar could have an impact on the size of an increase, if any, in the N.H.L.’s salary cap next season.
lead_paragraph: The N.H.L.’s general managers count on the salary cap to rise every year. But what if, as some fear, it does not go up next season?

headline: Raised Hands, and the Doubts of a Grand Jury
abstract: A grand jury rejected the image of Michael Brown with his hands raised in surrender before he was shot, but the questions surrounding his final moments remain murky and unresolved.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — It is the image that became indelible, fueling protests nationwide after the confrontation on a muggy August day here: Michael Brown, an unarmed 18-year-old African-American, with hands raised in surrender moments before a white police officer fired the shots that killed him.

headline: Movies, Meet 4D Theme Park
abstract: To increase attendance, theaters are trying to redefine the moviegoing experience with amenities and effects like mist, scents and moving seats.
lead_paragraph: To increase attendance, theaters are trying to redefine the moviegoing experience with amenities and effects like mist, scents and moving seats.

headline: To Lure Young, Movie Theaters Shake, Smell and Spritz
abstract: To combat declining attendance, movie theaters are experimenting with more immersive and interactive experiences, including moving seats, scents and precipitation.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Having tried 3-D films, earsplitting sound systems and even alcohol sales in pursuit of younger moviegoers, some theater chains are now installing undulating seats, scent machines and 270-degree screens.

headline: Gun Play for Grownups
abstract: A married couple bonds over their shared love of the local shooting range.
lead_paragraph: A married couple bonds over their shared love of the local shooting range.

headline: The Strip
abstract: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.
lead_paragraph: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: Independent Is Elected Taipei Mayor as Taiwan’s Governing Party Falters
abstract: The election results signaled that Taiwan’s governing Chinese Nationalist Party, known as the Kuomintang, would be hard-pressed to retain the presidency in the 2016 election.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A doctor running as an independent won the mayor’s race in Taipei, the capital, on Saturday, as Taiwan’s governing party suffered heavy losses in local elections. In response to the defeats dealt to the party, which favors closer ties with China, the prime minister resigned.

headline: Amid Slump, Brazil Congress Seeks Raise
abstract: Seizing on a generally sleepy time in Brazil, congressional leaders in the capital, Brasília, are pushing ahead with legislation to raise their own salaries as much as 34 percent.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — After a tight re-election victory marked by quarreling over a sluggish economy and yawning budget deficits, Brazil’s president, Dilma Rousseff, has ushered in a new economic team led by Joaquim Levy, a University of Chicago-trained banker nicknamed Scissorhands for his readiness to slash public spending.

headline: Concussions, by the New Book
abstract: A hit to the head of an N.F.L. player, once cause for little more than a shrug, now sets in motion a long management protocol, outlined in an inches-thick document.
lead_paragraph: It happens dozens of times in every N.F.L. game. There is a fierce collision, or perhaps a running back is slammed to the ground. Most of the time, all the players rise to their feet uneventfully.

headline: For the Buckeyes, a Win and a Loss
abstract: No. 7 Ohio State defeated Michigan, its archrival, but its hopes of reaching College Football Playoff may have been damaged by the season-ending injury to quarterback J. T. Barrett.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — J. T. Barrett lay flat on his back, looking up at the sky, his arms spread wide, and Ohio Stadium watched in silence as Ohio State trainers attended to his right leg. In the fourth quarter, against the team’s rival Michigan, Barrett’s leg had been caught beneath a pile of maize and blue.

headline: Where Grass Is Greener, a Push to Share Drought’s Burden
abstract: The lush residential horse pastures in Rancho Santa Fe are a reminder that life has continued almost as before in much of the state, even as some elsewhere cope with dry taps.
lead_paragraph: RANCHO SANTA FE, Calif. — In these hills overlooking San Diego, the only indication of the continuing drought — now among the worst in California’s recorded history — is the perpetually cloudless sky.

headline: G.O.P. Gains by Tapping Democrats’ Base for State Candidates
abstract: In taking control of nearly 70 state legislative chambers in the midterm elections, Republicans focused on recruiting women and minorities as candidates.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Republicans took control of an unprecedented 69 of 99 statehouse chambers in the midterm elections, they did not rely solely on a bench of older white men. Key races hinged on the strategic recruitment of women and minorities, many of them first-time candidates who are now learning the ropes and joining the pool of prospects for higher office.

headline: Shaking Off Injuries, Rangers Subdue Flyers
abstract: With two goals from Derick Brassard, and one each from J. T. Miller, Lee Stempniak and Jesper Fast, the Rangers claimed their 10th straight regular-season victory against the Flyers at Madison Square Garden.
lead_paragraph: The Rangers were depleted even before they took the ice Saturday for their home-and-home finale with the Philadelphia Flyers.

headline: As Mexico Addresses Climate Change, Critics Point to Shortcomings
abstract: Mexico has passed laws to regulate emissions and promote renewable energy, but some analysts doubt it will commit the resources to meet its much-lauded goals.
lead_paragraph: EJIDO RANCHO OJO LAGUNA, Mexico — For six years, while drought ravaged Chihuahua State, Mario Ruiz clung to his small herd of cattle.

headline: At Clemson’s Stadium, a Rock Meets a Hard Place
abstract: At Clemson, players change, coaches come and go, seasons pass, and one constant through it all is Howard’s Rock.
lead_paragraph: CLEMSON, S.C. — Cameras are trained 24 hours a day on a black granite pedestal that is inside the gate behind the east end zone at Clemson Memorial Stadium. A plexiglass case protects a precious quartz stone that is embedded in the top of the shiny, polished pedestal. Those who dare to get too close may hear a recorded warning that they are being watched by police.

headline: Egyptian Activists Protest Mubarak Verdict Online and Outside in a Sealed Tahrir Square
abstract: Activists who supported the uprising that drove Hosni Mubarak from power in 2011 jeered a court ruling acquitting him on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: In the hours after an Egyptian court dropped all remaining charges against former President Hosni Mubarak on Saturday, activists who supported the uprising that drove him from power in 2011 jeered the ruling online and in the streets near Cairo’s Tahrir Square, which was closed by the security forces.

headline: In Comeback Stride, Sarkozy Wins French Party Leadership
abstract: With a preliminary total of 64.5 percent of the votes, former President Nicolas Sarkozy gained control over the center-right opposition and established a steppingstone in his attempt to run the country again.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Former President Nicolas Sarkozy was elected as the leader of his center-right party on Saturday evening in a widely expected victory that could serve as a steppingstone for his 2017 bid to become president of France again.

headline: Roger Goodell Has 32 N.F.L. Owners in His Corner, for Now
abstract: Goodell has had his share of withering criticism as N.F.L. commissioner, but the league’s owners contend he would be difficult to replace.
lead_paragraph: From the moment seven years ago that N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell began his law-and-order campaign aimed at cleaning up the league’s dubious image, he has been criticized for abusing his sweeping powers to penalize players and teams for infractions large and small.

headline: Suit on Health Law Puts Focus on Funding Powers
abstract: House Republicans say Congress never appropriated money for a provision of the Affordable Care Act that offers financial assistance to low- and moderate-income people.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In mounting the latest court challenge to the Affordable Care Act, House Republicans are focusing on a little-noticed provision of the law that offers financial assistance to low- and moderate-income people.

headline: City Tarnished by Defeat Gets to Bask in Victory
abstract: Belo Horizonte, the city associated with Brazil’s embarrassing 7-1 loss in the World Cup semifinals, has experienced an unlikely soccer rebirth.
lead_paragraph: BELO HORIZONTE, Brazil — Their telltale faces represented the two sides of Brazil.

headline: Japanese Unearth Remains, and Their Nation’s Past, on Guadalcanal
abstract: Expeditions to the South Pacific island where many thousands died reflect a surge in interest among young Japanese in World War II.
lead_paragraph: GUADALCANAL, Solomon Islands — Using a trowel to dig into the shadowy floor of the rain forest, pausing only to wipe away sweat and malaria-carrying mosquitoes, Atsushi Maeda holds up what he has traveled so far, to this South Pacific island, to find: a human bone, turned orange-brown with age.

headline: Intrusion on Sony Unit Prompts a Shutdown of Messaging Systems
abstract: Sony Pictures Entertainment is investigating what provoked the cyberattack, including whether there are any ties to a coming film that has elicited the ire of North Korea.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — While rivals focused on the holiday box office, Sony Pictures Entertainment spent Thanksgiving weekend coping with the continuing effects of a cyberattack — and investigating what provoked the onslaught, including whether there were any ties to a coming comedy that has elicited the ire of North Korea.

headline: Zap!
abstract: Matt Ginsberg does us a tremendous favor.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — I spent a good part of my early career in advertising, and I was always amazed at how hard the media department worked to make sure that the clients’ products got in front of the television-viewing audience.

headline: Squandering Two Leads, Red Bulls Are Ousted
abstract: The New England Revolution advanced to the M.L.S. Cup final with a 4-3 aggregate victory after tying the Red Bulls in Saturday’s second leg of the Eastern Conference finals.
lead_paragraph: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — The New England Revolution booked a ticket to the M.L.S. Cup final on Saturday as two goals by Charlie Davies gave them a 4-3 aggregate win over the Red Bulls for the Eastern Conference championship.

headline: Tradition Saves Camels’ Spot in Jordan’s Desert Forces
abstract: Jordan’s Royal Desert Forces, descended from a camel corps, still rely on the animals for work like catching smugglers and recovering stolen cars on rough terrain.
lead_paragraph: WADI RUM, Jordan — Hitched up in the sandy lot by the police station, next to the four-by-four trucks and the dune buggy, is some other important equipment for enforcing the law in this parched and forbidding desert valley: eight surly and perpetually masticating camels.

headline: Doing What It Takes to Keep Her Family Together
abstract: Born prematurely with many ailments, Aislinn Kennedy’s son Jah’Meire was placed in medical foster care. Her goal now is to regain full custody and reunite him with his siblings.
lead_paragraph: Sprawled on the floor of her bathroom atop a clean bedsheet, Aislinn Kennedy gave birth to her son Jah’Meire in February 2012. She was 26 weeks into her pregnancy.

headline: Sunday’s Matchup: Giants (3-8) at Jaguars (1-10)
abstract: The Jaguars may have only one victory, but they have sacked opposing quarterbacks 33 times.
lead_paragraph: 1 p.m., Fox

headline: End of Texas School’s Book Ban Doesn’t Mark the Last Chapter
abstract: In September, complaints about content prompted Highland Park High School in Texas to pull seven books from the curriculum, creating an uproar that led to an about-face.
lead_paragraph: HIGHLAND PARK, Tex. — In mid-September, about two weeks after sophomores at Highland Park High School began reading “The Art of Racing in the Rain,” by Garth Stein, in their English classes, they were told to stop.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers react to recent articles in the Sports section of The Times.
lead_paragraph: Why Was Beckham’s Catch A Big Deal?

headline: Three Years After Fire, a New Culprit Threatens a Texas Park’s Rebirth
abstract: As shrubs and seedlings take hold in scorched Bastrop State Park, whitetail deer are thriving, and concerning officials enough so that they have decided to allow hunting.
lead_paragraph: BASTROP, Tex. — Greenery has begun to cover the scars of a fire that ripped through 32,000 acres of Central Texas three years ago. Feeding on tinder and trees withered from a searing drought, the Bastrop County wildfire burned for nine days and destroyed more than 1,600 homes before it was brought under control.

headline: Will Texas Meet Budget? It Is All in the Math
abstract: Budget projections are coming in Texas. They will set the stage for the next round of maneuvering by state lawmakers.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — A small group of Texas legislators will meet this week to decide how much they think the state’s economy will grow in the next two years.

headline: In Religious Order, Texas Women Find a Place to Call Home
abstract: In 2009, eight Catholic sisters came to Austin at the invitation of Bishop Gregory Aymond to teach and establish a new permanent residence for the Dominican Sisters of Mary.
lead_paragraph: BURNET — Instead of the name of her school, the sparkly letters on Caroline Smith’s homecoming mum, or large corsage, spelled “Jesus is my homecoming king.”

headline: Bob Dylan, Not Looking Back
abstract: Mr. Dylan has replaced the fluidity and arrogance of youth with a more genuine, lived-in sense that he has nothing to lose and no one but himself to please.
lead_paragraph: The latest stretch of Bob Dylan’s Never Ending Tour, which started a five-night stand at the Beacon Theater on Friday, is, no surprise, a hard-nosed conundrum.

headline: A Soaring Emblem of New York, and Its Upside-Down Priorities
abstract: A critique of the design of 1 World Trade Center, the newly opened skyscraper built at the base of the former twin towers.
lead_paragraph: The observatory, with the wraparound, nosebleed views, is not finished. Almost half the office space isn’t leased yet. But a baker’s dozen years after Sept. 11, 1 World Trade Center is up and running.

headline: Black Friday Sales Slip as Discounts Start Earlier
abstract: Initial weak numbers revived concerns among retailers that, despite improved economic conditions, shoppers remain wary.
lead_paragraph: Even as more stores opened their doors on Thanksgiving, hoping for a jump start to the holiday season, an initial reading suggested that combined sales on Thanksgiving and Black Friday fell 0.5 percent from the same period last year.

headline: Honoring Small Business, Obamas Go Book Shopping
abstract: The president and his daughters, Malia and Sasha, visited Prose and Politics, an independent bookstore in Washington, on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama, joined by his daughters, went shopping Saturday at Politics and Prose, an independent bookstore in the capital, in what has become a Thanksgiving weekend tradition for the first family to honor Small Business Saturday — an outing that mixed policy and purchases.

headline: Glossy Photo Cards, Highlighting Grief
abstract: This is not a campaign to end the photo card. But the year our daughter died, it would have been so much kinder to send something else.
lead_paragraph: The best holiday card we received the year that our daughter died said simply, “Continuing to lift you up in prayer” and came from an aunt and uncle we hadn’t seen in years.

headline: Taxi Owners in New York Seek Inquiry on Medallion Prices
abstract: The Greater New York Taxi Association is calling for an independent investigation of reports published by the Taxi and Limousine Commission that said average prices for taxi medallions were steady when they were actually falling.
lead_paragraph: The Greater New York Taxi Association, a trade group for the city’s taxi medallion owners, is calling for an independent investigation of reports published by the city’s Taxi and Limousine Commission that said average prices for taxi medallions were steady when they were actually falling.

headline: Mississippi Pulls Out of Its Skid and Leaves Mississippi State Adrift
abstract: The No. 18 Rebels (9-3, 5-3) beat the No. 4 Bulldogs (10-2, 6-2) on the strength of a feisty pass rush, solid play from quarterback Bo Wallace and a career day from tight end Evan Engram.
lead_paragraph: OXFORD, Miss. — It was not two months ago here that Mississippi beat Alabama, the goal posts came down (one of them was carried to the historic Square downtown), and anything — Ole Miss’s first division title since 2003, or even its first national championship since the 1962 season — seemed possible.

headline: On Rooftops of Ferguson, Volunteers Patrol, With Guns
abstract: A group called Oath Keepers, regarded by some as an antigovernment militia, is placing sentries atop businesses as tensions continue in Ferguson, Mo.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — When Sam Andrews awoke on Tuesday morning, he found his wife watching a television interview with a woman whose bakery had been vandalized during the violent unrest here on Monday.

headline: Measuring Up a Big Ten Expansion
abstract: Saturday’s game between Rutgers and Maryland reflected the Big Ten’s geographic venture to East Coast television markets to help, among other things, develop its in-house network.
lead_paragraph: COLLEGE PARK, Md. — It wasn’t quite the Big Ten’s most traditional annual classic, known as the Game, between Michigan and Ohio State. But at least it became an entertainingly competitive and even compelling contest, like the scare the unranked Wolverines put into the heavily favored Buckeyes before losing by 14 points Saturday at the Horseshoe in Columbus.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 29, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Islanders Hold Off Devils to Wrap Up a Strong November
abstract: The Islanders improved to 8-2-0 against division rivals with a victory against the visiting Devils, and ended the month with an 11-3-0 record to extend their franchise-best start.
lead_paragraph: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — The Islanders have dominated their Metropolitan Division rivals this season, a key reason they are off to the best start in franchise history. On Saturday, they took advantage of another division opponent, with a 3-1 victory against the Devils at Nassau Coliseum in the teams’ first meeting this season.

headline: Mario Cuomo, Former Governor of New York, Is Hospitalized
abstract: Mr. Cuomo, the father of the current governor of New York, Andrew M. Cuomo, is being treated at a hospital in Manhattan for a heart problem.
lead_paragraph: Former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York has been hospitalized for treatment of a heart problem.

headline: Krista Dubin and Eric Giambattista
abstract: The bride is studying for a medical degree and a Ph.D. in microbiology; the groom is studying for a Ph.D. in economics.
lead_paragraph: Krista Alexandra Dubin, a daughter of Randi and Michael Dubin of Manhattan, was married Saturday in Long Island City, Queens, to Eric Matthew Giambattista, the son of Janet and Brian Giambattista of San Jose, Calif. The bride’s father, who became a minister of the Open Ministry for the event, officiated at the Metropolitan Building.

headline: Joanne Bruno and Michael Peters
abstract: The couple were married at the Three Hierarchs Greek Church in Brooklyn
lead_paragraph: Joanne Helen Bruno, a daughter of Jacqueline J. Bruno of Maspeth, Queens, and the late Daniel Bruno, was married Saturday to Michael Perry Peters, a son of Maryanne and Parry M. Peters of Marlboro, N.J. The Rev. Eugene Pappas performed the ceremony at the Three Hierarchs Greek Church in Brooklyn.

headline: Leslie Kaufmann, Lyron Bennett
abstract: The bride is a medical student; the groom is the business manager for a children’s book publisher.
lead_paragraph: Leslie Kaufmann, a daughter of Susan Kaufmann and Ronald H. Kaufmann of New York, was married Saturday evening to Lyron Elisha Francis Bennett, a son of Dominique M.C.N. Raccah and Raymond W. Bennett of Naperville, Ill. Rabbi Neil Zuckerman officiated at the Rainbow Room in New York.

headline: Morgan Handsman, Ian Spitalnick
abstract: The couple were married at Guastavino’s in New York.
lead_paragraph: Morgan Jena Handsman and Ian Harris Spitalnick were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Howard Stecker at Guastavino’s in New York.

headline: Laura Waluch and Michael Solomon
abstract: The couple married at San Ysidro Ranch, a hotel in Montecito, Calif.
lead_paragraph: Laura Rebecca Waluch, a daughter of Paula G. Waluch and Dr. Victor Waluch of Altadena, Calif., was married Friday to Michael Stern Solomon, the son of Janet Stern Solomon and Lewis D. Solomon of Chevy Chase, Md. The groom’s father, who was ordained at the New Seminary in New York, officiated at San Ysidro Ranch, a hotel in Montecito, Calif.

headline: Amy Lerner, Evan Gold
abstract: The couple married at the Ritz-Carlton in Arlington, Va.
lead_paragraph: Amy Beth Lerner and Evan Matthew Gold were married Saturday evening at the Ritz-Carlton, Pentagon City, in Arlington, Va. Rabbi Esther Lederman officiated.

headline: Dana Klinek, Jason Pinter
abstract: The bride works in the Advanced Placement program at the College Board; the groom is the founder of a book publisher.
