lead_paragraph: Dana Lauren Klinek and Jason Lee Pinter were married Saturday evening at Shadowbrook, an event space in Shrewsbury, N.J. Cantor Gabrielle Clissold of the Monmouth Reform Temple officiated.

headline: Jordana Gruenwald and Jonathan Beck
abstract: The bride manages consumer websites at an online marketing and services company; the groom is a vice president of national sales technology at JPMorgan Chase.
lead_paragraph: Jordana Wendy Gruenwald, a daughter of Laurel R. Gruenwald and Abraham I. Gruenwald of New City, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Jonathan Scott Beck, a son of Janet S. Beck and Bruce Beck of White Plains. Rabbi Jonathan Blake officiated at the Oheka Castle in Huntington, N.Y.

headline: Jennifer White, Martin Lawlor
abstract: The couple were married at the Grand Cascades Lodge in Hamburg, N.J.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer Lee White and Martin John Lawlor were married Saturday at the Grand Cascades Lodge in Hamburg, N.J. The Rev. Nancy Young, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

headline: Sarah Rothenberg, Evan Schonfeld
abstract: The couple, who both work in real estate, were married at the Hanover Marriott Hotel in Whippany, N.J.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Rachel Rothenberg, a daughter of Caren Rothenberg and Larry L. Rothenberg of Livingston, N.J., was married Saturday evening to Evan Benjamin Schonfeld, a son of Amy Rothman Schonfeld and Dr. Steven M. Schonfeld of East Brunswick, N.J. Rabbi E. Samuel Klibanoff officiated at the Hanover Marriott Hotel in Whippany, N.J.

headline: Michael Meltzer and Monte Albers de Leon
abstract: A portfolio manager and a lawyer wed at the Harvard Club of New York.
lead_paragraph: Michael Ted Meltzer and Monte Roberto Albers de Leon were married Saturday evening at the Harvard Club of New York. Matt Levy, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

headline: Joey Pakes and Prentiss Nelson
abstract: The bride, a postdoctoral researcher at Harvard, and the groom, an executive with a Canadian bank, were married on the Harvard campus.
lead_paragraph: Michal Joey Pakes and Robert Prentiss Nelson were married Saturday in Cambridge, Mass. Sol Matthew Pakes, the bride’s brother, who became a Universal Life minister for theevent, officiated in Adolphus Busch Hall at Harvard.

headline: Sharing a Love of the Outdoors
abstract: The couple enjoy hiking and share an Eastern European heritage.
lead_paragraph: Siyana Yordanova Kukularova, a daughter of Seta K. Kukularova and Yordan K. Kukularov of Plovdiv, Bulgaria, was married Wednesday to Andrew Christopher Huszar, a son of Dr. Theresa G. Huszar and Dr. Gabor B. Huszar of Woodbridge, Conn. Angel L. Lopez of the New York City Clerk’s office officiated at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau.

headline: Surging Sabres Edge Canadiens in Shootout
abstract: Bryan Flynn scored in regulation and had the winner in a shootout for Buffalo, which, after losing five straight, has won five of its last six games.
lead_paragraph: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — The Islanders have dominated their Metropolitan Division rivals this season, a key reason they are off to the best start in franchise history. On Saturday, they took advantage of another division opponent with a 3-1 victory against the Devils at Nassau Coliseum in the teams’ first meeting this season.

headline: Corrections: November 30, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Sunday, November 30, 2014.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Bill Cunningham | Thanksgiving
abstract: For many, Thanksgiving has stretched into five days of festivities.
lead_paragraph: For many, Thanksgiving has stretched into five days of festivities. One highlight this week was the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade, where youngsters gathered curbside and clowns entertained. Older women dressed in colorful outfits came out with walkers decorated in pink and green. Two of the more amazing sights were the balloons and the many visitors who wore headgear resembling turkeys. Another highlight of the week was the New-York Historical Society’s train exhibition. It was a tour de force in its design. Nothing was static; it was all moving. Children can watch through a clear protruding bubble.

headline: Qatar Frees U.S. Couple in Death of Daughter
abstract: After being cleared in Qatar of wrongdoing in the death of their daughter, an American couple was held by immigration officials when trying to depart Doha’s airport.
lead_paragraph: DOHA, Qatar — An American couple in Qatar who spent nearly two years fighting accusations that hey had killed their adopted daughter from Ghana were cleared of wrongdoing on Sunday in an emotional courtroom reversal by an appellate judge who said that they were good parents and that the prosecution had no case.

headline: Kin of Thai Princess Stripped of Royal Name
abstract: Police officers with links to the family are accused of corruption, and in an unusual twist, have been charged with lèse-majesté, because, the authorities said, they used symbols of the monarchy for their own benefit.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — In a rare public display of palace intrigue in Thailand, relatives of a prominent member of the royal family have been charged with numerous counts of corruption and stripped of their royally bestowed name.

headline: Math Anxiety: Why Hollywood Makes Robots of Alan Turing and Other Geniuses
abstract: The visionary who stares at formulas written on walls or mirrors — or better yet, thin air — has become a Hollywood trope. So has the depiction of the genius who can’t connect with real people.
lead_paragraph: Math movies have become a dependable genre. There is a shot of a genius staring rapturously at mind-bending numbers. He is an insufferable person. There will be much drama about whether he can learn to value human emotion over cold fact.

headline: Racing From New York to Barcelona
abstract: A sailboat race from New York to Barcelona was the setting for a thrilling — and sometimes terrifying — video about this challenging sport.
lead_paragraph: The documentary “Strangers at Sea” was really the result of conversations going back four years seeking a compelling video that would introduce professional sailing to The Times’s audience. At the last minute, I tried to capture the finish of the Vendée Globe — a solo, nonstop around-the-world race — from the perspective of both the sailors and fans.

headline: The Daily Gift: Picasso Plates for Creative Dining
abstract: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.
lead_paragraph: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.

headline: 1889: Metropolitan Opera House Reopens in New York
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The Metropolitan Opera House reopens in New York in 1889.
lead_paragraph: Wealth, art and society were well represented at the reopening of the Metropolitan Opera House. It marked the beginning of the sixth season of opera in German. The house had a brilliant appearance when the curtain rose on the first act of Wagner’s “Flying Dutchman.” Although it rained in torrents all the evening, the ladies appeared in their rarest toilettes, and the boxes literally blazed with diamonds. Mrs. Astor was in white pink brocade, and occupied a box with Miss Marion Longdon and Mr. Ward McAlister. Miss Longdon wore pale yellow with a long boa of ostrich feathers. In an adjoining box sat Mrs. William C. Whitney in a décolleté dress of pale green and silver, with diamonds in her hair. Mrs. Paran Stevens wore a brocade toilette, and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt wore white brocade and pearls. On the stage interest centred chiefly in Theodore Reichmann, the popular Viennese barytone, and in Fraulein Sophie Weisner, the soprano, who made their debut in this country as Senta and Vanderdecken. Reichmann scored a great and instant success, thanks as much to his admirable and artistic acting as to his rich and sympathetic voice. Fraulein Weisner’s success was less emphatic, although, like Reichmann, she was warmly applauded. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Dec. 1, 1889

headline: Police Break Siege of Government Offices in Hong Kong
abstract: The police used pepper spray to try to subdue thousands of pro-democracy demonstrators who surged around the Hong Kong leader’s offices in an escalation of the protests.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Pro-democracy demonstrators in Hong Kong suffered a setback on Monday, when their attempt overnight to besiege government offices collapsed and the police thrust into the protesters’ biggest street camp.

headline: What’s On TV Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (Sundance) THE KING’S SPEECH (2010) Colin Firth, above with Helena Bonham Carter, in the role for which he won an Oscar for best actor, portrays Albert Frederick Arthur George, or Bertie, as his family called him, the shy second son of George V of Britain (Michael Gambon) in this film from Tom Hooper. Geoffrey Rush is Lionel Logue, the speech therapist who helps Bertie conquer a debilitating stutter. And Ms. Carter is Elizabeth, his wife and staunch support system, who can’t quite stomach Wallis Simpson (Eve Best), the divorced American who leads Bertie’s older brother, David (Guy Pearce), to abdicate as Edward VIII. “It isn’t exactly ‘Pygmalion,’ not least because Mr. Hooper has no intention of satirizing the caste system that is one of this movie’s biggest draws,” Manohla Dargis, writing in The New York Times, said of the film, which received 12 Oscar nominations and won four. “Like many entertainments of this pop-historical type,” she added, “ ‘The King’s Speech’ wears history lightly, no matter how heavy the crown.”

headline: Netanyahu Hints at Possibility of New Elections
abstract: Amid growing acrimony among the fractious partners of Israel’s governing coalition, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu also berated ministers for attacking him.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Amid a political crisis over a proposed nationality law and growing acrimony among the fractious partners of Israel’s governing coalition, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu hinted on Sunday at the possibility of new elections only 20 months after his current government was formed.

headline: Leader Asserts China’s Growing Importance on Global Stage
abstract: President Xi Jinping told Communist Party officials that China would be nice to its neighbors in Asia but that he would be relentless in promoting his idea of China’s rejuvenation onto the world stage.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Sounding confident after a burst of high-profile diplomacy, President Xi Jinping told Communist Party officials in a major address here over the weekend that China would be nice to its neighbors in Asia but that he would run an active foreign policy and be relentless in promoting China’s rejuvenation onto the global stage.

headline: Optimism Faces Grave Realities at Climate Talks
abstract: Even as United Nations negotiators expressed optimism that they may finally achieve a deal, experts cautioned that it probably would not stave off global warming’s near-term impact.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After more than two decades of trying but failing to forge a global pact to halt climate change, United Nations negotiators gathering in South America this week are expressing a new optimism that they may finally achieve the elusive deal.

headline: Plane Evacuated at Kennedy Airport After Bomb Threat
abstract: The American Airlines flight, which originated in Barcelona, was cleared after a phone threat, but the authorities found no evidence of any danger, a Port Authority spokesman said.
lead_paragraph: A plane was evacuated at Kennedy International Airport on Sunday amid an investigation into a bomb threat, the authorities said.

headline: 1914: Russians Dominate in East Poland
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Russians dominate in East Poland in 1914.
lead_paragraph: PETROGRAD — The steady increase in the strength of the Russian troops is transforming the appearance of the battles in East Poland. During the recent fighting in this region, and more particularly on Thursday, the Germans have sustained enormous loss. After a multitude of charges by the Russian cavalry, the state of the fields and roads rendered the use of automobiles absolutely impossible. The Russians have consequently garaged a large number of their machines at Lodz, whither they are also sending hundreds of transport and ammunition wagons captured from the enemy. The prolongation of the struggle in the neighborhood of Lodz is probably due to the feverish activity on the German strategic railways on the Silesian frontier. The enemy is bringing up troops with all possible speed, and it is estimated that 50,000 men, or nearly half the garrison of Breslau, were despatched north-west to Czenstochowa to join the newly-formed army in that region. Another great battle is to be expected somewhere between Lodz and Kalisz. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Dec. 1, 1914

headline: The European Outlier
abstract: Who’s causing deflation?
lead_paragraph: I’m doing some work on matters European, which should see the light of day shortly, and for future reference I want to post a simple chart. It makes the same point already made by Francesco Saraceno and Simon Wren-Lewis, but in a more stripped-down and possibly clearer (?) way.

headline: Swiss Voters Reject Move to Restrict Immigrants
abstract: Business and union leaders had lobbied against the suggested quota on new immigrants amid fears that it would harm Switzerland’s economy and ties to the European Union.
lead_paragraph: COLOGNE, Germany — Swiss voters on Sunday overwhelmingly rejected a proposal to drastically curb the influx of foreigners seeking to work and live in their country in the second major effort this year aimed at restricting immigration.

headline: Pope, in Turkey, Issues Call to Protect Middle Eastern Christians
abstract: Francis and his counterpart in the Orthodox Church vowed to work together to prevent a Christian exodus from the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Pope Francis and his counterpart in the Orthodox Church on Sunday vowed to work together to prevent an exodus of Christians from the Middle East, and they called for “constructive dialogue” with Muslims to resolve conflicts in the embattled region and around the world.

headline: Churches Urge Healing, but Also Activism, After Stormy Week in Ferguson
abstract: Clergy in Missouri called for recovery after a week of tension and chaos in Ferguson, but in many of the messages, there were also calls to continue a movement.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — At worship services around this region, clergy on Sunday called for recovery and healing after a week that began with an announcement that a grand jury would not indict a white police officer who shot an unarmed black teenager in Ferguson and that then careened through looting, fires, and tense standoffs with the police and National Guard soldiers.

headline: Afghan Fires His Cabinet; Police Chief Offers to Quit
abstract: President Ashraf Ghani fired most of the current ministers, all holdovers from the previous administration, amid struggles to form a new cabinet. The Kabul police chief’s job was also thought to be in jeopardy.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Unable to form a new government, the new president of Afghanistan, Ashraf Ghani, settled for the next best thing on Sunday: He fired the old one.

headline: Beijing Wind
abstract: The umbrellas aren’t holding up in Hong Kong.
lead_paragraph: The umbrellas aren’t holding up in Hong Kong.

headline: N.B.A. Game of the Week: Warriors at Bulls
abstract: Chicago remains a hard team to pin down, largely because of injuries to several key players. Everything is light, fun and gravity-free for Golden State, but they, too, have injury concerns.
lead_paragraph: Every week, The New York Times will choose one essential game to watch, highlighting hot teams, winning and losing streaks and statistical intrigue in the N.B.A.

headline: A Big Man Shrinks Into a New Role
abstract: Marc Gasol, who “looks like he lost 50 pounds,” according to one teammate, was averaging 20.2 points a game entering Sunday amid speculation he might leave the Memphis Grizzlies as a free agent.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In early September, months after the last N.B.A. season had ended, Mike Conley tuned in to watch the FIBA Basketball World Cup on television. He saw someone with a resemblance to his Memphis Grizzlies teammate Marc Gasol: same bushy beard, same stern game face and same backward shuffle down the court after shooting a jumper from just beyond the free-throw line.

headline: Should a Therapist Reveal Herself?
abstract: Mental health professionals respond to a Sunday Review essay.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Rewarding Lawbreakers
abstract: Ross Terrill, a China expert, says President Obama’s immigration plan insults those who go through the legal citizenship process.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: California Tuition Protest
abstract: Stephen Brier, a Berkeley alumnus, writes that he is “saddened because the great public university that gave me a world-class education without charging tuition is increasingly out of reach.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Leader, Acknowledged
abstract: Michael Green, a reader, adds to David Brooks’s list of requirements for “the unifying leader.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Tax Credit to Help the Poor
abstract: Michael Rubinger of the Local Initiatives Support Corporation defends a tax program intended to lift low-income people and places.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Choreography That Stretches Performers and Their Art
abstract: The Lyon Opera Ballet presents works by William Forsythe as part of the Festival d’Automne celebration of him in Paris.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — This city has been important to William Forsythe. It was here, in 1987, that his “In the Middle, Somewhat Elevated” had its premiere at the Paris Opera Ballet, earning him international recognition. In 1990, his own company, the Frankfurt Ballet, began an eight-year residence at the Théâtre du Châtelet, performing there for several weeks every year. During that time, Mr. Forsythe’s faithful fans could see almost all of his new work and track the evolution of his artistry.

headline: Funny, This Little Town Is Full of C.I.A. Operatives
abstract: In “The Happiest People in the World,” Brock Clarke’s latest novel, a cartoonist has to move to upstate New York.
lead_paragraph: Dear Brock Clarke:

headline: A Not-So-Mad Scientist and His Blue-Eyed Buddy
abstract: Joseph Silovsky’s “Send for the Million Men,” based on the 1927 execution of the anarchists Sacco and Vanzetti, stars his signature creation: a robot called Stanley.
lead_paragraph: Stanley, one of the stars of Joseph Silovsky’s “Send for the Million Men,” stood behind a lectern during a recent rehearsal. Stanley has wide blue eyes and excellent posture. Collegial and professional, he’d long since memorized his lines and his blocking, which he executes with his eight fingers, mismatched joints and tangle of wires.

headline: Raising a Defiant Hand Against the Fist of the Law
abstract: In “Ungli,” four young professionals — led by Kangana Ranaut and Randeep Hooda — set out to avenge the aggrieved and the powerless amid widespread malfeasance in Mumbai.
lead_paragraph: In “Ungli,” written and directed by Rensil D’Silva, four young professionals — led by Kangana Ranaut and Randeep Hooda — set out to avenge the aggrieved and the powerless amid widespread malfeasance in Mumbai. They are giving the finger to unscrupulous police officers and officials (“ungli” is the Hindi word for finger), and finding ingenious ways to expose those misdeeds publicly.

headline: Opaque Justice in China
abstract: The mini-series “One Child” sends a young Chinese-British woman into the heart of China’s capital punishment system.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — It was so important to the British screenwriter Guy Hibbert to preserve the unexpected ending of “One Child,” a television drama about executions in China, that he waited years for a financial backer who agreed to do so.

headline: Crossovers Add Flavor to Classics
abstract: On Monday, the string quartet Brooklyn Rider is performing selections from its new album, “Almanac,” featuring pieces commissioned from the worlds of folk, indie rock and jazz.
lead_paragraph: To many classical music lovers, “crossover” is a dirty word. And who can blame them? The holiday season is especially rich in ill-advised CD releases by opera stars belting out operetta arias or crooning Christmas jingles in arrangements that do no favors to either the singers or the songs.

headline: Two Titles Won at Bridge League’s Fall Championships
abstract: At the American Contract Bridge League’s fall championships in Providence, R.I., the first two national titles were won on Saturday evening.
lead_paragraph: At the American Contract Bridge League’s fall championships in Providence, R.I., the first two national titles were won on Saturday evening. The Smith Life Master Women’s Pairs was captured by Bronia Jenkins of Vero Beach, Fla., and Bernace De Young of Miami. They led after each of the four sessions, finishing three-tenths of a board ahead of Victoria Gromova and Tatiana Ponomareva from Russia. The Russians, who were second after each session, won this event in 2012. Third were Ljudmila Kamenova of South Setauket, N.Y., and Linda Lewis of Las Vegas.

headline: Notes on the Floating Crap Game (Economics Inside Baseball)
abstract: Statistical analysis of my profession.
lead_paragraph: Link replaced

headline: New Sugarplum Memories
abstract: Philip Henry Duclos plays the Nutcracker and Sterling Hyltin the Sugarplum Fairy in “George Balanchine’s The Nutcracker,” from New York City Ballet.
lead_paragraph: When did “The Nutcracker” become more than just a ballet? With its intoxicating mix of the fantastical and the human, this venerated dance is a ritual that has stuck around for good reason: How many works of art are able to capture memory and the passing of time so profoundly on both sides of the stage? “The Nutcracker” has as much importance for the dancers who grow up performing it as it does for the audience members who grow up watching it. The charge in the air is real; somehow the dancers and the audience unite in the middle.

headline: Secure in Its Sound and Fury, Despite Transitions at Its Core
abstract: Slayer, a landmark band of West Coast thrash metal, plays a set with its new members at the Wellmont Theater.
lead_paragraph: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — Here’s what a Slayer concert does. You might hear gigs by 500 bands and feel pretty certain there is something inherently good about aesthetic change. Then you get to one by Slayer, and you might think, no, there is not anything inherently good about aesthetic change. It’s not necessary.

headline: ‘The Hunger Games’ Dominates the Holiday Weekend
abstract: The No. 1 movie in North America was again “The Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part 1.” But moviegoing over the Thanksgiving holiday dropped 21 percent compared with the period a year ago.
lead_paragraph: Moviegoing over the Thanksgiving holiday dropped 21 percent compared with the period a year ago, as two new wide-release movies, “Penguins of Madagascar” and “Horrible Bosses 2,” became the latest studio efforts to underperform. The No. 1 movie in North America was again “The Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part 1,” which took in an estimated $56.9 million from Friday to Sunday, according to Rentrak, a box-office tracking firm. Domestic ticket sales for “Mockingjay” now total a hefty $225.7 million but are nonetheless running roughly 24 percent behind the last “Hunger Games” film.

headline: Celebrating Singers, Current and Not So Much
abstract: PBS does music, with specials highlighting Bing Crosby, Bruce Springsteen and Peter, Paul & Mary.
lead_paragraph: You’ve probably never wondered what would happen if PBS were to merge with MTV, or at least with the MTV of yore, the one that was defined by music. But you can get a glimpse of that mythical hybrid this week as PBS lets its hair down.

headline: A Certain Win for the Giants? Not So Fast
abstract: The Giants appeared to be saved by a 33-yard Josh Brown field goal with 3 minutes 26 seconds to play, but Josh Scobee delivered a winning 43-yarder with 28 seconds left.
lead_paragraph: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — The Giants’ season may already have been lost, but grim realities remain in the shocking and absurd ways they can pivot so quickly from bad to worse.

headline: Egyptian President Won’t Pursue Action Against Mubarak
abstract: A day after a court dropped all charges against the former leader, President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi said he would not try to hold him accountable for abuses.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi said on Sunday that he accepted the end of legal actions against the former president, Hosni Mubarak, declaring in a statement that Egypt must now “look to the future” and “cannot ever go back.”

headline: The Billionaires’ Park
abstract: Public spaces are increasingly built and cared for with private funds.
lead_paragraph: CAN billionaires remake the Manhattan shoreline? Apparently so, in light of the news that a new park will be just offshore in the Hudson River, largely financed by the media mogul Barry Diller and situated, conveniently, a short walk from his office in Chelsea.

headline: Take Part in a Buddy System
abstract: John Guzzetta and his puzzle adore us. That’s a nice way to start our solving week.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — What better way to start our solving week than with a message from an ADORING constructor?

headline: Late Bloomer Finds Audience for His Art
abstract: Jay Moss, 91, has made sculptures in his spare time throughout his life, but an exhibition of his work now on display at Manhattan College is only his second-ever solo show.
lead_paragraph: The Palisades were a blazing blur of orange, red and yellow, but Jay Moss had no time to savor the autumnal Hudson River view. He grabbed a small plank of soft wood and went to his bedroom, hunched over a band saw and slowly carved the contours of a masklike face. Specks of sawdust floated in the sunlight, their slightly burned odor filling the air.

headline: A Father Strives to Rebuild Ties Strained by Divorce and Alcoholism
abstract: Leonard Sharp, who began drinking heavily after his marriage crumbled, says he has become closer with his children again. He hopes to become a substance abuse counselor.
lead_paragraph: Leonard Sharp limped toward a park bench in front of the Queens public school he had attended as a boy. On another bench an older man sitting with two quiet companions discreetly lit a smoke under the cover of his hooded sweatshirt.

headline: Missing for Four Days, Kosta Karageorge, an Ohio State Defensive Lineman, Is Found Dead
abstract: The police told news media outlets that they found the body of the 22-year-old football player in a trash bin.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — Ohio State defensive tackle Kosta Karageorge was found dead Sunday, four days after he had last been seen, Sgt. Richard Weiner of the Columbus Police Department told reporters.

headline: Long Overshadowed in Realm of Business Magazines, Inc. Grabs the Spotlight
abstract: Inc. is becoming a mainstream publication, turning out glossy covers that broaden its appeal.
lead_paragraph: For many years, Inc. was a magazine that featured obscure entrepreneurs and quirky start-ups on its covers.
